description:
So I was actually going to go to the restaurant literally right next door. But I peered in that one and saw no Japanese people in there. I have a rule of thumb that if you look into a restaurant there is not their own people in there, you have a problem. That's just feom experience.. if their own people won't eat there food, it must not be all that good. There happen to be a Japanese couple who went through the trouble of taking out their toddler from her stroller and folding up to walk down the stairs to go to this place. This place is not handicap friendly. The stairs was a bit steep to me. Be careful with your elders, you don't want them breaking a hip going down these steps. 

When you get to the bottom, your see the room is small. But bigger than the one next door. They do have a bar. I had the Katana ramen with tonkatsu broth and medium spicy flavoring. The tonkatsu broth was an additional $1. To add spicy flavoring was another $0.75. The chili oil gave the broth an extra depth to it. Just the right amount of spicy that didn't set your mouth on fire and be suffering through your meal. The ramen was perfectly done. If I could have a do over I would have requested to have my gyoza outside of the bowl. It made it soggy. I like my gyoza to be crispy, soggy gyoza isn't the greatest texture when you're wanting crunch. All in all. I would give their food a solid 4 stars. With so many places to eat at here in SF. IDK if it w as s so good I would forego exploring other eateries to come here again.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Came here with a friend to try the ramen. Great location, walking distance from Union Square. They took us without reservation and we even got to choose our own table. 

I got the spicy ramen with 3 kinds of meat. I'm not a huge fan of fried chicken so I gave that to my friend. I enjoyed the ramen with the pork belly. 

This place is basement level so you may or may not have cell phone signal. They only have one restroom too.
author: Diana C.

description:
My bf brought me here and honestly, it was alright. He got their ramen which was not bad, but I've had better. I got their sashimi salad and although it was an okay size, it was drenched in their dressing so it was way toooooo salty which was a negative for me. 

It's pretty cool how it's located downstairs, but sadly, I won't be coming back.
author: Rosamond H.

description: It's super sad.... I ordered the spicy beef ramen and it tasted like minestrone soup with egg noodles...so no good. It was not spicy at all! And the beef was small like dice size. Super contrast to my first two experiences here. I'm not sure if it was the chef or if they changed the recipe, but I'm mad about it.
author: Navila H.

description:
I came here on a weeknight around 5pm and we were seated right away. I read the reviews on Yelp for this restaurant and this was the closest ramen place to where my friends and I were at and had great reviews.

I ordered the Katanaya Ramen which had BBQ pork, gyoza, karaage, corn, half hard boiled egg, seaweed and onions. I wanted to order the ramen spicy but it was going to be an extra charge so I added Sriracha instead. It seemed like there was a charge for anything extra.

The broth was good and the ramen was tasty but I don't think it was worth the price. We all shared a sushi roll that was $18.95 and the quality of the sushi roll was not that great. I forgot which roll we ordered. 

Overall, the ramen was tasty but the sushi roll was not that great. It did help that we were able to try this place out and there wasn't a wait to be seated.
author: Michael H.

description:
I love this place. I treat myself to their spicy tofu ramen once a week and I am never disappointed. The place is hidden away under and the ambiance is lovely. There is always a nice mix of locals and people who have wandered in from Union Square. 6 stools for single diners which are great to beat the rush! The ramen is made my a super talented chef and the servers are always very speedy and friendly. I love their broth and their kimchi. It is one of the only places to have no-meat ramen so it is worth the $14.95 price. 
Only areas for improvement: no WIFI or service in the restaurant. 
Highly recommend!
author: Abigail S.

description:
Staying in Union Square is SF's equivalent of staying in Times Square.  As you walk the streets and see all the homeless people, the contrast is striking!  SF has so much to offer in terms of shopping, eats, architecture, things to see and do!  Ramen for dinner always, no matter where, has a way of warming you up.  It's a classic comfort food for any Asian.  This place is tucked away, underground, off a main drag in Union Square, on Geary St.  The place is a little dark, intimate, familiar, and friendly.  They had a good selection of ramen broths, toppings, and reasonable prices.  They also have other Japanese staples - sushi, donburi, teriyaki, etc...
Worth a visit for locals or visitors!!!!
author: Kevin B.

description: 3.5 stars: Flavor wise, this place is surprisingly delicious.  The noodles were perfectly chewy, the soft boiled egg cooked just right and the Tonkotsu broth super flavorful.  I had the pork belly ramen with tonkotsu broth, and a medium level spiciness, which was very good; however the pork belly was a bit dry and super fatty.  Definitely an expensive ramen as the toppings are a la carte.  Also note, the menu photos on yelp and online are not up to date; the soups are about $2 more expensive now.  The service is pretty crappy in general, but one benefit is you can jump the line by checking in through yelp; you won't regret it.  Be sure to take bart or Uber/Lyft here because parking is a bare!  I'll definitely be back to try another soup.
author: Adriana G.

description:
It had been awhile since I've been to one of my favorite spots in SF, and boy has a lot changed. 

While I miss the cozy, hole-in-the-wall vibe of the original space, the downstairs space is just fine. (For a mid-day lunch however, I found it rather dark!) 

When I arrived, I was also disappointed to learn that they no longer serve sushi during lunch hours, just ramen. Also, could have just been an off day, but there was a sign that indicated cash only, so I had to make sure I hit up the ATM prior to dining. 

However, the Katanaya Ramen that I had was still as delicious as I remember it so be and loaded with all of my favorite goodies!

Overall, still enjoyed the food but left feeling nostalgic about my past experiences.
author: Tara L.

description:
I was looking for a ramen place in SF to try. My friend and I decided to try this place since our original choice was super busy on both nights we walked by there. This place was near our hotel so we walked there for a late dinner. So they are actually located at a basement level, so we had to walk downstairs to the restaurant. There was a line of people waiting along the stairs, but it moved along quickly. The interior was dark but spacious. 

I was all set to order a ramen, but then I saw that they had an Uni Don on the menu. My eyes lit up because I love uni, so I decided to try that. However, to my disappointment, our waitress indicated that they were all out of the uni. My excitement turned to being bummed out. So I ordered their signature Katanaya ramen, which was basically ramen with a combination of everything. It was average, nothing about this ramen really stood out for me. I've eaten at many ramen places and this one was just alright. If I'm ever in SF again in the near future, I might comeback here to try some of their other items.
author: Alan Y.

description:
Came here with a group of people and we wanted to eat some ramen in the area. We ultimately chose this place. There was a line, but we were able to snag a table immediately. It's actually a small establishment. Our server was super friendly and service was great.

KATANAYA RAMEN- 2 sliced bbq pork, 2 piece fried gyoza, 2 piece karaage, corn, half hard-boiled egg, green onion, and seaweed
Our server recommended their most popular ramen and I thought it fell short in terms of flavor and texture. The broth was way too salty and sadly the gyoza and karaage got all soggy by the time it got to the table so it was missing that crunchy/crispy flavor I was hoping for. Flavor was just too heavy and not the type that was heavy because there was too much going on or because there was a lot of seasoning, but in terms of salt overload and after a few bites, you just get tired of it all. The pork was too meaty and chewy. I would've preferred more fatty pieces for that tender texture. 

PORK BELLY
We got an order of pork belly and this dish was heavy with flavor. The meat was fatty and super tender. I would've preferred this over the ramen and just eat this dish over rice. 

SAKE 
I ordered some fresh salmon and it was my favorite dish of the night, which is pretty sad because they didn't have to prepare this in any way other than cut the fish and plate it. I like the freshness of the fish and how smooth it glides on the tongue. 

Overall, not my favorite ramen place. Most likely, I won't venture here again when I'm in town.
author: Anh L.

description: Very good ramen in a central location! We came here on the last night of our vacation, before heading to the Tonga Room for tiki drinks and live music (it's about a 15 minute walk but all uphill). My friends hadn't had restaurant quality ramen before, and all loved this! We went with the miso and tonkatsu bases, and an assortment of toppings. The tofu is plain and quite large, which I liked. The gyozas were fresh. Broth was salty and delicious (medium spice, + $.75). Highly recommend!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
What kind of sushi place carries only 2 types of fishes: salmon and tuna. On a Friday.  
Then call yourself a "sal- tuna" restaurant, not Katana-Ya. 
Also they charge almost 6$ for basic edemami when it's free at most places. 
We were informed by the waiter that the menu is being redone hence the new limitations. 
My friend and I came here to grab some rolls prior to seeing a show. What a fail.

Ramen flavor was good. Really liked the noodle texture. 

But still .... no fish at a sushi restaurant ?! :/
author: Zita M.

description: Came here because my other dinner plan fell through, and I feel like you don't really need to come here unless you just want to cure your hunger and you are too lazy to hunt for other options. The ramen is ok, I got the regular one, and the pork slices weren't very good. Like I said, you can find better ramen if you do your homework and make some effort, this place feels very plan-B.
author: Kailin H.

description: We got Kakuni ramen with tonkatsu broth. It was good, however there wasn't enough broth. I asked them to make mine extra spicy. If you're going there on a Friday night or a Saturday night, be sure to join the wait list on yelp.
author: Madhu J.

description: I had a sushi salad, the ingredients like the fish were pretty good, but holy hell who uses this much soy sauce as salad dressing. If u like salty food, this is too salty for you. My salad was swimming in a pool of the dressing so the bottom was hard to eat. This rating is just for the salad I tried. Service was pretty good, otherwise I would've done 2 stars for salad alone.
author: Franklin S.

description:
We came here for late night ramen. It's right next to Jack in The Box, walked downstairs, a cool and casual joint. It looks run down 

Veggies Tempura Udon was mediocre, no depth in broth, don't order it.

Katana-Ya ramen was a good, large portion, on the lighter side of broth, egg, char siu, dumpling, corn, onion, and more. 

Sake list was small but they did have 1 Junmai Dai Ginjo, we tried that. Unagi nigiri was good. 

Credit Card machine broke down so CASH only. 

Service was friendly.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Oh no-no-no. If you don't care about having good ramen, then maybe. But there are SO MANY other great ramen places. 

When Hubby and I first moved to the area, we were deceived by the high Yelp reviews and very very disappointed with the sub-par ramen. This place isn't even subpar for SF; it is sub-par for even a non city. 

We did appreciate that there was no wait. It is possible this place used to be good, but with other places like Marufuku, Mensho, etc, if you are a ramen fanatic, do not waste your time and tummy space.
author: Michele L.

description:
There is a door into this place, but you have to travel down a flight of stairs to the downstairs area which is where all the seating is at. Service is quite slow, I didn't get my water refilled at any point in the night and they basically just came by to deliver the food.

The ramen here doesn't taste all that great. I had the Katana-Ya ramen, and really, it was just tossing everything they could into a ramen bowl, from karaage to the gyoza, which I thought would appear on the side, not in the ramen. They both ended up being mushy cause they sat in the soup.

The noodles don't taste that good, more like the maruchan fresh yakisoba noodles in those plastic bags. I had the miso soup, and it tasted like they took the shio soup and added miso paste to it, since it was a bit saltier than I would have liked.

And overall, the soup didn't really have anything special to it, no flavor, no extra essence that really made it shine. It was just plain.

Overall a big pass for the future.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Big portions. Expect a lot of noodles and will definitely fill you up.

location is downstairs.
3 ppl w/ one appetitizer $75. Not Cheap.

Thanks!
author: Lee L.

description:
3.5 stars. It's not the best ramen I've had, but it hits the spot in a pinch.

Ordered the miso ramen for $12. Noodles were of the thinner variety. The chasu was tender and flavorful. Broth was a little on the gteasy side for me. Overall, if you're in the area and craving ramen (and there's no line) this isn't a bad option.
author: Michelle C.

description:
I'm a regular...and tonight was the first time I was disappointed. Don't be fooled by there fancy new menus, because what matters...the food, has changed. When we got our much awaited bowl of ramen we were shocked to see that the majority of the bowl was noodles.  Hardly any broth, and the broth is what we love at Katana-Ya. We were puzzled by what was in front of us. It didn't make sense. You'd think that if they were trying to cut costs, they'd skimp on the noodles and all the meat and vegetables...not the broth, that's the least expensive part of ramen. We thought maybe it's just our bowls, but looking around everyone's was the same. 

Hoping things return to how they used to be...
author: Chris T.

description: We found this place while walking around San Francisco. We were craving a ramen and were within walking distance to Katana-Ya. It is down a flight of stairs, and I think the location adds a lot to the ambiance. It's dark and intimate, the tables are small and seating is close together, but a comfortable distance apart. We ordered edamame and two bowls of ramen. I ordered the soy beef with spice and my date ordered the spicy pork bowl. My bowl came with gyoza, pork belly and some other toppings. The edamame came out lightly salted with two bowls, and then they brought out the ramen bowls. The servings were generous and filling. The spicy bowl had a lot more flavor but the pork bowl had more toppings and more depth. It was a great find for the trip, but I would love to explore more ramen places in the area, as there appeared to be many.
author: Sandra V.

description:
Came in tonight for some ramen. We sat at the bar and ordered two of the ramen with the fried chicken and order of gyoza and I got a hot tea. 

The ramen was perfect. It was a bit thinner of a broth than other places I've been but it's kinda what I was looking for. It wasn't as silky as other broths which allowed me to slurp much more of it! 

The gyoza was good. Not the best I've ever had but it was still good.
author: Michael P.

description: This reason I'm giving this place three stars is mainly because I liked the way it looked. Ive never been to Japan and seen a ramen restaurant, but I feel like this is what it would look like refer to my pics. Now unto the next topic the food. I wasn't really a fan I'd give the ramen about a 2.5 stars. The ramen was just way too salty, not to mention it was one dimensional. The ramen wasn't what I've grown accustomed to at other restaurants. It wasn't full with a variety of vegetables, bamboo shots, sprouts, or even different seasonings, it was just mostly salty so such so I didnt get a chance to really sip the broth. I also order a tea, and that had to be the worst part it was bland and watered down. I don't think I'll be visiting this place again.
author: Henry O.

description:
I did reservation and it said we were the party that was next but they start calling other people. What's the point of the reservation if we weren't even next. We have 5 people in our party....They can simply add another chair on the 4 people table. But We have to wait for a big group to leave. And these guys aren't leaving any time soon. They are busy chatting it up for another 30 mins after they ate. On a Saturday night they are really busy and they only have two employees on the floor that's working. They look like they are struggling. Place is small, it's about 20 seatings only. The workers are actually nice and very considerate but I just think they need more workers on a busy night. Two people on the floor was not enough. Price is really expensive for basic sushi rolls. 15-20 dollars. And it's alright. 

But the ramen is really good. And worth the price. I ordered the pork belly ramen and it is mouth watering. Large bowls and large portion. Many different selections on the menu and you can even customize your own style of ramen. And it only took them 5-10 mins to get the food out. Overall the food save our night. So I will come back and probably when it is not busy. I do recommend this place if you are craving amazing noodles and delicious soup base.
author: Ralph D.

description:
Great ramen house with a dim setting and traditional seating assignment. You have to come early as usual and put your name down on the list. The line builds up by going up their stairs. Last night was pretty good because the line was moving but I'm not sure how different days differ.

Their menu is pretty extensive with a nice amount of different ramen bowls. I got their Katanaya special which had gyoza, egg, pork belly, ans other hardy toppings. I love my ramen soy based over miso because it's stronger, heavier and a bit saltier. I added $.75 to make it spicy and they did an excellent job with that. Each broth scoop had heat so that was perfect. My ramen was $16 which is a bit expensive due to the added on toppings that come with this special but a typical bowl is around $11. I'd say this is an expensive ramen house compared to the other low cost ones. 

Their service is quick and straight to the point which is pretty typical for ramen house service. This is a great spot to come to during cold nights in the city. It's warm and cozy inside.
author: Allister D.

description:
I had the katayana bbq ramen extra spicy.
Im not a big ramen fan...well I wasn't, until now. This ramen has sooo many flavors in it, and a good kick! Service was good. As long as servers don't bother me too much, I'm good:-)
author: Sergio G.

description:
Cons:
-Small location in basement of union square 
-Waters served were not safe to drink - had a very weird 'tappy water' smell. Make sure to get bottled water or soda Can
-Ramen was OK, nothing special or as wow as Tatsu on sawtelle Blvd (L.A)

Pro:
-If your crammed with time/no reservations elsewhere, then this is your spot
author: Harry H.

description:
Just what I needed on a Thursday afternoon to get me going. Got the tofu ramen with miso broth which was definitely the move. Added a boiled egg of course. Amazing depth of flavor to the broth and added a bit of heat to take it to the next level. Loved everything about this meal from the meal to the service to the ambience.

Only negative - they don't serve coffee so I had to look elsewhere to get me out of that post-ramen itis
author: Chandani D.

description:
This place was really nothing special, located near Union Square we decided to get some ramen before starting our day shopping. On a Saturday, we went there around noon just in time for the rush hour. We wrote our name down for a table of 3 and waited for roughly 10-15 minutes before we get seated. 

The service was okay because my sister asked if we can get hot water and the waitress told us that they don't serve "hot water". We thought that was strange because this is a ramen place and they need hot water to make the ramen, but anyways we just got tap water. Let me tell you, towards the end when we were about to finish our meal, couple tables across from us, we saw a family with a cup of steaming hot water. Either the waiter lied to us or she does not want to put the effort into giving us hot water. I was unpleasant about the service I received and I know when someone suggests eating, here again, I would definitely decline and try somewhere else that serves better ramen.  

Food was mediocre also, I got the spicy tofu ramen. Not really good because the noodle they use taste like egg noodles they used in wonton noodle soup. I was really disappointed that the noodles did not match the soup base. My spicy tofu ramen contains so many cabbages and some tofu. I was really stuff with eating so many cabbages and I never see any ramen with that many cabbages. I couldn't finish the noodles, it was really hard to finish the noddles in the bowl. 

The service and food was a disappointment and you can see the people that usually go here are mainly tourist. The price is not worth for this egg noodle so-called "ramen". You will also get really thirsty afterward from eating here.

Definitely, trust the Yelp reviews of being 2 stars rating restaurant.
author: Judy M.

description:
My friends and I stopped by here today for some dinner after strolling around San Francisco. We got in around 5:45ish and there was no one in front of us, but we waited about 10 minutes for a table that could hold the 6 of us. The restaurant itself is pretty small and has very few tables (I would say up to 10 tables in this establishment) 

There were people lining up behind us for the dinner rush so I obviously expected this place to be pretty good if there were people who wanted to eat here and would even wait to get a table. 

After we were seated, I perused the menu and there weren't many ramen options that caught my eye so I ended up ordering the ramen with soy soup ($11.95) - BBQ pork, seaweed, green onions (I added an egg for $1). That was all that was in the ramen - no egg, mushroom, corn... nothing, you have to pay more to add that stuff. You also have to pay more to get it spicy or extra spicy... ($0.75 for spicy). Why would you have to pay extra just to get it spicier? I was baffled at the prices, I was paying so much for practically nothing. After ordering I was expecting something really good judging from the prices. 

Food came out after 15-20 minutes and I was underwhelmed. The ramen didn't look good overall, but I was super hungry so I just ate it. The broth was VERY salty (i couldn't even finish my food bc it was so darn salty), the noodles were like packaged top ramen noodles, the noodles were overcooked, and the egg wasn't even a ramen egg!! It tasted like glorified cup-of-noodles. 

My friend ordered the pork belly ramen ($15.95) and made it spicy ($0.75). She told me the pork belly was super unappetizing and chewy. She decided to go for the more expensive ramen and was very unsatisfied. 

I ended up paying $17 for my meal (they added 18% tip for a table of 6+). It was 100% not worth it and I don't see myself ever returning here. I'd rather have microwaved ramen over this place.
author: Julie N.

description: Average, standard Japanese comfort food... with kimchi as a side. The sakes are just so-so. Easy and quick service. Like fast food Japanese style more than anything else, which might be just what one needs.
author: Kimberly H.

description: I stumbled across this place while walking around Union Square.  There was a crowd of people waiting outside a door.  Out of curiosity, we checked it out and found out people were waiting for Ramen.  This must be pretty good Ramen if people are waiting like this. After a quick 10 minute wait, we were lead downstairs to the main dining area.  There's nothing bedazzling or unique about the interior; just a lot of old dark wood. The ramen itself was very mediocre and on the saltier side.  We also ordered some sushi. Overall, this place is eh.  I think the dense population and the tourists makes this place as busy as it is, but I'm skipping this place next time I'm in SF.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Came in at 3 pm, no wait, and the Ramen was off the chain. Got the silken tofu ramen and added spicy, and It was on point. Hella flavorful, a slight kick (although I added sriracha), and a boiled egg? Done deal. 

Go get you some.

Pros:
Ramen
Price
Ambiance - super low key

Cons:
None - but I can imagine this place gets busy during real meal hours
author: Vyshak C.

description:
Hm, definitely new management.....

I work in the area. The smoke and dust from the northern fires have been giving me a scratchy throat. I wanted something soothing. This ramen place was the only one open at the time and i though id come in desperately wanting some soup.

The decor looked very nice in its new downsrairs location. There was a couple people inside but not too crazy.

They definitely had a new menu. I opted for the pork soup, my bf got the katana soup.

The pork soup was very expensive. And didnt come with any extras, corn, bamboo, egg. Thats all extra to pay for. 

The katana had gyoza in it, and it was super cold in the center. Not even freshly deep fried or reheated on a pan -_- it had too much green onion in it, barely any meat inside. It did come with half an egg. Same price as the pork soup though.....both $15 but one had more inside of it.....makes no sense.

Not once did they come by and ask how were doing, not once did they come by to refill waters. I had to stand up, walk over and ask for my bill. 

They definitely rely on tourists to walk in here to pay their outrageous prices on their not so good ramen. Very sad actually. They should discuss a different business plan and stop making ramen.
author: Lynn C.

description:
This place was a hard miss for me... which was a bummer because the year before when I stopped by for a meal I was amazed by the quality of the food and service. 

A few friends and I stopped by for an early dinner after exploring SF on foot (meaning we were famished) and although we arrived around 5pm before the dinner rush and the place was pretty slow -- we had to wait around twenty minutes... which wasn't the worst but still not great either when it's clearly not busy. 

Once we were seated I ordered the pork belly ramen which was a special and which also went for around $16. (Plus an additional fifty cents to add spicy) I always crave pork belly though so I just had to splurge. Once we got our ramen I couldn't finish my pork belly as the quality of it was rather poor... the color looked off and the texture was too hard to chew. My friends didn't get the same ramen but they also noted how salty their respective dishes were. 

They weren't happy with their meal and to be honest I'm a little disappointed at how the quality has declined since the year before. Perhaps it was just an isolated incident? Anyways, as a group we definitely weren't blown away by this experience.
author: Christine W.

description:
TL;DR: Really terrible ramen here. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone for any reason... like, EVER.  You'd be better served boiling some water and making a cup noodle; it'd taste better and you'd be saving money. 

The Review: 
San Francisco, I love you but... what is this place and why are they calling this ramen? 

I came to Katana-ya because I happened to be staying at a nearby hotel and as always, am looking for good Japanese restaurants. As always, I just do a quick google search and was thrilled to see that this place had pretty solid ratings on both Google and Yelp. To boot, I saw they were on lists that included, "The 7 Best Ramen Restaurants in San Francisco". 

"Great! With ratings and articles like this, what could go wrong?" Short answer: EVERYTHING. 

The Ramen:
Oh, jesus... the ramen at Katana-ya is a hot mess. Trust me, it's just plain bad. 
 
I ordered the shio ramen and the menu said it comes with kara-age and gyoza. Makes sense as both are common sides with ramen in Japan. When it arrived, both items were inside my ramen. WTF? It made both items just soggy and gross. Mind you, they probably both wouldn't taste good even if they were served on the side but putting them inside just exacerbated everything. 

I wish I could tell you that the gyoza and kara-age in my ramen were the least of my concerns, but sadly, they weren't...

So how was the ramen? Simply put, the ramen at Katana-ya just didn't taste good; almost as if nothing was actually made at the restaurant. The gyoza actually tasted like it was purchased at the frozen aisle of a grocery store. 

More over, the presentation of the ramen was awful. If you ever have ramen from a halfway decent ramen restaurant, the ingredients are each thoughtfully placed and in the end, you have something that looks pleasant to eat. What I got at Katana-ya was ramen that was disastrous to look at. Half of me thinks that the cook in the back was drunk and blind folded when he put this creation together. Absolutely no thought or care when into the presentation of the ramen. 

As for the ramen broth, it just tasted off to me; I've had shio-ramen before but this was unlike any I've ever tried. It was... strange. 

Of course, with all of this said, it is absolutely possible that Katana-ya has some good items on their menu, but ramen just doesn't seem to be one of them. 

Other Things About Katana-ya: 
- The staff is very hands-off; not the type to check back on you and see if you need anything.
- It's very dark and dingy inside; Kinda gross. I hated the atmosphere. 

The Bottom Line:
I still can't figure Katana-ya out. It's a place known for ramen but from what I could tell, they do ramen very poorly. Like I said earlier, there's a chance they have something good on the menu but it's honestly one I wouldn't be willing to bet on. 

Do yourself a favor; Skip Katana-ya. There are too many good restaurants in SF for you to spend your time and money here.
author: Kenji O.

description:
After a long morning of Christmas shopping, we realized we were starved and needed a lunch time pick me up. We stumbled upon this restaurant while we were actually looking for another sushi place (which we realized had closed). 

This restaurant has super fun ambiance! You walk downstairs into the restaurant. It makes you feel like you're in another city, like NYC! Super cozy and intimate! Not many tables and a really cool wooden bar area!
 
We were seated immediately on this Sunday. Service is a bit spotty. Took off a star for service. They were short staffed and rarely came by our table unless we flagged them down. 

We both got the ramen. Bowl was huge! Ramen was pretty good! It's a basic ramen with meat and chives. Anything like egg, seaweed, etc is an additional fee. Something like $1 I think?

We also ordered an appetizer of the fried chicken, which came out after our ramen..little odd. Chicken was fantastic! 
Had to flag the waitress down for water and the bill. Waiting for the bill took a good 10/15min. Or at least it felt like we were sitting there that long. Another star subtracted for this treason. 

Overall, a good spot for non-fancy, average ramen, in a super fun environment! I'll probably be back again when I'm in the area. 

Ramen was $14. Pretty average price.
author: Milena R.

description: Very nice waitstaff. Easy to find location and clean. We were pretty bummed on the sushi though. They only had tuna, salmon and one other fish. We really wanted to try the butterfish, which why we came here. Our tuna maki had a lot of tuna, which was nice. Next time I would just just order ramen, other people had ordered it and looked great.
author: Stacy M.

description:
Ugh never again. I honestly don't know what other people are raving about. We saw so many good reviews for this place and wanted to check it out. We waited almost an hour for food...ended up being very disappointed.

1. Everyone in my table got the same thing - miso Katana-ya ramen. (the special). As a table consensus, the broth just tasted weird. Usually, ramen broth is creamy and fatty but this broth it didn't only lack in this, it also just tasted bad. I've literally had boba shop ramen taste better than this. We did go around closing so maybe the chef just got tired or ran out of broth and quickly put something together, but that's not an excuse; especially for the price tag of 16 dollars/a bowl.

2. The Karaage was seasoned pretty well, but why are the gyoza and karaage put inside the ramen broth? Who eats wet fried chicken? That just made me really confused.

3. The service reminded me of fast food service. I saw the waitresses when they got the orders, the food, and the bill. That's it. I understand that it's customary to pre-charge tip (18%) for larger tables but at least show so type of effort even when you know you'll get the tip regardless.

TL;DR:
Broth was bad. Service was really lackluster. Fried chicken was seasoned pretty well, but soggy. Expensive. I don't recommend.
author: Jason L.

description: Best Ramen in San Fran! Went twice during our stay and from service to food....we were not dissapointed. Cant wait to come back!
author: Corina C.

description: The "vegan" ramen was bland because the vegetable broth was not good. They said it was vegan but then they gave me egg noodles... That actually doesn't bother me as much as the fact that it just didn't taste like anything. The agedashi tofu was great, though!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Hubby and I are slowly transitioning to a Vegan lifestyle, so we decided to try the vegetarian ramen. It was very flavorful, we actually went there again the next day! The restaurant itself was underground, dark, and small. But for some reason I actually like it. Servers were not very welcoming and sluggish. But not bad enough to where I wouldn't go there again.
author: Kristen K.

description:
Was looking for some warm food with my boyfriend on a Saturday night in DTSF. This place is a lot different from the last time I've been here! They moved their dining area to the downstairs. It is stuffy and tiny down there.

We waiting about 30 minutes for 2 people. 

Their chicken karaage ramen is still the best. Expect large servings. What was disappointing was that my egg was 100% cooked and not runny, and it was COLD :( The best part of the ramen was the broth. Nothing else about the ramen really stood out. It was also about $40 for two bowls of ramen and no drinks or appetizers which is a hefty place. 

There were only 2 servers running around, taking out food and hosting so the service takes a drop because of that.

There are other ramen places that are cheaper and higher quality than this place. I wouldn't come back here again. They definitely downgraded from the last time I was here.
author: Leah A.

description:
In 2013, katanaya was one of my top ramen places in San Francisco.  Sadly over time the prices have increased dramatically and the quality of the food has decreased equally so.

If you go to katanaya I recommend getting the katanaya ramen.  It has dumplings, fried chicken (karaage) and other meat and vegetables.  

Katanaya is located next Curran Theater but is in the tendernob and is a bit of a rough area.  The chefs are Japanese and the waiters/waitresses are Russian.  I recommend going to Ramen Underground or Kan Ramen if you're looking for a good ramen place.  

There's a lot of expensive and mediocre ramen places in San Francisco and unfortunately katanaya is now one of them.
author: Mark C.

description:
Pretty good ramen. Not the best
 I've ever had but certainly better than average. I got the spiciest ramen. The broth was so red and delicious. The restaurant was downstairs there was not wait. Service was good and there's a candy bowl filled with lollipops. Nice way to end the meal
author: Young-Ju O.

description:
This little Gem, is a little hidden... but man was it a great stop!!!

We ordered the katana -Ya 
Spicy Beef Ramen
Pork Belly Sampler

The Pineapple Sake was good. The service was quick and they are open late, so that's a big plus for us late eaters 

Will definitely be back for some Sake Bombs, with friends!
author: Abraham R.

description: Let me start by saying the servers here are not very attentive and friendly. I had the miso ramen and the broth was on the saltier side. I definitely was not a fan of the pork belly- it was dry and had no flavor. For a bowl of ramen that only had pork belly, seaweed and green onion ( no soft boiled egg)  was pretty expensive.
author: Reginne B.

description:
Oh my God this place is wonderful! This restaurant was suggested to me by the concierge at the hotel where I stayed while I was in San Francisco for a few days. He told me that this was a place where I can get authentic Ramen. And I don't mean the ramen that most folks from the states think about.  Plus,  I don't mean the ramen that college kids buy for $0.10 a bag. This stuff is delicious! The soup is especially for this time of year because it is served hot. Although, it is a Japanese dish, it contains Chinese-style noodles made of wheat.  I couldn't get enough of the big, tasty noodles.  These noodles are served in a meat or fish broth that is flavored with either soy sauce or miso. This restaurant offered three different options (miso, soy or salt) for a basic Raman. Then the noodles are topped with such options as sliced pork, seaweed or scallions.   In my case I chose slices of BBQ pork in my Ramen, plus wonderful seaweed.  I ordered the Miso because it is the most popular and this would be my first experience with having authentic Ramen.

 The first entryway into this restaurant was a was a little off-putting. However,  because it is a wonderful Hole-in-the -Wall Restaurant, you have to go downstairs before you can actually enter the establishment.  Once you come downstairs, you enter a very cozy atmosphere (the restaurant is small and only seats about 40 people comfortably). I was greeted immediately and seated at the bar, since I was alone. The server was very patient with my "Ramen ignorance" and I really appreciated that.   Once I ordered, per his gentle suggestion, the food came quickly (it was lunchtime) and I had to wait for the Ramen to cool a little.  Though it was served piping hot, I couldn't eat it in that condition.  

Everything about this quaint place appealed to me.  I recommend it highly on your next trip to San Francisco.
author: Aleeta P.

description: Great food, large portions and great variety. They spiced everything just right, almost a comforting spice level, just enough before you feel smacked in the face:)
author: Christopher B.

description:
Taste is all relative and I can only comment on my experience and feedback. 

1. It's odd to have monthly special ramen not available when ordering so I settled on spicy beef ramen which the waiter recommended as an alternate special here. It is like beef stew tossed into a ramen noodle bowl. I can smell the burnt beef from the cooking process. The soup was mediocre. 

2. The service seems a bit lacking also. Getting refill on water seems to be a lost cause and I'm echoing the sentiment of few other reviewers along with another table right next to me. 

3. The positive is that it is in a prime location in Union Square and opens until late night. So if you have a craving when staying in hotels nearby, it will get you filled.
author: Nick X.

description: I like this spot for ramen and it used to be busy until Mensho Tokyo opened. Haven't been to the city in a while and honestly went to try Mensho Tokyo at 10:30pm and there was a line! It's so SF to wait in line when there's the same thing 2 blocks away, so I opted for Katana-Ya which was sadly pretty empty but satisfies the ramen craving! Got the vegetable ramen because I'm trying to be healthy-ish and it was enormous and tasty! Def like pork better but good noodles and kimchi and more than enough. I feel like I can usually finish my noodles and when I was finished eating I still had what looked like a full bowl left.
author: MaryKate M.

description: Little raman parlor down stairs. 5he ambiance was excellent. Dark natural cut wood gave the place a very japanese feel. Our party got different version of the tonkatsu raman and were not disappointed. The broth was full bodied and not overly sweet. I had the 3 pieces of pork belly which came out as delicious looking as the picture. I will definitely come here again.
author: Alex T.

description: Ramen was delicious! Coming from a small town we are on the hunt for a good ramen place. Judging from yelp reviews we were very satisfied! We all ordered the Katana-Ya special it was a bite spicy! But we managed to eat all of it. Very friendly staff will definitely be back if we get the chance!
author: Amelia L.

description: I ordered karaage miso ramen & so delicious. I think the serving portion was big enough for two people. We supposed to order sushi but they only serve it after 5pm. Nevertheless, the ramen was worth it. I'll try their pork ramen next time.
author: Marygail S.

description: If you plan to go on a low carb diet this place is great. The ramen tasted worst than instant ramen. I tried a few pieces and decided it wasn't worth the calories. The broth was so salty that I felt off for the afternoon. Not happy about spending 20 on subpar ramen, would not recommend.
author: A B.

description:
I was able to sample their monthly special of Kakuni Ramen spicy, I also got to sample the butterfish nigiri, here is breakdown of what I sampled and how well it fared.

Found on Geary in SF in the fidi area. This place is one of those hole in the wall places, dark inside, almost club like, barely lit, if you are driving you will probably pass by it fairly quickly, if walking due to the awning you will be able to pin point it out. 

The Nigiri butterfish 2 pieces was very good, for most people probably 3 bites to scarf this down, did it in one per piece, delicious, buttery, soft, didn't even need soy sauce, I would order this again over and over

The Kakuni Ramen spicy- included seaweed, 3 fairly large pork belly pieces, diced green onions, and noodles, served piping hot, the broth was heavy almost like a tonkatsu broth which is usually very heavy and filling, the added spicy makes your throat tickle when you sip on broth. Portion wise approved!!! You will get full finishing this massive bowl. The pork belly pieces were on level of falling apart once biting down, the tendon and fat still held everything together. The noodles were not my favorite of this dish, the broth and pork belly was the star. Yes pork belly is fatty it is pork belly for god sake

I will have to come back and try their unagi combo and some more of their rolls or rice bowls. 

ramen *** pork belly good, spicy miso broth good, noodles not so good
nigiri ***** butterfish is a must try, don't use the soy sauce you won't need it
price $$ 1 bowl and 1 nigiri place came to about $28
service ***** excellent, very helpful staff
ambiance **** very dark, full bar, small, I can imagine with an extra 15 people this place would be packed
author: Clarence A.

description: This was my second time having ramen.  I got their monthly special with pork belly spicy miso broth.  It was so much more than I expected.  They broth was flavorful.  The pork belly was so tender and tasty.  If I ever come back to SF I will be stopping here.
author: Bryan B.

description: We came in from the cold expecting a nice warm bowl of ramen and were severely disappointed. The broth was flavorless and couldn't match up to the flavor of the noodles. The noodles were ragged and much too thin--they became soggy within minutes thanks to the broth being practically boiling hot. The meat was also flavorless and sad--I couldn't finish. I wouldn't go back. All of these food grievances are compounded by the dingy interior, rude servers, and terrible tableware (the chopsticks are 8 inches long and are NOT appropriate for eating noodles). The reason I am not giving one star is because I understand how hard it is to make ramen but it doesn't excuse the poor quality and the overall bad experience.
author: Bret R.

description:
I lived around the corner and was always fond of this place. But that was years ago. Coming back they moved to the downstairs and so has their quality. Moved, down. The noodles were not yummy anymore it tasted somewhat like cup of noodles. Not the traditional chewy ramen. Everything was salty and the fried dumpling ( was that always there?) was such a distraction. The chicken karagge was soggy. I'm just...sad. Yet still there's a line crawling up the stairs and out the door? Why? Location perhaps. - near union square and all the hotels. Oh and servers... time to learn how to give just a smidge better service. 

I rather try going to mensho again... since I've yet to try that and it's like was the only reason why I ended up at Katana-Ya
author: Linda T.

description:
Pretty good ramen. It was delicious. You can spice it up if you want you with their delicious chili pepper sauce  

Con: usually busy, the wait time was about 30 mins for me.
author: Cecile ..

description: First time here! And had Amazing service! Ask for their popular dish with miso soup and its so delicious! My server was amazing as well! And the whole environment was comfortable and low-key!! Highly recommend!!
author: Jasmin S.

description: We ate here two nights in a row, not because of the service but because of the delicious Ramen. It's a difficult review in that 1 employee was very nice when you could get her attention, but our waitress kept going behind the partition where the register was and would ignore most of the patrons, it was frustrating. That being said the food was great, the prices are almost reasonable, and some of the servers are very nice. I will definitely go back when I am in town.  If you like Ramen this is the place!
author: S. H.

description:
Used to be a regular here but not anymore. Not sure if they got new owners or something but it seems to have completely changed. The ramen is either bland or just tastes like it's out of a can. The proportions are all wrong and the ingredients are not good quality. We had a salad as well which consisted of old lettuce and dressing out of a bottle. 
It's really too bad as we used to frequent this place but won't be going anymore because the food truly took a nosedive.
author: Matt D.

description:
Yes, the place has moved next door and down the stairs. Why is still marked as closed with so many Yelpers verifying the move?

I agree that Katanaya is not what it once was. My ramen was still delicious, but the service was really really bad. There were only three customers, so they were not overwhelmed. All of the servers were just standing around talking while I sat with an empty water glass and blazing tastebuds after eating my Tuna Poke. 

Speaking of the Tuna Poke, this dish was pretty amazing. The bottom layer of rice was coated with a super spicy red sauce. Next, the Tuna with a delicious sesame soy glaze. The dish was topped with a seaweed salad and some sprouts. I wish I had just eaten the tuna and skipped the ramen on this trip.
author: Or C.

description:
Their ramen is forgettable, but I'm not here to talk about that. I'm here to reflect upon how DIRTY THEIR RESTROOM IS!! I walked in and the first thing I saw was all the toilet paper and paper towels strewn about. It wasn't until I sat down that I noticed it... a dead cockroach the size of my thumb lying legs up just a couple feet away from me! I must say, I'm thankful it was dead rather than alive and scuttling around.

It was also a good thing we had already finished our meal, or else I would have hightailed it out of there so quickly. If their restroom is a reflection of their establishment, I'm not sure I can trust the sanitation of their kitchen.
author: Jennifer V.

description:
What happened to this place? I've gone here a handful of times in the past, and I've always liked it! 

My cousin just moved to SF from Hawaii, and I know she loves her ramen! Since she lives by here, we figured why not?! Although a friend of hers forewarned her that this place isn't what it use to be, we still went to find out the hard way on our own.

I guess they closed the restaurant upstairs. I heard they are turning it into a cafe. Now katana-ya is located next door... down a set of stairs. It still has that dark and dingy feel that it did before. There was NOBODY in the restaurant... that was very unusual because I'm use to a crowd at this place. The guy who was working was okay. Nothing special stood out. He welcomed us in, seated us, gave us menus to look over, and took our order.

We ordered a "set" to share. We went with a katana-ya shoyu ramen with tempura bowl and hamachi sashimi. The sashimi came out first, and was pretty good! Then when the ramen came out, it had an odd smell to it. I didn't like the smell, so it was a bit hard to eat it. The flavor of the ramen was bland. The only thing that stood out was the corn. I usually get the spicy miso flavor, so maybe I'm just use to that flavor and like that one better. Then the tempura bowl came out. The tempura itself isn't bad, but there was WAYYY TOO MUCCHHH sauce over the rice. So much that it became unedible. 

I was so sad because I wanted my cousin to have a good experience. It doesn't seem like shes found anything that floats her boat. Its worst that I was highly recommending this place, and it let me down. Now she probably doesn't trust my choices anymore. We both left with the same thought in our minds... never again...
author: Lily T.

description:
THE PORTIONS ARE FREAKING HUGE. I always ALWAYS finish my ramen, but it was so hard for me to finish my bowl last night. I got the Karaage Ramen, which I have not encountered at any other ramen place so it was worth the try. It's deep fried chicken, which sounds phenomenal. I wish they would put the chicken on the side though because it gets soggy in the broth way too fast. The flavor that the deep fry leaves a delicious buttery flavor on the chicken. I like how you can choose what kind of broth you want for your ramen such as Miso or Soy. I got the Miso and it was kinda on the saltier side. 

The line was out the door because there is minimal seating and there were only like two waitresses. They have like a sign in sheet for you to write your name down to be seated, there is no hostess SO PUT YOUR NAME DOWN RIGHT WHEN YOU WALK IN. They waitress charged us for a Takoyaki we ordered, but they never ended up bringing it out to us and we didn't remember until the end. So check your bill just in case!
author: Jenni T.

description:
Visit katana-ya few weeks ago
Taste awful even the beer is room temperature 
I didn't get it tap sapporo is not cold enough, and room temp. 

We got recommend from server and i was order combo meal with unagi but it wasn't that good
author: Elaine L.

description:
We ordered Miso-Ramen (But taste so-so) ( *_*)       Sake Salmon Sashimi taste yummy (The washabi taste wired, nit spicy)(*)     Spicy Tofu Ramen with Soy soup (But the soup taste like Kimchi)

The last one we ordered is good one!!!
I highly recommend everyone should taste here's Ramen.
I think this type of the ramen are tasty and refreshing!!!

 Vegetarian ramen restaurant option last order (＾＾)

Total spend $44 & $7(Tips) for 2Ramen 1Sake Sashimi(6 pices) 

           **the food are not worth this price!!!!
The soup base contains a lot of ajinomoto(MSG), and before I finish my Ramen, my water is finished. The waitresses did not take the initiative to add water for me even when the restaurant was not busy.
author: Yingying C.

description: This is my least favorite ramen place in SF. Come here if you love salt. Lots of it. We couldn't believe how salty the tonkatsu and regular ramen was! I also don't like when the photo on the menu doesn't match what you get. Most ramens surprisingly do NOT come with the egg as pictured. That would cost you extra. The chicken I added to my bowl was nothing but 2 grisly pieces of bone. Really now. It's a pricey place for what you get, which isn't much.
author: Paul S.

description: Solid regular ramen medium spicy after a night of drinking. Didn't fill me up too much but it was a good way to end the night (10pm) and sober up
author: Clayton B.

description:
I came back here again a couple of weeks ago and it definitely has went down hill.

I ordered the Katanaya ramen since I loved it the first time I came here. It's the bowl with two slices of pork belly, two gyozas, and karaage. This time around, I felt the broth was not as flavorful and the gyozas were so mushy. 

Even if it is SF downtown prices including tax and tips is nearly $20/bowl of ramen. There are definitely much better ramen places with better ingredients for a lower price.
author: Allie Y.

description:
I came here for dinner at 6:30 before a show across the street. Not a lot of people were there, so we got seated immediately.

I ordered the regular ramen with soy broth. Usually I enjoy drinking the broth along with the ramen, but I found it way too salty. My dish was around $12 and it came with noodles, seaweed, and some pork. Any other add ones would be through ordering the specialty ramens, or paying for the extras like egg or kimchi. Overall, I thought the ramen was just mediocre. I didn't have very strong feelings towards or against it since I was just stopping in for a quick dinner. But I would find somewhere else in SF if you want a really good bowl of ramen.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Soup is no bad. As a Japanese who knows the depth of Ramen, noodle and egg can be improved more. Noodle would be thicker and egg would have stronger soy taste by dipping soup longer. 
One more thing I want to add is counter table. It's too high,,
author: Tetsuo O.

description: Been on that ramen craze so me and my friend decided to come here for lunch since every other ramen place didn't open till 5pm. Located below the sidewalk with stairs towards the opening, it's a little inconvenient for people that have trouble walking, including disabled people. It's really dark in there which also is inconvenient. It was quiet at the time me and my friend arrived, but the service seemed ehh. The menu didn't have that many options just like any other ramen places, short and simple. I opted for the Katana-ya ramen also the most expensive one out of the options at $16.99 I believe which had many toppings like fried gyoza, corn, seaweed, chashu, and pork belly. When the ramen arrived, the ramen was rather hot warm than piping hot which threw me off. Right away, I tried their broth which wasn't so bad, just wished it was hotter. I also took a bite of their ramen and I liked the texture, but it left this stench taste in my mouth, almost like plastic hence I just drank most of the broth and ate the toppings. I don't know what the ramen had, but it just left a plastic taste I couldn't stand. Besides that, this is ehhh. There are definitely better ramen somewhere else. Save your money.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Ramen here is bland. The meat all tastes the same and it reminded me of Top Ramen. Pretty sad that my favorite part was the corn in the bowl. 

Service was also terrible. We were done with our meals and had to ask for a check and then our check was brought to us 15min later by someone else - it also wasn't crazy crowded so can't blame business on the poor service. Waitress seemed to have an attitude with us when we sat down. Fake tight smiles, no personality. Even asked if we were done while ordering. I'm sorry I'm ordering a lot - usually that means you'll get a bigger tip!! We got 2 ramen bowls, sake and sushi. Not like we were asking for anything special or modifications. It was just me and my boyfriend and we aren't high maintenance but we do enjoy some personality, waters filled and a timely check drop. 

Best part of the experience was the spicy salmon roll. Just the right amount of spice. If I ever come back, it would be for the sushi and I'd opt for delivery. The noodles and service aren't worth it.
author: Kris T.

description:
It's gone way down the hill. Use to like this place. Should've believe my friend when he told me the week before ... but I had to try it myself. I used to come here especially after hours to get a good meal. My experience over the weekend was just bad.

The broth was okay but the noodles? People in Japan will just laugh. Ramen, really? more like wonton egg noodles but was not good and over cooked. I didn't even finish and I never waste food.

Also ordered the spicy salmon roll. 6 small pieces for $11 dollars. You kidding me? What pissed me off was that they squeeze some not so spicy mayo sauce on top of the not fresh salmon. Worst ramen and sushi experience ever!! Can't believe it's this awful now. Not giving it a 1 star because service was nice. Please up your game! So gross.
author: Sandy B.

description:
First spot to hit once we arrived in San Fran. Being that the dining area is small with limited tables, we did end up waiting a bit, about 20-30 mins. 

The ramen was pretty good, but not great. The broth could use a little more flavor in my option. Would I go back again? Yep! But next time, add kimchi (my friend had it in his and it was soo much better!).
author: Johnny K.

description:
Wow. I don't know what happened the past half decade but the service here is bad. The ramen is overpriced and not worth it. 

Not coming back again.
author: Debbie T.

description:
Not a fan. I truly don't understand the 30-40 min wait. There are far better places to have Ramen in SF. The ingredients are not fresh and the staff is unresponsive. 

If you are eating here, don't have the Spicy Beef Ramen. The vegetables were over cooked--beyond recognition. Basically, it was beef stew with low quality ingredients.
author: Villa S.

description:
So, this started my ramen addiction but as time went by and I came back multiple times. 

I realize that a bowl of ramen here, while healthy in size and portion, is overbearing. So much going on and not enough quality.

Sometimes too much of something is actually a bad thing. If you're more into quantity over quality, here is the spot for you.

Again, SERVICE IS STILL HORRIBLE. Regardless of foot traffic.
author: AQ N.

description: Good food, but they prices for alcohol are extremely expensive. Cash Only- enjoy your 9.00 Sapporo :) it could be just the San Francisco prices but...
author: Alicia A.

description:
I have been here several times, only have had ramen though, so this review can't speak for other parts of the menu. My favorite is the Katanaya Ramen Spicy Miso flavor. It has plenty of goodies in it - karaage, gyoza, BBQ poke slices, egg, and corn. The portion is great and their ramen noodles is pretty decent. I love their broth the most. It's usually all gone by the end of the meal :P

I tried out their Special Pork Belly Ramen in my most recent visit. I have to say I was disappointed. Instead of being "slow cooked to perfection" as the menu claimed, the pork belly was sadly overcooked. My friend ordered the same thing and hers was dry and hard as well, so it was probably not bad luck. Maybe it was due to how late we came in (around 11pm), but it was sub par from their usual food quality for sure.

The upstair part of the restaurant is currently under some remodeling as far as I can tell, which means only downstair seatings are available. You will definitely hit a line if you come during dinner hours, ~30 min wait on average I would say. I would still come back in the future, just probably not getting Pork Belly Ramen anymore.
author: Angel C.

description:
This place is not bad for some Ramen.
Broth - mediocre
Pork - mediocre
Noodles - good

I was looking for a good place for Ramen in SF but still haven't found one. This place was okay, but not great.

Best place I found so far in the SF area, but not as good as Shinma In Oakland. 

Met a guy from China here who really liked it, but to each his own.

Service was mediocre too.
Price was pretty reasonable for the amount of food they give you.
author: Philip J.

description:
Bummer!  Was hoping to find a good ramen spot in SF - but have not yet found the one.

I had the karaage miso ramen and added an egg.  Unfortunately not all of their ramen dishes come with an egg, so I had to pay the extra dollar to add to mine.  The karaage ramen was about $15 before the egg, so a pretty pricey bowl of ramen by the end of it with tax and tip.

The broth was super salty and I was left thirsty the rest of the night despite how much water I drank.  The karaage wasn't a good idea.  What's the point of throwing the karaage in the soup if it's just going to get soggy?!  My bad for ordering it - but I've learned my lesson.

Noodles also weren't stand out, just standard.  I wouldn't come out of my way to go here again... But it is in a convenient location from Powell Bart.  Expensive, mediocre ramen... I expected better from you SF!
author: Kenna H.

description:
I used to love this place, not sure if they changed management after the move or something, it was completely awful last time I went.
The place was half empty, plenty of empty tables. But they still kept 3 groups waiting in the line for nothing for at least 20 mins until we complained to them and promptly left. The waitresses would walk by, look at us, pretend not to see us.
I understand this place is not even nearly as busy as it used to be, but do you really have to waste people's time to keep them waiting for nothing just to create the feel of the place being busy?
Yes the food is good, but do you really want to go there be treated like you are begging for their food?
author: Jake Y.

description: Killer ramen bowl and great service, was the perfect place to go after a long day of traveling.
author: Cody F.

description: Regular bottle beer is $9.  Regular sake is 12.75. The young lady was cold and not really interested in serving our table. While we were eating she was reaching to take our condiments off our tAble. No excuse me or nothing! We felt rushed since we sat down when there was absolutely empty. They hand write receipts to charge you any price for drinks I caught on really quickly.
author: Shawna R.

description:
"One day you will be the one called Master (Naruto). You'll be the one to treat others to ramen. We can't stay kids forever." - Shikamaru Nara

Nearly 4,000 reviews. 

Authentic Ramen. 

Late night hours. 

'Nuff said. 

That would be my wabi-sabi review. Simple enough, but I just can't help myself and need to complicate things & say why I've always liked Katana-Ya. I've been coming here for years and like thrilllist.com says... 

"The only ramen address where Lonely Planet-toting tourists and savvy locals line up with each other, Katana-Ya served the masses long before ramen was cool. Really -- it was even a destination before Asian fusion cuisine ripped apart the '90s. It's old school, it's crowded, it's an essential enough San Francisco institution that it's worth the line". - thrilllist.com food critic

Yup. That pretty much summarizes why I've been coming here for years. Well before hipsters knew the difference between Nissin Instant Ramen vs. Authentic Japanese Ramen. I mean even Michelin recommends this somewhat cramped "tokyo-like" eatery. For me, it's all about the noodle & Katana-Ya never disappoints. I usually go with the Shoyu base regular Ramen w/ Karaage (on the side) + added Gyoza. It's simple, hardy, and satisfies my cravings. If I'm famished I'll go with the combination with a choice of Ramen, Soba, or Udon (I choose Ramen) & includes a mini Donburi (I usually go with the Tonkatsu or Tempura over hot Japanese Rice). I always go with the house hot tea & glass of Tenderloin water. 

Note: Mild-Extra Spicy options. Vegetarian options too. 
Located on Geary St., one block west of Union Square.

Open 11:30 am everyday
Sunday - Wednesday last call 11:45 pm
Thursday - Saturday last call 1:15 am

Okay, I need to confess and base my review prior to the move "downstairs" - it's hard to imagine since it was always on the low-light/cramped-size to begin with. I also noticed the recent onslaught of "what has happened...", "it went downhill...", etc., from regular customers, but to be fair I won't jump on the negative bandwagon and say my experience here has always been good to excellent, again this was before the move downstairs. The service always a hit or miss, but the noodle always on point, and I've been to Japan & was raised in Hawaii, so have that al dente badge in my back pocket as a noodle critic. Hope these recent schizo reviews are temporary, but I guess I won't know for sure until master slithers on downstairs...
author: Eric R.

description:
We used to love this place until they moved DOWNSTAIRS.  

Why on earth would you want to eat at a restaurant that has no windows.
author: Richard C.

description: I'm usually a noodle  gal...but this place does it well! The atmosphere is pleasant and the waiters are super helpful. I will return shortly:)
author: Lense E.

description:
Now in a basement room that feels more polished and somewhat less funky than the prior iterations, they had the nerve to hand us fresh new menus with newly inflated prices, among them $14.95 for a freakin' vegetarian ramen. Hot garbage. We walked out.

The owners have shown they're either confused about what they have to offer, or they just stopped caring. Apparently they think that with the Mensho-fueled SF ramen bubble, they can charge more or less whatever they want. Wrong. This is not destination ramen; all it had for me was proximity and a reasonable price point. Remove that last piece and I won't be back--with one minor caveat, which is why they're dangling by a thread in two-star territory, and that's the late hours. I could imagine a rare occasion when I might grit my teeth and pay for a late-night bowl on a sloppy weekend. A rare one. 

Who knows; maybe they think they can get fat on tourist dollars from lost Union Square shoppers, and maybe they're right, but we who know better will go elsewhere.
author: James D.

description:
I don't usually write Yelp reviews anymore but I feel really compelled to let everyone know about my dining experience here tonight. 

I came in with a party of 5 including myself and waited around 20 minutes on a Saturday night. After we got seated, the waitress takes our orders and the food came out relatively quickly... for 4 of my friends. My order of the ramen didn't come out until 15 minutes after which I didn't understand. The table next to us got sat after my party and they all got their food before me. 

After I told the waitress, she went to the kitchen and brought out my order immediately.  I tasted the food and it was obvious that my order had been left out for a while. 

Tldr: ramen was mediocre and service was horrendous
author: David T.

description: Definitely a wait to get in but the good news is they will text you when you're up. I tried the vegetarian ramen. The noodles were very, very good, the ramen came out super hot (temperature) as ramen should be, but perhaps I didn't pick the right one. Mine tasted more like a spicy vegetable soup than a ramen. Perhaps because it has carrots and broccoli. Next time I will try the beef ramen. My friend got it, it looked better and he likes his better. It's hearty and has beef chunks in it. The service was good too. I was disappointed that they had a cash only sign...even though it said their machine was down, it appeared like a long term/permanent sign. We had to go find an atm.
author: P S.

description: Omg I cannot find anything to say but it was amazing! I did the katanaya ramen without egg and it was exceptional. I loved the dumplings so kept all for the last finger. Will definitely be back.
author: Zeynep D.

description: So good! Speedy service and the spicy beef ramen is so good! During peak hours, the wait can be a bit long but totally worth it!
author: Fermin A.

description: Average. Lacked rich flavor that I've had at many other ramen places, and choices were a little basic. Guess we shouldn't have expected great ramen right at Union Square, but given high ratings and short distance from the hotel it was worth a try. Lots of young adults talking really loudly and slow service topped it off. Not quite the hole in the wall we Haight it would be.
author: John K.

description:
Okay i honestly dont know why there are a lot of negative reviews about the taste and all. All I know was I picked this place based on the fact that its open late, and when I searched google it actually had a decent amount of stars. I guess I expected more.

It was Saturday Movie night last night with my boyfriend, and colder nights have begun! After the movie, went to this place, lucky enough to find parking on the street just across it, dont have to pay for parking yay. But i can imagine going here in the day? Where do we park 

Anyways, street level was closed? Wasnt aesthetic or inviting at all. Does it ever open? If it does, you think they can clean them up? Maybe people would go more?

So theres an arrow leading to the downstairs area! And in the little basement is a cozy place that I love and music is playing 2000s RNB/hiphop/pop. Cool. 

So half star rating taken off for the cleanliness, idk, its not like its so dirty, but something about the vibes telling me its not one of the cleanest place in town. Reminds me of old kbbq places in LA. And this one doesnt serve kbbq or any bbq at all. And the menu? Why does it look like that? Am i picky? Maybe. Lol

Anyway! We ordered and prices are what you'd expect they'd be. Beer price too much tho, we usually order a pitcher that we split, but last night just a big bottle of sapporo 13$ thats fine, and we filled out two pints i believe? 

My boyfriend got the Miso Ramen with Extra Kimchi and his California Rolls.

I got the Udon Curry. 

Served in less than 15 minutes, they were sooo good. Well alot better than diy ramen places ive been in LA. I actually kept eating of my bf's ramen. I wanted udon and curry, but i liked his more. But both were not too salty, noodles were cooked just right, everything was right. 

California roll was just okay, but thats fine we didnt come here for that.

Given so, I really liked our orders and wanted more. They did serve them in big bowls tho.

When bill came out, i guess it just adds up, his cost around 20+ dollars, mines just 14, plus out beer. With tips and etc. 60+ for two? It was worth it, for the taste and for the beer. But i thought we could save more eating ramen than kbbq. Hmm i guess not. 

But i said we'll
Go again! And so we shall.
author: Aubrey Marie S.

description:
I called it a night and went home disappointed. Starved myself all day for some tasty ramen only to be let down. 

Noodles were plain, broth tasted like toilet water and my freaking egg was cold? 

Had to yell for service and everything was overpriced, which is really unsatisfying. 

$50 for two bowls of ramen and a large hot sake

Only left the Mensho Tokyo line because of the 1hr wait and rain. I wouldn't go back if it was free.
author: Chase R.

description:
I completely regret coming here to eat...

Unfortunately I didn't go to Amami upstairs which looked really good and got baited to go downstairs by the yelp reviews on here.

I came here just looking for a nice dinner with my girlfriend on our trip to SF..

The only reason I give it a 2 star was because the waiter was quick. Just not with the check..

Here are the reasons for the rating I'm giving it.

Atmosphere: I liked the atmosphere,  yet I didn't get any signal down there (using T-mobile and my girlfriend sprint) 

Food: Was not very good.. I got the shoyu bbq pork ramen and my girlfriend got the special pork belly. 

1. Noodles clumped together because sill cold.
2. Meat Luke warm.
3. Soup salty

Price: expensive! For the quality.. I've had very good ramen out in LA and the OC area costing around 10-13$ but this was ridiculous. $15 and up..

Service: I felt very unwelcome by the female at the register whom was not busy but on her phone and threw the check after we asked the waiter for the check he walked away and ignored us. The other waiter with the tattoos put the ramen on the table and spilling some of the soup and walked away quickly to tend to the other tables. 

Overall: 2 stars is a fair score because the atmosphere was nice and staff was quick, not friendly but quick. Maybe it's because they've been dealing with tourist all day. But that's no excuse for the quality of the food.
author: Nick L.

description: Meh. I have had better. If you want a real bowl of authentic ramen try Menya Ramen (San Diego) even food star Andrew Zimmern made a stop there. As for Katana is easy to find it's right in the heart of Union Square. However, I must warn anyone with a walking disability or who uses a wheelchair should skip this place. At the very tip of the entrance there is a very steep flight of stairs. Even an athletic person like myself found it quite difficult making my way down the stairs but I was wearing high heel boots! Once you make it down the steps (hopefully with no broken bones) the restaurant itself is quite small. The ramen however is served in HUGE bowls and for the price the serving size is quite generous. You can easily share one bowl with another adult or two small children. They will give you extra bowls if you ask. I ordered the ramen and sushi combo. I got tuna and it was served over a bowl of rice. The sushi was fresh tasting and the serving was decent there was about 4-5 pieces of fish. Out of all my foodie adventures on my recent trip to San Fran this was my least favorite meal. Then again it's impossible for any place to beat Gary Danko where I dined at the night before. If you don't know good ramen from bad then you will enjoy your food here. Skip if you are a true foodie as you will be disappointed.
author: Diana A.

description: Came here this past Saturday with some friends and my girlfriend. I ordered the Katana Ya ramen with a miso broth. I thought the broth was good and was a fan of the large portions they offered. I would give this place 4 stars for the quality of the ramen but I have to dock them a star because this was one of the more expensive ramen parlors I have been too. My ramen was nearly $16 while my gf's udon was about $13 and her basic 6 piece tuna roll was 9! A draft of Sapporo goes for $9 here, that's insane! This place is good, Katana-Ya is good, but not good enough for what they ask.
author: Tristan S.

description: Went there before going to a show. Place was great and the service was good. Food was ok. The chicken karaage was not crispy and the reman was just ok. They had a few sushi and rolls that was not available. Maybe because it was d weekend.
author: raimundo t.

description: We searched for a great ramen spot in the bay and found this suggestion on Yelp. It's a 2 floor level restaurant and for the evening was only serving downstairs. It's a small lower level section with 10 tables and bar area for 4 people. We waited for 15-20 mins for a table on a Monday Night. Upon being say we ordered the vegetable ramen with tofu and were taken back by the amount of food! We were midway through and could not finish our ramen. It was pleasing and nothing else called my attention but, the reviews. The ramen was ok.
author: Lidia D.

description:
A small ramen place underground close to Union Square. It's decorated very fun and had a great vibe. Was a nice respite from the chilly SF night. 

Seems to be a mixture of locals and tourists. We had a really long wait for a large party. I found that the drink prices were kind of ridiculous, like $9 for a Sapporo? Maybe I'm just used to cheaper beer prices outside of Union Square. 

The ramen was good and the portions were large. The miso broth was not overly salty, but didn't think the pork was all that. We investigated what "spicy" was, and the waitress said they put Saracha in your soup. 75 cents for a shot of hot sauce, really?
author: Brian B.

description:
Came for dinner at 7pm on a Thursday night and got seated immediately. I took a while choosing which ramen to order because the choices weren't what I was used to. They were a bit pricier too. Ended up going with the karaage ramen in extra spicy. 

The ramen overall was good, although I do wish that the ramen noodles were thicker. The broth was flavorful and adding extra spicy probably enhanced it for me. The karaage came in big pieces and was yummy. For the price of what I paid for the meal, I would probably prefer another ramen joint, but it was worth a try.
author: Annie H.

description: Their habanero option for  is the spiciest I've ever tried throughout my whole life in the ! #justsayin
author: Moorissa T.

description: If you're into over cooked eggs, fatty karage chicken, tough pork slices, and a princely $17 price tag for all of it: Katana-Ya is your ramen panacea! Otherwise, don't bother, there's many other tastier and/or less pricey options real close by.
author: jacob m.

description: This was my go-to ramen and I brought all travelers here. Was craving some quality ramen and returned and it was an utter disappointment. They expanded and the place is just gross now. The bathroom was riddled with trash and no tp and the ramen was so sad. I used to get the extra hot and did the same and the now the  top inch was literally just oil and grease, if our server would have ever come back I would have sent it back. Service was always a little inattentive, it was even more so now and unfriendly. I ate a few bites and that was it. No more. Sad day to loose another great
author: Morgan S.

description: Cash only? Hmmmm, seems like there's a problem if credit cards aren't accepted as it's been around a long time. Food is awful, staff doesn't want to be there and are on their smartphones watching videos, sometimes bathroom is broken for days. Are they closing?
author: Ken K.

description:
Best ramen broth that I have ever had. Extra point for the fact it was vegetarian. It was silky and so flavorful. I can't get over it. 

We were seated right away on Saturday afternoon. I ordered the spicy tofu with soy base & was so so so so happy with it. Why the four stars? The noodles were not as soft as expected. I thought with such a flavorful broth they would be... I'm not sure how to describe them but they were almost crunchy. If I go back again I will definitely be adding an egg and asking to make it even more spicy.
author: Jaki F.

description:
I was craving ramen and starving- went here after the line for Mensho was down the block. Restaurant was dark and unwelcoming, thought it was closed because it was so quiet down the stairs.
