Very cold waitresses- ramen came out quick but was extremely salty. Super hard to eat. Karrage was very fatty (probably 0 breast meat). No check-in from the waitress. 

Will not return.
author: Sarah N.

description:
The ramen here reminded me of college, a time when my bank account was empty and I'd have to get creative to get a decent meal.

One of my go tos was Pork Top Ramen, 3/4 of a flavor packet, 1 spoon full of miso, and some dried seaweed on top.

It tasted just like the miso ramen here.

2 Stars for the nostalgia.
author: Scott P.

description:
Very subpar. First off, they just put random appetizers like dumplings in the ramen. That is not a thing. Dumplings were soggy, pork was bland, broth not even worth talking about.

I could've just made my own ramen.
author: Ryo I.

description: This is seriously the BEST ramen I have ever had! I miss it so much and often, and if I had the opportunity, I would take a trip to SF just for a bowl of this ramen with kimchee. I went there with one of my dear friends, and we reminisce about this often, and we have shared with the world just how amazing that bowl of ramen was. All ingredients were perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned...making the bowl perfectly balanced. The addition of the kimchee just made it out of this world. I'm so glad that we ignored the negative Yelp reviews because this was worth EVERYTHING!
author: MoniQue H.

description: Amazing ramen, I was extremely lucky to stumble upon this place! I always look for good ramen and this exceeded my expectations. Will keep this restaurant in mind when craving ramen.
author: Peyton S.

description:
People keep recommending this place to me.
Partially, I believe that it's because it's one of the few Japanese-esque ramen places around Union Square that serves ramen that is alright.
Partially, I believe that it also has to do with the last closing that they have here.

I came here a couple of times before - during dinner and during late night.
I have to say, people who raved about this place, confessed their disappointment after returning here.

I rationalized that maybe it has something to do with the different shifts.
The flavors of the food tasted much better and made with more love during the dinner shift.
Maybe they have a 2nd chef who gets the late night, and he doesn't care as much as most of the customers who come in late night are usually inebriated already.
author: Kevin W.

description: This is probably one of the best restaurants I've been to. Very trendy and a cool place to hangout with friends!
author: Gabi R.

description:
The ramen was pretty good and it was a hearty meal... but I don't think it was worth $20 (including tax/tip).  I understand that this place is right near Union Square, but damn it was just a bowl of ramen.  I got the Katanaya miso ramen, which makes the most sense to me because it has EVERYTHING (all the meats, corn, egg) in it.     

I came on a Monday evening and there was still a decent wait to get a table so don't expect to be able to just walk in.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Unfortunately the original owner sold the business. I hope they can maintain their prior quality.
The sushi was not as stellar on my most recent visit. I'm hoping  this was just an anomaly. 

What I liked about this place was the rich miso broth ramen with the odd optional additions (fried chicken and pot stickers), and the generous sushi nigiri portions. 

They have expanded seating by moving into the space next door. No line when I visited on a Friday night, this was unheard of 2 years ago. 

They were on Eat24 for a little while, but no more. The only delivery company they are using as of 9/2016 is Postmates. 

They are are open till 12:30am late if you need a midnight sushi fix.
author: David T.

description: This is legit my favorite ramen place to eat. I love the tasteful vegetarian ramen in the menu. The miso broth is so full of rich flavors. At Night the line can be long but if you come during the evening there's rarely any waiting time.
author: Glenda P.

description: This place was fun, quiet and in a great location. We had the ramen noodles and were not disappointed.  It was great food and a nice evening.
author: Sean A.

description: This place is not good. I got the karaage ramen and the chicken tasted like it was fried hours ago and just put on a plate. Not crispy at all. The broth didn't have any depth of flavor there are so many better ramen places in its general vicinity don't waste your time going here
author: Jennifer B.

description: I heard that the ramen was great so I went there.  I forced myself to stay put and eat there once.  I couldn't get over how filthy everything was; and I mean EVERYTHING.
author: Ricardo O.

description:
Get here early as a line forms and it's small inside. I had the house ramen soy and she the veggie soy. Mine was good, salty broth noodles and meats I enjoyed it. Hers a bit bland, chock full of veggies. I tried it and liked the broth but mine was better.
   Side of pork belly..yummy, but heart attack waiting to happen. It all hung up on the uni.. I asked for nigiri uni. They brought me unagi. Big difference. I said I ordered uni and maybe it was for someone else. She came back agitated and said here it it you order uni you eat now? I said no mam I'm sorry that is unagi I ordered uni. She came back and told me it's pronounced uni. I looked at her puzzled but said no mam that is unagi, bbq salt water eel .  Uni is sea urchin with rice in a seaweed roll. She came bk again and said they were out of uni for the day, but did I want the unagi now?
No I dont. 
   Ok here for cheap noodles( lots of college kids in here), or a cheap lesson in improper Japanese language skills. But if u want good sushi go elsewhere.
author: Dan W.

description: The service was great! Our waiter was really nice and noticed that I couldn't sit comfortably at the bar area so he asked if my boyfriend and I wanted to sit at a table instead. From my first time being here the menu hasn't changed. Anyway, we ordered a Karage ramen(soy broth), the regular Ramen(miso broth), and a small hot sake. Overall, we were pleased with our food. The broth was really flavorful and not too salty. The amount of food was just enough to fill our stomachs but not be too full. Honestly, if I lived in the city this place would probably be a my regular place for ramen.
author: Jackie F.

description:
Starting off with kaarage was a fine choice. You could take several bites from one piece. This was a big portion of kaarage served with salad for starters. 

We ordered pork belly miso ramen. One spicy, one not. Loved them both. Portions are very large. Not too salty. Prepared just right. I highly recommend and will be back to try other dishes. Thank you!
author: Michelle P.

description: Delicious ramen but pricy. I had to pay to add "spicy" to my ramen. Nevertheless the soup was meaty, with yummy chunks of pork belly. I ordered the house salad which was "ok" but pricy as well as it was $8. I def would come back again for the ramen. Sooo delicious
author: Nadia S.

description: We had Katanaya ramen with salt flavor, BBQ pork ramen with miso flavor, karaage,and beer for dinner. Everything seemed ready to heat again for quick serving. The ramen tasted like instant noodles for us. Fried chicken's batter coated sloppy , although chicken was tender. The sliced BBQ pork were too chewy.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
I'm so sad. Katana-Ya used to be my favorite ramen spot in the city, but that was back in 2008-2009, back when the store wasn't basement level and was a super narrow hole-in-the-wall. Now, the ramen is just okay, but twice as expensive as it used to be.

Friends from down south found Katana-Ya online and wanted to try it. When they mentioned it I was excited because I used to love the spicy kimchi ramen (which they don't even have anymore). It had been a few years since I'd been to Katana-Ya, so I was hoping the ramen was as good as I remembered. Unfortunately it wasn't.

- Katanaya ramen $12.95

The spicy kimchi ramen they once had and was my favorite is no longer on the menu. Instead, I went with the Katanaya ramen because the server said it was the most popular and it has their name in it. There's a lot of sh*t in this ramen: BBQ pork slices, gyoza, karage, etc. I felt like the broth was too thin and salty. Ramen broth should be rich with flavor (not just salt), and this wasn't. The noodles were a decent al dente, which was good, but overall, the ramen, for the price, was just unimpressive. 

Service wasn't very good. Our server was regularly missing. We had to keep trying to flag people down for water and the bill. When we finally flagged people down, they didn't seem to care much about the fact that we'd been trying to get anyones attention for a while. 

Overall, I'm super sad that this place has gone downhill. At least they've opened more ramen places in the city.
author: Eifeh S.

description: Ordered the Katana-Ya ramen. It came with corn, seaweed, cha siu, gyoza, kaggare chicken. The texture of the ramen was too soft for me and the soy base isn't rich like tonkatsu... not my kind of ramen
author: Kevin W.

description:
Love their ...
* Katanaya Miso Ramen with Kaarage on the side
* Karaage Miso Ramen with Karaage on the side
* Shiro Maguro Tataki
author: Mindy - Oishii Moments S.

description: Delish! Perfect lunch. The ramen bowl was to die for. I had the tofu vegetarian one. Also, the fried appetizer tofu was great.
author: Elina S.

description:
I think the chef shouldn't be Japanese. probably southeast asian.
that food isn't Japanese food. I felt very disappointed!!!

 Well, for Karaagae(fried chicken), you shouldn't have put it in the microwave. 

I can't score on it.
author: Cecile L.

description:
Delicious ramen! There was a little queue on arrival for an early dinner and we had to put name on a list, but they soon seated us and served us a some veg & shrimp tempura (not as good as the soup) and massive bowl of ramen.

Would recommend!
author: Elyse S.

description:
Came on a Saturday night around 10:30PM, looking for something open until late and this restaurant is quite lively. It was a bit confusing finding the place because there's an upstairs and downstairs. But we sat downstairs and my first thought was that it was very loud. It seems like people go there late at night to drink but definitely louder than I enjoy while eating dinner. Service is alright; the employees  seem like they don't want to be there or are bored.. Fast service but nothing great. 

The food comes out quick! I shared the katanaya ramen and salmon and avocado roll with my boyfriend and it was enough food for the two of us to leave us comfortable! The roll is pretty standard, nothing too special. The ramen was good but on the saltier side. Not sure if it was because the karaage was soaking in the broth but it was super salty.. 
I enjoyed it for the most part. It's different from ramen in SoCal!
author: Kimberly H.

description: Not worth the hype if you ask me . My BF and I have been in a ramen hype lately so we have been trying all the ramen on SF. We came here a little after 9 and the place was packed , but why do you only have two waiters working ?  We finally got seated and we questioned the menu , the waitresses weren't really knowledgeable if you ask me . Ramen was wayyyy over priced and just tasted generic . Nothing special . Save your money and try somewhere else !
author: Monica M.

description:
If I could give them negative star, I would! I ordered the combo -ramen and tempura don $17.95. The ramen was extremely salty & tempura tasted like it was deep fried in the morning and microwaved to heat it when ordered, the rice was soaked with unagi sauce which was unexpected. I asked the waitress to replace the rice to just white rice without sauce for me because it was too salty , she said "$2" extra, I said "no, I couldn't eat it because the rice had too much sauce."  The waitress responded so you wanted for free? I told her that she got it all wrong, the kitchen put too much sauce and I couldn't eat it repeatedly 3x. When she brought the rice and she said that this is for free. 
She really caught me by surprise of her response. 

Food-everything was too salty and not fresh. Ramen was hard even steam rice was stale and old so as the tempura. 

Service-she was ok at the beginning until I asked to change the rice. I had to try to get their attention and wait for refilling water. 

I highly NOT recommend it. Worst Japanese restaurant I ever been!!
author: Tina C. W.

description: Not gonna lie, we ended up here because of a super long wait at our first ramen choice. Overall, the ramen wasn't bad at all, but it also didn't stand out in any way. The edamame was cold and the salt was sort of just dumped on top without much delicacy. Service was alright, and atmosphere was unique with rustic basement vibes.
author: Deidre L.

description:
Pretty subpar in the taste and appearance of the food, and most definitely not worth the wait and price. 

My friends and I wait around 30-40min for a table, and once seated, I felt paranoid bc of the many eyes staring at us since our table was right at the entrance where hungry guests were waiting in line.

I ordered the tempura don, which left much to be desired. The tempura was vegetables in a soft, thick batter. The sauce was tasteless and the rice to tempura ratio was off. My friend ordered the ramen - it looked abysmal. Not appetizing at all - just very oily with very few contents, such that they could barely be seen in the overwhelming amount of soup.
author: Hee Y.

description: Subpar ramen that is pretty pricey. Noodle texture is not very good. It's similar to nisshin instant noodle texture, and the soup is just so-so. Price wise the ramen is also quite expensive. At $14-$16/portion, it's quite expensive given the quality is just ok. Service is good and fast though, so I still give 3 stars
author: Ali B.

description:
Decent food and price worth 3 stars, however 1 star docked due to inattentive/abrupt service and poor food sanitation. 

Their prized ramen is mediocre: 2 slices of meat, some undercooked noodles, and salty broth with lack of substance. The BBQ pork don had great slices of meat, but the sauce was too much and rice was undercooked. The 3 piece salmon sashimi was the saving grace, though I fear for my stomach due to the low sanitation score. 

Our server was ok with getting us what we needed. I'm ok with inattentiveness, but when you see a beggar come in asking patrons for money, you don't turn a blind eye and let everyone feel uncomfortable. We had to wave her over to get the guy out. That made us uncomfortable. Would not recommend unless you are desperately hungry with nothing else open.
author: Kristi T.

description:
I had high expectations walking in due to the long line, closeness to union square and yelp reviews. However, the ramen is not worth the $15.95. The pork was tough, the soup did not taste like miso and we had to wait at least 40 minutes before getting a table. I have been to other ramen places, for example in Japantown in SF and that are cheaper and worth the wait. The ramen itself is fine other than the additions although it absorbs the soup making the noodles slightly thicker. 

If you really are craving ramen, this place will still sate your taste, but keep in mind that it's a bit pricey.
author: Andrea C.

description:
I always have the kakuni ramen in miso and it's... good.

It's really hard to have kakuni ramen without comparing it to Ippudo's version.

I love Ippudo's version the most but this one is good.

Broth also tastes authentic but the pork belly is less tasty and soft.

There was a group of people waiting at 11:25 to get in at 11:30am.

Service was fast. They had no choice because there are always a lot of people.
author: Ray M.

description: Drove all the way from  Sacramento to try  The Raman noodles at this place. Was not disappointed with the noodles Don't anything negative I would have to say about his places after receiver and food the waitress the didn't come by to check on us until she handed us the bill
author: Carlos C.

description:
Ramen with miso soup rather than bone soup and it's too salty. Overpriced sushi with little fish( compared with other sushi bar)
Not authentic Japanese food, not even close.
author: Elise L.

description: Everything is pretty good. Sometimes they run out of food. But it's great. Tried: pork belly ramen, pork belly soba, bbq beef udon
author: Nimi K.

description: We had seaweed salad and Katanaya Ramen for dinner. Ramen portion is large. Though I could not finish it, but the it tasted good. The broth might be over-seasoned for people prefer light seasoning.  It does not take long for the food to come out but the line does, we lined up at the stairway leading to the restaurant level. the stairway is quite cramped.
author: Olivia T.

description: Had the Katanaya miso ramen and it was amazing! First time I've had karaage and gyoza on a ramen it was absolutely delicious. And the pork was so soft and flavorful. I'd definitely come back to this place again.
author: Jonah L.

description:
Haha is this a joke? 

I live in NYC and trust me I'm not a food snob. I'm quite forgiving, but how can you charge premium price for this garbage? 

I thought I had to call a lifeguard because my noodles were drowning in way too much broth. Pork was lackluster and noodles were straight out of packaged ramen. 

Severely disappointing. 

Flavor was a mess. I would rather eat instant noodles over this trailer trash you call ramen. Japan would roll over in their grave if they knew this abomination represented the country's staple food. 

Please AVOID. It is a crime they charge you for this.
author: Timothy P.

description: I did like the ramen, but I've had better broth. The spicy was the way to go. We ordered a delicious cold sake. The bathroom really needs some work. We waited for a while because it was a busy Saturday night. Our service started ok, but it seemed like she forgot about us and we had to wait a while for our bill. I'd want to check out some other places.
author: T H.

description: Came here with some friends on a rainy chilly day. We were originally craving for some hot pot and decided to check out little sheep mongolian hot pot. Unfortunately, the wait was at least 40 minutes and we were starving and cold. So we searched for a ramen place and low and behold this place was just around the corner. I should've known better when we went downstairs and the place was practically empty at 7pm. We ordered 2 bowls of ramen, an appetizer, and some rolls. Salty pretty much sums up our meal. Every dish from the broth of the ramen to the fried baby octopus and even the sushi were overly salty. Then the bill came and it was expensive! We had leftovers and I have never not want to doggie bag leftovers but i didn't want to here. The servers were nice, but other than that, this meal was a total regret. Wasted my meal quota for the limited meals to try in SF.
author: Gen L.

description:
I hope I can give negative stars.

Worst ramen place I have been to. 

1. Soft boiled eggs are cold and hard
2. Ramen is more like microwaved than freshly cooked
3. No water in the bathroom!!! 
4. Overlay fried fried octopus
author: Zheng Z.

description:
Yelp's poor food safety score notice was not enough to scare me away from trying Katana-Ya's ramen. I could see why they got a poor score though. The place is pretty gnarly inside especially towards the back near the kitchen, but their food is good so they must be doing something right! 

Tried their shrimp tempura roll, takoyaki and miso ramen. All delicious! Genius idea of putting giant fried dumplings in the ramen.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I didn't have high expectations the first time I came to Katana-Ya (my friend and I were starving after seeing a play in the area and were desperately searching for spots still open so we could grab some food). I was pleasantly surprised! The noodles are great, chewy with a nice, wheat-y, inherent flavor that complemented the broth and toppings nicely. 

Last time I dropped by at 7pm on a Monday and there was a 15-20 min wait, not too bad but come earlier if you don't want to wait! I recommend the Katana-ya ramen, which comes with everything your heart could desire, pork slices, corn, egg, chicken karage, and even 2 pieces of gyoza! (sounds kind of weird but really tasty!). It's also quite a large bowl so you should definitely leave satisfied. 

I plan on coming back, especially if I'm not in the mood for a long wait for my ramen fix!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Japanese food is fun. I enjoy it v much. However there is only so much enjoyment one can have before the lack of service starts to cut into it. I can only say that the wait time was unknown. We just stood there in hopes to get a table sometime today, even after being acknowledged. I would not say that this was the worst meal in my existence 

I have to say the food is pretty alright. If you want run of the mill udon. The food that was there was not worth the price. But overall it was nice food. I would have been happier with a more appropriate price. 

The venue is small, so if you want to be seated immediately make sure you come at a time when it's not busy. Or maybe find some place else to bring your business
author: Paige O.

description: This is one of the best ramen place I have tried so far. The consistency of the broth is on point, the noodles are cooked to the perfection and the pork was melting like butter.
author: Naoufel T.

description: Okay okay, sometimes I'm wrong--I gave this place another try and holy shit, the ramen really is amazing. Best in SF that I've had. I forgive them for the bad service years ago, I'll put up with a lot for this stuff. The little fried chicken and potstickers that come with your ramen is epic as well. Love you guys at Katana-Ya thank you :)
author: Lilly M.

description:
Overall, I'd say this isn't a bad ramen location around Union Square. On the pricier side for ramen in general but I would say it's average considering its location. It can really busy around dinner time but if you come earlier (before 6:30) shouldn't be a problem getting seated. 

I was impressed by their portion sizes, it was larger than I expected and I appreciate how they matched that by giving more toppings rather than just adding more soup and noodles. The add-ons are also better variety than other basic ramens! The gyoza for example was a really nice touch. My main complaint though is the soup base. It was just way too salty. usually I like to have some of my soup base with my ramen but I avoided it completely because of how insanely salty it was.

I can see myself coming back if I had cravings and I was looking to avoid lines. Wouldn't be my ramen place of choice though.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
The following review is not the businesses  fault but my own because I saw how many stars the restaurant had and I still chose to take the chance because my group and I were desperately hungry. 

The food wasn't great and the service wasn't either. 

We waited to be seated for about 15-20 minutes and in between that time we were not greeted or acknowledged. 

When we were finally sat and put in our order we asked the waitress for waters all around, straws, and ponzu sauce, despite saying she would bring each thing right over to us she never did. In between each request a good 15 minutes passed until we called over another employee. 

The food took a while to arrive and it wasn't worth the wait. No one came by to see how we were doing from the moment the food was dropped off to the moment the check was paid.
author: Karla B.

description: SF local here. This place used to be know for its decent ramen. But because of its touristy location this place has ridiculously exaggerated its price. SF is expensive but even at higher end restaurants beers are 6-7$. But here Sapporo bottle is 12.50$ and a roll is 18-20$. Avoid this place if possible, it's become a tourist trap!!!
author: Anu O.

description: I wasnt sure what to get when i first walked in! It wasnt really welcoming either! I wanted bottled water cause their menu says they have that, but i guess not, then the roll that i ordered was supposed to have crab, hamachi, tuna and quail egg, no quail egg and it was delivered with salmon! When i looked at it , i thought to myself WTF! I dont think this is what i ordered! My friend being super vocal told the waitress in a civil manner that i dont eat or like salmon, and the waitress said we only have salmon and tuna as the only fish tonight! How can a japanese / seafood place have only two kinds of fish, and not address that the other selections were either sold out or not available! What was funny was that the receipt showed smiley face! I laughed to myself and put the opposite of happy face no tip! Terrible service from the walk in! Sorry!
author: Alaric S.

description: It's been a while since we last came, and both food and service has gotten worse. On a Friday night, it was only a third full instead of the long line. The ramen wasn't the worst I've had, but it was below average. And the staff looked like they hated working there. After quickly dropping off our food, they avoided us until it was time to pay. The atmosphere has changed too. Instead of being at street level, you take a door down to the basement level. Nothing wrong with that, but they decorated the place into a tacky underground dive bar. I regret coming back, would have preferred to keep my happy and tasty fond memories of this place
author: John F.

description:
I like how this place is conveniently located by Union Square and is a reasonable option for some decent ramen. I've always gotten their katanaya ramen (12.95) that comes with pork, an egg, bamboo shoots, seaweed, and chicken. It's a little too salty for my liking, but add some spice and cold weather, I wouldn't mind it. It's great they also open super late!

The restaurant itself is VERY small and squished. I've usually came here when the wait was about 10-20 minutes. My first time here I sat by the door and it got a little uncomfortable, so the times after I always preferred sitting towards the sushi bar and by the bathrooms. 

They offer other Japanese food such as sushi, nigiri, and donburi. Good to know they have other options for those who aren't craving ramen.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Last night on 2/3/2016, I decided to have a Luncher here at this place called, "Katana-Ya." With over 3500 Yelp reviews and counting, this local Japanese restaurant has it all delivering the guests with the finest Ramen noodles, sushis, BBQ, and more! As I entered their doors, the atmosphere is quite laid back inside. The concept is much wooden Japanese made inside this small rectangular room.

The employees here are doing a fine job here for making the customers like me an enjoyable service. One of the issues here is this place needs more improvement for more customer service to make it more appealing without letting it over and let it go. I'm sure it needs it in the near future. So far, no cons at all.

Now onto the food! I ordered the Ramen noodle with a choice of soup base: miso, soy, or spicy which I chose the miso, plus two strips of BBQ pork, and an optional choice of add ons which I added a hard-boiled egg for an extra protein punch. As I ate it, it tasted very good! The broth of that miso is on point, and delicious which I can feel the flavors of added sesame oil. The BBQ pork strips and a hard-boiled egg also tasted fantastic too especially the boiled/cooked Ramen. Simply an irresistible meal!

Parking at Katana-Ya can be difficult to park. You can park it at the nearest surface metered street parking nor the parking garage. Otherwise, you can ride a bike, walk, or use public transportation easier without the hassles.

After all, Katana-Ya is a fine, yet remarkable Japanese restaurant that I've ever tasted right at the Union Square neighborhood in San Francisco. Perfect for friends/family gatherings. A well, worthy visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
I actually really enjoyed my experience at Katana-Ya. This restaurant is definitely one of the better ramen places I have gone to. The venue here is pretty small but it's quite cozy and clean. The service here was pretty fast and they fill up your water, which I find most ramen places rarely do unless you ask.

I ordered the Soy Ramen with extra corn and my friend ordered the Miso Katana-Ya ramen. I like how the menu allows you to have 3 broth options for every type of ramen. I do wish they included an egg in every ramen dish like others do. I liked the Soy broth better than the Miso since the Miso seemed a bit too salty. The broth here is definitely more oily than some ramen places. I also really liked the noodles here and they were the perfect amount of chewy. If I'm ever in the area and am craving ramen, I would definitely come back!
author: Catherine S.

description:
Surprised at the low average rating! I guess there's so many great options in SF, but I really enjoyed this place. It's a lot bigger than it first appears (it's pretty hard to find, very small sign and it's underground), and can get pretty loud at night. If you're looking for an intimate dinner, this might not be the right place to go. Great for happy hour or a group dinner though!

I tried multiple sushi rolls and got their Japanese curry, which was pretty good! I don't think it was anything SUPER special, but I really enjoyed my sushi - I forgot the exact roll, but it was some sort of salmon/lemon one! It was FANTASTIC. My friend and I shared the karaage appetizer, which was a surprisingly large amount of chicken and also pretty delicious. I would say that their expansive menu was really impressive, too - it seemed like they had almost every Japanese dish I'd ever seen before!

I would give this place a shot despite its low reviews - it's a tad bit pricey but what Japanese restaurant in heart of SF is not...? The ambience/decor is great for a night out, and the service was decent for how crowded it was.
author: Steven L.

description:
Used to be awesome but now overpriced and bad. Sadly another SF institution has turned to crappy food and higher prices to capitalize on the tourist crowds. I have been here twice since the new owners took over; fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me. I just ordered tenpura donburi and got a bowl of white rice, 1 shrimp and a variety of veggies covered in, wait for it, sweet teriyaki sauce. It's not that I expected the best thing evar, but, by definition, this is completely wrong. I also ordered the small which cost $10.95. The gyoza is made with thick, gummy, chinese dumpling skins and barely qualifies as gyoza. You also get four of them, no Japanese person serves a bad-luck four pieces of anything. 

*sigh. Cross this long beloved spot off the list.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
This place is not bad, but not good. The ramen is so  so. 

Wet the Bed by Chris Brown was playing pretty loud. Like the song, just not when I'm eating lunch with my dad. Whoever had the aux cord was setting a weird vibe.
author: Taylor S.

description:
I came across this ramen shop during my trip here after I saw how long the line for Mensho Tokyo was.  I saw the Yelp food safety score and although I almost hesitated to go in, I really wanted ramen wasn't willing to walk an further so why not give this place a try.  Service was prompt and we were immediately seated.  All I wanted was a nice bowl of ramen so after quickly glancing at their menu, we decided to order their big bowl of Katana-Ya Ramen as it was a popular choice.  After waiting a bit, the server brought out two large bowls of ramen and we immediately dug in.

The ramen for the most part was decent, it didn't taste like authentic to me, and I could taste the difference in quality compared to the other ramen I've had before.  Although it was a big bowl and definitely did the job of satisfying my ramen craving, something was missing.  Maybe it was broth, or the toppings in the bowl, which included fried dumplings for some reason; but it just didn't feel like real ramen to me.  The dumplings tasted like they were thawed from a freezer and the broth just didn't taste right to me.  Not only that but for the price I paid for the Katana-Ya Ramen ($13-14), I was expecting a lot more, but I was ultimately disapointed in this big bowl of ramen.

Would I come back here again? Probably not, but for anyone that is desperate for ramen and unwilling to wait the long lines, then this place is okay; don't get the Katana-Ya Ramen and maybe try something else on the menu.
author: David L.

description:
I went into Katana-Ya ramen with zero expectations since it was a on-the-drive-quick-pick-a-place kinda moment. Since it wasn't exactly safe to stop and find somewhere to eat,  we ended up at Katana-Ya ramen because it popped up in my search results. 

Thankfully I had a seemingly more pleasant experience than fellow yelpers...  I don't hesitate to bump up a 3.5 rating to a 4 due to the short wait time and flavorful broth. 

Perhaps my lowered standards are due to the fact that there aren't that many great ramen places in the east bay area for me to indulge in.. I found the broth to be really flavorful with lots of flavor without being too salty. With the Katana-Ya ramen I ordered, it came with a couple of gyoza, karaage, and half of a perfectly soft boiled egg included in the ramen. For added spiciness,  you have to pay an additional charge though.

Arriving around 3pm on Saturday, there was no wait and we were seated immediately at a cramp table by the door, but we were able to put in our orders quickly and the ramen came out in a timely manner as well. The only thing that was negative was the fact that their chashu was EXTREMELY dry... So dry that I didn't even want to bother trying to chew on them. Luckily, the chicken karaage soaking in broth was enough to satisfy my meaty cravings. 

Although Katana-Ya ramen was on the pricier side,  the portion was fair for the price and the location of the restaurant makes it easy to walk over to a bar nearby with no hassle for after dinner drinks!
author: Evelynn C.

description: Pretty good but definitely not the best ramen ever. Good broth flavor and light on the meat inside the soup. The tempura shrimp and vegetables was all vegetables, mostly zucchini and 2 shrimp. Very greasy and wound up not eating most of it. Overpriced (But then, all of SF is)
author: Jenn K.

description: My favorite ramen place in the city! I always get the Katana-Ya spicy miso ramen. It is delicious! The staff are quick and friendly. The ambiance of the restaurant makes It feel like you're eating a secret underground ramen restaurant. I love taking friends who are visiting SF here.
author: Gabi T.

description:
A small street door leads you downstairs to an underground restaurant filled with red and orange hughes while long mirrors give a night life vibe to this cool restaurant. 

A friend suggested I try this place if I was craving ramen. It was very quick service and for my first time here I enjoyed the Katanaya Spicy Miso Ramen with the chicken on the side. The broth is what sold me though I'm  obsessed and finished almost the whole bowl which is rare for me!
author: Sarah S.

description:
I thought the food was just ok here.  Nothing that was amazing but it wasn't terrible either.  I was staying down the street from there and decided to check it out since there were so many reviews and I wanted some ramen.

I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen and also got the Crispy Spicy Tuna.  For me, I was caught off guard what the crispy spicy tuna actually was.  I was expecting something like the crispy rice with spicy tuna on top, but what actually arrived was salad with a fried spicy tuna roll on top.  It was pretty good, but it wasn't what I had imagined.  They need some descriptions on their menu.

I'm not sure if it was because I was one of the earlier tables there, they open at 1130 they did let me go in a little earlier to sit down but they did warn me about their start time.  That was appreciated.  I did order around 1130 as promised but then it took a while for me to get my ramen.  I got my crispy spicy tuna salad about 15 minutes later and then my ramen finally arrived in another 10 minutes after that.  It seemed like the other tables got their food soon too so I'm assuming was the kitchen was up and running they were able to crank out their food.
author: Jeff L.

description: Hole in the wall ramen shop with subpar service. Not the ideal place if you have a large party. Ramen was good and loaded with protein so, very filing and for a great price.
author: Pam T.

description:
I went to KatanaYa at 2 p.m. with 3 other friends and actually got inside at 3. 
The worst thing is waiting. The place is so small.
The waitress is not too friendly if you're sharing food since the ramen is so big and I just ate sushi before I came here.

But most of all, I still give this place 5 stars.
Why?
My hunger is satisfied with their delicious ramen!!
I got the Fried chicken ramen with miso.
author: Candice L.

description:
I was so excited to come to this place since I was craving pork belly and takoyaki (My two loves in this world! HA HA I'm going to serve those two things at my wedding!). I met up with my best friend for dinner and I was such a cheerleader for this place saying that it had so many reviews on yelp blah blah blah...

We came last night for dinner around 5:45ish there was no wait at all, several empty tables and we were seated right away(Awesome!). By the time we left there was a line going up the stairs! I ordered the takoyaki $8.95 of course and the pork belly appetizer $9.95... first of all, that's the most expensive takoyaki I've ever paid for.... Y'all who follow me know that I'm obsessed with takoyaki. Most places that I go to from San Diego all the way up to North Bay are priced around $4.50-$6ish. Damn Katana-Ya! Way to over-price! It comes out to over $1 per tiny ball! The takoyaki tasted just okay though, not the best I've had. The pork belly was served in a bowl and I was surprised that they give you so many pieces! I thought it would just be one big slab but it actually reminds me of Filipino Chicharon (pork rinds) except this isn't cripsy or fried.. I think it's braised actually... The pork belly was not good, damn did it lack flavor or what? It could use a sweet and sour glaze (similar to that of Carnitas Snack Shack in San Diego). I'm not sure what I was tasting but I think it tasted somewhat fruity? TF? Kinda tasted like eating person. Service was okay. Not super attentive but they get the job done.

Pro: They had really good Christmas music playing LOL good to listen to while eating dinner!

Makes me wonder why they had so many reviews.... Probably a better idea to go to Japantown for Japanese Food.
author: Ramona G.

description: Very tasty ramen. We ordered Katanaya Ramen in miso broth, which had BBQ pork, fried chicken, gyoza, egg, scallion and seaweed. Spicy and flavorful. My husband got his extra spicy and it had a serious kick. We got there at around 6:30 pm and waited a little less than half an hour. Service was ok.
author: Laura S.

description: Taste not bad, but soooo expensive!! There is no net work inside at all. Be ready have a meal without phone
author: Tina Z.

description:
I'm from LA so this was my first time ever going to a restaurant where you had to walk down a set of stairs to get to the tables. I thought that was pretty cool lol

Bf and I went around 9pm on a Saturday night and it was a bit busy but we only had to wait about 10 mins before they sat us down. The hostess came off as a little strange because she kind of just had a blank face and was very monotone. Our waiter was kind of the same way but she did check up on us a few times so  she was at least attentive.

The bowl of ramen was pretty big. The broth was savory and they gave a generous amount of noodles, which was nice. Halfway through the bowl I was super full and it hardly looked like I had made a dent. 

I give 4 stars only because I wanted dumplings in my ramen and they were out. I wanted a Coke and they were also out of that.
author: Jazmin M.

description:
Expensive foe what it is, but still good. I would go with a 3.5 but will allow a 4 star since I ant rate .5 and there was nothing really wrong with our meal.
We got a bbq pork ramen, it tasted good but the pork was really hard, not worth the extra $.
Also got a donburi (rice bowl) with bbq pork and for some reason that bbq pork was slightly better (average good) and the rice tasted very good with the sauce. Rice bowls come with a miso soup and that was very tasty too.
Service is normal, correct, nothing special to write down.
The place was full with a small wait list, it took a while to sit us down after the bar was cleared up, but it was within normal limits. 
I think this place is rather a ramen place you go with friends because the place looks better and more spacious than most ramen places, food is Ok but prices are high.
author: Mimi Y.

description: Don't ever come here. They for sure are only open because it is in a tourist trap. I got the pork bellow rice bowl and it was entirely unseasoned. The pork belly had the skin on but it wasn't crispy.
author: Eric S.

description:
We arrived at opening on a rainy day and made our way down the stairs and seated ourselves.  The place fills up quick!

Service was not really there and kind of annoying how you had to fight to flag your server down to get water, check, etc.

Ramen is EXPENSIVE and mediocre at best.  The pork was not tender.  Egg was overcooked. Broth was salty.

Overall, not a repeat place even if it was the only ramen joint open.
author: Amy T.

description:
After a late ball game, we were on a mission for Ramen...at least my buddies were. We ended up here as they were open late and still serving...we actually had to wait until a table opened up.

My friends got Ramen, but I opted for the BBQ Pork Don. The server initially brought the wrong Ramen soups as it was obvious certain items were missing from the broth. Turned out the waiter wrote down the wrong item. My BBQ Pork Don was pretty good. They only serve Sapporo beer here...so keep that in mind if you're thinking about enjoying a different brand of beer.

Next time I'm in the area (and searching specifically for Ramen), I'll probably search for another Ramen house first. But if nothing is close or open, I'd come here again.
author: Terry K.

description: My girlfriend and I were in town photo-shooting and walked around to find a good food place something "light". Went to this place and ordered something enormous and delicious ! She loved the potstickers in the ramen and her miso soup. Delicious food and good vibes!
author: Roberto M.

description:
Got here around 12:30pm-1pm with a total party of 5 and had to wait around 40 minutes, if not more to get in. We didn't get to sit with each other either but I wasn't too bothered about that (3 at the bar; 2 at a table). The shop is so tiny but the portions are huge. 
I went with the vegetable ramen because I'm just about that green life and I was pretty satisfied. I've had better miso broth but I really like this place because the portions are huge. Maybe a bit too large, but it's definitely worth the money you're shedding out. COME HUNGRY! 

I probably wouldn't come back because of the wait + the decent broth, but it's worth a try. I've heard that I made a relatively poor choice for my first bowl but I can't help it! I like the greens rather than the fatty pork okay!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
This place has mediocre ramen. The serving size is large but that's all it has going for it. Broth is lacking in depth and flavor -  choices are miso, shoyu and salt. The last one shouldn't be a flavor, yet my spicy miso tasted like salt anyway? 

Broth: if the spicy options automatically makes a ramen superior, it's just masking the true flavor. It can't be handmade broth, very one note and salty.  

Toppings: lacking. 1/3 of the ramen experience (noodles, broth and topping), yet most menu items only come with two toppings. You have to order everything else extra. Why is corn A WHOLE FREAKING $2 EXTRA??? A holes. I'll just bring my own 89 cent can if someone makes me go back to this place. 

Noodles: at this point, I don't even care. They were fine. 

Two bros sitting next to me kept exclaiming how amazing the ramen was. SO EFFING MEDIOCRE. Shin black ramen from the package is better than this. 

THE PRICE IS ON PAR WITH THE AMAZING RAMEN WE HAVE IN SEATTLE. It's a rip off. Don't go here. Just rethinking about this ramen made me more mad as I type my review.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Ramen here tastes good but for some reason I find that Ramen taste warm not hot.

As a Ramen lover, I like when Ramen taste hot to eat-!
author: Jang R.

description:
Ramen became my usual meal so I always check ramen places close by or even if it takes some time to get to. I wanted a hot ramen cause San Francisco  summer is not summer at all... it's freezing! (67F in August ). Fortunately we found the hidden spot - Katana-Ya. 
There was a small wait which was about ten minutes but by the time we got seated there was crowd waiting to get into. 
Yes, I put my name on the waiting list as the sign says and I saw people who came inside passing the line behind and they were ignored by the employees...which is totally ok because The Huge Sign is there and you have to respect the rules of the place. 
Yes, service was friendly and helpful, answered all my questions. 
Pitcher of Sapporo was dropped in 1 minute. 
Food came in...6-7 minutes. It was good. Miso veggie and veggie tempura don were enough for 2 people to share. Ramen bowl is huge. 
The place is tiny. You can hear new music inside. 
So I say "Yes", you'd better come and just try it with your buddies!
author: Roman S.

description: It's just not very good.  It's baffling how this place got so many reviews and remains one of SF's most popular places.  Our server looked totally disinterested.  The ramen was not even lukewarm and the sushi was food court quality.  It's gone further downhill from my last visit 6 years ago.
author: Angel S.

description: Went in by myself today at 2:00PM. It had been years since I had been here last when it was upstairs. There were 2 young wait staff that looked genuinely disappointed that I had chosen to come in. However, they were  efficient and my spicy miso ramen with tofu promptly arrived piping hot. The broth was pretty tasty, other ingredients had been cooking for quite a while, including the noodles. The wait staff was completely disengaged. A previous reviewer reported a strange unpleasant smell and I picked it up as well. Keep tabs on the latest reviews. The place has changed.
author: W. Harry K.

description:
Came here for dinner on our last night in Sf. The restaurant is TINY. We were squished in our table. I had to put our extra bowls next to me on the booth. That's how small the table was.

The food was pretty good. We ordered agedashi tofu as appetizer and the combo of katana ramen and the poke don to share between my boyfriend and I. The katana ramen was huge. It had egg, corn, green onion, 2 pieces of fried gyoza, 2 pieces of friend chicken, chasu, bamboo, and seaweed. Not sure if I'm missing anything. It was pretty good, but not the best I've had. I really enjoyed the poke don. Wasn't really feeling the agedashi tofu though.

Service here was meh. They weren't very attentive. We literally had to go up to them to ask for our waters.
author: Mary X.

description:
I can only speak for the Katana-ya ramen with miso soup base. 

OVERALL IMPRESSION
They have karaage (fried chicken) and fried gyoza in it, which is what makes it really different. I actually enjoyed the ramen because of that unique spin. 

BROTH
The broth is way too salty though, and it doesn't have any other kind of flavor except excess sodium. It didn't feel like a rich flavor. 

MEAT
The meat in the ramen also wasn't particularly good. The pork was not fresh and it wasn't fatty enough.


Would I come back? Maybe, but definitely not at the top of my list. There are better ramen places to go to, but if you want ramen with fried chicken and gyoza in it, then you should come try it!
author: Alicia L.

description:
I'm being generous... Probably more like a 2.5 star spot. I came for lunch with a coworker, we usually go to Ramen Underground on Kearny, but worried we wouldn't have time to wait, we decided to try Katana-Ya. It's overpriced.. but that's to be expected in downtown SF. They don't have tonkatsu broth.. which is my personal favorite. You can only choose between miso, soy, and salt broth.
I got the kakuni ramen, it starts at $16 just for the broth, noodles, two pieces of pork belly and some green onion. Where's my egg? I usually like to add extras like corn, egg, bamboo shoots, and make it extra spicy... but the add on prices were ridiculous.. $2 for corn? $2 for seaweed? $1.50 to make it spicy? $1 for an egg (actually that's a pretty good price), but then I'd have a $25 ramen..  Discouraged, I didn't get any add-ons. 
The broth was okay.. I added a bunch of cayenne pepper and a little soy sauce to give it a little more oompf. The noodles were very nice.. great texture. The pork belly was extremely disappointing.. no flavor whatsoever. 
I'm sad now that we just didn't try to go to Ramen Underground, while that's not my favorite ramen spot, it's still 300x better than this place. 

1.5 stars for nice noodles
1 star for being seated right away and food coming out fast
author: Nicole R.

description:
Conveniently located near our hotel and the Powell Bart Station, the bf and I came here for dinner before taking the Bart to SFO. We came around 5:30pm on a Sunday. With about 4 parties ahead of us, we were quickly seated within 15 minutes. The restaurant is pretty small and has table as well as bar seating. The dim lighting makes for a very cozy atmosphere.

We ordered the Kakuni (Pork Belly) Miso Ramen combo with Kimchi Fried Rice (+$5) and an order of Gyoza. Our server was really attentive and friendly, and our food efficiently arrived after our order was placed. 

Besides the 4 pieces/order Gyoza, the ramen and fried rice were both generously portioned. The Kakuni Ramen came with fatty chunks of pork belly, seaweed, and a good amount of green onions. The broth was flavorful, however, a bit oily for our taste and not too miso-y. The Gyoza was decent but also on the oily side. Highlight of the meal was no doubt the Kimchi Fried Rice! Flavors were great, and the rice grains were perfectly separated. 

Overall, solid option for Japanese food in the area. Note that the line/wait got really long after we left during the dinner rush hour, so plan accordingly!
author: Eva I.

description: Love love love Katana-Ya! Eat here every single time I'm in SF sometimes more than three times! Never disappointed!
author: Jacque Y.

description: The pick up process is the worst I've ever seen in a restaurant. They do not take phone orders and you need to use the Eat24 portal which does not list items they are out of. Also, I called ahead and if they listened to what I requested, I would have been notified that they were out of my first request. Instead I had to go digging through trying to find any pieces of beef in my beef curry don.
author: Lisa X.

description:
One of my daughters was craving ramen.  Who am I to say no to ramen!  We looked and saw Kayana-Ya.  While I usually only try places with at least 4-stars, we went in anyway, because there wasn't much ramen in the Union Square area.

First off, the place is small.  But, not only that, the tables were small.  When they say table of 4, it's actually more of a table of 2, but 4 chairs around it.  We ordered our ramen.  Since the consensus seems to be to order their Katanaya Ramen, we ordered 3 of them.  I got mine made spicy.  We also ordered a BBQ Pork Donburi bowl for my youngest daughter.  

The broth in the ramen is just ok.  It didn't seem to have the complexity of other salt broths that I've had.  Nothing stood out in the noodles, as well.  However, what WAS different were the toppings.  Yes, they had seaweed and corn and pork, which are standard fare.  However, in this one, they also had fried gyoza and fried chicken karaage INSIDE the ramen bowl!  While both tasted good, it would've been better served to be on just the side.  The Donburi bowl was actually really good, which is why I decided to bump this up to 3 stars.

Service was ok, but I had to go up and get my check while other tables got theirs.
author: Jamie J.

description: I ordered their Spicy Tofu Ramen. The noodles itself were a great texture, until I noticed that the noodles were clumped together in some areas. The broth of the soup was so salty that I had to ask for a bowl of hot water to drown out the salt. The Kimchee was good and so was their tofu. We also ordered their gyoza appetizer. It comes with 6. This has been The far worst gyoza I have ever had. The skin was soggy and when you bit into it, a gush of water burst out. The meat was completely water logged and lacked flavor. The staff was friendly and the ambiance was cool but I will not be back.
author: Cynthia W.

description: Great place for a bowl of ramen and some sushi! We had katanaya ramen with spicy miso so good and sunset sushi is delicious
author: Suzane S.

description: Loved the veggie ramen - huge bowl of warm hearty noodles with a generous serving of veggies!  We were downstairs and I think they have recently added this area for more seating.  Would love for more lighting!  Also would love it if the bathrooms were cleaned more frequently as it was quite wet when we were there.  Great noodles at a reasonable price in a convenient location in Union Square, thank you!
author: Carolyn L.

description: I have been eating ramen in US and in Japan, this one is NOT an authentic ramen noodles. Very Americanized version. Broth is full of msg and minimum ingredients come with it.
author: Brownie S.

description:
I was craving some good Japanese comfort food one night, and we found this place. We had somewhat a high expectation...

The exterior didn't look like much. The inside was not too big, it felt very cramped. It had lots of interesting huge light fixtures of many colors hanging, creating this strange, purple - red hue inside the restaurant. Looked a bit old, not super clean, but then again, it was rather dark with weird colored lights.

We got seated quickly, and we decided on what we wanted. Easy enough. However, getting a server's attention was not easy. After a little while, we finally caught a server and made our orders. When the food arrived, the strange purple lighting made the food look weird... The food was all ok, nothing special. 

The worst thing about this restaurant was the service. I am not sure if they care about their customer, they really are not attentive, helpful, or polite. We couldn't get anyone to refill our water. We had to wait forever for someone to take our order and to bring us our check. The way they treated us was almost rude. They were more interesting in chatting with each other than attending to customers.
author: June S.

description: Overpriced ramen and the worse part was it didn't even taste good :( noodles were over cooked, gyoza (asked for on the side) didn't taste fresh, took one bite and that was it. The fried chicken was okay.
author: Nana S.

description: Loved the downstairs, no window, smaller setting. Had good relevant music playing. Everything tasted great! Will definitely come back next time I am in the city.
author: Cody E.

description: Good ramen but they didn't have beef ramen, super, super bad service,  they did not ask me what I wanted to drink, they forgot my table, rude waiters with customers, it is the worst service experience I have had, i am giving it one star for the service no the food.
author: Wonka M.

description:
I went with my best friend for lunch and I didn't knew that it was really close by Market street . The restaurant is downstairs in the basement and it looks really dark inside . Once you sit there for few minutes , you don't feel dark . 

I order the vegetables ramen with spicy tuna roll ( it 's the combination ) . The ramen is a lot and they don't go cheap on the spicy tuna roll. The tuna was spicy and it was good . I couldn't finish my portion and I love it .  

I will come back to have lunch next time . I probably will skip the combination because ramen is already enough for me .
author: Isabelle L.

description:
I had the shio ramen and the broth was good, not great.  Portion is huge and the ramen was al dente, but I hated the fact that kimchi topping was $3.  Highway robbery for a Korean to pay that much for a few bites of kimchi.  But being Korean, I had to have my kimchi =)

They have spicy levels and the guy next to me had a bowl that was bright red...  He was sweating but swore it was delicious.

Located a few blocks from Union Square, it's worth a visit if you need a warm bowl of noodles!
author: Seung Eun C.

description: Terrible tasting vegetarian ramen. The service was non existent and we constantly had to ask the waitress for things because she didn't check on us for anything. We had to ask for sauce, we had to tell her we were ready to order, and we had to ask for our bill. In addition they forgot to add tofu in my ramen.
author: Monica E.

description:
For my first Ramen experience, I can definitely say I enjoyed it. I got the Katanaya Ramen (spicy) and it was the perfect amount of spice for me with all of the delicious ingredients. Definitely a lot of food and while I ate all of the filler, I couldn't finish the broth. Could've probably asked for more noodles based on the amount of broth I had left. 

Interior is small and cute. Loved the intimate feel of the place. 

All in all, great ramen experience and I'd definitely be interested in going back!
author: Jimmy L.

description: Ever since Sapporo Ya closed in Japan town I had been in search of a replacement ramen spot. Katana-Ya has satisfied my cravings and is definitely my new favorite spot! On weekends and especially evenings, they can get pretty busy and you'll have to wait a while to be seated. But, they are open late and this makes it easy to come by nearly any time! Their ramen is delicious af and I have never been able to finish a bowl. Their signature Katana-Ya ramen is a must. They have kind and attentive servers who check in and are not pushy even when they are busy. The restaurant is tucked down below street level making it fun to get to and cozy inside. I've been here a handful of times in the last year and have been meaning to leave a review but to all my friends and folks I reccomend Katana-Ya first!
author: Kiva M.

description:
I chose this restaurant to catch up with some friends due to its proximity to BART and union square. Of course, it likely was a tourist trap, though I thought I would give it a try. I entered the restaurant at street level and walked down a set of stairs. The restaurant was dark, though spacious and decorated. There was no wait at 4 PM on a Saturday, though when we were leaving, there was definitely a small crowd waiting.

I got the Miso Ramen, which came hot and quickly. Though that was probably the only plus and the ramen was disappointing from then on. The first thing I noticed was how the bowl was drowned in soup and had almost no visual aesthetic. The soup was simply not memorable. If anything it reminded me of a slightly better instant noodle soup. The noodles themselves were a little bit too chewy and tasteless. The worse part was the meat--extremely salty and sort of just fell apart in my mouth. Finally, the portion size was small and I was barely satisfied.

Overall: This place is definitely a tourist trap, located about 1 block from union square. There are definitely better ramen places not too far away if you're at all familiar with the city.
author: Vivian L.

description: Had the spicy miso ramen.  Good run of the mill ramen. A bit salty and greasy for my taste, but it did the job. There's a lot of room for improvement in cleanliness, service, and ambience, however.
author: Michelle S.

description: Not impressed. Only if you're desperate for ramen. And I am, which is why I'm here -- and at Geary and Taylor at all, for that matter.
author: Bowen D.

description: The place is super small so expect long wait.  The food is good not great.  The spicy is spicy which I love.  The ramen is chewy.  The server deliver whatever we ask.  Price is on the higher end but the portion is huge.
author: Thuy H.

description: Fast food. Not my favorite. Has a supermarket ramen character. We had normal ramen and vegetable ramen soy basis and miso Basis both below average
author: Why-Tie Z.

description: At first I judged this place by the way it looks from the outside. Decided to take a chance and eat here anyways and was blown away. Definitely will be coming back.
author: Thomas T.

description: Basic ramen with miso was delicious but I don't really like the restaurant inside. It looks like a bar.
author: Alex I.

description:
This place used to be good. People would line up outside in the chilly night waiting to eat here. I used to come here when I crave a good ramen. But man, I don't know what happened to it, my recent visit was very disappointing.

I ordered the basic ramen in soy flavor. It comes with 2 thin slices of dried bbq pork, green onions and seaweed. I had to pay extra for the half boiled eggs, which were mediocre and bland. Broth was so salty that our group had to get water refills multiple times. Edamame beans were overcooked or frozen with a mushy texture.

Totally not worth it for the price. Don't come here, it's probably became a tourist trap like other reviewers said.
author: YY M.

description:
Although not the best ramen in SF, Katana-Ya has two great things going for it, proximity to Union Square and open late. 

So after a night of debauchery in SF, you can stumble your way over to Katana-Ya for a heavy, carb-laden meal to cap off your night. 

// FOOD //
     + Miso ramen: Very generous portion with tender pork and very fatty broth.
author: Pauline P.

description: We'd heard a lot about this place but very disappointing, way too much broth and not very flavorful
author: Pratika M.

description:
Pros:
- We came at 5pm today, no wait. Hallelujurrrrr
- Broth for the spicy miso katanaya ramen wasn't too salty. Big plus! 
- Ramen portions are HUGE, shareable. But I ate the whole thing to myself anyways lol 

Cons:
- noodles were ok. I've had better. 
- To add "spicy" to the broth was .75 but it wasn't even spicy. Yes there is an "extra spicy" option but I feel like I shouldn't have to get "extra" spicy for it to be spicy lol And why should I pay more for it to be spicy? Are you really gonna charge me for pepper flakes? -_-
- They forgot one of my friend's orders. They did not acknowledge their mistake, no apology, no anything. 
- Some of the waitstaff seemed like they really hated their jobs :/
author: Jessica C.

description: Great place for some spicy hot ramen on a cold day. They have good selection on sake as well. Come hang out with a friend for some ramen.
author: Aditya C.

description:
The service was great. I only
Tried it here because recommended to me as one of my customer. I tried it for the first time and man i sure love the taste of the ramen. The meat was so tender. The boiled egg and everything just compliments one another. For people who loves ramen, this is the spot to go in downtown san francisco. Its a bit of a high price but its worth every bit of it
author: Eric S.

description: Great Ramen place but the quality varies too much every time I come here. The first time I came here was after a one hour wait and after sitting down the delicious Ramen and sushi they serve was well worth of the wait. How ever I've been back about three times since then and every time I come my ramen is either too salty, served lukewarm, or just tastes watered downed. I liked this place a lot from my first experience but it's not some place I'm willing to give another shot.
author: John V.

description: This place is good for a late meal, if you need it.  But if I had another option I'd go to the other option.  The roll I got, the tuna look too messed with.  Nothing memorable about the roll we got.  The vegetable tempura was nice. The miso soup, good. We also got the kimchi fried rice.  It's was decent enough.  I'd order it again.
author: Septima M.

description: Everyone had bad stomach ache after eating the ramen. We all rushed back 2 blocks to Hilton in Union Square to take a dump. Hope you guys reading this enjoys a good laugh.
author: ZhiCheng Z.

description:
Ramen joint that seems inordinately popular relative to its actual quality, likely because of its prime Union Square location near lots of theatres, shops, hotels, and other touristy attractions. While the meat in the karaage was pretty tasty, the whole equation soon turned into a mushy mess as it drowned in a sea of rather thick, salty, oily soup and noodles. Probably would have been better to order the karaage as an appetizer or part of a rice dish. 

Even if there's a wait, it's usually a quick in-and-out experience like you would expect of a street establishment in Japan - just minus the overall quality.
author: Vincent L.

description: This is the worst ramen place I have ever been to in the Bay Area. I got the spicy miso ramen. Didn't like the noodles at all. They weren't the traditional ramen. They were like thin flat noodles. I hated the noodles which ruined the whole bowl of ramen. The pork was relatively tougher than what I had had at other ramen places. The broth was just okay. I wouldn't recommend this place and wouldn't come back ever again.
author: Emily M.

description: Came here after going to Jones. I ordered the ramen miso broth. Price was about $12. I don't like paying extra for spice. They got our order messed up. Quality wise it's just ok. I give it three stars because they are open past midnight. Call me a homer but I think LA ramen is better to be honest.
author: Marco S.

description:
It's a struggle looking for good late night food sometimes. Lucky for me , my cousin recommended this place. Hehe

We ordered  : 
2 bowls of Spicy Katanaya Miso Ramen 
1 order of Hotate (Scallop) Nigiri 
& 1 Spider Roll 

We got there around 11 pm and they ran out of spicy beef ramen , so we ordered 2 Katanaya ramen.
The soup base was delicious, it was super addicting. I loved the fried chicken and the gyoza that was included, both were flavorful but not soggy at all. Even though, they were sitting in the soup. The outer layer of the gyoza was super unique and different from other ramen places. I would recommend adding a side of gyozas(2pc) for $3 (:   The ramen also includes half egg, 2 pork slice, corn seaweed and g onions. Corn was sweet, seaweed was tasty. Ahh, everything was good about this ramen, it's also the restaurant name haha

The scallop nigiri was super fresh, the sashimi pieces were big , the scallop melts in your mouth. I usually don't like wasabi , but the perfect amount of wasabi was put on the rice . Loved it.

The spider roll had 4 large pieces, there was tobiko on the rice . The deep fried soft shell crab was super crispy with a little bit of unagi sauce on it. A decent roll ! 

My cousin thinks the rice is #1 important in sushi , the rice here is approved by my picky cousin :) 

Overall , our check was about $70 , a little pricey but considering location and taste , it was well worth it.
author: Tiffany F.

description:
The ramen here isn't bad, but the store front is pretty small so you might have to wait if your party is big or you happen to come in when everyone just sat down. I came in the early evening and ordered the katanaya ramen which comes with karaage and gyoza, except these were already in the soup when my ramen came... I'm not a big fan of my fried foods soggy, so rescue them from the soup quickly if you still want to eat them while they are crispy. The portion size is appropriate for the price, but the noodles themselves could be a bit more al dente (they were a bit too soft). It's also super dark in here, which might be enjoyable for some, but I prefer being able to see my food.

Overall, it's located conveniently near Union Square and worth a try if you're craving ramen, but it's not the best I've had.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Decided to have some ramen before leaving SF. My girlfriends and I were excited to try this place but was set up for disappointment. Quality of the food was poor. Not only was there a long wait but service also sucked. 

I got the ramen with soy broth, and boy did it lack flavor... it just tasted like hot water and noodles. Decided to try my friend's miso ramen and that was just as bad. Everything in their dish is just missing flavor, no effort put into the food whatsoever. Instant ramen tastes better than this. 

To top it off their service did not make it any better. You have two girls with bad attitudes running the place. Never once stopped by to ask how we were doing. Every time we wanted something we would have to flag them down and wait a lifetime. 

I was so unsatisfied at the end of my meal I seriously considered getting Jack In the Box afterwards (it's next door). I'm sorry but please get it together.
author: Sophia L.

description: Good ramen, went at 5:30pm on a Sunday and there was no line, by the time we were done (at around 6:30pm) there were people waiting on the steps. Reasonably priced and in a convenient area.
author: Patricia P.

description: Use to love this place but it has gone way downhill.  The ramen ingredients used to be much fresher, but the last two times I went, the egg wasn't cooked right, the meats were cold or soggy (the fried chicken they put in was nasty!).   Would no longer recommend.
author: Willy K.

description:
We came here at around 9pm on a Friday and had to wait around 30 minutes to be seated. The place isn't too big and doesn't have too many seats so a wait is inevitable. We got seated at the bar because that was the first available-- *I highly do NOT recommend sitting at the bar. The stools are too low for the bar counter so it's very uncomfortable to eat while sitting down.*

We each got the pork belly ramen and the takoyaki to share. The portion size of the pork belly ramen is VERY BIG, but it's perfect for one person to be full (so come hungry with an empty stomach!). The broth was very rich in taste, the noodles were just the right amount of chewy, and the pork belly was good. The takoyaki was also good, would recommend this as an appetizer.

Although the wait was long, the food made it worth the wait. If you're looking to eat ramen or comfort food, I highly recommend Katana-Ya. The price is definitely on the expensive side, but you really do get what you pay for (the portion size is HUGE). Also, great service!

Personal tip: If you're hesitant about waiting in line at ramen places, just think, do you really trust a ramen place with no line???
author: Jen S.

description: Pretty good ramen and donburi spot.  Wife had the miso vegetable ramen and I had the special buta kakuni donburi.  Pretty big portions on both dishes.  This place is worth a try.
author: Alan I.

description:
I don't know if SF has the plethora of ramen places like Downtown LA, but this place doesn't quite measure up to what I'd expect.

This place has a real underground Japanese joint type of feel, and I really did feel like I was back in Tokyo. It's a pretty small place, dark and intimate. I enjoyed the atmosphere.

So the ramen was nothing outstanding. At paying around $17, I ended up getting ramen and a spicy tuna roll as a combo. Pretty pricey, and individual ramen was already $12 and up/. I don't think I've ever really paid more than $12 for ramen unless it was a special or size upgrade. Paying pretty much $20 out the door for a spicy tuna roll and bowl of some decent ramen wasn't worth it IMO.

Maybe I'm spoiled with better ramen back in Los Angeles? But I'd venture off to a different spot..
author: Kevin N.

description: I've gone to Katana-Ya for 8+ years, and it has really gone downhill. It's only a few blocks from my apartment and there are not many other ramen places around so it has been my go-to for many years. Ever since they moved to the downstairs location, I feel like there must have been a change in management or chef. The broth tastes different, ramen noodles are thinner and not the usual al-dente, and service is horrible. I was just there for lunch today and decided that I cannot go back. The ramen broth tasted like they cooked the noodles right in there- it was slimy and tasted sour. Go to mensho down the street, or wait until Ippudo opens!
author: Peggy L.

description:
We went on Monday for Mensho but realized Mensho was closed on Monday so we tried this ramen restaurant instead. 

I tried the Katana-Ya bowl with soy sauce broth and felt very underwhelmed. The broth was meh, and all the meat, gyoza, karage were all meh. 

The server was also pretty unattentive and couldn't understand what Calpico was. I asked her what Japanese soda was in the menu and she had no idea. We also had to wait 30 mins for bad ramen.

It was expensive too. $27.5 per person for bad ramen. Haiz
author: Tung D.

description: Had the Katanaya ramen bowl, edamame, shrimp & veggie tempura - all delicious!
author: Tad R.

description: The room is too dark. The miso soup is good but the noodles portion is too Small! The ramen only has 2 pieces of pork. Only barely half full. PS: I ordered the ordinary ramen, not the combo.
author: Kelvin Y.

description: This place is totally cozy, I love the vibe.  Broth was beautifully made, I had the soy.  One except is the noodle, it's could be better.  Good and cozy, a must go.
author: Quoc N.

description: The best ramen in city. Service was great and the ramen bowls are huge. Highly recommend sharing the spicy tofu and kimchi ramen.
author: Andreea B.

description: Kind of dark, kind of dingy, kind of pricey -- and the ramen is only ok. Regret that I wasted a SF meal here while in town. It's probably awesome when you've had a few too many to drink or can't find other late-night eats.
author: Sarah K.

description:
My last visit was a bit disappointing. The PORK RAMEN came in a big bowl but definitely could have benefited from more broth, which rarely covered the noodles and pork pieces. I liked the noodles but the broth just didn't convince taste- and portion-wise. They also seemed a bit stingy with the green onions. If you want extra onions they'll charge $2.

I've definitely also had better sushi. The SPICY TUNA ROLL tasted alright, so did the WHITE FISH & TUNA ROLL. Solid, but nothing over the top.

Two waiters were serving the small dining area - one friendly, the other one seemed grumpy. Some improvement needed here...
author: Sebastian F.

description: Nice dark intimate setting! Delicious pork belly shoyu ramen! Outstanding noodles and dashi! Perfect spot to warm your soul on a foggy San Francisco day.
author: Koichi S.

description: Had been trying to avoid this place since the reviews are not the best. But this was the only place open late for Ramen. Was it worth it? Debatable. The ramen was okay. Nothing special. I had the spicy ramen. The broth was watery and the noodles weren't as thick as I like them. The customer service leaves much to be desired. I had to keep asking for water because the waiter did not fill it up every. single. time. He did not fill up the glasses. The last time he spilled water all over the table while filling it up and left it there for my sleeves to clean it. He was more interested in socializing with the other waitress instead of doing his job. Not impressed and not interested in coming back.
author: Antonella H.

description: Having had proper authentic ramen in Japan as well as in Europe and North America, I feel Katana-Ya is decent, but not the place to be if you're looking for an authentic ramen experience. The spicy beef ramen (kinda gave it away already) and the monthly special pork belly miso were both tasty, but did not meet the expectations of authentic ramen.
author: Tony D.

description: I have been to this spot twice now and the second time was not that great. Their pork belly seemed liked it could've been slow cooked a while longer. It still had great flavor but on the tough side to eat. The Katana-ya ramen was in point tho. The broth had great flavor and they do not skimp on the portion sizes.
author: Camera P.

description:
This place was phenomenal!  We were wandering the streets of San Francisco hungry as it gets, thinking of settling for just some diner type of place and then as we were walking, we saw Katana-Ya. My buddy looked it up and as he was feeling like ramen, we decided to go there.  

At first, you take the steps down into the restaurant and it's a darker atmosphere. Kind of creepy  We all ordered different ramen bowls.  I ordered the Katanaya bowl with the spicy Option.  It was absolutely incredible.  It has a little bit of everything.  The flavor just completely overwhelms the senses.  Not too spicy to take away from the other flavors but it was just so good.  Highlight of the day, for sure.  Two big thumbs up for these guys.  I absolutely recommend going here.
author: Joshua B.

description: I was so excited to try this restaurant as I am a huge fan of ramen! We went to have a late dinner (around 10pm) and the place was still full. I ordered the Miso Ramen, comes with two slices of pork, noodles and some veggies/seaweed. The broth is really good, although quite different from the Miso I am used to. Noodles we're exactly the way I wanted them to be. Servings here a huge so don't order too much. Place is nice, nothing fancy. Will definitely go back.
author: Karissa A.

description: I've been here quite a few times now. I love the Karaage Ramen! This place is great and not too busy on weeknights, which is surprising.
author: Zachary J.

description:
My issue with the majority of the restaurants near union square is that they just stop trying to keep the food good because they know they have a steady stream of tourists they'll never see as customers again. Believe me I have given this restaurant a chance,  I've been here three times. The flavor is lacking and the ingredients do not seem fresh... 

Get it together for these expensive prices!!!
author: C. L.

description: Expensive but they you definitely get what you pay for. The sushi is extraordinary, shrimp tempura was great. Salmon melts at the bite. Would definitely recommend to a friend.
author: Oscar D.

description:
If you are looking for amazing ramen dishes at affordable prices !! This spot is amazing ... I would recommend the spicy beef ramen  !!

Make a trip and enjoy
author: Michael M.

description:
Expensive but big portions. The most portion of all ramen places I've been to. If you are a person who eats little, make sure to share one bowl, otherwise, you will either take it to go or just waste it. 

Pork belly was good, but other piece was too fatty for my liking.

Good place to go to after some light drinking, before heading home, walking distance from some bars. Also walking distance from the shopping center, union square.
author: Sarah L.
