description: So -so ramen; noodles were nicely chewy but a bit oily with the soy soup. Fried rice combo is not bad... a bit salty tho. Friendly staff & clean decor.
author: Art L.

description:
Came here after Black Friday shopping. Boy was it packed! We waited 30 minutes for a table, which was a lot less than I expected after seeing how the hot pot place was 2 hours...

The interior was very dark and had a bar ambiance. The eating area was packed with tables. I ordered:
3/5 Katana-ya ramen with gyoza and kaarage on the side (I recommend doing this since these two things are fried) with the miso base. The noodles were a little too soft and I didn't find the broth too flavorful. The gyoza and kaarage were great though.
4/5 Edamame with loads of salt on top. Hard to mess this one up
4/5 Agedashi tofu, came very hot and flavorful
author: Jingting W.

description: I think this place is a bit overrated. I had pork belly don special and karaage here for dinner, but was not impressed. Pork belly had a good texture but lacked flavor. Karaage wasn't crispy and the inside was slightly dry.
author: Dex Y.

description: Second time here, and it keeps getting better.  My "go to" spot whenever I visit the city.  Katanaya miso extra hot is the best!!!
author: Tony P.

description:
I was craving for ramen and the place that I originally had intended to go to apparently closed down. Shame on you yelpers for not reporting that! 

My friend recommended this place and we headed over there to write our names on the wait list. I've read reviews about the long wait but maybe we just got lucky b/c it was under a 10 min wait. Now instead of bringing us to the main store front, they brought us next door which was another 6-7 tables. Maybe they expanded?

For the price and quality of the ramen, I thought it was decent. The broth was flavorful and the noodles had a nice consistency. So from the sound of this review, you would think why only 3 stars? Well here's the kicker, I paid for the bill and just stuck my credit card into the envelope without looking at the actual bill. When the copy came for me to sign, they charged me $96 for 2 bowls of ramen!!! $96!!!! That's ridiculous... how does one do that???

I pointed it out to the waitress and she was apologetic and gave me a void copy of the receipt in case I had cc troubles but still.... i'm still dumb founded about how that could happen. So moral of the story: Always check your bill at this establishment.
author: Lisa C.

description: I haven't had ramen too many times but this was way better than the ramen I've had from 4 star places in Los Angeles and San Diego. My girlfriend and I went at around 10pm and the wait was around 15 minutes, I can't imagine how long it'd be on a busy day. My girlfriend got the regular ramen ($12) and I ordered the Katanaya Miso Ramen ($16, same as the regular with a few extra things). The bowls were really big and had a ton of broth, but that's okay since the broth was super good (maybe a tiny bit too salty for me). All the extra things in the Katanaya Ramen were good, but probably not worth the extra $4. I'd stick to the regular ramen. Service was standard and the place had a nice vibe.
author: Kevin D.

description: I'm a fan of Ramen, and this place extremely mediocre. The ambiance is great, but the food was so bland.
author: Prav T.

description:
I was excited to visit after hearing about how great the ramen was and seeing the many reviews. Unfortunately I was disappointed when they were out of vegetables, beef, and many other popular items. When I received the ramen it was bland, basic and I was a under impressed as I've had waaaay better. My friend ordered the vegetable ramen as she is vegetarian and it cam out with meat in it. When we told them about it they took it to the back took the meat out and gave it to her. It was clear that they gave her the same bowl. The staff was also very cold and they got our order wrong may times. Despite the basic ramen our appetizers were pretty good. We ordered a few rolls, house fried rice, and crispy tuna. The crispy tuna and house fried rice were my favorites! 

To their credit we did come at about 10pm but still thats no excuse for bad ramen, bad service and an empty kitchen with no ingredients left.
author: Brittney B.

description: It was Friday evening before 6:30pm and about 10 people already waiting in line on the stairs in front of us (the restaurant is in the basement). When we sign up our name and peek around the tables, 2/3 are empty so I asked the woman first waiting in line how long she had been standing there and the answer was 10 minutes. We just left, it's not worth to help these kind of Japanese ramen house for free advertising while their usual unethical business practice is always like "Oh we're popular coz customers are waiting in line." I feel so sick of 'em~ many choices to eat in Union Square area!
author: Freya-Loki O.

description: The restaurant was about three blocks away from our hotel and we decided to just order take out.  Instead of phoning in our order, we ordered our food inside. The staff was friendly. It was quite busy so we waited about 20 minute for our order. Something told me that I should have looked through our food before walking back because as soon as we go back to our hotel room, we found out we were missing one order.  My husband was not happy walking back to the restaurant to get his food that they forgot to put in.   The food overall wasn't great either. The ramen broth had no flavor and the fried rice my husband had to go back and get was bland.
author: Faith J.

description: I think this place is fairly rated on Yelp. 3.5 stars is exactly what I would rate it. We came here yesterday for a quick lunch and it hit the spot. I ordered the Katanaya Ramen and my boyfriend had the Fried Chicken Ramen. I had mine spicy with miso, but felt that both were lacking. The amount of spiciness was disappointing to the point where I asked for more Siracha so I could drown my broth in Siracha. The fried chicken and the gyoza were really soggy in my Ramen. This was disappointing because I love gyoza and was looking forward to it, but it was inedible. The hard boiled eggs were good and I appreciated they were not poached. The service was really bad. There were 2 servers and both of them were standing at the front on their phones/talking to each other. It was really quiet in there, so I'm unsure why the service was lacking. Overall, I would rate this place as average and would be up for trying other places before returning.
author: Zoe Y.

description: Yummy ramen and donburi combo! I paid $18 before tax for a tonkatsu donburi and a pork ramen which were both delicious. I walked in extremely hungry so the portions being big was great for a girl with a big stomach. My friend got the nigiri there and she said it tasted really fresh which is also great. I will definitely be back for lunch because the location is convenient however the store is very small so I probably won't be back at night due to long waits.
author: Grace H.

description:
I should like this place given its close proximity to
my apartment and the constant crowds, but really, I don't get it. It's not that good. I wasn't amazed by the sushi or the shrimp tempura. We also got a chicken ramen dish that wasn't remarkable as well. Maybe the happy hour offers unbelievable deals? Not sure, but I am sure that you can go to other places in this city and find better sushi.

The customer service is nice and very welcoming. We were seated and greeted immediately, and checked on regularly. This place isn't too big, so I don't recommend it for large groups. Overall, this is a place to grab sushi if you're staying near Union Square and don't want to walk across the street to the sushi boat restaurant and/or are drunk and in need of some ramen.
author: Tracy T.

description:
The food was bad. The service was awful.

The service was bad. This asian girl serving us had a bitchy face the whole time and look even annoyed to be at work. She kept on chatting with her co worker and at one point, she sat down and was using her phone. Very unprofessional.

The food was bad. The ramen was full of MSG. The taste was mediocre. So much better options in the city. 

This place needs to close. Such a sad excuse for a restaurant.
author: Angelo P.

description:
Was really craving some ramen so my friends and I decided to stop here. Unfortunately, the service and the food was pretty bad. We walked in and the server guy immediately rushed us to find a table and repeatedly said at least 3 times sit where ever you like. When we were trying to order he was very rushed as well. 

So I got the Katana-ya ramen which is loaded with Karage Chicken, 2 slices of pork, egg, seaweed, and gyoza. First off I think the chicken and gyoza should be placed on the side because it gets really soggy after a few minutes. Everything was very salty. Didn't like the noodles, the texture tastes like the noodles from an instant ramen cup. 

Definitely won't be coming back here.
author: Chloe W.

description:
Came in here at 12am and there was no wait. Was served by a tall skinny guy who looked like he was in his twenties. Maybe he had a stick shoved up his ass before he took our order? He stood there impatiently waiting for us to order and when we told him to put the orders in first, he ROLLED HIS EYES.  Another waitress came to serve our food and she was really nice, along with the guy who looked like the manager? 

We hoped the food would compensate for the shitty service but it was shit too. It's disappointing because this used to be our favorite ramen spot. I think there were several changes of ownership. They moved downstairs. 
It was overly expensive shit. 

Shit service. Shit food. Get your shit together Kataya-Na
author: Jia Jie R.

description:
The ramen is good but pricey.  

I ordered the Katanaya Miso Ramen, and it comes with really thick & tender pork belly.  We got lucky that we were able to get a table right away, and service was pretty good and quick (we did happen to sit next to the cashier though).  For what it costs, I was disappointed it doesn't come with much else besides the noodles and meat.  Eggs are usually one of my favorite parts of ramen, and I totally didn't think to add it, since it normally just comes with the entree already.
author: Eric L.

description:
Good?
I had baby octopus fried and soy miso ramen with egg and BBQ pork now finishing up with salmon sushi  1 block ish from my hotel amazing
author: Joe O.

description: Was going to order something to go from here, but last minute I told the woman at the front that I didn't want to spend my money here. She had been extremely rude and unpleasant toward me, treating me like I was such a burden even despite being a paying costumer (well so I thought). Her bitter attitude and unpleasant treatment toward me was so blatant I walked out and got ramen next door instead. I do not have the patience or energy to deal with people's unwarranted BS and snooty behavior for no reason. Do not go here. No need to support a business with terrible customer service.
author: Bea A.

description:
If this is the best ramen in San Franciso,don't know if I should feel sorry for bay area residents or proud that my home town of Chicago has come so far in the food scene.

I'm not quite sure if the quality of the ramen has declined in recent months, or if it's due to the sanitary concerns but when I arrived at 7 PM on a Thursday it was  nearly empty. I must say that my first impression of the restaurant as a whole is dingy. This should have been the absolute first indication that Katana-Ya does not serve authentic ramen, because every single Japanese establishment I have been to (no matter how small or cramped) has been absolutely meticulous. The counters, floors, and sauce containers were clean and unsticky. However, the bathroom was atrocious and smelled like my grandma (and not in a good way). With that being said, I still decided to give the ramen a chance.

I ordered the flagship Katana-Ya Ramen, which came with karaage and fried gyoza inside the broth. I had several issues with the ramen. Firstly - I'm not even sure how I feel about this concept as a whole. Why fry something only to let it soak in broth and become soggy? Secondly - the fry batter on the karaage did not seem to be close to authentic and I have never seen fried gyoza with such thick skin. Thirdly - I chose the Miso broth and while it wasn't too salty, I have definitely had better. Perhaps I've been spoiled with Misoya in Chicago. Lastly - The egg provided is not a traditional ramen egg. Great ramen eggs are marinated with a creamy (almost gelatinous orangey yolk). The ones here are just plain  boiled eggs... not even soft boiled. 

At the end of the day, the service I received was mediocre and the ramen is a far cry from the best that I've ever had.  The ambience also left more to be desired... really.. what kind of shop gives you bamboo chopsticks? I thought Cali was supposed to be green. I definitely won't be back here. I did walk past Mensho Tokyo on the way back to my hotel and it was absolutely packed with a long line out the door, so that may be my next venture.
author: Julie Y.

description: F'N $9.50 for a small Sapporo beer!  I couldn't believe it, at least warn your customers before you gouge them and let them decide!  Never again!
author: Marlow M.

description: Service was horrible. Nothing special about the ramen I had better felt like I could've made this myself and they were out of pork belly. Really? This is a must when you have ramen. Not a spot I would go back to.
author: Danila Y.

description: I just don't understand why this restaurant is so popular...salty and tasteless. So disappointed ...I was a huge fan of this place three years ago, but not anymore. It change in a bad way. Just good location.
author: Sammie H.

description:
Came around 9pm on a Thursday for take out. No lines and no one was inside, so I was able to order but yeah reading from previous comments, very small place, the mirror wall is a great illusion but too bad, small place and about 5 tables seating from 4-6 people. Plus this establishment is a combination of the sushi place and katanaya.

Anyways, got the Katana-ya spicy miso ramen, plus $0.75 to make it spicy. Which came with dumplings and karaage chicken, pretty good and the soup was hot enough to warm up anything including the noodles and meat. The ramen itself does the trick but the broth is a little salty. I also got the takoyaki which comes with 5 pieces, not the best I've had, and a little soggy- not crisp on the outside whatsoever. But I guess its because I got it for take out. I had my dog with me so I couldn't eat in but overall, not bad. I wouldn't stay in line more than ten minutes for this and was asked to wait outside so they can let people in from the long line through the back of the resturaunt.
author: Jackie O.

description: I ordered the ramen + unagi don combo - wanted to try the uni don but they didn't have it :( you can choose either miso or soy based ramen for the combo, and I was able to try both since my friend got one too. They were both pretty mediocre, but I liked the miso one slightly better. The soy was a bit too salty for me, but the miso was better in that I could keep drinking the soup. The noodles were cooked fine - not to much or too little. The mini don that comes with it is actually pretty mini. A small bowl with three pieces, but the unagi was not bad. Overall not a bad meal but would probably find another place to go if I want ramen.
author: Jeana Y.

description: Food was ok but service was terrible/interesting. After looking at the menu for 15 minutes the manager on duty came to are table and asked are we ready and what were we looking for. My gf said pork belly ramen but they were out of pork belly at 9:30 pm and they close at 1. Then I said I don't really eat ramen but did they have chicken over rice. His response was "if you don't want this you can go somewhere else". What? The only reason I stayed was because my gf really wanted ramen. Probably wouldn't go again. But a good Ramen spot in the city is Marafuku according to my gf.
author: Erick A.

description: Not sure why this place has higher ratings than I expect. The food doesn't feel very authentic, got the combo type ramen with gyoza. Really just felt like this was a dish where all the leftovers were just thrown into the soup. Probably wouldn't come back unless I was in the area and really craving drunchies.
author: Chelsea W.

description: I was in San fransisco for my first time and was craving ramen on a chilly day! The entrance threw me off because at the door one must walk down an eerie set of stairs that opens up to a relaxed atmosphere. We waited a good 30 minutes until we were sat and I ordered a vegetarian ramen. The ramen broth was a bit too watery for my taste besides that it wasn't terrible just an average ramen. My friend on the other hand ordered a spicy tofu ramen who's broth I immensely preferred due to its explosion of flavors but sadly I could not handle it's spice for more than 2 bites. Would go back to taste the different bases for my vegetarian ramen and see how radical the change would be.
author: Jasmin L.

description: We visit here every time we're in the city. The beef Raman is full of flavor and delicious!
author: S B.

description:
ordered two things,
ramen: artificial soup base, easy to tell
unagi nigiri, eel was not fresh
the waitress came to our table too much times, annoying
author: Lu S.

description: This place is god awful. I used to like this place and only recently came back. The food is terrible. Can you even call the bowl they give you ramen? And for whatever reason they decided to bump up the prices to something so ridiculous even higher than  nice places that actually serve good ramen. DONT COME HERE!!! They must have changed management or something because the menu, prices and food have all changed. They're cutting corners and ordering poor quality ingredients coupled with the fact that they don't know how to make a decent broth. Also their service is so slow. I feel like they should get a new yelp page because this one is super deceiving considering it is completely different from the old spot which is probably what garnered the mass amount of reviews in the first place. I'm so disappointed and sad the old Katana-Ya is gone. :(
author: Gabrielle B.

description:
Can I get some ice? *receives ice after we already had our meal* wow such bad service!I know it seems weird but everybody had ice water except our table.We had just came from a festival so we were really thirsty and it was hot both out and inside the restaurant.Is it really that hard for some ice?
Food wise,I've had better and at a cheaper price.Sushi was pretty good tho.I dont think "the best ramen in San Francisco "would be the best title for this restaurant.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Pretty good ramen.  
I like the underground vibe too. 

Nothing stands out to me as being spectacular, but in no way was it bad. 

The ramen was served in a HUGE bowl and was delicious. I couldn't believe I ate the whole thing!

I would like to try the sushi, maybe next time!
author: Christopher R.

description:
Overall, this place definitely hit the spot for my ramen craving. However, I don't know if I'd want to come back. 

The noodles were very egg-y, so if you don't like egg noodles you probably won't like it. The texture of the noodles was really good though. It was perfectly chewy, but not over or undercooked. 

I got the salt broth because usually salt broths are the lightest one, but it was very, very salty. It was still good, but definitely very salty.

The katanaya ramen was very interesting because they had chicken karaage and fried dumplings put into it. It tasted very nice, but if you're big into texture, I'll warn you that the karaage and dumplings definitely got soggy. It was sort of gross, but it still tasted really good? 

I feel like the pricing for the ramen was very odd. The katanaya ramen had everything in it and cost a little less than $16, whereas the normal ramen with nothing in it except meat slices (not even eggs!!!!) was much cheaper, but if you wanted add-ons it'd have reached 16 very quickly ($1 for egg, $2 for corn...)

Another thing that bothered me was the bathroom. This did not affect my review, but I want to give a PSA to everyone. I struggled trying to figure out how to turn on the faucet. You push it back. I don't know if that makes sense, but you'll see what I mean!!!
author: Sao B.

description: This is my go to ramen spot whenever I'm in town for work. Fast, uncrowded, delicious. I almost always get the Katanaya ramen... yum. Also an excellent hangover remedy!
author: Kim D.

description:
I tipped out of guilt. Why did I do that??
We were sat quickly. Then we sat there for ten minutes waiting to order anything. Even some water.
Finally was able to order. Sake and two nigiri. That took another ten minutes.
Then the nigiri was bad. Didn't even finish it.
Ten minutes after finishing we had to get up and ask for our bill. The two young Japanese people (a language issue?), working, had a difficult time finding, ringing up, and even giving us our bill.
They acted as if it was natural for us to have to come get our bill from them and wait at the counter while they chatted and struggled to get our bill.
If that all doesn't entice you to go there, I dunno what would.
author: Paul G.

description: Oh......I'd like to thank the chef for the six or seven giant chunks of pork which was ...... insane. I'm posting the pic. No more visit, no....
author: Yao L.

description: I wasn't sure what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised.  The Ramen was delicious.  The gyoza was my favorite.  Get there early or you will have a wait in a stairwell.  It is not very big.
author: Carin H.

description: Their ramen is very mediocre. It's served in a huge bowl but the broth is loaded with msg and salt. I don't even know how many glasses of water I had to drink because I just kept feeling thirsty. I really dislike places that use a handful of msg so I won't be back.
author: Rachel W.

description:
Came here after 5pm since it was near my hotel. Did some research and found the previous owner who made this place renowned sold it and now it's OK compared to their prime days.

First I walked in and saw the place pretty empty and did not know where I should sit since I didn't get greeted. I picked a random place to sit down. After 15 minutes or so was finally acknowledged and ordered my food. I was looking in Yelp at other places to eat while I was waiting for my order to be taken. 

I understand that there was only 1 waitress, but service was pretty slow for no one being there. After seeing what people choose, I decided to try the Katanaya Ramen. I choose to get Miso Broth with spicy. 

I'm too use to something more spicy, so I would recommend people try to extra spicy. Overall experience of food was a 3/5 since it was okay. There was plenty of meats to try while eating the Ramen. I finished the bowl without any issues. I can say this place is not bad if you are nearby, but there are much better places to try Ramen with better service.
author: John L.

description: It was ok not the best but decent ramen I would come again just for the sake. I do recommend the pineapple sake is good with some Sprite. Ramen I would order the house special that sounded really good. Please check it out sushi looks bomb here.
author: Joey S.

description:
Three stars is entirely right.

I stopped by because the menu on the window called to me. "Vi," it said. "Ramen and your choice of a side for $11-14. TOTAL" it said.

Alright. I'll bite.

Walked into an extremely dim and narrow dining area; even at 3pm on a clear City Saturday, the sunbeams from the one unobstructed window in the front of the establishment struggled to get three feet in. Being the model Elite Yelper I am, I asked to be seated by said lonesome window, knowing full well that I would need decent lighting to take my "foodie fotos" (serious about my grub or just plain crazy? You be the judge). With a warm smile, the waitress said that would be fine. Hmmm... Easier that I thought! I quickly decided on the miso ramen with kimchi fried rice combo for $13 and excitedly requested a fried egg to be added to the rice dish................. buuuuut no dice. She shook her head and told me it could not be done. Darn. Well too late to get up now. I thanked her for taking the order hoped I wouldn't be too disappointed in what was to come.

Enter rice dish first. To my pleasant surprise, the kimchi fried rice was actually pretty good! Not nearly as amazing as my homemade stuff (duh), but certainly much better than expected. There were tons of salty pork pieces, kimchi bits, and scrambled eggy goodness incorporated throughout... plus, the flavor was good! I dug it.

Then came the ramen. A cavernous bowl big enough to feed two was placed in front of me. Impressive. However, the noodle accoutrements were a bit lacking (did I use that correctly? *shoulder shrugs*). I got two pieces of charsui and a whole gang of green onions and seaweed in place of the usual corn-bamboo-shoot-cabbage-etc. variety. What's more, ramen, when ordered as a combo, doesn't come with an egg. Uhm, come again??? I had to waive the waitress down to add one to my order -- not to mention it was just a plain ol' boiled egg, not one of them fancy marinated eggs most places give you. In anycase, the broth was decent, the few pieces of charsui I did get were tender, and the noodles had a good bite, just how I prefer them. 

The verdict? All in all, once you get over the part where you feel a little gypped about the fewer ramen toppings, you realize that the flavor is good enough to not leave you too miffed about your overall meal. Plus, that rice was on point. Though I would chose other ramen joints over this one, I can see why people who live or work in the area might frequent it out of convenience, value, and the promise of a decent meal.

So handle that, Geary St. dwellers. Come to Katana-Ya for a some ramen if you're craving it. Just please don't go in expecting the cream of the noodle-y crop.
author: Vi T.

description: Delicious ramen, affordable prices!
author: Angelica L.

description:
I don't understand the hype! By 6pm you see people waiting outside for a table. The ramen here tasted cheap and quick. The egg isn't softly boiled and the toppings are all fried... Nothing fresh. 

Don't come here if you're looking for ramen. For other stuff on the menu, I can't speak for it.
author: Linh L.

description:
Big bowl of ramen with karaage, gyoza, sliced pork, corn, nori, bamboo shoot, mushroom...
It's like one big happy gathering. Except the miso broth can't quite complete the harmony with its lack of depth. Still on a journey to find the best ramen in San Francisco.
They do offer appetizers, sushi and rice bowl as well. (Happy hour 5-7pm)
The place is small, expect to wait on the evening.
author: Jenny T.

description:
3/25/16 Came on a Friday night around 8pm. We were a group of four but the place was packed. The waitress came out asked us to wait, went into the other side of the restaurant and came back out to seat us. Idk but I think the restaurant has two parts to it, with separate entrances. Our side wasn't nearly as packed as the main side which I was okay with. 

I ordered the combo, a side dish and a choice of ramen, udon or donburi. I got the spicy tuna with udon. The spicy tuna was really good. Packed a lot of tuna into the roll. It wasn't really spicy but I could still feel the spiciness. My first roll I stuffed in my mouth almost shot out of my mouth because I didn't know how packed it was. My udon was good, nice and hot. Hadn't had udon in a long time so it fulfilled my udon appetite. I'm not a ramen fan lol. 

We also ordered sake and Sapporo.
My sister ordered the fried gyoza and it was tasty, just like any other gyoza. Everyone else ordered ramen and they all said it was quite tasty. One ordered the habanero ramen with miso soup and he said it wasn't sweat while you eat spicy but definitely spicy. 

The staff there were Super friendly and several different people checked up on us and we really felt comfortable. I'll be back!
author: Janice J.

description:
Katana-ya used to be one of my favorite ramens in the city. 

I heard there's been a change in ownership but whatever it is, things are not the same. The food is not good anymore, the service was bad. The one good thing is they've expanded so the wait is not long anymore. 

The hostess gave our table of 5 to 2 people as our friends were walking down the street (we could see them from katana-ya). After we sat down, the waitress took a long time to take our order, she also let us order something that they ran out of - a curry don. All our ramens came and we had to ask about the curry don, that's when another server told us they were out. The manager told us pick something else and a got a tonkatsu don. But what came out was not a tonkatsu don. It was a bowl of rice, with salad and tonkatsu. 

Overall, our group agreed this was the last time we're eating here. Don't waste a good meal, go elsewhere for good ramen!
author: Terry C.

description: This place is wack. I ordered the spicy tofu ramen and they put kimchi in it. Kimchi wasn't stated in the description which is annoying because if it was I wouldn't of ordered it. My friend ordered the Katana-Ya ramen which has 2 pieces of pork 2 pieces of gyoza and 2 pieces of karage. The gyoza and karage came in the ramen so it was soggy and gross. The restaurant itself seemed really dirty too. Never coming back. This place is trash.
author: Ronnie T.

description:
I got the Katana-Ya Ramen with Rich Miso broth and it was great. Among many other things, the ramen comes with fried chicken karaage, dumplings and pork. The variety was certainly enjoyable and bumped up my feelings about the place. The ramen cost $13, but it's a super large bowl. I finished everything except the noodles. :)

My fresh-off-the-boat Japanese friend (born and raised in Japan, only very recently came to the USA) said he really liked it. But knowing Japanese people it was probably just okay by his high Japanese-ramen-standards and he was just being super nice.

Also, unlike most other places in San Francisco, it's open late. Last call is at 1:15 AM so don't show up right before closing time (2 AM) and except to eat some ramen!
author: Mark C.

description:
Let me start by saying this review is strictly for the ramen, and the ramen only. Oh how I love you, let me count the ways. I've been on a total ramen bender lately and still think Katana-Ya ranks amongst my favorite on the western seaboard. 

Legit noodles (more traditional than most), slow cooked eggs, and fried chicken in a bowl of extraordinarily flavorful broth make this a monthly stop for me. It must be the sheer amount of sodium in the broth that makes me feel like 100 bucks every time I walk out the tiny front door. 

Speaking of which, this place is small and there is usually a line. Given it's proximity to Union Square you would think it would be full of tourists, but I generally find more locals in this spot because we all know it's so good.
author: Benjamin F.

description: The service is terrible. I rise my hand for checking and there is no one come to help me. I eve need to go to ask the waiters and they were play phone.
author: Zijian M.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend for our first night in San Fransisco. The overall atmosphere was pretty hip, even if the music got obnoxious at times. It really felt like a young and vibrant place to be, like dance-club-meets-sushi. 

The food itself was great, but had a lot of technical problems. I ordered the Tuna Poki, house salad, vegetable tempura and miso soup. The Tuna Poki WAS SPICY -- which wasn't indicated. Now don't get me wrong I love spice. I just wish I had known before my mouth was set on fire.

I found reprieve in the house salad, since it was fresh and even had avocado! But it was SWIMMING in mayonnaise sauce. Going lighter on sauces could have saved both dishes overall.

The tempura was not crunchy, but was rather a little spongy. I think changing the tempura batter recipe just a smidge could solve that problem. It wasn't a good mouth-feel overall.

I think the saddest part was that we never got our miso soups, though. We were never charged for it though, I don't think? Our receipt didn't go over what items we ordered, but after doing the mental math I think our waitress just never clocked it in.

I wish this restaurant the best of luck, but it needs a little more attention in the details!
author: Rachel B.

description: Microwaved my egg. Service is not friendly. No attention to comfort or details. Below average broth. Expensive.
author: Ryan K.

description:
I won free tickets to see a live show of "America's Got Talent" @ the Filmore, and after that ended a little after 10pm I was starving and wanted a late night meal. I pulled up my YELP app and searched for a place that looked good and that was open late - that's when I discoverd Katana-Ya. 

The Ramen here is dee-lish-cious! Honestly, the best i've had. I ordered the "Katana-Ya ramen that came with pork, karaage chicken, a hard boiled egg, seaweed, green onions & corn - yummmm! It was really fulfilling, so after realizing that our food server forgot to bring out our spicy tuna roll we were so glad she did. If you're going to eat the ramen here there's no need to order an appetizer. 

The only complaints that I have is that the restaurant is really tiny and that it felt musty inside. The tables were also a little bit sticky and weren't cleaned that well. So i do question their cleanliness.
author: Kat D.

description:
Cramped place, not too bad of a waiting time, huge portions and okay ramen. 

Came here on a weekday and the wait was only about ~10 min for a party of 3. This place isn't small but it sure feels like it because it is VERY cramped in the inside. You will barely have any elbow space to fully indulge in your food. 

For ramen, I got the karage miso ramen w/ added spicy. There are a total of three different broth flavors and I chose the miso flavor. The portions of the ramen was hugeeee! Probably 1.5-2x the serving size of most ramen places. However the broth was definitely lacking. I can't quite put my finger on it but it wasn't like it wasn't flavorful... it just didn't taste that great. I love ramen and I tried miso ramen at many different locations and for some reasons the flavor didn't quite exactly tasted like a miso ramen. The karage and the rest of the toppings were good though.

Overall, I'm not really a fan here but I can't say that I won't come back here again because I probably would if my friends wanted to.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Wow...how far this place has fallen. From the liquor license transfer on the front door, it appears they have new owners and they've pretty much ruined this spot. Katana-ya used to be the nearly the best ramen in SF, but now that there's a new shop seemingly every week, perhaps this place is indeed capitalizing on the tourist traffic and severely cheapened their product

Ramen is average at best. The basic bowl doesn't even come with an egg and pretty much is just the pork, noodles and seaweed. $11.95 for this? The noodles are chewy and I miss the old menu where you can choose how rich of a miso flavor you want. It's not quite bland but not anything like it was.

Service is below average. We were sat at a table by a seemingly disinterested server. It took forever to take our order and then took about 10 minutes to bring us the check when we were finished. Water was delivered, but each cup was only half full. Beer is outrageously expensive at $9.50 for a glass of Sapporo.

There's plenty of other fantastic spots in the city in places that are much easier to get to than Union Square. Visit them. RIP Katana-ya.
author: Chris I.

description: I came here a couple times a few years ago. It seems to have gone downhill since then. The flavor just wasn't there anymore. The broth was a bit bland, the noodles weren't great. The only thing that added flavor was ordering the spicy broth. Also had gyoza which was decent but again, a bit flavorless. Unfortunate turn for a previously delicious spot.
author: Kevin M.

description: Went here for my first SF ramen experience and sadly it wasn't a good one. I was super hungry so I ordered quite a bit of things. First we had the kimchi. That was good and tasty. Well seasoned and crispy. Next, I ordered the soft shell crab. It was deep fried in a lot of batter. There was WAY more batter than crab. It came on a bed of lettuce with dressing, which I enjoyed more than the crab itself. Last, I had the Katan-ya Ramen. The pork could have been cooked more, wasn't tender at all. The noodles also seemed like they could have been cooked more. The miso broth was good and the portion was hefty but the overall taste wasn't anything to write home about. After eating the ramen, I suddenly had an urge to throw up and did just that in their restroom. Not sure if it was their food or just my stomach, but the only other thing I had that day was cereal earlier that morning. When we had walked in, there were no other guests except for us. Perhaps that should have been a red flag for us not to stay to eat. Nonetheless, we stayed, we dined, and will never return again.
author: Monique W.

description: I am very surprised by some of these reviews.  I thought it was excellent!  My only suggestion is to not put so much cabbage in the Spicy Tofu soup.  Other than that, great!  We went there twice in one weekend.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Worse ramen I've ever had. Super salty and basic. I only came here cause Mensho was closed. If you want real good ramen that's worth waiting for, definitely go try Mensho it's just two blocks up the street.
author: Ana P.

description: Their vegetarian ramen was so very delightful. The noodles were of perfect texture. The serving was huge too. We had to wait for a little bit because the place was kind of small and there were really lots of people willing to  line up to get seated. Everything was worth the wait!
author: Kristine U.

description: The size of the portions and deliciousness of the ramen (seriously, quite good) makes up for the length of the wait and unfriendliness of the staff.
author: Peter D.

description: The wait is too long, the staff is terrible and inattentive, food is meh. Do not come here.
author: Marisya N.

description: I am giving this place three stars mostly because of the service. When my friends and I first got to the location, we were very excited because it was underground and seemed to have a great atmosphere. But honestly our waitress was quite careless. We asked her several times to get us water but all she did was do other things, so we asked her again and then we finally got our water. The place was not quite busy so I was confused why she took so long with everything. She also gave out attitude when we kept asking her for our water... girl isn't it your job to assist me??? But I must say that the ramen I purchased was delicious. The ramen noodle itself was probably the only ingredient that I was satisfied with. The place isn't overall bad but I only wished that the staff would improve a little more on their service.
author: Tanya D.

description:
One star
It's my first time to give one star on yelp !!!

After eating my ramen ,  Need to toilet !
I  was walked in front of the waitress  then went to restroom !!!

When I washed my hands.
One Male waiter opened( the  lady's restroom door)he looked at me for one minute and closed the door very fast ！！！

i have no idea what happened
But I felt very uncomfortable !!!

Will They do this to me ?

Racial discrimination at japan ramen store
Such ridiculous!!!!

Definitely never come back!!!!

( Used to be awesome but now overpriced and  bad service)
author: Yi Xuan G.

description: Neither good nor bad. The Ramen dish was sort of blandly spiced and nothing special.  It was hot as opposed to one reviewer saying it was warm.  The Japanese chicken (karaage) appetizer was good but not great. The takoyaki appetizer was very good.  Spiced octopus balls were sweet and flavorful. They did not supply plates to share the food. Water was without ice.
author: Paul And Helen K.

description: A painful experience for dining.  The food was awful the service was abrupt and ill informed. Went there to have a real dining experience came back home hungry.  Signed up on waiting list to be seated and was greeted by a member of the waitstaff who seemed confused about the order to seat diners. After being seated at a bar our waitress greeted us with "ready to order" menus had just been handed to us.  It was downhill from there like a steep street in San Francisco. Our waitress had extreme difficulty explaining menu items and could not clearly explain what items on the menu contained seafood or shellfish.  Ended ordering chicken and rice.  It tasted awful and was very fibrous. I couldn't finish eating my meal. We paid 45$ and ran. Later on all food came up. Not a good experience. Stay away.
author: George Kenneth M.

description:
Pretty good and affordable place to get ramen in SF close to Union Square! My friends and I came at 7pm on a Saturday night and the line looked huge, but it actually moved pretty quickly (~15-20 minutes) so I would recommend staying in the area. The restaurant actually has 2 different sides so they have a lot of seating overall (the right side is nicer lol). Service was great and our waitress was very attentive. 

The combination dishes are a great deal for $15 imo - you get either ramen or udon plus a don bowl (or other various sides). I had the plain salt ramen, which was pretty flavorful and not too salty for me. The pork slices were slightly dry though. You also have to pay extra if you want an egg. I also got the salmon don, which tasted very fresh. My friend's eel don had a lot of tiny bones though, so maybe stay away from that one. 

Overall, I left pretty satisfied. This probably isn't the best ramen place in SF but definitely hits the spot!
author: Marie H.

description:
I was drawn into this place by the Yelp reviews, the fact that it seats only about two dozen people, and that it's such a hole in the wall I walked right past while hunting for it. If it's tiny, the lines must be long, and it must be good, right?

But the ramen here was just okay. The straight noodles were too soft and lacked that fun curly, kinky quality. I prefer them chewy as I usually enjoy at my favorite noodle houses. You can select your tare' -- shio, miso or shoyu -- to flavor your soup and I chose miso. The soup was good, not too salty. Definitely missing in the ramen was the ajitsuke -- the soft boiled egg with a creamy yolk -- which is my favorite part of ramen. Some places will give you a half or whole egg, but Katana-Ya skips it altogether.

You can get your ramen with a side dish, which is pretty cool. For $14, I got my miso ramen with a small bowl of mixed poke (salmon and tuna) over rice. The quality of the fish seemed fresh given its silky smooth texture.

Service and time to get my food was very quick.

Overall, it was a good spot for quick meal but food was not especially memorable.
author: Peijean T.

description: The new renovated restaurant is nice and cozy for a good spicy miso ramen. Add karage to your ramen and it's heavenly.
author: Prashanth C.

description:
On a very special date night, we decided to grab some ramen, which meant it was time to Yelp! After searching for places close to us, we decided to come to Katana-Ya. Reviews seemed good and boy was I hungry.

When we approached the location, we noticed the long line outside, which told me it was going to be good! We put our names in and waited for it to be called. The lady working the clipboard was a bit too soft spoken so a lot of folks missed their names being called. After about 30 minutes we were being walked to our table. The initial restaurant was super small and seemed like everyone was on top of each other, however, we got taken to another dining area downstairs to the right. Tiled floors, dark wooden tables and low lit lights made for an intimate setting, perfect for the date! The service was quiet but efficient. Not a standout but not bad at all. Here's what I had that evening:

-Katanaya Ramen for $12.90: Ramen, miso broth, green onions, seaweed, fried chicken, fried potstickers, BBQ pork and a boiled egg. The broth was on point! I ordered the medium density so it wasn't too salty but came with a lot of flavor. The fried chicken was awesome as well. crispy and nicely soaked up the broth. Loved the crunchy element from the corn and scallions. To me, the boiled egg would have been better if it was a soft boiled egg. Overall, it was a good meal!

-Hamachi sushi for $7.00: Hamachi (Yellowtail) and green onions. The hamachi was creamy and good, kind of weird with the green onions. Never tasted this combination before. It was different. Something I'll have to get used to, but I wouldn't mind ordering this again. 

All in all, this meal was a huge success. I really enjoyed my experience and liked the food. Definitely will be back. If you're in the area, come check them out!!
author: Rockne H.

description: Ramen was very good. I had the pork belly. It came out quickly and was very flavorful. The vegetarian ramen also got high marks. Cool atmosphere and good food. Definitely a winner.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
Pretty terrible service, but really good food, I think!

We walked in without a reservation on Thanksgiving weekend on a Saturday afternoon. The tiny place was already packed. My mom was cold and didn't want to stand outside to wait for a table so she pretty much sat down for one that hadn't even been busted yet. Even though there were parties who were waiting before us. A waitress asked if we put our name down and my mom said no but refused to move. Sorry to whoever had to deal with that...

The place is really really small and I think that contributes to the bad service. The ladies here don't necessarily have a bad attitude or anything, they are just spread way too thin so they're hard to flag down. Two waitresses serving the entire restaurant and manning the cash register and busting the tables. Can't blame them.

Anyways, I'm here just to recommend any ramen with the gyoza inside. It sounded like a weird concept when I first saw it on the menu, but holy shit, it's an amazing concept. It's actually more of a deep fried dumpling that really soaks up the flavor of the broth. Bite into this juicy morsel and be met with tasty pork and fresh leeks.

The ramen here is really great quality. Love the corn.
author: Toni L.

description:
The storefront is a little small and inconspicuous, so it's easy to miss. Inside, there are a few small tables and a small bar area.

I got the Miso Katana-Ya ramen, which includes 2 sliced BBQ pork, 2 gyoza, 2 karaage, corn, egg, and seaweed. Pretty packed, right? This ramen is good for those who can't make a decision on whether to get an appetizer or not because it's all in the ramen.

Broth was great and not as salty as I thought it would be from other reviews. The other parts of the ramen were disappointing- average noodles, below average BBQ pork, cold gyoza, and fully cooked egg. The karaage was my favorite part. All things considered, $12.95 for this packed bowl is very reasonable. 

They also offer other items, such as sushi, donburi and udon. Service was pretty inattentive.
author: Angie K.

description:
Food was not great, only good for late night eat but I'd rather go somewhere else. Ramen was lacking flavor, my katsu don was worse than some katsu you can get at l&l or other places. 

Service was slow. Price was high for what the food is worth.
author: Albert M.

description:
Getting back from the gym after having had nothing to eat all day left me famished. Unfortunately it was 11pm at night and just about everything was closed. Busting out my list of late night options to try, I saw ramen on the list and  immediately knew what I was having for dinner.

About two blocks west of Union Square on Geary, Katana-Ya is a small little ramen shop just bordering on the tenderloin. Inside is a small amount of seating, maybe 20 in total, and a bizarre collection of neon lights mixed with traditional japanese design. When I got there at 11:30, the entire place was filled with drunk japanese businessmen in suits. No idea what was going on there but it looked interesting.

I sat at the counter and ordered the Katanaya ramen, which is basically a little bit of everything. It had some potstickers, some karaage, an egg, some char siu, some corn and a few other veggies. None of this was particularly quality stuff. The egg was super hard boiled, the karaage and potstickers were average as was the char siu. I ordered the miso broth with this and asked for the rich option and extra spicy. The broth itself, ordered like this, was actually pretty tasty. It felt almost creamy and very hearty.

I also tried an appetizer, the spicy crispy tuna. This turned out to be a mistake. It was just a subpar tuna roll thrown in the deep fryer and loaded with sauce. Skip this.

The service here was not very friendly or attentive. They also failed to get my order right and took even more time to correct it.

Overall, although I had a ton of issues with this place, I will probably be coming back because where else are you going to get decent ramen at 1am? Thus I feel compelled to consider it "A-OK".
author: Mark O.

description: They changed ownership and the ramen tastes microwaved.  The freshness is gone and I would not come back until it's improved. Don't believe the older yelp reviews because it's a different restaurant now. It makes me sad to see a restaurant with so much history and character go to waste.
author: raymond c.

description:
I remember coming to this places years ago and truly enjoying the "Katana-ya Ramen." WHAT HAPPENED? 

The Katana-ya Ramen was extremely greasy and oily tasting. Bf ordered the Kimchee Fried Rice which was super bland and tasteless. Sushi with raw salmon was warm, wtf!

Super disappointed at the down hill direction this place has gone. Oh, and super overpriced!
author: Shela D.

description:
** if you are really desperate for over priced ramen feel free to eat here, but IMO you can get better ramen else where**

For the price that this place was charging I would have expected it to be hella good.... but turns out it was a disappointment. $12 for regular ramen, $1.75 for making the broth extra spicy, $1 for adding an egg, & $2 for corn..... now if you do the math I think it's pretty steep for mediocre ramen.... only plus was that they gave you a good amount of noodles total of my meal was $50 for 2 people 

Let's begin with the ramen noodles. Thin and not thick and chewy as other ramen places, kinda reminded me of undercooked egg noodles in Chinese dishes - so that was a disappointment. 

Next let's talk about the broth.... first off it didn't taste like miso whatsoever, my first sip was kinda sour and not even spicy. It left my mouth with a bad aftertaste. TBH I can't even describe to you what it tastes like cause it wasn't good... lol 

AND this damn "soft boiled" egg was cold & hard boiled... seriously -______- 

Lastly, don't get the soft shell crab.... was supposed to be deep fried and crunchy... came out sad and kinda mushy. To top it off service sucks sooo I'm pretty sure this is the last time I'll be going here.
author: Kim T.

description: The food here is average and the sushi prices are much to high as compared to other sushi restaurants.  They really push people in and out quickly so they can turnover tables.   The service was not very friendly as not one person smiled at us when there was any interaction with us.
author: Rayna V.

description:
Fairly standard ramen shop that provides a generous bowl of noodles with ~5 slices of roast pork. The broth wasn't too salty and had a deep, rich flavor. Nothing too special but a solid experience all around. 

Tip - the restaurant does not accept amex. Put your name on the waitlist clipboard located outside in-front of the restaurant.
author: Julia K.

description:
Pretty awful quality food.
The ramen noodles are so chewy. How long were they left out? Jeez.

Don't order the unagi. It's just microwaved food. Hell, this whole place is probably microwaved/reheated food.
author: Adrian C.

description:
This place used to have the best ramen a few years back. Now it's way over priced and bleh. 

Took forever to be seated when no one was even there. Took forever to bring water and out food. Never spending money here again.
author: David M.

description:
This tiny restaurant with a red brick facade is located a couple of blocks away from Union Square, just far enough from all the tourists and their selfie sticks. The ambience is intimate, with dim lighting and small capacity, ideal for groups of 2 or 3, but they can also accommodate larger parties--I went with 8 people, and that was no problem. I went to spend some time with good friends, and try Katana-ya's (supposedly) famous ramen. Or so I thought. More on that later.

Pork Belly Donburi (4/5)-$11.95 The rice bowl was served soft and warm; went well with the pork belly, which in turn was soft, tender and flavorful. This meal was served with miso soup. 

Hawaiian Sushi Roll (3/5)-$13.95. Not too bad of a roll, I've had way worse compared to this one. Presentation needs work--the roll was served on a small plate, and it just didn't look appealing to me. The sushi rice was soft and fluffy, no complaints there. The fish--salmon, tuna, butter fish--were alright. Nothing too special about this roll, didn't feel like it worth the money. I don't recommend it. 

Hamachi Sashimi (4/5)-$19 & Salmon Sashimi (3/5)-$13. They have 3, 6, and 9 piece options for the sashimi plate. I'd say the cut is worth the price. Salmon wasn't that fresh, it didn't have that bright orange color and had obviously been frozen for a while. Hamachi on the other hand, was pretty good.

Pork Belly Ramen (1/5)-$13.95. Are you sure this place is known for their Ramen? Look at my picture; sloppy presentation to the max. It's the opposite of scrumptious. The broth tasted nothing like rich pork bone broth but rather just watery MSG. It was very oily, but it was not from its gelatin. This is thus far the worst ramen I've experienced in town. Ramen was so-so. Overall, I'd rather have Japanese instant ramen, it might've been better. 

This place charges 18% fee for party of 6 and more and takes maximum two cards. Please be sure to double check your bill, as all the tax, tips and gratuity are included and you don't need to do anything after the pre-tip amount. 

Bottom line, this place stays open till late, unless there's absolutely nothing to eat around, I probably wouldn't come back.
author: Tammy C.

description:
Very disappointed that they do not serve ramen in tonkatsu broth. I had the katayana ramen in miso. While the ramen is ok, the char siew (barbecued pork) was tough. The soup falls short hence I could not finish my bowl of ramen at all. The only redeeming quality of this bowl of ramen was its karage chicken.

For the price, I definitely would not visit this place again. Really underwhelming.
author: Nicky N.

description:
If you like ramen with attitude, literally, then come to Katana-Ya.

In a city filled with other good ramen places, I'm not sure how this one surpasses the others.

The broth isn't anything special. I had the miso with kimchi and onions, but honestly I've had better kimchi from a jar out of an Asian supermarket.

When I asked the waitress for a menu, I thought she was going to karate chop my head off. Ditto when I asked for chopsticks to eat the noodles with.

The price was decent at around $11.

Therefore, I won't give it 2 stars.

But will I wait in 30 minute line to come here again.

Katana-No!
author: Jack R.

description: Swung by here after seeing the yelp reviews and a pretty chilly afternoon. Was unfortunately not too swooped off my feet with the quality of the food :(  the spicy tofu ramen was more sweet and sour than savory and spicy, and the karagee chicken didn't even look like real chicken. The chicken looked almost translucent and a pink color (I made sure that it wasn't just undercooked). Super disappointed since previous yelpers seemed to have a good experience here.
author: Angelina G.

description: This was the best ramen I have ever had, SO WORTH THE WAIT. I was able to customize my ramen to my liking but the pre-made ones are also so good. Flavorful, hearty, and downright delicious. It can be packed but if you have time definitely go here. It is casual, not fancy, so a good way to end a fun night out. The service was fast once we were seated so you won't have to wait much longer once you have your food. A downside, it is costly for ramen... BUT IT IS SO GOOD
author: Tooka Z.

description: This place has some of the most delicious ramen I've ever had. The food is great, and this place has cool traditional Japanese decor which gives it a lively and fun atmosphere. My only complaint is about the msg. Other than that I really enjoy coming here.
author: Jenna N.

description:
Just arriving to our Hotel my girlfriend and I were famished and decided we wanted something nearby and warm, so we settled on Katana-ya. Upon walking in and going down the the stairs we were quickly greeted and directed to a table in the corner. After sitting down we realized we had no menus and spent the next few minutes trying to wave someone down. 

We ordered our food (which was decent at best) and would rate it 3 out of 5 stars, but the service is what this review is about. I have never made so many attempts to grab a waiter/waitress and waited so long for my check. We spent just shy of 30 minutes both requesting and waiting for out bill and when they finally dropped it off, it was incorrect. Overall this was one of the most frustrating dining experiences we've ever had.
author: Gil P.

description:
Tonight, our visit yielded meaty and tasty unagi, delicious soba noodles, and flavorful agadashi tofu.

Still a great place to go for a healthy late-night bite.

Note: If you're gluten-free and didn't know that buckwheat is okay to consume, consider yourself informed!
author: Diana V.

description:
What happened to this place? I remember this was the spot for ramen in the city. Then they decided to a remodel and everything changed.

Ramen: what happened to the thick broth that was full of flavor? It literally tasted like they pour hot water and put a splash of salt or seasoning or whatever it was but broth was nothing more than just hot water. The pork belly looked overdone, and why is their mushy potstickers floating in my soup? 

Service: forgot to bring our drinks, not once did they stop by to check if everything was ok. Still left the drinks on the bill and not once did anyone acknowledge they were sorry for forgetting the drinks. Why?

Wait time: literally waited 5 minutes to get a Togo container. Another 10 minutes for the bill. I hate when I feel trapped inside a restaurant  because servers won't bring you the check

Heavy guy server: Learn to smile bro. Learn it's ok to mess up but when you do be a man and man up to it. Why hide and avoid our table for the rest of the meal? 

With all these new trendy ramen shops opening in the city Katana- See Ya later. 

This place blows, go next door to Jack in the box and order yourself 2 tacos.
author: Dan L.

description: Fast, simple service. I got the basic ramen ($12) and both the soup and noodles were good for a reasonable. Nothing spectacular there but I enjoyed having a good amount of seaweed. If you want an egg, you'd have to add it on as a side, or get Katana-ya ramen for $17. Made for a quick dinner before a movie if you can get past the queue!
author: Charmaine C.

description: I visited this place twice. In the second time, it was not my choice and I just followed my friend. I did not like kakuni ramen's taste and price. Nigiri's rice is not prepared by Japanese way. I think that Katana-ya should have very good cooker for Japanese food.
author: Shirchin B.

description:
Finally got a seat here on a Wednesday night!

This place gets packed FAST. This review is after my third attempt of trying this place, and overall I am happy with everything! My friend and I chose a Soba combo with Tuna over rice. We also had the Spider Roll and Caterpillar Roll with a side of two pieces of Toro and two pieces of sweet shrimp (which included the fried shrimp heads).

I know, I know, it sounds like a lot of food... but who cares?! I was expecting the Soba to come cold, but maybe that's the Japanese style of eating it? Or.. maybe just Katana-ya's way of serving it. The rolls were decently packed with stuffings. I wish the Toro was fresher, but no complaints otherwise. The sweet shrimp tasted like.. raw sweet shrimp. The bill came out to be around $60, and I would say that's fair for all the food that we had.

Definitely going to come back and try their ramen!
author: Linda K.

description:
I really do not understand the hype for this place at all. But then again, it was only 3.5 stars on Yelp. I guess I thought the 3.5 star rating was deflated since there were 3k+ reviews? Whatever it was, this place is solidly 2-3 star category.

My brother and I each got the signature ramen with the karaage, dumplings, and pork slices. I think it's absolutely silly to put deep-fried food into a bowl of soup and noodles. The dumplings and karaage was soggy (duhh) and tasted funny. The pork slices were incredibly tough and the noodles were really lackluster.

There are way better ramen/food options in the city. Really sad I wasted a meal here.
author: Amy B.

description:
mediocre sushi/sashimi, pretty decent ramen. This place is super tiny, and very limited on space.  The bf and I were squished at a table next to the sushi bar and kitchen and had to lean towards the wall to avoid being jostled by moving waitresses. 

The sashimi here was not that great.  It tasted like thawed fish (which, I am aware that a lot of sushi places get their fish frozen, but this place didn't thaw it properly so it had a watery, just thawed feeling) The salmon was the only decent fish from out 14 pc omakase.  

The ramen and mini donburi combination was great, and a pretty good value.  You get a regular ramen and your choice of mini rice bowl (they had about 10 options with different prices).  We chose the uni and ikura donburi and upgraded our ramen to the katanaya ramen with miso base.  The ramen was pretty good, although a bit too salty and the ramen noodles were too thin for my liking.  The uni ikura don was pretty basic and not too memorable.  Probably won't come here again, even if i was in the area.  There's just too many good food places in downtown sf.
author: Kay A.

description:
I enjoy  very much their  dishes. The ramen is exquisite. 
The service is magnificent.  Awesome  establishment. 
I do recommend  Katana  !!
author: Adrian S.

description:
Food is okay, service is terrible. First time came here, I was one of the few customers, after I ordered, i waited for 40 mins while watching new customers come in and finish, when I asked the waitress, she apparently forgot about me and it took her another 15 mins to bring my order, this is not rush hour, it is from 9:30pm to 11pm at night. 

Second time came here, I was going to the airport and had two pieces of luggage with me. But after I already found a corner table and sat down, they asked me to move to a single person table, while there were only two other customers in the whole restaurant when I came in. 

If I'm a local and know other alternative, I would not come here.

Update: Things just got worse, I've only spent 5 mins eating, they sent in the check, will never come here ever again.
author: Lisa S.

description: Its our 1 year wedding anniversary and the phone keeps ringing and ringing - first time in SF celebrating.
author: Shaly A.

description: Pork belly ramen was a salty broth laden bowl of fat.  The pork belly was not seared but rather residual pieces from the broth that were  boiled chunks of pork fat and skin.   The ramen had minimal vegetables, salty broth that was not umami.  No egg included but this bowl couldn't get any worse.
author: Kevin T.

description: One of the best ramen in a city. The food is so good and the ramen portion is so huge. Highly recommend Katanaya miso ramen. Very nice broth and full of flavors. Service part is ok. They do their job. But need to be improved.Will be back!
author: Alex E.

description: The first time I tried Katana Ya I thought it was the best ramen I've ever had.  Tried it again a few years or so either and I'm left baffled to wonder what happened?  Perhaps I was too inebriated back then and was simply famished from hunger after walking blocks from a night of bar hopping.  Maybe my palette wasn't as refined.  I guess I should have noticed sometime peculiar as we walked in there were only a couple of patrons.  Anyways I thought the ramen was just ok...not as good as I remembered...I was also told that they changed owner.
author: Phung L.

description: Excellent Ramen! Waited about 20 minutes on a Tuesday night around 8 pm. Service was a little slow but it seemed like they were short staffed so that may not be the norm. Portions were gigantic so come hungry.
author: Kate O.

description: I always stop here when I'm in San Fran overall pretty good and close to walking distance from Union square. Must try!
author: Leanne D.

description:
If you plan on dining here, eat before you shop! Small place, somewhat cramped and there wouldn't be space for your merchandise.

My boyfriend ordered a bowl of ramen and the waiter asked him "what kind of broth? Miso?" He replied with a yes.

When it was my turn, I told her "I'd like a ramen with miso broth please." She replied with "miso?" I replied yes.

We also ordered amaebi and hamachi nigiri. That came out a few minutes later with a small bowl of miso soup and my boyfriend's ramen. 

We asked the waiter where my ramen was and she said all I ordered was soup. Really? 
8:00PM I suppose a customer would come in and only want soup. But wouldn't something seem strange if a customer came in and didn't order an entree? Good thing she was smart enough to remove the miso soup off the bill, otherwise there would be a problem.

 I personally prefer tonkotsu broth so I will not be returning here. Their miso broth was too sweet and oily. Literally a thick layer of oil on top of everything. 

Located near Union Square. Perhaps this is the kind of broth tourists prefer?
author: Danae L.

description:
Came here middle of the afternoon for a late lunch. We were seated right away near the back and decided on the combo special to share between two. We got the regular ramen with miso broth and mild spicy plus the salmon don. Mild spicy is barely spicy and they do charge you 50 cents for adding spice and a bit more if you want extra spicy. I thought the ramen was okay. The salmon don was a small bowl with about five pieces of salmon and it was quite delicious. We also ordered takoyaki and it was crispy on the outside and slightly soft inside. 
It's a small place and I think they have long lines at night since there's a sign up board outside. Inside is dimly lit and has nice decorations for an inviting atmosphere. Not suggested for big groups since the tables are quite small.
author: Diana C.

description: Service was horrible - waited forever for the waitress to take our order and then forever for her to bring us our check. Food was below average - Just a lot of MSG and meat was overcooked. I would not recommend this place. There are better ramen places in the area like Aijesen in the Westfield mall!
author: Vivi M.

description:
My experience here was pretty unpleasant. Although, my server was very kind and complimentary, I will never come back here. 

Cleanliness: Mid eating my dinner, a mouse come out from under the table.... A MOUSE! 
The manager was then called by the server and he didn't seem surprised nor apologetic. He just moved some chairs around so that the mouse would go hide. This made me lose my appetite and I no longer wanted to eat the ramen, which was very low quality, esp for the price. 

I then called the manager over to ask why there is rats in their restaurant and why isn't he doing anything about it. I asked about the health rating of the restaurant and he seemed very upset the fact that I would even ask that question. I told him I didn't feel comfortable eating the food nor just eating the restaurant any longer. He kept insisting I can just take the food home then and eat it there if I'm not comfortable being there bc of the mouse!!




Food: they're suppose to be popular for their ramen, but they're ramen was not very tasty. The meat was tough and seemed it had been sitting out for days. The egg in the ramen was over cooked. The broth was bland and salty. 
The sushi seemed old,  I'm surprised I didn't get sick.  I would give the food a lower rating if I could. 

Service: my waitress was very kind and sweet, but the manager was rude and careless.
author: Jette H.

description: Well, the food was still really good. I gave the two stars to the service. I ordered a udon with shrimp and vegi tempura and I waited for more than 20 minutes without any notice. I came by myself and was sitting by the bar. When I waited for about 10 minutes, the waitress was handling two bowls to my next table. 5 minutes pass, a guy sit down next to me and he got his ramen in 5 minutes. I still got nothing until then and when I asked the waitress, she just smiled...almost 25 minutes passed, my order finally came and she told me the sauce for the tempura will come right after, and it never came...I don't wanna be mean, but that's the truth. Katana-Ya was always my go-to place in Union Square. Though the food was still good, the service really disappointed me.
author: Kathleen K.

description: Amazing Ramen. Service mediocre but the food far outweighs that. The spicy miso ramen was the best!
author: Jen L.

description:
DON'T EAT HERE. Cockroach was inside of bowls.
And complained about this but no apologize.
Who wants to pay for this !?
author: Kohei K.

description:
I always like coming here when I'm craving udon. It's nothing special but it's always so satisfying. 

Most recently, I had the udon combination with Hokkaidon.

Yumyum. BTW, they're always playing some hip house music in here.
author: Angela L.

description: The Unagi Don and the seafood fried rice are so good!!!!! The best choice when you want something to warm your stomach up. The Ramen is also very good. Strongly recommend this place.
author: Annabelle L.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the Ramen here, but it didn't blow my mind. When I rate Katana Ya, I have to compare it to other ramen places I've been to. Simply put, I've had better ramen in SF.

I cannot speak for other options on the menu, but the Pork BBQ Ramen was pretty good. Large portion and savory flavor. It was missing some key ingredients, like a soft-boiled egg, but I was satisfied. It just wasn't exceptional.
author: Vasiliy M.

description: Yum! What a cool spot tucked away in a quaint location. Hands down one of the best ramen noodle soups I've had!
author: Val G.

description:
T'was a last minute decision to try this place out, but in reality, I've had this place bookmarked for quite some time now. The timing was right on a sunny yet chilly San Francisco evening. Finally eating here paid off!

With no reservation and about six people ahead of me, I put my name on the list, and they called my small party of two within five minutes. The place was small and a bit tight, but yet totally reminded me of some of the old school restaurants in Dublin IR. Not a big issue, it's the city; so it is what it is. Although, I wouldn't recommend bringing a large group here. Our table seemed clean, and I was ready to order!

Started with the Cheese-Age appetizer; basically white fish with cream cheese in it. For those that know me, I hate cream cheese in my sushi. It was like a Philly roll, only dipped in batter and fried.  I didn't care for it, sorry!  But thank God for the Toro sashimi ($6.50), it melted in my mouth and saved the appetite.

Now, how to order ramen?  The menu may look confusing, but all you have to do is select the soup type, spicy level, and if you want it rich or light.  I chose the miso, and had an excellent bowl of hot ramen noodles with chicken karage, not spicy.  My Chicken Karage bowl was nice'n'hot, and just delish!  If you can't decide on what to order, I would recommend the original Katanaya bowl.  It had beef slices, some chicken karage, and goyza.  Sooo good!  Super filling, and I really enjoyed it too!

Overall, it was pretty average.  $43 for two bowls off noodle soup, one appetizer, and six pieces of sashimi.  
~ No issues with service either, as it was quick. 
~ Definitely a great place to grab some ramen, especially after a party! Not that Ruby Sky is around the corner.  Or grab some for lunch!  3.5 Stars!
author: Ron R.

description:
Nice little ramen spot near Union Square

I've been here on two occasions, but let's talk about my recent visit (the first one, was during a bar hopping night lol =) ). My coworkers and I wanted to try Ramen, so I suggested this one after my first visit. Located about a block away from Union Square, you can find this restaurant, easily spotted by it's sign that faces both ways on the sidewalk. My first visit, we only had the upstairs option, but to my surprise, there was another room located downstairs. We were seated right away, and this was around 7pm.

The decor of both rooms is pretty nice. The lighting is lowkey, setting a very mellow vibe. The walls are filled with oriental decorations. During this visit, they had both floors open because it was still late afternoon time. They were playing edm music, a nice touch to keep the environment lively. We were sat right away and had our orders taken in no time. This time around, I decided to order the limited time Pork Belly Ramen that was being featured on the front of the menu. I also put in an order of Gyoza. My coworkers decided to try it too as we also ordered the ingredients for sake bombs. Our waiter even encouraged that we test the craftsmanship of the table with our sake bomb procedure.

We received our pitcher of imported beer and a bottle of sweet tasting sake pretty fast. Between 3 people, we were able to do like 2.5 sake bombs worth. As soon as we finished our last drink, our food came out.

The Gyoza was pretty good. Cooked perfectly with some good Gyoza sauce. It was pan fried, and not deep fried. I like both styles so I'm not complaining. Our huge bowls of ramen came out and it was a site to be seen. A lot of noodles, a lot of soup, and a lot of pork belly. The soup was really hearty, the noodles really firm, and the pork belly was simply delicious. Definitely a contender for one of my favorite braised pork belly bowls.

If you're in the area, this is a good ramen place to check out.
author: Robert O.

description:
I would have given this place a four star if it was a few years ago but I think the quality has diminished. My husband and I had many delicious memories of this place while we were still dating but I was sad it wasn't the same.  

What we ordered: 
Spicy miso katanaya ramen 
Shio (salt) katanaya ramen 

Pro: the noodles were cooked perfectly and my spicy miso broth was good. Portion size was enough to fill you up! The broth basically saved the add-ons! 

Cons: chashu was dry and had no flavor. Potstickers were too doughy. Maybe order them on the side to keep the crunch. Karage was okay. Again, maybe order it on the side and not in the ramen. The biggest disappointment was the EGG. It was fully cooked and dare I say, over cooked. I believe having a perfectly cooked egg is a must for Japanese ramen! 

Overall: I would only come back if I happen to be in union square shopping and too hungry to drive to a better ramen place.
author: Tami T.

description:
The ramen isn't anything special but the service here is super fast! I think they used to be much better, but now the stuff they churn out is pretty average. If you've got a craving for ramen and are in the area, just head here to get your fix. The serving sizes are pretty big too, so you'll probably leave full. I like the Katana-ya Ramen because it comes with a bunch of things :D Gyoza, karaage, BBQ pork, egg, corn, and more all come in the bowl! 

Katana-ya is also pretty decently priced so you'll get a bang for your buck. They have a great combination menu where you can order donburi with your order of noodles! Spicy tuna don FTW!
author: Grace C.

description: The ramen is too Salty to finish. Also, the tiny space is totally uncomfortable. Not recommend at all.
author: Ford L.

description:
The best ramen I have ever had and it was a very authentic experience. O ordered the vegetable ramen and it was good, but my friend ordered the pork and it was amazing!!! 


The only downside was the tiny tables and the mold in the window seal, we were sitting in the window. I honestly will be sure to come back next time I'm in the area, but that place could be cleaned up a little:
author: Samantha H.

description: Worst restaurant I have ever been! Worst attitude I have ever got! When we got there, the waitress said we just need to wait for 5-10minutes. And then she pointed at one of the table says that table is leaving soon. So we stood at the stairs and waited. When the people at that table left, a women just sat down there. And we ask one of the waitress she said she didn't know we are waiting so she seated her. And then they talked to the manager and that man didn't even care about this he just stand in front of the kitchen not even looking at us! And then all the waiter and waitress just carry on with their work. No one even came and explain to us why. We waited for another 5 minutes and they just said she sat down first and it would be impolite to ask her to stand up right now. We are not asking the women to move away but didn't us deserve an apology?
author: Lisa P.

description: Although the place is a little small I must say the food is very delicious here. I've been here two times within the same week and it was my first time trying this place out. I had to come back! So I noticed that everyone usually comes here for the ramen which looks and smells amazing but I have not had the ramen yet. I've only had the sushi here and I feel like the price is reasonable for it being what it is. I also love the music that they play because you usually don't find spots like this playing music. I will definitely be coming back to try out their ramen.
author: Luis M.

description:
Meh.  Come on SFO... you can do better.

Party of 4, and 3 of us had their Spicy Miso.  I thot it was so-so.  My other 2 buddies raved about it. So much, that they want to come back the next night.  

I was less impressed.  First of all, it has the hype and shack-appeal of a ramen superstar.  The hole in the wall restaurant gave off a vibe that implied.."
