I am so sexy and my ramen is so good, you can eat it in this shack and wait in line.." .  Unfortunately, the ramen was not that sexy.  The noodle looked and tasted like it was sphagetti from a box.  The server was all attitude. The broth was one dimensional .. think greasy and salty. 

Scratch this place off my list for good Ramen in SFO.  Moving on.
author: Luke T.

description: Recently went to this place and really enjoyed it. The food was delicious, great customer service. I'll be back for sure.
author: Marina B.

description:
The Katana-Ya Ramen with miso broth warmed us up on a cool, breezy San Francisco night. On any given day, this restaurant may be cramped but in this season, we felt comfy and cozy. 

The ramen bowls are huge. Watching the hot steam sizzle out from them was so satisfying. The chicken karaage was plump and soft. Ask for extra dressing on the side to dip the karaage in. The fried soft shell crab was sort of a miss--not because the dish itself was bad--but because the ramen and karaage overpowered everything.

The service was nice. They look irritated or distracted half the time but they're really not. They always respond to your requests immediately, which is saying a lot since I saw only two waiters manage the entire restaurant.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description: Came here after a show at the SF playhouse on a Tuesday night. We ordered a Miso Ramen and karaage donburi. I didn't think it was the best food in the world but it definitely hit the spot and i would definitely go again. The ramen was HUGE with tons of noodles! I added the option of extra spicy which was an additional $1.50 which is a little pricey but if you like spicy it might be worth it! This place is open late so if you get hungry at night you know where to go!
author: Eileen H.

description:
3.5 stars.....

Located downstairs in a dark room, servers were mediocre, not overly friendly at all. 

My husband and I both ordered the miso ramen. The noodles were slightly undercooked and we both had to add soy sauce to make the broth more flavorful and salty. I also added chili to my noodles. The pork was tender and just okay, no bold flavor there. The portion size was decent but for $12 I would have expected more noodles.

We also had a side of friend rice, that is what redeemed this restaurant. It was very tasty minus the kimchi. 

This ramen joint was fine. The ramen isn't anything to rave about but it's not disgusting either.
author: Bree D.

description: I actually really like the Katanaya ramen. This is the only ramen I get when I come here. It's a huge portion, and the meat and dumplings fills me up very quickly. The miso broth is not too salty, not too bland. The seaweed and corn are a bonus, without adding onto the price like most ramen places that are considered as add ons. I also ordered sushi here before, which is ok and cheap, but it's not very fresh. I can only depend on the ramen. Last weekend was the third or fourth time I've been here, and it tasted consistent with the previous times, which were a few months ago. I'll keep coming back. There hasn't been a line when I've eaten here, but several times I've walked by and saw a big dinner crowd standing outside.
author: Alice S.

description:
NOT INTO THE RAMEN HYPE
(3 stars)

We had initially came here craving ramen, then after waiting for seats to become available, the idea of ramen checked out and we settled having sushi and appetizers. Also, I just heard the ramen is "mediocre" or "just typical ramen" it really doesn't hype my idea to get ramen. 

1) their menu online is minimal, so is their menu posted on the door, but the real menu is extensive.
2) honestly, I don't really know why there is always a line. the hype is nothing.
3) if I'm having a hard time trying to figure out what to right, there was nothing great nor terrible about this place to rant about

KIMCHI - meh. had better.

CRISPY SPICY TUNA APPETIZER - imagine a spicy tuna roll, deep fried, cut into pieces, and blended with a tasty salad with spicy Asian dressing. that's what you get. it doesn't look that great but it was very good. This dish does have a little bit of heat, be warned. Highly Recommend.

49ER ROLL - Just like any 49er roll in the bay area, it was the same. Nothing special but always tasty. its a sushi roll with nice cuts of salmon nigiri on top with a sliver of lemon for zest. I love all 49er rolls and enjoyed this one - even though it was "typical". Highly Recommend.

SPIDER ROLL - the pieces were HUGE. I had one piece was stuffed. The rice was too much and the slices were just too big it didn't feel like sushi. Nothing special about the roll, tasted like typical spider roll that's bigger then it should be. Don't recommend.

Will I be back? I don't know.

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description: Let down by the flavor of the broth (if any, it was just salty). The portions are really large and the service is quick, but not a place I would go back to.
author: Nimeela D.

description:
the ramen noodle broth didnt have much flavor, poke salad was also very bland. the hawaiian roll was ok but it took forever for chef to roll it up. It came out when we finished our ramen....about 30+ mins later.
Terrible customer service n rude waitress. I told waitress my hot sake was not hot cuz i tasted it and it was cold, she replied "it is hot," i kindly asked for it to be a little hotter, she grabbed the jar and turn her back and walk away. After a long wait for the hawaiian roll, i had to ask to make sure it wasnt forgotten, the waitress responded, "he's making it...is tat alright," Im like SURE tat's alrite but how f#% long will it take?! 
feel like i can katana-chop this chick if she gives me another dumb response!
author: Suzie Q.

description:
Chilly summer days in SF calls for a nice, hot bowl of ramen for dinner. Thank you Bay Area summers! 

I opted for the KATANA-YA SPECIAL RAMEN in rich miso soup, which included fried chicken, BBQ pork, fried gyoza, half of a hard boiled egg, and veggies. 

What I loved:
+ Fried chicken pieces
+ Thinly sliced BBQ pork
+ Mushroom slivers and abundant corn
+ Ramen noodles...perfectly chewy with just enough texture and bite

Ambivalent about:
- Fried gyoza...skin was too soggy and the meat interior was a bit cold
- Overly salty soup
- Rich miso soup was a bit heavy and oily for me...will get light or regular next time 

Katana-Ya is a rather cozy restaurant. I wouldn't come here with more than 2-3 ppl in my party. I was able to squeeze into a seat at the counter after work, but there was a line of people already gathering out the door at 6 PM on a weekday evening.

Their ramen bowls are a bit pricey (~$10-12), but the portions are big.

I plan to come back and try different ramen combos! Or maybe a chirashi bowl, mmm...
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Back last night after many years. This was the place for ramen in SF years ago and I remembered that it was quite good. But what happened?
If it wasn't for the fact that I was starving after some Friday happy hour drinking, I don't think I could have eaten the Katanaya ramen that I ordered. The California roll (not fancy, just average what you would expect) was way better than the ramen! 

I chose shoyu (soy sauce broth) over miso. Broth was okay, not as salty as I remembered which is a good thing. Noodles were a bit over cooked and just too much in the bowl. Maybe if it was good noodles, I wouldn't be complaining. Chicken karaage was oily and did not taste freshly fried, potstickers weren't that good either, best part of the bowl was the corn which wasn't even sweet but I'm biased because I love corn and it was white corn. I was a bit upset that it wasn't put into the bowl in one area so I couldn't spoon a spoonful of corn at once easily! 
I was able to eat half the ramen and couldn't eat anymore, even if you paid me or bribed me. During the meal, I told my husband at least three times that I wish we had I some freshly minced garlic to help. He felt the exact same way. $13.95 per Katanaya ramen and with the California roll, bill was $35 excluding tip. I would not want to come back again. 

Not to mention, this place is dimly lit. Maybe this helps hide the appearance of the quality of the food?!? I would choose King of Thai any day over this and would be 10x more satisfied.
author: Iris H.

description: Katana-Ya used to be my go-to place for ramen because I like that the servers are actually Japanese and speak the language. These days, it's really hard to find a Japanese restaurant owned by Japanese. However, lately, their staff is no longer Japanese so it's less authentic and the quality of the food has gone downhill. My miso ramen broth was tasty though not as hot as usual. The ramen texture wasn't as chewy as I'd like it to be and my egg was way overcooked. Their soups still settle my ramen fix on a cold day when I'm shopping in the area and the sushi is still good and plenty but I'm sad that the place is going downhill. In fact, this past Wednesday at 7pm was the first time I've ever seen them without a line at dinner time, granted it was the day before Thanksgiving but the only reason we swung by was because another restaurant in the area had a wait of over an hour.
author: Jen L.

description:
Stayed in SF for a few days to catch the GS vs. CLE series and ended up eating at this late night eatery twice. Open late, Newly expanded with a classy dark den like atmosphere, and pumping the best R&B mix I've ever heard, Katana-ya has the makings of a great spot for a dinner date night.
The food is amazeballs. Pork belly ramen was succulent with a generous 3 pieces of pork belly. 
The fried octopus appetizer was good too. They serve little fried octopuses instead of octopus strips. Good photo opportunity on these guys you instagrammers.
Service was excellent: quick, friendly, and accurate. Nothing more you can ask for.
And yes they serve alcohol. So, win!
author: Jose L.

description:
A small hole-in-the-wall ramen house run by a Japanese family. Came here on a Saturday afternoon (around 3pm) in the hopes of avoiding any wait time. That was indeed the case but 15 min after we were seated, the place was already fully packaged! Great business I guess.

I got the #14 House Special w/ light miso broth, which includes samples of their best toppings. It was a large, hearty bowl, very fitting for a Texan's appetite. The noodles were good and the broth was excellent. A well put together bowl overall.

Now, the fried chicken part is obviously a gimmick towards the non-asian populations. I mean if you know ramen, you just don't put friend chicken or gyoza into ramen. Period. But with that said, the fried chicken (boneless meat) were cooked well and I could see why it's popular among the customers. Actually, now that I think about it, every single person from the 6 tables around us ordered the Fried Chicken bowl. That's pretty impressive.

I would put this place somewhere between 3 to 4 stars but it's late night presence pushes it into a solid 4-star rating! (If I came here late at night, it'll probably be a 5-star.)
author: Aron Y.

description: Hands down best ramen noodles in San Fran! It filling and delicious! You will not be disappointed
author: Joan R.

description: Overpriced and service slow. Also, the first place I've ever been to that didn't have soy paper.
author: Aaron E.

description: This was close to my hotel and hit the spot when we needed a warm bowl of ramen after a freezing summer day exploring San Francisco in shorts. The basic miso ramen was surprisingly good contrary to all the recent negative reviews. Broth was rich and not too salty, noodles perfectly cooked. The Uni donburi was fresh, although not live as you would get from Chelsea market. The servers were polite and attentive.
author: Mike S.

description:
I have always loved this place 
And now they just upgraded the space to the downstairs which is super dope! 
I always get the miso ramen with pork and an extra egg! 
Once I had guests in from San Diego for a week in SF...we ate here 3 out of the 6 nights they were in town! 
That says a lot
author: Kyle J.

description:
During the first week of March, I stayed in downtown SF for about a week and made it a priority to satiate my month-long ramen craving by slurping up that perfect bowl. (*Note: I've been waiting to eat an excellent bowl for two years -shout-outs to all dem joints in San Diego- and would seriously consider stabbing my cousins with wooden chopsticks to get one.) I Yelped "ramen," and Katana-Ya seemed like a convenient and possibly tasty option.

Michael T and I visited one Thursday night looking to grub. But before we could get seated, we had a terrible experience with a staff member. Although, I would love to dive into the crappiness that is the waiting line, you can read Michael's recap here: http://bit.ly/1gX1Xls. It was absolutely ridiculous, and our asses should've walked out because the food was not worth our trouble.

*****
For our meal, we split an order of the agedashi tofu and each had a bowl of the Katana-Ya Ramen.

Agedashi Tofu - nicely battered, perfectly salted, and beautifully plated - I wish we ordered two of these. 

Katana-Ya Ramen - This was such a disappointment in so many ways: 
-Hardboiled egg? Why wasn't it poached?
-Fried gyoza + ramen broth = mushy textures and washed-out flavors.
-The bbq pork, kelp, and corn were just okay.
-Broth lacked deep flavors, hence the MSG (that's also clearly noted on the menu, btw.) If you're looking for chicken or pork broth that's slow cooked for several hours, this is not the place. I felt like it was hastily thrown together.

I left unsatisfied with my trip to Katana-Ya, unfortunately. I guess my quest for great ramen in SF continues...
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Oh.. it's okay. I don't think it was anything special at all. My friend and I got in right away, but this place definitely has a wait if you're less fortunate. I wouldn't wait for it again if I had a choice.

We both opted for the katana-ya ramen, which comes with gyoza and karaage. I asked the waitress if the gyoza and karaage came on the side, and she said yes. Turns out, she meant she'd put mine on the side, and my friend's ended up in the bowl which I assume is normal. Ain't nobody trying to eat soggy gyoza/karaage!!

I wasn't a huge fan of the noodles itself, like it lacked any springiness.. and the broth (I opted for miso) was just not memorable. That said, it was a ridiculously filling meal and it was pretty cheap.

So manage your expectations, I'd say.

They do take credit! :D and have a pretty late-running happy hour.
author: Vivian H.

description: The Ramen-soup is tasty! It is more than enough quantity for one person
author: Arjan N.

description:
Generally, a good meal lasts only for a day. 2 days if it was so exceptionally good and if you reminisce about it the day after.

I have to give props to katanaya for reminding me of it for 3 days. And only because I've been peeing out my butt for the past three days because of it. I suppose I should have heeded the warning yelp puts out about their amazingly low health/food safety score, but we had already ordered by the time we saw the warning. I hate you so much Katanaya, I would have never imagined I would be in this much pain.

I mean, I did a lot of dumb stuff in San Francisco while I was there for the week, but deciding to eat at this hellhole was by far the dumbest decision I have ever made.

My two friends and I sat down and spent 47 dollars on the grossest "ramen" I have ever eaten. In fact it takes the cake for being the worst food I have eaten in San Francisco by far. In fact I can also say this was the worst ramen I have ever had. I mean my blacked out drunk friend made better instant ramen than this.

The service was terrible. I can't stress this enough.

The noodles tasted like undercooked instant noodles, so bad.

What's the point of throwing fried dumplings and chicken into the soup? Isn't it fried to make it crispy? Like whats the point of it? Throwing that stuff into the soup just makes it gummy and disgusting. On top of that, I have never had to spit out so much gristle that came within the dumplings either. I had an entire napkin full of it. 

The soup of the ramen was so headache inducingly salty. 

Needless to say none of us ended up finishing our disgusting food.

Heed my warning (and my diarrhea and my puke.) Avoid this place at all costs. For what I paid, I could've gotten an entire platter of pizza from pizza. And I wouldn't have food poisoning.

I don't think I've ever been this mad about food before.

Nor have I peed out my butt this much. 

No thanks Katanaya. Don't pass go, don't collect $200.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Katanaya USED to be my go-to ramen fix in the downtown area. Katanaya USED to have good ramen and good sides (chahan, Japanese-style salad, appetizers, etc). Don't let the same decor fool you. The current restaurant is not what it USED to be in 2010. The service is still attentive where water is being refilled without asking. I am sad and disappointed the menu has changed and food isn't as good as what it once was. The portion size however has increase so that is deserving of the lackluster 2 stars. 

P.S. do not bother ordering the house salad. I had given my order before finding out the change in ownership. The house salad glaringly highlights the drastic difference of the current vs previous restaurant. The house salad is now a few pieces of chopped iceburg lettuce and literally a quarter of avocado. Plus the kitchen managed to only finish making the salad much later after we had already received our other appetizers and entrees. Lesson learned tonight. A restaurant with the same name that looks the same, might not be the same same afterall.
author: Mindy C.

description: Don't be fooled by the long lines. The vibe is fun but the food is not great. The soft boiled eggs and meat had cold spots, seeming as they had been cooked hours ago and were just pulled out of the refrigerators. The gyoza was pretty greasy as well.  The broth was fine. My friend, who will eat just about anything, barely touched his food. Everything was over priced and they are outstandingly understaffed.
author: Katharine P.

description: First time in San Fran, but this place reminds me of home. Good food, great service, very inviting atmosphere. Had their ramen and unagi, authentic and tasty.
author: West Y.

description:
I have been here a couple of dozen times over the course of about 5 years when I  am in San Francisco. It never has disappointed.  I was surprised to see the new larger and more upscale location downstairs from the original, but still a great place.  I have to admit I liked the grittier vibe of the old spot,but still one of my favorite restaurants in the country.  And I travel a ton.

Always very friendly, fast and attentive service.  The sushi and Ramen are both superb.  If you leave hungry or disappointed I would be surprised. 

Tonight I had a Rainbow Roll that was Very fresh and huge with real crab. I also had a bowl of spicy vegetarian Ramen. I think the bowl could serve two and the flavors were extraordinary as usual.  

If you are in the city do yourself a favor and find this little gem. Shocking to see less than 4 stars now as its still wonderful from my point of view.
author: Brian B.

description:
3 stars. It's good, but nothing impressive.

First of all, there was no line on a Saturday evening. You know it's good when there's a line of people waiting to go. Second of all, I think it was just okay. Maybe we should have stayed with the tonkotsu, but we got the special that day. The meat was fatty but the nonfat parts were too tough...if that makes sense. 

It's not worth going out of your way for in my opinion, but maybe I just ordered something wrong? Anyway, it's an okay spot for ramen.
author: Ariana V.

description:
Large bowls of ramen with rich and flavorful, but not heavy, broths (unless you ask actually ask for the heavy broth -- which you can do!). Noodles are nice and chewy. I'm not sure if these are housemade or imported, but I'm happy with them either way.

The BBQ Pork chashu ramen w/ miso is: Flavorful. Spicy. Yum. Solid favorite for $11. 
No soft-boiled egg in the chashu ramen though =[

The Katana-ya ramen w/ heavy miso broth is hearty and I want to say creamy. There is too much stuff in this $12.5 bowl of ramen for me. Egg. Corn. Fried chicken. AND dumplings. However, the thick-skinned fried dumplings provide a great contrast for the noodle soup.

I saw the combo for $14, but what looks like house ramen didn't appeal to me today though it still looks good.

Pricey ramen, but worth it.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Food was subpar considering how pricey it is. Bland broth, egg was not soft boiled and has no flavor. Salmon sashimi was OK.

Also, they no longer accept groupon. That's just unfortunate when you go out of your way to visit the restaurant solely because of Groupon.
author: Jerel A.

description: I loved the look and feel of this place being down in the basement was such a cool environment. I ordered sushi and I was disappointed, I was hoping for better taste and just more from my rolls. I wouldn't get sushi again. However the others in my party all ordered the ramen and were very impressed. They had great flavor and HUGE! if I come back I skip the sushi rolls and stick with the ramen.
author: Lori C.

description: I would rather give them 0 stars but I'm not sure how to do that. My husband and I got referred to this restaurant. We went in, waited for a table and got seated. We sat at the table for 30 minutes and no one came to our table. People who came after us were getting drinks and food and no waiter had even came over to get our order. We eventually got up and left. Very disappointed.
author: Liz A.

description:
* My ratings only apply for their ramen


 I had high expectations for their ramen.. Especially seeing how long the line can get for this place. I think it's because this place is located in the heart of SF, tourists go here because of the hype. 
If you're a ramen fan like me, this place is mediocre.

I do give them props for the kind customer service, but their food quality is meh.. For the following reasons:
* their broth is dense and watered down
* they overload their bowl with noodles
* and the boiled eggs are entirely boiled, the yolk is solid hard.. Usually it would be soft boiled and the yolk would still be runny. 

I also ordered a side of tempura, it was under fried, so it tasted greasy and soggy.

I'm almost sorry for my downing reviews, but this is all my honest opinion. Not the best ramen place to go to. Maybe their sushi rolls or rice dishes are better? 

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description: Seriously, this is some of the best ramen you'll get on the late night, especially after some drinking. It's small and quant but so worth the struggle to find parking.
author: Madisen W.

description: We enjoyed the atmosphere and decor of this basement restaurant.  Excellent service.  The ramen was decent.
author: Mike H.

description: The Raman was pretty good! There was no egg though. I got pork belly, miso for about $15. They played a lot of 90s hip hop which was a plus. A little too dimly lit for my taste though.
author: Christian M.

description:
The texture of the ramen is my favorite thing here. And you can customize your bowl to make it exactly what you want. 

It's a small space and if it's raining and you're by the door, order it a little more spicy to keep you warm.
author: Kathryn T.

description: I was craving Japanese today and I happened to stumble on this place. It's a hole in the wall and you basically have to go downstairs to reach the restaurant. I was seated right away and I ordered the combination dinner which included either ramen/soba/udon and a choice of a mini donburi. The price averaged 12-17 per person, but the portions are pretty big and very filling. The one problem I had was that they focused more on the delivery aspect of their restaurant rather than the customers sitting inside. It took a long time just to receive my check, the to go box, and even to refill the water. Just improve the service, otherwise it was pretty good.
author: Lorraine J.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet. Katana-ya is one of my favorite restaurants in SF. It's not fancy, the service is hit or miss, and the wait for a table is often a pain. Despite all of that, I can count on this place to quickly bring me a ridiculously large portion of deliciousness for a very decent price. My favorite item is the Katana-ya ramen, which comes with a ton of stuff in it (fried chicken, pork, boiled egg, corn, seaweed, etc) and is always far too much for me to eat - I usually save half for lunch the next day. 

It's not the fanciest and the physical location is a bit grimy, but I just stay selective about who I take there or recommend it to. You should not go there if you prefer to get dressed up and demand perfect service and pristine conditions and zero wait time on every occasion. I've never eaten a disappointing meal there, and when I'm in the mood for consistently good, inexpensive large portions in a hole-in-the-wall environment, this is where I go.
author: Sarah G.

description:
This place has changed.  It used to be one of my most favorite ramen places in the city when it was upstairs.  We used to come every other week to get our ramen craving satisfied.

The noodles are different now it doesn't have the same texture, and the pork belly isn't as fall apart awesome as it once was.  For $16/bowl, I wanted the old Katana-ya.  Broth and other ingredients are still good (corn and seaweed).  Maybe it was just an off night.
author: Tori C.

description:
Another disappointment in ramen in NorCal. This place has such good ratings too! Another false hype ness on Yelp! Gotta be careful about that! I think this place has higher ratings more for their drinking an chilling atmosphere than for their ramen 

They were known for their Extra Spicy Ramen so I ordered that. The boyfriend for the BBQ Pork Ramen. Both ramen a were extremely oily. Very oily. To the point where it literally was like drinking oil, butter, and bile all at once. No joke. And there's no flavor in the ramens!! I normally love drinking everything broth but this was too gross. Furthermore, both broths taste very diluted  

Decoration is very weird, colorful, and abstract. NOt typical of an authentic Japanese restaurant that I'm used to! :( Bathroom was weird! Door doesn't really lock but it's kind of locked at the same time? It's weird...

Pros:
-Opens late until 0130AM in case you night owls are desperate for some....bad ramen :D
-I like their noodles though! Same type of noodles as you would get for peanut sauce noodles for all you Taiwanese people...you know what I'm talking about ;) 
-they don't just serve ramen here..also sushi and alcohol! The vibe is kind of like a bar restaurant. A lot of people come to drink and chill. So their specialty isn't in ramen :(
-you can ask for either light or rich density for your broth

Cons: 
-oily broth 
-not flavorful
-bad service (we had to keep reminding them to bring us our waters!)
-a lot of their items are crossed off on their menu...hmm wonder why? I was disappointed cause I wanted to try mabo tofu ramen but it was crossed off :( 
-Extra Spicy Ramen? Was not spit AT ALL. Just really red lol

Conclusion: If you must, must eat ramen in norcal, I highly suggest Ramen Dojo :)
author: Cuc N.

description:
I signed the clipboard for what I thought was the entrance, then got escorted through another door and seated at a tiny table by the window. The menu is confused, they're trying to do too much and it shows. I'm a ramen snob. The ramen is huge, but getting served a huge amount of mediocre is not my cuppa tea.

I saw a termite-type bug chillin out by the window sill. I still ate the ramen, but I wasn't happy about it.

Dirty, dingy, okay service, not great ramen. I wasn't happy about it. I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Vicky E.

description: Interesting location downstairs. Wait wasn't too bad for a Thursday night at 9:30. Only 10 minutes. Make sure you sign up on the list at the bottom of the stairs. Starting the Rock and roll was great!!! The eel and avocado was very generous and in good proportion to the rice. The ramen was only okay. We got the charsui ramen and the katanaya ramen, both in miso. The noodles were okay as was the broth.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Having been a long-time fan here, I was super excited to hear about the new restaurant makeover that would be taking place where it was now being moved underground!  I finally got a chance to experience this tonight when I went to grab my usual late night ramen.

When you walk downstairs, it was surprising to see how spacious the new dine-in area is and nice music bumping in the background as usual.  The owner from what I remember is also really friendly and has been accommodating on past occasions.  This time, I ordered the original ramen with soy and added corn.  After eating a few bites, my throat began to hurt from how salty the broth was.  I also was served with no napkins and had to hail my server again for some napkins.  Additionally, the soy and chili bottles were dirty and I got grease all over my fingers.  Gross! Next time, maybe someone should wipe them down especially since tonight was a slow night...

I figured it was time to order something else, since my ramen was barely edible.  I called my server over and asked how much it would cost to add a Salmon Don (as part of the combo special).  He seemed confused and said he didn't know what that was.  I then asked for a menu that was sitting at a nearby table and when I pointed out what I was referring to, he looked offended.  Then, he said, " I think it's 16 or 17".  I said, "Is it 16, 17..which one is it?  If you're not sure, maybe you can check with the manager".  He snapped back at me and said, "I'm the manager". I explained to him that my soup was too salty and I couldn't eat it and needed to order something else and he completely ignored my concern.  Then he said, "It's 16 and 17 cents".  What the heck was his problem.   I was so appalled at his attitude!  Never seen him before so I think he must be new.  Regardless- Katanaya: a word of advice.  TRAIN YOUR STAFF BETTER, PLEASE.  Attitude and poor service not acceptable for a historic local establishment like yours.

Also, the portions are same price, but heavily reduced in portion.  Quality poor.  Too overrated for my tastebuds!
author: Phan ..

description: We had an amazing meal. We tried the house ramen, sushi rolls, saki, Goya, seaweed salad. We could not stop eating. The miso broth was so rich and flavorful, the noodles had the perfect bite. I will be back!
author: Kerry S.

description:
Came here twice now and I have decided that this place is legit.

Keep in mind that this place is uber tiny so it's easy to miss, which in turn can make the wait for a table quite legnthy. Also, because of the small venue, I HIGHLY suggest NOT coming here if you are with a large group or don't mind not sitting all together.

They are not only limited on table space, but with menu's as well. Before we were seated I had asked to view the menu since the person I went with has never been and they said they were all out. (how can you run out of menus?! at least have a togo menu)

We ordered the shoyu base ramen with gyoza, tempura and rice.

The shoyu broth is really good, not too salty and had a ton of flavor. The noodles were yummy.

The gyoza was alright, they were tiny and only gave 4. They gave a ton of rice and tempura though, that was tasty and had a thick terryaki sauce that topped it off.

We washed it all down with warm sake.
author: Jerrica N.

description:
Super tiny spot that's open late. 

I wasn't very hungry, so I had my friend get the ramen combo with a side of ikura and salmon with rice so I could eat the rice bowl. 

One other friend got a roll and the other got ramen.

The sushi items came out first. The ikura and salmon were good, but portion is a bit small. Understandable though, because it's meant to just be a side dish with the ramen.  

Had a bite of the soy ramen, it was ok but nothing special.

Service was quite slow. 

A decent place to go late at night in a convenient location.
author: Noelle H.

description: Good Stuff.... The Miso was Delish. My Girlfriend underestimated the Spicy, So be careful.
author: Robert L.

description:
Gave this place a try and didn't know what to expect. Honestly for a party of 5 we did wait almost an hour, and other smaller parties were helped even after showing up after us 
I loved it!! I am satisfied and have a picky brother that the waitress kept coming back to make sure everything was to his liking and that's pretty awesome!
Four stars because of the long wait but other than that it was a nice dinner.
The vibe of the place is cool and a little small but I was to busy enjoying the meal to even worry about what was going on around me.
author: Nicolas B.

description:
This is one of those places you'll randomly stumble upon when walking up on Geary and immediately you'll be turned off by the ridiculous wait you see outside but let me tell y'all IT IS SOOOO WORTH THE WAIT!!

My old coworker Josephine N. first brought me here years ago and since then this has become my ramen go to whenever I am in the city. I usually go with the extra spicy ($1.50 more) tofu ramen with additional toppings (kimchi and corn) and their soft shell crab appetizer is pretty much a home run.

Service is a hit or a miss but cut them some slack..with the amount of people that's coming in and out, they aren't really looking to have a nice conversation with you..basically get in and get out. Space is incredibly tight like most SF joints but you'll be too busy slurpin' away so you won't notice TOO much the guy that's literally 2 inches away from you, also slurpin' away.
author: Jenn K.

description: The wait time on a Friday night for a group of 6 is a long wait! Be prepared to wait if you have a larger group! The staff was super super nice and we had a chance to meet the owner! You can tell they care about their customers and love their restaurant. The food was definitely worth the wait! I recommend to add the spicy sea weed! So so great! Check this place out!
author: J.C. F.

description:
Small place in the basement off Geary Street. As it was the basement, there were no windows or cell phone reception. The restaurant doesn't have WiFi either. 

The Ramen was just okay. I ordered the miso-based Katanya Ramen (which is different from the regular Ramen in that it comes with two fried goyza, two pieces of chicken karage and corn for a $2 up charge), and my combination came with a tonkatsu don. The Ramen was fine, but again, I've had better. 

The tonkatsu don, on the other hand, was terrible! The rice was undercooked and the fried katsu pieces were greasy and overly-fried. The tonkatsu don comes with a lettuce salad drenched in dressing. 

My wife had the combination set with a regular miso-based Ramen and an unagi don. The unagi don was actually quite good and the rice was surprisingly moist. Not sure why there was a difference in the rice between the two dons, but it was night and day. 

Other notable point is that alcohol is extremely overpriced here. For example, a draft glass of Japanese beer was $9 per mug. Other alcoholic beverages were even more. 

The waitresses were very nice, friendly and warm.
author: Joe M.

description: Food was decent.  We had 2 ramens and one rice bowl (don).  It's not as good as our usual place but OK if you're craving some ramen.  We didn't have any sushi to know if it was any good or not.  We didn't have the best service though.  Did not seem to be all that efficient in seating tables.  And they were not all that attentive in taking our order (or bringing the check when we were done).
author: L N.

description:
Favorite ramen in the city. Get the Katana-Ya bowl.

Pro tip: If you eat in the portions are a touch bigger.
author: Michail Y.

description:
I've been sitting here waiting for the bill for the past 20 minutes, and although we've reminded the waiter 3 times, there's no sign of progress anytime soon.............so I thought I'd use this prime opportunity to leave a review. 

General atmosphere/decor = 5 stars. Very cool spot. 

Food = 5 stars. Honestly, we all loved what we got! (Both ramen + donburi bowls)

Price = 4 stars. A little pricier than normal. But not bad. 

The wait = 1.5 stars. I'm totally taking into account that we're a little larger of a group and that it was a Sunday night, but the food took about half an hour, and getting the bill was even longer. All together, with wait time, ordering, and paying........we spent 2.5 hours here

Would go again because it's a cool spot. But really disappointed because the experience went from "awesome" to "eh"
author: Chelsey C.

description: Yummy ramen, short wait time and easy order through Yelp. Really liked the broth! I ordered the regular ramen. Awkward waiting area but overall good experience.
author: Vanessa S.

description: quite possibly one of the worst ramen spots in the city
author: Jon C.

description:
Mmmmm!!! Nothing like really good ramen during "June gloom" season. A little hard to find, but worth the search. There was a short wait for our party of six. 

The ramen was great - I added kimchi to mine. Delightful!
author: Hal W.

description:
Newly renovated! The ramen is handmade and super long and fresh.
Talked with the owner today had such a great outlook on life and his place! Great to the see the place thriving.
author: Holly B.

description: Walked in around 5pm and it was quiet with only a couple people. I ordered the regular ramen spicy and my boyfriend ordered the special ramen.  I LOVED my Ramen and so did he!  Server was friendly and attentive. Small place but don't let others make your mind up on eating here. It was delicious and quick!
author: Theresa M.

description: A great little find and it helped a hangover. I ordered a pork belly ramen and uni/ikura don set. It was a lot of food and the price was extremely reasonable, I want to say under $15 for the set. Definately coming back.
author: Adrian K.

description:
I was craving for some ramen and found this place on yelp. It didn't have the greatest reviews but it was close by so my boyfriend and I decided to just eat here. Upon coming, I already knew there would be a wait. So we put our name on the list and we went to the Mexican restaurant next door to get drinks at the bar while we waited. That was a great idea because we were sat about 5 minutes after coming back. 

Be careful when leaving while waiting for your name on the wait list, especially if you're in parties of 2. 2's get seated quickly. If they call your name and you're not present, they will mark you off and you will have to put your name on the bottom of the list again. 

Now on to the food. I ordered the ramen that came with 2 chicken karagee, 2 gyozas and 2 sliced pork. I chose miso broth and spicy. I recommend getting the chicken and gyoza on the side so they won't get soggy. They were perfect and crispy :) 

We also had sushi to start before the ramen. We ordered the salmon avocado roll. Simple, yet delicious! 

My boyfriend didn't really care for his ramen. He said it was okay. I don't think he really liked the miso. I think I liked the miso broth more if spicy. (He ordered the sliced pork ramen with no spice miso broth) 

WELL, I LIKED IT :) it was good! I would recommend it. There are A LOT of mixed reviews and hit or misses. You might like it :)
author: Alina T.

description:
Very good Ramen! I ordered vegetable and added Kimchi, gyoza, fried chicken and egg.
Gyoza was a deep fried style I didn't care for.
Fried chicken bits were tasty! 
I had 1 level of spice and it was pretty spicy! 
Servers were available as soon as they saw I needed them. It was very busy and they were doing a great job!
Noodles and broth were very tasty!
I recommend!
author: T B.

description:
Best ramen I've had in San Francisco. Didn't think it was possible to find legit ramen in the city anymore after so many fails and disappointments everywhere else. The bbq pork miso ramen and spicy miso ramen were both enjoyable.

Wait is fairly short (by SF standards) even when you have lots of groups ahead of you (~20min with 5 ahead of us).

Not really a place to hangout unless dingy claustrofuck spaces are your thing.
author: Tian Q.

description:
Food: 5
Service: 3
Uniqueness: 4

----------------------------------------------------------------
I was definitely disappointed to see the poor food quality scores for this place because it is one of my favorite Ramen restaurants in the world. As to other reviews' comments on the poor service, those criticisms are generally warranted when the place has long waits during dinner rushes. Try to get in before 6:30/7 and you won't have to deal with that as much.

Otherwise, it definitely fits the bill of a 'hole-in-the-wall' type of restaurant but those lines out the door speak to the tastiness of their fare. Go whole hog and get the Katanaya ramen - you will not be disappointed. It comes with Japanese fried chicken that is something very unique that I haven't experienced in other Ramens. Also, the spicy and very spicy are not that hot but add a great amount of flavor to the broth.

I'm still a fan of this place and will make an effort to experience it again.
author: Jeff W.

description:
We came here after the lunch crowds left. The food was bad, the soup tasted really weird. After reading the other comments here, I wonder if they were really unhygienic.
Furthermore, the service was the worst among the restaurants I've visited in San Francisco. It was absolutely atrocious! We sat in for nearly twenty minutes before one staff came over and took our order. There was one particular staff who served us with an extremely bad service attitude - she literally just slammed the food on our table, mumbling our orders with her back facing us. We were stunned for a minute. What kind of service was that? 
I recommend that anyone who craves for legitimate ramen should head to another restaurant further down the road instead (:
author: Sherry L.

description:
Tiny ramen restaurant with limited seating, so be prepared to brave the cold weather while waiting outside to hear your name called. The location of this place is good, as it is a little over a block away from Union Square, and they are open late (~1:30am or so most nights) which is great for late night cravings. 

My go-to choices would be the spicy tofu or butter corn ramen with light miso soup.  Even for the lighter choice, the broth has good flavor and the portions are large enough to last a couple meals. Unfortunately the service has never been that great when we've gone, as the waitresses always seem to be in a rush to take our order and get us outta there as fast as they can.
author: Kim D.

description: I'm not really a Ramen person and tend to hate all things hot liquid but this place was pretty damn tasty. I got a traditional Ramen with pork and veggie. The broth was super flavourful, marrow tasting, and greasy. The meat in my and my friends Ramen seemed a little questionable but was fine. Cooking kills all bacteria. Service is slow and not very attentive, you'll be asking for everything.  Not the cleanest place either and can get pretty loud and and crowded. All that aside I'd gladly return.
author: Sabrina D.

description:
My friend and I met up at Katana-Ya for ramen after work last week and good thing we arrived early (by 6:30 pm)! We were able to walk in and get seated immediately since it was just 2 of us. By the time we left, there was a line out the door of people waiting to get a seat.

I ordered a bowl of miso ramen - it was OK (decent but not out of this world). the ramen tastes like it came out of a bag and the broth was not memorable. It did fill me up though. I also ordered a bowl of uni/salmon roe over rice. It was quite expensive! 
Again, the rice bowl was not memorable either, as the salmon roe didn't seem all that fresh - i would give my experience and food a rating of 3 to 3.5 stars. the restaurant interior is quite crammed, since it's small and seats are limited.

I think what it has going for it, is the great location of being right in Union Square and high foot traffic. :) Probably wouldn't come here again if I had other ramen choices!
author: Yonnie C.

description: The place has not changed a lot, since my last visit. The Katana-Ya Ramen (combination meat ramen) is still very good.  During my last visit, I ordered it with the Miso flavor broth. The ramen bowl was very good. The miso broth was flavorful, not too salty. The noodles were cooked perfectly.  Also, their Kimchi Fried Rice was pretty good.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: I have never been so dissatisfied with a restaurant's staff as I am with the one here. We were a 6 person group and we were told that the wait was 30 minutes, but we waited almost 2 hours. None of the staff tried accommodating for us, or offered us any ways to get a seat faster. There were countless of other people behind us in the list being seated before us, and they didn't talk to us unless we approached them ourselves. When we expressed our discomfort to the manager, he simply brushed us off and pretty much blamed us for their terrible service. Food itself was subpar at best but a restaurant that doesn't care about its customers needs to get their act together. NEVER COMING HERE AGAIN.
author: Emilio C.

description: Local find, wasn't expecting much from this small place but the sushi, drinks and service were really good. Reasonable prices and lots of choices
author: Scott S.

description:
Conveniently located next to my hotel, this place was an easy choice for a late-nite bite and the line indicated we'd struck ramen gold. Unfortunately the wait built a certain level of false hope and left us with a solid ramen experience somewhere between three and a four stars. 

I opted for the extra spicy ramen - just enough spice. Not enough to make your nose run but just enough to give you a little bite. I have a pretty high threshold for spicy food so I'd say this was about a 6 out of 10 when it comes to spice level. Something easily tolerable for fire eaters but definitely not ideal for someone easily stricken by Taco Bell hot sauce. It's loaded with all the standard fixins but a soft boiled egg rather than hard boiled would take this bowl up a notch or two. Perhaps it's an option?

Divey, small, dated, quick, cheapish and tacky. Not a bad little spot.
author: Brad B.

description:
Was a little disappointed. A little bit of a wait for such a small place. The decor was ok and the service was at least fast. 

I ordered the Katanaya Ramen (pork, chicken karaage, and gyoza inside) for $12/$13. The broth was very "separated" and was sort of watery and bitter. There were a lot of noodles which were cooked pretty well though. I've had better Ramen in both San Diego and LA.
author: Drew C.

description:
My friend and I ordered two katanaya ramens. The miso soup base was great, and we liked how large the bowls were.

However, the ingredients in general weren't fantastically made. The egg was cold and overcooked, and the dumplings didn't seem to be freshly cooked. The pork didn't taste that good either.

I don't have much to say, but that I've tasted better ramen.
author: Natalie C.

description:
The waitress is nice, and ramen itself is not bad, just the noodle. But sorry, the roast pork tastes like paper and are you sure this is 'half - boiled egg'? I would call it 120% cooked egg... 

Don't think I will come back.
author: Seddie S.

description: food tastes like it's been in the fridge for two weeks. Noodles were soggy, soup was rotten tasting, kakuni wasn't tender nor Japanese, rice wasn't well cooked (hard and dry).
author: Justine T.

description:
I always hate to write bad reviews, but I'm going to have to rain on everyone's parade.
As an avid Ramen Lover, I was taken back with the watered down soup base & un-flattering noodles. 
Perhaps they forgot to add one more ingredient that day? Or maybe their soup base is geared towards their community's liking. What ever the reason, I couldn't finish my Chashu ramen bowl. 
Other than the soup disaster, their egg was amaze. Chashu,amaze. Green tea, amaze. Customer service, amaze.
Unfortunately, the broth is the heart of any ramen bowl. With no heart, there is no life. That ramen that was served was dead.
author: Sherry T.

description: Delicious. I had a rainbow roll and a vegetable ramen bowl. The rainbow was perfectly rolled and homemade egg noodles in the ramen were perfect
author: Nick U.

description: This is actually 2.7. The service is pretty quick. If you are 4 or less people, you don't wait too long. But let's talk about the taste. The noodles are fine. They taste like any other ramen shop. The broth however is very strong. Strong is not in a good way. It seems they add too much salt to make the flavor come out, but you feel bad after finishing the meal. As for portions, it's pretty small. I would only come back if nothing else was open.
author: Marcus J.

description: We came to the place since it is very popular. After 30 minuets wait we were seated. I don't see they serve food by order. People came later had their food earlier. They forgot about the fried rice for my kid. After 3times push, they finally served it and no sorry at all.
author: Dongmin Z.

description:
Love their vegetarian ramen. I am not an vegetarian but will be a good place to go if you want some hot vegetarian ramen here. 
Super yummy especially picked the miso-based (but not for vegetarian, v need to place vegetable base soup) and adding kimchi.
author: Derek C.

description: Service was good, and the broth of the miso ramen was quite tasty. I ordered the pork belly miso ramen, and the pork belly was cooked well, the noodles had a good texture, and the broth tasted great. Everything came pretty quickly. What more can I say- it's a traditional ramen house with good food!
author: Owen C.

description:
The long line had always stopped me from trying Katana-Ya out but the stars aligned and I walked right in without a wait on a holiday, late in the afternoon, amidst a Bart strike that emptied Union Square.  

It turns out the real reason for the line is that the space is pretty small but the folks are efficient and turn tables around fairly quickly. It's a pretty expansive menu with items ranging from the apps to ramen to sushi to rice bowls. If torn between choices, they have half-and-half specials. I went for the namesake Katana-Ya ramen in miso broth and it was decent. I thought the broth was flavorful and the variety of ingredients (pork, fried chicken, fried potstickers, corn, scallion, and seaweed) was a nice touch. If I were to order it again though I would probably ask for the fried items on the side. Alas, I was a little disappointed with the consistency of the noodles compared to other ramen joints - I wished there was a little more spring to their noodles. 

All things considered, I wouldn't mind coming back to Katana-Ya but not if the line is ridiculous. It's decent ramen but there are better alternatives in the city.
author: Jon L.

description:
The noodle is basic and tasty: soup, noodle, and meat. Not too much going on. 

Bathroom smells. 

Usually you don't expect Japanese restaurant's bathroom to smell but this one does. It is more of a bar feel inside and very dim but feels kinda dirty too . If you are seekingarrangement.com, you would come here to meet your lady friend
author: Strella B.

description: It is the worst restaurant in San Francisco. Terrible Shrimp Tempura Roll and Katana-Ya Ramen.This place is the most disgusting. Don't waste your money.
author: May H.

description:
Not the best Ramen I have had. This place is really small and cramped. We got in at a really good time. As soon as we sat down, 5 minutes later people were storming in trying to get seated. They give you a really big portion so if you're a light water you might want to share it with someone. I ordered the Spicy Beef Ramen... What can I say about this dish? First, everything that was in the bowl was very soggy... Did not like that at all... I asked for extra spicy but it wasn't even all that spicy.. Over all this place is ok. I wouldn't come back here again! 

Finding parking was a bitch! We drove around for 30 minutes just to end up parking in a garage for a flat fee!

Also, service here is terrible. They don't even come by to make sure whether you need your drinks refilled or not. One of the girls here with short brownish hair also come off very stuck up. They need more extensive training! I gave them two stars because we were seated very quick and our orders were taken very fast...
author: Kelly L.

description: Had their fried baby octopus appetizer as well as the combination BBQ Pork Don with Ramen. My sister had the combination Curry Don with Ramen. We asked the waitress if the curry came with any meat she said yes it comes with pork. When the Curry came there wasn't any meat it in, which was kind of a bummer. All in all the food was amazing and the staff was very friendly.
author: Janelle T.

description: Absolutely delicious! Wrote our name on the list. We were seated within 10 mins (Saturday night around 7:30). Had the Katanaya ramen. So freaking good!!! Also had the Lava Roll which was delicious as well. Super fast service. Ramen came out in less than 5 mins. My noodle craving has been satisfied!
author: Nayan S.

description:
Avoid this restaurant! Absolutely horrible place for Ramen! It can't even count as a Ramen shop!

The environment has noting related with a ramen shop. The noodle is not ramen noodle. Taste like instant noodle. The Gyoza is not how the Gyoza should be. The skin is way too thick!

The bbq pork is not how I had before in any Japanese ramen shop. The bbq pork is SOURED! It is DISGUSTING! The only thing taste right is the ice water! I will NEVER come back ever!
author: Neal H.

description: Stumbled upon this place many years ago, tiny hole in the wall with steamed up windows and the best ramen in town. Fast forward to yesterday. Tiny place is gone and moved to bigger downstairs location next door. I didn't like being downstairs, claustrophobic and dark. Looked forward to the ramen to make up for the ambiance. It was not the same. Too salty, no depth in flavor, pork tasted old and noodles overcooked. The tonkatsu and rice in donburi was cold. My sister had the gyoza, and the dipping sauce wasn't vinegar based. When asked for vinegar, they said they didn't have any which is a lie because you need vinegar to make sushi. When we got the check I was surprised to see that the tip was already added with no option to alter it. Service was meh. Felt like we were asking too much when requesting things. We were given a comment sheet with the bill, so I let them know how bad it was and that we won't be back. Hope they see this and do something about it. Such a shame. I used to recommend this place to visitors from out of town. Not anymore.
author: D. C.

description:
Sadly my updated review for my old favorite ramen place is now going down to just 1 Star. (That's how disappointed I am with Katanya).  Feels like this old favorite of mine is going downhill.   I am definitely taking my ramen cravings to another Ramen place.   I used to love their spicy miso ramen n was here every 2 weeks with friends, n now it's time to give my business to Ramen Dojo and other SF ramen houses. 

The service n evening/night staff terrible, pretty rude folks who doesn't seem to want to be there.  That really influence my dining experience, n I am definitely not coming back. Huge No No!!

N please don't EVER bother ordering take out.  They never separate the noodles n broth, N it's really DRY and SOGGY  n takes away the yummy flavors of the spicy ramen. N they need to add more broth to the take outs.  I threw out my ramen, it was that bad!   See attached pics below. BAD Takeout!!
author: ThuZ W.

description:
If I could give zero stars I would. Another restaurant I was suckered into because of the number of reviews. Not sure why there are so many good reviews for this place. Definitely overrated. I ordered the katana-ya ramen because I assumed that since it had the restaurants name in it, it must be good. Once the server brought out my bowl I knew I was horribly mistaken. karage and gyoza in my ramen? I guess the 3500 people that gave this place a good review like soggy fried appetizers and oily soup. The gyoza tasted more like Chinese pan fried dumplings than Japanese style gyoza. It's just not the same. The consistency of the noodles were also rubbery and the soft boiled was more of a hard boiled egg. I've made instant noodles that tasted better than the ramen here. 

I didn't mention anything about the service... Because there wasn't any.
author: KJ H.

description: Really not worth. Expected more from this restaurant but the broth was not flavorful, the noodles average at best, and the meat was dry and tasteless. Sushi was okay but overpriced. Not coming back to this place any time soon.
author: Louisa Z.

description: Pork belly ramen was a bomb! Although, I paid for it later with a pork belly of my own ;)
author: Radif S.

description: I ordered the regular miso ramen. The slices of pork were very tough. The noodles were all bundled together. The toppings were all very plain and did not add extra flavour to the ramen. I would not recommend this place for ramen.
author: James S.

description: Overall great food. Really enjoyed it. Definitely would recommend it to family and friends.
author: Forest Z.

description: Very good Ramen. A little pricey on the sushi rolls, but could just be the prices for the area.
author: Mark C.

description: Got in and seated quickly, but had a lot of unexplained charges on our bill, the waitress didn't really explain things well when we asked questions either. When we paid, she didn't bring us back our change and I guess assumed she was getting a 30% tip for bad service. We had to ask for our money back from another server because ours wasn't paying attention to us.
author: Nicholas A.

description: Tiny place, delicious ramen, but questionable cleanliness. I got sick rather promptly upon leaving (not sure when the last time I had food poisoning was but it's been at least a decade). I also got the vegetarian ramen, which makes it worse (how can they contaminate cooked veggies??).
author: Sophie A.

description: Terrible service. Waited 30min and got skipped, had to wait longer an none of the staff hellped or cared. Dont know how the food taste because we left after the long wait.
author: Felton A.

description:
February 13th, Friday. The day before valentines day, and it's empty. Barely a line, so score for us!!! Only my 2nd visit but it was as good as the first time I had it here.

Soup bases are the same for all the ramen you choose (as in if you decided on Miso, or Soy Sauce, its the same base they use for everything, just different toppings)

Regular Ramen - For the one that's not that hungry, which was me in my case. The toppings are only chasiu, onions and seaweed.

Katanaya Ramen - If you want a variety of ingredients in your ramen, this is the one to get. It comes with half a hard boiled egg, chasiu, corn, 2 pieces of chicken, and 2 pieces of dumpling, onion, and seaweed. The chicken and dumpling are absolutely delicious, and if you waited a long time for this place, I recommend you get this. It'll definitely be more satisfactory. 

Miso broth is not bad, but I like the soy sauce base better and I got this one both times. 

Overall, delicious place. But I'm hesitant to wait longer than 30 mins if I'm starving, especially the wait is only long during dinner hours in the weekdays since people just got off work.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Not bad for the price. The shrimp & veggie tempura was very good, I loved the fried rice, just wish they didn't have all that green onions, they should use frozen green peas instead. 
Remember it's a very narrow place not meant for large groups.
There is another room on the side for larger groups of two or more.
author: Elsa N.

description:
Me and my family went here after a day of drinking in the city. After reviewing Yelp for potential candidates, we came across this place.

The location is in near Union Square, next to other Asian restaraunts. The place is quite small and maybe has about 8-12 tables max with a sushi bar.

We had a party of 9, but we were extremely lucky that they had enough tables to sit our table. The waitresses are realy nice and were very kind and funny when taking our order. We had asked what the special was and they stated that the katana ramen was the best.

I ordered the special and you have a choice of miso, soy, or salt broth for the ramen. I chose the miso because the creamy broth is the best. 

When the food came out, which took only about 10-15 minutes, it was delicious! They portion was perfect. Great amount of noodles, with egg, corn, fried chicken, meat, and wonton. So so yum!!!! 

I devoured the entire thing. The price for this was about $12-$15. It is a little pricey, but OMG. Yum.

If you are in the area check this place out, only reason why the 4 stars was because of the size. Other than that... Defintely try it.
author: Ben P.

description:
A decent ramen spot that is open late in SF. I had been craving ramen for awhile and decided to come to this place after a show. All three of us ordered the katanaya ramen which was extremely filling. I also opted to order a takoyaki which was delicious and perfectly puffy. I couldn't finish my ramen because of this.

The katanaya ramen is great because it comes with everything, but the best part was the chicken karage inside. It was soaked in broth and yet still managed to be crispy and delicious. I think next time I'll just get chicken karage ramen.

Noodles aren't the best, but are decent. With the many options other then ramen, all of your friends will be satisfied. Come here for some comfort food, you won't regret it.
author: Samantha D.

description:
Ok, so I have to fix my last review.  Why?  Because I got the Spicy Tofu Ramen.

The spicy tofu ramen with miso flavor is rich, well balanced, spicy, and appropriately priced.  I could eat this every day.  Mmmmm.  

I like this a million times better than their namesake "Katana-ya" ramen. 

Also, I am now much more of a fan because of attending during the late night hour.  Something about getting noodle soup after 10pm makes me very happy.
author: Susan C.

description:
Disappointed! Years ago when I was in town for work i remember going to this little ramen spot near Union Square that had a great atmosphere and yummy ramen. Now that I live in SF, I was excited to accidentally walk by this place one day and a few days later I stopped in for some Japanese food. 

I ordered veggie tempura and some seafood fried rice. The tempura was bland and soggy. It had no flavor and wasn't crispy at all. The fried rice had a bunch of good stuff in it and had potential to be yummy, but something seemed off and it was also quite bland. The miso soup that came with my meal was ok but it had way too many green onions in it.

Overall, I would probably come back someday because it is convenient when I'm out and about in Union Square, but I would stick to getting the ramen. There are plenty of other nearby Japanese hole in the wall spots that are much better.
author: Elaine Tiffany P.

description:
Recommendation: Absolutely delicious ramen! The service was subdued and non-intrusive. No music but great decoration! I'd go back if we're hunting for delicious ramen; otherwise, there are more interesting places to go!

Service: We must have gotten there as it had just opened, even though it was a little before 12:30am on a Sunday. Regardless, we walked in and the place was empty apart from a waitress putting down chairs and placing napkins/soy sauce/chopsticks on tables. We were helped quickly though. Our waters were also constantly filled throughout the course of the meal, which was nice. However, there wasn't too much interaction with our waitress. The only real times we talked were to order our food and to ask for a container for our leftovers. I'd say that the service was intended to be attentive while being a background to the actual meal, and it achieved its goal wonderfully. 

Atmosphere: The restaurant was very well decorated and despite being tiny, was still brightly lit and not too cramped. Tables were made of granite and had a heating element in the middle, which I assume is for cooking meat for certain dishes. Even with the 1ft hole in the middle of the table, there was adequate space for our dishes. Strangely, there was no music of any kind at any point during our meal. It might have been to complement the previously mentioned subdued, non-intrusive environment or it might have just been too early for music. 

Food: I ordered a combination meal, which was a bowl of ramen and a side plate with a 6 piece sushi roll of spicy tuna. We ate the sushi roll throughout the meal and thought it was defintiely a quality roll. Surprisingly the ginger that was served with the sushi was really notable too! However the ramen was definitely the centerpiece of the meal. While mine didn't have an egg on top, it came with the ramen noodles, green onions, seaweed, and 2 pieces of BBQ pork in a miso soup broth. It was really quite delicious! Served quite hot, it stayed warm for the entire meal while being cool enough to start eating right away. Proportionally, I wished I might have had a bit more pork in the meal and maybe an egg as well, but the base ramen was still quite good on its own. The broth was very rich and full of flavor, and the noodles were pefectly cooked. My dining partner's spicy tofu ramen was also awesome, but I think this restaurant is even better because each dish had such a distinct flavor. 

Recommendation: I really enjoyed the ramen here! It was simply made and very delicious, making it one of the best ramen I've tasted. However, the environment didn't leave too much of a lasting impression, so unless I wanted to show people the very best ramen I've found so far, I'd probably rather choose to continue exploring the city for other delicious ramen.
author: John B.

description:
Big mistake in getting the sashimi.  It wasn't fresh. It's like what you get from an Asian market pre-made.  And the tonkatsu was meh.  The combo wasn't much of a value. The place isn't very clean either.

Got here early and was able to sit right away, avoiding the long line even on a weeknight.  I think it's because there really isn't any other place for ramen.  Ramen is good in taste and portions but not hot enough.  I'll come here again when I'm really hunkering for hot noodles and in the area until I find something better.
author: Susannah K.

description:
This place was just ok. I originally wanted to eat in but they were super packed. I got the Katana-Ya ramen and got it to-go. Since I was at the Westin St Francis this place was super close by. The to-go really can show you the quality of the meats. I assume when you eat in they have the fried chicken and egg inside the ramen. When it is to-go it is in a separate container. The meat wasn't that good by itself so I'm guessing that when you dip it into the soup base it becomes a bit soggier and good? I'm not too sure. 

It was just ok in my opinion however I do like that it was packed super hot. Kind of pricey too I think it was like $14 after tax. If you need a ramen fix and are nearby this place can do it otherwise I'm sure there are better establishments a bit further away.
author: Jacob H.

description:
I've been to Katana-Ya a couple of times, and there is always a long line. I guess it isnt that surprising since the restaurant itself is pretty small/cosy and customers have to huddle up. 

The ramen and sushi are both pretty good. They offer a meal combo which is a ramen with a side (either rice bowl, sushi or appetiser). I like the spicy ramen, and always order medium. 

This place is walking distance from Union Square, which makes it a good place for dinner after a day of bringing your friends around the city. For those looking for late night food hunts, this is also a great place for supper/ ramen.
author: Christina N.

description: Their ramen is OK at best but customer service is pretty much non-existent. Both waitresses are rushing you, stare at you constantly and generally don't make you feel welcome. Tried this place twice, but there won't be a third time for us.
author: Gabor K.

description:
I Love going there for ramen and edamame and a little hot sake for warming up the cold nights in SF. Never wanted to try the other things on the menu, becaus thy don't look good.
Service is just too seriously oriental: no smiling, no friendly talks, but fast and ok.
Price is honest. I never complain.
author: Daniela N.

description:
NOTE: THE FOOD DESERVES 5 STARS BUT I AM GIVING THIS A 1 STAR BECAUSE OF THE INTERIOR AND EXTERIOR OF THIS PLACE. 

That saying do not judge a book by it's cover speaks volumes for this place. Literally the exterior & the interior of the place is a hole in the wall. 

The wait time took forever just to get table. On another note there was just a sign in sheet/book left outside because the place is so small there is no room to wait inside. So they call you by name... (first come, first serve)

To be honest I was grossed out just seating down.. And the thought of a place being so rambunctiously packed to the point where they didn't even care whom or how large the party was. They took in whom ever that could filled their tables that was available. 

But low and behold, I was shocked how DELICIOUS the food was seriously. 

I would so come back to this place if I were to visit San Francisco again & if they did some serious renovations to this place. They need it. I don't want to know nor see how they made my food behind close doors but I have to admit I cringe because I can't believe I ate food from a place like this.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I have been here a few years ago, but did not remember the experience. Upon my second time here, I came with a big group, so we were able to order a wide variety of food. Upon sitting down, I noticed that they have combination sepcials of ramen and poke-don. They had a a bunch of options for either $13-15. Would recommend getting this so you can try more!

For appetizers, we ordered the fried tofu, fried octopus, and deep fried tuna roll. I would definitely recommend the fried octopus, as it was fried lightly and the octopus was great. I also got my tuna and salmon bowl, which was the perfect amount as an appetizer. The tuna and salmon was very fresh and flavorful, and they added a hint of onions for more flavor. This was my favorite part of the meal, and I was sad to see my last piece of fish eaten.

I got the spicy miso ramen, and although the broth was flavorful, I feel like SF ramen can't really compare to socal ramen. However, this place is a great spot in SF, as the ramen was cooked well and the pork was tender. 

If you are craving ramen or japanese food, this restaurant is a great place to go to! The restaurant is very small and cramped though so I would recommend coming at odd hours so you don't have to wait.
author: Celine L.

description: The ramen is fantastic, very tasty kind of ramen noodle. Ordered Katana Ramen with miso soup, would recommend. However, would not recommend its sushi. I ordered Ikura sushi but the ikura has a strange taste and just does not look full.
author: Kelsey W.

description:
So turned off by the total lack of regard for the customer.  Seemed the very brusque young woman at the register was doing me a favor allowing me to buy their their food.  Practically didn't receive service because I paid with a debit card.  

Told that the wait for take out ramen would be 20 minutes.  50 minutes later after watching order after order shipping out for delivery was told "gee sorry, we got busy."  Yeah.  The food was okay, but gee sorry, I don't appreciate an unappreciative person to whom I give money in exchange for a product.  

I won't be back.
author: Tim F.

description:
I first stepped into the right side of the restaurant and I was immediately told to go next door. This confused me because I thought they told me to go to a different restaurant instead of theirs. Turns out, the restaurant is also next door but there just happened to be a wall in-between the restaurant that they didn't want to break down.

To start off, the restaurant was tiny as hell! The tables were tiny and the seating arrangement was terrible! My table barely fit but the table next to me of 6-8 business men couldn't even fit on the table! It seemed funny because they were like giants on a little kid's table. Also, the lighting and decor was incredibly dark. Four bowls of ramen barely fit on one table with condiments and such. They should really rethink this layout! 

The ramen was good, but it wasn't great. It was a typical ramen. The rainbow roll was also average, so there isn't much to say here other than it is what is expected of it. The service was average too.
author: Heather N.

description:
Wow! Amazing. 

Hole in the wall, literally. It seats maybe 30 people. Really good sushi. By far the best fried rice I've had. I loved the Udon soup. Great service. Highly recommend.
author: Ilene H.

description:
There are a lot of fantastic ramen places back home (Vancouver), and my family was craving ramen to warm ourselves up from the cold. We found this place and that was an interesting (read: horrible) experience.

- Stayed away from the sushi because it looked incredibly overpriced. 
- The ramen was really, really ordinary. Like plain Jane ordinary. 
- We had to wait a solid 1 hour before they would give us a table. When we did get down there, there were plenty of empty tables, and not to mention we weren't the only ones in line that were waiting to get in. So, why make everyone wait??
- Once we actually sat down, it was at a cramped table (so 5 people at a two seater table and you seat a couple at a large, four seater table at the same time as us? really?)
- The service picked up significantly once we were actually seated. The server we had, who wasn't Asian, was the only nice one. The other servers were quite rude.
- The ramen was reminiscent of cup noodles and also overpriced.
author: Rachel W.

description: A little on the expensive side, but their portions are huge and it's really good. My girlfriend and I got a ramen bowl each and split a California Roll. The ramen bowls are big enough for two people and are very flavorful. The California Roll, although simple, was very fresh and tasted great. Would definitely visit again.
author: Jessica M.

description:
If you're vegetarian, this could be the place to try ramen for the first time. Very few ramen places have vegetarian broth, and because it's pretty rare, I'm going to give it 3 stars for the effort.

However, if you're not vegetarian and have had ramen at [insert some place with good ramen] before, you're probably going to be disappointed.

The broth was underwhelming. The noodles were decently chewy. The chasu was definitely the highlight of the dish, but that said, I don't care for it all that much. It is just a very average bowl of ramen. On top of that, we were 2nd in line before they opened, got seated right at the window, and didn't receive any service for a long while. We had a hungry toddler with us too... what's up? I didn't ask to be seated at the bastard corner of the shop, especially when we came so much earlier!

All-in-all, it's probably not worth its place on the 7x7 list.
author: Alice C.

description: I came here cause my friend found out about it somehow. Honestly, I've had way danker ramen. This tasted like some pretty basic stuff. The noodles were a little harder? idk what's the word they just aren't as soft as they should be. the broth was eh, the pork was eh, everything was just eh. I ordered their specialty ramen if any of you guys were wondering. definitely wasn't worth the $15 for sure. it tasted like somebody who enrolled into culinary school cause they were bored. their service was pretty lame too. servers were rude and all that. you gotta keep in mind that it doesn't take much to tell you what's good or what's not. this is definitely not a place I'd recommend to anyone! lol
author: Jaspur P.

description:
Yooow the wait was loooong, but well worth it. During our 45 minute wait, we went to the wine bar down the street (forgot its name) and it was a good place to kill time. 

We all got the Katana-Ya Ramen. I got mine with soy, light density, and medium spicy. I guess I could've went with extra spicy, but that's riskayy. I couldn't even finish mine because it was just so much. The service was very fast too, which was exciting since I was so hungry and seeing the great rating on yelp didn't help either.

Will be back!
author: Harmony L.

description:
I should have listened to all my friends when they told me this place was over-hyped. Despite their warnings, I came here anyways on a Thursday during lunch time. The restaurant is pretty small, so there was a long wait.

I ordered the Katana-ya ramen. They put a few pieces of karaage chicken and a couple of gyoza in the broth. I actually enjoyed the chicken but the gyoza weren't that tasty. The broth and the noodles was what I had issue with the most. The broth is watery and not flavorful. It was just salty and bland. The noodles tasted like the kind of noodle from instant noodle packages. It was overly tender. I enjoy chewing on the noodle but I was not able to get that satisfaction with my ramen here. They do have a lot of other flavors of ramen on the menu, so I may return back to try a different flavor.
author: Wayne C.

description: Best bowl I've had in SF - particularly partial to the pork belly ramen (added karage chicken).
author: Jules A.

description:
Service are pretty good! But the environment is noisy, I mean it's not like a bar, there are three girls nearby us talked really loud but nobody stop them...

Food is not good. The kimchi fried rice is bad and sashimi is average. Me and my friend just ate a little bit of the fried rice. 

Overall, I love the service. Especially our waitress was nice and sweet. However, food needs improve.
author: Janice W.

description:
3.5 stars. I crave ramen. A LOT! So having a ramen place by my work is nice when the mood hits. I almost always get the katanaya ramen since I like a variety of toppings in my ramen. And I always ask for it extra spicy. Their extra spicy honestly is not that spicy, so don't let all the redness in the bowl fool you! The soup when made extra spicy can be a little oily, but it flavors the toppings and works with the fried potstickers and karaage.

Note: They get really really busy during lunch hours so make sure you show up for an early or late lunch. Otherwise, you may have to wait a while since this place is tiny.
author: Elena N.

description:
Oh man, ramen craving overly satisfied!!!! I loved the katana-ya special ramen with extra pork in place of potstickers. The karaage in it was amazeballs! It had a nice kick to it with the heat and a nice helping of perfectly made noodles.
