My friend ordered the udon and mentioned it was too flavorful. They could have diluted IMO. I'll definitely give this place another go when I'm feeling cold and ramen-y inside! It's a must!

Also, counter to what most people review, we had a short wait! I shall say you should consider that we did eat past 9 pm.
author: Bern M.

description: Great ramen, worth the modest wait to get in. Nice Sake selection. Sushi appetizer was great as well.
author: Ed K.

description:
So not good.

Came here with some friends for dinner. Excited for ramen, sushi rolls, and don bowls. 

Since noodles and sushi sounded great, I ordered the combo. The tuna salmon don bowl came first, and was way smaller than the photo. Basically 3.5 pieces of small fish. and a heaping cup of rice with hella mayo sauce. Not a fan of mayo in wish I had known. Tuna and salmon were watery, bland, warm, and flavorless. 

All ramen has pork based broth, so I couldn't eat it. Friends who ate it said it wasn't very good. Noodles aren't hand-pulled, probably from a package. The soba was tasteless and the broth was overly fishy.

The rice in all the rolls was hard and fell apart quickly. 

Friend got food poisoning later on :( 

Not a fan. 

Next.
author: Shereen A.

description: The Very Spicy Miso Ramen hit the spot on a cold city day. I did appreciate the location being so easy to get to after the Union Square festivities. Reading the past reviews, the broth we had did have good depth in flavor. The price was also decent to the Ramen we usually have in the peninsula. We also had great service. 4 stars because I still believe Ramen Dojo in San Mateo will forever be the best ramen!
author: Ankita T.

description:
Service was horrible, we didn't get our food for an hour and a half (after they forgot about it)

They compensated with loads of sake and great music. Overall a throughly mediocre ramen experience
author: Jessie S.

description: This is the best ugly place, the food has no flavor, I would never go to eat a saucer again.
author: Fau've C.

description:
A neighborhood must! Intricate bone broth taste + chewy noodles and the perfect amount of spice. I recommend ordering to go as this place is tiny and has a wait even in the strangest of hours. Staff could be nicer, but the food compensates for the service and then some.

Try the 
-BBQ pork ramen.
for the true ramen noodle lovers. This dish is a little light on the toppings, but the broth and noodles should be all you're seeking anyways.
author: Patricia K.

description:
Over 3k Yelp Reviews and me staying at the hotel across the street = I had to come here. 

Share the following dishes with my GF:

Alaska Roll 
Rainbow Roll
Crispy Spicy Tuna 
Katana-Ya Ramen

All of the food was solid and the two rolls were my favorite. Not sure if this place reached the hype but it provided for a good dinner. 

Service was average.
author: Tim R.

description: I ordered the bbq pork with miso. I have had some really stellar ramen in the city, but I thought this one lacked much depth. My pork and egg were both cold. My friend ordered the vegetarian ramen and that too was meh. Maybe it was the time of day. I had heard good things about this place but I shall not soon return.
author: Sean C.

description:
I mist have gone on a bad day. 

I ordered the Tonkatsu don, one spicy tuna roll, iced tea and a water. My soup was forgotten, as was my iced tea. The rice was undercooked in the don bowl, the sushi roll was a bit fishy and was not fresh. 

I wanted the spicy beef ramen, but there was no beef and no veggies for the vegetarian ramen. As I have said, I mist have come on a bad day according to the most recent reviews.
author: Mat M.

description:
I don't understand why everyone loves this place so much and why there is always a line out the door at night (besides the fact that it's really small inside). 

I've been here twice and haven't been super impressed either time. I've tried their shoyu and miso ramen and last time went all out with their namesake katana-ya ramen bowl. It's ok, don't get me wrong (that's what three stars mean afterall), but it isn't like mind-blowing, willing to wait 30 minutes outside in the cold on geary for.
author: Leina K.

description:
Saturday at 2pm: 15 min wait. Small place with maybe 10 tables and counter seating.

Ranked in order of preference:
Miso based
Soy sauce based 
Salt based 

I felt like miso had the most depth in flavor. Salt just tasted like brothy salt water. Soy sauce based was fine.

The regular $7 ramen tasted pretty good, but there wasn't much stuff in it. Not even half an egg! The Katana-Ya ramen has more stuff in it with egg, fried gyoza, fried chicken, and corn. The fried components are pretty good on its own, although I would eat it first and not let it sit in the broth for too long. Not really sure why it's not just served separately.
author: Alice T.

description:
Order two sushi roll and two ramen for 4 people during a late night. 

Ramen: Katanaya Ramen $12.95. Good broth and good variety of protein. Noodle itself wasn't as good as other noodles places. 

Sushi rolls: both rolls were not good. Not worth mentioning or ordering in the future. Kinda pricey. 

Service: excellent service! Ambiance it decent.
author: Nicole N.

description:
Katana - ya was located only a few minutes from our hotel, so we went there for late lunch.
We were able to sit right away and their customer service was good.  Friendly and quick service.
We were so glad we went there at that time, because we saw a line every time we walked by.
Their food was great.
We can recommend this place.
author: T M.

description:
16.09.28                 One of many visits

Ramen ------------------------- 3 1/2
Sushi --------------------------- 3 - 3/2

The ramen is pretty good.
The ingredients is not bad.
Some add on ingredients are best put on the side ...
    add it to the soup when u are ready for best outcome.
Many rivals from Japan are showing up in SF making this 
      place ok.
Still a good plaace for a decent ramen.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
Made a return visit after many years.  Stayed away from the kitchen sink Katana Ya ramen order and simply ordered the chasu and butter corn ramen.

Pros: 
Great location near Union Square
Turnover is fairly quick
Bowl size generous and the noodles are cooked well
Can order broth as rich or light.  Salt, Soy, and Miso available.

Cons: 
I'm continually surprised this place is a 7x7 pick for great ramen in SF.  The South Bay establishments (Orenchi, Santouka, Shalala, and even Ryowa absolutely blow this place away)  The key is their broths are so much more flavorful.
Prices are a bit on the high side if you add all the options, but stick with the basics 

Katana Ya accpets credit cards, but not American Express.
author: Randy F.

description:
It's hard to find good ramen in the city, oddly enough, but I like coming to Katana-Ya to satisfy my ramen craving.

I get the Katanaya Ramen with miso soup, which comes with loaded with pork belly, karaage, and pot stickers. You have the option to make it spicy or extra spicy. The extra spicy soup looks like volcano lava, but is surprisingly tame.
author: Monica H.

description: Amazing broth, and although I've been told adding spice to your order (75 cents for spicy, $1.50 for extra spicy) masks the flavor, it's still nice to have a little zing in the ramen. Prices are fair, range between $9-$12 a bowl, which could include veggies or meat, whatever you select, and they even have udon (even curry udon, and also donburi bowls) for anti-ramen fans. It also has a full sushi bar (although limited seating), and a range of standard side dishes like agedashi tofu, chicken karaage, edamame, poki salads, etc. Really extensive menu so there's something for everyone in your party, even the pickiest eaters. Super minuscule venue so expect to be waiting out on the busy street curb anywhere from 30-45 minutes during the non-busy times, and even longer during rush hour or on weekends.
author: Alison A.

description: Went there for the first time last night! This is the perfect place to go late at night especially if it's raining! I had karaage ramen and it was really delicious. The service needs a little bit of work since one of the waiters was kinda rude to us. Overall, I would come back!
author: Micah G.

description: Food average. Service bad.  There's a jack and the box next door, maybe a better bet. Had the sashimi
author: Doug A.

description: This restaurant should close already. Worst customer service ever. I never learned. I went again there today thinking they added more servers or maybe they thought of an efficient way to serve the customers better, no!!! This time though, j only waited for like 5 minutes because I talked to a guy before me if it's of if we share a table so it's faster and he agreed. So we got a table, waited for the waiter to approach us. I looked around and there were 2 tables of 4 people that weren't served yet so fuck it, I walked out!
author: Jake D.

description:
Alright so here's the thing...
Ordered takeout from here on a Thursday night for my roomies. Ordered it on the Eat24 app. 

DELIVERY:
$4.99 delivery fee. The fee is fine, completely understandable.. But they were late over the estimated time. 

FOOD:
NEVER AGAIN. I'm sorry, I've eaten at SO MANY ramen places that my expectations are pretty high. We ordered three ramen. 

SPICY BEEF RAMEN(11.95): My roommate requested a beef ramen with no spicy/spice. I explicitly told them not to make it spicy because my roommate has a low tolerance for spice, and it got delivered spicy. The spiciest out of all the ramen. She didn't eat any of it because she couldn't :( 

VEGETABLE RAMEN (11.95): ordered the vegetable ramen because I'm starting to feel under the weather. In the end, I couldn't finish it... It just tasted REALLY SALTY. And the flavors just did not mix well together. I couldn't finish it, and it's rare for me not to finish food/save it. 

KATANAYA RAMEN with spicy (12.95 and .75): my friend ordered this ramen.. It wasn't that spicy. The flavors in this didn't mesh well either. 

DYNAMITE ROLL(7.95): this is a mix sashimi in a sushi cut. Seemed like a sushi boy type of roll. Very basic, very bland. Very Americanized. Friend called it worse than "Safeway sushi". 

TIP: .75 for extra spicy. 

5 stars to 4 stars: For being late
4 stars to 3 stars: Food not tasting good. 
3 stars to 2 stars: Adding spicy to roomies order
2 stars to 1 star: Americanized sushi. 

Perhaps it was just the orders we picked that weren't good, but this place was not even close to the mark for me. If any of you guys have good ramen recommendations, please send me a shout out. I have yet to find the place.
author: Tiffany J.

description:
Before the ramen trend started in the City, this spot was the spot for ramen. Unfortunately, it has fallen severely from grace. What use to be a favorite of mine in the past is now a place that I don't have to ever go back again.

It's great that they have been able to expand their seating, but that's about the only positive I can write about. I've heard they are under new management now and it seems to show, especially with its service. They are certainly really strict about their wait list policy. When the lady called my name, the rest of my party was walking here from the corner of the same block. I told her they'd be here in 30 secs and she kept asking me where they are. Instantly, they gave away our table. That's their policy though so I can't argue it.

When we were seated, no server came for some time. We finally ordered...I ordered the combo ramen with curry don. When our bowls arrived, I asked about my side of curry don and the person told me they don't have it. I said the server took my order and never told me they were out and never even came back to tell me that they didn't have it! Someone that seems like the manager came to talk to me and he said the original server that took our order didn't know they were out of curry. The manager offered to get me another don so I got a tonkatsu done. When we were near done with our ramen, the tonkatsu don finally arrived. The manager said he brought me a large size order to make up for the mistake. Too bad the don was more rice than tonkatsu. He still charged me for it though... Would've been nice to at least have it comped.

In the end, even the ramen broth and  noodles itself tasted different from the past. It just wasn't as good...as flavorful as before. It's great that this place still opens late at night given the limited food options open after hours but it's unfortunate that I can't ever come back again. Jack in the Box on the corner may be a worthwhile option you may want to consider.
author: Rick T.

description:
The big city was calling me to try the ramen. This was the closest ramen restaurant w/ veggie options to us. As we drove towards it, we realized it was in a very busy tourist area = lots of traffic.

The ramen gods were on our side that day. We found parking easily down the street and there wasn't a wait.

The place is really small and tight but I wasn't surprised considering the location.

I ordered the veggie tofu ramen and added kimchi. It was supposed to come with cabbage but they forgot it. The warm broth soothed me soul from the cold air of the bay. The broth was delicious but the noodles could have been better. $11-13 for my bowl, a lil expensive. I was just happy I got my ramen fix.

I'm a fan but it could have been better. 3.5 overall.
author: Mypang T.

description:
It's maybe a little overcast and down in the 50's weather-wise right now - which obviously means it's winter in San Francisco. If you're stuck at work with bronchitis and want something soothing for lunch, Katana-Ya is a great option.

They offer pick-up and delivery through their Yelp/Eat-24 pages and are also available through other delivery avenues. 

Their curry udon is the perfect cure for a cold, sickly work day. The broth is thick and very flavor-full... maybe a little greasy even, but in a good way. It comes with generous portions of beef, carrot, potato, seaweed and scallions; and the noodles are a perfect al-dente (I'm going to go ahead and use an Italian term on Asian noodles).

This was the next best thing to watching Netflix in my bed.

... Instead I'm going to get all these motherf*ckers in my office sick.
author: K M.

description: Food had no flavor at all. The ramen bowl was bland and so was the tempura. The coating didn't seem like regular tempura coating. Service was very slow.
author: Danielle E.

description:
Came on a Sunday afternoon and it was PACKED. Maybe people were getting snacks after shopping all day...but the restaurant itself is pretty tiny. The wait wasn't too long, maybe 15-20 min and there were only a handful of parties ahead of us, even though the crowd outside looked like much more. People were  being seated relatively quickly.

The ramen itself was decent, I'm not one to be picky about good ramen or can tell the difference between good and better. We split a Katana-Ya ramen and it was enough for a good snack. 

The service was pretty slow though, which is why I would rate them much lower. We were seated first and served later than other people who were seated after us, even though we put in our order right away. It also took forever for them to bring the check out, and the waitresses were very curt. I don't really care about service too much, but is it too hard to ask for my credit card back after waiting for 10 minutes to get the bill? We were falling asleep waiting to leave. It turns out their credit card machine wasn't working. At least tell me I have to pay cash so I can leave and you can seat the poor people outside waiting in the rain. I had to go up to the counter and inquire about my credit card, and everyone was very confused as to what happened. 

I've been here before and it was okay as well, I wouldn't go back again. Not sure why everyone goes crazy over this place, maybe there aren't too many places in SF to eat ramen.
author: Chrissy G.

description: Something bad has happened to this once beloved Union Square enclave. What was used to be a go-to for Japanese food is no longer. A bowl of rice with teriyaki-covered tempura is not "donburi." The smiling, attentive staff have been replace with a waitress who took our order and never came back---not to check on our food, refill our water, or offer my husband more tea. The ramen broth is not nearly as goodas it used to be and the gyoza is chewy and sad. This massive drop in quality is exacerbated by the fact that they've jacked up the prices. RIP Katanaya
author: Jess H.

description:
We had the lunch specials. Pretty good selection for less than $15. You get a ramen and a side dish to accompany your meal. I chose the shoyo ramen and ahi tuna side. The ramen is flavorful and not salty. The side tuna was spicy! OUCH!!! 

My friend ordered the miso ramen with fried rice. Damn I should have gotten the fried rice. DELICIOUS!!! 

Be mindful the place is tiny!! The back of my chair was hitting the person behind me and my chair was pushed in all the way. Good thing I'm small!!! Expect a wait if it's prime time. Stool seats available but there's only about 5 chairs. Restaurant capacity is about 20-25. TIGHT!
author: Maria C.

description:
I feel like this place is the KFC version of ramen. I had the house special ramen, it was very greasy, tasty at first but gets tiring very quickly. I had the fried chicken and fried gyoza on the side, but ended up putting the fried chicken inside the broth. The broth was very thick, rich, but oily. 

Overall, it was an OK bowl of ramen, it definitely warmed me up and filled me. Service was friendly. Seating was tight but understandable given their location.
author: Wendy K.

description: The ramen was decent.  I had it karage and gyoza and did not think those 2 items were the best. Service was not great. The ramen it self was tasty.
author: Jason W.

description: This was my first time here and it was terrible. Started off walking down stairs, no one greeted me and then i was just prompted to sit in the corner. Service was terrible. The server was dressed frumpy and sloppy and did not even acknowledge me. i had to personally walk up to him to get his attention. even to pay i had to walk up and ask for my check. the food was overpriced and bad. they also messed up my order twice.  This was my first time not leaving a tip. Will never go back.
author: Chloe S.

description:
HORRIBLE SERVICE!

HORRIBLE PARKING (unless you get UBER'd to the front)!

It's funny how all the patrons are yelling at the servers for their attention.

Yet, people still keep coming back... I guess their food makes up for it.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description:
The service was terrible. Everyone there except one lady seemed apparently angry at something. Everyone was very short and not friendly at all. Asking to get seated seemed like we were bothering the staff more than being welcomed into their restaurant. 

The food was subpar. The egg was cold and overcooked. I had the Katanaya Ramen in miso broth. Overall, I was unimpressed with the ramen as it didn't stand out as anything impressive at all. The place left a bad taste in my mouth overall. I will not be going back or recommending it to anyone I care about.
author: Nick S.

description: Used to really like this place. Their service was always horrible (super slow, rude, etc.) but the ramen itself was pretty good which made me overlook those things but with so many other great ramen places around - with better prices and much better service - there's hardly any reason to come here anymore. I was in the area recently and thought I'd give them another try. About 15 minutes after being seated and not having anyone take my order (and it wasn't even crowded or anything) I started thinking why the hell am I here and just walked out. There's no reason to give them a a pass anymore. After years of the same crappy service with decent but nothing that stands out food, I'm giving up on this place.
author: Ali A.

description:
Average ramen, but the guy beside me ordered kastudon and that looked better, he refused to comment for this interview though.

Noodle: 5/5, great quality noodles, cooked to perfection with the right tender

Broth: 3.5, just average, a little too much MSG.

Karage & pork: 1.5, maybe just today, but neither food was fixed prior to cooking to get rid of the blood stink, so that wasn't pleasant at all.

Half egg, sea weed, green onion, corn bits, all the standard stuff.

Oh, and they put the gyoza in the soup, that was a first and very strange. I'd rather they had it separately.

Line up all the time though (but if you are by yourself you could walk up to the bar, otherwise fill your name on the sheet at the door), so there must be something amazing here.
author: Richard Y.

description: The salmon sashimi I got is not fresh. I think it has been siting in room temp for a while. The ramen is okey. But the price is really good.
author: Chloe C.

description:
We ate here the night before we left San Fran and got sick. The food tasted fine at the time, we had the Katanaya Ramen, Unagi Don, Caterpillar roll and one other small roll. My girlfriend mentioned that the Unagi tasted slightly off but I thought nothing of it. 

We came at 10pm on Sept 7, 2016. Not sure if we got all the leftover scraps from the day. Being sick on the plane ride home the next morning is not an ideal way to end a vacation. Not a chance in hell I would be back.
author: Tony T.

description: Ordered Ramen and Unagi Don, the ramen was soso and the worse was the Unagi (eel) tasted like plastic out from the freezer and put in the microwave , I almost threw up not fresh at all and disgusting. Don't recommend this place and it is also very expensive !
author: Alexandre W.

description:
I came here a couple weeks ago while I was in SF. I ate here for dinner with my cousins. 

I got the cha siu ramen, which tasted okay. It wasn't the best.... ended up being way too heavy for me and I couldn't finish it. I would like to see a ramen with more veggies. 

My cousins got the udon and some beef ramen. They seemed to both enjoy it, but couldn't finish it either.

Also, this place is very tiny and I mean very. So come early for dinner or you're going to be waiting outside. Also, this place is not good for big groups. Our party of 3 was uber cramped and everytime the door opened, there was this big gush of air that made it very unpleasant. 

All in all, I think this is average. I've eaten at better places in LA. :D
author: Nina W.

description:
Service needs an improvement.  Our server seems had a bad day.  Here is our observation from today's lunch:

-* for not being attentive to the customers.  
-* for negligently splashing water only half glass.
-* for bringing a bill in a middle of the meal.  

Ambience is good. 
Food is good.  Thanks!
author: Alex R.

description: Can't complain! We had the sushi, the tempura vegetables and the pork ramen! It was delicious! Highly recommended!
author: Michelle F.

description: Very good ramen, there a crunch to it like al dente, the pork belly ramen special is tasty, had to walk around afterwards, I just wished they had asahi draft!
author: Bram S.

description: Worst ramen I've had. Noodle was over cooked. Egg was cold. Service was bad. What happened??
author: Ray T.

description:
This place is not so bad, but it's not super great either, just in between! I do not understand (and never will) why this small ramen shop, could pass being smaller than a matchbox, has over whooping 3,000+reviews! Does it mean it's that amazing or is it really all hype? Continue on and I'll tell you.. 

Solid 3.5 stars. 15 minutes wait time to get seated at the bar next to two Japanese guys who are huge like sumo wrestlers, being squished in between. This place is super small, no joke! The service was friendly and efficient. Cool Japanese contemporary decors, not very well-lit, with cool vintage Japanese lantern lamps accented with reds. It has a sushi bar that seats about 5 people, with 6 small tables. They have the usual broth flavorings: miso, soy, or salt, but also a spicy broth, which is a couple dollars more. I aimlessly had the signature Katana-Ya ramen, with a nice array of garnishes, including buttered corn, chopped green onions, half egg, seaweed, a couple gyozas, meat, and a few other ingredients. The broth is pretty darn good, which has a succulent taste! It will surely fill up your tummy with yummy! Even tastes better while under influence from hot sake. 

Slurpali-cious!
author: Jan P.

description:
They're not the best, but they're also not bad. The broth as well as their noodles are both decent. One good thing is that you can order pretty decent sushi to go with your bowl of ramen here. I usually order their Katanaya ramen which pretty much has everything thrown into the bowl.

The place is pretty tiny and gets packed early during the usual lunch and dinner hours. They have a sign-in sheet next to the entrance. But if you're dining solo, you can almost always find a seat at the bar. The one thing that I don't like about the place is the lighting, it's the neon nightclub-type lighting. It's just kind of weird to be slurping a bowl of ramen in the afternoon under that kind of lighting. :)
author: Emil C.

description:
I came to Katana-Ya for Chicken Kastu Curry!

My co-worker was craving ramen and I was craving Japanese style curry. We both had never been to Katana-Ya, so we decided to venture into the lunch rush wait and experience the hype! The store front is very simple. You'll notice a lot of folks waiting around for their names to be called. We signed our name on the list and had a nice conversation out on the sidewalk. It was a nice sunny day, so it was great to chat and enjoy the weather.

When we were called to be seated, we walked into the restaurant. It is a pretty narrow space, so it can get a little humid inside if it is a warm day! The team at Katana-Ya were very nice. Despite the feeling of a lunch rush, our service didn't feel rushed at al. They spent time to discuss their menu options and to answer our questions about the restaurant! 

My co-worker ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen with miso. I ordered the chicken katsu curry. I enjoyed the rich, thick, and creaminess of the curry. It wasn't too spicy, and it was just the right level of thickness and consistency I like that allows me to mix well into my rice. The chicken katsu was perfect. cripsy yet moist and juicy when you bite into the katsu strips. The juicy and tenderness of the chicken went so well with the curry and the rice.

Can't wait to return and experience the ramen, but as of this visit, Katana-Ya is on the top of my list for what usually can be pretty generic chicken katsu curries.
author: Ben C.

description: The taste is totally different from Japanese ramen. The smell of katanaya ramen is terrible.
author: Yoshitomo M.

description: The best vegeterian Soup noodle i've ever had.I will go back there to eat, inspite of the fact that the owner was extremely rude and asked us to leave just because we had added our name in togo order as well.
author: Pooja J.

description:
Since becoming a vegetarian I've thought this place was dead to me because most ramen houses don't serve broth other than meat broth. But last Friday i was passing by at an auspicious hour and decided to peek at the menu. Sure enough they seem to have added - or I seem to have noticed - a vegetarian ramen on the menu. 

If I weren't writing this review at the inauspicious hour of midnight, I'd wax more eloquent about my nice experience sitting in the window feeling calm and welcomed, and my delight at the massive bowl of beautiful steaming noodles, fresh broccoli and heaps of seaweed.

As it stands, I'll say slurp and two thumbs up. Thanks for remembering the vegs, Katana Ya!
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Came here after a friend recommended it.

Parking here is horrendous, but people always seem to manage to find spots here.  I'm scratching my head.

The inside is dimly lit and honestly reminds me of an old school Karaoke bar, with all the neon lights.  This place is CRAMPED.  I'm sure this place fails all municipal fire codes.

As I didn't go to any other ramen places, I can't say how it compares to other local joints.  However, the food here was pretty good, albeit a bit pricey.  My combo ended up being some $15.  With that said, there's quite a bit of stuff in there.

Uni - wow, nice big pieces.  Definitely not for everyone, but I really enjoyed this.

Ikura - not the freshest (eggs were a bit "caved in"), but tasted okay.  Generous portion.

The ramen noodles were quite decent as well.  Nice springy noodles, and delicious broth.  Pork wasn't too fatty which I like.

The service was a bit lacking (understaffed), but I'm sure the waitress was working her butt off.

Definitely a decent place to get your ramen fix.
author: Edward L.

description: Given the number of reviews I was excited to try the ramen here. We ordered the katanaya ramen with miso. Highly recommended in all the reviews. But it was nothing special. The broth was flat. The noodles were like rubber. I would not go back.
author: Rapunzel C.

description:
Mmm MMM Mmm! I love me some ramen! And I love ramen so much more at 11 oclock at night! What usually lacks in restaurants is their times of business. Hate it when places close at 7pm because people get off work at 6pm sometimes and want to eat the food at your restaurant! Okay sorry I'm ranting. 

Came here on a Tuesday night, there was a wait. Maybe around 10 people lingering outside of the restaurant waiting to be called. It was like 11 oclock at night- what the.... Must be good then! So we finally get seated and order. The bowls are huge! I ordered the butter corm. Man, I can still taste it in my mouth. There's really not much to say- this place is worth checking out. I think they're open later so if you're craving ramen after the club- this is the spot to hit up. Well the only spot to hit up. No ramen place is open this late. Ooooh that's competition right there!
author: Dara S.

description: I had the karage Ramen and it was really good.. I was not a big fan of Ramen but that has changed recently due to places like these
author: Shashank D.

description:
Ramen restaurant located in central downtown, San Francisco!  YUM and how convenient!  Great place to grab hot broth with noodles when the fog comes into the bay!

I love their ramen!  Katanaya ramen has everything you can ask for in a ramen meal!  With the noodles and the broth, you also would get fried popcorn chicken and fried potstickers!  Soooo fulfilling and it hits the spot!

Small place, but it's like other Ramen shops with the size.

Good service and price, great ramen meal, and located in central downtown! Definitely coming back here again!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Great ramen with reasonable price!!! My boyfriend had katana ya ramen and he loves it. The only problem are those horrible waitresses...super bad attitude not leaving any tip today because they don't deserve it(would be happy to tip the chef though)
author: Chloe L.

description: I liked the ramen, would go back.
author: Julia S.

description:
7x7 100 Best Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 2012

#5 Chasu Ramen at Katana-Ya

When it comes to ramen, I definitely have tried my fare share so when I say Katana Ya is A-Ok I literally mean they are A-OK. For what you pay for you get a decent amount of good food. There is a slight wait but their turn over is rather quick so it's not that unbearable. I have heard it can get insanely busy but thankfully I did not run into a huge wait problem.

My breakdown of Katana-ya Chasu Ramen

Broth-balanced broth but lacked any depth, miso flavor was not as predominate
Noodles-cooked well, portion was great
Pork-quantity is scare but the flavor is good, not the best pork I have had

For me, I don't think this is worthy of being on the 100 Best Things to Eat simply because I believe there has to be better Ramen places in SF. If there isn't, that truly would be the greatest crime of all. 

Overall Thoughts

7x7 why do you keep disappointing me!
author: Eddie W.

description:
I love this place. Hole in the wall hip without the hipsters. There's a line of regulars even so. Fabulous Ramen, late night service. Sign me up.

My goto is the Katana-Ya Ramen, Miso broth, light spice. 

*Note - Light spice is still a little spicy, really a little spicy. So if your palette is a shy wallflower, order no spice.
author: E R.

description: Our server Eric was amazing! Very polite & fast service!!! The food is delicious, we got the katanaya, spicy and Miso.
author: Victoria R.

description: Good location with awesome atmosphere but did not appreciate the attitude of the staff.
author: jean l.

description: My ramen frenzy continues! What I thought was just a craving is quickly becoming a full blown obsession. I might exclusively just review ramen this fall. I Came to Katana-Ya on the recommendation of several Bay Area friends and was able to walk right in at 2:30p on a Thursday for a late lunch. The restaurant is small but very quaint. They have a short sushi bar framed by neon lights and panels of art featuring storks and gold. The restaurant only has 9 tables total so I can imagine it gets quite busy during dinner rush. I ordered the BBQ pork ramen in a miso broth - EXTRA SPICY. The pork was beyond disappointing. Gray meat with no BBQ flare whatsoever. The broth and noodles were the dishes saving graces. The extra spicy sauce was a little thin but flavorful. Reading other reviews this spot is all about the veggies. Stick to tofu and you'll leave satisfied!
author: Ashley J.

description:
worst ramen i ever ate！！！！i went a lot of places, la
 ny, sd. This place is  really bad!!! You need  to pay
 extra but you do  not get what
 you  need! You even need  to  pay  extra  for  spicy
  1$ extra spicy  for 2$. No service, they are playing their phones all the time. I doubt  why they have  so  many  reviews! Idi they pay yelp more? I do  not care how much it is but please make your ramen  tastes a little better.
author: William W.

description: Sad. This place used to be great 8 years ago but now it's barely a shadow of its former self. Just had a shoyu ramen + karaage don combo. Karaage don was slapped together with a salad on top of the rice bowl. Who puts salad on a donburi?? Not to mention the indifferent service. I won't be coming back here again.
author: Danny L.

description:
Horrible service. We called in 5 min before arriving, they said it was open and there was no wait. When we got in they said they were closed.  It was 45 min before closing.

Even on writing this review it's 30 min before yelp closing time!!
author: Amy H.

description:
My buddy was visiting town with some friends and I met up with them at the Beer Store for the debut of a limited edition brew.  Walking around the city while catching up all day can be very taxing and exhausting, so we broke for an early lunch at Katana-Ya since they had a hankering for some ramen and San Mateo was too far away.

I ordered a combo with their basic miso ramen along with their uni and ikura bowl for $16.  It wasn't a cheap lunch by any means, but I wanted a little variety in my meal.  The ramen itself was decent, though not memorable, and I found the uni slimy and the ikura dry.  It definitely wasn't the freshest sushi I've ever had.  This place just gets a pass and wouldn't be my first choice for ramen in the future.

Service was ok but the space is really quite cramped, especially for a group of 5.  I wasn't thrilled with the prices for the food quality, but it'll do in a pinch.  Overall, just a meh experience for me.

Food: 6/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Terrible service. The waitress don't really care about you.

I ordered the spicy miso katanaya ramen. It wasn't good at all. The broth tasted like lard. It was so greasy and oily and totally not appetizing... The bill came out to be $14.90 after tax. Super expensive for a bowl of ramen. And what's with adding $.75 for spicy and $1.50 for extra spicy? The spicy isn't spicy at all. 

Needless to say, I will not be coming back here.
author: Erni L.

description:
I come here so often because it's delicious and worth it.

Bang for your buck, portions are huge and ramen is delicious.

I believe I've tried all of the ramen here before. I'm pretty in love with the Spicy Tofu Ramen, with Miso broth. It has kimchi in the broth as well as other veggies. I add corn to my soup to make it tastier :p. 

My least fav. would have to be the chicken karage ramen, only because it comes in a smaller bowl, very few pieces and I've found that fried food in soup doesn't work too well. LOL, gets soggy, so it's like a race to finish it. haha.

Fav go to ramen place in downtown sf. You must try!
author: Mel T.

description:
Annie K is my new Yelper friend so when she found out that I was going to San Francisco for a few days for a business trip she very nicely put together a list of must-eat places for me.  The first restaurant on the list was Katana Ya, which was recommended by her boyfriend (who also happens to be my boyfriend's best friend--small world right?) for ramen.  I am always up for a piping hot bowl of ramen so I made this restaurant my first destination immediately after checking in to the hotel.    

The restaurant is in a non-descript building a few blocks away from Union Square.  I was not immediately seated or greeted when I sat down but I'm used to Asian service so I didn't mind too much.  I was dining solo so I sat at the counter and ordered scallop nigiri and a bowl of BBQ pork ramen with salt broth. I was feeling awkard about eating by myself (I am a very social person and eating alone makes me feel sad) but as soon as my ramen came out, I became at one with my bowl of soup.  It was humongous!  The broth was not as buttery smooth as Santouka's ramen but on the Kimberly scale of tastiness I would rank it at somewhere between "Yowza!" and "Hot Diggity Dog!".  

I have two regrets about this place:
#1) I wish that the counter space had retractable shields like they do in Japan because I'm pretty sure I ramen bombed my neighbor a few times with all my glorious slurping and unwieldy noodle handling.  
#2) I wish I was a cow so I could have four stomachs to order a few extra sushi rolls that came so highly touted by the lovely Tara L. and dapper Brett N.
author: Kimberly S.

description: The food here could very well be amazing but I guess I will never know. When I walked in, I know both servers saw me but they chose to ignore me and continue to walk back and forth in front of me numerous times. Until one finally got the hint that I was waiting to get sat after I stared at the side of her head very longingly. I sat at the bar among three other loners. Figured out what I want within a minute and waited while I just watch the two servers go back and forth for each table. I thought it may make more sense to print the checks and distribute them together rather than print for one table, drop it off, go back to register and repeat. But what do I know? Ten mins later, everyone at the bar was still unserved and we were just looking at our phones trying to hint that we were ready. And we must feel stupid to continuously play with our phones knowing damn well no one has any service since we're underground. No one came. Then they sat a couple down. And they got their order taken a minute after. Again, I thought it would probably make more sense if she has taken all four orders at the bar all at once and put all the orders in together in less than a minute. After 15 mins of opening my IG, seeing the no internet connection message, and closing it -- I decided it was time to leave. I wonder if the other three are served yet
author: Kevin C.

description:
Ramen was okay. I got the katayana ramen with a salt base. Cost $12.90 but has everything in it (pot stickers, egg, karage, seaweed). Conveniently close to Union square and Bart. 

Place is pretty small and fills up fast.
author: Mimi T.

description: I wasn't going to write anything until I got so sick in the middle of the night from the poke. We ordered Katanaya ramen, agedashi tofu, pork belly, and the seafood poke. The ramen and the pork belly were good, not great. The tofu was soggy and chewy on the outside. The poke tasted nothing like a normal poke from a good poke bar or from Hawaii. It was so spicy and full of red hot chili pepper flakes, it covered whatever bad taste the stale sashimi had. It was our mistake not to heed to the advise from the other yelpers.
author: Betty W.

description: Visiting San Francisco. I was nervous about poor health rating but it was really late. I ordered ramen miso. The broth was more of an instant noodle quality, not the quality of an 8 hour slow cook. Completely disappointed. This is not authentic Japanese Ramen.
author: Nick N.

description:
I love this place, I really do. I have been MANY times as I work at a nearby hotel AND I recommend Katana-Ya to many of my hotel guests. Having said that I have some not-so-great news to report.

I was CA-RAVING the pork belly ramen bowl for days. So I went there on my meal break to satisfy my appetite. I have to say the staff is always warm and friendly as well as welcoming. In addition to the ramen I also ordered the basic spicy tuna roll. Both dishes were great.

My issues are with the fact that there were fruit flies seemingly everywhere. They were on the soy sauce bottles and around the salt and pepper shaker. They were hovering around my spicy tuna roll when it came. I was endlessly shooing the flies from my table and area around me. I was looking around to see if anyone else was having the same fly experience. I felt like nobody else had this issue and if they did it wasn't bothering them. At one point I had to take my napkin and place it over my exposed spicy tuna roll to keep the flies off! They still kept landing, only on the napkin now. I couldn't get out of there quickly enough!

I had to say something to someone. I got the attention of the waitress and explained that although "I know there was nothing that you can do now, you should know that there are flies hovering all around my table" She was apologetic and again I stated "You should let management know. I know you cannot do anything right now." Having felt better for getting that off of my chest I could see in the reflection on the table top that it was quite dirty. Someone had wiped it off but it was TOTALLY streaked and I could notice some food particles on it. I have not written a review in sometime. When I have it is due to a positive experience. While the food was positive, the uncleanliness and overall experience was not so.

Again, I am sad that I have to report this because I do enjoy the ramen at Katana-Ya but after this last experience I will think twice and hard before going back. ALSO, since I am regularly sending numerous guests to this place for delicious food, I will very likely seek alternative noodles/Japanese venues for my hotel guests. I am giving 3-stars only because the food is that good. If there were a section for overall experience this would render a 1 from me. 

Thank you for reading my unfortunate review.
author: Anthony R.

description: The California sushi roll was among the best I've had, the shrimp tempura was very good also. The ramen miso style was bland but probably authentic, I have spent too much time with top ramen. Great portion sizes.
author: Dani T.

description:
I'm not too familiar with Japanese food, and the menus didn't have pictures but the waitress was kind enough to explain each rice dish with me and even recommended her favorite. I took her up on her recommendation and was not disappointed. Their kaarage don (?) basically chicken on rice bowl, is the bomb. I also ordered a california roll which was cheap, but the quality of the sushi was great, not cheap at all.

Although it's a small space, the staff are so friendly, it's a good late night grub place and it's definitely one of my favorite sushi stops now.
author: Jenny M.

description: Subpar at best. The place is dark and dingy, which could be fine. But the staff was just plain rude. No hello, welcome. No may I take your order (she just stood there staring at me when she eventually came over). No offers for more water or is everything okay. My ramen was bland. The sushi roll was acceptable, but a mess. Some pieces of the roll had fish, others not at all. And it was falling apart upon arrival and I could barely pick it up with my chopsticks. See photo.
author: Heather H.

description:
Came here with some friends that were visiting San Fran and staying at a hotel in the area.  

The ramen here is below average.  The broth is not as flavorful as I have had at other places in the bay area. There were very few vegetables in the ramen which hurt the presentation and made it less enjoyable to eat.  The worst part though was the noodles, I am not a fan of ramen joints that use a noodle similar to spaghetti. It's not the texture I want with ramen and doesn't compliment the broth.

It's not bad but there are so many great ramen joints in the bay area, don't let this be the one you experience if you are visiting.
author: Steve M.

description: Ramen was pretty tasty. Came here late one night after work and enjoyed myself. Had some fun 90s/00s hiphop playing. Atmosphere was cool. Ate in the bottom half of the restaurant which is like underground. Service could have been better and my only other complain is that for $15 a bowl the vegetarian ramen should have more of the broccoli and carrots, etc instead of just a ton of cabbage. I also would have preferred if they used extra firm tofu instead of soft. Will be back.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I had heard mixed things about Katana-Ya, was craving Japanese food after work, and wanted to make up my own mind about the restaurant, so I decided to venture in and see what was up.

PRE-FOOD
It's in a pretty prime location, about a 4-minute walk from Union Square. In other words, a super convenient place to go to after you finish shopping! Once I arrived at the restaurant, I was kind of confused about how to place myself in line since I didn't see any designated person taking down names. There's a sign-in sheet on a shelf right outside of the main door and next to the outdoor menu - make sure you don't veer too far away from the restaurant while you wait, because I hear that they place you at the end of the line if you're not there when they call you. I ate at around 7:00, and the wait-time was not even 10 minutes long, which was great!

FOOD: 3/5
I ordered the BBQ Pork Ramen with Soy Broth in combination with the Tonkatsu Don. The cutlet was pretty tasty - crispy and tender like a good cutlet should be. The serving size was relatively large considering how much ramen they give you, which really adds to the value of the meal. The ramen was very mediocre. The noodles were cooked well, the broth was decent, the pork was a little boring, and the lack of toppings was a tad underwhelming. Overall, I understand the ambivalence of Yelp reviewers now. It was just a very average bowl of noodles that was pretty filling and only somewhat satisfying.

SERVICE: 4/5
Service was pretty great. I was seated quickly, and was given a water with the menu. My waiter was really nice and patient about answering some questions I had about the menu. My food came out pretty quickly, and my waiter was attentive about refilling my water and checking to see if everything was OK. The one reason why I bumped the service from a 5 to a 4 was that there was a small mix-up with my bill, but the problem was resolved. Overall though, really efficient and friendly service!

OVERALL
Food was decent, service was good. You can get a lot of food without spending too much money. Should I ever come back for a late-night meal of something, I would try something else!
author: Christina C.

description:
We luckily were staying close to this restaurant and even though there were only 3.5 stars the 3000+ reviews told us it was worth trying...and it was!!!  Small hole in the wall place, none pretentious and definitely seemed like where a lot of locals go.  I was good to the last drop!...if you can even finish the ramen bowl!!!  Plenty to eat!  We went twice in two days!  Don't let the star rating fool you!
Vegetable Ramen - miso - light - mild spicy = perfection
Pork Ramen - miso - light - was delicious but added siracha because I forgot to order it spicy.

ENJOY!!!
author: Miss H.

description:
This is for the older lady who decided to embarrass the hell out of me because I only had an American Express... and they don't take American Express. 

I ordered a Ramen and when they brought it out, the waitress saw my American Express card sitting on the table. She then asked me if I wanted a check to which I replied, "yes." She then said that they do not take American Express and then walked away. 

I stood up and walked over to the older lady at the register and said, "It is to my understanding that you do not take AmEx cards...? Since this is the only form of payment I have, I will leave what I ordered on the table untouched." 

Lady: "You already ordered it. What's the problem? Just take your card and go get cash!"

Me: "I understand I already ordered it, but I'm not going to consume it knowing that you do not take the only form of payment I have with me. You cannot get cash out of an ATM with an AmEx card - it's only a credit card." 

Lady: "BUT YOU ALREADY ORDERED IT!" (at this point she is causing a scene in the restaurant)

so then I gesture to her as I throw my hands up and say "look, I haven't eaten it. I'm not going to eat it. I am leaving it on the table and I am not paying for something I did not eat."

Lady: "Fine, I'll take your card. We don't usually, but I will do it this time."

NO THANKS! You've already caused a huge scene because you won't take my card. THEN, you tell me that you will take it..?!?! 

They have (HANDS DOWN) the worst customer service. I will not be back nor will I recommend them to anyone.
author: Marisa D.

description: This place is ok. It is good ramen, but definitely not the best in the city. The issue is the broth is very thick. I understand that thick and flavorful broth is usually a positive, but the broth here is the consistency of whole milk, but spicy, and a little bit grainy. I was pseudo-satisfied with my meal and not sure if I will return.
author: Roxanne A.

description: Get ready to wait to sit down. I ordered ramen. The portions are huge. Too bad the ramen was so so. I had better.
author: Angie N.

description: Crazy small restaurant. The seating is horrible and the wait is long, we arrived at 5 and wait a good 20 minutes for everyone's dishes to be ready. The line got really lone after 6, glad we arrived early. The dishes are considered pricy since they all come in fairly smaller dishes. I guess everything is better in Texas and I'm used to bigger plate and cheaper prices. We had don and noodles with miso based soup. They're good, but you get one slid of meat, and the mild spicy miso soup is really too mild for my taste. We probably won't come if we had to wait.
author: Ling C.

description: Little hole in the wall. Noodles were awesome, but the broth was just average. The pork was really good :)
author: Chloe P.

description: Mediocre food and bad service = less than one star. Meet was cold, took 20 minutes to get menu, 10 minutes to get the bill, and it wasn't that bisy either
author: David H.

description: Exploring union square when bf and I wanted some ramen. We saw this ramen place. And wanted to give it a try. It's a dark door that leads downstairs. Bf got a ramen with extra BBQ pork and I got a vegetable tempura udon. The ramen wasn't anything special and didn't seem like it's extra BBQ pork. My udon tasted like udon that was cooked and placed into a seaweed soup (not the udon soup base). For 2 bowls and a beer, our bill came out to be around $50. It's expensive for the quality of the food. We were full but not satisfied.
author: Connie L.

description:
If the chashu wasn't dry as cardboard, this place will be 4 stars. 

noodle wasn't too thin or too thick. slightly over cooked but bouncy like it supposed to be. 
the broth was solid. (too many places in SF makes it into soup.) they could cook it down ever so slightly but it is good already good as is. 

I wish they got the chashu right. so I can go back and give them 4 stars.
author: A O.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Monday night after work with coworkers. We arrived at around 7 and there was a line, roughly 6 parties ahead of us (guess this place is pretty popular, or it might be the "a restaurant in the downtown area" effect). When I asked the hostess/server how long the wait would be, she was very uncertain and just threw out "30 minutes or more" after a long "Uhhhhhhh" and staring at the wait list... 

Anyways, we were seated in about 30 minutes because a lot of people decided to leave instead of wait. The restaurant is super small, and we had a teeny table for four people, literally elbow to elbow. 

The ramen menu is... Interesting. They do NOT have tonkotsu broth and I was very sad. Soy sauce (shoyu), miso and I forget the last one are the only options. Then you can choose rich or light for the broth. Extra spicy costs $1.40 while mild spicy is $.50 I think. 

I ordered the combo -- regular ramen, extra spicy, rich miso with a tekkadon ($16). Definitely worth it. The broth isn't that spicy for extra spicy. If you can eat hot cheetos, you can eat the extra spicy. The regular ramen only came with one slice of pork. The tuna was super fresh, and there was a Sriracha-like sauce all over it. I was in food coma status after this meal. Okay, back to the ramen. Overall not too bad, but the noodles were slightly overcooked and seemed thinner than usual. The broth was decent and one of the better miso broths I've had, but I've had better. I also prefer tonkotsu so I was quite disappointed when they did not have it. 

My coworkers had the spicy tofu ramen, which comes with kimchi in it, the BBQ ramen, and the karaage ramen. They were all pretty satisfied and happy. 

This place is a bit...different and isn't the usual ramen place (i.e. They have a kimchi ramen, vegetable ramen with beef broth, ramen with potstickers in them and some other variations that I don't usually see). They also serve sushi, donburi, and some appetizers as well. 

I'd come back after work with my coworkers because it's close to the office. However, I wouldn't really recommend this place when there is better in the city (I like Waraku on Post in Japantown, for now at least). But for someone in downtown craving for ramen, sure -- if you don't mind the wait.
author: Doris K.

description: I was in sf for a conference and looking for the dinner options near my hotel on yelp.  This restaurant was on top by reviews. I tried and liked the food.
author: Atul K.

description: This is my favorite ramen place. It's very busy but it's so good. I am stoked about their expansion. I highly recommend and in a central (albeit touristy) part of SF.
author: Erin C.

description:
I just moved to San Francisco a little over a month ago and this place has been at the top of my list since I got here. So today I finally made time to stop by for dinner.

I had pretty high expectations for the food considering the 3000+ reviews already but honestly, I don't think the food here lived up to the hype. I ordered the katana-ya ramen in shoyu broth as well as the hand roll combo. 

The pricing for the food was reasonable, $12 for the ramen and $10 for the hand rolls and for that price it's hard to beat but the quality also wasn't quite as I had hoped. The ramen, which had karaage chicken, gyoza, and BBQ pork in it, was decent but the noodles weren't the best and I found the broth to be a little too salty. The hand rolls was also just decent at best, the rice was a bit soggy and it was disappointing to bite into. 

All in all it's worth coming back to again, although I would recommend coming before the dinner rush, as the line outside grew quickly soon after I sat down.
author: Zach C.

description: what a cute little minature spot feels like im right in japan delicous but in small portions
author: Kaylie B.

description:
What a rude people working there.
They don't even look at you when you place an order and didn't even bring utensils.
The food that I ordered didn't come.... and it came after I finished dinner. I feel like I had to beg the serving staff.  It totally messed up my appetite. I had a tummy ache after the bad dinner.
I saw some good reviews before but I have to say 'THE WORST Japanese restaurant'
Don't even waste your tome and money.
author: Diana L.

description: My go to ramen place. The seating is split into two weird spaces but the food is awesome
author: Deepa G.

description: The ramen here was amazing! I got the house ramen medium spicy and it was delicious! Would definitely recommend this place if you are in town!
author: Irma H.

description:
The ramen is average at best.  The noodles were ok, the broth was ok, the spicy tuna roll was ok, nothing to be excited about.

Why the low rating?  The service needs some help.  I witnessed
1) Not enough chicken in the chicken ramen (menu listed 6 pieces and we got 5), and no apologies when we informed the waitress
2) Waitress kicking over another patron's bags (accident yes, can be forgiven)
3) Waitress ignorning man who asked for a business card (she very nonchalantly told him to look up the website for information)
author: Yeeman N.

description:
I went here for lunch today. We started with the seared albacore tataki which was my favorite! Not too thin slices of seared albacore on a bed of lettuce with some wasabi soy sauce. It was great and super tasty! 
Next was the ramen and una don combo. The una don was just okay. Just a small bowl of rice with 3 pieces of una. The poured a lot of sauce on the rice so it was too sweet. The ramen was good but not amazing. We got the light miso soup. I really recommend the light since it was flavorful but not too salty. My friend mentioned that the regular was too salty. From that ramen I didn't really get why its ramen was the best; it was pretty good but not amazing. It was pricey too...
author: Kristy K.

description:
TLDR: GET THE FRIED CHICKEN MISO RAMEN

I'm with the other two star givers here.  As I waited in line the external appearance of individuals waiting and the Michelin sticker recommendations in the window made me drool after my 6 hour long flight from Orlando.  

After waiting maybe 20-30 minutes or so and breathing in copious amounts of second hand pot smoke from the local homeless, I was finally brought into the small shack of a restaurant.  I was excited by the size and craziness that ensued from the waitstaff of trying to please the crowd; however, I went on sitting around for another 20 minutes before getting water or being asked any questions about ordering food. Busy night I guess...

I ended up getting the agedashi tofu and the number 14 (the house ramen) which is 
inclusive of some char siu, two deep fried gyoza, corn and deboned fried chicken.  

The agedashi tofu was cooked excellent, but the complementing sauce was lackluster and nothing special.

The ramen broth was a bit watered down and over hyped by the waitstaff.  Had I known the chicken was deboned I would have just got the fried chicken ramen because this was by far the only tasty thing in the bowl. In the future I may have late night pizza instead.
author: Anthony C.

description: I was always curious about this place as there is always a lot of people standing outside. I finally got to try it recently. I'd say that the ramen is good and pretty straightforward, but it is not in the top for me. I got the salt broth so it's the lightest one, and I enjoyed the flavorful broth. I had the fried chicken ramen and the pieces felt more breading than chicken. Overall I enjoyed it and it was perfect on a chilly night, but I have definitely had better ramen.
author: James K.

description:
Came here for a nightcap after a double date night of drinking. The prices are a little steep for ramen that doesn't come with any meat ($10), but the quality is pretty on-point, and besides, ramen is healthy if you skip out on the meat right? Right? No? Oh.

The portion sizes are fairly large, so have no fear; you're getting a pretty good bang for your buck. My girlfriend and I were debating between Kimchi Ramen and the Spicy Ramen that night, and boy am I glad we settled for the Spicy Tofu Ramen. It came with tofu AND spicy cabbage (which is basically kimchi, right? No? Oh.), so I feel like I got a one-up for the same price.

The ramen itself is of a much different texture than what I'm usually used to, and while it's still good, I docked it a star because it didn't FEEL like ramen. Dismiss this criticism as you will, but in my mind, ramen has a specific texture and feel that distinguishes it from other noodles, and if you lose that, you lose a big part of it.

Still, the noodles are good, and it's close to a few bars. Perfect for a late night snack -- sober or drunk.
author: Zi-on C.

description:
Seeing as my hometown doesn't have a ramen shop, when I travel abroad I'm always on the lookout for a great bowl of this savory and sophisticated soup from overseas. 

This so-so experience started outside the shop, where there was a small line to be seated. My friend and I slid in behind a few ladies that were waiting, and settled in to wait our turn. Another group walked up 10 minutes later and sent one person inside and I quickly realized this line might not be self managed, so I asked the ladies in front of us about the wait list. They pointed to a clipboard and told us that's the way it's done at Ramen shops in the Bay so my buddy goes to add our name just as the girl is walking out with an employee to find it. She lets out a loud "UGH!", then adds her name and draws an arrow indicating they were there first. They seat everyone ahead of us, and then the employee looks at the list confused. We explain she added the arrow because she thinks they arrived first. The girl starts yelling that they were and actually went so far as to get up in our face and ask to fight over the next table. I said let her have it, but the employee RELUCTANTLY agrees to let us sit down first. 

Due to the way we were treated, I literally almost walked out during all of that. To be honest, I probably should have because it ended up being a bowl of OK ramen. We ordered up agedashi tofu as an appetizer and both of us had a bowl of Rich, Spicy Katana-Ya Ramen, which had gyoza, karaage, bbq pork, kelp, corn, and a HARD BOILED EGG. The egg had us wondering about this place, but the broth was pretty tasty, the other elements in the bowl were good and added nice texture to the soup, and the noodles were cooked just right. 

Overall, Katana-Ya was an ok ramen experience and could fill the need for some soupy goodness, but with the service we experienced, I might look elsewhere.
author: Michael T.

description:
This is my go to place when I'm in town and is craving for ramen. This place was recommended to me by a former co-worker of mine last summer when i was visit sf and I've been hooked ever since. 

My best friend and I were in SF over the weekends celebrating my birthday. Our tour bus was running late so we decided to go grab some food and this happened to be nearby. There was no line since they just opened, but this place tend to get crowed pretty fast. We both ordered the Katana-ya ramen and takoyaki. When the food came out I was in shock because I forgot how big the darn bowl of ramen was. It was A LOT of food for a a really cheap price. The soup base was so favorful it made my soul happy sipping it since it was cold outside. SF weather makes everyday a ramen kind of day. The butter fish nigiri was my favorite part of this dish. 

The only reason I marked down a star for this place was their service. The lady that was our waitress was quite rude. I don't know if its because we caught her on a bad morning or what but she was not very nice, she gave out a vibe like she did not want to be there. After we were done eating, I went to the bathroom to wash my hands and when I came back my friend told me that the waitress was rushing us to leave since we were done eating and already paid. I understand there were people outside waiting to be seated but It wasn't like we were sitting there for an hour after we already ate and paid, I was just in the bathroom for 2 minutes.
author: Nikki N.

description:
Infamous Fried Chicken Ramen: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=nBK0XuOv4sqsvphHH1oXtw#RKXLY27nJ73dUT8qnC6JRA

You know.. after trying 25+ different ramen shops, Katana-Ya is just ok. It's very popular because it's in Downtown SF, but here's a secret from your one and only Ramen Sheriff: there's another ramen shop that's in Downtown SF (financial district)! And it tastes better too! 

And here's my link to it ;) http://www.yelp.com/biz/ramen-underground-san-francisco#hrid:PcB4wM8m5g5oWBfPov4k_Q

The ramen shop in the above link also has a long wait because it's even tinier than Katana-Ya, but the ramen bowl is a lot better. If I were to recommend a ramen spot in SF, I wouldn't say Katana Ya OR Izakaya. I'd say... (click the link to find out :)
author: Raquel Y.

description: Good ramen spot! It is tiny and crowded all the time！tried their sashimi, just fair and ok. Ramen noodles are tasty! I really love the miso and soy soup base! Recommend katanaya ramen because it has everything in it. The only bad thing is soup base to too greasy!
author: Nina H.

description:
Ramen was decent. Good spot to grab a quick and hot lunch of oodles of noodles. 
I recommend the kimchi tofu ramen
author: Jeanette L.

description:
Delicious, hot, steaming bowls of ramen/udon/soba noodles PLUS a roll, rice bowl, or other fancy something or other for the amazing deal of $10 - $14?! Katana-Ya has an awesome deal going on, and I am a definite, definite fan. I can see why the line is often out the door for this tiny ramen/sushi shop -- Kimberly S and I were super lucky to get seats during a miraculous lull in patrons. Within minutes of us sitting down, several groups came in looking for a late night bite. Oh, did I forget to mention this was already at like 11 PM?

I opted for the combo that included a hot steaming bowl of udon noodles and a salmon + avocado maki roll. The roll came out scary fast, and tasted fresh, though the bites were pretty intensely big. The soup noodles came out shortly there after and was burn-your-tongue hot, just like it should be. 

We also ordered some dumplings as an appetizer, though they actually ended up coming out last so we were basically too full to enjoy. Which was fine, since they were the most tasteless part of our delicious meal anyway. Either way, next time I'm in the fine city of San Fran looking to satisfy a noodle craving, you know where to find me!
author: Gretchen F.

description: Ramen place was packed when i arrived after 8pm+ but the wait was short. Spent less than 10mins in queue and got a table. As for the ramen, i didn't like the noodles- there was no options for how i'd like it to be cooked(normal, hard, soft). I've ordered the spicy tofu ramen and the broth is okay and tasty. For those who like their broth spicy, add $1.50, more green onions add $1, ginger slices $1.50. For a table of two, our bill came up to $45. Will i visit again? Probably not but their service was good.
author: Eminence P.

description: I'm not sure if upstairs is separated from downstairs but there are two doors and people seem to line up for the one going downstairs. I got the Spicy Miso Ramen. I should've gone for the extra spicy or even habanero spicy because it was very mild to me. It comes with only 2 thinly sliced BBQ pork so I definitely recommend getting the BBQ Pork Ramen, instead. Personally, I like the seaweed dry so I can dip it quickly into the broth and eat it with my noodles but they were shredded and mixed into the broth. Overall, I thought the broth flavorful but can be richer...but still a pretty good bowl of ramen in SF.
author: Thao T.

description:
Katana-ya has been my intended target forever. And every time I passed by here, there is a ton of people waiting to be seated. The long wait with all those people deters me from dining here. 

Until a few days ago, I finally made it here for my early dinner before my trip to Oracle Arena. When I see the size of the tiny restaurant, I can tell why the long wait. I don't think this place can hold more than thirty occupants. 

On my long-awaited debut, I ordered the Katana-ya's Noodle combo. Ranging from $11.00-15.00, I get a noodle soup with a side dish. I chose the Soba Noodle soup with a side of Spicy Tuna sushi. The thick buckwheat noodle and seaweed in a milky broth was the best way to warm me up. Soup: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=yCi8oT2ZjCUWVUA4UrjKlw

The spicy tuna sushi was really good with fresh ingredients. Sushi: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=PnzM3BDq8O9-QNNAELdY_w

As I was enjoying my meal, more people arriving for dinner and the wait was on for others later on. I also like the Sapporo beer on tap with the cool silver Sapporo can knob for the beer. 'Will a $14.00 pitcher of Sapporo beer mess you up?" Beer: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=pVSJpWRia5vW_TW3XHGOIw

Many of my followers know I'm not a Japanese food expert. But I wanted to try something different. Mission accomplished on my part to finally eat here.

Will I eat here again? 

Only I come around the same time and lesser people.
author: Matt G.

description: First time having Ramen and I loved it! Got it with a mild spicy and it had a nice kick for flavor, but I added more spice to get some fire going! Lady who was our waitress was nice, but really fast to move on. No matter we had company to talk with. Overall it was great, food was excellent and I would come back
author: Andrew M.

description: This place is dark so if you want a sort of lounge vibe this is a good place. The ramen was pretty good and came in a big bowl. Takoyaki was pretty good too although that was my first time eating it. Service was nice as well.
author: C. L.

description:
Every time I am around Union Square, I thought about  coming here to eat the ramen but  I would end up eating something else. Finally last Sunday, I took a chance and came here during lunch hour. Surprisingly it was not crowded and got seated right away. 

I ordered the regular ramen with miso broth ( you can choose from miso, soy, or salt broth). The broth tasted bland and the texture of the ramen was not my cup of tea. I did not enjoyed the ramen and was not able to finish the bowl of ramen. 

I am sure that I will not be eating here again due to the food quality. The service itself is not great and the place is very small. Do not expect to come here in a group because you will never get a table or have to sit separately. Also, it is hard to find parking around this area therefore walking is a sure thing.
author: Owie N.

description:
WTF.....Why does this place have so many good reviews.  No doubt these reviews were from half soused tourist wandering in at midnight

First off I didn't know this place was operating in the 1920's and using some archaic clip board system.  As soon as I walked in I was shouted to  put my name on the clip board.  Not in a nice directing tone, but rather a scolding indignant tone harkening back to the days when my grandmother would yell at me to take off my shoes before entering the house.

But rudeness aside, it's the food that really matters in the end.  To say this place is gross would actually be complimentary.  Everything about their ramen is messed up and adulterated.  They don't even use ramen noodles!!!  It's a ramen shop god's sake.  Instead wide egg noodles are use. Other short cut include using a hard boil instead of soft boiled egg, not using pork belly but rather a pork loin "ish" looking meat that may have been in fact Oscar Meyer Bologna, and the list goes on and on.

Everybody do yourself a favor--if you're drunk, in Union Square, and want ramen go to 7-11 and buy a packet of Mauchan
author: Johnny M.

description: The dragon roll I ordered here was delicous. Their other sushi is of very high quality, and I would recommend to anyone. I had the spicy miso ramen, but it was only okay. If you're a ramen fanatic, this may not be your place. The sushi and other food makes me give this restaurant a 4/5.
author: DiAngelo S.

description: One of the most delicious ramen place ive ever been. You can choose between two ambiance for places to seat. I loved their takoyaki! very affordable and big servings. Satisfied with their customer service.
author: Camille B.

description:
What we got: Katanaya ramen (extra spicy), agedashi tofu

Our hotel was downtown and we were craving some ramen. After reading a couple reviews, we thought that Katana-Ya would be the best from our options. The place is small (probably seats 30 people or so) and tight. My chair was pretty much rubbing against the guy behind me the whole time. 
The food was ok at BEST. There wasn't anything special about it. The ramen lacked flavor and I felt as if I could throw something like this up at home.
I guess if you're craving some ramen, this would be your best bet around this area. Next time though, we'll try to convince ourselves to crave something else.
author: Marc C.

description: This used to be our fav place for ramen. Since the new management everything is going downhill. The pricing is jacked up, just two piece nigiri cost $8, Its unheard of. First time ever I didn't have to wait in line, the restaurant was empty when we got in, now I know why. Ramen is not good at all, it felt like we were eating packet ramen which gives pretty bad after taste. But cost $15. Unfortunately this is the last time for us here.
author: Shreeza S.

description:
Last night marked my return to Katana-Ya after five years. As I ducked under the red curtain and walked into the tiny dining area I was transported back to the night I had one of the first legitimate ramen experiences of my life. That is to say, ramen that didn't come from a cup or a square wrapper with a seasoning packet inside. That night rich broth, savory slices of bbq pork, spicy kimchi fried rice and ice cold beer wooed me. 

Some experiences are better left as cherished memories.

This place has not aged well. In the city on business with a few of my colleagues, I recommended we visit Katana-Ya for a bowl of ramen at one of my favorite spots. Most of my colleagues don't have as much experience slurping down ramen as I do and I answered most of their questions, but when asking the waitress about the menu, they received pretty hostile treatment. Not cool. 

As for the food, the noodles were far too undercooked while the pork and the broth (salt/soy/ or miso) were just so so. The only saving grace was the kimchi fried rice. I'll admit this meal at this 3.5 star (it was 4.5 stars years ago) was more disappointing than a bad meal at a 5 star because of the sentimental value, but it would be wrong to attribute this underwhelming experience to the unsuccessful recapture of a meal I had years ago. Since my first visit I've had better ramen, and I'm certain my standards have gone up, but ultimately the food speaks for itself. Whatever magic Katana-Ya once had is gone. And so am I. On to find the next great bowl of ramen in this city.
author: Sergio R.

description:
I've passed by this place on many occasions.  There is always a wait, but luckily the evening a friend and I went, the wait was less than 10 minutes.  The menu is pretty extensive and Katana-Ya offers everything from maguro sashimi to fried chicken ramen.  

I ordered the fried chicken ramen combination that came with a side of curry rice.  I was a fat ass and split an order of gyoza with my friend as well.  I am sure I will receive some flack for this, but the ramen here was tasty, the broth was well balanced, and the karaage atop the ramen was crunchy/salty awesomeness!  I would say that this bowl of ramen was so good in fact, that it's probably one of the best bowls I've had since moving up to the Bay.  Say what you will!

If it weren't for the extensive wait and the congested location of the restaurant, I would definitely come back to this place again and again and again.
author: Josh S.

description:
Came back to this place about 3 times so far and I love it! 
The place is a bit crammed and is usually a bit busy, but good. 

The very first time, I wanted to order the spicy beef ramen, since I love spicy foods,  but they were out, so I opted for the spicy tofu ramen instead. It seems to me that ramen is generally pretty salty for my taste, and so this spicy ramen was particularly salty. My brother got the Katana-ya ramen, and he kindly let me taste it and it was delicious! I like the regular ramen broth better than the spicy broth because it was less salty! 

The next two visits, I had the special that came with your choice of noodles: udon, ramen, or soba, and your choice of a side dish for about $15 dollars without tax & tip. I chose the regular ramen with a miso base and the Poke don. Loved the ramen AND the poke as well!! Good deal and good food!
author: Christina C.

description:
Over-rated but it's one of the few quick, easy, and cheap places to eat when you're shopping on Powell. The broth here is nothing special and the same could be said about the toppings and noodles. 

But with the right expectations, your belly will still be satisfied after a meal here. I would go with the chicken karage ramen or the Katana-ya ramen (comes with chicken karage and deep-fried gyozas). It's not exactly your traditional Japanese add-ons, but just think of it like going to Panda Express for Chinese food....

If there's a line, bounce immediately! Not worth the wait!
author: Catherine C.

description:
I was new in town with a co-worker for a conference, and we just wanted to go get dinner since we're tired. This was close to the hotel we were staying in.

We both had the house ramen (Katana-ya Ramen) on miso, and I liked it very much. Hearty, but not too salty. It had chasu pork, karaage (fried chicken), and veggie gyoza along with your standard ingredients, so it was good in my book.

I'd recommend this place if I'm trying to introduce them to ramen.
author: John D.

description:
Came here with high hopes as I was told from a friend that this place is good.  Arrived in our group of 3 and was seated within 10 minutes.  Upon seating, we were given a menu and was ignored for the next 10 minutes.  I understand there were other guests that needs to be tended to and you need to figure out how to seat the next few parties waiting but this little ramen shop probably holds no more than 30 people.  After flagging down a waitress, we ordered 2 katana-ya ramen (fried chicken on the side) and butter corn ramen.  Probably should've ordered the potsticker on the side too as otherwise the chicken and potsticker becomes soggy from sitting in the broth.  

As I took my excited and hungry self to take the first bite, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off with my ramen.
