Was it me or did my ramen noodle texture seem to be like flat noodles?  It wasn't until my friend pointed out that yea the ramen texture was similar to that of cup of noodles. Likewise, she was disappointed but not from the noodles but from the broth as it lacked flavor and richness(perhaps we could've went for the option between light/rich but we were never asked...so we'll blame ourselves for that)  Overall the meal and service was rather lackluster.  I was definitely full from my meal but the quality of food and service was a downer.  I'd come back if I was really craving ramen near Union Square but I'd rather travel elsewhere to get my ramen fix.

$38 for 3 people + tip = $45 (about $15 pp is a tad high for this place)

Sorry Katana-Ya, maybe we'll cross paths again eventually but preferably not soon.
author: Samuel Y.

description: The ramen is not bad. You don't need to wait during dinner time.
author: Qianren Z.

description: The food was delicious! It was a little pricy but I think the food tasted so good, it made up for how much we had to pay for. I also loved the atmosphere as well: dim lighting, cozy seating. There was also a bar if you prefer that instead of dining tables. I would give 5 stars but the service wasn't that great. It wasn't that busy when we sat down, but it took awhile for the waitress to get to us just to take our order. Also, a couple sat down AFTER we did and they received their food first before we did. So overall 4 stars because, food was great but service was just a tad too slow.
author: Mae-Elisa S.

description:
This place used to be one of my favorite ramen restaurant in the city. Now I understand why there were no more lines and some people gave bad reviews.

The food quality & taste are getting worse and worse over time. I ordered Katanaya ramen & rice tops with uni & salmon. 

The Katanaya ramen tasted horrible. Having vegetable gyoza & deep fried chicken inside the ramen is clearly a terrible idea! Not only that they tasted horrible, those deep fried stuff suck up a lot of liquid in the ramen. It's like having a pile of sh*t in your ramen!!!
I really don't understand. Ramen is not supposed to be filled in with a bunch of greasy deep fried stuff!! You can try to be generous but not with sh*tty food that I don't even need it. You should not throw all junk food inside your ramen and serves it to your customer!!

The uni & salmon roe didn't taste fresh either. They tasted really weird!

Having this horrible food convinced me that I should not come back!!!
author: Bee L.

description:
The ramen here isn't impressive..I ordered the Katana-ya in miso,which is a hefty sized ramen with corn, chasu, fried dumplings, fried chicken, half a hard-boiled egg, scallions, sea veggies and bamboo shoots.

My bowl of ramen seemed to be served lukewarm, is that normal? Parts of the soup were warm but the temperature of the noodles probably brought down the heat of the soup. The noodles were good, easy to chew and seemed fresh.

The toppings of the ramen were SO DISAPPOINTING! The chasu was thick cut but also was so tough!  I also usually expect a soft boiled egg..hard boiled eggs just make the ramen seem cheap. Oh well, not my place to say. 

Portions were good, it's a big bowl but cost $12.50. I'm saying that this is fair considering all the toppings that come with the ramen, though I found them disappointing. The fried chicken and dumplings were of course soggy, so didn't seem freshly made..

Also ordered an agadash-tofu, which was pretty alright.

Poor service, they could be a little more polite. Every other ramen shop I've been to has had exceptional service. Lol.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Played an endless loop of shitty Black Eyed Peas music. $9 for cucumber sushi with too sweet rice $15 for ramen. It made me sad just eating here
author: Tori l.

description: We waited 27 minutes to be sat. My boyfriend order the katana-Ya ramen. The only complaint was the boiled egg wasn't as runny as other places. The ramen and Seaweed salad good price for amount. BEST potstickers. Could have better selection of sushi.
author: Haleigh M.

description: Really average food, and terrible service.  But hey, at least it's expensive and has really long wait times.  Skip it.
author: Ben H.

description:
I'm not really sure why this place has so many ratings or why it gets so packed. It's not really that good and there's nothing special about it. 

Tried the Katana-Ya ramen and for $13, it's a pretty big ramen. Too bad it's not amazing or anything. I don't like how the gyoza and chicken is fried and put in the ramen. Why fry it if it's going to get soggy? I asked the difference between rich and light (never heard of that before), and the server basically said rich is creamier and light isn't as salty. I usually don't like salty food but I went for 'rich' because she made it sound better. Oh yeah, and their menu says they add msg in their broth, but for some reason I totally missed that and my friends told me afterward. I should've gotten 'light' because the ramen was very salty and full of msg. Not authentic ramen, in my opinion. 

The server was very forgetful, and didn't make sense. My boyfriend wanted his ramen to be a little spicy and asked for it (about $2 to make any ramen spicy). The server said, oh so extra spicy? He said, no, just a little spicy. She goes, oh sorry we can't do that. Just extra spicy. What? How does that make sense? If you can do extra spicy, you can do normal spicy. Just don't add so much -___-. This conversation took hella long just to talk about the level of spiciness. It was pretty stupid.

I wouldn't have came here if this place wasn't so close to Union Square. Don't live in SF, but wouldn't consider coming back even if I was in town.
author: Michelle L.

description:
On the day of the Epic Ramen Festival, it looked like a lot of people had the same idea as me: Screw the ramen festival and four hour lines for mediocre ramen burgers; let's just get ramen at a restaurant. We got to Katana-Ya and the waiting list was already half full, and the outside of the restaurant was intimidatingly crowded with other hungry customers willing to brave the wait. Defeatedly, I signed my name but we thought it'd take forever, so we left to see if Ajisen had a shorter wait. It did not. By the time we got back, our name had already been called. Luckily, once I got ahold of a waitress (which took ten minutes by itself), she called us next. 

The restaurant is small, but I'm not picky about spaces as long as the food is good. My friend and I ordered the soft-shelled crab and the deep fried chicken ramen. The crab was deliciously crispy and hot, and I dipped my crab into the salad dressing (so good!), instead of the sauce they provided us. The ramen came next, and the noodles were delightfully chewy. The chicken was soft, not overcooked. My main gripe is that the broth was a bit too salty and kept me reaching for water, though I prefer too salty over tasteless. The portions are big and definitely worth the $8-10 you spend. Service was fast, although the waitresses took a while to refill water. If you're looking to avoid lines, you probably shouldn't come here (or any good restaurant in SF), but I'd say it was worth the wait.
author: Sophie W.

description: All fresh and cramped in this little consistent treasure. Locals and yokels love it and the sushi and Ramen rocks.
author: David B.

description:
Visited here since I was working in San Francisco for the day and figured I might as well take advantage of the plentiful food opportunities that SF has.  Had the BBQ pork ramen with miso.  

I mean, I guess it hit the spot.  But given that I usually have a good memory awesome food that I've had and that I can barely recall this bowl of ramen, I can't really say too much else.  At least I do have a picture of what I ate.
author: Alexander Y.

description: the service was great at this place. my friend ran 35 minutes late (sigh / lol) and they let me keep myself busy at a table and order tea. we shared 3 rolls between the two of us, and they were okay. some of the rolls were bulging with tuna that tasted like it had been sitting out for a while and one of the rolls had onion in it, which didn't work out so well with salmon.
author: Meryam B.

description: The service is okay, but the food is disappointing and overpriced... me and my friends ordered the katanaya ramens which includes gyoza and fried chickens. At the beginning we expected gyoza and fried chickens would be served in a separate plates, however it turns out they put them in the ramen and made it very soggy.... the noodle tastes like instant ramen... it is totally not worth $16...
author: Daniel C.

description: My boyfriend and I had our first date here! The sushi was good and the place is great! I remember sitting at the bar close to the bathroom. The service is amazing. The place is kind of small but cozy and service was great. Parking is hard to find.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Ramen was way too salty. Topping was almost nothing. It had three thin slices of pork, scallions. Everything else which should be basic in a ramen (cooked egg, vegetables) has to be paid as extra. 

Gyoza was soaked in oil and disgusting. I had two pieces and couldn't finish the rest. 

Service was poor and inattentive. 

Overall bad experience and will never go back.
author: Ji l.

description:
Yay to my 400th review!  

Today was a special day...it was a day where wifey and I both joined lottery pools at our work...we thought it would be a sure thing to win the mega millions...or at least get 5 numbers.  Are we millionaires?  Nope.  But we did finally get to try katana-ya...AND we didn't have to wait for a table.  Chances of winning the lotto?  1 in 176 million.  Chances of getting a table at katana- ya?  Pretty gosh darn lucky if you ask me.  

We picked up the last table...a small little area in between 2 doors.  Employees kept walking in and out of the door to the right of us...but we prob shouldn't complain.  There was a huge line after us.  We were greeted within a few mins and the server took our order.  

Wifey ordered the unagi don with soy sauce ramen combo...I ordered the uni ikura don.  The server somehow misunderstood wifey and brought her a spicy tuna don...normally we'd just bear down and eat the wrong item but wifey doesn't really eat spicy foods.  we had to call back the server to change her dish.  Yeah, the server wasn't too happy with that.  She looked super irritated and didn't even bother to apologize...heck, she didn't say a single word!  -1 star.  

Anyhoo, once the correct dish arrived...everything was delish.  The ramen was super tasty...we ordered the light ramen which was already heavy...I can't even imagine how the broth is for the other 2.  The noodles were plentiful and cooked perfectly.  The pork was thick and super flavorful.  I freakin love uni...put it on anything and bam, you've won my heart.  

Another complaint was that we felt super rushed...we eat pretty dang quickly already in the first place.  We were prob in and out within 20 minutes...but I hate when someone hovers over me as I take out my wallet to pay the bill.  You just dropped it on the table.  Give me some space, will ya!?!?!  -1 star. 

Great food...awesome ramen...decent prices.  Definitely would've been 5 stars if it weren't for the minor irritating details...I'll go back again for the food...and if the service improves, I'll definitely bump it up to 5 with an update.
author: Jen W.

description:
A letdown. Lots of choices on the menu and big portion sizes but not the best tasting food. I came in here for a late lunch, because I was craving Japanese curry. I asked for the katsu curry and was told by my server that they were completely out of curry. I went for the katanaya ramen instead, somewhat disappointed that my first choice was unavailable. 

The ramen came out quickly and was chock-full of toppings. The bowl itself was huge. It was easily the biggest portion of ramen I've ever seen at a restaurant. But that's where the good aspects of the dish end. The miso broth had a really one dimensional, salty flavor and lacked richness that I've tasted in the broth elsewhere. The noodles tasted like they came out of a package. The toppings were probably the best part of the ramen but even they were just okay... not anything to write home about. Prices were about $10-15 for most dishes and not too bad considering the massive portions. Service was alright, not great but not bad either. The interior of the restaurant is small, cramped and poorly ventilated. I came on a fairly warm day and sat near the back of the restaurant. I was practically sweating into my ramen. 

If you're in the area and dying for ramen, its not the worst place but I recommend looking elsewhere if you can.
author: Kate B.

description:
I'm sorry, but I really don't understand the hype...

The ramen was disgusting to say the least....
Spicy broth was really not spicy...
Ramen was flavorless and tasted like plastic...

I'm a hardcore foodie and this is the FIRST time where it was so bad that I couldn't bear to eat everything....
Neither could my friend....

Sorry...not coming back here again....
author: David W.

description:
Ate there last night.... Absolutely disgusting!! My stomach has been hurting all morning. 
Food:
I ordered combination miso ramen with tonkatsu bowl. The broth was super salty very clear and the noodles was overcooked. My friend ordered the katanya miso ramen and she hated it! Why do you put fried chicken and fried potstickers soaked in the ramen?? Gross!

Service:
As soon as we walked in the restaurant , the rude Asian girl said to use the other door because it's the "wrong door". Then when we were ordering and asking for more water, they kept rolling their eyes at us. I'm sorry your life might suck, but please don't take it out on us paying patrons!!
author: Victoria C.

description:
All right. So I've tried a few places in SF/ around the bay area for ramen, and from the last time I remember, this was my favorite-- it was so delicious and their ramen came in more flavors than what they offer now (either that or I was really drunk), but I give myself the benefit of the doubt.

There has been ramen I've tasted that's been better around the bay area in general and katana-ya became so expensive ($15) for a bowl of ramen- just because you're Michelin rated doesn't mean you have to double the price of what ramen used to be. Sometimes the line is literally 40 minutes long out the door as well. I've eaten inside and taken to-go and eh, it's all right there are other gems in the city you can find.
author: Sophie P.

description:
Not sure why so many negative reviews...Solid ramen options at great prices. Fast service and good music pumping through the speakers. $6 Sapporo draft hit the spot as well.

I'll be back. Those of you that won't will just make the line shorter for others, thanks!
author: Vu N.

description:
*update* 

Upon coming back to this place there were two other people in the place, and about 4 other people that work there standing around. Didn't get any service for ten minutes while the servers and staff didn't do anything. Pitty to go from a 5 star review to a one. Ended up walking out without anyone even caring or noticing. 

Get your staff inline and respect the customer or you will fail. Treat every customer like gold not like a problem that they are coming in to give you business.. Pity 

Love this place prob the best late night spot for ramen. It's super small but it's super delicious. Get the katakana ramen. The service is a little slow but it comes with the territory. Great first date spot or to come and fuel up before going out.
author: Kenneth G.

description:
On my recent visit to San Francisco, I was on a bit of a ramen quest and I think no ramen tour of the Bay Area would be complete without a visit to Katana-Ya

Reading about the restaurant told me that it has a reputation for value for money. A perusal of the menu shows that you can customise your bowl of soup noodles and then combine it with lots of other dishes to make a value combo though you can also make up your own a la carte menu

Something which made me smile is their bold declaration on the menu that they use MSG. I don't mind MSG in my food and I like their honesty

I spotted the Katana-Ya ramen on the menu, which offered amazing value for menu - deep fried potstickers, fried chicken, chashu pork and egg are included in the bowl for $12.90. I opted for ramen noodles with non spicy miso broth. The broth was flavoursome. The noodles were cooked to al dente perfection and I loved the accompaniments though the deep fried ingredients got a bit soggy towards the end of the meal

I also ordered the special of the day - hotate (scallop) nigiri. The scallop was lovely and sweet

Despite it being a small space, I lucked out in getting seated for lunch immediately. Service was friendly and the food was served up admirably fast

Its location just off Union Square is convenient and I shall definitely return
author: Yee Gan O.

description: The waitress tigy was awesome she introduced to some new sushi which was the spider roll all the food was amazing if i didnt live so far i would definitely be here 3 times a week
author: Eddie L.

description:
Ramen is good.  A lot more meat than usual ramen places.
I like the soy base ramen.  Delicious!
Knowing that it is smacked down in central SF downtown, the prices is decent and fair!
author: Phu P.

description:
I'm not a ramen expert, but I'm fairly certain Katana-Ya's ramen is only average.  I came here at 6pm on a Tuesday and did not have to wait to be seated, though there was a line by the time we left.

The two standout points?  1) There was a generous serving of noodles and they were well cooked - still had some chew and were not soggy.  2) I had the miso broth and was pleasantly surprised that I didn't feel the need to drink gallons of water afterwards due to msg overload.  (That is always my greatest fear with ramen and pho!)

The issues: 1) They put the fried chicken and fried potsticker directly in the broth which completely defeats the purpose of frying those items in the first place.  2) The pork in the potsticker was very gamey and frankly pretty disgusting.  3) The egg was not boiled in the broth but was instead half a hard boiled egg plopped into the bowl.  They couldn't even make it a soft boiled egg?!  Moreover, the hard boiled egg was overcooked so the yolk at the yolk-white border was green.  4) They charge extra to make it spicy.

Overall, I'm not impressed.
author: Beatrice W.

description: A generous three stars at that. The ramen miso rather heavy and salty. If it could maybe be dialed back a little bit. It cost extra to add a little of spice to the ramen which does really provide that much additional kick it to it. The BBQ pork with the ramen was on the bland side of things. Lastly, the place is expensive. It was close to $35 for two bowls of ramen...better to go elsewhere next time.
author: Joseph B.

description: I really like the atmosphere here as you need to go downstairs to get to the restaurant, I thought it was some good Ramen, but not really wow and I have had better so I gave it 3 stars.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Thanks to our QUEEN yelper EMI from Hawaii and the fact that our hotel was half a block away (Handlery Hotel)...I have her to thank for trying this place out! We checked into our hotel at about 11:30pm and it was freezing cold (being from Hawaii), this was the perfect place to kaukau (meaning eat in Hawaiian) since they close at 1am. 

We got there at about 12am and this place was packed to the gills like a can of sardines! We waited for about 10-15 minutes outside because there was no space to wait inside and we were freezing our tooshies being that we're from Hawaii. After finally being seated, I was shocked to see a full menu of sushi along with ramen.  I order the Chirashi even after complaining of being cold lol and other people in my party orders ramen. I've had fish more fresh in my Chirashi but it was still good... It satisfied my Chirashi craving! It was good enough that I ate it two more times after our first visit. I tried my fiancé's ramen broth and it was rich, hot, soothing, yummy and everything you want a broth to taste like from a ramen shop. We also had their gyoza which we really enjoyed as well! I will definitely be back to visit this establishment on our next trip to my City By the Bay!
author: Joan A.

description: Massive drop in quality and offerings. They cut out most of the variety of sushi they used to have and the ramen is flavorless.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Why 4 stars?  Because of the freshness!

   ---   ---   ---

It takes a special kind of place to make a Spicy Tuna Roll taste the way that Katana-Ya's did.  It's such a run of the mill roll, I usually tend to stay away unless I'm picking up a to-go sushi box from the grocery store.

This tuna tasted like it had been swimming around in the Pacific Ocean until I ordered it.  Sweet, unbridled freshness.

I also ordered the Alaskan Roll and Catepillar Roll - these weren't the best rolls I'd ever eaten, but found themselves in a class right below that.  We'll call this the "Solid" or "Real Real Good" class.  

Katana-Ya opened at 11:30, and I arrived at 11:05 to ensure that I would have a table.  I heard that there can be some decent waits at peak hours, and I didn't want to risk it.  By the time the restaurant opened, there were already enough people outside to fill it halfway up.  It definitely was not a big place, so I wouldn't recommend trying to bring a large party here.

I know Katana-Ya is known for its Ramen, but I am not a huge fan of Ramen and was told that the sushi is where its at.  I'd rank its sushi in the top five that I have ever had, but the top 2-3 places I've tried were in a class of their own.
author: Brett N.

description: This place is awesome! The ramen taste very flavorful and the sushi is real good too. Had the extra spicy miso kaarage and 6 pieces of spicy salmon roll. Everything taste very fresh too. So this is definitely one of the spots I'll be going too in the future!
author: Marcus A.

description: Ramen was great! Also had the kimchi and that perfect. Service was friendly and fast. Would recommend this place.
author: Ana B.

description:
I am shocked to see the reviews for this place are so low! My hubby and came here around 9:45 and had a great meal! We waited around 15 minutes to be seated and even that late at night there was always a queue waiting ti enter even when we were leaving. 

For appetizers we had some nigiris that were ok. My hubby had the katanaya ramen with miso & kaarage don and I had it with soy sauce. The Kaarage don was really good and juicy. As for the Ramen it was really really good! The best I've had so far. The soy one was in our opinion better than the miso. The noodles were good and there was lots and lots of toppings! The pork pieces and the egg were a little meh but the gyoza was just perfect. 

We really loved this little hole in the wall, the service was good and the fact it is open so late is just perfect. We are coming back soon!
author: Tamara S.

description:
I've been to several kickass ramen places in New York (Ippudo, Totto, Hidechan). This is my first ramen experience in SF and Katana-Ya cannot compare. Fortunately, the service was very nice, and I had a decent meal for a great price. 

I got the Katanaya ramen since it seemed to be the special here. The noodles were fine, but the broth left me wanting more. It was unnecessarily sweet even with medium spiciness. Didn't quite get the rich bone or pork fat taste I get from really great ramen places. The fried Gyoza was soggy by the time I got to it, and the chasu was dry and on the leaner side. Don't get me wrong, it's perfectly edible, but I feel I've had better ramen from food courts in LA.
author: Fred W.

description: This is an okay place to eat for your ramen fix. Don't expect it to be similar to what you get in Japan though. The broth isn't as flavorful or thick. The noodles are between medium and soft texture. The sushi rolls are super cold which leads me to believe they're premade and thrown in the fridge. Bottom line, don't expect too much. Especially if you're used the the ramen in Japan.
author: Allen T.

description: I took my friends out here for some late night ramen on a Monday night at 11pm. There was about at 20-minute wait but it was well worth it. The Katana-ya ramen with a miso base was absolutely delicious. The serving size was also a bit larger compared to other ramen places I've been to and I definitely left full. Given that other ramen parlors close at 9 or 10pm, having Katana-ya available is pretty nice.
author: Nick A.

description:
Aside from their recent BOTTOM 5% FOOD SAFETY SCORE, i would tell prospective diners that you should have two expectations going to this restaurant:  1)  Poor, rude service and 2) they are guaranteed to be out of their spicy beef ramen dish unless you are some friend of theirs or know the secret code.    

Service:  Couldn't care less about even being merely average in their delivery.  I don't think a "thank you" has ever been uttered by this wait staff.  Further, at the last second, they claimed to us that their credit card machine didn't work and demanded that we pay cash.  This is usually an indicator that the business is struggling and looking to save a few pennies.

Spicy Beef:  We have been to this restaurant over a dozen times.  Only once have we successfully ordered the spicy beef ramen.  Perhaps we should try different days?  Check...we did that and no luck.  Perhaps we should try different times of day, maybe earlier at open?  Check, we tried that as well...no luck.  We have heard from other customers that there is a some kind of secret for ordering this dish.  I suppose they didn't like the way we look (i.e. - normal and clean cut).

We will not be returning to this restaurant.
author: D J.

description: Sat and waited to order... waited.. waited.  They took to go orders before taking those who were seated. Us, along with others who tried to order, attempted to get their attention and we were obviously ignored. Left and went to Chabaa instead
author: A W.

description: I wish I can leave a zero star. The service is super rude and slow. I have waited two ramen for an hour. The waiter hasn't checked on us not even once. This's a horrible dinner experience and I don't recommend it at all.
author: Shi Z.

description:
This little place was just a few minutes walk from my hotel. The food was tasty and plentiful, if a little pricey.

Unfortunately, it was just too cramped for comfort. I sat crushed against the wall do that the wait staff could get past in the very small walking aisle.

It's worth checking out just try to go during non-peak times and sit so the arm you use to eat isn't trapped against the wall.
author: Chester M.

description:
What is the hype? I was very disappointed about my ramen, especially at the price it is at. $2 for addition of corn? 

First thing that caught my eye: the egg was very hard boiled - not at all with a golden yellow center. 

I also got a spicy broth, which is essentially liquid hot sauce poured on top of the broth. :( I can see the hot sauce splashes in my bowl. It tasted very much like vinegar based Mexican hot sauce. Not to mention, they now have habanero flavor as an option advertised all over the walls

Would have preferred my karage on the side instead of in the soup, as I prefer to preserve the crispness. But that's not their fault I forgot to ask.

Questionable how Japanese the ramen really is and wondering how it was decided to be one of SF's best ramen.  Sure, this could be stomach warming after a late night out, but not worth it. I swear my first visit years ago was much better...
author: Angela L.

description: I wish there was an option for 4.5 stars.  In my opinion, perfect ramen comes down to the broth and the noodles.  This place delivers on both.  Like other reviewers mentioned, it's a little confusing to find the sign in sheet unless you are a regular.  You do have to walk down the stairs into a space that is reminiscent of an old pub and this is no frills.  Tight tables in a dark location, BUT good ramen and the servers and kitchen staff were working their tails off trying their best to accommodate those waiting for tables.  You gotta want it at 40 mins wait time on a Tuesday night.  We were glad we did.
author: Kerri L.

description:
Got the Katanaya ramen (very good), Hawaiian roll (decent), and edemame (okay). Big portions compared to other ramen places in the city.

The people there are awesome and deserve a shoutout- my friend forgot her credit card behind and the waitress ran outside onto the street to find and catch up to us.
author: Ziran X.

description:
Fried chicken Miso Ramen - good flavor, ramen with good texture, a little on the greasy and salty side

Got in at 11:40am, no wait at all. 

Good location and decent ramen at union square.
author: JC C.

description: Wildly disappointed with this Ramen. The most flavorless ramen I have across the US. The service was poor as well, they treated us like we were a nuisance. Spend your money somewhere else...
author: Ashley M.

description:
I had a good experience here and definitely would recommend for a quick yummy lazy dinner.

Broth and noodles were good and the list of toppings was plenty. The bowl is outrageously big (which is always a positive thing) and although I believe Ramen Underground does it better - there was no wait and it's great to curb your ramen grumbles.
author: Mayra M.

description: I wish I could give zero star. The server was extremely slow and rude. She barely said anything to us when taking orders or serving food. When serving our food, she literally spilled the food onto our table. Not worth the wait at all.
author: Merlin L.

description: This place is good but last time I went. I waited 45 minutes for it to go order when I had paid for 20 minutes prior.. and they didn't know what order was mine kept asking me are you sure that's what you ordered. But all in all it was good I was just upset I had to wait an hour. The day was 12/16/16
author: James L.

description:
Overall I'd say they make a good bowl of ramen - but not great.  I've had better.  I got the Katana-Ya Ramen and asked for the fried chicken and potstickers on the side.  Everything - the broth, noodles, char siu, hard boiled egg, chicken and potstickers were all okay. The noodles were probably the best of the bunch.

Our waitress was a bit resistant to help. When my sister-in-law asked what she recommended for the ramen, she did a side sigh and said everything is honestly good. Well, that's great but that doesn't help us to narrow anything down.

I'd probably eat elsewhere next time I'm in the city.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Not sure what they're missing in their ramen, but they're missing something for sure. All the ingredients were there, present, checked in, but it's like someone forgot to taste all of them and together, they just failed. Miserably.

Overpriced mediocre ramen, just what SF needs more of.

Just don't tell the tourists waiting outside - we'll keep the real good places for ourselves, OK?
author: Stephen M.

description: I don't know what people are talking about with the bad service. The servers who were friendly and attentive to us especially being in a crazy busy restaurant. Food is delicious!!! I had the Katanaya Ramen and shared some some Sashimi with friends which was great too. I have been to a lot of Ramen places in San Francisco and Katanaya is definitely the best place I been too. The manager with Tattoos is extremely nice and friendly even if he looked like their security. I definitely will be back!!!
author: Martin D.

description:
The good:
- Eatable, ramen broth wasn't the worst I've had
- I was no longer hungry after eating here
- Close to my hotel 
- Draft beer was cold and fresh tasting

The not so good:
- Server was curt and cold, not welcoming at all
- All ramen ingredients were subpar
- Ramen noodles were chewy and hard to eat 
- Gyoza in the soup tasted old and stale

I've eaten a lot of very good ramen in my life, this was not one of those times.
author: Mark B.

description: I ordered a tuna and avocado roll and a hamaichi roll through Uber Eats. Both rolls were super salty (this is the rolls on their own, without soy sauce). Apart from the extreme saltiness, they were also very plain tasting. The combo of these two qualities made it impossible to dip the sushi into some soy sauce to give it some taste because the soy sauce would only add to the saltiness. There are better places to get sushi from.
author: Suzzette A.

description:
I just don't understand the hype. If I'm going to wait outside for food... It better be fantastic (like ramen underground). This was just ehhh.

The kimchi was terrible.

The katanya  ramen was OK but the chicken in it was inedible and the wontons were just  alright. The BBQ pork was delicious though. 

At least the servers were nice?
author: Jessie L.

description: Nice small place, went during off hours so there was no wait. Had the katanaya ramen and added spicy. It's a good ramen and worth the walk to it!
author: Isabel L.

description:
We had some errands to run downtown, and the reviews for this place were pretty good so we thought we would make it an outing.

The decor is pretty cool, and typical for ramen joints from here to Tokyo. It's a little cramped, but that perhaps only adds to the ambiance. We went straight for the ramen with no messing around with appetizers or drinks. I got spicy (extra $0.75, but worth it) shoyu, and I really enjoyed it. Now, there are a variety of topping options, including the classic sliced pork, fried dumplings, and fried chicken pieces. I went for the combo option which included everything. It was nice to sample things, but in the end it was a little overwhelming and I would probably just get the sliced pork only next time. The ramen was super-hot though and the noodles were well cooked.

No real knock here. Definitely the spicy option is worth it. I'd come back for sure if I were in the area.
author: Brent W.

description: Good spicy miso ramen and decent sushi. I was very concerned after reading the negative reviews, but there was no one where else open at the time we wanted to eat lunch! But the super negative reviews must be from picky eaters. Put your name on the paper list outside the front door --we saw so many individuals enter to meet the hostess and she gave them the boot to wait outside. Very small interior but comfortable.
author: Stephy S.

description:
I've heard so much about Katana-Ya over the past few years & even walked pass by it at night while eating at nearby Cocobang.  While I've been wanting to try one of their enormous soothing bowls of ramen, the wait & location has always kept me away.  Until a couple weeks ago that is!  My co-worker asked if I wanted to go out for some ramen & after taking the street car & getting off on Powell, she called the restaurant & asked how long the wait was & they told her there wasn't one.  When we got there a little before 12 on a Monday there were two free tables left in this tiny place.  

The menu does offer a lot of choices & I like how I can choose which broth I want & what kind of spiciness.  Even mild has a bit of a kick to it.  I got the soy broth Katana-Ya Ramen medium spiciness ($13).  The Katana-Ya Ramen reminded me so much of the Suzu Ramen at Suzu.  It came with chicken karaage, pork, gyoza & the normal toppings as well as some corn.  Everything was tasty & plentiful!  The broth was flavorful & was pretty spicy.  The noodles were cooked perfectly as well.  The mild got my co-worker coughing & they were nice enough to bring her a bowl of extra plain soy broth to balance it out. The wait time is alright, doesn't seem too long unlike when I went to Suzu in Japantown.  Service was alright but could be improved.  Just like Suzu, prices are definitely up there!

Wouldn't mind coming back for lunch though being bloated after lunch in the office isn't that great.  Four stars for now.
author: Cat C.

description: What has happened to this place?!  This used to be one of my favorite ramen places in the city.  Looks like they've had a management change, because the whole place feels different.  First of all, the ramen has gone downhill, in particular the broth.  The gyoza was deep-fried and not fully cooked.  Worst of all was the service.  The rudest wait staff I have experienced in recent memory.  The server practically threw down the menu and our ramen.  Never cracking a smile or eye contact.  They've gone downhill as the city's great ramen options have increased.   And now to see that the health department has rated them in the bottom 5% due to their safety violations...that's the nail in the coffin.
author: Eric C.

description: Had the Spicy  tofu ramen  and it was delicious. The broth  had a lot of flavor , lots of vegetables , a big bowl of soup , and a good amount of noodles. Ive been on a search for a good ramen place  and i think  i found one!  No complaints except a lil on the pricey side (but its sf!)
author: Bekah Cow ..

description:
Long wait, $12 ramen, food poisoning.  Avoid this place.

I have no idea why people wait for so long to eat here.  The ramen is subpar and not homemade.  Broth lacks complexity of flavor.  My bf and I each had our own bowl--I had the BBQ pork ramen ($11) with soy sauce base, and he had the katanaya ramen ($12.50+$1.50 to make it spicy) with spicy miso base which included fried gyoza, a hard boiled egg, and katsu.  And we BOTH got food poisoning--we didn't even share any food or drink earlier in the day, so it was definitely this place.

Sat at the dark sushi bar.  Didn't order any sushi, but witnessed the sushi chef coughing directly onto a couple rolls, and preparing the rolls without gloves.

Another patron at the bar mentioned a couple other ramen places that she considers way better than this place in Japantown.

Service was also lacking.  Asked for hot water to drink before we ordered and right before we were finished with our food, the waitress admitted she'd forgotten and asked if we still wanted it.  My stomach started feeling not so well partway into the meal, so I only ate a small portion of my ramen.  Flagged a waitress down and asked for the rest to go, and was given a small container.  Had to flag another waitress down again because the small container would only fit half of what I had left.

Since we got food poisoning, leftovers will be going into the trash anyway.
author: Vanessa O.

description: I don't normally enjoy ramen that much, but this was was easy to eat ramen. I definitely recommend adding an egg to your ramen as it makes it more flavorful. You can add an egg for $1!
author: Bertina Z.

description: Over price and salty. Don't waste your money here. You'll be disappointed. TRUST me. I was so unsatisfied  that I went next door to order from Jack in the box. Smh!!!!
author: Sammie P.

description:
I ordered pork ramen, it was so so...or not good.
pork in ramen is too dry 
ramen's miso soup is just okay.
ramen's noodle isn't good enough, just like bought from super market.
Totally, it's not original for Japan, but also special for foreign.
Actually, it makes me remember the ramen I ate near my college in my country, it's sold $ 2 dollars.
You can eat full, but it's not delicious. You have the other choice. Treasure your money.
Definitely, it's not worth this price. Maybe under $10 is reasonable.
By the way, the service not good enough, a little rush, but I don't care. I just care about the food. It won't effect the stars.
author: 文廷

description:
Arrived at 11:30 am.  Got seated right away. Surprised it was not crowded.  My co-worker enjoyed the miso based katana-ya ramen and I enjoyed the combination - miso ramen with bbq pork  don.  

$13.95 for the katana-ya ramen

$13.95 for the combination - where I selected ramen and bbq don 

Ramen had good flavor, but a little oily. 
Bbq Don came with seaweed,  lots of pork slices over rice.  

Came here numerous times.  Each time I leave satisfied with my meal.
author: E. C.

description: Food was salty. Ordered a tempura but never came. Ordered a don katsu which was supposed to come with miso soup. But they forgot to serve miso soup.
author: Xia W.

description:
Brace yourself for the wait and cramped quarters. It's definitely not a place for groups larger than 6 ('dd recommend 4 or less). While it's known for its ramen, it's definitely not authentic Japanese ramen, but it's delicious regardless. The serving size is also super generous! I recommend either the miso based fried chicken (karage) ramen extra spicy or the miso based spicy tofu ramen. If you want to spice it up, DEFINITELY ask for extra spicy. The spicy upgrade alone does pretty much nothing. Also, try to take out the chicken and not let it soak - it'll get too soggy.

Service is prompt and you will get your money's worth. Worth stopping by if you're downtown!
author: Nikki R.

description: Maybe I was super full from eating at off the grid, maybe it just wasn't that good? I might have to try it once more on a empty stomach, but I didn't think it was anything too special. I went when two of my friends, one who had been there before and one who likes to eat everything and anything (almost). The one who had been there before really liked it and thus why he took us there. The service was great and we got seated pretty quickly for a Friday night. We all ordered the same thing - the katanaya ramen (which has everything - from pot stickers to fried chicken to pork). I personally thought the broth was a little too salty for me.. Along with all the other fixings.. Making it SUPER salty. Also, the egg was way too boiled. I prefer my ramen egg to be soft boiled and I felt like this was a full on hard boiled egg. I could have lived without the fried chicken and potstickers - they were soggy after being in the broth and maybe it would have been less salty without those two components. Definitely would give it another try, but maybe try one of the more simple ramens...
author: Erika C.

description: I've tried a lot of different ramen places in the area and this one really takes the cake. The service is top notch too and the setting reminds me of real ramen spots in Japan!
author: Sat D.

description:
3.5 stars, but I rounded up*

I got the BBQ Ramen with miso soup base. I thought the ramen noodles were cooked just right (at least to my liking) and the soup base found a great balance of not too miso-y and not miso-y enough. The meat is how I judge ramens, now that japanese ramen is so popular. There was nothing special about the meat, but I did like their service, even though it's a very busy place, and I enjoyed the meal overall.
author: Grace C.

description: One of the best ramen restaurants in San Francisco. I can tell that their ramen is fresh and handmade. Recommended for ramen lovers.
author: Tran M.

description: is good but the taste is soso for me i order spicy beef but to me is not spicy and i put more chilly but no spicy too is ok for other people like no spicy and im asian and the eeg is lik well done in ramen i think onsen egg is better
author: Namwan L.

description: Very bad service... i ordered sushi for to go and I waited for an hour... man just so annoying....
author: Evelyn B.

description:
I loved it! The Ramen is sooooo good. I am a huge uni fan and I was impressed with their uni quality. Very fresh and good amount.
Our server disappeared at one point so had to wait to get a check from other server. I wish this restaurant is in Chicago ;/
author: Hanna L.

description:
Great sushi! I recommend the Caterpillar and Alaskan Delight rolls.  Extra spicy vegetarian ramen was delicious, plenty of vegetable, I added kimchi as a topping and it tasted great!  
We were 4 and were seated quickly. Will definitely come again!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Came for dinner, not too crowed at 5PM.
Ordered Cheese Age and Katana-ya Ramen extra spicy, the Ramen is the worst ramen I have ever had, chicken and Gyoza in the ramen very cold inside and not crispy at all.

The service is very good. (Only the old Japanese lady)
author: Thancha N.

description:
The fact that this place usually has lines for such subpar Ramen, speaks to the still sad state of Ramen in San Francisco. They've expanded with service extending to the small restaurant next-door, that used to be shabu shabu and their menu has changed a little, but not for the better. 

The noodles aren't particularly fresh tasting and the broth has a strange sort of sweetness to it, that couldn't be masked by any amount of pepper or hot sauce.  

The redeeming qualities of the place are good service and decent kaarage.
author: Baron C.

description:
I think this place is no longer worth going for most of the ramen lovers who already have their favorite ramen places no matter where. I would like to give a 2.5 star which for me means not worth coming back any more and certainly not recommend to others. But I waited in the rain for almost 20 minutes and the services at least not bad. 
Reading all the previous review made me just ordered the Katana-ya ramen with soy base and miso base for my BF. Miso is salty and denser than soy and these two base absolutely are at low cost to ramen restaurant compared to those tonkotsu ramen base. The fried dumpling and karage is so so and oil in general. Just as most people said they just put different toppings on top of a big portion of ramen noodle with salty broth.
author: Siyue Y.

description: Ordered tuna poke today. It was too spicy for me. It's like they drowned the whole salad in spicy dressing. Took tums later the evening. Still can't eat anything.
author: Raymond V.

description: I don't know what happens for this store ,it is overprice now and kimchi fried rice is too salty and taste not good. Anyway, it disappointed.
author: Yuyan M.

description: Food was meh, service was meh meh. Used to be better a few years ago. Flavors we're a little more one dimensional than I remember and the service was just ok, just not very attentive. There are a ton of great places in sf and if you want something memorable I'd go elsewhere. If you live on top of katanaya and forgot to buy groceries and it's 8pm on a Wednesday night, yea grab a bite.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Had the Katana Ya ramen. Corn, fried chicken, gyoza,  fried potatoes, seaweed, scallion, BBQ pork, & boiled egg. So incredibly stuffed. So incredibly delicious. 

Worth a 30 minute wait and $13? For me, just barely. Your mileage may vary.
author: Davin L.

description:
Second time here, this time for sushi takeout. I called repeatedly around 2pm on a week day. No one picked up for half an hour straight. Finally, went to the restaurant during my lunch hour to order and waited 15 mins for the order to be ready. The restaurant was half empty when I arrived so I'm not sure why no one was picking up before. There were 2 "waiters/cashiers", 2 sushi "chefs", and another lady who appeared to be the "owner/manager", all in plain sight. Both sushi "chefs" were just standing idle until my order came in, and the other 3 were talking around the cash register, where the phone was, for most of my wait time.

Ordered the "Rainbow" Roll. It was overpriced at $13.95 for what I'm about to describe: there was uncooked/raw rice in every bite, the rice was not seasoned (no vinegar) and the presentation was so sloppy (didn't look like any Rainbow Roll I've ever ordered, see photo). The rice issues were proof that the "chefs" don't taste their food and the presentation was proof that not only do the "chefs" not care, but that there is no quality control. 

My "Rainbow" Roll - http://bit.ly/1I19Uu7

A few years ago, my first time here, I dined in with friends for ramen. The chicken karaage tasted like it was fried in oil that was not fresh and it overwhelmed the overall taste since they were just sitting soggy in the broth. My friend said the same thing about the gyoza that were also sitting in the broth. Then in the middle of dinner, we were sitting at the table by the window on the right side (as you're walking into the restaurant)... pieces of the ceiling came crashing down onto our table and our neighbors'. Black water from above also splashed/dripped into my friend's ramen - it had been raining off/on for a couple days when this happened. There was a big enough hole in the ceiling that we could tell there was a storage space above. 

Based on these 2 experiences, I won't be going back again.
author: Nadine D.

description:
This place is alright.

I don't understand how it got michelin recommended. No mind blowing ramen here.

I've come here twice only because its one of the only ramen places in the union sq/fidi area and one of the times we thought they maybe had gluten free noodles (they actually don't).

The bbq pork ramen was greasier than the broth that i've had at other ramen places and had 4 pieces of pork in it and lots of green onions. I'd say for $11 its pricey for what you get.
author: Sheena N.

description:
Went here as a suggestion from a friend in Houston. My boyfriend and I ordered a roll, a few pieces and each a bowl of ramen. From what I concluded, I could tell this place does not focus on sushi so I had fairly low expectations for fresh fish and I was right. It was not as fresh and well executed as I wanted it to be. With being in SF, there are way more options than this place. 

The ramen itself was served in incredibly large proportions. Way too large for one person. I felt like I've had better options in my hometown for way less. I ordered the spicy miso broth. I don't recall much of my experience at this restaurant besides the fact that it was mediocre at best. I remember feeling awkward because the walls are lined with mirrors and I could see what everyone was doing at their table and behind the counter...
author: Debbie P.

description:
Katana-yeah!

We tried them for lunch and I guess we were lucky. We walked right in, no wait. We each got the katanaya ramen. The broth was flavorful. I went soy sauce, Marty went salt. I think I liked his broth a little better. So many little presents of yummy goodness in one bowl. Still looking for a place where they make the noodles right there but these noodles were fresh and had a good chew to them. No complaints except that there was too much food and we couldnt finish it!
author: Mimi G.

description: Delicious potstickers in the ramen! Had the signature ramen miso style. Delicious! 2 sushi rolls- both on point. Good amount f fish. Flavors were balanced really well.
author: Cassy L.

description:
It's a pretty small ramen joint in the heart of downtown union square. There's a sign in sheet outside the restaurant to write your name and the number of your party down. I went with a group of 5, and that was quite big too. I suggest sticking to 4 and smaller party size. 

We ordered regular ramen, BBQ ramen, and the spicy beef tofu ramen. Ordered miso base for all of them as well as medium spiciness. Out of all of them, I enjoyed the BBQ ramen the most, it came with pieces of cha-shu pork and the soup was the most flavorful of all. The regular ramen was delicious as well, but not as good as the BBQ ramen. The spicy beef tofu ramen had kimchi based miso soup, reminded me a lot of kimchi soup or stew I had growing up with added beef, tofu, and the miso based soup.We also ordered a roll, I believe it was the rainbow roll? But really fresh fish, tuna and salmon to be exact. 

Service was just okay, I hear this place is always busy, so wasn't expecting any spectacular service.

TL;DR: BBQ Ramen, if you like kimchi go for the spicy tofu beef one, but overall pretty solid ramen joint! Would visit again when visiting SF.
author: Tina Y.

description:
They have been serving ramen for as long as  I can remember. It might be safe to say that they are one of the original places in SF that started to serve Japanese ramen before it became a trend. 

Their food is good and consistent. Sitting in the bar and hearing few words of Japanese exchanged between the waitresses will have you thinking that you may be in Japan.
author: Youna K.

description:
3000+ reviews in San Fran, I had high expectations, unfortunately, like many other yelpers, I believe this place is overhyped. 

I arrived around 845pm on a Tuesday night, and were lucky enough to get seated immediately. (A waitlist formed after we were seated, even at the late hour!) This place is SMALL. My seat near the door was uncomfortably seated against the wall, and my boyfriend was far too close to the table behind him. 

For an appetizer, which we received after our ramen, we got the Poke Salad. IT WAS AWFUL. We both at one piece each and it tasted so fishy, we thought we were going to get sick, so we didn't eat anymore. Dont get this.

We opted for the Katana-Ya Special Ramen with Miso, extra spicy. I thought the ramen was decent, just a bit too oily. The broth left a lot to be desired, and overall I just wasn't slurrping it down like i anticipated. The bowl does come with 2 pieces of pork, gyoza, egg and other fixings, but for some reason still falls a little flat. 

I don't rate too harshly because I didn't wait long, but I imagine people wait hours in such a small place. I don't think i'll be back.
author: Krystle B.

description: Rich miso ramen soup perfect for the cold San Francisco weather. I ordered their house special and sip every drop of it. The  egg ramen noodles is flavory and the meat slices are so tender. They have added corn and fried gyoza. I would surely recommend the place to my friends. The place is small and crowded, got lucky we did not have to wait for our table.
author: Marco S.

description: Ramen is decent (broth is very salty). Can't really enjoy my food in this place though
author: Sui N.

description: Great bowl of ramen! The special combo is a great idea, with at least a little spice. The place is small and cramped, and waiting can be rough (I saw a table of four who came after us seated before us despite a sign up sheet) but it really is worth it. They also forgot to bring one of our party's bowls out entirely, even after reminding them several times that he hadn't got it. But they gave it to us in a take home container at the end of our stay, free of charge!
author: Peter M.

description:
Don't know why that place has so many reviews, perhaps, because of its location. Ramen is average, I would give it 3 starts. 

I really didn't like the service. First, nobody came to take an order. Then the waitress just threw the plates to our table. I won't come back.

Besides, the check included items we didn't order. First gave them 2 stars, but then saw the check...
author: Olga V.

description:
Still thee best Ramen in town!!! This is 2nd/3rd favorite overall Ramen place (Monta in Las Vegas still my #1). 

Anytime I am in town, this is a must have and must stop! Be patient, there is always a wait, but its worth it! Trust me!

Happy slurping!!!
author: Johnny P.

description:
First time at a place with over 2,000 reviews! Yes, with 2k reviews and 4 stars I thought this place would be off the hook. Oh and it's open until 1am~ 

It can be really frustrating finding parking here, but since we came around 8pm we just found a spot on the street. No way were we gonna park in a garage - ridiculously expensive!! 

There was a 20min wait for us to get a seat. The place is tiny tiny but it moves pretty fast. We got a seat at the bar and we all ordered the namesake ramen. We're here and might as well try it. The food came out pretty quickly. I got the shoyu broth. I didn't really like my ramen. There was way too much oil from all the fried stuff they throw in there. Gross! The taste was alright, but was missing some of that pork broth flavor. Not worth the drive all the way here just for ramen. 

They wouldn't accept more than 3 credit cards per table. Well guess what?! We were at the bar. We didn't get the luxury of a table. I don't think it was fair. Actually the nice obaa-san was willing to run our cards, but the dude was rude and threw our cards back at us. WHAT? Geez. 

That left me unhappy, and I'm not coming back.
author: Cindy K.

description: Love this place. Great owner! Ramen portions are so large! One of my favorites on the city.
author: Buddy J.

description:
Our first stop on the San Francisco/Sonoma vacay was at the Ramen-famous Katana-Ya. 

Where it fits on the ramen scale:

Daikokuya :: Katana-Ya :: Ippudo

It's got that "traditional Japanese" vibe like Daikokuya (no WASPy hostess minding the trendy front entrance here, folks), and doesn't mask it's downright yummy bowl of ramen with a startlingly well-decored interior. Price-wise, it's between the LA and NY, only fitting for an SF joint.

Seating is quite limited (use the sign-in sheet if you're waiting), and there's a bar-seating area that's strictly sushi-based. No boiling pots of ramen noodles to be seen.

The big boy, the Katana-Ya ramen, is a wallet-unhealthy $13, but it comes packed with a few pieces of chicken karaage, a couple deep-fried completely crispy potstickers, half a boiled egg and a slice of pork. And some kernel corn, to boot. There's about 11 other types of ingredient-topped bowls you can get, and there's a huge variety that extends through the rest of the menu.

The broth was fantastic. We both got the medium, but you can specify if you want the broth thicker or thinner. In retrospect, thick sounds awfully appealing. We also both got the regular shoyu instead of the miso, also a good choice. Like I said, it's a little on the thin side, so if you're interested go thicker, and add spice, if that's your style. If/when I visit again, that's how I'll roll.

The noodles weren't as curly as I envisioned, and they were just a hair on the thin side. Yeah, you may be thinking, it's just noodles, but the absorption just wasn't quite where I'd have liked it to be. Needed more surface area, imo. Ramen noodles can be substituted for udon or soba, which sounds oddly fun.

The ingredients send the bowl to over-the-top tasty, but if we're strictly talking soup and noodles, I still side with Daikokuya. The chicken karaage was the highlight of the bowl. Like tempura udon, the crispiness of the chicken (and the dumplings) sober out as the meal goes on, so the first bite varies greatly from the last. The corn was an interesting touch in color, if not taste.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
We cam here for the ramen but stayed for the sushi!

Don't get me wrong they make a mean bowl of ramen but my boyfriend and I were surprised at how delicious their sushi was! Even their California rolls were packed with crab and avocado. No carrot or cucumber filler.

If you get the ramen and like it spicy go for extra spicy because spicy, in my opinion was not very spicy.

The place is very small so it isn't great for large groups but it is perfect for a date night or morning hangover fix. Also, there is a line on weekends. We got there 20 minutes before the place opened and there was already a line so come early!
author: Loryn F.

description: This is my ramen place when I am at the union square, but yesterday was a disappointment. Both of our Miso soup base ramen was way too salty and I can't even eat it. The noodle was okay, but the broth tastes funny and salty. It's like a instant noodle broth from grocery store, actually worst than it. I read a lot of recent posts comment the same salty broth issue too. They need to improve it to keep the customer happy. Anyway, I will not come back to this ramen place anymore.
author: Happy R.

description: It's the worst noodle I have ever eat. It's too salty to eat. I complain it too salty and they said they will add a cup of hot water for me but it took 30 mins to get a cup of hot water.
author: Jianhua W.

description: If you are hungry, you have found the right place because the ramen portions here are huge! If you get the kayanaya ramen you will surely be filled up because it is loaded with pork, gyoza (who knew you could put gyoza in ramen?), egg, and all sorts of other goodies. However, though I walked out satisfied and full, this wasn't the greatest ramen I had ever eaten in my life. Overall, seems like this place goes for quantity at the sacrifice of a bit of quality, but overall still an enjoyable experience.
author: Karen X.

description:
the fish was fine to their price
but overall experience was bad 
i was order a large uni lkura don $18 (not the 16.95 ramen mini donburi combination on the menu)
and u can see the pic after i take out all the radish wasabi and ginger ...  
Also when i was waiting the server was talk to chef about the order ,chef said to server that they dont have enough uni  but they didnt make any change or talk to me 
and i was order mackerel nigiri and they give me tuna
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Decent food.  Truly terrible service.

Perhaps we should have known something was wrong when we tasted the iced tea.  It was our first clue: someone had accidentally mixed coffee into the iced tea, creating a foul-tasting mixture.  But the waiter apologized and brought water, and we're pretty forgiving people.

We ordered 4 things: an appetizer of gyoza, a bowl of tempura udon for my wife, a bowl of ramen noodles and pork belly for me, and a bowl of plain udon for my teenage daughter.  The tempura came first, followed soon thereafter by the ramen.  Both were very tasty.

Ten minutes later, we asked about the plain udon.  Somebody came out from the kitchen and asked my daughter what she ordered.  "Oh, three orders.  I thought there were only two," he exclaimed and disappeared.  But, incredibly, he did not start cooking it.  We asked for it again 20 minutes later.  The waiter went into the kitchen and we could hear them say they forgot.  The waiter emerged and informed us the noodles were "still cooking."

By the time the noodles came, my wife and I had been done eating for a while.  My daughter tasted them and decided she was no longer hungry.

I asked for the check and my wife reminded me we had never gotten our gyoza appetizer.

I was pleasantly surprised that the check was only about $15, and I assumed the waiter had removed everything but one dish to make up for the lousy service.  I paid the exact amount--no tip.  (I am a good tipper--20% for minimally acceptable service--but this did not meet a minimum standard.)

As we were leaving, though, somebody from the kitchen chased me to the stairs and said they had given me the wrong check.  I said "they gave me the wrong order too" and went back to straighten it out.  The young man from the kitchen stated, "we're taking care of upstairs too.  Don't take it out on us."  I paid for everything but the gyoza and even left a small insulting tip.  

It's not the waitstaff's fault.  This place needs to hire a manager with food service experience.

As I was preparing to leave this review this morning, I saw on Yelp a health warning that the restaurant had a poor inspection.  I believe it.

Stay away.  I will not be back.
author: Jim B.

description:
Met friends here on a Saturday for dinner, they have two sides of the restaurant, which is kinda tricky. 

Three ordered ramen and loved it, the bowls looked really large and had lots in them.

Two of us ordered sushi and were less impressed. I came a few minutes after my friends had already ordered and ordered one rainbow roll.

Let's just say my friends got their food, ate all their food and I was still waiting for my one very generic sushi roll. 

Well, was it good at least you may ask?... not bad- the fish seemed fresh enough and I was hungry. It could have been rolled a bit better, several pieces were spilling open. 

I do want to go  back and try the ramen though.
author: Javi Alexa A.

description:
Avoid this place. What the hell is wrong with SF and the shitty service? I could not enjoy the food or my beer to the "could not be bothered" waitstaff in charge of serving my family. It was all I could do NOT to wring some necks. 
Ramen was ok. One star goes to the ramen. If you want good ramen AND service, then make a trip to Tokyo. Eff this place and this city. Y'all have a lot to learn.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I remember the first ramen I ever had in San Francisco was at Katanaya back in 2008. It never left a lasting impression, but I have finally made a trek back.

Katanaya has the basics of ramen down. You have shoyu (soy sauce), miso, and shio (salt) that can be varied in richness and spicy levels. Shoyu and miso are easy broths to make as the strong flavors involved can hide many flaws of the broth. I decided on the katanaya shio ramen to really gauge the flavor.

My broth came out piping hot with an abundance of noodles, two dinky pieces of chashu, 2 gyoza and to pieces of fried chicken. Let's break this bad boy down.

The broth: (3/5) the heart and soul of ramen. It was chicken based I believe but the individual flavors were muddled and none of the separate components really stood out. Almost as if it was chicken broth with msg. Not that they use msg, or that msg is bad, but the flavors were convoluted. The tare they used, if any, lacked the umami punch that a good ramen should have.

Noodles: (4/5) As the body of the ramen, the vessel for the broth, katanaya hits the spot. They were thick and had the right tooth feel to them. The texture felt a little off, but I enjoyed the noodles. They really held their shape to the very last slurp.

Toppings: (3/5) There was an abundance of toppings so I was satisfied with variety. The fried gyoza and chicken were juicy, but the chashu was sliced like sandwich meat and didn't have the unctuous mouth feel that pork belly has.

Katanaya has a dive ramen bar feel and feels dark and dank, but when enjoying ramen you just need a good place to sit and a nice bowl. I enjoyed the bowl, but with SFs ramen game slowly getting better (at a snails pace...) Katanaya is average. Props that it is open late though!

P.S. Get their early as there can be a long wait.
author: David C.

description: The food was ok. I am not a fan, but some people may like it . My Ramen was greasy, not expected. The service was not very pleasant, long wait for my boyfriend's Unagi dom, served till I almost finished my ramen.
author: Kimberly G.

description: SO DISAPPOINTED! Service was AWFUL, prices were way too high for the quality of the ramen. We have been regular patrons to Katanaya when they were at their old place upstairs, but now they increased their prices...a small beer costed us $10! And extra spicy ramen costs $17.50. Not worth it at all
author: Mark T.

description:
EXCELLENT food and very fast service. Katana-Ya was everything I had hoped it would be.

My boyfriend and I made a late night visit to Katana-Ya last night; when we walked up we were a little disappointed because there were three parties waiting outside and we expected to have to wait a while to get seated, but within five minutes the host came out, seated the parties ahead of us, and he took us inside with them.

Choosing to sit at the sushi bar instead of the small table for two wedged against the door, we took a look at the menu and decided quickly on what we wanted. I was a little put off by the fact that they charge you $1.40 to make your ramen spicy (Really? Who nickels and dimes for spiciness?), but regardless I chose to make my BBQ pork ramen extra spicy, while my boyfriend went with the Katana-Ya ramen, and we ordered the kara age and gyoza appetizers, as well.

I was really shocked by how fast the food came out - there's no way we even waited ten minutes. In fact it came out so quickly that we had our appetizers to eat alongside our meal.

The kara age was really hot, juicy, and delicious, and comes with a small salad and a wedge of lemon. The gyoza were good, not the best I've ever had, but definitely tasty and worth ordering with your ramen.

My ramen was SO good, and man, was it spicy. They weren't kidding with the "extra" as the preceding adjective. The BBQ pork was so tender I could pull it apart with my chopsticks, and as a noodle fiend I was very pleased with the amount of ramen in my bowl. The miso broth was a great compliment to the spice. My boyfriend's Katana-Ya ramen was filled with different ingredients - corn, gyoza, seaweed, and meat, among a couple of other things I can't remember - and he chose the soy broth. I tried the soy broth and it was good, but I much preferred the miso over the soy.

When we got the check, I was a little surprised to see it was $42. For two bowls of ramen and two appetizers, I thought that was a little steep, especially where the gyoza were concerned ($6.95 for four tiny gyoza is, frankly, a rip-off). I will say that the speed with which we got our food, the friendliness and attentiveness of our waitresses (and the rest of the staff), and the outstanding food made me feel better about the price, not to mention how much ramen we got in our bowls. In the future however, I'd probably refrain from order appetizers, seeing as though you get enough ramen in a serving to be satisfied and you don't really need them unless you're starving. 

Overall, a great experience, and I'd love to return.
author: Angela M.

description:
Not the same ramen taste as before 
Hardly any broth, I asked for a little more broth woman told me there would be a charge... 
Extra spicy no longer spicy 
Tuna poke super salty. 

I used to frequent this place because it's close to work but I have to find a new place. 

SO SAD!!!!
author: Shivonne T.

description: Pathetic service. Unorganized arrangement. Waited super long when there are tables available right in front of us.
author: Tim Y.

description:
This is my favorite ramen place in San Francisco. It's actually near Union Square and the ramen here is better than the ones in Japan town.

Go with their house ramen, the "katanaya" and order it with soy sauce. I usually try to order it with extra egg.
author: Mark Johannes C.

description: Friendly hospitable service.  Always nice to customers.  Nice location too.  Can be a bit crowded, but otherwise it is ok.
author: George P.

description: Good ramen but there is better out there. 3 stars for price. 4 stars for food. $9 for a draft beer are you kidding me? Extra spicy for 1.50 was not worth it. Reminded me of cheap ramen in Japan, okay but there's better out there for the same price. Cool vibes for late night though.
author: Don E.

description:
This place might be a little over-rated.

I intentionally went early - at just before 5pm - and I'm glad I did. Sat at the bar and ordered their Katana-Ya ramen which comes with gyoza, chicken karaage, chasu, seaweed, green onions, corn. Their miso soup base didn't have a particularly strong bean taste I typically prefer, but that may be due to regional style of soup their chef brings. The noodles are actually pretty close to what I like - al dente and not too chewy, with a bit of that kansui taste which brings me back to memories of a Tokyo trip a few years ago. The rest was a bit underwhelming - maybe I just had too high of expectations from seeing this place on almost every SF ramen list that exists on the internet. 

The egg was fully hard-boiled (bleh) and the gyoza & karaage was soggy - I should've asked them to serve separately. 

This place also needs a bit of clean up. I mean, I don't expect a lot from a small Japanese ramen shop...afterall, the sometimes stuffy, cluttered shop (anyone remember the old Ramen Underground before they moved?) are characteristics of what makes a ramen shop feel like one. BUT there are literally strings of dust hanging as if they're about to fall from the ceiling, directly above where the sushi chefs are preparing their dishes. 

In the end, I really wouldn't wait 1+ hour for a bowl of ramen at Katana-Ya, not really worth it. It's good, but not THAT good. I can easily name a couple of other places in the city that are much better, like Miki in Outer Richmond and Ken Ken in the Mission.
author: Jackie C.

description:
This review is for a takeout, but judging by the really cramped dining area inside and the hurried staff, I wouldn't want to go back for a dining experience.

I ordered the pork ramen, miso broth, and thick to go. I've had many a good ramen in my life, especially in Tokyo, and this was average. The broth lacked depth, and the ramen noodles were really thick and too firm.

For $11+ a bowl, it's pricey. And I guess it's location means it will always be a bit touristy. It does get really crowded though. At 10pm on a Thursday, the place was packed with a small queue outside.
author: Boon K.

description: Good ramen but the worst service I've ever seen. If you want to impress someone or enjoy your meal without waiting an excessive amount of time for no reason probably don't come here. The staff would rather talk to each other than do their job serving food, seating guests, or taking your order.
author: Penny N.

description: Four friends and I went to this restaurant because we were rushing to get to Grace Cathedral on Saturday, and we assumed it was a good option. The food wasn't that good (e.g., my seafood rice was dry and salty), the waitress forgot to bring drinks (decided not to have after such a long wait), and the music was loud and rock, which is not a good fit for this type of restaurant.
author: Migdalia R.

description:
I just don't think I'm cool enough for this space. This is not your obachan's ramen house by any stretch of a Far Eastern mind. This is where the young and indifferent go to have their noodles late at night after finishing their menthol smokes outside on this semi-scary block of Geary right across from the ACT. I made Jamie W. come here with me after seeing "The King's Speech" at the Embarcadero. I kept hearing how good their ramen is and was thinking it would be less crowded after 10PM when we were feeling peckish. 

No such luck. It was packed, and we were told by the young, unsmiling hostess to step outside in the cold and sign the waiting list. In the meantime, the hip streamed in and out as if they had secret passes. When we were finally seated at the table next to the front window, the smug, disdainful waitress could barely look at us as we attempted to order. In return, I gave her a glare and a deliberate case of small-mouth as I first ordered the $6.50 Chicken Karaage (fried chicken) to share. It was a solid bowlful, not too greasy, and it came with a side salad of mixed greens in a light miso dressing (see photo). 

Soon after we were both served our $12.95 bowls of the Katanaya Ramen, which had a grocery cart of ingredients (corn, fried chicken, fried potstickers, seaweed, scallion, barbecue pork, and the obligatory hard-boiled egg) swimming in a miso broth full of al dente ramen noodles (see photos). It was tasty enough, but I wish the focus was more on the noodles and less on the overabundant accessories which didn't quite do it for me. The potstickers, for example, were steaming hot in the broth, and they were hard to eat at that temperature. We ate quickly since the hipsters were staring at us through the window. 

FOOD - 3.5 stars...a decent bowl of ramen but over-accessorized for the money 
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...this much blacklighting can't be right 
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...small-mouth is all I gotta say 
TOTAL - 3 stars...wish I was hip enough to care about this place
author: Ed U.

description: The place is tiny and it is difficult to almost impossible to accommodate a group of 10 or more. However, when it comes to the food, especially the ramen, the one I ordered was probably the best ramen that I have ever had. Then again, I have never found and/or ate any good ramen anywhere in Miami, FL before. The bowl that the ramen was served in was big and I did not manage to finish all of it. When it comes to the service, it was decent but not great.
author: Junisa V.

description:
I love this place. The restaurant is pretty small and usually packed so you have to write your name in a little board by the door and they'll call your name once some tables've opened up.

I got the Katana-Ya Special - with everything in it; the portion's pretty huge and the taste's heavenly!!! It includes Kara-age (deep fried chicken), Gyoza (Japanese dumplings), Chashu Pork, Bamboo Shoot, Seaweed & Corn. My 1st experience here was mind blowing...  If you don't want the special, get the Miso Chashu (BBQ pork). Should definitely ask them to make it extra spicy (extra $1.50), but it's worth it. This place definitely has 1 of the best ramen ever!!!
author: Robert C.

description:
Well, 
I wouldn't give even one star. 
Horrible service ever! We've been waiting for our delivery for 2,5 hrs!! Eventually it wasn't delivered!! 
No apologies at all!!! Person who was on the phone just replied: "This is not under my control". Yea, so what are you doing right there??!!!
author: Sayana B.

description:
Haven't been in a while. 
Surprised to see no queue. 
Surprised to see new crew & menu. 
I asked and was confirmed the bad news. 
UNDER NEW OWNERSHIP. 
Disregard all my previous posts and tips regarding katana-ya
author: Geordie E.

description: I'm a little torn between a 3 and a 4.  The place was very busy and we still got in right away.  The ramen was pretty good, I had the spicy soy broth.  There were lots of ingredients or toppings so to speak - egg, pork, fried chicken, and noodles of course to name a few.  The sushi was okay, nothing special.  Quickly prepared, which I'm not certain what to think about that.
author: Jason G.

description:
Eh, it was okay.
Smallish place, already packed on early Monday evening. There was a wait going on too.
I like that you can adjust the soup and spiciness. I got a green onion ramen, not too spicy, with shoyu broth.
Decent, but nothing to write home about. I'd rather go to the Thai noodle place next door- portions and prices were better over there.
author: Rumi F.

description: Worst ramen I've ever had. Broth wasn't hot, meat tasted old, and noodles were bland. And on top of that expensive.
author: L M.

description: Diners beware! They overcharged us by almost $20, randomly wrote a number that didn't add up to anything on the bill. We caught it and brought it to their attention. They didn't apologize, didn't seem surprised, just nonchalantly crossed out the random number (see left side scribble), wrote down the right amount and gave it back to us. Check the amount before paying or you'll get scammed here!
author: Jenn L.

description: Ate here when Mensho was closed for the day. At first I thought it was 5/5 but the more I ate it, the more bland and greasy I found it. The egg was also just a plain hard boiled egg, which is not a really big deal, I'm just used to a more seasoned egg with my ramen. The pork was also pretty meh. Not much flavor to it.  It was an OK ramen fix for the night, but I wouldn't eat here again.
author: Wing D.

description: I wouldn't eat sushi here, especially if you carefully watch the sushi chefs, too much cross contamination and servers handing tickets on the sushi counter, but as far as ramen ... Yum! Big fan of their shrimp wonton ramen, miso and add mild spicy yummy! It can get really crowded especially at night.
author: Stefany H.

description: This is a good Japanese ramen place.  I would say this is a hole-in-the-wall kind of place that is always packed and busy.
