Every time I come here, I am pleased with its good quality food as well as good portions.  Add a cold Japanese beer in a chilled glass, and you have a perfect meal.  Cons: the wait can be long sometimes though and the service can be slow.
author: J H.

description: Big portions. I had the salt broth which was tasty. It wasn't too salty. I was left satisfied.
author: Nick M.

description: Thus far this is my favorite ramen place in the world. It's a tiny hole in the wall that is easy to miss. Space is very limited, although waits are rarely long. The Fried Chicken Ramen is out of this world, although if you ate it regularly, I'm sure it would probably kill you. Still, I cannot resist. This is a fantastic little place that is affordable, always delicious and as I write this, I look forward to my next visit to San Francisco and my next stop at Katana-Ya. With that said, this is as casual as it gets, so if you are looking for frills, this is not the place for you.
author: Mario K.

description: Great restaurant! I will for sure be back. The udon was delicious and the sushi was fresh and very tasty. I'm really picky about sushi & they just nailed it. Great lunch menu..after work someday will have to try the sake.
author: Kelly T.

description:
My San Francisco trip last year with Sharon led us to Katana-Ya. Twice. It was that good. What looks like your hole-in-the-wall dive, is actually a Michelin star ranked restaurant. The "Bib Gourmand" category are for restaurants with good food, reasonably priced (under $40 for two). You can see how they select the restaurants here. With my last (and only thusfar) Michelin star visit, the multiple courses were beautifully presented, with complex components, servers around you paying 100% attention. My philosophy: good food is good food. What I thought would be a meal of a lifetime, still isn't the best meal I've had. Best food ends up being random finds, local restaurants, cheap to moderately priced good eats! Which is why it shouldn't surprise anybody that on this last trip to San Francisco with Joe, we were there. Three times.

The restaurant is located just off of Union Square, a short walk for most tourists staying in the downtown area. The place is tiny, seating maybe 4 at the sushi bar, and maybe 25 - 30 people at the tables. There's a clip board outside so you can jot your name down and menus posted along the windows so you can start perusing. Downside: you have to wait outside and if it happens to be a windy night, it can get cold. Upside: service is lightning fast if you order just ramen and the table turnover is quick. On average, we waited for about 5 minutes with 2 - 3 tables in front of us, each seating for 2 - 4 people. Everybody knows to order fast, eat and enjoy, and get out!

Their specialty is ramen, multiple different types which you can order in a salt, miso, or soy base broth. If served with cuts of pork, you can choose a rich or light as well. Joe ordered their regular ramen on the first night, miso and light. It came with three slices of chasu pork, bamboo shoots, onions, and seaweed. For an additional $1.50, you can also make the broth spicy, which not surprisingly, he did.

Since this was my third time here, I knew it's all about the Katana-ya Ramen, their over-the-top deluxe ramen. Served with two of their fried gyoza (pork dumplings), half of a boiled egg, two pieces of their chicken karaage (fried chicken), two slices of chasu pork, bamboo shoots, corn, green onion, and seaweed (drool!). With an overload of toppings, I ordered the same broth as Joe: miso, light, spicy. Tip: ask for a plate on the side. I like to take out the dumplings and chicken so they remain crispy! Hand spun noodles, just perfect in texture and in size, a very flavorful broth, served piping hot and within an average of 6 minutes (you bet I timed it), you can't go wrong with this place!

On my fourth visit, I opted for just the chicken karaage ramen (not pictured) because I love the fried chicken here. It comes with three pieces to compensate for the loss of gyoza, egg, and chasu. Joe's second visit taught him to get the extra spicy ramen (not pictured, imagine an blood red broth), not for the faint of heart! Too spicy for me!

I knew Joe would be eyeing some of my noodles, so I also ordered the salmon and hamachi nigiri. Like all other sushi places here, the fish was fresher than Edmonton's selection. In this case, the sashimi was nicely cut and also had some sort of glaze on top. Warning: wasabi in the middle! On our very last visit (5th for me, 3rd for Joe), there was an overwhelming amount of wasabi! Depends on the hand of the sushi chef I suppose.

My picks: if you're a big eater, get the Katana-Ya ramen to try all the possible toppings. If you'd like a little more selection in your meal, get the Chicken Karaage Ramen and a few pieces of sashimi or nigiri. I've only tried one roll on last year's trip, which wasn't that memorable, but still good. They have quite a selection there as well but looking around, most people have a big bowl of ramen and a few pieces of sushi. If I ever return (high chance next time I'm in San Francisco), there's a kim chee ramen, spicy tofu ramen, and a selection of udon soups I might venture into. Open for lunch, dinner, and late night eats (last call 1:15am), definitely go here if you're in the area! Also worth the wait if the lines does get long!
author: Cindy N.

description:
This is our Go to spot for Ramen and Sushi... Whenever I am in SF to shop and hang out I always make sure to stop in and have the Ramen and the Alaskan roll...

Tasty, Simple, and Affordable....
author: Krystle T.

description: Service was incredibly slow. Good luck trying to order an additional beer, flagging for a refill of water, or trying to get the bill to get out of there. Got the BBQ Pork Ramen, miso. Food is average for a ramen joint,no need to go out of your way to try it. If you're nearby and want ramen, it's an option. If the service wasn't so bad, I'd rate it 3 stars.
author: Joe K.

description: Late night or early lunch.. is the best way to go. The place is small and gets filled up and waits can be long.  The combo's are hmmm good.  I had the shoyu ramen with a small uni/ikura donburi.  The three others had miso and spicy ramen.  The aji (taste), ramen and portion size were just right but the broth a little on the salty side.
author: Wayne K.

description:
RAMEN! Previously, I came to Katana-Ya twice for donburi, sashimi, and sushi, but I had forgotten or not paid attention to the ramen, which is what this place is famous for. Finally, a friend took me here for ramen, and after reading Thrillist's review on the best ramen places in SF as well as what to order, I tried the katana-ya ramen, which was a hefty bowl of ramen with sliced barbeque pork, fried gyoza, karaage, corn, hard boiled egg, green onions, and seaweed. I have never had this big a bowl of ramen before, and the taste was amazing, especially the taste of gyoza and karaage with the miso soup. 

After eating, I noticed that the restaurant was almost full even though we came when it opened at 5 pm. The space is small and intimate, and tables fill up quickly, especially in an area close to Union Square. I will definitely come back for ramen again!
author: Annie C.

description: Been a regular since 2008. The restaurant is going down the hill ever since the new owners took over. Way over priced than before. Service is really slow and servers like to be in groups and talk to each other instead of walking around to check if everything is ok or not. This was my last visit. Never going back. Soggy ramen for $16 and Unagi don for $20. Seriously?
author: SpawnPukar J.

description:
I dig this place a lot because you can get a huge bowl of tasty ramen and a bowl of chirashi/poke don for under $20

Who doesn't love a good deal. Sure the wait sucks and the space is tiny...but it's a great spot for those of you on a budget but are still looking for a satisfying meal
author: Josh C.

description:
Pros: service was quick.  Food was piping hot.  Convenient location.  Nice staff.  I liked the taste of the ramen broth.

Cons: the bowl of mostly ramen noodles with sparse toppings didn't seem to be worth the price (came out to just under $50 before tip for 3 ramen bowls for lunch), but given SF wage/space costs, I can't complain too much.  Their sushi selection could include more vegetarian options besides just the cucumber roll.
author: SF O.

description:
Maybe I wasn't starving but this ramen spot is only hits 3 stars to me. My friends and I all went for the classic Katana-ya Ramen. I don't know how I feel about fried foods in my ramen. There were fried popcorn chicken and a fried dumpling. It definitely made the ramen a little more oily. Maybe I can try something on the lighter side the next time I come. Prices are from 11-14, not too bad for ramen. 

Food comes out super fast! Kudos to them!
author: Phuong V.

description: I got the combo with the miso soup based ramen and a bbq pork don bowl. The ramen was fairly good, but the don bowl was mediocre. The pork was rather dry and the dish wasn't that tasty. Food came quickly and service was friendly.
author: Annie L.

description:
My friend can't stop talking about this place.  So we went.  And I'm glad I can say that I went so I don't have to pretend anymore.

Why not 3?
a.) it's pretty good.
b.) it's centrally located.

Why not 5?
a.) it's not the best ramen I've had.
b.) it's not the best ramen in SF.

What could make it a 5?
a.) shoyu tamago
b.) bamboo shoots
c.) bean sprouts
d.) wood ear mushrooms
e.) ginger
f.) opium
g.) just kidding re: f

Def worth a try I think and go with extra spicy - it's like white man's mild/medium.
author: Alex T.

description:
My go to for late night eats, ramen cravings, and sushi!
I always get the Miso Kimchee or Mabo Ramen. SO DELICIOUS! The broth to noodle ratio is always on point, and they definitely got the umami flavors down!
Surprisingly, if you go on a Monday or Wednesday, the sashimi is fresh and scrumptious as well.  The service can be kind of lacking depending on who your waitress is, but heck, as long as my ramen gets to my tummy within 15 minutes of ordering, I can't complain.  
I always recommend my friends that are in town for a business trip to come eat here! If you don't like your ramen too salty, go with light density. 
LOVE LOVE LOVE KATANA!!
author: Kay H.

description:
Ordered the usual, Katanaya Ramen. Noodles are decent, nothing special. The flavor of the spicy miso was good. The meats were lacking in flavor, but coulda been because of the broth. The egg was terrible, the driest yolk ever, powder-like that made me instantly spit it out. The water made me laugh, it was slightly below room temperature with small, almost melted down ice cubes in the cup. So 4 stars since I'm generous.

Now this is what brought the rating down down down. The wait is actually unreasonable. I don't mind waiting, but 30+ minutes for a single seat? It's more insane since there were empty seats inside. Two empty counter spots. Two empty tables for two. There were about 6 groups waiting after me still, most either single or two. I was let in with another group of two when no one left. I sat at the counter that has 4 seats with only 2 people there, empty seat between them. The couple sat at one table while another table was left empty.

I ordered my food and waited. I looked around the room. I can see people trying to peek inside to see it crowded then be surprised to see empty seats. A group leaves leaving an empty table. You would think they invite another group in, but no. Left empty.

I get my food. The guy next to me, finally gets his bill after almost 10 minutes of waiting since asking for it, leaves. No one replaces him for my entire meal. Then I see why the lack of customer replacement during my meal. I had so much room. I even moved my stool a little to get more spacing. I ate my meal with more than arm distance away from the next person. Glorious for me, sucks for the single person waiting outside.

I notice a group leave, which contained two tables. They clean that one up and invite a couple in. The couple takes the table that was open about 20 minutes ago. While leaving the newly opened two tables still empty. This crowd control works wonderfully since people will grumble outside, but still continue to wait.

I finished and ask for the bill. I ended up waiting for about 10 minutes to pay. In that 10 minutes, I reflected and decided to write this up. Saw my bill and noticed they charged me $1.50 for extra spicy when I ordered regular spicy which cost $0.75. The broth was spicy, but definitely not extra spicy. But $0.75 is whatever. I struggled to decide tip. $0.23, $1.23, $2.23, or $3.23.
So I decided $18 on one bowl of Katanaya Ramen and a story. 2 stars for everything besides the food.

P.S. When the guy next to me left the counter, the waitress used a wet towel and cleaned the counter. Then she uses a napkin (the one they give you to wipe your mouth) and dries the counter with it lightly so it doesn't wrinkle or mess up the factory fold of the paper napkin, then places the wooden disposable chopstick on top of the same napkin. So the lesson is, use the inside of the napkin to wipe them lips.
author: Avery K.

description:
I'm a ramen lover and find this place over hyped and just OK.  Been here a few times and find the soup base too salty, the noodles are al dente and good in texture but veggies are very sparse.

I've definitely had better ramen elsewhere.
author: Yue L.

description:
This is my first time trying ramen at a restaurant, and I'm really glad I chose Katana-Ya as my first. I got the Katanaya ramen because of all the ingredients that were included. It was really good! The karaage and gyoza complimented the ramen, as well did the miso soup base (though it was a tad salty). 

The only problem I had with this place was the amount of free space within tables. It's a bit compact in there, but at least the food makes up for it.
author: Sheena V.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon based on yelp reviews. There was a wait so we had high expectations. Ordered the fried chicken ramen and it was mediocre. Soup was bland and noodles were overcooked. Save yourself the trouble and grab some ramen somewhere else.
author: Nebbie N.

description: After walking in the rain all morning I wanted some ramen to warm me up so popped into Katana-Ya after 1pm. Since it was just me I was seated immediately by the counter which was good because all tables were filled. I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen with miso soup because of all that's in there and oh my it was delicious. The miso soup broth was a bit too salty and thick for me however everything else I ate greedily - I've never had dumplings or fried chicken in my ramen and oh man I should have ordered more - they were still crunchy even after sitting in the broth. But I'm glad I didn't as after finishing the noodles I was stuffed. I would go back and repeat this experience again.
author: Teresa T.

description:
I've been to this place a ton of times. It's fast, reasonable and the ramen is good (not great but good). It does what it says on the tin and is enjoyable. 

Their sushi is very generous also.
author: Emma D.

description:
I think I can officially call myself a ramen snob. After traveling to Japan and eating ramen almost weekly in the South Bay... I think I know what it takes to have the ultimate bowl of ramen. I decided to order the soy sauce Katanaya Ramen... it is named after the restaurant so I thought it had to be the best thing on the menu. My mom got the regular miso ramen. 

The Katanaya has almost everything you can imagine putting in a ramen bowl - chicken karaage, a gyoza, egg, and tons of meat and veggies. Although the portions are huge, the taste is just not there. The broth tasted plain and there wasn't anything setting it apart from just regular noodle soup. My mom and I barely tasted a difference between our two broths. Disappointing. The chasu was overcooked making it chewy and dry! Lastly I don't think the Katanaya is really worth it. There was too much fried stuff and it made the ramen more oily. The gyoza was basically fried dough with meat inside and fried chicken was soggy even when they brought me my bowl.
author: Britney L.

description:
Decided to check out because of the great reviews. Ramen was okay. I have to admit it was my first "real" ramen but a little too al dente for my taste. The broth was good. You get to pick from soy sauce, miso, or salt broth and light, regular, or thick density. The uni ikura don was awesome! Udon was good.

Even at 8:30pm on a Sunday night we were 4th on the list for a table for the tiny restaurant. Be prepared to wait even if you're a single wanting a seat at the sushi bar.
author: Jane N.

description:
Good ramen in the tenderloin area. I usually get the pork or miso flavors and ask for additions like corn, an egg, etc. .. the ones that have the works in there. I usually go there after a happy hour somewhere in the Union Square/Tenderloin/Civic Center area, but I don't just like it because I'm buzzed at the time.

Their sushi is okay, I usually look and see what's on special... this is one of those spots that ramen is what they're well-known for and you should stick to it.

I don't think they take reservations and they're always crowded.. so expect to put your name down on the sign-in sheet and wait a little bit.

The place is small, so it'll be very difficult to accommodate groups larger than four or five.
author: Mike L.

description: The Katana-ya Ramen is the one to get, with the miso soup base.  Words and photos can't quite capture the experience like a video.  But until Yelp supports uploads, here's two words: delicious ramen.  Enough said!
author: J L.

description: I'd never had ramen before and this place was right around the corner from my hotel, so I gave it a try. Happy to say I really enjoyed the food! I got the Katanaya ramen with spicy miso broth, which I'd recommend since it gives a nice contrast to the sweetness of the corn. I don't know how Katana-Ya stacks up against other places, but I'd recommend it to a friend trying ramen out for the first time.
author: Deric G.

description:
This review rests solely on the quality of the meal I ordered. Their service was perfectly fine.

I'm really sad to be typing these words, but I just had Katana-Ya ramen for dinner and can say with absolute certainty that it is by far one of the worst bowls I have ever eaten.

Before you get too far into this review, please understand that my ideal bowl of ramen is a tonkotsu broth that's been cooked for 48+ hours with thick noodles.

I went into Katana-Ya knowing that they only offered Miso, Soy, and Salt based soups. That was fine, since I do like a nice miso broth every now and then. I ordered a Spicy Miso BBQ Pork Ramen and a Chicken Karaage appetizer.

Red flag #1: I called during dinner service, and was told that I could pick up my food in under ten minutes.

I work only four blocks away, and by the time I brought my food back to the office I was excited to get started.

Noodles: Thin. We're already starting off not-so-well.
Broth: Not that tasty. A bit watery.
BBQ Pork: Thick, dry. No wonder it was dunked in the soup to begin with.
Seaweed: Shredded to pieces. Not pleasant. Soggy.

Chicken: Not crispy. Cooked fine, but the exterior was soggy.
Salad that came with the chicken: Not necessary, especially when you're going to pour dressing over it and mix it with the chicken. Really takes away from the chicken.

Am I full? Yep. Am I satisfied? Not in the least bit. I've been trying to think of a good thing to say about the quality of food or taste, but I really can't outside of "My taste buds and body didn't reject it".

In the future, if I were starving, I'd go to the Jack-in-the-Box next door.
author: Richard K.

description: I don't get the hype. To me, a true ramen is a tonkatsu broth. But Katana Ya doesn't have that. So I ordered the spicy miso ramen (regular) with an egg. The miso had decent flavor, but the egg and pork slice ruined it for me. The egg was hard boiled (I'm used to soft boiled in ramen) and the pork was chewy and overlooked. The only reason I'm giving 3 stars is because my BF loves this place. It's all a matter of taste. If you like miso ramen, I'm sure you'll like Katana Ya.
author: Amanda R.

description: Disappointing is the best way to describe my meal. I got the namesake dish, katana-ya, which included fried chicken (karaage), gyoza, BBQ pork, egg, corn and the broth and noodles. Everything was just so-so. Nothing stood out and it didn't even go together very well. It served its purpose as a warm lunch on a chilly day, but I wouldn't go back to have it again.
author: David B.

description:
i made the big mistake of having a breakfast sandwich an hour before coming here. 

do yourself a favor and come HUNGRY. the food is good and they give VERY generous portions. we came for lunch and i had to settle with sashimi and seaweed salad; which was great but i really wanted ramen. i just couldn't stuff it in my gut. my friends got the combo which was a bowl of ramen and a small bowl of don. you have a selection of rice bowls to choose from. it's a small space but they don't rush you.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Wow, I'm so sad.  This use to be my favorite sushi and ramen spot in SF.  I've been coming her for the past four years every time I come up from LA.  This time, I'm incredibly disappointed.  This was my first time here since the new ownership and the food quality has definitely declined.  The ramen broth isn't as flavorful.  Most importantly is the sushi isn't as fresh as it use to be.  I ordered the spicy tuna roll per usual and only ate 2 pieces.  To make matters worse, I pulled a small piece of plastic from my mouth as I was chewing and asked them to remove the roll from my bill.  Terrible!!!  I won't be coming back.  Can someone recommend a new sushi spot?
author: Constance K.

description:
Stay away.  There are so many other better options so close where the staff care whether or not you eat at their restaurant.  The bad service reviews are here for a reason!!!  You have been warned.  

The food is mediocre and better places are less than 2 min away.  Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Pros:
- You get to visit a place everyone recommends

Cons:
- You start questioning SF people's taste
- Worst ramen I've had in my life. Buying packed ramen at your local Asian store is better and much cheaper
- Soy sauce plate came in dirty - so dirty obviously nobody checks them unless they are blind
- Tea cup had soap bubbles in it - I tried to lie to myself thinking the bubbles were the hot water. Once they served the second cup I noticed I had drank soap
- Neither me nor my fiance could finish the ramen. I'm Japanese food fan and she's Chinese, so we know when we talk about ramen.
- Service is mega slow. Got there with 1 person ahead of us. Took like 40 minutes to get a table. Service was mega slow. Not worth the wait even for decent ramen. 
- Waiter kept coming to scream random things nobody understood. It was a really confusing experience.
author: Alejandro S.

description:
We went to this place before we came back to LA. This place is just around the corner of the the hotel where we stayed on union square. we went there for lunch, it was packed, we had to wait for about 15 min. my friend said it was worth the wait, cause usually I don't like to wait. 

This place is so small, they serve sake and beer, yes I needed beer to be my hangover cure, ordered Kirin, salmon sashimi , eggs with crab meat ball, and sushi rolls, didn't order ramen, cause I barely eat ramen. but hubby ordered pork ramen, it looked so yummy. 

This is a good neighborhood eatery, just a little too small and crowded, but it is a good place to have a hangover cure lunch. ;p
author: Mimi L.

description:
The first time I tried this place a couple of months ago I thought it was AMAZINGGG! Probably because it was my first time trying miso ramen. But I've now been around the block a few times ;) this place is just not that great anymore. 

First off the broth is very bland, and doesn't have the depth and fullness miso ramen normally does. Secondly, the noodles seems like something I can get from dry noodles. There is a generous amount of toppings to it, but I rather have quality over quantity. 

Living in OC/LA area makes you really spoiled because they're are a lot of good ramen spot, and Katana Ya really does not compare. I guess if you REALLY need your ramen fix, then Katana Ya is your dealer.
author: tracey d.

description:
When traveling to SF, I went to Katana-Ya based on my friend's suggestion. It's a small, dark restaurant that didn't really have the "wow" effect when you first see it. But trust me, it's a hidden gem! 
I had the Katana-Ya Ramen, and my boyfriend had the shrimp wonton ramen--We both love it! Although I love mine a lot more. The deep fried chicken was amazing, and so is the dumplings (it was a little weird to have fried dumplings in ramen soup... but it's delicious nonetheless). My friend had the spicy ramen, and since they love spicy food, they also loved it.

I would certainly recommend this place and go back for it next time I visit San Francisco.
author: Amber F.

description:
Sigh. Foiled again by the 2000+ reviews. Usually when a restaurant has that many reviews, I get really excited and feel like I have to try the place out. For some reason I've also been told that this is a prime place to go for ramen. But even after reading what fellow Yelpers had to say and preparing myself for the inevitable disappointment, my goodness I'm not sure I really could prepare myself for the real disappointment. 

Yes, it's a small place. Yes there's a wait. We went around late 8ish and had a very brief 10-15 minute wait which was fine. Plus points for how quickly the ramen was served. Friend and I ordered the Fried Chicken Ramen as per request of other Yelpers. He had the miso broth and I had the salt broth.

First comment: ???? Why is there nothing in this ramen??? Three small pieces of chicken karaage and a giant bowl of noodles which was cool. We were both like... wow maybe we should have just gotten karaage and put it in our noodles. Although to be fair and honest, I don't really know what else I should have expected from a Japanese place selling fried chicken ramen. Anyways.

Karaage I have to say was prime. Very prime. Delicious, cooked to perfection, tender meat. Really have nothing to complain about expect for dang it was good. The ramen itself. As reviewers said, there is a TON of oil in the soup and very little flavor. The noodles tasted so bland to me. You've really got to get the holy trinity of noodles right for ramen--noodles, broth, and toppings. And this holy trinity.. meh. Noodles were fine, ... there basically were no toppings except for some seaweed, but oh man the broth. I usually consider broth the dealbreaker/maker for me and this broth was just so ... meh. Tasted like nothing, was very difficult to drink because of the thick layer of oil on top.. and yeah.

It's pretty expensive, but to be fair this is the city, so I'm not surprised. But given the how little food I got, maybe I should have gone for one of the combos.

tldr; a meh experience. don't really recommend. definitely don't make a special trip to come here
author: Jasmine X.

description:
If you plan on dining here, you may want to take a read. My first piece of advice is to heed the warnings of bad service. Yes, it's that bad. I'm one of those optimistic ones that thinks, I'm just here for some good food and how bad can it actually be? I mean I've grown up with dim sum in Chinatown as my example as service. If that doesn't say something to a local, then idk what does. The 3 girls in the front were standing up the register gossiping and talking amongst themselves, failing to refill waters or do anything for that matter. When we placed our name on the wait list, we waited over 10 minutes despite an abundance of empty spaces available. It should've been a sign to walk out when we stepped in only to find people standing there in the front. I was also dining with my grandmother who is partially blind. We noticed them pointing and giggling at the manner and way she was eating. When I looked over, they stopped. It can be seen through the reflection in the mirror. Overall, wouldn't come back again. The food was ok. I warn you that this is one of the few places where I thought bad service ruined the meal, and my expectations were low coming in. 

Good luck yelpers.
author: Chian T.

description:
Another show at the Curran. We were lucky to be first to arrive at opening time so there was no wait for a nice change of pace. Another bowl of Katana-ya Ramen with extra ramen. This time, we got what we ordered at the same time. Of course, we both ordered the same thing, so that should have simplified things. 

Deep Fried Gyoza were nice and garlicky and not salty this time. Everything else was just fine and as expected. 

Service was very good today. What would make us give a 5-star review? Ditch the MSG, a whole egg instead of 1/2 and soft boiled instead of hard. 

See you next show!
author: Dexter D.

description: Food was great fresh sushi and the katanya ramen was also delicious . Worst service I've ever experienced . My mother and sister came a few minutes after me and they wouldn't even bring menus . They knew I had more people  coming . 20 minutes go by they don't even bring water or anything . We had to literally walk to the back to get someone's attention so my mother could order . We also had to do the same thing to get the bill . They were treating us like we were homeless bums.
author: Valerie P.

description:
I had the normal Ramen extra spicy with miso base and the Tonkatsu. I'll start first with  the Tonkatsu. This was pretty dry and it was nothing like the version I had in Japan, but that could probably be said of every other place in the UC. The meat was pretty thin and there was as much breading as there was meat.

The Ramen came with A LOT of noodles. Trust when other people say its a lot of noodles. I got the rich base and it was very thick. I thought it was good, but a lot of the flavor was just the spice. There wasn't much meat in this ramen, it was just one slice of pork.

Overall it was very filling, nothing too special though. It was a little pricier than most other ramen places.
author: Victor D.

description: Came here on a Wednesday night around 7pm and did not have to wait long for a table - I've been wanting to come here for a long time so I was excited to finally get to try the ramen here. To be honest, the Katana-Ya Ramen was not that exciting and the miso broth was too salty for my taste. I also would have preferred for the fried goodies to not be sunken in the broth, but the bowl contained a very large portion of noodles!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Katana-Ya is underwhelming, bland, and overrated. 

The miso soup broth lacks depth and flavor. It also has copious amounts of MSG which I usually don't have a problem with but when I need to take a gulp of water after every bite... I think that's where I draw the line. To top it all off, the noodles are hard and what they lack in flavor, they definitely don't make up for in toppings. No bowl of ramen is not complete without a delicious soft boiled egg. 

If this is the best of SF ramen, I am sorely disappointed. I know what I will be ordering on my next trip to LA.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Really BAD service. Waited for a while u till finally someone came to take order.. One waitress forgot to submit part of our order to the sushi bar until we asked. The other waitress seems to be in a really bad mood and served our order wrong twice without any explanation or apology. When my ramen finally came, the spoon was "floating" in the soup... Btw their spicy ramen = regular ramen + sriracha, not thing special..
author: Chloé Shuaiqing L.

description:
The bf and I was staying at Hotel Serrano, and because I was on crutches, we had to decide with the bf's brother on a nearby place that I could hobble over to.  We ended up choosing this restaurant because of the bf's and my cravings for some Asian food.

We had to wait around half an hour before we could be seated.  Because I was on crutches, this probably meant that we were waiting a bit longer than normal, as the bar was open, but we needed a table because I was too short to try and reach the bar.  Regardless, the waitress did ask if I wanted to sit down to at least rest my feet, but I'm a strong, independent (read: stupid) woman and decided to stand during the entire half hour.  Anyways, we were eventually called, and we were able to sit down at a table.

So, first things to notice.  This place is small.  Lots of tables in a very small area.  If you're in a wheelchair, they might be able to fit you in, but it is cramped.  I was having trouble trying to figure out where to put my crutches.  It ended up being between the bf and myself, where we took turns in elbowing it while we ate in order for it to somehow not fall on other customers.  

The bf's brother ordered the udon and the crabcakes.  The bf ordered the ultimate ramen that had the corn and egg and, more or less, the entire kitchen sink.  I just had the regular ramen.  Now, the reason why I got the regular ramen was because everyone was raving about this place.  So, I thought, "hey, if this place is that good, then I should be able to taste it from just its basic ramen".  For the most part, that's how I gauge other ramen places I go to.

Sorry to say, but I was a bit disappointed.  As a background, the bf and I are from southern California, where we have a lot of different options for ramen, Japanese food, sushi, Asian food, etc.  From what I understood, it seemed like this was one of the few ramen places in SF.  So, I can understand why everyone would say this place is the bomb, especially if they haven't been able to venture out of SF for other ramen places.  But, if I had to compare it with other ramen places that I've ever had, this place wasn't that good.  The soup wasn't anything to rave about, the actual ramen was a bit tough, as if it wasn't cooked thoroughly, or cooled too quickly, and the rest of the ingredients in the soup was just meh.  

For the bf, he definitely enjoyed his kitchen sink ramen AKA katanaya ramen, but only to a certain degree.  The broth was great, the ingredients, such as the corn and the meat and the garnishes were awesome, and likely the best he ever had. He thoroughly enjoyed the fried chicken and potstickers/gyoza, and he normally doesn't like fried stuff in his soup, yet he very much enjoyed it this time, which was a definite first.  And, because the ingredients were so good, he saved the supposed best for last.  But the ramen itself had no soul.  It was just...flaccid?  The ramen just couldn't follow-up with the rest of the bowl...

The bf's brother, who has lived in Seattle for a good 8 years, and then moved to SF recently, thought this was the best ramen ever, and he seems to be a bit of a regular.  But, he doesn't have ramen down in southern California normally, either.

Prices were okay.  A little higher than what I'd normally pay for in southern California, but this IS San Francisco, where cost of living is definitely a bit higher.

If the bf and I had a choice, we probably wouldn't come back here when we have a lot more options back home in soCal.  Good effort, and the service wasn't bad, but we've had better.
author: Grace C.

description: The worst food I have ever had! The servers are rude. They don't even talk to you. They just shake their heads. They are tude. They charge tip and fee for utensils. Avoid this place. Extremely rude and food tastes horrible!
author: Cansu S.

description:
I do not understand why people rate this up to 4 stars.

My friend and I ordered miso based ramen and some rolls. I spotted a HAIR in the ramen! They apologized and did not charge for the ramen, but we already lost our appetite. 

If you are a ramen lover, I would recommend Tanpopo, Ramen Yamadaya in SF or Ramen Dojo in San Mateo.
author: Angela K.

description: This is my #1 must go ramen restaurant. I always order kantanaya ramen. I dont eat sushi here unfortunately. The place is dark which I really like lol.
author: Linh C.

description:
Is it weird that I went to a restaurant famous for their ramen and didn't even order it? Well, that's what I did when I went to Katana-Ya. On a Sunday afternoon, Katana-Ya was still busy with a mild wait. The place is very tiny and I am sure on a crowded evening, the wait can be unbearable. Luckily, there was no other party ahead of my party of 3. We got seated immediately after about a 15 minute wait and service was prompt. The staff kept coming up to our table asking if we need anything which is great in my book. I ordered the tonkatsu plate which came with a very good portion of deep fried pork goodness, a salad, miso soup and a large bowl of rice. At some other Japanese restaurants, sometimes you gotta ask for extra rice but here at Katana-Ya, I didn't have to.

The tonkatsu was crispy and already sauced so it saved me time for dipping and re-dipping. For $8.50, it was definitely a great value and I can tell the rest of the items on the menu are all good values. You can get ramen with a small bowl of rice and meat or other types of noodles, ie soba and udon. With nothing but mainly expensive restaurants in the Union Square area, this is a great option for the San Francisco cold and won't hurt your wallet either. I am definitely coming back to try the ramen. I have my eye on the Katana-Ya ramen special that includes fried chicken, corn, chasu pork and other goodies.
author: Danster L.

description: Deep fried chicken ramen noodles with miso soup based and deep fried tuna salad was my highlight here. Even though I don't have reservation, the staff was kind enough to take my last minute request for dine in and gave me an estimate of 30 minutes wait. When I returned back to the shop, true enough the seats was ready for us in 30 mins.
author: Alex G.

description:
I came here two times this week.

My first visit:

Came here with a group of four people and we were seated with barely enough space to eat and sit. The restaurant was pretty empty.. So I'm not sure why they squished us on the corner.

I ordered the kimchi ramen in miso base soup. It was quite a lot of food, I really liked the noddles and texture of the ramen. I prefer thick noodles so I know my friends didn't like it as much..

Parking was difficult to find.



Second visit:

I ordered the regular ramen with a soy based soup this time. The soup was very salty, and flavorful. I like how every order of ramen comes with bamboo shoots! They're my ultimate favorite.

I came here this time with a group of five people and it took them about 20 minutes to get seated.. We ended up getting seated by the bar. 

Overall the service was decent and I would go with soy broth over miso any day.

On a funnier note, I saw the sashimi cutting guy behind the counter drinking half a bottle of Sapporo beer.. He chugged it down as if no one was looking and went straight back to cutting sashimi and making sushi
author: Jonathan L.

description: Ugh horrible service and food! Should've checked their health score before I ate there I guess. 70 is pretty bad.
author: paul b.

description:
Food is about 3.5.

The ramen is decent.  They open late and have lots of seating.  

I had the regular ramen ($10) and fried rice ($3) combo.  Overall was decent, 3.5/5.
-Chose your noodles.  You can go Udon or Noodles.  They OVERLOAD your dish w/ noodles.  They give so many noodles I didn't even finish my bowl.  The noodles were alright.
-Choose your soup.  They have miso or salt.  I chose miso. The broth soup was okay.  It's kinda salty but I enjoyed it.
-Comes w/ 1 slice of pork and some bamboo.  

The fried rice was okay.  It's decent.  

TIPS:
-Apparently they just remodeled so the downstairs section is brand new.
-They have other stuff like hot pot, sushi, etc.  
-Ramen portions are pretty massive, which is probably why they charge $10.  If I come back I'd just get ramen and no sides.
author: Mike T.

description:
Absolutely LUCKY there is no 0 star rating for the type of service we got today. The food is delicious but the service is what will run away their business.

Came here with a total of 8 guests. 4 adults and 4 kids all under three. First the placed us at a table next to the door and told us the stroller had to stay outside. But the table we sat at had a space that does not block the entrance or ways in and out of the restaurant. So of COURSE i will put our stroller there. Theres a 1 year old baby laying inside it asleep. Not blocking any door entrance or walk way so it shouldnt be an issue....

Secondly.. 4 adults ordered a bowl of ramen each. Two kids are on an all milk base diet-- the other two eat solids so each kid was ordered a small rice bowl. Somehow the waitress sent us 5 ramen bowls. When we told her there was a mistake for the extra bowl. Waitress rudely said we ordered it and thats why there's an extra bowl of ramen. No lady-- we did not order 5 bowls total. It also doesnt make sense to give a 2 and 3 year old spicy ramen so NO that is YOuR mistake-- instead of apologizing.. She took the bowl back and said loudly to her coworkers we mistakenly ordered 5 bowls and now we want them to take one back! Dude... If you got some BS you want to vent about to your coworkers.. Do that in private. Not mug at me while i sat there eating. This is your fault. Not ours. Your mistake. Not ours. And then you wanna mug at me??? Youre lucky i didnt walk out with 6 bowls of food left there to waste-- why is this chick still here?! I had an issue about this same waitress before . Disgusting-- never coming back here. If i do ill really piss you off -.-
author: Linda L.

description: Absolutely great ramen! Went with a group and we had to wait, but it was well worth it. I was very pleased with the food. Flavorful broth and yummy noodles. Will definitely head back.
author: Lilly K.

description: Katana-Ya is where you go for ramen when in Union Square.  Brother and sis-in-law led me here the day after Christmas at 11:30a to avoid the wait and got the window seats.  Order the home-made gyozas (4 pcs) and Katana-ya ramen which comes with corn, hard boiled egg, 2 pcs of chicken karaage, 2 pieces of fried gyozas, sliced buta pork belly, scallions, and norii.  There was a line forming outside but never felt rushed to finish our food.  Service that day was nice and friendly.
author: N P.

description:
Katana-Ya is under new management and has moved up the street to a larger location.  What was once a warm, friendly and good food restaurant has appeared to have disappeared.  I had lunch there today, and went out of my way to go there.  No one approached my table or greeted me upon arrival, I sat there for 5 minutes and then as I stood up some waitress behind the cash register somewhat acknowledged me and then a more surly waitress came and took my order.  I ordered tempura/udon and it was not what they used to serve.  The bowl of noodles was smaller, soup luke warm, the tempura was soggy and they did not serve the tempura dipping sauce.  I had to get up to find a waitress and ask for it and was told by the waitress many people don't want it, instead of asking me in the lst place if I wanted it.  It took a while to get to me and was steaming hot, more so than the tasteless soup.  

There is no longer a sushi bar and they now have a soulless downstairs, that was not open at lunch.

I am very disappointed to see this great little place under new management that does not appear to appreciate the food or service they took over.
author: Sally Z.

description:
This is my favorite spot for ramen near my hood. I love the variety of the Katana-Ya bowl, the broth selection is amazing, and its just the right amount of yummy. 

It's always packed so get there early or expect to wait for 10-20minutes. It's a tiny joint too, so don't get all hot and bothered when you're a little crammed in. Just enough the hot and delicious bowl of ramen.
author: Donna H.

description:
This place is only a few blocks from time square and I wanted to try out this ramen place rather then the one inside the mall. To my surprise, there was not wait for an early dinner on Saturday so my friend and I were seated almost immediately. The place is pretty small so I cant imagine how long the wait is when it is packed.

I got the Katana-Ya Ramen that comes with fried chicken, dumplings, pork, corn, pickled veggies, and an egg. The bowl was $13 which is more expensive than most ramen places. The broth was pretty good but I didnt like that the noodles were not soft, so I soaked them in my soup for longer. I had never had fried chicken or dumplings in ramen so I thought that was different. However, the ingredients by themselves were average but when you mix it all into one bowl of ramen, it makes it a little bit more special. You wouldnt think of putting fried chicken in ramen because it will get soggy but it added a lot more flavor to the dish. The broth wasnt spectacular either and it is usually the broth that makes or breaks ramen. You can definitely find better ramen places in the bay area like Orenchis.

**TIPS**
1) The bowl is pretty big and since there is a lot of meaty items in there, you can split with someone.
2) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description:
Opening up late is nice.  Why they choose to open until one and not a little later to pick up more of customers from people coming out of bars and clubs is past me.  One thing is for certain; my views of Katana-Ya have changed from when I first tried it.

In any fighting sport, be it the UFC, boxing, or whatever.  There's a term "gatekeeper".  This person is usually an aging former champion, a fighter whose abilities can only defeat average to above average folks and fold to anyone superior in talent.  For each weight division, there's an unofficial gatekeeper.  Within the arena of ramen in San Francisco, Katana-Ya is that gatekeeper.  I grade a ramen shops in SF according to Katana-Ya. 

I still go here because of the convenient location as mention in my original review.  This is the main reason I ever come here.  If I'm in Union Square, and ramen is calling, I'd just go to Katana-Ya.  Pass on Aijisen for me.  My order is still always the Katana-Ya ramen.  If you can't choose one, just get this; the bowl is stuffed to the brim with almost every side item they have on the menu.   

There's nothing really wrong with a gatekeeper fighter and there's nothing wrong with Katana-Ya.  Using outdated is a little far out to express my take on their ramen.  Gulping down their ramen, my belly is still satisfied, but many newer ramen shops can take out this fighter.
author: Arnold T.

description:
I knew I should have checked this place out on Yelp before entering!!  The night before, I had seen a line out the door and subconsciously thought of dining here.  The next day, a friend claimed it was a great place for ramen and since it was right next to our hotel, we signed ourselves up for a table...

My boyfriend ordered the Katanaya Ramen and it came with deep fried chicken, which was about the only thing I enjoyed from either of our bowls.  However, I've never been too big of a ramen fan.  I ordered the Regular Ramen, which was exactly that; regular.  I've had better in Sacramento (shout out to Shoki!!).

I would probably give Katana-Ya 2 stars except for the waitress seriously tried to rush us to leave.  Although I was done eating a quarter way into my bowl, my friends were still eating so I don't know what made her think it was okay to ask us if we paid for our bill yet.  The place was packed so they obviously didn't care about losing customers..

Even as togo, the ramen wasn't great.  Bummer..
author: Yvonne N.

description:
I love this place!

Late floor get arrival from Hawaii.  Looking for a place to eat that was open late.  Brought here by a friend.  This place is busy!  With dine in and take out!  Waited 20 minutes to be seated but worth the wait!

The spicy tofu ramen hit the spot!  Large portion, I couldn't finish!  Next time I'll try the Katanaya ramen with lots of adds to it.  I can't wait to return.
author: Lisa H.

description: Possibly the worst place to get ramen!!!! We drove an hour expecting some delicious ramen but instead we got a flavorless surprise waiting for us instead. The broth was oily and lacking any flavor whatsoever, the instant ramen I make at home has more flavor than this place. The noodles were hard and difficult to eat, definitely undercooked and not made correctly. The potstickers sounded like a unique touch to the ramen, however, the first bite was the only bite. The dough was undercooked, I could literally see the flour in between the layers and the filling was oily and tasted like mashed vegetable. The egg, which is typically my favorite part, was probably the most disappointing, not only was it over cooked, it fell out and mixed with the ramen before I even got a chance to taste it! DO NOT GO HERE!!!!!!!!
author: Jenny T.

description:
I like Katana-ya, have dined here for many years and will continue to do so (mainly because they're open late). But the long wait times, cramped tiny space and inconsistent quality, makes it difficult to rate higher than 3 stars.

In the past the kitchen was able to make a bowl of ramen so good that I'd drink all the broth. Nowadays quality is not the same so I come only for nourishment. Also they make hard boiled eggs, I prefer soft boiled eggs. Hanjuku tamago should be standard when u pay $12 for a bowl of ramen. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BJHkpaHa0ROaLYCav6zsMA/l The sushi is not that great.

Some examples of the inconsistent kitchen, last year was the first time I sent food back to the kitchen because my bowl of ramen was too salty. I think that someone over-seasoned the toppings (meat and veggies) so the combination was too much. Maybe they were training someone new in the kitchen, dunno. And then earlier this year around April, my ramen bowl had zarusoba (yes, the cold buckwheat noodles) instead of ramen noodles. It was late (after midnight) and I was hungry, so I didn't complain and just ate it. Maybe they run out (if so, they should have told me) or someone in the kitchen wasn't paying attention. Customers can substitute soba or udon in any noodle soup, but I didn't request that. Best of SF? not really. The only thing I see in common with Santa Ramen, is that for many years both have one waitress with blond hair. Here it's a Russian girl named Helena.

And in case u decide to order the "grilled salmon donburi", note that it's NOT a filet of salmon. What u get is minced cooked salmon already mixed with white rice. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XHuaQLKdldnY10JwBSnqTg/l That's a home cooking style, like a kids meal. I hope that they stop resting on their laurels (praise by 7x7 magazine) and try to improve consistency.
author: Luis C.

description:
So glad my friends found this ramen spot within 3-4 blocks of our hotel for a nice Sunday night dinner. It's right across the street from the American Conservatory Theatre on Geary. I would definitely recommend this place... but with one caveat... Be prepared to WAIT... We waited about 30 mins for our party of 3 to be seated. No big deal. Everyone has to wait. I think we got there around 8pm so we were definitely starving by the time we got a table.

I went with the signature Katanaya ramen which came with fried chicken, potstickers, scallions, seaweed, bbq pork, corn and a hard boiled egg. I chose the miso broth, mild not spicy and regular as opposed to a light or rich broth density... So I suggest, while waiting to be seated and standing on the sidewalk, look over the menu and have your order down. Memorize it. Do not deviate from your first impulse on what combination of ingredients to order. Don't doubt yourself. Just go with it.... HA! I'm sure whatever it is, will be tasty.

The broth was delicious... Cant go wrong with a miso base. The noodles were just the right amount of chewiness. There was a tiny bit of spice to it.... I'm not one for super spicy but I'm sure they can accommodate all you heat-seekers. The fried chicken surprisingly worked very well in the broth and amongst the noodles. My friends said that this is what they read (on Yelp) that this is what they were known for. I'm glad I listened to them. The fried potstickers were also very good tasting. Perfect crunch and taste to compliment the broth. Bbq pork was very tasty and belonged with the rest of the goodness in the bowl. I opted for no corn but the seaweed, scallions and egg were all great together. I definitely left satisfied... I'll definitely be eating here again next time I'm in the city.
author: Chuck D.

description: The Poke Don and Ramen were the highlights of this place but the service was so bad that it's hard to give this place the stars that it deserves on food alone. Highly suggested for take out.
author: Ashley B.

description: I ordered the katana-Ya ramen: pork, chicken karage, Gyoza , seaweed , egg and miso broth. The broth had no, "Bang, Pow or Wow" effect . It was suuuuuuuper bland . The chaShu was not buttery melt in your mouth quality. It was just Blahhhhhhhhhhh...same goes with the chicken and Gyoza . The fried tako was good, but could be crispier. Overall, it not worth the visit
author: Joe L.

description:
This place is too hyped..
The soup was okay but the noodles were.. Horrible and cheap quality.... No flavor to it.. No perfection on chewiness... 

Service was okay... Kept our tea refilled..

There was a wait when my group and I came, and there still was a wait when I left... Honestly I don't think it's that good of a place to have a wait :/

Overall, not coming back again
author: Catherine Y.

description:
Tried this hole in the wall ramen restaurant out primarily because it was across the street from the Curran Theatre where we were about to watch "Jersey Boys." Thankfully we just avoided the big crowd and were seated within 10 minutes. The place is tiny and crowded. You are virtually shoulder to shoulder with the diner at the table next to you.

I had the fried chicken ramen which is basically ramen served with 3 pieces of chicken karaage in it. The broth was fine, but not anything special. I was impressed with the quality of the noodles though. Just the right texture for me. But for $11, this ramen bowl, as big as it is, is really overpriced.

Our table also shared a sushi roll. I forget the name but it was pretty good.

My dad ordered his ramen "spicy" and I was shocked to learn that they actually charge you an extra $1.40 to make your ramen spicy. WTF.

There's no way the bill for a party of 4 at a tiny ramen shop should be over $70, and yet that's what it came out to be. Ramen was good but with so many options in the area, questionable as to whether I'd go back.
author: Myong C.

description:
I don't know if I am qualified to review this place, seeing it is my first ramen & it being vegetarian and all but here goes...

Big, steaming bowl of chewy ramen noodles with a broth that is boring at first but becomes tastier & tastier with each bite as all the flavors from the veggies steep & meld together. Soy sauce, spice & mysterious white powder are on the table for adding, had my nose running in no time!

Cute little space tucked away on Geary amid tourist central. Reasonable prices ($11), big portions and fast, no nonsense service for the win.
author: Cec D.

description: Pork bbq ramen is good. hubby ordered the spicy one and mine was regular. hit the spot on this cold winter night. good but didnt blow my mind. no lines when we got there on a sunday night.
author: Nikki E.

description:
First time there. Some people recommended the ramen at this establishment. Knowing them, I expected it to be great. Eh...

I ordered the regular ramen with uni don (Unagi Donburi) on the side. The soup was tasty but filled with MSG and really oily. Got pretty thirsty afterwards. Also, they only give you one small slice of pork, the rest is just noodles and some veggies. Nothing else. Nothing special at all.  The uni don was alright, I've had better. For $14, i think the food wasn't horrible, but not good either.

Service on the other hand, was great. Our waitress was so sweet and apologized when she forgot to bring the sushi and rice. They were all really nice and kind, even though the restaurant was packed as hell.

I might give it another shot, not too sure though...
author: Alex L.

description:
Amazing ramen. One of the best in the city.
If you're craving that ramen dojo or those great jap ramens hours away, this would be a great alternative. The only downside is the wait. Sushi here is also pretty great.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Satisfying your late night ramen needs in the Tenderloin until 1:15am!

(3.5, if I could.)

Hole-in the wall, yes. Busy with a wait, yes. 

Deep fried chicken ramen? The other reviewers rave, so I should'a done it but didn't do it. Instead, I opted for some tofu-laden spice-tastic goodness. 

I shared my spicy veggie delight with Jeffrey S and in return tried his order, which wasn't the deep-fried chicken, but wasn't the spicy version of anything, either. (It was late guys... c'mon. I can't remember everything I eat all the damn time, especially after hanging at Local Edition for a bit.) That said, the verdict on both our parts? Mine was wayyyy more flavorful and delightful.

That said, I wasn't blown away by either dish, and I don't know how to feel about that. Maybe it's that Ramen is this thing that we don't really have here in the good ol' Mil but people talk and talk about and talk it up and then all the sudden it's on this pedestal and can never live up to what it "should" be because the whole thing's inflated now. Does that make sense?

IN SHORT: The food was pretty tasty, it was late at night, it satiated my hunger, and the whole experience? A pretty solid one.
author: Rachel F.

description: 5 stars and counting. Go for the Ramen Miso spicy delish!!! Sign in if there's a wait about 10- 15 minutes and scoop worth it!!!
author: Misti G.

description: Katanaya is unique from many other ramen places I've been to in that they have a number of different topping options, as well as soup base options. I got the fried chicken miso ramen. I'm normally not a huge ramen fan, but some of my friends absolutely love it, so I've been to a good number of ramen restaurants in SF. Katanaya is by far my favorite. I loved the miso base as well as the fried chicken option. I am definitely returning.
author: Cici A.

description: This place has continued to be "the" place we suggest other visitors to San Francisco go to. Just a couple of weeks ago, our son's friend and her family went and their reviews were as stellar as ours always were. Don't look for super warm service, but the FOOD is sensational -- and this is five years later.
author: Nadine M.

description:
I would say that I was shocked by the rating of this place, but then again people in SF do not know their Ramen. This place is a bastardized fusion noodle shop.

* Fried food in broth... is that a joke?
* Sushi in a ramenya? Another joke?
* No soft boiled eggs? Isn't this supposed to be a ramen shop?
* No tonkotsu (pork bone broth ramen).
* Boxed noodles, don't absorb broth flavor.
* Shouyu ramen is far too oily, and not from pork...
* Chasu is dry, not fatty at all.
* Not a single Japanese staff.
* Staff have horrible attitudes.
* Ridiculous wait for shitty food.

If you want to learn about real Ramen go to LA. Go to Daikokuya!
author: Grayson K.

description:
The food was great! I just took off a star because the restaurant is super small and crammed, so i'm sure usually there's a long wait to eat here.  

I got a special- i think it was called the spicy beef noodle...i hate to say it but I would NOT ever order this again..it was basically just american vegetable soup (carrots, tomatoes, onions etc.) and mixed with some beef and noodles....definitely not a traditional Japanese food. 

The boyfriend ordered the Katana-Ya special and THAT was really good!  I would highly recommend getting that one to eat.  I'm sad since I am only visiting so I won't be able to get something else there but I would definitely recommend this place if you want traditional Japanese noodles...minus the spicy beef one :P
author: Amy Y.

description:
Not sure why this place is rated so high.  There's always a long wait, decor is ugly, and the food just average.
A little expensive for what you get.
author: Michele S.

description:
Have lived a block from this place for a year now, and have wanted to eat there but always  a line! After seeing a movie on Saturday we passed by around 9pm and shiver me timbers.. no line! Woot

Wow this place is tiny tiny tiny! But super cute. We weren't really that hungry so we just ordered the Katana-Ya ramen.. which has pork, chicken, dumplings, eggs, corn I think? It was everything let's just say haha Ordered the miso version. Yummers! Really good, one of the better ramens in SF. We were done quick and knowing people were waiting outside.. left right away. Yes we're awesomely nice that way. You're welcome San Francisco foodies.
author: Vol T.

description: Those ramens are really good and authentic. Plus, they open very late, which is really convenient if you go to the opera or to the theater before
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description:
Came here for my first SF ramen experience and while the food was delicious, the rest of my experience was only ok. 

- Food - I ordered the Katanaya ramen with spicy miso broth, and it was probably one of the best bowls of ramen I've ever had. Perfectly done noodles, luscious broth, and a perfect array of toppings including hot gyoza, fall-apart-tender karaage (fried chicken), pork, and seaweed. I might order extra karaage next time because it was so good!

- Service: A bit unfriendly, and way too slow. I had to ask several times before I was served a glass of water. It took more than the time it took the couple next to me to get served their food, finish it, and leave to get served. 

- Ambiance: A small but charming place. There's usually a line but it goes quickly.

- Price: For such a large and delicious meal, a steal!
author: L H.

description:
I cannot and will not trust a single person who tells me this place is good, because that is a joke, despite the long line full of hipsters on any given night. For a restaurant that was once upon a time Michelin guide recommended, I expected a quality bowl full of piping hot broth, perfectly cooked noodles, deliciously seasoned and incredibly braised pork. Instead, I got a bowl of what I deemed to be the equivalent of instant noodles made by a poor chap who thinks that Maruchan chicken flavored 'Ramen Noodle Soup' is the same thing as Japanese ramen. 

Maybe it's just me, but when it comes to ramen, I'm all about keeping the toppings as traditional as possible, so I knew it was a bad sign when the most recommended ramen dish was the one with fried chicken and the other one with dumplings. Also the fact that they DO NOT have tonkotsu broth still perplexes me. But I sucked it up because I actually prefer miso broth and ordered the regular ramen with miso at a medium spice level. When my food came out, it was beyond disappointing. While the broth was light and hearty, it wasn't spicy in the least bit. The two pieces of dry pork was clearly not marinated nor braised. The seaweed was wilting since they more than likely added it in before they poured the soup in. The egg was half a hard boiled egg that was lost amongst the thick noodles that were so undercooked that every bite left a raw doughy residue in my mouth. Also, who eats lukewarm ramen or soup in general, especially when it's supposed to be fresh from the kitchen? I mean, I don't want my ramen to come out giving me second degree burns, but I would like it to be hot enough to see a bit of steam like it was actually made to order. Am I asking for too much?!?

However, what offended me the most was how sucky the service was. My sister and I came in on a chill Monday afternoon around 4pm; there were three other couples inside and about four waitresses "working." We were thrilled because we thought we could be in and out of Katana-Ya and waste little time before our next adventure. But no. What easily could have been a 30 minute pit stop turned into an hour ordeal because the staff is not only lazy but incompetent as well. Yall, it took over 20 minutes just for someone to get us our bill. Then it took another 10 minutes of just sitting there glaring at the other lady in charge of the cashier, waiting for her to swipe the card but she was too busy getting chummy with the old man at the bar. If I was soulless, I would've dined and dashed because they obviously didn't care enough to close me out ergo they didn't care enough to get my money.

PS: if you're unfortunate enough to dine here and want kimchi fried rice, think twice about ordering it. It's bland and the kimchi was bitter af. Also, the kitchen allegedly cannot add a fried egg on top because "there's already eggs in the fried rice so it won't be good." Ooooh god forbid scrambled eggs touch a fried egg. *10842049 eye rolls*
author: Tiffany W.

description: Katana-ya used to be an authentic Japanese ramen restaurant but sadly no longer. The servings are huge, but both the miso ramen and curry katsudon were only so-so. If good enough is good enough, this is your place: but if you want authentic and delicious Japanese food, this is not. Wait staff were nice enough though I had to ask for everything -- napkins and utensils. They never came around to refill the water. They even do not have Japanese tea -- they only serve Chinese tea!  This plus the poor health inspection record means I'm not coming back here again.
author: Koko P.

description: If ur hungry and are looking for a hot bowl on a cold day then this is the perfect place. Although if ur looking for all around better taste and higher authenticity of ramen, I don't suggest this place. Great late night meal if u got the munchies. It has a versatile and diverse menu to choose from, including sushi, ramen, and other Japanese appetizers. But if ur looking for a higher quality of taste for ramen and not merely food to fill u up, look somewhere else.
author: GianCarlo L.

description: Came here because it was close to union square and i've had it bookmarked for the longest time. Over 2000 reviews, 3 1/2 stars got me wondering if this place was worth a try. Took a quick glance at the reviews and 3 of my friends rated this place less than 3 stars, nevertheless, i still gave this place a try. My friend and I both ordered the Katana-ya special ramen. It came with pieces of fried chicken, fried potstickers, pork, and corn. I tried the soy sauce based broth. It was very salty and nothing stood out about the broth. The fried potsticker was weird to eat with the ramen and quickly got soggy. Honestly i would rather have it on the side. Overall, i did not enjoy the ramen and couldn't finish the bowl because it was so salty. Service was very friendly and attentive. Restaurant was small and dark. Bummer that this place didn't live up to it's par..
author: Mimi V.

description: the service was really terrible, and the waiters were having bad attitude. I ordered curry don, but they gave me curry udon. I clearly said don, but the waiter argued with me for he's own fault. Won't go back anymore
author: Henric L.

description:
This was my ultimate go-to ramen spot for years when living in SF. Just recently I returned for a visit, and first on my list was Katana-Ya! I saw that they had added more ramen choices to their menu. I decided to stick to my usual - spicy tofu ramen and was actually disappointed. There was barely any broth, all noodles and it didn't taste as flavorful as it used to. 

The gyozas are still good. Nice and tasty.

I wasn't able to return one more time before leaving, so not sure if it was just a bad day. But it was a major disappointment since I looked forward to dining here so much prior and during my trip. Hopefully next time will be better!
author: Natasha S.

description:
Every time I've been here, my order has been for the vegetarian ramen, with spicy miso rich broth. I've tried the different noodles in it and personally find the soba to be best. They don't skimp on the vegetables or tofu, and your bowl is filled to the brim with piping hot broth.

Food comes out quick, the line moves fast, and the service doesn't mess around. I can't recommend it enough to others.
author: Amy S.

description: This little hole in the wall is amazing. It's super tiny and busy but most people are in and out quick. You sign in outside on a little clipboard, the wait was quick and the food came out fast as well. The toro nigiri was soft, fatty, and yummy! The BBQ pork miso ramen, mild spicy was really good! The broth had so much flavor. So glad we found this place. Def recommend and would come back if I'm in the area again!
author: Holly A.

description:
3.5 stars, but I graciously rounded up.

Best ramen in San Francisco - okay, I can get that.
But that's only because there is a limited number of ramen places in San Francisco, especially compared to Southern California's Daikokuya, Santouka, and other assorted ramen establishments.

I had the miso ramen, which reminded me of really good instant ramen bowls - (not quite a diss. I like those!). They gave exactly one piece of meat in my bowl, which was kind of sad. All would be fine by me as the ramen itself was pretty yummy, but my group of four waited for over an hour and a half on a rainy day, and really now... Cut us some slack for waiting so long!

The broth is decent, but not like how I usually have it, which is thick and oily. Like Manubu M. said, it really does tastes like canola oil versus pork fat oil. 

Be prepared to wait during high times!
author: Colleen M.

description:
Overrated by SF'ers. The best thing about this place is that they're open late, and serve an ok bowl of ramen. However, avoid the wonton ramen - it's horribly overpriced at $14, and the extra $3 to combo it up with a salmon bowl didn't come with token vegetables like their picture showed, dangit. They give you maybe ~6 pieces of wonton in that bowl, which contain a piece of shrimp and some other meat I think. The flavor is nothing special; you can get more legit wonton of course along Kearny St. during normal hours. Still, the regular ramen here isn't bad, esp. if it's after 10pm on a Sunday when everything else is dead. Their noodles are also a good thickness with a little chew, adding to the sense of fullness when you eat (not a fan of wimpy thin noodles in ramen).

If you wanna try some good ramen, you're best bet is to venture to the south bay (Ramen Dojo, Ramen Parlor, Orenchi...), or try the tonkotsu ramen at Izakaya Sozai.
author: Linus W.

description:
For dinner, you need a slight wait.
One star off for its dining environment. It feels crowded and bluely dark. We had an ordering miscommunication and one of the staff insisted telling/pointing out to me that I made the mistake first and then said I will replace your dish, but what's the point? Guess life is always hard on everybody.
We ordered Takoyaki, it tastes normal and over floury. Taste a little bit Kimchi fried rice - average but homey and warm. For Nigiri we ordered Unagi and Amaebi - Need to cultivating my taste for saw sushi but overall not bad.
Ramen seems pretty good. So, till next time :)
author: Yixi F.

description: Egg was over cooked, even had a thick green grey layer on the yolk. Noodles were overly soft, karaage was tough and stale. I would not allow my friends to eat here
author: Wats S.

description:
I am rating Katana-Ya in relation to the other ramen places I've tried so far in the Bay Area, and also keeping in mind that it is in San Francisco and therefore a much easier commute for this SF resident than, say, San Mateo or anywhere else on the Peninsula.

Katana-Ya might not offer the most authentic, perfectly cooked bowl of Japanese ramen, but it has a lot going for it--more than enough to warrant a visit. My boyfriend and I both got the namesake Katana-Ya Ramen (his with soy sauce broth, mine with miso, and no scallions for either of us). 

Pros: 
- Possibly the most plentiful amount of ramen "toppings" you'll ever encounter on a menu--corn, 2 pieces of fried pork, 2 fried gyoza, several slices of barbecued pork, seaweed, scallions and half a boiled egg. Compare this to Ramen Dojo, where you have to pay an extra $2.50 just for bamboo shoots (which I had never encountered before Ramen Dojo--bamboo should always be included). Let's just say, that's a lot of food!
- Both the miso and soy sauce broths were tasty, though I preferred my miso
- The fried pork pieces were quite large and very tender, and the barbecued pork was well cut
- The noodles appeared overcooked (straight, little curl), but were actually pretty al dente
- The entire bowl was huge and filled to the top. In other words, big portions for just $11

Cons:
- The fried items should have been served separately so as not to get too soggy in the broth. Being Asian, I've grown up with a lot of fried-items-in-soup dishes, so I sort of intuitively know how long a fried item can be in a soup in order to absorb the flavor without getting too soggy. But a lot of people probably don't know when that cut-off time is and end up with lots of soggy pieces of food. Serving the fried items on the side would allow people to choose how long they want that stuff in the soup
- They should offer tonkotsu broth for this particular bowl. None of the other broth options perfectly complement the ingredients the way a well-seasoned pork broth would 

We didn't actually plan on going to Katana-Ya for lunch, but happened to be in the area and were craving something hot and soupy on a cold, rainy day. Despite coming at around 1pm on a Saturday afternoon (peak time), our wait was maybe 15-20 min at most. There isn't a ton of seating at Katana-Ya (no more than at other ramen places), but the turnaround seems to be faster here for some reason.

However, what impressed me the most about Katana-Ya was the service. The staff were incredibly friendly, gracious and attentive. They consistently checked in on us despite the busy, harried environment, and every single staff member thanked us for coming when were on our way out. I'm so glad we stumbled upon this spot!
author: Josephine L.

description:
First time here. Me and my boyfriend had to wait outside (cold and windy), but the place looked popular (crowded).
The bbq Ramen was enough for both of us. People is polite. 
The ramen plate was really good. I definitely will come back.
I wish they had some traditional desserts to finish the dinner but they only had sesame ice cream.
author: Ivette H S.

description: This place is a small hole in the wall. It's ok. Not the best ramen I ever had but they give you a big portion and My wife and I were stuffed. The egg was not half done as I'm usually accustomed to and I don't think the materials are very fresh but the broth was pretty tasty. We came right at 6 so line was short. Like most ramen places it's small so don't bring a big group.
author: Ander C.

description:
The ramen (on a weeknight) was flat out awful. Sure it's a huge portion, but the broth is weak, the noodles are too thick, and the toppings - especially the egg (it was just plain hard boiled) were just not good. 

I got a combo with a little mini tuna don and that wasn't much better. Lots more rice than tuna - but at least it was better than the ramen. 

I'm a ramen guy so maybe I'm harsh. If you're new to ramen, who knows, you might be like the other reviewers who have no idea what good ramen is. So if you're such an individual go have the ramen here, then go have it somewhere decent - because then your mind will be blown :P
author: samuel a.

description: I would actually listen to the reviews of others yelpers for this place. My boyfriend and I thought we'd give it a try since we were in town for the Cherry Blossom Festival. Surprisingly, we couldn't find any stellar ramen joints in Japantown so we ended up here. Yeah there might always be a wait but I don't think I'd be coming back anytime soon. We had their ramen with miso and it was mediocre. Their broth simply couldn't compare to other 3k+ reviewed ramen joints. Moreover, their prices were a bit high for ramen but I guess it's normal for SF standards. I don't know if I'd recommend this place even to satisfy a craving but try it for yourself! Maybe you'd agree.
author: Cathy M.

description:
I secretly love this place. From the outside - and the inside - it doesn't look that amazing; it's super small and a little dark and outdated looking, but the ramen keeps me coming back. 

I have not tried anything besides the ramen, so I can't vouch for the sushi and such, but it's the perfect bowl of hearty, salty wonderfulness. I always get the Butter Corn Miso Ramen, and it is a huge portion full of delicious, fattening broth, noodles and meat. For the price point of about $10, you're really getting your money's worth. It's a simple and cheap bowl of non-pretentious ramen that tastes like what ramen is supposed to be. I'm not saying the $14 bowls of ramen at Ramen Underground and Ramen Bar aren't delicious in their own right; it's just that we're talking about different species of ramen here. 

I also love that  you can pick which broth base (salt, soy, miso) for every ramen option and how rich you want it. Plus, they have a lot of ramen options.

It is small inside, so it can get a little busy and they will force you to wait outside as there's no room inside to wait. But, for how busy it can get, the servers are also super competent and fast, so you can get in and out quickly.

Surprisingly, I've been a couple of times during weekday lunch hours, and it's never looked too busy to get a spot. I usually call ahead for pickup though just in case they could get suddenly busy.
author: Christina R.

description:
If you're hesitant about coming here, just go!

Katana-Ya, you were my first ramen love and I still dream of you. The texture of your noodles, the breath of toppings available, and the consistency of your broth is unmatched. The only thing to taint my memory of you is that long line outside and the cramp space in which to consume this taste of heaven.

When I'm in San Francisco, you're the first place I visit.
author: Robert H.

description:
I don't eat ramen as often as I'd like to, so take this with a grain of rice. haha.

Had the very good agedashi tofu, agreeing with with other reviewers.
Had yelper TC's standard, the good $12.90 Katanaya Ramen = #12, which was the same as the #1 = Regular Ramen but with more items - choosing miso broth, medium-spiciness - get extra spicy - the waiter offered three options (mild, medium and extra spicy).
Had a large Sapporo, which was their only size = large?

Went here with yelper, TC, at 10pm on a Tuesday, and was surprised to see no line! Yep, no line which is rare! I tried stopping in here before with yelper TH, same time but on a Thursday, and was five-names deep waitlisted. On this try, went straight in and there was one small table open, perfect.
