The waiter who served us was really helpful, and we did not feel rushed even when a line started to form while we were there.

I always knew this place was around the corner from Ruby Skye but didn't know exactly where. It's almost a hole-in-the-wall. At least four stars, but the no wait-no rush large bowl of tasty ramen gets that final star on this visit.
author: Peter L.

description: We ordered the Katanaya and Vegetable ramen bowls, +spicy! Both bowls were very good. I would recommend the Katanaya- it had a flavorful, rich broth and the karaage chicken and gyoza fillers made it even better. An added bonus, slurp and sing along to pop songs on a loop circa 2000's!
author: MissM R.

description: I was meeting my friend for lunch here today. I ordered a bowl of ramen and after a couple of minutes into the meal I noticed a weird object floating in the broth. It turned out to be a piece of metal shaving! I immediately called the waitress, who was pretty apologetic about it and offered me a new bowl. I declined it because I didn't want to wait any longer, so I finished my bowl (which I probably should not have done). But at the end of the meal they didn't even exclude it from my check. Not the best customer experience.
author: Mikhail K.

description:
Do you know when a strangely dressed person is talking in the open, and you can't tell whether they're crazy or using bluetooth? That was my first impression here.

I ordered tuna sashimi, and it took quite a while to arrive at the table. Others nearby also were questioning whether their orders were forgotten. Once the sashimi arrived, it was sinewy.
author: Cory K.

description:
Don't believe the hype. I still don't understand how this place has lines out the door. There are much better and authentic ramen options in SF. 

The service is lackluster and the food uninspiring. The broth is over seasoned, and I feel caters to western palettes. The next time you're at Katana-Ya just take a look around and you'll understand why.
author: Damien W.

description: Great miso flavoring. The pork belly slices were thin and not much bigger than a half-dollar.  The ramen noodles were slightly under-cooked.  The service is sub-par but once you flagged them down, they were helpful.
author: Hauce C.

description:
It gets really crowded but I don't see the reason why. The ramen is definitely not the best that there is around.

My BIG issue was the service. I had to ask the waitress twice for water. First off, the restaurant is pretty dark so you can't really see very well. (I don't mind dark restaurants) BUT, when I finally got my water, I drank a from it a few times because I was really thirsty. Then, after a drank a bit, I noticed LIPSTICK STAIN on the rim!!! I don't wear any lipstick so obviously it wasn't mine and the cup wasn't cleaned properly.

I'm not a crazy customer or anything and don't like to make a scene at restaurants, so I told the waitress and asked for a new water. She just took the cup and didn't apologize or anything. She just handed the cup off to a busboy to bring a new water cup for me.

Honestly, if something like that happens they should AT LEAST apologize. Overall really rude.

Go somewhere else for ramen. You'll get more for your money, better food and service.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Be prepared for a wait and to get cozy with fellow patrons!  

But it will be worth it.

A local friend took me to Katana-ya when I first moved to town and I was surprised to find such affordable eats so close to Union Square.

I ordered the Chicken Karaage Ramen and my dining companion got the Regular ramen with a spicy tuna roll.  

Not only is the ramen good here, the sushi is legit. probably the best sushi I've had in the bay area so far.

As other reviewers have noted, parking is a nightmare, but if you're in the area, this place is definitely worth the wait.

Open late nights til 1:15am!
author: Camille B.

description:
Sadly - i think i have reset the Ramen bar by eating too much Ramen in Shinjuku this past fall.

Katana-ya was probably my fave in SF and I have enjoyed the fried chicken and spicy red versions in the past.

This time I got the standard Ramen with Pork and it was passable.  But not all the inspiring considering the time spent waiting and then the almost room temperature draft beer.
author: tim b.

description: I only had take out sushi, and it was so incredibly fresh. As good of quality as it can get. I did pick up, so while waiting for my food I saw a few Ramen bowls come out of the kitchen, and they looked incredible. I'm definitely coming back for Ramen here. Looked and smelled amazing.
author: Monica G.

description: Worst experience ever. The noodle tasted horrible and the waitress is rude. Their noodle is hard like stone. The soup has a wired smell. I also ordered salmon sashimi which tasted like it has been in frozen for a month. I was too cold to be near the door and ask the waitress if me and my partner can seat to another empty seat. She gave me a fake smile and quickly said NO with no reason. After awhile, she gave the seat to a gentlemen who came in alone. I understand if she need to save the seat for a party size group, but in this situation I am very confused. In addition, they let a Mexican gentleman waited half an hour until they notice he was there.
author: Lan W.

description:
I love the BBQ pork ramen with soy sauce based, which is the best. 
If you are a ramen lover, you should definitely try this.
author: Judy F.

description:
This is one of our favorite ramen stops, it's the only ramen shop in San Francisco that satisfies our ramen needs!
The service is great and the has a great ambiance, especially with the waitresses speaking in Japanese. There is a waitlist, but it usually doesn't take more than 30 minutes for a table.
As for the food, we usually go for any of their ramen bowls with a miso base for the broth, and we really recommend the cold ramen during hot days; it's just super refreshing and tasty! If you're not up for ramen, we usually go for a Katsu Curry Don; it's just awesome. 
Great flavors, good quality and freshness to their menu items, especially their noodles!
author: Milli M.

description:
I'm really sad... 

- waited over an hour to be seated
- disappointed with the ramen (pork ramen)
- sushi wasn't any better
- had super high expectations for this place

What happened Katana-Ya? Have you been overhyped? Or maybe I ordered the wrong things...
author: CeCe C.

description:
I'm a loyal fan of Katana-Ya, and have been taking my friends here for a few years now. Their combination dinner (pick a noodle dish and a side) is a favorite of mine, as it lets me have all the carbs I could ever want in whatever way I want. The wait can be long, but it's well worth it. They're open late, so I stumble in here sometimes with my friends after boozing in the neighborhood. Staff is so nice. :)

I love their udon, which is fresh, nice, and chewy. It is lighter and comes in a smaller bowl than the ramen, and doesn't come with any meat or bamboo toppings either. It is a bonito (fish) broth.

I love their ramen now, which has a great bounce to it, but I couldn't stand the taste for a while until I tried it spicy -- everyone else loves it, and it's great .. but I grew up on instant ramen, so it was weird at first! It's very, very filling, and comes with meat and bamboo. I sometimes share it with a girl friend if we're not too hungry.

I love their unagi don and almost always get it as my combination side. I'll go for fresh poke or tuna/salmon don sometimes. Their rolls have been good in my experience as well. 

For those who don't like noodle soups, their pork katsu curry entrée is a good choice. It comes with a side salad, miso, and pickles. The fried meat is covered in katsu sauce, so if you don't like that, ask for it on the side.
author: Louie R.

description:
Ramen that warms your soul and tummy! Yummy!

Came here under the recommendation of my best friend and former coworker and he was right, finally! HaHa...

Anyway, this place gets crowded, so it must be a hit, right? It is okay. The place is small and cozy...almost the size of a walk in closet similar to those ladies on the real OC house wives show. It's like a room. The place can probably fit up to 30-45 people. Clean for a hole in the wall place. I got the KatanYa Ramen, mild spicy. It was good and very filling. Somewhat salty and I was a bit disappointed because it really was not mild spicy, it was not spicy at all. My cousin got extra spicy, and she said it was not spicy at all. Then again, she has high tolerance for spicy things! The staff is friendly. Don't sit next to the door, a draft comes in each time people enter to ask how long the wait is.
author: Joyce D.

description:
After landing in Oakland and making our way to SF, my party and I were hungry, with a capital "H".  We stayed at Union Square and by the time we checked in, it was late.  I was smart enough to use social media to chat with some peps on what was good to eat around our hotel and Katana-ya was recommend.

Katana-ya is a small ramen shop that holds about 20 people max.  There usually is a wait but the wait goes by pretty fast.

Starving and dehydrated, we order our ramen.  I ordered the kim chi ramen with miso.
The kim chi ramen was good but you could tell they used store bought kim chi.  The miso broth was hot and delicious on that cold Friday night.  The prices here were a little on the higher side, but I expected that being in the city.  The service here was okay.  I guess since it was packed, the servers were pretty busy.

I'm not sure about the parking since we walked here from our hotel.
author: Dean N.

description:
This is probably the best ramen I've had in SF so far, but that's not saying much, I know. This is certainly one of the most popular, judging from the line and semi-long waits. Part of the reason you have to wait is due to the size of the restaurant...it's literally a hole in the wall that seats maybe 15 people total.

You choose broth and whether you want it light or rich. I went for shoyu, light, with green onions (which surprisingly costs nearly $1 more to add).

Bf got the Katanaya Ramen with miso broth, rich. I preferred my broth over his. But he did get a deep fried gyoza and an fully-cooked (but not overcooked) egg in his.

I LOVE that the ramen is al dente here. Not soggy or overcooked like some other places. Perfectly chewy and elastic.

A little on the expensive side for not getting much. We also got takoyaki and toro nigiri, which were both decent.

Overall, I'm not impressed for the price. I must be spoiled by Ramen Dojo...
author: Esther Y.

description:
Came across Katana-Ya after a long adventurous day in the city. Was craving ramen and all signs pointed this direction. There seemed to be mixed feelings regarding their ramen so I wanted to give 'em a try, to compare with all the other ramen places i've been. 

No line when we went, which was fantastic because we were hungraaaaaaay.  Small little place so i'd imagine this place gets packed during peak hours. Both the GF & I tried the Katanya-Ya ramen, which came with 2 gyoza's, fried chicken, cha shu and an egg. 

Portions: 5/5 Great for the price, lots of noodles, fresh wakkame (seaweed), bamboo shoots, etc. 
Taste: 3.5/5 I chose the Miso broth, you can never really go wrong with miso right? It was not bad, not very rich but still flavorful enough. Wasn't mindblowingly good though
Condiments: 3.5/5 I really enjoyed the fresh wakkame, while most people use a one sheet of dried wakkame. The bamboo shoots were pretty standard, egg wasn't so great. Fried chicken was awesome, very juicy and goes well with the ramen and broth. the gyoza was kinda nasty I must say. Doughy and just all around not too good flavor wise. (It also came extremely late, I thought they had forgotten it or didn't come with the ramen anymore)
Service: 3.5/5 Could've been better, felt like I really needed to wave a server down to get any service.

Would love to give them 3.5, though they just weren't the best that i've had. Will definitely visit again when i'm in the area.
author: Elliot K.

description: The only reason why I'm putting a low rating is not because of the food. Food is great here. LOVE LOVE LOVE the takoyaki, which is why I like going here as well as their amazing ramen...BUT...I've been let down three times now. Phone orders basically do not exist even though they supposedly offer pick-up orders over the phone. Yeah, good luck. I'm sad, Katana-Ya. I want you in my belly for lunch, but you're not allowing that to happen.
author: Clarissa M.

description:
I had been told that this was the best ramen in San Francisco by a few friends.

To quickly sum up our meal:

Great Octopus special
Good noodles - Not great
Mediocre Sake
Rude Service

The service here was possibly the worst I've ever received at a Japanese restaurant. Worse than some Japanese buffets I have been to.  I'm not sure, what was worse. Being yelled at while standing outside waiting for a table, or being rushed after we sat down (I know there's a bunch of people waiting outside.  I waited there too. Stop fucking reminding me)
author: Josh D.

description:
Honestly impressed with how bad this was. Came here on recommendation from a friend, but they are currently under scrutiny for providing such a suspect suggestion.

I am rating this on more or less the food alone. The space, and staff were fine. Not impressive, but no complains. 
The food just spoke so loudly, that I would never return.
I got the Katana-ya ramen. The namesake. The variety. Surely it has to be good?

There are 3 important components to ramen. I generally experience each piece individually in the first 3 bites.
1) The noodles: The first step is to take a nice chopstick-full of noodles, and straight to my mouth. Mushy. A texture that did not say "fresh noodles." In fact, packaged ramen may have a better texture. These were overcooked and simply not good.
2) The broth: Next is to take a spoonful of broth and experience this. Now, they have 3 different broth options for their noodles. Miso, soy and salt. Miso felt like the safest option for me (not a huge fan of soy, and salt is a difficult to do right (otherwise you're just drinking glorified seawater.) This was also not good. Perhaps the best part of this bowl in the end, but really not saying much at all.
3) The gu, the toppings: Because this was the katana-ya, it had the best of all worlds. 2 pieces of chashu (bbq pork), 2 fried gyoza (deep fried potstickers), 2 karaage (fried chicken), boiled egg, corn and seaweed.
None of these things were memorable, and most were just bad. Ramen tends to have a poached or soft boiled egg, and not a tasteless hard boiled one. Strike. Flavorless, though tender, chashu pork. Strike. Completely atrocious potstickers that I have no clue what they were doing in my ramen. Strike. That's three strikes already, so the toppings were a disappointment too.

Now, maybe the merry medley of these pieces of the symphony would make something astounding. Something beautiful. Something actually delicious. Well, if you got your hopes up, you probably already saw my star-rating, so no, they did no justice for each other. 

People are kind and give this 3 or even 2 stars (or crazy and give it 4 or 5.)
I implore you to save your money; this won't be a delicious meal.
author: Hideki M.

description:
An absolute gem downtown that hasn't been taken over by tourists *yet*

Love coming here on my lunch away from the office 

It's a tiny little hole in the wall but I will always say that is what makes this place so special.

My coworkers get the "everything" katana ramen that had friggin potstickers and fried chicken in it...what?? So unique! 

I'm a little pickier so i get the zaru soba with a sushi roll. Always good.

great place..the sweetest women always are working and they are always kind and happy to help.
author: T R.

description: I went on Sunday, November 15th and had the Katan-Ya Ramen with miso broth and hot tea.  Woke up 5 hours later violently ill.  My first reaction was that I would never return, but It's been three days and I am still not well so I thought I should say something.  Be careful.
author: Chris B.

description:
Very cute, tiny little ramen spot. Surprisingly - there was still a wait at 9pm on a Sunday night! Relatively fast, about 20 min though.

Our server was really cool and able to rush our order like we asked (we had 25 minutes to eat and a flight to catch).

Overall thoughts (considering the tight ramen competition in the bay area):
- best part are all the additions/ toppings in the Katanaya ramen.
- next best was the noodles - clearly made in house, good texture. A tiny tiny bit hard for my liking (but I like my pastas softer than the average person).
- hard to judge the broth. I got the light soy as I wasn't crazy hungry, and it's nice to have options of light/rich for soy, miso, or salt for all the ramen options. The broth was good, but didn't blow me away (though the rich one may have done that, had I had room for it).

Katanaya Ramen (with corn, fried chicken, fried potstickers, seaweed, scallions, BBQ pork, and boiled egg. I got the light soy) - Oh god bless you fried food. I loved their potstickers - these were the type with a thick, crunchy fried skin. Soak that in ramen broth and you have a tasty mix of crunchy yet soggy.. yummm... and same goes with the fried chicken! Already delicious, but soaked in the broth.. I think I just have a soft spot for soggy foods. The pork was nothing extraordinary, plain thin (but lean) slices. Boiled egg didn't add much. But like I said, good hand pulled noodles (a little on the hard side). 

Good meal overall. I'll see if I can come back and stomach the rich broth one day.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Arrived 1:15ish on a Friday, very busy. Didn't realize at first it was a self sign-in out front. Signed in, waited 45 min and the hostess crossed us off without calling our name so 3 groups went ahead without noticing the mistake. Once notified, we were seated immediately. So probably would have been a 30 min wait. 

Karagee was good; though I'm used to having with a curry sauce back home.  

Very good ramen. Fresh seaweed, miso broth was delicious as well as fried chicken. Wish the egg was soft boiled. And I have tasted more tender roast pork.
author: Katrina G.

description:
My friends and I like this place and it has become one of our regular stop for lunch in San Francisco! The food is always on point here hungover or not! I usually get the miso ramen with additional toppings with a roll or one of their combo options!

The reason why I'm giving this place 2 stars this time is because they messed up our bill! I went here with four friends and we ended up splitting our bill to three with cash and two cards and they were willing to let us do that. After giving our cards back I noticed right away that she over charged mine by atleast $20!

After finally calling her over our table I told her she over charged my card, so she grabs the receipt and comes back with a calculator and a pen. She explained that she added the gratuity in the check and that's how she got that total. My friend and I then explained to her that she did the calculations wrong and she told her the right amount. Of course at this point she was really confused and still insisted it was the gratuity. My friend then grabs her phone and uses the calculator on her phone to show the lady the right away to calculate the bill WITH the gratuity. The lady paused and then apologized for her mistake. Thank god she finally got what we were saying. 

I was hoping that she would just return the difference to me in cash to makes things easier, but instead she grabs my debit card and the receipts and she ended up voiding the wrong amount and recharges my card for the right amount. -____- What a complicated way to do it! She should've just handed me the cash to correct the difference! 

And on top of that my friend checked her card statement several days later to find a $90 charge on her card instead of $45, which was the original amount on her receipt. RIDICULOUS!

Overall, this place serves really good food! Just make sure you check your bill before you walk out of there!
author: Glenn L.

description: Good in a pinch. I went in after the normal lunch crowd, and service was rather slow. I ordered the Kakuni (Pork Belly) Soy Ramen. Generous portion of meat. Food was okay, not stellar. I probably won't crave coming here specifically, but if I'm in the mood for ramen, and I'm in the Union Square area, then I can see myself stopping by again.
author: Bobby L.

description: waste of money. The broth was salty and didn't taste good at all. The ingredients were tasteless and not fresh. Not worth the money!!
author: Yan L.

description:
Can someone tell me who generated the 7x7 list of "100 Things to Eat and Drink Before You Die"? Or, do restaurants pay a hefty fee to be listed so they generate more business?

My friend was craving ramen yesterday, so I decided to YELP something and came upon Katana-Ya. It sounded familiar, and as I looked through the reviews I noticed that their Chasu Ramen was #5 on the 7x7 list. Excited to be able to cross something off my list, I suggested this place as it's also conveniently located in Union Square. 

My friends and I arrived at Katana-Ya at 6 PM and were promptly seated at a cramped table.

DRINKS:
*Nigori Sake Sayuri ($12) - six bottles downed *smile*

FOOD:
*Agedashi Tofu ($6 for 6 cubes): YUMMY! The silken tofu was lightly battered and fried. It was nice and crisp on the outside and silky smooth in the inside. It was served on top of tentsuyu broth made of dashi, mirin, and soysauce, which gave the tofu a light sweet and savory flavor. The katsuobushi (fish flakes) and seaweed strips gave it a nice crunch. You MUST eat this dish warm otherwise, it will absorb all the tentsuyu broth making the tofu soggy.

*Chicken Karage ($7.50): Meh! The chicken was crisp, however, the meat was overcooked and had a jerky texture. It wasn't seasoned and there was no accompanying sauce, so it was basically dry, leathery, and flavorless.

*Gyoza ($6.40 for 4 pieces): The menu states it's "homemade", but it looked and tasted like it came from a frozen bag from the local Asian market. It wasn't cooked thoroughly so the sides of the wrapper looked and tasted like raw dough. The pork veggie filling wasn't seasoned and there was no gyoza sauce. Instead, Chinese chili oil was which was odd. 

*Softshell Crab ($8.50): YUMMY! The tempura battered crab was delicately fried. It had a nice, crispy outer crust and a soft interior. The crab was fresh and very sweet.

*Dancing Bonito ($13): It was GOOD! It was essentially a deep-fried roll filled with spicy fish mix of salmon and tuna and then drizzled w/ spicy aioli and tobiko. The outer layer of the roll was crisp and the fish was tender and moist. The spicy aioli gave it a fiery kick, so no soy sauce or wasabi was really needed, while the tobiko gave it a slight crunch. 

*Katayana Ramen w/ chasu, 2 potstickers, chicken karage, boiled egg, and corn in miso broth  ($12.40 + $1.40 for spicy): It was ok. We ordered one spicy and one extra spicy. The waiter screwed up our order and brought out the chasu ramen instead (on the 7x7 list, but NOT worthy to be). When we informed him, he said the other components would be out later. Errr, isn't the potstickers, corn, chicken, and egg suppose to be served with it? At least that is what was shown in the picture.

Do note: Katana-Ya CLEARLY states on their menu that they use MSG in their broths.

-The spicy miso was NOT spicy at all and lacked that savory slightly sweet and rich flavor. The chasu was just blah. Although it was tender, it was completely flavorless. The noodles and tasted like a thicker version of cup-o-noodles. 

-The extra spicy miso had the spiciness we were looking for but lacked the savory and rich flavor from the miso, and was more oily then anything. There was an oil ring around the bowl--ECK! The chasu and noodles tasted the same as the one in the spicy miso version.

When the other components finally arrived 5 minutes later, we dunked into the bowls. The deep fried potstickers were extra crispy and the extra spicy miso gave it the flavor it needed. After the chicken karage soaked in the miso broths, it wasn't as dry as the app version and took on the flavor from the broths which gave it some seasoning. The corn tasted like can from a corn. And, the egg which is suppose to cooked in soy, vinegar, and sugar was just a plain boiled egg. BOO!

SERVICE:
The waiter and waitresses are quick to get your order and quick to get you out of their door. They're NOT very friendly, nor do they seem knowledgeable about the things on the menu which may be attributed to a language gap (Japanese and Latin wait staff). As we asked for more bottles of sake, they kept on giving this a "WTF" look and seemed irritated. Hey, they should have been happy; the higher the bill, the higher the tip right?

AMBIANCE/DÉCOR:
Katana-Ya is more of a hole-in-the wall establishment in Union Square. It's TINY with seating for about 20 people. The tables are extremely small. They use a table that's meant for 2 people for 4 people; so expect to be bumping elbows with your dining companion(s) and have your other arm/elbow hanging out of the table. Not much décor, but posters of sake and alkie advertisements.

Sorry Katana-Ya, I really wanted to like you since you claim to have the "Best" Ramen in SF and was listed in the coveted 7x7 list, but there's far too many superior restaurants in SF and the Peninsula area that serve "authentic" ramen with better service. NEXT!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
So this is like the 3rd ramen house I've been to.  I was never really excited about ramen as my history of ramen was always instant Top Ramen, as I'm sure is the case with most of you.  The 1st ramen place I went to I didn't even order ramen.  My 1st true experience with ramen was Santa Ramen in San Mateo, but let's talk about Katana-Ya...

I had the Chashu Ramen (BBQ Pork) and my husband had the Katana-Ya Ramen, both of which are on Foodspotting lists.  Both were so yummers!  I had the BBQ Pork with the soy broth and the pork was really tender and tasty!  

My husband's Katana-Ya Ramen was with miso broth and spicy green onion.  I just started getting into spicy food so I still like to stay on the mild side of the meter but his was spicier than I probably would be able to handle - yet it was still so good!  It's loaded with so many yummy things like fried potstickers, fried chicken and a hard-boiled egg.  Let me tell you, if you have this for lunch, you won't need to eat dinner!

The downsides to this place are 1) it's a small restaurant so space is kinda tight, 2) they don't have pork broth like Santa Ramen, which is incredible, BTW and 3) parking in the area sucks but it's in the City, so it's expected.

Other than that, this is a must try!  And a definite come-back!  I'm craving ramen again just by writing this review...
author: Rose A.

description: Pretty good food - customer service though is lacking. I enjoyed my cold soba - but they didn't provide any sauces (like other places in SF) so I was stuck just pouring some soy sauce on a bowl of cold soba noodles. Some people complain that the place is too small but I like the size and the dining process. Will most likely be back
author: Nick Z.

description:
My SF friend suggested we come here after a day of explorin' around the city and I was glad to grab some ramen on a chilly winter night. But when we arrived, I already had a feeling this place was going to overhyped judging from their "Yelp" and "Trip Advisor" stickers plastered on their front windows.

I ordered the Katanaya ramen which for $12.90 is extremely steep. For $9, I can get a pretty bomb ass bowl of XL pho, so for $13, I was expecting amazing ramen. 

Unfortunately, my instincts were correct. The ramen itself was mediocre as it was filled with two potstickers (got soggy fast), a couple of pieces of popcorn chicken (again, soggy), corn, pork, green onion, and the noodles itself. The miso soup was extremely salty and loaded with TONS of MSG. The only upside was the noodles itself which were chewy and in abundance.

But my reason for the low star is the place itself. The tables are cramped together and it was hard not to bump elbows with strangers sitting next to you. What is worse is that the mirrors they put up on the wall (to give an illusion of a bigger place) actually makes it awkward as you find yourself making eye contact with strangers. 

To put the cherry on top, the worse part of the night was I went home with stomachache. This speaks volume to how dirty their kitchen is as I could withstand eating street food in Southeast Asia and not get sick. 

Tourists, beware!
author: Eva L.

description: Met some friends here for lunch. Its the second time Ive been here and the ramen is delish. The first time the lines were ridiculous but the food was so good. This time, a Monday when they first opened, we got a table immediately. The BBQ pork is tender and tasty and the ramen broth is rich and flavorful-- I always get the miso. I wish this place had other locations, like in JTown, but I'll gladly make the trek and brave the tourist zombies to eat tasty foodz.
author: James S.

description:
I have to be honest... the thought of ramen outside of my house disgusts me... I can't imagine eating those kinds of noodles and imagine anything but crap... however, this place was marvelous! The bowls are huge and the broth as well as the common noodles were tasty! It was dirt cheap too... 

I'm usually a noodles snob and can only tolerate good Pho or Bun Bo Hue or Udon or Soba or anything Thai, but I guess there's a first for everything... who knew ramen can be good?

An added plus was the advertisement of MSG... I love MSG! 

I hate snobby places that advertises the non-usage of MSG... no MSG? No business... Brandy Ho's Hunan, I'm looking at you!
author: Nathan D.

description:
3.5 stars

I've been yelp stalking this place forever, and my friend decided to have his birthday dinner here.

Since we were a fairly large party of 6, we had to wait for our table. That's no problem. One of the staff members came out and informed us the large party before us had paid and were chatting at the table, and he offered to take our order and have it in the kitchen so our food would be ready right when we sat down. That is some awesome customer service! 

We sat downstairs and our food came out right away. Well, kind of. Everyone else's food except for mine came out. Although it was obvious everyone had a dish in front of them except for me, it wasn't until we flagged someone down that they checked on my order. It turns out there was a mix up and they had to make it on the fly, no biggie. They offered appetizers or drinks but I said it was fine. Shortly, my food came out., I had opted for the Mabo ramen. It was pretty good, but it didn't blow me away like I thought it would. 

Two of my friends ordered a side of uni, and they both got food poisoning. I would opt for ramen, but stay away from sushi here.
author: Angela L.

description:
Oops forgot to update this review... This update is 1 year too late.. Better late than never. Now that I've had Izakaya Sozai and Ippudo, Katana Ya and I are just friends aka I found my new brothfriend because Katana Ya just doesn't cut it.


See what I did there.


I mean it's pricey, and the broth is ok. But, it's all just mediocre. I used to be so frivolous with stars and little did I know that I just didn't know what I was missing out on. If I want ramen while in the downtown area, I'd rather go to Ramen Underground.
author: Donna H.

description:
Okay place for ramen. I had the spicy tofu ramen with an addition of an unagi don. Ramen wasn't spicy, but it was a good portion. The thing that irked me was that every little thing was "an extra charge." Why would you need to charge $2 extra for vegetarian broth when it's cheaper to make than the chicken broth? I wasn't sure how much everything would cost with the combination of the ramen and the rice bowl, but it ended up to be $18. Pretty expensive. 

We arrived at 6pm and there was already a waiting list. Not worth the wait.
author: Jackie S.

description: If you are hungry and looking for a tasteful Lamen with modern music ambient you should try katana-ya. The lamen is huge and i recommend the spicy one.
author: Marcos K.

description: First time here and I love it!! Then again I usually love most ramen. You get a quick fix and a decent price :)
author: James L.

description:
I ordered take out for both my friend and I.  I asked for no seaweed in my friends ramen. Well,  there was no seaweed in hers but there was no meat or flavor.  I did have it in mine but the ramen dish was not supposed to have it in mine.  

Both tasted horrible.  I do really like ramen normally.
author: Cory D.

description:
Service: Make sure you are not sitting at the bar so you will have the servers attention.  But they have extremely poor service anyway, I waved the servers 3 times to order and they absolutely saw me but didn't come to the bar. There were 2 parties sitting after me, they got their orders and their foods were served 10 mins before mines. Wasn't it supposed to be first served? 

Food: ramen is really good, but the broth is okay.  You only got 3 slices of pork in the regular ramen and you will need to pay and add whatever you want. 

May come back another time, but definitely not going to sit at the bar anymore.
author: Josey T.

description:
Selected Katana-Ya because it had decent reviews and was close to my hotel. This is NOT a place to take clients. It is a place to go for very good neighborhood sushi. I sat at the sushi bar (seats maybe 6?) and the whole restaurant only seats 20 or so. At 4pm, a 'tween time, it was full. I was one of only two or three non-Japanese in the place - also typically a good sign. 

I ordered a Salmon Skin salad - exactly what it says, cooked. Wasn't sure I would like it but it was quite good. Miso soup was good and I had one of their reasonably priced splits of cold sake. Had a Sushi Combo wi Avocado Salmon Roll and Dynamite Roll. Prepared right in front of my eyes. Not the best I have ever had, but by no means bad. I also had a soda, served in can but with glass of ice. 

Bottom line, good food. Good service. Come here for sushi, not ambience. You will be happy. This is a 5 star neighborhood joint, and a 3 star in comparison to sushi restaurants in general.
author: Chris K.

description:
In a city so exciting, I know that there is much better ramen to be had.. Main complaint was that the broth was a bit too salty and I wish there was more than one pork slice in the soup.
The noodles had good texture though.
author: Lydia N.

description:
The first time I've heard about this place, I thought someone was referring to a video game character but I was wrong. His real character name is Kazuya Mishima from Tekken. D'oh!!

Anyway, all the raves about this place urged me to get rid of my bookmark and check it out for myself! The most talked about was Katanaya ramen #12 that's a sure hit and a must try from 7x7 magazine. Well, I couldn't pass up this opportunity! My boyfriend and I came here after a few drinks from a friend's birthday. This place was within walking distance, so our late night munchies took a toll on us. After a short discussion with my boyfriend, we already knew what to order.

Thanks to 7x7 magazine and all my fellow Yelpers recommendations, I wasn't disappointed! A huge slurp of the broth and a couple of nibbles of the corn, bbq pork and egg, I wished I hadn't shared my bowl at all! By far, one of my favorite ramen places I can't get enough of! Another trip back, I've had their Butter corn ramen #8, I was awfully happy!

Despite the small space and very little accommodations to get a table, try to either come late before they close or come early! You'll end up waiting in line for awhile, but it's all worth it in the end!

Will I come back?! YES!!! Open late until 2am, short walk from clubs and bars, huge portions, easy on your wallet, and delicious food!!
author: Fraulein C.

description: aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaAaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa! Tasted so so and attitude so bad! never come here again!!!!!!!! chicken was rusty!!!
author: Wendy L.

description: TLDR: Poor customer service tied with microwaved food. The young lady who approached us immediately ignored us after asking what kind of table we wanted. The menu also took longer than the food to arrive. While we were waiting for the menu, the two servers were chatting in the corner as if they had nothing better to do. Upon ordering our food, we asked the man who looked like the manager for water with our food which we never got. Everything(egg and meat) in the ramen was cold except the soup which told me that they just microwaved everything. The food came within 5 minutes which supports the fact that they rushed it. We had to take the bill to the counter because the staff was too busy ignoring us. In addition, we had to take it back to them because I guess they really wanted to win the reward of worst customer service of the year. I've had better customer service and food at Mcdonalds. If you want something for dinner, go to the Starbucks next door.
author: Aska C.

description:
I really want to like this place, I do. Everyone gives such raving reviews about this place, but personally, I thought their ramen was just "okay." I suppose it's a bit unfair, but I'm comparing this place to Daikokuya in LA, so this place definitely pales in comparison. I got the miso ramen and added corn, which I thought was pretty good, but there was a slice of butter in my soup. Why??? I suppose the soup isn't rich enough on its own, so they need to add some oily butter to it. Sigh. I came here with my brother, and he was also not satisfied with the ramen here. It was just "okay," so I don't think we'll come back anytime soon.

Also, trying to find parking in the area is really frustrating. We drove all the way here from the East Bay, hoping to hit the ramen jackpot, so we were a bit disappointed.
author: Karen L.

description: I wish I would have checked out the Yelp page for this place before coming here for dinner. They aren't lying about the "Poor Food Safety Score" here. I go to a new ramen spot every Wednesday and can honestly say this is the wort ramen I've had in the city. Had to take a sick day from work because this restaurant made me that sick. The noodles were bland, the karage was terrible and the broth was even worse.  The only saving grace for this place is the lovely waitress who was waiting on our table.
author: Kylie H.

description:
I usually just come to Katana-Ya for Ramen, but I have actually tried some of their sushi which, wasn't the best but, was pretty good.  They have an extensive ramen menu so it shouldn't be hard for someone to find one they like since you can basically build your own.  Maybe one day I'll venture out of my comfort zone and actually order a different ramen but for now, I'll still to my Soyu Ramen ;-)

The place is pretty small so they can get really busy which is why I usually go at "off hours". Ask them, they'll tell you when that is.  Or you can always call ahead and pick it up to go.

The service can sometimes be lacking, just depends on the day and server.  All in all, I like the place and I'll keep coming back whenever I'm sick, in need of some warming up, or craving ramen.
author: Ninja H.

description:
Delicious ramen, spotty service. 
This was my second time and I went with a friend. After 1 minute of sitting down we were asked if we were ready to order. When I requested a few more minutes, another waitress came by within 2 minutes to ask if we were ready yet. Yikes! Calm down! You were so quick to take my order but when it came to the bill, you were nowhere to be found and there was a crowd surrounding the door.
Also, I feel like I was typecasted and was given a fork to eat my food with but my friend was not.
If the ramen wasn't so good, I probably wouldn't go back to eat there.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I used to be really loyal to Katana-Ya when I lived in the city, but now that I've experienced greener pastures of ramen elsewhere, I unfortunately have to dock this place to just OK. The other night I was here and I went for the regular soy sauce ramen, which is just about the most basic ramen you can get anywhere. I guess I figured it would be a good test as to the overall quality of the ramen here. While it wasn't bad, it definitely wasn't great. The broth was too much of one bland salty flavor, the noodles were just ok (I could be wrong, but they didn't seem to match the soup very well), and the rest of the toppings were meh. Basically the ramen fell asleep in my mouth... and no one wants that!

If I'm ever in the area again, I'm open to re-trying the spicy tofu ramen, which I used to really like (though I'm not sure I can trust the "old ramen me" anymore). For now, Katana-Ya is probably best saved as a safe bet for newbies; more seasoned ramen palates, however, will be left wanting more.

PS: I TOTALLY forgot the story of how I dropped my phone in my ramen here once. Oh the memories... thanks Yelp Updates!
author: Kate V.

description: Very very very mediocre food for SF. Broth was thin and lacked body and flavor, ramen noodles were fine, BBQ pork wasn't particularly flavorful or tender. There are many better options if you want ramen in the city (Ie nojo, yamadaya). Good for people who don't know Asian cuisine well, but if you've been exposed to the good stuff, you'll be disappointed.
author: M L.

description: The soup was not tasty at all. The pork was only 2 small slices. With the price of the ramen, it is considered above average, on top of that, we have to pay extra for the chili?
author: Maria S.

description: Terrible service and terrible ramen. The music and light drive me crazy. NEVER come again.
author: Xuyun L.

description:
Was desperately craving ramen on a random Monday afternoon and was told specifically not to go into Japantown, but to stop at this place. 

We were seated immediately and very well attended to. I went with the spicy tofu ramen and my friend had the green onion ramen; the broth was was very fresh, the noodles delicious, it really hit the spot.

Be warned: They add MSG and they're not afraid to say so.
author: Adena B.

description:
I've had Katana-Ya roughly 3 or 4 times. So, I've been here enough to get a general gist of what the food tastes like.

The wait can be incredibly and tediously long. It could range from 30 minutes to 2 hours even. The space is very small and very squished. You sit so close to the other table, there's no privacy in what you can say. However, I don't mind it being compact, but I'm not sure how some might feel about this. Thus, why I pointed it out.

Obviously, I go here for their ramen. I feel like since it specializes in ramen, I shouldn't order anything else. I've ordered squid and other miscellaneous appetizers, but they kind of pale in comparison to the ramen. The ramen isn't bad, but it's not that great either. I feel like the broth is a little bit too oily and heavy. The texture of the noodles is perfect upon arrival, but if you're like me, then you'd prefer them harder so that in the midst of eating your meal, your noodles don't soften up. Once again, my preference and bias coming into play. 

I mean I come here when people are craving ramen and want something nearby the area, but don't want to settle for Ajisen Ramen in the food court of the mall. But to be honest, I prefer Ajisen Ramen to Katana-Ya's ramen. 

Overall, the ramen doesn't wow you enough to make you want to continuously come back on your own free will. But not too bad. Just not as great as some of the reviews make it out to be.
author: Jessica X.

description:
Came here for dinner today. We wrote our name down on the paper outside and waited maybe a minute.  Then a waitress saw us, told us to go in, and said we didnt need to sign in because there was no wait. Winning. 

I came here with no expectations of the place. All I knew was that I wanted ramen. I got a medium spicy vegetable (also had tofu) ramen soup with miso base. Boypren got fried chicken ramen with miso base. Both were around $11.50 (each). I think they charged an extra dollar or so to make mine spicy.  

Mine was jam packed with cabbage, tofu, carrots, broccoli and..I dont know what else.  And noodles of course! It was the perfect spiciness,  the kind with a nice kick that almost came with a runny nose.  Good flavor.  

I didn't like the noodle texture. .it tasted undercooked? Not sure if that's how it's supposed to taste or if I had to leave it on the piping hot soup for longer. 

Overall it was okay. It wasn't the best but I'd come back for the large portion and the nice spice.
author: Vivian L.

description:
I came for a late dinner with a friend at 9pm on a Sunday night, thinking that we'd miss the dinner rush. TOTALLY WRONG. The waiting list still had about 8-10 parties ahead of us. I definitely would have given 5 stars if it wasn't such a long wait at that time or if we were told an estimate of how long before we were seated when we arrived, but that wasn't the case.

Finally after about 45 minutes of waiting outside (and a little luck, since about 3 parties weren't there when their names were called), our name was called and we were seated. There was a menu outside, so we already knew exactly what we wanted, which made the food come much, much faster. I suggest that no one waste time looking at the menu and waiting for someone to come to your table to take your order before ordering, especially after such a long and probably hungry wait.

Both of us ordered the Katanaya ramen ($12.90) with rich broth, which had boiled egg, potstickers, fried chicken, chashu pork, corn, seaweed, and scallions. I would highly recommend the rich broth over the light broth because the broth was VERY good--good enough for both of us to drink the whole bowl clean. It was probably the best ramen I've ever had.
author: Sara L.

description:
I can honestly say that this was one of my worst Ramen experiences, and I am a avid fan of good ramen. I had really wanted shabu shabu from Henry the IV next door (same owners), but my friend insisted on trying something new. After wandering, we ended up here. We waited about twenty minutes and were seated in the dungeon downstairs. We waited another fifteen minutes for water and for anyone to even help us. I understand that in SF, space is hard to find, but the restaurant is terribly cramped and i was starting to get claustrophobic halfway through my meal. 

Ordering went fast enough; I came with my UC Berkeley friend and her visiting UCSD friend. We obviously wanted him to enjoy some good San Francisco cuisine. However, we were sadly disappointed. I ordered extra spicy ramen, and the soup was literally RED. I am a huge fan of spicy food, and the broth was not as spicy as it looked. I am still wondering how it got to that color. My friend ordered regular Salt ramen and a side of some fish thing. The fish thing came quickly, but we waited...and waited...and waited...and waited for the Salt Ramen and it didn't show up for about an hour. It seemed that the order was mixed up, because a waiter approached our table and tried giving us a random bowl. We told him it wasn't ours, and he just left us there. For an hour. No server came down within that time period, so we considered going up to find someone. At this point, I was really pissed off and my friends considered just canceling the ramen so we could catch the Bart back to school. 

Magically, the moment we were considering just leaving, the ramen arrived. My starving friends devoured the bowl, while I sat and watched, having eaten my poisonous looking red bowl of noodles fifty minutes before. Their broth was just ok, and it was a fish base. The noodles were too soft for my liking. This was honestly not a good experience, and I had a good experience at Henry the IV. I was thoroughly disappointed, and I don't think I will be coming back.
author: Alice Z.

description:
If you're reading this while perusing for dinner options, know this: get here early, and bring an appetite. 


THE SLURP:

The ramen is definitely the go to at this restaurant, their spicy miso broth is perfect. The noodles have that good springy texture and the portions are generous.

But, surprise! Their unagi nigiri is amazing. melt in the mouth, perfect texture. Didn't expect any quality from their sushi, but it was well worth it. We didn't try any thing else off of their sushi menu, so don't get mad at me if it is predictably bad. 

THE ENVIRONMENT:

a little claustrophobic, and they haven't changed the decor since the nineties. Or the playlist, they must have a burned CD in the 8-disk player titled "Hot Jamz 97' ". However, the jamz are pretty hot, if a little retro, it was fun.
author: Patrick T.

description:
YUMMY Food, ramen, and sushi!

-Butterfish mmm I love butterfish and this place serves them good here, warning it can get expensive
-Sake sashimi the fat on the salmon gave it a melt in your mouth effect. 
-Katana-ya ramen, regular and spicy. It's better to get spicy just cuz it's not really spicy =/ kind of sad there, but oh well ti was still delicious. The bowl is huuuuge (hehe) and there is a lot of stuff, fun stuff, going on in the bowl. The pork on the other hand is OK not like how it is at Ramen Dojo. 
-Small fried chicken curry plate this is NOM NOM. This is really a small plate and if you are really really starving or drunk stat I reccommend not getting the small size. But this is worth trying.
-Soft shell crab, this one is pretty good too - just have to try it for yourself.
 Be ready to wait outside because the place is pretty small inside and seating is limited. Make sure your whole party is there because they will not seat you until everyone is there (just qutoing the sign posted on the window). The service is hit and miss. Most of the time miss because even though there are like 3 of them, they still look confused, and forgetful about things that are asked of them.
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
I'm not sure what happened here. I either went on an off night or my expectations for ramen are much higher now that I have tried other places. I'm hoping it's the former and their food didn't go downhill.

We arrived with a party of 6 last night around 11pm. The restaurant was packed and we hung around for a while before getting a seat. We thought that the place would be empty at that hour but we were wrong! In the end we lost one because the wait was too long and he'd miss his train home.

I ordered the Kantanya ramen because it's been a while since I ate here and I wanted to get everything in it. When the food arrived, I was slightly disappointed. The ramen wasn't done to my liking. It tasted slightly overcooked and soggy. The al-dente taste was not there that night... I think the remaining ingredients: fried chicken, hard boiled egg, corn, pork, gyoza, bamboo shoot, and seaweed overpowered the bowl of noodles. Not to mention my entire mouth was left feeling extremely dry from all the MSG that was put into the broth. The menu specifically states "MSG added" in case you didn't know.

I think I'll give Katanaya a benefit of a doubt and come back on a different day. I normally go during the day and the experience last night might've been a fluke. I'm hoping to bump their rating back to four stars the next time I'm back. Until then, I think they are a solid three stars.
author: Tim G.

description:
I prefer Maru Ichi Mountain View and Shoki Ramen Sacramento. So far, in SF, while Katanaya is far better than genki's, it's still not something I'd write home about. I guess SF's strength isn't in its ramen.

DON'Tt get the sushi, it's kinda meh.
DO get the spicy miso with rich (i.e. fatty) broth.

Whats with charging $1.40 for spiciness!? Sidenote: the spicy is really not that spicy. If I'm craving Ramen I'll be back, they've got good lunch specials, but if you can, make the trek to south bay.
author: Jess C.

description:
This is my go to spot when I have no idea what I want for lunch.

This place is small and I knew it was going to be good based on the waiting list and the people willing to wait. There may be seating for about 15-20 people, the tables are tiny so don't expect a lot of elbow room. There is a sign-in list on the shelf outside the place. You may be tempted to go to Jack in the Box next door because of the wait, but trust me the wait is worth it.

The service is quick and generally friendly. I was pretty impressed that the owner spoke Cantonese, Mandarin and Japanese. 

The ramen can be ordered in several ways: they use one soup broth and add a flavor base from there, soy/salt/miso, from extra tare making it richer in flavor, added spice and etc (generally with a surcharge).  The portion is avg and will fill-up a fatty like me. My fav is the Katana-ya Ramen that comes with a little bit of everything (~$14, gyoza, karage, char-sui, corn, egg, seaweed and etc.)

The sushi is fresh and simple, nothing fancy, not a lot of sauce hiding the fresh favor of the fish.
author: Vay V.

description: Walked in around 6:30 expecting a little wait, however they were able to seat us immediately at the sushi bar! Had the baby fried octopus to start and a bowl of the katanaya ramen! Flavorful broth, nicely cooked noodles, very tasty overall. Quick and friendly service, enjoyed our first experience here quite a bit!
author: Missy P.

description:
First time Ramen eater, but I brought my daughters who are ramen aficionados. Although the restaurant was small, the service was great, the food was superior and the prices are reasonable. This is definitely a local favorite- they knew all of the rules including walking in with the fingers numbering your guests are probably displayed. 
I'll definitely hit this restaurant up again while I'm in town!!!!
author: Todd C.

description:
Perhaps I was harsh with my previous review.  My heart has softened after four years in SF and at least two dozen meals at here.  For being Vietnamese, it's kind of a surprise and a shame that I eat ramen at least five times as often as pho, but such is the case.  The ramen at Katana-Ya is much better than the pho at the Vietnamese restaurants I've had in the city, anyway.  

For cold days, hangover days, sick days, and days when I just want to be alone, I'll come here for a hot, rich bowl of spicy miso BBQ pork ramen.  The noodles are fresh and chewy.  The BBQ pork is big and tender.  The spicy miso broth is deep and delicious with just the perfect level of kick (for me, but it may be too spicy for most).  This is my kind of comfort.  Ahhhhh.

If it's your first time, I highly recommend the Katana-Ya ramen, which has a little of everything. I'm not impressed by the sushi or sashimi, and you mind as well just order ramen like everyone in here (it must be good if everybody is having it, right?).  Don't come during peak lunch or dinner hours--although service is efficient, there will inevitably be a wait.  It's Union Square and this restaurant not much bigger than a shoebox.
author: Liz T.

description:
The location is pretty convenient.  I came in famished 4 pm on a Friday and got seated immediately.
The ramen was fine.  I got the chicken karage shoyu ramen "extra spicy."  In terms of spicyness I'd give it a 3.5/10.  Not really spicy but there's enough to keep things a little more interesting than if it weren't there at all.  The noodles were really average and could have been better.  The karage was great.  The only other toppings were green onions and seaweed.  The flavor was decent enough that I did manage to finish all the broth.
I'd come back if I were craving ramen and I was near Union Square.
author: Audrey D.

description: Brought my Groupon for takeout in they told me no longer honoring them :( told me to contact Groupon for a refund. So I will. Buyer beware..Fyi, if you're going to renege on your deal, do the right thing and contact Groupon and refund everybody sheesh
author: Raoul D.

description:
I feel that there was a time that this place was really amazing.... and that time has passed. Maybe it was the lack of a line or just the fact that the waitress could barely hear us due to the loud pop music that was playing in the background. 

The fried chicken and won ton found in the soup did not seem that fresh and was kinda for lack of better words kinda sad. It seems like there are better places out there now. Hope they can fix these issues...
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I actually really like this place but if they ask if you want to sit next door DONT. Awful flat lighting that screams "get the fuck out" and no music is playing at all. Just silence.

The main spot is AWESOME but next door you'll get shitty service, flat lighting, and a silent meal
author: jessica c.

description:
Made my way here after seeing it on the 7x7 list. It was late on a  friday night and we had to put our names on the wait list. It wasn't too bad. We waited for 20 minutes outside. It's not exactly the best area to be hanging around outside either with people passing by asking for change.

I ordered the BBQ Pork (Cha Siu) for $11 with Miso (there are 3 options: Miso, Salt, or Soy). It comes with 4 slices which was more than enough. You can even add extra noodles for $2, but the amount of noodles they already give you was perfect for me.

The broth wasn't too salty and the noodles tasted perfect. Most ramen places, I can easily finish the glass of water even without sipping on the broth. Not this place! I barely finished half of my glass. It really did taste like I was sipping on miso soup and ramen at the same time. What a great experience!

Good service but too bad this place is so small! The smallest ramen places I've ever seen. What a chill place to try!
author: Lauren K.

description: Came here at 11:58pm and they said they were closed but we got there the same time as these two girls and they were seated.... And they said their kitchen was closed.... If so, change the yelp time... Absolutely rude staffs and it was supposed to be my first time at this place.. Never coming back, would give a 0 if I could.
author: Ina L.

description:
For my second time in SF, a ramen spot was definitely a priority. Being in Union Square at the time, this was the closest location to suffice my cravings. 

The fried chicken shoyu ramen, or Katana-Ya ramen as it could have been called, was great! Well portioned, and a well ornate bowl with several add-ons to try. I like my ramen spicy, and they give chili powder on the side in case you have the same palette. The only down side about this item was that the egg was too bland. It was nothing special in comparison to the fried chicken, pork and others that were in the bowl. It says on the website that they have spiciness ratings, which I was not asked about regarding my item. 

Overall, the food was great. The restaurant is a little cramped but not too much. It could probably use a little better lighting, but other than that this place is a must try.
author: Luke L.

description:
Piping hot bowl of miso Katana-Ya Ramen here the other night; it was filling and different than other ramen I've had in SF. Lighter than Tonkotsu, add the spicy-heat yourself, and delightful bites of pork, fried chicken AND gyoza dumplings all in there together with corn and bits of seaweed. 

I drained the bowl, unashamed.
author: DJ D.

description: Food looks great but the service was a bit slow. It just looked like they were really busy
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I've now tried Michael Mina's Ramen Bar, Ramen Underground, and Katana-Ya is my fave of the 3 FiDi options!

Not only was it speedy- even at lunch time, the ramen was piping hot (so hot my mouth is still suffering the consequences) and extremely tasty. I got the medium spicy salt broth with butter corn and it was great. Not to mention, HEAVILY LOADED with corn. It was a big bowl of ramen- big enough to cover two days of lunches and I can't wait to return. 

While Ramen Bar is clearly trendier, Katana-Ya definitely has the best flavor and is a nice casual medium between the sexiness of Mina's establishment, and the down-right hovel of Ramen Underground. Prices here are also the cheapest of all three (depending of course on what you add in).
author: Rachel L.

description:
UPDATE: KATANAYA HAS NO DONBURI bowls. Not even for lunch. 

Yelp pictures can be so deceiving and outdated sometimes. Major bummer!
author: Amber S.

description:
Coming from Chicago, I was soooooo pumped to try ramen in SF. I'm a big fan of ramen, and it is easily one of my most favorite comfort food. 

Got the miso ramen and I was extremely disappointed. Granted, my expectations were inflated because I thought SF would have great ramen like NYC or LA, but hell, I can name 3 places in Chicago that's better than Katana-Ya, and that's disappointing. Plus side, it's open super late, but overall, I'm extremely disappointed that Katana-Ya was just average.
author: Pete B.

description: Wow, finally a time when there is no wait at the restaurant! I was in search of restaurant nearby downtown for a quick lunch and remembered about this place. My friends were visiting in town so I decided to stop by this place. We all got the ramen aa recommended by fellow yelpers and it was delicious! Portion was much bigger than expected $9.95 and under! I got the miso and it was very flavorful. No wonder there's always such a long line!
author: Shanna C.

description: Delicious! Number 12 with medium spicy was perfection. I would definitely recommend this ramen place to anyone visiting the city. This place has given LA's Ramen restaurants a run for their money. NOTE: The receipt writing is VERY confusing and messy so if you're splitting the check, keep track of your order based on the menu.
author: Amanda L.

description: Not  my favorite maybe because it's not the same owners sign said new management service was slow and ramen was undercooked soup had sea weed my fault not a fan of. It just didn't have a upbeat vibe  for such a high rating please forgive me if I'm off on this one just thought it was lacking in presentation
author: Lee H.

description:
This place used to be memorable a few years back.  What happened?

Today I got tuna poke and regular ramen in miso broth.  The tuna pieces were fresh enough but the soy marinade was so salty I could not eat the leafy greens that came with it.  The ramen was not that great either.  There was one lone piece of pork and it was cold and not particularly flavorful or tender.  The noodle tasted starchy like it was cooked in not enough water or in water that had previously been used.  

I have had better ramen elsewhere in the bay area.
author: Alice A.

description: The Ramen here is just okay; certainly not Ramen that I would ever crave. I've had far better at other SF spots. The ramen broth here lacks the richness and umami I crave. I'd rather eat at Izakaya Sozai especially since both spots require a wait!
author: Aleyna S.

description: Arrived at 5:40pm and there was a wait list. Thought we had to wait at least half an hour but we only waited for five minutes and we got seated! I ordered the combo which you can choose any ramen and a side of sushi for 15$! I got the BBQ Ramen with Miso and a dish of spicy tuna roll. Let me tell you, the first bite was amazing!! The soup was super flavorful and I really like the ramen as well! We will return soon! (:
author: Tina C.

description: Wow, what's wrong with the older lady waitress? She was being rude from the beginning. I tried to use my groupon but they are refusing to take it now. There's supposedly a sign at the door stating this.. but how can I see the sign if the door is always open? Anyway, we decided it's okay, we'll still eat there. Food wasn't bad (wasn't the best ramen ever). When she gave me our bill, I started calculating it since the 1 looked like a 7 and the older lady waitress was literally standing there staring at us the whole time. Sorry lady that we had to make sure our total is correct because your handwriting is hard to read. I felt very uncomfortable. Never ever, ever, EVER coming back again.
author: Yer L.

description: Got a BBQ ramen last night. The miso soup was salty, the noodle was too chewy like rubber bands, and the pork tasted nothing. I guess it was frozen. The staffs were rude and the interior was hideous. I cannot believe they call themselves a 'Japanese' restaurant.
author: Bryan B.

description:
KATANAYAAAA!!!!! I've been waiting to come for a month. To celebrate finishing our first final project/presentation, we decided to come here.

Lots of articles about KATANAYA from magazines on the windows.

Come before 6PM or you'll have to waitttttttt.

This place is very intimate...tables are small, it felt like I didn't have a place for my bowl. 5 people sharing 1 table...all the tables were pretty close together.

Inside looked cool, pretty lights http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=VPWAfqScvZs3gQand1iUxg

We had...
~2 katanaya ramens w/ miso soup http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=b3NQHlqiIj2J5a0kpSewRg for $12.90, it came with a lot of stuff...corn, fried chicken, fried potstickers, seaweed, bamboo shoots, scallions, bbq pork & half boiled egg. I would think it's the BEST ramen they serve.
~1 katanaya ramen w/ salted soup (taste like chicken soup)
~1 deep fried chicken ramen
~1 rice w/ salmon, crab, & roe

I'd come back if I was in the area, I wouldn't come out of my way to come back just to eat it.
author: Kylie L.

description:
I had a craving for ramen and my friend found Kayana-Ya on Yelp with rather good reviews.  She also mentioned that they had a Chasu Ramen that was on the 7x7's list of "100 Things to Eat Before You Die".  Immediately, I got excited, however I was not at all impressed...

We arrived around 6pm last week on a weeknight and were seated right away.  As we looked at our table, we knew that there was no way we could fit 3 people plus our food.  After the couple next to us left, the waitress allowed us to put the two tables together...Let's face it, we over order ALL the time.

FOOD:
*California Rolls - They were okay, nothing special about it.  

*Agedashi Tofu - DELCIOUS!  The tofu was perfectly deep fried while the middle still remained moist.  The broth the tofu was placed in was absolutely yummy!  It was sweet and complemented the tofu.

*Gyoza - I love gyoza, but I didn't love this one.  It tasted like it was brought out from the freezer, microwaved, and pan fried on one side.  The inside was barely flavorful and didn't taste fresh at all.  It did not come with the usual gyoza dipping sauce but instead was accompanied with chili oil.  

*Chicken Karage - It consisted of large pieces of chicken and salad.  The chicken was okay but the pieces were way too large.

*Softshell Crab - YUM!  I'm not usually a fan of softshell crab but this one was unbelievably sweet!  Definitely a must try!

*Katana-Ya Ramen (#12 on the menu) - The menu CLEARLY states that the ramen comes with chasu (bbq pork), gyoza, chicken, corn and an egg.  However, when the ramen arrived, the only thing was chasu.  When we asked the waiter, he said he would bring out the rest on a SEPARATE plate.  When you look at the menu, the picture clearly shows you that it comes in the bowl.  We ordered one bowl mild and the other spicy (there's an additional cost for spicy).  The mild had NO spiciness to it and I ended up combining the two ramen soups in my bowl to get the amount of spiciness I was looking for. 

SERVICE:
Service was VERY spotty.  As we walked in the waitress was quick to seat us.  As she came over a couple of minutes later to take our order, we said we were still waiting for one other person.  After that, she was either in the back doing other things or catering to other tables.  We had to flag her down several times to get our order in and was never asked if everything was okay.  The food was brought out by a Latin waiter and additional food requests were asked from him.  

Credit cards accepted.

As my hunt for additional ramen venues to cure my ramen cravings continues, Katana-Ya will be left off the list.  I'm sorry Katana-Ya, your ramen DOES NOT belong on the 7x7 list.
author: Nicole S.

description:
BEWARE

Purchased a Groupon to Katana-ya weeks ago in Hawaii to use at this establishment in San Franciso.  Walked in on Tuesday August 4, 2015 and the cashier pointed to a hand written note on the store front noting that Katana-ya is no longer honoring Groupons as of July 13, 2015.

Immediately wrote to Groupon and am still awaiting a response :(
author: Marvin M.

description:
I constantly come to this place expecting something miraculous to have changed between the last time I came and the current time, but nothing ever does.

The ramen is pretty standard ramen fare, if you don't include the fried chicken. It's not the best ramen in the world, or even close, but it's close by to SoMa and great for an after-work get together with some friends.

The portions are quite huge, but again, the broth leaves something to be desired and the chicken, after being drowned in soup for a bit, also isn't too terrific. The wait is usually okay, but there have been times where I have waited twenty minutes or so.
author: Alexander L.

description: Not a bad place to satisfy your ramen craving when you can't make it to the south bay. Decently priced ramen with a variety of topping choices. All come with a standard piece of char siu , bamboo shoots, etc. I ordered the basic one with no additional toppings and 2 pieces of uni nigiri. Not the best uni, but I'll take it. Satisfying meal for a stressful week.
author: Cynthia X.

description: The cold soba is so delicious.  It's the perfect spot to get some rest after a day of shopping in Union Square.  I am a Katana-ya Fan!
author: kathi k.

description:
I've been here a few years back and I honestly did not remember my experience, except that it was a very tiny restaurant and I disliked fried soggy chicken in my broth. I drive past this restaurant on a daily basis and was lured into giving this place a second try after seeing so many patrons outside each time and re-experiencing why this is listed as a 7X7 Big Eats restaurant. The wait was about 30 minutes or so and a friend and I just missed the cut-off for the first wave of people already inside (not too bad considering that some people have waited a lot longer). 

Jot down your name on the clipboard outside and be prepared to wait...OUTSIDE. The restaurant is a hole in the wall with just enough space for the waitresses to walk through one at a time.

- Asahi: Only the large sized bottle available to order. 

- Sapporo light: the small bottle size is available for this beer.

- Katanaya Ramen with "light" miso broth: Love that you are able to customize your soup (miso, soy sauce, or salt) and the flavor intensity (light or heavy). This big bowl consisted of fried potstickers, fried chicken, corn, bamboo shoots, green scallions, half a boiled egg, bean sprouts, and seaweed. All for the price of one, unlike some other ramen places that I've been to where additional toppings = additional $. Ramen was cooked to perfection and the broth was surprisingly just the right amount of flavor, thank you for giving the "light" broth option!

4 stars for the ramen, but I'll have to minus one star for the service. The waiter called our name on the list for a table, then immediately went back in without saying anything and came back out 10 minutes later to tell us that our seat was ready. At least he could have notified us that he was checking to make sure we were present rather than giving us a slither of hope that we were about to be seated. What made it a worst experience was when the waitress never brought us water when we inquired about 2 times and still never brought us water in the end...I'm being too generous with the rating. Your ramen is good, but service also makes or breaks the deal. 

P.S. Open until 1AM. Go early during dinner time to beat the rush.
author: Tracy T.

description:
I was in the bay area and was CRAVING authentic ramen.  We had a hotel close to this ramen bar and the concierge recommended this place, thank you mister cause it was one of the best meals i had in sf.

I ordered the spicy bbq pork ramen combo with donbbq pork rice bowl. I got the broth regular/salt based/and very spicy and when my rice bowl came out i just put the pork in the ramen.  Beware the spicy paste will make you sweat a lil but the spicy taste isn't overwhelming. The noodles were perfect, not too soft not too hard and the broth, was very tasty!

I wish i had this place nearby cause i would eat it every effin day.  Everytime i return to the bay area I'm DEFINITELY going here first!
author: Lisa K.

description:
Fantastic Ramen, huge portions, and long lines! Not ideal for groups larger than four, even better for just two. 

I came here on a cold day with my dad recently and we loved it. He had his ramen with a beer and I enjoyed mine with some tea. Conveniently located near Union Square, this is easy to get to from all corners of town. 

There are different broth types and also different soup sizes. With options aplenty there's a little something for everyone. It's also a quick meal. We must've been in and out in less than thirty minutes. Better than all ramen I've had in Seattle, I'll be back here for lunch again when I visit in March. Yum!
author: Katy H.

description:
There's one thing I care when I eat in Ramen restaurant. That is, when you have a ramen that has your business' name on it, IT BETTER BE GOOD.

"Katana-Ya Ramen" is bad. Only cons is the broth. The noodle, chasu, eggs, menma, everything sucked. Other ramens are just same stuff with funky toppings. Miso ramens were a-okay. Still, I had better.

Funny thing is Katana-Ya's other stuff are pretty good. Like Chirashi, chicken kara-age and such. If you want some Japanese stuff with sake, Katana-ya is not a bad choice. But as a ramen restaurant, don't even bother. It's just like other lame mediocre ramen restaurants all around bay area.

p.s.

To the people who are standing and waiting in front of Katana-Ya everyday, check your tongue. And walk around to find good restaurants, not just follow by internet shit.
author: Brandon K.

description: There is something about wonderful Asian food in the City by the Bay: San Francisco, California.  My favorite Chinese restaurant, and dim sum house are in the Bay area, and now I may add one my favorite Ramen Noodle House.  I arrived early on a Monday and avoided the crowd.  The small family-like staff was wonderful and accomodating.  I had the spicy scallion ramen with the fried chicken on the side.  The fried chicken breast nuggets were good, but not the wonderful item I had heard about.  However, the ramen noodle soup with separate areas of scallion, and spice was truly spectacular.  I am not an authority on Japanese, or Taiwanese food and am a bit old school in my love of Cantonese food.  Still, I know quality, and would argue that Katana-Ya is on the "A" List for Ramen Noodles.  After all Noodles = Life!
author: Thomas W.

description:
I have recently moved to this neighborhood and as a ramen-lover decided to check out this ramen place, since it's only 4 blocks away from my home, deeply regret it.
I will start with ramen itself, it was below 'Ok'. I have tried tons of places in SF Bay Area, and this one was the worst so far, I have't tried rolls or sushi there, so can't say anything about it.
I wouldn't be writing this review tho if service there was at least decent. The lady who seated and served us in the beginning was extremely rude, I thought "Oh well, we all have bad days, or maybe it's just us particularly who she was treating like this", but while we were eating 4 people came in and were seated by that lady near us.. and yes! She treated them just like us. They were probably not as hungry as us, so they just stood up and left immediately, good for them! If I wouldn't be starving-I'd leave right away as well. 
There was another super nice waiter who brought us our bill, he was very professional and friendly and I wish he'd serve us in the very beginning.
I'm not coming back to that place ever.
author: Kseniya S.

description:
Honestly I never understood why there's so many reviews and long lines for this place.  It's small and the food is really just mediocre.  

The ramen really isn't that good as the broth is thin and flavorless.  They throw all kinds of stuff in there and overcharge.  I've been there three times and have just gotten worse each time.  Probably won't be going again.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
2800+ reviews. Do you really need to read mine? The correct answer is, "Of course." But, I am not going to be offended if you glaze over and just check the star rating. In the interest of expediency, I'll give it to you short and sweet: It's alright. It'll scratch your ramen itch but it won't, likely, make you lose your breath.

Long answer: fried chicken ramen. Sounds ridiculous, right? Life changing, right? It's not. It's ok. And that's... frustrating. I mean, come on. Fried chicken ramen. That just sounds like something you have to have in your life. But, the description is the most exciting part of the experience. After you choose your protein, you choose your broth, consistency and spice level. It's all very particularized and I'm not opposed to the idea that maybe I did something wrong. But, I'm pretty awesome at flavor combos, so I don't think that's it. Fried chicken protein, miso broth, regular, and medium spice. The bowl came out and the portion was huge. Try as I might, I couldn't make a dent in it... but that could be because I wasn't that inspired. My broth was a bit more bland and watery than I expected/wanted and I had more greens and bamboo in the bowl than meat. I get it: costs count... but if you're advertising a protein, give me the protein. Good for groups. Fun for late night. A bit blah for ramen. Hope this helps.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Katana-Ya Ramen with any soup base is wonderful.

And the music- when did I transport back to Palladium, NYC, 1997?

And they're open late! I'm usually only here for lunch, but I totally need to come here at midnight some time! I bet that's quite a thing.
author: Rob C.

description:
If you're wandering around Union Square late at night and craving Japanese, this is probably the closest option. It's open late and about 2 blocks from Union Square. After a day of shooting photos and looking at Xmas trees, it's time to chow down.

Like most Japanese restaurants, it's tiny inside. You find yourself sitting about 2 feet from the table next to you. It's great of eavesdropping. Good thing I don't have long elbows!

Katanaya Ramen - A large $13 bowl of ramen with fried chicken, fried potstickers, corn, seaweed, pork, eggs, and scallions. All the protein in it made it one of the most filling bowls of ramen I've ever devoured. It was a bit much though, as the fried items got soggy. The ramen texture was a tad harder than what I prefer. The miso broth wasn't too bad. Being the hungry man I am, I inhaled it of course. It better be filling for $13!

Service was very good which I liked. It was near closing time so the crowds were dying down.
author: Minh D.
