description: I've eaten here 2 years ago and loved it! Went today and was disappointed. I ordered the ramen combination with salmon donburi. The salmon donburi was served in a small miso soup bowl with sushi rice and 3 pieces of raw salmon. The ramen was fairly proportioned. The soyu ramen came with 2 pieces of pork, seaweed and shallots. The ramen noodles was soggy and the soyu soup base was a little too salty for me. Service was horrible! We kept trying to get our servers attention, she glanced at us even knowing we were trying to get her attention and she just looked at us then looked away. I probably wouldn't come here again.
author: Krys S.

description:
I came here bcuz of the long line I always passed by so decided to give it a try. SERIOUSLY DISAPPOINTED!
I ordered the katanaya ramen for the variety of topping you'll get and to be honest none of the topping is good. The skin of the gyoza is way too thick and there was way too many noodles and not enough miso broth. I asked for more soup and the server replied with bad attitude saying "two dollars"
WHAT!? I couldn't see any broth when they served it and they are asking for extra two dollars???!!!
There is nothing special about their ramen, ajisen's ramen is way better

Oh and while I almost finish my disappointing meal there was a small cockroach on the mirror wall right near me it was absolutely fvc*ing disgusting }:(((

Totally not worth the wait and I am NEVER COMING BACK

PS. The only good dish is their soft shell crab
author: Eza C.

description: Best ramen in town. I come here everytime I'm in town. Its by the union square. Ramen is so good. Spicy beef ramen. They also have sushi happy hour.  You can get udon or regular ramen.  Small space so the wait can get long. Come early and enjoy!!!
author: Wynn N.

description:
Very friendly staff, and pretty good ramen. We came in late at night, and it was crowded, but we found a seat right away. 

The portions are big, but I could do with a little less noodles, so that I can have more soup. The soup is good! I recommend the Shio (salt broth) butter ramen with corn. It hit the spot. The flavor was good, not too salty, the noodles not too mushy.

Not my favorite ramen ever, but very good late night ramen.
author: NY C.

description:
One of my favorite ramen place in the SF bay area! Remember to order the Katana-Ya special one! 

This is a cozy place, better to visit within 2 persons together.
From my past experience, 1 person normally within 15min waiting time, 2 persons within half hour if you agree to sit at the sushi bar. 3 or more, 45min+ waiting time.
author: N L.

description:
BAD, BAD SERVICE!!!!

The japanese waitress has some attitude problem. She got none of our orders right, ZERO. I think Katana-Ya is only good when the ramen soup is the strongest miso base, but NOOOOO, she just had to give me the weak light miso. I told her its not right and she said "that is the heavy miso." DOES SHE THINK I'M STUPID?! So I ate that bowl with a stomach full of rage.

She also gave 3 cups of water when there were 4 people. She also calculated the bill incorrectly. It came out to be $6 for 4 people. Good thing my friend had more morals than me, or else I would have walked right out of there $54 richer. And much less angry since that waitress would be getting negative tips.

Anyways, she ruined it.
author: Betty T.

description: Exceptionally slow service, overpriced decent sushi, and don't expect your water to get refilled at any point.
author: Elise G.

description: Went there today with a friend to grab some ramen. Old lady was just so RUDE. Completely ignored taking our orders and acting like a bitch!
author: Arman A.

description:
I think I have been spoiled by the ramen in LA.  With all the reviews this place has garnered, I was hopeful this could be an option for my ramen cravings.

I was a bit surprised - no Tonkatsu ramen option - just "standard".  I ordered the standard miso ramen and that is exactly what it tasted like...standard ramen not that much better than what can be bought at Ranch 99.  A bit of an exaggeration but it was meh.  The broth was definitely fresh and had a nice assortment of vegetables and toppings but lacked flavor.  And the texture of the actual ramen was similar to store bought.  Although the single slice of BBQ pork was tender and tasty...yes 1 slice for you $8 bowl of ramen.  No egg but I did see others with a hard boiled egg - may be optional or available in a different bowl.

The restaurant is small as are the tables but it is a ramen shop so it adds to the atmosphere.  There was a wait through out the night (Saturday) with a hard to see clipboard outside to sign up (many people walked in to ask).  

Service was good, very attentive and friendly.

At this price point, there is not a lot of upside for me here - I rather cook up my pre-packaged ramen at home and throw in an egg.
author: Roy L.

description:
Conveniently located and consistent food if you don't mind waiting.

And waiting.

And while you're still waiting, my friends and I will already be chowing down elsewhere nearby. Holla!
author: Dan B.

description:
I'mmmm baaaaAAAaack...

And once again, I was not disappointed.

I kept being wishy woshy, the Katana-ya ramen or the extra spicy ramen.  Where is a flower when you need one?  So, I finally decided on the fried chicken ramen $10.50  with a spicy miso broth. Ok.. I had to get the kaedama (extra noodles).  My hubby ordered the katsu don $9.50 - pork cutlet with scrambled egg on top of rice. 

They both did not disappoint again! 

My ramen was spicy! Did not have to add any togarashi and the broth was simply divine with kelp and thick pieces of menma (bamboo).  The ramen noodles were perfectly cooked, on the firmer side and they were a lovely yellow thicker noodle.  The broth and the noodles were certainly a match made in heaven...

My hubby normally orders ramen, but he opted for something different. The katsu was fried to perfection and the egg on top of the rice was just how Mom used to make it!  

The decor is the same, not the traditional Japanese rame house decor...

Food - 5 Stars
Service - 5 Stars 
Ambiance - 3 Stars
author: Cathy S.

description:
This review is based purely on service (moreso lackthereof.)

I've been here several times before. It's good ramen for the price and location (touristy Union Square). I live very close by in downtown, so I decided to take a friend out for a visit.

After being sat, I noted quite angry service by the lady, who had a short temperament during the ordering process. I let this slide -- everyone has a bad day. We got our orders but they forgot to give us a few utensils and requested bowls. I waited patiently to get their attention -- they're busy, ok it happens.

Then they send out the wrong adjoining course -- some spicy tuna bowl. (I unfortunately cannot eat spicy foods.) I alerted the lady, and rather than being apologetic, she defensively tells me, "This is what you got." I said "No, I got the tuna and salmon bowl." And this started a scuffle, where the lady kept asserting herself aggressively and a gentleman who claimed to be the manager told me to "calm down". First off, no one should ever treat a customer defensively and accuse them of ordering wrongly. EVEN if that were the case (which it wasn't here), the attitude should be of understanding, not of defense. Second, the manager did nothing to calm the situation besides assert that the lady apologized (if she did, it was a sassy, sarcastic, passive aggressive apology).

I don't want an apology -- I want things to be fixed and fixed quickly. They kept point at a menu above my head as I was sat, so I stood up to point at what I ordered, and I was pretty much demanded to "just sit down". This was simply appalling. I was appalled of the rudeness and unprofessionalism displayed at this restaurant. It's absolutely unfortunate because this is a decent ramen place and we all like ramen. Nonetheless, you, the viewer, need to be aware that this type of (dis)"service" does exist and that buyer beware.

I stood up and left -- the only way I can hold this restaurant accountable for their misdeeds (well and write this review -- my first negative review.)

Don't bother waiting at this joint. If you're in downtown/fidi, just go to RAMEN UNDERGROUND (http://ramenunderground.org/) on Kearny -- it's much better there anyways.
author: Bryant R.

description:
Katana-Ya is where I take any friend who's never tried real ramen!  My favorite so far is the BBQ pork with soy broth--MMM!!  I love how it's open so late (makes me feel like I'm back in NYC) and they do everything so well.  Last time I went with a friend who ordered a California Roll as an appetizer and I was surprised how fresh and tasty it was!  

Now that I enjoy their sushi as well, I'll be back more frequently.
author: Joshua G.

description: I am not usually a ramen fan, but I enjoyed the food very much. My soup was hot and somewhat flavorful, and it was at a reasonable price. My only complaint is that it is a small restaurant, so there was a long wait time. The spacing was cramped and I felt like I was an elbow away from the next table. However, I feel like most restaurants in San Francisco are typically small. I would come here again if I had no where else to go.
author: Angel N.

description: The foods are not so good, but it's very convenient location after drinking in downtown. The key is not to have high expectation. Then you don't have to be disappointed much. Don't go in like you gonna have great ramen or sushi. Just go in like you are getting some late night snack. If you want better food, there is ryoko restaurant:)
author: Mii L.

description:
I tried this place for a weekday lunch after recommendations by a few colleagues.  The only thing I didn't do was read the reviews prior to coming in regards to the service. 

The ramen was substantial and very hearty. The ingredients were fairly portioned for the price.  

The service was something else.  I had to go up the waitstaff at the counter 2 times to get a menu...that's correct...a menu.  I had to go up to the counter 3 times to ask for water.  If I was not in my correct state-of-mind, I swear I would have jumped over the counter (and probably knocking someone down) and poured myself a glass.  The place might have been packed, but it it is a very small joint.  It doesn't take THAT much effort to walk over to the table by the door to see if I needed anything especially if it's the only spot where anyone can get fresh air. 

At least they didn't take too long with my order.  I'll give them that.
author: Michael C.

description: Best Tofu Ramen ever! The bowl was so big, you can share easily with 2-3 people. Get there early to avoid a long wait or be patient as it is well worth the wait.
author: Jena S.

description: Food was decent. Not the best ramen. Not the best gyozas, but itll do. There was a health issue message about the place but i found it okay.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Came here for lunch today and had my usual: the deep fried chicken ramen with miso. This place was crowded for the weekday lunch hour but I snagged a seat at the sushi bar with no problem. 
Service was ok, food came out fast and I was out of there in less than 30min.
The ramen was good- the noodles however tasted differently then I remember...not as firm. The chicken was yummy and the miso broth was also not bad. 
The bowl was $11 and still reasonable for decent ramen downtown. I wouldn't mind returning but I found myself walking over to Underground Ramen first (they were closed unfortunately).
author: Miss H K.

description: worst ramen i had ever had, also the entrance is scary i almost fell, they should get some light at that shady entrance
author: Jaesang C.

description: We came looking for noodles, and ended up here, with a bowl of Udon.  It was great, and the place inviting.  It is very small and tight, and there always seems to be a line.
author: Katie M.

description:
I love Ramen when the weather is cold and foggy--which in SF, is pretty often. This is my all time favorite! They have generous portions of perfectly cooked (al dente) noodles, tasty broths (most important) and savory toppings. They have a good combo menu with delicious rice bowls and ramen with various toppings--that doesn't do it justice--so you can choose your faves!

Sapporo on tap! Izakawa type foods for starters. The wait can be long for groups, so not a great place for younger kids.
author: YearOf M.

description: Compared this to Ramen Dojo, I prefer Katana. Broth taste better, larger bowl, noodles are cooked well, cheaper, and you get more in your bowl as well. Ramen dojo barely gives you anything that isnt charged extra.
author: HonestOpino N.

description: I just want to know when Katana-ya will improve the Health Score to at least normal? I was really liked this place in the past!
author: Ed K.

description: Ramen came out very fast. Had the combo ramen with miso broth add some spice. Service was disappointing, ordered a large Sapporo but never got it and almost still got charged for it. Didn't even get a water until I pretty much finished eating. Just saw the "Poor" rating notice on here from the food inspectors, would not have eaten there if I saw that last night.
author: Levon G.

description: Nice hostess, but I regret ever going there. My lunch order of Katanaya Ramen (miso style) was too salty. I could not finish it because it was salty and not really tasty.  I wish I went next door to the Mexican restaurant or the Thai restaurant.  I just assumed that a Japanese Ramen bar in San Francisco for over 8 years would be serving something better, more satisfying.
author: S. H.

description: This place is on a roller coaster. Another owner change. So-not-worth-it food combined with terrible service.
author: Jake M.

description: Do not go if you want a chance of getting sushi to go in any reasonable amount of time.  I've been sitting here for 30 min and they just keep saying "he's making it now".  I've lost hope.
author: Amie K.

description: Excellent.  The Raman was the shit!  The restaurant was kinda shitty.  Forget the lackluster service and forget the lackluster decor.  Remember that the spicy ramen is awesome and not too spicy.  Went there at 6:15 on a Tuesday.  By 7:30 there were 7 tables in line and probably a 30 min or more wait list.  The house ramen is very good.  Order it thick with extra spice.
author: Gio G.

description: Went with a Groupon and found out they had stopped accepting the coupon.  The waitress could not be understood due to her thick accent and was not very patient or helpful when asked questions about the menu. Ultimately she messed up our order. We should have asked for another server who could be understood. Our bill came and we were surprised about the prices of the (wrong) items served. Chuck it up to a live and learn experience. Not returning to this place.
author: David T.

description: Good ramen at a decent price.  Vegetarian options (including broth).
author: Zachary S.

description:
I can't take credit for this find - I owe it to 7x7's 2010 Big Eat List. All I have to say is NOM NOM NOM NOM NOM. I suppose that's a lot to say but it was good. 
I have had ramen before and I have always enjoyed it, so I was throughly excited to come here and try their Chau-Siu Ramen. They have different kinds of soup base - Miso, and some other stuff I don't remember. Oh! Salt was one of them. I ordered the Chau-Siu, Light, Miso Ramen. It was so good. Just thinking about it is making my mouth salivate. The boy ordered Spicy Tofu Ramen Salt Ramen. He said it was delicious. We also decided to split a Small Sake (Salmon) Donburi, which was also very good. The Sake was super fresh. 

We arrived around 6:30 pm, and only had to wait about 10 minutes, but as we were leaving around 7:30pm, they wait seemed to be long. 

The prices aren't bad either, so if you're looking for something to eat around Union Square and you're not trying to shell out a lot of money, and you're trying to be full, you should stop by.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
The size was big but the waitress only smiled to me when I was ready to pay the check:( Maybe cuz there were too many people....idk 
However
Tastes good and worth the price
i might be back when i visit SF again :)
author: Synthia A.

description: Nothing terrible, but I've had much better ramen elsewhere in town.
author: David S.

description:
a bit of a wait but worth it! the place is small so we waited 20 mins for 2 people. I got the spicy rich miso Katana-ya ramen. I should have just had it like that but I got fancy and got the one with fried chicken and pot stickers. Which were not edible so I just ate the noodles.

I would definitely come back. I would just be more cautious with ordering.
author: Lisa N.

description: Good ramen. Went with the Kantanaya Ramen cause it's the name of the spot. $13 for a pretty hefty portion of ramen. Sushi, the fish was good but the sushi roll itself don't stay together so nahh don't bother. Service was kinda wack. Takes awhile for them to notice you for your order or check or water. Speaking of water, something about this water it tastes good as hell.
author: Daniel D.

description:
This place is not that good, it does not deserve 3 stars or the waiting line.
Come on, SFO have better Sushi bars and Ramen places just a few miles away in Japantown for example.
author: Roberto A.

description:
My regular order is the vegetarian ramen: plenty of vegetables, tofu and long tasty noodles in a HUGE  bowl full of delicious broth. It is definitely enough for two people but I love it so much that I never have a problem finishing it to the last noodle.

Service is good and the order arrives pretty quickly.

Highly recommended.
author: Li L.

description:
Came here as I was craving Ramen and well the closest place I can find decent food is San Francisco.

I had the lunch special of a regular ramen in light miso + kim chi fried rice. My brother ordered the regular ramen in regular miso + grilled salmon rice. The ramen wasn't as good as I had hoped, but I am glad it  is better than Top Ramen. The Kim Chi fried rice was NOT good. Lacked flavor and had a weird after taste as well. The grilled salmon rice was basically what it was. Nothing bad nor anything to rave about. For lunch for 2 cost about $26 after tip.

I guess it's hard to find good ramen when you are from So-cal and you've tasted ramen from Japan
author: Kathy W.

description: Ramen was good! Sushi was ok, have had better. However place didnt seem clean at all.
author: Christian G.

description: Went in during lunch hour Saturday and got seated at the sushi bar. Ordered a spicy miso ramen bowl with salmon, crab and ikura don. The fish was fantastic melt in your mouth and the crab was sweet mixed with the saltiness of the ikura. Great meal and hit the spot before my adventure around town. Would come here again or recommend it to any of my friends visiting the area.
author: Vivian C.

description: Oh. My. God. I love ramen, but this was the best I ever had. I ordered the Miso  Katana-Ya Ramen with a Sapporo Draft. The beer was icy cold, the ramen super hot. The gyoza was a perfect mix of crunchy and chewy. This is my new go-to place for ramen!
author: Rachel Q.

description:
Not bad but not GREAT!

This was one of the main pitstops during our SF day trip for my friends and I.  we came at around 2:30pm and waited for about 15 minutes.  The place is definitely small just like any other ramen places.  It is located right in the heart of san francisco so parking was hard to find.  We squeezed into a table for 3 and all ordered the Katana-ya Ramen.  So far, my winner is orenchi so I was curious to see what this place had in stock in SF.

Pros:
- potstickers
- lots of pork slices
- fried chicken
- corn
- broth options of light or rich

Cons:
- no runny egg

For some reason the Con still wins over the Pros.  For someone that eats alot, this bowl is DEFINITELY worth it.  The broth was pretty good but didn't scream I am craving for more.  

It was pretty good but it didn't completely impress me! I rather go wait in line at Ramen Dojo and Orenchi!
author: Kathy D.

description:
KATANA-YA Mon! This is the best Ramen in town! I just realized that I have been recommending this place to everyone I know and have not wrote a review for this place. Shame on me!
Yes this is the best ramen place in SF!  Full of flavors and tons of ingredients!
I ended up getting the Katana-ya ramen with miso broth.  This comes with a fried chicken in the ramen.  It's the number one ramen on the menu and made the 7x7 list.   Definitely a great dish to have on a cold day or night. 

This is a small restaurant and has very limited seating.  Of course, all the good restaurants has a waitlist.  This place is well worth the wait.  The service is really fast so don't let the line or the packed dinning room full you.  People come in and out of this place fast.  I think the longest I've ever waited to eat here was about 20 minutes.
author: Ying F.

description: Food was really great! The girl who was in charge of the waiting list could have been friendlier but the service inside was good.
author: Juliana S.

description:
This is a tiny restaurant so expect some waiting time for sure, especially during peak hours. But I'll say it's definitely worth the waiting. 

Me and my friend got a table for four so it's quite spacious compared to other small two-people tables. They have really good combo deals where you can order a ramen/udon as an entree and a side dish such as kimchi fried rice or sushi rolls with an average price of $13. We got gyoza as appetizer, which is my all-time favorite. I got the Deep Fried Chicken Ramen with miso sauce and mild level of spiciness. As a Chinese, I'm pretty picky about Asian food. I have to say that this restaurant is pretty authentic. 

Would like to come back and try the sake next time! :)
author: Xiao L.

description:
I checked this place out for lunch and there was actually no wait even though this place is small. I tried their Katana-ya Ramen which has corn, bbq pork, egg, spinach, fried chicken, and fried gyoza in it. I got the miso broth light. You can get light or rich and I chose light. 

The ramen itself was good with the right chewy but firm texture. The broth was good but not quite as flavorful as I am used to. My favorite place for ramen right now is Shoki II in Sacramento. My brother-in-law, who had never had ramen from a restaurant before thought it was good. 

I would say the light versions of their broth still need a little more flavor. I also don't like that they charge you $1.90 to make it spicy. Most places don't charge you to make it regular spicy or hot spicy. 

I plan to return and try their rich Miso broth as well. If I like the rich miso broth better than the light, I will consider bumping this to a 4 star review. I might be a little harsh here but really ramen is all about the broth. This is definitely a good place for lunch or a quick dinner and you get pretty good value for your bowl of ramen.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Ordered delivery now three times.  Delicious, fresh, large portions.  Highly recommend
author: Shannon J.

description: Food is great like always, but if you also rate the customer service as one of your habit. Then I suggest don't go here. Even though the food is good around the busy area of Union Square at San Francisco. The service is just decent. The waiter didn't smile at us and gave our tea 10min-15min later after we order our food. Missed one of our order and the waiter just didn't care.
author: jiopkly Y.

description:
Ramen isn't that great. Noodles aren't the best noodles in town but they give you good portions. Soup was bomb though. Very small unique ramen joint. Needs to improve on a quality of noodles. 

Wait wasn't too bad at 6 pm on a Sunday night!
author: Tony H.

description: Best Ramen in Union Square! Love the combo deals. Tight space inside and usually a line, but worth the wait!
author: Peter K.

description: The ramen here was delicious and the place was nice, cozy, and clean. I was really pleased with everything and will definetly be going back!
author: Camilo N.

description:
Great ramen joints are part of a dying breed of restaurants in San Francisco. Katana-Ya, however, is an exception to that. And comon now, the restaurant is named after a freakin' samurai sword afterall. (+Cool points right there!)

Super Spicy Roll - [http://s3-media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/y6Ap-svp6Hk4rdhoomKXqg/l.jpg]
We ordered this as an appetizer since my girlfriend and I love spicy food and with a name like that, how can you resist? It's like they subliminally target fire-eaters! (and you can't argue since it's only $6.50 either). We got 8 pieces and if you do the math, that's a steal. It was a collabo of salmon, hamachi, and spicy tuna, topped with their homemade spicy sauce. It wasn't dramatically spicy but with the wasabi, it had a nice kick. The chef's didn't skimp on the fish either, which was a major bonus!

Katana-ya Ramen - [http://s3-media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/nZym9koGT0Tbos_IqikkYg/l.jpg]
I ordered this a few months back and I returned for more! The Katana-ya ramen consists of: chashu pork, fried gyoza, fried chicken, half of a boiled egg, and topped with corn (I don't remember the corn being there the first time but whatever, interesting touch). I chose the miso soup base -- but forgot to ask them to make it "rich" for texture which didn't compromise the ramen, at all.  The quality of the ramen is not your cheap 10c instant noodles either, which I get from other ramen spots..

Chashu Pork Ramen - [http://s3-media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Ru0jaLFkBc05z4m5le6n1Q/l.jpg]
This was my girlfriend's dish. She, being the more intellectual individual in all things ramen, ordered her broth, rich (which you can definitely tell the difference here). It also came with 3 big portionate slices of the chashu pork and a few other fix-in's. I can't recall because I was too busy enjoying mine.. 


The only downer is that Katana-ya's a small little hole-in-the-wall so seating will be limited. Luckily, by calling ahead of time and asking if there was any wait, we got to snag two seats at the sushi bar (at around 7:30PM) with no wait. I felt very fortunate because as I was enjoying some delicious ramen, small groups of hungry fanatics were signing the wait-list and pacing back and forth on a nippy San Francisco night.
author: Albert L.

description:
With about 2,100 reviews already in the books (server?), what more could I say about Katana-Ya that hasn't been said before?  I'm pretty sure not much.  But at least now I can be part of the crowd!

Although it may not be the one listed on the 7x7 list, the Katana-Ya ramen is the one I usually get...because it's SO GOOD.  Restaurants, take note - this is how you do it when you brand your name on a dish (a few places I won't name could use the advice).  Loaded with gyoza, chicken karaage, roast pork, egg, corn, and the usual array of green onion/seaweed/bamboo on top of the noodles, it's one hearty ass bowl of ramen.  Despite all of those tasty goodies though, it's just not the same without the spicy broth.  Granted that it wasn't actually all that spicy, but it still provided some delicious flavor.  And besides, who wants to start sweating while you're eating?  Save it for the gym.

The overall menu is fairly extensive, with the different varieties of ramen, sushi and dinner combinations you can get (ramen plus appetizer/small dish, for example).  However, I admit I've never really taken a hard look at everything they have to offer since I mostly stick with the ramen (and usually one variety at that).  It certainly sucks that there's almost always a line due to the limited seating, and that parking in the area can be relatively scarce though.  It's a good thing the delicious food and their late hours help to compensate for those shortcomings.  

While I'm not really sure how Katana-Ya stacks up against the other big ramen joints in the Bay Area (Santa, Santouka, and Ramen Dojo come to mind), it's certainly the best in SF for me.  Then again, that probably doesn't come as a surprise considering the sheer number of reviews and the relatively high praise.  I guess the only real surprising thing about my review is how long it took for me to write it.
author: Mike L.

description:
Note: This review is purely for the Ramen, no other food was tried.

As always, KATANA-YA had a 20 minute wait outside but since this was the first time I was going to eat there, we waited. Too many people had told me that this was their "favorite" Ramen in the city so I just had to... HAD to try it. Since we were waiting, we knew what we wanted and ordered as soon as we were seated. The place is small and packed (no wonder there is a wait list) but the staff were moving quick and they were friendly. Ten minutes later, our giant bowls arrived: my friend ordered the soy-based BBQ PORK RAMEN while I had the miso-based GROUND PORK & RED CHILI RAMEN.

PROS: Spicy, good noodles, huge portion
CONS: Fatty pork, cold tofu cubes, lack of veggies.

The soup was hot but the tofu was cold! This shocked me as I was not expecting cold tofu. While the broth was a great color and flavor, the pork was fatty, the tofu was cold and there was a distinct lack of veggies in the bowl other than a few green onions on top. Overall, I enjoyed it but it definitely wasn't "the best Ramen in the city". I will go back to try other ramens, depending on how long the line is ofcourse.
author: G C.

description: Try to eat here, was told to sit at the very small table at the door, I wanna sit somewhere else other than the small table at the door which the cold wind keeps blowing in. I was told to wait rather than being seated at those empty tables. Totally disappointed b4 I tried anything. Screw u and I will never come back!!!
author: Mike Z.

description:
I would have given Katana-Ya five stars but I still have to try the famous Ramen Dojo so for now Katana-Ya receives four stars. Ordered one Regular Rich Salt Ramen and two Katanaya Miso Rich Ramen for our party of three. Also added the Katsu Don for an extra $4 charge. 

Katsu Don was a mistake - dry chicken that was not even crispy. This made me worry about the ramen quality. Crisis averted. The broth was so rich and fatty and the ramen were cooked perfectly. The extra additions were not necessary but were nice to have. Biggest plus was that the wait was under 15 minutes. 

What I recommend:
-- Katanaya Ramen with rich broth
author: Andrew W.

description:
I dont understand what's the hype about
On my first visit I did truly enjoyed my beef ramen soup, Whilst getting our bill, our waiter never mentioned there was a gratuity for parties of 5+, even though we were not sitting at the bar?? Also two of us paid together, and the entire gratuity was added to our bill. this is not including the tip! Clearly our server could not care less but to make more than his tip share. First off, how can you charge gratuity when we are not sitting together, and how come you get to decide which card gratuity gets charged without asking the customer.
A month later, I decided I would give this place another shot. This time not only your service fell short again by your waitress being to busy to check on us the entire time, but you were out of stuff, so I was stuck with a very bland salty soup. Is there even a manager in this restaurant?
author: Ale B.

description:
Cute little place, however service was terrible-and this is coming from someone who works in the restaurant buisness, not a high-end-feed-me-grapes-from-the-vine-kind-of-girl. So i do inderstand the stress and bs you get as a waitress. However i have never been treated so unkindly as a customer. 

Come for the food, but if you want ambiance with decent service... keep on moving.
author: C N.

description:
Went there on a recent visit to SF (January 2016) and man has this place taken a nose dive. Bland broth. A hard boiled egg (oh come on) and what tasted like canned corn. There are way better ramen places to go to in SF. 
---------------------
I love this place. I love ramen.  I'll let you read the other reviews for the ranting and raving about the amazing bowls of ramen you can have here. 

But here's my special tip - they have ramen noodle soups that are non pork based.  Perfect.  Just perfect.
author: Kamael S.

description: Ordered the ramen for delivery- delivery was fast but food quality was pretty poor. Broth locked flavor- very little pork, greasy gyoza... Would not recommend unfortunately.
author: Veronique O.

description:
The ramen is delicious here. But I got the tempura udon noodles and they charged me 19.95  for me, I think that's quite ridiculous for something way simpler than ramen. 

The tuna poki was delicious though. The place is kind of small too and usually there is a wait so be prepared for that. 

If I were to come back to San Fran, I would def come back here for some ramen and tuna poki. It was really fresh!
author: Joanie T.

description:
One of my friends from Walnut Creek left me the choice of finding a place to eat. I mentioned this to my good friend. Going over my limit of how much I could spend and what kind of food I might want to eat, he suggested this place. Funny thing, my Walnut Creek friend asked me if this place was okay, without me telling her about this place! (Great minds think alike, no?)

Tucked away in-between hotels and shops on Geary, Katana-Ya is a true hole-in-the-wall, in comparison to Daikokuya, like 3/4 of the size of the Little Tokyo branch, or maybe the same size as the Monterey Park branch. Getting seated by a cute waiter, I already knew that I wanted to try out the ramen, being the Japanese foodie fanatic I am.

Not really knowing what ramen to get (and not reading any reviews of the place, but noticing the LARGE amount of reviews), the regular ramen in miso called for me.

Not mind-blowing, like Daikokuya or Orochan, but not cheaply made like Ajisan, Katana-Ya wasn't bad. The broth and toppings were just your typical ramen toppings, but the ramen itself, I have to say, it's does hold a candle to other places. Not broth-soaking, not broth-repelling, but just enough porous surface to soak up SOME of the flavoring but not enough to lose its texture/elasticity, if that makes any sense.
author: Tom T.

description:
This 3-star review is for the Katana-Ya. Not the place, but the ramen which is named Katana-Ya...

I decided to shell out that extra $4 for the Katana-Ya since it looked really good last time. It arrived in the same size bowl as the other ramens and with the same amount of noodles. It had all the ingredients a regular ramen had (pork, bamboo shoots, wakame) plus 2 gyozas, 2 pieces of chicken karage, and half of a marinated boiled egg. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=W43bD1MW6T4sHq6P0iXjhg)

Verdict: Save your $4! The gyoza was less than spectacular. The chicken karage was only good when it was first brought out. Both became soggy and unappealing. The best was the egg. Stick with the regular ramen!

THEN in looking back at my previous review, I saw that my friend's Katana-Ya also had corn! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=uFuwaLTVmDGmmz_Du6-o4w) They jipped me of corn!!!! What da freakaleek man? (o_O)
author: Marti L.

description: There are a lot of hater critics here. This is likely in contrast to a place with better ambience and a full bar. This is a hole in the wall place so if that is not your speed, you really shouldn't come.  First, and equally important as the food- great service. They did well for service.  That said, I thought the ramen was totally on point. It was perfect in broth, consistency and altogether very good. This is NOT somewhere to take a date or have a romantic night. Jump in for a quick ramen fix and it's all good.
author: Donna D.

description:
I'm not sure if it's the fact that I've ventured out since declaring eternal love for Katana-Ya (I'm flaky, whatever) and have discovered far superior places (namely in the South Bay) or if it's because it's been years since my last bowl of perfection at Ippudo in Manhattan and I've since then glorified it to the absolute point of no return . . . but Katana-Ya, on my last few visits, has been subpar, at best. The hardboiled egg is cold, the yolk is grey and crumbles into dust in your mouth. The noodles are just . . . there. The pork is neither fatty nor deliciously porky (just kind of lean and flavorless), and to make matters worse, the broth (I usually get miso or salt) is waaaay too salty and one-note.

On the other hand, it's by no means inedible. And totally hits the spot after bar/club hopping nearby (they're open fairly late - 1:30 am I believe). But if sloppily downing a bowl while inebriated is the only way I prefer to consume something, then that's telling.

Meh.
author: Betty W.

description: Got a Togo spicy miso katana-ya and it was really good. The perfect amount of spice, I was treated very well and I'll definitely go there again.
author: Aaron M.

description: Ramen OK but not particularly good. Terrible karaage chicken fried in stale oil, and come with salad ranch? Weird combination. Location is a plus, and opens late. But there are other places to eat late at night too. Good part is that we did not need to wait.
author: liang w.

description: Good size ramen, noodles were a little too soft... The specialty i feel is the fried chicken ramen... The chicken was decent.  I've had better so for me this is 3* - I'd probably try a diff place in the area for ramen next time.
author: Kay C.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here after a wonderful night of drinking & dancing. Ramen is always my first choice of food after I drink.

We came in right when they opened so we got seated right away. Vincent's obsessed with fried chicken so we ordered the Karaage Chicken. We both really liked it. It's comparable to Orenchi's Karaage Chicken in Sunnyvale.

For our main entree, we both ordered the Katana Ramen. I asked to make mine spicy though. They offer two levels: medium or extra spicy. I stuck with medium since my stomach was already suffering from all the Hennessey I had the night before. The Katana Ramen came with corn, sliced pork, fried chicken, pot stickers, and bamboo shoots.

Vincent didn't really enjoy his broth much. We noticed on the menu that they offered a "rich" and "light" version of the broth. The server didn't ask us which we wanted, but he felt as though his was a bit bland. 

We both agreed that my broth was tasty. It wasn't too spicy by any means. I would definitely upgrade to the next level of spicy next time. Sadly, I didn't really enjoy my ramen as much as I thought I would. 

First, my egg was hard boiled instead of soft boiled! Second, if chicken is fried, I feel like it should be eaten dry. My fried chicken became soft chicken while it was in my broth. The potstickers were quite mushy. It still tasted good, but I would rather have those two things crunchy. I definitely didn't consider any of this when I ordered it. I just thought, "Whoa potstickers and fried chicken and ramen all in one? Down!" I'm definitely willing to go back and try other choices in the future.  

I do appreciate the fact that the Katana Ramen offered a lot of variety in one bowl. Every spoonful had a different ingredient in it so I kept coming back to it. I enjoyed myself here, but it's not my favorite.
author: Enza P.

description: I came back here again and ordered pork choshu miso based soup. Oh! It's so good. I just added one star for it.
author: Ann K.

description: After going to Japan and having the ramen there, I'm admittedly a bit of a Ramen snob. However, the ramen here was not even as good as the Ramen in Toronto. I got the Katana-ya ramen which had very soggy noodles and soggy gyoza and chicken. It was also significantly over-priced for ramen. If I had to do it again, I would skip this restaurant in favour of another place.
author: Serena L.

description:
This place is truly overhyped. Came on a Monday night and this place was packed. I quickly realized we had to put our names down ourselves, so I went and reached for the clipboard and one of the servers came out the door, pretty much pushing me aside and grabbed it. No "sorry"? Fine. We waited, and after about 10 min, I asked the same rude server/hostess for an estimate wait time. Ignored. Three times, with increasing loudness. No response. Fine.
Another server came out and started calling off names. I'm literally standing 2 feet away and I couldn't hear her because of how softly she spoke, 2 groups missed their calling and they had an argument, further extending our wait. 20 min, and they finally had a table ready for us. She walked us in, no sorts of welcoming gesture or Hello or welcome and pointed to our tables, and walked away. 
She came back, less than 30 seconds later asking if we're ready to order. 30 seconds, without a menu? This isn't a McDonald's. I'm beyond frustrated at this point, but I bear with it because of how great everyone says about this place. 
Server came back, I asked her (and this is legitimately my one and only question), what's in the "Super spicy Don"? Her answer? "Uhhhhh.....(silent) just...you know..stuff." what?! "Yeah, like spicy stuff!" We wanted to know what kinda fish was in there. "Basic stuff. Like....scallop...tuna..You know" Yeah, whatever. 
We ordered it, and at first glance, I noticed 3 things (salmon, Tuna, yellow tail). How hard is that?

I give this place one star, simply because their service matches the quality of their food. Seems like all the hype and attention they are getting makes them believe their food is genuinely delicious. It's not. 
By the way, I'll make a quick rundown of the foods I was able to try. 

Katana-ya ramen: Pasty, bland broth. Noodles were beyond firm. It was really the basic ramen, they just add fried chicken and gyoza. 

Una Don: Eel over rice. Rice was good. Eel was way overcooked, and there was no eel sauce to accompany it. 

Plain udon: PLAIN. Broth literally tastes like water. The only flavor came from the veggies they put in it. 

Super spicy Don: probably the most decent thing on here. They gave a fair warning, though. It really is super spicy. 

Never would recommend this place. Overpriced ramen, with a ridiculously set of waitresses with little common sense and no common courtesy. Sorry. Not Sorry.
author: Rendy G.

description: Management is terrible. The ramen isn't that good actually. Go yelp ramen, there are many more choices.. trust me. I've lived in the city for years, this restaurant was good back then, and now, no..
author: Stefan L.

description: Amazing! Had the Katana special Ramen, it is a Delicious experience, satisfying and definitely coming back!!
author: Hiram M.

description: This is a great treasure find for me and my husband. The ramen is so tasty and rich and the sushi rolls are super good. We enjoyed every bite of our meal, it was not that bad of a wait either, The place is small and a little too cramped but we will still come back.
author: Liliana P.

description: We've been here during the daytime and the service was ok! They have sushi, rolls and etc. The prices are not so expensive, mostly average like in other Chinese restaurants :) So if you want to try, do it, but be careful at the evening, this place is overcrowded! There are not enough place for people and the line for entrance is pretty big!
author: Ilia S.

description:
Ate a super early dinner and then couldn't sleep around 11 because I was starving!

Ordered ramen and sushi from Postmates, a awesome delivery service (thanks Demarco!)

Ramen was great but have def had better. Sushi was delish (I'm from Seattle where the sushi is amazing so that's a
Saying a lot)

Would def return.
author: Stephanie R.

description: We were unhappy with what we are eating right now. The tempura don is very disappointing. They served us a lot of rice and only 1 pc tempura for the donburi. The crew was claiming that's why its price is reduced. The spicy tuna rolls were not fresh. Felt like it was left out in the freezer for a long time. Haven't tried the ramens, but I think they are better than these.
author: Von J.

description:
The first place I decided to try ramen was here. 

My friends and I came here randomly on a Saturday evening. There was a bit of a wait for a table of four. The place is very small, they only have about 8 tables and a bar area. 

We all ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen, which had a bit of everything in it (fried chicken, potstickers, corn, seaweed, pork and a few other things).

The broth was very tasty, I didn't drink all of it since it was a bit salty. The price is pretty decent too and the staff is very friendly. I wouldn't mind coming back here for ramen if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Kim L.

description: Great ramen. Loved the katana ya ramen. Everything and the kitchen sink thrown in there. Great after drinking food spot. Spicy ramen is so good after a long pub night. Highly recommend whether it's late night or lunch time, these guys serve up a tasty bowl of ramen.
author: David T.

description:
Foraging for food late one night in SF and found Katana-Ya. It was 'bout midnight on a Saturday night and the area around Union Square was hopping - parking was a b*tch. Takana-Ya is so small that we drove by twice and did not see it. We finally called and the person on the phone said it was next to the sandwich place - yeah, yeah I see it now. We walked in and this place was chill, unlike the craziness that was all around us on the outside. This place reminded me of a chill version of Hakata Ramen Shinsengumi in L.A. It was just as hip - though the ramen cooks at Hakata Ramen Shinsengumi was a bit more gangsta cool. Hip hop and R&B play through the sound system, topping off the chic ambiance. 

The ramen menu was a simple one but I suspect you could custom order your ramen and the server would take it in stride. I had their cilantro ramen extra spicy. I like my ramen like my spaghetti - al dente, and that is exactly what I got. The ramen was cooked just right and in a flavorful soup bursting with cilantro and spiciness. Woe Mama, it had a kick!   I loved their ramen. They also had a sushi bar. We though a couple pieces of mirugai would hit the spot, however they were out so we settled for Octopus instead. 
This place rates right up there at the top of my list of ramen places. The ramen was tight, the atmosphere was chill, they have a sushi bar, and they are open late night! Just stock up on some mirugai and that's it.

Next time? Mirugai sushi and onion ramen.
author: Eddie C.

description: There wasn't a long wait time to get in. I had the sushi which was just average but good for the price they charge. The service was terrible. They didn't refill the water cups, we always had to ask. Some of our sushi came late and we thought they forgot about it.
author: Marian P.

description:
Choose your own Ramen Adventure.

Seriously, I'm not joking. Choose your  base: Miso or Soy (Salt).  Then choose your thickness: rich, regular, or light.  Then, choose your noodle: Udon, Ramen, or Wheat.  Wait, I'm not done yet, there are more decisions that need to be made!  

Then, you can choose a variety of sides to go with your Ramen - sushi, fried rice, salad, gyoza, and more.  I recommend the Kimchee Fried Rice. And another option, you can choose from a selection of ramen's on the menu as well. Like I said, the choices are endless and you can't go wrong.  

One bit of advice: There might be a wait since there is limited seating. But, the turnover is pretty quick....
author: Shaman D.

description: The food was good but I wouldn't go back because of the service and atmosphere. It's cramped and not very clean. The waitress took forever to take our order or even bring a glass of water. She was rude and got frustrated because we couldn't hear her very well. Then she brought the wrong food and acted like it was our fault. I wish we had gone to the Thai place next door instead.
author: Darcie S.

description:
Katana-Ya is always a solid choice for me. The only dissuading factor is that there is usually a wait, but in my experience it's never been too terrible. 

This place appeals to my constant internal conflict at Japanese restaurants of wanting to get a little bit of everything. Their ramen combo lets you choose a slightly smaller (but still filling!) standard ramen with different side meals (mini sake-don! poke tuna over rice! etc.). It's a little bit more than I would pay for just a straight forward meal (my shoyu ramen with a sake-don - that included 4 slices of salmon sashimi - was $14), but I'm willing to occasionally splurge for the variety.
author: Karen W.

description:
This was one of the few places that i actually enjoyed in San Francisco. The Ramen noddle was delicious, but i got carried off and ordered the one that had everything in it, and that was kinda oily. Other than that the Fatty Tuna was DELICIOUS!!! and UNI couldn't be any fresher than getting it out from the sea!!!

The staff was amazing and friendly!!! definitely coming back and recommending!!!
author: Hiep N.

description:
One of the best ramen in San Francisco. I tried the Katanaya ramen and BBQ Ramen. 

BBQ ramen - Just an ordinary Ramen Ramen. I give it a 7/10

Katanaya Ramen - One of the best Ramen on the menu. Its a must have, if you are thinking about getting ramen. I give it a 9/10. Dont believe? Try it for yourself. 

The one thing i didnt like is the parking. If you are planning to eat here, good luck finding a parking spot.
author: Joseph B.

description: I've been hearing sushi is SF is a big deal and very good so I went on a hunt to try it. I found this place on yelp it was a block from my hotel. I wanted to sit in but the wait seemed a bit long; and it was a tas bit confusing because the establishment is in two buildings next door to each other. I ordered the katanya roll which was pretty good. Most people seemed to go their for the Ramen bowls, I definitely plan to go back and try it because it smelled so good. I also discovered that SF Wasabi  is a lot stronger than east coast Wasabi.
author: Melissa H.

description: This is a pretty small place, but it has really good food. Ordered the Katana-ya ramen with Miso. It has pork, fried dumpling, and chicken and it wasn't too pricey. There is always a line outside so make sure you're willing to wait at least 20 minutes.
author: Richie C.

description: This place is the bomb. Love the ramen here and other Japanese stuff we ordered. Akira is the best. He was very helpful and recommended a lot of good stuff for us to try. I'm looking forward to trying their food again.
author: Claudine V.

description:
Katana-Ya is very lovely hole in the wall type of restaurant. It's a small place, but its usually always busy and lots of people waiting in line, and that's for a good reason: the food here is delicious!

The portions are very generous, and the ramen and broth are great. The portions are so big, you may have trouble finishing it. On top of that, service is great too.
author: Al S.

description:
Hailed as the "best ramen in the city", I ran over to this place when I had the chance. The lines can be eternal so expect to wait.

I'm pretty lucky with lines and parking so I drove by the place, saw that there was a long line and breathed a defeated sigh and even had to park near the Moscone Center and walk over here. When I got there, there was no line (yay!) and I was seated right away. We tried the Katanaya Ramen which was extremely filling and as has been mentioned before, the portions are rather large and filling. We also tried a tofu rice dish (forget the name) which was tasty.

The best time to go here would be off hours on a cold San Francisco day where it's warm and cozy inside.
author: Julia P.

description:
Had to try this place since it was so highly reviewed on yelp. I went the night before but the place closed on me!  I want to give it 3.5 stars but i rounded down instead since I ended up dying from the MSG in the soup.

No worries the menu does warn you that they put MSG in their soup, which made it so salty good.  We got there on Sunday 1pm and was lucky enough to find a seat by the door.  No wait! Woohoo!

The noodles were not soft but firm just the way i like it.  I got the Katana-ya Ramen which is a mix of corn, dumplings, cha-shu, etc... We also got a side of the spicy yellowtail roll!  Amazing!  They put a little bit of rice and big pieces of yellowtail.  yum!

The service was good unlike what other yelpers said, but the seats are very close together. I couldn't help but overhear the next table's conversation.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
i get this delivered, and it may be thanks to the delivery man (thank you postmates), but the ramen is always piping hot. As a vegetarian, this veggie-miso ramen is so spicy and flavorful; i highly recommend it. 

HOWEVER i have not been to the establishment.
author: Julia Z.

description: Terrible service. Terrible at taking orders. And dangerous crowds outside. Avoid at all costs!!!
author: Lindsay P.

description: Really not good did not enjoy the miso broth whatsoever and the veggies and meat we're not enjoyable either.  Definitely try a different ramen place.
author: Josh B.

description: Waited 20 minutes outside and another 20 minutes sitting down for them to say they ran out of vegetables????????? WHAT. Pretty disappointed with how that could've even happened at 12 in the afternoon.
author: JaclynElizabeth A.

description:
Katana-Ya is pretty much a hole in the wall restaurant a short distance away from Union Square. The ramen is pretty legit here and they have won awards and other recognition in San Francisco for their food.  I've been to Katana-Ya a handful of times and have always experienced a wait. It is not the best place for groups larger than 5 since most tables are set for 2 or 4. Luckily the wait is not as bad as Orenchi in Santa Clara.

The ramen is pretty good here. The broth is what makes good ramen And the miso broth was great... Be forewarned that the menu does say that MSG was added so maybe that's why it tastes so good? You can substitute ramen for udon and soba for a small price. They also managed to squeeze in a small sushi bar inside this tiny space!

The noodles are decent but not Orenchi good. Definitely a go to place when I'm in San Francisco. It's always ramen weather there!
author: Steph F.

description:
Katana-Ya is definitely the hot spot for ramen, not so much on the sushi.  It makes me feel like i'm Naruto because he's always eating ramen.

So on the menu I usually get the butter corn with fried chicken ramen.  Totally hits the spot every time. Fatty, buttery and yummy the downer is when I wake up the next morning, I'm super bloated from all the salt hahahah.  But it's totally worth it.
author: Edrian D.

description:
I used to like Katana-ya and would tell all my friends to try it so I'm sorely disappointed by my ramen today. 

I went during the lunch rush on a Saturday. Surprisingly we didn't have to wait at all. I ordered the shio bbq pork ramen (rich) for $11. It came out in a large and wide bowl with the usual toppings of green onion, bamboo shoots, seaweed, and pork. The bbq pork ramen is pretty much their classic ramen with extra pork. It. was. terrible. The pork was tough and lean (it was dying for some fat), the broth was dilute and NOT rich like I asked for--it's an option on their menu--and the noodles were unmemorable and perhaps a tad overcooked. Did I mention the broth was lukewarm to warm when it came out?! Pet peeve, check. 

If you want soup you can certainly go here since you'll get at the very least..soup.  It's good for a late bite after drinking. But if you're venturing for some decent ramen and you have taste buds for ramen--stay away. I am sooo disappointed with Katana-ya. I'll have to consider this an off day for them since the last time I went was so amazing!

Note: do not get their special katana-ya bowl with chicken karaage. It's fried chicken in ramen broth, put two and two together. It's not worth the extra $4.
author: Sarah W.

description:
What can I say, I'm a sucker for mom and pop joints that make you feel at home and the last few times I've been to Katana-ya, I was greeted by a friendly hostess who politely apologized for the wait despite appearing fairly busy.

I love to stop by on chilly nights where they crack the door open to keep the chefs and waitstaff cool. Something so wonderful about having a hot bowl of ramen and feeling short wafts of cold air rush by.

My typical order is the shoyu ramen and a hamachi kama. The broth is very flavorful but not overly salty and the thin sliced pork is always tender and savory. I always wish I could have an extra slice. The noodles are always slighty chooy and never overcooked. Part of the reason why I regular this place is because the noodles are so consistent.

The hamachi kama is deep fried instead of grilled like most other japanese restaurants prepare, but I have to say, the frying keeps the kama extra moist and as an added bonus it doesn't take nearly as long to prepare. It comes with a side of ponzu-like sauce and makes for an excellent appetizer.

They also serve ramen with otger combinations of small donburis so you can try a bit of everything if you go in small groups. I wouldnt tecommend parties larger than 4 or you might be in for a long wait. If you are in the mood for some solid ramen without drying out your wallet, Katana-ya is a great place to stop by.
author: Jasper S.

description:
I just found out about this place today, and I ate dinner here with my roommates. While looking through Yelp reviews to figure out what to order, I kept reading that this place is way too hyped up... and I agree.

My roommates and I waited 20 minutes to get seated in this super small restaurant. The waiter gave us a menu to look at while we were outside waiting. Once we got seated, a waitress quickly came over to take our order O_O. She probably assumed that we made our decision outside, but I was still surprised by how fast she came over. I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen, which the waitress recommended. Our orders came out pretty fast, and I went for my first bite... and I was soooooooo disappointed. Wow. I could make better ramen at home. Although it was filling, it didn't have much flavor, and it just wasn't that delicious so I was forcing myself to finish...
author: Annie S.

description:
My wife and I both had their combo meal, which is around ~$15 each. You get a ramen bowl and another small don (I chose unagi don). Not a bad price. Their ramen is better than all the ramen places I tried in South Bay.

The service is however a bit disappointing. My wife couldn't finish her meal so we asked for a to-go container, but we had to ask 5 times to get it. For the check I only had to ask once, and they were so eager to collect my signed credit card copy even when it is not signed yet. I would have given it 5-star if their service and space are better.
author: Albert C.

description:
Have to say, the ramen was so so. Had the bbq pork in soy broth. It was fine. Noodles were cooked perfectly, but really the overall flavor was lack luster. 

Will be looking for another place to get ramen.
author: Keri V.

description:
I have been coming to this establishment for over 5 years and have NEVER experienced such awful guest service as I did from a "waitress" Chizu today. Here is the breakdown of the timing of today's work lunch order. 
11:20am: called to make sure that they were open and they confirmed they were. 
11:29-11:35 called 3 times to place an order and no answer. The phone just kept ringing.
11:45 walked in to place an order. There was 3 tables, so it wasn't busy at all. I had placed the order for 5 soups and she said it would be a half hour. I stated that out office was trying to call and place the order and no answer. As she walked away, I told her I would be right back as I needed to pick up another persons lunch. I came back 15 minutes later to find out that  Chizu didn't even ring in the order yet! She wouldn't ring it in until I paid? Oh really, then why didn't you present me with a check before YOU walked away?!!! She then raised her voice and started screaming things at me in a foreign language. "Do you still want the order?" she asked. I'm digging standing right here aren't I? Place the order, it's not for me... It's for the doctors and staff. If it was for me, I would have hightailed outta here. Your soup isn't worth for me to deal with this Bullcrap. 
My suggestion, if Chizu is working that day, STAY CLEAR. Worst. Service. Ever.
author: t f.

description:
My friend suggested this place so I gave this place a try.  He totally didn't hyped it up.  The ramen here was yummy!  I got the Katana-Ya Ramen which comes with pork, gyoza, fried chicken, bamboo, seaweed and corn in a miso soup base.  I especially love the fried chicken.  So moist and tender.  The soup was flavorful!  The gyoza was good.  The only thing I didn't really like is the noodle.  It's on a little harder side.  If its a little softer, the whole bowl of ramen will be perfect.  

We came here on a Saturday night so of course there was a wait.  We waited around 15mins so wasn't too bad.  When you looked inside the restaurant, you can see that it's quite small and congested.  Luckily, my friends and I got a table downstairs.  More roomier and cozy.  Next time when I'm in the city again, I will definitely come back!
author: Susan B.

description:
I've heard this is the best ramen spot ever. Ehhh, it was alright. It didn't really live up to the hype. 

As soon as my boyfriend and I saw that they had Kimchee Ramen, we both immediately knew that's what we wanted. He got his with Miso flavored broth while I had mine with the Shoyu broth. I tried a bit of his broth and it was super salty for some reason, but luckily, my Shoyu broth was on point! They don't skimp you on the ingredients that come with the ramen either. I loved all of it. However, I didn't enjoy the ramen noodles itself. It didn't taste very homemade or fresh. Shoki Ramen House in Sacramento definitely has way better ramen noodles than Katana-Ya. After a few bites of their ramen noodles, I just drank the broth and ate the ingredients that came along with it. I regret not asking to substitute the ramen noodles for some udon noodles instead. 

Their ramen is a bit on the pricey side, but I guess it's a decent price for what you get since the bowls are pretty big and full of ingredients!
author: Erica C.

description:
Katana-Ya serves a good bowl of ramen. And by good, I mean large, steamy bowls of delicious broth with your choice of base (miso, salt or soy sauce), thick noodles, and heaps of toppings. Their signature bowl, the Katana-Ya ramen is generously topped with corn, fried chicken, fried potstickers, seaweed, green onions, chasu and a hard-boiled egg. The more popular Chasu Ramen has four thick slices of bbq pork that is packed with incredible flavor, you feel yourself slowing down just a little to savor it. 

As far as the broth goes, I daresay I've had better. It's good, but it seemed to lack that strong flavor profile that I've tasted in other ramen places. 

The service is fast and friendly. The staff is always all-smiles and attentive when they take your order. Thankfully, the ramen wars have died down, so coming here for lunch on a weekday is easy breezy. No lines and a ready table for three. Like.

While it's not the best ramen place in town, Katana-Ya satisfies last minute ramen cravings in a pinch. 

3.5 stars
author: Racquel N.

description:
Spicy ramen is very good here. Its not the best ever but it is very good. Service is kind. The ambiance is nothing special but its not a dump either. 

I love coming for their lunch specials of ramen and a side dish.
author: Kristan B.

description:
OK, when I wrote this review I must have been a ramen newb. I went by what everyone said and at that time, there weren't a lot of  "Ramen-ya" in San Francisco. Since then, I have been to countless ramen joints and have even ventured into making my own and have come to understand the affinity that many have for that bowl of soup.  

I have been to Katana-Ya several times after writing this review as well so I think it's a good time to write an update.

The thing that wowed me at the time was the chasu but it was elevated by a false assumption. I thought the pork was simply boiled with the broth and somehow miraculously retained a lot of the flavor. In my experience, boiling meat is for the purpose of adding flavor to the broth and the meat doesn't really keep any of its own flavor. Well, I've experimented with making my own chasu and it turns out that it is marinated in soy sauce, mirin and sake and either roasted or slow cooked for a long time before slicing and topping it on the ramen. This was ignorance on my part when I raved about it in my original review. 

I don't mean to take anything away from Katana-Ya but there are apparently a lot more factors in what goes into a bowl of ramen than I had originally understood myself. 

It's all about the holy trinity:  the broth, the noodles and the toppings. Of course the broth is really where it's mostly at.

So as for their broth, their shoyu (soy sauce based) broth is good, but not great. I've honestly had much better broth in the places south of San Francisco (Ramen Dojo, Himawari to name a few). I've tried the shio (salt based) and it too was good but not great. I have yet to try the miso broth but I have tried the Katana-Ya ramen which was a butter-corn ramen with all the fixings. It has kara-age (fried chicken) AND chasu. It's a pretty hefty bowl of soup too. 

All in all, what really makes their ramen stand out is the chasu IMO and for that alone, everyone should check this place out. But with the proliferation of new ramen places in the Bay Area, Katana-Ya just doesn't hold a candle to the rest of the competition located south of the city (which people will take a pilgrimage to if they absolutely had to have a superior bowl of ramen) but is still one of the better joints in San Francisco and should be worthy of high praise based on their portions and yummy toppings.

Half a star gets deducted.

4.1 stars
author: Angelo B.

description: Tiny, tiny place. Always get seated almost on top of next tables. Good sashimi and very decent ramen. The sashimi here good.  I must say that the salmon was the best of all choices. The ramen was quite good, but a bit too salty. Portions are nice and the locations very convinient. Not impressed but will continue to come back.
author: John S.

description:
Food is good-it will definitely fill you up.  

If you ask me if I consider this ramen, probably no-having said that taste is adequate.

I have been here a few times in the past but I received the worst service today.... The server was just grumpy ( everyone has one of those days but still.... ) 

I do not think I'll come back here again....
author: Aki M.

description:
This place was a little underwhelming. For me, ramen is about broth, noodles, and pork belly. The broth was salty but not flavorful, the ramen was too chewy, and my two slices of pork belly were lean and small.

I expected more from you, SF. But I guess that's what happens when you go to the place closest to your hotel and there's no wait time
author: David H.

description:
This is my favorite Ramen place in San Francisco.  Sure, you might have to wait an hour in the freezing cold at 1:00AM in the morning after a night of debauchery in the city. Sure, there might be crackheads yelling at you or begging you for money while you worry about contracting some unknown disease from being in the vicinity of the Tenderloin territory.  But after you sit down, order your ramen, & take a bite/sip of the deliciousness, it would all have been worth it.

I've had the Katana-Ya ramen as well as the fried chicken ramen and they are both absolutely delicious. You can tell them how rich you want your broth (aka, how much fat you want in it, but they refer to this as "density") or what type of broth you want (miso, soy sauce), as well as the type of noodles you want (regular ramen, soba, udon).  So you have the freedom to customize your bowl of ramen.

The bowls are ginormous. I always share & make the other person eat most of it. And of course, MSG is added. They blatantly advertise this fact.

There are a few things that suck about this place: the excruciatingly long wait, especially if you have more than 2 people in your party, their reluctance to let you split the bill & the non-existent customer service. But what can you expect from an Asian establishment?

Happy eating!
author: Grace C.

description: When did Katana Ya become Thai-Na Ya? Really rude service and food was barely eatble. Please avoid this at all cost.
author: Jie J.

description:
This place would have earned that extra star from me if we didn't have to wait a lifetime to get in. My group of 5 waited for at least an hour for a table. To be fair, an inconsiderate customer was busy sipping on her green tea even though the queue outside was pretty long. 

On the positive side, the ramen is one of the best I've had. IMHO it's better than Underground Ramen. I had the salt soup ramen with fried rice combo and they were absolutely worth the wait. The ramen portion was pretty big but I wouldn't complain. Noodle texture was just nice and the soup was hot and flavorful. 

I could come here every week :)
author: Jason T.

description:
I was on my way to Katana-Ya because I was experiencing my third ramen craving in a week. I keep thinking that they'll go away but this place is hypnotic. So I was walking and talking on the phone and telling my friend in LA how I'm on my way to get me some delicious ramen. She was like, "You're going alone?" I was like, "Girrrrrrrl! I'm hungry! Ain't nobody got time to wait for a date!" 

It's THE BEST! No wait, because it's just me, so I just walk right up to the bar and immediately order my ramen. It's funny because I think the dude next to me totally had the same idea. And he was just slurping away like nobody's business. So...I slurped too. And I enjoyed every minute. 

After reading Summit's review for this place, I can't stop calling it Katana-Hell Ya! This place gets in your blood. I typically order the Katana-Ya ramen with the boiled egg, seaweed, pork, fried chicken, and wontons. I also order it medium spicy with miso broth. Uh oh. Here comes the craving again! I did however order it extra spicy and that was a little much. Not that it was too spicy, I just wasn't able to taste the miso flavor anymore because it was masked by the pure red sauce. So I suggest medium spicy. I also suggest ordering a cold dish like sashimi so that you can wait like 5 minutes and calm your hunger down while you wait for the broth to cool off (or else you will burn your tongue due to sheer impatience...true story.) 

AND, it's open late! So while everyone, was contemplating what to eat at 1am after a wonderful night of drinking...the usual 'pizza' came up. Come on...that's so cliche! Why don't we all get ramen??? YES! Game changer! I managed to round the crew up to Katana-Ya, and sneak in a seat right before closing. AWESOME! And as usual, it was delicious.
author: Leena B.

description:
This is the first time I've been back here since they moved underground. Was surprised to be initially directed downstairs to their new location.

But this review is about how they have gone down the drain for both service and food. The food and ramen here was not that good to begin with, but this was opened late when I needed an after midnight meal. My visit this time saw a sparsely filled KatanaYa that is usually full or had a lot of customers in past visits. This was not a good sign and the staff looks completely different, indicating new management. The new staff prove to be both poor, unattentive and most of all rude -- they looked out of place at a Japanese ramen place and looked like folks who should be working at a bar as bouncers.

On this visit, I ordered a cold tofu ($3.95) and a 49er roll ($12.95). The server brought the roll without a sauce dish for the soy sauce and wasabi. I had to flag the server twice before he finally brought a sauce dish that was actually a tea cup plate, not the traditional sauce dish. This indicated the place was no longer authentic with such poor attention to details.

The server was completely unattentive and lazy, spending time idling away while not paying attention to the tables. I had to call him several times to refill my water, he would for example refill water at the table next to me but completely forgot to check on my table.

The worst part was when the bill came. I was charged $10.95 for the cold tofu that was $3.95 according to the menu. I started to suspect if the new restaurant management was trying to pull some type of "bait-and-switch" on me. I told the server to bring the menu so that I can check the price of the cold tofu. Knowing that I am about to call their bluff, the server went to speak with his manager, a fierce looking man who looked more like a bouncer than a ramen place manager. I pointed out to him that the menu price stated that the cold tofu was $3.95, not the $10.95 written on the bill. I told him to please not charge me the wrong price. At this point, he became severely rude, telling me that "he is the manager", that he will fix this, and that he doesnt need me to "give him an attitude". Excuse me, but it is you who is giving me an attitude! Instead of apologizing for his mistake and his server's terrible service, he accused me of giving him an attitude when all I did was to point out the wrong price! Ridiculous!

At this point, I told him that he should be apologizing for both the attempt to charge me the wrong price, and the very poor and inattentive service I received. I told him that KatanaYa has now gone down the hill since moving to the new spot and with the new management. At this point, the inattentive and lackadaisical server started becoming rude and attempted to threaten me. I told them this lousy service is why they have very few customers now compared to the past and that as a long-time customer who have made many visits, this would be my last visit due to the rude service and lack of an apology for charging me the wrong price. The rude server then replied that they have plenty of customers and do not need me to be a customer here! Amazing! Good way to chase away your long-time customers!

I wont be patronizing KatanaYa any longer, as there are other spots around the area that have both better service and food while remaining open past midnight.

I left a 5% tip with comments about the poor and rude service!
author: L V.

description:
The ramen here is super overrated. I'm not sure what all the fuss is about. I mean, it's alright, not the worst I've had, but far from the best. Pluses for the ramen combo that comes with fried potstickers/chicken. But the quality of the ramen (noodles, broth, general flavor)... average.

Plus, this is a tiny place with a long wait. I'd rather go wait for my ramen somewhere else. Plus for being open late, that's the only reason we ended up here.
author: Andrea L.

description: Ordered fried chicken ramen with extra spicy miso soup base and plain hot udon- both are very good! The sashimi is kinda disappointing tho, just not as fresh but the noodles are awesome!
author: Vivian S.

description:
It's not a good restaurant.

Services r bad. Waitress doesn't care customers at all.

Sushi
Rice is bad. And chef's skill to cook nigiri is bad. He grabs nigiri to much time. It makes taste bad.

Ramen and others
Too salty. It's not good at all, not good for our health.
Noodle it self is not good. Too much boiled.
author: Takeshi K.

description:
This place is definitely one of the lower quality ramen I've had in my days. I got the fried chicken as many yelpers recommended, there was nothing special about it. I would of preferred my pork, get the pork. The noodles were horrible, thick and rough. It was very difficult to eat.

The sushi here was pretty good. The size is relatively large. I ended up getting something from their 'spicy' menu and wow that is the most spicy tuna I've ever had. 

If you are looking to try some local SF ramen, skip this place!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Katana-Ya, you shall forever hold a special place in my stomach for being a purveyor of tasty ramen, and for that, I give you a solid 3.5 stars. You're by no means the best ramen I've had, but you're up there, and quite satisfying after a night out on the town (and much better than the options around you!).

I love their combo options though: order a main noodle dish, and choose from any number of sides dishes, including things like curry rice, chirashi, and rolls, at a discounted price. Something like $13 for a combo leaves me with enough food to last a second, if not occasional third meal, so there's great value here too (don't ask me why I'm ordering that much so late at night). Having been here numerous times now, all the food I've tried (regular miso medium spicy, curry rice, soba in soup, among others) has been quite tasty. But, like many others have mentioned, the broth isn't quite as rich or deep as some other places I've been.

And the wait does tend to suck, especially if you're coming at a late post-drinking hour. I've been fairly lucky in this regard though, as they seem to give priority to me since I'm in a wheelchair (and they only have one table that's actually accessible), which may contribute to my increased love of this place over my friends'. There IS a clipboard wait list outside though, so don't do as I've done and wait around for 15 minutes before realizing you forgot to write your name down!
author: Johnny W.

description:
Charging me an extra $1.50 to make it spicy? what spice? I had to pile the chili sauce in my Ramen and I couldn't tell!

They don't offer any chicken Ramen other than the field chicken Ramen. My friend ordered the chicken and it was alright. I asked for extra egg in replacement for no protein and they hooked it up with only HALF a boiled egg.. wackkk!

miso over soy both, fasho.

Really small spot that fits about 30-35 people, largest table is for 4-5 people.
author: Sany N.

description:
Came here about an hour after opening and my siblings and I still had to wait.  There's a waitlist so make sure to put your name down if you do end up waiting.  The venue itself is pretty small with a mini bar seating section and a few tables spread out.

I ordered spicy miso ramen and was not expecting the portion to be so huge!  The ramen had a variety of items inside, I forget what they all were, but my ramen was tasty.  They also offer a ramen combo, which I believe would be more than plenty if you're really hungry.

Great meal before or after a day of shopping at Union Square!
author: Kathy Y.

description: This place has amazing ramen and sushi. There is so much to choose from that you could stare at the menu for hours. This was the first time trying ramen, and now I am hooked. I got the Katana-Ya ramen with miso and extra spicy. It was delish, but I think next time I'll go veggie cause there was a lot of weird looking meats in there. SUPER GOOD THOUGH! Ill be back!
author: Brittini S.

description:
