After being introduced to this place by my friend, all the Ramen I've had that day  after can't even come close to the dish I tasted at the Katana-Ya.  

I should deduct a point for the 20minute wait for Ramen, however, I do agree with most of the other Yelpers, it is totally worth it. Once I got inside Katana-Ya, I ordered the Pork ramen. The texture of the pork was so tender and very flavorful I can still taste it! The broth was also just as yummy. 

If you're ever in the TL (tenderloin), do yourself a favor, put your name on the waitlist for a table at this place and get warm bowl of Ramen and then you can thank me later!
author: C M.

description:
This place didn't really live up to my expectations of ramen. I wouldn't say it was bad, but at least the ramen I had was pretty mediocre.

RAMEN:
I got a Katanaya Ramen with miso soup base. The difference here than other places is I usually get chashu and tonkatsu broth, but I was open to different styles. They have bbq pork and miso instead, and I think a few other broth options? Another difference is they put fried gyoza in the ramen! That was actually pretty good.

The first thing I noticed was I didn't really like the noodles. I was worried I wouldn't like the bbq pork, but it fit right in and was pretty tasteful. I didn't really have a strong impression of the broth, it wasn't good or bad. I can't pinpoint something exactly, but overall this ramen was a little bit disappointing. 

In my honest opinion, I felt like this could easily be a good bowl of noodles -- but not ramen. It didn't taste like ramen to me. 

DONBURI:
We also got a pork belly donburi, it was a special on the front of the menu. The meat was tender and I really liked it! Medium sized portion, definitely too big for a side haha but that was our mistake. 

SERVICE:
I am never one to really care about service, as long as they sort of do what they're supposed to. However, at this place, no one really tended to us until we said something, to the point where we felt invisible. Anyway, we told someone we were ready to order so he got a waitress for us. She was kind of confusing, seemed a little unsure of things, and mixed things up easily. Other servers seemed to know what they're talking about though. 

Servers seemed nice, but, the whole experience we had with service was pretty bad. 

OVERALL:
I think if you have no expectations or standards for ramen you might like it. There definitely are better places though!
author: Lily T.

description:
Not sure what they hype is about this place. I sometimes see a line out the door (probably because it's located across the street from two theaters and only seats 10 or so).

I've had better ramen elsewhere, but it's not the worst I've had either. All in all a mediocre meal. Go here if there isn't a wait and you're looking for something quick. Don't go here if you're looking for stellar ramen.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: This place is a little hole in the wall spot with good Ramen. Please be mindful that it's really small and you must wait for a seat. I had the BBQ pork Ramen a good choice.
author: Jamie C.

description: Hands down the best ramen I have had in years. The broth is very delicious with layers of flavor. the portions are huge while the price is very very reasonable. overall it could not have been a better experience.
author: Richard M.

description:
Was in SF for a very brief visit.  Decided to try Katana-ya, because it was nearby my hotel and I had read very good things about it.  Arrived around midnight on a Friday.  Brief line, but since I was solo, got in quickly.  First off, my server was horridly bad.  Had to ask her four times for water, before I finally had to ask someone else for it.  I also had to remind her about the beer I had ordered a couple of times.  Every time I tried to catch her attention, her face was buried in her phone.  She should really be let go.  But, I never let such stuff overly influence my rating of any place, because it's really about the food.

I wouldn't call myself a ramen snob, but I know what makes good ramen.  This was not it, given the hype I read online.  The soup was definitely made on a reasonable base, but had a strong ginger flavor...not a typical component of a ramen base and resulted in an unbalanced soup.  The chashu was cut way too thick, was dry (very little fat), and lacked flavor.  The men was OK...one problem was they seemed to have twisted it into a tight ball, so it wasn't really swimming in the soup.  Took me a while to untangle it and let the men fully swim in the soup.  Had I not untangled it, my chopsticks would've pulled up a huge "men-ball", instead of small portions.  I tried their chicken karaage, which was just OK.  

Final judgement, Katana-ya is OK...clearly better than many of the ramen places out there.  But if it consistently ranks among the top five in SF, then I really feel sorry for SF residents, because it's not THAT good.  I've always argued that it's very difficult to find good ramen in the US.  I live in LA and among the hundreds of ramen places here, only a handful I would consider to be excellent.  Will have to try somewhere else the next time I'm in SF.
author: Richard W.

description:
As much as I loathe Union Square on a busy Saturday night, that's exactly when & where I found myself silencing a noisy ramen craving. I'm sure I'll end up here again, not because it's the best ramen I've had, but because they're open til 1:15 am, long after everything else has closed. 

The bf ordered BBQ pork fried rice & shrimp tempura, kind of off-menu, but they accommodated him nicely. 

I ordered regular spicy butter corn ramen with a soy sauce broth, which can be ordered 'light' or 'rich' (I close 'light.') I'm not entirely sure what is used to beef up the broth's texture, but even 'light' was slightly greasy & heavy. At other restaurants, my bowl is usually left bone-dry; at Katana-Ya, I did not wanting to ingest all of that salty, cloudy, porky-tasting liquid. Included perfect portions of corn, scallions, seaweed & bamboo. Noodles were long & some strands were clumped together, but passably chewy. $9.80 + $1.40 for spicy. 

Total for our midnight Japanese eats: $31 not including tip. No fried garlic on the table, but they are open late. Broth is saltier than I'd like, but they are reasonably priced. The pros & cons are pretty equal in my book.
author: Fancypants X.

description: The ramen noodle here is super chewy and makes you want to eat bite after bite. I got the Katana-Ya combination ramen but my favorite topping was the karage fried chicken. Decent portion for ramen in SF. I love the cozy, atmospheric lighting and the fact that it's open til 2am. Was genuinely surprised to not have to wait in line, even on a Monday night!
author: Melissa Z.

description:
Why only 4 stars for the best ramen in town? Well let me explain. There is never ever ever any seating. I just get carry out now instead of pretending I will get a seat. 

Besides the lack of seating the Katana Ya Ramen is one of the tastiest ramen I have ever had. A genius concoction of yummy and addicting with a side of HOT DANG!

I would come back here over and over again just for that item.
author: Luis D.

description:
one time i waited two hours to eat here... why? because i really wanted some yummy ramen.  Katana-Ya is a tiny, divey ramen restaurant... why should it be any other way?  when you are seated for a table of four, it really seems more like a table of two.  get comfy, because your elbow will basically be in someone else's bowl of noodles.

that being said, i really like the combos they offer here.  i get the miso ramen, regular, with a side of the uni-ikura don.  very few other places in san francisco will do it like that.  seems a little pricy for $16.50, but you really get a lot of food.  the uni and ikura are both fresh and delicious.  then comes the ramen.  you don't really need to order anything else. that's about all the food i can actually finish.  plus the table is really too small to get much else besides two bottles of beer (which you should).

if you haven't tried this place yet, i recommend you do.  there's a reason there's a big line outside most of the time.
author: Tina L.

description:
After drinking on a (fairly) empty stomach at the Starlight Room Yelp event down the street, we wandered over to Katana-Ya for some delicious ramen. It was my first time here, but I was really excited to finally experience what everyone was raving about! (A side note: apparently this place is popular with the Yelp Elites at the event because quite a few people made their way over to Katana-Ya shortly after us!)

At around 9pm on a Tuesday evening, the place was packed and there was a wait list of about 4 parties before we put our name down.  Approximately 30 minutes later, we were seated in a cozy little table for four. My friend ordered the ramen with uni and we got an extra bowl so I could try some (I wasn't very hungry and I never eat huge servings anyways). My other friend ordered the ramen with everything and then a sushi roll, both of which he shared with our fourth friend.

About 15-20 minutes later, our food came out. This was my first time trying uni, but it was nice and sweet, yet still reminded me of the sea. According to my friend, this place serves good uni (when you get bad uni at other places, it's really terrible). The ramen was also delicous. The noodles were of the perfect consistency and the broth was flavorful, without being too fatty. The other two who shared the ramen and sushi roll also seemed satisfied when they finished.

Overall, this is quite a nice gem amongst all the touristy places. Just a warning, though, they're very strict about their waitlist and if your entire party isn't there when they check up on you, they'll scratch your name off the list!
author: Leana L.

description: I had Katanaya ramen spicy it was okay and my bf had deep fried chicken ramen. Both of our ramen nothing special. Definitely not worth the wait
author: Linna S.

description:
We started off by waiting for about 20 minutes outside. This place is pretty popular so expect a wait. 

The interior is small and a little divey, but that kind of adds to the charm. 

We had the fried rice and it was very tasty, however we had asked for the kimchi fried rice and they brought us regular. 

The ramen we had was very good. We both got extra spicy and it was a perfect blend of spice and flavor. 

This was a great way to place if you're in the mood for some delicious ramen.
author: Mitchell W.

description: Akiko's Restaurant wasn't accepting walk-ins, even though we got there when it opened and there were a lot of seats. We decided to come here as it was initially our first choice. Last time I was here, I noticed they had a special on Toro nigiri for $6.50. I decided to get it this time and I didn't regret it. Big pieces and pretty buttery. Ramen has a lot of noodles. Since I wanted sushi as well, I had to share it so I wouldn't overeat.
author: Niroth K.

description:
Came in at 1am and the place was pretty busy.  

Seated immediately and next to a couple who were eating very large bowls of Ramen...which looked delicious;)

Just came from the Clock bar at the Westin  st. Francis and I wish I was hungry enough to try it.  Had some sushi anyway and was very satisfied.  

This is a great spot if you need some fresh fish late hours or a large bowl of ramen.
author: Joshua K.

description: Saw this place on Thrillist and decided to try it out. Ordered the karaage (fried chicken) miso ramen and it was average. The noodles and flavoring was not that great, and most definitely not worth the price ($11.99+ $1 for egg). The broth was very oily for some reason - it made everything in the bowl feel very greasy. I would not recommend this place considering that it's not cheap, the service is not that great, and the food is just average. The only thing was that there was no wait at 1pm on Sunday and food came quickly.
author: Constance L.

description:
Worst ramen I had in my life.  Those ready to make sold in Japanese supermarket for years are 100 times better.  Those high end instants are million time better.
The gyoza was also horrible..
It was not Japanese.  I believe they are made by some other Asian imitating and try to make some easy money by service those who does not know fair ramen and gyoza.
I wonder why there were people on line to eat this food.
I was just a visitor from Boston, trying to have a decent fast meal in the rain, near the hotel.
I know as I love ramen.  Every should stop eating here.
It was a shame as a Japanese to see this.
author: Kaye S.

description:
First time there, ordered the Katana-Ya ramen bowl with miso broth and some butter fish nigiri. SO GOOD. They give you a big heaping bowl of ramen for $12.50 that comes with bbq pork, egg, and fried chicken (which had small bits of wasabi in it. surprisingly tasty). The butter fish tasted fresh.

I hear there tends to be a line during peak meal times, so be prepared to wait a bit. When you write your name on the clipboard, don't wander and pay attention or they'll just go down the list. The place is small, so come in a small group of 2-3 people or be wiling to have your party split and eating at different times.

The waitress gave me plenty of time to look over the menu, didn't rush me or constantly pester me as I ate. The check was a little slow in coming, but they were busy so it's understandable. Good food at affordable prices, good service, would come again! :)
author: A.J. M.

description:
3.5 stars for reals... I used to think it was a lot better, but that was my untrained Ramen palette.  It is still pretty darn good tho.  I get the Katana-ya ramen, cause it has evertying from corn, to fried chicken, to gyoza along with everything else you would expect from ramen.  A medium spicy gives it just a little kick.  The bowls are pretty huge too.  I couldn't even finish mine, and I eat a lot.  

One drawback is its size.  Its a cramped tiny space, and they try to maximize all of it!  This also leads to a long wait at times, out in the unforgiving streets of Union Square.
author: Veasna H.

description:
delicious ramen, not the best i've ever had in my life, but still a really good meal. the bowl is big, don't come on a stomach filled with snacks! It's reasonably priced, and with a 20 minute wait, it's actually nothing to complain about :) 

the servers here are quick and efficient because they know how popular they are. They work hard to try to minimize wait time by updating you and even taking your order outside before you are seated, so that you don't have to wait as long. It may feel like they want you in and out quickly to accommodate everyone, but it's understandable and appreciated. 

Enjoy!
author: Tuwie N.

description:
Unless you are showing up at an odd hour, get ready to wait in line for a solid bowl of ramen near Union Square.  That said, I love the atmosphere where the obvious focus is your bowl, not the DJ or flashing lights or some other gimmick.

Broth: strong, flavorful, and rich. You cannot confuse this with something that comes in a plastic pouch.  One of those broths where you'll catch people lifting the bowls at the end to finish off whatever they have left - and you should too (though its at least a little salty/fatty - just like me).

Noodles: on the thicker side of ramen noodles, which isn't my favorite way to go (I still use the original Ippudo in Tokyo as my barometer for noodle perfection).  That said, they have a good texture and their own flavor, and are some of the better ones you'll find here in SF.

Meat & Veggies: good, but not amazing.  Not very memorable but not a *bad* memory either...
author: Jeremy T.

description:
late night eat near the union square area, super close to Ruby Skye, this is the only reason to come here.  I'm not really sure why it's on the7x7 list, it's not that great considering all the better ramen places in SF and South bay.  

Likes: the combo of ramen and entree for about $15?  options for light or heavy broth, variety of food such as sushi, udon, soba, etc.
Dislikes: Ramen is too chewy, broth isn't that great.  pretty expensive for sub-par ramen (understandable since its in union square area).

Not recommended, pass.
author: Bobby L.

description:
This place straight up tells you they use MSG in their menu--so when I ordered my ramen combo with spicy tuna don, I made sure to not get the "rich" miso broth option less I get too thirsty afterwards! If you like to share meals, the combo ramen + appetizer is perfect for two people, or if you are a big eater, the combo is perfect as an appetizer + meal. 

I really liked the sushi rice that came with my spicy tuna don. It was extra chewy and vinegar-ey, and that + spicy tuna + wasaba + extra wasabi + a whole glass of water really hit the spot. 

Sadly, they don't do reservations here. And this place is pretty small. But people do come in and out pretty quick so you won't wait long if you have only two people in your party. But we had six...so it took about an hour to get seated. But I like how this place opens up so late!
author: Jeanette S.

description: Katana-Ya definitely has OK ramen at best. I find it terribly expensive compared to some of the other places in the city (you want to charge me $2.00 for extra seaweed?!) and the ramen is nothing spectacular. The sushi is decent. Today I ordered a bowl of the specialty ramen (which is in limited quantity) and my total (with tip) came to $18.00. That's a bit steep for me. They leave out a lot of fixin's in the ramen, too.
author: Tommy C.

description: Honestly some of the best ramen I've had. And I've been to Japan. They have a wide selection of ramen with three bases (miso, soy, and one more I forgot, I'm sure someone else has mentioned it in the reviews belo) and endlesssss toppings. We got the miso ramen and as always, it was delicious. Standard ramen comes with seaweed, green onions, and pork belly. The noodles to soup ratio was perfect, something a lot of ramen places seem to disregard. The miso soup base itself was so yummy and not too spicy or mild for my taste. Only downside was that the customer service was kinda shoddy. Our waitress was really rude and snappy which was kind of overwhelming. She didn't show any indication of being friendly or welcoming, which was off putting for such a cute little hole in the wall ramen shop. Still giving this place four stars tho, since they other times I've been here the customer service has been A+. Will for sure be back!!
author: Kyle D.

description: Very expensive for a bowl of ramen. I have had a lot better for cheaper. It was decent and i would come back if I needed to but if I had to choose I wouldn't come here for ramen.
author: Am W.

description: I got the katana-ya ramen and uni ikura don combo. Uni ikura was better than the katana ya ramen. The fried chicken and fried dumplings would have been better as a side compliment to the ramen instead of drenched in the ramen broth because it came out soggy. Otherwise - the broth and noodles were cooked well. Came at an off time I suppose. Definitely worth trying though!
author: Kevin M.

description:
Talk about total disappointment. Let us be warned that places that don't specialize in ramen.. are not good for ramen. 

Here are my issues with this place. 

1. Over priced. Although I wills say their portions are larger than most places. 
2. Sushi is not as fresh as most places in the city are. 
3. This place is dirty and cramped. I don't mind rubbing elbows with other patrons, but having someone's butt face you as they pay at a counter is a bit annoying as you eat noodles. 
4. Disappointing ramen. The ramen itself was soggy, and the added ingredients did not complement the flavor. 
5. They use MSG for the broth. Although, they do warn you that they do. 

Dissapointed. I only gave it 2 stars because there are so few ramen places in the city... that I MIGHT come back if i happen to be in the neighborhood and crave ramen.
author: Winny F.

description: My favorite in San Francisco!  Love the miso, chashu ramen. Unpretentious,  busy, consistent, all good.
author: Paul J.

description:
I don't understand what all the hype is about for this place. I've been here a couple times, each time hoping that I will have a better experience; but after my most recent experience, I won't be returning.

Miso soup - I got a large bowl. I know, I know, why get a miso soup when I'm about to eat a big bowl of ramen soup? I love soup, what can I say? The miso soup is really flavorful, but SALTY. I would still say that it was good-ish.

BBQ pork ramen with rich salt broth - overall, the ramen was ok. the soup was good, noodles were a little hard, meat was ok. Also tried my friend's miso broth ramen, it was ok - not as good as the salt broth.

Here's the point of no return for me: the most recent time, I was having lunch with my friend. This time, the ramen was especially not satisfying, so i was already not-so-happy. My friend went to pay, and I put the tip on the table. My friend paid with cash at the register, got her change, and just as she turned to leave, the lady stopped her!!!!! She kind of signaled our table (right next to the register) and said "Tip". What.the.EFF???!! This has never happened to me or my friend before and was a major, major turn-off.

Maybe if they served really, really good ramen, I would overlook this. But they don't. So I'm never coming back again. Goodbye Katana-Ya!
author: Amy L.

description:
I came here on a tip from my bartender at the hotel.  He was incorrectly informed that the noodles were handmade.  They're not.  But that's okay.  

I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen, in a miso broth.  It's the ramen, with some pieces of karaage fried chicken and a few pieces of gyoza in the bowl.  The broth was ok, but underflavored.  The gyoza was good, a mix of crispy and soggy from soaking in the broth.  The chicken was average.  It didn't work as well sitting in broth and getting soggy.  
The rest of the soup had mushrooms, scallions, and BBQ pork.  i found the pork a bit too salty which buried the sweetness that should be there.

Overall a good meal.  A bit pricey, but that kind of goes with the high rent neighborhood catering to businessmen and tourists.
author: Alex K.

description:
People have a lot of complaints but the line doesn't lie. This is a place that stacks a serious bowl of noodle, even if it takes forever to get seated, a lifetime to get an order, and an eternity to get your check. 

Nevertheless, the katana-ya is such a deal at twelve dollars that I have to recommend it. It's a place is come to again and regularly, which warrants five stars.
author: Christophe C.

description: I really like Unagi Sashimi and Salmon sashimi here, I would say that the Salmon sashimi I ate here is the best sashimi I have ever had, it was really fresh and flavorful ! Ramen is popular and well known in SF. Try deep fried chicken Ramen, you will be amazed.
author: Jana Y.

description: I had the salt ramen with normal broth that came with a salmon avocado roll. It was very good, and cost about fifteen dollars. The restaurant is so tiny, and every time I walked past the line was out the door. It definitely hit the spot, especially since I am fighting a cold. The sushi was so fresh as well.
author: Lindsay R.

description: I've been coming here year after year. we love this place. it's  small  but everything is delicious.  ramen is the best try the katanya ramen. The portions are big...
author: Joann M.

description: I've had better ramen all around the world. This place ramen is just midiocre but the service is just something else. They should train their server to speak and comprehend English because after all, we live in America!! Our server is a girl with the short hair...were the worst but the rest were just as bad. They gave us an attitude and snapped at us because they couldn't understand and find the right words in their vocabulary to communicate. I mean, we asked for the 9-piece salmon sashimi and the server threw a fit because she did not understand the word 9 pieces. So not worth it. What a waste of money and time to witness these ramen nazis run this place. Horrible experience.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
I feel like I say this about every place I review, but really I've been waiting to try this place for awhile because we've been told by so many that the ramen is great, but every time we've tried there had been a huge crowd outside the doors. I usually don't let lines get me down, I've waited hours for Mama's, Plow, Orenchi Ramen...anyhow...

One random night the BF and I decided to suck it up and attempt Katana-ya. Surprisingly, we got there and there wasn't much of a line. We put our names down and only had to wait about 15 minutes.

I ordered ramen and chicken karage, my boyfriend got the combo ramen with the salmon don.  The chicken karage was meh. I've definitely had better. The ramen broth was ok, nothing special and the noodles tasted stale. I'm not even sure how that's possible as ramen noodles soak in broth, but there was just something off about the texture. Can not-fresh be a texture?  I'd tell you about the salmon don but it never arrived...

Service was fine, though I think they're used to their patrons knowing exactly what they want before they're seated. Seconds after we were seated someone asked us if we were ready to order.

No hard feelings, but next time I'm craving ramen I'll go to Ramen Underground.
author: Becca L.

description:
We shared a bowl of spicy tofu ramen with the regular miso broth ($10) . The broth was strangely a bit sweet and the solid components of the bowl weren't quite as interesting as we would have hoped (the cabbage was good, but we kept craving egg and pickles) 

The noodles were the highlight, with a good bite and texture. The staff was friendly and did not give us any grief for wanting to share just one bowl and made sure to bring us smaller bowls to share. 


Luckily, we came here for a Sunday late lunch so there wasn't a wait. We would give this place a 3.5. Since we consider the average restaurant to be 2 stars, we'd certainly come back as long as there wasn't a long line (which we hear can be more than 1 hr for dinner).
author: Amy D.

description:
Katana-Ya uses a few special ingredients: love, happiness, and deliciousness. 

My last review of this place was made only moments after finishing a meal here and was admittedly quite sparse. I was just so happy that there wasn't much I could say. But I feel as though I should beef it up a bit.

I have been to Katana-Ya several times now...ok basically every time I am in or near Union Square. The first time I ate there was after a whole day of wandering aimlessly around SF. It had been a great day and now my friends and I were hungry. One problem...it was 12 AM. My friend remembered hearing about Katana-Ya and we made our way over. We were immediately astonished that there was a group of people waiting to be seated. At midnight?? If you are coming to this restaurant at pretty much any time you will have to wait. But it is SO worth it. 

The restaurant is small and kind of cramped, but it makes it sort of cozy. The staff there is incredibly friendly and helpful. One time right before halloween a few friends of mine and I went here and there were two gumby's seated at a table. The staff seemed to be huge fans of gumby and kept talking to them. It was a lot of fun. (Ok, so my friend and I were gumby...)

The food I've tried (i'd recommend all of it!)

The Fried Rice: Hands down some of the best fried rice I have ever had. perfectly cooked and seasoned. Its just something you have to try.

The Ramen: Delicious! The miso broth was my favorite. The best in my opinion is the fried chicken ramen. The fried chicken here is just out of this world. Perfectly battered. The texture is amazing. It is a great meal on its own, but with the ramen it will blow you away.

The Udon: Some of the best udon noodles I've tried. This might be my favorite meal here....but man is it hard to choose a favorite.

The Sukiyaki Don: A bowl of rice with meat, veggies and an egg on top. i was curious about this dish and didn't quite know what to expect when I ordered it. Now I'm hooked. I've gotten it multiple times and one my friends pretty much exclusively orders this when we come here.

My only problem with this restaurant is deciding what to order. I love everything so much that I wish I could just order it all. When I come here I always wish I was a cow and had four stomachs. Alas.

So if you are in the area, or can get to the area, then try this place out. I doubt it will be your last visit.
author: Eli Y.

description:
I wish I would have known about this place when I lived in the Tenderloin! 

I am pretty picky about Ramen and I can honestly say I thoroughly enjoy the ramen here. Katana-Ya Ramen is Rockin'~! 

This evening for my visit, I was really craving some solid Japanese food and I felt particularly in the mood for chirashi. I was weary about it cause getting bad chirashi makes me super sad face, but I took the chance and I can honestly say.... it was one of the best chirashi I have yet to experience in the bay area! Kantana-Ya has a fantastic variety of fish, it was VERY fresh, and it was well presented. 

The only downside was the lighting at my table was so dim I could not see my food, I had to keep finding weird angles to sit so the light from the street would stream into the window and illuminate my food. 

Although dimly lit, this  small space with a short wait did not disappoint.   

This is my new go to spot for chirashi- it is worth all 19$ ;)
author: Stephie M.

description: I liked the flavor of the broth, but it didn't have that creamy OOMPH that Yamadaya has. Yes, the bowls were bigger, but sometimes, it does have to be about quality versus quantity. You have to pay a little more to get extra toppings; I would have liked more pork and an egg in mine. Then again, I may be confusing this place with the small one right next door. Either way, will still browse the ramen hideouts in the city.
author: Bahar A.

description:
Ended up at Katana-Ya because Ruby Skye was holding people hostage outside of the event.
Though, I have no idea how this place is Michelin recommended...

Ordered:
Extra Spicy Katanaya Ramen (Not actually that spicy)
Toro Sashimi
Salmon Sashimi
Chicken Karaage
Takoyaki
Sapporo
Hot Sake

I would say everything was only decent, nothing was supremely special. I probably would've given them a 2-star rating for the food but service was decent enough and they open late and took us in with no wait during a stupid captivity issue with Ruby Skye.

So honestly, for the prices, the quality of the food and its convenience (Open til 1AM, serious?!), I'm almost a fan of Katana-Ya, but I don't live near by so it's convenience is of no real matter to me.
author: Winè C.

description:
If you're ever craving for ramen soup this is the place where you need to be. I ordered the vegetarian ramen soup with salmon avocado sushi! The soup was just right; not too salty and light. Sushi was yummy! Customer service was efficient. 
Also don't get discouraged by the waiting list because it goes by fast.
author: Nelly P.

description: To be honest the service is awesome. But I took my dad here (who is born and raised in Japan ) and even he agreed with me.... the broth is too oily and the whole bowl was just bland in general :/.
author: Maya I.

description: Service was fine but this was probably one of the worst ramen I've had. I ordered the karaage ramen and salmon don; the salmon sashimi was  dry and slimy.
author: Glen O.

description:
Very busy place, probably the location! and GOOD ramen, CURRY RICY is betther.
Not my favorite ramen.
author: Momo G.

description:
This place is for not-too-fluffy-folks. If you just went shopping or you have a few extra pounds on you, skip this spot. Tables are tight squeeze! 

The ramen fills you up -- flavourful, well-portioned. DOWNSIDE: Service. You need to ask for tea 3 or 4 times. REALLY DOWNSIDE: Cleanliness. The waitress dropped a pair of chopsticks on the floor. Just throw it away! Instead of putting it in the to-go bag it was intended for, she put it on the counter. I still kept my eye on her though -- soon enough, the pair of chopsticks that was on the floor moments ago went into the to-go bag. Not okay. It was a rainy day in San Francisco and your carpeted floor picks up all the germs. You can afford to throw the disposable chopsticks away and get a new pair. 

Come here with 2 things: a big appetite and your own set of chopsticks!
author: Ato Z.

description:
horrible take out!
got a ramen to go and they didn't pack the noodle and the broth separately. 
everything in one small container. 
the noodle absorbed all the broth since they packed it together so there wasn't much 
broth at all.
author: Carli C.

description:
I was lucky enough to make it to lunch at this small Japanese restaurant in my recent weekend jaunt.  I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen which consisted of corn, fried chicken, fried potatoes, seaweed, scallion, BBQ pork, & boiled egg.  Any dish that includes almost all the food items from the other ramen selections and bares the name of the restaurant has to be good right?  :)

I liked that you were given the option to choose soy, miso, or salt broth in a rich or light form as well as ramen, udon, or soba noodles.  I opted for the miso rich broth with ramen noodles.

While I enjoyed my ramen and it was very authentic having just taken a trip to Japan in the previous month, I felt like the broth could have been a bit better.  With all the items it included, I expected it to have mounds of flavor, but it was a bit more simple than I expected.  I agree with the overall rating of 3.5.  With just a tiny bit of tweaking, it would be a solid 4.
author: Kim B.

description:
They're a small and busy place, so poor service is kinda expected I guess. You sign up on the waiting list yourself and wait outside. For whatever reason, I was outside for about 10 minutes while they took in 2-3 parties they came after me, but the waiter apologized afterward. That's not something I cared much about though, cause I came here to eat!

Got the Katanaya ramen with miso broth and salmon avocado sushi. The sushi was quite average and actually a bit worse than most supermarket sushis. The katanaya ramen was unfortunately not much better, as the portion was decent for the relatively high price, but the noodles were hard and all the toppings were nothing more than just average again. Gyoza, the meat, the egg (just a plain supermarket quality hard boiled egg, meh), all nothing special. The only really good part about it was the soup. 

Would not come here again :/
author: Bubba B.

description:
Every single time my son and I are in SF, we stop here for Ramen.  Really tiny place, but really great Ramen.

If you love Ramen, join them at their table.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
I used to come here all the time; usually an early weekend dinner or more likely, for lunch.  I hate waiting for food.

If you do end up waiting, it does not disappoint.  I love Genki and Ajisen, and I go to both those places way more than Katana-Ya, but the title of best ramen in the city goes to these guys.  The broth is magical.  What wizardry is this?

Their sushi and sashimi aren't bad either!
author: Erika C.

description: Late night, post gym eats.  After weights or cardio or rehab mobility work, my Italian gym partner and I come here for a quick sushi and some tea and unwind.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I've been at least 6 times. The wait is usually pretty long but IMO, well worth it. In the first couple times I went here, I tried the different types of ramen and now my go-to for a pick-me-up bowl of ramen is the Spicy Tofu Ramen. LOVE THIS. 

Only doubt I have is towards their uni-- if you want to order this, make sure to ask if it's fresh.
author: Cher C.

description:
My brother took me here, saying it's the best ramen place in SF. I was really excited and the Katanaya Ramen sounded pretty good (egg, beef, dumplings, pork and who knows what else). We waited an hour outside, there were five names before ours.

It was quite good. Good. But not amazing; something about the broth smell was weird to me from the beginning, and although the taste was nice it wasn't the best ramen broth I've ever had.

Too small to bring big parties, but ones, twos and threes are okay.
author: Christine Y.

description:
I felt like their food has gone downhill... It's not as great as how I remembered. I dont know if they changed a chef or the soup base. I felt like I was drowned in MSG... I was dying of thirst the entire night after my meal at Katana-ya. I was so thirsty to a point I was dreaming of ocean in my sleep... -.-

The line keeps getting longer and longer.... It doesn't matter what time I come here, there's always a line here! I guess yelp is definitely leading people to Katana-ya's way! I'm just not a big fan of lines...unless it's absolutely MUST try! I will be a sucker once and patiently waiting in line with a little complaints. 
Sorry Katana-ya, you need to be more consistent with your soup base! so 3 stars only!
author: Mindy C.

description:
Too many reviews, don't need to say much

However, the flavor aren't as good as ones in LA (esp in Torrance area)

However, I am very glad to found this popular restaurant in Union Square area (Adjacent to Westin St.Francis Hotel) late at night to get something warm and soupy.

The taste is very Americanized, which I didn't like it too much.  Too light in flavor and I suspect they added too much MSG in their broth.  I felt very thirsty right after the ramen.

Its filling, inexpensive, and due to lack of competitions in the surrounding area, this gonna be the best ramen house in downtown SF
author: Ken H.

description:
Looking for a late night dinner (10PM) while on a recent trip to San Francisco, I came across Katana-ya. It was packed when I arrived, but since it was just me, I was able to get seated at the sushi bar pretty quickly. It's been a few years since I've had ramen in Japan, but the katana-ya ramen (miso), and it was pretty good, albeit a bit salty IMO. I really liked the flavor, but the noodles were a tad undercooked.

The service was really lacking (I'm not sure if it was because they were so busy), and it took multiple requests to get my check, and then to have them run the credit card. I spent about 15 minutes after I finished my meal, just sitting and trying to flag down an employee.

I'm not familiar with the SF ramen scene, but based on my one experience at Katana-ya, I'd have no reservations in recommending it.
author: Chris L.

description:
Came in on Thursday evening at 9 pm, and waited for about 15 minutes for 1 seat.
Ordered the Miso Katanaya Ramen, which came out to be about $14.50 after tax (tip not included).

The Katanaya ramen was a pretty big portion, but I finished all of it. :) The broth was rich and pretty good, while the noodles were okay. Not bad.. pretty decent noodles. I noticed that the noodles were sort of tangled with each other, so there was some resistance when I started executing my ramen slurping technique. The noodles were so long, that as I slurped and slurped, I began to feel a little light-headed hahaha. Not a complaint, but something I thought was kind of funny. 

Anyway, moving on! In addition to a couple bamboo shoots, half a hard-boiled egg, seaweed, sweet corn, negi, and chashu, the Katanya Ramen also came with two fried dumplings and two pieces of chicken karaage. The fried dumplings were not really my taste... they were kind of like the doughy fried dumplings you get at some Americanized chinese fast food chain. However, the karaage was spot-on. Good texture, and excellent flavor. If I ever find myself at Katanaya again, I think I would definitely get a karaage-centric dish.

Overall, I think this place was A-OK, and so my search for THE RAMEN JOINT in the city continues.
author: Andrew S.

description: Disappointing. A bit dingy. Soup was average at best. Iced tea was weak like water. I would not eat there again. San Fran has much better choices.
author: Deonna M.

description:
Everything is great here!  I've only been here for lunch since I work nearby.  I've had most of the noodles here -- soba and ramen.  I can't choose between soy sauce broth (more traditional) and miso broth.  They're both very good!  The tofu with the rice is excellent here too!  Spicy tuna rolls are excellent here -- great rice to tuna ratio!  Lots of tuna chunks and little rice on the outside.  If I plan it right, I go there before the lunch crowds swarm.  If you can get there around 11:45am, you'll get seated right away.

It's a small place with a few small tables.  I don't know how they can handle a group of more than 4 or 6.  Most common are two tops.

The two ladies that work here are very helpful and very efficient.

They do have low sodium soy sauce and siracha hot sauce.  Just ask for it since it's not at the table.

Only thing I wish they would do differently is to add more lighting.  Dim lights are fine for an evening romantic dinner but depending on which table you get, it's really too dark.
author: Susan C.

description:
Just ordered takeout from here.  The Ramen and Udon - the noodles and soup were together.  Yes, you eat it that way, but when it needs to be transported, it gets SOGGY.  Yuck.  The egg that came w/ the ramen wasn't seasoned or colored, like you would see at a standard ramen place.

The gyoza we ordered did not come with gyoza sauce.  What??? 

Kim chee fried rice, below average.  

Won't be eating here again.  Believe it!
author: Lily T.

description: I really wanted ramen that night because I was feeling a little sick after OSL. Cool thing is that it's open late, but sucks that it didn't hit the spot. Some drunk chick even said "best ramen in the area" right as we got there. So I was kind of excited. Mediocre ramen. This place is hype! Broth is basic, noodles are basic, toppings are basic. Personally, I would not go back and would try to find another ramen spot if I was in the area. Service wasn't the absolute best either, but granted it was a Friday night and we went in really late. I did like that they had combo options where you could choose any ramen and any side order. The waitress recommended the spicy tuna roll which was good and my boo got the pork bowl. I forgot what it was called my bad. Those were good. I enjoyed the sides. Sorry, but I got to give this place 2-stars.
author: Janice B.

description: Would not honor a valid groupon purchased three weeks ago. Wasted time driving over there through traffic for them to tell me they will not accept this. Completely ridiculous. Horrible customer service.
author: Yana K.

description: This place is good and staff is friendly but WILL get crowded at night guaranteed. Lunch is a better option if you just need to have some ramen downtown. There is an option to get any ramen with or without MSG but be warned, without MSG the broth here tastes terrible. MSG is your friend yelpers, at least here it is.
author: Seiji S.

description: Too salty. Too many people and long line. I don't know why so many peeps waiting in line for lunch. Maybe the owner is an original Japanese.
author: Bum P.

description: Probably the best ramen place I've been to. I got the Katanaya Ramen and the broth isn't salty and there's a bunch of toppings. Potstickers, fried chicken, pork, corn, egg, seaweed and bamboo shoots! I came here a couple times during lunch time and if I'm lucky I don't have to wait. Service is pretty fast and the servers are super nice and friendly. I haven't tried anything else here, but the Katanaya Ramen is enough bang for your bucks!
author: Renee Y.

description:
Believe the hype. The ramen is deliciousness in a bowl that will fill your tummy and leave you needing a nap.

Perfection!
author: Erin L.

description:
Unique twist - Had the BBQ pork Ramen mild spicy. (Mild, hot or no hot are the choices). First time I had the spice and really did a different take on the broth. 
4 pork slices, seaweed, noodles, broth. 
Noodles were great, genuine and maybe homemade. Pork was good. Broth of course has all the flavor and the spice was a different take on Ramen but very good. Had a slight fish underlying taste from the seaweed in the dish. Hot house tea very good- I recommend.
Place is 3-4 stars. Overall - chill, relax, hip little place. Good for a quick eat or casual get together with friends. 
They focus on the food and it shows.
Sushi bar there as well, but didn't have any sushi.
Can't beat the price. Ramen, Tea and tip about $16.  I would go again.
author: Brian T.

description: Don't get fooled by the size and looks, we had a great meal and at a very decent price if you compare to the San Francisco average for Japanese. Highly recommended.
author: Hugo C.

description:
If you've been reading my reviews, you know I'm a huge fan of Ramen Noodle soup, particularly the tonkotsu (pork based) broth ramen and I've been on a mini-quest to find the best in my hometown and when I travel.   A friend recommended I try Katana-ya; so off I go. 

Walking in to Katana-ya is nothing to write home about. It's a little nondescript place, a bit aged, but fully functional.  They seated me at the sushi bar (party of 1) and the waiter quickly welcomed me and got me a drink.  The service was quick.  I was a bit confused by the house, techno-music they were playing with its overly mixed synthesized loops.  The night club sound experience with the aged ramen noodle house was curious. But I'm here for the soup. 

While I looked over the rather large menu, I ordered a couple Himachi nigiri.  I use Himachi as my benchmark for comparing sushi places, and I was very pleased with their fish - fresh, buttery, light flavors. Even the little bed of rice was well prepared and tasty. I might have to return to try out their other sushi offerings. 
 
They don't offer tonkotsu here, but have the standard miso, soy and veggie broths.  I ended up selecting the house special Katanaya Ramen - a bowl with miso broth and a little bit of everything in it.  Now, when I say everything, here it is:   fried chicken pieces, fried dumplings, hardboiled egg, BBQ pork, corn and seaweed.    I will admit, I've never had many of these items in my ramen, so interested to try something new. 

And I liked it. A lot! The soup was rich, spicy and maybe a little bit fatty for some, but I like that. I had to stop myself just short of lifting that big bowl to my face to drink the last drops.  The noodles were fresh, had a pleasant flavor with good bite. The fried dumplings were a great tasty addition (may I have some more please), the egg and corn fit well, I even wished there was a little more seaweed in the bowl because I liked the flavor when eaten with the noodles. The fried chicken pieces were slightly tough to bite through, but tasty.  

I'm not a ramen expert by any means, and taste is certainly subjective, but after trying lots of ramen at many houses around the world, I think I can distinguish a good bowl of soup - I really liked this bowl of soup at Katana-ya. I would definitely go back.   

As my friend did for me, I would recommend this place to you.
author: Marc W.

description: It's a very small place so it takes a little bit of waiting but nothing major. Food is decent quality and the prices are very good for the amount of food you get. You will be satisfied without ruining the bank. Also the menu has a considerable amount of options.
author: Gustavo S.

description:
(See pics)

So I did come back after a few months, on a rainy and very windy night. Perfect because most people would not want to wait outside like a nightclub.

Peter L and I came here a few times on weather like this or later at night. Always a good first choice and an excellent backup at the same time for good noodle soup and their combos (see pics.)

One thing I do notice is they finally applied for the liquor license for the basement that a few years ago someone told me they would want to open an Izakaya. Maybe it's finally happening as a recent night they were hosting some private dinner downstairs.
author: T L.

description:
I love this place; their butter corn ramen in miso will always be my favorite!! The soup is seasoned to perfection, and the noodles are extremely tasty. My favorite part is still the large amount of corn they put in the soup though, I LOVE CORN! :D

The wait can sometime be a little ridiculous, though. I remember coming here around 9pm one day with three friends and we still had to wait half-an-hr to be seated. They do have more seating area downstairs, but they close it some nights for i-don't-know-what :\

Despite the long wait, I definitely think the food is worth the wait.
author: Selina S.

description:
I walked in around 11h45pm on a Thursday and was seated imediately.

I ordered the butter corn miso ramen with extra rich broth and 2 eggs cause the eggs were not included, not even one half. 

The bowl was delivered few minute later,  very very hot which is great.

The ramen were perfect consistency for my taste. A little firm at first but get softer when you eat it in the very hot broth.

The broth wasnt that rich or thick, and only soy sauce and generic chili pepper powder were offered as seasoning.

The eggs were hard boiled. I really really wish they were soft boiled, thats why I ordered 2 in the first place. I dont understand the concept of putting a cold hard boiled egg in a bowl of miso when the yolk should be used as a dip for the noodles and add extra richness to the broth.

The portion was very generous. The other toppings included the corn, butter, seaweed, a slice of pork, green oignon, bamboo shots. 

The bill came up to almost $13 for a bowl of noodles and 2 cold eggs. Not worth it.

Oh and the music was way too load, that was too much on top of the poeple talking load cause they cant hear themselves...

So ok ramen, over priced, decent service, way too load.

UPDATE: Its now 1h09am and my head started to hurt real bad over 30 minuts ago.
                 I think it may be a msg reaction.
                 Removed a star. Be careful if you are sensitive to msg, I didnt know I was
                 Until now. Very bad headache...
author: Tia D.

description: Not the most amazing ramen. Location is touristy and food is overhyped. They have miso, shoyu, and salt flavored broths. Everything is pretty salty. The Katana-ya special has fried chicken and potstickers, odd combination to put in ramen. There's usually a long wait, so it's not really that worth it.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I feel like Katanaya deserves 4 stars but I was actually kind of disappointed, so im going to give them a 3.5. I hope its because I came on a bad day.

So I got the Katanaya Ramen with heavy miso soup base. The picture looks good enough. Fried Chicken, Gyoza, bbq pork and the usual as toppings, and after all the good things i heard about this place, i was readyyyyy.

BUENO!

THE RAMEN
The noodles itself is just the way I liked it. It was chewy and it didn't get soft in the soup really fast. It was really the best noodle i had from the ramen houses that I've been to. Just this alone I would give katanaya a really high rating.

No Bueno

The Soup Base
I know i ordered the heavy miso, but still, it was on the salty side. It wasn't like a nice rich flavor, but just kind of salty, so i didn't really like that.

The Egg
This was probably the most disappointing. Personally, I just expect all the elite ramen places on yelp to have that egg where its kind of yolky on the inside. Because thats the shit and thats something my dad can't make. But the egg they give here is the regular hard boiled kind that my dad could make : ( 

The barbequed pork
It wasn't fatty enough. I guess that makes it like, a little more healthy and stuff, but then it also makes it kinda dry.


Don't get me wrong even though there were 3 no bueno things and only one BUENO thing, katanaya was still goood. I just thought it'll be better. I think it was the toppings a chose (fried chicken, gyoza) and that hard-boiled egg and dry pork thing. Somehow, i feel like that rough texture toppings combination doesn't fit into my mental scheme of how a bowl of ramen should be. I'm definitely coming back still, but im gonna get different toppings and order a light miso soup and hope that my mind will be blown away then : )
author: Ringo M.

description:
Inaccurate/misleading Yelpy Insight "Vegetarians go nuts for this spot."
All the top-billed ramen dishes come with meat broth only. Our server had to struggle to come up with three vegetarian options.

Luckily, I wasn't the vegetarian!

There's a combo dish that has just about everything in it.  Gyoza, egg, pork, and that savory (meat) broth.  Or did I have miso?  I'll just have to try again!

Anyway, I've been late night, and seating was OK.  Have also been for a weekend lunch, and the wait can be longer.  But worth it.
author: Ken B.

description:
This is the first ramen place that I have eaten in SF.  Came here with the GF around 7:30p.m. on a weekday and surprisingly, I found parking on the street quite easily around the corner.  This place is definitely a hole in the wall, and extremely crowded.

Put my name on the waiting list and waited only 5 minutes.  There was a guy waiting in front of us, with his name on the waiting list, but his whole party was not there yet.  Sucks for him, because the waiter would not seat him.  So he started to swear at the waiter, and then stormed out like an angry jackass. Swooped his spot and was instantly seated :) . Worked out well because the people in line after us got seated when we were almost done eating. haha

Anyways, the tables are quite small and can barely support holding 2 bowls of ramen, an appetizer, and 2 waters.  The sushi menu does not look like it is ever looked at (or maybe should not be looked at).  I ordered the fried chicken ramen with miso soup.  GF ordered the butter corn ramen with miso soup.  I should have asked for the fried chicken on the side.  I mean...who likes soggy, watery fried chicken? It was okay an okay dinner though.  Nothing spectacular.  Will try a better ramen place next time hopefully.
author: Victor L.

description:
I love Ramen soup. I've had good ramen and i've had not so good ramen. This ramen wasn't bad but it wasn't the best I've had either.

This place is located right smack in the middle of all the hustle and bustle of downtown SF which makes it an easy target for being ultra busy and crowded. I showed up on a Thursday night around dinner time (7pm-ish) and the waitlist was soooo long! Anyway, I heard and read many good things about this place so I decided to wait it out despite my killer hunger -- I usually don't like to starve myself like that. After waiting for about an hour and fifteen minutes we finally were granted entrance. 

A huge downfall about the place is that it is really tiny. The table space is almost like a classroom desk being shared by 4 people and there's hardly any room to move around. We weren't fortunate enough to get a table (but I guess that's alright considering the tables are ultra small) but instead, we were seated at the bar (probably better with a little more space to move/breathe).

I ordered the deep fried chicken with spicy miso broth. It was alright tasting but I didn't like that I only got 3 or 4 pieces of chicken and i've had better tasting spicy miso broth elsewhere. Also, the noodles were sticky... kinda weird. 

The decor is also super cheesy. The outside part of the bathroom door has a huge crazy looking owl painted on it and it only gets weirder on the inside... it was weird to try to pee with 4 owls surrounding you on each wall starring straight at you... kind of a trip but I guess that's the most exciting thing about the place.

It was worth a try but I don't know if i'd wait in line at this place again.
author: Melissa B.

description: Yumm! I did enjoy it. It takes FOREVER to get in though. However, they had delicious delicious ramen. I'd go somewhere else though because the wait was just way too long and I've had similar ramen elsewhere. Nonetheless, if you're in the area you should check it out.
author: Natalie M.

description:
The search for cold ramen is finally over! Have had a tough time finding solid ramen places in SF let alone cold ramen.

The portion is generous (I couldn't finish). It comes with karagex2 and tons of other toppings such as tomago(!), seaweed, bamboo shoots the usual etc. There is also a bit of salad which was a bit weird to me but I eliminated those right off the start so I can have an uninterrupted cold ramen experience. Overall a solid bowl for sure!

Also had the fried mini octopus which were quite tasty.

Will come back for sure.
author: Cheung L.

description: Ramen is not up to standard. Pork is hard, and noodles are soggy. Find it odd to have dumplings soaked in my ramen broth too. Server was inpatient and unfriendly, which makes the whole experience worse. Will not recommend this place to anyone else
author: Darren T.

description: I really liked the "Katana-ya" ramen that included fried chicken, dumplings, pork, corn, etc. The chashu ramen is only okay, but the Katana-ya ramen in shoyu is really quite good. It's no Ramen Dojo, but given its convenient location in SF proper, it's good enough for me.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Umm...where to begin?

Ramen (I had the spicy, miso based Ramen) was just okay.  It wasn't piping hot like other places I've gone to, and I love my soup steaming hot.  It turned cool even before I could finish a quarter of it.

The restaurant is very small, and poorly lit.  This scares me because I can't really tell how clean the tables are, the floors, the seats, the utensils, etc.

The deciding factor to why I'll never come back to this place ever again was when the guy behind the sushi counter kept sneezing.  Not small sneezes, but big, full, blow your nose kinds of sneezes.  It became a little uncomfortable that even people in other tables began to notice, fidgeted in their chairs, and we ended up looking at one another as if to say "eww, gross."  Even worse, NOT ONCE in all the times he sneezed, did we see him cover his mouth and wash his hands!

Sorry - I'd rather drive to San Mateo if I ever want to get my Ramen fix.
author: Annalyn C.

description:
This place is very much overrated. 

The Ramen was ok but not great. I've had better. 

The Special Spicy Tuna roll was basically a regular tuna roll covered with Siracha (asian chilli sauce).

I think it's rated as highly as it is because there really isn't much competition for ramen in the area.
author: Mai W.

description: Katana-Ya is THE solid ramen reference in SF.
author: Mathieu F.

description:
Dear NYC,

Are you happy now? I officially coincide that ramen from NYC is superior to ramen in San Francisco. How is this even possible? It doesn't make any sense whatsoever. Distance from Japan to San Francisco is like less than that from Japan to NYC. Horrible, just horrible.

Sorry for getting off track and onto what my main purpose, at least for right now, is, the Yelp review. 

Katana-Ya definitely fits that neon lights, dim lighting, hole-in-wall description, where you can go by yourself, go with a friend or two, but please, don't bring your whole extended family unless it's less than 4 people. 

While their noodles are chewy (perfect texture), and this may very well be the best deal for ramen in the city, their miso broth doesn't quite make the cut compared to that wonderfully-soothing-feeling-after-a-cold-wintery-day derived from the pork broth in NYC's top ramen houses. I didn't quite get the feeling that this broth is this family secret passed down from generation to generation and stirred for hours in a large pot that could fit me and a few other people. Rather, it's just a level above that miso soup you can buy and make yourself from an Asian supermarket. 

However, if you're looking for a decent deal around Union Square, it's not bad and around 4PM, there is no line.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Solid ramen. 

Signature Katana-ya ramen for ~$12.50, and the portion is HUGE. I was really surprised when it came out. It has pieces of kaarage chicken, fried potstickers in addition to chasu pork which makes it super filling. 

Price point + good ramen + generous portion = trifecta of happiness  

I would definitely come here again when I'm in downtown SF!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Their ramen was awesome. I devoured a lot of it before I realized I forgot to snap a picture, it was that good. Well portioned and overall a great value. My girlfriend and I split the ramen and a golden roll. It was enough to fill us both. The golden roll was fat and filling. 

Service was responsive even at 1am when we stopped in. The food came out very fast and I slurped to my hearts content. 

I would like to add that the place was dingy and the pink light above the sushi bar didn't help to illuminate much. That in combination with cardboard to pad the walkway had me feeling like the place was not well kept. It may just be because I stopped by right before they closed
author: Sandy Z.

description: I do like how you can have your ramen with floating pieces of fried chicken and pot stickers. The broth is such an integral part of these noodles, but I find it fairly average here. This is a pretty good place considering the area, but not my go-to ramen joint.
author: Huey N.

description:
We asked if the owner was Japanese and our waitress said yes. Next thing we hear is the owner speaking Korean with one of the waitresses. Nice. 

We all got the Katana-ya ramen, but the miso broth was so salty! I also don't understand why there is canned corn in my broth. I liked the generous amount of green onions (probably the only fresh ingredient), the crispy fried pork, but the sliced meat strips were overcooked, egg is pre-boiled, and the fried dumplings has a weird-textured, lumpy filling inside. 

There are much better ramen places than this. This dingy ramen place is for tourists.
author: Tes Y.

description:
Been here a few times now and it's pretty solid each time. My only gripe is that the wait staff isn't friendly at all and they're in a super rush to get you in and out. I've been to smaller and just as busy establishments and the wait staff wasn't as pushy as the wait staff here.

The last time we were here, after we were seated, we had to move twice to accommodate a larger party, even after we've already ordered and placed our drink orders. Never the less the ramen here is quite tasty.

You can order different combinations here for whatever price range you're looking for. I'm a petite girl so usually one bowl of ramen is plenty for me. My advice for newcomers, get the Katanaya ramen, it comes with everything, egg, corn, fried chicken, fried pot stickers, pork etc. It's everything yummy all in one bowl, then the next time you can just get a bowl with just what you liked.

For the broth, you can choose between miso, soy, or spicy miso, they're all delicious so it's really whichever one you're in the mood for. 

Our usual is two bowls of ramen, a large beer and a coke, the total comes out to around $30-35 which is a great price for the location and price. Be sure to not wait until you're absolutely starving to come here, because there will be a wait.
author: Mindy T.

description:
Average... 

Ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen which included two things that stood out: House Special Gyoza & Chicken Karaage. Gyoza did not have the typical wonton wrapper and was similar to a samosa in size and wrapper texture. Chicken karaage was just chicken karaage, no special twerks.

Delicious broth makes a ramen shine but the broth here brought nothing but typical fog. It wasn't bad but it also wasn't anything out of the ordinary.

If there is a line (in most cases there is) head over to Ajisen Ramen at Westfield for another option within walking distance. At least there you are guaranteed a seat in half the time and the food is just as average.
author: Ryan E.

description:
The best noodle house in SF, no doubt.

Somehow they manage to handle the line outside w/perfection every single time. It's darned worth the wait, should you have to, too.

My personal fave is the Kimchi Ramen but they're all pretty darned fantastic. Try the Kimchi Ramen when you're sick with a nasty cold, you'll know why I suggest it at first slurp. This bowl will give your evil germs a run for their money.

The sushi happens to be pretty darned solid, too. And if you sit at the bar the sushi chefs are super friendly.

Service is quick and efficient. Don't go in hoping for conversation: it's not what they're there for. Go and eat and don't complain.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Nice ambiance. Clean place. Everybody's nice. 
Weird/ limited selection of stuff that comes in ramen though. I can imagine a more diverse quantity of ingredients at least. When did adding "spicy" start costing 1.50?
author: Christopher R.

description:
The best ramen in California resides in San Francisco.

The best bowl of ramen I've ever had in my life. 

Miso broth. Fried chicken. Gyoza. A slice of BBQ pork. Bamboo shoot. Seaweed. Corn. Hard-boiled Egg. 

Really enjoyed dining there over a weekend visit to SF after Thanksgiving.  We enjoyed it so much we made a second trip back before  heading South to LA.

The noodles were absolute perfection.  This is how ramen should be enjoyed.
author: Lauren T.

description:
There's usually a line outside, but don't worry, the wait isn't as crazy as Dojo (waited for more than an hour before, and they ran out of soup), just make sure you go inside and ask for the list to write your name on.

Soup:  miso, soy sauce, or salt.  Can ask for either rich or light.

Topping is minimal;  Standard is one slice of chasu, some bamboo shoots, and green onions.  Forgot if there're bean sprouts.  Portion is small, and ramen has good texture and not too soft.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
Katana-Ya is overhyped. To make matter worse, the restaurant is overcrowded and there is always a long wait of at least 30mins in the freezing cold.

My biggest beef with Katana-Ya is its limited selection of 3 simple broths - soy sauce, miso, and salt. Since I believe a good bowl of ramen consists of a rich complexly aged broth and perfectly chewy noodles, Katana-Ya's simplicity has left me disappointed. Both of the times I have came here, I felt like I was eating plain instant noodles with some sodium and MSG. Moreover, the toppings are limited or come with an additional cost.
author: Mabel Y.

description: I'm not sure what to give this place. I used to love it. However, recently it's let me down. I'm not sure what it is, the flavors just aren't there anymore. Yet, what other place in the city can you find ramen this late?
author: Christopher L.

description:
I waited a good 30 minutes to get a table for 3-not bad, especially since my hotel was only a block away!

I got the spicy green onion ramen with a miso soup base. The noodles were thicker than usual ramen noodles which was nice, and I did like the broth. I'd say this was a pretty solid ramen joint, and would like to try the kimchee ramen next time!
author: Lili K.

description: Found this place on Yelp, not sure what's up w/ the 3.5 star ratings but I think it's a gem in Union Square! When we got here there was a short line but I think the wait was about 20 min.  I think if SF that's pretty good.  The place is small but cozy w/ 2 servers taking care of the busy restaurant.  Though busy, we didn't feel rushed as it took us a few minutes to decide what to order.  We ended up doing a combo to share.  Miso ramen & vegetable tempura & a side of miso & rice.  The soup was good and my ramen was tasty & the noodles have the chew you want in good ramen.  The tempura was good except we got teriyaki suace instead of traditional tempura ponzu sauce which totally threw the whole dish off.  But when we finally asked for the correct sauce, it was fine.  Overall we enjoyed the food & the vibe of the place.  We will definitely be back the next time we're visiting SF!
author: Judy S.

description: I love their kimchi fried rice more than their ramen noodle.  I had the salt ramen and its OK, pork is chewy.  Overall, lots of food for getting a combo, but not as great as Orenchi or others in San Jose.
author: Brandon L.

description:
Ehh. Head to Kirimachi Ramen instead. 

I didn't really like anything about this spot - the location, the ambiance, the service or the food. 

I love fatty and juicy meat in my Ramen and this was completely dry and hard to chew. The noodles seemed pre-made and far from fresh. I got the shio bbq pork ramen and the sauce was overly salty, entirely bland and topped with scoops & scoops of MSG. I was thirsty for almost a day after this meal. 

The katsu appetizer was very ordinary and flavorless as well. 

Definitely try another ramen spot in the city before paying Katana-Ya a visit.
author: Priya S.

description:
Most certainly the real deal. Katana-Ya is a tiny space that you could walk past in a second, but is worth looking for.

Hokkaido w/ soba - excellent, excellent broth. Really, that's about all I could ask for, but once again I wasn't disappointed by the quality of seafood on the coasts. 

BBQ don w/ udon - my wife got some udon noodles, and it was a good thing. Same great broth, and a faintly sweet teriyaki-like sauce. 

Service was slow at times, but always friendly.
author: Robert G.

description: Awesome vegetarian selections and creative ramen, and cool club music. Friendly staff and quick service. Accommodating to special requests like my all-broccoli tempura. Win! I would recommend this to downtown folks.
author: Geri W.

description:
I've been here a few times and while the food is decent enough (but not worth the wait) the service totally sucks. Each time I come here servers are not very friendly and slow with taking orders, bringing drinks, and follow-up (if there is any), etc. The other night I went in, both my sister and I had ordered a ramen combo, and while my sister was giving her combo order to the waitress, the waitress turned around to talk to someone else for a minute. Surprise surprise when only half my sister's order came out. We asked the waitress if the ramen was coming and she told us we only got the sushi roll because that's all my sister ordered since that's what she had written down in her notepad.

Uuuuh, no that's not how it happened missy. We told you ramen and sushi roll combo. You were just being a cruddy waitress, only heard half the order because you weren't paying attention, and then not admitting responsibility for your screw up.

I'm not a huge ramen aficionado but I am pretty sure there are other places out there in the city with better food and much much better customer service.
author: Pauline T.

description:
First night in Frisco and tried this place primarily due to proximity of our hotel (Marriott Union Square) and the fact that the weather is chilly which to me is made for soupy meals.

First off, this place is not kid friendly due to it being a tiny establishment. Hard to move around which luckily we left our kids with my Mom back in the room. I can't imagine trying to drive a stroller around the tiny joint.

As for the food, loved the fried chicken ramen with miso extra spicy. It was really comforting. The noodle though was just okay. Maybe next time, I'll substitute for udon. As other reviewers have stated, the broth is awesome.

The other gripe is our check. The waitress must be a doctor in her day job because the way she scribbled on the check was to hard to read. We couldn't really tell how much was our total bill but decided the total price was fair so we just paid as is.

Definitely recommended.
author: Virgo L.

description:
I love this place for Ramen! Long waits accompany this small hole in the wall joint. located across from the Curran/ACT Theatres, it's a perfect place to grab a bite to eat before a show! I would recommend getting there no later than 6pm unless you want to wait 30-45 minutes. 

Also, don't plan on coming here if you want to leisurely eat your food. Due to the high popularity and few seats, once you're done you pretty much need to head out. 

However, I highly recommend trying it. So flavorful and so many options for sauces (Miso, Soba, Soy). I personally like the Soy Sauce broth as it was cleaner/tastier soup.  I would get the Katana-ya Ramen. It was on the 7x7 list as a must-try and it definitely doesn't disappoint!
author: Phillip D.

description:
I really thought this place was going to be good. But I like Shoki way better than katana-ya. 

Waited outside for 40 mins for a table, the ambiance is so dim in there i could barley see my menu. 

I was debating between the extra spicy ramen and the extra spicy ramen with tofu and kimchi, i asked the girl which was better and she said the ramen wit with the tofu and kimichi is their popular one, so i went with that. Our other plate was the curry dish. which i actually really liked, id come back for that. But when my ramen finally came out, it looked so over done. The noodles were way too soggy for me and there were way too much kimchi which made the ramen extra salty and not spicy at all. 

I'd come back and give them a try again.
author: Bhanie C.

description:
I was in the mood for Ramen after watching a 3 hour movie at Century Theatre, and this was the closer option. 

Was happy about the virtually no wait for a party of 2.  Sat at the bar.  Ambiance is cozy and comfortable.  I liked how they offered a variety of sushi and non-ramen items on the menu, but the ramen is nothing to rave about.  

Glad I tried this place, but I am looking forward to trying other ramen spots.
author: Jackie D.

description:
Im not really a ramen person so this could be a little biased.

The food was pretty good and the portions were quite large. The place is pretty small and cramped and it took about 20-30 minute wait to seat a party of 4. 

The food was good but a bit pricey and it was kind of annoying that my seat was 2 feet away from the table next to us.
author: Titus S.

description:
The ramen is pretty good.  Nice noodle texture and the spicy broth gives it a nice kick.  I had the BBQ Pork, and there was a nice amount of sliced pork, but the texture wasn't tender enough.
We didn't have much of a wait, but this place is just too small and cramped.
author: Karen L.

description: I thought it was superb Ramen. I had the house special. It was amazing. The place is not very nice. It is a typical union square/downtown location; pretty beaten up and looks old. But the food was truly special. And the service was very good. For $13, I don't think you can eat better food in downtown SF.
author: bora o.

description: Came here because it's open late. My only complaint is the service. We got our menus right away when we walked in and when we were ready to order, we were ignored for quite some time. My boyfriend and I shared the Katanaya ramen because we weren't that hungry and it filled us both up. It wasn't great and it wasn't bad. It was good enough to satisfy our ramen craving and I like that there was everything in it - gyoza, chicken, corn, etc.
author: Diana C.

description:
Very pleased with Katana-Ya

Need to know:

This place is tiny which is why there is almost always a wait.  Oh, and the food is good too which probably contributes.  The way that you put your name on the wait list is outside.  There is a clipboard and you write your name down sitting next to the front door.

I had the BBQ pork ramen.  I ordered my ramen extra spicy because I read that it wouldn't be that spicy and that was the truth.  If you love a little kick go ahead and get it extra spicy--you can handle it here.  This ramen is probably some of the best ramen I have had.  I can see how they built their business on this.

The other thing I liked about Katana-Ya is that they have a sushi bar with great tasting sushi.  My friend had salmon sashimi and they gave her extra pieces.  She commented on how great it was.

The decor of the place is very 1985 with mirrors everywhere, pink and purple neon zig zag and squares and strobe.  If you like a little nostalgia with your food you will feel it here.
author: Heather F.

description:
I've passed by this place quite a few times and there is ALWAYS a line outside! I finally decided to give in to the hype and try this place out! I dragged my family and we ended up waiting about 45 minutes. Was it worth it? I didn't think so.

My family and I ended up sharing everything (family-style!). There was the katana-ya ramen (pretty much everything is in this one: fried chicken, corn, fried potstickers, char siu) and two combos! Combo #1 was cilantro ramen with a bowl of rice and unagi; combo #2 was the plain buckwheat noodles with kimchee fried rice! Plus we got a sashimi roll.
The katana-ya ramen was yummy and the broth had a good flavor, but honestly, it didn't seem above and beyond other ramen places I've tried in San Francisco. The combos are great because you can get a little sampling of their ramen, plus another dish you know you'll like ie unagi. The price is right too! Again though, not amazing stuff. 
Do NOT get sushi here. Katana-ya is definitely for ramen! Our sashimi roll had mushy rice and my dad was saying that they didn't add vinegar.

Katana-ya is small, which is probably one of the reasons there's such a long wait. The service is OK too...not great, but not bad either. I would come back here, but only if there's no wait or not a very long one.
author: Kei H.

description:
What does it take for someone to lose his head somuchso that he orders a taxi to then realize that he needs a lift just seven doors down from Katana-Ya to Rye? Apparently two hours of Rye, then a bowl of the extra spicy deep fried chicken ramen. And, my endorphins were so increased & so nourished by the first ever bowl of top flight ramen, that I went through with the order -- and the driver was down! Maybe it's just that I couldn't walk after tackling the entire bowl. 

Tip on how to avoid worrying about the wait: drink enough before hand that it's blurry. Also, bring friends. 

Tip: It's a tight squeeze so splitting single drink orders one at a time will avoid spillage. 

Tip on ordering: there's deep fried chicken in a bowl of spicy broth with noodles as an option, the only option.
author: Jon A.

description:
Decent ramen but I've had plenty of better experiences.

The place is tiny and in a pretty busy area, so expect lines. Our group of three had to wait about twenty minutes, and this was after the peak lunch hour. There was still a line by the time I left too.

I sat along the aisle where waiters were constantly walking. Given the tiny amount of room, they're bound to bump into things once in a while. In this particular visit, the waiter happened to spill an entire glass of water on me. He apologized to me several times and brought us a free sashimi appetizer.

After the incident, we began ordering. Their menu is pretty interesting - you can customize your ramen and what you put into it. The diagram and the way they laid out their menu was a bit confusing though, so I do think they could try to simplify its layout instead of trying to make it look all creative. But anyway, the customization thing allowed each of us to order different things so we could all try different foods without having to order them separately.
