After we had ordered, the waiter came back and said that my meal would be free since he had spilled water on me. But he also added that my friends at my table that they would not be receiving meals on the house. He sounded kinda serious when he said it. It's not like those two were expecting it to be free since nothing happened to them, and we had already received free sashimi so we were fine as is, so the reminder and its tone kinda undid his repairs a bit.

Overall the ramen was not anything spectacular, but would be a solid choice if you didn't have to wait for it. And hopefully no water gets spilled on you.
author: Allen C.

description:
I used to love this place. When I went Friday night, I was very disappointed. The miso ramen that I remembered has changed a lot. It is very oily and made me really thirsty afterwards. I just didn't seem all that impressed with this place anymore. I think I drank all the oil before I could get to the miso broth! 

$14.00 for the ramen & spicy tuna don. The spicy tuna itself was really good. Very fresh and a minor kick to it. Prices was just ridiculous compared to other ramen places. I would probably skip this place when I am craving ramen.
author: Erica T.

description:
It's small, but crazy quick - we got in and out in about 20 minutes. We weren't rushed - they just kept serving and we kept eating.

The udon soup with chicken was BOMB. Like addictive comfort food. So yummy, so big, and yet suddenly just an empty bowl.

Crab cream croquettes were just sort of odd crab rangoon, but tasty. Rainbow roll was made with crab salad which isn't my favorite style, but it was enormous so the rest of the fish made up for it.

Sashimi was a big win. Ladies and gents, that's how sashimi should taste.

Overall, no bad news here.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
It was cold and rainy outside, plus our hotel was only a few steps away, so we gave this place a shot. I've never had ramen in SF before, so now was the time. Overall, I thought this tiny hole-in-the-wall satisfied our stomach for the timebeing, but for a serious ramen lover, there are some issues.

*Thumbs up*
I ordered the Katanaya ramen, and I thought the best thing in the bowl was the pork. It was flavorful and tender, and absorbed some of the spicy miso broth. The noodles were al dente and gave a nice chew.

*Thumbs down*
Just about everything else in the bowl of my Katanaya ramen was a big disappointment. When you put a perfectly crispy and deep fried piece of chicken and potsticker in a steaming bowl of broth, the end result isn't pretty. It's all a mushy mess, and you're not exactly sure what you're eating. 

The spicy miso ramen looked like neon lava, and tasted like one greasy and oily hot mess. Everything about the ramen somehow reminded me of chain restaurant Ajisen ramen. Perhaps the other bowls of ramen were better, but I struck out on this one for sure.
author: Dru C.

description: Once again, I am going to write another excellent review. This is my second time in San Francisco and had to visit Katana-Ya for a quick bite to eat and some beer and sake. Nothing more than fast and amazing. But as I said before, this is my second time here.
author: Keiki-Alexander D.

description:
Delicious place for ramen! The noodles are cooked al dente which is exactly the way I like my ramen noodles. The broth was also very tasty and flavorful. I tried the Regular Ramen with salt flavor soup which had 1 slice of chasu, bamboo shoots and seaweed. Very basic, but very good. 

The place is a bit divey and cramped and the tables are small. Not a good place for groups of more than 4 people. But I'll be back just to eat their ramen noodles.

Oh and they open late. I was here at 11pm on a weeknight.
author: Ali F.

description:
Best Ramen place in San Francisco?  
Maybe, but comparing Ramen shops in SF is like 'chestnuts competing to see who is taller'.  If I use the measurement stick in Tokyo, ALL SF Ramen shops are below average.  However, I cannot fly to Tokyo every time I crave for some shoyu ramen, so I look for the best available compromise.  This is where Katana-ya becomes handy.  

Let's make one thing clear --- many of ramen shops in South Bay are better.  Santa Ramen, Tokushima Ramen, and Maruichi to name a few.  (See my Ramen Ranking: http://www.yelp.com/list_details?userid=H7I6AKkYu-1jemA5cEVu4w&list_id=LGYfZyguH8zAHz-vDVliFA)

In the city, due to the weakness of Katana-ya's rivals (like Suzu, Tampopo, and Sapporo-ya), they standout.  For some reason, Katana-ya in 2007 doesn't taste as good as it did in 2006.  Did the chef change?  I am not sure.  I noticed that the chef was a Chinese man who spoke Japanese with an accent.  In Tokyo, that's sometimes a good sign for a good ramen.

NOODLE (men):  This is the biggest strength of their ramen.  Classic type with medium thickness, slightly wavy, and very good texture.  Very nice!

SOUP:  Slightly below average.  You get to choose between rich or light.  I always choose light since it is better for my health by keeping the fat content low.  I was initially worried that it would lack taste, but that wasn't the case at all.    

Order of my favorite soups at Katanaya:
1. Shoyu
2. Miso
3. Shio 

TOPPINGS:  BBQ Pork ramen costs $2.50 more than regular ramen ($6.50), but it was worth it.  Pork (cha-shu) was lean, tasty, and soft.  It came with menma, sea weed (wakame), and green onions.  No egg or bean sprouts was a slight disappointment. 

OTHER STUFF:  I tried their Ramen and Donburi (rice bowl) combination special.  It's a great deal at $9-10.  Their tonkatsu-don was pretty good.  Difference between tonkatsu-don and katsu-don is that katsu-don comes with dashi flavor and eggs.  Tonkatsu don was a bed of rice with sliced cabbage and tonkatsu - no eggs.  I also tried their Ten-Don.  Stay away from this!  Bad!  Soy flavor was WAY too strong and lacked sweetness.  I would stay away from tempura at ALL ramen shops.  Go to Udon or Soba places for good tempura.

SUMMARY:  Hey, if Katana-ya is good enough for Ichiro, it's good enough for me.  On my first visit there, I was singing 'Like to Be Like Ichiro', when the waitress asked me what I would like to order, I asked what Ichiro had.  She informed me that he likes BBQ Pork Ramen and Chahan (fried rice), so that's what I ordered.  She then asked which choice of soup flavor; soy, miso, or salt; I would like.  

'What did Ichiro have?'
 'Soy,' she replied.
 'Then it will be soy.'

Sitting right next to the mirror where he signed his name in a blue marker, I was ready to eat the same food as the 'true' MVP of the first ever World Baseball Classics.
author: トモ T.

description:
This is a favorite in San Francisco for me.  I like the food, the space, the service, everything.  I came here today after getting my brain vacuumed out by a brutal law school exam, and this was oh so soothing and deliiiiiiicious after that traumatic experience!  I got my usual - the deep-fried chicken ramen with light miso sauce.  GOOD STUFF.  But you know what would make it even better? If they add an oh so necessary half an egg, the soft-boiled kind where the yolk is cooked well but still slightly orange and mollety, but not quite so soft that it's runny.  If they add an egg, then it would be PERFECT.

In the meantime, I'm not complaining.  This is good stuff.  And for a place that always has a wait list outside, it goes by pretty fast.  We came around 1pm on Friday afternoon, and we were seated in about 15 minutes, I think.  Pretty fast!  And once you order, your food comes QUICK.

And a final note: I just gotta commend one of the super cute Japanese waitresses, the one who works the Friday noontime shift.  You are so charming, a fun and gracious host, and I love it! So cute!
author: Vivian C.

description:
Be honest, there's a shortage of good ramen in the SF/Bay Area. 

If you think otherwise, you've either A) haven't had a proper bowl of ramen, or B) eaten enough bad ramen long enough that you've already forgotten what it should taste like. Even by the standards of the surrounding ramen shops, Katana-Ya is not ranked high in my eyes. 

The miso broth was bland and really didn't do much to bring together all the flavors of the bamboo and cha shiu. I wouldn't recommend this place if you've got a ramen craving.
author: Meuy S.

description:
Pretty mediocre for a ramen joint compared to what's available elsewhere in the Bay. If you're really craving ramen near Union Sq then it'll do. 

As others have mentioned, you can choose between shoyu, miso or salt broth for each type of ramen they offer. Since the first two types of broth are pretty standard for a ramen joint, I opted to pair their signature Katana-Ya ramen with salt. It might not be a good basis to review this place after not giving the other types of broth a try, but the salt ramen was a bit bland and lacking in flavor. Certainly not the one-two punch in flavor that Santouka's salt ramen does so well.

Having fried chicken in your ramen to go along with the noodles is a bit different, but a welcome change. Fried wontons were a bit too soggy to really enjoy. The pork slice was also a bit stiff, oops? Noodles are the standard type you can expect, not particularly soft or special in any way. Some people might also be turned off at the pricing for their special since its quite high for a ramen bowl albeit filled to the brim. Eat at Ippudo in NYC first and then complain.

I didn't try the sushi/maki rolls here, guess they cater to everyone's cravings and tastes but I still found that a bit odd.

This ramen house was perhaps a good ramen joint before all the other shops decided to open up in the bay. As a ramen lover you'll most likely prefer Santa, Ramen Dojo, and Himawari off the peninsula. If you somehow further stumble into South Bay, there's Santouka, Maru Ichi, and Orenchi of course.
author: Steven C.

description:
Katana-Ya was awesome! I had the BBQ pork ramen and it was delicious. I should mention that I have a pretty much constant craving for ramen, so it's pretty hard to disappoint me, but this is certainly the type of place where when you finally reach the bottom of the bowl you're disappointed... despite being completely stuffed.
The place is really small, and pretty much always full, so you'll probably have to wait about 10-15 minutes to get a table, but it's well worth it.
author: Sam W.

description: Definitely not my favorite ramen place in the city, but it's in a convenient location if you're downtown, and the service is pretty quick. We only had to wait about 15 minutes to get seated on a Wednesday night, and we both ordered ramen. I ordered the spicy miso, and the broth and noodles were really good. I wasn't too pleased with the extras in my bowl; the bamboo tasted canned, and the egg was fully cooked. It was a satisfying meal, but the atmosphere is a bit weird (it's like being in a sushi bar + techno dance party) and the music was a bit obnoxious (techno dance party), so I wasn't trying to hang out there for very long. I will go back and try other options if I'm in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to get there.
author: Regina L.

description: Very nice little place for a casual dinner. Sea urchin uni don and soba combo is good. $16.99
author: Michael H.

description:
I love udon, but I'm picky about my noodles... And OHMYGOD they were so chewy and melted in my mouth! I liked the clean finish in my broth and loved the spicy tuna don on the side. 

Small establishment, cute cheap decor. It's in tenderloin, but it's pretty close to union square so it's actually not that sketchy :)
author: Rachel L.

description:
This place was filled to the brim and I can guess why. Drunk people at 12 am want ramen and this place is open. The thing is the staff was overworked and as a result they can act really rude. We were ignored pretty hardcore and I had to ask 3 separate times if we could please order our food for take out. They kept saying yes and then walking away from us! I asked a final time and the girl finally let us.. good thing cause we were about to give up and leave. The process of getting them to let us order took about 10 minutes.

As for the ramen it's "all right" but it's definitely nowhere close to the best ramen I've ever had. Didn't seem very soupy like the way I love.. the broth seemed almost like a gravy. Noodles were kind of weird/too thick and the tofu was good but it wasn't spicy like the menu suggested. At $14 I'm glad I split with a friend. Super pricy for so-so ramen in my opinion. I still liked it but I probably wouldn't come back here. I live in LA and can easily think of several ramen places that are way better than this.. I'm hoping this isn't SF's finest!
author: Dan N.

description:
We came here because we felt like sushi and didn't want to bust our wallets. My friend went here before for their ramen but they also serve sushi so we thought we'd give it a go.

Our time here didn't start off well. One of the waiters, no host, called for us and showed us to our table. Well turns out, they were hoping to squeeze five people into one small table, two feet by two feet. Really? We didn't sit because obviously we weren't going to fit so he tells us to wait at that table while they prepare a different table. Okay fine, but then a waitress who was trying to get through got all angry and short with us for "blocking" the walkway and told us to wait outside. She was so rude. It's not our fault one of your coworkers told us to stay where we were. 

Their sushi was par, at best.

What lost them a few stars was their service. They charged 18% gratuity for any party 5 or more which I wouldn't have mind if they actually gave service. Taking your order and bringing your food isn't not a service that warrants you 18%. They didn't even place what we ordered in front of us, they placed them all at one end of the table for us to grab our specific dishes.

Will definitely not come back here for sushi. If I must, I'll give them a second chance and try their ramen.
author: Dan N.

description:
I went to Katana-Ya because it was in 7x7 Magazine 100 things to eat in SF before you die.  It's also across the street from ACT Theatre & Curran Theatre where I was going to see "Next To Normal".  It's on Geary & Mason, not very far from Union Square & Powell St.

I got there about 6:05pm and there was a line for a table.  I went inside, and one of the workers told me to sign in on their waiting list outside.  I did and only had to wait about 10 minutes to eat at the bar.  I got the last seat at the bar closest to the bathroom.  The place is really tiny and cramped.

I got the Chasu Ramen which is on the 7x7 list.  I asked for hot tea & iced water - got both FREE.  Chasu ramen came out in about 5 minutes.  It looks like a big bowl, but it's not really.  Some ramen, for broth I picked Miso which is pretty rich, about 3 big pieces of roasted pork I thought was a bit tough, some bamboo shoots, & green onions.

I thought the Chasu Ramen was ok, but pricey at $11 before tip & tax.  Charged it.

They have sushi, curry rice, udon, & soba.  

Place gets really warm inside even on a cold day.  Bathroom: one unisex in the very back.
author: Ann L.

description: Ate here 2x during our stay in SF, small hole in the wall, but great RAMEN. We call is saimin in Hawaii, but the medium spicy karage chicken ramen was bomb. Perfect for the cold weather we couldn't help but come back. Also the agedashi was awesome. Sweet service, quite a wait, but well worth it!
author: Mary-jane G.

description:
Green onion ramen : Great!!
Salmon salad : Good
Kimuchi rice : Good

Service was good, too!
author: Kaori M.

description:
I've had ramen lots of times, but I must say, this is the best I've had so far on this side of the ocean.

Both my friend and I had the Katanaya Ramen. Immediately when the bowls arrived, I couldn't believe my eyes. To me, the portion was huge. There was plenty of ramen and pairs of the pork, gyoza, and chicken. The only downside would be that we both wished they had placed the fried portions on a side dish to prevent sogginess. Despite that setback, the flavors were impeccable. The broth wasn't overly salty like many other ramen places; my friend actually finished most of it.

If you're planning on coming here to eat, plan to wait at least 30 minutes for seating, and if you have a large party, it'd be best to split into smaller parties. We came around 1 p.m. and were seated around 1:35 p.m.

Be patient; it's worth the wait.
author: Bonita K.

description: expecting for air-condition or more fans. It is too hot inside when eating noodle. The taste is normal and too salty.
author: Mengjiao W.

description: Ramen was alright... Hard boiled egg in ramen is not typical, but that was the only thing that was a little quirky about the dish.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Very good! This place has me craving Ramen and I don't even like Ramen that much...

I ordered the cold soba noodles with dipping sauce accompained with mixed tempura.. it was nice.

My brother ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen with miso broth and it was very yummy!! I'd definitely get this next time!
author: Jennie S.

description:
Fast forward 4 years. 

This place blows as a ramen joint. There are better places in San Francisco now. If you don't eat here before you die, it's all right. *ahem* for those attempting the 7x7 list.

Katana-Ya's ramen lacks flavor and robustness. If I eat here it's for late night udon or sashimi. Stil, it's open late.
author: Susy C.

description:
Service- not too swell.  Friendly sushi guys at the bar but other waitstaff were not exceptional. 

Ramen- good noodles and veggies in my veggie ramen with soy sauce $11.00.  A bit overpriced in my book however my Veggie was significantly larger in portion than the Plain ramen. 

Room temperature: hot! Too hot when you are eating ramen in attempt to escape the cold night air of SF. 

FYI men: not a super classy date spot.  Also, too pricey to be one of those awesome hole in the walls. 

Overall, not the perfect package but hit the spot last night.
author: Ali B.

description:
We stopped once again for Japanese food at this little hole-in-the-wall in the Tenderloin. There are few tables, so be prepared for a wait; write your name on the clipboard to the left of the door. 

I ordered my usual miso soup and salmon sashimi. I was pleasantly surprised to have been served three extra pieces, which was nice. The fish was fresh and fatty, and the miso was some of the best I've ever tasted. 

I had a taste of my friends "spicy" ramen, which she ordered "extra spicy" and didn't find it to be that spicy. So if you're a spice fiend, ask for "extra extra spicy."

Overall, a good lunch experience, and worth the short wait.
author: Angela L.

description:
The wait to be seated is extensive because the place is tiny, so try to arrive early.  Seating is kinda cramped and tables are very close to eachother.  The people sitting next to you will probably hear your entire conversation if they wanted to.  It was very loud, hard to carry a conversation because the waiters were yelling things to eachother, everyone else's conversations in a small vacinity, and street noise.

Ramen is a little pricey but it's definitely worth a try.  It's flavorful, the noodles are perfect and they are quite generous with the chicken.  I got the Katana-Ya Ramen Special with everything in it and it was very tasty.  I asked them to make it extra spicey (they charged an addditional $1.50 for spice) but it did not taste spicey AT ALL, so that was a little upsetting.  I think the bowl came out to be $12 but you will be full.

The sushi was decent.  I cannot re-call what I ordered but the fish was just okay.  I remember the yellow-tail not being that fresh.  I expected more from their sushi considering fresh fish is available a trolly ride away at fisherman's wharf.

I do eat here everytime I am in SF because of the Ramen but I would hold off on the sushi.  Their alcohol selection is pretty limited and prices were normal.  Its more of an in and out restaurant bc you see the people waiting outside staring you down and mentally cussing you out so you will leave.

I reccommend going with just one other person to reduce your wait time.  I went with 5 people on my last trip and waited 45 minutes.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Disclaimer...
Food = 4+
Service = 1? can I give them 0?!
If you want to be treated like a decent human being, don't come here! Go to Orenchi (in Santa Clara), Maruichi (in Mountain View), or Santa (in San Mateo)...anywhere but here!

Came here for dinner (and another one of his friend since he wanted to come by for drinks) last week when we went to visit our friend's new apartment up in south SF. There wasn't much around the apartment complex, so we decided to go into the city for some grubs. I have to say that in the 2 months I've been in the Bay Area, I've yet to explore the city since part of me just can't stand it!

After almost an hour (since we missed the train by just a few seconds), we arrived in the City. The restaurant is located near the Hilton Hotel, where I was last year for a conference...I nearly didn't recognize the streets until I realized that I had eaten at a diner right across the street & the subway/pizza joint right next door before!

The restaurant is SUPER small like many other ramen places I've been to, and they barely have any space to seat the number of people they can fit inside - a group of 4 sat next to us and the girl next to me was slightly larger than usual, and she was totally in my space! I felt pretty claustrophobic the entire time I was in the restaurant...

I wanted to get the Katana-ya ramen since it has everything and sounded delicious, but my boyfriend talked me out of it because he said the serving is probably too big for me. Then I ended up ordering the combo of the regular ramen (soy sauce broth) with tonkatsu bowl...the ramen was still pretty big for me though, ha ha!
The ramen was pretty decent, good flavor/broth, but they don't have an egg (what kind of blasphemy is that?!) in my bowl! The tonkatsu was also one of the better ones I've had in restaurants, so that made my day too.

However, I have to say that their service is CRAP! The female servers were all nice, but there is this one guy who annoyed the hell out of me. He nearly kicked us out after having seated us because we were waiting for the last guy to show up for his drinks. Fine, I get that your have a policy where you don't seat people until everyone's arrived, but the way he handled the entire situation was outright wrong and disrespectful. I wanted to just walk out and not eat after the way he treated us.

Overall, I've had WAY better ramen elsewhere AND am treated like a real customer. I would not come back here again until they've re-vamped their staff!
author: Cathy W.

description:
I beat the dinner line so I had a 2 minute wait. However, right after we got in, there was a line of people.  I don't understand why people complain about the wait- the restaurant is small, they can't really help it.  If you have a party of more than 4, i suggest NOT dining here.  The tables fit 4 or 2 people. 

Ramen is decent. You have a choice of flavoring: miso, soy or salt. They also tell you that they add MSG, so I asked them to keep it out of my ramen. My noodles were cooked perfectly, and the ramen was hearty and good. AND the portion was pretty dang big. 

Only thing I could really complain about was that they didn't have much flavor options for ramen. they had fried chicken ramen, veggie skinny ramen, bbq ramen and the katanaya ramen, but they didn't have any other flavors like... seafood, curry, etc like ajisen ramen does. 

BTW, I eat a LOT but the ramen by itself is enough to fill you, so if you're not sure if you want to spend extra bucks for the combo, it may not be worth it if you can't eat that much.
author: Meena N.

description:
4-stars for ramen, service with the quickness, and not a long wait
0-stars for the sushi, please!

Of course, I came here for the ramen, and their soup noodles, so I'm not entirely disappointed hence the 4-star review. However, their sushi was just horrible, the fish were frozen and mostly flavorless and the portions (especially the raw sushi on bowls) were small. The rolls looked ok but I wasn't in the mood.

Now, onto the good part.

The ramen and soba noodles were like little slices of flavor heaven. The broth was thick but not heavy, flavored with MSG (as noted on the menu so all you allergic folk beware) and the noodles were thick and chewy but thoroughly cooked through. The portions are HUGE and the spoon speaks for itself.

The pork could have used a few more minutes or 4 more hours of cooking since it was rather hard and not at all like kurabuto pork should be, but I was happy with the taste of the ramen and the rich broth. The soba was the same story, less rich broth as it was soba, but fantastic nonetheless.
author: Lorrie M.

description: Decent ramen place near Union Square; good for a reasonably priced meal if you're out for a day shopping. The noodles are better than I remember, they tasted fresh. The ramen choices are quite traditional - soy, salt & miso soups which can be tweaked for spice and depth of flavour. I like a thick soup so the 'rich' miso option is perfect for me, the roasted pork is decent and the tofu is good. Service is rushed but efficient, the servings are huge so be ready to share dishes or take leftovers home. The restaurant is not large and it can be busy, it's more of an 'eat and get out' place than somewhere to dawdle or chat with a date.
author: Amaya B.

description: Awesome Japanese restaurant!!!! I order ikura sushi, hirame sushi and other sushi which I forgot their name. Their 唐揚chicken is awesome!!' My friend order the sashimi don and when the don is coming, we felt that we were in the Asia and it tastes like in the real Japan! Kind of regret that we didn't order ramen because we have no space in the stomach. Must have to try this..
author: Mandy W.

description: The food was good and the service just made it better. Walter was a great waiter. He was very nice and made the time there more enjoyable
author: Tony W.

description:
The stupid clipboard is still there after 2.5 years same as long line.

However, the food is very average and very cheap considering DT location.  Nothing special nothing great.  Not worth the wait!!

Not recommended unless you are too lazy to get on the bus to anywhere...
author: Sandy L.

description: It is a nice place with not a huge line in front. The Caucasian waitress was not very friendly or hospitable unfortunately . Moreover they have charged a large unagi price for the small one. I decided not to fight over it.
author: Ganna G.

description: This place made me angry enough to join yelp in order to leave a bad review. I think I would love this place if they would actually answer the phone for once. I've been trying to place pick up order, but they just let the phone ring. I thought it was a one off, but its the same the last 4 days I've tried to order and doesn't look like its improving. Food is probably good, but that doesn't matter if they won't serve it to you.
author: El L.

description:
Service has gotten beyond terrible. Our name was called but because we were ducking from the wind one door down we hadn't heard it. I go in and tell the lady but she tells me that she'll attend to me outside. Of course, she doesn't. The other service lady ignores me when I explain my situation and calls in a different party. We left. 

I've had this ramen before and it isn't even that good. They include MSG in their bowls too. Go next door to Chaba Thai.
author: Gabe L.

description: Ramen noodles seem cheap look like box ramen. Flavors outstanding and cool decor.Great rolls and prices. Could bump up the meat portions if you want loyal customers.
author: Larry D.

description: I really hate to knock a couple stars from previous reviews. Ramen was still good but not great.  Made me wonder though about a couple things...sitting by the sushi bar you see and hear everything that the chef does...such as, sneezing on his hands ,honking a loogie, and didn't wash his hands till after slicing the fish... Uhhh I was getting nervous. Glad I ordered ramen instead of sushi my mind tells me...nevertheless I kept slurping my noodles, this same sushi chef wearing a fleece vest and no hair net or hat started to enjoy a cup of tea but kept Burping!!! Mind you I was only over the bar and could smell it. Made me gag, really. Please please please, fix the talent behind the sushi bar.
author: Dustin G.

description:
Earlier this week I had an unfortunate night with take out at Katana-Ya. Upon placing my order, the host bluntly told me to wait outside - understandable though unnecessary as the space is quite intimate - and delivered my food after 20 minutes of huffs and glares. The dinner, two different ramen and sushi, was two dimensional: the escalating puckering of mouths from over-salted, third-rate ingredients.

I went back to investigate. Surely the service would be improved - who treats guests as pests? - and perhaps my party chose improperly for our tastes. Different appetizers, different sushi. Like magic, nothing changed! Same host, same passive aggressive attitude, same long wait, same palate destruction. I spoke with a delivery rider the next day outside the restaurant, eager to hear what his exchanges with the staff had been. "I always walk in smiling and gracious," he said "and they are always unkind."

It deserves a star for its popularity and the fact that, after all that, the atmosphere is funky and San Francisco-centric. Tourists love the place, but they AND San Franciscans, I think, could do better.
author: Christopher G.

description:
(I was extremely hungry when I went here, so my opinions may be skewed.)

This place is tiny, but service is fast and customer turnaround is quick. I went on a Sunday evening and it was half to three-fourths full the entire time. 

The ramen itself isn't SUPERAMAZINGFANTASTIC, but it is, in my opinion, very solid ramen that hits the spot. I ordered the regular ramen with miso base and regular soup thickness as well as the unaQ (unagi roll with cucumber) and home made gyoza appetizer -- I thought all three were excellent and would be happy to order them again. If pushed, I would admit the ramen was the weakest point as it was on the bland side. 

All in all, a good meal on a cold and windy day.
author: Rex X.

description:
Came here on a Friday night (bad idea) and wait nearly 45 mins before getting seated in the bar area. Given the fact that it was Friday night, I didn't mind the wait time, and instead looked forward to the actual meal. When we got seated, we ordered the Katana Ya ramen, the fried chicken (Karage) ramen and some sushi/ramen combination. 

The fried chicken ramen was the one I ordered. I believe it was with the salt base. Honestly, the ramen was really good and the fried chicken did not disappoint, however, I don't understand why this place has such higher ratings than other ramen shops in the area. The ramen was good, but it wasn't the best. The broth was not anymore flavorful than other ones I've tried. Actually, the broths here all tasted very similar. Just because it's doused in the red pepper doesn't make it anymore different beside that fact. The prices here are also much higher, but that's probably due to the fact that it's in SF. There are a few places in San Jose that are far better, such as Orenchi Ramen.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I was hoping that Katana-Ya would be like the ramen bar in the film Tanpopo, but I was disappointed.

It's small and maybe a little cute, but so is a chihuahua. The hot ramen bowls are decent, but the cold dishes taste sort of like a chemical solvent. The spicy dishes aren't very spicy, and I've never had anything here with much kick, unless a ton of salt is considered kick.

I think that this little ramen spot isn't performing at it's potential. Maybe they should read David Chang's treatise on ramen perfection?
author: Joanna M.

description:
What is there to say about Katana-Ya?

The service? Was just okay. Had to dip down a star rating because of it. The place is small & it's usually packed. No matter what time of day, expect a wait. The homemade ramen is pretty good. One bowl will be more than enough to fulfill you. I had to be somewhere so I just got the regular ramen to go. The wait for the food took longer than expected - maybe about 15 to 20 minutes?

Nice place to come w/ a friend or two. But like I said, expect a wait. & get there early!
author: Olivia S.

description: I always go back here for great food but service is really bad. The old korean lady is a must to avoid as she is the queen of rudeness. She is unfriendly, snappy, and will blame you if you dont get service after more than 15 min in the back waiting.....because it is your fault for not getting her attention. She is a joke and has no sense of customer service! Good luck!
author: Manila A.

description:
This place is super popular, I always see lines outside. Finally decided to give it a try after several friends' recommendations. Do
I have to say their ramen was good, but nothing amazing. It is a bit Americanized with thick-dough-and-over-fried gyoza (which I guess is necessary to keep its shape in the broth), fried chicken. Miso broth was a bit watered down in terms of the actual miso taste...not anything I would expect to see in Hokaido or even other parts of Japan. 
I did like their uni ikura don, which is basically a rice bowl topped with sea urchin and salmon roe. Portion was pretty small, but it was simple and delicious.
I wouldn't mind coming back for their uni ikura don, but there are both better and more authentic ramen places in SF.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Maybe my expectations were set too high, but I thought the ramen here was mediocre at best. Katana-Ya definitely doesn't stack up to better ramen houses in the Bay Area; it doesn't rank close to Orenchi standards.

First off, the broth is SUPER oily. I couldn't get past the taste after my meal and had to get something sweet to get rid of the oiliness asap. Secondly, I anticipated the fried chicken to be better (I ordered the fried chicken ramen with miso) but like the other reviewers it was soggy and IMO had too much batter. Third, it's a nice forewarning to see they add MSG to their soups but I'd rather not know in all honesty. It just made me even more conscious of how much I was going to eat. 

To top it off, the ramen doesn't come with an egg. :(
author: Donna M.

description:
I decided to visit again only to find that the popularity has increased tenfold.  On a Thursday night at 8:30pm, there were 15 tables ahead of me.  We toughed it out because there were some visiting out of towners.  Sadly we were disappointed because ALL our ramen was extremely salty.

Expand or improve or do something!  I will leave with one positive note that despite the saltiness, everyone enjoyed the spicy ramen. It comes out as red as flaming hot Cheetos.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Cramped seating, but the place is apparently popular enough to warrant the high density seating.  We got there fairly early in the evening and got one of the last tables; by the time we left, the line was down the block.

I had the straight-up regular ramen (soy broth).  Broth was ok.  Noodles were good.  I liked the seaweed & onions.  The pork was a bit flavorless and stiff.

The cheap pitcher of Sapporo will wipe away some flaws, but still this was just average.

My companion would like to remove another star, simply because kim chi ramen is on the menu.  When one person orders it, the whole place smells like a fart.

You're welcome.
author: Essential S.

description: If u want to eat real ramen, do not come here, the miso broth is fat oil soup with miso package.
author: BoChen W.

description: been here couple times, ramen were ok. but todaythe ramen soup tastes water downed. Wonder if they've changed owner or chef. not coming back.
author: Anita F.

description:
Oily and salty ramen, taste nothing like japanese ramen. 
Caught the sushi chef and one of the waitress smoking outside this place as I was waiting for a table. 

Didn't finish the ramen even I waited for an hour to get inside.. It's just NOT good ramen.
author: Daisy L.

description:
a tiny, poorly-lit, OVER-HYPED, hole-in-the-wall without the hole-in-the wall quality or taste. 

to be fair, there's customizable broth for those complaining--you can ask for miso, soy sauce, or salt flavor, denser or lighter broth flavor, and regular, mild, or extra spice. I liked the miso/regular density/mild spice combo. it's also reasonably priced (~$10-12) for a restaurant pretty much at the heart of downtown (and not even in the sketchier tenderloin parts). we got the katana-ya ramen which also had a wonderful plethora of toppings--bbq pork, crunchy onions, fried dumplings, fried chicken, a soft-boiled egg, and seaweed. for someone like me who can't commit to just one topping, this affordable option was definitely appreciated.

minor problems: the ramen was too al dente and the dumpling skin is just too thick to be enjoyable. I could be being a bit picky, but only because these two comprised a majority of my bowl which kind of spoiled the dish as a whole. all of this could be forgivable if not for...

major problems: the service was terrible and the fish was not fresh. the waitress l had no idea what was going on and had this annoyed expression the whole time. when we were choosing sushi rolls and asked her if the crab was real or imitation, she a) didn't know what imitation crab meat was b) fumbled awkwardly and umm'd after we explained c) wouldn't go ask the chef for us d) gave us a very transparent LIE and said that it was a 50-50 mix of both. it's one thing to not be a complete master of the entire menu, but straight up irresponsible to be dishonest with your customers. since one us is allergic to crab, we decided not to take the risk and got the katana-ya roll (some sashimi/tuna combo) instead. as noted earlier, it was not up to par.

if I'm being completely honest, I might end up coming here again just out of convenience, but only disgruntledly. if you're in the neighborhood, it's less than a block from union square and, unlike a lot of other restaurants in the area, affordable. but I'll be super bitter about it.
author: Cailin H.

description: This place serves good ramen! The price is reasonable for a ramen and the serving is big;) I oftentimes don't finish mine:) you have the option to make your broth rich if you like:) it's how I want my ramen;) there could be a wait if you come late night:) the place I would say is in a good spot:) I also like the ambiance of the inside;) this is one of my go to places when I crave for ramen;)
author: Jessca G.

description: Excellent ramen! Noodles were cooked to perfection. We had two different broths (rich miso and light shoyu) and were authentic in flavor. We knew it was a good sign seeing so many asian people waiting in line on a Monday night. The list was long but the wait wasn't bad at all. Definitely worth the wait and the prices rocked!
author: Pablo B.

description:
DELICIOUS RAMEN

Pros
-many lunch options for ramen + rice based dish (salmon, tofu, kimchi, sushi rolls)
-about $14 for TONS of food and leftovers
-younger crowd
-silky, rich broth
-ramen noodles that seemed very fresh and cooked al dente
-fresh salmon and tuna

Cons
-first come, first serve
-bad for a bigger group-- there are only 2 tables that seat more than 4 people
author: Brooke L.

description: Great ramen. Yummy sushi. Place is small so usually there's a wait. I'm not sure if they take reservations though. If you park on the street, make sure you're not violating some parking signs...I definitely got a ticket parking nearby! :(
author: Karen L.

description:
I went on Yelp to look for a good restaurant to eat at. Finally I saw that Katana-Ya had pretty good reviews and decided to see what the hubub was all about. Seeing that the reviews were very praising, I decided to go here the next day.  It was small, but I didn't expect it to actually be that small. We came early so there were still some seats, but I noticed that the place was almost already filled up. Got seated by the window, and proceeded to choose our orders. The waitress (she's slightly older than the rest of the waitresses) sort of scared me with her "hurry-up-and-choose" tone... I ordered the Spicy Tofu Ramen. I leeched off of my parents' dishes. Mom got a Sukiyaki and Dad got he fried chicken and boy, was the fried chicken G-O-O-D. I enjoyed my ramen, although it was REALLY spicy for me, I still finished it because I ordered it. I mostly leeched off the fried chicken dish...

By the way, I didn't know that there were sizes for the bowls. The Sukiyaki came in a Large and the Spicy Tofu came in a Medium. Didn't know until we saw the check. It seems a bit pricy for a teenage girl like me, but the chicken was tasty. If I get another chance, I'd like to try the other ramen dishes. I'm willing to give it a try.
author: Vicky P.

description: Wow, that Katanaya Ramen was delicious! At first glance, I did not think the fried chicken or the fried gyoza would be a good addition;however, it was probably one of the best parts. The complimented the broth so well. I will definitely be coming back whenever I crave ramen.
author: Charles Z.

description:
This place is sort of over-hyped. The ramen is actually pretty good but its totally not worth waiting for 30+ minutes. 
.
good size portions, different broth flavors to choose from, and you can add toppings a a la carte if you wish.

If there are only a few names in front of you I say go for it but otherwise i'd rather skip this place and walk to a thai joint nearby.

 Very cramped tables difficult for groups of 3 or more. Kinda awkward eating so close to some strangers. Pay attention to the names being called off because the servers get confused and sometimes skip people.
author: Obed C.

description: We were staying at the Adagio for a few nights and noticed night after night that there were crowds of people waiting outside to eat in this tiny restaurant. We finally took a chance one afternoon and had the best ramen of our lives. The miso broth was amazing and the price was right. Can't talk about the sushi because we didn't have it, but I can tell you, it's worth the wait. Enjoy!!
author: Jessica C.

description:
It is so sad to see a good restaurant is going down...
Simply this is not the restaurant I liked 5 years ago.
I left after I finished only half of ramen.
author: JK C.

description:
I will suffer looking for street parking for 20 minutes only to park in an expensive parking garage and waiting outside the restaurant for 45 minutes for really good ramen. And this was good ramen. Even though the bf and I had 45 minutes before we got seated, I still wasn't sure what I was going to order. There are different lunch combos you could get (Sun-Sat)... so in case ramen wasn't enough, you could get katsu or sushi or whatever Japanese side dish your heart desired.

The bf got a sashimi bowl (I forgot what it was called) with his ramen, and I got a katsu don bowl with my vegetable ramen. I'd say that the vegetable ramen left much to be desired (the carnivore in me was wanting more)... but everything else was delicious! BF said the sashimi was very fresh. It's been too long... I don't remember too many details, so I'll post pics.
author: Becky K.

description:
Not a fan of the lines, especially in the cold. It is also borderline on the sketchy part of town, but hey - huddle up in your group while you wait and you'll find that the wait was well worth it! 

If I'd take the cable car in the rain just to wait in line for a bowl of their ramen, then yea, I'm pretty much a fan! 

Try the spicy tofu miso ramen - da bomb for non-picky vegetarians!
author: Fiona M.

description: The food was ok. The place is very filthy with dust all over the place. Just look above you head and you will see pile of dirt and dust. Food was ok ! Nothing special but too dirty . Won't go back
author: Brn D.

description:
I was fooled... by long lines outside this restaurant at all times. 

You only go here if you are really hungry and don't have any other ramen / sushi choices.

It's not terrible, but it's not worth paying money for either IMHO.

Ramen:
- Broth had very little flavour (probably flavoured with msg to make it taste like something)
- noodles had the texture of that of a 2 minute noodle package (okay maybe I exaggerate a little but I really didn't think it was good)

They had really good menu options - we got the $14 ramen & donkatsu combo deal - but really the donkatsu don is really small so if you think you are getting two meals for a combo price think again.

I don't know how good their sushi is but I doubt it'd be all that good knowing what other items tasted like.
author: Sujan H.

description: If you're in the mood for late night ramen, Katana-Ya is your spot. They're open to 2am!
author: Kristen C.

description:
Wow seriously?  Their chasu ramen is part of 100 things you must eat in SF before you die?  I knew not to trust that list.  This was the first place I stopped by when I arrived in SF two weeks ago.  I ordered the chasu ramen under the recommendation of Big Eat SF and I was so disappointed by the pork.  The broth was delicious, it was light yet rich in taste, but the dry and tasteless pork just made my whole bowl of ramen unenjoyable.  My bf had the Katana-Ya ramen and his first reaction was "mmm the soup is good" but then 2 seconds later he said "the pork sucks and so does the noodle".  Agreed!  

As much as I liked the miso broth, I think the quality of the pork and noodle are equality important components in a great bowl of ramen.  I kept thinking to myself "if only I could combine this broth with Daikokuya's pork, noodles, and generous amount of green onions, then I would be eating the perfect bowl of ramen"
author: Karen C.

description:
Actual rating: solid 3.5/5

Really not much more I can add to the 3k+ reviews of this place. Came here around 11pm Saturday night and there was no wait time, however finding street parking was almost impossible in this area. Plenty of overpriced garage parking tho, so.... your choice. It's best if you walk here and park several blocks away. 

Restaurant is Small, sushi bar is very small. Maximum party is 4, otherwise no space for larger size group. I came here for the Katana-ya Ramen with thick, miso broth. I love the texture and taste of the broth. Definitely 5/5 for broth, just almost perfect in every way,  but you must get the RICH MISO broth! Interesting combination of food they put in your ramen. Fried dumplings, pork, fried chicken, and corn. The assumption is that half soggy fried food will make everything more flavorful. Well guess what?... You're right! it certainly does! Wow that is a hefty meal! It's so filing that in fact, unless you are extremely hungry and usually have a large appetite, I recommend sharing the ramen. Imagine dinner for 2 in the city for less than $10? Wow that is such a romantic, cheap ass (aka. smart consumer), perfect date night. Just don't eat all the green onions. Nothing is more intimate w/o p.d.a. than sharing a bowl of ramen with your significant other. Cuz now that you've shared dinner, you can share dessert, drinks, and so on and so on.... ahem. 

Anyway, yes I would definitely come back here as long as it's not busy hour, because jeez I can imagine wait times. The ramen also did not come out fast for us, I'm not sure if it's because they ran out of all the toppings and have to cook a large batch the moment we came. Also the sushi here looks average, as I sat in the sushi bar watching the sushi chefs. Nothing too fancy, but seems pretty fresh and solid in flavor. Probably wouldn't come for sushi but would come back anytime for the Ramen.
author: Andrew I.

description:
Spicy ramen with tofu and soy. Sooooo good!. My nose ran and my cheeks heated up as I inhaled this brilliant meal.
But you know I kept feeling like I could've made this stuff at home for a quarter the price and equal quality, you know?
This noodle house has sushi and other meals besides the ramen but I only saw people with the broth stuff. It's a small dimly lit place so don't bring a large group it's obnoxious.
author: Lizzy M.

description: Had a meal here with two other friends, all ordered the katanaya ramen w/ soy base and a bottle of large Sapporo. Ended up the bill is almost 19 per person. The soup just tasted like water with soy source and the cha sha was so hard. ( the strange thing is they put deep fried dumplings and chicken in the ramen..) Really disappointed and never coming back again.
author: Mark Z.

description:
Came here on a Friday evening with my SO around 6:45 and ordered three sushi rolls (California, spicy tuna, eel) and a bowl of spicy miso Katanaya Ramen (combination Pork, wanton, fried chicken). Between the two of us, we left feeling full,  satisfied. The Ramen was pleasantly flavored, the noodles were plentiful, and wantons were surprisingly good. The only down side would be the egg (overcooked). I will say that the sushi was average at best. The meal put us at around $15 / person, food only. Pricey, but it is the city. The service was okay: quick and attentive when you were done with food, but not so much with the water. It wasn't terribly busy, either. The waitress gave a recommendation upon request. It did not seem like they were attempting to contribute to the dinning experience, just conveying food and beverage.

I would give a 3.5, if only for the Ramen. The lackluster service and bland sushi took away from the experience. If you come here, come because you want to eat some Ramen. Maybe bring yourself some water if you like to drink a lot when you eat. Also, bring a breath freshener for after, because the Ramen breath is real.
author: Tyler H.

description:
Delighted to have strolled in to this small restaurant at 2:45pm on a Tuesday afternoon (shh!) after seeing lines 99% of the other times I walk by here.

There are sushi options but since the reputation stands for the ramen, we ordered the spicy tofu ramen and veggie ramen. Both in miso broth.

For all the kimchi and spices in the spicy tofu, the ramen was surprisingly lackluster in taste. The veggie ramen was improved with salt.  I shed a tiny tear of disappointment. 

The one odd experience I'd like to share is Katana-Ya's inconsistent doggie bag service. We were sitting next to a couple who needed both of their ramens doggie bagged. The server took their dishes and boxed them in the back. When I asked for my ramen to be wrapped to go, the same server comes out and gives me the plastic container so I can do it myself. ? Is it just me, or is that weird? 

At least I didn't have to wait in line.
author: Kim K.

description:
In the mood for something to fill my body with something nutritious, this place isn't bad at all.  Signed my name on the clipboard outside w/ a friend and waited for about 10 minutes.  We split the $14 lunch special which was a super small bowl of rice w/ unagi, but a larger bowl of spicy tofu soup w/ yellow noodles.  I guess this place is known for their fresh ramen, because I told myself ramen is not worth more than $5 in my opinion.  I gave them credit for the freshness though.  You can taste it.  However, we got tricked with the lunch special (w/o warning) and were charge $2 more because it was more expensive on the dinner menu.  

As for the restaurant itself, it does feel a little cramped, but if you like the whole busy, bustling feel which is what we're used to here in SF, then this place is for you.
author: Janet T.

description: This place throws DOWN on the ramen.  I was so inspired I went home to make my own.  The one  I appreciated most was named after the restaurant and had fried chicken, corn and tender pork loin in a miso base.  It was incredible.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Here is the secret that will make any ramen on the Katana-Ya menu a winner!  (I have finally figured this out after numerous trips to this establishment.)

The waitress will rarely point this out and if you're not a careful reader you will likely miss this on the menu.  You can customize your broth!  Get (1) miso, and (2) get it rich (don't forget this part!).  Hands down the heartiest broth combination on the menu.  It's essentially what elevates the star rating here from a 3 star to a 4 or 5 star.

What to Order Here:
Extra Spicy Ramen (9.80)
BBQ Pork Ramen (10.50)
Katana-Ya Ramen (12.90)
*Don't forget to get the broth rich and miso for all the above!

If you prefer your broth spicy, it is $1.50 extra.  Medium spicy and slightly spicy are both $0.50 extra.  To tell you the truth, I don't really understand the price differential here (maybe you can enlighten me Katana-Ya...).
author: Fei L.

description: I ordered spicy tofu ramen in miso soup, but what I got was just kimchi in ramen, there was even no tofu nor miso flavor. When I told the waitress, she insisted it is spicy tofu ramen until I showed her there is no tofu. And she just tried to add uncooked tofu in the bowl after my argument. Finally, I got a spicy kimchi tofu ramen, which showed that they didn't make a new one for me. When I asked the check, I found my tofu ramen was charged 11.95 while the price on the menu is 10.95. What a bad service. Please everyone goes to this restaurant, make sure what you get is what you ordered, and make sure the price on check is correct. Worst service ever!
author: Stella Y.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend on New Year's Eve. This place is tiny and super crowded. We waited for about 15 minutes. We were seated at this TINY table and I was starting to feel claustrophobic. I don't care about the setting as long as the food is good so I sucked it up. I had pretty high expectations for this place. My boyfriend and I decided to order the Katanaya Ramen with miso base and the regular udon noodles with salmon don.

Katanya Ramen - ehhhh I've had a lot better ramen and considering that this is their signature ramen, it was a big disappointment. The noodles were gross. They were hard and did not taste fresh at all. This is what came with the ramen:
- Two pieces of fried chicken (don't get that excited, it's like popcorn chicken and the meat is tough), which was soggy because it was soaked in the soup.
- Two fried pork potstickers, which was cold and also soggy. My mom makes better potstickers. Actually, Ling Ling potstickers are better and THAT says a lot.
- Two pieces of BBQ pork which had no taste. *Correction: it tasted not fresh.
- Half of a boiled egg (I gave this to my boyfriend...I think it tasted aite...it's an egg, you can't really mess that up.)

The udon noodles was the surprise of our meal. It was really delicious and the soup was awesome. I think it was fish base. The salmon don was OK too. The rice was soft and warm though.

I will definitely not be coming back. It's way overpriced for mediocre ramen. Our meal cost over $30 and considering that it wasn't that good and the portions were OK, I would much rather travel a bit farther and go to Saiwaii Ramen (Sunset) or even farther...Shin-Sen-Gumi in SoCal. Katana-Ya even adds MSG in their broth...isn't that supposed to make the ramen taste better? Anyway, after being super thirsty after our meal and not satisfying our ramen craving, I was super sad to realize that that ramen was my last meal of 2012.
author: Judy H.

description:
All this Yelp hype; therefore, I decided to stop by after work. It was around 2pm, and we STILL had to wait 15 minutes to be seated. What I was amazed was their Katana-Ya ramen. It has fried chicken, gyoza, pork, etc all packed in a bowl. WOW. Now that pretty much eliminates the need to get an appetizer all together. 

Pretty legit I must say. The restaurant is Japanese staffed, so you don't have to worry about the legitimacy. All these years of coming to SF and not thinking about Katana-Ya now makes me sad. This place is definitely going to become one of my regular spots in the city.
author: Michael W.

description: I'll be brief. This is a great place to go on a night out with my GF. We can safely split the special ramen, and the appetizer that comes free with it. We leave full, happy and hopefully a little buzzed. Thumbs up.
author: Jon C.

description: Looking for a quick ramen fix. Ramen was so so soooo delicious my partner and I came back the following night for another fix! Great for a quick, easy and tasty feed!
author: Alana H.

description: We were not greeted and the waiters were not very friendly. Our waitress did not speak very good english and forgot my beer. The atmosphere on the ground floor is not very nice and it seems not very clean.
author: Carole M.

description:
I did take out . Good service 
I only have sashimi. Friendly service and good fresh fish  . Will come back
author: Scott L.

description:
I can see why the 2000+ reviews are so good.  This is probably the best ramen I've ever had.  The line on a Friday night gets long, so get there early and still be prepared to wait.  For some reason, the restaurant was playing ABBA almost exclusively...

I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen with miso, medium spicy ($1.40 extra).  It wasn't quite spicy enough, though, next time, I'll get the next higher level.

It came with a smattering of different things like fried pot stickers, chicken, pork, half an egg, corn, some green onions, spinach, and of course, the ramen in miso soup.

I'll be back to try other things on the menu!
author: Wally W.

description: Service is okay, but the food is amazing. LOVE the katana-ya ramen, best ramen ever!!!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
What a disappointment.

We came here on a Sunday night. There were maybe a dozen people waiting outside, but turnover was quick so we were seated after maybe 10 minutes (be sure to sign in on the clipboard out front!). The menu is extensive, but most people come here to customize their own noodle soups; you pick your soup base, noodle type (ramen, udon, soba), soup type (soy, miso, salt), density (rich, regular, light), and spice level. We ordered:

- Katana-ya soup with ramen noodles in soy sauce broth, medium spicy: Totally loaded with goodies! My boyfriend thinks he would've personally preferred miso, but I liked the cleanness of the broth. I would order this again.
- Spicy beef and tofu soup with ramen noodles: I wish I'd seen more than a simple picture before ordering this. I didn't expect this to be essentially a super thick, traditional Asian beef stew (with carrots, potatoes, and onions). It was much too heavy to be enjoyed as a noodle soup, and was definitely not authentic.

And, because it's relevant, our post-dinner impressions should be included. My boyfriend's ramen did not sit well in his stomach (although I was fine), and we both couldn't shake the aftertaste of MSG hours later.

Service was very efficient and nice to us -- but I noticed that our waitress was a bit rude and impatient with the table next to us. She came out with food and, instead of declaring herself to the table, simply stood there loudly repeating the names of the dishes until someone noticed. Not the most inviting way to commence a meal.

Sorry Katana Ya -- definitely won't be back when there are better ramen options in the city.
author: Julie D.

description:
The Extra Spicy Ramen here is my favorite bowl of ramen in SF. The broth is incredibly flavorful and the noodles are just the right firmness and absorb the flavor.

The wait that builds up here at peak hours can definitely be annoying. I wouldn't recommend coming here with more than 4 people, or even more than 2 if you can help it. There are only a few tables that can accommodate a party of 4. Somehow I've been fairly lucky with the wait here though. If you go off of peak hours, you may find no wait at all. It's also awesome how late they're open.
author: Sophia C.

description:
I was a little disappointed, with over 2000 reviews you'd think this place would be awesome but it fell short of its hype, landing in just alright.

Before reading this, I'd like to note that I base my preferences over the noodles and broth first, and everything else second.  My favorite places to eat ramen are Maru Ichi (Mountain View) and Orenchi (Santa Clara).

I came with my girlfriend and ordered karaage chicken with the katana-ya ramen regular miso (gotta go full out when trying it without excess msg right?).  The chicken was alright, nothing amazing like what I've had at Honda-Ya in LA before.  The ramen came loaded with 2 pieces of BBQ pork, potstickers, bamboo shoots, fried chicken, half an egg, and some other goodies that I can't recall.

The broth was good, but not amazing.  This goes to the noodles as well.  Though enjoyable, I wasn't feining to instantly take another bite.  The flavor of the broth was good but not anything interesting or complex tasting.  Noodles had a good consistency that did not become mushy near the bottom of the bowl.  Ours came cooked a little bit more than el dente but still good.  Bamboo shoots were way too salty, BBQ pork was delicious, potstickers were lacking (just overall awkward and not good), fried chicken was of course soggy and could not compare to the karaage even though it's the same thing but was still ok to eat.  The egg was disappointing!  I love it when the yolk is still not fully cooked so it blends with the ramen when I eat it with the broth.  In this case, our egg seemed like it was hard boiled, cut in half, and placed into the ramen.  Boring.

Overall, this place deserves 3.5 stars, a little better than your average ramen shop but not quite bringing anything interesting to the table.  I know I should have been weary when noticing they didn't close from 2-6 pm and opened late, which authentic japanese restaurants often not do.  Maybe next time I'd probably just get the regular ramen or something cause the katana-ya seems more like quantity over quality in regards to the additional ingredients added.  I do like the noodles and broth, I just wish the flavor was a little more complex.  I was left feeling full (remember I just shared only the ramen and karaage chicken with my girlfriend so that says a lot) but slightly let down.  This place is a little overhyped but don't let this review stop you from trying it.  It's not bad but I definitely had better.
author: Mike P.

description:
Biggest complaint is the line. Other than that this place has been a consistently great neighborhood lunch/dinner spot. 

What the Ramen Shop in Oakland has over Katana-Ya in premium ingredients, Katana-Ya makes up for in value and overall experience. My fiance and I have been regulars here for three years and have had just about every variation of ramen, and I think we both agree that the fried chicken ramen with miso broth is the best. That isn't to say the others are lacking in any way--there is really no wrong choice.

In addition to the great ramen/udon/soup options other items on the menu are also pretty solid--the katsu-don is one thing that comes to mind. The sushi is ok...a bit overpriced for the quality, but not bad.

If you are looking for a Japanese noodle place in the Loin/Union Square, you can't go wrong with Katana Ya.
author: Steven W.

description:
Came for a weekday lunch. 

Stood outside at 11:15a (they open 11:30a), we were second in line. By 11:30a, there were six groups waiting.

I checked the menu and got a soy ramen with katsu don combo (~$15). Yum. You get a lot of ramen plus a small bowl of katsu don (yes, it's a rice bowl). That was a lot of very enjoyable food.

I'll definitely return.
author: qirk z.

description:
Service: besides the fact that the employees have to tell every SINGLE customer that walks in this place to put down your name, which the sign in sheet is located outside. I think they could be a bit more organized, put a sign outside the restaurant for customers to see. NOT everyone knows to sign in first when it's super busy, especially people who are not from the area. So as for the staff, you really don't need to talk to every customer like they're stupid "put your name down and wait outside" 

Wait: other then waiting in the freezing ass cold for over 30 minutes, I don't think it's the staff that's slow, it's majority of the customers being inconsiderate. After they've finished eating and paid for their meal they literally sit at their table FOREVER. I get it, you're chillin talking to your friends, but look outside, there are about 10 people waiting out in the cold. Get your ass up and leave. Go chat at the nearest Starbucks. 

Food: my boyfriend ordered the katanya ramen and I ordered the small kimchi fried rice don buri. Our food was served to us pretty quick! Kimchi fried rice was really yummy, especially with the sides of ginger. My boyfriend enjoyed his ramen, said the broth tasted pretty rich, super gingery, which was yummy. 

Now question is: is this place that memorable to where we would actually come back? 
Answer: yes for the food, but maybe for Pick-up. No to dine in, especially not during dinner time. Did I mention this place is veryyy small. So you could imagine how long their waits are.
author: Gerline R.

description:
Like any ramen shop(even the not so great ones), the wait is........
However, the food is fresh and tasty.  I always like to try the most basic broth(garlic/salt) to judge the foundation and quality of food that is made.  Go with the thick density broth(no dilution) since IMO the wet noodles and ingredients will naturally dilute the broth without being too diluted.
Sushi at this place is good.
I like visiting this place at least 2-3 times when I'm in SF.
author: Jason L.

description:
what i ordered... katanaya ramen, vegetable tempura

i went to this place eons ago when ramen places were so rare to find and i had a great experience and awesome food but i guess time pass and sadly they got left behind.

Ramen was ok..............good size, noodles was ok and plenty, meat was so hard compared to what you get somewhere else, dumpling was ok and the soul of the dish was bland

vegetable tempura was good but of minimal serving

ambiance... --
service... good (cashier was nice)
cost... $- (fair)
author: Gors P.

description: The best ramen I've ever had in bay area.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I had the fried chicken ramen and really enjoyed it.  The place is kinda divey/dingy, but overall it's not too pricey, well located, and the food is pretty tasty.
author: Yan L.

description: As I wanted ramen and this place was close to my apartment, I chose Katana-Ya despite its location in the Tenderloin. The location is on the cusp so it's not that bad. We got two to-go orders: one regular ramen and one spicy regular ramen. The ramens came with bamboo shoots and one slice of pork belly. The portions were quite large and we finished it after a few meals. The ramen was quite good and the broth was really tasty. I will definitely go back since it's so close to home.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I was absolutely satisfied when I ate here. Ordered the Katana-Ya ramen and it was great! This is the ramen I recommend to everyone. 

The place is pretty small and cramp but the food was worth it. I would say a lot better than Santa Ramen. The big downside is the long wait (2 hrs) but its in Union Square so you can be like me and show up 2 hrs before when you want to eat and shop around and come back.
author: Anthony N.

description:
So this is my first foray into the "famous" katana-ya. My friend had a discussion about the best ramen in San Francisco, and a few people brought this place up. Now that I have tried it, I would agree that it is very good ramen, but definitely not my favorite.

The wait was about 45 minutes for 3 people. It is a small restaurant that fits no more than 30 people. I ordered the one with everything in it (katana-ya) while my 2 friends "tried" to order the extra spicy ramen, which confused the waiter. They pointed at #10 or #11 which the name is LITERALLY extra spicy ramen but somehow the waiter got confused and brought them medium spice regular ramen. They took it back and returned it a minute later (probably just threw in some hot sauce) but mine came out right. The potstickers were cold so they just put it in the soup at the end... too bad I eat the potstickers first and spit out the first one because the meat was cold.

The soup was extra rich (my own mistake for asking for "rich" broth) the pork was alright but too skinny( tender but not enough fat), the noodles were well done and not too chewy nor too soft.

All in all, pretty good ramen, but not my favorite. What is my favorite, u may ask?
Izakaya Sozai.
author: Wilson T.

description: The worst serve ever seen!!!!!!!!!!!! Ramen taste so bad , greasy , using MSG!!!!!! And waitress keep ignore customers!!!! Plz don't waste money to eat here!!!!
author: Kay Z.

description: The best ramen and sushi I've ever had. I went on vacation in SF for 5 days and ate here 3 times. Everything here is delicious. I can't wait to go back. It gets pretty packed at night no matter what day of the week. There us usually a 30-1hr wait at night. This place us super small. I wish it was bigger because you will be sitting side by side with someone. Other than the place is small the food is delicious.
author: Abby S.

description:
Katana-Ya was exactly what we were looking for on a late Saturday night: fatty, comforting ramen. They have a wide selection of dishes (sushi included), but ramen seems to be their specialty. My bf ordered the fried chicken ramen (as if ramen isn't overloaded with MSG already) and I had their hot soba. My soba was very basic with a miso broth, a few veggies and lots of noodles. All the same it was very tasty, but nothing I would make a special trip for. The bf's ramen was another usual ramen that just had fried chicken in it. Of course, since the chicken is in a bowl of ramen it doesn't stay crispy or anything, but it still had pretty decent flavor. 

That being said, our entrees were about $9 each, a pretty fair price for the amount of food that we got. Pretty friendly service too, which is an unexpected perk at 1 am.
author: Jackie D.

description:
Hot ramen from Katana-Ya is delicious; especially when you're starving. The best part is that this place is open until 1 AM DAILY!!! That means late night eats or post-bar hopping adventures.

I came here for lunch and had the Katanaya ramen with rich miso flavor. It was pretty good. I mean, I *have* had better ramen that was loaded with much more flavor, meats, and noodles, but this definitely hit the spot. The place is kind of small, as some of the other reviews mention. You really won't be able to stuff a party larger than eight in here if you want to sit together. Imagine a hallway with square tables and chairs, and that's pretty much the interior of Katana-ya. They also have signatures of famous baseball players hanging on the wall. 

All in all, the staff here is pretty friendly and it's a decent bowl of ramen when you want it. I'm sure I will definitely be back here again sometime one of these evenings. :)
author: Mitty C.

description:
I wonder why I never came here and I live around the corner! I decided to come here when a friend and I were hungry. I ordered the Katanaya special because of the variety it included. My friend ordered the spicy broth which she wanted even MORE spicy but the waiter thought she wouldn't handle it. Clearly he didnt know my friend...
We also ordered Extra Spicy Roll. It was alright. Wasn't THAT spicy though.

This place reminds me of Ramen Dojo. The size of the restaurant was quite small but seating wasn't a long wait. When I am craving ramen, definitely will stop by again.

I would say the only thing I hate is the lighting in the place...
author: Jade L.

description:
I tried this place based on other Yelp reviews as I'm always in the mood for sushi, given they also had ramen, told myself, had to try it.

Winner!!!!

I was able to sit right down at the sushi bar which maybe sat 5, and the rest of the place had maybe 8 tables if I remember correctly.  

I ordered the miso ramen, which was perfectly made and full of flavor and enough for a meal in itself, but of course I didn't stop there.  They had a toro sushi special so HAD to get that and also through a shrimp tempura on there.  

Toro came our first and had to have come right from the Warf - just melted in my mouth.  Ramen and roll were next and just as delicious.  

One item to note - as I was in town on business, tried to use my Amex which they don't take.
author: Michael S.

description:
I told my friends I knew a great ramen place, and the first response from one was "I don't eat ramen at home, why would i go to a restaurant to eat it" after explaining to him that it was not Top Ramen, I got my group to join me here, and they were definitely pleased!

Super small space, but amazing ramen! So worth the cramped seating and wait! 

The ramen is delicious, fresh, and comes out quickly.  You can also choose the type of broth you want, I would recommend the miso with the cilantro ramen ^_^

The Toro (fatty tuna) here is really good as well!
author: Samantha O.

description:
This is probably my favorite place to grab a bite around the downtown/theaters area. A bowl, nay, a CAULDRON of ramen is perfect right before you go across the street to catch whatever musical is rolling through town at the moment.

I always just get the Katanaya Ramen, which has just...lots of stuff in it. This includes corn, BBQ pork, pot stickers, and fried chicken, among many many things. Those last two will lose its crispy exterior if you don't eat it as soon as it gets to the table, because it's sitting in soup. Everything in this ramen is tasty, and, praise the lord, you get enough of it to feed two.  Of course, I always eat it all anyway.

For the broth you can pick between rich and light, as well as between miso, soy, and salt. I have never had the light broth (WHY WOULD YOU?!), but all the rich ones are tasty.

The wait can be very very long during peak hours, to the point of it not being worth it.
author: jon y.

description: My one and only stop for ramen when I go to SF. It's walking distance from union square. The ramen is no where near shin shin in Cupertino or Orenchi in Santa Clara but it's pretty good. I normally just get the katana-ya ramen cause it comes with everything. On a normal day, expect to wait for at least 15 minutes to be seated. I have never had any problems with the service before but on my last recent trip, I asked the waitress twice for tea but she did not give us tea until right after we paid. Maybe they had an off day...Other than that, I recommend this place if you are in the area.
author: Ken L.

description:
I had my eye on this place for over a year; it was always too busy for me to go in alone (I travel to SF for business regularly)

This time I had my wife with me and she made sure we waited ...and it was well worth it

The good was great! The service was surprisingly good, and it was reasonably priced. 

Don't avoid it. Just get in line and make it happen!
author: Venice Beach Dad K.

description: I wanted to have some good quality Ramen soup with my girlfriend, and I have to say going to katana-ya was the best idea of all. The service was 8/10. The food was 10/10. Great price for a great meal!
author: Jose M.

description: I had an order of vegetarian Ramen and it was very tasty. The serving sizes were quite large and exceeded my expectations. The only thing holding it from five stars is the fact that the service was not as quick as I'd hoped, but it seemed as though there were only a few servers covering the restaurant, so it was understandable.
author: C B.

description:
Normally, with a shop this small, you would walk right by and not even notice it.  But for Katana-Ya, there's no missing where it is, because there is always a crowd waiting outside of its doors.

I came here in a group of 4 around 7:30 on a Sunday night and we put our name down on the waiting list, with at least 10-15 names ahead of ours.  The hostess told us that it would be about an hour wait, so we took this opportunity to go shopping.  It is only a block from Union Square, so there's plenty to see or do in that one hour.  

When we came back, it was only a short 10 minute wait until our table was ready.  The place is really small, with maybe 8 small tables (the tables are actually really tiny) and a sushi bar area.  I ordered the chashu ramen (BBQ pork) with miso broth ($11) and got free tea (and water).  The ramen came out fairly quickly, less than 10 minutes.

The bowl was a pretty good size.  I was able to finish most of it, but I was completely stuffed at the end.  There are a lot of noodles and about 4 pieces of pork.  The also throw some bamboo shoots and seaweed on top as garnish.  The ramen is really simple, but really good.  It isn't trying to be anything fancy really, but you can taste the quality of the product.

If you're feeling extra hungry, they do offer combo meals, ranging from $11-$14 (i believe) which include a bowl of ramen in addition to a side such as: california roll, curry over rice, tuna over rice, etc.  

Note: parking can be difficult in the area.  We got lucky and found free street parking about a block away.

The place is open late, and even when we left, around 9:30, the place was still packed with a crowd still waiting, outside.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Very decent ramen! It's not the best I've had, but it's definitely good when you need a good ramen fix.  We had 8 people, and the place was packed, we managed to get 4 people in first and the other 4 waited only about 15 mins before they were able to join us. They had a really easy to understand menu and how different combo equal what price.  I love the combo options.  I love how all the ramen options can have different types of broths and light/rich choice: soy, miso, salted.

We ordered:
Agedashi Tofu: okay, nothing special
Light Soy BBQ pork: not bad! Pork was yummy!
Salmon Avocado Roll: did not blow my mind
Salted BBQ pork: very yummy! They're salted light broth is very good!
Mapo Ramen: I didn't try this, but my Taiwanese friend say it was very good, not too spicy....very unique. It was something he hasn't tasted before and he enjoyed it.

The ramen noodles were very yummy....chewy just what ramen noodles should be.
I recommend just getting the light broths, because it's already salty enough.  If you like salty, I would go for the light salted broth, I enjoyed that alot.

Would I go back? Yes if I'm ever in the area.  Would I especially go out of my way just for this ramen? Probably not, unless I really really need a ramen fixin'
author: Lily H.

description: Worst service ever...don't even try & call to get a to-go order as no one cares to answer the phone. Crazy...
author: Nicole E.

description:
This was voted the best ramen in San Francisco for good reason.

This is a tiny place. Seats maybe 20ish people. That's why I try to only go during lunch during the weekday. Even then, sometimes there's a small wait. Better than an hour wait during their rush hour. They definitely need to move into a bigger place. But it's something you have to come to terms with if you enjoy eating here. 

I've only ordered their regular ramen. Some people complain that the soup is too bland or plain, but I beg to differ. Americans love their soup base to be full of crazy flavors.
