Katana-ya keeps their soup base very simple, the way it's suppose to be. They don't overload it with flavors. I know because I've been to Japan, and the ramen tastes pretty similar. I rarely get ramen like this in the states. Other people say that it's too salty. Every time I've gone, that hasn't been an issue. Maybe it's a lack of consistency and I've been lucky every time.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
I didn't really think katana-ya was worth the hype. Came here with the girlfriend because it was on the 7x7 big eats list of things to eat before you die. I thought it was a pretty big disappointment. I got the chasu ramen with miso and asked for the light option, but the flavors were still too strong. You could also tell that they dump MSG into their soup, it actually made me gag thinking about it.

The environment also wasn't amazing. The restaurant is really small and dingy, and the seats were a little too squished. Not a fan at all
author: Victor C.

description: Fantastic ramen!  Ordered the Katanaa Ya ramen with fried chicken and potstickers. The bits of corn were the perfect sweet addition to the tasty miso broth. I also ordered salmon nigiri---like buttah!  So fresh.  Definitely earned a repeat customer!
author: Angelica B.

description:
I've been here a few times, with every other time before last night occurring during the less busy weekday afternoons. In those instances, we were seated promptly to a mostly empty restaurant. When my roomies and I came on a Friday night for dinner, however, I didn't anticipate such a large crowd at all waiting outside! Still, our group of 3 put our name down with literally 6 parties ahead of us and proceeded to wait. We were seated only 20 minutes later, so DEFINITELY put your name down and wait it out because it is so worth it.

The Katanaya Ramen is the best option if you want a taste of everything; it's basically like every other bowl of ramen they have combined into one. There's corn, fried potstickers (which gets really soggy, so it's kind of weird), fried chicken (soggy too), corn, half a hardboiled egg, scallions and other green things, and chasu (melt-in-your-mouth amazing, the only reason why this ramen joint is better than anything else in the city IMO). You get a choice of broths (miso, soy, salt--which ranges from heaviest to lightest) and density (rich or light). Yay for options!

It isn't ridiculously cheap (like $8 from the most basic ramen bowl to $14 for the Katanaya) but still more worth it than other places in the city.
author: Shira C.

description: Love love love this place! Every year I come to San Francisco, I make sure I stop in here for either lunch or dinner. There can be a wait, but it's worth it! The place is very small and service is not good, but it's because they are so busy and they're trying to turn tables. Udon noodles are fantastic and their sushi is delicious!
author: Bren T.

description:
Came here on a very cold, rainy night - perfect pho/ramen weather.  

The wait was disastrous, because it was... well, COLD AND RAINY!!  We had to wait outside as there is no room whatsoever to eat comfortably inside, let alone a waiting area.
The restaurant is the size of a studio apartment.  I'm not hating though - I don't really care about the size and how much elbow space I have, but this for those who do care and for you to keep in mind that if it's your first time here, expect a long wait at dinner time as I think the max capacity is like 30 people. 

I ordered the Kimchi Ramen with miso based broth which was good, but after I tasted my bf's Fried Chicken Ramen, I wished the crapload of kimchi in my ramen bowl would magically transform into fried chicken.  Sigh.  The texture of the noodles were perfect - kinda sort al dente but not really.  It was perfectly chewy I guess.  

Wouldn't say it's the best ramen I've ever had but I'd definitely come back here the next time I'm in town.  This place opens til 1:30 AM and their portions are gargantuan.  Their service sucks though. Our server was a grumpy European lady that acted like someone poured vinegar in her ramen. It took forever for our check to come and while we waited, we were stared down angrily by everyone who was waiting in the freezing rain (we sat right by the window).
author: Stephanoodle T.

description: The ramen itself was cooked just well enough; not too soft, not too hard. The restaurant itself is quite small, which makes it difficult for people to get in at a designated time. Wait is a must, but it's definitely worth the wait, considering how much meat goes into the broth.
author: Lina Y.

description:
Still love the ramen.
Still don't love the sushi.
Today, I've decided to hate their tempura. It was GF's order, not mine, but I ate off of it. Veggies were limp and old, possibly previously frozen, and the the batter was thick, not flaky at all. I'm not dropping a star because I only come here for the ramen anyway. Just FYI...
author: Helen L.

description: Two star for the memory.  They change the waitress and wired perfume with bad service.
author: Christina M.

description: Worst ramen ever. I was so excited to try this place out, but was deeply disappointed by how disgusting the broth was. I can't tell you enough how much you should avoid this place...I opted for one of the spicy ramen choices and seriously got a mouthful of salt and off-tasting broth. There are TONS of other great ramen and Japanese options, especially around the tenderloin. Katana-Ya? Definitely not one of them
author: Surge C.

description:
I really wanted to give this a 5 star - and by no means does my 4 star mean that I don't like it - I actually like this place for their Ramen! 

That last star is because of wait time and how small the space it. But as soon as you get in, get a table and get your ramen all of that pretty much goes away.

I do love that control over how spicy and what kind flavor for the soup you can get. 

Over all I would recommend this place and I have! 

:)

I might go tonight, actually, very hungry for some ramen.
author: Sol P.

description:
Somewhere in my heart, I'll always have a place for cheap sushi restaurants. 

To be utterly honest, the food is somewhat forgettable here. The sushi quality is standard, the flavor of the ramen is good but is nothing special. The menu is a bit more diverse than most sushi places as well. For the most part, there's no bells and whistles, nothing that makes this place stand out from the many other sushi places in the area. 

Still, this is the best restaurant I've been to that has served both ramen and sushi, and I'm strangely appreciative of that. Most other places I've been to that have claimed the same have been so sketchy that they give you food poisoning just from breathing the air inside. In comparison, sushi and ramen that's forgettable compares pretty favorably.
author: Eugene P.

description:
I expected this to be A LOT better considering the hour long wait. 

It definitely did not satisfy my ramen craving. I got the shio ramen. Compared to other ramen places I've been to the pork here is below average. They also use canned corn - yes you can taste the difference.  

The best part of the meal was the hamachi kama - hence the 3 star review. 

Final verdict: there are TONS of better options if you are willing to wait an hour.
author: Anna H.

description:
The noodles were great, like perfect. The woman who took our order was pretty rude though. Had a chaotic atmosphere, so I recommend take-out. Order ahead of time.

I live in MIchigan and all I've been thinking about are those noodles though. Worth the crappy parts.
author: Taylor H.

description: I've been here twice, and I must say, it's over rated. i think I had the salt regular ramen the first time-meh. I got miso (i wish they had tonkotsu) katanaya ramen the second time, and ya it had a bunch of stuff in it, but, was not very flavorful at all. Also they use MSG.
author: Shayan S.

description: I do not know why people rave about their Ramen. The broth was bland and nothing special. In fact, the broth was way too thick and tasted spiked full of MSG. I did like the fried pork and Gyoza in the Ramen though. The fried octopus was good. The Gyoza appetizer is not frozen but way overpriced. I am on the fence about whether not I will return.
author: J. W.

description: Seriously love this place. Reasonably priced, great ramen, quick service just amazing.
author: Julie M.

description:
Agree with other yelpers. Best ramen in SF but ramen in LA wins this ramen battle. 

Ordered the Katana ramen while my bf had the BBQ ramen. Then u get the option of soy, miso, or salt base. We tried the miso n soy. I can't say one is better than the other since this is up to personal taste. Both good. I like that they're open late. May come back but may just wait till my next LA trip. 

Fast service. Fun loud atmosphere
author: Logan N.

description:
What happen... no seriously... what is up with the customer service of this place?

When my girlfriend and I first entered the spot. They seated us immediately in this center corner of the room and it would be cramp for some patrons (just a heads up).

We ordered the following items:

-2 orders of BBQ Pork (Chashu) Ramen.
-2 orders of Nigiri Sushi (2 pieces of Salmon and 2 pieces of Yellowtail).

Within the five minutes of sitting down I went to use the bathroom. Came out and got to my seat and out of nowhere my girlfriend tells me, "They said they cannot make the sushi orders because the sushi chef, is TOO BUSY."

Now at this point, I'm really disappointed. Granted I could sympathize with the guy (especially after working in the restaurant industry), I could tell he was in the weeds. However this becomes an issue stemming from one of three points of origin: staffing, logistics and time management. 

In this case it was staffing (lack of an assistant sushi chef) and the lack of training in customer service by said waitress. When I inquired with our immediate waitress she merely replied, "Uh he has too many orders and therefore cannot serve you sushi."

As she walked away, I looked around and practically 90% of the patrons had some sushi rolls (and plates) available and served to them and yet they couldn't serve to us?

Then things got really dicey, after a 10 minute commotion between the waitress and the Sushi Chef in Japanese she rolled her eyes towards me and said, "Would you still like to have your sushi orders... he'll make yours first. Yes or no?" (Later we found out that the Sushi Chef complained to the staff that he was running low on rice and therefore, couldn't make orders as promptly as he normally does. If the waitress paid attention or actually inquired about this firsthand before stating something as ignorant as "too busy" I would have been more content with waiting even if it was towards the end of the meal).

At this rate, I'm pretty irritated but I said yes, just to see whether or not it was worth it. The hassle of getting four nigiri pieces, left a bitter taste in my mouth (the sushi was fresh but the overall experience began to sour).

Our ramen arrived within, five minutes after ward. The miso broth was probably the best thing of the dish (good and hearty but wasn't clean and robust like other places I've tried; Daikokuya, Shin Sen Gumi, Santouka etc. in SoCal. The noodles needed to be a bit more al-dente (lacked a bite of) and somewhat thinner (not braces friendly) and the pork cuts were similar to SSG, but not as marbleized as Daikokuya's Black Pork.

When we asked for the check and the waitress asked if there was anything else we needed, before I can even reply "no thank you" she immediately turned her back and rushed the receipt to our table and walked off. WTF? 

So as a recap, we spent $36.00 (with poor tip due to bad service) just to get shafted on a half assed experience with subpar food? This is exactly why my "overpriced" experience at Senior Sisig was better off, than this Japanese crack in the hole.

My original rating for this place was 3-3.5 (maybe 4) if the food was just as good as my favorite Southern California ramen spots. However since this place was full of crap...

1.5 in reality, I'm giving a 2 out of pity from having experience in the restaurant industry.

No thank you, I won't be coming back.
author: Ryan M.

description: A nice big portion, I was stuffed! The broth was a bit salty and there wasn't too much to my karage ramen. I wish I had known the chicken was served in the broth, I would have asked for it on the side. It lost all crispiness and made the broth oily. All in all it was decent ramen.
author: Chauanh D.

description:
spicy tofu noodles are wonderful! YAY!
wait too long, especially for parties greater than 2! BOO!
author: Mi M.

description: As others said, be prepared to wait but come hungry - their ramen portions are ginormous. Order the BBQ pork with extra spicy miso broth. Their spicy tuna don was also pretty good. Overall, great place when you need a ramen fix but not as good as many other places in LA.
author: Wayne H.

description:
Ramen ramen ramen... Usually it will taste extremely good in cold weather and while I am super hungry. We came here on the weekend pass the lunch hour around 1:30ish and we still need to wait for around 15minutes-ish. It was a really cold saturday afternoon. Finally we got it and We ordered katanaya ramen(which is the most complete one). I ordered with miso base and my friend with soy base.
My friend said she prefers mine and I prefer hers -_-.... It was only okay.. Nothing special and I don;t see why a lot of people want to wait so long for this ramen if they already had it once..
The portion is HUGE and the service is really nice. I dont think I will be back here cuz I dont think it is worth it to wait that long and I think there are alot better ramen out there.
author: Diana A.

description: They also have good sushi!  They're cheaper the other ones in the area but just as good.  I was hesitant to try sushi at a ramen place, but I'm glad I did.
author: Alex T.

description:
Best ramen I've had in the city.

This is a tiny hole in the wall place and the wait is long on a weekend night, but I keep coming back because their ramen is that good.

I've tried their udon, Kimchi ramen, Katanaya ramen, and ramen + tonkatsu don combo (about $14?). A bowl of ramen will set you back about $10-12, which is pretty pricey, but you will leave feeling very full! You can choose salt, miso, or soy sauce flavor for the ramen broth. I usually get salt, but i haven't tried any of the other flavors. Their geso karaage is really good too! (fried squid legs appetizer). 

Open until 1:30am, (last call for food at 1:15am), this is a good place to come for 4th meal, (if you don't mind the wait that is).
author: Jennifer C.

description:
We waited about an hour and a half to be seated in the restaurant and we arrived around 8pm.  Make sure you come early or late at night because their seems to usually be a pretty big waiting list around dinner time. 

I got the spicy green onion ramen and the Golden roll.  The ramen was good.  Wasn't the best I have ever had but it wasn't the worst I have ever had either.  Nothing about the flavor really stood out to me.  One thing that I did like was that the broth was a lot lighter than other ramen places like Orenchi.  I actually thought the Golden Roll was really good and well prepared.  It had what I think was a thin tempura lining on the outside of the roll which made it taste absolutely great! 

What I thought was odd that some customers inside the restaurant didn't even order ramen! This place is known for ramen right?  You are going to wait an hour and a half to eat at this place and just get a sushi roll?  Might as well have gone to a sushi restaurant!
author: Murt S.

description:
Delicious Pho. 
Come in at off hours and you don't have to wait in line on the street. I got veggie miso pho. It was the perfect thing for a cold day.
The service was really friendly too (I noticed other reviewers didn't think so). Not sure about that, maybe they were expecting a foot massage whilst they slurped their pho.
author: Lark M.

description: The ramen is normal as other places. I got the miso lamen medium spicy as always and it was pretty tasty. The line was not bad when I got there for lunch around 12:30 on a Saturday. But every time I past by there is line. It is worth to try the place at least once ;)
author: Kim K.

description:
Thanks Aaron for showing me this place!

I never had Ramen before, that didn't come in a cup and required me to add hot water.

As expected from the many reviews of ramen that i've read here, it was a hit.

Headed down here for lunch a few days ago and got the deep fried chicken ramen in miso broth. 

The chicken was cooked perfectly but i felt like there could be more of it.

The noodles were good and the broth was delicious. I cant wait to check out more ramen places and compare as well as return to Katana-Ya.
author: Oleg H.

description:
I thought it was more like a 3.5, but husband gives it a solid 3.  I had the Katanaya ramen, miso style.  It was really salty and the broth wasn't complex.  The egg and goyza were fine, but the fried chicken was fairly tasteless.  The noodles were chewy.  Husband had the BBQ ramen, he thought the pork was tough but the broth and noodles were good.  The space is small and cramped, which is ok but makes for a long wait outside, there's no lobby.  When you walk up put yourself on the list outside out the door.  They did get our party of 5 in fairly quickly, but we were there at about 4:15 pm, not peak dining time.  The older woman was very pleasant, apologized for the tempura ramen being brought to the table much sooner than the other dishes, which resulted in a soggy tempura dish for my brother in law.  The other 4 dishes came out about 15 or 20 min later, almost all together.  

I know this place is supposed to be the BEST ramen place, but I like Maruichi in South Bay better.  I had better ramen in a hole in the wall no rated shop in the middle of Shimbashi in Tokyo.  I don't get why this place is revered.  Maybe it was an off day.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Talk about a wonderful bowl of Ramen. I went to Katana with two others my little sister and my boyfriend. There was a wait outside to get a table in this tiny Ramen Noodle place. But I don't mind waiting, The longer people are willing to wait the better the food. We waited about twenty minutes and during the twenty minutes the door would open and close letting the smell of warm Ramen broth sneak out and tease you. 

When we got in and sat down the scent changed. The scent then become musty and dank, like sweaty people were crammed in this tiny room to eat Ramen. Sweaty Ramen?? Anyway, we started with the pot stickers and they were delicious!! Then we all got different Ramen, My Boyfriend got the BBQ Pork, my sister the spicy and I the cilantro. The bowls were gigantic!  They were all delicious, but the spicy Ramen was by far the best (if you into that sorta thing). All and all the food was delicious, servers were short but all in all nice. I would recommend going, it is delicious and evenly priced for what you are getting.
author: Diana L.

description:
Good chewy ramen without the heavy and oily aftertaste like the some of the other ramen I've had. We've attempted to eat here before but did not have the patience to wait their long wait. But today, we arrived in between lunch and dinner and the place wasn't even halfway filled. 
I tried the kimchi ramen in the soy broth but I'd wished I ordered the miso broth as hubs ordered it and I got to have a taste. Tasty!
Parking in this part of the city is no bueno. But lucky for us we found parking a block away and did not have to wait to be seated. All in all a fast, cheap and decent lunch. Next time we are going to have to try their sushi.
author: Esther A.

description:
A must try for ramen!!  The best I've had yet in the City.
Dont let the line scare you.  Definitely worth the wait!!  Actually only waited less than 15 minutes. 

The portions are HUGE!    We had the Spicy Tofu (medium, regular miso, soba noodles) and the Fried Chicken (medium, regular miso, ramen noodles).  Both were super yummy!  The Spicy Tofu was just what the doctor ordered for my stuffy nose and sore throat!!

The Saki is HOT, but drink fast because it gets cold quickly!  Probably better to order the smaller size so that you always have it freshly heated.  

The staff is friendly and the coziness is quaint. 

By the way...they serve Sushi too!!  We didn't order any, but from the tables around us that did, it looked really good!
author: Deb T.

description: Haven't had many ramen places yet but this is one of the best!  Be prepared for a wait but totally worth it.  Small restaurant so it'll be a little cozy.  We had Katana-Ya 2 nights in a row so it must be that good!  First night, my husband and I had our own bowls of the Katana that had everything in it - including 2 fried potstickers! Delicious but OMG we were both so full.  The next night, we were out late dancing and Katana-Ya was one of very few restaurants still open at 1 AM so we gave it another try.  This time we shared a bowl of Katana and seaweed salad - that was the perfect portion.
author: Linh T.

description:
I've been to Katana-Ya before but never found myself to review it previously. I do have to agree that it is overrated with inflated-praise by 7x7. This place is authentic but Genki Ramen (inner richmond district) does a better job at execution, flavor, value, and presentation.

I went with a friend at 5pm yesterday and there were many vacant tables. I felt a bit rushed as the waiter kept asking if we were ready and peered at us from the cashier counter. There are a lot of options on the menu and I had a hard time deciding between just ramen or the combinations. I eat a lot so I was definitely looking at the combos more but for $14, I could get 2 full boxes of kimchi fried rice. I have to watch my weight too so I didn't go for any meats in my ramen. Ended up with spicy green onion ramen with lite density miso soup. Lite density soup has less fat.

The wait was a little less than 10 minutes. I took one look and I was a bit sad that I didn't order meat. It was just too simple for $9.80 worth of a meal. The "spicy" is just a spoonful of Chinese chili sauce found at Asian restaurants (NOT Sriracha). The miso broth was alright but I've had better. It's probably not standard in Japan but I wanted corn in my ramen. I didn't take too long to finish it either. I wanted to order sushi but I felt the need to conserve my money for better things. I'll come back to try other things but somehow I need a recharge if I return to be reminded not to get basic ramen.
author: Dominic T.

description:
If you've been looking for a really good ramen place then search no more because Katana-Ya has it. 
I would order some right now, Bart it for my lunch break but I don't have the energy to do it today. 
This review is based on ordering for pick up only. I was always able to get through over the phone, order what I'd like and have it ready by the time I get there. This place always seems to be packed everytime I do go but maybe one of these days, I will eat in. 
The only thing that sucks is that they do not have a to go menu! How did I know what to order over the phone you say? Well my ever so helpful food adventurer sister told me to try the Katana-Ya special with miso broth and I've been getting that ever since. It is a little pricey but so worth it. Rain or shine, I'd get their ramen anytime(",)
author: Anna P.

description:
My favorite is the miso ramen with chicken karaage on the side. The broth has a lot of depth and flavors. The noodle is cooked perfectly. 
The restaurant itself isn't that large, so there is a little wait time.
author: Connie M.

description:
I'm ridiculously undecisive when it comes to food, but when it's rainy, I'm definitely in the mood for noodle soup!! (or korean bbq, or pasta, or.... the list goes on haha)

So I was headed towards the Bay Bridge on this RIDICULOUSLY rainy day... then I decided it was too rainy and I was hungry so I opened up Yelp on my phone and found Katana-Ya. :) After a few drives around the block we finally found parking and spotted a crowd gathered in front. People are waiting?? The food must be good. So foodie friend and I waited out in the rain where I stared at the menu for a good 15+ minutes, and when we got seated, I continued to stare at it. There were so many possible combinations of stuff, and the inside menu had even more things listed !! I ended up ordering a normal ramen... I think it was #1, salt flavor. I also ordered a pork katsu, BUT IT NEVER SHOWED UP !! Good thing though, because I was way too full off my soup. So anyway, the noodles were nice and fresh tasting, but my salty broth... omg SO SALTY that the MEAT tasted like salt. I know, my own fault for ordering salt flavor, but I'm not too fond of miso or soy sauce and I usually LOVE oversalting my food. Oh and that super salty piece of meat I mentioned? It was tiny. :( I don't remember what else was in my bowl because there really wasn't much else. I mooched some of my bf's spicy tuna roll which was too spicy for me too :( Overall, food was okay, my friends seem to like it, definitely bummed about my forgotten order though (and yes, I checked with them, it was definitely ordered... just lost somewhere along the way....)
author: Christine L.

description: This little shop reminds me of the ramen shops in Tokyo! Very cozy and hopping! Be sure to come early because this place is well-known. As a single diner I only had to wait 5 minutes for a seat at the sushi bar. I had their ramen special: Katanaya Ramen! Totally worth it!
author: Joanie R.

description: Supposedly the best. Veggie ramen's tough, but they have the option, so I'll give them credit for that.
author: Dimple B.

description:
Miso EXTRA spicy Ramen with BBQ pork! Im surprised Katanaya doesnt even have four stars. Maybe because the place is too small?

That's what I have every freaking time. Been here a few times already but first time visit while I am sober and not tired. Since it's right next to Ruby Skye, we come a lot after clubbing or even in between. It's ALWAYS packed but the food is too good to not wait.

Thumb up. Double. Love this place.
author: Hailey K.

description: I got the shoyu ramen with pork chaashuu and a tuna/salmon bowl. I was pretty underwhelmed by the ramen. It wasn't distinctive in taste and it didn't differentiate itself from any of the other ramen places you can find in San Francisco. I am also from Japan so I'm very picky about my ramen. However, what is great about this place is that it's cheap and the portions are huge. You definitely won't leave hungry!
author: Hana K.

description:
Yummmmmm!!
This Thai food was great. We had Som Tam and the vegetarian Pad Grep Pow.
Both were really authentic tasting. Some of the best Thai food I have had in the US.
Obviously they use fresh Thai ingredients.
The prices are amazing.
The place is pretty small and I can imagine there could often be a wait.
author: Holly M.

description: I got the Katana-Ya Ramen with miso base (made spicy). I thought it was pretty good. I did not like that the egg was hard boiled, that did nothing for the dish (if the egg were still runny that would have been amazing). Also, the pork was pretty bland.  there were some great elements, the miso base was good. The spice was not very spicy but was definitely noticeable. I would try the extra spicy next time.  Everything else in the dish was really great.  i would eat here again if I were in the neighborhood, but I would not travel any distance to eat here.
author: R M.

description: This place was recommended to my wife and I by some locals when we were on vacation. It is literally a hole in the wall. Not much seating so my wife and I ate at the bar, but I enjoyed the intimacy of it. I ordered the extra spicy Katana-Ya ramen and the Lava Flow roll, then washed it all down with Sapporo. If I was rating it on food alone I would give it five stars, but do to the lack of seating I knocked it down a star. Other people might complain about the crappy parking, but what do you expect in San Francisco?
author: Rey M.

description:
I was really lucky, and came before the rush.  We had a party of 5 and were seated immediately, but it looked like most people had to wait outside because the restaurant was really small. I ordered the sukiyaki don, and thought it tasted okay.  It was really big, and was served with a lot of meat and rice, but too little egg and tofu.  It came with a miso soup too, which was so salty that I couldn't even finish it .  I didn't try their ramen though, which is what they're known for, so maybe I didn't get the best that they could offer. My friends ordered the soba, udon, and spicy seafood, but no one was particularly impressed with the food, and was mediocre at best.

The service was okay, up until they started rushing us to leave.  My friend was still working on his food, and they came by twice to ask if they could clear it. I think it's because people were waiting outside, but it made us feel like they were really trying to kick us out.
author: Jenny H.

description:
Probably one of the better Ramen joints I've been to in SF but still just okay for me. 

Lines are almost always long during peak hours so you may have to wait a while. You write your name down on a sheet of paper and they'll call you as the table is ready. The place is TINY so if you have a big party, this is not the place for you. We had a party of 4 once and we got cramped into a tiny corner with barely any room to move. 

Now on to the food. Overall, a-ok. The Katanaya ramen with miso broth is my go to. The karaage chicken and gyoza in the ramen is a winner for me - also something unique that other ramen places don't have. The broth itself is not bad, but not great. They do give you a pretty hefty portion of food so be forewarned. I can never finish a whole bowl of their ramen. 

Sushi was.. mediocre. There are SO many great sushi joints in the city that I definitely wouldn't waste your money or calorie on the ones here. 

If you really must try this place, get the ramen and stick to that. They have a pretty neat combo thing that lets you have your ramen with a small side of something for an extra amount of money. It's usually too much food but you could go that route if you are sharing with someone.

I'll come back if I'm craving ramen really badly, but only because there's not too many ramen joints in the city and I sure can't make my own ramen (not one that is delicious anyways).
author: Ashley V.

description: It's always such a letdown when you wait outside in the freezing cold for an hour just to be seated and eat the best bowl of Ramen of your life, only it's not the best bowl of Ramen. It's not even close. Service was okay. Seating was slightly uncomfortable. But I came here based on all the wonderful yelp reviews only to be severely disappointed. I got the house special miso Ramen. The hard-boiled egg was too overcooked, The fried pork was fatty but not in a good way, and the fried Gyoza that they put on top just gets soggy in the broth so it becomes more of a chewy wonton. Broth= worst part. On the upside it had a trendy ambience.
author: Kazzi F.

description:
I thought the ramen here was just average.

The location is convenient to Union Square area & it's comfort food on a cold, rainy day.

Compared to the rest of the foods we tried in SF, this was the least memorable.  Maybe it's because we have so many good ramen shops in Hawaii?
author: Lori F.

description: The best ramen I've ever had! I got the Katanaya! The portions are big. This place gets pretty busy.
author: Angela C.

description:
Sushi AND ramen? best combination ever. Would recommend coming here with 1 or 2 people. this place is tiny, and you'd be waiting forever and a decade if you came with a bigger party. The service was really fast though, my friend and I decided to share a bowl of ramen, and try the sushi selection they have there too. We were not disappointed...it was so good. 

We decided to go with the miso regular ramen, the noodles were the perfect texture, and the BROTH! oh gosh the broth is so good. I'm a stickler for not-too-salty broth, and this was just right. I wish it had more veggies or an egg in the ramen, but it came with just chatsu pork and bamboo. 

I also recommend the Shiromaguro tataki appetizer (albacore). it's melt in your mouth delicious. 

Next time I want to try the Katana ya ramen, it has really odd things in it though, so I was hesitant. it has corn, fried potstickers, chicken wings, and pork in it. That's so random right?

I'll be back Katana! thanks for the great meal.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Katana-ya sounds like a karate chop. Seriously. It does.

I'll keep this review sweet & simple by using the 5 W's: what, why, where, when, and well!

*What? Katana-ya advertises itself as the best ramen spot out there. Really now!? Says who?

*Why? It's backed by SF's 7x7 list of 100 places to dine before you die. I must admit, I was curious about their chasu ramen ($10.50).

*Where? It's located a few blocks up from the Powell Bart station on Geary & Mason, near Ruby Skye and the American Conservatory Theater.

*When? We went for lunch, of course. They open right at 11:30AM and I hear it gets pretty crowded. The crowd usually results positively in most cases. However, in this case I think it was crowded because the spot is so small & cramped.

*Well? Worth the lunch rush from FIDI to Union Square? No. I absolutely LOVE soup, all kinds of soup even. However, the chasu ramen was satisfactory. The chasu (bbq pork) was tender, but didn't differentiate from any other pork out there. The miso flavor was a little too salty for my taste. There weren't very many vegetables which I LOVE, only a bit of spinach from what I remember. 

Recommended by a fellow Yelper, the Agedashi Tofu ($6) appetizer was a hit. It was really, really good. Honestly, although it's my favorite it's ALWAYS served good anywhere you go. So, no points earned for that dish. 

Bottom line: If you're in the area, sure give this spot a try. However, I didn't think it was worth the trek from Howard/Beale to Bart to Union Square and back for the food offered... even if it did make the 7x7 list.
author: Joy A.

description:
My first experience at Katana-Ya was heavenly and I have been craving it ever since, but after my second time going, I don't know if I'll ever be going back?  It was just decent.  Maybe there were other variables involved that made it not the best experience that gave me a cynical perspective.

The waiters were pretty rude and not very attentive in giving good service, which is extremely important to me.  I was constantly working to get their attention and even though they didn't have much to do I could tell they were doing their best to ignore me.  We were simply trying to order after waiting patiently outside for 30 minutes and then waiting at the table for another 10 minutes.  

The food came out and of course it was tasty.  The broth is delicious and the noodles are pretty heavenly I'm not gonna lie so I forgave them.  But then later on had to wait like 20 minutes just to pay the bill.  It was especially annoying because they were so attentive to the people who were seated after us.  Didn't quite make sense, but it was annoying?  Did I say that already?

I would definitely recommend this place because it is quite delicious and somewhat of a must try place in San Francisco check it out, but keep the expectations low regarding the service.  But get your taste buds ready for wonderful deliciousness!

the Great,
GumZ
author: David C.

description:
Contrary to popular belief, the best thing about Hawaii isn't the beaches or the sun. It's the ramen! (Well, for me anyway. I'm not ashamed to admit that I don't use umbrellas just for rain :P) On a recent trip there, I enjoyed some of the best ramen outside of Japan (4 times in 4 days!) I've been jonesing for a little taste of Hawaii in the form of expensive ramen since being back in SF and this craving brought me to Katana-Ya.

If it wasn't for 7x7, I don't think Katana-Ya would be as popular as it is. I came here for a friend date on a Thursday night at 7. With about 14 tables ahead of us, we waited outside for almost an hour. Patience is not one of my virtues, so if I have to wait that long for dinner, it'd better be worth it.

Though known for their ramen (again, all thanks to 7x7), they also serve a variety of appetizers, sushi, sashimi, and donburi. We ordered a uni ikura don, a small kimchee fried rice, and a katanaya ramen to share.

The UNI IKURA DON (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=D6sYiq8_tLxiFoE422YZPQ) was incredible! The ingredients were so fresh. Mixed together, the dish was definitely greater than the sum of its parts. The creaminess of the uni, the pop of the ikura, the brininess of both, and the not-too-vinegary rice combined in perfect harmony. All the flavours were balanced with nothing overpowering anything else. I also really liked the KIMCHEE FRIED RICE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=1nY3aiDFTjl37rdWneP3Gw) and thought it had great flavours. I just wish it wasn't so greasy. 

As for the ramen, though the noodles were cooked just right and the rich shio broth was delicious, I wasn't that impressed. We got the KATANAYA RAMEN (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=PHUPE83Ispl2eogm6dcmCA) since it came with a bit of everything (corn, fried chicken, fried potsticker, seaweed, bamboo, bbq pork, and egg). One of the reasons I like fried foods is the crispiness. But, putting fried foods in a bowl of broth only makes them soggy. Though the chicken was juicy and flavourful, I couldn't get over the mushy breading. I also wish they had more soup flavours than just shoyu, salt, and miso. That is to say, I wish they had my favourite tonkotsu broth. I'm a bit of a loyalist when it comes to this creamy pork bone broth!
author: Steph L.

description:
The best Ramen in town! Get the spicy ramen! Wait times are stupid long though (like, 45 minutes +). This place needs major investment to expand!

There used to be another Katana-Ya restaurant near UCSF, and I heard the chef was an ex-sumo wrestler from Japan. however, I think it closed down. Not sure why.... 
How I miss having 2 katana-ya's in the world....
author: Donato J.

description:
I was in SF all weekend for a conference and since Friday I was hearing all good things about an amazing little ramen shop two blocks away from my hotel. I knew I had to try!

I tried to go on Saturday for dinner, but the long wait and rainy weather made it unlikely.

I ended up there for early lunch on Sunday and there was amazingly no line! The ramen was quite pricey at about $13 for the Katanaya Ramen. The Katanaya Ramen came with corn, deep fried potstickers, charsui, half a hard-boiled egg, and deep fried chicken. It was a strange combo, but I wanted it because I wanted to try it all.

Anyways, the broth wasn't amazing to me. I actually prefer the broth of other ramen locations. The fried chicken was REALLY good! The potsticker was pretty standard.

It was a filling meal & good meal, but I'm not sure I would come back again.
author: Emily T.

description:
Its located in this little, dark space, with not much room to move around. I had to eat with my elbows pressed into my sides lest I stab my neighbor with my chopsticks. I got the Katana-ya ramen in miso, which is a huuuge bowl of yummy goodness that I food-coma'ed after finishing. It tastes like the real thing (I've had a good number of bowls of ramen when I was in Japan) and its at an okay price (~13).

Service is meh, so minus one star. The waitress was reluctant to seat us when we came in because we said that there was a small chance one more person might be joining us. We came right when it opened and there were empty tables and another party who was waiting for their partner. Also, the waitresses were clearly judging us as our party of four was taking a bit too long to split the bill.

Tip: Come early, just after it opens to snag a seat without waiting for long.
author: Frances L.

description:
Katana-Ya has some of the best ramen in SF, but I would rank Santa in San Mateo and Maru Ichi in Mountain View ever so slightly (and I mean by a hair) higher when making a comparison of ramen restaurants around the Bay Area.

Standing in line at the theatre box office, I was so happy to see that one of the places on my list of restaurants to try was just across the street!  However seeing all the people waiting outside for the place to open had me worried, but we were prepared for a wait..  Luckily our timing was just right and our wait was no more than 10 minutes.  

I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen with a light miso broth, which comes with two pieces of fried chicken, two gyozas, two slices of pork, corn, seaweed, green onions, bamboo shoots and half a hardboiled egg.  I would recommend this dish for a first time visit, especially if your heart is not already set on something specific.  There was a good balance of noodles to the other ingredients to the broth.  The ramen was good and still had a tiny bit of chew in them (perfect!).  The chicken and gyoza were freshly prepared and arrived hot and crispy.  The broth was good, but I felt it was missing something, as if it was one dimensional.   In addition, I do wish the broth could have been hotter; it was at an adequate temperature, but I prefer the broth for my soup noodles to be HOT, as in almost boiling.  I've had better, but is it fair for me to compare it to the ramen I've had in Tokyo?   

They have a pretty comprehensive menu of sushi, noodles (ramen, udon, soba) and combo items with ramen and rice bowls (e.g. fish, curry, katsu, etc.).  During this visit almost every table had ordered noodles.

The place is small.  During our visit, there was always a small line outside.  When you arrive sign your name up on the list, even if you wish to sit at the bar.  Tables are placed close together and seating is farily  cramped.  This would not be a place to bring a large party.  However, the service more than made up for this.  I found the staff to be somewhat friendly and very efficient.  Our water and tea were brought to us immediately and often refilled without our having to ask.  Our waitress made sure that we had everything we needed.  No complaints at all, especially given the packed house.

I definitely recommend the ramen here and am looking forward to future trips to try the other items on their menu.  Remember, slurping is a-okay here!
author: Melissa L.

description:
Came here at 7.30 on a Saturday for a table of 4. There were only 4 names above us, who would've known, we'd still have to wait over 30 minutes in the cold? At least it wasn't raining! and we later found out there are actually 3 seats inside! 

Regardless, right after we got seated in these cramped seats, our hot tea came lightening fast. 4 orders of katana-ya special, however they got confused with one of the order and it was the regular ramen.

The agedashi tofu which was highly recommended was pretty good. It does get soggy fast, but it was super hot when it came! Swimming in a sea of soy-mix sauce, topped with green onions. crispy on the outside, melts in your mouth on the inside. Be sure to get the sauce everywhere or it could be somewhat plain.

I got the spicy miso. barely spicy but broth was pretty delicious. not too salty but full of flavour. The ramen was al dente and not soggy. They only gave 2 pieces of char siu, 2 pieces of popcorn chicken, 2 gyoza, some corn, bamboo shoots, seaweed, half an egg. Portions were not very big, especially for the hefty price of $12.50! I did leave satisfied, however the regular ramen only came with like 2 pieces of char siu. so Definitely not filling at all.

It's good ramen, but I've had similar for nearly half the price in LA. The wait is also pretty ridiculous for so few names. 

***

Tips: Don't be fooled by the lack of names above you! your wait will exceed 30 minutes during a weekend dinner time! Ramen portions are relatively small, so be sure to at least share an appetiser or get the set!

Favourites: Nice ramen texture, flavourful broth

Do not want: Slow wait, small portions, pricey.

Last words: Definitely one of the better ramens i've had. though i've had cheaper quality ramen.
author: Celine L.

description:
Ahhh I was craving ramen so freaking bad. Pretty decent, portions are huge (highly recommend sharing a combo), and they have other Japanese items too. #12 is my go-to bowl of everything in one. 

Downside is a bit salty, heavy on MSG, and a bit overpriced for a bowl of ramen. Expect a wait but not bad if you get there early on a weeknight for a party of two (around 6pm).

I'm really disappointed that I couldn't finish a bowl on my own. Shame on me.
author: Annie L.

description:
Stumbled upon this place looking for a quick lunch and it was probably the best thing that could have happened to us.  We found the best ramen we've ever had.  It was so good we came back for lunch the next day.

Regular Ramen with Miso:  BF had this and thought it was great.  It comes with a slice or pork, some seaweed and green onions. 

Salmon donburi:  BF loves salmon and thought the size was the perfect portion to get some sashimi in.

Vegetable Ramen with shoyu:  Clean and sweet tasting, I added a little white pepper and chili powder and it had just the zing I like with my food.  I felt warm and happy after this meal.

Spicy tofu Ramen with Miso:  My favorite so far, with spicy broth, chunks of soft, white tofu, and kimchi and green onions to jazz it up a little.  The ramen noodles are perfect texture.

Avo-kyu Temaki with Cream Cheese:  It's what I like to eat after a race.  I really like the sushi rice here.  

Service:  Fantastic and friendly Japanese ladies that are quick with the food and your check.  Always filled our waters and checked to make sure everything was okay.

Overall:  This place obviously doesn't have a problem getting customers because every time we are here there is a line out the door.  It's because they have great ramen!
author: Matty K.

description: Came in for a to go order after trying to call for 45 minutes and no one answered the phone. The woman who took my order told me the bag fee was .25, which rubbed me the wrong way as I live a block away and know for a fact its .10. I feel that bag fee is just another attempt to literally nickle and dime San Franciscans...to hear someone trying to make more money off a bag fee that already strikes me as being borderline theft is too much. I told her that I live in the city and know exactly what the fee is. She shrugged. I told her she lost my business (at least 4 times a month) and again, shrug. Very petty and extremely disrespectful. Try Fujiyoshi a few blocks away, it has way more room and the staff is ultra polite.
author: Michael G.

description: Went for lunch and the food wasn't good at all for what I paid. The sushi was pre made and the roman hand nothing in it but some noodles. I was better of having a cup of noodles. The servers were okay but the amount of time I spent actually talking to them isn't a very good example on how good their serves was. Over all the place wasn't good and I still have no idea why it's such a big deal.
author: Antonio C.

description:
Yummy Ramen in SF! Rare!  

Ordered the fried chicken ramen and the cold ramen.  Both of them were yum!  We ordered other side dishes too.  Just order those two - can't go wrong!
author: Deb L.

description:
I'm sure everyone says this place has great ramen, but I loved the udon A LOT more!

The prices for their combinations vary and can get pretty expensive for ramen. The menu was a little confusing and looks strange. They have the different sides you can have with your ramen/udon and the different broths. I'm not sure how many combinations they have, but it's a lot. 

I ordered the ramen with the fried rice on the side. I liked how thick the noodles were, but there was not unique or special to me about it. I actually preferred my fried rice more. 

My cousin let me try her udon and I fell in love. The miso broth was perfect. Just enough miso without being too salty. The noodles were soft and thick. There was so much that both she and I could not finish it. I wish I ordered the udon. 

This place is pretty small so be prepared to wait outside. Also I wouldn't even try to fit a group of more than four in here. We went with five and took up the whole bar since they couldn't get a table for us right away. 

Bottom line: They may be known for ramen, but the udon is also a fabulous dish!
author: Hang T.

description:
The ramen from here was just "meh". Judging from the pictures the ramen looked delicious, and I couldn't wait to dig in. The flavor however, left a lot to be desired. Maybe I need to be Asian to truly appreciate the blandness of the soup. Anyhow, I ordered the green onion or something with an addition of the spicy seasoning. 

I think I took four sips before I decided I was done :(  I then focused my attention to the rose flavored sake that the waitress suggested to us. We arrived there pretty late, and there was a group of six waiting to get in that parked themselves half an inch away from where I was eating :-| The sushi there is also of equal quality as their soup. Maybe ill try it again cause I really want to like this place, the ambiance and attentive waitstaff would be reason enough to give them another go.
author: Sab O.

description:
I love the ramen here! I usually get the 'regular' miso ramen, which comes with chasu and bamboo shoots, and request for it to be spicy. The broth is very flavorful, maybe a little too rich for me, but they offer "light" and "rich" options too. I love the consistency of the noodles!

There are also a bunch of combos you can get if you order the regular ramen. My friend and I shared a spicy tuna roll the last time we were here, and found that it was spicier than most we've had, which made me happy since I love spicy food. But that made me wonder how spicy their "super spicy roll" must be...

The restaurant is tiny, but I've been here about 3 or 4 times, and haven't had any trouble getting seated right away. I would recommend coming just slightly before 'typical' meal hours to avoid the crowd!
author: Ju J.

description:
The WORSE service ever by this Asian lady at the night shift! 
I have ordered their Katsu curry like a million times！but today what a disappointed service!the waitress gave me the wrong order twice!!!!firstly she wasn't welcome us or anything , then she doesn't even know what is "Katsu curry" and she told me they don't have such a thing!instead of that she gave me a tongkatsu?!

After she brought the second"wrong"order which is only curry！ I have to say something about it. But she keeps arguing with me while I want to eat!!she was really rude and unprofessional! She didn't even apologize of messing up our orders. And it made me NEVERd want to go back again!
author: Catherine W.

description:
After about my fifth attempt i FINALLLY got a table at this place.  I always get there late when it packed or about to close.  This place is really small but I LOOOOOOOVED THE RAMEN HERE! 

I got the butter corn ramen.  Broth was really flavorful, a little on the heavier side - hence the butter.  

Next time however, I'm going to get the spicy green onion broth!  It's super flavorful with a more simple/lighter taste than the butter corn. 

I love this place because the noodles taste so fresh and have a nice texture to them.
author: Christine N.

description:
3 and a half stars. 

I've been here twice now and both times were pretty good. I'll review the ramen since I just had it last night and can remember. I had the spicy broth which was actually spicy and quite I. The only gripe I had was that the pork wasn't very good. It wasn't fatty at all and very rough in texture.

It's a very small place but has a good vibe to it. Overall I'd recommend trying the place out since then  aren't that many good ramen places in sf, especially ones that are open late.
author: William L.

description: The only good thing about this restaurant is because its cheap but taste so ordinary and do not meet expectations.
author: Evander J.

description:
I don't know, Good but not crazy good is my experience with ramen here. I am comparing it to LA ramen. 

I had the katanaya ramen aka the ramen with all the crap in it. It's ramen with fried chicken, potstickers, boiled egg, seaweed, bamboo shoots, chasu, corn, and I don't know what else. I liked the flavor of the miso broth, the lightness of the chasu and the bouncy texture of the noodles. The egg could have used more flavor. The potsticker was a bit too fried for me but I did like the taste of the filling. The fried chicken was also a bit too fried. I think the potstickers and the chicken were just average and really didn't bring any value add to the ramen. Sometimes simple is best. 

This place is not good for larger parties. We had a party of 5 and it took forever to get a table. 2 is best for quick in and out.
author: Minda w.

description:
OH. MY.

If I could eat at this place 5 days a week... I WOULD. Never had "Ramen" before and was a little more then apprehensive (the pictures on the menu DID NOT do the food justice). Katana Ya was pretty much across from the hotel I was staying at in SF and it was also open super late. I think I walked by 20 different times and there was ALWAYS a line out front. Day and night this spot has a line- that to me, is a good sign...  Upon entering, I noticed that the place in its entirety was as big as my closet. Seriously. People were cram packed into the smallest space but! It was cozy and smelled wonderful... Bring on the ramen! Several dishes were tried but the only one that I'm still dreaming about and think I'm addicted to, is the deep fried chicken ramen. I know, I now, it sounds disgusting, believe me, it LOOKS disgusting but WOW. Its one of the BEST things I have EVER eaten. 

This is one of my new fav spots in SF- tiny, tiny hole in the wall sure. You would never know it just by looking at the menu, but this place KNOWS what they're doin. Mmm Mmm Mmm... D.E.L.I.C.I.O.U.S.
author: MsMichele P.

description: It was okay the broth was not very flavorful. I read the other reviews and was super excited about trying this place. My husband had two bites and couldn't proceed. I feel their prices are not comparable to quality. If you look at my other ratings in pretty generous. I just can't be here.
author: Ginger M.

description:
During my visit to SF, my old roommate took me here for dinner since this is one place she eats at often. 

Their miso ramen makes me almost wish I never had to go back home. This was the perfect dinner since it made up for the windy & cold weather I am not used to this time of the year.
author: Debs C.

description: There was a fly - an actual fly - in our soup. We complained, and they didn't seem all that surprised. They charged us for the rest of our meal as well. Yuck!
author: Azhar S.

description: The 49ers suck, the 49er roll that is. Too many salmon eggs, it's like they also have a salmon sperm bank. Lose your appetite yet? Go on to the next place
author: Yonus A.

description: One of the worst ramen places I have ever been to.. Bad taste and expensive food combined with poor service. Was surprise to see in the bill that a hole in the wall restaurant will charge $6 for small glass of beer. Food made me feel sick. BIG ZERO
author: Karuneek A.

description:
For this review, this is where I wish Yelp would give us more allowance on the number of stars given. In this case, I'll round up to 4 stars although I think this place earns a solid 3.5 stars.

Be warned, this place is tiny and there will be most likely a 30 minute to 1 hour wait until you're even seated. As soon as you find the place, have a friend sign you in on the waiting list while the other parks the car.

As for the ramen, it's great here! The broth is nicely done, the meat is tender, and the noodles are executed properly. I will say this, I've experienced better ramen in NYC, but this place was still fulfilling! I thought all the ramens I tried were full of flavor, especially the Katanaya ramen -- highly recommended! 

BBQ Pork Ramen - 3/5
Deep Fried Chicken Ramen - 3.5/5
Katanaya Ramen - 4/5 (includes the fried chicken + BBQ pork)

The deep fried chicken ramen is wonderful! You would think that the crispiness of the chicken would be soggy in the soup, but it holds nicely together it adds great texture and flavor.
author: Luigi C.

description:
As a ramen fan, I knew this was a popular spot, but I didn't have high hopes. It was just a little less "good" than I had expected.

Straight off the bat, I'm just going to say that I'm not really comparing this to great ramen I've had in the South Bay and in New York. I quickly realized the noodles didn't have the chewy consistency I prefer, so instead of being disappointed, I decided to change my standards instead.

So, by approaching this simply as a bowl of normal noodle soup, it was solid. Spicy tofu and kimchi are wonderful with anything, so that made me happy.

Overall, a good choice on a cold Union Square Saturday outing.
author: Jeena C.

description:
I'm slowly trying to check off items on the 7x7 list.  Came by for lunch one day and made it just before the rush.  

We ordered the spicy salmon and spicy scallop rolls.  Then we both got the Katanaya Ramen.  The rolls were ok.  We mainly got them because we weren't sure if the ramen was going to fill us up.  The ramen was quite good and filling....perfect for a cold day.  There was so much to eat....potstickers, fried chicken, bbq pork, egg, bamboo shoots and corn.  The noodles were nice and chewy and the broth was seasoned just right.  

The place is really tiny, so make sure you go early to beat the lunch rush.  They're open late, too, so you get can your ramen fix until 1am!
author: Patra I.

description:
Frankly.. I am obsessed with this place. I stumbled on it by circumstance last year - a choice recommendation from a doorman at the nearby Hilton who basically said that is where he would eat if looking for Ramen. I figured what the heck? I loved it so much I made three visits on that trip. Ramen 2x, sushi 1x. Sushi was good, but the Ramen.. ahhhh... some of the best I've ever had. Now, I schedule my visits to San Fran around a visit here. 

OK.. it's a little small and cramped.. and the wait can be a little nutty.. but the Ramen is worth it. Seriously. I like the extra spicy with the miso broth - yep, bring on the spice. Totally makes you sweat! I've never been able to finish the whole bowl, more due to getting full than the spice, but an hour or two after I leave I am ready for more. I've sent others here and brought a group on a recent outing, and they've all loved it as well. Bottom line, you can't go wrong. It's not just Yelp hype.
author: Stephanie P.

description: I take my ramen very seriously and when I heard about Katana-Ya, I said YES, I will try it. Its a cute little hole in the wall with friendly staff and super busy on late-nights. I got the the pork -noodle spicy ramen. My thing with ramen is the thicker the better, I specifically asked for it to be thick but why was it just plain MISO?! STRIKE 1. Then it wasn't even spicy! STRIKE 2. Portions are big and it's no doubt tasty but I've definitely experienced better. Luckily no strike 3, so maybe I'll come back if I have a midnight craving of watered down miso ramen.....oops!
author: Caye Q.

description: The space is super small, we need to sit very close to each other.  The sushi is ok, the ramen is big size but the noodle to soft, the server very nice
author: Auntie L.

description: Come here for decent ramen.  Don't eat anything else.  It will be all good.
author: Byron L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night for dinner around 7pm. Had to wait over an hour. Thought the wait would be worth it cause everyone raved about this being the best ramen house around. Once we got in we discovered the place was so tiny and squished. No wonder it's such a long wait, barely room for anyone. So waiting outside for so long, we figured out what we wanted already. Got the katanaya ramen that pretty much had everything in it with the miso soup base. It was pretty good. But for some reason I can't get over the fact that a fifty cent ramen packet taste so similar. Only difference is the side dishes like the fried chicken and the corn and pot stickers. I love shin ramen, that spicy Korean ramen in the red package. Mmm. Anyways, it was decent. Not sure if
I'd come again for another hour wait in the cold.
author: Matthew G.

description:
Ramen ramen ramen! I think I am in a ramen phase right now. I crave it all the time and always want something warm to eat with this cold weather! This place was pretty crowded when I came here and I had to put my name on the wait list. Luckily it wasn't that cold outside so I didn't mind waiting. 

When I finally was seated the menu was so overwhelming! I guess it is because I wanted to try all of the different soup bases and confused about the density that they had on the menu. I like that you can order Ramen and a donburi for an extra $3 bucks. 

The ramen noodles were super FRESH! I felt like it was homemade or something and was so satisfied after eating my BBQ Pork Ramen noodles. The only negative thing about this place is that it is so cramped in here. Otherwise if you're willing to wait to be seated and willing to sit in a small area for one meal, I definitely suggest going here for Ramen. You won't regret it!
author: Katrina T.

description:
Katana-Ya is the only Ramen house that keeps me coming back,. seriously who would pay $15-$20 for a bowl of RAMEN?! 

ME , ME , ME,...

I order the same Ramen bowl every time I come in here, especially with the rich spicy miso soup base.  The ramen bowl comes with a slice of hard boiled egg, slices of pork, deep fried egg rolls and chicken karaage, topped with green onions and ramen noodles cooked to perfection.

When I bite into the noodles, they aren't soggy nor hard, but in between,.. 

Of all the times I had dine here, the soup base and the ramen noodles had been consistent.  THUMPS UP to that!!!   

You can easily miss the restaurant, if you're not specifically looking for Katana-ya.  The place is small and the tables are literally right next to each other, sometimes I catch myself eavesdropping on my neighbors conversation.  x_X  

You should also try to arrive before 6pm, because the dinner rush comes right after. 

If this place wasn't in downtown and so far from home,. I would def come here at least once a week.

Noodle Soup = great comfort food!
author: Chanel L.

description:
I'm from NY and we are lucky enough to have IPPUDO. I've went to tokyo and IPPUDO was still the best ramen place. So i am a bit biased as I've been blessed to have access to great ramen anytime. Katana ya had great reviews and I was expecting good ramen, close to what I'm used to. The broth was heartier than I've had at some places but it still wasn't enough flavor. I had the katanaya ramen and I give it to them that there were so many things in it! The potstickers were crispy and pretty delicious. There was also an egg, corn, chasu, beansprouts, seaweed...  All the other things in the bowl were subpar, including the noodles. Didn't seem that fresh.

Also had salmon sashimi which was sweet and fresh. Also had some rolls that had too much rice on the outside (kind of a petpeeve of mine)

If you are a ramen lover, you must try IPPUDO in NYC east village or in Tokyo
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Katana-Ya remains my go-to place for ramen in San Francisco. I've easily been here a dozen times. Su-Zu is pretty darn good too, but there's something about Katana-Ya's bustling street location and thumping music... 

I usually stick with the regular ramen (miso / light) with extra noodles. Most of the time when a dining companion orders something else like katsu or udon, the response is that they should have chosen ramen.

Order the ramen. It's simple. Be prepared for a wait at prime hours, though the shop has opened some dining space for larger parties in the basement.
author: Randy M.

description: This used to be one of my favorite places to dine.  I didn't mind the waits.  Since they changed ownership I have to say that both the quality of the ramen and especially the service has gone downhill.  They don't care about customer service and won't pick-up their phone for orders even during non-peak hours when they are not busy.  Do not be deceived by their past reputation.
author: Bobby N.

description:
This place has a LINE. One time I ran from Macy's just to put my name on the list at 6pm so we could scarf down ramen before heading across the street to see some shows. Actually now that I mention it, this is my go-to pre-show place to eat. Conveniently across the street from ACT and the theater--can't remember what it's called that has SHN musicals. 

The go to thing here is ramen ramen ramen, but I've had friends order kare-rice. 

Great chicken karage, great miso soup base--just go with the combo if you're not vegetarian. 

This is NOT HK ramen--it's Japanese style--tiny little place with maybe 10 tables, so the line is out the door. Not unfounded, the soup is heavy and flavorful--I would say don't drink it all (for health reasons). They're pretty quick but if there's a huge line in front of you, may not be worth it depending on your time. Be ready to wait..even on a weekday. If you have the time, it'll be worth it!
author: Vivian C.

description: Not impressed. For warning, the wait for this place is always long (20+ minutes) yet I'm not sure why! I am an avid sushi eater and may be a harsh critic when it comes to asian food but I was bored with the flavors. Had the combos of the unagi rolls and the ramen. Both alone were very boring and nothing special. Had high expectations for this place considering the hype and they were definitely not met! Also, very upset with the customer service. I understand that being such a small place in high demand can put stress on the waitresses but bluntly saying the word "no" to a substitute request put a sour taste in my mouth about the place before I even got my food.
author: Alyssa P.

description:
This shop is small and opens pretty late. It's cute and cozy and the broth is savory and salty (as most ramen is). The noodles are soft with a good texture.

I had one of my first ramen experiences here (not counting instant ramen as an experience). I'd come back again though it is more expensive that what I'm used to paying for a noodle bowl.
author: Brenda L.

description:
Look.

I don't understand how in the world this place has been ranked so highly on the 7x7 list for ramen in the city. I can think of plenty of places around that can outrank the place in terms of food and ESPECIALLY the service. The only reason why I can even think of the possibility that it was on there was because it is located in Downtown and perhaps everybody just converges there after a night out of partying or shopping. I don't know. 

Even to this day, I felt like this place should NOT have deserved any form of tip. 

We noticed that there was a line outside the restaurant so we wanted to go inside to at least try and put our name down somewhere. Although the restaurant was kind of small, there were FOUR EMPTY tables around, and it took us at least five minutes for us to be noticed by the waiter and when he finally did, he shooed us off to the side without asking for our name. Finally we noticed the clipboard off to the side but the way the waiter was passing us off was extremely rude. 
After a few more minutes, slowly..all the parties on the waiting list are called in to fill up the remaining tables, including us. That is poor time management on their part. 

We felt pretty rushed to order so I decided to get the Katana-ya ramen with bbq pork. 
The ramen itself wasn't bad. Granted, the broth was flavorful but honestly, it reminded me of genki ramen except that genki ramen has a much better ambiance and friendlier staff. 

Once we got our orders, the waiter never went back to check on us, refill our waters and it took forever to try and chase him down with our bill. 
The only way we got noticed was when my boyfriend propped one of his legs up onto the empty chair across and the waiter noticed it and kicked the chair away from him without any word.  WHAT IS THIS?! Look. I can understand how that's not polite to be doing that in the restaurant but really now, you should've at least been polite about it, not to mention be COURTEOUS in the beginning and even then, the only reason why that was done in the first place was because we were bored to death waiting for YOU to come over and get the check.

UGH. The only reason why this place has two stars is that the ramen was semi decent. and even then, I would rather go somewhere else for it.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The ramen, and the extras, are all good; who knows if it's the best, but the variety was great, the location convenient to theater district (but plan on a wait), and the service inside was just fine, considering how crowded it always seems to be.  I've eaten in LA on Sawtelle,  San Jose's J-town, Sunnyvale, Redondo, and it's amazing the differences in style.    We had both miso and salt, and both were well balanced.  We also did the combo, so we had a katsu rice bowl, and a fish egg (salmon and sea urchin which was especially delicious). 

What is great is that you can sign up, figure on a half hour wait (so do some walking around), and get back in time to be served; once inside, it's bustling, but still relaxed and friendly.  Price is ok.
author: Gary Y.

description: RAMEN FOODIES STAY AWAY!!! Tourist trap!!! No No No...! Ramen miso tasted like sweet jasmine tea. Foodies beware!!! But if you are  hungry and have never eaten great ramen then please endulge, because the next time go to a half decent ramen place you will know what ramen is supposed to taste like!!! Food here is par!!! Don't waist your $$$ and your time...
author: Nick K.

description:
Me and my bf were having good time eating ramen and suddenly that skinny Japanese guy server started to gave us unbelievably disgusting attitude after his foot touched my bf's bag on the floor. He came right next to our table and loudly said "this is a problem" so that the girl who was serving our table can hear it. It ruined our mood because he said it loud right next to our table with the annoying look on his face. It felt like he wanted us to hear it or did't care if we hear it. And later when we asked for check he took our credit card and retuned it by throwing the bill plate on our table hard so the card bounced out from the bill plate. He didn't even say any word like thank you or whatsoever while he throw the bill on our table like that. He was already got into my nerves at that time. 

good food but they've got a horrible server.
author: Nicole H.

description: I had a great experience at Katana-Ya. The place was busy for 3pm, like packed busy.  This is usually a good sign.  I had the Pork Ramen, my dining partner had the Veggie.  The broth was spot on, pork was on par with what could be expected, although after a few bites of the veggie I would probably order the meatless on a return visit.  Service was a little slow, but the woman who waited on us called us "exotic" (I suppose she is right, lol.), and that somehow earned extra service points. I'm a sucker for flattery, it would seem.  I may return to Katana, it's an OK spot, but with so much good Ramen in the city, and me being an infrequent visitor, I might not make it back as they don't do anything special to really stand out in the crowd.  It's just ok.
author: Ch H.

description:
This place is small so prepare to wait. 

I would say no group more than 4 or else you should split up. 

I've only gotten the cracked out Katanaya Ramen special. 

Where else are you going to get yummy ramen that has fried chicken, potstickers, boiled egg, meat, and veggies!? 

Its soo good. 

I always love coming here.  Especially yummy after a night of drinking!
author: Anya R.

description:
Excellent ramen, good sushi and sashimi, but a bit too crowded. I had a party of four and we were given a tiny table, granted it was their normal sized table for four people. We each ordered ramen, had a pitcher of beer with sake, one sushi, and seared albacore. We had absolutely no room on the table. 

The food is great. I've tried various ramen places, and this one had good tasting pork. Sometimes pork can taste a little older, rancid like. But katana ya is not one of them. Their seared albacore was excellent and the same goes for the spicy tuna roll. 

Great food but in a crowded place.
author: Matt L.

description:
3.5

After a tiring, cold day of shopping in Union Square, a bowl of ramen just hits the spot.  While the wait is still a bit long, there is downstairs seating in addition to the cramped space upstairs.  My husband and I enjoyed our miso flavored bowls in rich and regular density.  I thought mine was the right balance of creaminess and flavor.  While the rich density option was still tasty, there is definitely added oil and fat layers to the broth.  The bowls are large (given the hefty $9 - $11 price tag), and filled with thick noodles, bamboo shoots, and juicy slices of bbq pork.  We also ordered a salmon-avocado roll on the side (as part of their regular ramen combination meals).  It tasted fine, although the rice was a bit dry.  This place is a solid, although slightly pricey ramen spot.
author: Pauline L.

description: Ok, its not fancy but if you are hungry for some good, warm up your belly ramen than you should try this place. The ramen has a lot going on but they manage to pull it off. The staff is friendly and very much on point, its small so they have to turn the tables. They have a full sushi bar however we did the soup and they serve you a lot of it. Really great spot!
author: Brook M.

description:
Ramen is kinda my weakness.  It's my go-to comfort food.  It's my hangover cure all.  It's just what I learned to eat growing up.  

After getting my hair done and walking around Union Square, I decided I needed to refuel.  I've heard great reviews, so naturally I had to try for myself.  I must say, I'm not totally blown away, but I'm not hating on the place either.  Lucky, there was no line and I was able to get a seat at the bar.  Not the most comfortable and the lighting in there is like a bad night club just before all the lights come on.  I sat as I watched the "sushi chef" prepare the rolls while he jams to his tunes in his headphones.  It's sorta like Bizarro up in that joint.  But whatever, I've seen worse.  

Food-wise, I had the combo Katana-ya ramen with the soy sauce broth.  It pretty much had everything in it.  I couldn't decide on one, so I wanted it all!  It was tasty, the noodles were fresh and cooked just right.  The texture had a nice bounce to it if you know what I mean.  Everything sorta checked out so no real complaints.  I just wasn't blown away by it.  

The place is smal and it gets hot especially when you're eating a big ass bowl of ramen so it definitely feels good on a cold day.  

Bottom line:  It's worth a try. It's a good find. It's a good alternative to other greasy choices around the hood.
author: Meshell C.

description: Katana Ya is a small ramen shop that my friend loves because of the chicken. The ramen shop was introduced to me by my roommate for late night ramen.  The restaurant  has limited seating, but people will wait in the typical long line for SF's best ramen joints. I get the Katana-Ya Ramen that comes with fried chicken, dumplings, pork, corn, pickled veggies, and an egg. The ramen is pricier than most places but I assume its more expensive because of the chicken and the location being very close to Union Square. I'll probably come again because my girlfriend has not tried it yet :D.
author: Jason L.

description:
Had the deep-fried chicken ramen with cilantro. Was excellent. Also had spicy hamachi and a rainbow roll. Sushi rolls were so-so. Nothing special. 

I'd stick to the noodles.

-- UPDATE

Been there numerous times since first review. Quality has gone downhill. Last visit was horrible. 

Watched a sushi chef cough continuously over sushi without covering his mouth. Ordered ramen, and the eggs were hard boiled with hard yolks, and were cold. Obviously hard boiled ahead of time and thrown in the ramen. What a disappointment.
author: Matt S.

description:
Dining alone has it's pros and cons.  The obvious con is that you're alone and have no one to share your food experience with.  The pro is that you can score a single seat at the sushi bar here ahead of everyone else on the wait list that is paired up or in a group.  Yay me!

I had the ramen and salmon don combo.  This ramen thing is starting to grow on me.  The noodles were very tasty and the perfect texture.  I would probably get just the soy flavor next time; the miso was good, but a bit heavy for me.  The salmon don was a nice addition.  It was pretty easy to get filled up quick.  Next time I'll have to try the fried chicken since I see other yelpers say how good it is.  Never would have thought of it in ramen.  

The only draw back was that they were out of diet Pepsi, but that's forgivable.  This is a pretty good place to hit after class or when you're finished partying for the night.
author: Maria S.

description: Very good. The only thing I can say is I did not like feeling like they were trying to rush me and get me out when there was not a wait for seats.
author: Sierra F.

description: This place is really good. Can't go wrong with anything if I might say. It's quite tiny but cute inside. Hard to find parking and long lines but that's the city life for ya. I never miss ordering the 49er roll here. The way they incorporate the lemon makes it outta this world!
author: Jen C.

description:
What happened to this place? It seems like it's under new ownership. The room was half empty when we walked in this Wednesday at 10:30pm [a first, as I've eaten here over the years a handful of times, and it's always packed.]. There's a new menu with what seemed like fewer noodle options. Staff usually greets you when you walk in, but all we were greeted with was one of the waitstaff slumped at the bar texting when we got there. Getting their attention was work, drinks not delivered with the dinner, the water requested arrived super late, never refilled. And they were all sort of milling around--and it was not a busy night.
And the ramen. The reason this place has such high marks over the years is their broth is super rich and delicious. Tonight's was edible, but so-so at best. And they're putting these pre-made rolls or dumplings [or I don't know exactly what they were] in the raman that were just soggy and gross. And now both of us totally have heartburn.
After we left we saw a sign on the window outside says they're no longer accepting Groupons and I thought, oh, ok, this must be new ownership after all. What other business owner just stops honoring Groupons they had sold previously? 
Very disappointing! This has always been our place to go after seeing a play on Geary.
