I'll try it one more time to see if this night was a fluke, but reading the most recent reviews, it seems like things are going downhill.
author: Kevin C.

description: We were here for a late night dinner on a weekday because some friends recommended the restaurant and we were in the mood for some good ramen. When we got to the restaurant, we were surprised by how busy this place was at 10pm. Luckily we didn't have to wait too long before getting a table, but it was a relatively small table for four guests to share, not to mention we were sitting very close to the the tables next to us. Well, given that it is in Union Square and real estate is expensive, it's understandable that the restaurant tries to cram in as many customers in the tiny space as possible. Most of us ordered the ramen, with some variation, and generally enjoyed our food. I personally thought the ramen broth was a bit too salty, and my friend (who has been to the restaurant before) commented that the broth was unusually oily... the waitress was also too busy to offer anything more than the basic services. Maybe we happened to have a sub-optimal experience that day, hopefully next time will be better.
author: Sarah W.

description:
I'd do 3.5 stars if half stars existed, but I liked it more than i disliked so I am going to round up.

I wish there was pork flavor, but there's not. 
I wish there wasn't always a 1 hour wait, but no dice.
Between miso and soy (sauce) I liked the soy better.
The fried chicken is pretty bomb
The texture of the noodles (al dente ) is delish - maybe better than Santa Ramen?

But overall, GOOD for SF - favorite ramen in SF, but Santa Ramen is #1!

Heard from friends the sushi is also very good?
author: Melody T.

description:
What's the difference between this $12.90 bowl of ramen and the 19 cent package in my cupboard? Freshness, deliciousness, and fried chicken goodness!! 

Katana-Ya is a tiny restaurant nestled between many other restaurants and shops along Geary St. so it's easy to miss on first glance. Once we found it, I was relieved that it wasn't closed mid-day like many other Japanese restaurants. I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen, which included fried chicken, potstickers, egg, seaweed and bamboo shoots. I chose miso for the soup base.

The ramen soup was flavorful and reminded me of what I had at the popular Ippudo in New York - except less trendy, equally tasty, larger portions... and fried chicken! It's not like KFC though. This was lightly battered, flavored, fresh out of the fryer and is the most unlikely yet best compliment to my ramen. I'd come back again.
author: Thuy T.

description:
Katana-Ya is probably my best ramen spot in the city. It's open late and is centrally located. I've heard there are better places in the Richmond and the Sunset, but that's like impossible to get out there. Katana-Ya also boasts a huge menu, which means they will always have something to satisfy your mood even if you don't ramen. I personally like their salt flavor the best and tend to add extra chashu. Their curry and sushi are pretty superb as well. Now they do the ramen and rice bowl combos, which I think is SUCH a good idea! I've never had their shaved ice dessert but it looks quite yummy. Try it and let me know how it is.

Sometimes you gotta wait for table, but the restaurant is generally pretty efficient so it's never unreasonable.

~A

PS: My friends and I come here drunk a lot after a night of bar hopping. We somehow always get the same waitress; I think she judges and laughs at us but secretly loves us.
author: Alex C.

description:
I'm thinking this place may have better reviews if they only served ramen--the sushi did not look good and the sushi chef kept wiping his nose while we were sitting at the bar (eww). 

Came here one day looking for ramen and found just what we were looking for! Noodles are thick and chewy (but not too chewy), the broth is good, and the portions are quite large. The pricing could have been better, but hey, you're in Union Square. The servers here are also extremely friendly.
author: Anna V.

description:
The ramen here is delicious.  Best ramen ever!

It's a little on the pricey side, but if you are a Ramen fanatic, or just feel like a good soup after a long day of shopping, this is the place to you.  Might as well shell out the extra bucks if you've already dropped a load at H & M.

There's a lot of different kinds of ramen to choose from.  Chicken, buttered corn, etc.  Plus you get to choose what kind of base broth you want.  I always like to go for the miso, but the other ones are probably pretty good too.

The Ramen stands the ultimate test, my friend, who is a picky eater, enjoyed it and tried to make it herself.  That's the ultimate stamp of approval in my book.

There are a few negatives about this place.  A) Seating, it's a big hole in the wall, good luck trying to get in right away.  B) Other items.  Not looking for Ramen?  Then why the hell did you come here?  The other items are so so.  C) Again, price.  You may think, why would I pay 10 bucks for something I can make myself.  Trust me, you can't make this yourself.

If I could give a 6 or 7 star for the Ramen alone, I would.  Everything else is a 3 or 4 star.  Thus it evens out to 5 stars, hooray!
author: Andy V.

description:
Second time I been here.
This time I got the Katana Special Ramen, which was a mistake on my part.  Don't get me wrong, it was good.  It's just not the traditional Ramen that I was thinking of.  Friend chicken and friend pot stickers don't really go in ramen, do they?

Last time I got the BBQ pork Ramen and it was awesome!

My buddy got a california and shrimp tempura roll and was in love.

When I'm back in San Fran I'll definitely be back!
author: Theodore Y.

description:
I have a confession to make. I've never been to a ramen place. Well, until now.

On the cue of a local's recommendation, I walked into Katana-Ya after nearly passing by it. I was warmly greeted and guided to the bar, and this is when things got difficult.

The menu had a lot going on, and while I originally came for ramen, I found myself having appetite-induced ADHD. Every few seconds I wanted something else, but I willed myself to just look at the ramen options...after ordering some sashimi to start.

I went with the miso flavor, and got the Katana-Ya ramen, which had pork, a boiled egg, some potstickers, and chicken, corn, and possibly the kitchen sink. I could have done without the potstickers, honestly. They didn't really mesh with the broth or noodles, and might have been better on the side. The rest of it, though? Amazing. A good broth, the noodles were chewy but not rubbery, and the flavor of everything (potstickers aside) blended very well. Another thing: the broth had oil floating around in it--that's GOOD. All you people complaining about oil in broth should probably stick to hot water. 

Sashimi was fresh and good. Nothing bad to say about that.

Service was relatively quick, and I wasn't rushed. I'll most likely return here when I return to SF someday.
author: DeShaun C.

description:
Small, amazing, cheap.
Be prepared to wait. Only spot near Union Square that I'd love to eat at.
Yum Ramen, do it!
author: Francesca F.

description:
This place is good, but it ain't THAT good for the wait. 

The place is tiny and everyone is all up in your space too.

As for the ramen, you have a lot of options in terms of flavoring, richness of the broth, and different ingredients to add.  You get a good serving of noodles also.

Too bad Ramen Dojo is so far away, Katana-Ya does just enough of a good to job to fulfill my msg/sodium needs, when my lazy ass doesn't want to go down to San Mateo for the king of ramen.

In terms of ramen places i've tried........ Ramen Dojo in San Mateo is #1, Katana-Ya #2, Ippudo in NYC is #3.
author: Kyle W.

description:
Sushi and ramen, always hit or miss. No matter where you are, know before you go.

I figured this was a sure thing based on the abundance of Asian clientele, both inside the small, divey space and outside, line-forming. Overall, definitely a solid choice for what it is.

In a rush to grab a bite before hitting the theater (feeling all classy and grown up, but who am I kidding), rush in, snag seats, order up. 

Two steaming bowls big enough they should come with a drowning warning for a small child show up so fast I'm skeptical, but thankful since we've got no time to spare.

Both shoyu (soy) broth, one BBQ pork (4ish slices) and one Katanaya (the works) ramen.

BBQ pork ramen is pretty straight forward: noodles, seaweed, pork, broth

The Katanaya had all kinds of stuff I'd never otherwise order, but those hunks of fried chicken in it were awesome, the fried dumplings a little bit behind them. Corn, seaweed, green onion, slice or two of pork and a hard boiled egg... it's in your health's interest to share some of that.

I took home leftovers and let me say, the fatty texture of it only worsened as time went on. It cooled into a nice congealed layer of fat on top. Soup, healthy? Ha! 
Just add MSG. (Oh wait, they already do... but at least they're up front about it on the menu. And why do you think it tastes so good?)

Bottom line: I'd be back, but I know what I'm in for and you should too.

In other news, they serve til 1:15/1:30 am... and you know SF, that's a rare find.
author: Alissa A.

description:
What was once a mainstay in the SF ramen scene has fallen victim of uprising competition and a dwindling of passion for the art of ramen. While I was burning time waiting for a friend to get off of work for happy hour, I decided to indulge in a bowl of ramen so I wouldn't get rockstar wasted at the bar. Yelp! searched around Westfield centre and came up with insta-noodle "Ajisen" chain, "Ramen Underground" which charges by the topping or the infamous "Katana-Ya"; San Francisco's finest! Katana-Ya it is!

* I ordered the Katana-Ya aka "the whole sha-bang" aka "the kitchen sink" aka "the simply everything plan" ramen and it was just "A-OK". Everything was just thrown together. Ramen was decent, broth was decent, buttered corn was good, chasu was good and gyoza was excellent but did it belong in the ramen though? How 'bout that stale fried chicken that got soggier than cereal sittin' in milk for more than a few several seconds on a warm sunny day! Blasphemy!

Katana-Ya wasn't bad but I just wasn't impressed by the quality nor by the service. It's also small, quaint and possibly comforting to the Tenderloin residences but it wasn't my steezy. I should've checked out Ramen Underground according to the reviews from a few ramen connoisseurs but I'll save that for next time! I'd give them a generous 2.75 rounded up. Until next time everyone!
author: Joe S.

description:
Delish! 

We tried Katana-Ya for lunch during the week.  I guess it was an off-time because there was no wait and only 2 other tables of people in the restaurant.  We were greeted and seated immediately.  The service was attentive but not annoying.  My husband and I both had ramen - I had the BBQ pork in miso, he had the fried chicken in miso.  He loved his fried chicken ramen and I loved my BBQ pork.  The bowls were large and definitely more than enough for lunch.  

Very good, will be back!
author: Meaghan P.

description:
I'd heard a few mixed things about this place -- mostly leading me to believe it was a victim of its own hype.  I've had more than my share of overhyped ramen joints, so I came in with minimal expectations.

The place is small and a little tough to spot (it's right next to Quiznos).  It wasn't too long of a wait for 5 people on a Sunday evening, but I hear it gets lengthy so keep your group small.  We got seated at a very small table for 5, but you just take it and roll with it.  We got a pitcher of beer and all ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen miso broth, which has a bit of everything in it: fried chicken, corn, gyoza, BBQ pork, and hard boiled egg.  The broth wasn't bad but wasn't too interesting, I immediately regretted not trying the spicy broth instead.  So it's decent but I need to come back before I can make a final conclusion.  The service was okay, they seated us as soon as a table cleared and they brought out the wrong order but promptly fixed it.

We also ordered the Philly Cheesesteak roll just because it was different and unique.  That is one of the worst rolls I've ever had, but in such a way that you have the simultaneous reaction of wanting to exclaim how terrible it is but of also wanting to hide displeasure to persuade others to taste it as a cruel joke ;)
author: Vu N.

description:
Last time I was in SF, we passed on coming here because of the crowd outside, but this time we were lucky enough to stop in just at the right time and slip in with just a 15 min wait.  

Seating here is a  little cramped, but hey, it's a ramen place.  It was nice and casual and the waiter was friendly and fast. We ordered a bunch of things but they have a great meal deal which is a bowl of noodles and an don for anywhere from $14-$17.  We ordered some apps which were good (the fried chicken was tasty and the cold tofu was great).

When the ramen came (in the blink of an eye), the broth was tasty and the don was a good portion (though a little small), but it was a lot of food.  The only thing about the ramen was that I prefer that my noodles are chewier and that they are wrinkly- like original ramen, but that's just me.  All in all the food was ok.  Not amazing or over the top, but a simple good meal.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Ok ok.. the first time I came here a few years ago, the ramen I got tasted so bad I couldn't finish it.  There was a weird smell in the restaurant and I was pretty disappointed.  

I believe in second chances when it comes to food...

After a night of bar hopping and stumbling around downtown, hunger maneuvered us here on our way back to Hotel Clift.  There was no line at 1am and we were seated promptly.  

California roll
Shoyu Kimchi Ramen 
Sapporo

mm... mmmm... 

Noodles were chewy and the broth tasted lighter than alot of the other ramen houses I've been to.  There's nothing classic tasting or epic about the flavors... it's just a tasty bowl of ramen.  However, it's definitely not the best ramen I've had (compared to Santa Ramen and Halu, where the explosion of flavors spark nostalgic memories of simpler times... can I have a hug?) 

Conveniently located and open late.  I'd recommend if you're willing to wait and pay $10 for a bowl of ramen.
author: Kat C.

description:
I like the ramen here, although it's on the greasy side.  I always get the katana-ya ramen, which has everything but the kitchen sink in it.  I always sub out the fried chicken for extra dumplings.  The chicken is dry and simply not good -- I grew up in the South, so I know.  

Give it a shot if you like trying out different ramen places.  Be aware that they are usually on a wait, and since the joint is super tiny, that means you'll have to wait outside.  The area is "colorful," so be prepared.
author: Jade F.

description:
I guess I'm just in an excellent mood but I love katanaya!! I've had a few less than stellar Japanese food experiences as of late and I found myself wishing I was eating at the inexpensive, savory hole in the wall that is katanaya. 
The ramen is SALTY and I bloat the heck up when I eat here but every now and then I can gobble up salt and feel quite good about myself lol. Some of the combo orders are kinda disproportionate and oddly paired so I usually stick to ordering the ramen and sharing the salmon skin roll or some other small roll with a friend. 
I was kinda weirded out by a few things that looked less than sanitary in the kitchen (which you pass on the way to the restroom) but my food has always been consistently satisfactory. 
Anytime that I'm in this area, starving, and it's not peak hours I definitely choose to eat here. Yum.
author: Amber R.

description:
Okay, at first, I was like, if I'm spending more than 10 cents on Ramen, something is wrong. 

And then I tasted this.

I ordered the Pork Ramen in the Soy Sauce broth and it was delicious! I love how they offer a few different broth options. The noodles are delicious. YUM!
author: Lauren F.

description: Not sure if it's because the quality downgraded since I first tried it or my ramen tastes are more refined now, but there's definitely better in the Bay Area.  Katana-Ya's ramen is super salty and gets gross quick.  The pork belly is dry.  Noodles are so-so.  I think the reason it attracts so many customers is because it's the best in the touristy part of SF.  Other better ones are further out in Sunset or South Bay.  The only perk of this place is that it's opened until 1AM.  So if you're drunk and hungry on a usual cold SF night, this place will probably be god-send.  But if you want quality ramen, better to avoid Katana-Ya's long wait and go some place better.
author: Jane N.

description: Kayana-Ya usually has long lines, so I arrived right after they opened on the weekend for a big bowl of ramen.  I decided to order the vegetarian ramen with a spicy miso broth.  The portion that they give us pretty huge - I ended up eating most of it, but towards the end it was almost an uncomfortable struggle.  I felt like I was trying to prove something by eating all of it.  TLDR, the food was quite good.  Tons of noodles in the ramen that were cooked well, cabbage, broccoli, soft tofu, and more.  I didn't ask for any add-ons, but you can get extra seaweed, an egg, or whatever else your heart desires.  I didn't order any sushi, but because I sat at the sushi bar I couldn't help but notice that their rolls looked pretty good.  I think next time I'll try some of their sushi.  The price is a little expensive for ramen (including tip it came out to $15), but this is an authentic, really tasty ramen spot right off Union Square so it's understandable why the prices are a bit high.
author: Zach S.

description:
Ramen has a soft spot in my food-heart. I'm even in love with Tom Yum's Spicy Shrimp Ramen you buy at the Asian markets. Howeverrr...Katana-Ya makes me sad. FYI, there is always a wait for this place, so be prepared to have conversation topics with random bums that may cross your path. 

I had the Chashu Ramen (recommended by SF's 7x7) with an extra egg and corn. We also ordered the fried chicken as an appetizer. I was excited. 7x7? Hell yes. It turned out to be mediocre. Nothing was memorable. I kept adding spice to my bowl hoping something could be saved. Nope. The fried chicken was also just blah. Tear.

A good thing about the food is its portion. HUUUGE! I could not finish, but I did anyway. I pretty much rolled out of the restaurant. Don't get me wrong. The food isn't bad, but it's not great. If I'm going to wait in line and crave for good ramen, it'll be elsewhere. 

My favorite ramen restaurant: Himawari in San Mateo. Look it up. :)
author: David P.

description:
-- Yum Yum YUM!!!! --

** Come in 2 or less for quicker seating **

* The broth does have MSG *

I had the Katanaya ramen with thicker broth and it was heavily good.. Oh, I like my fried chicken and pot sticker crunchy so I place it on a small plate. I also like a little kimchi too!

Btw, it's a small and cozy place... they also offer sushi but I haven't tried it. I see most people ordering ramen. =)
author: Kaycie Y.

description:
The place is cramped and borderline dirty.  I don't think I'd bother with the sushi.

But the ramen here was damn good.  The Katana-Ya special was nice.  Definitely if I come again, I will skip the sushi, and go right to the ramen menu!
author: Rocco B.

description:
Here in San Fran for a visit and got really excited after reading all the reviews.  Got to the restaurant and had to wait for a table so I got even more excited that the good reviews were true...

Food was eh, edible and got me full.  Nothing to write home about.  Nothing to come back for.  The place is close to my hotel and I really wanted to like it so I could come back for more tomorrow.  Instead, I'll be find another place.

I got the BBQ pork ramen and a spicy tuna roll... eh, on both counts with no real upside.
author: Catherine S.

description: Small place, with a somewhat dirty atmosphere, but very good food. Katana-ya ramen was very good. I would recommend miso and light as the ramen options.
author: Cody F.

description:
i haven't written review in what seems like years but my experience at Katana-Ya last night is worth my words of wisdom. not sure why this place has as many stars as it does. it's really unfortunate that tourists, as well as locals who refuse to get out of the city, know no better. 

i woke up this morning swollen as hell from the amount of sodium consumed last night. i'm not going to review a particular dish because hell, everything here is just salty. salty for what reason? god knows why. 

if any of you are following my blog or my instagram, you know by now that i kind of know my shit. i came here with a friend because he wanted it - AND I'M NEVER GOING BACK. 

dear tourists and snobs who refuse to leave this bubble - i suggest you try Ramen Parlor or Ramen Dojo in San Mateo. get a lyft though for reals. 

toodles. @thaoism
author: Thao T.

description: Overall, a delicious experience. I got the vegetarian ramen and we shared salmon sashimi and shrimp tempura at the table. My soup was quite good but could have been a bit more flavorful. It was great once I added soy sauce and chili powder. My friends loved their non-veg ramen as well. I would pass on the soft egg as an addition though, just tasted like a hard boiled egg to me.
author: Natasha P.

description: I got the butterfish sashimi, Ramen and susi combo with spicy tuna sushi. It was all good but nothing amazing or memorable this time. I don't think it's worth the long wait sorry.
author: Karen T.

description:
I finally got around to trying this place out ... long over due in a sense considering I grew up in San Francisco!

First off, this place is tiny.  Seats maybe 20 people or so; so if you show up during any lunch/dinner peak times, be prepared to wait.  I showed up early for dinner on Saturday, so the wait was maybe five minutes for our party of six.  Because the inside is so small, the entire place feels very intimate.  

I ordered the green onion ramen -it was good.  The ramen was fresh, and not soggy (unlike some other places I've been to).  The food came out pretty quick too.  The broth was good because it was not overly salty, and tasted pretty wholesome. 

I wouldn't come all the way down here from the sunset area to just eat there, but if I was in the neighborhood during non peak times, I'd certainly consider it.  

Also, the prices here are fairly on par with other ramen joints, for the most part.
author: Anthony L.

description: 3.5 stars for this place is about right. Good value, solid place to get ramen and a little bit of sushi if you're craving it. I came here with a friend after a delicious but unsatisfying dinner at a sushi restaurant. We shared the combo which came with a bowl of spicy miso ramen and a side of Tuna Poki don for $14. The ramen broth was really delicious and done perfectly, but the noodles left something to be desired. They were overly done or just plain chewy and not soft enough. The tuna poki don was pretty good- the quality of the tuna isn't the best but it's good enough. Overall, I'd come back since it was such a great value for the quality of food.
author: Lillian C.

description:
I was staying at the Hotel Adagio on business a block down and was really curious about this place as the window had tons of Zagat stickers and a couple of Michelen as well.  I love ramen so I figured when I was on my own I'd try out Katana-ya and sit at the bar so I wouldn't have to deal with the long wait that was always outside.  There's a clipboard that's left outside where you need to sign in and with one person, they can always sneak you in more quickly.

I was seated almost immediately and I ordered the Katana-ya ramen, which included fried chicken in the ramen.  OMG, I know that might sound off or disgusting to some but you have not LIVED until you tried it.  It was insanely bad for your health but was amazingly tasty.  The broth was just ok, not too hearty.   Everything else in the ramen was just ok.  I supposed after having friend chicken bits in your ramen you can't go anywhere but downhill.

The next night I ordered an unagi bowl for takeaway.  Not bad, definitely did the trick for a quick meal after meetings.  Katana-ya didn't blow me away, in fact I think it's overrated.  Four stars for the Katana-ya ramen.  I still stand by that NYC has the best ramen in the US.
author: Mari Y.

description: Yummy food, but nothing that blew my mind, and so crammed in there. I saw the establishment next door had the same name, it would have been nice to open that up to use so our party of 4 was not crammed into a table that was meant for 2.
author: Alexandra W.

description:
We put our names on the chart in front of the shop door and waited for 30+ mins on a Sunday around 5:30pm. 

I'm a tourist from NYC that stumbled into this place from 2000+ reviews on yelp. Ramen was solid, not super special but solid like you would find at a decent authentic Japanese place. 

Boyfriend had the green onion ( which is just like the regular one but with a bajillion times more green onions on top) ramen with rich miso broth ( you get to choose thickness of broth). I had the famous fried chicken ramen with regular soy sauce broth. There was three pieces of juicy marinated deep fried chicken in my soup. I also had a side of ikura (salmon roe) and uni (sea urchin) don. I LOVE uni and ikura, and the stuff here was fresh and portion was generous, made me one happy girl! (See my pictures) Also worth noting that rice texture was very good, just the right amount of firmness and oil. I regretted not ordering the rich broth with my ramem. I thought the fried chicken would already be too greasy, but it turned out mine broth was a little tasteless and that I preferred my boyfriend's ramen broth so much more! 

Perfect meal for a chilly summer evening in San Francisco! Would def come back again!
author: Virginia C.

description:
This is the "Mix & Match" Menu of Ramen joints....

WHO... Myself & the boyfriend(my usual late night Katana-Ya dining date)
              - - and the 20 other people waiting outside in line - - 

WHAT...We frequent this spot pretty often as it's only walking distance from us & 
              hardly ever deviate from our usual picks. I always get the udon with fried 
              gyoza in it.(pretty straight forward udon) As for the BF; the Katanaya Ramen 
              which as a whole gang of munchies in it... Egg/Pork/Fried Chicken/Fried 
              Gyoza/etc. And sometimes we'll even spring for a Ca roll or a fried rice. 
              (Yummy fried rice...)

WHEN... I've be here for lunch... dinner.. and late night

WHERE.. What ever seat you can get... Small spot with only about 8-10 tables and a    
               sushi bar. I have been here multiple times, and there is always a sign up 
               sheet.

WHY... Why not.... I can not think of a reason you wouldn't want a warm, tasty bowl of 
              ramen goodness.
author: Teena Marie T.

description:
I was in the area, and checked Foursquare for ramen recs. I have a serious ramen addiction, and I started salivating as soon as I saw an 8.5 rating for Katana-ya on Foursquare, so I scurried on over.

I don't know man. This place did not do it for me. I went there on a weekday at 2 pm, and it was fortunately only a 5 minute wait. They have a clipboard to write your name down if it gets busy.  The overhyped $14 Katanya Ramen which comes with pieces of fried chicken, fried dumplings, pork, egg and broth (your pick of miso/shio/salt and flavor intensity) didn't get me all warm and fuzzy like ramen usually does. The broth was decent, the noodles were average, the toppings were disappointing. Uni sushi was good, think it was $8. They don't have tonkotsu broth here by the way, just shio and miso. Oh, I also found it hilarious they proudly advertised "We use MSG!" on their menus (which by the way has some good $14 regular ramen and donburi combo deals for lunch).

Come here if you're doing shopping in Union Square and want to escape the tourists for a bit.
author: Minnie M.

description:
Hole in the wall type of place, really small restaurant, and place is usually packed! But their food is soo yummy so since we were in the area again, we came back to try their other goodies!

This time, we ordered the Agadashi Tofu and of course their seaweed salad to start off. I love seaweed salad. =). We also tried their Crispy Fried Chicken Ramen and Rising Sun Sushi Roll. Ramen once again did not disappoint and tasted delicious! The broth has a spectacular and unique flavor, makes you want to slurp it all up! The Rising Sun was presented beautifully on the plate and its appearance matched its name. Tasted pretty good too. We also ordered the Grilled Salmon Don again since I enjoyed it so much the last time. 

We will definitely be back again...and again...and again!
author: Cathy N.

description:
Great ramen. The wait can be a bit long. Make sure to write your name on the paper and clipboard outside upon arrival and stay close by to listen for your name.  (Been burned a couple times not being able to hear them call out.)

The Katana-Ya ramen has a little bit of everything in it.  Great way to try each of the possible "toppings" in your raman.  Prefer the miso base (soy and salt are your two other options) and "medium" spicy.
author: Steve K.

description:
I've been here a few times now and have  had several of their dishes.  I first heard about this place reading maxim magazine.  It was named one of the best ramen places in the country.  While i know these ratings can be hyped up, i still wanted to give it a try.   

When you get there, you sign in to the waiting list outside.  They also have menus outside so you can figure out what you want to order before you get in.  That allows the line to move a little faster.  The restaurant itself is fairly small and as a result, the tables are pretty small as well.  

I've had the Fried chicken ramen, katana- ya ramen, corn ramen, and the grilled sake don. Overall, there is nothing too special about the ramen here.  The soup is good but not the best I've had.  The texture of the noodles are good but definately not the best.  I like a little fried chicken in my ramen but I know a lot of people don't care for it because in a way it's mushy fried stuff in soup. The grilled sake don was a little dry but ok. 

As for their prices, they're ok.  Granted it's near union square which creates a premium.  I've been to other places where the ramen is cheaper and better.  

Overall, this place is ok to try, decent if you want ramen late night but nothing to get too excited about.  

Overall, this place is ok. Good if it's late at night and you want ramen.  If you're going during the day, there probably are better places you could go.
author: Patrick L.

description:
It was a blurry night so this review is going to be short becasue I don't remember much but I do remember the service and food lol.  We walked in and was greeted and seated right away.  I was surprised we got seated so quickly because it was Saturday night and the place was packed.  

Food:  I ordered the Extra Spicy Ramen.  OMG it was so delish!  It was spicy but not too spicy.  The noodles were cooked perfectly.  Some veggies and an egg.  I ate all my noodles and 70% of my broth.  I wanted more but had to stop myself.  This place has definitely ruin all the Ramen places in Sacramento for me.  Nothing will compare to Katana-Ya.

Service:  Our server was rude as hell.  She gave us someone else's order and we tried to send it back but she gave us this big attitude about it.  She kept saying, "why don't just eat it?!"  Well lady...we didn't order that dish and don't want you charging us for something we did not order.  Duh!
author: Pon K.

description:
Based on the reviews, I was expecting it to be THE BEST BEST BEST Ramen I've ever had..but NO... it was only OKAY. It wasn't very flavorful. 

This is a very small restaurant. They do have a small sushi bar available. 

I had the Katana special ramen with Shoyu broth. My fiance had the Miso broth. Both were okay. Compared to Santouka,- it just doesn't... I wouldn't come here again. I'm glad I did though to know that I'm not missing out on anything.
author: Lisa N.

description: 3.5 stars.   3 stars for most of us from LA who are completely spoiled by ramen spots in J-Town, Westside, and SGV.   4 stars for SF folks I guess.  (10 stars for the company, if she ever reads this).   Generally, I liked the texture of the noodles here, but the overall takeaway was that the ramen broth was too salty and ingredients not as fresh as I'm accustomed to.   I did like the pickled radish and green onion, though the piece of pork was totally non-descript.   Not the worst deal for $8 a bowl, but nothing I would particularly go back to try.
author: Dave C.

description: I was walking around Yerba Buena Gardens on a cold night in SF and I was in the mood for some hot ramen.  I didn't feel like taking Bart home and drive out to Majikku or Genki, because I was pretty much hungry on the spot.  I used the Yelp app on my iPhone and searched for ramen and Katana-Ya popped up as the closest spot.  When I got there, the place was packed but I managed to snag the last empty seat at the sushi bar.  I was so hungry and cold, so I immediately went straight for the ramen list on the menu and ordered the Katanaya Ramen.  For $12, they throw in chicken karaage, fried gyoza, bbq pork, and a boiled egg.  It was very filling was pretty good. Got soup burn though on my tongue.  I hate when that happens.  I thought it was a little overpriced, but that's understandable considering it's near Union Square.  I would come back again if I'm ever in the city and need a ramen fix.
author: Rodney H.

description:
this review is solely for the ramen...didn't have a chance to try the rolls.

maybe i'm spoiled by working next to little tokyo and all the yummy ramen shops down in socal or by eating at various ramen joints in japan..but i thought katana-ya's ramen was just alright. it did it's job of carbo loading us for the weekend's race, but i'd say there's better ramen out there folks (though i'm not familiar with all of sf's ramen places..yet=P).

you get a choice between miso, salt, & soy sauce broths - was kind of disappointed that they didn't offer tonkotsu broth! especially after claiming to be the most delicious ramen in sf- tonkotsu is just SO dang good..how could you not have it??!! anyways, after choosing the broth you can decide if you want your broth light or heavy. now the server told us they make their broth with it's regular consistency/flavors unless you specify if you want it light or heavy.

i went with the spicy green onion ramen with a heavy miso broth. we also ordered some gyoza as appetizers. 4 gyoza per order and they came out with a nice fried crispy texture. yum!

then out came all of our ramens....

spicy onion w/ heavy miso broth - i really liked the broth..that was about it. it wasn't really spicy (haha or maybe my spice tolerance has gone up?), the pork slice was kinda tough and hard to break off pieces, the noodles were okay though.

spicy onion w/ heavy shoyu broth - i tried my friend's shoyu (soy sauce) broth..wasn't too big a fan on this one. i don't know, it just had a meaty taste to it..hard to describe.

kimchi ramen w/ light miso broth - for the folks not big on spice..no worries, my friend who ordered this was worried it'd be too spicy for her. it turns out she was able to finish the whole bowl and didn't say it was spicy at all. i tried a little too, i'd order this but probably pay the extra 1.50 to make it more spicy=P.
 
bbq pork  w/ heavy miso broth - not sure if the chashu is bbq'd, but you get 3 slices of chashu pork, opposed to the 1 slice we got in the spicy onion & kimchi ramens.

katana-ya w/ heavy miso broth - ha, now this is the jambalaya of ramens. you've got the deep fried chicken, gyoza, pork, corn, etc... all up in this ramen. heheh our friend liked it all.

i do love the japanese feel to the restuarant..the long narrow interior and small tables (reminiscent of the actual ramen places we frequented in japan), and hearing the servers speak japanese..so kawaii! 

Katana-ya..would i go again? hmm, probably need to try a few more of sf's ramen shops to decide on that one. but if you just want a hot bowl of ramen and aren't too picky, then check them out!

check out my buddy "Jay B.'s" review on Katana-Ya below for more info on the place.
author: Belle L.

description:
This place is small and gets crowded during lunch on weekdays. Went there on a Monday and had to wait in line...didn't realize that there was a waiting list on the outside near the entrance until later. Just be ready to sit at a bar if you went there solo.

I left aftering waiting for ten minutes because i didn't have the time and ate at sushi boat which is half a block away. I was bummed and went back to katanaya again the next day. thid time i was seated at the bar and had the miso katanaya ramen recommended by someone on yelp. It was delicious and the portion was huge! Just know that you are there for the pretty decent food and quick service but don't expect any service beyond the order and the check.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Yes!  Finally, another Ramen joint!  And this one comes w/ all the accolades that I would like to see in such an establishment....

...so during the weekend of the SF half, my friends and I were recommended to come here, to Katana-Ya and try the ever-so-highly-praised, ramen.  

I had the spicy green onion ramen with the soy flavor and also had some of the Finz' Kim Chee ramen with miso - both were excellent.  I actually think next time, I'll lean more towards the miso than the soy flavor...but rich as always(you can specify how you want it).  I thoroughly enjoyed my ramen, oh and the gyoza as well, and would definitely make this a regular spot when I'm in the area.  The noodles come out a little harder than I'd like, but it was still pretty good. 

The ramen is priced between 10-14 bucks, so you're definitely paying more than the other ramen places that I've reviewed, but this is the only one I've hit up in the SF area, so they may all be comparable.  But that's what you're lookin at for a bowl tho, so buyer be notified! :)  But even at that price, I would think that there should be some better spots around.  Still not as good as my faves back home.

The place is tiny, so even if it was just a little popular, you'd be lookin at a good wait.  Now consider that this place is REALLY popular, and well, you do the math.  Luckily, we came early and got seated relatively quick.  Parties of 5 or more will have a tough time here...it's really packed tight.  So make sure you time your visit accordingly.

Service - well, it was busy, so they were runnin around taking a million orders, so I can't fault them for that...but it was good enough for me!
author: Jay B.

description:
Me and my girlfriend found this place on a whim while looking for a late night 'snack' after walking around Union Square.
The noodles were good, the chashu was average. But the broth... oh man, the broth.  You get to pick from Shoyu (soysauce), Miso, or Shio (salt) based broth; AND light or richly flavored.  You can also go spicy for an extra $1.40.  
Try the katana-ya ramen, or the fried-chicken ramen.  The rich miso broth is my favorite.
author: Ryan P.

description: I ordered the house ramen and some sashimi for lunch. The service was prompt, the atmosphere was warm, and the food was delicious. I will be back.
author: Mike H.

description: Visited 2 times already, food is great but the place is small. Had the signature soy ramen and on the second visit had the chicken donburi + miso ramen combo. Both times left extremely satisfied. Lot's of food at a very good price! Will visit again
author: Victor F.

description:
Parking is horrible. Park down in Union Square and walk. Chance you won't find street parking.

Food is okay. Salty. I don't like that they add MSG. Usually place try not to put MSG in their food, this place is the opposite.

Service is horrible. 3 times I have been here and each time I felt rushed and under served. The only time they come fast is to pick up the bill.

I asked for water one time, it never came. I asked twice. That was a little annoying since their food was salty. Tea can only do so much.

Their sushi is okay. Not fantasitic. it's standard like other place.

There awalay is a line in the evening. Their turn around rate is slow.

For foreigners, they don't know that they need to put their name on a list. I saw 2 parties last time that didn't know to put their name down and had to wait 20 extra minutes. I think this restaurant needs  a better system for visitors to know where to sign up their name. Waiting over an hour for food at this place is not worth it. maybe no more than 15 mins wait is okay. Anytime beyond that is not worth it.

I don't get any smiles at this place. The associates are not very friendly.

I don't like being stared at form the window by the people are waiting. I feel like there are dagger coming at me.

In the end I will only come back here if all my friend want to go. I will not make a special trip out here.

The food was okay overall. A little salty but filling.  At first my parents and I didn't know which dish was are because the lighting was bad and the servers didn't tell us which dish was what. The ramen here is much better than Tan PoPo.

I don't understand the hype of this place.
author: Shelley L.

description:
3.5 stars - Another extremely popular hole-in-the-wall in the city. I've been here multiple times and every time I am here, I always have to wait at least 20 minutes. The ramens here taste pretty authentic. Unfortunately, my taste buds have been spoiled by ramens in Japan hence it's hard to give this place five stars even though it's arguably the best ramen house in the city. 

My favorite ramens here are fried chicken ramen and their signature Katanaya special which consists of fried gyoza, corn, veggies, fried chicken, bamboo shoots, and an egg. The fried chicken is one of the best I've ever had - crispy thin skin with succulent meat that's not overdone. The noodles are chewy and broth is always flavorful. The portion is huge so you totally get your money's worth ($9-$12 per bowl). Overall a great ramen house, it would've been four stars but the broth is somewhat heavy/salty. Ask for less salty because their normal broth could be pretty heavy for people who are not used to eating salty food. 

I've eaten mostly ramen here. Appetizers are decent but haven't tried their rolls or sashimi so can't speak for those. They look pretty tasty though, so will definitely try those next time.
author: Melody L.

description: Great sushi... This is a real deal as evidenced by the cloud here... A mix of regulars and tourists.  Small place, so if you want to be seated without a wait, come early.
author: Brad H.

description: Great miso ramen. Get the meat vegetable regular one. Large portion. I recommend that you share one between two people. Mild spicy was too spicy for me. The chicken was really well made. My boyfriend ordered the bbq pork ramen and the pork was average.
author: Neha Z.

description:
Ramen, ramen, where art thou, good ramen?

There are not too many good Japanese ramen places, so I'm thrilled that I found Katana-Ya.  Yummy ramen, especially the #12 Katana-Ya Ramen with miso broth; it comes with fried chicken, corn, poststickers, seaweed, scallions, BBQ pork, and boiled egg.  But $15 (including tax and tip) for ramen...really?  Isn't ramen super-cheap and that's why I ate every single flavor of it in college?  I don't think their ramen is thaaaaaaat good it warrants a 1 hour wait and $15 for a bowl.  It is good enough for a 20 minute wait and $10 for me.

1 star off: I should have opened a ramen stand out of my dorm room in college and charge as much as they do.  It could have paid for a better Shakespeare class to quote from.
author: Ally W.

description:
At home (Australia) I have sushi one - two times a week so coming to America I thought it could continue like that. Unfortunately all the sushi I came across just wasn't up to standard.

I searched Yelp to find a good Japanese place nearby while I'm in San Francisco and came across the reviews for Katana-ya so I decided to check it out.

Finally after 7 weeks of travelling the states I found good sushi! I had the salmon avocado rolls.

The service in this restaraunt is also great! They were quick to take my order and organize the cheque when I requested it. I'm not one for eating at the same place twice but I might just have to with this place :)
author: Laura A.

description:
I went here to see what all the hype was about.  I tried this place during peak lunch time, 12:30 on a wednesday, guess what, NO LINES! Heck yes! It was about 350 degrees outside, told myself if I had to wait in line, this ramen will have to be another time.  The whole time I was there, I didnt see a line outside, so I guess go on a wednesday and when the weather has a high chance of giving you a 3rd degree burn.

I had a dish with yellowtail on greens for apps and then had the cold ramen (hiyashi chuka), where is the love for  this dish?! Great on hot days like these, and jam packed with ingredients and flavor. See photo #538 haaha, but seriously, take a look!  Dish came with pork, fried chicken, vegetables, lots of noodles, in a soy/miso type sauce.  Think cold noodle salad.  The sauce was just a pinch of salt too salty, and does have red ginger in it, which overpowered some of the bites.  

I'd give it 3.5 stars and prob come back to it if I was in area and maybe for a late night eat, open til 1am!  But on this hot day it got bumped up to 4 stars since it was so damn refreshing.
author: Haydon Y.

description:
Delicious!

I ordered the Katanaya Ramen and I must say, that I was pleasantly surprised. The soup had a wonderful combination of flavors, the meat was extremely tender, and the portions were quite large. The Takoyaki was soft and flavorful and the House Sake was smooth and delicious. Overall, it was a delightful culinary experience!

My only complaint is that the restaurant is extremely small, so the wait can get long and the restaurant gets very packed. Even when you get a seat, getting service is tough because they're so busy. That being said, the quality of the food is well worth the wait.
author: Dan K.

description:
Absolutely abysmal service. Waiter kept us waiting outside despite the three empty tables clearly visible from the outside. When we inquired as to when we could be seated, the waiter refused to give us eye contact and proceeded to walk out the door to call our name while we continued to stare straight at him. The poor service would have been forgivable had the restaurant been bustling but this was clearly not the case. Furthermore, the food was just average.

The short version:
Passable food+craptastic service+long wait=not worth your time.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Kind of a dank, greasy joint but the sushi speaks for itself. We had the cilantro ramen too, which appeared to be a bit oily at first glance but was actually really, really delicious.  Their iced tea is absolutely disgusting, I'm sorry. Tastes like dirt! And not in a good way.

I'll totally go back if I'm on Geary sometime. Which I hope I'm not anytime soon, fyi.
author: Lisa P.

description:
Mmm, late night ramen.

Wandered in right before closing time on a Saturday night. The ladies were nice enough to accommodate us. I had the char siu ramen which was flavorful and satisfying. Very salty and fatty, both of which I crave (unfortunately) after a night of drinking. Not the best ramen I've had, but gets the job done! This place is tiny, so I could see how there would usually be a long wait.

Until we meet again, xo.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Really good Ramen. The only place so far where I actually liked Ramen.

Recommend!
author: I B.

description:
Katana-Ya does not care...

If their waitress has the plague and is sneezing directly onto people's food.

If they seat people out of order. A 2 top that arrived first may have to wait 45 minutes, while a party of 3 or 4 may be seated much faster. Hey, they're buying more food!

If the sign in sheet is missing, and chaos breaks out at their doorstep because people start lying about who got there first. I've seen punches thrown, true story.

If angry angry bums come in and start heckling clients for money.

If the waiter mixes up tables and puts down a bowl of ramen in front of the wrong person. Rest assured, if the incorrect owner of the bowl of ramen has touched your noodles, Katana-Ya does not care. Once the mistake is sorted out, you will NOT be getting a fresh bowl of noodles, you will be getting the bowl that has been poked by someone else's chopsticks.

Katana-Ya does not care. They don't have to care about customer service, because their ramen is very good, and their system is very efficient for the restaurant. 

Most dinners cause me to seethe silently in my chair, but somehow I always keep going back for more. That's got to mean something right? Try the extra spicy extra rich ramen, yum.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Overall my favorite ramen joint ever! I've been to Santa ramen, Dojo, and a chain in skyline plaza and nothing comes close to here! For the small whole in the wall feeling, to the authentic Japanese service and taste you can't go wrong! 

Definiately try the katana-ya ramen or the deep fried chicken ramen! Two of my favorites!!!
author: Brittany B.

description:
By far the best ramen I have ever had.  Their spicy green onion combines a deep broth of either miso soup or salt water with noodles with the right amount of firmness and spices that satisfy.  The bowls are fairly large for the price, though, if you're like me, it will all go fast.  Other than the somewhat dry cuts of pork, everything else was top notch.  

A word of warning though - this place gets dangerously crowded during weekends due to Ruby Skye and Union Square being so close.  Sometimes Jack in the Box (which is next door) just doesn't cut it, you know?
author: Casey S.

description: This place is great!   Don't go for the decor or even the service.  Go for the awesome food.  Sushi was really fresh and flavorful.  Can't beat it!!
author: Salaish S.

description: Ok so I'm adding this review late. I was having so much fun in San Francisco I didn't have time to post. OMG this place is so freakin good!  We stayed at the Clift & asked the concierge for a recommendation for lunch on a Saturday. I usually ask for the best vegan but randomly changed my mind mid asking & said I need the best Ramen. How lucky was I that Katanaya was right across the street & no line when we went?!  Totally small cool place with a rock star looking chef with his shades on in the dim lit restaurant. Great music too!  I got hot hot spicy vegetarian ramen. Omg soooo good!  Such a pleasure finding vegetarian ramen!  I heard it was a cool late night spot after drinking at the lounge at our hotel but unfortunately after 9 days of Napa wine tasting just couldn't stay up late. Instead enjoyed my hotel room with another - yes another ramen bowl dinner. I barely eat at the same restaurants when i'm home, I like variety so much, let alone on vacation!  I thought maybe eating spicy food at night woke me up but nope it was the earthquake. Pretty exciting day & night thank goodness I left Napa for SF that weekend. Will def go back here on my next trip!
author: Samantha B.

description: Bad service and its ramen was mediocre, the server never came by to take our order nor giving us our bill 'till I went up to them, I was very disappointed with their service!
author: Sam W.

description:
I want to emphatically write this review for Katana-Ya, because IMO it totally does not deserve the hype that it gets (7x7 top 100, I'm looking at you).

Personal credentials:
-In SF/Bay Area, I've been to Izakaya Sozai, Genki Ramen, Suzu Noodle House, Hotei, Saiwaii Ramen, Halu Ramen, Maru Ichi.
-In NY, I've been to Kombi, Ippudo, Setagaya, Naruto, Totto, Momofuku.
-I also lived in Tokyo for a month and visited Japan ~12 times in my life.

I visited Katana-ya 3 times: 1) Deep fried chicken ramen, 2) Katanaya ramen, 3) BBQ-pork ramen. Each time as a combo with a small sushi-don.

Katana-ya's broth is on the lighter side to ramen broths, which is a plus for some, but it lacks the distinction to make it a savory enough broth to merit repeated visits (Ippudo and Izakaya Sozai are outstanding in this regard). Before you fault me on the fact that Ippudo and Izakaya's best broths are tonkatsu based and the comparison might be unfair, I point to Naruto's Shoyu and Halu's Shoyu as examples of lighter ramen broths that are memorable. Even Suzu's Shoyu, although not outstanding, is tastier compared to Katana-ya.

The perfect broth is a delicate balance between saltiness and the umami factor - it is salty, but not overwhelming. The umami taste should blossom at the end on the tongue, after the broth is swallowed. 

My assessment of Katana-Ya is that the saltiness is there, but after that it falls flat and doesn't redeem itself. It's a decent broth with ramen, but does not "go places" with it. In fact, it is probably only a few steps better than broth that comes with instant noodles (which generally all salt + MSG).

I've tried Katana-Ya's rich broth, expecting more of the umami flavor, but all I got was more saltiness.

The BBQ pork is unremarkable, and the noodles are alright - I generally don't feel like the texture of the noodle should be faulted because this is a personal pref and can be changed on request. They do have pretty good fried chicken, however.

Surprisingly, their sushi bowls (salmon don esp.) are super! The rice is a perfect balance of sour/sweetness, and the fish is extremely fresh.

I feel really silly for saying this, but if you must come to Katana-Ya, I recommend skipping the ramen and getting the sushi instead. In my 3 visits there the sushi has consistently been the highlight.
author: Chris S.

description:
My daughter, Joy took me here to have soup.  That's all I wanted to eat for dinner . . . soup.  The serving was surprisingly very small . . . no-miniscule best describes the size serving portion, but the broth was delicious.  

Also, as a dinner extravaganza treat-as if we were watching a theater production like the ones seen across the street:  We got first hand spectacle seeing an extremely violent person consumed in a forceful drama action inside the restaurant which began as a heated argument between a homeless person, a restaurant customer, and the restaurant owners.  Yea!  What a great dinner show!

I have eaten at Mafia infested restaurants in New York and Italy, but this restaurant immediately wins first prize for heated violence!  Bravo!  Good show!  Dinner Ambiance=ZERO.  One extra star for tasty, but very miniscule portion for seafood soup=stingy small cup serving!

Next!
author: Shirley M. J.

description: Had just gotten to San Fransisco and was looking for some legit ramen. Found a few good reviews so thought why not. All the people on line were locals and I figured my chances were good. Waited outside on line for an hour and a half (around 7pm), since the restaurant is extremely small. Then they decided to open the take out area next door for dine in. Finally got our food and it was horrid. Had absolutely no flavor at all. We also got the gyoza which was gummy and had something oddly hard inside. It was pricey. I'm willing to pay for quality but this wasn't it.
author: Joelle F.

description:
I got the spicy tofu ramen with miso soup base. It had silken tofu & kimchi. Soup was tasty & flavorful. The ramen had good texture. 

Don't think I would get the tofu ramen again- the combo was a little strange (even though I love tofu & ramen separately). 

But otherwise, good stuff.
author: Lee L.

description:
My friends and I came here before we had to head to a concert nearby which was in the Nob Hill area.  We decided to grab dinner here before we went.  We came here because my roommate said that their ramen is delicious and their soup was very flavorful.  

I got the fried chicken ramen.  It tasted like any other ramen with fried chicken soaked in the soup.  MEHHH. I wanted it spicy so I paid $1.50 to be extra spicy.  When it came out the soup was yellow not red.  I didn't want them to remake it again because the wait for the food was ridiculously long even though the restaurant wasn't busy or were there a massive of people waiting outside to be seated. *sigh. I was quite disappointed.  The soup was SALTY and i could taste the MSG! =( the ramen noodle's texture was too soft. The fried chicken was soaked in the soup for a pretty long time, so the fried part was soft but the meat was tender. so that was a plus. 

i walked out the place feeling unsatisfied though. =\ maybe if i'm ever in the area again i'll give this place another shot.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The ramen was good, but I like Suzu better.
The menu was a little overwhelming, and I felt a little rushed. The atmosphere is also really interesting...
The ramen itself was tasty. The broth was flavorful, though maybe just a bit on the salty side. The noodles were great. I would definitely go back, but next time I'll ask more questions to make sure I order the right thing.
author: Cami J.

description:
I was in San Francisco all by myself and missing home so I decided to stop in at Katana-Ya for some lunch. Ramen = Home = Happy! I was banished to the sushi counter with all the other single eaters. I hate eating by myself and I dread the thought of one day being an old lady who eats lunch by herself in a crowded restaurant while reading a book. The only fate worse than that would be death by cats! Don't think kitty hasn't thought about it once or twice! I squished in next to two dudes eating their noodles and ordered a bowl of miso ramen. It was obvious that the guy next to me was also forseeing his possible future of dining alone forever and rethinking his chances of finding someone on eHarmony.

My miso ramen was brought to me under five minutes, which in single counter banishment time feels like five days. Oh God why didn't I bring my book to read! Ack! The noodles were tasty and not over cooked, the broth was just salty enough without being oily. It was Japanese yumbly in my tumbly and my bill came out to under $10. It wasn't exactly Hawaii but it helped me feel like I had a little bit of home in my stomach.
author: Emi H.

description: Deep Fried Chicken Ramen was extremely flavorful. Also got a side of Kimchi fried rice, which was on point. All for under $20 which is really reasonable!
author: Chad L.

description: Silly fast takeout. Went with the sashimi plate. Just the right amount and beautiful pieces.
author: Alyson B.

description:
Ramen joints have always had a soft spot in my heart...so when my buddy listed this spot as one of the many options to eat in the area...I immediately selected the ramen house. 

On a chilly Sunday afternoon in the City, a bowl of ramen in your tum...can be one of the best feelings ever... 

We walk up to the spot and it was pretty crowded...sign up list outside and all...we put down a name and waited for about 5 minutes. Not that much of a wait. 

We get seated at the bar and were handed menus. The menu is pretty extensive...alot of things to suit pretty much anyone's taste. 

I got the Deep Fried Chicken Ramen (with miso broth [you have a selection of what kind of broth you'd like: soy sauce, miso, or salt. You also have a selection of how flavorful you want your broth: rich or light]). 

I also ordered the Agadashi Tofu (fried tofu with tempura sauce). 

Both my ramen and tofu came out in about five minutes. 

I took a good whiff of my ramen...the bold, robust, savory smelling broth forced open my sinuses and almost sent me into a tizzy. 

I tasted the broth...it was excellent. It was strong...flavorful...not watered down. The noodles were equally as excellent. They were fresh sturdy noodles...no soggy ramen here! 

The fried chicken pieces (I got about 4 good sized pieces) were soaked in that broth goodness...every bite was infused with that awesome miso flavor. 

The agadashi tofu was pretty good...5 cubes of fried tofu...some sauce...and alot of thinly sliced green onions. some places cut their tofu into rectangles...but I think that the cubes were a good shape...managable pieces... 

Back to the ramen... 

Every spoonful of noodle and broth was fantastic...I found myself eating super slow...just to savor each bite... 

By the end of the meal...90 percent of my broth was gone...the tofu was gone...everything was gone...noodles...chicken...yum. 

Comin back definitely to try out the other dishes they have to offer! 


I ordered the Deep Fried Chicken Ramen
author: Sean-Paul G.

description:
Delicious Ramen with many options to customize it the way you like it!

I came here with my boyfriend and we were initially told it would be a 20 minute wait but it seemed people were moving pretty quickly.  Then Voila! It was literally a three minute wait and we were in!

I had the green onion ramen and ordered it with a very strong miso base.  It definitely delivered!  My boyfriend ordered the Katana-ya ramen which while more "interesting" was a bit greasier; it included fried chicken, potstickers, and extra spiciness added.

We also got sushi which was standard.  nothing to complain or rave about

Servers were efficient and polite but not dilly-dallying making small talk

4 stars instead of five only because the flavors were not so incredible that I'm immediately careening back there to try more things.  I would love to visit again but could live without it.  Very good nonetheless. No complaints.  Reasonable prices and great selection  

Just a heads up the atmosphere is fast-paced and jam packed.  It's very fun and cozy but beware if you are looking for a fine dining experience, look elsewhere.
author: Meg M.

description:
My boss and I had cravings for these noodles for a year. An ENTIRE year. 

When we made it back to San Francisco for a conference a year later, our first stop was Katana-Ya, and after 365 days of dreaming of these satisfying and delicious noodles, they lived up to the memory. 

Way better than Ippudo NY (which gets tons more buzz), by a LONG shot.
author: Caro D.

description: Best Ramen I've had. My favorite is the fried chicken with miso broth medium spicy
author: Stephany D.

description:
Had the Katana ramen with spicy Miso base. Real yummy but not very spicy and serving was huge! 

The restaurant is really tiny and the party next to use had to squeeze 5 people to a 2 person table. And servers were not very friendly at all.
author: Jane N.

description: This place was my favorite spot until they tried to charge for service changes for party of three that was an uncalled action and when I confront them they didn't even apologize this is what I don't like about the tipping system in American it makes people greedy and for god sake I'm showing My guests whom are visiting from France and for them to witnessed this event was unnecessary I hope your management team do take an action for this! Or shall I say the b*tchhhh in leopard shirt! If you're going in today be aware of her!
author: SS C.

description:
Nice restaurant in the area.  Cozy TINY restaurant with WARM ramen and fried chicken.  They haven't done me wrong yet.  And I haven't waited in those crazy long lines I've seen in the evenings...so I'm a happy patron for now.

=)
author: Janet L.

description: Best ramen I've had in SF yet! I always get the miso ramen. Their dragon roll and calamari are really good as well. The only down side would be that there's barely any meat in the ramen, but they give you a lot of noodles.
author: Lisa N.

description:
I was really excited to have a go-to ramen place in FiDi! Was disappointed after having the ramen twice. The broth is not bad, but the noodles just didn't seem that great somehow. I've tried their fried rice in a combo before too, but it was not that impressive. Maybe they have other good things? Must admit though, my ramen standards are quite high now after having NY Ippudo's ramen and other super ones in LA. 

OH, and their service is not that great.. One time when I came here, we had to ask the waiter for the menu THREE times! Whhaat? Also, try to come with less people, since you'll get seated faster.
author: Rose Y.

description:
I heart this little hole in the wall. Their ramen is just awesome! The BEST in the Bay Area! (Yes, I think it's better than Santa Ramen)

This time I got the Spicy Tofu Ramen and yeah, it was spicy. Besides the inconvenience of trying to wipe my nose before it dripped into my ramen because it was so spicy, I enjoyed my bowl of fresh silky smooth tofu, green onions, napa cabbage, and ramen. Their ramen is just the perfect slightly chewy consistency and the soup is just amazing. It's not as salty as I remember, but very rich and flavorful.

Extra points for being open late!
author: Linda C.

description: I left this place feeling like oh they do ramen but that's  about it. Nothing extra nothing more. Two stars are for the broth only, it was very good! Service was blah, staff is blah and the inside is blah.
author: Rowena B.

description: Very good ramen. After a scary looking wait, only lasted 10 or so minutes. Service was then fast. I got the katanaya ramen, which has a crapload of stuff in it with the miso broth.  Very good. The noodles could have been a little chewier, thus the 4 stars. Otherwise, very good and popular.
author: gary g.

description: After 6 months, I'm finally posting a few reviews for when I was in SF. My boyfriend and I went here to try the ramen after a long day of sight seeing. It was our first time trying real ramen at a restaurant and we're both glad we finally did. I still crave the ramen there. I loved everything that came in the ramen --the egg, wontons, fried chicken. The bowl was pretty huge and I couldn't finish it even though I wanted to eat it all. Yum yum yum.
author: Alisa S.

description:
I had the basic ramen.  The soup base was good but I was disappointed that there were only 1.5 pieces of meat in it.  I literally swished and fished around my bowl looking for more... a sad scene.

I definitely want to go back and try some of the others, like the kim chi ramen.  But I didn't think my bowl of ramen was as good as Ippudo in NYC - which has more flavor and pizazz.
author: Anh D.

description:
Pretty darn good ramen.  Definitely one of the best in the city.  However, I feel it's a bit over-hyped for what it actually is.  If you've ever been to Los Angeles (downtown, South Bay, San Gabriel Valley), the ramen there is much better.  Daikokuya, Shin-sen Gumi, anyone??  Anyone?  

But if you 1.) feel like waiting in line for about 15-30 minutes on any given night at any given time; and 2.) don't mind being cramed into tiny kid-sized tables and chairs; then head to Katana-Ya for good ramen.
author: Derek L.

description:
Came here at 6PM on a Wednesday.. Yay to no wait! 

Although there was a wait during my first visit to this place, I remember the food tasting better. 

I ordered the takoyaki (fried octopus balls) and the combo ramen (fried chicken, BBQ pork, corn, seaweed). I had high expectations for the takoyaki but they were extremely mushy. The outer layer was not crispy and the inside was very mushy-- tasted like I was biting into raw dough. And ramen was tasty, but I'd chose  Izakaya Sozai over that anytime.
author: Nance L.

description:
I am one of those people who to go ramen places and don't order the ramen. Although in my defense, this time it was because I already had ramen.  My rating is based on the service, location and curry rice bowl I got.  

I came here on a recommendation from a friend, who said the food was good.  There was a 20+ minute wait, but the turn around was fairly quick.  I had a group of 5, which I had no idea, but the place is almost unable to accomodate such a "large" group.  We sat at a cramped table that normally seats 2-3, with 5 bowls of ramen and 5 cups for water as well as other appetizers, it felt reminiscent of a bunch of clowns in a clown car.

I've never been more uncomfortable in my entire life. I could barely move from the walkway, tuck my legs under the table or even rest my meal/drink on the table. The fact that the restaurant found this arrangement suitable is beyond me. What's worse is that when the table of 2 next to us got up to leave, instead of letting us spread out a little, they gave the table next to us away to new patrons. 

The restaurant leaves something to be desired. The place is poorly lit, the size of a shoebox, and gives off a strong "dive" vibe.  I'm not looking for anything fancy and actually like dive bars/restaurants, but for the wait and the food (good, but average) I think you are better off going somewhere in the Richmond district for better ramen, or even Japantown. This is a good option if you are Downtown, but expect to wait, and sit tightly.
author: Jeanne M.

description: Ok but doesn't meet the hype.  Fine ramen but wouldn't go out of my way to get it.
author: Heather G.

description: Went to a conference down the street and stopped in for some dinner, based on reviews here. The ramen was outstanding. I could probably eat here 3 times a week if I lived here. Probably a good thing I don't then :)
author: Jacob D.

description:
Love the ramen, hate the wait! I almost don't want to mention the best time to go is right when they open, but oh well there's your helpful tip of the day. There's also SF's best harassing you outside...ok fine I'll stop complaining now.

On a better note, I've tried the chasu ramen and though it was good, I can't recommend anything but the Katanaya Ramen which includes: corn, fried chicken, fried potatoes, seaweed, scallion, bbq pork, & boiled egg. Oh my. I also learned not to pay for extra spiciness, instead I just use the chili powder to control the heat.
author: Miko L.

description:
Not quite 3 stars.  More like 2 3/4 stars.

So my friend Jasmine has been raving about this place for awhile now, so after hanging out with her for the day we decided for a night cap and ended up here.

Arrived here to a packed house around 10ish, waited for a bit in anticipation of some good ramen.  

First off too much things on the menu.  Keep it to Ramen and a few appetizers.

Had the Katana ramen and was disappointed,  the texture of the ramen isnt very good.  The soup is ok, but the items addded to the ramen becomes soggy.

Note to customers, when dining here, eat and leave, (yes i referring to you, the doochie bag that I told off who was on a date and stayed and lingered  to chit chat and made me wait a bit longer for the next table )

This place is small so be respectful to people who thinks this place is the bomb (like my friend Jasmine) and are waiting in line for your seat.

Effff it, in the midst of writng this review I decided that they are more like 2 1/3 stars haha.

Yeah, I will not be returning here by choice.  So now Jasmine is on my cannot choose dinner spot list
author: Tony Y.

description:
Being one of the highest rated ramen joints in SF, I now see why everyone says to go to San Mateo for good ramen.  I came here for the purpose of expanding my ramen knowledge and I'm surprised anyone would wait to eat here.

I got the katanaya named ramen.  Portion was as big, but aside from that I felt that nothing in the bowl meshed and individually none were of stand out quality.  The egg was fully hard boiled, but not overcooked.  The noodles didn't have the feel of great bay area ramen joints.  Overall, it was kind of meh.  Also, eating here makes flying coach feel like a luxury.  I rank this place worse than Kirimachi and better than Tanpopo.

This place got an extra star for featuring a beef noodle soup.  Oddly enough, it was very legit for something Taiwanese style.  I would possibly stand in line for this and would definitely order this over the ramen.
author: Terry Y.

description: Poor service. I did a to-go order and made the mistake of not checking my order before I left the restaurant. But who would think they would forget noodles in ramen?!? And I called several times without anyone answering. So I HAD to return to the restaurant to get noodles for ramen.
author: Chelsea H.

description: came here last Sat around 5:30pm the waiting time was not that long. Ordered Katanaya House Ramen, Pork Katsu Don, and 5 Piece Salmon Sashimi. To be honest,with 3000 and 3.5 star reviews I was expecting a lot more. Ramen soup base selection is missing my favourite Tonkotsu 豚骨, and the sides of the ramen doesn't come with Menma ( preserved bamboo shoot) and those are must haves for me. I was quite disappointed when reading the menu.  Port Katsu-don is about the same, very plain taste and didn't even finish the dish.  When I walked out the restaurant and I see people lining up and most of them are Americans, and I figure that's probably why the review is high since they have never tried the authentic Ramen before.
author: Lucy G.

description:
On a cold winter night, all I want is a nice hot bowl of ramen to warm me up.  I came here one night before going to the movies at Metreon.  The wait was long and the worst part is that we had to wait outside in the cold...  I got my usual shoyu ramen and I can't say I was satisfied... It was somewhat salty.  Probably would never come back unless I'm really craving it super late at night.

Tip: Dress warm and prepare to stand outside in the cold.
author: Mimi P.

description:
Not all broths are created equal.   

I wasn't really impressed with the miso broth the first time I came here.  Sometimes, a second visit is a must to explore other options in the menu.  

I've come back twice in the last week and I've gotten the same exact soup:  the green onion ramen in a salty broth. 

I've forgone my usual late night run to McD's in favor of Katana Ya's ramen.  Fat, long, chewy noodles are a more fun way to gorge myself with carbs than french fries past midnight.    There are tons of sliced green onions floating in my tasty salty broth but like before, there are only 4 slices of chasu in there.  Nevertheless, the portion size was big enough for me. 

The expressionless face of our waitress didn't even bother me.   With ramen this good and the fact they're open til 2 am, I'll keep coming back here for my late night eats.
author: Janice C.

description: A very popular place! I ordered the katanaya ramen, which has a bit of everything on the ramen menu. The potstickers were a little disappointing - the insides were kind of dry - but everything else was fine. I wish the egg yolk was a little more "softboiled" like a lot of ramen places are doing now, but that's just a personal preference. The portions were huge - I eat a lot and I could barely finish everything, but that might be because of the pint of Sapporo that I drank. Be prepared to wait for a while when you come.
author: Angus C.

description:
Confused by the bustlin' line outside since honestly the food isn't really worth the big wait. Glad we took counter seats since that just meant a ten-minute pause outside. I got the combo of udon and UNI IKURA DON. Havent seen many places with this stuff, and it honestly is like wacky crack. The uni was fresh enough that I didn't taste any bitterness and along with the oily ikura and wasabi sting, it was aspirationally tasty. 

The rice really really x 3 hurt the bowl though. Not only was there not much of it (how much is rice, doods?), the rice was undercooked to the point of oddly crunchy. Way to ruin the otherwise awesome uni plus ikura mating dance! Gari was folded into a cute little flowery thing, but whatever, into the stomach that went. The udon was definitely very forgettable. For the $16 you're paying, you'd expect at least a little fishcake slice or something. Instead you're giving a packet of udon in miso broth, with a little bit of green onion and some tempura bits. I hunger for more than that.

I couldn't help but compare to Maru Ichi in the South Bay, and honestly, this place was lackin'.
author: Kevin L.

description: My friend and I randomly choose this place. We ordered the buttercorn ramen and Tokatsu (Pork cutlets). The Ramen was AMAZING. However it did not give this place a higher rating because I waited almost 20 minutes for my dish, resulting in my friend and I eating at different times.
author: Ken S.

description: So I'm in San Fran for vacation and I have my heart set tonight on Shabu Shabu  or ramen so I'm here at 6:30, they're open but a man is waiting at the door and locked. I'm looking at the menu and a group of 5 Japanese locals or a table walk up, he unlocks the door, let's them in and I'm locked out, Guess I wasn't the right guest! No private party, just, I don't know, just pissed, looking forward to the dinner and experience. I love food, but I don't love attitude, and that ruins a business,, sorry!....I have to leave a 1 star because they won't let me leave  nothing, can't rate , didn't eat, and won't now. I've eaten in fantastic restaurants in this city,,, wish they'd have given the chance, this review could have been stellar!
author: Teresa T.

description:
Came here yesterday night with four other people. Two people got the table while me and two others came in a couple minutes later. We had two tables by the booth-y seats. We all order and then the waitress comes over and ask if we can all move to one table because they had 6 people waiting for a table and would like to give them the empty table next to us and one of our tables. We were not happy about having to all squeeze and eat on one table. We told the waitress that we wouldn't mind sharing part of our table with the group of six. 

The other group didn't mind so we did the Chinese style of sharing tables. It was fine. While the other group was walking to the table one of my friend told the waitress that they should give us dessert for the trouble.

Our ramen soon came and they messed up on of the order. Instead of the soy based soup they gave her the miso. When we said it was wrong the lady just stood there expecting us to just say it was okay. It was not okay and the waitress went to change it.

At this point we wanted to give them no tip but found out we couldn't since we were a table of five and they include tip in the bill for any party of 5 or more. =[ 

They waitress took my friend's suggestion and gave us a strawberry shaved ice with condensed milk to share. Perfect! I have always wanted to try their shaved ice. It was really good and perfect to share with four other people. 

The food was good but the serviced sucked yesterday night.
author: Sarah C.

description:
still a line at 11 pm...must be good.  i even saw someone throw out a thumbs up when the food came out.

i love any ramen place that has a salt base option...and that's what i would stick with.  we ordered two bowls...salt based and miso based, and the salt is far superior.

we ordered a side salad...and it was surprisingly delicious.  who woulda thunk. 

i wouldn't wait an hour or anything, but C would.  ramen makes him happy.
author: Leslie K.
