description:
Authentic and casual Japanese food by Union Squre.

I had awesome miso ramen and salmon udon lunch combo for $16 after tip.   Pretty cheap meal for the high quality.  The miso ramen had great broth and is I would definitely come back here again.

There are only a handful of tables in here (less than 8) and sushi bar seating.   Be prepared for a wait depending on what time you come.  I came in on a weekend for lunch and was able to sit at the sushi bar with no wait.
author: Tim H.

description: As others have said, small location so waits can get long during prime eating hours, but luckily my party of 3 did not have to wait too long last Saturday night. I ordered the katanaya ramen (miso base) because if I could, I'd always order everything on a menu just because I like to try everything - so this was the perfect choice! Good thing too, because now I know that if I am ever in the area again and have a chance to eat here, I will get the FRIED CHICKEN RAMEN. mmm. what a great idea! fried chicken + ramen noodles, two things I love. The chicken gets a little softer too because of the soup, but still has texture and a bit of crunch. They also have a "light broth" option if you're trying to cut back on all the (delicious) fattiness.
author: Kathy L.

description:
My first time trying ramen was at Katana-Ya and I looooved it. I used to come here all the time and would only get their spicy tofu ramen in rich miso broth. The soup is full of yummy msg goodness and the bowls are HUGE. Their Katana-Ya ramen comes with a little bit of everything but the soup isn't as flavorful. Nowadays, I've been spoiled with other more easily accessible ramen joints and only come when I've got shopping to do or tailoring to drop off in Union Square. And for some reason, the noodles have changed. They were a lot harder to chew through the last time I came here... had to take one star away for that. Did they change owners? The original waitresses no longer work there either.

It's a hole-in-the-wall type of place with tables separated by 2-3 inches or less. Get there a little before it opens and you won't have to wait too long.
author: Liana L.

description:
Came here for the first time last night with a friend, since it opened til 1, so I was game.  It was about 10:30 when we got there after passing thru many bums on the street and then having to wait for about 20 minutes for a table.

We got seated and they do have an extensive menu from ramen to sushi to rice dishes.  I decided to order the combo, which was the ramen and the fried rice = $11.00.  When the food came, there was plenty of ramen which was nice, but the ramen noodles were thick.  I was not a fan of it..  I don't think I had any ramen that thick before - kinda reminded me of spaghetti noodles.  The fried rice was okay - nothing great.  

I would have given this place a 2 star but for the late night opening and the abundant of ramen in my bowl, I gave it an extra star.

Would I be back...probably not.  Quality over quantity over rules...had better in Japantown and in Gardena, CA.
author: James L.

description: So we showed up at about 1030 on a Thursday night and waited 35-40 mins for a table (party of 2). We decided to wait it out since we assumed they were swamped bc it was amazing! We got in and ordered when we were greeted, which was about 10 minutes after sitting down. My husband got his entree within 5 minutes, and we waited an additional 15-20 mins just to get waters on the table. 10-15 mins later we got my hot sake. At this point I'm wondering where my food was (ramen) and I didn't even really want sake, just food!! The table next to us came in after the water and before the sake, and ordered right away. They also got their ramen within 5 mins of ordering, ahead of their appetizers and ahead of my ramen. When I asked the server where my soup was, he took a bowl off my neighbors table and handed it to me, saying that it was the same kind. The guy at the other table was very gracious and said he wanted me to have it, but it was super awkward so I just took it. Anyway... Very disorganized. Mediocre food. I've had better ramen in both San Diego (Underbelly) and OC (Ajisen). Awful, AWFUL service...And I'm a server so I'm super forgiving.
author: Dani W.

description: If you don't get there early enough, there will be a line and your entire party has to be present before they seat you. It was definitely worth the wait. We ordered ramen, sushi, and agedashi tofu. The ramen servings were huge. I liked the chewy consistency of the noodles and the broth was delicious. The sushi and tofu were good as well. I'll be back here the next time I visit.
author: Kat A.

description: Even though I committed a rookie mistake as a vegan dining in a ramen restaurant, the ultimate results were worth it! (I totally blame the happy hour cocktails beforehand.) Just make sure you tell them you are vegan, otherwise when they bring you your Spicy Tofu Ramen, it will be in meat-based broth with a big ol' hunk of pork floating on top. Ick. After talking to the waiter, he explained that they do indeed have a vegetable-based broth for us veggies and of course, tell them to hold the bacon! What I ended up with was a delicious, super-flavorful, spicy, perfect and ENORMOUS bowl of ramen! Yum! Been thinking about it since we left. Must go back soon...
author: Susie D.

description:
I'm not really a fan of Katana-ya's ramen.

It's not very... elegant. It's sort of just a big ass plop of noodles and other goodies. 

There isn't that interplay between flavor, textures and temperatures that you get from other ramen-ya's.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I have a serious love affair with ramen. It warms your body on a cold night and can cure cancer (FDA disputes this). 

Katana-Ya is a one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Despite being just off touristy union square, it retains a small restaurant charm. The staff is exceedingly friendly and will always make sure you have a positive experience.

The ramen here is some of the best in the bay area (second only to Kahoo in San Jose). The broths are always filled with layers of intricate flavors and the noodles are always cooked to perfection. Although Katana-Ya is known for their ramen, their fried rice is just as amazing. I can't come here without ordering at least a side of fried rice, it is over the top delicious. I swear the put a mixture of love potions into their rice because it is more addictive than heroin. 

If you're craving ramen or fried rice in the city, Katana-Ya is the place to go.
author: Tom L.

description:
Katana-Ya is one of those places in SF that everyone raves about and is on the "must try" list. And certainly, the first time I visited, it met all my expectations. The ramen and soup ratio was perfect, the spicy green onion hit the spot late at night. There wasn't much of a wait since we got there at the tail-end of dinner hours.

Since then, I've tried to go to Katana-ya to re-create the memorable first experience. Maybe it's because I've gone for lunch hour since then, but the lunch feels rushed as the lines start staggering outside and the door is constantly opening and closing. The food is also never quite as satisfying with the ramen being mediocre compared to some of the places in South Bay that have been popping up in the "hot ramen spots" radar. Some of the better food choices include the corn ramen as well as the lunch combos where you can choose a side dish with your ramen. NOTE: The combo is literally a full-sized, regular ramen bowl with whatever else you choose on the side. Not a 1/2, 1/2-sized deal, so I guess it's you'll get a bang for your buck.

Still Katana-ya is one of those places you've got to check out once in SF!
author: Angela S.

description:
I'm not a noodle/ramen person. I prefer eating rice but Katana-Ya's ramen is really good. I only tried the regular ramen but i'm definitely hooked. I love the soy sauce broth and their noddles are really tasty. 

I never waited longer than 10 mins for a table but its definitely worth the wait. Too bad its so small!
author: Carol Y.

description: Ever since they switched owners, the broth in the ramen has been quite lacking. It's a lot saltier then it once use to be.  The ramen is still good and tasty, but long lines, high prices, and saltier not tastier soup has me going elsewhere.  Granted there aren't a lot of good ramen places in SF, so if your in the area and have the time to wait to spare this is a decent spot.  It use to be a gem, but it's not so shiny anymore
author: J Y.

description:
Generally pretty disappointing.   We went here based on RAVE reviews of a friend. 

1. Our group of 4 was seated at a table for 2 which made for a very crowded dinner.
2. When we asked if the spice level of the broth was appropriate for our teenager who doesn't like food that is very hot the server did not steer us to another dish.  Our child did not touch his order.
3. The "rock and roll" roll (featuring Unagi) was covered in a sweet sauce that covered all other tastes.  I've eaten Unagi rolls from a dozen good Sushi restaurants and have never seen a roll covered in sauce.

Plus side...
1. Potstickers were above average.
2. The spicy tuna roll was above average

Neither were "great."   For the price there are options I think are quite a bit better.
author: Joel D.

description:
The ramen here was okay, nothing remarkable.  The karaage (on the side), gyoza, and salmon don were disappointing.  The waitress was kind of rude, and really abrupt with taking our orders - and we knew what we wanted before she got to us!  We didn't ask any questions or delay her by staring at the menu, yet, she seemed annoyed that we were ordering more than just ramen.  Uhhhh...

I can't believe the line to get into this place was as long as it was now that I've tried the food.  Don't believe the hype.
author: Barbara T.

description:
I love ramen! Good ramen, that is... this was decent ramen. My friend and I came here at 6:45PM on a regular weekday, and there were around 6 tables before us. The wait was surprisingly short, but the reservation system wasn't very efficient. You basically wrote down your name and the number of people in your group on a clipboard at the entrance. No waiting area, unless you count the pavement, so everyone was just standing around and blocking the way. I'd imagine it'd be horrible on a rainy day or if you were just extra cranky.

So I ordered the BBQ Pork Ramen and asked for it to be made "extra spicy". My friend had the Deep Fried Chicken Ramen. For the price, I'd say the portions were small and there wasn't enough meat or noodles. Yes, the broth was delicious and the noodles were the perfect amount of bounce, but it doesn't take away the fact that it cost me $10 for something I could've gotten for $6 elsewhere. I was also disappointed that it wasn't all that spicy, but I guess that's what the chili pepper is for!

The restaurant looks like a traditional ramen house inside and out, and there's quite a lot of tables for such a small space. Like I said before, the line goes by fairly quickly. I'd say Katana-Ya is one of those must-try places, but I wouldn't go again.
author: Katie M.

description: I order their special ramen with everything and then tried to figure out why someone thought it would be a good idea to put fried potstickers and fried chicken (karage) in ramen broth. Maybe I eat too slow but I was disappointed when everything was soggy by the time I got to it. The serving was huge and I barely made a dent in my bowl, so I felt a little guilty when my two friends and I left our three full bowls behind. Maybe next time...
author: Jenny W.

description:
Being in a cold place like San Francisco some hot ramen & sake sounded great.  The place is a little hole in the wall.  It reminded me of Sushi Deli, with a clipboard outside, you sign yourself in and just wait for them to call you.  We only waited for about 15-20 minutes.  That wait time in the cold was worth it...the food was bomb.  They have these combo deals.  So I ordered a bowl of ramen that had friend chicken in it...so good...along with a salmon roll.  Best salmon roll I have had.  Best ramen I have had hands down besides the ramen I tried in Japan.  I asked for a little spice in my ramen and light miso.  The bowl is very filling; luckily the boyfriend helped me out.  The fried chicken in the ramen was boneless chicken which I prefer.  From all the slurping I heard coming from the people stuffing there faces I knew this place was going to be good.  

My boyfriend and I liked it so much we went back the evening we were leaving before heading to the airport.  My boyfriend and I shared the spicy ramen but without the fried chicken.  I ordered a spicy tuna roll my fave!  My boyfriend got spicy salmon and New York roll both very good

. The second time around was just as good as the first.
author: Marlene M.

description:
I finally found my ramen joint in the city! Do you know how difficult it is to find a good ramen place in the bay area? Although there is a ramen restaurant on the east bay of the same name, I don't think they are affiliated as my experience was different at both establishments. This katana-ya in the city is much better.  

The only drawback is that the place is so small.  Get there early or you may have to wait in line. We were fortunate in getting there right when they opened at 11:30 on Sunday, so there was no wait. But all of the times I've walked past there , there have been lines. 

The staff is entirely Japanese so that was a good sign that the flavor was going to be authentic. I ordered a miso ramen and kim chee fried rice combo. The broth of the ramen was so good. Hearty, just the way I like it. Kim chee ramen was pretty good, although it could have had a little more spicy kim chee flavor. Also had a side of gyoza. I was a little disappointed as I like my gyoza bursting at the seams with pork filling. This was was only about half stuffed. The flavor was still good though.
author: Kenson K.

description:
This is okay. I had the ramen and a spicy tuna roll. I've had better ramen in SF. The flavor of the soup could be better, and the stuff in the ramen isn't exciting (unless you want to pay more- like egg, etc.). 

The spicy tuna roll is ok. Definitely not great.
author: Jamie T.

description:
Katana-Ya's neon lighting and cozy layout gives a good, chill vibe overall. The ramen here is just OK, nothing great or to be craved. I was not wowed in the least bit, but that's not to say the food was awful. Wait time here is very fast, and the service is good. Prices were a little on the steep side, but that's to be expected for an establishment near union square. Love that they're open late, so it's a great place to go with friends if you have the munchies.

Worth a try!
author: Kevin D.

description:
I had to admit, I wasn't initially impressed with the food.  Read on though...

I've been wanting to try out Japanese ramen for awhile now but had no idea on where to go in Houston for it.  While planning my trip to SF this past weekend, I read the reviews on Katana-Ya and knew I had to put this first on my list.

Came here at odd hours so we were seated promptly.  Ordered regular ramen, fried chicken ramen and some spicy onion dish.  Not knowing what to expect, I thought my ramen was pretty boring at first.  My gf thought her fried chicken ramen wasn't that great either.  So uhhhh....if we both thought our meals weren't all that then why the four stars?

For whatever reasons that I couldn't pinpoint at that time, we kept craving Katana-Ya throughout the entire trip.  We've been back in Houston for a week and we are STILL craving Katana-Ya.  In the past week, I've been to about three Japanese restaurants just looking for anything remotely close to the ramen from here.

Looking back, I realized a few things:  the entire meal was superb.  All of the ingredients seemed so plain and boring at first but with hindsight being 20/20, everything was great.  The soup wasn't heavy at all; ramen had nice texture to it and the toppings were actually just the right amount.  Maybe being from Texas, I expected the entire bowl to be overflowing with toppings but good thing it wasn't.  The meal was "just enough" and hit the spot perfectly.

If I ever make it back to SF, Katana-Ya will definitely be on my list of restaurants to visit.
author: William V.

description:
This is definitely the best ramen in SF! I got the Katana-ya Ramen which comes with fried chicken, chashu, fried dumplings, corn, and boiled egg. The miso broth was just the perfect flavoring. The noodles were a bit thicker than I like, but I didn't mind it too much. It was a hefty $14, but worth every penny! It was still good even after the soup soaked into the noodles during the walk back to my apartment. 

The place is a bit small, but slightly bigger than Underground Ramen. They also take Visa or Mastercard.
author: Caroline C.

description:
It's a pity that yelp is the only place to report food-borne illnesses in the city...it's true, look it up.  I'm no germaphobe, but this place is petrie dish. 

The first time we ate here, my boyfriend and I both got horribly sick. He had one piece of salmon sushi and I had three...He was sick for one day, while I was sick for three. Odd, isn't it? And I mean, knockdown, under-the-covers, run-to-the-bathroom sick. 

Don't ask me why I went back.  (A fluke, I thought, coulda been anything.) It was about five weeks ago, right after a dentist appointment. I skipped the sushi and just had vegetarian ramen soup. Cut to...I just got over a 4 1/2-week protozoan guest in my stomach. 

When I was sitting there, the sushi chef was surfing the web on his iPhone and reading the newspaper, bare hands, no head covering. Dirty dishes were mouldering in a bucket by the bathroom. The air was dank. I shoulda run.
author: Elliott K.

description: Another thing to eat on my 7x7 100 things to eat in SF. Complete hole in the wall, and probably wasn't wise to eat here on a day where it was 75+ in San Francisco, no air conditioning and in 30 minutes my car would be towed away. Nonetheless the ramen was super fresh, I had the shoyu broth which was ok. Panda's salt broth was better. I think I've had better ramen in Sacramento at Shoki where you could taste how long the broth's been stewing away. All in all, pretty good, but doesn't see how it made it to the 7x7 list.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Kata ya ramen with soy broth was good did not care for the potsticker . Wife had green onion in miso broth was good too!
Service was very good at lunch time
author: Lee O.

description: So the ramen is definitely not worth waiting in a line for. Horrible horrible service I've never experienced anything like this and should have known better when a group of people left after ordering their drinks the waitress was very rude and spent 15 minutes arguing with another table about what they did or didn't order. We had to ask multiple times just for a diet coke. Then when we go to pay for the bill they didn't even charge us correctly. We ended up paying cash since they obviously had problems just adding up a bill, I can only imagine what they'd do with the credit card information. Save yourself a headache and stay away from this place.
author: John F.

description:
I ate here based on the recommendation of 7x7 SF magazine. wtf, did I eat at a different place? The ramen here was very below average. The only thing I liked about it was the ramen noodle texture, which was chewy and not overcooked. As for all the reasons why I disliked the ramen: The BBQ pork was almost right, but did not quite have enough of that melt-in-my-mouth quality, the broth was far too salty, and the egg was just a regular hard boiled egg instead of the Japanese style egg with the soft, squishy yolk that I love. 

I also tried some sashimi, which was okay, but nothing to write home about. It did not taste fresh to me since there was a hint of a slightly fishy flavor. 

In short, the food is edible and not TERRIBLE, but definitely way below expectations. I would not come here again.
author: Wendy S.

description:
Wanted to check out the ramen joints in SF to see how they compare to the ones in NYC/NJ...unfortunately I was less than impressed.  I got the salt Katana-Ya Ramen, that has gyoza, chicken karaage, bamboo shoots, half an egg, chashu, seaweed, and corn.  The toppings were okay, but too bad the noodles were overcooked and soggy.  The broth was clear, not exactly the most flavorful.  The salmon don was a bit better, but the temperature of the fish was a tad higher than usual sushi temperature.  

We sat at the sushi bar, too bad we couldn't chat it up with the sushi chefs because we can't speak Japanese.  I think the 2 ppl who sat next to us got a free raw fish salad...I remember some sushi restaurants do that when you frequent them and they recognize you.  In any case, while I can't judge the SF ramen scene based on just one restaurant, it makes me feel better to know the ones in NYC/NJ are yummier!
author: Yingwai W.

description:
Am I the black sheep for Katana-Ya? 

I wish my experience could have been better. I had high expectations, especially after hearing about Katana-Ya through Yelp and the people here in SF. 

My friend & I both ordered the Katana-Ya ramen. This was just OK. Nothing special aside from the fact that they put so much stuff in that bowl! (Seriously). Pork, fried chicken, gyoza, corn, egg... basically filled! So its great if you are hungry. However.... I felt the quality was lacking. The pork was kind of tough and the chicken didn't fit in with the ramen. While it was just average to me, I was disappointed and probably will not order it again. Granted, I may be a bit picky when it comes to ramen (its one of my favorite Japanese dishes), so I have high expectations.

We also ordered a dragon roll sushi dish. This again, was just ok. I guess Katana-Ya is meant more for their ramen... 

The prices here are a bit steep (especially noticable with their sushi!!). This is Downtown though, so higher prices are expected...

Katana-Ya was a 3-star in my opinion. I'd probably only go back again if it was out of convenience, as I do not think I'd ever go back otherwise.
author: Mari S.

description:
I'm not sure if you have to have a very refined palette to appreciate what a true Ramen is. Said to be the best Ramen in San Francisco, Katana-ya was just a disappointment in my book.

The restaurant was supper tiny, with a wait time of at least 30 minutes during the day. I meant if i have to wait for my food for an hour, it need to be great and worth waiting for. Sadly, they don't deliver to what they are raved about.
author: Jan R.

description: Nice little place in the downtown area. During lunch time it can get a bit crowded and closes early. ramen ranges around $8.95 and up. Overall, I was happy with my order. The portion was pretty big and filling. I would recommend this place. Not good for big groups.
author: Christina G.

description:
I've been here twice since moving to the city and I wish I could say that I love this place, but it's just, ok....
I had high expectations for this place because of all the good reviews I've heard from others, but so far my experience has not met them.  Both times I've come, there has been such a long line.  And since the restaurant is so small it feels like forever before you actually get to eat.  The taste of the ramen is actually decent but I don't know if it's worth the 1 hour wait for it.  Now I will not wait more than 15-20 minutes for the ramen here.
author: Love U.

description:
Visiting from out of town, I was skeptical of all the raves. But I'm glad I went anyways.  For someone outside the big cities, its the type of food you can only get in a place like San Francisco.

But's its more than that. Service was attentive.  Had the big special bowl of ramen.  Really great.  

The sushi bar looked tired and some of the fish looked like it had been in there more than a day or two.

So stick with the Ramen and go away happy.
author: Dan S.

description:
NO NO! Why why why do people wait outside for this kind of ramen???
Not trying to be a kill joy but this place doesn't taste like they slow cook their ramen broth. It taste as though loads of salt were used. I think if a ramen place is overly salty there's nothing else to say about it. I cannot drink a bowl of salt water.
author: Jen L.

description:
I been here so many times, I cannot believe I never written a review.  I order one thing and one thing only when I eat there.  Luckily today there was absolutely no wait.  Walked in and there was a table waiting for us. :)  However on any other normal day or night, the wait is usually 15-20 minutes.  Is it worth the wait???? HECK YEAH! :)  

You cannot go wrong w the the Katana Ya Ramen with miso base soup!  I love it! I frequently eat at this fine establishment and the Ramen always hits the SPOT!
author: Sandy L.

description:
I wouldn't say it's the best, but it's not bad.

I must reiterate that most ramen places in the bay area doesn't come close to what you find in LA. By Bay Area standards, though, this one's pretty good. 

I tried both their miso and shoyu broths.. Their broth is very light in flavor, which I like because it doesn't leave you with that parched-mouth feeling afterwards. It probably means they use little to no MSG, either? Unfortunately, though, both broths tasted regular... as in, there was nothing that made me say "Wow, this is good ramen broth!". That's where this place loses a couple of points, because it's one of the key points of a good ramen!

The noodles were good and had a nice firmness to it. It's on the thicker side, and in fact, I thought it was nearly identical to Santa Ramen's noodles.

The ingredients were in the ramen were just average. The egg wasn't the flavored kind, unfortunately. The chasu (pork) wasn't anything to rave about. Menma (bamboo), corn, etc were all standard too. One interesting thing is that they have ramens where they have karaage (fried chicken) and a fried gyoza inside. BLASPHEMY! I've never heard of such a thing... but I tried it and I gotta admit, miso-broth-soaked karaage and gyoza were pretty good lol.

We also had some fried rice and that was good. Wait what? They have SUSHI here? I thought this was a ramen specialty shop? I guess not...
author: Kazu O.

description:
Based on the  many times I've been here...I just don't feel the same about the place anymore :(

I'm not saying I won't go back, but is it really worth it?
When I first went years ago, it was pretty good, but then after a while, it---for lack of better endearment, "got hella salty."

I did enjoy the texture of their noodles. Y'know that correct chewy factor? Yeah, even though I'd heard it wasn't house-made...I was still like, "slurrp." But I just can't handle all that sodium these days :/

If I'm hungry, there's no line, and I'm feeling skinny enough to sit, "I'll be there."
author: Carol L.

description:
Saturday night in the city.  
Cold and hungry.  
Want a place for some yummy Japanese.  
Yelp to the rescue!
Parking karma in full force!

This place is tiny and had a long wait.  Having said that, I did meet a yo-yo master in line where he showed us many tricks. :D But when we finally sat down and got our sushi rolls and ramen, it was really really tasty and worth all the wait.  The prices were reasonable too for Union Square standards.  Afterward we were able to walk to the square and check out the tree and also Macy's for some quick shopping. :D

Only gets 3 stars from me because 
1. I was hella thirsty in about 30 minutes. (way too much MSG!)
2. perhaps it was my own miscalculation, but the two of us shared a bowl of ramen and two rolls, but were both hungry enough to have full desserts in about an hour.  (I'm usually way full with either a bowl of ramen or two rolls, so half of each should have done the trick unless the ramen portion is smaller than normal)
3. Santa ramen or any of the San Mateo or south bay places are equally as good if not better and parking is easier and all that.  I know this may not be a plus for those who live in the city, but it is for me!
author: Cindy C.

description: Nick from the InterContinental suggested this place was good should have gotten the Ramen but had a time understanding the waitress and wound up getting sushi.
author: Flyinlow ..

description:
Considering that I didn't have a real meal the whole day, I was cranky and grumpy considering and it didn't help that I was waiting for my buddy to go eat dinner.  We end up leaving my house at 9 to fly down to Katana-ya and found parking a block away! Lucky!! *_*. We got to the restaurant and saw that there was a waiting list. I saw it and was thinking "GREAT!! AKLJGFSGJF but after putting my name on the list, 5 min later the waitress called my name. YOSHA! sucess!!!! ^_^.  The advantage of having a smaller party wen in a smaller place. After browsing the menu, I saw Katana-ya Ramen! It comes with pork, two pieces of Kaarage and two gyoza.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=wZrXCLwHWXVoq54agVGghQ

The broth was very delicious, rich with flavor. My buddy got the rich broth while i stuck to the light broth. The light broth is the way to go, my light broth was rich with flavor while the rich broth flavor was masked by the fat in the broth. For some reason I always go for Shoyu now! lols. The Kaarage was well seasoned and yummy, the pork was a  lil tough but it still had good flavor. The inside of the restaurant was pretty small, decorated with Christmas lighting and art.  There choice of music was very interesting: Backstreet boys and Justin Timberlake? reallie now. I have no problem with them but it jest caught me off guard, i was expecting some J-pop lols . I will be back to try the different ramen. With the shitty weather and me feeling shitty a bowl of ramen always cheers me up. So does Plum wine which i am sipping on rite now as i write this review :D
author: Jonathan W.

description: They changed ownership not that long ago and the taste of the soup got a little saltier. Service, however, became slow and terrible. Waitresses are rude and likes to talk about customers behind their backs and since I speak the same language as them I understood what they were saying the entire time I was eating there. Sadly, I won't be going back there anymore.
author: Pat M.

description:
When I first moved to SF over two years ago, I was on a desperate hunt for a good go-to ramen joint. I love noodles. I grew up eating noodles, and love every single kind - pho, ramen, egg noodles, Chinese knife cut noodles - anything! After trying a couple of places near where I lived in the Nob Hill, I settled on Katana-Ya, as it had the most flavorful and rich broth, with nice chewy noodles. I would get the Spicy Tofu Ramen every time, and share the Albacore Tataki with my boyfriend as a light appetizer.

However, I realized that as I came here more and more, it seemed like the portions would get smaller and smaller. They would skimp me on the noodles, fill up the bowl with less broth, and what was the most ridiculous was that the prices on the menu kept going up! Then, I noticed on the menu in small fine print that you could request for no MSG in your ramen. What? - Their ramen is filled with MSG? No wonder it was so addicting (and every single time I left, I would be dying of thirst and my tongue would have a weird feeling to it for the rest of the night). 

So I finally asked for my order without MSG. And low and behold, my ramen was ruined forever - the broth tasted watered down and flavorless. I've never gone back since. Still searching for a good ramen place in the city. Someone please open one up!
author: Carolyn W.

description:
Worth the wait.

Waited a good 30-40 minutes to get a table. The place inside is small but even at 11pm, there was a line waiting to get in. The ramen was good with lots of options (i was hungry and am not super picky about my food). A friend got the donburi which was pretty delicious as well. It they could double the size of their space they would be rolling in it.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
I was meeting a friend for dinner one night and wanted to try some place new instead of going to our usual noodle house as a chance of pace.  I searched for "ramen" since we both like asian noodle soups, picked this one based on the reviews I've read (and it was in the vicinity of where we were).

The place is small.  I found the menu to be confusing (too busy) and it was hard to understand the Russian/European waitress when I asked her about things.  We finally decided on our orders: I ordered the Katana-Ya special with the miso broth and my companion the BBQ pork ramen bowl with the salt broth.  We also ordered an order of sushi as an appertizer.

Based on the reviews, I was expecting something spectacular but it was okay... I've had better else where.  The service and friendliness of the staff was okay, not very personable.  The flavors were okay with the soup, nothing memorable EXCEPT that their BBQ pork slices are thicker than most places and were pretty tasty.  That was prob the best part. 

So their soups comes in 3 different bases (miso, salt and plain?).  Know in advance what you want cuz they don't appear to take the time out to really explain that to you...

Happy eating!
author: Kacee B.

description:
Wow I never noticed this place right across the street from Ruby Skye :O 

Food/price: I've only ever tried the Ramen here since that's what seemed to be popular, but I didn't think it was that great. I think one of the most important parts of ramen is the broth, and yes the broth here was tasty, but I think it was more of an MSG and oily tasty than that rich and deep flavor that GOOD ramen should have. I ordered the deep fried chicken ramen in miso soup, and I think it's cool how you can choose from either miso, soy sauce, or salt based soup regardless of which ramen you get. You can also make any ramen extra spicy with an additional $1.40, which is cool too. The deep fried chicken was average, nothing special, but I did like the texture of the noodles. I don't know why ramen is always so expensive, and the ramen here is around $11-13 per bowl. I didn't think it was worth it, considering you really do get what you order: deep fried chicken, ramen, oily broth, and maybe a few pieces of bamboo

Environment/Service: This place is definitely in a good location, I would totally come here before going to Ruby Skye or something. It's a pretty small place though, and I imagine there being lines during busy hours, but there's definitely a home-y/authentic vibe to it. The lady here is super nice too! I remember her constantly asking us if everything was okay and if we needed anything else :)
author: Tiffany H.

description:
How upsetting! I've had an on-off relationship with ramen for a few years now where I'll crave it like crazy and other days, I'm cheating on it with pho and wontons. I first heard about Katana-Ya when the craving started but never wanted to trek down to DT with the parking situation and traffic. I heard lots of reviews raving it and other people saying it was mediocre. 

I'm sad to say I agree with the mediocre critics. It's pretty upsetting considering their selections. I wanted to try their house special ramen with all the fixings but my gut told me it was going to take it out on my bum, so I decided to listen and go with the simple ramen. The noodles were definitely nice and chewy and the broth was okay. I didn't like paying $9 for a basic ramen. It only had one thin slice of cha siew and the rest were veggies. Would it really kill you to add more to my broth for $9. I don't care if the location is pricey in general, if I'm trekking all the way down there, give me a reason to come back!

The ramen was good overall, but not enough of an edge to bring me back. I've tried ramen in South Bay and they definitely hold the title for best ramen!
author: Connie C.

description:
I don't know if it's another change of ownership or just random Union Square touristy-ness or what.  Long ago they gave up on the sincere sweet Japanese food thing and just went for late night food for the masses.

On my latest visit everybody I knew was gone, there was a whole new crew that had more than a little trouble paddling the oars in terms of what was on the menu, what fish they had, and other basic stuff.

Thanks to Yelp and all the tourist guides there's still a long line out the door in prime time, I hope to heaven they honor all that attention but based on my experiences they don't.  To me this i the equivalent of an all night diner, cheap, basic food (with a Japanese bent in this case) at an affordable price if you're willing to lower your expectations.
author: Gil S.

description:
3.5
Had the soy sauce BBQ ramen here, typical ramen was. Not anything special, like. The other ramen places that specializes in specific broths like ramen dojo or ramen parlor, but if I'm in the neighborhood, I would give it about a 4 to go to but if I'm not in the neighborhood I would give it a 3. 
There was a heaping portion of ramen which I l like, but what I did not like is that it clearly says on the menu it has MSG and while eating I had to remind myself not to drink too much soup but by the end I was sooooo thirsty!!
I would not go out of my way for it but it would be a nice place to go to on a cold day, and when is went there was no line, it's a small place, so if I had to wait too long I would probably not eat here.
author: Steph Q.

description:
3.5 STARS

Slurp!  Slurp!  It was a cold day and a perfect time for a hot bowl of ramen!

I came with a group of  12 and we were seated quickly since we waited outside before they opened.  The place is small so there may be quite a wait during peak time for lunch and dinner.  The service is efficient given that our large party got all our orders rather quickly and with no mix ups.

They have a large variety of ramen to choose from, and I ordered the Katanaya Ramen with shoyu broth since it includes just about everything.  Not only do you get your standard ramen ingredients such as the hard boiled egg, seaweed, bamboo shoots, green onions, and corn, but also the BBQ pork, fried chicken, and fried potstickers!  Yes, quite unusual to have fried chicken and fried potstickers with your ramen, but it was a satisfying meal!  You may want to eat these first before they get too soggy from sitting in the broth too long.  The broth was flavorful but not greasy, and the ramen was good but could kick it up a notch in terms of chewiness.

Overall, I was pleased but not amazed with my meal, and I would come back if I was in the area and had a craving for a hot bowl of ramen.

Thank you Katana-Ya for the hearty meal!
author: Karen L.

description:
Bomb a$$ Ramen. So fresh, so tasty, filled with a billion things inside, right in my backyardigans. Small inside, always a wait, but so worth it. #DUHH #SCORE #YUM #GIMME

-Katanaya Ramen: Corn, fried chicken, fried potatoes, seaweed, scallion, bbq pork, & boiled egg
author: Monalisa M.

description: If you happen to be in Union Square and are craving Ramen and don't want to go anyplace too far, then this place will do the trick.  Don't expect great ramen, don't expect great service, don't expect any ambience, and don't expect comfortable chairs.  Expect to wait outside, as it's a tiny place, and quite frankly, if you have to wait, why not wait for some fantastic ramen someplace else?  Anyway, it's good only for its location.
author: Lyn Y.

description: Okay.  The katana-ya ramen was disturbingly greasy.  Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing, but seriously floating in grease.  Fast service, good sake.
author: Nicole B.

description:
This place is soooooooooooooo pricey for a hole-in-the-wall restaurant! My friend and I ordered 2 bowls of ramen and 1 sushi roll and ended up paying $25...each! ($43 + tax +tip). Ouch...my wallet just whimpered.

I think that's the biggest factor that weighs heavy on my mind...because just yesterday I shared 2 pretty hefty plates of delicious greek food with a friend for $17 in Alameda.

Is my complaint justified...?

Anywho, I've been meaning to try this place out for a while now because there's another version of this place in El Cerrito I typically venture out to with my siblings for good Bento Boxes.

Today, ventured the ramen:

---FOOD---
1) Kantanya Ramen, $12.90 
- Served with 2 fried pot stickers, 2 fried chicken pieces, 2 pieces of thinly sliced chasu, corn, 1/2 a boiled egg, and a heaping amount of fresh noodles.

You get to select what type of soup base you want:
- Soy sauce
- Miso
- Salt

I read on Yelp that the miso wasn't that great, so I tried the Salt while my buddy got the Soy sauce -- opt for the soy sauce base because the salty one is...REALLY salty! 

ALSO, the menu tells you blatantly that MSG is added. So for those of you that are actually allergic to it, be wary. BUT, Food Network's "Food Detectives" found that MSG doesn't truly have any significant side affects and that most of it is mental...so...don't worry about that! Just sayin.

2) Alaska Roll, $13
- This item is described as a salmon, avocado roll stuffed with shrimp tempura. On the 8 rolls...there was only 3 tiny slivers of avocado. Bah. So pricey for an average tasting roll. (Oh Yojimbo and Geta in the East Bay, how you make the world go round).

---AMBIANCE---
Small place with low dim-red-lighting, and holiday music in the background. We ate at the mini sushi bar that was adorned with holiday lights and xmas. Quite a comfy lil place with a long-line out the door by the time we left. 

---SERVICE---
Mediocre. Though, they don't check on the sign-in sheet outside as often as they should..eventhough they had some tables available. 

---FINALLY---
I'd come back just for the Katanya Ramen with the Soy Sauce base...but even then I'd have to seriously be craving ramen.
author: Gail N.

description:
I was thankful to catch a seat, in this tiny establishment, but the ramen did not fulfill the expectations that a crowded hole-in-the-wall promises.  I appreciate that the bowls were huge and the soups were piping hot.  The noodles were also no different than other ramen joints.  But the broth's flavors were in desperate need of more OOMPH!  I like oomph!  The line outside may have made me feel happy about my endeavor, but the ramen did not.  Now, off to find more oomph!

FYI- on a busy evening, you will be booted if you're done eating.
author: Diane N.

description:
Convenient little location near Union Square. Prepare to wait a little though because the place is small so seating is limit. Definitely prefer going with smaller groups, if possible. Tables are pretty close to each other so you'll have to cozy up. Always try to get there early to beat the lunch and dinner rush.

I love ramen so my go-to is always the Katanaya Ramen. At about $13, it includes fried chicken, fried potatoes, bbq pork, corn, seaweed, scallions, and a boiled egg. I like their miso broth much more than soy sauce. 

Food comes out quick and although service is not exceptional, they are very polite and helpful.
author: Chris Y.

description:
I like the broth.  It is hot and tasty.
The soba texture is just right.
The deep fried oyster is not bad.
Good eats!
author: Flora C.

description: Great late night eatery. Small and always a crowd. I recommend it's namesake ramen, rich broth and chock full of all the good stuff.
author: Charlene L.

description:
This is my go-to ramen shop in San Francisco. The four star versus five stars is mostly due to the lack of consistency in service, including one very bad experience over a year ago, but this last visit the waitress was pleasant and quick to place our order. My friend and I had to wait outside in line for a table as always, but the line goes quickly enough. I get the same thing every time, which is the spicy green onion ramen. This bowl of noodles is the closest I've ever come to recreating my all-time favorite ramen experience in Yokohama, Japan, where I studied in college. The broth is spicy but not overbearingly so (you can get extra-spicy by request) and not too thick, although you can thicken it by request as well. The green onions are a perfect contrast to the spicy broth, as they meet its integrity with strong flavor and a crunchy texture. Katana-ya cuts their green onions length wise as well as width wise, so you pick up long strands of onion along with your noodles as well as spoon them into your mouth with the broth. The bowl comes with bamboo shoots and nori. You can add other things such as soy sauce eggs (which normally come with ramen) but its an extra charge. I usually get the egg and extra bamboo but it ends up being $3-$4 more. If you're not as much as a ramen fan as I, they also have sushi and well priced lunch special combinations where you get a smaller bowl of ramen, soba or udon as well as something from the sushi bar or kitchen. And, of course, they sell cold Japanese beer and hot sake.

For you fellow Japan-o-philes who are familiar with the Japanese ramen scene, the ramen shop in Yokohama I mentioned is Hokkaido Ramen on Isezeki-cho. I've randomly met two people in the US who have also said this is the best ramen they've ever had. In all fairness, this style of ramen originated in Hokkaido which might be why its hard to find elsewhere, as it seems that most restaurants in San Francisco serve Tokyo-style ramen with light soy sauce or salt broths. However, I lived in New York for three years and have tried all kinds of ramen places and not one has come close to recreating that Yokohama experience. For some reason, spicy ramen is almost always miso based in the New York ramen joints which is not at all the flavor or consistency I crave. When it comes down to satisfying my passion for spicy ramen in the US, its Katana-ya in San Francisco or nothing.
author: Marie S.

description:
what can i say?  i really wish there were places like this everywhere across the country.  i mean, people should know ramen not just from the packages for a quarter from the super market.

we ordered the fried chicken ramen, the gyoza (which was standard), Katanaya ramen, Green onion ramen and Crispy spicy tuna- sushi with spicy sauce drizzled.  The soy sauce the best broth--I expected it to be very salty, but it really wasn't. The miso, was a little thick for my husband's liking.  but overall, it was an awesome evening of eating.  this place is definitely worth the wait. and i had to wait with my young kids.
author: mei s.

description: I was really excited coming here for ramen but its was pretty disappointing. My friends and I got a variety, each with a different broth (they have four), and I tried all of them. They were all very one note and none of the ingredients were special. There just wasn't a lot of thought or care put into flavor. And they barely give you anything other than the noodles. I've had much better and even made better with instant ramen. I feel bad because they were very nice to us, but really nothing about the food made me want to return.
author: Dexter H.

description:
This is one of those gotta-love mom and pop restaurants. Even though I prefer Ajisen Ramen in the Westfield food court, I feel compelled to like this place more just because of everything it represents: small business, divey hole-in-the wall, small gem in the Tenderloin.... 

The ramen is pretty good, though there isn't a whole lot of selection. The price is decent - about $8 for a bowl - but the portions aren't overly large. I can comfortably finish one bowl. I think I've only gone for the regular ramen with miso soup base the last couple times I came. It doesn't come with that much, but you do get a few slices of pork and some straggler vegetables thrown in. I can't say that it's the best I ever had, but it's pretty good.

I also got to try the lunch special with a salmon avocado roll, and I think that's definitely worth it. The roll is pretty big and you get big chunks of salmon. 

I like the atmosphere of the place. It's nice and cozy and the service is warm and prompt. I've only come here with a party of 2, and both times - dinner on a Sunday night and lunch on Friday - we didn't have too wait long. 

Verdict: I'll definitely come back!
author: Jamie C.

description: Sadly, not as good as I remember from my days in the bay :( Perhaps I've been spoiled by Ippudo and Menkui-tei in NYC but the ramen this time around was bland and boring, and they changed the kind of gyoza they serve. No longer as crispy or light. The lines are still as long as ever though...
author: Priscilla T.

description: Service here was terrible, waitress was rude and inattentive. Food was okay, definitely did not make up for the poor service. Portions are large, gyoza appetizer was good. Was with a large party and gratuity was not written on the bill but added to the total which was confusing. The manager corrected the error on the bill which was a relief. Will never go here again.
author: T. P.

description:
Why the fuck do people come to Katana-Ya for their shitty ramen?

Really, waiting in line for thirty - forty mins only to eat terrible, terrible ramen boggles my mind. And worse, these same people who cream over their bowl of ramen are writing egregious reviews on yelp, praising Katana's name in the same breath as good, great, and fantastic. 

This is all bullshit. 

People, do you realize how bad their noodles are? Or how crappy their broths are? Or the quality of their char siu? And their skyhigh prices? Look around the restaurant and spot the Japanese tourist from the ignorant locals. See that? That's the look of disgust. That's the feeling of being ripped off after spending 12 bucks on a bowl of shitty ramen. That's pain when the Japanese tourist realizes they are eating the most god awful ramen in their entire life, and is wondering why they took a chance to eat a ramen place outside of Japan. 

Call me a ramen snob all you want, but once you eat ramen in Tokyo, you'll never, ever accept mediocrity for awesomeness. Katana-ya is by far the worst offender for Yelp inflated ignorance, and I get irrationally angry  when reading five stars reviews for this place. God, stop spreading lies, people. Please stop.
author: Richard L.

description:
PROS
- Expansive ramen menu with combo options (there's something for everyone)
- Cheap ($10-$15 a meal)
- Fast (food comes out pretty quick)
- Friendly wait staff
- Location (downtown, near Union Square)

CONS
- Small, limited seating (cramped tables for more than 2 people)
- Not good for big groups
- Usually at least 30 min wait unless you go during off hours
- Busy and crowded

OVERALL
Katana-Ya is a decent ramen shop in SF.  That said, there aren't very many ramen shops in SF to begin with or compare to.  If this was in the South Bay, I'm not sure that it would be that crowded or highly rated.  People flock to this place because it is one of the few ramen shops in SF and it's centrally located downtown.   I have to caveat this review by saying that I am Japanese and might have a higher standard for ramen than the average person.  The ramen broth is OK--it's good, but definitely not the tastiest I've had.  The noodles are not freshly made, but still soft and chewy enough.  The fish is relatively fresh, given the high turnover.  But then again, it's very Americanized sushi rolls, etc. (e.g., lots of siracha sauce).  Overall, its a decent bowl of ramen with a good portion for the price, given the limited ramen places you can find in SF.
author: Miyuki I.

description:
Very tiny, always packed- finally got to try it, and now I know why there is always a line outside.

The menu includes sushi, sashimi, appetizers, ramen, soba, udon, and more. Everything is cheap, and comes out quickly. I'd never really been to a ramen spot before, but this place made me a fan.

We started with a dynamite roll and a super spicy roll. Both were spicy and delicious (which is good, because I hate ordering "spicy" things and having them end up not that hot), and only 6$ for 6 pieces.

My boyfriend ordered a spicy pork ramen. It came in a giant black bowl with tons of spicy broth. There wasn't much pork- just a little on the bottom- but it didn't really matter because it was super delicious regardless. Just the right amount of spicy, lots of noodles and tofu. And the bowl was huge, enough for leftovers for most people, for only about 9 bucks.

I ordered the noodle combo, and chose soba and spicy tuna don. I thoroughly enjoyed both. Nice miso style broth for the soba. All for about 14$. 

Definitely would come here again if I find myself back in San Fran.
author: caley t.

description:
mmm, I don't think i'll go back to this place.

The waitresses were really nice and kind but the ramen was no good at all. I've heard about this place from ppl who live in SF and they recomended me but no good. I know i can't have really good ramen in the U.S.(at this moment, not 5stars but the best ramen to me is TOTTO ramen in NYC) but I want them to improve their ramen more....
author: Oso S.

description: I came here after a long night from traveling across country, desperate for some good Asian comfort good. I had two things: the California roll and the fried chicken ramen. The California roll was a tasty appetizer, and the ramen was simply delicious. I got he Miso soup base with the fried chicken and was not disappointed. Plenty of food in a huge bowl. Miso broth tasted great, noodles were flavorful along with the various seaweed, green onions and bamboo shoots. Will definitely go again while I'm here. Very close to Union Square (about a block away). It was wonderfully dim inside in the middle of the day, quiet and friendly.
author: Presh C.

description:
I don't get it.

I was led here last year by my love of ramen and for theirs being listed on the 2011 7x7's Big Eat list. Safe to say it should be a match in heaven, right? WRONG. The first time I went I got the green onion ramen which was very bland, and the texture of the noodles was off. I left the place happy I tried it, but convinced I'd never return.

The 2012 Big Eat list came out earlier this year, and without fail, there it was again, lingering, like that one person who doesn't know when to leave the party. But then I started to question myself. 'Maybe I should give it another chance. Maybe I just ordered the wrong ramen.' Fast-forward a couple of months, and after a night of drinking in the area, surprise, I was hungry. And I craved ramen. So my cousin and I walked over to Katana-ya, grabbed a seat right before it closed (it closes late, that's a plus) and ordered a bowl of their chasu ramen. REDEMPTION!!

If only. Still bland, still the same. No amount of pepper or soy sauce could make it better, though it did make it more unhealthy. I kept asking my cousin if he felt the same way, and he agreed. Underwhelmed again. People say the katanaya bowl is pretty good, but I'm guessing it's because they throw the kitchen sink into it (fried chicken, potstickers, pork, egg). If good ramen is defined by how many fried pieces of food you can fit in the bowl, I'll gladly pass.

No hard feelings Katana-Ya. Alot of people seem to love you, so you'll keep getting good service. I'm just not a fan. You provided quick and easy service both times I went, and it's great you're open late. I'll keep going Ramen Dojo in San Mateo, and you can keep fighting the good fight. Everyone wins.
author: Stan A.

description:
This time I ate at Katana-Ya.  At first when I got here saw the people milling around outside, I was afraid I had made a bad decision for Friday lunch (I know, what was I thinking?).  But if you have a small group, like 2 people, the turnover is pretty fast and you won't wait more than 10-15 minutes.

It's tiny inside but doesn't feel crowded.  I didn't feel like I was eating on top of my neighbors and I didn't get bumped by waiters at all.  

This time we split a shrimp tempura starter and the katana-ya ramen.  The tempura batter is a slightly heavy but okay.  The bowl of ramen was huge.  I'm not sure how I finished it before.  I think I like the bbq pork better than the katana-ya.  The fried dumplings and fried chicken were okay, but I think I would prefer more bbq pork instead.
author: Jean K.

description:
Hands down the best ramen noodles I've ever had.   That may have had something to do with the fact that it was well after midnight when my girlfriend and I stopped by, or because we'd had a few late-night libations, or because we'd been flying all day and were still famished, but I'm pretty sure that none of those factors made a difference.  When our food arrived, it was incredible.  The noodles were firm, but not under-cooked.  The meat was tender and delicious.  But the broth...ohhhhhh the broth.  I could drink gallons of it.  Salty, sweet, filling, comforting, unicorns, glitter, rainbows, pots of gold...amazing stuff.  I'm pretty sure that if you bathed in it daily, you'd live forever.  Mostly because they may not serve it in heaven, making death and the concept of some sort of after-worldly paradise moot.  Try the ramen, any ramen here.  You'll love it.

A word of caution though: the hole-in-the wall descriptions of other reviews are not exaggerations.  It's tiny in there.  Only a handful of tables, most of which are two-tops.  We lucked out and were seated ahead of a group of three.  Yes, three.   They were incredibly angry and I'm pretty sure glared angrily at us the whole time were eating, but hey, we didn't notice because time and space and everything in it ceased to hold any meeting while savoring the ramen.  Seriously.  Try it.
author: The Dandy G.

description:
Like many things (diners, karaoke, jägermeister, unexpected evening guests), this place is way better when not sober!  Having come directly from an A.C.T. performance across the street, I was able to experience the food here for the first time with a clear mind and palate.  I've had a lot of good ramen in my day (mainly in Manhattan's East Village) so from that perspective I can't get really excited about this joint's oversized noodles and bland broth.  However, for the Union Square neighborhood and as a late night option, I can definitely see why it is so popular.  With all that in consideration, it is an A-OK (3-star) experience for me.

Gyoza: Standard - one side crispy and one side steamed.  The ground pork inside was tender.  Done well for this basic comfort food.

Katana-Ya Ramen (rich salt broth): Basically the "Kitchen-Sink-Ya" Ramen.  There was half a hard boiled egg which I expected more from.  If it's going to be half an egg, it should be semi-soft boiled for a gooey center.  If it's going to be a hard boiled egg, it should be sliced thin because the hard boiled yolk center is a tad overwhelming in a complete half egg bite.  The dark meat pork was tad too thin and tough.  The deep fried gyoza was like something from a Chinese take out joint in a bad neighborhood, they totally should have used their appetizer gyozas.  The salt broth, was well, salty.  I had hoped it would enhance the natural meat broth flavor but it did not as the meaty tone was still mild.  I'll get into the bits of fried chicken when discussing the next ramen...

Fried Chicken Ramen (rich soy broth): The good chicken karaage I've had in the past contained small, juicy morsels of dark meat chicken in a thin and crispy fried batter.  This karaage was oversized, overbreaded and tough instead of juicy tender.  As a by-product, the excess batter falls off into soup... which I'm neutral about though could see folks on either side of the fence on that point.  I appreciate that the soy broth didn't taste like eating pure soy sauce, but like the salt broth, it didn't help bring out the meatiness of the base.
author: Adam B.

description:
FRIED CHICKEN RAMEN.
 
That's right, put two of my favorite foods in one and then try telling me not to order it. Plus we bypassed an insane line of people waiting for some random reason, so they make me feel special.

Did I mention it's owned by Japanese? And that they put FRIED CHICKEN in their ramen??!?!!?!
author: Alita M.

description:
Never had been too much of a ramen person as it really struck to me as last resort college food for starving students, so damn did this place so easily knock that perception out of my head. Get the Katana-Ya ramen with the miso broth since it comes loaded with everything such as crispy dumplings and more meats. The regular ramen (though much cheaper) has only 1 small strip of bbq pork. Just one. 

And as crazy delicious as it all is, I'm still not sure if I could justify paying $12 for ramen since to me, it's still such a simple food... And the venue is very small with limited tables so come at an odd time!
author: Lily A.

description:
Long story short, its a very small Ramen house on Geary a small walk from union square and its open until 1am so its a good place to go if you finished shopping late and everything else is closing! 

Heres everything else I have to say about it. 

Looong wait! Got there around.. 9:30ish, was seated around 10:15 or so. VERY squished. Table fits about a bowl of noodles each person. Order anything more, and well, no space! We had  We had a party of 4 and where we sat, it seemed like a table for two. Very cool atmosphere inside. Dim and nicely decorated with all its prized "best ramen" articles around. 

Service.. their attention to you is only when you order, and when you finish. Quite hard to get anybody's attention if you needed something. 

For me, I ordered their spider roll and it wasnt too shabby. I'd order again if I had a choice. Nice BIG pieces. Think it was 4 pieces.. 
Now for their noodles, I ordered their KatanaYa ramen at the medium spicy level, the bowl with everything.. the pork, chicken, corn, garlic, etc. The soup was rich enough, not too spicy so I couldve went a level higher in spice. But as you eat on, it seems to become super salty.. so I figured the soup was maybe overloaded in sodium and MSG? Their menu says that their soups have MSG (even the bamboo shoots were crazy salty) Their noodles were very good! taste, texture, the way it soaks up the broth. 

All in all. I thought it was too long of a wait.. and too uncomfortable of a seating just for a bowl of noodles that were a tad too salty. But their location and how late they're open is very convenient. Supposedly voted best ramen place and how they do ramen 'right' But give it a try if you can!
author: Sharon L.

description:
My coworker dragged me here after a meeting near the civic center.  His "it's just around the corner" ended up being a hike through the Tenderloins in my 5 inch heels.  By the time we got to the place, I was starving and really had no patience to wait.  By the time my gi-normous bowl of ramen came out, all the blisters on my toes seem worth the walk. 

The place is tiny so I definitely woulnt come here to socialize with my coworkers or friends.  People eating here seem to be on a mission--to eat.  Despite the long wait, once we were seated, we were able to place our order and did not have to wait too long to get out food.

I like how you could basically customize your own ramen.  I got the super spicy (well I asked for super spicy) and it was just right.  The broth was excellent and yes, I will definitely return but maybe bring my walking jelly shoes..
author: J M.

description: This place has gone down. What seemed like an SF cult classic has now turned into another over salted tourist trap with B grade sushi and random bowls of chop-suey like ramen (aka Katayana Ramen). But if you have to eat ramen and you can't get to a respectable place down the peninsula (or all way to complete respectability in SJ at Orenchi), then you gotta do what you gotta do and wait your 45 min to get into this small alley of a joint. Enjoy.
author: Elton L.

description:
Their service and host recently has really picked up on the waiting list which is nice! Now that there is a extended downstairs, the wait for this place is a lot quicker. I prob had 7-8 parties in front and only waited 15 mins. 

My go to order is of course the Katana-Ya Ramen which is one of my fav ramen because I get the best of everything. There is literally everything in this choice of miso based ramen including the deep fried pot stickers, corn, mushroom, pork belly, seaweed, etc. This ramen bowl is fulfilling, the noodles arent too hard or soggy, and I love its portion!

I know a secret that many alcoholics don't know about this place though :) Found out that the red wine they charge for $7 is just really $2 Charles Shaws from Trader Joes tsk tsk! So order up some sake or beer instead with that ramen or sushi and enjoy!
author: Shirley L.

description: Visiting San Fran and staying close by so per yelp checked it out.. Food and Service were both good with no wait on a Friday at 10:30pm (flew in late). Prices weren't crazy too which was nice.  Defiantly coming back again next time I am in town.
author: Yuri W.

description: I still like the food, be careful if you want to use a groupon. The owner has decided not to accept them anymore, even though they have not expired
author: Will H.

description: instant noodles, salty broth, dirty interior, hungover waitresses, and please stop serving fried dumplings and chicken in the soup!
author: Sherman L.

description:
Katana-Ya's msg enhanced ramen broth is the glorified version of Cup O Noodles. In a city where there's no shortage of restaurants serving delicious and well made food using fresh ingredients, I'm surprised to read people are quite content with a ramen shop that uses msg and even wait in line for it. Heck, even the cheap Chinese restaurants proudly say no to msg. Are the tourists giving the rave reviews coz, I mean, come on, really? Even with msg it's mediocre at best. Plus my drinking glass smelled fishy. If like me you get a headache after slurping a bowl Katana-Ya's broth, rest assure it's the msg doing all the dirty deed.

Skip the line and head on west of the city. Get farther than Japantown (ironically) if you can, though Suzu is tolerable in a pinch. Get yourself in Sunsets or Richmonds to get the better ramen SF has to offer. There are different types ranging from the creamier tonkotsu broth to the lighter shoya or miso broth, so choose your shop based on your taste preference.
author: Rina W.

description: Came here for dinner on a Wednesday at about 5:30 p.m. for a pre-theatre dinner.  Food wasn't very memorable.  What's memorable was how the server tried to rush us out and how cramped this restaurant was.  We finished dinner a little bit after 6:00 p.m.  Ended up having to kill the remaining evening before the show next door at Colibri.
author: Anne S.

description: mediocre ramen. wasn't impressed at all. Much prefer orenchi or mitsuwa. price is a little bit high too, but it is in the city so that's expected. wait is also long, it is not worth the wait i would say. try other cuisine in the city, many better choices.
author: Jiaomin O.

description:
Based on a friends recommendation, we went to Katana-Ya during our stay around Union Square.  It's a small hole in the wall, so be prepared to wait.  I was seated by the bar and was left freezing all night since they decided to keep the side door opened.  However, I must say the food compensated for everything else.  We don't have any good ramen shops in Houston so I went with the miso ramen, extra extra spicy, basically the spiciest one on the menu!!  I am always up for a good challenge!  The ramen broth was delectable, and covered in a red slick of spicy oil.  See my pic attached.  The ramen alkaline noodles had a nice chewy texture as well.  The appetizers were decent, but honestly, we weren't hungry especially after downing a couple animal style in n out burgers!

Great ramen if you can overlook the size of the restaurant.  Definitely will be back if I am back in the bay area!
author: Eric L.

description:
Kantana-Ya is probably one of the best ramen spots in SF (in my opinon and that's what counts). Despite the tourist chatter and the ruthless bums at union square, it is a little knook of splendidness.

The vegetable ramen is so amazing! Lots of good veggies. Sometimes I'll order the sushi roll with rame, but FYI it's a lot of food so be very hungry. The ramen noodles are cooked to perfection, the spiciness is always just enough. 

It's a small spot, and the line can be gruesome, but it's well worth it. My mouth is watering thinking of that salty flavorful broth... that's what she said.
author: Tova L.

description: Katanaya katanaya. I heard so much about this ramen place before coming here. It was pretty decent but I can't even really remember it anymore. =( Might have to come back and try it again. I really like noodles and ramen so I'll give this place 4 stars, but I know if a ramen place is amazing, I'll remember it.
author: Annie Z.

description: The ramen here is good but the service I encountered was ridiculous. I decided to bring my friend here for her birthday and we felt so unwelcomed. Our waiter was rude and didn't even let us finish our sentences at times. Plus when it came to paying she didn't even give our change back. I hope next time I don't get the same waiter because I really enjoy the ramen.
author: Christabel R.

description: the restaurant is pretty narrow and small not too big. I  number 14  pretty big for me to finish. The philly roll is okay. cream cheese and salmon. Our bill was surprisingly high for here .. The ridiculous part is they now charge a service charge which is like tips. so regardless of good service or bad they get a tip. they charge us a total of $10 for service charge .. it's only the two of us. which is pretty bs. .. they almost forgot my philly roll until I ask them about it.. I'm disappointed in this place. I might here again just to take my friends out to ramen when they visit one time only. but other than that I won't come back
author: May L.

description: Miso was average, it was bland but could be better if chilli (medium spice) was added. Noodles were ok. Weird music in the background made it off putting atmosphere.
author: Alice T.

description:
Cute little Japanese spot. I've heard about this place many times from friends, and happened to have dinner here a few weeks ago with my boyfriend. We were in the mood for noodle soups, and he decided to come here. The spot is cute, service is average, food is good, and the price makes it all even better.

The Ramen here is good, but not the best I've had. However, it is better than all of the other places I've tried in SF. While we were here, we both ordered combos of ramen + rolls - got Spicy Tuna and Unagi Rolls. Can't remember how much it was exactly, but I remember it being a good deal ($12-$13?) The rolls were okay - not bad, but not great.

I thought this place was great for the value. It's also a cute place and everything is very comforting. The portions of their Ramen are also pretty big - I feel like the bowls are bigger than most places. I would definitely come back for a casual Japanese food fix. Yum!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Okay, so I'm bumping up the rating a star level.

After coming her about 4 times in the last two weeks, it's quickly becoming THE "go-to" spot for late night ramen endeavors.  No one else is open this late (1:15am 7-days a week).

Again, best ramen in the country: ...maaaayyyybee.
Best ramen in the Bay: possibly depending on preference.
Best ramen in downtown SF: yes!

I've tried both udon and soba noodles and both are good.  Suzu still has the freshest noodles out of anyone else, but this ain't bad.  So far I've tried the Katanaya ramen and the Karaage ramen, both of which are consistently good.  Their pork is a little tough/dry for my taste, but the gyoza and chicken are good.

One thing that sets this place apart is that they do serve sushi.  Sometimes I'm just not hungry enough for ramen, but the gf is, so I just tried their sushi this week and it's actually decent.  Maybe above decent, but not stellar.  However, it'll definitely get you by...and you can order until 1:15am.

Everyone from the servers to the chefs are all really nice folks.  And it is really a typical hole-in-the-wall so I'd hesitate to try to come with a party of 4, but it's possible.  One drawback of going there so late is all the bums lurking around...so watch out!
author: Dylan T.

description: This is the best noodle house and sushi bar outside of Osaka!  You will enjoy their incredible menu selection.  They often have Toro available and I swear it will melt in your mouth.
author: Norris B.

description:
Yum!  I like this place, but  just not as much as Santa Ramen.  

I had the Soy Sauce ramen with regular noodles, and there was barely any bamboo shoots but lots of seaweed and green onions.  Anyhow, the broth was delicious and super salty - the way I like it.  I ordered the lunch combo, so I also got a bowl of kimchi fried rice which tasted like hash browns and breakfast sausage (how does that happen?).  Despite the unexpected taste, the rice wasn't bad.    

Their curry was bland and kind of boring, but the service was good and there wasn't much of a wait!  Although, the restaurant is pretty small - I can't imagine it could ever be good for groups.

I'm adding the 5th star, because I JUST REALIZED that this place is open late!  And SO CLOSE to Slide and Ruby Skye and a whole mess of other bars downtown.  SCORE!!!
author: Cora L.

description:
5-Second Review: 

Overpriced 'ramen', small small joint, decent spicy tuna bowl.

5-Minute Review:

I had just finished running the San Francisco Marathon [1st Half] and it was a cold day, so I wanted something hot to warm me up. Ramen it is!

I Yelp'd around for the best ramen in town and all of the roads pointed to Katana-Ya. I should read the writing on the wall when other Yelpers wrote 'best ramen in town because there is a limited number of ramen places in SF'. 

I decided to get the most basic ramen bowl with a side of spicy tuna-don. Polus T. got the ramen bowl with extra veggies and extra bbq pork. When the food arrived, we both knew we were in for major disappointment.

The pork was overcooked in comparison to the typical chashu you'd usually get with ramen. We both got the salt based broth and knew right away that it didn't seem right. The broth just didn't look right, and it certainly didn't taste the way it's supposed to.  Maybe they just royally screwed up on our bowls, but it tasted like water with some added artificial flavoring. There was no real richness to the soup that I usually experience when I get the salt base broth at ramen joints.

The ramen seemed to be consistent with that of SoCal's Daikokuya, a little thicker and slightly al dente. I like mine more like Shinsengumi Hakata, which is still my favorite ramen joint for strictly ramen.

The other ingredients that came with the ramen were forgettable, as I really did forget what else came with it. I think I was so hungry after the race that I inhaled all my food, but I ate it only because it was there.

The place is really really small, and as others have said, a party of 4 is already considered 'big'. The servers, while not rude, were really 'short' with us. If we weren't ready in 2~3 seconds after getting their attention, they fluttered off somewhere else and we'd spend a few more minutes getting their attention. Their English was not the best, so pointing at pictures was the next best option.

The highlight of my meal was the Spicy Tuna don that came with my ramen. The Spicy Tuna really was quite spicy and tasted pretty good.

Overall, I don't think I'd ever come back since SF has so many better offerings to show. I've had much better ramen at much more affordable prices. Sorry Katana-Ya, you just weren't worth it.
author: Andrew F.

description:
This place is too over-hyped! With 4 stars and 2000+ reviews--it must be amazing right? Ehhhhhh...not really. If you want something inexpensive (for the amount of food you get), overly greasy and filling, come here!

The wait was about 20 minutes for a Sunday night around 9PM for a group of 3, they sat us at the bar. They definitely deliver in terms of quantity but not quality. I ordered the namesake ramen with miso broth--a tad on the salty side and very oily. The deep fried items (chicken and potsticker) in the bowl were yummy for about 10 seconds before becoming this soggy mess and the noodles were soggy to begin with. The only saving grace was the thin sliced cha siu, it had a good flavor and not too much fat.

When the bill came we asked for 3 separate checks instead they brought over one check for us to split. We put down 3 cards and they accepted it at first before returning and rudely slamming down ours cards shouting "only 2 cards per table for bills under $100.00". First of all we're not even at a table, nor did you give us the option of waiting for one before you place us there. Secondly, who would spend over $100.00 at a ramen place? Stop making excuses and just tell me that you don't want to split the check 3 ways because it's expensive/you're lazy.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Bummer.  Just when I thought Katana-ya was a no-fail, consistently tasty option, I have been proven wrong.

Note: Don't get your ramen extra spicy.  It's super oily and not spicy at all.  Halfway through skimming the top oily layer of my soup, I realized the whole soup was oil and there was no miso base.

I'd still come back though.  The sushi is consistently fresh and tasty, and I'll take my chances on the ramen.
author: Betty W.

description:
I went on a bad date here a long time ago, didn't get laid. But at least the ramen was delicious.

I asked for my ramen to be EXTRA SPICY. (C'mon man, I'm asian can you blame me. This is not a question, this is a statement). It wasn't spicy at all, asked for more hot sauce. 

Gave me a a tiny ass excuse for a dish with hot sauce.

Asked for more 2x's then decided to just ask for the damn bottle. 

In the end it worked out and it was delicious, except for the date. There was nothing delicious about the date.
author: Thao L.

description:
We went there last night for an early dinner at like 5:45PM so no wait but it got quite busy shortly after. I didn't expect it to be quite as small in size but it was cozy. We ordered the green onion ramen, katana ramen, and fried chicken ramen and some appetizers. I'm not a big noodle soup person but since this place was famous for their ramen, I had to try it. The green onion ramen was ok. The broth was really good but the noodles were a little soft. 

The appetizers we ordered were pretty good though - Salmon Don, Salmon Skin Salad, and Cold Tofu. 

would definetaly go back but going to stick with a rice dish
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
I am a ramen expert. I can say that loudly and proudly.

I've lived in Japan for a long time and my favorite ramen flavor is tonkotsu. The best place to get tonkotsu ramen in Japan is Ichi-ran and Ippudo. Tonkotsu ramen requires a really long time to make. You start the broth with boiling pork bones, fat, and collagen for many many hours and if you do it correctly, and only if you do it correctly, you'll get a nice, rich, creamy, cloudy, intense flavored broth at the end. 

I've both seen long lines at Katana-ya and read up reviews about how amazing their ramen was before I went to try it out.
I went on a weekday around 1 pm; the line wasn't bad, my friend and I got in without having to wait.
