We sat at the bar and memories of Japan rushed back as people around us were conversing in Japanese. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen, (I was going to order the tsuke-men but they said they stopped doing that) and I can't remember what my friend got since it wasn't memorable enough.

Maybe it is because I had too much expectations for this place; as soon as I slurped my first spoonful of the broth, I was disappointed. It wasn't creamy and cloudy as I was expecting and it certainly wasn't rich either. It tasted like they got some pre-made tonkotsu broth paste and mixed it with water and served it. So the broth wasn't good, maybe the noodles would be nice and chewy. I was wrong again. The noodles tasted bland. The broth didn't soak into the noodles like it's supposed to. The noodles tasted like they have been frozen for months and costed less than a cent to buy. Even the chashu was gross. And afterwards I felt sick and dizzy. It must from all the MSG they put in. 

From then on, I just go to Tanpopo; their kara-miso never disappointed me.
author: Erica L.

description: Just had this ramen last friday and its really good, but unfortunately the place are too small and like a closet than a restaurant.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Small Ramen Joint, Packs a Big Punch in flavor!!! Loved this place. I got the house katana ya ramen, with the rich broth and extra pork. Sooo delicious! Broth was so flavorful, I loved the juciy chicken and pork inside and perfectly cooked hard boiled egg and al dente noodles. Everything came together beautifully. 

The place is pretty small. You are looking about a 30 top restaurant in downtown tenderloin. A little bit of a wait but it is soo worth it. The fried chicken and calamari was wonderful. So tender and perfect asian style aioli and side salad that went so well with them. Awesome dining experience! Will come back again.
author: Joseph G.

description: The best I've had so far..great selection of fish as well as ramen. I recommend it!
author: Gina N.

description: Went for the first time for such a Ramen experience. It was quite interesting. I enjoyed my soup/meal very much. I had the chicken (karaage) ramen. I didn't like that the chicken was fried I wish it was more chicken breast way, but nontheless nice place and meal. Will return again!
author: Tanvi C.

description:
Small busy joint in DT, it gets super packed at night.
I came on a busy night, hoping to grab a bite before heading over to a party....

Well what can I say...

I'm sure that my stomach was nicely coated with oil and who knows what enough to protect my body from hurling up all the alcohol I downed that night.

I used to eat whatever the hell I wanted, and stuffed everything down this awesome body of mine, and honestly I would've given it more stars except my body can't handle everything I used to eat. It's like the soup is trying to clog your arteries.

I believe I got the butter corn ramen.
Their ramen is good but the soup just tasted too hearty. I liked it, I just felt like they didn't have to add so much of whatever they put in their ramen. Noodles were also overcooked, almost soggy-like.

I will be back, though. Maybe for a healthier option.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
One of my fave ramen spots in SF! I like to get the spicy green onion ramen combo with kimchi fried rice. The combo portions are actually really large, I never manage to finish everything. The soy and miso broths are both really good. I would recommend getting them "light" and not "rich" because the rich broth tends to get really greasy.

Great ramen, but just be prepared for a long wait and average service.
author: Meesh N.

description: I have to say this is by far the worse ramen I have ever had.  I'm from SD and have had nothing but good ramen down there.  I got the katana ramen miso flavored.   I have no idea how some people actually like this ramen place.  The noodles weren't even the thin ones.  I didn't know what I was thinking when I saw the corn was included in the ramen.  Do yourself a favor and stay away from the Ramen.
author: Dan B.

description: First of all, nice soup noodle.  I ordered the fried chicken soup ramen with appetizer of the fried soft shell crab.  The soup choice was miso and I liked it.  However, it really took a long time to get the noodle and when I started to eat it, my boyfriend had already finished his.  It is a restaurant that you wanna go if it is nearby and it won't disappoint you because you probably don't hope anything fancy.
author: Benoît L.

description:
It is solid. Nothing spectacular, but nothing horrible.

Service is attentive, but nothing special.

The ambiance is cozy and quaint.

It is the type of place that one would find themselves running into on a cold, rainy SF day.

What to get?

Ramen!

I usually go with the spicy tofu and slurp away.

Katan-Ya is not the best ramen joint in town, but it does ramen well and is convenient for those near in the downtown area.
author: Richard K.

description:
A limerick dedicated to Katana-Ya:

This ain't no top ramen, mind you
It's a soy broth and porcine to-do.
There's a line out the front
You'll utter a grunt
When they get you tore up on soju.
author: Eli B.

description: Favorite ramen spot in SF so far (granted I haven't tried that many yet) and might even beat Totto Ramen in NYC. I went late on a weekday and ordered the butter miso ramen with corn. It must have been 3000 calories but so worth it.
author: Jia H.

description:
6/11/11
Literally 200 feet from our hotel just being around the corner...we were so pleasantly surprised! There was short wait...the place is soo tiny and crowded, but you can tell why...the food was yummy good...
author: Belle N.

description:
It's a small restaurant and sometimes its a bit of a wait or it just means its good food. Best part they are open till 1:15 am!
There menu is great because they have really good lunch combos.  There is also something for everyone who is craving Jap food from Ramen, to sushi, to Donburi's. My favorite is the salt flavored green onion ramen with the uni and ikura don combo (Thats Sea urchin and salmon roe over rice)  and dite coke or pepsi no Ice.  Bouns point they always remember me and never put ice in my drink water or soda.  The ramen has an amazing broth full of flavor and the noodles are just as great.  If you are in just for the ramen, the deep fried chicken Ramen is also on of my faves.
They also have some really good assortment of sushi rolls and beer by the pitchers!  what more can a girl ask for!
author: Michelle A.

description:
Small place in downtown. Most of the time it's crowed, but if you're in downtown and really want ramen. It's worth the wait. 

Food: 
The food is pretty decent. I wish they had more soup base to choose from. They only have Miso, Soy Sauce, and salt. The ramen isn't hand-made, so it's not really the best. It's just okay...

Service: 
Service was quick and semi-friendly. Although after you get your food, they kind of just leave you alone. Which is great if you want to just sit and chat and eat, but kind of sad when you want your tea or water refilled. 

Overall: 
Great place. I would recommend to others.
author: Christina L.

description:
Ramen = good
Sake = good
Service = good
Atmosphere = good
Sushi = good

I'll be back
author: Jennea N.

description:
Surprisingly busy at 2pm on Superbowl Sunday, but the 20-minute wait wasn't bad, and there was plenty of people-watching to be had!

Had the Spicy Tofu Ramen which was scrumptious, although not as spicy as I expected. Still top-notch ramen at an excellent price!

One downside, the wait staff were quite inattentive, but the taste made up for it!
author: Gwen T.

description: I moved to San Francisco two years ago and really hadn't eaten Ramen before. I stumbled upon many reviews of Katana-ya, and honestly it lived up to the hype. It's a little pricier than I thought it would be, but the broth is tasty not salty, and the noodles are fresh. Paired with a tall Sapporo, you can't get a better meal downtown!
author: Kim O.

description:
I tried the katanaya ramen in light miso soup for dinner. It was alright, but then again, I was also still full from a late lunch that day, so that could have affected my level of enjoyment for this meal. 

My friend ordered the same option with light salt base. I think that tasted a lot better, miso was probably too flavorful for me. 

I was disappointed that the egg yolk was not of gelatin/creamy texture, it was fully cooked.
author: Caroline S.

description:
I've been here a couple of times now and love it.  It is very small and can get crowded fast.  Great place to quench that craving for ramen.

My only wish is that their noodles were as good as QQ (no, QQ is not a ramen house, but their noodles are killer.  I've also reviewed them).

Service here does lag when they are busy.  i.e. the last time a friend and I were there, we had to ask for a menu after waiting about 5 min..  However, I am not knocking them for this since I knew what to expect going in there at lunch time.

Anyone that likes ramen should def give this place a try and for those that don't know much about ramen, this is a good place to start.

BTW, they also do sushi here, but I've never tried it.
author: Khim Y.

description: As one of the most reviewed ramen place, the noodle tastes like plastic. I'm confused.
author: Shannon C.

description:
Sukiyaki rice bowl was awesome!!!

Tried the ramen but it wasn't anything special...
Noodles were too soft and not thin enough, broth wasn't clinging to the noodles well, and the combination of toppings didn't really compliment the whole thing.
author: Yuki A.

description:
Each year on my annual trip to San Francisco, I inevitably end up at Katana-Ya for the 45-minute or hourlong wait.  Because the ramen is just that good.  I've never had anything else here, and always admire the super fresh-looking sushi as it comes out, but I'm sold on the soup, baby.

Any selection with the spicy miso broth is wonderful, and the katana-ya special ramen is a potpourri of goodies -- wontons, sliced pork, veggies, chicken -- it's like an appetizer and meal in one big steaming bowlful.  And if you're a spicy fiend like I am, ask for it super hot.  My sinuses have been clear for a month, thanks to that decision.

Plus, it's open late so there's really no excuse to miss this spot!
author: Jill H.

description:
Saturday, 10:00PM.

Quickie:
*Cramped place, long lines
+Nice service
+Ramen bowls are good
- Slow response though!

And then...?
Finding a decent noodle joint in the city is surprisingly difficult. 

*********
Stuffed my face in:
1. Regular ramen (with extra noodles, +$2.00)
     +Miso broth hit the spot
     - Extra noodles were not so "extra" (I'm a phatty)

2. Wakame salad
     - Plate bedding (ie. lettuce, arugula) was half of the dish (should be more 
     wakame!)
author: Chuck N.

description:
This place is awesome! I've been here twice already.

First time I ordered: Udon + Tofu Don
Second time: Udon + Veggie Tempura Don + Salmon Avocado Roll

So far my food has been fabulous, service is pretty good, wait time for food is reasonable considering the size of the place. The only hiccup this place has...ITS TINY.  You shouldn't go with more than 4 people, max. They just can't accomodate that many guests. I've heard during peak days/hours there is a line out the door...

But awesome food, and if there was a line out the door, I'd be waiting in it. :)
author: Ashley H.

description:
This place has been redeemed!  After trying a few other ramen places in the city it was nice to come back here first of all, and then on a weekday late night to get some grub, lastly I found parking right in front and we didn't have to wait - completely unheard of.  

I had the combo, Udon & Katsu Don.  Totally hit the spot after a long day.  My bf had the Fried Chicken Ramen in rich, miso broth - the broth was damn tasty.  I loved my dish - the udon was made to perfection, chewy noodles!   And one can never go wrong w/ katsu don.  We also shared an order of gyoza which I thought was super tasty.  My bf thought it could've been smaller since he thought it felt more like a potsticker :)  I didn't care as much.  With all that and just water to drink it totaled to $40 with tip & tax.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I've never been a huge ramen fan, but a couple more trips to Katana-Ya may very well turn me into a fanatic.

Came here around 6:45 pm, barely beating the dinner crowd. We were seated within 15 minutes and therein begins my adventure to ramen greatness. 

The Katana-Ya ramen was awesome. Filled with an assortment of different fillings, my hungry self soaked it all in. Nomnomnom. And yes, the fried chicken they add is no joke. It's such a good complement.

A bowl will fill you up and leave you happily satisfied. Despite the crowded seating arrangement and the slightly higher prices, Katana-Ya definitely is the type of place that I'll aim to come back to again and again. Located in tourist central, the atmosphere  - both inside and outside Katana-Ya -  easily breeds good company and good times.
author: Tom P.

description:
After waiting outside for 20 minutes, I went swimming in a bowl of ramen. 

Yup, the Katana-Ya Ramen is a big order. I think I remember these things being in it: pot sticker, corn, dumpling, pork, seaweed, bamboo, hard-boiled egg, elephant foot, tiger blood, lion heart, bison leg, brontosaurus thigh and miso broth. It was good, but, boy, was it filling. Maybe we shouldn't have ordered the unagi rice bowl and three orders of nigiri: tako, amaebi and toro. Who am I kidding? Of course we should have ordered it.

The toro was fresh and affordable, for once, and the amaebi came with the heads deep-fried, which is the only way to eat shrimp heads. 

We stumbled out of Katana-Ya full of ramen, sushi and contentment. Oh, and brontosaurus thigh.
author: Tim O.

description:
This is a real ramen place. Id prefer this over ramen dojo anyday. Its located in a place that is very scarce on parking so if youre in the area you might as well spend some of the day downtown shopping. 

Its a small, dark place but once you get your food everything seems a lot better. I had a good experience here so I'll give them 5 stars since I'm not too particularly picky with other things as people are. 

A spot you can go to more than once!
author: Tim M.

description:
Pretty good ramen! Not the best I've had, but really not bad.

The place is really small - seats 30 people max (I counted while waiting for my group to show up). The tables are really small though. I'd approximate 3 feet by 1.5 feet thats suppose to seat 4 people??  Man...I guess they're going for Japanese-person size. Boo.  Also, the tables are really close to each other. Just an FYI - all you stroller people (there were at least 3 families that came while I was here), please leave the deluxe stroller at home. Just carry your child, you lazy bum.  The huge strollers really didn't work out well to maneuver around the "cozy" space here.  And you child cries. A lot. Just saying.

Got here around 5:30 to make sure we had a table for 8 (yeah, we took over 1/3 of the place!) and it was a GOOD DECISION! By the time 6PM rolled around, there was already a like of 2 parties waiting for a seat!  And this was Sunday night!  Generally, I'd say don't go with more than a group of 4. Just seems like a bad idea...

Most of us had ramen, including me. Had to get the BBQ Pork, to cross off my 7x7 list.  I...don't get why it's on 7x7.  I mean, its good ramen, don't get me wrong. But its not amazing. And to be on that list, I expect amazing (who greased a few palms? Ehh??).  The ramen wasn't soggy,. wasn't crunchy, but the texture was what I expect good noodles to be.  The soup, you get a choice of Miso, Soy or Spicy (spicy cost extra), and I went with Miso. Pretty good.  Although I also loaded it up with the chili...  Its a little overly salty though.
author: Lily W.

description:
Before I forget, adding another review to this popular ramen place.

It's a small restaurant in the middle of the bustle of union square that usually has a waiting list. Usually any place with a constant waiting list sets me up to expect amazing food. Half the time it is, the rest it's just good.

This is definitely in the 'good' category. Both times the broth was yummy and the noodles stood out from other joints but it's not my favorite place. I like my broths more fragrant and strong and these were more delicate if not slightly bland. You definitely get huge portions and that is a plus when you're super hungry, great price for ratio I would say.

They're fast and the service is good. I would come here for  a ramen craving or when it's cold and you want something warm and cozy. I just wouldn't set too high an expectation and you'll end up perfectly happy.
author: Sam H.

description: Katana-Ya it´s really good, we came in 2012 and now again, and they have a really good ramen, we tried the Katana-Ya Ramen, miso spicy, maguro-don and of course some hot sake for the San Francisco cold weather, recommended!  TIP: the waiting list at the door so you don´t have to find someone to put your name on it or to know how many tables you´re going to wait!
author: Francisco M.

description: San Francisco is blessed with some of the best ramen places I've ever been to. This place is no exception. However, with 1000+ reviews, I feel that another extensive review chiming in on how good the food is will simply be redundant. So in short, if you love ramen, this place is a must try. My recommendations: Katanaya Ramen and the Unagi Don. Mmm that Unagi don was a little piece of heaven.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I came here for the Chasu Ramen that's on 7x7's Big Eat 2012 list. We came during a dead hour, around 4pm, so there weren't many people there. We were seated right away and our waiter came, took our drink orders, and apologized for the smell in the restaurant because they had a repairman fixing the fridge. I thought that was nice because I didn't smell anything, lol. 

The Chasu Ramen was pretty good- came with a few slices of chewy flavored pork, some bean sprouts and seaweed. You can choose your broth either miso, soy, or something else based. I got it with miso. I also ordered it extra spicy for $1.40. 

The service was good and food decent.. although, I'd still rather go to Ajisen Ramen in the mall.
author: Chau T.

description:
I went here in May 2010 and I went back again in Dec. 2010. I tried alot of places in Texas and can't find a good ramen place. I felt like I was so deprived and definitely needed to go back! BBQ ramen is my favorite, but I got to try the Katana-Ya ramen. All time favorite ramen place for now.  

Seating 2 people is faster so just leave your other friend home. LOL
author: Cali H.

description:
Late night soup after a few drinks... IT WAS GOOD.
I am not a ramen soup kind of a person, but this place is good.  Would I go back yes... HOWEVER, be prepaired ... smells like FISH - OBVIOUSLY (sushi-bar)
author: Belina G.

description:
Went back and tried the karaage (fried chicken) extra-spicy ramen.  I would NOT recommend getting anything extra spicy here, as you get a big bowl of fire-engine red, oily broth.  It's not too spicy...it just doesn't taste good.
Best stick with medium-spicy for the flavor.

And fyi, they removed their tsukemen from the menu.
author: Nancy O.

description:
Oh Katana-Ya, I SOOO wanted to give you the 5 stars... I really did... but sadly, your sushi just doesn't come up to snuff with your ramen!! 

I had the pleasure of coming on a Friday night and was surprised at how PACKED the place was.  The restaurant is tiny and therefore all of the waiting takes place outside.  There are a handful of tables inside as well as a bar area to sit and enjoy the ramen.  After a short wait, we were seated, so don't worry - don't let it discourage you.

The best ramen ever - at least that's what my husband though.  I opted for the miso based soup with the deep fried chicken ramen.  Sounds weird, but it works.  In retrospect, I should have tried the soy sauce based soup - heard really good things about it.  I think the thing that made the ramen so good was that the soup had so much flavor packed in it! Dang, I'm hungry just thinking about it (and it's about 85 degrees outside).  

Aside from the ramen, they also have sushi.  The albacore tataki was great... the rest was ... only okay.  Sadly to say, it wasn't memorable enough for me to really remember everything that we had.  To my recollection we had some variation of an alaskan roll - with the salmon.  

My recommendation - get the ramen, come early, come often!
author: Michelle N.

description: If there were zero stars, I would give it.  This is usually my go to ramen spot in the city when near union square, but today I found that the restaurant is no longer run by the same owner.  The menu is different, the service is horrible and the ramen is below average.  Noodles were over cooked, Gyoza in the ramen were cold (seems like they didn't defrost the frozen gyozas well enough). And to boot, there was a surcharge of $1.00 + for spicy, extra spicy and/or habanero.  I was disappointed that I wasted my time, money and appetite on a $14 ramen that was worth $5, at best.  #ramenfail!
author: Nalen U.

description:
I've had BETTER ramen than this.

If you're around downtown area, sure it's a good place to sit down and have some overrated ramen, but first, you gotta wait in LINE...worth the wait? if you're dying for ramen, that's your best bet I guess.

If you're looking to order to-go, DON'T bother. I waited mine for at least 20-30mins, while the people who were waiting in line, GOT IN, ORDER, and Started eating before me. HOW IS THIS POSSIBLE?

ps: If you're sensitive to MSG, then you're in big trouble. My friend and I ate there one time, and we both got SUPER BLOATED, it's disgusting. So make sure you ask for NO MSG....
author: Chi L.

description:
Where do you go when you have a show at The Curran?  KATANA-YA!  This place always has a line and the restaurant is small.  

We got here early, 5:30 and the restaurant was completely full.  We got lucky and a table was just getting up and leaving so we were seated within 5 minutes once they cleaned the table.  The interior is dark and a bit grungy but they deliver A-OK ramen and QUICK!

I actually think in terms of quality of ramen I prefer Izakaya Sozai in the inner Sunset or Himawari in San Mateo but when you're feening for ramen and getting off work DT, there isn't really any replacement except for Katana-Ya.  We ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen with miso and seawood.   The food came within 10 minutes of ordering hot and ready to be gobbled up.  The boyfriend isn't a fan of this place because the taste isn't there for him but I think you get a lot of quantity and an overall decent bowl of soup.  I've been there a handful of times and they have some inconsistencies but overall I keep coming back.  The soup comes out hot and brothy, the noodles are OK and all of their meats and sides are given in generous quantities.  

I think my 3 star is because theyre so concerned about getting people in and out that they start to lose the quality of the food.  The broth was a bit too greasy, the seaweed salad while the taste was there, they just threw it onto the plate and had bits of seaweed dripping off the platter and some areas of the salad was more salty than others.  There have been some days where I think theyve done an amazing job and others just OK.  This night we went it was just OK.

Definitely worth going at least once since I do feel that this is one of the GOOD places IN San Francisco to have ramen, but if you're able to venture out there's GREAT places to have ramen. Feel me?
author: Sandy L.

description:
As much as I would love to give this place a 5 star, I will have to consider the fact that the place is too small. I love coming down here because of the ramen and calamari but sometimes I also had to consider the long wait for a table and the thought that I will actually be sitting next to someone from the next table. 

I usually come here with a group of 4-6 people and we normally have to wait for an average of 45-90 mins to get seatted. When we do get to our seats the place is too crowded and you usually have to rub elbows with the person from the next table (literally).

Still, We love the food but just maybe they could start thinking of expanding?? :D
author: DaNe S.

description:
Came here because the other places in union square were packed.

When we walked up, there already was a line to wait to get in.  The place is TINY and not really recommended for parties of 4 or bigger unless you don't mind waiting.

After waiting for about 20 minutes in the cold we were finally able to get in, but it was a little cramped.

Came here on a recommendation by my roommate about the veggie ramen as they said they can customize it so that its vegetarian (or at least thats what they told her the last time she went).  When we went in this time they said the only vegetarian ramen they had that was served in a veggie broth was the veggie ramen.

So I ordered that, but the soup base was kinda bland and for mild was a bit spicy.  Had your typical stuff in it, tofu, bamboo shoots, brocolli and carrots.  Nothing that really WOWed me about the ramen, I've had better before in the south bay.

My other friends got regular ramen and they said it was good, so this place is probably good for those who eat meat, but vegetarians only have a few limited options.
author: Kameron K.

description: Showed up at 1:20am because it says they close at 2. They said they close at 1.  I own my own business. Its not hard to change business hours. What a waste of $15 for the cab ride.  No wonder they have such a low rating.
author: A.S K.

description:
Such small restaurant space...even though my friend showed up right after it opened, there was already a waiting list to be seated. Boo. Luckily for us though, since there were only two of us, we were able to be seated quickly.

There is some kind of complex menu, which presents the different combination options in a confusing picture method. I just ordered the char-su ramen, without any of the side dishes because I couldn't figure it out. But alas! They I had more choices...like whether I wanted my broth to taste like soy sauce or salt. I'm not sure those are the best terms to describe my broth...haha.

The ramen was pretty good, but I don't feel like the serving size is very large or filling since I was still hungry afterwards. I honestly considered going to the restaurant next door for a second (cheaper) dinner. This was also not even close to the best ramen I've ever had, which was disappointing for all the hype I hear about this place. I'm not sure if I would come back here, especially knowing that I would have to wait a long time to be seated.
author: Melody L.

description:
My old roommate made me come here with her because she claimed it was one of the best ramen ever... oh how I disagreed. Then I came here again yesterday to give it a second chance--I still disagree.

First time here, I had the regular, rich, soy sauce ramen. It was okay. I thought it was oily and my BBQ meat had a lot of tendons. Ramen noodles didn't seem to absorb the flavor of the broth as much as I liked. I wasn't that satisfied but I thought it was because my roommate hyped it up for me.

Second time here, I decided to give it another chance since many yelpers seem to love it here. Unfortunately, I have to abide by my original impression. I ordered the BBQ pork ramen with salt broth and there seemed to be too much oil floating in there. My boyfriend thought the pork was very salty and inedible. I thought it was better than the soy sauce broth though. I also had some of his Mabo Ramen and it tasted decent. There was enough tofu but not so much ground beef, nonetheless, we both enjoyed its small kick of spiciness. 

Service was attentive. Seating was cramped. My green tea was always promptly refilled. Overall, an okay-overrated ramen place but not one I would recommend.
author: Pansy L.

description: Great Ramen in cramped quarters. Saw a line outside and stopped in. Didn't try the signature ramen, but had special which was a pork based with huge chunks of pork. Tasty dish.
author: Nick P.

description: This is a tourist trap! Service was below average. The ramen tasted like it's from a Korean instant noodle pack. Noodles were pretty hard. Everything looks like a hot mess in a bowl that I can do myself at home. I lost my appetite after a few bites, and the portion was huge! (Which I guess is not a bad thing, but it is if the quality is poor). My fiancé felt bad for me and offer to switch dish, but I didn't have the appetite to eat after. I felt guilty as I watch him try to eat the chicken pieces in the ramen so it wouldn't go to waste. It takes a lot for something to make me loose my appetite to eat. You won Katana-Ya!
author: Thuy C.

description: This place is Japanese owned and have Sapporo on tap. What more can I say? It's a punch in a wall. The Ramen and Karaage is great! I shall return.
author: Gene B.

description: Even though the average review was 3.5 stars, I Came here with my family cUz there was a lot of review.  My party wasn't thrill with the overall experience cUz they told my husband he couldn't order his dish cUz they were out of salmon, yet my bro in law was able to order his dish that contain salmon-go figure. When the waitress came with my husband's beer, she tipped and spilled it all over my husband and didn't bother to apologize.  We cleaned up the spill with all of our napkins and asked for more but she didn't replenish the napkins until we were ready to pay the tab.  I gave it a two star cuz our food was decently good and it was slightly entertaining to see a hobo messing with a patron waiting for their table outside the restaurant.  Definitely not on the top of my list to return.
author: Amber V.

description:
One of the best ramen places in SF, if not the best. I always get the shio ramen with grill salmon don.
The downside is that it's a really small place, but I prefer it that way since it makes the place feel cozier.

Omg so delicious
author: Howard K.

description:
Its just another sushi place, we'll be comparing two pieces of copy paper if we go further with details. The soups are good here.The price? maybe a little bit more pricier than your usual sushi place (if you have one). 

What caught my eye on this place though is the top 40 mainstream music, it gives the atmosphere a very hip vibe. Maybe thats why its popular? The place IZ small, but don't book a reservation - there's Hana Zen, Sushi Boat, Sanraku around the area.....
author: K C.

description:
The Katanaya ramen is sooooo delicious! I highly recommend.
The place is small, I had to wait a few minutes, but its completely worth it.
author: Kauana D.

description:
The Chasu (BBQ Pork) Raman has been on 7x7's Big Eats List of 100 Things to Eat Before You Die, including the most recent 2010 version, so that's what I ordered.

We managed to avoid the crowds that everyone yelps about by arriving a little after 6 on a Monday evening.

The miso broth was yummy, and the ramn was fresh and had the fine bounce that Italians would call al dente.  If you're thinking the BBQ pork or "chasu" is like the Chinese BBQ Pork, you're kinda wrong.  There is none of that artificial red coloring, or the delectable sweet glaze on top.  But, otherwise, it's pretty much the same in texture.  Though, this particular chasu was quite tender, so it's probably more like the good Chinese BBQ pork from places that do it right.

Overall, I was satiated, but it isn't anything I'd go out of my way to eat, and especially not if I had to wait in some crazy long line.
author: Christina L.

description: Our server was not friendly/attentive. I did feel like our waitress (the older lady) either slacked off or is just plain rude because she knew that since we were a party of 6, gratuity is automatically added, so that gave her an excuse to be unpleasant. Throughout the night we were there she seemed reluctant to take our orders as if we were doing something wrong and acted like I didn't exist when I thanked her while we were leaving. I don't care if you are having a bad day but if you are a server you should be able to leave your bad attitude and problems at home. This lady either needs re-training or should not be a server at all. Will not be coming back.
author: James M.

description:
Really great food! Outside it looks like the wait is much longer than it actually is. Waitstaff is very fast and efficient. The food was fantastic. I had the #12 ramen, which tasted great. Great value, too! 
Definitely worth a visit if you are wanting quality Japanese food in downtown SF.
author: Blake E.

description: With over 2000 reviews and 4 stars I was really excited to check this place out.  It is a tiny little restaurant with a line.  Line moved fast.  The staff was accommodating to our "large" party of 6 (when there are only 10 tables in a place party of 6 is considered large).   Good menu, reasonable prices, attentive staff.  The entire table ordered ramen.  All were pleased.  Mine was a little on the bland side, I ordered vegetable ramen so what did I expect.  I would love to try this place again and try something different.
author: Jessica R.

description: Good decent food; service at lunch can be slow, but they seemed to be geared towards dinners.  Certainly a competent restaurant with the look and feel of old world trapping of London.
author: Kwan M.

description:
Came here since their Cha Sui Ramen was featured on the 7x7 Eats List. My BF got the Cha Sui Ramen and I got the extra spicy Ramen.

Hmmm .. wasn't too impressed. I had really high expectations since they were featured on the list. The noodles were thin, like the ones you get from packaged instant noodles and the broth also wasn't anything special. For noodles, any type of noodles - Pho/Thai/Chinese, it's all about the broth. I've tasted really good broth before and the broth here was just OK. Dont take me wrong, it wasn't bad, but it wasn't mind blowing Ramen. It didn't make me go WOW. I still like Santouka much better. 

They get 3 stars because if you get the meal combo, you also get a small bowl of rice. I ordered the kim chi fried rice and it went very well with my Ramen. From the pics, the curry rice also looked really good.
author: Rosie W.

description:
This place is a super small hole in the wall.  I mean if you aren't paying attention, you'll walk right past.

I recently drove up to San Francisco with my boyfriend and best friends for gay pride and we decided to check this place out after we settled in our hotel room.  

I usually don't like giving negative reviews but this place was such a negative experience, I have to say something.  First off, the wait is incredibly long.  We waited about an hour and a half before we were seated.  No joke, we went to the Jack In The Box three doors down and split a large order of curly fries to tide us over.

Then when we were finally seated, the waiter took forever to take our order and give us our waters.  On top of that, my glass of water was half full (WTF...)  I ordered the Spicy Scallop Roll and I was incredibly disappointed in what I was given.  It seriously tasted like the rolls you buy at Ralph's for $5.  I'd actually welcome that than this place's.  At least with Ralph's I get more than 5 pieces of sushi.

I'd definitely drive back up to SF but I think I'll leave this place out of my plans.
author: Louis T.

description: After many years of attending the American Conservatory Theater (A.C.T) performances, and seeing the line out the door, I finally ate here. I arrived early at 12 noon and was able to get a table no wait. This place is small and our table a little cramped. I enjoyed my udon with fried chicken spicy. The tempura and sushi. I would come again, I just have to time it like this again.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
I'd give this place 0 stars if I could.

I waited after I got off work and put the waiting list for 2. The lady came over and asked me how many people I had and I said two. She said she'll let me know when I table frees up. OK, cool. I noticed a few tables opening up and eventually the lady who greeted me first said hang on.

Then some guy who looked like he hated his job asked, "How many?" I said "two."

He then asked me if my party was there. I replied, "She's on the way, but I know what I want to order." 

Did I mention the person waiting in front of me had a to-go order meaning at least she knew what she wanted?

OK, he tells me "I can't seat you until your party is here" and calls the other couple standing in line who literally waited just a minute.

At least let me take my food to go if you can't seat me or get my order in. 

Maybe that guy who works there really sincerely hates his life. Anyways, bad experience and a wasted 20 minutes of my life but at least I know where not to go!
author: Daniel Y.

description:
This place gives restaurant ramen a mediocre reputation. Try some of the places in San Mateo if you want tastier ramen.

The noodles here are thick and not chewy enough (I love thin and chewy.) The rich version of the broth has visible fat floating in it, but the flavor doesn't cut it.  The Miso broth had a sort of non-distinct muddy flavor to it. The soy sauce broth tasted bright in comparison, but lacked the meaty, hearty taste I crave in ramen.

The fried chicken which many people rave about feels chewy and rubbery in the mouth, with the fried outer portions glistening with oil (meaning the fryer isn't hot enough.)

And the gyoza type thing in the Katanaya ramen was just gross -- the skin tasted like it was never crispy (much less after having sat in the broth) and the insides were absolute mush, almost like uncooked ground pork.

I didn't hate the place (except for the gyoza) but I certainly won't be back, when there are so many better choices.
author: Alexander J.

description:
My Long Awaited Return Trip.

I started off my discovery of ramen here but had no context to what I was tasting, so I eagerly looked forward to returning after experiencing other ramen spots as to properly compare and contrast flavors, textures, etc.

One of the things I've discovered about my taste in noodles is how much I enjoy spice.  In short, the spicier the better.
Katana-Ya's spicy tofu was so super good that I'd still want to have it on a hot day.

The broth was seasoned just right, there was a lot of al dente ramen (I'm allowed to describe Japanese noodles in Italian terms right?), and enough tofu and kim chee to balance the flavor and heat of the dish as well as really fill you up.

They do offer an even spicier version of it and one day I'll dare to taste how much more heat that brings.  Until then there are still plenty of other dishes I still want to try.

Overall, I can't wait for my next return.
author: Dan B.

description:
So, I just spent $17 for ramen and a tuna roll. This palce is interesting.

I am allergic to onions which usually makes it a nightmare to eat out.

I went here and I ordered the ramen lunch special and a spicy tuna roll, no onions. The bring me the tuna roll with green onions which makes me sad, but seeing as when I ordered my food I said I'd have a "spicy tuna roll and a soy Ramen with no onions" I can see they thought I meant only the Ramen. Common mistake of the English language, I begrudge them not one bit, it was my own dang fault. So I begin picking out all the onions on my sushi, and after 15 mints the waitress feels sorry for me, and grabs my plate and orders me a new one to be made without onions.

So that was pretty sweet that she did that, I was happy. Um, she was very pretty too, but that's unrelated so never mind that, I just had to tell someone, might as well be the internet.

The sushi wasn't that good, however they did just ask the chef to hurry and slap me together a new roll, so I doubt it was as well put together as it's predecessor. It as good though, it would have been great if the cucumber had been a litter firmer, and if they sprinkled sesame seeds on the outside (I LOVE that crunchy feeling in my sushi like no tomorrow).

So I'm kind of half and half a this point. Nice people, and okay food, but I'm starting to feel this place is overrated, but trying not to be too judgmental.

Enter my Ramen. So first thing I notice is they took all the veggies out altogether. No fish cake, no, bamboo, etc. I guess they were afraid of my allergy so they just took out everything but broth and noodles. I'm feel really sad at this point, because I am deeply in love with all the veggies that Ramen provide (except seaweed, yuck. Yes, I am as ashamed of me as you are for not liking it. Heck, I've lived in Japan and still can't stand seaweed, it's beyond disgrace). I realize that everything is cooked together, though  and it's either have it all including onions or nothing, still I'm sad plus I see a few onions that they missed, but whatever I'll pick them out.

So I pick out the onions and then take a bite.

DELICIOUS! Holy Crap! Everything is forgiven and I fall in love. They have a really delicious broth and good noodles. Am still hungry though, and I hate being hungry for $17 out of my pocket. My bowl was like half full though, so I'd probably be less hungry if I ordered an unaltered meal.

So $17 for okayish sushi, and amazing Ramen. If they could find a way to make it without seaweed and onions, but give me a full bowl of soup I'll give them that 5th star. If anyone knows any Ramen shows that are able to do that, please let me know! :-)
author: Cory D.

description:
This is a good hangout for my co-workers and myself. 
On a late night out with my coworkers, we again, waited in line. I agree, with everyone else, it is worth the wait... to an extent though. My body does not do well in cold weather, so if tourists are flocking and they are ahead of us, or if there is a long line down that list, I can surely go somewhere else. Sometimes that cold weather outside, i can't take. 

Their service is fast, but nothing emotional or engaging about it. It's just take order, serve, make no conversation, take dishes away, present check, go. clean. next person please. nothing to engage the customer with. I do understand why, with a long line they do that. But I wonder if they do that when there are no lines as well? The only reason I question, is because I've only seen the service at this restaurant like that. 

The ramen and the udon at this spot are delicious. Big bowls that I can never finish. Good flavor. Very good hot sake. But whenever I order the sushi, I am always disappointed. It's not very good. Not very fresh, I believe? But other than that, what they're known for is the ramen. 
The last time I went, I ordered the Udon to switch it up. This is very good here. The noodles are tasty, but the tempura batter was just okay. Not golden like I was hoping. Still, the soup is amazing. 

Will definitely will always be back.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
This place is GOOD!  Please trust me!  You should try this place.
I am from Hakata Fukuoka Japan.  If you know about Japan, you know why I mentioned about where I am from.  Yes...  My area is very famous for ramen noodles.  Since I am from there, I am very picky about ramen.  
My favorite one is "Katanaya-ramen."  It fulls me up completely.  I did not need to order any side order.  My another favorite one is "Ma-boo tofu ramen."  It is very very tasty.  If you have not try this place yet, it is time to go there!
author: David O.

description:
Didn't have to wait in line, got seated right away when we got in.

I was sharing with a friend and she said she didn't like ramen so I got her a side of kimchi fried rice. The ramen was good and the kimchi fried rice really surprised me. 
My friend eats one of the pickled ginger and really gets grossed out because she hates ginger. I felt bad so I let her have the rest of my ramen and she complains the next day that no one wanted to share ramen with her when she said she hates ramen. 
It was good enough to change her mind and I really liked the kimchi fried rice so 5 stars.
Thank you for serving us drunk folk.
author: Henry C.

description:
Sadly, not my cup-of-tea... or should I say, not my bowl-of-ramen?

My friends and I (5 of us total) came here one early evening for some ramen. The wait is quite long because this is such a tiny place. I would not recommend coming in with an odd-numbered party because the tables fit 4 people max. Because the restaurant is so busy, service was non-existent. If you need to order or would like some water, I would suggest just flagging down a random waitress. 

I was not impressed with Katana-Ya's ramen or their broth. I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen and asked for the broth to be rich. Apparently, if you don't request it, the broth is just "regular." My friends mentioned that the "regular" broth was not quite flavorful. Even my "rich" broth was missing the essential pork-flavor that makes ramen broth delicious. The Katana-Ya ramen included pieces of karage and gyoza, both of which came out soggy. The karage was too salty and had too much breading while the gyoza was just ok. 

Overall, over-priced ramen served by busy staff. I've had, and experienced, much better ramen.
author: Stephanie L.

description: 20 min wait for 2 on a Tuesday night, lights are little too dim, food came fast, ramen was good.
author: Assaf U.

description:
FOOD: below standard
PRICE: too expensive

totally overrated! We had to wait in line even it was 2.30 p.m. 

I ordered 1 combo: very-small bowl of appetizer and small bowl of cold noodle. It costs me $14 + 18% tips since we had 5 people.
author: Aileen G.

description: 3 1/2 stars for this place.  It is a casual place, but I like casual places so not bagging it.  I am more about the food.  And the ramen was pretty good, but I've had better ramen.  It is not in the league of Santa Ramen or Orenchi.
author: M. T.

description:
Small place that seats maybe 25-30 people at most.  The wait can be long.  No reservations.

I ordered the miso ramen with a "rich" broth, which indeed was rich.  The noodles were a nice firm texture.  Overall, probably one of the better ramen places that I've had in SF... at least better than any place in Japantown. 

Also got the salmon don.  The salmon was fresh, and best of all, the rice was perfectly seasoned and at the perfect temperature (which often makes or breaks the overall perception of fish freshness).
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Short version: delicious ramen (the kimchi and the cilantro both are my favorites) in enormous portions, really good fresh sushi and nigiri, and attentive service (surprising considering how busy it can get). Long waits (though not in off-times) due to its small size and popularity. Cozy, tourist-friendly décor. 

Long version: the first time I had Katana-ya was actually Thanksgiving weekend and I helped compose a group of five, which is probably larger than the typical group size there. As such, and because its location is so close to Union Square which was packed that and every weekend, the wait time ended up being about an hour, if not slightly more. The servers cleverly addressed this problem of overwhelming popularity by asking those next to be seated to go ahead and choose their selections (menu is posted by the door), with any questions being answered warmly and adequately. Puts a bit of pressure on you, the eater, but it did streamline the experience and process. And you can always order more or modify the order once inside. 

The food is delicious and you have quite a bit of control over the character of your ramen (oil level, spiciness, etc.), though not as much as other ramen places I've been to. The noodles are standardly at a level closer to soft than to hard, which is perfectly fine with me. The broth is unctuous and delightful, and if you order the cilantro ramen you get a ton of it! Great value! And for being a ramen-centric restaurant, the sushi is good and fresh and tasty. Nothing like an order of saba nigiri to go with your noodle-y elixir. 

This is hardly a complaint, but I do wish this restaurant were located in Japantown, or at least closer to the Kabuki hotel and Sundance Theater.
author: Jake m.

description:
We struggled to find a sushi joint in the area open for Sunday lunch, but Kantan-Ya delivered.

We were seated at the door and served with expediency. We certainly overdid it between the two of us, with a seaweed salad (crunchy, sweet, refreshing) and four rolls. What were we thinking?!  These rolls were all huge; no skimping here. And we ate them ALL. Every last piece.

The one that sticks out in my mind was the Red & White - butterfish that melted in your mouth.  The mango in our Tropicana was fresh, juicy and just the right amount of sweet and sour.

We were some of the very few indulging in sushi (would be our only chance during our quick trip); almost every other person was digging greedily into a big bowl of ramen.
author: Taryn L.

description:
I'm not a big ramen fan, but this place made me second guess that.  And it comes in such a big bowel that, when it was served to me, I thought I'd never finish it.  But it was so delicious i couldn't stop eating! 

I got the combo with the miso ramen and the salmon don. The salmon sashimi that accompanied the ramen was fresh and buttery, just like I would expect from a good sushi restaurant. 

The staff was super friendly and very accommodating. Next time I'm in SF this is yet another place I'd love to revisit.
author: Ian W.

description:
I went to Katana-Ya on spring break.  One weeknight we passed by the place around 7pm, and there was a line already!  So the next day we decided to come back around 6pm (a little earlier) to beat the dinner lines.

My boyfriend told me that a lot of Yelp reviewers liked KatanaYa's ramen, but I'm not a huge restaurant ramen fan (I actually prefer instant ramen over a lot of Japanese restaurant ramen... okay maybe I haven't been out enough), so I ordered a bowl of udon.

Boy, was I glad that I did!  I tried some of my boyfriend's ramen - the soup was meh, I would have taken instant noodles over the soup, it was nothing special - but MAN did I love my udon soup!  The noodles were very tasty and had that perfect thickness and slipperyness (it sounds weird, but it's true).  The soup base was also very delicious.  They had put in some scallions and some tempura flakes.  I'm really picky and don't like a lot of things in my soup, so the scallions and tempura flakes were just the right amount.  I gobbled up my bowl right away.  I also thought it was reasonably priced - the udon was about $8.50 if I remember correctly.

I also got Ikura sushi (the only sushi I will eat, the salmon roe).  It was priced two pieces for $5.50, which is reasonable, in San Francisco.  The sushi pieces were pretty large, and the eggs were very fresh.  This was a great change from another Japanese place I had tried the night before, two VERY TINY pieces for $7.....

All in all, a great Japanese place!
author: Danielle C.

description:
Deep fried chicken ramen! Thank the Lord (and the owners of this fine establishment) for supplying us with a warm dinner after spending quite some time in the cold rain. So, 1000+ reviews and an average 4 star rating? Of course this place deserved a visit from me. 

A few friends and I decided to come here for dinner before hitting the club. and I must say it sure hits the spot on a typical cold night in the city. Yup, this place is super small. Perfect place for parties between 2-4, so anything higher than that, you're looking for a longer wait. In my case, there were a total of 5 of us, which lead to a 20 minute wait. On top of that, we weren't even seated together. Well, 3 of us were seated at the counter, while the other 2/the couple sat in a table right behind us. 

Considering the hustle and bustle of this place, service was pretty good here. Food came out in a reasonable amount of time, and waiters were able to come at the right times to fill water and whatnot. Well, seems expected since the place is so damn small. 

I ended up ordering the deep fried chicken ramen, one of my friends ordered the katana ya ramen, and my other 3 friends ordered the beef sukiyaki rice bowl. To be honest, I had a hard time deciding between those 3 since they all looked delicious based on the pictures haha. We also split a bottle of sake between us, while the 3 of us shared a spicy tuna roll. The sushi was whatever, but the presentation looked interesting with all the extra veggies the sushi was resting on. The soy sauce flavor was delicious, and the portions are generous. The only thing I wish they did was include more chicken, since there was basically only 3 nuggets.  

So would I come back? Definitely! I just need to come here during off hours, or at least try to beat the rush.
author: Loren John B.

description:
Great bowl of ramen yesterday! Had the BBQ pork with miso flavored broth and it came out quick and hot.

Also had a pint of Sapporo for $4, I believe. Great meal and solid service for a cold SF summer day.
author: Art O.

description:
Katana-Ya serves pretty decent ramen, but I have definitely had better in the city elsewhere (I'm thinking Japantown, or Halu). The broth is a little bland but the noodles and the chicken karaage in the ramen are good. 

However, all that said... the wait is ridiculous every time I go there and the service is generally pretty rude. I don't get what all the fuss is about for this place. Slightly above-average ramen but definitely nothing to write home about.
author: Lucinda W.

description:
Small ramen house down the block from Union Square.  The people waiting outside (us included) can fill the entire restaurant.  Half an hour in the blistering cold, I was ready for my bowl of ramen.

I have to admit that it's pretty pricy for what it is.  I mean, soup base, ramen, green onions, bbq pork, butter and corn for $8.50.  Add $0.50 for mild spicy, and $1.40 for extra spicy.  You're looking at 40 top ramens, plus tax and tip.

Nevertheless, it was one of the best bowls of ramen, ever.  I just wish they gave more noodles.  Because I left feeling not so full, but didn't want to order another bowl for fear of looking like a pig and also making the people waiting outside wait longer.
author: Jenny L.

description: Pretty sure I got food poisoning from this place Tuesday of this week and have been sick all week. So...,
author: Ryan M.

description:
Went here with a friend and had lunch. She had the vegetarian ramen with light salt flavor, which still came with the pork meat. (strange) I tasted her soup and it was really good. I had the lunch combo with soy sauce, rich in strength and it was delicious. The combo I selected was the most expensive one with a bowl of rice, ikura, crab, and raw salmon. This was yummy too. Overall, I enjoyed my experience here but do expect to spend roughly $20 bucks per person. 

We were lucky and did not have to wait on a Saturday. However, the line got up to 20 ppl waiting. It's a small place so prepare to wait.
author: Minh H.

description: Ramen flavor was decent. Small place but that's usually the case for ramen places. Service was just ok. Overall I'd probably go somewhere else for ramen.
author: Nadine S.

description: Went around 1:30pm and waited about 20 mins to be seated. I ordered the Katana-Ya miso ramen. The fried chicken was so delicious! I wasn't a fan of the fried dumplings because it was soggy and lacked flavor, that broth was a tad too salty for me but my BF enjoyed his miso broth. The portions are large and you will be full when you leave. I also tried the fried rice and that was equally delicious. They have different combinations that you can order and perhaps next time I will try one. Service is quick and friendly.
author: Ariana B.

description: It's basically the worst experience in SF! The food is ok, yet pricy. The smell of the restaurant is disgusting!!!
author: Xiao L.

description: Had the Katanaya Ramen with rich shoyu broth. The fried chicken was nice, so was the pot stickers, but you gotta make sure you eat them before they get soggy. The broth was really drinkable, and even though it's rich and oily, it doesn't feel like it'll clog up your arteries. Noodles were the perfect consistency. Only weakness was the egg, just because it was regular boiled egg, not onsen tamago like most ramen-ya's. Would def come back again next time I'm in town to try their miso and shio broth.
author: Shuang C.

description:
This place gets 5 stars from me. What great food!

Katana-Ya is more of a fusion restaurant in many ways. They do a pretty darn good job at it, too.

My friend had the spicy fried chicken miso soup (forgot the real name), and I got the udon noodle soup with the salmon/avocado sushi rolls (combo plate).

The udon noodles were much more flavorful than I expected, and the fish broth with the seaweed and the green onions was very very good. The really impressive part, however, was the salmon/avocado sushi rolls. I could count on one hand how many places can pull off a roll like that with any degree of success, and this place makes them to perfection.

For $12, it really wasn't an expensive lunch. I got in just before the lunch rush showed up, which was actually kind of late (12:30 or 12:35). I managed to get a table right before my friend showed up and we were able to get served quickly. 

Great place, can't wait to try other things on their menu.
author: Andrew L.

description:
When I arrived here I immediately knew seeing the few people standing around outside that there was a waiting list.  So I promptly located it by the front door and put my name down.  I thought to myself this is typical of any popular ramen place so it must be decent.  I quickly took to the menu that is posted outside the doors and saw that all the broths that were in the images of the ramen were dark in color.  This quickly changed my expectations for what I was about to experience.  The service was great, nothing good or bad to report there.  Now to the ramen...

Definitely do not come here if your a fan of the pork base, tonkotsu ramen.  I had the Katana-Ya Ramen and was not very impressed.  I had it with the salt base hoping for the possibility of maybe a pork flavored salt base which it wasn't.  I eventually decided that it was decent but not great.  I did not taste like it came out of a instant noodle bag but still was not good enough for me to slurp up every last bit of broth.  The pork was not very tender and the bamboo shoot was too sour for my taste.  

The Mapo ramen is definitely sub-par, especially when you consider the price point.  This unfortunately did taste like it came from an instant noodle bag.  I'm not from San Francisco so I did not have an opportunity to try many other ramen places in the local area but compared to places in my home town like La-Men in Buena Park, CA, Gomen in Cypress, CA or Shin-Sen Gumi, Fountain Valley, CA this place would be easily beat and for much less money.

If your ever in the OC try out one of the places i mentioned and you will not be disappointed.
author: danny k.

description: This place was really yummy. The fish was just crazy fresh which was just...so good. I also ordered ramen to share, and everyone else liked it but I found it a little bland and I was not really into the noodles, they didn't taste exactly like ramen, but I guess that was my own personal taste. This place is not good for large groups though. We had to wait quite a while for a table since this location is so small. I do still think it was worth it and would overall recommend their sushi since it is so fresh.
author: Heather Lynn H.

description:
Summary: Overrated Ramen, Rude Japanese student waiters, Nosy customers, $12 Dingy-door-parking

This place is not worth coming if you are expecting a good bowl of ramen from outside the city. It only makes sense to people if you live in the hip city and likes to go clubbing etc. When we were waiting outside, people are smoking, checking each people out as if we are going to clubs, making false assumptions of nationalities and judgmental comments. Definitely a not kind of place for family whatsoever. 
It seemed like half the people there aren't coming for ramen, more like 'to get lucky'. Japanese waiters were rude, they have no recommendations of anything just kept repeating what they are supposed to say to take orders - "shio? shoyu? or miso?" (which one is better, lady?). The waiters not paying attention to customers and talking each other about going to a club later (in Japanese), kept worried about how her hair looks.

Anyhow, the quality of ramen itself was ok for in the US (this place would be out of business in a heartbeat in Tokyo), nothing to write here about. People are drunk anyway so how'd they know if the ramen is good- this place is like a hook-up bar. A guy sitting next to me came alone not ordering ramen, drinking beer just waiting to see if he can go talk to some girls. 
The space was cramped and the interior looked poor and unorganized, looks weird sitting next to expensive boutiques etc. Service-wise you get a lot more for your visit when you go places in the south bay. 

TOO BAD a lot of people think this place is good - are you f'in kidding me??  try some others in the south bay, if you have a car, that is.
author: Another R.

description: I don't know what it is, but I haven't found a place that I can compare to either Ramen Dojo or Orenchi, The noodles here are a more traditional style ramen. Its pretty thin where I like my noodles thicker. I ordered the chasu ramen extra spicy and the karaage chicken. The ramen was decent not very spicy at all. The pieces of the meat were a little too thick. The Karaage chicken however was pretty good and were pretty big pieces of it. I like how they have a wide selection of items to choose from. It made ordering a little hard because I wanted to try everything, Maybe I'll come back here one more time and give it a try and order something else.
author: Wendy T.

description:
My biggest complaint about Katana-Ya is that it is in SF and I'm not.  What's not to love about a big steaming bowl of ramen with a good variety of meat, veggies, and pot stickers in it?  My husband thought the hard boiled egg was weird but I liked it fine... I thought the pork was lacking in flavor but short of bacon and sandwich ham, I am really not a pork fan.

We visited very late on a weeknight and the place was packed!  We grabbed the last table and enjoyed our bowls and nice big bottomless sodas... 

Service was efficient and polite but not friendly... Wish we had more guidance on how to order the broth, I liked mine but wish it was a little more thick while my husband was looking for more spice and salt.  I blame us for not knowing the way to order but I also blame the server for not taking a minute better educate us... She merely told us what was most popular without saying the differences.  It was certainly tasty though!

Overall, we liked it and wished we had more time in the City so we could have tried it a second time.  I'm looking for a similar dish in my home city but it looks like I'm going to have to learn to make it or go back to SF!
author: Allie R.

description:
I've found my favorite ramen place in SF! They are second only to San Mateo's Ramen Dojo. There always seems to be a small crowd gathered outside waiting for a table, which is very telling of their quality. We waited about 30 minutes for a table on a Friday night, which wasn't too bad.

My husband got the Katanaya Ramen which came with fried potstickers and fried chicken. Whaaat? You heard right - fried chicken. He was in heaven. I, on the other hand, am not a big fan of the fried stuff. So I opted for the appropriately named Simple Ramen, which was more traditional. I paid extra to make it spicy, but I later realized I could have used the spice jar on the table to spice it up myself. Oh well.

Everything was delicious. The broth was perfect. Service was fast and efficient. I can't wait to come back :)
author: Mariela D.

description: Decent ramen, bad service. Asked for a to-go container and the server was visibly annoyed for no apparent reason. I shrugged it off as a bad day -- we all have them. Then she came by and dropped off a plastic container on the table for me to pour it. In most situations I have no problem packing my own food, but how is one supposed to get messy ramen out of a huge bowl into a takeaway container without proper utensils and without making a mess? I ended up just leaving it because we were in a hurry and I didn't want to ruin my work outfit for the day.
author: Kristin D.

description:
Came here based on the numerous amount of reviews. Sometimes I think that within this area of San Francisco,  1000 + reviews is more like 200 reviews elsewhere.
Anyway, I found this place to be o.k. I liked that there was a lot on the menu. I had the Katanaya ramen, and while it was good it was nothing impressive. 
Still, this place is better than an average score, thus 4 stars.
author: Justin N.

description: This is a fine hole-in-the-wall Japanese noodle joint.  True Soba and Ramen as you would find in Japan.  I didn't try any of the Sushi, but I was very impressed with the noodle options.   It's a cramped small space, but the service and food is genuine.  I would most certainly go here again next time around Union Square.
author: Ross B.

description:
Katana-Ya is GOOD, solid 3.5-4.0 good, and reminds me a bit of one of my favorite ramen places back home in So Cal (Shin-Sen-Gumi) so naturally it became a hot spot for me and my boyfriend.

My favorites are their Chashu Ramen and their Shoyu Ramen. So good. The broth is hot, creamy, and fulfilling. I liked their ramen, even though it is a little firmer than I like; pork is flavorful but could be made more tender; seaweed is thick... eh, I like mine thin (since I always get my ramen with bamboo and I don't like it when the seaweed's texture feels the same as that of the bamboo's haha).

Their combo (+___ don) is amazing! Get their spicy tuna don... yum.

We haven't ran into any long lines at Katana-Ya, except for the first night we arrived in SF... but the wait was only 10 minutes tops? And not to mention, our first time at Katana-Ya was so fun because of our loud Russian neighbors. I know some people don't like being all cramped up but we find it so entertaining. We struck a conversation with them and became buddies by the end of it all.

Overall, I like Katana-Ya but let's just say that I'm thankful for the ramen places I have back in LA/OC ;)

**Accepts card.
**Tight seating.
**Service is mediocre/poor (waitresses take forever to get you a glass of water/your bill/etc.).
author: Jenny O.

description:
I asked a server at our hotel bar for some late night grub recommendations and she sent us to Kantana-Yu. I was intrigued because she said it was a ramen bar. Now I LOVE pho and I have never had ramen in a restaurant--just make it on my own!

There are so many options that I almost don't think it's far to rate them yet, but I would highly recommend checking this place out if you like asian food/fusion! I ordered a miso ramen with corn, pork, boiled egg, fried chicken, and a bunch of other ingredients. I thought it was good, but it could have been better--I would definitely go back and try some other stuff!
author: Danny K.

description: Great ramen and good sushi. Long wait to get in but worth it. Quite reasonably priced.
author: Sasha D.

description:
I came here on Wednesday 

I ordered the Katanaya Ramen with Mild spicy Miso broth
It was REALLY REALLY good


I like the their ramen noodle as well
I'm always picky about my noodle texture, I hate instant noodle-like ramen, it makes me annoyed that i'm paying over 10 dollars for a bowl of soup with what feels and tastes similar to instant noodles. And their ramen did not disappoint
author: Gly Q.

description:
I had the kimchi ramen w/miso flavored soup (soy & salt being the other options).  Awesome.  Pretty standard japanese ramen base (seaweed, green onions, stir-fried pork meat, bamboo shoots) which was all very tasty.  The soup was delicious too (and comes in 3 'intensities' if you don't like super strong miso flavor).  I didn't try any of the sushi or soup-less noodles.

Portions are pretty big & reasonably priced.

Service was reasonably prompt.

Expect to wait though.  I came at 2pm on a Sunday afternoon and the place was full.  I got a bit lucky--I hadn't been waiting 5 minutes when like 4 or 5 additional groups showed up.  Still, I'm willing to wait a bit for tasty ramen!
author: Eric L.

description: I love Japanese food and I love a good deal. I got the noodle combo with miso ramen and tuna poki rice bowl. Even my big appetite couldn't eat everything. My eating partner had the spicy miso udon, which had pretty solid noodles. Not kind blowing ramen, but I've definitely come back for a cheap hot meal and a pitcher of beer.
author: Haley J.

description:
Pretty good place for lunch.

Good choices, decent prices, and good service. Small tiny place, but that's what you should expect around this area anyway. 

However, I'm still biased, because I do like Santa Ramen more - this is just a personal preference though. I just don't like miso-based soup as much. But, I have to say, I do like the noodles here a lot better. Love the fact that hey serve their food pretty quick! 

Oh and I thought it's really cool that they close late - like 1am late! So if you're coming from the theater or from the club, you can go straight here! Just try to beat the rush as much as possible.
author: Jillian R.

description:
Went here on a rainy day. Great place to drop by before hitting the shopping stores!

The price is really small, but the price was decent. 

Service: 3.5/5
Food: 3.5/5

I thought the "fish salad" was a really good deal--basically it is sashmi and greens. 

I had my friend's ramen noodle, and it was pretty good. The portion size for the ramen is pretty big!!

Nothing too special. Would probably come back in the future.
author: Jen H.

description:
Katana-Ya is tiny.  Teeny-tiny.  Teensy-weensy.  

Katana-Ya also has some seriously kick ass sushi.  Kristine G., E.D., S.F. and I stuffed ourselves silly in here last weekend.  I almost broke into a fit of giggles at the end of lunch, I was so damn fat and happy.

note:
Beware of patrons who think it's perfectly civil to stand on a cold rainy day, cluelessly holding the door open while they survey for table availability.  You'll be blasted to within an inch of your life by the balmy, tropical SF air (haw haw haw).  To avoid amputation of your nose and fingertips after you eat, I highly recommend using the tables (they'll seat 3, maximum) in the nooks to the direct right and left of the entrance if possible (or sitting at the bar).

Katana-Ya, may we meet again soon.
oxox
author: Cara Y.

description:
Came here a few years ago when ramen was the next biggest thing, but haven't been around since then. Until a few weeks ago when some friends and I were in the area and were feeling for some hot soup for a cold spring evening. Friends got the miso broth, I got the shiro. Miso is much much better than the Shiro. But the shiro is still good if you're craving clear broth. Got the "Katana-ya Ramen" which came with everything you could imagine. Pork, fried chicken, gyoza, corn, and a whole lot of other stuff. The fried chicken was bomb! Pretty much the highlight of all the junk floating around. The noodles had a nice snap to it.

Would never want to wait to eat here, but would come back if it was convenient and I was in the hood.
author: Moraia W.

description:
I tried this place for the first time last night and loved it. I ordered the Katana ya ramen in the heavy soy sauce broth and devoured it. Along with the noodles, it has pot stickers, corn, a half hard boiled egg, pieces of pork and pieces of fried chicken in it. The pieces of fried chicken in it were heavenly! 

My BF didn't finish his ramen so I ate the rest of his too. He got the fried chicken ramen. Yum. However, he got the miso broth and I liked my soy sauce broth better. 

The only thing I didn't like was that Katana-Ya doesn't have takeout menus or an online menu. I live nearby and would like to be able to peruse the menu and try new things via takeout, being that it seems that place is always crazy crowded. If you're reading this Katana-Ya, please consider takeout menus (:
author: Liz M.

description:
Visiting San Francisco from North Carolina, I was in a desperate search for good ramen. While North Carolina has more ethnic cuisine than you expect, authentic ramen is one of the few things you can't find. So I was really craving for some good ramen.

So after searching Yelp, I found Katana-Ya. The location was at the edge of the Tenderloin district, but it felt safe. The store is small, and given the crowd, you had to sign a waiting list to get in even at 8 PM on a weekday (hint: if you are dining by yourself you will get in quicker if you take a counter seat).

The menu is a ramen fan's dream. It has all the major flavors of soy sauce, miso, and butter. I chose the standard chasu soy sauce ramen with a side other of spicy tuna don (a rice bowel topped with spicy tuna).

The ramen is just as great as any good-to-great ramen-ya in Japan. The noodles are real noodles that are hand made (don't know if they make it on premise) that are boiled al dente (bet you didn't know ramen noodles should be treated like pasta). The soup was authentic, and seemed to have been made with real broth (instead of instant mix).

The spicy tuna was a mixed bag; the tuna was fresh but it was too spicy for my taste.

And the staff was great. While dealing with the crowd seems to slow them down, they were attentive.

In general, a great find for someone searching for ramen. Perhaps all ramen shops in San Francisco are of this quality, but regardless this will definitely be a stop the next time I come to this city.
author: Toshi T.

description:
I will put in my quick two cents here. Authentic place as evident by the actual Japanese workers here. The Ramen is quite good, but not as good as Maru Ichi down in Mt View, but much better than all chinese owned japanese places. 

Very small place so you have to not mind sitting real close to all the other patrons. Had the famous Katanya ramen, and that was pretty good. the Fried Chicken was on point and the best part of the meal. The broth was good too. 

yes, this place is near the craphole that is the TL, and you will have to dodge bums milling about, but it is worth the ramen.
author: Jerry C.

description:
I usually get their Katana-Ya Ramen bowl which includes potstickers, fried chicken, some chasu, hard boiled egg, bamboo shoots, and broth of your choice. Check out this blog which has a featured review of katana-ya and other noodle dishes!

http://thenoodleguy.com/2012/05/31/katana-ya/

http://thenoodleguy.com
author: Vernon V.

description:
OOOOODLES AND OOOOODLES AND OOOOOODLES OF NOOODLES, and fried chicken, and tasty broth, and tea. 

After reading others' reviews of this place I realized my friends and I got lucky with only 5 minute wait time(even though we were being harrassed by unfriendly transients outside), then we were seated a tiny table for 3. 

So we were basically being forced by our own subconsicences to go eat ramen because the night before I was pretty inebriated, falling asleep and wouldn't stop whispering "NOODLES, let's go eat NOOOOOOODLES, hey hey hey hey hey hey hey NOODLES!!!!" ........... "come on, you know you want NOODLES!!!!!!!!!!!!" in my friends ear. I do not feel one bit of guilt. Not at all. 

I had the fried chicken ramen, in soy sauce soup. I was worried that the chicken would be very soggy and yuck. It wasn't crispy, but it wasn't the soggy I imagined it to be and it was delicious and pretty easy shove in to my mouth while rapped in tastey noodles that were swimming in tasty salted oily broth. The whole meal left my mouth feeling a little oily. But it tasted so good that I'm not complaining. The chicken was tender and flavorful, the noodles were the perfect consistancy of desired  chewy-ness, and the broth was salty and delicious. 

In the menu it states that they add MSG, Just sayin'. I think I'm good on my MSG fix till 2012. 

Service is slow to non existant. Waiter popped in once to take our orders and then delivered the food, and then dissappeared. Getting the check was annoying but. Whatever.

Just another reason why I need to move to San Francisco.
author: nicole r.

description: I love this place! Their ramen is the best and the bowl is bigger than your face. Everyone that I've brought here has loved it. I have the spicy tofu ramen with miso soup which has kimchi in it. My friend has tried the spicy beef ramen but thought my choice was better. Neither was spicy but they were still flavorful.
author: Mariana L.

description:
probably the best quality ramen noodles i have tried next to mifune's. they are the perfect chewy texture, and not instant-ramen-like.  however the broth does not compare to santa ramen or ramen dojo's by far.

mabo ramen
- kinda like ma-po dofu - spicy tofu with ground meat except in soup form
- broth was thick and sweet kinda like a type of americanized chinese cuisine.  the broth was just mildly spicy
- medium-soft tofu was a good texture
- very one of a kind flavor - i'm glad to have tried it even though it is not really my idea of a spicy ramen

katana ya ramen
- broth was pretty watery although we got the "rich" flavor
- deep fried chicken - pretty juicy and popcorn chicken-esque
- gyoza - inner meat was flavorful and outer skin was more of a deep fried wonton wrap instead of a steamed dumpling wrap
- corn was sweet and still crispy
- probably the highlight dish of this place - it is not bad, but not too amazing.  i would certainly recommend this as a safe dish.
author: Tina A.

description:
oh man, this place is a gem of a hole in the wall.  I've been here only twice so far but both times have been good times. the second trip followed within days of the first, because that's how much i liked it. i've had the spicy tofu ramen and the fried chicken ramen, both with miso based soups. damn, it just hits the spot. the sushi rolls weren't bad either, but the ramen bowls are where its at! add a pitcher of sapporo or some sake and you're golden! 

be prepared to wait outside since this place is SUPER small. and to save yourself the pain of waiting even longer, come in small groups of 2-4. anything more is almost impossible. I cant wait for next time, their donburi looks great too.
author: Jennie L.

description: This is one of my favorite places to grab ramen, and it's almost always packed.  The place is small, and it is one of the few good deals in the Union Square area, so it's not surprising that there is usually a line of people waiting out front (there is nowhere to wait inside).  My favorite is to get the extra spicy broth, and I do quite enjoy their kimchi ramen.  I don't know that the sushi is of the same level, but I'm usually happy with the huge bowl of ramen.
author: Scott E.

description: For the love of GOD, please change your hours on yelp. They take their last order at 1:15am (not the standard 1:30) and do not budge on timing.
