They also don't answer their phone, which would save many wasted trips. 7 other people were turned away the same night -- please save everyone the hassle and just say you close at 1:15!
author: Nikki X.

description: This super awesome dive has the most delicious ramen in the city! Try the tofu ramen with salt or the Veggie Tempura Bowl. Deliciously amazing!
author: Scott C.

description:
I would have to say this ramen restaurant is a little over-rated for me. But then again, I just went to a super awesome one in Southern California called Hakata Ramen so I may be a little biased. 

Waited 30+ minutes for a table, ramen overpriced ($12.50 for Katana-ya Ramen), loud, & crowded. 

Noodles were okay. Menu seemed a bit Americanized. Tried a couple sushi rolls too which were good, but again, overpriced. 

Overall, just 'okay' for me.
author: Alysha K.

description: Katana-Ya is a good place for ramen if you're craving for a warm bowl late in the evening. I don't like the fact that it's dark and it's also very small inside, so you'll be squeezed into your seat while you're eating. The ramen itself is decent. Nothing special. This wouldn't be my go to restaurant if I'm in the area, but I will go if there's no other restaurant opened at the time.
author: Edgar G.

description:
Came here the second time yesterday and ordered butter corn ramen with soy base soup. It was good but I've had better. I can't really say that it's special because I've had better at other places. The first time I came here I shared a katana ya ramen with a friend, and it was good. We probably got the extra dense soup base but I can't really recall. So this review will only based on my experience from last night.

They do give you a good portion of everything, good amount of seaweed, bamboo shoot, relatively big piece of BBQ pork, and a lot of corn. It isn't cheap (~9-10 dollars) but acceptable for the portion. Soup base is good but again not super special..I can't say I had a memorable experience here...though I remember I seemed to like it a lot better the first time I came.

One thing that sort of bothered me was that the waitress seem to be in a hurry for us to order our food. They weren't too pushy but it'll be nice if they don't come check on us every 2 minutes when we're still looking at the menu. The bf added an egg to his ramen, that costed 1 dollar...not worth it unless you're really craving for an egg. 

Note: Go 30 mins to an hour BEFORE you actually want to eat around dinner time (between 6-9pm). There is usually a line. It's located near union square so there's plenty to do while you wait.
author: Whitney W.

description:
the menu looks like it has a good variety of food. theres a boat roll with eel and crab over tabago and rice that was interesting and different. the fried octopus was good and fried well but theres only 4 or 6 pieces.

now to the ramen, the miso is not as good as the soy, but towards the end of the meal, it gets better as you adjust to the strong miso taste. the soy broth is tastier. on the menu, it says there is msg included, which makes it sound not as good because if they cooked their broth for a long time with natural ingredients, they wouldnt need msg.

the katanaya ramen is a very good portion and almost too much stuff. its a pretty good deal for a big bowl of ramen with fried chicken, fried wonton, egg, corn, pork, etc.

its not a place i would crave for, but if im in the area and really want ramen, i would come here again.
author: Alex H.

description:
I have to give them one star. I'm from Southern Cal and I've been to lots of ramen places but this was the worst ever. I went to this place because of the yelp rating, and on the review this guy was saying "I'm from Japan and this is the same taste I had there! Believe me!" or something like that. Well, actually I'm a Japanese guy as well but I've never tasted this kind of ramen. The taste of broth was just so boring, I didn't see any effort there. Noodle was ok, the topping was just general stuff. Price was higher than the So Cal ramen places which have way better taste and service than this place.

I really like the city of SF but if this is the only ramen place in this town, I will never move there.
author: Kobe K.

description:
Craving Ramen at 11pm? No worries, head to Katana-Ya. It's open till 1am. 

This place is perfect on a cold night and more specifically when it's already passed 9pm when most of the ramen places are already closed. 

I ordered the combo ramen that included a regular sized ramen. I requested it to be miso flavored rich in texture and mild in spicy. (I'm weak when it comes to spicy).  As a side, I ordered the pork fried rice. 

Portion sizes are pretty descent. Ramen Noodle ratio is good. Wished they gave you just a few more slices of the pork and that a hard boiled egg was included. Flavor of the soup was descent, but to be honest, I've had better. 

Fried rice---love! I think this is the reason why I would return to this place is for their fried rice. Love, love, love it. It's a perfect combo with the ramen and the size of it can be shared with someone else. So long as that someone else also gets a combo and picks another side for the both of you to share. :)

Please be warned though that this place can get pretty crowded! The secret to getting in pretty fast is to not arrive with a big group. A party of 2 or 3 is perfect.
author: stacy k.

description:
At the insistence of my coworker who said he knew of a place that had ~*amazing*~ ramen, we hiked our way up to Katana-Ya during our lunch hour. Surprisingly, there was no line and while the inside was busy, it wasn't that bad that service suffered. We were seated quickly and served promptly.

That being said, the tables here are *TINY*. There was four of us seated at this tiny little table built for two, I was constantly bumping and banging into my friends and frankly, was moving into the foreplay territory given how much we were touching. The restaurant itself is small and I get wanting to fit as many people in as possible, but yeeowch. This was a bit too cramped for my liking.

Portions are *HUGE*. Cripes, this is good if you have a big appetite. If you're like me, it felt like a really big waste of money and food. I could have done with something half the size and not paid out $15. 

That all being said, the ramen soup was pretty good. We were given the options of what type of noodles and broth we wanted (udon vs ramen and soy sauce vs miso). From what I understand, their vegetable ramen soup can really be made vegan (unlike some other places that have fish in their vegetable broth) so I was happy with that as an option.

I did enjoy what I had for lunch, but it's hard to say if I'd be back. The cramped seating and cost for such a large amount that I can't eat makes this place a little less appealing than the ramen place in the mall food court. And if I'm at the office, it's a pretty far hike up to Geary to get to it.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Most likely filled with MSG? YES.
Deliciously Tasty? YES. 
Always Packed? YES.
Decently Priced? YES.
Will I come here again? YES.

Every ramen item here is deeeelish! 

My two favorites: 
Katanaya Ramen 
Udon Soup

Note: for extra flavor there's a little salt shaker, which appears to be a spice. For all I know its MSG but I pour it onto every single spoonful of ramen. Mmmmmm....
author: Erin M.

description: The ramen Katana-Ya serves is really filling, especially #12. Katanaya Ramen. I've been here about three times, each time I could never finish it except that last time I did. It is very very good. (:
author: Cherie B.

description:
Ask me a year or two ago, and I would have given this place a 5 star rating. But after frequenting this place a bit more, and receiving noticeably smaller portions of chicken karaage and fried gyoza each time,  I feel like I'm getting over, what was just a lot of hype. You know, whenever I see review of 1000+ or lines out the door, I have great expectations. Katana-ya is a decent ramen place, but I feel like you can find better ramen outside the city, like in the South Bay. 

Also a turning point was when I was sitting at the bar and saw the sushi chef, who must have been getting over a cold, hack up a luggie and spit it out, in what I hope was, a sink or a trash can behind the sushi bar (but still in plain sight in front of me and my friend). This was slightly embarrassing because at the time, I was raving about how good this place was. Now I tell people to avoid the sushi.
author: Ray W.

description:
Okay, this review is rather late: I came here with a group of friends on a SF road trip in May of 2011. We came here after noticing the high yelp rating, figuring it would be a great place for a ramen fix. After waiting outside on a crowded sidewalk for almost an hour and a half...

This was definitely not it. My BBQ pork ramen was not anything special at all, the broth was not flavorful, ramen texture was too soft for my preference, and I just wasn't as wowed by it as I thought I would be. Disappointment after hype is the worst kind. Others in my group were also very unimpressed, someone ordered a spicy tuna roll which came out warm (ew?) and one member of our group ended up having a severe episode of an upset stomach about 30 minutes after we finished our meal. The place was super small, and the waitstaff was not helpful and seemed annoyed that we wanted our bill and that we were a bigger group.

Definitely will not be returning.
author: Susie M.

description: I've eaten here twice and the first time was phenomenal and the second time was ok. I got the regular ramen which is what I got last time and the mushrooms in the ramen tasted like plastic, and my California roll was good. I'll probably come back.
author: Damien C.

description:
It was around 2 on a Saturday afternoon. Bunny and I were worried that this restaurant might have been closed in the afternoon. However glancing at the hours on Yelp, we noticed that it was open pretty much all day. 

Katana-Ya is located within walking distance of the SF Shopping Centre. Hearing about this place, we were anticipating trying it out. As with most ramen places, there was a wait. We put our name on the clipboard and stood out in the sun waiting for our table.

A swarm of people start coming up and we were hopeful in getting a table soon. FInally, we get called. The turn around rate was so fast that I sat on a very warm seat. As we were walking in, the couple had brushed past by us. I decided to order the regular ramen with miso favor and katsu don combo while Bunny gets the regular ramen with curry don.

Our bowl of ramen comes out shortly. The toppings are bamboo shoots, seaweeds, pork and bean sprouts. The katsu don came with three pieces of katsu. I liked the broth. I enjoyed the noodles and the pork was tender. The katsu was also good. I was able to try a bit of the curry as well. It was a little spicy for me. Luckily there was rice so that helped a lot. There was also salad at the bottom of the bowl which was a good mix.

The combo was tasty and I can see myself going back!
author: Doris W.

description:
Thank you Katana-Ya for being open late! Late night eats FTW!

The spicy tofu ramen with miso soup base is delicious, as was the tuna poki salad. The extra spicy ramen is definitely HOT HOT HOT. But the spicy ramen -- just right. Comes piping hot (temperature-wise) too.
author: Angie C.

description:
With 2000+ reviews and 4 stars, I was expecting a lot.

Sadly, Katana-Ya did NOT meet my expectations. 

Ordered the regular ramen (rich and salt flavored), while my boyfriend ordered the Katana-Ya ramen (rich and miso flavored). Got a good taste of both. 

Honestly, while filling, both ramen broths were lackluster and the chashu, not so tasty. If this is generally recognized as the best ramen in town, I'd say, go to another town for ramen because better ramen definitely exists. In fact, friends of ours who live in SF said that there is a better place a bit farther off. 

While the place is small, service was fast, so I'll give credit to that. But no way can I recognize this place as an amazing ramen joint.
author: Kristina R.

description:
Some men, when they are sick, are big whiny babies.

This unscientific information has been gleaned from Arbitrary Polls 'R Us (i.e. the lovely women of my acquaintance agree).  Admittedly, my friends are some bad a55 women.  I don't know if it's years of dealing with debilitating PMS cramps or what but when my chicas get colds they just go about their business while the menfolk sniffle and gasp like they are at death's door step. 

Katana-Ya's ramen is perfect for soothing the throats and stomachs of the cold afflicted.  I cannot resist anything with the words "FRIED CHICKEN" in it so of course I got the Fried Chicken Ramen with Miso Broth.  The Whiny One got the Green Onion Ramen with Miso Broth.  We also had a roll with Eel, Avocado, Crab & Tobiko - mmm!

The noodles had a nice consistency, the slurpilicious broth was flavorful and the portions solid.  The Perfect Medicine.  

Arigato gozaimasu Katana-Ya!
author: Amy C.

description:
Man, you have to hunt down this place. But it had a lot of people waiting outside for lunch, so I guess the food should be good to the average tongue. I even overheard an elderly man commenting on how it was good as he exited out the one puny door.

Overall: 2/5
It's good ramen! As always, read all my pros and cons before assuming anything with the seemingly low rating. 2+ is recommended in my books. And I give 2 stars for this fine dining experience, although it may literally be just fine and so-so (relatively). But it's ramen! Ramen is edible and mouth watering no matter what. In fact, I had half a Samyang spicy ramen pack as a night snack today.

Decor: 0.25
This place uses its space efficiently, with the bar running along the hall, if you will. The entrance is not conspicuous but just there along the street, sandwiched between other fine dining establishments. What can I say? It's in the middle of San Francisco, the industrial analogue of a honeycomb--buildings stacked for efficient spacing.

The seats were hard. Since I'm not that big of a fatass, it was kinda noticeable, until I started getting distracted by the taste of my ramen (and lively conversations)!

Food: 0.5
I got the Fried Chicken Ramen with rich miso broth (not sure if I got the right one because 2 other people in my group got the same, with different richness).

I have had better authentic ramen (Mitsuwa on Saratoga, Ryowa House in Mountain View), but I welcomed it after a long morning. Still, the ingredients tasted pretty generic: generic miso broth, generic flat circular pieces of green onion, generic bamboo shoots. I guess if they tasted like other places, that could also mean it did it right? Or at least this place can blend in with ramen places and still get business. The one in Mitsuwa (it's inside a Japanese supermarket) has the best broth, though. I think it's simmered with bone, Korean style.

I prefer my broth to be piping hot, but it was decently warm. The noodles were nice and chewy, and the fried chicken was well done and delicious. Chicken tastes good.

If you like to add stuff to your meal, this place only has the basic soy sauce, ground red pepper and ground black pepper. BYOFJC: Bring your own fancy Japanese condiment. You know, like the potpourri of red and black and sesame seed and stuff. Or the red chili oil.

The menu also claims the food has MSG, and still it did not amaze me. But ramen is ramen, and ramen is good.

Price: 0.25
$11 LOL

Well, I guess it is San Francisco after all. If I came back, I would still consider what I got. It's only a $2.05 difference between a regular ramen and one with nice additions of fried chicken, boneless ;)

If you have a party of 5 like we did, you might want to pretend to be strangers for a while because they slap on 18% for parties of 5 or more. My share turned out to be $14.

Today's price/portion ratio: high. I was not even that full after finishing the bowl. But according to my sexist friend, it is because I am a guy. I attribute it to the fact that they were noodles. Nah, it is because I am a guy. Sexism wins.

Service: 0.25
Why is there an 18% gratuity again? We got our order taken with someone with a thick accent (assuming Japanese), and the Hispanic dude who brought our food had better pronunciation. He (perhaps this specific man) will call your fried chicken ramen karaage, so don't get confused here. That's cool and all, but he couldn't distinguish which bowls had rich broth or not. He's also the one who brought our waters. He basically did all the work! I'd rather have tipped him directly. The waitresses were busy counting cash. Another reason to split up into smaller groups fewer than 5 members.

Bonus: 0.75
But for some reason I am biased for ramen, which I like in general. I have to bring the score up to 2 stars :)

PS: Can someone recommend me to be an Elite Squad member? I still haven't gotten a reply for my application. I have the yelpitude!
author: Brian H.

description:
Good spot to go to when you're shopping in Union Square. It's usually pretty cold walking around the shops in SF, so a good bowl of ramen hits the spot. This place is not the best ramen I've ever tried, but for the location and price, it's good enough for me. 

I've tried their spicy tofu ramen and the katanaya ramen. Both good. I recently realized I like the soy flavor a little more than miso, even though I always order miso. My friend and I shared and the soy was really good and not too bland. 

Food is good, but if you gotta wait more than 1 hour for this place, I'd skip it. There's so many other better ramen places in the city that fall within the same level as this place if not better.
author: Vi L.

description:
One of the best ramen places I been to. My friend and I was on a bus to somewhere and then we happened to both spot this restaurent because of the LONG line outside. Then we decided this was the place for dinner. It was REALLY good (but a bit pricey). 

Keep in mind you have to wait for a while.
author: Jessica H.

description: Really fresh sushi with excellent rice. Went here with two of my girlfriends and got miso soup, house sake, and a traditional sushi roll. All of it was great. Didn't have to wait too long on a Sunday after putting our name on the list. Service was quick but probably cause they want to keep customers flowing. I would go here again.
author: Kelly F.

description:
Only 1900+ reviews?  Clearly, this place is in dire need of more reviews.  After flying in to San Francisco, we dropped off our luggage and walked over to Katana-Ya for some late night dinner (around midnight). The place is tiny so we had to wait a bit before getting seated.  

I was really hoping for some tonkotsu ramen but turns out they didn't have any!  I was slightly disappointed but I looked over the menu and was eager to try some of the ramen.  We had a group of 4 and we ordered the Katanaya Ramen in a salt broth, Spicy Tofu Ramen in a miso broth, and I think the last one was the extra spicy in a soy sauce broth (which despite the name, was not THAT spicy).  I may have gotten the broths confused but I think that's what we ordered.  Most of us preferred the miso broth overall though I thought the soy sauce broth  was pretty good too.  The noodles were cooked to perfection and the pork was oh-so-tender.  We had tried to order a hamachi collar (yellowtail) but they were out.  No matter, the noodles were enough for us!

I just love love noodles so this was the perfect way to start my trip!  I will totally go back when I'm in town again.
author: Jessica L.

description: The ramen texture felt like the store-bought variety, and the broth was ok. I ordered Butter Corn Ramen, and true to its word, the ramen has a stick of butter on top of the corn. When was this ever a thing!? Shame on me for ordering something with the word butter in it.
author: Rosalind W.

description:
Mediocre at best. 

Had to wait 2 min. to get greeted then unenthusiastically was lead to my table. I kindly asked the waitress in Japanese what the best thing on the menu was and she recommended the chashu ramen.

I had the chashu ramen with miso broth, rich.

Broth: Rich but bland. Flavors of chashu but still borderline tasteless.
Noodles: A complete disgrace, too thick to be ramen, overcooked, meh.
Chashu: Chewy
Uni: sweet, savory and a good amount for $7.50
Service: Bad but tolerable. Easy to see they just don't care. Oh well..

Overall, I say pass on this place. If this is the best ramen in SF, then I pity SF for I could not go more than 2-3 months w/o a decent bowl of ramen and a pint of sapporo.
author: Jon R.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Spicy Green Onion - Broth still good. Only one piece of pork. If I wasn't so full from snacking beforehand, I would've finished this whole bowl soup n all like the other times.
author: Angela L.

description:
I haven't been able to have their tasty broth for over a year.  Thanks to yelp, there is always a long line out the door even if I come at random times like 3pm.

--

Finally got a table, and it did not disappoint.  20 minute wait at 9pm on Friday.  Full flavored goodness that's unlike anywhere else in SF.
author: Chanson H.

description:
If you live around bay area, I don't see the point of waiting in line for more than 30 minutes for this place. All right noodle, all right soup base, and all right service.
The soup is not as milky as it should be, and the noodle is not very chewy. Overall I feel this place very touristy.
author: Dragon F.

description:
Beware of the hype.

I'm moving out of the Bay Area for school and at the suggestion of my wise and loving girlfriend we have been tackling some arbitrary list of top things to do in SF. 

It would be fun to be a tourist before I trade Oakland for Hudson County, NJ.

So far, I have been unimpressed with this list. 

Tiny spot, hole in the wall, so expect a wait. Tables are cramped. After reading all of the reviews posted on yelp and their window I was expecting a life changing bowl of ramen.

The ramen is life changing if the only ramen you have ever had was the instant noodle crap. 

Nothing was bad; noodles are fresh, broth is OK but the chasu was bland and tough. 

The concept of the Katana-Ya Ramen (put everything in it) is awesome and for the components in it, is pretty damn good. 

Still, expecting awesome and got just OK. 

For ramen in SF, I'd rather go to Ajisen at the Westfield. There are plenty of better options in the East and South Bay.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Tasty ramen.  Good noodles.
I had the #12.  I liked it but my wife just thought it was okay.

Really small restaurant.  Near union square.
author: Addison P.

description: Horrible place! Food is not real Japanese is more  Chinese waitress are so rude.... So rude!!! They just throw the bill at us... Never again
author: Alma M.

description:
Arriving in SFO around 1:30 am, our time clocks were screwy and our stomachs growled, 'let's eat!'  We checked into the Hotel Diva (http://www.yelp.com/biz/hotel-diva-san-francisco#hrid:3iHJ4IHLisNU36yNCe_Mfw) and recalled passing a Thai restaurant nearby.  We peeked into the Thai restaurant only to find not a soul there.  Well, it's 1am, but still not a good sign?  Wait a minute, what's that next door?  Noodle shop?  

That instantly sounded amazing as the night's chill was nipping at our thin island-born blood.  The place was packed, but they squeezed us into a table near the entrance.  We ordered their combination meal of udon and soba noodles with chicken katsu/rice/salad and pork dumbori and the spider roll.  Man, this hit the spot!  Both broths were nice, full of flavor with perfectly done noodles.  Everything else was just icing on a cake I knew could easily become a bad habit.  Place usually packed all times of the day with young Asian twenty somethings.  Good enough for me.
author: Kalani C.

description:
I really LIKE Katana-Ya.

An OC native, the types of ramen I encounter are way different than that of Katana-Ya. First off, I feel like the broth here is a lot clearer and maybe has more of a vegetable taste? It's not the pork flavor that I'm used to having at Shin Sen Gumi or Santouka. It's DIFFERENT, but a different that I like and welcome.

Fried Chicken Ramen - I really liked the chicken. It was fried to perfection and had an awesome taste mixed with the ramen. The chicken came in strips, and definitely didn't get very soggy in the broth. I liked the flavors and the fact that the ramen noodles were a little bit on the thicker side. A good amount of greens in the soup. Weirdly flavorful broth, but not a creamy/cloudy consistency. Pretty good.

BBQ Pork ramen - definitely had the taste of BBQ pork in the ramen. The only big difference between the two bowls were the choice of protein. I think the broth takes on the taste of whatever protein you choose, but other than that, same bowl of ramen.

They also have sushi, which I haven't tried, but here's to next time?

The restaurant is very small, and although I've heard of a long wait, I didn't really experience that at Katana-Ya. Everyone working is very nice.

A solid four star eats :)
author: Trang B.

description: These guys are no joke when it comes down to Ramen. Get the BBQ Ramen Medium Spicy.
author: Elias C.

description:
katana-ya's chashu ramen (11) isn't a last meal ala "you'feel like you're fixing to die" (country joe mcdonald). far some it.  it's above pedestrian but nothing is 24/7 must have about it. 

katana-ya is very small and cramped. no need to sign in as few people were in the restaurant. seating is very tight here. gozilla-sized ramenists may have to take their ramen to go. myself, a petite panda. (not kung fu, but food fu) bearly fitted onto the stool.

menu is ramen. udon, soda, curry rice,  and sashimi/nigiri,
ramen starts at 8.90. add on toppings are available. shio, shoyu and  miso broths are options. included toppings were bamboo,  green onions,  and 4 chashu pieces. chashu very well done here, nice  chashu flavor.  a little fatty.
broth was miso, not much else. ramen smoothly  textured, good for slurping, al dente. toppings anemic.

music: r & b soul

temakI:
-seating of 5 at bar, 10 tables of 2's or 4's.
-cold water provided.
-food came fast.
-japanese baseall  players in the majors have autographed pics here.
-ajisen in westfield may be cheaper, more filling.
author: Victor G.

description:
If you come here on a busy night, be prepared to wait outside. This place is tiny, and the management knows it. You wont be seated unless your entire party is present, so best to keep it at four, maybe five people at most.

Food is good, I only docked a star because the pork/chicken in the ramen bowls isn't the best... Everything else, however, is great. There are a ton of options available of you're in the mood for noodles. The combination ramen/appetizer dishes are very reasonably priced, and will leave you feeling satisfactorily full. The servers are friendly but obviously in a hurry, given the amount of traffic the place gets. 

The hours are great to end an early-ish night of drinking, considering the location.
author: Taylor S.

description:
This place deserves a review since Ive been a fan for the past year and have visited many times.  So here goes:

I ALWAYS order the miso, medium-spicy, Katana-ya ramen special.  It comes with 2 deep fried duplings, as well as a couple of deep fried chicken bits, corn and bunch of other good stuff.  The bowl is a good size, and is especially savory for the winter/colder seasons.  

I have never been a fan of Ramen, UNTIL NOW.  Writing this up makes my mouth water, and more than likely, I will pay a visit to them this weekend.

The ramen is my favorite part to it all.  It taste freshly made, and nothing like the stuff you get in a package for $0.50 at the store.  

I would give it a 5, but a few things took my rating down.

a.  the wait is usually too long ... they need to expand or move locations.  It fits probably max 20 people in the restaurant at a time.
b.  it is NOT kid friendly (because see note a above).
c.  Their service is not very good, but then again, what do you expect.  It's an asian business... it's NEVER about service at these places.
d.  Broth can be a little bit salty sometimes.  Add a couple of ice cubes, and it's tastier!

Nonetheless, its the best RAMEN place Ive been to,  but then again, Its the only place Ive been to.
author: Barb B.

description: consistent. good for a late night with drinks since the broth is always a bit salty. Their combo deals are good and you get a lot for $15 bucks.
author: Dee N.

description:
Really cute hole in the wall and their ramen is on 7x7! They used to have this amazing green tea and red bean shaved ice desert but not anymore :(

Sushi is also consistently good.
author: Amy M.

description:
I've only been here once so far. 

The Ramen was ok but the service to me was just bad.
I went in and sat down it took them like 5 mins to give us the menu because they were chatting it up with each other.
During the meal I noticed that my meter was about to run out so I asked them for change for ONE DOLLAR and they refused me... 
Is missing four quarters really going to hurt? 

Methinks not.
author: Vincent T.

description:
Like other reviews have said, this is a very tiny restaurant. I don't think me and my friend would have gotten seats if we didn't come at 5:30pm. Asked the waiter what the most popular menu item was, and was quickly answered with the Katana-Ya ramen with miso soup, which contains a whole host of deliciousness. 

The noodles came out relatively quickly (again, this was at 5:30pm) and I got to eating. The dish served me with great portions of meats, veggies, corn, noodles, and soup. I was done with the soup at the moment when I finished the noodles/meats = perfect ending!! The best part of the dish was the fried dumpling. I don't even know what it contained, but I'm still craving it.
author: Jason T.

description:
This is a tiny place right across the street from the Curran Theater. I was late, so my friends had already been waiting for a while for a table. The wait here seems pretty long. We were a party of 5 and were seated at a relatively small table, luckily, we are relatively small people. 

I had the skinny veggie ramen. I usually avoid things with the word diet or low-calorie... I should have known to avoid the SKINNY veggie ramen but opted to order it anyways since it was the only vegetarian ramen. Overall the ramen was pretty good. It was really light and I would have probably enjoyed it more if I had been in the mood for a REALLY healthy meal but in this case, it was a little too light for me. I just wasn't completely satisfied by the ramen but my carnivorous friends seem quite alright with their meal.

Overall, seems like a pretty cool place to go with a friend or two. Good deal with the ramen combos and open late! But be prepared to wait and sit at a small table. Also remember, parking downtown is horrible.
author: Angela T.

description:
Hot ramen on a cold, gloomy San Francisco day? Automatic 3 stars, at least, right?

I don't know much about ramen so this review will only be useful to those who are also as clueless as I am.

I ordered the Katanaya Ramen (~$13) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw?select=yMmFYTV6RigHOvkP9BOZCQ for 2 potstickers, 2 slices of pork, 2 pieces fried chicken, 1/2 egg, and corn. I chose the soy sauce soup base (miso, salt also available). 
- Ramen was good. I can't comment on this aspect much.
- I would say the fried chicken was really yummy! It reminded me of Chinatown fried chicken legs. Very crispy and flavorful. 
- The potstickers were also good. 
- The pork was forgettable. 
- I thought the soy sauce broth was actually really good. My first ramen experience was at Japantown and my broth was SO salty!! I thought that's how all ramen was like.

We also ordered toro nigiri ($5.50). Of course, we did not expect much for this price. It was chewy and did not melt in mouth like other great toro pieces do.

My friend ordered the ramen that came with uni & ikura. The uni was actually good - sweet and creamy. 

The ramen and the toppings were good but I thought it was quite pricey for noodle soup. They're not known for their sushi and I'm sure everyone knows it so try at one's own risk. This would be a great place to go after a night of drinking and partying, though! Open until 1am!
author: Tina T.

description:
I've been to Japan and spent a significant amount of time there, so believe me when I say that this ramen is about as good as it gets!  I got the spicy green onion ramen with miso base soup.  It wasn't overly salty and it wasn't too spicy.  There was a nice bit of seaweed in it and it was about $11.

Really nice atmosphere, managed or owned by a Japanese guy.  The feel of it is very much like a ramen noodle shop you would find in Japan.  And they're open until 1:15 AM!  Great feel, but don't expect super top-notch American style service.

Note for vegetarians, there was a huge cut of pork in it and I don't believe many of the ramen dishes are made with vegetarian soup bases, so something you may want to check on, even if what you're ordering doesn't say it has meat in it.
author: B L.

description: Health score is back to 100 and the ramen is superb! I like the kimchee ramen with miso broth. Very tasty!!
author: R. P.

description: Loved this place! Great ramen and a fun atmosphere...the place is truly just a little hole in the wall with a lot of character. I got the ramen combo for lunch with miso broth and grilled salmon on the side, was delicious. The dumplings were also amazing. Can't wait to go back!
author: Emily N.

description:
Ok the sad part is that this review would have been a 4 star rated review if it were just based on the food alone.
I ordered the Katana -Ya ramen and it was crazy super good, chicken was perfect with the potstickers and pork all in the miso. 
My GF ordered the Spicy Tofu Ramen and instantly said it was very good and the best she has had in a while. 
The wait wasnt too long considering we were there around Midnight and the service was good. 

Now the Bad Part : 
As soon as i finish my ramen i look to my right and spot a ROACH crawling on the wall. I watch it for a hot min and wait for a chance to kill it. when i finally step on it the waiter says thanks like its a normal happening there. So that made me think about it more, Roaches usually arent just roaming around alone, if you see one there is probably a few more running around close by. 

Maybe some day we might go back. or maybe take out
author: Blake R.

description:
My friend had nothing but good things to say about this place so he took me here to try it out since we were in the SF area.  We came on a Saturday afternoon and the place was already filled up.  The place is super tiny.  Probably could only fit about 15 people in there.  However the wait wasn't too bad.  We waited for about 10-15min I would say.  The inside felt really cozy since it was so small.  The staffs were really friendly and attentive.  

I got the kimchi ramen which I had to admit was pretty good.  The broth was super tasty.  Just the right amount of spiciness and saltiness.  The noodles were good too.  I plan on visiting again soon next time i'm around the area.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Katana-ya, I really wanted to give you 5 stars again. But alas, I was really disappointed.

Katana-ya used to be my favorite ramen place to go to in the yay area. I took many of my friends there and they enjoyed it too. Unfortunately, I'm not sure if I'm more of a ramen connoisseur now, or if their standard simply fell. 

I came here on a Sunday for lunch with the bf, and surprisingly, there was no line! We got there 5 minutes before noon, and they told us we could sit anymore. I ordered the spicy green onion ramen (soy sauce) and the bf got the katana-ya ramen (miso). 

I'm not sure if my broth was better than the bf's because it was spicy, or if it was just better. But I definitely preferred mine. The miso was just not very flavorful, and the noodles (for both of ours) were on the soft (I prefer al dente) side. 

For me, the two most important things for ramen are the noodles and broth, and so I was pretty disappointed. I used to think this place was great! I also added a hard boiled egg to mine, since they don't really give you a lot of toppings. The bf's ramen had plenty of ingredients though, and they seemed to give a lot of karaage for his ramen which was nice.

$28 in total including tip. Would I come back? Maybe... But it'll be a long time before I step back in here.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
I'm sorry my friends, I'm just not as in love with this place as others. The wait time was long. We got there at about 9 and we didn't get seated 9:30. I totally understand the long wait time during a rush time, but at 9? Seriously? It wasn't horrible once we got seated, but the lady looked over us to another table to order. I know it's not that big of a deal, but we were seated first and knew what we were going to order. It just made me a LITTLE mad. 

We ordered the Katanaya Ramen and the Chasu Ramen from the 7x7 list. Both were just about typical. Nothing amazing. I guess because I thought it was on the list it would have been perfect. 

It's pretty pricey for a bowl of ramen. The total for just 2 ramens was $30.

I'll probably only be back if someone forces me to go. It's not the best food and the wait is just too long to be justified for me. Sorry, we're just not in love.
author: Nina Y.

description:
If it is your first time here, you have to try the ramen combo. It comes with fried potstickers/chicken, corn, bamboo, seaweed, and pork. I get mine extra spicy. 

Long lines during peak time. Get there before 7pm if you can. 

Small place that fits probably only 25 people at a time or feels like it.
author: Eileen C.

description:
After wandering the bone cold streets of San Francisco you'll be happy to sit down (after a 10-20 minute wait) to a warm bowl of noodles at Katana-Ya. The restaurant is really small on the inside and nothing fancy, they employ the mirror technique all along the walls to make it look bigger. Be ready for a cozy experience and a longer wait if you show up with a big group. I've had the vegetable ramen as well as the katana-ya special ramen which has fried chicken, fried potstickers, boiled egg, and bbq beef. I was worried it was going to be super heavy and crazily decadent but it was actually delicious. The first few bites of meat when the fried bits weren't completely souped up were just the right combination of fried goodness to salty liquid and even when they had been floating in the ramen for a while, the fried potstickers were juicy and tender. My complaints would be that the noodles were dense and got pretty gross once they cooled down and when I asked for a recommendation the waitress said she doesn't make recommendations because everyone has different preferences. Well duh--but I'm asking you for a RECOMMENDATION meaning I'm open to whatever you think is good. It's always a bad sign when a server can't think of something on their own menu that they like. 

But anyway it's a popular spot and even though the ramen isn't the best you'll ever have it's worth checking out and conveniently close to Union Square and across the street from the American Conservatory Theatre.
author: Alice L.

description: The wait here is frustrating, but we keep coming back whenever we visit San Francisco.  The ramen is delicious.  We also really enjoyed the gyoza, and the service consistently fast.
author: James A.

description:
I'm updating this with a 4 so that it'll average out to about a 3.5. Does Yelp work that way?

My boyfriend and I came to Katana-Ya after watching a movie at the mall, and mostly because we had just read that the chasu ramen was listed on 7x7's Big Eat 2012. I didn't have a great memory of this place, so I figured we could try again.

There wasn't a wait, which was nice (probably because we were there before 6pm). We ordered the:

chasu ramen
philly roll
spicy salmon
hamachi nigiri

The ramen again did not blow me away (the chasu was just super dry! the noodles are good though), the rolls were decent and arrived at our table quickly, but the hamachi nigiri was pretty good! Nice and buttery. My boyfriend thought it was all yum.

Our savory taste buds were satisfied, but we still had room to down a Snickers ice cream bar and an It's It ice cream cookie sandwich on our way home.
author: Alison C.

description: My first time was amazing and my most recent experience with their fried chicken ramen turned me waaaaayyyy off.  Soup was salty, yet under seasoned?
author: Lyyddsss ..

description:
I guess I was so caught up in job hunting I forgot to review this place since trying it a few months ago. 

I came here right before dinner hours and was able to get seated right away with the mister.

The service was kind of laid back for such a highly reviewed place. Anyway, we ordered two bowl of ramen. 

Hubby had the pork based with some type of meat and I had the spicy tofu miso one. We also ordered the crab croquet and a California roll.

I didn't enjoy the croquet much as I could not taste much crab and did not understand why they would put katsu sauce on it? It just completely covered up the crab flavor.

The California rolls were neither the worst nor the best I've ever had in the city but probably better than in most places in the east bay.

But what I did enjoy was my ramen. The spicy miso broth reminded me of the Shabu House miso based soup, only cheaper. I loved everything about the the soup, unfortunately so did the hubby who kept trying to steal it as he didn't find his as appealing..

Told ya that not all meat dishes are better than their vegetarian ones hun! :P

Now as far as coming back, YOU BET, for the ramen! Skip the appetizers if possible and arrive early, otherwise parking is not so great here!
author: Petra S.

description:
This is my first & only ramen joint in SF, so i can't be sure that this is the best in the area. What I can attest to, is the broth being perfectly smooth,   the fried chicken was tender and juicy and the bbq pork was edible. 

My recommendation is to get the Katanaya ramen - which has a little bit of everything in the bowl.
author: Rae F.

description:
I finally found it! A ramen place in the city that is good! I am so excited that my search is over!

Figures that the Yelp Master would know where to find this place. I guess I should have asked her ages ago. I had the miso BBQ Pork Ramen. The soup is really rich. I have to say that it was a little too rich, but if that's the only thing that I'm going to complain about, that's pretty amazing. The pork was the worst part of the meal and it was decent enough. The noodles are fantastic. 

I also ordered a starter of Karaage. So good. I'm drooling just thinking about them again. 

Oh, I can't wait till I go there again!
author: Mariko F.

description: I loved Miso taste katana ramen. I think it's better than shoyu favor. The place is  small and it seems always crowded. Sushi was so-so.
author: Yaeko M.

description:
The only late night ramen spot around.

However, after trying numerous other ramen places, by comparison, this place is only "good" to me, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Like the majority of the good ramen places in the SF Bay Area and Socal, their noodles are cooked perfectly. The fact that you can combo it up similar to Maru Ichi is also nice (and the price point for the combo is a great value).

I recommend getting the chicken karage or the Katana Ya special bowl with rich broth (any of the 3 pretty much are good). Just note not to expect an ultra rich flavorfest though, as comparable ramen spots have a richer broth without the title of "rich" added to it. The karage was nice and crispy before it fully absorbed the flavor of the miso broth, which wasn't overpowering, despite asking for the strong flavor. Fresh green onions, bamboo, and seaweed further added a nice sweetness and texture to the ramen.

What causes me to dock a star are the prices (slightly cheaper than New York, but thats because SF rent is expensive, plus they have extended hours), and the fact that I prefer the broth from several other establishments over Katana-Ya. Also, when requested to sit at a table for 3, which there was roo, we were denied the small table and were seated at the bar, which was a bit cramped. Note that there were 2 more tables (a table for 2 and a table for about 6-8) open in addition to the table for 3 we wanted (by the window).

Nevertheless you cannot deny that the quality of food is good, and that it is located around a bustling nightlife. The soup also provides for curbing down your hangover. 

I guess for me, it really weighs down to convenience: wait till the next morning to grab ramen for a hangover, or kill 2 birds with one stone.
author: Marc T.

description:
What the shit? Are you serious? Is this what everyone's been talking about?

Fuckin hell, man! For the past 6 months, I've been adventuring around the bay area, trying all these ramen shops in order to prepare for Katana-Ya. I was expecting the Hatori Hanzo of Ramen but instead, I got Maru Ichi.

**Miso flavored Fried Chicken Ramen (~$12)

When you think about it, fried chicken and ramen SHOULD be a good combo, yes? I mean heck! I'm not black, but I like me some chicken, nor am I a Japanese man, but I love me some ramen! This should be a match made in heaven! 

WRONG!

(Antoine Dodson voice) WELL! OBVIOUSLY the skin of the chicken starts to get soggy once it's been bathing in the broth for awhile! The chicken itself is delicious, but you get 3 pieces of these tiny, popcorn chicken lookin things. It just feels incredibly lazy and they could have put in one or two more pieces.

The miso broth at Katana-Ya is absolutely embarrassing. No, I mean SERIOUSLY, it's embarrassing. Not only was it lacking in depth and complexity, but it was flat out boring. I actually thought about seasoning my broth with soy sauce and some salt. It was THAT sad.

To add insult to injury, I ordered the RICH version of the broth (Katana-Ya lets you choose regular broth, light, or rich.) 

When it comes to noodles, I am the NOODLE KING! Well... not really, but I definitely know a good noodle when I chew one. On a scale from 1 to amazing, these were "uhhh... mr. chef? I think you need to cook these a little longer." 

It was too chewy, and too bland. Generally speaking, if the noodles and broth are in harmony, the noodles will act as a beautiful backpack where globules of flavor and seasoning can ride their way into your belly (or ass, whichever comes first.)

SHAME on you Katana-Ya! I think it is only fair that you kneel down (in traditional Japanese fashion) and cut open your stomach while I chop your head off. 

So to all you people thinking about going to Katana-Ya: "HIDE JO KEEDS, HIDE JO WIFE, AND HIDE JO MONEY CUZ KATANA-YA AINT THAT GOOD!"

I give Katana-Ya a very disappointing 3.0 out of 5

P.S. Orenchi Ramen and Santouka (in Santa Clara and San Jose) are 10000 x better.
author: Ray M.

description:
Pros:
*Fast
*Spicy Tuna Roll is awesome
*Katanaya Ramen is top notch
*Friendly staff

Cons:
*Always crowded -- long lines/waits even late in the night
*Cramped seating

All around, the best Ramen joint in town!
author: Tushar T.

description:
Everytime I come in this restaurant, I feel like I'm in Mortal Kombat. The place sounds a bit like Kitana. I am greeted by Liu Kang, come on people, that guy that's worked there for years looks just like him, especially the hair. I just feel like hes going to jump on the sushi bar with Johnny Cage and be like "Tsung, I challenge you!" In this case maybe a homeless crackhead from the loin who walked inside. Then the song comes on:  MOOOORTAAAAAL KOMBAAAAT!! Tun tun turun tun...

Ok enough nerdy talk. I love this place. The first time I ate here was right after a Broadway Musical named Rock of Ages at Curran. My two roommates and I got a table in about 10min. It's a very small restaurant, hole-in-the-wall, and we sat in a small table almost sitting on top of a couple next to us who didn't talk the whole date, how does that happen? You guys need to read dating for dummies. 

We were all dressed up and my lovely roommate drops the soy sauce by accident all over my white/beigeish dress. Just great. Weird thing is no one complemented it before It got stained, everyone was saying my dress was so cool after, because somehow the soy sauce made cool shapes and looked fashionable.  

I say order the Miso soup, butter corn ramen (could use some salt), sake sashimi, golden, unagi, one of the rolls with mango, about $18 per person. We got served at 1:35am and super fast. I will return, but never again in a white dress.
author: Stephanie M.

description: I was waiting for a flight, and this was around the corner from the Hilton.  I ducked in and got a seat at the Sushi bar.  For $17 I got a bowl of hot miso that was very savory, and 8 pieces of assorted nigiri (all different ) with a roll.  Fish was very fresh, and service was polite and quick.  No complaints.  Granted, I live in Philly where sushi is not as famous as cheese steaks, but this equaled many NY sushi experiences I have had and where I paid a great deal more.
author: Jan K.

description: I still love the ramen but having found other very good ramen places (Chotto in Marina is very tasty) I'm not as impressed as before. Also the service isn't veryt friendly or attentive despite how small the place is, seems like they have a bit of an attitude here, you know the kind where it's like they are doing you a favor since they are so popular and cool. But still the Katana-Ya #12 house ramen with spicy miso is a damn tasty and hearty meal.
author: Christopher Steven O.

description: Great for what it is.  Generally when I get Japanese noodles I'm looking for soba, broth that isn't a salt bomb and something like fried chicken in the bowl.  This place has it all.
author: Click C.

description:
Katana-Ya is extremely popular and especially hopping at dinner time.

It is a great option among all the touristy and blah restaurants downtown near Union Square.  The Chasu Ramen (pork) is what is recommended on 7x7 Magazine's Big Eat SF.  The ramen is great but the pork had no flavor.  I would go with a meat that might offer more flavor...chicken maybe?
author: Chad S.

description:
Classic case of claustrophobia in a hole-in-the-wall restaurant.  One thing you should never do is come here with a large group, that's a death wish.  Seating arrangements give you minimal space and if you're like me, you'll find yourself subjected to the curse of being sandwiched between two tables of wailing devil babies.  Expect a crowd and a wait of approximately 20 minutes on weekend nights...had I known about this beforehand, I would've brought a coloring book or something.

However, the delicious food compensates for all that.  I've had both the Katana-Ya ramen and the regular ramen.  The regular ramen isn't anything special because for $8.50, you're not getting much.  I'd much rather drop another $4 for the Katana-Ya ramen which contains fried chicken, potstickers, corn, seaweed, BBQ pork, and half an egg.  I was afraid that the fried chicken and potstickers would be too soggy after sitting in the broth but was pleasantly surprised by how crispy and flavorful both were.  I got the miso broth which I found to be cooked into a perfect state of equilibrium; it was neither salty nor dull.  The noodles aren't bad but felt rough which are not always easy on the chewing process.  Overall, Katana-Ya is great and has definitely become one of my hot spots.
author: Alex L.

description: This ramen shop has been a SF fave for a long time.  It's a small place and there's usually a line, but it's a damn good bowl of ramen.  The ramen is obviously the star here but they also have other food.  Once in a while I like to get the kimchi fried rice.  The only problem is that I can never pass up ordering ramen.  Ramen + fried rice = total gut bomb.  At least I'll die happy.
author: Alan C.

description: I had the mild spicy BBQ pork ramen with miso broth and it was delicious! Nice cosy atmosphere and nice staff! I will be back many times :)
author: Konstantin D.

description:
Order the fried chicken ramen with miso soup.

You won't regret it. The chicken is cooked to perfection and the noodles are delicious. 

Major points for being open late, but if you do drop by late at night, expect a line. This place is tiny, so I recommend going during off-hours, ie. not during lunchtime, after work, or late at night.

Don't be discouraged by the crowd though, it is worth the wait. One of my San Francisco indulgences, certainly.
author: Sara D.

description:
Due to the name of this restaurant I feel obligated to put references to samurai in this review. 

If Cup o' Noodles is like Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II - The Secret of the Ooze and Top Ramen with all the fixin's is like Tom Cruise's The Last Samurai, then Katana-Ya is like Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai. 

This is my favorite spot for a great bowl of ramen in San Francisco, especially a nice bowl of bbq pork ramen with the miso based broth (rich). The ramen noodles are perfect and the miso broth is rich and savory. I probably wouldn't recommend much else from here but just to stick to the ramen. It's just a shame this ramen house has so little room which generally means you can expect a wait at all hours of the day.
author: Erich D.

description: Simply amazing!  Sushi fresh!  Ramen was to die for!  And impeccable service!  Highly recommend this place!!!
author: Kelly B.

description:
Finally came here for the ramen and definitely enjoyed it! This place is always crowded so put your name down and get ready to wait a bit.  

Skip the sushi, it's expensive for what you get so help your wallet and your tummy by sticking with the ramen and don buri bowls.
author: Betty C.

description:
1 order of Golden Roll (6pcs; salmon and mango with tempura crumbs on top)
1 Regular Ramen with Salmon Don
1 Udon Noodle (give to us by mistake, and later charged for it)
total bill: $33.06

So my friend and I agreed on Japanese for lunch, and we decided here after finding it on Yelp. Around 2PM, the place was packed and we had to sign up on the wait-list. I don't like how small the restaurant is, especially how close the tables are together. But I guess a small size has its benefits, such as the easiness of getting the wait staff's attention. I liked how the menu has a few pictures to go along with the descriptions! And there's more pictures outside the restaurant too -- gives you something to do while waiting to be seated.

The Golden Roll was delicious! The salmon and mango were very fresh, and the ginger was a perfect compliment. The ramen (in miso broth, rich flavor) was much better than the out-of-bag ramen I make back home. The flavor was just right and the noodles were cooked perfectly, not too hard, not too soft. Broth was a little oily. The pork slice is nice, tender, and has smokey flavors. The salmon don -- basically rice, grilled salmon, and seaweed as garnish -- was very simple and moist. Rice I generally eat is very dry. However, there could have been more salmon. The udon was almost like any other, with the udon noodle, seaweed, tempura crumbs, and broth. It was nothing too special or unique here, but it is better here than at some other Japanese restaurants I've eaten at. We didn't realize the udon wasn't part of our order until a few minutes later, when one of the girls at the table next to us asked the waitress where her udon was. So, the kitchen made her another one, my friend and I kept silent, and Katana-Ya would have received a 5 star from me if they didn't charge us and extra $7.50 for THEIR mistake. Also, on the bill was a service charge of about $5. Good thing my friend asked what "s/c" meant, or else we would have been tipping Katana-Ya twice as much! I personally think that the amount of tip should be the customers' decision, not the restaurant's.

I'll be back again, trying different sushi rolls and more ramen! I know I can trust the freshness and quality here. Katana-Ya has three Public Health Dept score cards, all 100%
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Upon my arrival to SF, I immediately started yelping in order to find a lunch spot that could satisfy my appetite for something that made me feel warm and fuzzy. Katana-Ya did just that. We only waited for about 15 minutes to be seated in the very minimalistic dining room, no fluff, no BS, no elegance, just phenomenal food.

I knew I had to order the signature dish, Katana-Ya Ramen, with 2 handmade gyoza, BBQ pork, boiled egg, wakame seaweed, chives, corn, fried chicken, and of course, the ramen.  I ordered the soy base and asked for it moderately spicy. It was PERFECT! The noodles were cooked to perfection, and the broth was just spicy enough to break a light sweat.

Needless to say, I finished my entire bowl (about 50oz.).  

I didn't have the guts to ask where the bathrooms were but I am willing to bet they were nothing to write home about. 

Go here for good ramen!
author: Ryan L.

description:
After eating ramen in SoCal, Katana-Ya is just not hitting the spot anymore... I've experienced much more savory broth and tasty meats... and for the wait and hike in prices, I wish they would work on their service.  I hate standing outside in the cold just to receive the same icy treatment once inside.  

Not sure I'll be coming back anymore...
author: Beatrice T.

description:
Yummy Ramen spot in SF!!!!!! Been so eager to try this noodle house , finally my girlfriends and I decided to go on a weeknights. Line is long, but who am I kidding? The line is always long anytime of the day.. But it  is worth the wait. Every dish is freshly cooked and tasty!!! Drool.

1. Sashimi salad : super tasty/ fresh
2. Mango and salmon roll crispy coating: my favorite
3. Pork ramen : our fave ramen of the night
4. Chicken karage: tasty as well
5. Kimchi: it was okay
author: Tess C.

description:
Will I come back? No! Never! I stood there for about a good 5 mins before being approached. Yes I saw the staff looking at me too without saying anything; also Waiting on the bf to get out of the restroom otherwise I would have prob left already if it wasn't for my stupid ramen craving and  Ramen Dojo closing early! (Ramen dojo is the shiiiizzzzz btw). 
As far as the broth, I still don't understand what the 4 star rating and hype is all about. U guys obviously haven't tried other ramen places! It was like sucky home made broth with nothing but salt as a flavor. 
The guy waitress, I don't know if he was just an employee working there or part ownership or owned the restaurant but he had the nerve to ask for tip! After taking our leftovers to the back to pack and coming out with it, he didn't hand it to me as I reached out my hands to get them, he walked to the tab that was on the table still and reminded me that it was just the cost of the noodles and tax not incl tips. In my head I'm like the fkn nerve of u! There's no law saying I had to leave a tip. There was just 3 of us. So I left him $3.83 in tip.
author: Julia V.

description: bad food. the chairs are from quizno! slow service and lastly, unauthentic cuisine
author: Leslie M.

description: A friend native to the bay area told me about this place when I lived there. If you go there later in the evening, it won't be as crowded. Honestly it's the best time to have ramen and udon anyway. Everything I've had are super fresh. Fried chicken ramen is a must have!
author: Betty Hoi F.

description:
I go out of my way in San Francisco to make sure that I come to Katana-Ya at least once. If i'm lucky, i get to go twice. Double the pleasure baby. I can't leave SF without having myself a nice big bowl of Katana-Ya Ramen with Rich density and make it spicy for an extra $1.50 (or was it a $1.40?)

The Skinny:
Usually, when I want ramen, I tend to settle for pho. Why? well when I want ramen, its just me yearning for noodles in soup. And Pho noodles in soup, and cheaper. BUT! For Katana-Ya...its more than just noodles in a soup. It's an EXPERIENCE. The place is small as all hell, probably not bigger than a freakin' dorm room. But despite the long wait time, the tight sitting, and funky neon lights can easily be overlooked by their amazing ramen. They even have some ridiculously good sushi too.

The Food:
I won't say i'm a ramen expert, and i will never say i'm a ramen expert. But there's something magical about this ramen. Maybe its the noodle, maybe its the broth, maybe its the different yumyums added into the bowl (omg chasiu is too good), but its freakin' amazing. A year ago I got their Katana-Ya Ramen (spicy plz), and i remember it so very fondly. I recently got the extra spicy ramen, rich density. Holy crap was it rich. The soup was bright red and holy crap was it heavy. It was THICK but man it was so good. Careful though; not for the weak stomach. Heavy handed with the chili oil, but if you're a masochist, then go for it. It hurts so so good. 
Their sushi is also really top notch too. Their uni was fresh, and the buttery white tuna and halibut had a great texture and flavor. I want to hug their sushi chef. 

The Service:
They were really friendly. Big smiles all around. The staff made sure we got the right bowl of ramen, and they came around once or twice to make sure our water was filled. Which was a good thing too. Dam spicy ramen.

Katana-Ya has amazing food and great service. Quirky decor, but you'll be face down in a bowl of ramen to even notice. OH! and its even open til 2AM. What more could you want?
author: Ken L.

description:
came here on a very cold night in SF, so a bowl of hot ramen sounded perfect!

very small restaurant so I heard there's usually a long line. got there around 5:30pm and luckily the wait wasn't too bad for 2 people cus it was freezing outside!

ordered the Katanaya ramen which had everything including fried chicken and postickers. slurped it up and warmed me up immediately.

paid $12, which is a bit over-priced considering you can buy a bag of ramen to cook at home for a dollar. but it did help me warm up and it was a very yummy bowl of ramen :D
author: Christine C.

description:
The timing:
Arrived on a Monday night with a group of six at 6pm &we were seated within 20 mins. An hour later the line extended and there were a ton of people waiting outside- woah we got lucky there. 
Also I think street parking is free after 6pm, so plan ahead for a cheaper ramen eating experience.

The food:
5/6 of us ordered the Katanaya Ramen because we were indecisive first-time Katana eaters &this order came with a sampling of all the toppings (egg, pork, fried chicken, seaweed, corn, fried wantons, onions)

The verdict:
Their broth was rich& flavorful, but their ramen lost some of the noodle's natural crispness. Now... this could mean that the ramen used wasn't the best quality or the cooks failed the noodle-timing-part of their noodle making classes. The fried-chicken in ramen concept though is really good. 
MmMm.. I might have to put fried chicken in all my ramen now...

The atmosphere:
Very quaint, but exciting all at once. Where else can you eat ramen in comfortably small little hole-in-wall joint, but be in the middle of a bustling city, get yelled at by the homeless, still be across from a bunch of bars& theaters& clubs?
author: Lucia C.

description: Though it does get a bit cramped inside, you'd be surprised with how many people can fit -- I believe there is even a downstairs seating area, too! That aside, flavors are delicious here in their ramen servings. I tried their BBQ Ramen, and was stuffed after barely 3/4 a bowl of it. Very well-prepared. You can specify preferences for spiciness, too. Too bad you can't get reservations here, because that sure would help... But, put your name on the list as soon as you arrive, and you're bound to get a delectable dish.
author: Garett T.

description:
I've always liked cooking ramen at home, so this was a first for me to go to a ramen shop. The Katana-Ya ramen $12.90 with miso soup base consisted of 2 pieces of fried chicken, 2 fried gyozas, 2 pork pieces, half boiled egg, bamboo shoots, seaweed, green onion and corn. It was "OK" I guess-- very greasy. Definitely had a food coma right after!! We also tried a spicy salmon roll--- was yummy! 

Parking was definitely horrible..... bring your quarters. Service was alright. It was pretty busy today and had to wait about 10 minutes, but food came out fast. The place is small and you'll have to squish with other people and eavedrop on their conversations....
author: Allyson L.

description: Frigid and looking for a place the hungry, we stopped by Katana-Ya straight from the airport. We had to wait a little bit since its a kind of small restaurant at about 11:00 at night but it was no biggy. Finally found a little squishy booth corner seating area type of table. Anyways, the husband and I order the Extra Spicy Ramen with gyoza. The ramen was really red and spicy. My nose was continually running because of it. They were pretty busy and our friends ordered spicy tuna sushi but they took so long we had to cancel it. Probably give it between 3-4 stars. Nothing super special but nice to go to since we eat ramen all the time in Hawaii.
author: Cheryl K.

description:
Went with a party of 10 and everyone had a mixture of ramen or the sushi combo, all of which was yummy.
The downstairs dining room was so romantic ... perfect place to take that special person you really want to impress.
author: N B.

description:
You know those fancy ramen places that have intricately placed ingredients, perfect ambiance, and treat ramen like the newly rediscovered culinary art of the ages? THis is not one of them. This is your crowded, hot, greasy, and absolutely delicious hole in the wall ramen place.

I try to stop by if I'm in the SF area and just have one of my (fairly frequent) ramen cravings. I almost always get the katana-ya ramen, which is a huge portion - but hey, if you're going to consume greasy salty food, might as well go all the way with all the toppings! It's delicious and some of the best ramen I've had. Definitely go with the miso base as well.

I've tried some of the other items, and those were hit or miss. Maguro don was nice and fresh when I tried, but the curry don was mediocre and tasted like box curry. The spicy tofu was a complete miss. I still give a 4 star though, simply due to the excellence of the standard ramens though, if that reflects of how tasty it is! Stick to the ramen and you'll be quite pleased.

Be prepared for a line though - the only time I've not encountered at least a ten minute wait was when I had an awkwardly time 430pm lunner.
author: Jessie Y.

description:
This place a good so do definitely go. The hard thing about finding a "delicious" Japanese restaurant is the fact that there are PLENTY of good ones. Because of that, I wouldn't think a visitor need to go their way out to try this place but if you're in the area, do try it.

Apps: I got the Agedash Tofu which really wasn't so special. The tofu was fried enough so the fried skin was getting a bit slimey (and there weren't enough breading on it to start with).

Entree: My friend and I got the miso bbq pork ramen and the soy katanaya ramen (which has everything in it). The bbq pork is REALLY good.. just the right amount of fat. At the same time, the katanaya potstickers were really good too. The ramen noodles are really chewy and really good. The only downside to the meal is probably the broth. Even though we ordered regular, the broth was reallyyy rich for my taste and made me sick of the bowl fairly fast. 

Overall: I would order regular or light broth so that the broth isn't too oily or too overpowering compared to the deliciousness food in the ramen.
author: Funglin W.

description:
The most reviewed place,
Ramen is real delicious,
Get spicy miso.
author: Louis N.

description:
Went for lunch on a Saturday afternoon.  The wait was initially intimidating, but in the end, not that bad, about 15 minutes or so.  

Once we were seated the service was pretty efficient.  We started with agedashi tofu... and mine almost fell out of my mouth when I saw the people next to us get their ramen.  The bowl was HUGE!  

I got the Spicy Tofu Ramen, and as I mentioned, the portion was enough to feed 2 people.  It was really delicious though, and so of course I had to eat the whole bowl!  I left Katana-Ya so pregnant with noodle baby that I was ready to register for gifts.  I would have loved for it to be a little spicier, but the noodles were perfect, and the soup was full, complex, and delicious!

Also, note for Vegetarians, they'll make anything on the Ramen menu with vegetarian broth, just ask!
author: Linda L.

description:
After sweet drinks and walks in the rain from Lion Pub for pre-B2B, my boyfriend and our wonderful B2B hostess came here. This little spot in the Union Square/FiDi District is quaint and moreover open very late. My boyfriend and friend order their udon and ramen (respectfully). I like to eat fried stuff after drinks (go figure on losing that girlish figure quickly) and ordered their tonkatsu-don. 

Their food was on point and completely did its job of comforting me from the rain and feeding me from my alcohol-infused evening. The breading on the katsu wasn't mealy or dry. The salad and rice were a great complement to the dish, but because I always order the same dish at most Japanese places I go, this one was memorable for the moment. 

Their service was great for so late in the evening and the prices aren't so bad either. I now know of a great little spot to go to for that late need of substance.
author: Jamie L.

description:
I want to be short and sweet here:

The Good:

1. The soup base was rich and flavorful, the top-class.
2. The timing (2pm) was perfect - no line, no fuss.
3. The noodle was also very al dente (I know it's not the appropriate term to describe ramen noodles).
4. The variety is awesome - and the kitchen seems to handle it really well.

The Not-So-Good:
1. The server looked a bit aloof - or is it just me...
2. The Katana-Ya ramen - was a bit too greasy (chicken karaage and the fried gyoza toppings didn't help).
3. Side condiments would be nice...
author: Mike P.

description:
A bit disappointed in this place after all the 4 and 5 star reviews. Yes, the ramen is good, but it's not exactly life-changing. If you are (like me) not a fan of MSG, then you're not going to be happy with this ramen. Also, the BBQ pork was fatty and lacking in any discernable flavor.

Service and ambiance: No complaints at all. Everyone on the staff was friendly, accommodating and efficient. We were originally squished along the corner of the bar, but the waiter moved us to a little table as soon as it was open. Nice touch.
author: Marina C.

description:
i absolutely love this place!! you can get a combo with order of ramen, udon or soba and pick your other dish! I've also tried the dynamite roll which is the best! It consist of spicy mixed fish! 

It's a small place, which can easily cause customers to wait but this place is totally worth the wait!! 

highly recommend it and will come back!
author: Angela L.

description: Tiny place, wait is normal to get seated, combos are great for the price, the ramen soup is a little too salty for us.
author: Kay M.

description: Simply put... Amazing ramen. Best I've ever had, incredibly flavored broth and quality ingredients.
author: Todd G.

description:
Best ramen in SF (but lose to Orenchi and Santouka in SJ)

good selection of ramen and combo plate. the line can get very long so arrive early to avoid waiting.

Recommend Spicy ramen and Shio.
author: Scott B.

description:
I had too much expectations with 2k reviews with 4 stars. 

Food: 3*** Not bad, Not great... Just average. 
Service: 2** mmmm? They were yelling at the customer 
Cleanliness: 2** Chinatown restaurants are much cleaner 
Price: 1* wow! expensive...
author: Ryu C.

description:
Otaku has often been used to describe obsessive collectors but in the case of the ramen world, this term applies to the cult following of this famous Japanese noodle dish. Through out the years, ramen diners have infiltrated the entire globe. Ramen can be considered the popular choice for comfort food. Popular websites such as Ramenworld.com and Rameniac.com have formed communities. While most Americans associate ramen as the square package block of noodles for budget eats, authentic ramen involve master chefs that demonstrate this craft with delicate skills.

Katana-Ya, located in the trendy Nob Hill district, has created a cult following in the thirty seat restaurant. Chef owner Yoshiaki Noto has duplicated an authentic ramen environment resembling the ramen houses I have been to in Japan . Forty years ago in Japan , the master ramen chef started learning the craft from working at a ramen restaurant owned by his relatives.

 Although he only had one day of formal training from his relatives, he studied hard by making twenty different ramen bowls a day in order to create his own ramen recipes. Twenty years ago, he immigrated to the United States and started his own business. Although being an entrepreneur included long hours and stress, Noto desired to reach the American dream. Noto admits that his biggest challenge is finding a prime location.

Being featured in various newspapers and magazines has increased his business. Opening till 2am, Katana has been a top choice for clubbers and other late night goers. The minute I step foot into the cult tavern, the ambiance is colorful. White Christmas lights hang over the sushi bar, small painting decorate the red walls, and mirrors surround the eatery.

Without hesitation, I order a range of ramen to taste. For those who enjoy a heavy full bodied broth, the miso will deliver. At the other end of the palate spectrum, the salt broth is light. Salt flavor resembles chicken broth (although our ramen broths contain chicken and pork) and miso (fermented soybean paste) flavor taste similar to miso soup but richer.

I start off with an order of the regular ramen ($7.50) in miso broth. Bamboo shoots provide a chewy crunch while tender pork slices enhance the flavor in the pork ramen in miso broth. Although I would have preferred the noodles more on the al dente side, the texture of the noodle was good. 

For an instant rush of heat, the spicy tofu ramen ($9) marries spicy flavor with a minor note of sweet after taste. My favorite ramen dish is the fried chicken nugget (karage) ramen ($9.80) in salty broth. Coated with a thin layer of batter, four chicken pieces were tender. Next time, I would request that the nuggets be served out of the broth so that I taste a crispy skin.

A great side dish is the yellowtail (hamachi) neck( $5.50). Served on the side of a green salad, chopped chunks of hamachi neck are fried in a light batter. Biting through a crispy crust, the meat with the texture of marshmallow greets the palate. A slight dunk into the soy sauce provides the needed savory boost. A dish that can be featured on Bizarre Foods with Andrew Zimmern , the shiro kara (raw squid in a brown paste-$6) would take the gold trophy. Although the waitress advised it be consumed with alcohol, I don't think it would have washed off the lingering taste from salt and malted rice. With a slimy consistency, the dish is truly an acquired taste.
author: Rayfil W.

description:
Went here about 3 weeks ago with the girlfriend for lunch.

The place is very small, but efficient and fair.  If there's no room, you sign up on a little clipboard with your name and table, and they'll call you as soon as it's ready.  Since there's no waiting area, you will easily see when people are getting ready to go. 

It was raining that day, which was slightly less-than-pleasant, and a definite fault of this system - if you wait, you wait right outside.  This means that whether it's 5 or 50 minutes, you'll be standing outside the restaurant, since I think they only give you about 30 seconds to show up after being called before moving on.  I saw at least 3 groups get skipped while I was eating inside.

Inside, the restaurant is jammed to the fullest with tables.  Clearance between tables is thin - expect to bump elbows a couple of times - and my chair back was right on the table behind me.

The waitstaff was efficient and quick, and they were ready to go as soon as we were.  Probably wasn't helped when the line was starting to travel down the street.  However, they didn't get a single order wrong as I saw, and knew exactly what we wanted starting from the first word, which makes ordering in a noisy, crowded restaurant much more enjoyable.

As for the food. Easily some of the best Japanese ramen I've had outside of Japan - just chewy enough, well made soup base, and a whole ton of it to boot.  We had the Spicy Tofu Ramen and the Extra Spicy Ramen, which both lived up to our versions of "spicy".  We managed to finish both giant bowls of soup, which was pretty much amazing in itself.

Price was very low - similar to authentic prices, which I think is really a bonus for this place.  The food amount and quality is high, and you just get away with a good deal if you're in the mood for japanese-style ramen.
author: Justin L.

description:
The ramen is good large portions and tailored to your needs. The Sushi here is eve better though the rolls, nigiri, and sashimi and well proportionately sliced and quality is very good. Unlike some places that has little no fish this  place gives you what your ordered and at moderate prices.

Cons: The place is so small I feel claustrophobic and if they just removed the carpeting and get wood floors it might appear cleaner.
author: N A.

description:
There will be a wait. I got here on a Thursday a little after 8 and had to wait half an hour for a table. The waitresses are a little impatient/passive aggressive - when we couldn't decide on what to order, the waitress said, "You know you can ask me questions." ::shrug::

In any case, I decided on the miso ramen. The soup base was a little too salty for me. I really like salty foods, so if I say something is salty, it is salty! The noodles were a little on the hard side, compared to the chewier/softer ramen bowls I have had back east. I was also a little disappointed in the amount of toppings - 2 bamboo pieces, 1 piece of seaweed, and 2 pieces of pork. However, the pork was very tender and not too salty. 

I was told that this ramen place is a little more expensive than average for San Francisco by a friend who lives here. So, it is safe to say you can skip this place if you can find another OK ramen place for cheaper.
author: Stacy T.

description:
We ordered Katanaya ramen and Cilantro ramen and they were great! But here are the reasons why I gave 3 stars...
 
1. Server served OUR foods to the couple who came in later than us... therefore we had to wait at least 30mins for two bowls of ramen.

2. Servers noticed their mistake and brought one of ramen but the soup was not cold... 

3. 10mins later they brought the other one but didn't even apologize for the wait...

It gets pretty busy and hectic... be prepare to wait outside.
author: Mizue A.

description:
EDIT 7/15/07:

I've been back to Katana-ya at least 3 more times since the first, and it has been consistently good.
