However, since embarking on Ramen Hunt 2007, I am forced to reflect back on my assessment of Katana-ya. Although I do believe it still deserves 5 stars, I am compelled to note a few things since my first glowing review:

-I have tried all the broths (soy, salt, and miso), with my favorite being the soy (shoyu) light style over the rich (so rich I could not bring myself to finish those last slurps).
-The oil slick atop the broth is rare among other broths I have tried, although Katana-ya does not have as much of the floating pork shoulder fat bits. 
- I love the noodles here; among the best I have had.
- The chicken katsu is too salty, especially in combination with the very flavorful ramen broth. Stick with chasu roasted pork, order an extra for your proper dose of protein.
- I am SOOO happy that quality ramen is accessible to me in the San Francisco city proper.

Noodles: 5 stars
Broth: 4.5 stars
Pork/Meat: 4 stars (it has been inconsistent, but overall great)
Ramen Accessories: 4 stars
Non-Food Factors (price, service, wait, menu, etc): 4.5 stars
OVERALL: 4.5 stars
----------------------------------------------
ORIGINAL REVIEW:

Today's lesson learned: it pays to do your Yelp homework (even better with some supplementary research on Chowhound, sorry Yelp). Thanks to some trusted Yelpers' reviews, I didn't even have to look at the menu to order the light shoyu (soy) broth with BBQ pork (though I passed on the extra serving for $2 more...which I might have to reconsider next time). I also picked up a tip from Chowhound to order the noodles cooked "hard" so you don't end up with tragically mushy noodles by the last slurp. Hey, now it can be a Yelp tip! (Forgive me now?). 

Beautiful ripples of yellow ramen noodles with just enough bite, thin slices of richly flavored marinated BBQ pork, seaweed sheets, green onions, and bamboo (or maybe it's bamboo flowers?) come alive, yet harmoniously coexist with the deep soy broth backdrop. I found the flavor and oiliness of the "light" broth  (as opposed to the "rich" choice) to be well balanced. Don't be afraid of the oily sheen that skims the surface a few millimeters deep. Among the strongest of the mixed messages I received about food as a kid is that fatty, porky oiliness = delicious. My fellow noodle slurper ordered the miso-tofu ramen, but I can't speak to how that was. Let's just say that next time it will be two orders of shoyu roasted pork ramen. We also split an order of the handmade gyoza, which seemed to have quite a fresh wrapper and filling, though somewhat forgettable.

I feel the need to disclose that I am no ramen-foodie. Before Katana-Ya, my ramen experience was limited to the crappy ramen shop in the Porter Exchange in Cambridge, MA and my favorite 6/$1 Maruchan Chicken Flavor (totally kicks Top Ramen's ass, by the way). BUT I do know crazy delicious when I taste it. It's probably a good thing that Katana-ya is so far from my home, because I can see myself craving a bowl of this ramen at least once a week. Soondubu may have found it's match.
author: Steph P.

description: Small, charming dining room, very friendly service, generous portions. Excellent ramen.
author: AJ C.

description:
1.5 Stars

Came here 3 years ago or so.. tried it again recently. finally writing a short review!

Small and cramped location on Geary. Maybe my eyesight is failing me or maybe it's the dim lighting but they say they add MSG on their menu?
Overpriced for the amount of food that you get (my biggest pet peeve).

Go spend your money elsewhere; much better food establishments nearby.
author: Aaron H.

description:
OMG You Guys! Total noms. 
I've been to this restaurant numerous times, and I always bring my out-of-town visitors here to experience the best non-traditional food San Francisco has to offer. The place is a teeny hole-in-the-wall restaurant with room for maybe 20 people who really like each other. If you go during peak hours there's always a line. No reservations as far as I know. 
I've had a bunch of different kinds of ramen soup at Katana-Ya, and all have been wonderful. I'm personally a big fan of the soy-based and miso-based stocks. The house ramen has fried chicken in it and it's excellent. I've also had the pork ramen and it was also swell. The last time I was there I got some octopus ball appetizers and they were really good too. However, they were hardly necessary, given the extremely large portion-size of the soup. I'm told that the sushi is excellent too, though I've never tried it. No room. 
The food is extremely cheap, and the wait-staff are friendly and speedy. 
If you go, I'm sure you'll enjoy it!
author: Paul M.

description:
It's definitely not easy to find a decent and not too over-priced ramen place near Union Square.  Katana-ya is TINY.  It's a narrow strip of a restaurant with a few tables.  Luckily I went alone on a Sunday early evening, so I could waltz in and eat at the sushi bar.

I ordered their regular ramen noodle for $8.95 or so.  It was not the cheapest ramen ever, for sure.  The service was good - I wanted tea and it was placed in front of me within minutes.  The ramen certainly didn't disappoint.  The soup was pipping hot.  Nothing turns me off more than luke-warm soup.  It had plenty of seaweed, a generous cut of roast pork, good amount of bamboo shoots and of course, noodles and soup.  Although their soup was a bit on the greasy side, it wasn't so fatty that I couldn't have any.  It was very flavorful.  The noodles were al-dente and definitely NOT the store bought kind where one gets a pack of three for $4.50 to cook at home.  

I didn't have anyone to share the sushi or rolls with, but the ramen definitely was authentic enough.  Next time, if I find myself at Union Square craving some ramen, I'll certainly return to Katana-Ya for more.
author: Sherry K.

description:
So update of update... 

After reading Nob K's update and Jesper J (He was super drunk when he went there and he was flirting with the sushi chef -man- at the bar -he is not gay last time I checked- I didn't trust him but) telling me Katanaya's ramen was good, I decided to give it another shot. 

They closed "additional room" and the Ramen was good again! I think they need to cook yakibuta little longer to make it more tender but the broth had good flavor and the noodles were not overcooked. It is nothing close to ramen in Tokyo but I'll go back to Katanaya if I'm drunk with craving for ramen. 

FYI Ramen etiquette 

1. NO TALKING after receiving Ramen PLEASE!!! You came to eat noodle right? Your mission is to eat the noodle ASAP before the noodle suck up all the broth. That means you need to eat all the noodles within 6 minutes maximum. Then, you finish the soup. 

2. NO Sharing. Unless you are a kid. 

3. Beverage choices during eating Ramen are water or beer. Water, cold light flavored unsweetened tea or cold beer are the only beverage choices to go with Ramen. (You can have other drinks before starting to eat ramen) 

If I am serving you a bowl of ramen at my home which took me over 12 hours to make the broth / slow cooked yakibuta, perfect temperature broth in a preheated bowl, and perfectly cooked al dente noodles, you better obey my ramen etiquette!
author: Chie J.

description:
The Ramen was fantastic! I really enjoyed both the Shiyo and Miso broth. The noodles were nice and semi-firm, and the portion size was acceptable. 

I did also order a side of Toro, which was marginal to say the least, hence why I did not give Katana-ya 5 stars. I also had a chance to eat their curry over rice, which tasted decent, but not anything to write home about. On a side note, the pickles that accompanied the curry were great and complimented the dish well.

Great value, hard to get a seat (Order the Ramen -- you'll know why), location is difficult to park at, and the draft from an open door will chill you so bring a jacket.

Worth every ounce of pain to eat that ramen!
author: Jason C.

description:
Tasty chewy spicy noodles...enough said

Quite the drive from San Jose, but damn these noodles were well worth it. 

THREE CHEERS FOR YUMMO-NESS
author: Tess R.

description: I'm as far from a ramen expert or traditionalist as you can probably get. I don't care if it's not authentic Japanese cuisine. I care that it tastes great. The signature Katana-Ya ramen with the fried chicken and potstickers in it is my favorite Ramen I've ever had. I'm sure there's room for improvement as I discover more places, but so far this is the ramen I crave.
author: Corry F.

description:
I always go here with my friends after work. Katana-Ya Ramen is one of my fave on the list! :D Good Jap-Food!

Just be prepare for long waiting time.
author: Zett M.

description:
Not all ramens are created equal...and the Katana-Ya Miso Ramen has no equal in the Bay Area....simply the best....bum bum bum bum...better than all the rest....

The Katana-Ya ramen packs a delicious surprise around every corner. First the star of the show, the miso-flavored broth which if I could, I would bathe in. Then there's the perfectly cooked noodles that delicately walk the fine line of chewiness and tenderness. And of course no ramen is complete without meltingly tender cha shu pork. But if that isn't enough, how about a few pieces of chicken karaage, fried gyoza, a hard-boiled egg, and corn...yes you have officially died and gone to ramen heaven.
author: David H.

description:
This place is open later which is always a plus in my book.  They have other items then ramen such as sushi and goyza or fried rice but i've only had noodles.

every time i've come here they have had a line.  Doesn't matter if its dinner time at 6pm or 1am at night this place will have folks inside.  It is very small so don't expect much elbow room.  Your close enough to the table next to you that you can almost taste their food.  If you did i'm sure it would be good.

They have a variety of broth and noodles.  I usually get the miso or soy.  There are also option of what you can add to your ramen.  I go with the fried chicken. 

A think a bowl of ramen alone is very filling but next time i'm gonna try some goyza.  The table next to ours had some and they looked really good!
author: Hella B.

description:
They get 3 stars for the food. Extra star because my girlfriend took me here. She been wanting to take me here so bad and when she did it was definitely worth the drive out of our way. 

Food: This place is lucky because I don't really eat ramen at restaurants, since it's my first real experience I cannot really compare it to anything...so good rating from me. The house special ramen was waaaay yummy. It was good. The best part......THE BROTH. WOW. Seriously, just amazing. When I crave for a place, it is good. And I'm craving for it right now. Ordering ramen was a bit weird...they ask what kind of broth (miso, soy, or salt) and if you want it light or dense. Whatever for me, it was good. 

Final verdict: This place is so good that it got me wanting more ramen from different places. Or maybe now ramen just holds a special place in my heart because my gf took me here. Either or, this place is good. 

Oh yea, this place gets packed and is extremely small. Be prepared to wait for a long time if you have a "big" party which is FOUR people.
author: Tim H.

description:
Man, this place was BOMB! Went there with a big group on 4/20/11, and enjoyed every last bit - even though we had to wait 30 minutes for a table on a Wednesday late-night! 

Heaping portions, as any good ramen place should have; My friend and I split a serving of the pork bowl and barely finished it! Be aware that the medium spicy is not that spicy, and the spicy is still not that spicy. I ate my friends' who got the extra spicy and it really wasn't very hot... just sayin.

Affordable, good service, and the mirrors that line the place make it seem much larger than it is :) Beautiful bathroom decor, funny hand-painted owls and trees. 

Yummy, fun spot to have some grub.. just don't DRIVE there - parking is a joke! Especially on a weekend, with Ruby Skye just around the corner!
author: Lauren S.

description:
We were staying next door at Hotel Diva and needed a bite to eat but didn't want to go out. We'd noticed this place just down the block, and looked them up on Yelp to call for take out.  Easy done (the menu is online). Five minutes later, we had two piping hot quart containers of tasty ramen to nosh in the peace and comfort of room - which was doubly-convenient, because the place is tiny and was full in the middle of the afternoon.  

Mine was the spicy green onion ramen. Spicy as advertised, the noodle bits were perfect but the broth was just too spicy (and oily) for me to slurp. His was something more mild but equally delicious.  

The portion is massive, the service is efficient and the kitchen is quick.  Tough to go wrong!
author: Andy W.

description:
My grilled saba was delicious!  The mackerel was perfectly grilled and perfectly seasoned.  It was crunchy at all the right parts and it was a little too salty, which I liked.  The miso soup that it came with was better than other miso soups I have had.

The best part about eating at Katana-Ya last night was listening to a drunk, desperate woman who was in a party of three.  The other two, were married to each other, and were not displaying acts of desperateness.  This single woman, however, was quite a sight.  She was madly flirting with the sushi chef, drinking with him, and bringing up the topic of sex, but in the worst way ever.  She said that he probably haven't gotten laid in a while we all know that what she meant was "I haven't gotten any in a long time, I'm horny and lonely, my best friend just got married, I'm still single and I'm forming wrinkles as we speak so there isn't much time left, you're a cute sushi chef -- or at least right now you are but I won't really know until later when I'm not drunk anymore--, so why don't you come over to my house when you're done with the last roll?  Perhaps you can roll around with me in my bed for awhile."  Very, very sad, and the mood quickly turned sour.

Anywho, when we were done overhearing the lady embarrass herself, my boyfriend and I decided not to try their desserts and opted to go somewhere else.

Perhaps I will return to try the ramen.
author: Vivian H.

description: Excellent spicy fish on salad.  Very reasonable prices.  Small space, but friendly and efficient staff.
author: Guy K.

description:
Ramen is pretty decent, nice and simple. Kind of disappointed at getting only one piece of meat in my big bowl of ramen though. I like their combination menu, where you can choose your noodle, (ramen, soba or udon) then your sides depending on the price etc. There's a pretty good selection. I think they have pretty authentic Japanese dishes, this is only based on what I have tried in Japan during a vacation I took with my friends. I am not Japanese, so take that was a grain of salt. 

I have been here twice and both times really liked it. Their sashimi tastes pretty fresh. Food comes out quick. Can get super packed since its such a tiny place. There is usually a wait and since its in downtown, expect to wait somewhere between 15-30+ minutes. I'd recommend going early to beat the crowd or later...I've been wanting to try their fish gill dish, but they always seem to run out. =(
author: Amy L.

description:
good ramen, NOT great.

I've yet to find a great ramen which has a tasty well made broth and nice chewy ramen noodles.  Until that day, those ramen places that don't match up to it will have to be only subpar.

I've been here 3 times now which does mean I'm a fan.  They've got a pretty good deal here with the everything ramen (it's actually called something else but i forget) which has chicken karrage, potstickers, and other usual ramen stuff.  I've had the miso light, soy base, and salt flavor and they all leave me fully content.  On a gloomy cold day, it's just the thing you need for that go to ramen spot in the city.

Only downside is the feeling of thirst for the next 4 hrs due to the msg, but hey, I'm asian.  I understand.  MSG it up.

agadashi tofu was ok.  not worth the trouble though. get your ramen and leave it at that.  And theres a wait, but at good times, it goes by fast.
author: Vincent K.

description:
2.5 stars: the half star is invisible (like platform 9 and 3/4)

Been to Katana-ya a few times, twice with a party of 2, once with a party of 6, which is a ginormous table for katana-ya. 

Obviously my first two experiences here were enough to make me come back a third time, but after this last time I'm not sure I'll be coming back. It was a rainy evening when B and I were in the city after workclass, and ramen sounded like the perfect cuisine for the weather. We knew there'd be a wait at Katana-ya, since there always is, so it was expected when the waiter told us it'd be a 30-40 minute wait. 

We trekked over to Macy's to wait for our table out of the rain, but when we got back, they had put a giant question mark next to our name since they had called us and we hadn't shown up. We informed the waiter that we were back and he said ok, and showed us to an indoor waiting area. We waited for 10-15 minutes, but after a while we noticed that people who were just adding their names to the list were getting seated before we were. B went to go ask the waiter what the status of our table was, and he was flat-out IGNORED 3 different times. I know they're busy, but this was just really rude. When B finally got a hold of him, the waiter had forgotten to un-question mark our name, which meant we would've been seated when we got back if only he had remembered....

And after having Orenchi ramen in San Jose, Katana-ya ramen is only ok. Orenchi ramen broth has so much more depth in its flavor; Katana-ya's fell flat.
author: Julia C.

description:
Have been here a couple times and really enjoyed their Ramen & Soba soups.  If you're having a hankering, this will satisfy the craving.

Don't know that I would try sushi at Katana-Ya; haven't, but am picky about the kinds of places that I trust handling raw fish.  I didn't get those clean, fresh sushi vibes at this location.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Delicious ramen in a tiny joint.

I came here with some cousins, after spending a day watching the Giants romp on the Indians and shopping at Westfield. It was about 8pm and already there were groups of people waiting for their party to be called.

We ended up having to wait 20 minutes but luckily we live in the age of smartphone so we kept playing Hanging with Friends to pass the time. The waiter even gave us a menu to look at and took our order 5 minutes prior to seating.

As we entered the establishment, I immediately noticed how incredibly small this restaurant was. My cousins who sat by the wall were almost rubbing elbows from other customers... which can be a good or a bad thing depending on what you fancy.

We got our food 5 minutes after we sat down. We all ordered the Katanaya Ramen except for my cousin John, he ordered the Deep Fried Chicken Ramen but they gave him the Katanaya instead. Oh well it still looked good. My Katanaya Ramen had 2 porkchops, 2 fried pieces of breaded chicken, 2 fried potstickers, and a boiled egg in miso soup and it's probably the best ramen I've ever had. My brother Jay got it in mild spicy and also loved it. We wolfed it down in 10 minutes, about half the time it took us to wait there. By the time we got up to leave, there were about 20 people waiting outside. Sucks to be them.

I can't speak for the sushi yet but If you can wait the line and can dish out 10-15$ for a bowl, go for it. Just make sure you have VISA, they don't take American Express.
author: Kevin A.

description: Had the regular ramen and ordered a few dishes of sashimi - salmon, hamachi, maguro - food was alright. We were brought to the shop next door as the main establishment was full, but it was ok.
author: Rosaline C.

description:
Fresh ingredients. Not so fresh service.

Its rare that I go to a place with food that is THAT amazing and service that is THAT terrible. The only good thing was the food, but the food was TRULY INCREDIBLE. 

I suppose you should know when you're waiting outside that they're going to shovel you in, push the food in your face, mess up your order and then rush you out. But somehow its all worth it. Damn it was tasty. 

BOTTOM LINE: Its kind of like the Soup Nazi.
author: Joe S.

description:
Serious food envy ensued when our noodles arrived. I looked at my bowl of soba with some disappointment. I had actually wanted zaru soba and absent-mindedly thought I was getting it right up until a steaming bowl of soup arrived before me. Meanwhile, my lunch companion's bowl of ramen called out to me in an overly seducing manner. I knew immediately I had not ordered correctly. I detest that feeling. Luckily, my soba was accompanied by a delicious plate of California rolls which partially remedied my ramen resentment.

Finally, the discovery of a wonderful noodle shop in walking distance of Huddle Room D!
author: Miriam W.

description:
Thanks to Yelp, I found my new favorite place for a quick fix before I get my retail therapy groove on.  Yeah, it's a bit pricy (it's Union Square) and the shoya broth can be salty, but the noodles are so friggin' good.  I loved my shoyu broth, bbq pork ramen, but I was rather disappointed that there's no egg in my ramen.  Wassup with that?  

Good and relatively fast service, but a very claustrophobic shop, no matter how much mirrors you put on the walls.
author: Kris H.

description: The food is ok, but that old ladyT_T= bad service, rushing me and my three friends to leave right after we paid!!
author: Cloudia C.

description: I was expecting more from this highly rated place. I was looking for outstanding ramen while on a trip to SF, and Katanya was on several lists of top ramen joints, and very close to my hotel. I ordered the Katanya ramen (namesake bowl always seems like a good choice), shoyu, spicy. Their special ramen comes with 2 slices of chasu, 2 gyoza, 2 pieces karaage, corn, seaweed, and a half of a hard boiled egg (!?!). It was all just pretty disappointing. Broth was salty and spicy, but no real deep flavored. Chasu had an off taste. Gyoza were deep fried with a heavy-on-the-leek filling. Noodles were soft, nothing special. Everything tasted a little stale and pre-made. (I was there at 11:30, and was seated just as they opened). Nothing special at all. I probably only ate a third before becoming just bored with it.  I'm always one to kill a bowl of ramen, but not this time. I'll try to find a better bowl for dinner.
author: Joshua E.

description: I have enjoyed lunch at this spot plenty of times, but today will be the LAST TIME I eat here. We had a party of nine and received the worst service from the female server with the short hair. She forgot my friends app which was kimchi, she also forgot my friends coca cola. We had to ask repeatedly for water. Never once did she smile at us, even though we were more than pleasant with her. All but two people ordered ramen or a rice dish, our bill was around $100 not including (I left before seeing the bill) so that means she would have got at least a $25 tip, had she done her job. My pork was chewy, I could hardly eat it. When I was finished I had leftovers that needed packed up, but when I asked her to do it for me not wanting to risk a spill she told me to "Do it myself." Well. That being said I will be eating ramen anywhere else but there. If I could give ZERO STARS I would. DO not waste your time with this place. There are plenty of other great ramen spots in San Francisco!
author: April S.

description: A friend brought us here for the second time and it was just as good as the first. The ramen noodles is delicious. The restaurant can get a bit crouded and cramped. Definitely not a place to sit around for conversation with friends. A must try when visiting the San Francisco area.
author: K R.

description:
Ramen is the ultimate comfort food for me and the spicy tofu ramen here is probably the best I've had. It is absolutely yummy and comforts the heart and soul.

I'd like to try their sushi but I can never make room after inhaling the entire bowl of ramen...maybe next time I'll split the ramen and then try some fresh fish.

Note: don't come here if you are afraid of tight-crowded spaces
author: Mimi T.

description:
I love Ramen, and when I heard this was "the best of SF" I knew I had to try it. This place is tiny, tiny, tiny, so yes, there will probably always be a line. BUT the ramen IS good here!

Really fresh, the miso broth is the best. Adding spicyness costs more but does add a lot of depth to the broth as well, and don't worry, it's really not that spicy at all, but for some reason the lady made it seem SUPER spicy, kind of a let down...

A little pricier than most ramen places but definitely delicious.
author: Michelle H.

description: I really liked Katana-Ya. How could I complain about ramen with a sampler of potstickers, fried chicken, and pork? Two stand out touches, besides  the protein potpourri, were the corn and the select-your-own broth. The only reason that I would not return on my next visit to sf is the size of the restaurant. I went around 5pm on a Sunday night and was seated immediately at the sushi bar, but what I gather from other Yelpers reviews is the place can get back up. If you are a ramen aficionado and have the time, I would recommend checking it out.
author: Sophia T.

description:
Oh Katana-Ya, I really tried to like you. The few times I passed you by, there was quite a crowd around your small storefront. With such buzz surrounding you, I thought you'd be a sure bet.

The first time I visited, I had soy ramen with chicken karaage. The soup base was lightly salty and had that awesome umami taste. Unfortunately, the noodles didn't feel good; it didn't have that al dente bite. In fact, I thought the noodles were a bit on the limp side. I was rather disappointed.

Maybe it was an off night? Perhaps I was being a rather harsh judge, letting nostalgia of truly fantastic ramen get in the way? Katana-Ya ... you deserve a second chance, right? I decided a second visit was in order. A few weeks later, I went with a friend. This time, I tried the miso ramen with BBQ pork. Alas, my first impression wasn't wrong! Soup base was quite nice, but the noodles felt soggy! ACK!

Ramen is a beautiful, humble dish. The combination of a savory broth with springy noodles is the perfect cure for a rainy day, awful hangover or just plain hunger. Unfortunately, Katana-Ya felt imbalanced -- good broth, but bad noodles. It's not terrible, but it's not great either, falling in the ho-hum middle ground. If I'm looking for a ramen mix in the city, I'd much rather get it at Tanpopo or Izakaya Sozai.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Many of the reviews that I read mentioned Butter Corn Ramen. Being intimately familiar with both the stale, plastic-wrapped versions as well as fresh ramen in Japan, the combination intrigues me, so I read no further and we're off in the rain to get hot noodles.

It's a tiny place, 15 tables max. We're seated immediately and start to pour over a huge selection of ramen, sushi, and donburi choices. My mind's made up going in, though: butter corn ramen for me! I can choose from either shoyu, salt, or miso broth, and opt for the miso. As it the norm for a fresh noodle house, the food is out almost immediately. I quickly discover that, although I'm expecting some exotic flavored noodle or strange ingredient that would explain the name of the dish, it turns out that butter corn ramen is...you guessed it!...a bow of ramen with a couple of pats of butter melting on the top and a half-cup of freshly cut yellow corn. It's good, don't get me wrong, but given the many choices I had on the menu, I wish I'd read the reviews a bit more closely. The food is delicious and hot, perfect for a rainy evening.
author: Ryan C.

description: My go to place for late night eats and quick takeouts. Great combo deals. Bit sad ownership changed but still love it
author: Cat L.

description: Last time being there was 1 year ago - i was really sick in the mid-night and they happen to open until 1am. remembered i had the curry bento which is AOK - not amazing but ok.  Was here 3 years ago had some great memories with sushi... i can never remember the shop's name, yesterday happen to get lost on the street (I'm still new in town) and originally wanted to go to the Thai place next door, but the owner's baby is crying so hard and there was no customer - bad sign - so i had no choice but moving to the next door, which is happen to be Katana-ya again - I recognised that because of the owl drawing on their bath room!  Had their signature ramen... not that great at all! The noodles are "meh", the miso soup base is "arrrg", as its quite oily compare with all other ramen i had in the past... i'm not a food snob, but i honestly think they can do better...
author: Yiying L.

description:
Even though I waited an hour to be seated for 3 because the lady kept seating couples before us, four stars for their wonderful ramen! I swear there were about five or six names crossed off AFTER our name... I was so annoyed!

But their ramen makes up for it, definitely. I thought there was no such thing as good ramen in the Bay, too, shoooot. I go through withdrawals when I'm back for break since I get it all the time in LA! I don't remember the name of what I got, but it was soy-base regular with the fried chicken. Heehee. The soup was flavorful, and the noodles were so goood. Chewy, but not too chewy; thick, but not too thick. It was the perfect size and texture. And the chicken! Mmmm, the chicken. It was hella juicy and yums (:.

Don't know if I'd come back with the wait, though... It was only worth it the first time. Maybe after many failed ramen explorations around the Bay and the realization that thiiiis, this is the spot.
author: Winnie B.

description:
I waited for 2 hours to eat here to see what the buzz was all about. I would have waited longer had it not been for people that signed their name, but ended up leaving. Anyway, restaurant is small, but the place is always packed with people. 

The food was very good. However, when I take into account that i waited for 2 hours, I'm not sure that it was worth the wait. The ramen itself was a little on the salty side, but just a tad. I still gobbled it up.
author: Runner R.

description:
If you're willing to wait a while or go at an odder time, this place is definitely worth it. You can choose how heavy your soup is as well as what kind of soup. The ramen is always nice and chewy. For a small place, the menu is massive with a wide selection of ramen you can't go wrong with. They also have seaweed salad (yum) and sushi (also yum) with side dishes to go with a regular bowl of ramen as a combo (spicy tuna on rice, unagi don, etc.)

My first stop for ramen always!
author: Z L.

description:
I wanted to see what all the hype over this place was about...but I guess coming here on a Saturday night around 7pm was not the smartest idea! Had to wait in line outside for about 45 minutes before getting a table :( 

We ordered the Katana-Ya ramen (with soy sauce base and a slightly lighter broth) and the Alaskan Delight (I think that's what it was called) sushi roll. The ramen is good - and unique in that it has two fried potstickers and two pieces of fried chicken - but not great. For great ramen, drive an hour south to try Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara. Also, the sushi was not particularly memorable. 

Would only come back if I was already in the area, didn't have other food suggestions in mind, and was really hungry for a heaping bowl of ramen.
author: Cheri D.

description:
Definitely one of the better ramen spots I had in the city (still think orenchi is the best US ramen spot I had so far, Ippudo in NY included).  Noodle is nice and firm (stays un-soggy), the soup is pretty solid.

Of course, everyone does the obligatory jaw drop at the Katanaya ramen.
FRIED CHICKEN, and FRIED GYOZA, and CHASHU PORK, and EGG all thrown in a goddamn bowl 'cause they goddamn can.  I ordered, I conquered, and I was satisfied.  

But, from the breadth of the menu's various home-cooked Japanese dishes, it seemed that their understanding of Japanese tastes run pretty deep.  If I'm in the city and I'm hungry around noon, Katanaya will definitely be one of the first spots to come to mind, and not just for the ramen but for all that it has to offer.  I'll update if I have a chance to go up again.
author: Hiro K.

description:
I gets a salt broth,
I gets a miso broth,
I gets a shoyu broth,
I get that spicy broth.

I eat some ramen to remind me of the good times,
I get katana-ya to remind me of the best times.

I get knocked down, And then I get ramen,
My hangover's never gonna keep me down.
I get regular ramen, with rich miso broth,
Then I scarf that soup right down.
Or I get cilantro ramen, with shoyu broth,
Then I scarf that soup right down.

I get knocked down, And then I get ramen,
My hangover's never gonna keep me down.

Do you guys remember Chumbawamba? Is this the worst review you've ever read?
author: Erich S.

description:
So I've had Ramen...at home, out of a package, out of a plastic/styrofoam bowl.  I've had it made with pan-fried hot dogs/SPAM and eggs and veggies for deghettotification.  

I've also had it at good Japanese places (who purportedly had the best ramen)  but they didn't leave a mark in my foodie memory bank.

But this place...

I tried their spicy tofu ramen with soy sauce broth.  It was spicy, it was fresh, and it was delicious to the very bottom on the bowl.  I slurped the noodles, I drank the broth, and I craved more.  It was a huge portion and well worth every shiny penny!  

Service = super friendly!!  Space is limited, so you can have some very, very testy fellow diners.  

Yeah, be hungry when you come here...because your fellow diners won't let you keep your leftovers intact.  ;-)
author: Fannie S.

description:
I've eaten here twice and after the first time I had no memory of how the food was. That should've indicated that this place wasn't that great. I'm super stubborn and had to go back and eat it again so I can yelp about it.

Had the kimchee ramen and they gave me the soy sauce ramen. They took it back after I told them about it. The kimchee was flavorful but the noodles wasn't anything special. Broth didn't have much flavor and was oily.

Probably won't come back here again.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Finally found the best ramen place in the city and I don't need to trek all the way to Japantown!!! yay!!!

I had the spicy tofu ramen w/miso broth. I love that you can pick the broth you want for your ramen. It makes a huge difference. I loved it so much and it filled me up but I couldn't stop eating it! The noodles taste fresh and perfect. 

Also ordered the agedashi tofu & mix tempura. The tofu was crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. the sauce base for the agedashi was very delicious. The mix tempura was yummy too. The ramen was so filling we couldn't finish our side dishes.

The place is small and a wait list builds up so come early if you have a big party. Ill be back very soon!
author: Natassia S.

description:
I was craving for JP food. My friend has recommended me this place so I went.  I was not disappointed with this place at all. I chose their vegetarian ramen noodle. It's very rare to find a vegetarian option in ramen noodle shop, let alone, taste good. The vegetarian ramen noodle is not blend at all. 
One thing I dislike the place is, it can get crowded at times.
author: Annette L.

description:
Sluuuurp! Ramen. Ramen open late night, perfect. Small place, hard to spot (corner close to Ruby Skye) delicious place, I love ordering the one that includes everything in your ramen, I believe it's called Katana-ya ramen (well that makes sense). 

I was forewarned this place may have a long wait but my boyfriend and I went around 10 or 11 and we sat right away. The broth can directly warm your soul on a typical chilly foggy night in the city. The price per bowl is expensive comparing to Pho but I remind myself it's not right to compare apples to oranges.
author: Johanna P.

description:
Tiny little place but no wait for a midweek meal. Fast service. Best Ramen i've had in SF so far...I mean no, it's no Saitama but it hits the spot.

 I had the corn butter ramen, my fav. You can specify what kind of broth you want (miso or soy) and I thought the soy had a good flavor. I sampled the "orange" vegetable tempura as my friend Sharon M. will not eat the orange veggies and I found it very tasty and not greasy.

Oh and horray for my $8 dinner. Being laid off sucks but Ramen makes it okay.
author: Nikki M.

description:
There's a reason why people either wait in line before Katana-Ya opens or wait an hour to eat when there are tons of other restaurants in Union Square. Their Japanese food is a good value for the quality. 

I've had their sushi on a few occasions, but I'm a big fan of their hot food items. I can never choose between rice bowls or ramen and at Katana-Ya, they make the decision easier: BOTH! There are combination specials that allow you to pick one kind of ramen & a rice bowl. I usually get a bowl of miso ramen and a rice bowl of katsudon (pork tonkatsu in egg), and this combination is very satisfying. 

Katana-Ya is not my favorite ramen in the Bay Area. Ramen Dojo in San Mateo holds that coveted position. However, when I need a ramen + rice bowl fix in the city, Katana-Ya is always a safe bet.
author: Monelle A.

description: Awesome good and great portions! I suggest the shrimp wantan soup. Not to bad on wait time. I highly recommend!
author: Trevor S.

description:
I think this was one of the first ramen places in the city, before the all out craze. So being the noodle lover I am, it was only right to see how it fairs. 

Just ok. The broth tasty but a little oily and I felt it lacked some of the standard toppings. Literally, if they say it's pork and seaweed, that's all you're getting. Bamboo, egg, pickles, corn....anything, is additional. So that was a little disappointing, because these all start adding up! Spicy does mean spicy, though it was oil-laden. 

While they have a cool option, where you can order a noodle set meal (ramen/udon/soba + donburi or + sushi, etc) but it looks like the ramen you get, would just be plain noodles. I think the deal @ Mariuchi is better, that you can actually get a loaded ramen + donburi/sushi and I think it is more affordable! 

It is a tiny spot, and for us, we only had to wait maybe 20 mins. If anything more than that, we probably wouldn't entertain it. I feel they need to keep up with the current trends to stay in it. But I guess they may not necessarily need to as there isn't any competition nearby.
author: Ly T.

description: I thought I'd give this small cozy looking restaurant a try.  I was very pleasantly surprised at not only the cost, but the quality and quantity! My Ramen and fried rice were an excellent paring of flavors. The severs were very polite and helpful explaining items on the menu. The restaurant is very small, clean and cozy with a very clean bathroom.Located at the start of the Tenderloin it's in a safe location with many tourists and locals around. If you're in the mood for Ramen and in SF you just have to try this place!!!!!!
author: John V.

description:
I don't know I should come back and try this place again because i really thought it was just OK.

I ordered the ramen and did not find anything good about it. I had the buttercorn ramen and tried the Katana ramen. Both were EH.

If you really want some good ramen, please make a visit to Santa Clara and try Santouka, Orenchi or Ryowa. This place is garbage compared to them.

The ramen broth itself was very bland, the pork was whatever and there was only one chicken nugget in the ramen. Looking at pictures from people who ordered the same thing, it looks like they got a whole chicken wing and some more! We got a chicken nugget. Just one.
author: Rosalynn D.

description:
My review was incorrectly posted on Yelp under my boyfriend's account. (see Chad O's review dated 4/26/12 ...I didn't know he had logged on while he was on my iPad!)

I would give this place zero stars if I could ... very unsanitary!
author: RL O.

description: Always busy. Expensive ramen, but it hits the spot. Avoid the crowds and either go early evening (like what the senior citizens do) or close to closing (like the drunks do).
author: Siam E.

description:
Went last night (Sunday) around 9 pm and there was still about 4 parties ahead of us waiting for a table.  While we waited, we walked around and by the time we came back, our table was ready.

Initially, I thought this was just a typical ramen restaurant, but Katana-ya actually has quite a lengthy menu.  Although I probably wouldn't try any of their sushi, it's nice to know that you have the option.

The first item that jumped off the menu at me as I was browsing was their Chicken Karaage ramen.  Then, as I went down the list, I ended up finding the Katanaya Ramen, which included 2 pieces of chicken karaage, 2 pieces of fried gyoza, 2 pieces of pork, half of a hard boiled egg, corn, seaweed and bamboo shoots.  I was fascinated by this option as typical ramen restaurants usually don't have much in their bowl of ramen, and would require you to order add-ons to make a filling meal.  Then, not only do you have your typical choice of soy or miso base, but you also have the option of rich or light broth.  This was a bonus for me, as I usually don't like rich broths.  The only downside was that if you wanted your bowl to be spicy, then you actually need to pay an additional $1.40.  Something about that just doesn't sound right.  I did it anyway, since I wanted my bowl to be spicy, but since when should you pay for spice?  I went with the medium spice, but I think I could go up another notch next time.

But all in all, this was a great meal.
author: Audrey C.

description: Had this for the second time ever last night as a late dinner. I ordered the Katanya ramen with the soy sauce base. I thought it was okay compared to all the other ramen places I've had in LA/Toronto/Mountain View. It's not something that I'd say is so good to be writing home about. Prices are reasonable for a ramen place in San Francisco.
author: Anders C.

description:
Perhaps the other items on their menu are delightful and mesmerizing enough to earn Katana-Ya an average of 4 stars over 2,000+ reviews, but based on the ramen alone I can't say that I agree.

As I scoured Yelp in my conquest to sample the finest ramen in the Bay Area, my journey brought me to Katana-Ya after a day's worth of shopping at downtown SF. The reviews alone warranted a visit from one of the many self proclaimed ramen hunters of Yelp, and I brought my A game (meaning I haven't eaten in hours :P)

Came in at around 5:30, with no wait. Hmmm, red flag #1. Kidding. I was actually relieved since I was starving at that point. My selection of the night was the Katanaya ramen, salt flavor of course (pretty much tonkatsu). I've always used tonkatsu broth as my ramen benchmark, so I had to keep it consistent. On paper the dish seemed amazing. For about $12 you get a bowl of ramen with the works, including pork, egg, corn, seaweed, chicken karage and potstickers. All that in mah ramen? OMGWTFBBQ right?!?

My ramen arrived in a very timely manner. And now onto the taste...

Broth: Meh. It's alright. Not thick and creamy as I was expecting, but still edible (drinkable?), 3/5
Noodles: Thin(ner) than what I was expecting, but decent. 3.5/5
Pork: Thick slices, Niice! 4/5
Egg: lawl, what a joke, my 3 year old nephew can boil an egg like that. 1/5
Potstickers: Not to my taste as I didn't like the filling, but it was deep fried and really crispy, even while soaked in the broth. I just didn't like the filling but I will put that bias aside and say the potstickers were a 4/5
Chicken Karage: The chicken karage was AWESOME! WHAT U KNOW BOUT THAT CHICKEN KARAGE?!?!? 5/5 it's a shame the rest of the bowl couldn't live up to it.

So yes, overall, the Ramen in my eyes is slightly above average. It's not bad, in fact it's good, but NO it does not stand out for me and honestly I cannot recommend this place to those seeking the BEST ramen. But if you're in the area and feeling like Japanese food, sure stop by. Maybe even try something else, I hear the BBQ Pork is fantastic. But in terms of tonkotsu ramen sadly this one is a no-go for me.
author: Ron T.

description:
A long line is not a strike against this place, any good and small ramen place should have a line.

Tight eating quarters are to be expected, it comes with the territory.

My 3 or 3.5 star rating is based on the ramen, I have tried the katana-ya and green onion versions. They are tasty enough, but they have way too much salt/MSG. I am no stranger to liberal use of salt and/or MSG, but this place goes overboard.

My tastebuds were sodium-numbed for the following 24 hours.

"Ugh, this coffee tastes kind of fu... oh. Wow."

Bad days? I'll give them one more chance and post an update.

Tastier ramen and more balanced broth can be found at KenKenRamen in the Mission, Orenchi in Santa Clara, and Shoki in Sacramento.
author: Kelly M.

description:
You probably shouldn't get anything but ramen here.  Or rather, if you're in the mood for sushi, donburi, etc., go elsewhere.  The ramen makes this place as popular as it is, though admittedly, so does the location.

They have some pretty unconventional choices when it comes to the ramen in fact: kimchi ramen, cilantro ramen, karaage ramen.  The katana-ya ramen has a grab bag of things thrown into it, if you're feeling spontaneous.

I'd recommend going with a combo: regular ramen with any one of around 20 to 30 sides (don, rolls, etc.).  You're asked to choose a broth (soy, salt, miso) and a broth richness (rich, medium, light).  Note that with a combo though, they'll withhold the egg and second slice of pork.  The noodles are of the straighter, less chewy variety.

That'll run you about $13 to $14.
author: Alex C.

description:
Amazing.  We waited for ever (2 hours I think), but by the time we got seated I was soooo hungry!  The fried chicken ramen is one of the best ramen's I've ever had.  Go for that alone.  

The place is tiny--in a fun way, but as a result it's tough to get into.  My advice: put your name on the list and go next door for a drink at the bar.
author: Matthew M.

description:
I had the Katanaya Ramen here. It was pretty fantastic. The fried chicken and gyozas are a great addition to the ramen, although I'd rather have them on the side so that they stay crispy instead of being swamped by soup. I got the spicy miso soup and it was really good. Not too rich, but just right. The medium spicy packs a pretty good punch, so I probably won't venture into the extra spicy realm. The major selling point for the ramen here I think is the noodles. They are a perfect consistency. Nice and chewy, the right thickness and they give you a decent amount of the noodles. 

This place is really tiny. It has a counter/sushi bar and maybe 10 tables in it. We went on a Tuesday evening at about 7:30 and still had to wait about 45 minutes, so be prepared for a wait. Since this restaurant is kinda near the T-loin, you get a lot of homeless folks asking you for change and some randoms yelling things. Not too strange for SF, but it's good to know ahead of time. 

The atmosphere inside is cozy (it has to be because it's so small) and casual. Service is decent. The prices are a bit high I'd say for ramen. The one I had, which I believe is the most expensive was about $13. The others started around 9 or 10 bucks, so not exactly your every day budget ramen place, I'd definitely recommend this place and come back here again.
author: Tyler C.

description: We waited in line for about 15 min. which wasn't bad. We were seated and started to look at our menus. When we were 1st approached by our waitress my fiancé mentioned that she wasn't very friendly. I shrugged it off and said it was 9:30 pm, almost closing time (10:00) and she had probably been on her feet working long hours or something. We ordered edamame, 2 spicy vegetarian ramen bowls,1 very spicy vegetarian ramen bowl, 1 large Sapporo and a sprite. The edamame was GROSS!! It was cold, and looked like it had been sitting out for an hour or more. We did not complain, but again passed this off as it being close to closing. Then the ramen came. She put the 1st bowl down and it was not seasoned with any spice at all. My fiancé asked if this was the spicy ramen and she said "No" and walked away. The other 2 bowls of ramen came and honestly they all were so delicious!! I loved the ramen. Even the non-spicy was excellent. Very good!!! But that waitress was just rude and acted like we were inconveniencing her by being there. She almost ruined the experience, it was weird. She had short black hair and I've noticed her mentioned in reviews here before as being rude. I looked after we had our experience here. Hope the management does something about it, or she's ruining this great place!
author: Dawn H.

description:
Two words:

FOOD POISONING

If it wasn't for the food poisoning that my girlfriend and I both got, I would have highly recommended it.  BUT, it does not matter how great the service is or how good the food tastes, if I get food poisoning and can't go to work the next day, it ain't worth it.  I doubt it was the ramen that we got the poisoning from...most likely the spicy tuna.  

It sucks that I have to give this place a 1 star because I actually liked it and feel that it is unfair to the waitresses, however, the chef needs to make sure that he cleans his food and his hands.
author: Max Z.

description:
This place caught my attention when I saw tons of people waiting outside. The reviews also hyped it up, but I wasn't amused.

I was told there wasn't much of a difference from OC ramen and here. I should have listened and I would have saved money. 

I got the combo with ramen and kimchi fried rice. 

Their ramen was soggy and they don't put too much meat. The broth was a little salty, too. 

Kimchi fried rice was actually the highlight of the meal. 

We also ordered sushi which btw is ridiculously overpriced for how much they give you. They're so tiny!

And the server was rude. When you're ordering and saying too much, she isn't able to process it so she tells you to stop in a snappy way so she can write it down on her notepad.

I've had better ramen and definitely better sushi for the price I paid here.
author: renn a.

description: Katana-ya ramen was ok. Not as good as Ramen Dojo in San Mateo. Can add a side to any ramen for extra.
author: Anup K.

description:
After work I drove my co-worker to Katana-Ya for dinner. We fought through the inner circles of hell to find free parking (there are parking garages but the number of limbs charged was a little daunting). After walking a few blocks we went into the restaurant and put ourselves on the wait list. 

While we waited we looked at their menu and our appetites grew. Everything sounded so good that we began to get really hungry. They seated us after we reached the top spot on the queue (it took about twenty minutes but it was pretty damn busy). We were at the bar which was way cramped as was the whole restaurant. The servers were relatively nice and very good about keeping the water filled and serving us quickly.

I ordered the regular soy sauce ramen and the grilled salmon fried rice. The fried rice came out first and it was amazing! The salmon was so flavorful and it wasn't greasy at all. Just as I was finishing the fried rice my ramen came so I didn't have to wait at all to start the main part of the meal. The ramen was pretty damn good. My ramen lacked interesting cuts of meat and veggies but that is because it was the regular ramen. My co-worker ordered the miso Katana-Ya ramen and it was ridiculous. He really liked all of the amazing flavors and textures in the dish.

We also each got a tonkatsu to go for eating the next day. When I ate the tonkatsu I was convinced that the restaurant is ridiculously delicious. Even though it was a day old, it was some of the best tonkatsu I had ever had. The place wasn't super cheap, it was overly cramped, and the servers weren't too friendly but the food was amazing and authentic.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I've been to SF many times but can't believe I just found this place recently on my trip down here! The place is tiny and pretty much a hole in the wall kind of place but awesome location (very close to union square).  I ordered the combo meal: miso ramen and a small bowl of rice with sashimi. The ramen is good and the broth is tasty. Few times we went there we were lucky. we only waited around 15 min before we were seated and  enjoyed our food. 

be warned: MSG. If you have allergic reaction to MSG, skip this place. They do put MSG and they even mention it. The food was really good and fish is fresh but you'll need 1 gallon of water to quench your thirst after consuming those meals. Still worth it for me since I can't find any decent ramen place in Portland area! :)
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I came here to see what all the fuss is about but was a bit disappointed.  The ramen is not the traditional selection of shoyu, tonkatsu etc.  You select a broth (e.g. miso, salty, soy) and then add in a flavouring (if you desire).  I had regular miso ramen with a rich broth.  It was fine, but nothing special and I have had better ramen elsewhere. 
Prices were reasonable and portion size generous.  I'd come here again if I was in the area but certainly wouldn't come out of my way and don't think I would line up if the queue was more than twenty minutes.
author: Pig E.

description:
I always come here when I was in the union square area craving ramen. The mix fish salad and miso ramen are the things I always order. They both are good but nothing impress, and the ramen sometimes could be salty. 

Since the place is so tiny, there's alway a wait in front of the door. Prepare to wait half an hour or more for your table!!!
author: isabella y.

description:
Place is a little small but its not too crowded. My bf and I wanted to try this place and drove to downtown for a late friday night dinner. We put our names down and went to go look for parking(cause we all know how hard it is to find parking everywhere we go). Circled around for about 15-20 mins, went to check how far we have gotten down on the list, and we didn't move. The wait was still about another 1hr and 15 mins for the two of us so we decided to order take out. 

We ordered the cha shu ramen with miso soup base. The total came out to be about $12 for a bowl of ramen.  The menu said it comes with 4 slices of pork but in our order for to go, only came with 3. Noodles were very nice and tender and the soup made it so much better. This place is good, but for about $12 for a bowl of ramen and 3 slices of pork, I'll think twice about it.
author: Anita W.

description: I just had dinner here again, and tried the kimchee ramen and my friend had the Mabo (sp?) ramen and both were delicious! I got the kimchee ramen with rich shoyu and definitely recommend it above the katanaya ramen.
author: Jacie N.

description: Loved the spicy Ramen - great location and the service was really very welcoming
author: Steve G.

description:
If you're looking for a good ramen place around downtown, and willing to wait.. this is the place to go.
The wait isn't as brutal as Boiling Crab if you guys have been there but it's about 30 minute.

I ordered the KimChee Ramen with the Soy, one word, deeeeeelicious! The spice was just right but the soy was ON POINT!

One thing I dislike about this place is that there isn't much room space. I feel like I was too close to everyone as I slurp my ramen.
author: Lianne D.

description:
I ordered the soy sauce ramen with 1 slice of bbq pork in a medium density and medium spicy style. It was pretty good. The ramen texture was pretty good. The fried rice it came w/ was also tasty. Others say that it wasn't as good as expected. I thought for the wait time (which was like a few mins) and for the time of day I had the food it was perfect. I wouldnt wait for this ramen. I wouldnt wait in a long line. But if its not too busy , go for it!

One of the reasons I like SF is that at 1130pm on a saturday night I can stroll down here and get a table for 6 and just grub. Late night eating so bad for you but so tasty.
author: Mary M.

description: The dining experience was bad. It was a hot day, and there is a fan in the restaurant. We were just finding some places to take a rest and have a dinner. We ordered the BBQ pork ramen and dragon roll. It was super hot, and the waitress just turned the fan for her own usage. I can't stand that. We are the customer! She is so rude! And I don't want to tip her for her bad services. The food is a little bit expensive, and is not good. I probably will not go there   anymore. BAD!
author: Yu C.

description:
Yeah, I don't know. I came here since I had heard good things and it had appeared on the 7X7 list. 

I ordered the chasu ramen like everyone had suggested, but I wasn't that impressed. Not sure if I'd come back...
author: Tammy C.

description:
I have places to go for good ramen, but I wanted to check out this place because of words of mouths and its yelp review. 

I came in on a Sunday evening before 6 pm with my bf. the wait was short. Otherwise, I would feel more awful after a-OK ramen dinner. 

Basically, there was no service. We had to wave at the wait staff to get our dinner ordered. 

The place is too small and the space is extremely tight that you would be afraid to move freely and accidentally hit someone's head. That just made me a very poor dinning experience. 

Ramen: nothing special compare to some of other ramen places in town!  I certainly can get tasty ramen elsewhere with a better dinning environment. 

We also ordered chief recommended spicy seafood salad, which was disappointing. It didn't meet our expectation since it was chief recommended! The spicy sauce is a typical Korean sauce, however it is not spicy at all. And because of the sauce and red color, we basically didn't know what types of raw fish we were eating, except that obvious boiled shrimp. I also over heard the table behind us complaining about paying extra for a spicy broth that is not spicy at all! 

The combo we ordered was (regular ramen + Uni Don $18) with 3 extra slice of pork for $21! I certainly can pay $21 elsewhere for quality ramen, and would rather pay more for a service and big enough dinning space! 

It may not to a nice thing to say! But I was telling my bf that this place has a high rating because these reviewers never had good ramen elsewhere before!!!!!

For this kind of crappy dinning enviornment, I would rather go elsewhere for good ramen!!!!!
author: Bei K.

description:
Got the Katana-ya special ramen w fried chicken, eggs, corn, and all the goodness - miso based. 
Loved how crispy the fried chicken was and the perfect seasoning (not salty) of the broth.
BUT, for its $$$ and long wait, I probably won't come here again

Well, granted, I'm biased as a lover/slave of some Shin Ramyun made in the comfort of my own kitchen, bitchn.
author: Ami Y.

description:
***Good***
Best ramen in the city perhaps. Good close location near Union Sqr.

***Bad***
Tiny. Inefficient way of seating people. Can take a while.
author: Nick K.

description:
My least favorite ramen place ever

Miso, extra rich, katanaya special was terrible. Half of a boiled egg, 4 slices of bbq, green onions, and one other item... disappointment

The 30 minutes wait wasnt worth it :/
author: linda L.

description:
I don't really get why this place has such high reviews.

I had the katana-ya ramen with miso broth. I also fried my friend's kara-age ramen in shoyu broth, and miso definitely was much better.

Let's talk about the broths first. Shoyu was in my opinion pretty bad. It was very salty, and tasted nothing more than soup and soy sauce. There was no depth to the broth at all, merely a flat and dead salty taste. Miso on the other hand was much better, though still slightly on the salty side. Flavorful, but i think the saltiness masked the miso flavors of the broth.

The ramen noodles were good, nice and tender. Kara-age and gyoza were nicely soaked in the broth, but even though the chicken was tender, it was kind of also very salty. The skin of the fried chicken crazily overpowered everything else. Fried gyoza was a bit boring.

Basically I just felt like the chef here went crazy with the marinate and salt. All I could taste was the salt, and because of that, the ramen here felt very heavy. I got sick of the taste very quickly and wanted a change in flavor, but everything else in that bowl of ramen was just as plainly salty.

I downed a lot of water.

Basically this place is eh. If you pass by it and feel like ramen, yeah sure, go in. But it's definitely not worth making a trip for.

On the plus side, the waiters were nice.
author: Chia L.

description:
Katana-Ya pops up everywhere -- 7x7, Chowhound, food blogs, etc. -- so I was happy to finally have the chance to try it today. Even on a rainy, cold, midafternoon Sunday, there was a line. Can't imagine what it's like at peak hours. 

The wait took quite awhile, especially as a party of four. And then they finally decided to seat us, it was at a two-person table that they squeezed an extra two chairs at. Not the most comfortable conditions. 

I ordered the deep fried chicken ramen in miso broth ($11.00). It absolutely hit the spot. The ramen is chewy and nicely al dente, and the broth has great depth (thanks MSG!) The fried chicken was well flavored though a bit fatty for my taste (think popcorn chicken from Quickly's, not Southern fried chicken). 

Will come back, particularly if I'm looking for a cheap-ish place to eat in Union Square.
author: Ada T.

description: Ramen was not as good as I have had in San Francisco. I would not recommend this place if you want really good ramen. Salty, and the noodles were a little undercooked. Not much flavor in the broth.
author: Diego L.

description:
The first thing I noticed off the bat was that Katana-Ya's employees are very friendly. They engaged in a brief conversation with us and seemed very genuine!

We ordered #12 Katanaya Ramen which included: 2 pieces of Chicken Karaage, 2 fried Gyoza, corn, pork, 1/2 of a boiled egg, scallions, seaweed, and julienned mushrooms. It was SUPER delicious! They offer three kinds of pork broths: miso, soy sauce, and salt.

Seating is limited, so get there early! Service is friendly and for $12.00 the portion was generous!!!

We'll be back!
author: Juliette R.

description:
Made a detour at this place on my SF trip because my friend recommended it, overall the ramen was pretty good, not spectacular but liked it, we also ordered a couple of  otoro sushi and it was fresh.

One thing I had a serious problem about is how crowded it is and a bit pricey, other then that, it should b a good place to grab a quick lunch or dinner if you come early.
author: Allen L.

description:
when we sat down the table yesterday evening, the waiter told one of my friends " are you chinese?" .........we were like ???????? and my friend simply got upset on him( waiter).

he didn't ask us to take any drinks or the starers , just said "are you chinese?". then we asked him that why asking us the race/ nationality? then he now got upset on us for no reason.

food was good but the service. the server over there wan't simply professional, and they charged us the service fee( 15%) on the bill. i am not sure that this is legal or illegal.

last night was my all treat for the party, but i definitely not satisfied and not happy even i spent close to $200.

we are coming from san francisco, california, not china.

come on, yelp, why don't you have zero"0" rating?
author: Sugar Y.

description:
Long Lines...
Portions are huge, and priced well for a touristy part of town
Food is flavorful
Service is quick
author: Raymond F.

description:
I came here a while back with my boyfriend at the time. 
Everyone was raving about the whole ordeal and not trying it would be such a crime.
So we dropped by around 10:30pm on a weeknight and was met by a line.
Trying to find parking downtown sf is not very kind.
Parking was already very hard.
The BF decided that Bentleys could park anywhere since it was the trump card.
Although it was nice not getting the car towed.
We couldn't figure out what katana ya's ramen rave bestowed.
Definitely not worth the hype.
People waiting, waiting, and almost got into a fight. 

Himarwari in San Mateo is where I will be. 
I heart my friend Dennis for taking me! 
I am forever a fan.
A quarter for 30 minutes of parking in San Mateo just makes you feel like a rich man!
author: Wanster L.

description: Near a tourist area but actually one of the best Ramen place in SF!
author: Brian L.

description: I've been here before for the ramen but never tried out sashimi. Me and my friend decided to eat here coz we were craving for salmon sashimi tonight...well, I wasn't satisfied at all since it's not freshhhhh at all. Won't come back for sashimi again but yes for ramen...
author: Lyn Z.

description:
UPDATE: 1/16/08

Had the BBQ pork/char seu ramen; I still think chicken karaage is better!  

---------------------------------------------------------------

Oh, ramen.  Oh, steamy bowl of goodness.

After a challenging night of missed eating opportunities and lost parking spaces, my friend and I ended up eating at Katana-Ya.  I'd been meaning to try it for ages, so I was overjoyed...even if we had to endure a frustrating night before that.

The place is tiny - probably only ~15 seats in the place (if that many).  So if you're with a big group...good luck!  I got the ramen, of course, with rich miso broth with chicken karaage (isn't everything better fried?).  Delicious goodness, especially that rich miso broth!  Russ S. tells me that the char-seu is where it's at, so I'll have to try that one the next time I'm there!

Big bowl of deliciousness for less than $10!
author: Wendy L.

description:
The ramen is unlike any other I've had. They give you three different types of soups to choose from-different toppings and styles of noodles. I get the miso soup ramen with kimchi. Slightly thick with the spice of kimchi. Fantastic. 

Then comes the normal menu. Which I have not yet partaken in really. The sushi is okay. Just okay. Honestly. 

I had the rainbow roll and the spicy tuna. Rainbow roll only had thin layers of salmon and hamachi on it and the spicy tuna wasn't spicy. Quite disappointing. 

On the plus side, this place is open till 2 so I'll give it that. The homeless that stand outside aren't helping the atmosphere much neither do the tiny itty bitty tables. Not a place for a first date, that's for sure.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Not sure why this place has 4 stars.
I'm giving it a 2.5, cause I guess I just didn't order the right thing?
Monday night, got in right before the rush and got seated in a small area.
Service was nice and friendly.

We all pretty much ordered ramen and some sort of extra donburi dish (the noodle donburi combo). I did not especially like the ramen. My date ordered some special ramen that came with egg deep-fried dumpling, vegies or meat in the soup.  Noodles weren't very good, soup base was very basic. Not a big fan of the other items in the soup.

The uni don was pretty good, pretty sweet uni. But wth? I pay an extra $4 to get a wayy smaller bowl of donburi than the other people I came with. Ended up paying $20 for the mediocre noodles and extra small bowl of donburi.

Overall, I'm not really not sure whats the big deal. Should've read the other reviews to see what to eat.
author: Adorable T.

description:
Katana-Ya is so great. I know there are other good ramen places in SF (many of which I have yet to visit but will, someday soon) but Katana-Ya is in the city and is darn good eats.

I first came here with the Fiance's uncle and his family who recommended it as a good place to get good ramen late at night (and he's right - they're open until 1 a.m.). One random and unexpected thing about Katana-Ya is that they were the first to get me to try raw tuna and I've loved it ever since. It was at Katana-Ya that I discovered I like some sashimi but only when it's really fresh and the tuna at Katana-Ya was fresh!

I digress.

Their claim to fame is of course the Japanese-style ramen. This is not your poor-college-student-Cup-Noodles establishment. The broth is hot and fragrant and seasoned and flavorful and warms you right down to your toes on those cold, foggy SF nights. You can order it so many different ways - with fried chicken, green onions, donkatsu, seafood, the list goes on - and the broth comes in 9 combinations as well (between the flavor base such as miso or regular and then the spiciness level). 

I'd recommend the spicy green onion ramen - it's got just enough kick to perk up your tongue but not enough that you need a fire extinguisher. 

If you're looking for some simple Japanese fare, the combos aren't a bad choice either. You get regular ramen (with still your choice of one of nine combinations of broth) and a second item from a varied list including chirashi, donkatsu, tempura and others. 

The wait can be anywhere from a few minutes to around an hour because the establishment is tiny. You put your name on the clipboard right outside the door (if it's not there, one of the waiters has it inside and will bring it out shortly) and wait around. Try not to block the sidewalk! If you need something hot to drink while you wait, there are two or three cafes that are open close by. Yelp 'em. =)
author: Christine P.

description:
Been to SF for  few days and a local friend of us recommended this place.The first time we went there at night, there were long lines and had to wait for 30 mins. We decided to go elsewhere and went there the day after for lunch. The place was packed but no lines.
The location was good, near union square but it was  tiny,no wonder people have to wait.
We ordered miso ramen and although the ramen was not spectacular, they were tasty.
We don't think it's worth waiting 30mins though...
Give 4 star cos the waiter was friendly and sweet!
author: Mr F G And Mrs M S.

description:
I have only great things about this place, so I decided to go with my boyfriend to try Katana-Ya. We got there around 1PM and there was a line outside the door. I was open to waiting in line for a spot to dine because the ramen looked delicious and the people inside looked like they were enjoying the food.

We waited approximately 40 minutes to get a seat for 2. My boyfriend and I both ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen. I would highly recommend ordering this dish. This ramen had everything from noodles, gyoza, and fried chicken! WOW, what a great choice! I have never had ramen with fried gyoza or fired chicken. 

Aside from the wait and the tiny restaurant, I would definitely go here again and highly recommend this restaurant to those whom want some good ramen!
author: Lisa H.

description:
Disappointing.

I was on a ramen binge for the past few months and was super excited to try this place after hearing rave reviews from several of my friends. Upon their recommendation, I ordered the katanaya ramen. 

The toppings were good. The chicken crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. The corn was sweet and provided a refreshing contrast to the rest of the meal. The fried thing-y was also quite tasty.

The noodles and broth, however, were not so good. The noodles weren't chewy (perhaps they were undercooked?) and the broth lacked dimension. It tasted like one of those frozen supermarket noodle packages you could prepare at home. 

The meal wasn't bad. It was decent, but I will unlikely return as there are so many better ramen shops in the Bay Area.
author: Chiaming C.

description: I waited for an hour in line in Tokyo for these same noodles. Stop yer bitchin' about a 30 minute wait in SF. The Ramen here is outstanding. This is the real deal, and not to sound like a jerk, but if you don't like the Ramen here, then you just don't like Ramen.
author: Melissa M.

description: 12 mintues after opening time and there is already a waiting list! We had to nab some on seats at the sushi bar and that makes for cramped seating, especially in this little place. I had the udon and salmon don. The udon was pretty good, but I regret gettng the salmon don because I could've made it at home. Still, I enjoy eating here and it's relatively affordable. Also, I think they have pretty damn good service even though it's always crowded in here.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Really, I would give it more stars.. however!  I would have to say the main problem with this place is that everything they serve is disgusting.  I'm NOT down for murdering, cutting up and cooking the bodies of innocents and calling it 'food'.
author: Brian H.

description:
This place is delicious.  The ramen tasted even better with me sitting with my back against the door and customers coming in every 5 minutes.  This helped with reducing my ramen's temperature instantly.  

Expansion?  Fuck it, stuff your customers in there like slaves on a slave ship.
author: Doug F.

description:
Living in Atlanta, I rarely have a chance to get really good ramen (unless I go to Yakitori Jinbei). It's been a long time since I had authentic ramen in Tokyo. So when I visited San Francisco, it was my mission to find some good ramen.

Katana Ya hit the mark perfectly. Ever since having great ramen in LA, I knew the West coast should have some decent ramen. Thanks to Yelp, I found Katana Ya. 

Like I said, I haven't tasted authentic ramen in Japan in a while, so I don't know how good Katana-Ya is compare to Japan's. But for a ramen shop in the States, it's good as it gets.

The menu has a good selection of ramen.  Japanese restaurants here in Georgia only have selection of 1 or 2 ramen. But Katana Ya has several varieties and they all look delicious. It's too bad I only came here once, I wanted to try all of the varieties.

The space is cramped, but that's okay. It gives off a more authentic ramen shop feel. I can't wait to come here again when I visit the Bay Area.
author: Jang C.

description:
So you finally decided to join elite ranks of Ramen lovers in the San Francisco Bay Area. But after talking to a few veterans you hear that every good Ramen spot is outside of the city. Forget these people because they have never had real ramen in Japan. Which I have done. 

Here is the thing. Ramen is never going to be as good as in Japan. They literally have Ramen spots everywhere and I can only imagine, the skill and ingredients are just more readily avaiable over there. Can you imagine a ramen spot where one guy is dedicated to making noodles, another guy is dedicated to working on the soup, and another is dedicated to the chashu (pork)? Not likely in this economy. But in Japan most of the spots are like that. Dedicated to the Ramen art.  Not to mention the number of Ramen lovers has got to be higher. 

Katana-Ya is a very decent facsimile of Ramen in the city in San Francisco. 

This restaurant is very close to union square in downtown San Francisco. And you can tell because there are many bums milling about the neighborhood.

This place is perpetually crowded. I swear everytime I go there is a crapload of people here. But its a very small hole in the wall type spot. 

On to the food. The Katana-Ya Ramen is a great choice. Has everything in it. I go for the soy soup base. But I have tried miso as well and its very yummy. They have a good deal were you can get a bowl of ramen and some side for pretty cheap. 

The gyoza is very tasty as well. The spicy tuna and misc sushi is very good also. 

You won't find better ramen than this in the city. You will have to venture to San Mateo or San Jose for better fare.
author: Lawrence S.

description: Ramen Bowls are Amazing!!! Fiancé and I were looking for a light meal, after all the snacking we did at local must eats during the day and adjusting to PCT eating schedule (from east coast). We decided on sushi and after searching locally found this place and all the amazing Ramen Bowl photos! Had gyoza which was good, red dipping sauce had a little hear but lacking in flavor. Shared the Lava Flow sushi roll, really good shrimp tempura roll. We finished off with the Ramen Bowls!! Sooo soo good! I ordered the bowl with everything (fried chix, corn, pork, seaweed, wonton) in medium spicy miso! Amazing. I really wish we had something comfortable in South Florida! Def would revisit!
author: Sean G.

description:
Nothing to add to the great reviews. Came here thanks to yelp, waited in line for a relatively long time, ate very well and got mildly drunk.

Got back to my hotel happy!
author: Paola M.

description:
I don't know if it was the cloudy weather or me being tired and hungry at the end of the day, but I remember this being the best ramen I've had.  Even considering the 45 minute wait.  I even went here twice while on vacation (which is something I never do so I can optimize my food experience while traveling).  

I got the soy sauce ramen with BBQ pork, that's pretty much my go to flavor at any ramen place.  I remember it being good, but I don't remember why exactly.  So because it isn't as memorable, I have to say it wasn't the best (but it is the best I've had so far).

It's a small place, so you really just have to order, eat, and go quickly.  But it's worth the wait to try it at least once.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
My friend and came here on a whim during the week. It was late and we just wouldn't figure out where we wanted to go eat. It had come to the point we wanted something delicious but didn't want the high price tag that can usually come with it.

Since we had walked by Katana-ya earlier we decided we wouldn't go wrong with ramen. Plus, all of the yelp reviews said it was bomb.com.

Upon arriving there was a decent group of people waiting outside a packed restaurant. I did notice it was a very small place that could only seat 20 or so max. With our names on the list, the wait began!

30 min later its dinner time! We didn't waste any time deciding and both ordered the Katana-ya ramen.

That first bite was heaven. A combination of spice and salt was exactly what I couldn't decide on earlier. Pure silence for the next 10 min pursued between my friend and I. You can't interrupt something this good.

Reasonable price for the portions. The wait is worth it in my opinion. Only improvement needed is the service.
author: Derek J.

description:
Please see my update below for a better alternative for ramen in SF:

I came here  today with mom. She had the combination meal, basic ramen with katsudon (10.50). I had the spicy tofu ramen (8.00). We both had miso light broth.  My mom liked her broth and so did I.  However,  I could only manage to sip a few spoonfuls before I had salt overload which causes terrible bloating. The ramen is pretty good but cut a little too thick for my taste. 

The service was not good and we had to wait awhile for our food. I was sitting right next to the cashier's desk and when I asked three times for a tea refill, she responded but didn't tell anyone to bring us a tea refill.
