There was a lamp and some sake sample bottles sitting at the edge of the cashier's desk and the lamp fell on me!!! No one apologized or said anything. 

I like the food enough to come back but these people are waiting for a lawsuit if they allow lamps to fall on their customers.

Update 12/11/07: Came back again for the miso light broth ramen.  Sooooo salty that I couldn't taste anything else but salt.  I recommend Mifune-- they have the best ramen currently (just started serving ramen) and it's less salty and the service is better.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
What can I say about Katana-Ya that's probably not already been said...its in the middle of everything. Its small, its crowded and you will wait on probably any given night of the week to get in judging by the sheer amount of foot traffic in the area.

The staff is friendly, even when they are real busy and they do tend to you a lot...again even when its really busy.
There were a few gnats flying around but it wasn't gross...I think its cause the front and back doors were open.

The food is top notch, I had me the Regular Soba and it was hearty. the broth was smokey and had a nice flavor to it without the soba. When you add a heaping spoonful with noodles its perfect.

For Sushi I had the Crispy Spicy Tuna App. Its a salad with a fried spicy tuna roll. Amazing, the texture was just right, the fish tasted more like a juicy tender steak than tuna...it was just outstanding.

I also had the Butterfish Sushi, about 3 pcs. Very light with a slight chew but nothing gross. The texture was also nice, almost felt velvety in my mouth. It was a really nice piece of fish and I'd get it aqain. I also had the Spicy Tuna Roll and a few pcs of the Lava Flow Roll.

 Again all the rolls were really fresh tasting. The Lava Flow Roll was brilliant. The hot (shrimp tempura) was hot and the cold part (the spicy tuna) was cold. First time I've ever had a roll like this that was properly hot / cold where need be. The texture of the fish was always clean, never tasted anything fishy or smelled any ammonia like smells from the fish (yes its actually happened out here in SF). The salmon was also very clean tasting.

All in all this place kicks ass and not only will I be back more often but I will tell everyone I know about how great this place is.
author: Dean M.

description:
Small enough not to notice when you just pass by but difficult to go unnoticed during peak eating hours; the line more often than not goes out the front door and onto the sidewalk.

I had their combo special picking the Miso Ramen with light density and their grilled Salmon Don. My friend also ordered their combo with the spicy tuna don. Both their dons were almost devoid of  fish. If at all, the spicy tuna don consisted of this thin layer, which you could barely taste after mashing it up with the rice. My salmon, the same. The bowls of rice inevitably left me wondering if these sides were purely cheap fillers for those stomachs a regular bowl of ramen wouldn't fill. If you come here, do try the combos, but don't get it with any fish. 

I liked how customizable* the combos are and the option to choose the "density" of your soup. Their noodles were tasty, their soup comforting, but I've had better without the wait and with better sides. I ordered a Kimchi fried rice to go for later and it was not good. I think I make a better kimchi fried rice (and I'm a poor cook), but nice try.
author: Alesia T.

description:
It really only deserves 3.5 stars, but I can't do fractions, and this is probably the best ramen place in SF. Very old-school Japanese vibes and decor, and polite service. They do take cards, but they don't take Amex.

Delicious broth, perfectly al dente, thick, wavy noodles, and excellent toppings. It's good enough that I'll actually take leftovers home and eat them the next day. Yay for not-overcooked noodles! :D

The fried chicken is great, but I disagree about it being the best ever. There is a decent vegetarian ramen option, a rarity for traditonal ramen places. The combinations are also interesting and a decent value.

The sashimi/fish is of great quality, but unfortunately both their sushi and regular rice is weak. 

Beware the sometimes long wait, although during off hours you're usually seated immediately. Also beware the aggressive crackheads panhandling on the fringes of the Tenderloin.

Beware the ramen food coma. 

I still go almost every week. Yum!
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
This was the first time I tried ramen, so I don't really have anything to compare it to, but I gotta say I really enjoyed the food. I ordered regular ramen with miso, and the Dynamite roll on the side. Everything was delicious, and the hot broth really hit the spot on a cold San Francisco day.

This place does have limited seating, so often a long line forms at lunch and dinner times. If you're getting lunch, try to get here at 11:30am as they open. We got there around 11:45 and we took the last table.
author: Gene V.

description:
the one black mark on this trip. the one sf failure. the one time yelp, 7x7, and friend referrals all failed me (it's ok though.. yelp usually never does me wrong so I'll forgive you ;) ).

americanized, stale, flavorless broth. overcooked egg. the only saving grace was the jumpy jump jump of the noodles. but no. that was not enough to save the place.

&there was a hair in my soup. not only did I get my ramen 20 minutes after everyone else. but there was a hair in it. that is never ok. I appreciate them taking it back and changing it out, but then of course that means I am eating alone while everyone falls prey to the post-ramen MSG coma. not useful, funny, cool.

we arrived at off hours so there was no wait. people really wait 2 hours for this place? I'm sorry. I wouldn't try it again if it was handed to me on a platter.
author: Mindy N.

description:
Be prepared to wait! But it's worth it! We were staying at Hotel Diva a couple doors down. We waited about 20 minutes around a lot of impatient people. I ordered cilantro ramen in miso. Wonderful - you better like cilantro! The kids had chicken ramen in mild broth and shared a bowl. Next time I'll let them have their own bowls. They are big eaters. Hard working and very nice service but not enough to keep all the tables happy however, the restaurant isn't big enough to have more staff! The have beer: bonus!
Small tip: skip the sushi.
author: Mar R.

description:
I went once last year, on a first date and I'll just say that both my date and the ramen left a lot to be desired. I forgot what type of ramen I ordered exactly, but it was very meh, the broth was decent, wasn't amazed by it, the ramen didn't have any particularly outstanding taste or texture. I felt like I emptied half the jar of spice powder trying to give it some sort of flavor.

It was my date's first time ever experiencing ramen that didn't come from a plastic package and maybe he's just a hick whiteboy from up North, but he wasn't impressed either.

Only plus when I went though was we scored the last table, no epic wait for us!
author: Daneca V.

description:
Great place. I guess there's been new ownership since some of these reviews have been written. I don't know how much better they used to be, but I like this place a lot. It's small and cozy and everyone speaks Japanese except the one whitegirl server ("and one hawmawchi, onehgay shimawsu".)

My girlfriend and I came after walking around Union Square in the rain and boy was it worthwhile. I had chashu ramen with miso broth and she had karaage ramen with shoyu broth (oh my god what a BRILLIANT idea. color me american but I have never heard of this until now.) Noodles were firm and kinda bigger than I'm used to but I liked it. Broth could've had more character, but I have not had better around here.

I also got a small beer - it came in a small izakaya style glass that reminded me a lot of Japan, and it was also cheap at $2.50. I also got sanma (mackerel pike), one of their daily whiteboard specials. The bill came out to something like $26. Nicely done Katana-ya.
author: Josh K.

description:
First walked by this place after seeing Rock of Ages at the Curran Theater.  At the time it was packed, so I decided to keep it on the list and try another time.  We went on a Saturday afternoon at around 3PM.  The place is small and we had to wait about 20 min. to be seated.  

I ordered the Hamachi Kama (yellowtail collar) and the Katana-Ya Combination ramen with soy broth.  Wifey had the same thing with the miso broth.   

1) The ramen came with 2 gyozas, fried chicken thighs, seaweed, corn, and a hardboiled egg.  The ramen was cooked perfectly ( a little al dente), and both broths were tasty, although I did prefer the miso.  Size was as expected.

2)  The Hamachi was ordered as an appetizer, but didn't arrive until we were almost finished with our ramen.  Typically this dish is broiled, but in this case, it was floured and deep fried.  The portion size was very generous and the yellowtail was fried nicely.  It was accompanied with a ponzu sauce as is done traditionally.

Other than the mix up with the hamachi, the service was fast and somewhat attentive.  For good quality ramen, I recommend this place.  Although the value could be a bit better (ramen was $13-$14), I would definitely come back.
author: David D.

description:
I've never been a big fan of ramen. I don't understand why someone would pay $10-$15 for noodles when I think my Korean or Kung fu packaged noodles always tastes better.

But Katanaya set me straight! I had the Katanaya special ( with bamboo, corn, fried chicken, potstickers, egg and pork) in the light soy broth, spicy, and it was yummy! on a cold day, this soup really hits the spot!
author: Anna T.

description:
YUM YUM YUm!  Arrived here with coworkers at about 6pm on a thursday night, no line yet.  We got seated and not long before we even ordered, the rest of the tables started filling up and a line gathering outside.  This is a tiny tiny resturant - no legroom, walk room, table room.  So get acquainted with the friends you're eating with.  (Side story, bumped into a friend that got seated beside us, basically turned around and we're in the same party).

My party each had a bowl of ramen, a roll to share, and pitcher of beer.  I love the chilled glass! (table becomes completely full - no movement allowed).

Food?  Great!  Cant get enough!  I ordered the katanaya ramen, it comes with everything! your choice of soy, miso, or ___ soup.  I chose miso, the flavors were already coming in from the loads of fried chicken, potsticker, bbq pork, and just a small splash of corn it was topped with.  ooohhh... slurp slurp yum!  the broth isnt msg salty, but flavorful.  Great ramen in SF that I could find.  Big quality portions, service is corteous and price is decent. 

Place is small, be prepared to sweat after eating ALL of your ramen bowl.
author: Ju D.

description: Sushi was great and I was full with few rolls. They are really delicious, especially shrimp tempura. But service wasn't so good. I had to ask for additional stuff, they don't care too much about clients.
author: Malgorzata N.

description:
Well I haven't written a review in a while so let's get cracking.  This place is good.  One of the better ramen places I have been to. 

So from reading all the reviews, looks like the biggest complaint is the lunch hour wait.  I was here the day before Thanksgiving.  Lucky me, most people had already taken the rest of the week off work so my wait was only about 10 minutes or so.  

The second complaint is that the portions are small and pricey.  I would have to agree but I would rather pay more for less good food than pay less for massive quantities of crap.  I had the regular shoyu ramen because sometimes I think simple is better.  The noodles were fresh and chewy, which means they were cooked just right.  The toppings were really no different than most ramen places but the broth was excellent.  My fried had the katanaya ramen with miso broth and he really liked it.  I tried his broth and it was delicious.  I personally would never order that bowl just because as far as toppings there's way too much going on in there.  

The other complaint I heard a lot about was the fact that they use MSG in their broth.  Yes, I know MSG makes everything taste better so it's kind of cheating.  Yes, I MSG is bad for you but I don't eat here everyday so honestly I don't care.

Needless to say this place has it's flaws but there's not a lot of places out there that can top it, so quit your bitchin and go have some ramen.
author: Thao H.

description: The first time I came here, the service was bad. After a long wait, they sat us in the basement by ourselves and we were pretty sure no servers knew we were there. We had to go upstairs to find someone. The ramen, however, was amazing. So, we came back last night. Basement again, and terribly slow service. One waiter took orders, and another would come down to the basement and ask every person at the communal table who ordered the food she had in her hand. Very unorganized. I asked for an egg in my ramen, and I swear they had a bag of cold, precooked HARD BOILED eggs that they cut in half and dropped in the soup. The soft cooked egg is my favorite part of any bowl of ramen. If you mess that up, you've lost me as a customer.
author: Lauren D.

description:
I ate here a few weeks ago, and had ramen for the first time, and let me tell you it was DELICIOUS! I feel like this neighborhood has a few good hidden spots because I've eaten at Pearl's burgers (which might be my favorite burger place). The staff was pretty nice and helpful with their suggestions, and the customers eating there were super friendly and started up a random conversation with my friend and i. There wasn't a lot wait, but that might have been because it was mid-day. 

I ordered the original ramen which i loved, but left me wanting to order something with a little more personality. My friend ordered the extra spicy ramen, which i wish i had ordered. It wasn't super spicy like they had said which i liked. Despite the hot chili pepper shaker busting open and attacking my food, it was still goooood. I recommend Katana-Ya especially if your bringing friends from out of town.
author: Jordana A.

description:
Not really a fan of ramen.. But always gotta try something new! First time here and it's pretty decent.. Place is really small.. Parking is crazy! I happened to be lucky and park right across the restaurant..  

For the food.. I actually enjoyed this better than the place I went to in J-town.. I had the katana ya ramen bowl with soy broth.. Had pot stickers.. Boneless chicken.. Pork and eggs.. Broth was good.. And noodles were soft! I didn't really like the taste of the pot stickers in my ramen.. Since it was soaked in the broth.. But still good.. 

Service was okay.. But gotta realize that its in downtown with a lot of foot traffic.. In a small restaurant.. Overall I will go back if I'm ever in the downtown area.. And my car is already parked.. Lol!
author: Marc M.

description:
Im having a hard time remembering another restaurant that has left me so utterly disappointed as the "ramen" that I attempted to eat at KatanaYA. 

FIrst off, I don't want to sound like someone who's generally ungrateful so I will say that the servers got us to our seats quickly (considering the line of people out the door) and were attentive. 

But the food! Its gotta taste better! 

Checking out the menu before-hand, I noticed that many people were recommending the miso ramen. Miso is interesting in that it tastes just as good when mixed with water (aka miso soup) as it does when mixed with soup stock (since the miso pretty much masks any other flavors). So I thought I'd try the shoyu (soy) ramen. A good shoyu ramen (IMO) balances the tastes of the soup stock with the rich salty goodness of soy sauce (or whatever blend is being used).

I got nothing. A taste black hole, if you will. Its like someone took a bowl of ramen and removed every taste morsel from it surgically, and then served it to me. 

The soup was the color of the sky in SF in July. Grayish and without life. There were bits of fat floating in the soup, but they were the kinds of fat that most other ramen chefs would discard for lack of flavor (most likely fat from chicken carcasses that wasn't discarded, instead of pork back fat that is added to the soup stock after it is been fully ready). The soup tasted like it had once been a shoyu, but had been stripped of it's shoyu-ness (new word) through cost saving dilution methods. The end result was a soup that tasted more like stone soup than shoyu ramen soup.

But I wish that was the only problem. 

One of the chefs must have ran out of ramen noodles, because the noodles that landed in my soup were definitely of the spaghetti breed. Thick, round, straight, unable to hold any soup to them, and worst of all- soft. Not a little past al dente soft, but old folks home denture soft. 

Finally, the toppings. 

I could tell that the toppings were tuned to an American audience, which although not authentic, has worked out very well for their business. I will say this though. There was about 4x as much fried junk (fried gyoza torpedo and fried chicken pieces) in my katanaya ramen as chashu, which was tough and lacking in the flavor department anyways. 

In conclusion, I'm not saying that YOU (the reader) shouldn't eat at Katanaya. Most people who eat it, love it. Just remember this: As much as you may like it now, it could, and should (because of all the people who line up outside to eat there) be better.
author: Dan L.

description:
After watching a morning IMAX show, we headed here for a bowl of ramen on a Saturday, expecting to wait awhile.  Pleasantly surprised to be seated without a wait at 12pm on a Saturday afternoon.  Like most ramen joints, it's a small cozy space that hustles diners in and out.

Pick your ramen, pick your broth (regular, soy, shiyo), pick your salt content (regular or light).  MSG included.

Katana-Ya Ramen for me.  At $13/bowl, this is one hefty bowl with your standard boiled egg, slices of pork, corn, and 2 fried potstickers and 2 pieces of fried chicken all sopping up the ramen broth.  It was okay, but the chicken was overcooked and I didn't enjoy the intentional sogginess of the fried chicken and potstickers.  The broth was so-so.

Shiyo ramen with tonkatsu don combo for him.  He enjoyed the option of having both ramen and a side of don for $12.  But again, the shiyo flavor was just okay.

We prefer the ramen joints in San Mateo -- but this is a suitable pricier alternative if you're in the city.  It just doesn't live up to the incredible hype.  And be prepared for massive MSG-induced coma afterwards - I went home and slept for 2 hours!
author: Heather s.

description:
Katana-ya is located right near union square... no parking what so ever. If you're planning on going here, take the public transit or park in the garage. There's always a line for this place and there's a wait list outside.

The place feels pretty cramped inside. They really try to have as much seats as possible. During the day, the place gives off a darken mood inside due to the lightning.

Katana-ya has pretty great ramen. The broth is okay, the noodles are good, and the meat is good. It's one of the better ramen places in SF. As mention in many other reviews, they put MSG in their ramen, which really kills it for me. I do agree this place is a bit over hyped and a bit pricey.
author: Steven B.

description: Food was great. However, the service sucked. They need a host person. Make sure you put your name on the list outside. I could barely order a second beer- asked 2 different people (who were not our server, because i could not find my server). It finally took about 30 minutes to get another beer.
author: Tanuki T.

description:
Came back to give this place a second chance.  Got the regular ramen combo with a side of fried rice.  Decided that it deserves more than 2 stars!  The broth was tasty with good noodles. 

I think its a good place to get your ramen craving but would I say is the best? Nah.  I've had much much better ramen in NYC and this place is decent.  Will venture around this city more to find something better if not, this will be my go to place to kick that craving.
author: Nho C.

description:
The wait for the line is long, it's tiny, no more than people should be in your party or else it will be way too crowded. Cramped even with 2-3 people. 

The ramen is subpar. The spicy ramen wasn't very spicy, nor was it very good. I only got one piece of meat, and the noodles were meh. 

If you're hankering for Ramen (really bad), yeah come here. if you want some good ramen, skip it.
author: Rohan D.

description:
We originally had dinner plans at some fancy-shmancy restaurant, but fell asleep through our reservations... Oops. LUCKILY, Katana-Ya was across the street from our hotel & was opened late !

I had heard of this place through a friend. Thank goodness I listened to her ! 

We ordered the Crispy Spicy Tuna as an appetizer. YUM-O. It had a nice kick, with a different twist to the usual mashed up "spicy tuna" rolls. I usually don't like spicy tuna, but anything deep-fried sounds a hundred times better. Heehee. And in this case, it definitely was !

The boyfriend ordered the Extra Spicy Ramen in miso soup.  If you're a typical Asian who lovesss spicy foods, the Extra Spicy won't faze you. According to the him, it wasn't all that spicy, but it still had wonderful flavor. It'd get about a 7.5 out of 10.

Meanwhile, I am a wimp and I loved my Kimchi in miso just fine... without the spice. I'm not a fan of warm kimchi, but I was craving kimchi, so I decided it might be worth a shot. So worth that leap of faith. 

The broth in both our bowls were thicker than other places we've eaten, but neither of us minded because the flavors were so yummy. However, I'd have to say that our favorite part was the noodles. They were perfectly chewy, but tender. I didn't finish my bowl (I was stuffed!), so the bf devoured what was left of my noodles.

It's always packed, even on a random weeknight. So, be prepared to put your name down & wait. Enjoy !
author: Paulina N.

description:
I find it hard to judge ramen places simply because the differential between ok, good, and awesome is so narrow. 

This place was decent, maybe a bit overpriced for ramen in my opinion.  I'd eat here again if there was little to no wait (which is rare).  Stop by if you're shopping in union square on a cold afternoon and looking for something to warm your belly, but if there's a fatty line, not worth it.

I tried the Katana-Ya Ramen with miso broth, but I also tried the other soup broths as well, all did the job, but not super tasty or nothing. Our group also split the Kimchi fried rice which was decent as well.  Bottom line: worth a try, but not worth a long wait.
author: Ngoc N.

description:
i remember thinking this place was sooo good.... well, i just went back recently and had a bowl of the special ramen with everything in it. miso flavored +spicy (which is $1.40 more; ridiculous, especially because it didnt even have a kick at all.) 

the soup flavor was ok, but there was a thick layer of oil at the top which was so gross that it made me not want to eat it anymore. fried chicken tasted old, and the service was terrible. Their space is so cramped and one waitress kept bumping into my elbow  as I was eating (not once did she apologize or even acknowledge doing so. RUDE!) 

I wouldn't recommend it, and I will not be coming back!
author: Lisa N.

description:
The bad thing about this place is that there's very limited seating, and ideally not a place for huge groups. The wait time is pretty long as well, and can take at least half an hour to be seated.

However, I loved the ramen here. It is the best ramen I have tasted in my life. Loved the broth and the chicken. Thank you Katana-Ya, you are awesome and you get 4 stars!

Definitely check this place out, it's worth the wait.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Ok, what is all the fuss about? 1500+ yelp reviews and 4 stars?! For the majority of my life I've been in San Francisco and yet...I have not tried this godly, yelping good place?! So on one cold, San Francisco night, I decided to try this place with a few friends.

When we got there, we were met by a line of people waiting to get inside Katana-Ya presumably. But wait, I don't see anything...Oh there it is! It literally fits like 15 people and still, you will be cramped. But we came to eat Ramen and we were not going to walk away without trying this supposedly Queen of Yelp. And so we put our name on the list and waited for about 30 minutes to get a table. 

There isn't that much to see inside but it's definitely very Japanese-feeling. If you have a large party (6 or more) and want to sit together, it will be kind of hard to accommodate as most of the tables there are suited for only 4 people.

What about the Ramen? I mean, that's all we care about right? I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen that came with fried chicken & gyozas. I didn't know what to do with the chicken and gyozas at first...am I supposed to dump them into the broth? I still am not too sure but that's what everyone else did so I followed suit. So I then dug myself into the ramen and...

It was.....MEH. It was only OK, not even that great. Maybe my expectations were too high and maybe because I'm so used to eating Ramen down in LA (sooo gooooood), but Katana-Ya was a mile short of my expectations. The broth was nothing special. The ramen itself tasted like Top Ramen. The 1k+ people who gave this restaurant 4+ stars have obviously never tasted GOOD Ramen in their lifetimes.

After waiting in the cold for 30 minutes and being cramped in a corner only to find out that the Ramen was BLEH...I don't think I'll be back, or at least not for a while.
author: David W.

description:
I was craving ramen when I went to SF because of the cold weather and I am a big fan of ramen so we decided ramen it is for dinner...unfortunately, many other people wanted ramen that night. It was pretty packed and the place is really small. For a group of 4 of us we waited about 45 minutes. On the plus side, they are really quick and efficient there. 

My sister and I shared the Spicy  Ramen with Chicken Karrage.You can tell them how much spice you want in it and we opted for super spicy. It had really good flavor! It was a good amount too! They gave us also a good amount of chicken in it. The chicken was really good and juicy. I loved it. We also got it with a small order of fried rice. Also very good. It tastes very fresh here. 

Service was really quick and we got our food really quickly. Definitely a good ramen place to go to if you are in SF; just be prepared to wait.
author: Phuong K.

description: BEST ramen soup I've ever had!!! Deep fried chicken, with miso broth and a bit spicy.    It's a small cozzy place :) and the personnel is really kind. Eventough there was a huge line to get a table, it took us only 15 minutes to get one. I'm definitely coming back!!
author: Cristina N.

description:
Overrated ramen. Sorry. 

I had the BBQ Pork Ramen in the rich miso broth and it was quite disappointing. The broth was just alright, okay flavor and not too salty. But heavy on the MSG. The pork slices were bland and tough. Not at all tender. And the noodles were AWFUL! Much too chewy and overcooked. What is ramen without good noodles?! 

I would recommend the Super Spicy Roll though. That was actually good. And cheap at $6.50! But considering the TERRIBLE parking access and the prospect of long waits (I was seated immediately), I'd go elsewhere.
author: Gee K.

description:
This place is always jam packed! The restaurant is tiny and very squishy so don't expect to stretch out your arms and legs while you eat. The ramen is tasty but not amazing. I'm still on a hunt for the best ramen place ever.

P.S. The workers stick you with the check before you're even done. Not cool.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Ok... so I was just here a week ago and I must say, 4:00pm was a perfect time to go because there was no line and I was seated immediately. This place is really tiny so that would explain why normally there is a wait. But let's get to why I only gave it 3 stars. I had a spider roll sushi and the BBQ pork ramen with the miso broth. The sushi was great! I enjoyed every piece but the ramen was a different story. I didn't find anything special about it and the bbq pork was actually really tough and not tasty at all. The miso soup and noodles were very bland as well and well, I just didn't enjoy it. I left most of it. 

The service was great. Everyone was really friendly. I just wished the ramen was better tasting. I might go back for the sushi...but only if there is no wait.
author: Beldevina P.

description:
Too many 5 star reviews! Gotta stop going to awesome places. Wait, did I just say that?

Wandered around SF for a while, around Market then Union Square. Wandered like hungry zombies. A friend suggested (gurgled) ramen. I looked up "ramen" on my trust Yelp app on my Moto Droid. It gives me Katana-Ya, which has amazing ratings and is only a block or two away. We start shuffling towards Katana-Ya making zombie noises. And eating tourists brains along the way. Don't taste good, we want ramen.

We get there, and its pretty full inside, but nobody outside? Cool. We get seated shortly, I don't see anything particularly stand out to me on the menu. I choose BBQ pork ramen. Better than brains. Noodles were great, broth had super depth, pork released all sorts of juices in my mouth that made me very very very happy (sounds dirty, eww). Full now. No more brains tonight.

Got the house sake, which was pretty dry but went with the meal well. Sake is good for zombies. Nothing real special, just boring old Ozeki. We look outside and there are a crowd of zombies lurking. I was glad we came when we did.

Price was a little pricy for just noodles if you look at it, but great for the quality of food we got. Top 5 ramen places I've been to ever.
author: Andrew M.

description: I come here every time I'm in town and love their ramen! I've brought several friends here over the years and have always received positive reviews on my pick of restaurants. Food and service top notch!
author: Dawn R.

description:
Wooh, the ramen is amazing....but expect at least a 20 minute wait during peak hours.

It's so hard to find a good ramen shop in the Bay Area until I came across this place. I came with a friend who loves this place, well I fell in love too. I normally get the soy sauce flavored ramen with chicken. But they have an a la carte style ordering menu for those who want to build up their own appetite. It's not too salty nor bland like many other ramen shops. The one downside though is the wait. The location is a very small restaurant which is more confined such as coffee shop. Because of the small space, seating is extremely limited with a table for 2 seating up to 4. It'll bring families closer together....literally lol. There is other Japanese cuisine as well such as sushi but I honestly have yet to try another dish there. Service is pretty quick and attentive so it doesn't lack attention the way some other restaurants do once you recieve your food.
author: Neland M.

description: This is my favorite ramon place anywhere. It usually has a long wait because it has very limited seating inside. But the food is worth it. Service is friendly and fast too. Go Now!
author: Michelle L.

description: This is my fav ramen place in the city; however, I really HATE to wait in line. The wait is just ridiculous. I haven't been there for a while but I used to always get the Ramen with Fried Chicken Wings on the side. Hhmmm yummy. Writing this review makes me wanna go there now.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description: Ermigaaad, Japanese Ramen, so goooood....  ...  ......  Totes. But is it just me, or do they all taste the same? Despite the wait, it's still a great option for late night eats.
author: Deevie K.

description:
I was visiting from Texas and planned on making this my first stop for some grub. It was a Thursday night at 8pm, and I was greeted at the door with a sign saying "no more ramen". *sad face* Second attempt was successful: Monday night around 7:30pm. There was a 15-20 minute wait for our group of 4, but we just wandered next door to grab a drink. 

The location is very small--less than 10 tables. It's a tight squeeze and you may end up bumping elbows a few times, but it's not too terrible. 

I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen with miso broth, extra spicy, as suggested by my friend/tour guide. First thing to note: BIG portions. I was able to split a bowl with a friend and still be fully satisfied. So for those on the petite side, I would suggest going halfsies with a buddy. The broth was delicious, and the "extra spicy" is just enough to make your mouth tingle without burning. The Katana-Ya comes with pork, half a boiled egg, a couple of pieces of fried chicken, and a couple of fried wontons. I wasn't a huge fan of the pork, but the fried chicken and wontons were super yummy. And duh, eggs are always a win. 

The price seems a little high for ramen ($15/bowl), but that may just be my Houston bias coming through (Asian food in Houston is dirt cheap and delicious). Overall, I liked this place and would recommend it to any ramen lovers. My advice: Come in a small group. Be prepared to wait a few. Order the extra spicy.
author: Monique N.

description:
Not to say I haven't been here with other people, but this is my favorite place to have dinner by myself, mostly because I feel a sick sense of satisfaction when my name is called before all those couples and groups of friends who have been waiting outside for a real long time (yes, I am an a-hole).

I usually get the BBQ pork ramen with salt broth and a glass of plum wine (sweet and delicious) and read a book while I wait for my food (which means I read about two pages, because service is real quick). I love that you can ask for the rich broth, too, because that's awesome. I've also ordered sushi, and I vaguely remember that tasting pretty good, but I also vaguely remember being drunk, so don't take my word for it.

There aren't a whole lot of ramen places I would come back to, but this is one of them. It's somewhat nearby my home, the wait's not too bad when you ride solo, and it's totally not awkward to eat by yourself at the bar. Plus, I think I really just like the taste of MSG.
author: Erin V.

description:
Small ramen venue hidden away in the middle of the block. Pick your type of broth (rich or light), any special flavoring (soy, miso, salt) & add-ons.

I like the light, miso ramen with BBQ Pork. Mmmm delicious! Honestly didn't even realize how much effort can be put into ramen once I stepped out of my college Top Ramen days.

Quite a long wait, though. Not sure if there's ever a better time to swing by.
author: Anna R.

description:
We got the handmade gyoza based off some of the recommendations here on help.  While it was pretty good gyoza, its nothing special in my opinion.

We also got the ramen... very tasty!  The noodles were cooked perfectly and the broth was not too salty.  Even though it was a big serving, it still felt light.  We also got the chicken curry which I thought was just OK.  The curry was a little thick for my tastes (but flavor was there!)

I forgot the name of the roll, but it was shrimp tempura with spicy salmon on top... and it was DELICIOUS.  Writing this review is actually making me crave it right now.  Damn.

Also - they offer 15 dollar pitchers of Sapporo which got us pretty good and toasty.  Reasonably priced considering we got about 4 glasses in there.

Yes, the place is quite small and 3 of us had to share a tiny tiny table.  It was all in the experience though and I'm glad we got to try this place out.  Definitely a thumbs up.
author: Nikki M.

description:
No fair, it must be an off night but why me?!?!

We found a space just doors away and figured it was our lucky day, nope.  Hubby hasn't been but I told him it was good and the ramen is a must, blab..blab...blab...  We walked in and there were 2 seats at the sushi bar - lucky day, right? nope.  After getting a cold draft Sapporo draft each ($5), we saw the table at the front window corner was empty - lucky day, right?  nope.

We didn't end up ordering too much - lucky day, right?  perhaps!   What we did order and what brought them down to 3 stars.

Extra Spicy Ramen - I was so excited to taste it again and kept telling hubby how good it will be.  It looked and smelled good but as soon as I pull a string of noodles, I know something was not right.  The noodles were limpy, lifeless, droopy...overcooked!  I was beyond disappointed and the broth (miso rich) was not thick and rich as I remembered.  Boo!  Sorry hubby.

tuna and hamachi sashimi - tuna was ok but the hamachi tasted "thawed".  
salmon sashimi - not bad
shiro maguro nigiri - ok
butter fish nigiri - ok

Just a really really off night or ?!?  I shuddered at the thought...
author: Gloria H.

description: I don't see what the hype is over the ramen in this restaurant. I ordered the regular ramen with a rich shio broth and a side of spicy tofu don.  The spicy tofu don was alright, but I thought the regular bbq pork ramen was very flat.  The piece of pork belly in my ramen also tasted stale.
author: Kai C.

description:
The Ramen is good, but not great.  Between 3 and 4 stars.  

When I first had ramen, I thought the ramen was fantastic but as i tried another places, I still would come here (close to work)  but always feel that I'm missing something from the ramen.  It's probably in the broth..where it has decent flavor, but not as rich as I prefer from other places.  Noodles are not consistent, as i prefer them chewy and sometimes it's not.  maybe that's why these days I get the miso broth or salt broth - 'rich' and extra spicy.    The extra flavorings helps make up for the broth.  Not bad...just not great.

The variety is good with the donburi's and sushi.  Plus they close really late... would come here after going out to the bar.
author: Vien C.

description:
This place made me a ramen fan, but its sushi is great too.

Stumbling down Geary on a rainy Tuesday night, starving, I saw a small crowd in front of Katana-Ya's unassuming storefront and remembered I'd always wanted to go there, but there was always a huge line. Since I was alone I slipped in the door and asked about a sushi bar seat, and voila, there was one right there for me. (FYI they have 5 sushi bar seats so I think that makes a single "leftover" seat for the solo diner more likely). 

I wasn't sure how or what to order, and I'm not really a noodle or soup fan, I mean, my thoughts about soup in general are that it's something to make less food seem like more food, you know? Like, add salty water and your stomach thinks you ate twice as much. I like *value* in my food. So I've generally avoided ramen, but everybody was having it and their menu seemed to foreground it. I will say the menu was a bit confusing, with a crazy front page illustrating various noodle combos in a big circular diagram, and so I just said to the waitress, what should I get, I'm hungry. She said the namesake ramen is a favorite, and I said I wanted some nigiri too and she seemed skeptical that I would be able to eat that much but I assured her I would be fine. However my initial idea of two sets of nigiri was talked down to one, and thank God she did, because what I got was a lot of food.

First of all the hamachi was smooth and buttery, big slabs of fish on little clumps of rice. I realized suddenly that I'd been eating sub-par sushi so much lately (sorry, We Be) that I'd forgotten how good hamachi can be. 

Then, the ramen. The house-named ramen features fried chicken, a couple gyoza, half an egg, copious seaweed and green onion, and much much more, and a rich miso broth that absolutely exploded my concept of soup-as-a-watery-cheat. This was rich, dense, flavorful, *food*, and I devoured the giant bowl, paid like $30 for the sushi, ramen and a quality bottle of sake, and stumbled happily out into the rain, which didn't even bother me, because my brain was bathing in delicious warm broth. Hooray ramen.
author: Ben G.

description: One of the better Ramen places in the city. The house special katana ya Ramen is the best.
author: Vikram D.

description:
3.5 stars

It's a cold and rainy Saturday afternoon, perfect day for ramen right?  Yes, but NOT at Katana-Ya.  If you're ok with waiting in the rain for 30ish minutes then be my guest.

This was both mine and my BFs first time here.  After reading the Yelp reviews I had high expectations of the ramen and low expectations of the sushi.  We actually did order some hamachi nigiri and it was actually very good.  I wonder if the previous Yelpers were reviewing the rolls and not the quality of the actual fish?

Ok, now it's ramen time!  I ordered the "rich" Katana ramen, with "soy" broth and my BF got the BBQ pork ramen in the same rich, soy broth.  I should have known to ask them to put the fried chicken and the gyozas on the side--mushy fried things don't = good.  I got two pieces of each so we each tried one.  Other than that, and some corn, those were the only differences between mine and what my BF got.  

We finished both completely, minus some broth.  The girl sitting next to us vocalized how amazing it was to see my BF finish his whole bowl.  Now how could anyone take that the wrong way?  Haha.  But after his, we finished mine and surprisingly I left a little bit hungry so we went to go find dessert.  I'm small and if I can polish off a whole bowl of ramen then I can't see why a 10 y/o kid couldn't or a full grown adult male too.  Haha!

The ramen was good, but not good enough to fight downtown traffic and wait in the cold rainy entrance way for 30 mins.  Next time I'll go find some ramen in Japantown.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Eww.   In San Fran for a business trip, and figured that this city, this metropolis, this gestalt of varied urban denizens will have the Holy Ramen I seek.  I yelp, find a place, and see it has four stars.  AND it's two blocks away:  boosh.  I get here and there's a 20 minute wait, but don't care.  

I am a tonkotsu ramen fan, but I saw the reviews raving about their house ramen, so I ordered that.  Bad mistake.  Dumplings tasted old, chicken was tough and flavorless, and broth was "meh.". To top it off, service blew:  waiter was slow to take order and needed a tranquilizer dart gun to get the check from him.  

I don't know why NoCal folks like this place, but this SoCal boy was not enamored.  Like, at all.  

I'd avoid it and try somewhere else.  Yuck.
author: Jim H.

description:
Came here last night with some friends around 7, and it was already packed. We waited about 15 minutes before we were seated. It's really small inside, so the tables are pretty small as well. We were just a party of 3 and the food we ordered barely all fit on the table.

I got the Kim Chee ramen, it wasn't bad at all. For some reason my broth tasted slightly sweet, but aside from that, it was very tasty. Now I don't have to drive all the way to Santas for ramen! We shared some appetizers, the calamari and and some rolls. The calamari was VERY good. The dynamite roll was a pretty good size as well. Spider roll was tasty to me since I've never gotten that roll, but my friend who usually orders that roll said it was alright. Oh, we also got a pitcher of beer, so that made the meal that much better.

Overall, the food was good, just wish the location wasn't so small since I kept getting my seat bumped into, which was a bit irritating.
author: Johnson S.

description:
Yesterday I was anticipating my Ramen dinner all day. I asked friends, read other reviews and decided to give "Kantana" a try. It is a small space and great location close to Union Square. The noodles seemed fresh and the soup overall had a great flavor. 

Only concern - MSG. The menu states "MSG Added". When I asked about this - the staff explained you can have it without MSG - but I am not clear about how if the ingredients are cooked with it ... how do they avoid it in the soups. I tried to clarify this - and was told it is added or not. 

While I did enjoy my soup - I have some after effects of MSG today-  so I conclude there *might* have been some MSG in the food. 

If you have no MSG food issues - then have at it!!!! YUM!
author: Andrew K.

description:
I have gone here 3 times so far. It is located conveniently near my work, even though I only ate here once during work. 

My coworkers introduced me to this hole in the wall ramen house and fell in love first sip i took. I ordered the fried chicken in miso broth ramen. It has since become my usual. The service here is decent. And out of he 3 times  I have been here I only had to wait once, unfortunately that was when I was on my lunch break, so we were in a time crunch. The other 2 times it was little to no wait, but it did get pretty busy after arriving, so I like to say I made good timing.

I don't have much else to say, other than their ramen is really good. However it is only good hot and fresh, I took some left overs home and it had a strong fish taste after it set for a while. I am not a huge seafood fan but it definitely didn't taste like that when i first ordered it.
author: Mandi S.

description:
My girlfriend took me here for dinner because she said it's definitely the place to go for tasty ramen in that particular area of San Francisco.  I'm going to deduct a star right away for the wait time -- we had to wait nearly twenty minutes (if not more, I don't quite remember) for a table, but at the same time, the place is small and was very busy.  It wasn't really that bad, I suppose, but I do question why tables were cleared off and empty without being utilized again for the next customers all that promptly.  In any case, when we did sit down, the service was pretty decent and friendly.  Most of my stars go to the food -- my unagi don was amazing!  The unagi (eel) was absolutely melting in my mouth, which is a sure sign of fantastic eel.  I can' even recall the last time I had eel that good.  The miso soup was also tasty, and my girlfriend loved her ramen as well.  Great broth.  

They are open 'til 1 AM, so if you need to go somewhere for a late dinner, this is a recommended choice.  I'm not sure how busy they are later on into the night, though; I went at about 7 PM.
author: Olga P.

description: Where else are you able to get a Ramen 1am in the morning? No where.  Even in Japan the Ramen places are closed before that.  I was in the mood and got a Shoyu Ramen at 1.  I chatted with the sushi chef Gabbi.
author: Jim J.

description:
It's places like Katana-ya that make me love being a city gal! The only other place I've been to for ramen is Ramen Dojo in San Mateo and the wait as well as the food left me weary of whether I even liked ramen in the first place. 

Thank you Katana-ya for bringing me back to the nostalgia of tasty noodles in the most delighting broth! I had the BBQ pork ramen with rich soy sauce broth and it was delicious! Everything was just right and I love that there wasn't too many fru-fru condiments. Just pork, daikon, broth and noodles. LOVE! 

I went on a Tuesday night and there was still a crowd but surprisingly the wait was not too long. I'd say 20-25 minutes at most because the staff knows how to hurry their patrons along. I will most definitely be back!
author: Crystal C.

description:
My friend and I checked this place out since it was from the 7x7 magazine. It wasn't such a pleasant trip there since it was cold and raining, but the upside was hearing the roars of people in result of the Giants wining the World Series and our meal which I will get to later.

This place is really busy, and it doesn't help that the place is small. We waited for at least 30 minutes if not more until we were seated, and I personally didn't like our seating since it was near the stairs to what I believe was their storage room, not to mention it was a bit cramped. The upside to this place was it having a cozy and lively atmosphere.

Now down to the FOOD! We both ordered the BBQ Pork Ramen, and you can't expect much since it is ramen after all. The size was adequate, but they definitely could have done better for the cost of the meal. The slices of pork had a interesting flavor, but they only had about five slices which was not enough for my hunger! :( The broth was another story.. I don't know how, but it was really really good and I don't know how to put it any other way. The noodles tasted like Udon and although it wasn't up to par to my tastes, it was significantly different than the noodles I've had before.

Overall experience was decent and the service was mediocre. I wouldn't come back to this place unless they decided to get a bigger place since waiting in the cold for 30 minutes is not awesome.
author: Richard C.

description:
I find this place to be grossly overrated, and I didn't have to wait at all, plus it was cold outside, so that should tell you something.

First off, it took me nearly 10 minutes to even get a menu or some water, and I was sitting by the hostess stand. It took another 17 minutes (yes I counted) for a waitress to come by and take my order. Seriously? Mind you, the place wasn't even full at this point.

I ordered the BBQ pork ramen with miso broth and I was underwhelmed. First, aside from the 4 slices of pork sitting on top, there isn't much else besides noodles. Second, the soup was overly salty, and definitely had that MSG taste. I don't think I even ate half of it, it just wasn't appetizing at all.

So to recap: overpriced, meh food, bad service. I should have gotten pho instead.
author: Sarah Z.

description: Katana-ya is pretty decent. Their sashimi salad is sooo good and they're pretty generous with the sashimi they throw in there- salmon, tuna, shrimp, octopus, and hamachi. (about 8 to 10 pieces) I actually prefer it over the ramen. Their ramen is good too but it didn't leave a marked impression. Parking around the area sucks so bring quarters or you just might have to park it in a lot. Since the ramen house is small expect to wait in line, but don't you fret, I never had to wait for more than 30 minutes.
author: Jenny K.

description:
For first timers, get Katanaya Ramen.  Rich.  Miso.  That's all you need to know.  I got the soy, because I'm normally not a miso fan.  Tried my friend's and had major food-envy.

The Katanaya has all the fixins, so it's good for the first time out, but next time I'll get the sweet butter corn.
author: Jess F.

description:
Have you ever been so hungry that you don't even know what you're craving?  You just want to shove food in your face and hope that gnawing hunger will go away?  That's how I felt when my friends and I walked into Katana-Ya, and now this place will be burned into my brain as the place that successfully quenched my hunger with a happiness and great flavor.

After much deliberation, I decided upon the Ramen-Donburi combo, got the soy ramen and katsudon (deep fried pork with egg over soy sauce rice), my friends got the soy ramen with kimchi and miso ramen with tempura-don.  We also go the karaage chicken.  I have to say, I was completely delighted with everything, and since we went in the early afternoon on a Tuesday, it wasn't busy.  Everything was made really fresh and it was piping hot.  Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area.
author: Asha H.

description: Best Ramen I've ever had.  I've never seen the option to choose your broth density before.  I chose dense and I would recommend that option!
author: Bassman Z.

description:
I normally don't like giving a business bad reviews but this place was just horrible. I came without any expectations as me and my bf were just trying to look for a place to eat around the area that's open on a Sunday and we came across this restaurant. 
My bf ordered the spicy miso ramen and I got the deep friend chicken miso ramen. The portions were big but the ramen itself was nothing more than average if evn that. What really made me give them the one star though isn't the food but the service. So right after our food arrived, my bf noticed a cockroach crawling on their mirror that was right behind me. So we called over the waitress and asked her to take care of the cockroach. However, she disappeared in the back and I felt super uncomfortable to eat my food while a gigantic cockroach was right behind me. So I got up from my seat, and at that point, the two other waitresses noticed the cockroach too. But nobody did anything about it! I stood there for over 5 min before one of the waitresses brought out a guy cook from the back to kill the cockroach. Nobody seemed to want to do anything about it, but the cook was kinda forced to take care of it so he stepped onto my seat to get the cockroach. Afterwards, everyone just pretended like nothing happened. I didn't get an apology, they didn't wipe my seat after having it be stepped on or anything. Needless to say,
I did not enjoy my meal and I will not be coming back again.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
I would give this place 3-1/2 stars if I could...I read about this place here on Yelp and had heard about it word of mouth from others, but I thought it was a-ok plus.  I was really hungry when we came here for lunch, so I scanned the menu at the ramen, udon, but was really happy to see the lunch specials that are $10-13 (reasonable!) with a choice of ramen, udon or soba with a choice of another entree.  

I ordered the udon and the grilled salmon don - I completely enjoyed the salmon over rice (tasty, salty just right, good flavoring with nori and ginger), but the udon was eh...ok.  Honestly, I didn't care for the udon broth (sort of tasted smokey, kind of like they cooked bbq near it) although the noodles were cooked just right and were the right consistency.  We also ordered the strawberry shave ice with condensed milk on top - not as good as the ones I have had in Hawaii (they know how to make these right!), but it was a good, cool cap to our meal.

I would stop by if I was in the area, but I don't know if I would go out of my way to go here.
author: Maile N.

description: We came here after watching Peter and the Starcatcher at the Curran, this was right across the street and so naturally we came here for a bite.  My ramen was good, not particularly amazing.  My lady had the curry rice, which was also not bad.  It does have quite the kick and it comes with miso soup.  Health score is at 88, which did make her nervous.  But so far we remain unscathed.
author: ML ..

description:
A friend to took me here one late Friday night in an attempt to sober up.

I'm not really a fan of ramen so I thought I'd just order the regular and requested a richer broth.  My friend had the spicy onion.  I was surprised, soup is very tasty, rich indeed and I actually liked the noodles.  After tasting from my friend's bowl, I regretted to have not scanned the menu better and ordered the spicy onion instead.  Soup was not as rich but it was spicy good.  More suits my taste.

Next time I'm in the area, I'll come back to Katanaya for more ramen.
author: Pam S.

description: After 7x7 published their annual Big Eats list of the Top 100 Foods in SF, I rushed to Katana-Ya to try the now-famous Chasu ramen.  It was definitely a treat, but I'm not sure I could recommend the relatively long wait outside or the rather plane atmosphere inside.  Prices are reasonable and service (once seated) is quick, so if it wasn't for the long lines, this would be a great neighborhood restaurant for noodles.
author: Greg B.

description:
KATANAYA RAMEN - BEST I EVER HAD.

The ramen noodles are perfection. I got the miso base with medium spice. If you're into spice, get medium because it doesn't overwhelm the soup. Good balance of salt and spice. 

Egg, fried chicken, fried wonton, beef slices, corn.....how can you say no?!!! The fried chicken and fried wonton are so delicious, probably because they were perfectly fried. And the corn with the miso and noodles? PERFECT. 

I know I keep using the word perfect, but that's what I kept thinking in my head. Every taste, every bite, I thought to myself - YES THIS IS SO FREAKING GOOD! 

Tip: Eat the fried wonton early. Don't wait til the last minute to eat it because in my opinion, it tasted better when it was freshly fried as opposed to when it became kind of soggy. 

I never usually crave what I ate the day before, but I woke up this morning wishing I could go back and order again! 

My table enjoyed our server too. He does rush you, but think of it this way, you get your food faster! He was really nice and doesn't mean to be rude when he bombards you with his fast speech. But it does suck that the restaurant is small. I felt cramped.....but damn, that ramen was soooo worth it!
author: Stephanie B.

description: Tiny place but good service and better ramen. A must try if you are in the Union Square area. A refreshing change from the usual fare around the square.
author: John-Ashley P.

description:
Came for a quick client lunch and was pleasantly surprised....this place gives sushi Yasuda a run for the money back in NY...

the fish was fresh, my tea was well filled, and I walked away full and happy
author: Renee M.

description:
Came here for the first time with my cousin last month... came here again a few weeks later. 

This place is good if you want a quick fix of ramen or asian food. The taste is pretty stellar and the portions are huge. First time I came, I ordered the fried chicken ramen which was pretty good, the chicken was delicious and the ramen was well flavored. Second time, I got the normal ramen with the Salmon Don. The Salmon Don was kind of warm and I don't think the sushi is too great here. My friend got the soba though and loved it.

I will come again if I want a quick lunch or something but besides that probably won't be coming here too often. Not bad but not amazing.
author: T L.

description:
Decent Ramen place, kind of expected more for the area. 

To be more specific.... The soup stock wasn't donkotsu. It was still greasy. They charge extra to make it spicy. The noodles were ok. Not too thick or too thin. The egg was overcooked and.... what else?

What can I say about these ramen shops that don't offer anything particularly special but still tug at my heartstrings?

I'd still go to them. That's what.
author: Dominic C.

description: I had the katanaya ramen here and while i appreciated the variety in my bowl of ramen (fried chicken and potstickers), there wasn't really anything special with each item. Once you begin to focus on each item in your bowl of ramen you will realize everything is average to below average. the broth, noddle, meat, and everything else is just average.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Another great Yelp recommendation, we ventured a few blocks over to eat the famous ramen at Katana-Ya.  Indeed, the ramen broth was very therapeutic in all its spicy and brothy goodness.

It is a small easy-to-miss joint, more like a store with tables than the a restaurant given its petite size.  Service is managed by one, but enough due to the managable number of tables.  We went around 3, an uncommon time for a meal, yet there were about three other tables.

From the recommendations given, we ordered the spicy tofu ramen with the miso broth (photo), and the spicy tuna-covered california rolls (photo).  The broth was definitely evident that it was marinated carefully over time; "miso" broth is not to be confused with miso soup, which can be a quick stir of some bean curd and hot water with sprinkles of tiny tofu cubes.  No, this broth was different - the kind of stew you would savor and wonder, did the Japanese have a stew culture?

The bits of kimchi gave a crunch to the spiciness, although I am giving this four stars because I yearned for more crunch.  The tofu was the 1/2 inch thin, widely sliced tofu undressed, but I enjoy tofu of all kinds.  The ramen was a bit more thick, coarse consistency.  I ate about 70% of the tofu, kimchi and broth, and about 40% of the ramen.  Portion sizes were huge, however (the large bowls are brought out by hand and I can see the server's biceps bulge as she maneuvers one in each hand), so this is no indication of the tastefulness of the ramen.  

The spicy tuna california roll on its own I would give three stars for, just because I thought the consistency of the spicy tuna was decently comparable to what everyone else serves.  However, we came for the ramen, and the ramen we would come back for again.

Two ramens and the roll appetizer came out to about $24.
author: Theresa K.

description: Very small and cozy but don't let that fool you! This little hole in the wall is amazing! Fresh sushi and Ramen noodles (not the kind you lived off of in college) that are out of this world. Ill def be back!!!
author: Brian M.

description: The food was alright but the service was horrible. Our server was really rude and impatient. The tables were also too small, our party of 4 could hardly fit 4 entrees and 4 drinks on the table. We won't be going back.
author: Courtney L P.

description: Is it really that great?? Crazy busy, which is good. Food is served faster than you can eat it.  Seriously, I mean McD's fast. Tables are stupid small. I get the small location and tight quarters thing. Heck even Japan has larger areas to sit. Anyway, three of us did a business dinner out and it was 100 without booze. Food was fine, not magical. Better ramen and so a elsewhere. I trusted the 2900 reviews as a good measure of the food to come. I was mistaken.  If they served it slower, pushed, no offered sake or beer we could have spent a couple hours and dropped 400, but they'd rather change tables quickly for the next 10 dollar ramen buyer. Dumb.
author: John C.

description: I had the Katanaya ramen, which is kind of the kitchen sink ramen- with fried chicken, gyoza, corn, and pork in soy soup. It was pretty good, but I have to say that fried chicken and gyoza in ramen sounds better than it really is. I think I should have taken my friend's advice and ordered the spicy tofu ramen. So overall, not bad, and the noodles were very good and chewy, but I thought the broth lacked depth. I wouldn't be opposed to trying this again.
author: Terry N.

description:
After finding this restaurant on Yelp earlier last year, I decided to go check it out because I had a craving for ramen. 

There was a long line, which I had already expected since we knew it was a good restaurant. There was a janky looking clipboard where we had to sign up for reservations, and we had to wait a good while until we got seated. 

There's a menu outside, near where the clipboard is, so we took the time to decide what we wanted to get speedier service inside. 

There's more than just ramen, but the restaurant is famous for their ramen --  it's not something you should miss, at all. 

The ramen is specialized in how you get a couple of selections, one for the richness of the broth, the spice, and the additional ingredients (meat or no meat). I ordered a miso (rich) broth, spicy, with onion. It was heavenly. My partner had a light broth with kimchee, and he gobbled it up as fast as I did.

There is soy sauce and the spicy Japanese powder already on the table, so you can add to your heart's content if there isn't enough flavor. I added a bit of the powder, but realized after I tried the ramen that nothing else needed to be added. 

The portions are large, and the prices aren't too bad. It's around ~$10 for a bowl here, but it's definitely worth it.  I haven't had any better ramen since.
author: Vivian L.

description:
I found out about this place from 7x7 magazine and decided to come here after work with my friend. It was a rainy and cold night, the same night that SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS WON THE WORLD SERIES!!!!!!!! YEAH!!! Anyways... it was a long line when we got there, and we waited for about 30 minutes until we were seated. The inside was pretty and packed together. the tables were very close together and very little walking space, but it was a warm little cozy spot.

My friend and I order the BBQ Pork ramen with miso soup base and we wasn't expecting much. However, when we tasted it, it was pretty good. the miso soup base is really good and the Pork was on the leaner side of the bunch. it wasn't bad, it was prefect for a rainy and cold night. 

The only downside was that it cost 12 dollars for a bowl, and they only gave us 5 slices of BBQ pork, which was clearly not enough for a growing boy like myself. I only wish the price was a little cheaper, that they will give us more meat and that we don't have to wait outside for so long to get seated!! Get a bigger place!!!
author: Daniel L.

description:
3.25
Better than I expected but doesnt compare to the quality of santa, orenchi, or ramen dojo a little bit down south

Katanya Ramen
Regular ramen with 3 pieces of chicken karaage, 2 pieces of gyoza, corn,  1/2 boiled egg. Got the salt flavor extra heavy although it still tasted watered down. The chicken and gyoza were decent but eat it fast before they become soggy. The noodles were around the same quality as santa ramen: nice and chewy texture. 

Mabo Ramen
Good flavored ramen with a very slight sweet and spicy kick. The tofu and ground pork like gravy sauce mixed with the broth makes it quite unique and flavorful. I would choose this flavor over the katanya one. Noodles were consistently good in both ramens.

Overall not bad ramen although it doesnt compare to the ones outside sf. This is a candidate for best ramen in sf but thats not saying much.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I cannot believe I haven't given Katana-Ya a review yet. Whenever I'm in the vicinity, I always come to Katana-Ya for good ol' ramen. I don't mind the wait. But just to inform you, it's a small place and the wait can be anywhere from 10 minutes to 45 minutes. I don't think wait has ever reached an hour because service is very fast. Best not to come in groups larger than 4 or you'll sit in separate tables.

Honestly, I've never looked at other menu choices except for the ramen. I went with my dad once and he ordered a rice meal with his ramen and split it with me. But I honestly cannot remember what the rice meal tasted because I was focused on the ramen. 

I always order the miso ramen, which is exactly what you need on an especially cold day. Toppings are never scrimped on and they are absolutely tasty. Service is always good and staff is always friendly. They rush you with your food but gently so you can still enjoy it. 

It's best to arrive during non-peak hours, right when they open at 11:30am and after 2:30pm and probably anytime after 9pm.
author: Jaclyn A.

description: Ordered katsu don and ramen here. Definitely had much better. Absolutely did not like the bamboo shoots in the ramen and did not like the ginger in my katsu don. Totally distracted me from the flavor of everything else in there. Pork was tender in the katsu-don...maybe if ginger wasn't placed in there it probably would have been better. They also gave me a lot of rice compared to the pork so I had a lot of rice left. The portions were big though so I was still full. There was a very long wait for this place...don't think it's worth the wait.
author: Liwei Y.

description:
Expect to wait! There is usually always a line, but that's just a sign that it's a good restaurant, right? RIGHT!

I dig the vibe and the Jamiroquai that's on repeat for sure. I always get the chasu ramen with extra spicy miso soup; it's the best.

I've been to many different ramen places all over the yay, and this spot keeps me coming back every time I'm in the City.
author: Ed P.

description:
Best ramen.

Just get it any way you want as long as it's spicy.
author: Fat T.

description:
Hungry after a Friday concert out of town, we needed some late night eats.  And  we were talking about our last trip to NYC and Momofuku Noodle Bar, so I was craving ramen... Katana-Ya here we come!

Even at 12:25am, there were 2 couples on the wait list before us.  We waited 15 minutes then got seated.  The room is very small, so expect to wait.

They have a rather large selection of options including many items to add, broth type, and flavoring.  We went with the BBQ Pork Ramen and the Katanaya Ramen, in miso broth and spicy.  

Both were very good and the ramen noodles were cooked perfectly.  I would have preferred it be a bit more salty, however I did choose the spicy and not salty option.  We also had the chicken karaage (fried chicken) and it was tasty as well.  

We will definitely be back, even though it's crossed off the 7x7 list now!
author: David D.

description:
Solid ramen joint.  I really like that they give you so many options to customize your bowl with add-ins and order it to suit your personal tastes.  For example, you can get miso, soy sauce, or salt broth, thin or thicker consistency, and varying levels of spiciness.

Pluses: fried chicken in the ramen and lots of options.  Fairly authentic Japanese taste.  Friendly waitstaff.  Open late!

Minuses: Cramped atmosphere.  Flavor of the ramen still not quite as good as Ippudo (NY).
author: Bryce G.

description:
What I love about this place is that you can specifically request how rich you want your broth to be. In Japan, most places usually make their broths super rich, and I have been constantly searching for a place that emulates that best. I guess American's like their ramen to be on the lighter side, but hey. As long as I can get my rich creamy miso broth, I'm good. 

I also really like the fact that you can pair up your ramen with another donburi bowl of whatever you like. It ends up being so much food, that I dare you to finish it. 

The place gets minus a star because I wasn't a huge fan of the noodles. I thought that they were a bit hard. 

I still would go back though, just because the miso is just that delicious.
author: maria g.

description: Sushi is really fresh and tasty. But the real reason many come here is for the ramen. I remember this place to be first introduction to great ramen. But since then their ramen quality had plummeted. For a quick bite is fine but it's not worth waiting on line for.
author: anil b.

description: Dry chewy pork. The soba is meh. Tempura too heavy, not light as it should be.  That about sums it up.
author: Christine L.

description:
Came here for lunch today and it was delicious. Plus I've been craving it for such a long time, but it's a small trek to get here from work. So worth it though! 

I came here at around 1:15 and there was no line with empty tables. Perfect. Usually around lunch, you have a good 10-15 minute wait.

Got the mobo ramen which is ground pork and tofu in a spicy sauce. Pretty good! They are kinda stingy with the pork but I realized it wasn't ground pork, it was slices of pork shredded into bits and they were just at the bottom of the bowl. 

It's definitely not as spicy as I wanted but it was sure tasty! Will be back!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
When they closed down the one near UCSF, I was absolutely heartbroken. But one day I was cruisin' around downtown, and they're still around!!!! I just about flipped! 

I love getting the ramen noodles in miso soup with chicken karaage.
I always ask for the chicken karaage on the side so that it stays crispy.
author: Erma B.

description:
Not sure if it's worth the wait and cramped quarters.
Broth is rich, but salty and we had to request hot water to help dilute it. Noodles are nice and tender though. 

Overall satisfying, but partly based on hype (just look at all the autographed photos!).
author: Ashley K.

description:
I love their ramen!  This place has sushi as well but their ramen is pretty darn good.  Also open late but always has a line out the door.

I think i'll return and try their sushi in the near future.
author: Patrick C.

description:
For years I have passed by this restaurant whenever I was shopping in the Union Square area. I am thankful for a friend who wanted us to check this place out, so we did, with the thought of ordering some delish ramen! 

The restaurant is a TINY place. It's nicely decorated, but you WILL hit elbows with other customers! There are a lot of mirrors at the place, too. 

The waiting staff have thick Japanese accents, but you will have no problem placing orders. They are use to the tourists who stop by their restuarant, so they are super friendly. 

SO. We ordered the regular ramen, miso base and it was milky-good! Though a bit salty for my taste, it was still very good. We also ordered a Sashimi Bowl with Rice. The sashimi was fresh and fairly tasty. 

For both dishes, it was about $40. Not super cheap, but it was good food.
author: Melinda L.

description:
Delicious broth, perfectly textured noodles, great vegetable ingredients - the katana-ya ramen could have been better with the fried chicken and gyoza on the side though... they ended up a little soggy.  

Maybe it was the crisp San Francisco air, but this warm soup hit the spot.
author: Ken P.

description:
There is no tonkatsu broth here, which is too bad.  Your choices are soy, miso, and salt.  You also have the choice of rich, regular, or light broth.  I usually go soy and rich.  Not sure why anyone would go light, akin to ordering a lean pastrami sandwich.

The noodles here are decent, but I think the noodles at Suzu are better.  The broth at Suzu, though, leaves a lot to be desired.

The reason for four stars is because of the cold ramen they serve during the summer.  I ate here two days in a row recently, one day cold ramen and the other day regular ramen, and I definitely prefer the cold ramen.  The noodles are in a delicious dipping sauce, topped with chicken karaage, pork strips, omelette, seawood, veggies, pickles, and mustard.  The dipping sauce is solid.
author: David C.

description:
Oh, the days before this place was ousted into the Yelp world!

The waiting used to not be as bad (now it's an average 30-40 minute?).   Always a summertime favorite, when chilly SF lets you crave some warm Ramen in town!

The place is really small.. about 8 tables?  And small tables at that-- each table seats just two people.  The bar seats another 6-8..?  I mean, if I brought all of my friends, we would still have like 3 chairs left over, but I'd think that most people couldn't use this place as a venue.

The ramen here is one of the best I've had.  If you like Shin Ramen (yes, the one that comes in a bag), then you'd love this place.  If you love Maruchan (yes, the cup kind that you used to eat to save money), then this might be too salty for you.

They really know how to heat up the spice without making it saltier.  Most other restaurants do that.  A richly flavored soup, without the salt, and plenty of chopped green onions floating around... getting the jist of this? Yum!

Price is decent (~$9 per bowl), though it's jumped in the past 2 years.

Also recommended: Donburi.
Not really recommended:  Sushi rolls (not very big here!)

Also recommended:  Santa Ramen (in San Mateo).
author: Eugene L.

description:
So I went her last week on a Thursday and there was about 10 people standing outside.  They do a written wait list.  I got there early, so I put my name down, ran up the street to the Clift and grabbed a drink.

First off, I am not a huge fan of Ramen, but this place had a lot of good reviews.  Also, I didn't chose it- she did. haha.

I had the BBQ Pork Ramen- which is less like a "cha-seiu"/bbq pork and more like a braised pork.  It was pretty good.  Had other standard japanese necessities... sake, asahi, sashimi- All decent.

Lastly, we had chicken karrage/fried chicken.  The pieces were a little bigger than I am used to for chicken karrage- but it tasted great.

Service was good and fast.  The host/waiter was cracking jokes and was really nice throughout the night.

If you have time/patience to wait for about 30 minutes and you like ramen- definitely check this place out.
author: Travis L.

description: My cousin recommended this place to my friend and i from what she told us it was a great place to eat ramen. I have never had ramen other then the packaged ones that you cam do at home. Anyways I ordered just a regular ramen soup and extra spicy and it was delicious! I will be coming back very soon to have some ramen. The staff were very friendly and the overall atmosphere was nice and cool.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I really wanted to like Katana-Ya. Living in San Francisco I really wanted a local place for me to go to for my ramen fix. I was really really disappointed.

The 45 minute wait at peak dinner time was as expected for a place that was touted to be "the best in the city" and it only heightened the anticipation for me. Alas, it only set me up for disappointment.

I ordered the shoyu chasu broth and it was way too salty and had a slight viscosity that I associated with not so good noodles. The slaty broth basically overpowered the rest of the bowl and for the first time in Karen's ramen history I could not finish the ramen.

I'm sure Katana-Ya is "the best in the city" as it is definitely tough to find good ramen. However, once you've tried maruichi, orenchi, santouka or kahoo (all in the south bay) you really can't go back to qualifying what you look for in your ramen.
author: Karen K.

description:
Update- they changed the menu!  No more ramen/donburi combos, so a bowl of ramen will set you back about $10.  Not as great of a deal as before, but still worth it.

If  I have to choose between noodles or rice, I go for the former every single time.  My roots were formed in a country where a hefty bowl of noodle soup (usually the curry type!) is considered the breakfast of champions.  And thus I'm seem to always be craving something similar.

So being that I'm often wandering about Union Square, I'm on the constant lookout for a cheap-but-tasty place for said noodles.  King of Thai is alright but can get pretty tiresome after a few times.  This place definitely fits the bill and lives up to it's Yelp reputation.  

The noodle and donburi combos provide a lot of food for under $10- and hey- noodles and rice- you don't even have to choose!  I had the ramen with rich soy broth for maximum flavor, and it was as delicious as I'd hoped.  The noodles were perfectly cooked and the soup was total comfort food.  I don't know how we did it but we polished off the donburi rice, ramen and most of the soup, and some sashimi off the specials board.  No leftovers whatsoever.  Yep, this place definitely works for me.
author: Joanne G.

description: We went searching for ramen and udon on a brisk day.  We were not disappointed.  This place is small but it was worth the short wait.  We sat at the sushi bar and were able to order from the full menu.  I had the BBQ pork ramen (spicy option), miso flavored and it was delicious.  I can see why this place has 400+ reviews.
author: Trina D.

description:
The fish was fresh and good. High turnover should always ensure that. Rolls were standard fare. Not cheap by any means and has a divey ambience. 
People were ordering a lot of Raman so perhaps I missed the reason for going there. Small but not overly noisy.
Not somewhere I would particularly seek out again.
author: Adam O.

description: La fama precede a este restaurante y lo notas en cuanto te acercas por la calle ya que la cola suele ser siempre bastante grande.
