Te apuntas en la lista a la entrada y a esperar tu turno. El lugar es pequeño pero merece la pena la espera. Los ramen en sus múltiples variedades están realmente buenos, no dejes de probarlos!!
author: David Q.

description:
I can't really say anything that hasn't been said before...really amazing ramen. Second best ramen I've ever had; first would be Ippudo in NY, NY which was probably the best noodle soup I've ever tasted...this includes any viet variations such as Pho or Bun Bo Hue etc.

I ordered the "rich" version which was silky and deeply flavored. Perfectly cooked fresh noodles with a little bite and chew to them. Maybe another slice of pork wouldn't hurt..little skimpy on the oink oink.

Be prepared for a wait at almost any time you decide to check this place out.
author: Chow L.

description: Good food, good vibe! What more can one ask? Great place for ramen!
author: J C.

description:
I have been here twice. Gave it a second a chance, and, really, baffled at why it has four stars o__o. Maybe downtown SF doesn't really have a decent ramen place...such that when an establishment...such as this...comes along, it is really...really delicious?

I have nothing really to say about this place, but really disappointed by the quality of food, especially since I had to wait in a 30 min. wait. It is just decent. Perhaps delicious for those who have not had a good, authentic bowl of ramen? Seems to cater to american tastes.
author: Steph K.

description:
I think this is the BEST ramen place i've ever had. 

The servings are so much, and if you get the Katana-Ya Ramen Bowl (might not be the exact name, but the lady referred me to this because I had asked which was the most popular one), It's filled with numerous goodies like the veggies, the chicken, the dumpling, seaweed, and many others. The noodles are so chewy too, and that's when you know it's good!

I walked here from union square, and it's not far. Great place to eat if you're craving Japanese cuisine and not down to pay a whole lot. 

Restaurant granted is a bit small, but the way they seat people is cozy and just right. I would def come back if i was craving for ramen again. 

happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description: Pretty solid ramen especially for those rough hungover mornings. Place is quite small so not great for more than a group of 4. They used to have this mapo tofu ramen that was amazing. I was devastated when I found out they took it off the menu. For the love of god, please bring it back. Now I usually get the kimchi ramen with some pork. Not bad but not the same.
author: Minh N.

description: Best sushi in the city hands down.  It's a little hole in the wall with tiny tables but the sushi is amazing.
author: Snoopy C.

description:
This was my first restaurant since moving to San Francisco. We came on a Friday after work and it was crowded, but only a 15 minute wait. We ended up sitting at the sushi bar.

We ordered a spicy tuna roll (my fave), another roll with avocado, the Katanaya ramen and the deep fried chicken ramen. All of it was delicious. The sushi rolls were large and tasty - especially the one with avocado. The ramen was perfect. Delicious broth. The fried chicken was an interesting choice, but I loved it (confession: I really love fried chicken in general). I'd definitely recommend.

Tip: The ramen comes out very fast - we had hoped to have the sushi rolls as an appetizer and had gotten only one by the time our ramen came out. So plan accordingly!

Environment: tiny - don't bring a whole lot with you. There's tables and some room at the sushi bar. 
Service: efficient but otherwise they leave you alone completely.
author: Kailyn G.

description:
My husband & I visited SF in August 2010, staying at a hotel on the same street as Katana-Ya. We checked their menu simply because they were so close by. We quickly noticed their huge selection of ramen & great prices. We decided to get our food to-go so we didn't have to wait for a table. This is the ONLY location & it is very small, but the food is prepared very promptly & the entire staff is very friendly.

We absolutely adored the ramen we had, customized to our individual tastes. We ended up ordering from Katana-Ya 5 more times during out week-long visit to the city - it is THAT GOOD (and affordable)! Great food, great price, great service, easy-to-find location, but still not a very well-known restaurant - the best of it all! :)
author: Victoria K.

description:
FIrst off, I miss SF!

During my trip in SF, I actually came here twice to get a taste of their wide variety menu.

I tried the ramen, soba, and sushi.

I like how Katana is quite honest with what they put in their dishes. Under the ramen section, they quote "MSG included" Kudos for honesty. 

The soba was great.  Temperature and flavor together was perfect.  I had a spicy tuna and california roll along with my soba and it was very freshly made and well put together meaning the rice and fish was all intact. 

My second visit, I had a Skinny salad ramen which was quite interesting.  Different on the taste buds but an interesting experience.  The noodles are made with tofu and yams all in a ginger soy sauce with tempura vegetables.  

It was a well portioned meal and the noodles were definitely something i've never had before.  I'm not sure that it would be something that I crave but it is definitely something I would try again.  This place is definitely known for their twist of ramen flavors but the skinny ramen salad would be something to try as a healthier option. 

Be adventurous and eat up!
author: Deborah K.

description:
I have been to WAY better ramen places.
The soup base is a little bit too heavy then it should be.
author: Michelle L.

description:
After walking around all afternoon at the Fillmore Jazz Festival -- and still full from brunch (read post below), we opted for a lighter dinner option.

I'm so glad we remembered this place, we've been wanting to check it out for a while now.  We arrived at the restaurant a bit after 6pm and there was already a line! Luckily, we didn't have to wait too long, turnover rate here seems to go by quickly-- minus the bigger parties.

I had the regular ramen with extra corn with the light miso. My bf had their regular ramen with soy sauce + katsudon combo.

Everything was very satisfying. I really enjoyed the noodle texture and the broth!  

I'm so glad we came and checked it out! We both left with out stomach satisfied-- and the wallet wasn't hurting either.
author: Connie C.

description:
I was excited to try their ramen after seeing how many reviews they have on yelp and it still being an overall rating of 4 stars.  

I waited 20 minutes in the rain to try their ramen.  When I finally tried their ramen, I was sooooo disappointed.  The ramen was just OK.
author: Pete C.

description:
3.5 Stars

On a random weekday evening, a NY transplant and a BA native stumbling into Katana-Ya for a night of catching up.  Lucky for us, we arrived at 6pm exactly and took one of the last 2 open tables.  Within 15-20mins of us sitting down, a line began to form outside.

Items ordered:
-Charshi = a large variety of fish sat on top of a verrry large bowl of rice
-Spicy Scallop Roll = mildly spicy with large pieces of scallop, but the roll began to fall apart the moment you tried to pick it up.
-Katana-Ya Ramen = large portions, good soup, noodles were good, but no great.  The chashu was okay.  Had a bit of post-msg thirst set up after a little while... $13 bucks for a bowl of ramen is a bit much.

Total cost of meal = ~$60

Bottomline: large portions, small space, long lines, okay ramen

Overall, it's not bad.  Due to its proximity to my apt, I would probably return, but would have to think twice if I had to wait in that loooong line.
author: E C.

description:
Agedash tofu is good, very good!

Butter corn ramen in miso is also very good! 

I will let the other thousand reviews convince you that you should get it.

Tuesday 6:30pm - no wait, one table left
Tuesday 7:00pm - 3 to 4 groups waiting.

Get here late or get here early!
author: Betty W.

description: This place used to be god. I want to know what happened. They no longer speak Japanese either. Did they change the owner and chef??? They obviously not cooking the ramen the usual way it supposed to
author: Fort Z.

description:
I love the ramen here! The sushi is also really tasty. It is very hard to find parking and when you do, you need so many quarters! There is also usually a decent wait to be seated. You put your name on the waiting list by the door and wait outside. Everyone in your party has to be present when they're ready to seat you. I went here with 6 people and it was cramped, but worked. I wouldn't go with a group more than 6. Seating is better for 2-4 people.

The food is so good! I thought the miso ramen with rich broth was the best. They give you a huge bowl that I could almost never finish. It was always steaming hot and I couldn't wait to eat it so I always burned my tongue, oh well. I would always get their philadelphia roll and it was so fresh. After moving out of state, I miss this ramen place.
author: T B.

description:
How do I review a place that has already been reviewed over 1450 times, and I completely agree with the rating?

Just go. 

Tips for going to this restaurant:

- if you go during a typical dinner hours, expect to wait at least 40 minutes after you write your name down on the clipboard by the door

- fried chicken ramen is their specialty ($10.50 a bowl)

- parties of 2-4 work best, but they will accomodate a larger party (I've seen 7, just make sure everyone is there)

- they do use msg, so I usually go for the "light" miso option for the soup so that I am not ingesting so much sodium
author: Joyce L.

description:
Small hole-in-the wall nook in the middle of SF downtown. Always busy, usually have to wait for about 15 min on any given day. 

* Katanaya ramen* with request for miso broth and extra rich flavor -  This bowl is the KING of all ramens!! It  provides a complete taste of all add-ons thrown in the ramen  bowl - bamboo shoot, corn, half portion of boiled egg, fried dumplings, fried chicken n bbq pork slices all in a bowl of highly rich and flavorful noodle soup. Cant get better than this!!  

The portion is absolutely filling for dinner ($12).
Service is fast, but don't expect ambiance here!!
author: Payal B.

description:
Having spent nearly every summer in Japan as a child and having lived in Tokyo, I have pretty high ramen expectations.  I guess you could call me a donut snob and also a ramen snob haha.  I had heard rave reviews about Katana-Ya, and had always seen this ridiculously long line out the door from 5-9pm.  I mean, to wait 45 minutes-1 hour I figured it had to be spectacular.  And I had also heard that Japanese people worked here, so I figured it must be authentic.  

It was A-Ok.  We ordered the Katana-ya ramen and a veggie ramen in chicken broth.  The noodles are good quality, but the broth is pretty boring.  Further, the ingredients that go in with the ramen were of average quality.  This place is probably popular for those unfamiliar with ramen (i mean, it looks like ramen...smells like ramen), but not the place to go if you know what real ramen is like.
author: Naomi P.

description:
MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload! MSG overload!!!!

Pricy and long wait. Not worth a penny!
author: Niu N.

description:
What a fun place! Waited about 30 mins for a counter spot, and ordered the Fried Chicken Ramen with rich miso broth as well as the Mango Salmon Roll.

Yums! Price is reasonable for a large bowl, the broth was rich and hearty, had my favorite pieces of bamboo, chicken was fried well, and the noodles with the right chew.

Mango salmon roll was good too. I loved the buttery salmon to the slightly tart but sweet mango.

Yay I'd like to come back here again ^^
author: Alice L.

description:
On my recent trip to San Francisco, I decided to try Katana-Ya because my friend had told me they have the best ramen and sushi in the Bay Area. I trekked 15 blocks and waited 20 minutes outside the restaurant thinking that this place better be as good as it's hyped up to be.

I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen with miso broth. The noodles itself were good but I found the broth to taste bland. I had to add a good amount of the spices they had available in the shaker containers on the table. They put pretty much everything in this bowl. Gyoza, fried chicken, tofu, corn, mushrooms, pork, etc. One thing that got to me was why someone would order  fried chicken and fried potstickers and submerge them in broth? Sorry, but I like my fried foods crispy!

The staff was pretty friendly but they want to get you in, take your order, give you your food, and usher you out as fast as they can.
author: Julianne A.

description:
Likes: buttercorn ramen, poki, lollipops at the counter, nice server

Dislikes: the wait
author: Karen M.

description: Do you ever get mentally anguished because of a poorly executed meal after having such high expectations? Mistakes were made. Many. Why are there fried gyozas and chicken in my soup made instantly soggy? Serve on the side, problem solved. Why is my egg hardboiled until green and not soft boiled with a creamy, runny yolk? Why is the soup just salty and not flavourful when it should be opaque made from hours of boiling bones to form gelatinous goodness? Why is my cha siu pork portion so skimpy and just plain boring in taste? I think the noodles were ok. Biggest mistake was trusting recommendations here to go give it a try. I'm not trying to put myself on a pedestal but this is NOT good ramen, please go try ramen at Izakaya sozai and then compare to this. I rather eat kenzo ramen back in Toronto, that's saying alot. Maybe if I had no expectations then maybe I'd leave not as upset but at $12 bucks a bowl, this was just upsetting. (Spoiler alert kenzo is very very unauthentic ramen).
author: Samson T.

description: Ramen here is not as good as it use to be. Maybe it's because it has gotten so busy and always crowded that not enough attention is placed on the food but rather just cranking out the food.
author: just d.

description: Hubby and I went here on our trip to San Francisco for our wedding anniversary. We love Ramen and Yelp did not fail us! I had the miso Katana-ya and it was deeelish! I also tried the spicy tuna rice bowl which was fantastic.  Hubby had the same. Needles to say we were not disappointed and we often find ourselves wishing we could go back. Especially with the rainy weather we've been having.  :)
author: Penny R.

description:
I ate here three years back at midnight while staying at the boutique hotel above the Starbucks next door and remember really loving it, but that was based on the sheer fact that it was so convenient. I'm currently up in the bay area and decided to give it another chance. We got really lucky and snagged the last table without having to wait. 

I ordered the ramen and the salmon don, and both were DELICIOUS! The ramen was perfectly salty and the salmon don was fresh. 

The restaurant itself is cozy and charming. I would go back in a heartbeat!
author: Tiffany G.

description:
Somehow my stomach already knows I'm heading towards the city and yes, getting closer to Katana-ya and it's heavenly ramen. It will let me know it knows by sending out a series of grumbles, growls and moans. 

"Sshhhhh, shhhhh... We're almost there k." I coo to my tummy while rubbing it gently. 

"Babe? Who are you talking to?" 

*snap back to reality* 

"Oh, huh? Oh me? Uhhhh, haha, nobody, nothing... haha.  Man I'm really hungry, how about you? Wanna eat Katana-ya?" 

Success!! We usually manage to find great parking (thank you parking gods for smiling upon us during times like this!) and most of the time find about a 10 to 15 minute wait. Hang in there it's worth it. Don't be tempted by the Jack in the Box next door, just keep your eye on the prize. 

We only order one single item off the menu, every single time. The Katana-ya Ramen. The Katana-ya Ramen has everything in it that you could ever possibly need in a ramen. Crispy pieces of chicken, gyoza dumplings, slices of pork, corn, a ton of noodles, rich miso broth and a hard boiled egg to top it all off. I always like to break that egg up and make the broth even thicker and more creamy (a little tip from my Top Ramen eating days *wink*). 

I would totally recommend you go check this place out. Be there, or be square! Which, I guess if weeerrrre there all the time, you probably would end up being round, if you catch my drift... These are not light soups! 

P.S. A few months ago my Hawaiian relatives were in town from Maui and we took them here to see what they thought, and they absolutely LOVED it!! They couldn't finish their huge bowl, so they even brought it back to the hotel with them to eat later! Awwwww!
author: Miyako L.

description:
The fact that my group of 4 had to face a 1.5 hour wait on a Thursday night for this "Best Ramen in SF" shows just how lacking SF is in the ramen department. 

The wait time, setup and storefront is very similar to LA's Daikokuya, but the ramen is not nearly as flavorful. I got a regular salt ramen combo. I like my broth a little bit creamier, a little less like the kind I can make myself at home. Although the noodles were pretty good, I missed the ramen I'm used to having in LA to notice that much. 

Seating-wise, you're out of luck. There are virtually no tables for groups over 2 people, with a total restaurant capacity of about 20 people.

On the positive side, they have more combination options. I got a side bowl of Ikura/Uni, which is hard to find at restaurants, but always good. 

I would come back here, but not for more than a 20-minute wait. For the best ramen in SF, I was kind of disappointed.
author: Jules C.

description:
Stayed at hotel across the st.  came here based on yelp. there was a line outside, but you sign in inside & the wait was no more than 20 min.  small restaurant, but great service!

food:
their menu was pretty simple & decently priced!  

i ordered their miso ramen regular with fried rice combo.  enjoyed both!  $11

my boyfriend ordered their soy sauce ramen regular with tofu rice bowl (forgot the name).  he enjoyed it, considering he has only eaten ramen once before in so. cal.  his was also $11.

our rice bowls came out sooner than the ramen.  the ramen actually took awhile to get to us, so we asked out server and he gave us a couple of Sapporos on the house for our wait.  

like i said service was great.  the food was enjoyable.  i would come back if i live in sf.
author: Lulu A.

description: I think this ramen place is legit! The wait wasn't too long and the service was really nice. I ordered the Katanaya Ramen and a side that I forgot the name of. The weather was cold and chilly so it was nice to have some hot noodle soup. There were dumplings, eggs, and other condiments that really blended well with the soup. However, I can't really give this place 5 stars because my ramen came out super late and my friend had to wait a good 15 min to eat. Also, the price was a little high for me. Other than that, I really enjoyed the experience!
author: Robert L.

description:
They state on their menu that they use MSG which is fine. I'm glad I had the heads up and it usually doesn't affect me that much. I ordered the fried chicken ramen with extra spicy miso broth. The broth was really thick like it was just regular miso broth with a shit ton of dried pepper flakes. It made the texture a little weird but it was still tasty but halfway through the bowl I got a pounding headache and became really nauseous. This was exacerbated by the blaring top 40 and clubby lighting but I'm not taking my allergic reaction to the mass amounts of msg they must have put in my soup in my review.

The ramen was fine but really expensive and they charged a slightly higher price than stated on the menu. I'll probably come back get get something other than the soup just because it's open late and near my job.
author: Nadia P.

description: Went on concierge reco with kids upon late night arrival. Noodle portions are large and tasty, sushi is very good, staff friendly, service was extremely quick. We sat in "basement" as upstairs was full, ambience not great but OK.
author: Sam J.

description:
It's good ramen for San Francisco....but if you compare it to LA, then that's a different story! Read on. 

I mean, it's not bad at all. The soup base is flavorful and rich, and the ramen noodles are slightly firm (which I absolutely LOVE). But the noodles don't exactly taste fresh, and I can't quite pinpoint what exactly it is about it that doesn't really work. I'm assuming these aren't homemade noodles, and they buy it from somewhere. That's exactly what it tastes like; slightly store bought? Ya dig what I mean? Overall, it was good. Not great. 

To avoid a long wait, come before the rush at dinnertime. We came at 5 pm and there was no wait at all. Score! It's a super super tiny place, so just beware of that!
author: Lauren L.

description: Good ramen w/ bbq pork and boiled egg. I ordered extra spicy, not spicy to me though.   Service was kind and patient, but they did not tell there was a fee for the tip on the bill unless we asked to double-check our bill. Plus, check-out process was slow, almost 20 mins.
author: Yuwu C.

description: It's been over 3 years since I been back and it is the same place that I remember.  Nice little small restaurant (no more than 30 people) - hole in the wall, the pink iPod playing dance music, the lineup outside, the old Japanese sushi chef behind the bar, and the delicious smell of ramen all around you.   I really wanted a bowl of uni ikura don last night but they did not have any uni, I was kind of bummed out but the chirashi don was excellent with the surprise of local crab.   I recommend going if you are in the neighborhood, but this is not a restaurant for all.  If you want upscale go somewhere else.
author: Kyle C.

description:
REASON FOR VISIT: 
I was in town on business, sick with the flu, and staying at the St. Francis.  I was in desperate need for comfort food.

AMBIANCE:
Pretty small, no frills and very casual.  

TIPS:
Get the Katanaya, and if you like spicy, ask for the spicy miso broth. OMFG! This is so tasty, and comes with fried gyoza, chicken karaage, hard-boiled egg.

If you care, the menu says they use MSG. I don't care.

The sushi - meh. Skip it.

If you're not prepared to wait in line for over an hour, avoid peak times. Or do what I did and just order for take-out.


BOTTOM LINE:
This place is a must for tasty ramen soup. Go!
author: Rae R.

description:
Everytime I come here, there's a line and the wait is usually between 30 mins to over an hour. I try my best to come here on non-typical-eating hours, but its still crowded. I think its best they open a new location with more space and try to make more money!

The ramen is really good. I like how they are honest AND upfront with their "we use MSG" statement. Despite the MSG, I still like to eat their food a lot. 

:) This is Bearica's and my favorite food hotspot.
author: Nance H.

description: Great ramen, as everyone in the city already knows. Minus one star for inconvenient wait / capacity.
author: John M.

description:
I'll be extra hard on Katana Ya because of my ridiculously high standard for ramen.

The soup really just isn't as creamy and flavorful as Santouka's, the noodles aren't as fresh tasting as orenchi, and the meat unfortunately doesn't stack up to the aforementioned heavyweights.  The other goods in the soup (pot sticker, corn, and fried chicken) were nice, but definitely not needed in the Katana Ya ramen. I also left with slightly more of a salty aftertaste than Santouka, which really is my threshold.  With the self disclosed msg added, this wasn't much of a surprise.

It's a tiny bit concerning if this is considered the best ramen in SF, as my 2nd tier places south of SF (santa, himawari, halu, kahoo, or maybe even maruichi) are still better in my opinion.  

This bowl of soup would still be nice on a cold day, but i was a bit disappointed when leaving, having the expectations as high as Santouka and Orenchi.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I had always wanted to try Katana-Ya, but it was always too long of a wait for my hungry tummy. (A telltale sign of good food!) I finally had the opportunity to try it last weekend. In the city for the Chinese New Year Parade, the cold and rainy weather made it the perfect selection for lunch.  I wish I had tried Katana-Ya sooner!  The Shoyu Ramen is so rich, delicious, and flavorful!  Slurpy ramen goodness!  My friend and I loved it so much, we had it twice in one week! We were in the city again yesterday, and this was our obvious lunch spot!  We both had the Shoyu Ramen again.  

It's also right across the street from the theatres so it's a convenient and quick meal after the show if you're hungry!  My only wish is that Katana-Ya had a bigger space to accomodate more customers.
author: Anna R.

description:
I don't get ramen.  I really don't.  I know I'm wrong -- many of you will tell me that a steaming bowl of strong miso broth with a pile of noodles, fried chicken, and one or two pieces of seaweed and green onion is comfort food of the highest order in Japanese cuisine.  All I tasted was a strong miso broth with some other uninspiring stuff thrown in there that tasted only of the same strong miso broth it was swimming in.

So no, I don't get the ramen thing.  As for Katana-Ya, I'm sure they do a great ramen since the place was full of appreciative Japanese diners.  But I'll probably look for something else on the menu next time to suit my overactive palette.
author: Laurence W.

description:
I finally got a chance to try the fried chicken ramen (on miso/light) and it was pretty good.  Grabbing the ramen with a lighter broth helps to offset the fried chicken as it overpowers the flavor.  I also tried their tamago special, which included crab and unagi over tamago, separately and respectively.  This was a pretty ballsy choice, but I just wasn't too thrilled about it.

I don't understand why this place is as popular as it is, but whatever.  There are better places out there around the City (and around the Bay Area), but as far as downtown goes?  Perhaps.
author: Ren L.

description: One of the magazines calls it "the best Ramen in SF". That statement is clearly a joke.
author: C J.

description: The food was decent. I waited about 20 mins just for 1 person, was seated at the bar and received pretty bad service. The waitress took my order and brought me my food and that was about it. I had to ask another server for more water, a to go box, and my check. I then had to go up to the cash register to pay after waiting and giving the obvious signs that I was ready.  I'm a pretty lenient customer because I work at a restaurant and understand that it's hard to please everyone but I felt like I was being overlooked and no customer should feel that way.
author: Adi G.

description:
One of the restaurants I bookmarked on yelp to try and it was decent.  The place was a bit tiny and crowded with a waiting list and people outside in the cold waiting to be called.

I ordered the Katanya Ramen since my girlfriend ordered the BBQ pork.  I always like to order different things because I can get a taste of hers as well as my own.  In the Katanya Ramen it comes with corn, fried chicken, fried postickers, seaweed, scallion, BBQ pork & 1/2 a boiled egg.  Most Ramen places I have been to usually don't give enough noodles, so I asked for extra noodles for $2.00.  Not bad of a price.  It was a lot of extra noodles.  I was stuffed and devoured it in no time. 

The combination of items in my Ramen was an interesting choice as I was indecisive of what to get.  The pot stickers were very good, the skin was pan fried perfectly and the meat filling was incredibly delicious.  The other thing I really like was the fried chicken.  The batter they use to coat it was very crunchy.  It wasn't over battered or fry too much, very flavorful.

Overall, I was satisfied with the Ramen.  I picked the miso soup base and it was very well balanced.  It wasn't over salty or plain it was perfect.  On the other hand, this place is worth the wait even if it's freezing cold outside.  Just a bit tiny and bit crowded with tiny walkways.  It is not the best neighborhood as it is listed in (union square), about a block away, near Jack in the Box and there are a lot of pan handlers.  I recommend going with a friend or two and this place doesn't seem to be ideal with a large group.

I would like to recommend 

- Kantanya (especially if you never been here so you can try everything) 
- BBQ PORK
- Deep Fried Chicken
- Kim Chi
-Parking-

This is near the heart of Union Square in San Francisco so parking can be hard.  If you go night time you can probably find street parking, if not there are always parking lots around.
author: Kenneth Y.

description:
Dang. Used to be a HOT SPOT for a 4-star late night sushi/ramen spot but quality has gone done dramatically and service is horrible. Just looked it up and they've gone down to 3 1/2. 

SOLD OUT. Much better spots out there.
author: Tim T.

description:
great for late night eating after drinking. still think the food is just mediocre (better than eating jack in the box)

the ramen is nothing spectacular

and the sushi is just fine..
author: Bon N.

description: I got the Katana-ya ramen. It came with potstickers, fried chicken, half of a boiled egg and corn along with other standard ramen items (bamboo shoots, seaweed, etc.) I gotta say it was just okay. Nothing special. I wish it was better. I had my first ever bowl of ramen at the old location on Judah back in 2003. I remembered it being fantastic. Maybe I've been spoiled by Orenchi, Santouka and all the awesome ramen places I've been since then.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description:
So nice I came here twice...at midnight...on Tuesday and Thursday. In the weird Frisco Rain. What is up with your weather Nor Cal?

I was in town for a meeting. I landed after four hours from a flight from the midwest (i.e. Ramen DESERT). Yelped a ramen spot and no doubt Katana-Ya was by far the winner. Walking a mile, we finally arrived..and waiting 15 minutes..at midnight.

In any case, the Katana-Ya combo was ridiculous. Amazing broth, great noodles, and the fried chicken was perfect, albeit slightly soggy.

I came back again on Tuesday with 10 of my closest co-workers and everyone agreed this place hits the spot for midnight munchies.

Nicely done Nor Cal.
author: Ronnie G.

description: I've been to Katana-Ya many times over the past 5 years and I think they are slipping a little. The last time I was there, I was with two other people and they forgot the order for our whole table. We had all ordered ramen and it took nearly an hour to get our food. When we finally got it, the broth was warm, not hot like it should be (I think it had been sitting on the counter for a while) and the flavor of the broth and the texture of the noodles were forgettable.
author: Jessie L.

description: Came here for lunch since the menu looked a lot better than Sushi Boat across the street.  The fried chicken ramen/miso salad combo was good, but the spicy tuna roll and eel/cucumber roll were average.  I would recommend this place if you're in the area.
author: Carol S.

description:
Ramen snobs are are a sad, sorry lot.  Just because they've seen "Tanpopo," or have spent a week or two in Tokyo, or banged some chick named Chieko, or drive a Honda, they now act all proprietary about ramen.  They hype ramen-yas afar for the purpose trashing the nearer noodle joints.  Typical amongst their complaints: 1) It's not as good as that place in NY/LA/Tokyo/Wichita; 2) There's no tonkotsu broth; 3) There's MSG and it's salty and greasy.  Quite simply, they just like to bitch and moan.

Now...that all said, on to Katana-Ya.

It's Wildly inconsistent.  In general, I'm pleased with the various ramens at Katana-Ya.  In particular, I like the one that comes with everything in it with miso broth.  Yeah, that miso broth is just thick enough but not too salty.  Also the noodles are nice and al dente.  No, Katana-Ya doesn't offer tonkotsu broth, but neither do many places in NY/LA/Japan/Wichita.  The broth isn't all that greasy either.  However, my friend Christina usually finds the broth to be too salty.  But she's a delicate flower who gets stressed easily.

But there's something really nasty lurking on the menu.  Sukiyaki-don.  To make it, I'm pretty sure they took a few scraps of beef, put them in a freezer for 6 months or until funky freezer flavor replaces that of beef, then boiled the fuck out of it until extra tough.  That's one to avoid.

Long story short, stick to the noodle dishes.
author: Suo L.

description:
Cheap, fast, friendly, and good food.  It happened to be an 80+ degree day, and they don't appear to have an air conditioner, so it was dang hot but apart from that I have zero complaints.

To be honest, I didn't think there were any real proper ramen places in the city.  Years ago I went to one in Japantown that was pretty good, and plan to explore there further soon, but in the meantime my jury was officially out.  No longer!  This is a great destination.

Noodles were al dente, the broth was rich and flavorful, and out of our group of five, everyone really enjoyed their dishes. Together we sampled all of: chicken teriyaki, soy bbq pork ramen, spicy chicken ramen, cold ramen, salmon roe nigiri sushi, udon, and probably a few other things I'm forgetting.

I'm posting some pictures now, so feel free to check them out, but better yet -- go there and eat it yourself.  You will be happy.
author: Walter K.

description: Was really looking forward to trying this place, with all the reviews I figured it would be a great ramen spot.  Turns out, there are way better ramen spots in socal.  I had the soy sauce ramen w/ an egg.  It just wasn't what I expected it to be, at all.  We also got some spicy tuna rolls which were decent as well.  I'd eat here again though and try something different.  Place is a bit small, the service was good, but the ramen, nothing spectacular..
author: Nic J.

description:
surprised i haven't written a review yet for this place. especially since i'm all about reviewing overhyped places. 

there is always always a ridiculous wait. i generally come after 10pm. probably the only time with no wait. 

i've tried at least 4 different types of ramen here. my favorite is ma po ramen...yes, that shouldn't be my fav for a ramen spot like this. also, i wonder if i like it because of how salty it is. i'm always dying of thirst afterwards

i've also had their sashimi, chirashi bowl and some of their appetizers. it's good for downtown (non richmond, non sunset) but wouldn't say it was amazingly good. so when people say "the best ramen in town is katana-ya" dont have crazy expectations but worth the try just to say you've been. and if you live downtown like i do, this is one of the few places to fulfill that craving.
author: Janet Y.

description:
Solid choice for Ramen!  I'm a HUGE fan of ramen and have been to many great restaurants including Ippudo, Ryowda, and Himawari. This place compares well. 

I got the Katanaya with medium spiciness.   It's a great choice for variety because you get the crispy chicken, dumplings, and the  roast pork. Noodles have just the right texture and springiness. Only thing I would have liked to have seen is a soft-boiled egg instead of the hard-boiled one that they use.
author: Jeffrey F.

description: This place never fails. Their ramen is superb and it tastes the same every time we come back. We don't go to the city that often but when we do we're always drawn to this place. I always want to try something née but we always end up coming here. Maybe it's the crisp in the sf air that makes us want to eat something warm and soupy. We bring friends from out of town here and they really enjoy it. Cant wait to come back soon!!
author: Truc N.

description:
Katana-ya holds its greatest appeal in the hole-in-the-wall quality it exudes from the front windows. If you go on a weekend night, prepare to wait an hour plus to get even a few square inches of bar space. 

Now, on the food, the abundant variations of ramen bowls are excellent, though definitely not authentic. A local told me that this place got famous from its everything bowl, which sounds and is completely unappealing. Overall, if you want to try this place, I recommend going at off-hours and getting a basic ramen. The sushi is mediocre and overpriced.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Everything in Katana-ya is OK but not spectacular if you have had quality Ramen in Japan. The noodles are cooked to the right level of softness, the miso broth that I had was rich, fragrant and not too salt. The piece of BBQ pork that came with the noodles was way too fatty but not inexcusably bad. Everything in the bowl of noodles worked well together. Service was not bad given the typical long lines outside.
If anything, the long wait and long line outside the restaurant would be the only thing that would stop me from going there again. If you don't mind either, you'd like this place.
author: Alfred L.

description: The only thing to come here for is the ramen.  It is outstanding.  I tried it with all three broths, the soy sauce, salt, and miso.  The soy sauce is the best in my opinion next to the salt.  The miso is basically miso soup with noodles with is a little bland.  We also had sushi, but it's average and nothing to write home about.  The big downer is the wait.  We waited about 45 minutes outside on a cold night.  Other than that, the service is good and they do try to get you in and out.
author: Zach P.

description: My friend and I stopped by after the Bay Bridge lights opening ceremony. We just happened to get there when a table opened up. We were seated quickly and handed menus. We were cold from getting soaked in the rain and had ramen. They also have sushi there. Good stuff. If there is a wait, you've got to put your name on the list outside and wait outside. There isn't a lot of room inside, but it's cozy and I really wouldn't recommend a group of more than 4 people.
author: Melissa A.

description:
I was in search for some ramen and the boyfriend have been bothering about wanting sushi, so we decided to come here based on the reviews I read on yelp. Plus, our hotel was close by. 

The wait was about 30 to 45mins at 8ish. If you don't hear your name within the first two calls you'll lose your spot, so listen close for your name. The food comes very fast after you order, so I think it makes up for the wait for the table.

I ordered the fried chicken ramen soy based soup and he ordered the chiraishi bowl. I've never seen fried chicken ramen, so I decided to try it. I thought the chicken was very flavorful but it was soggy because of the soup. the ramen noodles was cooked just right, they weren't over cooked and was still a little chewy. The chiraishi bowl was okay the fish was fresh but the rice was just plain rice. 

I would come here again if I stay close by.
author: Karen C.

description:
I have heard good things about this place, so I jumped at the chance to check it out with a Meet-Up group of Hapas, some of whom are half Japanese and should know good ramen. I am a ramen novice, so this review is aimed at my peeps. 

The place is quite small and intimate. Its located a couple of blocks from Union Square right near Downtown. There are no large tables for large groups, so with 5 people we ended up pushing tables together. But hey, that gives it that intimate feel. 

I ordered the Kim chi ramen. It was a solid choice for me. An ample sized bowl of noodles and a nice broth. The Kimmi was on the bitter side but OK. I got the medium spicy bowl and can still feel the mark it left on my palate, so if you like spiciness, you'll enjoy the spicy ramen. Another guy got Curry Chicken, and the bowl looked like it could serve a family of 4. No joke. 

The waiter was very friendly and helpful. And why wouldn't he be with an automatic 18% gratuity added to the bill for groups of 5 or more? :P

For a friendly atmosphere, good prices near Union Square, and solid ramen, I recommend this place to anyone interested.
author: J C.

description:
too bad I don't live in SF! 

their ramen is really fresh and delicious! I can't believe we were here on a Saturday at 6pm and there was no wait!! My cousin who is from here says that there is always a long wait. We actually just beat the rush. It was awesome!

Real authentic ramen joint! love it!
author: Kim T.

description:
My uncle tried to take me to this place 4 years ago, saying it was the best ramen place near where he worked in downtown SF. We just happened to get there before they opened that day so we didn't get to eat there. Then when I tried to find it again a year later when I was back in town with friends, I couldn't find it because I didn't have a smart phone and I was one street off. Finally this past spring break when I ventured up to SF with a friend, we managed to find it.

It was cold out, rain was starting to pour, yet the place wasn't full at all. Service was good, and I would say fast, but we took forever to order so it took awhile.

We shared the deep fried soft shell crab, udon and the spicy salmon roll, kappa maki, and a great roll I can't remember but I know there was a quail egg with it.

Udon was fantastic for a cold, rainy day. I know it's not the thing, but my non-asian friend really enjoyed the thicker, chewier noodles! She's now hooked on them. Everything was great! The sushi tasted awesome! Definitely coming back!
author: Brandon S.

description:
Ordered take-out around 9PM after work. They get bonus points for efficiency - my order was ready in 10 minutes. 

On another note, I don't think I will be doing take-out from Katana-Ya again... 

Here's the break-down of my order: 

Extra spicy ramen - The spiciness was fine, but the consistency of the broth was extremely thick and the noodle to soup ratio left me with a surplus of noodles at the end. There was also a very strong taste of bamboo - next time, I'll ask for no bamboo. Counted one slice of pork in my ramen, which was a little disappointing. I want to say that my underwhelming ramen can be attributed solely to the fact that I ordered it to-go, but I just wouldn't recommend ordering the extra spicy ramen - I'm a huge fan of extra spicy food and spicy ramen...but coating regular ramen with Korean spicy paste just doesn't do it for me. 

Gyoza - decent, nothing spectacular, but I would probably order this again

Edamame - bland - which is okay for edamame, but they were also a little undercooked...

Despite all the negativity in my review...I want to give Katana-Ya the benefit of the doubt - I'll have to come here again, sit down (so that the noodles don't soak up all the broth-they should definitely consider packing the soup and ramen separately for to-go orders), and order a ramen that isn't coated in a spicy paste...until I follow up with another review...Katana-Ya gets three stars.
author: Melissa M.

description:
The ramen didnt do much for me. I tasted it with the shoyu broth, and the miso broth. Both were okay, but for a 4 star place, I was just expecting something... more. Its just average ramen, with above average prices.

Tempura is good, sushi is good, curry is good too, but again overpriced and nothing special.

The restaurant itself is pretty small, and ever so slightly crowded. The service tends to be slow and rather inattentive. I love that they are open late, though. I would come here again only for a late night meal, but for dinner there are better and cheaper options than this.
author: Alison A.

description: The Katanaya Ramen is delicious. It comes with everything in it! The restaurant is a little small so there was a wait. They actually sat us downstairs. It was secluded and more quiet than the upper level, but it was kind of lonely down there. Definitely a good place to go if you're craving a big bowl of ramen late at night.
author: Jenny B.

description:
In my quest to eat everything on the 7 x 7 top 100 list, I ventured out to Katana-Ya after an afternoon meeting today. From other reviews, I think I went at the perfect time.. I arrived at 2:15 and placed my take-out order right away. There was tons of choices when ordering ramen- light, medium, rich.. miso, soy, etc.. I went with light miso ramen and it was delicious. I think they might have made the broth a bit rich as it was a little stronger than I was expecting but was great. I am watching my calories and know that this was a major no-no but I just had to do it.

My take-out portion was large and from what I saw on the tables in the restaurant, the bowls looked just as big. I could barely get through half of my soup so I'm saving it for later. The only thing is the price.. it is a little high for a standard ramen. I guess it is a little close to union square and attracts some tourist crowds, so they can justify it.
author: Seema M.

description: If something has ramen in it, it automatically gets 3 stars, because...ITS RAMEN PEOPLE! It takes serious effort to bugger up slurpy chewy carbs in a homey savory broth mixed together with an assortment of meats and veggies. Katana- Ya delivers average but satisfying ramen that hits the spot on a chilly foggy day (you'll need it after waiting in line in the chilly fogginess for a while). The Katanaya Ramen does not offer anything special other than the chasu, which is the best thing in it, so just stick with that or even the regular ramen which comes with it. The bowls are big enough that you really may wanna think twice about ordering  combos or anytyhing else with it (and do avoid the Katsu Don, trust me).
author: Snuffles B.

description:
So far, the ever-delicious Katana-Ya continues to satiate my ramen cravings with its rich broth, noodles of the perfect chewiness, and tender chasu pork.  What is not to love?  Whether it be a cold rainy day, or a balmy San Franciscan spring day, no one in the tiny restaurant minds being elbow to elbow with the person next to them when a bowl of steaming ramen sits before them.  

The first time I came here, my friend got an undercooked oyaku don (which, in their defense, isn't their specialty).  But aside from that, their ramen has yet to disappoint.

A must eat of SF!
author: Jane Ann C.

description: I have to re-certify my 3-star rating for Katana-ya... I was going to give them one more star for my last visit: butter corn ramen with medium spicy miso soup. The soup base was great! The ramen was the same as last time... a bit too hard for my taste. Worth a try, not worth the wait... expect to wait up to 30 minutes... this place probably seats around 40 at max.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
whaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaat! is this goodness!? WHAT! 

this stuff will get you addicted. just a few days ago i went and waited 45 minutes to get in. finally seated and then there's a man at the table next to mine who didnt even finish his ramen. he left pretty much 90% of the bowl there, uneaten. and he left. WHAT! 

i always get miso broth. im afraid to try other broths because once i find something i like i shall stick to it. 
i really dont know why katanaya doesnt open a larger restaurant or a restuarant #2?? ? ? ? ? they would do well!

BOWLS SO BIG YOULL LEAVE HURTING. but hurting so good. you would eat it all. or share if if you really need to.
try the california rolll too.
author: Veranna N.

description:
Stopped by here with a foodie group on a Saturday afternoon. We arrived before the store opened and by noon there was a small crowd waiting in line. 

The restaurant itself is dark and small and its seating arrangement is cramped.  In other words, the place is a dive. Parking is extremely difficult, there's parking garages or take public transportation.

However the Ramen soup is great!  You have a choice of broths, how rich it is and its spiciness level (spiciness costs an extra 50 cents).

The quality is worth the price. I would definitely come back here if I'm in the area.
author: vinh t.

description:
The ramen here is pretty good. I had one of those combos with the donburi on the side. The ramen was pretty good, and its one of the better places in the city.

 Hard to find parking, but thats the location of the place! The place is a little small and there usually is a wait.
author: Derek N.

description:
Hands down, MY FAVORITE RAMEN PLACE in town!! It's a "must visit" if you're a fan of ramen. Great place to go to after watching a Broadway show across the street. I've been here many of times and loved EVERY visit. I don't care if it's hard to find parking, I don't care if there's a wait, I don't care that it's so small inside...If I'm craving for ramen, my first choice is Katana-Ya. Another big PLUS about this place is that its great for "late night" eats - Open 'til 1am.

I usually come here for the "Noodle Donburi Combo": your choice of noodle soup (ramen, udon, soba) plus a donburi dish (prices depend on what donburi dish you choose) - my favorites are the miso ramen with kimchi fried rice or katsu don. I've tried the sushi here as well but its really all about the ramen.
author: jesiree b.

description:
Standard 45 minute wait. Almost too long to stick around. Almost. 

What's so special about this place that you'd wait in line for so long? Try their ramen with corn & fried chicken. Or the chirashi. 

How many people should I bring? You++; 

Can a place this good really be in Union Square? It's a legit diamond in the rough.
author: Izzy P.

description:
I work one block from here and there is always a line out the door.  I always wondered what the big deal was.  I like ramen but I don't crave it like I do other foods.  I always seem to enjoy it though when I find a good place.  I came in last night around 5 and the wait line was just starting to pick up.  We got seated in 15 minutes at the bar.  

I ordered the combo: Regular miso ramen and spicy tuna don for $14.  Not too bad.  My friend got the Katanaya ramen.  It looked so yummy.  I thought the broth was really tasty and the noodles were cooked just the way I like it.  I think in Italian they call it Al dente.  Since I got the combination, I was only expecting to get a small bowl of soup and noddles with no protein or veggies.  But to my surprise, it came fully equipped with pork chops and seaweed.  The ramen along with the spicy tuna don was more than I could eat, but I could never turn down a spicy tuna bowl.  It was yummy.  

I'm not a ramen person, but I would definitely come back.  This is a good place to go with a small group of close friends.
author: Kimba V.

description:
I'm a huge fan of ramen, so after searching yelp for a good ramen joint, I decided to take my chances at Katana-ya.

First impression. Tiny. Seats feel a bit sticky? I parked right outside (meters - 25cents for 4 minutes??? ugh! Not restaurant's fault... just a rant haha) But really close to downtown shopping areas.

I ordered the regular ramen w/miso soup.

Broth was really good. Although the garnishes felt sorta unnecessary b/c they weren't tasty... bamboo and seaweed tasted like ocean water to me... Anyway, the ramen had a really nice texture to it though!

I was super disappointed with the slice of pork they gave me! I've eaten at Santouka (LA), Orochon (LA), and Santa Ramen (San Mateo), and they all have extremely juicy and tender slices of pork that melts in your mouth! Katana-ya on the other hand -- not so much. The pork was actually too hard/chewy and SUPER salty!

$8-9 bucks for a regular bowl of ramen... I've had better. But probably the better ones I've had in SF area. So all in all... I would still recommend this place!
author: Sandy M.

description:
Real deal legit Ramen. Long waits, but good broth, and everything in here is just as you would taste it right out of a shop in Tokyo. i would know: I spent 5 years on and off living and studying there.

One of my favorite things about THE city (as I am now learning to call it) is the plethora of Japanese food. I never feel too far from my adopted home away from home. If you're a ramen-lover and in SF this is definitely on the top of the list to check out.
author: Milhouse B.

description:
Yes, more than likely, there's going to be a line but don't be discouraged! Add your name to the list and kill time. Walk the local streets, stop by Lee's sandwiches for a smoothie/coffee/tea- that's what we did. Make sure to buddy up, the Tenderloin streets can appear rough to amateurs. 

T'was my first time at Katana-Ya and I absolutely enjoyed it (which made waiting worth it). Ordered the Lava Flow sushi roll which is spicy tuna atop a shrimp tempura roll with spicy mayo on the side- Incredible!! Fresh & amazing quality made by real deal Japanese chefs themselves. I like my soup with a good variety of meat & veggies so the only one that stuck out most was Katana Ramen, ordered this with miso broth- savory, good portion, delicious all around. BF ordered the curry soup and asked for chicken to be added, no complaints there. It's a small cozy place with efficient service. Next time, I would go back during off peak hours to avoid the line. Waiting sure sucks when you're hungry!
author: Thuy M.

description:
Finally! A great ramen shop in the city. Emphasis on "in the city" as I still enjoy Santa Ramen a bit more. 

I expected this place to be packed on a weekday in downtown but was pleasantly surprised that it had space. It has a hole in the wall atmosphere which provided a cozy feel. There was some random reggae music in the background which helped set the tone. 

As with most ramen shops I go to for the first time, I ordered the chashu pork ramen -- my general guideline and standard for food quality. Let's start with the broth. I had the light miso base. It was in a word, AWESOME. It was not overly salty and it had enough meat fat in it. Seeing the oily droplets on top of the soup was a good sight to see. There was also enough flavor which is great considering this was the light base and not the rich one, which they also offer. The noodles were nice. Chewy and great texture. The meat was nothing special by itself. I was surprised to have one cold piece of meat thrown in there. 

Service was good. Waitresses were attentive and very polite. They were cute, too. Always a plus.

I'm giving this place a 4.5 stars. It is not quite the best but it's up there. A bit disappointed in the cold meat but the broth totally makes up for it. After finishing all the food, I was still sipping away at the broth. 

Reggae music + sipping on amazing broth = one satisfactory experience.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I love that this place closes pretty late on weekdays. I'm a fan of their Seafood Fried Rice, and their Green Onion Ramen. Their portions are pretty big, so bring your appetite with you.

Tip: It's pretty small in there, so get ready to wait. It's worth it though!
author: Valerie N.

description:
Katana-Ya was another stop in my west coast ramen extravaganza the summer of 2012. Essentially the first three days my ex and I got to the SF area we had ramen... EVERY DAY. Katana-ya was stop #2 on this journey.

Atmosphere: Okay this place is pretty small and cramped to be honest. The lighting is dim and seating is pretty tightly packed. We went at 3PM so we had no problems getting a table, but I can see how it would be difficult during regular hours.

Service: Given that there was only one other occupied table, the service was great. However I would assume that with a full house this might not be the case, but I can't be sure. I just feel that the restaurant layout is so cramped that it would be hard for the staff to navigate if all the seats were taken.

Food: Okay so while I was not as big of a newb at this point, I still wasn't impressed. Both the Ex and I got the Katana-Ya ramen but I asked that the fried chicken be swapped out for an extra slice of Cha-Shu since I was still riding my Cha-Shu high from Misoya... WORST DECISION EVER. After trying the Cha-Shu it was quite flavorless and unexciting. On the other hand the fried chicken I stole from my Ex's plate was juicy and tender AND perfectly fried. Suffice to say, I had made a bad call. Otherwise the broth was decent, but not as rich or deep as that of Misoya. In addition while the Ex liked the sheer amount of "stuff" in the ramen, I didn't think it was necessary. By the time I got around to them, my gyoza were a soggy mess and I didn't want to eat  my Cha-Shu. The noodles were decent, not memorable so I'm guessing fairly standard ramen texture and flavor. The pricing is right on point with how much is in the bowl of ramen (as I mentioned... a lot of "stuff") so I'd say a decent value.

Overall, given that there are better options around if you have a car I'd pass. However if you're stranded in the city it's worth checking out for a ramen fix.; not the best, but pretty decent.
author: Lily W.

description: Quick service, usually a wait however to get in. I always stick with seaweed salad and butter corn ramen. The first few times it was amazing but there are better ramen places in sf. This place definitely gives the most noodles though!
author: maxine b.

description:
Fatty, rich, pork-y and savory broth.

I'm by no means a ramen expert, but there's a reason why people are willing to wait 50 minutes in line to eat here.  The ramen is filling and deeply flavorful and satisfying.  Seriously, the broth coats your mouth in pork-iness (if that isn't a word, it should be).  I ordered the house ramen, which had fried dumplings, corn, bamboo shoots, seaweed, pork and fried chicken.  Yes, alllll of that.  Somehow it all works to create a wonderfully seasoned (albeit somewhat on the saltier end) bowl of ramen. 

It's tiny and they don't take reservations.  There's no way around it.  Be prepared to wait in line.   If you're super hungry, you can grab a slice of pizza next door while you wait for your name to be called. But make sure you're there when they call your name, lest you lose your spot.
author: Steph L.

description: Everything was delicious. My husband had the chirashi bowl, and I had one of their spicy noodle soups. I totally think mine was better but he was happy with his. It's funny because I usually have plate envy, but this time I was a happy camper!
author: Cynthia N.

description:
First, I need to say, this restaurant would have gotten a five, but I like to rate my overall dining experience. Everything was great except for a couple of minuses.. I will touch on that later. 

First, allow me to discuss the many pluses of this place. After a long day of walking around, my friend, who is an Elite yelper (=D), yelped this ramen place as our lunch destination. We ordered: Katana-Ya ramen with soy sauce base soup (2 of those), deep fried chicken ramen (2 of those; one soy sauce and one miso). Personally, I got the Katana-Ya ramen b/c it seemed like  signature and had a bunch of stuff in it (deep fried chicken, potstickers, 1/2 of an egg, and corn). Anyway, the ramen was delicious, cooked perfectly. The soup was great too, thanks to MSG. Great for a cold, rainy SF day. Another plus was the cute exterior look.. the red flag banners that hang just in front of the door reminds me of what ramen houses look like in Japan.. :o) Another plus was how quickly they were able to bring out the ramen, but then I guess, ramen doesn't take too long to make? 

Now, moving on to some minuses or "deltas".. First, the wait was a bit long.. we had to sign on the clipboard outside. However, I realize the wait time is something that they can't control.. definitely not a place for big parties, so pick your ramen buddy and partner up! Along that line, this place is actually extremely small.. we had a party of four and they sat us near the door, which was a table for 2, but they added 2 extra chairs and made it a table for 4... not to mention, it was awkward (I think) for my friend who sat by this other door (not the entrance, but it was a door to the back or kitchen or something), which kept opening and closing.. so it was rather distracting.. but we're pretty easy-going folks, so we laughed it off. Another minus is the price, I think it's a tad bit pricey for ramen, but I still paid for it and would probably come back again.. with a smaller party this time, so that we can get seated faster. 

So, overall, still a 4; just b/c this place reminds of good authentic Japanese ramen (and no I'm not Japanese, but I've been to Japan).
author: Cassy H.

description:
The one thing that's going for Katana-Ya is the incredible proximity to downtown. If you're hungering for something other than mall food at Westfield, simply trek up a few streets to this ramen place! I've frequented this place a few times before and had both the sushi and the ramen.

To be quite honest, I don't see why everyone's in love with it. It's a good place, just not incredible and groin-grabbingly jizztacular as everyone makes it out to be. It's overrated at best. But aside from that, the food is decent. The fried chicken ramen is the best! The fried chicken is floating in the soup itself and incredibly, the batter still retains its crunchiness, even after sitting in the broth. 

Good place, but not fantastic. I'll go here if I happen to be downtown and without transportation to somewhere else.
author: Sabrina C.

description: Fast service, great food, very fresh fish!
author: Donna L.

description: Had to try this place since I love ramen so much ! But it was a little disappointing. I came here with some friends, how ever this place is rather small and cramped , not ideal for a group or party. The food here was not the best ramen , they only have a few selected flavors, but no tokontsu!! , so I ordered the katanaya special ramen, comes with chashuu, pot stickers, chicken karaage and the typical vegetables in ramen. The ramen was average , not the best. I Also Tried the sushi rolls here, sushi came in room temperature , I'm not sure if its because it was a hot day or that's how it is , but it's was so-so. The food was rather expensive for the quality of the food. Overall 3.5/5
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
WOW!!! This Ramen place is ABSOLUTELY delicious! I'm in love!!

I came here kinda/sorta by accident with my sister about a month ago since they happened to be one of the few places that sounded delicious to have for lunch and had good reviews.  We ordered a salmon roll, spicy scallop roll, and a corn ramen soup. Ohhhh mmmyyyy goddddd the noodles were so friggin delicious, the BEST I've ever had, so tasty; perfect texture, perfect flavor.  The broth was also out of this world along with every single ingredient in the soup.  This place was so good that I had to bring my boyfriend and so I did the following weekend and he was also just as floored as I was with how amazing it was and I, again, was in Ramen heaven! 

This place is soooo good and leaves me wanting more ALL the time.  I can't wait to go back and have some more of their delicious ramen and rolls.  If you come during peak dining hours chances are that you will have to put your name down on their list and wait outside, but honestly it's sooooo worth it!
author: Carolina G.

description:
It's one of the best ramen you can get close to the fidi, not to mention they're open pretty late.  The lines outside can be intimidating, but the wait is usually not as long as it seems, and the service is friendly and more importantly quick.  I tend to find their miso soup base a bit salty, but the noodle is delicious and the overall experience good.  

I've been meaning to try some non-ramen dishes, but tend to fall back on it once I'm inside (besides, its a ramen restaurant).  I added a spicy tuna roll last night to my order and it was excellent.  I was rather encouraged, so maybe next time will be the day I try something new...
author: Daniel L.

description:
1/18/2012 -- I want noodles.  Why does Katana-Ya have to be so far away now?
1/26/2009 -- I had their curry pork rice plate for lunch the other day.  It was very good. The brown gravy was light and sweat with potatoes, carrots and onions in it.  The pork was crisp and fresh tasting.  The rice was fresh tasting as well.  A little pricey for lunch, but the taste is good and the portion size is large.
author: X X.

description: My ramen was too salty Cheap ramen noodle. One star for the good portion. Nothing special to me Will not come back
author: DreamHolic D.

description: okay ramen place, can be difficult parking, and can be quite a wait during peak hours. i've had better ramen, but this place is adequate to satisfy those cravings. only wish the egg was half cooked instead of full cooked
author: Long C.

description:
From 1/17/2010

People say this place is great, but I just don't fully agree.  It's definitely good, but the broth lacks the complete full flavor that I prefer.  I mean, a cemetery of Noah's ark.  Then simmered all day.  Anyway, back to their noodles, those picked up their broth's taste quite well.  We got the Katanaya ramen and it was a wise choice.
author: jerome c.

description: This must be one of the cutest place I have ever been too! So small and cozy!  I got the Katanaya Ramen, apparently they use pig fat in their soup because I asked the workers what light was and etc. It is yummmm though, worth the extra calories!
author: Janet Z.

description:
Ramen!!

So, I have a misconception about ramen. Well cuz....I'm use to 99 cent ramen from your local china-mart or HEB. And you know what, I LIKE that ramen. haha

So when ppl always talked about going to a ramen noodle place, I laugh. Why pay $10 for ramen, when I'm super happy with 99 cent ramen?

Anyhoot, a couple years ago we checked out one ramen place in LA which was pretty good.

So we thought to hit up a ramen place in SF. Lo and behold: Katana-Ya. (They have a few locations--we were at Union Square).

The menu was good. There are a few broths to choose from. I got the miso broth. Also, there were a ton of options of meats, veggies, seafood, and even rice noodle, egg noodle, etc..

The food came out pretty quickly. The noodles were al dente--just the way I like 'em. The broth was also very tasty. The bowl was a great size and the meat/veggie/noodle ratio was good. I think that's key..I hate when there is so much noodle, but not enough stuff to go with it.

Overall, I think you can't really go much in-depth about ramen. Like i said, I still fancy 99 cent ramen anyday.

Oh, one note about the decor. It's a pretty small restaurant. Tight knit and a little cramped. I usually don't like when it's like that, however, it does give you a more authentic Japanese experience. Many side street restaurants in Japan are tiny. In that regard, I think the room space and ambiance was a positive.
author: Sam Y.

description:
After spending a whole day in the city my date and I were looking for a place to eat nearby. We were craving something Japanese-ish so I pulled out the good ol Yelp app and started looking. This place popped up, 2000+ reviews and 4 stars?! Must be good, right? Alas, it was not so. I was not impressed at all. 

I got the Fried Chicken Ramen and the hamachi kama. The broth was flat, like what you'd find with instant noodles. The fried chicken was nothing special, tasted just like the popcorn chicken you get at your local TapEx. The hamachi kama was good of course (though it's pretty hard to mess that up). I didn't like how they battered and fried it though. Fish should never be fried!

Overall, very disappointed.
author: alan w.

description: What happened to this establishment...It is not the same as before even a year ago. Noodles are not as good as before, I ordered the SOY broth (Dark clear color) and it came out looking like MISO, yet they firmly say it is SOY broth....the "SOY" broth that I got was pretty musty and definitely not clear. The fried chicken was dry and bland, while the roast pork was extremely taste-less. I only yelp when I get my mind blown by great good or horrible food, you can be the judge from my experience today. It is not worth the 14.03 after tax for a katana-ya ramen...
author: Mike Z.

description:
After reading all of the reviews for KatanaYa, I was expecting something life changing. But, it was only good, not great.

The broth is good and so are the noodles, it reminds me of the saimin in Hawaii.  If you're from there, then you know what I'm talkin bout.

The sushi is okay; I do like the Salmon-Avo roll.

What I do like about KatanaYa is that they have Ramen, Udon and Soba combos which is perfect for lunch!
author: Marisa R.

description: This spot is pretty legit...I don't think it compares to my fave ramen spot in San Diego but it fulfilled my craving.
author: Ryan I.

description:
Katana-ya Ramen with a little bit of everything = a sure bet for a satisfied tummy. I always crave the delicious house made noodles, fried to a crisp gyoza, amazing fried chicken, seaweed side, sliced pork, hard-boiled egg, and a sprinkle of sweet corn in the yummy miso broth... DROOL. 

The appetizers and sushi rolls are okay, I've had the donburi bowls as well - the main attraction will always be the ramen piping hot when it arrives at the table. 

Note to reader: The wait is almost always long, the space is so small - don't bring a big group, and don't expect the most stellar service.
author: Joyce S.

description:
This place is always packed and I've been here so many times. I often think (and know) that when there is always a crazy long queue it is mostly HYPE.

This isn't the case here. Food is great, reasonably priced and super fast service. The wait staff try to help you out with what you want but you just got to pick something and they're all about throughput. For this -1 star.

I'm a fan indeed.
author: Dilip R.

description: Food is authentic, but a little pricey because of the touristy location. I ordered the ramen (which is 3 stars) and the tamago "boats" topped with snow crab meat and unagi (four stars). Overall the place should deserve 3.5 stars.
author: L S.

description:
I am prepared to take the tongue-lashing from all of my friends for the rating that I'm leaving for Katana-Ya.

I finally came here earlier in February with a friend who came quite often. She was accompanying me as I set out to finish the 7x7 list this year (I'm only at 44 as of this date).

First of all, many friends found it crazy that I never had Katana-Ya. I've heard of it many times and have read the reviews, so I knew it was a place that lots of people put on their MUST GO TO lists.

My friend and I had the chasu ramen with miso broth on the 7x7 list and also got an order of rolls. I honestly can't remember the name of it unless I go through my receipt to see which one we got.

Nothing wowed me as I ate. The broth was alright, the pork was okay, the sushi was decent... I would've left this place giving it 3 stars.

HOWEVER, I came by a couple of weeks later because I remember seeing a picture of their kimchi fried rice on the menu, and I told myself I'd come back for it. Yes, I know, it's not a Korean place so I shouldn't expect it to be good, but I was being hopeful anyway.

I tried to place a phone order because i didn't have a long enough lunch break, but couldn't get through for over 30 minutes (FIX YOUR PHONE ON YELP!). I decided to stop by after work instead to grab dinner before the Pendulum show at the Fillmore, and with a bit of wait time (20 minutes maybe), I finally got my kimchi fried rice.

The thing that brought a smile to my face was that they gave me a side of miso soup (I love that stuff!). But when I started eating the kimchi fried rice, I wanted to cry for having wasted SO much of my time that single day while trying to satisfy my kimchi fried rice craving.

It looked NOTHING like the picture on their menu. It was a light dullish brown color with some meager vegetables tossed in. It looked and tasted more like Chinese fried rice with veggies, and the taste was definitely LACKING. Not a single bit of kimchi in sight! I'm upset that I even asked them to make it as spicy as they could. What a FAIL. That's what happens when you order a Korean style dish at a Japanese restaurant - partially my fault.

Note to the restaurant, if you're going to sell/make something on your menu, make sure it looks remotely the same. And also, maybe take this item off the menu. Stick with only the ramen because this place is known as a ramen house.
author: Melissa D.

description:
I used to order from here to get my ramen fix while in the City.

So I called in at 11:30 A.M. hoping to phone in my order and pick it up.

You know what, they hung up on me!

NEVER EAT HERE!  POOR SERVICE-HOW CAN THEY EXPECT TO KEEP CUSTOMERS IF THEY HANG UP ON THEM.  I WILL NEVER EAT HERE AGAIN.

I unlike many others live a stone's throw away from Santa, Ramen Dojo and Kagura in San Mateo, so I can get my ramen elsewhere, but I will NOT be recommending this place to anyone anymore.
author: Jamie M.

description: In my opinion, Katana-Ya is somewhat overrated. However, it's not necessarily their fault that all the rave reviews inflated my expectations. From the most neutral perspective I can take, this place is quite good. The ramen here is on par with any other place, and the curry is not bad either. But if there's a long line when you arrive, I would suggest seeking a different place.
author: Bo D.

description: We went to Katana-Ya b/c it was walking distance to our hotel.  I ordered the shoyu ramen & kimchi fried rice combo - it was excellent.  The kimchi fried rice had a great mixture of pork, eggs, kimchi, and seasoning.  I was pleasantly surprised.  Sushi was good too, really generous cuts of fish.  Everyone in our party was happy with their dish, it was a great dining experience.  I'm puzzled why the Yelp rating is so low... it is a solid 4 stars in my opinion.
author: Sofie D.

description:
I've been here quite a few times and it has been very good. I've tried the Miso, Shio and Shoyu ramen. The Shio is definitely my favorite. Although there is usually a pretty good line, I've never waited that long. My favorite dish is the Katana-Ya ramen, since they have lots of different ingredients. 

Be prepared - ramen here is a bit pricier, so if you have a few add-ons, the bowl can get up to $15. I'll continue to come here, but price-wise, I've definitely seen better.
author: D C.

description: With so many other options for ramen out there, this ramen is just so so. Their name sake bowl is basically everything they can stuff in a bowl, which sometimes less is more. They do have similar noodles to Ajisen ramen in the mall, but the flavor of the miso falls short of ramen underground and Ajisen ramen in my opinion. The sodas here always taste so watered down or something, may be the water they mix it with. I would rather have canned soda in stead. If you are nearby give it a try youse enjoy it, but if you can go a few more blocks try the other two places mentioned. If you don't like chain places then just try here or underground, as Ajisen ramen is a worldwide chain.
author: James R.

description:
I cannot wait to go back here. Seriously the ramen is so good. There are some caveats to this place though as you might have gathered. It's small and there's ALWAYS a line. There is a wait, but it's worth it. 

My friend and I managed to snag some tea while we waited outside so when we were finally seated, we weren't too beat up about the wait. The wait was well worth it though as the dishes were delicious. The ramen that I had, the soba my friend had and his own special roll that they made for him was delicious.
author: Shauna S.

description:
My friends and I from Hawaii got to town and came here for the first time. They have a special combo where u can either choose a ramen (rich, light or regular), soba noodles or udon, then choose an additional side of one of many chooses (salmon avo roll, etc. for about $14!) 

Nonetheless they have many other choices on their menu.

They're on the list of "The 2010 Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Eat Before Leaving San Francisco."

Cons: Might have a long waiting list! No reservations.
author: Sarah C.

description:
katana-ya, compared to some of the ramen places in san mateo.... is just as good... but i'm bumping them up to a five star because they are the BEST in san francisco. HANDS DOWN!!!

i actually read about katana-ya in the SF 7x7 list of things to eat and was curious about their infamous CHASU RAMEN.... and then my boyfriend brought me their ramen for lunch one day. so i take it out of it's little tub and eat it after it's been waiting in it's container for a good hour.... and...

OMG.... besides the noodles being a little soft... it was perfect!

he didnt even know what he was ordering.. he just randomly picked things and delivered it to me. i figured... if this to-go ramen thats been sitting in it's container for an hour tastes like THIS... i wonder how it would taste like in the restaurant!?

so of course, i venture out there with a friend after work, even though i hate going downtown.... and we actually only waited for about 5-10 minutes. by the time she parked the car... i was already seated and waiting for her!

i ordered the chasu ramen of course and my friend ordered the same... minus the spicy topping and yupp.... just as i thought.... delicious and satisfying. the noodles weren't soft, they were al dente. the broth was hot, the ingredients and toppings...fresh. 

it was just what i had needed after a long day of work. i'll definitely be back, despite it being located downtown. haha.
author: amelia g.

description: A hole in the wall type of restaurant in SF with limited seating but pretty good ramen. If you come here, expect waiting times to be around an hour (esp if you come around the peak hours). Luckily the restaurant is located near many shopping areas so you can always just scribble your name down, go shop a bit, and come back later. Only thing I didn't like about this restaurant is how cramp it feels. I feel like a sardine in there!
author: Cathy R.

description:
The Background:
Tiny restaurant near Union Square, this place has excellent Ramen and food that can be made quite spicy.  While it's highly reviewed from Yelp and 7x7, it wasn't really any better than other ramen shops like Maru Ichi or Ryowa.  If you're there, it's worth stopping here if there is no line, but it's not worth a special trip

The Positives:
The ramen here is quite good.  The broth is tasty and the noodles are well cooked.  Additionally, the food can be made quite spicy and the spicy tuna is in fact, quite spicy unlike many other places.

The Negatives:
The place is tiny and its hard to get a seat.  Additionally, they charge extra to make it spicy.  Finally, I wasn't a fan of the chashu, it wasn't quite as melt in your mouth as other top tier ramen restaurnts.
author: Henry C.

description:
Very small restaurant- I think my friends and I waited 15 minutes for a table for six (and it was only 5:30 PM!).

The kitchen needs to learn how to put out orders from the same tables simultaneously- there must have been a time difference of 15 mins from when the first dish arrived at the table to the last dish. I ordered some raw tuna- ironically, it was the last dish out.
