The ramen with miso soup was okay-tasting, but definitely better than any of the other ramen I've had at the other restaurants (I don't have good ramen experiences, which is why I didn't order ramen in the first place).

Service was friendly, but the waitress... GAAHHH!! First, we couldn't read her messy handwriting, so it was difficult to tell how much each of us owed. She asked us if we needed an explanation (YES, please!). We each paid for what we owed, but were still $10 short even after we had tossed in extra tip. Three of us did the calculations, and figured that she had tacked on an extra $12. She came back around and said, "Here. I'll do the calculations with you... OOPS!"

Note: 18% automatic gratuity added for parties of 6 or more.

I don't think I'll ever be back.
author: Angela H.

description:
I book my hotel based on its location.

My husband and I love this place.  There is a little bit of a wait, it gets crowded and loud, but we're fans regardless.

I love the ramen, the sushi is underrated, and the pitchers of beer are great.

It is a little further from everything else going on in the area, but very walkable.
author: Sherryl P.

description:
On this hot day, I came here for some cold udon. Not as yummy as the place in San Mateo (Hotaru) but it's as good as it gets for SF! They now also have special items on their menu such as vegetable ramen and other appetizers. It's a must try. 

I love coming to this place around 3 to 4pm in the afternoon.... as this is the time where there is no line!
author: Eva Y.

description:
Although it was the July 4th weekend, it was extremely crowded (30 min wait) at 11pm on a Sunday night.  I was more than happy to wait.  Talk about options, I would definitely recommend going with the combination.  You would expect the portions to be smaller, but it looked like standard portions so be ready to unbuckle your belt.

A friend recommended the ramen, but after watching Anthony Bourdain's show in Hokkaido, Japan, I was craving soba.  Unfortunately, the soba didn't really relieve my craving and the spicy tuna chirashi don left a lot to be desired.

I would probably have given it 4 stars if I had tried their ramen.
author: Bryant T.

description:
Two of my friends and I came by Katana-ya on Saturday afternoon for lunch.  We were on our way to Chipotle when we noticed there was an empty table in Katana-ya and decided to eat ramen instead.

I ordered the Butter Corn ramen and it was pretty tasty.  I like the corn :)

- While there was no wait at Katana-ya this time since we came by at 2:30 PM, there is usually a 1hr+ wait if you come during peak hours of lunch or dinner.
author: Janice C.

description: Small shop with addicting Ramen.  If you can't tell the difference between this Ramen and the other places; face it all soup must taste the same to you.  The depth of the broth, the unique way they cut the green onions, the al dente noodles (ocassionally overcooked) mmm how else can I describe this bowl, this lover.  Oh yeah they serve sushi and it looks like it is coming along but I don't come here for their Sushi.  Spicy Negi (onion) w/Shoyu & rich broth.  Oh yeah and add some of that Cha Siu (pork slices)  I usually add a little hot sauce to boot.  Oh how I surrender to you.
author: Louis H.

description:
Yummy Ramen Goodness.

I was on the search for Ramen and didn't want to drive south so I ended up at Katana-Ya.  The place is small, so there's a good chance you will encounter a line, especially on a chilly day/night.  It was definitely worth the wait.

I popped into Starbucks to get a bev for my waiting, so the wait didn't seem very long at all.

I chose the Butter Corn Ramen.  I wasn't quite sure what to expect, but I figured, "I like Corn."  "I like butter"  I don't see any issue there.

So turns out that the butter corn ramen has all the goodies in the basic ramen bowl PLUS butter and corn.  Hell yes.  I was in heaven.

I have to admit, if I wasn't looking specifically for this place i would have completely missed it, but I am glad I didn't. 

I'd come back for more.
author: Lu E.

description: Read reviews and was right around the corner from our hotel.  As many mentioned we got there about 8:15pm and thre was a line on a Sunday evening.  Waited about 30 minutes but it was worth the wait.  The regular katana shoyu ramen broth had the authentic from Japan taste the mein was cooked perfectly not over.  Had the hamachi/majuro sashimi plate.  3 pieces each and cut thickly but oh so flavorful  and melted in the mouth so good,  also had the spicy hamachi roll sushi rice was cooked perfectly and the spice was not too hot. The fried aji fish was crispy and tasty.  All in all a excellent experience!!!!!
author: Howard K.

description:
I got through college eaten ramen.  The Cup o Noodle kind that costs 29 cents (or did when I was in college)...
This place has great ramen- broth is rich and flavorful and noodles are cooked perfectly.  A little overpriced considering a bowl of noodles and one piece of meat shouldn't be $9 but hey, it seems to be working.  The line is out the door because the place is tiny, but turnover is pretty fast.  Will definitely go back to try some different kinds of ramen.
author: Maxine S.

description:
This place was good.  But it wasn't 100 things before you die good.  I had the chasu ramen with spicy rich broth.  I can't ever tell the difference between absolutely amazing ramen and good ramen.  It almost all tastes the same to me.  I expected soup that exploded in my mouth with flavor, but nope.  The noodles had a great texture though, and were cooked perfectly.

Service was lackluster.  This was especially bad considering how small the restaurant is.  It's not exactly hard to see that i haven't eaten for the last 20 minutes.
author: Lawrence C.

description:
I really liked this place the first few times, but it didn't live up to my expectations the last time I went. The broth was still good, but the noodles were mediocre. It's still my go-to ramen place in the area though!

There's always a line, so put your name on the list and be prepared to wait for a table.
author: Aileen P.

description:
Okay, so I was so sick and had lost my voice and couldn't taste for over a week and a half & was in need of some GOOD ramen!!! Thank god for this place...I was cured in no time ;) KIMCHEE RAMEN..i love it!

The bf ordered the fried chicken and ramen and his verdict was A+++

I guess the only thing that i didn't like is the kindergarten size table?? OMG!!! due to the table being filled with 4 large ramen bowls, our server accidentally spilled water as she placed four cups on our table. She was sorry and so she gave us a complimentary ice cream ;)

funny thing about this place was that I've eaten here before, but only had their sushi for dinner. RAMEN absolutely is the dish to order here...maybe that's why I didn't remember my last visit cause sushi was just aiiight! but i did remember the SAKE--hahha
author: Maria S.

description:
This place is ok, but nothing to write home about.

When a date suggested this place I immediately checked it out on Yelp (as I always do).  Wow, who knew a tiny ramen joint could be so popular.  When we got there the line was pretty crazy, and it was raining!  After about a 20 min wait we finally were seated.

The food was ok.  Not bad but not as stellar as everyone had hyped.  I've had better and I've certainly had way worse.  Our service was fine, no rushing us out afterwards like some have complained about, but I also think there was no more waits outside, so maybe we were just lucky.

All in all it was a fine experience, but the wait and just so-so food makes me think I'll never go back.  I can find ramen elsewhere just as good without the crazy wait.
author: Jen K.

description: The noodles are tasty and the medium is definitely spicy. The is something about the noodles there, it's nice. The prices are more on the pricey side. I don't think I would want to wait a long time for the ramen. Go later and the wait is shorter.
author: Eve C.

description:
Visited on Thursday night around 11:50pm per friend's recommendation.  I actually had a dinner (early one at 5:30), two slices of cake for dessert, two glasses of beer, and a glass of scotch prior to arrival.  My friend wanted to eat ramen, and he suggested that we go here.

I guess it's due to the location... but there was six groups in front of us on the wait-list almost at midnight on a weekday.  Once we were in, I had spicy miso ramen, and it was pretty good.  My friend also ordered some sushi, and they were surprisingly good (given that it's a ramen joint for the most part).

One of the best plus here is that it's open late.  Last order is at 1:15 am, so that should be late enough for the night owls to get the grub on.
author: Eric P.

description:
Quest For Ramen has taken us to Katana-Ya. Kind of a cramped restaurant. My chair was bumped repeatedly throughout my meal and the space limitations of this place is what keeps this restaurant from attaining the five star mark. No fun eating hot ramen and soup with the chair being bumped all the time (and nowhere to go).   Also, you need to get here early otherwise there will be a wait and you have to sign in on the sign in sheet.

The ramen was excellent. Fresh noodles and tasty, greasy broth. Hands down the best ramen in the Bay Area?  Not quite as good as Misoya in Santa Clara or Santa Ramen in San Mateo but one of the best in San Francisco. Shio broth and miso broth look like the best options but they can also make things spicy. Soy sauce flavor was far too salty.  The menu is pretty interesting and has the Japanese sausage, poke, and special salads available.  Also has some good rice dishes.

Take out option is not the best.  For the take out ramen, they dumped the noodles in the soup.  By the time I ate it, the noodles absorbed all of the soup and salt and was really salty.  

On the wall, they have plates signed by celebrities and I recognized signatures of Japanese baseball players such as Ichiro, Yabu, and Saito.  If those guys eat here when they are in town, this place must be somewhat legit.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
It's been really gross in the city. My remedy for wet, cold weather? Ramen! 

I haven't had a bad experience here yet. Sure there's a wait, but the wait I feel is well deserved. The ramen and broths are delicious. I recently tried the udon and I think it's better than the ramen. The combo specials are also nice if you're really hungry. I don't live close to the Union Square/Tenderloin area but when I am there, I come to Katana-ya for my cold-weather food fix.
author: Devy E.

description:
I love Katana-Ya!  Big, savory portions of steamy noodle soup.  The broth is well-balanced and seasoned beautifully.  I ordered the kimchee ramen that added a spicy dimension which fits nicely into some of my favorite flavor profiles.  I thought the noodles held their part, although I have had springier noodles in the past.  It's a fairly high grade based on the taste alone.

I also enjoy the decor and atmosphere very much.  I feel comfortable sitting at the bar and sharing food with my buddies, and entertaining a good conversation.  

I would definitely come back again.
author: Joana L.

description:
Ramen? You mean the stuff I eat when I'm in super poverty saving mode?
Well.. not really.

This ramen is much better, albeit a lot more expensive.

This was my first ramen outside of a package so I didn't much to go on, so I ordered the fried chicken in miso soup base.

Although not amazing, it was a good meal that left me satisfied for my late night meal. Better than anything I would get after midnight back home.
author: Jeff G.

description: I was here earlier today and I was surprised there was no line. My usual side orders like Hamachi Kama and Fried Baby Aji were no longer available I was informed, although they were still on the menu. I was disappointed and thought about knocking a star but their ramen was still good as ever. So, oh well - just go here for ramen!
author: Cholita L.

description: This was the first time my husband and I have had REAL RAMEN.  We are definitely fans of the restaurant.  I actually had not just the Ramen but a bowl of Tongkatsudon with rice and some veggies.  I would definitely go again.. especially if I lived in SAN FRAN!  Not expensive and you get a ton of food for what you pay for.  It's a really small joint so I believe bringing big parties to this place may not be the best idea especially if you are really hungry.. cuz you might be waiting a while!
author: Melanie M.

description: The "Katanaya ramen" hits the spot every single time. I usually get a Philly roll to go with my ramen, but the Katanaya ramen is plenty to fill up most people. To sum this place up in a word: delicious.
author: Sylvester N.

description:
I had read some of the good reviews and I thought this place was only OK.

We both had the Miso broth ramen with a wide variety of things in the soup (the Katana Ya special) and the pork was nice and flavorful, and the fried chicken pieces were really nice. The gyoza (appetizer) were bland inside, but the wrappers were nice and thin and they were fried crispy on one side.

In the end the problem for me came down to the broth. It was  bland. I've certainly had better elsewhere (Suzu and Sapporo Ya in Japantown and especially Ramen Dojo in San Mateo). It's really kind of all about the broth and this wasn't that interesting. 

The place is also very very small and very crowded. The service is stressed out and not very helpful. They almost gave our table to someone else because the guy wasn't paying attention to the list and we were first for a 2-top. Frankly, take out might be the better way to go so you don't have to wait 30-40 minutes for a table. I'd wait 40 minutes for a table at Ramen Dojo, but not here again.

On the plus side it's not very expensive.
author: Mike F.

description:
Tiny place that is easily missed walking down the street. But don't! I went right when it opened and got a seat at the bar. The place was packed.

I like that you can choose what broth you want and spice it up if you like. I had the Katanaya Ramen with miso broth. It comes with pieces of fried chicken, dumplings, mushrooms and pork. Amazing cure for a hangover.
author: Pamela D.

description:
I was told that this place would probably have a wait because the restaurant is on the smaller side, but the food is absolutely delicious.  My friend and I waited about 30 mins for a seat...but it was well worth it.

This isn't just ramen.  This is darn good ramen!  I had a traditional bbq pork with seaweed, bamboo and green onion in a soy sauce broth.  My companion had the spicy tofu goodness.

Both very large bowls were delicious.

I'd recommend going to Katana-Ya during off hours (aka not during peek dinner hours up through 10pm)  Come on the later side for a yummy late night bite...they're open until 2am.
author: Dudley F.

description:
Why do I always have to wait for 30 - 45 minutes every time I go here? The line is always crowded and it's good to come early for dinner to save a spot. 
Yes, I do love their ramen. 
Katana-Ya, I must say, have amazing chashu ramen. I've tried their fried rice as well, but i'm not crazy about it. The restaurant is pretty cramped and it's really hard to eat because they tend to give you a very small table.
The last time I went here, the server was kind of rude so minus one star for that. 
Other than that, if you're lucky, you'll get a friendly waitress and enjoy your ramen!
author: Tessa A.

description:
Opening your review with how you just got back from scouring the streets of Tokyo, Osaka, Kobe, Yokohama, and Kyoto for the best ramen in Japan is about as asstardish as bragging that you're a yelper as you're being seated at a restaurant.  

Having committed only one of those fauxpas once, to date - and luckily the slightly lesser of the two - let me just say this place comes close enough for a spot in town when you don't have a few thousand bucks and the time to spare.   

Only order the sushi if you're curious about what it might be like at a place like this, but you should know better than to actually order it.  Do not miss the Ton katsu or fried rice, with your choice of ramen of course.  And telling people what to order, and which bowl of ramen to  get is equally obnoxious.  Go often, try them all, and find your personal winner.
author: Nikki F.

description:
First time here? Chasu ramen (pork) with miso soup. That's all you need. None of the fancy schmancy deluxe or sushi rolls...just ramen and 4 thick, fat pork slices. This place is known for ramen so just get the ramen. It's filling enough.

To all you skeptical socal folks who've had really good ramen--this place is incomparable and just as delicious!

Find yourself at the very bottom of a huge waitlist? No worries; run off to Union Square, take a stroll and come back. The hostess is kind enough to seat you immediately even if they passed your name. Of course if you're a name after it can get annoying...

I would say the ramen was worth the wait! Lived up to my expectations!
author: Hana J.

description:
Great Ramen - get there early!
I had to wait 45 mins to get a table.  You can avoid this if you get there early for lunch.  The service could have been better, I asked for a side of kimchee, and had to ask 4x.  What I got was a side of kimchee fried rice.  When I sent it back, the waitress was combative .....  nevertheless the ramen was tasty and I'd go back again!
author: Marcia K.

description:
Good God almighty, this place is ramen heaven!

We (my husband and I) were visiting San Francisco and a friend recommended this place.  Went there for lunch one day, and it was so great, we went back the very next day and had the very same thing.  I just could not tear myself away from the #12 with miso.  The broth is stupendous.  The ramen perfect.  The meats (roast pork, dumplings, half a boiled egg) were like a delectable treasure hunt.  A must-visit if you like Japanese food.
author: Kris B.

description: A very good ramen place, albeit a bit greasier than normal Japanese ramen.  I ordered the Katana-Ya special ramen (spicy style), which comes with pork chasu, veggies, egg, chicken kara age, and gyoza (yes, in the ramen).  It was humongous and because I love ramen, I ate it all, but worry about your waist, perhaps one should eat the tofu ramen and not be a glutton like me!  It was really intense. 0_O
author: Terry K.

description:
I still give this place four stars because their ramen was so delicious. This time I tried the katanya ramen and it was really good especially the miso broth. I wasn't a fan of their fried pot stickers because it tasted really soggy. I don't think fried food should be combined with any kind of soup except for chao :-). 

The spicy seafood salad, which was recommended on the menu was just okay. Basically it came with different sashimi fishes (squid, salmon, etc.) on top of mix greens. They used Korean spice, which I thought was a little bit overwhelming (2.5 stars).

The extra spicy tuna roll was just okay for me, nothing special just tuna with korean spice on top (1.5 stars).
author: Nhung T.

description:
This is one of those places where I always get the same thing even though I want to try something else. The shoyu flavored KatanaYa Ramen with the potstickers and fried chicken on the side really has everything you'd want in a ramen. Be ready to not do any work for the rest of the day if you come here for lunch because you WILL get food coma. The only downside to this place is that there can be a 30+ minute wait for dinner as it's a little small.

I've also tried their regular ramen with shoyu flavor, hamachi sashimi, and kim chi fried rice and I was thoroughly satisfied with those as well.
author: Angelo T.

description: Absolutely one of the best meals I've ever had.  I had Miso with regular ramen noodles, medium spicy.  Hubby had Katanaya.  His dumplings were to die for!!  Be prepared to wait - this place is always hopping, and REALLY really tight.   Leave the backpack home if you can!  Might take awhile to seat a big group - but if one or two are willing to squeeze in at the counter, it's all good.  And absolutely worth the wait and the squeeze.  Delish!!   A++++!!
author: Stacey M.

description:
overrated..prices are average. service is average. food is average.

so the line for this place is ALWAYYYSSS super long. the restaurant is TINY! i'm sure they can afford to expand, people are lined up to eat her at all hours, 7 days a week!

i've been here many times. the food is good, not SUPER good, but still good. I dont really understand what all of the fuss is about, though. it tastes average to me. I mean, how can you really make ramen taste exceptional? and yeah, they have other things too, and theyre all ok, but i dont think they live up to their hype..

if youre gonna come here, make sure youre not super starving, cuz im pretty sure you'll be waiting at least 30 minutes. also, this place is not ideal for parties of...3-4 or greater. its supppperrr cramped inside.
author: Linh P.

description:
The search is over.. I finally found equally good ramen place with the one from Seattle. Katanaya ramen on soy was very tasty. The broth, the chicken, the noodle, and everything else... ahhhh... typing this makes me hungry again :(

Gf not a fan for ramen though. She ordered salmon skin roll. It was good too. She like donburi but at the time, she wasn't in the mood to eat a lot. They do have variety of donburi.

Oh one important note.. this place always crowded. Just sign your name on the board outside along with the amount of your party. And just wait until they call your name. Expect to wait for 10 or more minutes outside.
author: Yohann S.

description:
--Ramen = yummy, but I still like Genki Ramen on Geary and 4th better.
--Atmosphere = cramped.  I'm not gonna even be cute and call it cozy.  Honestly...it's just small and you'll wait forever for a seat on a busy night, especially if you have a big group.
--Service = pretty good...food came out quickly, waters refilled promptly

This place was a bit hyped up for me, so maybe I came in with too high of expectations.  If I was in the area I'd go again, but only if there wasn't an insane line for a table.
author: Pam S.

description: been here a few times, we usually have to wait to get seated but it's worth it. Best ramen!!! delicious!!!
author: Eve W.

description: Best ramen I've ever had. I had the pork BBQ ramen. We tried their gyoza as well, and they're great!  Service is fast too.  Parking was a bit hard since it is located right by union square. But it is worth the walk if you're staying at a nearby hotel.
author: J L.

description:
ordered the katana-ya ramen with miso broth, uni and salmon roe bowl, and toro sashimi...

ramen:  broth flavor was not bad, but  the noodles were overdone...
uni and salmon roe bowl:  really good...the uni was surprisingly fresh..
toro:  was ok...

great place to come if you get the late night munchies...they're open till 1am...
author: Amanda S.

description: Stayed at the hotel next door and always saw a line spilling out into the street every night from this place so I had to try it. The ramen with everything in it was amazing! Just wish I hadn't eaten it right before a flight back to SD!
author: Shane P.

description:
Don't believe the hype. Its over priced and seriously charging me THAT much for a bit of Siracha? You've got to be freaking kidding me. 

I had the Chasu Ramen with Miso and it was only MEH. I've had MUCH MUCH MUCH better. Basically I won't go here again unless I'm desperate or highly imbibed. Save your self the money and go somewhere better. 

 On the bright side I can knock it off of the things I should try before I move out of SF.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Prior ramen experience in the Bay Area includes Hotei in the Sunset, Ramen Club in Burlingame, and Santa Ramen in San Mateo.

Overall, I was really satisfied with the ramen at Katana Ya. I think it is comparable and probably slightly better than Ramen Club, but I can see myself still going to Ramen Club more often because the wait is shorter and the parking is easier. 

The food:

I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen. Basically this ramen includes chicken karaage (friend chicken), deep friend gyoza (potstickers), your regular ramen pork, green onions, butter corn, bamboo shoots, and a broth of your choice (soy, miso, salt). I have never had a ramen with both fried gyoza and karaage before, so I really enjoyed this new variety. The combination of all these components surprisingly worked. The ramen noodles themselves were cooked perfectly, not too soggy, nor overly chewy. The soy broth I chose was not too salty, yet flavorful enough. Furthermore, I felt the proportions were perfect, it filled me up just fine =).

In comparison to my current favorite, Ramen Club, I would say the quality of food seems slightly better. Everything was cooked almost to perfection and the flavors were spot on. Ramen Club can just be as good and actually has (I believe), more variety in terms of ramen choices, but it can also be inconsistent in terms of quality. Therefore, I would say if it was just based on food - I would go to Katana Ya over Ramen Club. Hotei is my least favorite and won't even disrespect Katana Ya by making such comparisons, and Santa Ramen is just plain far and the line is too long for me to like it much either.

The service:

Eh - Let' s just say they get the job done. They sit you, take your order, clear the dishes, and give you the check. Smiles? Friendliness? Well, i guess that's extra. Nonetheless, the mediocre service wasn't bad enough to detract from the good food. Basically I felt that the waitstaff know this restaurant is still a hot place to go and need not waste energy on service to keep the customers coming. 

*Note that I came on a Sunday and got there 5 mins before opening (12pm) and 10 mins after i sat down, the whole restaurant was filled already and a line was formed outside the door.
author: Nathan T.

description:
The food here did not do justice to the high reviews. The ramen here is decent. Nothing spectacular. It's unfortunate to see that this restaurant is supposedly the best ramen you can get in the city because frankly, I've had a lot better. 

Don't get me wrong, it's not bad. It's just not good enough to rant and rave about. I'd go here if I needed an immediate ramen fix and didn't want to do the 45 min drive out to Mountain View for Maru Ichi.

I got the miso ramen and my friend got the fried chicken ramen. The service was cordial and friendly. 

CONS:
TINY restaurant with very little seating. Parking situation is pretty bleak. Only metered street parking which lasts until 6pm on weekdays. I'm not sure how the parking is around the area during that no parking interval, but I'd imagine that it's a pain in the butt.
author: Beck P.

description: mata iku beeeeeeeiiiii -koku stylu...if only they hadn't served the beer in a cold cracked glass....had to ask for another glass for that sapporo draft....tho...NIHONGO de douzo!
author: miriam b.

description:
WOW... This place really went downhill with their ramen. Came in tonight and ordered karaage ramen with soy sauce broth. The broth was like water with soy sauce added to it. And the noodles were all stuck together in clumps. The bf ordered butter corn ramen with salt broth. His wasn't even salty or flavorful. Just tasted like water with a little salt and clumpy noodles. 

TERRIBLE... I can't believe how good it used to be and how shitty it is now....
author: Jen D.

description:
As far as ramen go, it's not the best bowl of ramen of all time. However, it's the only decent bowl of ramen that I can find that is central in the city. I know there's good ramen in the Sunset and the Richmond but let's be real... I'm not going to travel that far just to eat some ramen. 

My favorite is the fried chicken ramen with miso-flavored soup. Be sure to ask for the fried chicken on the side otherwise it gets soggy. Honestly, I really think that Katana-ya has the best fried chicken (karrage). It's lightly breaded, boneless dark meat that is full of flavor. You dip that karrage into your soup, and it's a little bite of heaven. The chasu ramen is on the 7X7 list and I don't understand why. The chasu is kind of bland and not fatty enough. I've had much better chasu ramen at other places.

I'm a fan of their sushi rolls and I like how they have other dishes besides just ramen. It's nice to have the option to order sushi, fried rice, etc. 

This place is TINY. Be prepared to wait for an hour or more if you come at a peak time. I've had to wait at 10pm on a Wednesday before. Is it worth the wait? I think it is because I find a big bowl of hot soup with noodles so comforting. Will it be the best bowl of ramen you've ever had? Probably not, but it'll hit the spot!

P.S. My favorite ramen is Daikokuya in LA. Himawari also serves a pretty good bowl in San Mateo.
author: Jackie T.

description:
Katanaya simply does not compare to any ramen place I've been to in Japan and LA. 

I've heard about this place for awhile now, especially known for their ramen. But when I looked at my neighbors at the sushi bar as well as the possible choices on the menu, I don't think ramen is their "item" to get here. 

A typical place that serve ramen usually wouldn't have a sushi bar as well. But since I was alone sitting and looking at the possible sashimi choices, I made the last minute decision of getting the chirashi sushi. 

As you know, chirashi sushi is one of my gauges for authentic Japanese food in America. The sashimi places were fine, but what is with the brown rice??? I understand that it's more healthy, but brown rice just ruins the traditional taste of the meal. Moreover, the dish is $19! The most I think I've ever spent on chirashi sushi. 

The service was almost nonexistent after my dish was given to me. No refill of tea. The non-Japanese sushi chefs were not conversational and kept to themselves rather than chatting with customers. I even saw one of the sushi chefs eating his dinner right next to the sushi bar in sight of customers. Is that okay? 

My self-compensation for a mediocre dinner? A single scoop of Earl Grey and Salted Caramel ice cream from Bi-Rite.  

If you like authentic ramen experience in the Bay Area, try Santouka Ramen in SJ: http://www.yelp.com/biz/santouka-san-jose-2
author: Kenny L.

description:
Katana-Ya is a straight up hole in the wall type of Ramen house. the soup base here is never consistence. the 1st time i came here was with a friend after watching the Beauty and the Beast musical. I thought i was good food, yummy soup base, not too salty not too bland, it was just right. however, the 2nd time i came here with my boyfriend after Wicked i was not satisfy. the soup was wayyy too salty and the noodle was still hard. although the portion they serve is good because i can hardly finish my bowl is really not worth the wait.  

my 3rd and mostly last time visiting here was for a take out order during my lunch break. i was sick and really wanted something warm so i figure okay i'll give katana-ya another try. i know lunch time they tend to be pretty busy so i figure i'll call ahead to place order so i can skip the wait time there. well they NEVER pick up the phone call. its either they changed their number or the number listed on Yelp is wrong. so i had to walk over and order my ramen and waited 15 minutes for it to be ready.. there goes half of my lunch break already! 

overall, this place is overrated and over hyped. there are better ramen place than katana-ya and less wait time in the city. next time i'm craving Ramen i''ll take a drive to San Mateo to Santa Ramen which is better and consistence with their soup base.
author: Jenny G.

description:
Got the Katanaya Miso Ramen.
Great portions, but way too salty. Bit pricey (~$13 for ramen) but a nice stop for a windy day in SF. Nothing uber special except the tempura chicken in the soup was a nice touch. The salt kind of ruined the experience for me but the soup base was pretty good.
author: Julia P.

description:
Went here for the very first time tonight an I loved it! Mind you I am stuffy, congested and not able to fully taste everything I eat...but it was still amazingly delicious! I was with a friend who was perfectly healthy and said it was amazing! 

We had the "fried chicken ramen" which is served in the largest portion I could ever imagine. The soup was delicious, the chicken was tasty and the location was quaint. We also had California rolls which were good. 

Be prepared to sign up at the front door and wait in line for about 10-20 minutes on very busy days. It's a highly popular location that clearly deserves the hype. 

:)
author: Carlos H.

description:
3.5 stars but seeing as how Yelp STILL hasn't mastered the art of a half or no star review, I will round off to the highest rating instead of the lowest to be nice. Swear, you can make an app for this site but not improve upon the rating system...


Came here with a friend after picking up some party supplies for her job somewhere near-by. After dropping the stuff off she suggested ramen and I was like cool. So we walked a block and came to this place. It's a snug fit of a hole in the wall because if you walk too fast past it you will miss this place. A little bigger than a typical ramen shop in Japan, which in most cases is standing room only with a few seats at the counter.

We were promptly seated because the place was not bustling with the lunch crowd at 3pm. We looked and quickly ordered. I got myself an Extra Spicy Tofu Ramen with Miso Broth and my friend got the Kareage Plate. Ordered a Dancing Bonito roll and the Ame Ebi sushi, as well.

The food came very quickly one after the other. All in all the food was good. The bonito flakes on the roll weren't exactly dancing so that kinda told me the roll was sitting a little too long after getting deep fried. The ramen was good and tender. The soup, however, was a little salty. It looked like they used the spices from the bottom of the kimchi jar to make it spicier. But all in all it was a nice meal.



In closing, this place was alright. It was nice to see ACTUAL Japanese people working and cooking in a JAPANESE restaurant! Nowadays, it either Chinese or Korean runned. And if you plan on eating here be warned. When it starts to get crowded, it will get a little stuffy. Maybe a little stinky like somone's upper lip. Just saying.
author: Anthony L.

description:
The Regular and Mabo ramen was not bad....except there was hardly any meat and just tofu in the Mabo.  The broth was a little salty..... make sure you drink lots of water. 

At $13 for the Lava Roll, I'd expect it to be bigger but it was a tiny 6pcs =[ that tasted mediocre.... it you're hungry, in the area, and need a quick fix, i recommend it! it does get busy tho...so make sure you aren't extremely starving or you might not make the wait!

P.S Parking is a pain in the butt!
author: tracy l.

description: Yes guys!! I gave it a four!! Why because it was delicious!! The place was small and we had to wait for a little bit, but it wasn't that long. The servers were really nice. I ordered the Fried chicken ramen with Miso soup, everyone else ordered Katana-Ya with miso soup, and the butter corn ramen. All was very delectable. It was a rainy day and trust me the broth helped us soothe our throats. Man! it was good! The soup was not too sweet, to salty, nor watered down.  It was the right amount of flavor.  I would definitely come back. Huge portions and pretty reasonable prices $8-12 a bowl. I couldn't finish my ramen. That should tell you something.
author: Vanna Y.

description:
I've eaten at Katana-Ya now a couple of times, and I can only say that it is "alright." The ramen is pretty decent, a little on the oily side, but that's not usually a problem with me. 

The GOOD:  they have a wide selection to choose from with different noodles (somen, ramen, or udon) and broths (miso, shio, or soy sauce). They also have a little sushi bar, so you can fill up on even more carbs with crazy maki and sushi handrolls! Plus, they're open LATE, which is great!

The BAD: The reason why I'm giving this place only 2 stars, when it easily deserves 4, is that I came here last night for a late meal and was turned off mid-ramen by the sushi man's incessant coughing. My partner and I sat at the sushi bar and saw him with our own very eyes coughing like crazy behind the counter while preparing hand rolls! Now, I'm not a total stickler for health codes--being from Hawaii and all where the health regulations are no where near as strict as in California--but this was downright gross! I'm now wondering if I have bad allergies today or if I've picked up a bug! :-(
author: Jenny K.

description:
#130

After checking in to Hotel Adagio down the street, our group was trying to figure out where to eat. Being a cold, rainy, and windy December evening, we wanted something close by.

Something soupy and warm was going to hit the spot just right. I decided to whip out my handy dandy iPhone and enlist the help of the yelp app. The first hit when querying 'ramen' was Katana-Ya. With a four star average over a thousand reviews, it seemed like a safe bet.

There was a bit of a wait even though it was 10pm on a Saturday evening. I think we ended up waiting about thirty minutes. Once we entered the restaurant, I realized how small the inside really was. Despite the fact that the tables were cramped together, it looked to be quite a popular date spot.

As a table, we ordered a couple appetizers:

-Gyoza
They were average. I've had better, I've had worse. I believe the plate arrived with four pieces on board.

-Chicken Kaarage
These were pretty good I thought. The plate came with a creamy, mayo-type sauce and the standard lemon wedge. The pieces were meaty without having too much batter.

And, I ordered:

-BBQ Pork Salt ramen (mild spiciness)
The first thing I noticed about the soup base was the overwhelmingly spicy flavor. Mild had some kick to it! Compared to ramen and curry shops in LA, I'd consider Katana-Ya's mild at least a medium, if not more. Either that, or I was having a very weak sauce day.

For the supposed best ramen in SF, I walked away quite disappointed and so did my friends. I can affirmatively say that I've had better ramen in LA, even at what I'd consider second tier shops. I'm guessing Socal does have a relatively larger Japanese population? But, if this is the best SF has to offer, make sure to get your ramen fix when you travel to LA or NYC.
author: Brandon A.

description:
I would like to say that the first time i stumbled upon this awesome little ramen house i was extremely hungover and in search of a miracle soup, which is usually pho but i couldnt find one in union square so i decided i would try this place.

It was about 3 minutes after it had opened and i am so fucking grateful that i was not those people standing outside watching people slurp away at the delicious broth...we got the last seats and saw the line outside grow. That reassured me that this place was going to be more than just decent.

Of course to rid myself of the hangover i got a pitcher of sapporo, and had some of the home made gyoza...that was pretty damn good. The outside casing of the gyoza was definitely homemade because you can just taste the difference. But be warned the little bastards are extremely hot....i burned my tongue not once, but twice.

the menu is a bit confusing as it looks like some kind of match up game, i decided to go with the fried chicken with miso since they didnt have any pork broth. 

After burning my tongue and having a glass of sapporow, the ramen came. oh my god and then i came. it was so fucking good, the chicken was fried to perfection and hot, the noodles were al dente and amazing. The soup was beyond perfect. this was the ultimate miracle soup. I have now converted to ramen as my hangover broth. 

i nearly ate two bowls as my girlfriend didnt finish hers and i had the rest of it. 

Thank you and screw you katana, you spoiled my taste buds with something so great as ramen. My mouth is salivating too much while im writing this, ill probably have to get my ramen fix in mtn view at maru ichi since the city is just too damn far to drive for ramen.
author: Louis K.

description: This place was pretty good.  I got the combination with sushi and teriyaki salmon, so nothing fancy.  Sushi was good, and the salmon was really tasty.  Accompanying salad and soup were also better than average, and I appreciated the chilled glass for my Sapporo.  Definitely a good stop if you are near Union Square and in need of Japanese refreshment.  Service was quick and efficient, and that's all.
author: Jay C.

description:
Visited around 9:30 pm on a Tuesday night. Had to wait maybe five minutes as the two of us were the first and only ones in line.

We had the chasu ramen in miso broth and the spicy tofu ramen in light soy broth.
The pork in chasu ramen was generous in portion and yummy in taste. The ramen overall was a little bit disappointing though given our high expectations. Definitely not in the same class as the best in nyc, or even the ones in the south bay and peninsula.

The spicy tofu ramen however was a revelation. We didn't realize there would be so much kimchee included in the ramen. That was a huge happy surprise.
author: j d.

description:
Bonus: no wait

.... and that's about it. Maybe the 1,000+ positive reviews inflated my expectations but I was all ready to sit down, tuck in and completely lose myself in noodley ramen heaven. Not so, not so. The first turn off was that their menu said "MSG added" - thanks for being honest but um, also no thanks. 

Your broths of choice are salt (really?), miso and soy. The broth was pretty decent but the entire presentation just seemed standard. The Katana-Ya namesake ramen was loaded with all these yummy sounding fried goodies but it was just overkill: fried balls of chicken, fried pork dumplings, pork, egg ... oof. I think I finished maybe 8 bites before groaning and pushing the bowl away. 

For $14, I think it's better to just break open an instant packet of ramen (Not TOP RAMEN mind you, I have standards) and mix in your own toppings for much cheaper.
author: Faith Y.

description: I nearly gave this place a mere 2 stars for the food and wait (though I'm not sure if I should count that as a ding) until I remembered that it's open late night, which I appreciate. The ramen is fine, but I personally don't see what about it makes it one of the "city's best bowls." I assume those lists are all outdated or written by people who have never ventured west of Van Ness. Portions are okay but the broth and chewy chashu leave much to be desired.
author: Krystle S.

description:
Good butter corn ramen (get it with the miso base).  The broth is just one hair too salty for me (which is a lot less salty than most other ramen places), rich, satisfying, etc.  I could have used, however, more than just one slice of pork in the whole bowl (minus 1 star, would have been 4 stars otherwise).  

Also, despite arriving on a peak shopping day and at the height of the lunch rush, my friend got a table for us (I was running ... late) within 15 minutes.  So that was pretty amazing.  I don't know why people come here with strollers and babies -- where are they going to park those things?  The restaurant is super small, with small spaces between tables = no space for strollers!
author: Olivia L.

description:
Ramen is my ultimate comfort food.  I crave it every time I'm feeling under the weather.  And Katana-Ya is hands down my favorite (and it apparently is a favorite for most as I've never been there when there wasn't a long line, even at 10pm!).

After trying several kinds, my favorite is the Katana Ya ramen with miso soup base (has the works - fried chicken, potstickers, BBQ pork, egg, corn).  The broth is so good, I can't help but slurp it all up.

The decor is just average and the place is puny.  But I hardly notice because you'll find me face-first in the most delicious broth and perfectly chewy ramen.  

Wait, am I getting the sniffles?  Is this a cold coming on?  YES!!
author: F. P.

description:
Had a good dinner there with Katanaya Ramen.  Good flavor. 

Would not come back because they use MSG in the brooth.
author: The M.

description:
Why does one of the best sushi and noodle restaurants have to be across the other coast in San Francisco. I was there last weekend and I had to go 2 days in a row. The place is very small and there is a wait outside but I don't think I waited more then 20 minutes the first night and 5 minutes the second night. 
What I like about them is they have a great variety of fresh Sashimi and also noodles and rice dishes in addition to excellent roles.
author: Mike M.

description: First placed I ever tried a real Ramen (Of course this is no Japan). Their Katanaya ramen is the best.
author: Abel G.

description: Order the Katana-ya ramen! This place is always packed but they do open the downstairs when the ground level is full and about 5 parties waiting! Portions are a good size.. did not try the sushi and probably won't b/c we don't go to a ramen place for sushi (and vice versa). Also, the guys rolling the sushi are not japanese trained sushi chef... couple of guys speaking mandarin.... hmmm
author: Jay S.

description:
This is the destination for ramen, huh?
The wait was brutal, even after correcting for my 20 minute parking search whilst my friend put our name in.  Oh, hello schizophrenic homeless guy accosting the patiently-waiting patrons-to-be on the sidewalk.
The place is small and tight, the menu is a little confusing, and the ramen is good.  Just good.  I can't see why this place is featured in Maxim magazine and 7x7.  
If I'm going to brave Union Square insanity, park my car in the TL, and wait a half an hour, I expect a little more.
author: Eric S.

description:
I think everyone hyped the ramen a little too much. I personally thought it was just okay. I got the fried chicken ramen and the chicken was only crispy for about 5-10 minutes before it got soggy. 

I mean, there wasn't anything special with this ramen from this place. It tasted better with the seasoning you add. I guess the location is very convenient if you are done shopping and you crave ramen. But, if you had the time, ramen from J-Town is a lot better.
author: Amy L.

description:
I had my first visit more than 2 months ago. I ordered their ramen, which was more than ok but I won't miss it compare to Daikokuya in L.A. or Halu in San Jose. The guys next to me ordered quite a few deep fried dishes and it looked pretty good.

Just had my next visit like 2 weeks ago. I decided to try their deep fried Ten Don (Tempura with rice). The tempura was quite nicely fried with a thin batter and crispy enough even served on top of rice. The disappointment was the sauce they used. I would understand the absence of daikon pureé but I did expect bonito sauce. It turned out they drizzled some brownish sauce that taste like a mix of oyster sauce and teriyaki sauce. This totally turned me off. I have to say it's of a food court standard.

The funny thing is it's obvious to me that the majority of the staff is Cantonese speaking Chinese, while they would speak in English with a fake-Japanese accent. If you want to pretend to be Japanese, at least don't serve miso soup with spoon!
author: Roy C.

description: So disappointed.. its used to be my favourite ramen restaurant. Noodle overcooked, no ramen basic ingredients such as bamboo, boiled egg. Way overpriced for this quality.
author: Sze S.

description: The Katanaya ramen was pretty good. I liked the rich miso broth a lot as well as the chicken and egg they throw in there. Not the best ramen I've had, but it got the job done, especially since it was a cold day when we came here. The sushi is more than average price but average quality. I do think the place is pretty small but cozy (try not to sit at the table directly by the door) and the service was very friendly. The place opens at 11:30 but if you want to get an early table, try to be there 15mins early. The line is long and the place is busy most of the time after they open. I wouldnt drive all the way into the city just for this, but if youre in the neighborhood, give this place a shot!
author: Stephen G.

description:
Doesn't come close to anything in the Peninsula.  The rigor and precision in a traditional ramen house is lacking here, even if the noodles look the same.  If you have a car (or access to a zip car) it's worth the 30min drive to Santa Ramen or Ramen Dojo in San Mateo.

Lunch for 2  = $35
author: Christina J.

description:
3.5 Stars

As a heads up to future patrons, Katana-Ya is quite small so do expect to wait for a table when you arrive. That being said get your name signed in on the clipboard and grab a menu to take a look at what you're interested in trying at Katana-Ya.

I recall Katana-Ya is best known for their Ramen, but they do have a lot of other choices if you're not in the mood for Ramen.  I saw sushi, udon noodles, soba noodles, salads, and donburis on the menu as well.

I decided to try Katana-Ya's Ramen to compare it to the other ramen houses I've tried in the Bay Area. It did not WOW me to place it at the top of my list and it wasn't at the bottom of my list either.

To start off, you're provided with three choices for the soup base: Soy Sauce, Miso, and Salt.  I like how you are able to customize it with a lighter or darker broth.  If you like spicy, you can request it make it spicy for an extra surcharge. I remember it was about $1.50 extra to make it SUPER spicy. The broth looked NUCLEAR red. I'd probably be interested in trying this bowl of noodles next time.

For my order, I picked the BBQ pork ramen with the light Soy Sauce broth for $10.50.  My bowl had 4 slices of the pork, which were lean, but were also quite tough to chew on. Accompanying the pork, the bowl of ramen also had bamboo, seaweed, scallions.  The ramen noodles reminded me of the noodles they had at Santa Ramen and that's a good thing. The noodles were not as springy though, most likely because they cooked it longer.

On the side, I also had an order of Hamachi hand rolls that were $5.00 each.  The fish was fresh, but the pieces of fish were not big at all. I remember eating mostly rice by the time I got to the middle of hand roll. This is a good indication at least that the fish they use for their sushi is fresh and tasty.

When I look back at my experience, I don't believe it was worth the 30+ minute wait to get a table.  There are a plenty of other ramen houses in the Bay Area that serves up a tasty bowl of ramen without the long wait.

A big PLUS of Katana-Ya is that it accepts credit cards and not just CASH like many other ramen places.
author: Jason H.

description:
I really only like the lemon soda here.

Oh yeah, and the ice cubes are clear!  That's a plus. 

I don't really like the ramen and it smells dirty in here.  Do you know what dirty smells like?  Well, it smells like jeans that haven't been washed for a year.  It smells like a Good Will except that I didn't immediately want to rip my skin off because it got a horrible allergic reaction.  

More about the ramen: The shio is sweet at first sip but it didn't overwhelm me with deliciousness. The noodles are chewy.  The soup is really hot so I tend to just swallow the noodles whole cause it's too hot to leave in my mouth to chew, hoho. 

After I was done eating, I watched my cousin swat a giant fly.  

The lemon soda is a great palate cleanser.
author: Margaret S.

description: Would give zero stars if I could. Store manager asked us to wait outside in the rain, bitchily. I have never cared enough to give a place a bad review until today. I sincerely hope customers vote with their wallets and find food elsewhere. The food itself is two stars at best. I would recommend jack in the box next door instead. At the very least I can guarantee better service there.
author: Thomas C.

description:
I've gone twice now.

Both times, I got a giant bowl of the Katana-Ya Ramen.  How can you go wrong? A giant bowl of steaming ramen in miso broth with fried pot stickers, fried chicken, pork, corn, hard-boiled egg ... you leave feeling like you just got a warm hug from a Japanese grandma. 

We lucked out an got a lunchtime seat really quickly.  If you live in the city you can go when the timing is right.  And the service is perfect.
author: Cameron M.

description:
First off, let me just say WOW. This is the first time I've had a Ramen noodle soup of any kind but I loved it. Well to be exact I had the chicken yaki soba and it was delicious. Not to mention it was just what the doctor ordered to cure a hangover.

Going on a Sunday morning/early afternoon the wait wasn't long but the restaurant was full. Tried going the night before for dinner but the line was out the door and a minimum 30 mins. After eating here I would say it is well worth the wait. I went with my cousin who is a vegetarian and there were plenty of options for him. This place is great for all types of eaters and tastes.

The restaurant itself was small but the staff was friendly and the crowd boisterous enjoying their meals. The restaurant walls are laden with autographs of celebs and athletes.

Highly recommend!
author: Ankur P.

description:
Date/Time:   Monday - 2:45pm
Occasion:    Lunch
Party of:   Two
Ordered:   Chicken karage, toro sashimi, kimchi ramen extra spicy with soy broth, and extra spicy ramen with miso broth
Location:   Super small with very limited seating.
Total incl gratuity:   $47.00

I highly recommend the ramen.  The noodle is different that anywhere I've ever tried.  The different kinds of broth add a great kick to whichever you decide to order.  The serving sizes are good - you leave feeling satisfied.  I thought the toro was very good and fresh.  You should expect to wait for a seat given the place is so small...but it moves quickly and is worth it.
author: Jess C.

description:
Hands down the BEST ramen soup in SF! I can't wait to try it hungover...ok I'm lying, I was definitely hungover.

I honestly can't wait to go back and try the miso or soy sauce based broth instead of the salt based broth that was very delicious! I had the Katana-ya Ramen and I asked for extra spicy and that is exactly what I got....it did NOT however take away from all the flavors of the meats and veggies which can sometimes be an issue when ordering spicy. As far as the sushi goes, we had the red and white tuna and butter fish with wasabi which was delicious BUT definitely overpriced! I will probably skip the sushi next time I eat here. Rolls are very small yet we paid $14.00 for one order. 

The place is a little tiny hole in the wall, but so cute, full of SF flare! Service also gets a few of these stars here.
author: Genie M.

description:
We read the Yelp reviews and thought we'd give it a try.  Good eggy-tasting ramen that's al dente and not soggy.  Our waitress recommended the miso (not light) flavor.  Pretty salty and I liked it.  I would have given them 4 stars had they not been so stingy with the BBQ pork.  Only 2 slices.  Come on...

Quick service -- we ordered within 5 min and they came with our food 10 min afterwards.  

It's easier to get seated by yourself or party of 2 than any larger parties.  We waited for 5 minutes for a party of 2 at 8:30pm on a Friday night.  Not bad.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
Coming from a guy who eats sushi and ramen almost every other week in LA, this place was pretty good. I never have any issues with eating at hole in the wall joints. I love them! 

The wait for this restaurant was a bit long considering it's real small inside and it was a Friday night. We showed up around 8 and had to wait for about 45 minutes. When we put our name on the list, there was 11 parties ahead of us. The wait was well worth it though. 

The fried chicken ramen was very good and the soup base was really rich. The rolls were fresh and yummy. If I'm ever in the area again and am looking for a good Japanese fix, Katana-ya will definitely be in my mind.
author: Smitcha B.

description:
This would be a 5 star review if the pork hadn't been incredibly tough and flavorless.

I was able to try the regluar soy broth ramen and the BBQ pork ramen with miso broth.  Both soups were DELICIOUS... the broth and noodles were perfect.  But the pork was awful!  It was really tough and not flavorful.  What a disappointment!  Maybe I caught them on a bad day.  When you're talking ramen, the broth, noodles and pork are the main things... 2 of 3 isn't good enough!!
author: Kelly O.

description:
I have only been here once, so I may have to come back and write another review. However it is a small restaurant that is always crowded and has a waitlist on the door for you to sign, so that is a good sign that shows it's probably a really good restaurant.

I'm superrrr picky about Japanese food, so I was veryyy surprised that I was satisfied with this restaurant. I ordered the spicy tuna don, it was delicious and I could tell it was FRESH. I also ordered the agedashi tofu. It was decent, better than most restaurants but not the best. My boyfriend had some kind of ramen and he really enjoyed it.

I would definitely come back just for the spicy tuna don.
author: Kayla I.

description: If you happen to go see a play at ACT theater or you're near Union Square, you MUST go Katana-Ya for lunch or dinner. This little tiny restaurant is packed at all times.  Until this day, I always still order the same Spicy tofu ramen. The noodles is homemade and you can't find any ramen that taste this good.
author: Connie W.

description:
Prepare yourself for a real treat.  We stopped in for a late afternoon bite of sushi, then went back for a late night bowl of ramen. Then went back two nights later for another bowl of ramen. 

We don't tend to eat at normal hours as we are night shift workers, so we never had more than a 5 minute wait for two of the 25 seats in this little hole in the wall. 

The signature dish, the Katanaya Ramen (ordered with medium spice miso) is, to this tourist, a joyous bowl of steaming goodness. Having never been to Tokyo I don't have the perspective of some reviewers, but I'm not lying when I tell you that I enjoyed my meals and found the cost quite reasonable.
author: Ken S.

description:
After years of coming to this spot and eating the BBQ pork ramen every freaking time it's time for an update. I am now eating the Fried Chicken ramen and I have to say, that too is amazing. It's like yum all around.
Also now they have noodles made out of tofu or something so my gluten free man can have his ramen too.
author: Tracy P.

description:
After a long trip out of town, came here for a bowl of ramen because I remembered they open late.  Ordered the katanya ramen. Friends had 
the fried chicken ramen, and mapo ramen.

The consistency of the ramen noodles here are very good. Al dente and chewy. The portions on the katanta ramen is also good. Comes with two fried potstickers, two pieces of chicken karaage, and two pieces of chia-su pork. I just wish they would automatically give you the fried food on the side since it gets soggy swimming in the soup. 

They also give you a choice of the broth flavors. Miso, Salt, Soy. I opted for the soy this time. All the flavors are okay. But the best broth award still goes to Santouka in the south bay.

The wait here can be a pain. 9pm + on a Sunday and there was still a wait for a table.

A decent choice if its late and you want ramen, or if you happen to walk by and there isn't a wait.
author: Randy K.

description:
It wasnt as good as i anticipated it to be.....sadly, ive had better. I actually ordered the Alaskan king crab, roe, salmon Don.  Which was really good, and the perfect size.  But for $10 id rather go to Tani Kitchen.  The ramen was aight, nothing too special to me. Id personally would like the noodles to be chewier.  

The squishyness also is a prob.  But it is funny listening to some middle-aged korean ladies next to us curse in broken English about their ex-husbands. HAHA
author: kim w.

description:
Delicious.
Piping hot generous portions of hand pulled ramen with your choice of broth. How can it get any better?
First time I came to Katana-Ya, I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen with the miso broth and it didn't do me fancy. It made me wonder why everyone was so hyped up about this place with the cramped eating space and loud people..until I gave it another go and ordered the fried chicken ramen with the soy broth.
That soy broth totally sold me and now I am tied forever to Katana-Ya.
I love their bouncy, chewy noodles. Ahh goodness.
Thanks for being honest about the use of MSG in your noodles. I greatly appreciate it, and no it wont affect my visit in the future.
Gotta go back and try the spicy broth.
author: Ellie C.

description:
I love ramen! And you will find nothing short of the most delicious of it's kind right here (MSG added, boo). There's always a wait, so come early. But the line moves quite quickly. 

Love the Philly Roll and Golden Roll, not a fan of their California roll. 

Horrible soundtrack on instant replay guaranteed!
author: Tizia B.

description: Service was pleasant in a relatively sketchy neighbourhood. The ramen was unique (had fried gyoza and breaded chicken pieces in the soup) but definitely not authentic. It was also a bit on the pricey side, not recommended if you prefer decent Japanese ramen.
author: Chris Z.

description: The ramen here is by no means bad, but I've certainly had better. I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen with miso broth, which is ramen in miso soup, sliced pork, fried chicken nuggets, corn, and hard-boiled egg. The noodles were decent and slightly al dente. The fried chicken was a nice touch I have not had before. The broth was a little bit of a let down. I am used to a richer/porkier flavored broth. This is not a tonkatsu broth, which I was sort of expecting even though I did not see it explicitly on the menu. The broth was okay, but a little too salty and again lacking the deep, rich flavor I crave. The best thing about this place is that it is open really late, and serves as a good antidote to those late night drinking sessions.
author: Eugene C.

description:
I have high standards for ramen, coming from Hawaii. And I've been feeling the itch lately to stuff my face with it; since I've read a bunch of ramen reviews for Katana-Ya, I figured I'd give it a try. I'd been here several times before but only at like 1am where there's no line and no crazies showing their gaping wounds and incoherently begging for money from those poor souls who are usually stuck outside during peak hours. It's heaven. Eat dinner at 1am instead of 7pm.

Well, I did come here at 7pm last night on a whim and there was one hell of a line. And I did get accosted by a man/woman with a beard who was lifting up her jackets to reveal a GIANT gaping wound on her stomach with a medical bag coming out of it to catch the liquids and decorated with other soiled bandages. GREAT. SHE CAME UP TO ME TWICE. NO I DON'T HAVE MONEY. I SHOULD BE COOKING FOOD AT HOME BUT I'M FEELING NAUGHTY.

Anyway, I intended to make this review short because basically 1000 people have already said the same thing. The ramen is great. Not ABSOLUTELY SPECTACULAR, but tasty indeed. I got the Spicy Tofu ramen, and it was bigger than any bowl of ramen I've ever seen and also not that spicy. But the miso broth was rich (but not majorly flavorful, unfortunately), the noodles were perfectly al dente, there was a generous amount of tofu and they added cilantro for me, no questions asked. Well worth the money and mostly worth the wait and perfect for a blustery cold day in SF.
author: Laura M.

description:
Um, this place is overrated. I arrived at 11:30 with my sister. We perused the ridiculously option-heavy menu and settled on shoyu ramen with an unagi roll combo for me and a bowl of soba with chicken for her. They were training a new server that day who was pretty clueless. Even though the first server dropped off water, we waved and gestured futilely to try and get the new server's attention in order to request tea. Finally, another server noticed us and brought back the lukewarm tea. The server managed to write two of the three items down incorrectly, bringing out an unagi bowl with rice and a bowl of udon instead of soba with chicken. They quickly resolved the order, but I was surprised that they got it wrong in the first place.

The ramen noodles were medium width and straight. They were cooked a bit on the softer side. The soup, which I ordered regular, was just okay. The shoyu was a bit thicker than other places, but not very deep in flavor. The bowl was garnished with several pieces of seaweed, a handful of pickled bamboo shoots, green onions, and a single dry slice of roasted pork. Where is my half slice of boiled egg? The portion size was okay, but I wasn't that impressed overall. As for the unagi roll, there were tiny fish bones stuck to the rice which were odd. The roll itself was nothing memorable. My sister said her soba was quite bland and helped herself to a couple of spoonfuls of my shoyu soup. I tried the noodles and they were cooked beyond limp, which is why I guess soba is usually used for dipping. The chicken was boiled and tasteless and the soup and garnishment of napa cabbage didn't add anything.

I'm not sure about the popularity of this place, or the line that formed outside the door. There are definitely better ramen options in SF. I won't be back, as those three items alone cost $27! Overrated AND overpriced!
author: Leslie H.

description:
Very fun, authentic, casual and yummy environment. Huge delicious portions of ramen noodles with a twist; add your favorite veggies , meats and level of spicy-ness. Sushi and katzu don is to die for as well ! Enjoy this busy little shop. Asian food, with a mainly Japanese emphasis. 

#beennearlyeverywhere #i'veeateninover40statesand20countries
author: Seemewrite C.

description: I don't know why this place only has 3 stars!! Best thing about going to San Francisco was the piping hot bowl from ramen from here! Hands down, the best ramen I've ever had!
author: Brandy N.

description:
Eh..That's all I have to say. 

My friend ordered the Katana Ramen which includes deep fried chicken, deep fried potstickers, BBQ pork, and corn. I ordered the butter corn ramen with miso broth. They were both good but not impressive. I've had better. I've had ramen in Japan and ramen in Hawaii. Katana-ya ramen was just OK. Noodles got soggy after 10 minutes or so. Broth was flavorful BUT it has msg. Although they mention the msg in the menu, I didn't care. I like msg. I'm Chinese. I grew up with msg. So, if you do not want msg, you need to let them know. They can give you broth without the msg. Your order will take a little longer but it might be worth it for all you msg haters. 
Lines are always long during peak hours. So go early and write your name down and go shop.
author: Molly T.

description:
The Saturday after thanksgiving my fiancé and I were in Union Square and looking for a place to have lunch. It was cold and a little rainy so we ended up going to Katana-ya for ramen. 

Appearance: the place itself is on the smaller side but we were very comfortable sitting at the sushi bar. I always hate when I don't have a place to put my purse (and I don't like putting it on the back of the chair) but there were hooks underneath the counter as well as a shelf to put our coats or any other loose items. Just remember to grab them when you leave!

Customer Service: As soon as we walked in the door the waitress asked us to go outside and put our name on the sheet outside. I wasn't particularly bothered by it but I know if my mom were to go to this restaurant and get talked to that way, she would be turned off by it. We waited outside on entryway and read the menu while we waited which was nice because as soon as we sat down (about 5-10 minutes later) we knew exactly what we wanted. We were greeted right away by our server which was nice. She promptly gave us ice water and took our order.

FOOD: There are several options on how to order your ramen. I ordered the spicy tofu and substituted the ramen noodles for Udon noodles for an extra $1 charge. I also go the miso flavor with thick broth.  The portions are quite large(especially mine since I used the udon noodles which needed a much larger bowl). The flavor was good but I didn't think it was very spicy. Next time I would order it more spicy but just advise, every time you add something to your order they charge an additional $1.
My fiancé got the #12 which seemed to have everything in it but the kitchen sink. From potstickers, tofu, bbq'd pork, ramen noodles and more! He said it was good but definitely could have been spicier. (fyi-we like spicy food so this is just our opinion)

The food was filling, our water glasses were always filled, the service was quick. I enjoyed this place and will definitely be going back!
author: Whitney S.

description: One of the few places that offers dons as a combo dish to their ramen. For $12-$16 you can get a miso/shoyu ramen + a rice side dish. I got the Hokkaidodon which was surprisingly good. They use real crab meat instead of imitation crab. This place is small though so expect a wait and line outside.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Love it here! 

I normally get the spicy green onion ramen in regular (as opposed to light) miso broth, which comes one piece of meat (yes I wish there were two or three slices, but this dish is still amazing).  I love how it's acceptable to slurp noodles here. 

I've had cilantro ramen and spicy tofu ramen and chasu ramen, but my favorite is still spicy green onion.

I've also had the soba w/ tempura and that is another favorite of mine as well.

My only complaint is that there is often a long wait  which is not out of the ordinary when going to a restaurant with good food, but sometimes the waiter/waitress may call your name quietly (or silently) and it is up to you to make sure you're standing there so you get assigned a seat.
author: Erica D.

description:
Seeking out good ramen can often be a fraught experience.  Such was the case with Katana-Ya, where my Yelp-inspired hopes of discovering a decent bowl were laid to rest.

I ordered the Katana-ya ramen (i.e. everything) in soy broth.  The broth was basically satisfactory, and as far as proteins, I can say the same for the goyza and bits of corn.  The roast pork and fried chicken I was much less pleased with, being that both were overly laden with fat and somewhat rubbery in texture.  

Service was quick and, despite the cramped space, my party was never made to feel rushed.

I liked Katana-Ya well enough but I wouldn't necessarily come here again next time I am in SF.
author: Christopher R.

description:
Definitely delicious ramen, but it came at a price.  First of all, the bf and I waited about half an hour for a table since this place is TINY (and eerily dark inside).  

I got the Spicy Tofu Ramen in rich miso broth and we split 2 of the Salmon Avacado Rolls, which were so BUTTERY. 

I didn't notice on the menu that they add MSG to their ramen, and I usually try to avoid MSG as much as I can since I tend to get really bloated, tired, and thirsty after ingesting anything w/ MSG.  My ramen must have had TONS of MSG because even before we stopped eating, my vision started to blur and I thought for a moment my eyes were just getting misty-eyed from all the deliciousness piling up in my digestive tract, but soon dizziness, lightheadedness, and a POUNDING headache ensued.

When we left the restaurant, my headache was so bad that we had to stop by a nearby Walgreens to pick up some Excedrin and a giant bottle of water.  I would still recommend this place, but I'd recommend requesting ramen w/ no MSG, unless you want to spend the next 3-4 hours drooling on the bed and yelling at your lamp for being too loud.  Trust me, I speak from experience.
author: Jen L.

description:
So simple yet so delicious - Ramen!  It's a small little joint so we ended up waiting for 45 minutes in the cold before getting seated.  I had the miso bbq pork ramen and they were a tad skimpy on the slices of pork.  The bowls and spoons sure were big!  On a cold day, the hot broth and noodles really hit the spot.  The noodles had a good texture as they weren't too soggy or soft. He had the japanese curry and again they were very VERY skimpy on the meat.

The ramen here really is delicious but there are plenty of comparable if not better ramen places in the south bay closer to home so I don't think I'd trek out here for the ramen.
author: Steph N.

description:
Oh baby! I just had the Katanaya Ramen (BBQ pork, fried chicken, hard-boiled egg, corn, etc.) and it was fantastic!!! The waitress also asked how spicy I wanted it and I asked that it have a small amount of spice. It was the perfect amount that it made the noodle dish hot but it wasn't so strong that it hid the flavor. It was absolutely perfect!

I'm on a week-long business trip. And the food was so good that I will probably come back before I leave.
author: Jason B.

description:
Had this place once when I was still a ramen newbie. Now I know the types of things I like, so I was hoping that would help me this second time around.

There are three broth types: miso, soy sauce, and salt.
Then you can select: rich or light.

There are also various options of types of ramen.

I was sad to see that there was no pork (tonkotsu) broth, because all other broths I tried, I didn't like. I did remember trying a sip of my friend's Salt broth at Tanpopo before and I think it's just a plain broth.

I decided to get the Spicy Green Onion Ramen with rich broth in salt. Good choice! My favorite of the broths my two friends and I got. One friend got the Katana-Ya Ramen which comes with everything with the miso rich broth and that was good, too, though I liked mine a little. Mine came with plenty of green onion sliced very thinly so you can eat them, and one piece of pork. The broth was oily, which I didn't mind, probably "rich" just means more fat. Can't remember what the last friend had, but I think it was a light broth since she didn't specify, and I didn't like that as much.

Maybe I just like more rich broth which is what Tonkotsu (pork) broth is. Helps me re-evaluate what I like about ramen.

Wasn't too much of a wait for us either, which I was surprised about. Came around noon on a Saturday, put our names on the list and waited about 10 minutes. Pretty cramped in there, but we didn't mind since we all enjoyed the ramen.

This is now in my top 3 places with Santa Ramen and Maru Ichi.
author: Anita C.

description:
Yummmmm for the ramen! I tried the Katanya special this time with Salt soup and it was sooooo good. We had mild-spicy added to it and all the spicy was left on the bottom but the ramen was still the best thing we ate. 

Also ordered the combo meal, chicken katsu with salmon and the salmon was really dry and bland. We had to drench it with tempura sauce. Stick with the ramen and gyozas and ur tummy will stay happy!
author: Amy S.

description:
I dont get what the hype about this place is all about... I didnt think it was all that.  I went there for lunch with my buddy around 2 thinking we would miss the lunch crowd, but i think everyone else had the same idea.  We put our names up and waited about a half hour before being seated.  
When we finally got seated my friend and I ordered the Katanaya-Ya ramen spicy.  Our order came out fast but they gave us the wrong order.  We had to send it back and it took quite a while for the order to come the second time. When I got my ramen is was only OK the broth had some flavor but the Ramen wasn't aL dente like I like it.   and the ramen was way over priced, i will not go back.
author: Mike K.

description:
Hrm this place isn't bad!! And after all this time running around the city I never been into this place. To my disgust... the place was overlooked by the damn Jack in the Box hogging the spotlight in the corner. 

Its how I pictured how a ramen shop should be. Not too hipster and the environment had a mid range ambiance. I was seated at the bar and I was really indecisive cause of what I was looking thru by means of yelp. Yelp can only provide some good visuals but its lacking unless you are actually there to experience it. At least you don't have to wait outside before being seated.

What I had/ what to expect? :

- #12 Katana Ya Ramen w/ spicy miso (cause I have to have my food spicy)
- Spicy tuna roll (6 pcs)? I dont remember what I gotten
- cup of genmacha

I was positioned in in front of the sushi chefs. I usually end up being seated by a booth or a single table in the middle of the restaurant for some reason. I usually take a late dinner consisting of me being very indecisive at first but I boil it down to something that I haven't tried or haven't had for a while. The chefs are fast at preparing the meals since my roll was a handmake it didn't take that long and the quality of the fish that night was pretty good. It took about maybe a good 15 mins or so to get the signature ramen out to me and it was spicy as requested. Unfortunately I didn't get too many add on's this time since I was on a budget. What I did like was it was a bit more spicier than the ramen that I had at Izakaya. First time I ever had chicken karaage in my ramen. It went pretty well that night but I didn't get any alcohol. I did leave on a full stomach as always. I was a bit upset at how one of the patrons came a bit after me but the didn't finish their meal. I remember hearing the waitress asking if he would like it to go but he left it there. Such a waste of ramen... but maybe he had some other issues. 

I'd go back here cause its not hiding away from any of the main streets. The place may look a bit old but it does have that feel of being more authentic and less hipster. I like this place because its a bit more tone down and not all too crazy.

More variety = more things to try the next time

Hope this place works out for you peeps who love to have their dinner and ramen in the latter part of the evening!! So reminds me of that drama Tiger & Dragon. Best wishes on your next meal and good hunting!! Mission complete!!
author: Xeirhen V.

description:
Ok.

This may be the best ramen in San Francisco.

At the same time I've been spoiled by the great ramen joints in LA (daikokuya, etc) and NY (ippudo, etc) and Katana-ya is by no means even close to comparison.

The broth doesn't have that simmered for 24 hours taste and feel and the pork is cooked how they want it, just not how you probably want it (steamed, braised, slow-cooked) aka its not tender.

that being said, on a rainy day when you want a nice bowl of ramen in san francisco, katana-ya is the way to go
author: Noah P.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! I wish they would expand, but one would only hope. The one thing I ABSOLUTELY hate is waiting. A place with great ramen will most definitely come with a complimentary line. 
What never disappoints is the crazy bums that walks by asks for money who smells of booze and urine. Oh, and pees on the wall at jack in the box a few doors down. Inside is super duper cozy, might be too close for comfort for some people who have a larger personal bubble. I usually get my default Katana-Ya Ramen with the shoyu soup base with the chicken .
