I'm not a big fan of the rich soup base cuz I can just see the fat floating around... which is what rich means. more fat = more flavor! :) Somehow, I always get seated next to the booth by the door where the bowl of lollipops are. AWESOME!! I always grab one... (or two) on my way out. :)
author: Wendy L.

description: Ramen was below average egg was nothing more then a hard boiled egg dry an lacked flavor the miso broth wasn't great either. Not worth the wait I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Troy K.

description:
I burnt my tongue when I took my first bite, but it was totally worth it!

I've been on this soup bender for a few months. Pho, wonton soup, and the soup from Safeway are my favorites. Maybe because it's the winter months and there's nothing like a hot bowl of soup on a cold day. 

The last time I had authentic ramen was in Socal (Shin-Sen Gumi in Fountain Valley) a few years back and I never found a place here. This place has been bookmarked in my mind for a few months and I just got around to checking this place out.

My first time around here, I have the traditional ramen with miso soup. Loved the noodles and the broth. Next time, I was torn between the ramen with the fried chicken, spicy tofu ramen, or kimchee ramen. I chose spicy tofu ramen with soy base and I was pleasantly surprised that there was kimchee in it too! A Korean soon tofu soup/ramen hybrid.

The place is small so come during off-peak hours. It's across from the Curran theater and a block from Union Square. 

PS. The paintings of the owls in the bathroom is creepy. They're looking at you when you pee!
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
Came here late (between 10 and 11) on a Saturday night. The restaurant is very small, so we still had to wait for about 20-30 minutes. We ordered the miso cilantro ramen and the bbq pork don. 

I was pretty disappointed with the ramen. First of all, don't get the cilantro ramen. Its pretty much their regular ramen with a entire bunch of cilantro dumped onto the bowl. So you're pretty much paying an extra dollar for it. I had to take most of it out anyways because it was getting in the way of the food.

Here's my break down for the ramen:

Broth - very salty and unremarkable. There wasn't much depth in flavor like the broth at Santouka and Maru Ichi, This was my least favor aspect of the ramen

Noodles - perfect al dente...the noodles weren't bad with a decent chew, although my dining partner thought they need to be cooked more...just depends on your preference.

Pork - the bbq pork was very disappointing...not really fatty or tender...Santouka stands a head above this place when it comes to meat.

All in all a very mediocre bowl of ramen.

I don't think I will be coming back, especially with the wait.  Definitely subpar in comparison with Santouka, Orenchi, and Maru Ichi
author: Cindy C.

description:
I'm sorry, but if this place is one of the better examples of ramen the Bay area has to offer, I am sad for you guys.

Obviously, it's not going to be able to compete with the unbelievable ramen houses I've been to in Tokyo, but I don't feel that I'm missing too much by going to my favorites in NY like Minca, Totto, Momofuku, and Ippudo.

What takes this spot down several huge notches though is the wait!  Even on a Monday night, I had to stand there for an hour, hoping and praying that our name would be called to sample the food.  I know the seating is limited, but why are there so many people angling to try what amounts to very mediocre food?
author: Christopher D.

description:
I cannot believe this place has almost 2000 reviews - I never knew this place existed until last night, despite walking and driving by it hundreds of times. Walking in, one can see why it literally defines "hole-in-the-wall". Because of this, although we were there at 10pm on a weeknight, our party of 5 still had about a 15 minute wait in the cold amidst the interesting panhandlers of the TL. 

We sat at the sushi bar which was cozy and the Japanese convo flowing between the sushi chefs gave an air of authenticity. I ordered the Katanaya Ramen, which was deliciously filling, with everything but the kitchen sink in there - fried gyoza, chicken, hard boiled egg and of course, ramen! Perfect for a cold night and my sore throat. Our eyes were bigger than our stomachs and we also ordered sushi rolls: a pretty standard Philly Roll and Rainbow Roll, and an absolutely delicious roll called the Rising Sun roll, which contained crab, avocado, tuna, halibut and a quail egg on top - amazing!

Extra props for being open late!
author: Stephanie L.

description: Been to a few ramen places but this ones the best by far!!!
author: Marwa A.

description:
Best Raman I have had in SF!
Very good Spicy Raman base, with many toppings [ you dont get just noodles & soup]

I love the "Katana-ya Raman" - extra spicy with miso base!
This comes with slices of BBQ pork, 2 pieces of fried chicken, 2 fried pot stickers, seaweed, bamboo shoots, and corn!
author: Brian H.

description: I ordered the miso ramen and was not very impressed.  The broth lacked flavor and the noodles were overcooked.  The wait was long and not worth it. I would not recommend this spot for your ramen cravings.
author: Ren A.

description:
The WAIT here is a nightmare. Got in line while still bright and sunny and finally got seated at dawn.

The SERVICE is OMGEEEE BAD. Asked for tea and water for two and server came by with ONE cup of water and ONE cup of tea.WTF?  Not to mention that we had to ask for our check 4 times(not exaggerating).

The FOOD is what gave this review 2 stars. We ordered the calamari and Katanaya Ramen. Calamari is yay okay. The ramen was really good, except that they decided to add random big pieces of  fried Gyoza (BTW tasted like frozen costco gyozas) + Chicken karagae + a ton of salt and MSG= Instant artery blocker

The AMBIANCE is like a low budget strip bar minus the pole. I personally dont enjoy my ramen with heavy punk rock Japanese music but thats just me.
author: Gina H.

description:
Katana-Ya is the hole in the wall, late night Ramen place I have been searching for far and wide.

The fried chicken ramen with soy broth was perfect. The texture of the ramen was right on the money and the flavor delicious. The broth was excellent and the fried chicken was a definite positive surprise. 

The hamachi and spicy tuna were fresh and simple and a nice start before the ramen. 

Definitely a 4.5 stars rounded up to a 5. I'll be heading back for sure and this time its two bowls for me.
author: Kristopher Z.

description:
Very delish ramen here of course. 

I got the BBQ Pork Ramen in the rich soy broth. It was very tasty. Altho after awhile, the broth was too fatty and rich for my taste.

Next time, I am just getting regular broth.

I dont get anything but the ramen.
author: Jen T.

description:
Ever watch a Mexican eat with chop sticks?  Today I experienced just that when I went to Katana-ya for lunch.  It is so funny watching my coworker hold chopsticks like a pair of taquitos between his fingers.  The best was at the end watching him knock the entire bowl of broth back.  I love diversity and especially love seeing different cultures experience food outside of their comfort zone.  Myself included. 

We had a diverse crowd at Katana-ya which must say something about this little Japanese noodle house.  I discovered this place through www.sfgate.com and it lived up to the review.  Small, cheap and good food.  Ramen is yummy in Miso broth but don't pay the extra for a bit of dried up BBQ pork.  The fried rice is the best I have ever enjoyed.  Not greasy at all, I should have asked how they managed to do a tasty non greasy rice.  

Good stuff but I still think you can go to Yo Yo's and get Udon that is just as good if not better.  See my Yelp on Yo Yo's 
http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?q=Yo+Yo&userid=XmedPAJrptlUt9ZoaF3FNQ

Great bonding experience with my coworkers and worth a try.
author: Scott P.

description:
This place is pretty good. food is B. service A.
anything you get will be satisfying.
author: Roy P.

description: This is a very small restaurant, but totally worth going to and waiting for a table if necessary.  The ramen was excellent.  There are quite a few different varieties for you to choose from off the menu.  The portions are very large and you could share one bowl with another person.
author: Peter C.

description:
They have a great selection of different toppings for your ramen, ranging from your traditional BBQ char-siu pork, karage, tonkatsu to kimchi tofu. 

I tried the char-siu ramen with extra spicy broth and found it to be decent, but definitely nothing like the akamaru at Ippudo in NYC. Had to add a splash of vinegar and a dash of more spicy pepper to give it a kick. The noodles weren't anything to write home about, but it satisfied my craving for soup noodles (although if you were looking for bang for your buck, head over to Little Saigon and grab some pho). 

Be warned that this place is tiny. It's almost preferable to get your food to go and retreat somewhere else. However, the servers are very friendly and enthusiastic if you do decide to stick around and wait out the line of people trying to get in.
author: Ruby C.

description:
You can't throw a rock in San Francisco without hitting the side of like four sushi joints. 

I wasn't originally gonna write a review for this place, but it's too damn good. This is my chance to gush. Best damn ramen in SF, period. Like the best sushi in SF. Some of the most creative dishes I've seen, and definitely the most ethnically true to Japanese form and taste. How do I know this...because I've dated three different Japanese girls, legally that makes me an expert. No lie, google that shit.

To bring it down a notch, I really like the service I get at this place. They always serve you with a smile and are knowledgeable about what they're serving. They're more than willing to suggest if you're new to the sushi thing, or spot on if you're a veteran looking for something to reinvigorate your sushi spirit.

The joint is really small, and it's always packed. I've never even been there after 5pm because there's too long of a wait. I kinda wish it were bigger for just that reason. Even with the small space, the waiter/waitress is always hustlin'. It's kinda of hard to get upset bout that because you see them working their ass off trying to please everybody. 

I recommend checking in often because there's always something new on the menu. I love it; it's like an adventure each and every time I go. The food is always fresh. Their prices are reasonable too. You can really lose your shit eating of some of these sushi places, and still walk away unsatisfied. If you know nothing else about me, know that I'm a man that demands satisfaction. I overeat at this place, every time, without fail. Their chef is to be feared.

Now, for no other reason than I simply can, a haiku:

Deep in the river below
My gaze is skyward
I hella like raw fishies xD
author: Shirrod R.

description:
3.5 

I'm so torn between giving this place a 3 and a 4.  On one hand, it's easily the best ramen I've had in Norcal so far.  On the other hand, I've been spoiled by having awesome ramen in Socal & of course, Japan.  

I got the BBQ Pork/Chashu ramen, with extra rich miso broth.  Definitely get the extra rich broth, it adds a nice level of fattiness to the broth.  Chashu was excellent, tender and lots of flavor.  Noodles were a good texture and cooked to the right chewiness.  Serving are definitely big here, but it was a cold night and I was starving, so it was perfect!

Boyfriend got the Katana-Ya ramen, which has loads of random stuff in it: karaage, gyoza, boiled egg, chashu... pretty tasty!  

Verdict: definitely tasty & open late!
author: Joyce H.

description:
After a lengthy internet search to find a place that served ramen in San Fran, I finally settled on Katana-Ya.  It was not terribly far from where I was staying and it had been reviewed by many.  

On a recent trip to Japan, I had some of the most delicious ramen and was looking for some place that would come even close.  Katana-Ya does a pretty good job, although I wish they had a Tonkatsu broth ramen.  Anyway, the texture of the noodles were good.  Not too far from the "real deal".  The broth there was not bad...though not stellar either.  It was a satisfying meal and I'll go back if I'm ever in the area.  

As for the sushi, I was pretty disappointed although I am very picky when it comes to sushi.  I would have never served the uni that they did.  I'll stick with the ramen only next time.

In summary, stick to the ramen and it is a pretty satisfying meal.
author: Vy A.

description:
I was on a business trip by myself and was staying at one of the fun hotels on Union square when I decided to find out what was nearby.  Happy to see that Katana-ya was within walking distance of my hotel and the cold weather urging me to go for piping hot noodles, I threw my jacket on and trekked the few blocks over. There was a bit of a wait, but it wasn't bad. Since I was by myself I sat at the bar, but I didn't mind.  

The ramen noodles and broth was by far - THE BEST - I've had within the past 10 years.  I was so impressed by the depth of flavor and the texture of the ramen. The memory of it makes me want to go back there the next time I'm in SF which will hopefully be soon!

HONTO oishi desu ne!
author: michelle v.

description:
I may be a newb to the ramen scene, but this rates higher than the first ramen joint I went to and the crap I ate as a teenager.  Their sushi is sub-par and the wait can be long at times (especially when it's raining and you're standing on the sidewalk).  When I've had the craving for ramen this place has definitely satisfied it.  I thought having a piece of fried chicken in a bowl of miso would be, how shall I say it, soggy, but it was a nice addition. 

I've heard there are better places out there for ramen, but until I try one better, this place gets the four stars.
author: Michael R.

description:
Hubby read about this spot in Maxim and we were both pleasantly surprised to see it was just a few doors down from our hotel (Warwick).
Known for their ramen, we sat down anxious to check out their menu. Hubby ordered the house ramen (Katana-ya ramen) with the salt flavor and I ordered the pork ramen with miso flavoring. Party in our mouths, both dishes were delicious! Dirt cheap too! The place can get pretty packed and a waiting line can form as early as 8pm. Try this place out if you're in the area! We're really glad we did. Thanks Maxim! :)
author: Abby N.

description:
Hot ramen on a frikkin freezing SF night? I'm all over that shit. This place is hidden all stealthy like a ninja, but if you just look for the line outside of it (at like *all* times of the day), you're in the vicinity. You'd think at 10PM, you'd catch a break...but not so much. It is, however, invaluable to know that this place is open till 1am all the time. Win!

After waiting in line for about a half hour (we had a party of 4...note to self....come back with smaller group), we got into the warmness. Sake and beer on the menu to continue the post yelp holiday party buzz...double win! I take a peek at the menu, and note at the top of the ramen menu there is note that says that all dishes have MSG. You know what that means? They are all going to taste fucking awesome!

I got the super spicy ramen w/ miso broth, which was spicy, but not so insane tasting at the time. It was, however, amazingly delish. Perfect for what ailed my drunk, frozen ass that night. I would warn you to take some appropriate bathroom precautions for the following day if you go the spicy route...apparently it was a lot hotter than my taste buds were giving it credit for.

End real review...enter awesome story:

The night took a turn for the bizarre here when we were approached by this stumbling drunk, rich-ish looking older woman in heat. First I thought she was a bum, but then realized she didn't smell like pee, and that she was wearing huge earrings. In a polite I'm-your-granny-who-just-baked-you-cookies kind of voice, she asks me, "can I have your beer?".  For serious? WTF bitch!? How the hell can you get so wasted on a monday??

On wait...I think I did that the week before. Talk about pots and kettles and blackness all at the same time...yah. I digress.

After turning down this amazingly suave attempt to get my beer, she immediately turns around to the table next to us (with 2 of the nicest, coolest, people ever), and asks them the same...in more of a telling sense since she snagged a beer off their table just like a mousetrap can catch a mouse right after the cheese has been lifted. At this point, the server comes over and asks the wicked beer stealing with of the west if she is OK. There is a long pause where I was thinking one of the 3 things was going to happen:

A) The chick would be kicked out
B) The couple would kick the chick's ass
C) The chick would puke everywhere and slip on her vomit

Instead, the write-in candidate prevailed. The couple asked the hag to join them! WTF!? After a 30 minute convo with them, the nice couple leaves with their eyes rolling. At this point, the drunky is out on the prowl again..and finds some nice people with yelp staff sweatshirts on. To my amazement, they offer her a seat too!!!

WTF peeps! I know you prolly want to point and laugh at the drunky, but seriously...asking her to plop a sqat is always a bad call. Didn't your momma ever tell you to not talk to strangers?? I give them a fishing reel type gesture...which is of course universal sign language for "you need a bail out?" to which I get some rapid nods...from none other than my BFF Charlotte (who I just noticed was there)!! Anyways, I tried my best to lure her away, but failed after a few attempts. I had to run away before I got the drunky strain of black death all over me. Hope the rest of you cool peeps at that table fared OK, and didn't wind up with too much drool on your cheeks from some drunk granny kisses :).

In sum, go to this place. If an employee gives you an out because someone weird is there (like what happened here), for the love of god take it.
author: Sean C.

description: I was very excited to try this place seeing all of the positive reviews. I ordered the katanaya ramen bowl and substituted the chicken for tofu, which was apparently too difficult to do. My soup was supposed to have gyoza in it, which it did not, and also a substitution for the tofu meant no pork slices for me :-/ There was a party of 4 that sat next to us 10 minutes after we were seated (we already had our drinks - hot sake was good) who ordered the same dish and got served before us. There was one waiter working, who got some assistance from time-to-time from another person in the kitchen. It must've been way too busy for them to handle and also I saw an absolutely enormous takeout order being prepared after we ordered, so that was probably part of the problem of the food-bringing-out service being incredibly slow. 4 other patrons were getting horribly antsy too. The food was good, maybe not worth the wait. Whoever ordered that giant takeout order was a dick.
author: S S.

description:
One of my friends for months has been telling me that I need to try their favorite ramen place in the entire bay area.  I was intrigued, and went to give it a try, so we braved the line that went out the door and waited for a booth to open up.  I'm going to get my biggest gripe out of the way right now, the service, it was not very good, the waitress we had seemed to be in a pretty bad mood.  I'm not sure if she was just having a bad day, but after seeing some of the reviews it seems that may just be based more on her personality.  Even after she took our order, I finished my tea and asked for more, she looked at me, gave me a sigh, when she returned, she was darting through the tables holding the tea cup, she without stopping she poured the tea and kept walking, it would have been an amazing accomplishment, but she left a significant sized trail of tea that went from my cup to the edge of the table towards me.  I ended up cleaning up the mess but when I asked for more napkins she seemed even more annoyed.

Moving on from the meal I had the the house specialty, the Katanaya ramen, which actually was really, really good, you could almost say, that if this was based purely on the food in itself, it was fantastic.  The broth had a rich depth of flavor, someone in the back did a great job at laying the flavor profiles of vegetables and meats, the noodles themselves was perfectly cooked, slight bite to them which is what I love.  The other thing that I loved was that the hard boiled egg was actually a bright golden yellow, no hint of green in it which drives me nuts.  The only gripe I could come up with was that the little fried chicken pieces in here were served on the side, by the time we got ours, it was getting a little more soggy.  I've tried a few of their rolls which was pretty good as well, one that we had some some type of Hawaiian roll, had some eel, hamachi and tuna.

While we were enjoying our ramen the waitress came back and dropped off our bill.  I assumed she wanted us to clear out quickly, the funny thing was that after we finished up of meal it took us a while to flag her down so we could pay the bill and even once she took it it seemed she forgotten about us.  We eventually, got our change, and got up, to exit and maneuver through the crowd outside eagerly waiting for a table.  When I left I felt really torn about how I should approach this review, as it's really unfortunate when good food is spoiled by horrible customer service.  I'm sure some will critic that "the food is worth it" or "its the best I've ever had."  I hope this was a rare occurrence, as you can only be a good restaurant and have customers lined up out the door, and at the same time treat customers so poorly, for only so long.  As for me, I think for the time being I have a couple ramen joints that I prefer, and I think the food tastes better when you aren't having to sit on pins and needles worried you are going to offend your server.
author: Chris T.

description:
I had never really understood the fascination with ramen.  I mean cup of noodles is technically ramen.  A bowl of that would cost me less than a dollar, why would I pay someone else to heat up water, boil noodles and serve me their version of cup of noodles and charge me ~$10/bowl?!!??  The idea was so insane to me!  

That is until I tried katanaya!  I first experimented with the Katanaya Ramen with miso broth and devoured every delicious slurp.  Something about the the savoriness of the miso broth and the chewiness of the fresh egg noodles kept me craving for more. 

After experimenting with a few items on the menu, I'd have to say that the spicy tofu soup ramen would have to be my favorite bowl at this tiny, lively, bustling place.   The tofu is the perfect softness and smoothness, the napa cabbage adds a nice bite to the dish and the broth remains rich and delicious.  A side order of chicken karaage gives the entire meal a crunchy and satisfying finish.   

Sushi is alright, not that impressive but keep in mind that sushi is not he main attraction.  Come one and come all, at Katanaya, nothing holds a candle to the ramen!  rahh! rahh!

YUM APPROVED!
author: Kim C.

description:
WAY WAY AWESOME. I got the fried chicken one. The chicken stayed crispy through out the meal despite it sitting in the broth. It comes with chasu or some sorta pork. The pork isn't that good but i think it helps simmer the soup. Let that sucker soak while you eat with all them goodies.  Towards the end... Oh yeah... there it is. 

My girlfriennd got the katana variation + spicy options(which is another buckfifty). It comes with pork, fried chicken, gyoza, bamboo shoots, seaweed among other goodies.  The spicy was good at first but it gets old after a while.

i WILL be back. and next time i will get shitfaced so i can finsh off my night with the ramen.
author: Doug ..

description:
I loved this place!!! 
Everything was so authentic and reminded me of my childhood! They're open late too, which is definitely a bonus. After sightseeing all day and filling up at Ghirardelli and Boudin, we weren't really all that hungry around the normal dinner time. We went there at about 10:00 P.M. and there was still a wait! Luckily, not that long (about 10 minutes or so). The restaurant is a little tiny and cramped so I recommend sitting at the sushi bar. Servers are friendly, but the food is truly the reason I will always go back!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
O.K. From good this place goes to great!

I can never go wrong if I'm hungry here. Their Katsu Curry is fantastic. It's a huge portion of curry. And Spicy Scallop roll is to die for. Yum yum yum.
author: Yelena K.

description:
Stopped by in union square for some ramen a few weeks back.  First, I know there is better ramen to be had in the SF area, but in terms of location for tourists/conventions this is the best place we could find.

They had a 15 minute wait managed by a paper clipboard on the door.  

We ordered a udon with fish broth and a ramen as well.  Both arrived within 5 minutes and were of good size (although the price was a bit on the steep side for ramen, but it is union square) and were piping hot.  We found the flavor to be right on and worth the wait and price.  Is there better ramen to be found? I am guessing yes.  In this neighborhood, I doubt it.

This is the perfect place for a convention center lunch (though be prepared to wait) or a late night snack.,
author: Andrew S.

description: I like the ramen here and I work close enough to be able to come when they open and beat the lunch crowd. The combo is great when I want something in addition to the ramen. It's also great when you're drunk at night and decide to slurp down an entire bowl in 5 seconds.
author: Janny N.

description:
I pretty much haven't had a Japanese ramen I actually liked since I went to Ippudo's in New York, but this place doesn't even come close to the nommyness that is Ippudo. Though I've heard the waits are just as bad as those of Ippudo. Luckily we went on a rainy day, so there wasn't much of a wait at all and it's a pretty small place.

Got a ramen and don combination. 

Regular Soy Sauce flavored Ramen with Seaweed, Pork and Bamboo Shoots. YUM. I liked the noodles a lot, chewy and not mushy. If there's one thing I hate, it's gotta be mushy noodles. The soup was alright, more bland than flavorful but you do get to choose between light, regular and rich so there has to be one to your liking. They also had other flavors of broth like salt and others I can't remember. I do wish they had an egg in their ramen though... 

Salmon Don. I love me some salmon sashimi! Their salmon was pretty fresh so it was yums. I'm actually surprised at myself that I was able to finish the noodles and almost all of the don, ended up not eating some of the rice because I was so full. Although I could have done without the lemon slices because the acid ended up "cooking" the parts of the fish it touched, the fish itself was good. But it's hard to go wrong with sashimi + rice unless the sashimi is super unfresh, so this was average.
author: Constance C.

description:
What a small place on Geary.  But it's good.  Whenever we want something fast, simple, and close to shopping, we stop by Katana-Ya.  I enjoy the Ramen here, very flavorful.  The salt soup is delicious!  MMMmmn....

Also, if you get the butter corn ramen, expect real butter.  There was a chunk of it in my bowl.  Tasted good, but my heart & waist line is hating me.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: Nice little hole in the wall place that is always crowded.  Though I only ate the mixed fish salad, which was delicious (I had a big breakfast). I tried my partners miso ramen. The broth was so good.  Very tasty and savoy.   Next time I am hungry from shopping I will get myself a ramen.
author: Marck N.

description:
So there's not only ramen here, but udon, sushi, and more. I had the udon with salmon slices over rice. The rice was absolutely perfect, and the salmon was fresh and excellent. The udon noodles were that perfect consistency where when you bite into them you think you must have bit into a bit of air. The broth was tasty and not fishy at all. 

My buddy had extra spicy ramen, which looked like it was just a big bowl of chili sauce, and smelled wonderfully spicy. He really enjoyed it. 

Get here early - the line is insane. It's a small place, and it seems like a lot of people come in big groups - even on a Monday.
author: Allison A.

description:
After a cold and rainy day, my friend and I drove all the way downtown just to have a bowl of hot ramen! And 30 minutes added to your wait to make you want that hot bowl of soup even more!

We both ordered the katana-ya ramen.  I really enjoy the potstickers and breaded chicken in the ramen.  I usually take out the chicken and the potstickers to keep them nice and crispy!  I love the flavors of the soup.  I do however, find it a bit salty. Definitely a must try!

We tried the spicy tuna and I was a bit disappointed.  With six pieces, it was literally just rice and tuna.  It did not have any flavor.  Not worth trying at all.
author: Joanne H.

description:
What has 2 thumbs and has gotten clowned by the ridiculous wait that's always here, even at times you wouldn't expect it to be (9:30pm on a random Tuesday?  Really?):  THIS GIRL!

What has 2 thumbs and waited in the long @$$ line because the ramen [veggie with roasted pork added, shoyu broth] is yummy: This girl...

Bottom line: The ramen was really delicious, but I don't know if it was good enough to justify our absurd 45 min wait at 9pm on a weeknight, especially when there are other fantastic ramen places in SF.   (And this long wait has happened multiple times!)  I think we stuck out the wait out of principle and because we were already "too invested" at that point.
author: Alice C.

description:
To tell you the truth, I usually dont go for Ramen stateside. Perhaps the best ramen I had was in Tokyo but I would be deemed a cockamamie if I went to Tokyo just for their noodles (and probably deemed pompous by you readers). After overhearing many san francisco residents and even my love interest compliment with such proclivity about this Ramen House, I decided to give it a try.

They have an extraordinary menu filled with Udon, Ramen, Soba as well as sushi. Their combination menu has Donburi!. 

I recommend the Tonkatsu Donburi and Curry Ramen myself, my date had a soba bowl (I forget what she had, but it was good, yes... I'm terrible). But stay away from the sushi, its just too mediocre for what they give you (but satisfies cravings...).

The staff are nice and if it wasn't for the the cramped space, the long wait for a table for two (at least 20-30 minutes) and the feeling of being seemingly rushed, it would have given me the option of rating it a 5 star as well as coming back for a second time. Just to warn you though, you will get brushed by other people while you are eating (its just that cramped). 

Nonetheless, I would recommend this ramen house to anyone who wants a good bowl of noodles, its just not a place for dates.
author: Alvin L.

description: I wish I lived closer or they opened up one in the South Bay....just sayin!
author: J A.

description: This is my second time here. The first time I was here, I waited over an hour to be seated. This time, I just walked right in and was seated right away. -- This place is a hole in the wall kind of restaurant. It is really good. -- If you want to be seated right away you have to come at it's off hours. The first time was around 8 and it was really busy. The second time I came around 4. It was still early. The ramen was good, the tempura we ordered was great! -- The service was just okay.
author: Vanessa W.

description: The food was really good, but unfortunately the service was terrible. I went there about  2 hours before closing. It's a nice small place and the waitress was too "busy" to mind people walking in. She basically just shouted across 5 tables that I can sit wherever I'd like. The other waitress comes over to my table and was so cold and distant taking my order. I don't know why really. I've never received such service before, usually I'm always welcomed  very nicely and seated right away. I had a hard time pronouncing some of the names so I immediately felt so embarrassed and I just wanted to hide under a rock if I could. She just sort of gave me this look (I'm laughing about it now) that I just didn't know what to tell her. I felt like i was causing an inconvenience? I mean there was about two other tables with 3 people there? It wasn't like it was a full house and ordering time is crucial. After ordering my food I noticed that this other person walked in and im not sure maybe he's a frequent there? He was greeted way much nicer than I was. He took out his laptop, rolled up his sleeves, he got so comfy and the waitress was so catered to him. I'm not sure why I took that so personal (lol) However my food was served and it was amazingly delicious. My boyfriend and I compared our ramen and we had a nice midnight grub definitely. I'd love to go back there but i'm not sure after sort of being greeted so terribly. I visit SF frequently now and my boyfriend and I try to go to a lot places to eat at. This is probably one of the only places where I wasn't happy with the service from my entire list of sf food spots. However I do suggest to try at least once or twice. Ambiance was also pretty cool, and I'm sure you can find something to your liking from their menu.
author: Anu C.

description:
OVERRATED!!!

I was staying at the Westin St Francis whic is right around the corner from here.  I came thinking this would come close to the ramen I had back in Japan.  I was disappointed to say.  

The wait wasn't too bad for a Saturday lunch.  We made sure to get there shortly after 12, and we waited for about 15 minutes.  The selection on the menu is quite extensive.  I like how they server more than just ramen, like kim chee fried rice.  I ordered a combo meal of salt ramen and unagi.  

Out comes the ramen, and looking surprised,  there's only one piece of meat in here!  They need to do a better job of adding more toppings on their ramen.  One piece of meat?!!  The broth was good,  but this ramen doesn't compare were Santouka in the south bay.  The noodles were nothing special.

I'll come back as the choices are limited in the Union Sqr area.   The price is okay for what you get,  but if you want quality ramen in the bay area - Santouka it is.
author: Albert L.

description:
As far as ramen places go (from SF to San Mateo), it's safe to say KatanaYa is the best that I've been to. 

The portions are huge, the flavor is delicious, and the place is cozy..maybe a little too cozy because it turned out to be way smaller than i expected, but the day I ate here, there was barely anybody.

I first tried to come here and the line extended to the hotel next to the restaurant, so I figured this restaurant must be legit. I resolved to try it the next day, which I did, and it was pretty legit. Not only did they have the usual options of soup and kinds, but they also had the option of rich/light flavor and a mild/medium/hot spciy addition. 

I think I liked everything down to the taste of their water. Yes, it was that good.
author: Dexter L.

description: Two stars because the first time I went here, I thought the ramen was amazing, full of flavor, and just damn delicious. Service was meh, but it was pretty packed and the place is tiny so I was forgiving. The second time I went back, the place wasn't full, there were probably still 2 empty tables. I ordered the exact same thing I did the first time, and it was awful. The broth was bland, the veggies were bland, and the noodles were chewy. But my biggest gripe about this place is the service. It's horrendous. The server doesn't speak english and gives you a blank stare when you ask a question. The other two people in the restaurant (host and other waiter) never make eye contact so you can't flag them over. And when you do manage to get their attention, they're clueless as well. I won't be going back.
author: Sophie P.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Wednesday and there was already quite a line! Katana-Ya doesn't take reservations so expect to wait about 20 minutes if you go around dinner.

Interior was small and cozy - had a few tables and then a couple seats at the bar. They had a pretty sizeable menu with lots of types of ramen, rice bowls, and appetizers. I went with the Ramen + Don combo - got the Katana-Ya Ramen and the Katsu-Don.

Food came out pretty quickly and was excellent! Definitely worth the wait. I was never much of a Ramen fan but places like this are making me a convert. Would highly recommend!
author: Landon Y.

description: Nothing cures a massive hangover like a big bowl of yummy ramen. Super rich broth, chewy noodles and lots of green onions. Happiness in a bowl.
author: T. C.

description:
I LOVE RAMEN AT KATANA-YA! It is probably the best tasting ramen in SF. I love their spicy miso broth. The chasu is not tough like other ramn places.

This place is small and there usually a long wait. Come at the right time and you'll be seated right away! I also like how it opens late =]

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Chatree T.

description:
Mmmm! Came here on a Veteran's Day post duck hunting in GGP and pre-comedy college. We were lucky there was no wait. Got seated at the last table right by the window so everyone can watch us slurp our delicious ramen! 

The Spicy Tofu Ramen was delicious with just the right amount of seasoning. My date got the BBQ pork (spicy) which he said was the best BBQ pork ramen he'd ever had! 7x7's list recommends this dish. 

Quaint little place near Union Square. Decent service. Often a wait outside past 6:30pm.
author: Tina Y.

description:
This place is absolutely overrated and over price!
I've had ramen in Orange county, and Los Angeles, and this place is just not even good at all.  Maybe the high rating from people who haven't experience really good ramen....
author: Peter N.

description: Never had a bad meal here. Go to ramen spot if you are in the city. Tried the sushi for the first time today and it was great. Try the fish salad as a starter - it's sashimi with some fresh watercress. Fresh
author: Armand S.

description: Great ramen, but really pricey. Also, the spicy miso is never spicy enough, not even when you ask for extra spiciness for $1 more. Otherwise, the broth is always perfectly seasoned. I usually substitute udon noodles for their ramen noodles, but they also charge me an extra $1 for that.
author: Le T.

description:
Good quality ramen. Very flavorful, and several varieties. I really enjoyed the cold ramen too (not soup). 

Sushi is pretty cheap but really mediocre. There are far better sushi restaurants just around the corner. 

Service is speedy but not that personal, which is fine for a quick joint. 

I went there once with someone who doesn't tolerate MSG well and he asked if they had a broth the didn't have MSG. The server said yes, but only one of the broths (miso or soy, I can't remember which). The next time I went, I asked if they had broth without MSG and a different server said that they all had MSG. So, tell me, who was telling the truth? 

Weird experience, but still delicious food.
author: Kealie G.

description: The BBQ Pork Don I got on the side of my ramen was great! I wish I got that as my meal. We came here twice, once for ramen and once for sushi. The sushi was disappointing but the ramen was great! I'd come back for the ramen.
author: Lucy B.

description:
extensive menu.  decent taste.
try cheese age (fried cheese with white fish) for an appetizer.
don't be surprised to see a long wait at all times.
dohatsuten in palo alto still remains the ramen king in the bay.
author: Bennet A.

description:
I've eaten here a few times before these last two weeks when my friend insisted on eating here 5 times in the last 14 days or so. I love the fried chicken and the butter corn ramen. shoyu, of course. because its 'meatier', saltier, and just tastes like au jus' cousin or something. the service is super quick and they are vigilant. 
ugh. so good. and because i can never finish all that yumminess in one sitting, i take it to go, for the morning. the broth is so yummy in the morning. beats coffee any day. hand down.
um and open till 2. i'd like to see someone beat that!
author: Sydel S.

description:
The night was cold, but the ramen (and sake) warmed me, straight through my stomach and into my heart.

I had the regular miso ramen.  Now, I used to be a true ramen connoisseur, but as of the past few years, I've been off my game.  Katanaya rekindled that old flame and reminded me just why I had such a deep and profound love for these noodles.
author: Brianna H.

description:
A few months ago I went to Katana-ya with a few friends of mine who are big ramen fans.  I am not.  Thus as they were contemplating what bowl of ramen to get, I was looking all over the menu for something non-ramen to eat.

I decided on the Grilled Salmon Don and I absolutely loved it.  They have two sizes for their Don (meat over rice).  The first time I've been there, I got a small and finished it.  The second time I got a regular and have a nice to go container to take home with me.  The price is really reasonable too - I think a small is around 6.50 and a regular is 8.00 and comes with a bowl of miso soup!  I love the dish though, it's rice with shredded salmon, bonito shavings, some pickled stuff and some sprinkles of green on it.  I just mix it up, add a little bit of the ramen mixed toppings on it for a bit more edge, then chow down with my spoon.  

One day I'll actually try some of the ramen (miso, medium spicy) ... but until then, I'm gonna stick with my salmon bowl!
author: Anna V.

description: I got to try this place out with a good friend of mine! We didn't have to wait in line, I guess we beat the rush--I ordered the regular ramen with Miso soup and it was yummy! Would totally come here again for ramen when I am in the city!
author: Lynn C.

description:
Hai ya!!!! Get in my mouth lil noodle!
I really like this place... though we did have to wait forever ever... but as you well know people don't wait for crap. Fortunately the people here knew Michelle really well and treated us out to some great tasting something something. I have no idea what it was but it was a roll of  good deliciousness. That aside they have some great tasting uni. I do try uni everywhere I go and I would like to go here again and again. Otherwise they are known for their ramen and soup and stuff. The soup is great. All in all the place is kind of small but I do love sitting at the counter under the watchful eye of the sushi chef. 
WOOT!
author: John-Michael C.

description:
solid ramen, a wait as always but the combo deal is a good one.
The fish is not super fresh, but for the price, it's fine.
Had Miso vs.Soy and def. Miso is the better broth.
author: Monster E.

description:
I came around midnight and was served by a cute Japanese waitress. The tamagosushi were good and bigger than i thought it should be, the katanaya ramen could be better if no gyouza in it. 
5 stars for the service, way better than the ryo's.
author: Ke M.

description:
Went there at 1:45pmish on a friday afternoon and there was STILL a line!  Small place, Japanese-owned apparently, which definitely does make a difference.  We ordered the kanaya special ramen (with 2 pieces of chicken karaage, 2 gyoza, 1 chashuu, corn, onions).  I had the salt version and my friend had the miso.  Orders came out quick and hot, and the service was good.  Gotta say that the miso has a better flavor (and i'm normally stricly a tonkotsu kinda guy, but alas, they didn't have tonkotsu).  Mine was good too.  Noodles were nice and fresh and cooked perfectly.  Soup tasted good, not too salty.  Portion was pretty good too.  Not the best ramen i've ever had (since i've had some damn good ramen in japan), but definitely very good.  As usual, but pricey for ramen, but i guess that's the trend now, but at least the portions here weren't kid sized (lookin at you Orenchi).

Edit:
Gotta knock it down to 3.5 stars.  Went there yesterday and again got the katanaya special and a side dragon roll.  The ramen soup base (salt) is really lacking in taste.  The portions remain pretty good with generous portions of karaage & large pot stickers, but the soup base pretty much killed it for us.  The dragon roll was very well made, but tiny.  Especially for the price of $13.50.  I'd expect 8 pieces, not 6 small ones.  But that said, very well made.
author: B W.

description: YUM! Came here with Ellie L. because 1) we love ramen and 2) it was on the 7x7 list. I had miso ramen with all the fixins. My favorite is the corn! The gyoza was yummy too! It's a small joint but the service is quick, friendly, and helpful. I'll be back!
author: Jen Z.

description:
Tight spaces, good places. Heard about Katana-Ya from a friend saying it had some nationwide nods as well as from other people I know that rave about it. So I was pretty excited to finally come and check it out. And of course you can tell a place is good when people are willing to wait outside in the frigid air. OH YES.

We were a party of 5 but still needed to wait a bit longer for a latecomer. As we were driving up, searching for parking, a friend of mine saw the hoard of people standing outside and requested to get out of the car so he could put his name down on the list for us. That's how smart you have play it. What a good friend. It was only a 15 minute wait but once entering the place, I could see why. 

Katana-Ya isn't the roomiest of all places. Hell, it's a claustrophobic's nightmare. Tables are a bit small. Seating seems limited. But meh...whatever. For all I care, I can be sitting in a cardboard box, while eating the greatest dish on earth, and I wouldn't mind. Besides, the only space that should matter is in our stomachs and whether or not we have enough room leftover for dessert. 

The Spicy Tofu Ramen, with Misu, was the choice of my liking. I was hesitant at first by the "Spicy" label but my neighbor over at the table next to me said it wasn't that spicy. And indeed he was right. The ramen was very warm and tasty. The Misu broth was dead on. Spiciness is manageable, even if you don't eat a lot of spicy food. Gave me a good warm feeling all over. We also ordered a Rainbow roll and Golden roll. The rolls were decent but I know I've had better. Keep in mind: RAMEN is their specialty. Not sushi.

Between the 5 of us, we also ordered 2 bottles of large (HOT) sake. Very hot indeed. But unlike the sake, the service was not so hot. We ordered a 3rd bottle of sake but they failed to retrieve it for us. And after repeatedly telling them of our request, they still added it to our bill. What the eff, right? We expected them to bring us our 3rd bottle but instead they just took it off our bill because they accidentally charged us. Good job. Sorry for giving them business, I guess. But besides that incident, service was pretty good all night.

Anywho, despite the mediocre wait and the service mishap, the ramen was awesome and the times were fun. We came on a Friday night so of course we knew what we were walking into. But just don't let that stop you from coming here. I would mos def come back. Just you wait.
author: Will S.

description: Ordered regular ramen (#1) in miso broth and added corn and egg = bees knees.  Have been here every time I come in to town!
author: Stefanie N.

description:
2 stars for the Mabo Ramen.  Was pretty disappointed in it.  I recommend other ramen here and not the Mabo Ramen.

I also recommend the miso broth over the soy sauce broth.
author: Mark K.

description: Excellent ramen.  I live in Japantown San Jose so we eat great ramen often. This was really good. Better than expected. Had the mobo (?) pork and tofu  Dont let the dark red broth fool you. It is not crazy spicy hot. Have been back several times.
author: Melanie E.

description: Ramen is OK. Donburi is horrible.
author: MinLiang C.

description:
Coming from NYC, I'm spoiled by Menku-tei and Ippudo.  After 5 months of searching, I finally stumbled across this spot on my way home and was astonished to find a ramen restaurant only 3 blocks from my apartment!  

I admit, I was suspicious at first being the area is in a undoubtedly shady spot... be prepared to be accosted by bums outside  the Jack in the Box on the corner. 

Now the food. The ramen is legit!  Finally platable ramen, soba and udon for great prices.  It's not the best ramen I've ever had, but it's the closest I could find to the real deal!   I'm a fan of rich broths, so I was very happy to discover they give you the option to make your broth rich or light!  I always get the miso (rich) ramen, though I've tried the soba several times. if you're not sure if you want soup or rice, or sushi, or a fried cutlet...fear not!  They have a great combo section where you can pick a ramen, udon or soba and choose a rice dish topped with a huge variety of morsels like BBQ beef, Spicy Tuna (AMAZING), Unagi, sashimi bowl....you name it...it's there!  Really great deal for the variety, also great for a first date. 

I usually get the Katana-Ya Ramen, which has corn, seaweed, scallion, two dumplings, two fairly sized pieces of fried chicken morsels, and half a hard boiled egg. That's a serious meal that keeps me full for a long time! I do wish though, that they gave the dumplings and fried chicken OUT of the bowl...I don't understand why you'd fry something to dump it into a soup...

A small spot with some serious lines starting at 7pm, but worth the wait.  The only real disappointment for me is that they don't offer tonkotsu ramen, also known as kyushu ramen, which is my favorite hands down. 

I gave it 4 stars, because sometimes the service just outright sucks. I stood in the doorway with a friend for near 10 minutes waiting to be seating and finally when two couples plowed right by me and plopped down, I went up to the waitress and asked if I was supposed to seat myself. Maybe I was, I don't know, but she didn't even acknowledge our existence the time we were there. She replied, "Oh! I'm so sorry, I didn't know you were waiting!"   

Also, actually ordering your food can take a while, but the food does hit the tables pretty quickly.
author: Annie W.

description: Got the spicy green onion ramen and the spicy tofu ramen. Both were delicious and just the right amount of spice! Prices were reasonable; $9.50 for each bowl. You have to get there right when they open, otherwise be prepared to wait in line. Minus one star for the small space, but I guess that is part of their charm. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Mo A.

description:
Came here with a cousin and waited for about 15-20mins. The place was pretty tiny and kinda tight. The funny thing was after we were seated, we were told that there was another party before us, when clearly before I decided to seat, I didn't see any other name above me that hadn't been scratched out. Anyway, we were told to stand up and wait again for another 15minutes. As much as the waiter kept apologizing for his mistake, I think he should tell that other party to wait cause of his mistake, not us!

Back to menu, I ordered Cilantro Ramen, my cousin ordered the Spicy Green Onion Ramen with Kurobuta Sausage. Both of them were priced below $10 per bowl, simply said that this location located in Union Square, that price was quite affordable. 

Coming from LA where all the ramen were much better, I was kinda expecting this one to be good as my friends told me, "this is the closest you can get to LA ramen". My respond after eating it, "Nah, it doesn't even come close". 

Yeah okay, they have all different flavor that I never seen before and that's why I ordered them, but the ramen tasted like rubberband to begin with, so chewy, definitely not fun to eat and the meat given was so little, I needed to search for any meat underneath the broth. The Kurobuta sausage that my cousin got was huge and plenty for that small portion bowl, taste wise, it's okay. 

Will I come back? Hmm probably to try the one called fried chicken ramen cause, according to my cousin that was their famous one for beginners LOL!
author: Jenny B.

description:
Being a huge ramen fan, I knew I had to try Katana-Ya. I ordered the butter corn ramen with the salt broth, gyoza, and spicy salmon sushi. The texture of the ramen noodle was right on. I felt the broth was a little lacking in flavor but it was still pretty good. My friend got the spicy green onion ramen with the soy sauce broth. It wasn't spicy at all but I felt his broth tasted a lot better than mine.

The gyoza came with 4 big pieces and a side of spicy dipping sauce. The gyoza was really tasty. The spicy salmon sushi was okay, nothing special. Overall, it was a pretty good experience. I will be coming back to try the other ramen dishes.
author: Laura L.

description: Don't see what all the hype is all about. Been here only 3 times even though it is a block from my office and it gets worse everytime. Not saying Tampopo is the best, but it's better than this. Cheaper too!
author: Rudy G.

description:
YUMYUMYUM. 
I love this! But it's a little on the pricey side. I just get plain ramen with miso soup, which is nine bucks I believe? The ramen is all you need here! It's nice on a cold day, which is like everyday...
It's not that good for groups and it's a very small, hole-in-the-wall looking place, and when you're waiting, there's plenty of shops to look at and some art displays across the street =) 
Anyway, the freshest ramen ever.
author: Emily K.

description:
I'm going to describe this place in one sentence:

If you love ramen, worship ramen, understand the beauty of ramen, you gotta try Katana-Ya.

Enjoy :)
author: Rika P.

description:
Food's great attitude not so great.

Katanya's restaurant had great ramen noodle soups. We noticed this resturant for several days walking past it and seeing the large line out the door.  We were lucky enough to get in one weekday afternoon and the experience was great.

Negative review below

However, just a warning: Be sure to check your bill. There was gratuity slapped on without warning. In the menu it said there will be gratuity added for groups larger than 5, however, we were a group of 3.  Not only was there gratuity, but the gratuity was based off the the price of the meal including the tax.  Not just the price of the meal.  There was no warning of gratuity added on the bill.  When we asked what the charges were they would not answer us directly and after some time they just told us "you don't need to come back".  She offered the number of the manager to us and it was a fake number. We went back to tell them it was the wrong number and they told us they did not have it. Just be sure to check your bill.
author: Matt J.

description:
Definitely GOOD ramen!

I went to this place after seeing a musical with some friends.  They were open at 11PM, which was awesome because there was no line. It was also a Tuesday night....I went to check it out tonight (Friday) to get some more and there was a long waiting list.

I got the Light Miso Regular Ramen, just because I didn't know what to get. It was so good and just perfect on the saltiness factor and the taste.  I didn't get to try the sushi, but I plan to go next time :o)
author: Charlayne A.

description:
In short: I love a good bowl of ramen and this tiny little establishment did not disappoint.  However, I believe there are better bowls of ramen in the SF Bay Area that are easier to access, and of course, it does not stack up to some of the best I've had in Japan or even NYC.  Chasu as tough as finding parking in the neighborhood, and hurried service are its pitfalls.  Its boons are customizable bowls of ramen and the yummy fried chicken ramen.

In long: The restaurant service is very efficient and they expect their patrons to be equally efficient.  We were hurried out of the restaurant by their staff who needed our table for more hungry downtown metropolitan types.

My advice is to arrive at 6:00 pm sharp.  At that time, parking meters retire for the night and you beat most, but not all, of the dinner-time rush.  We arrived at 6:00 and had to wait about half an hour for a table for around 6-8 of us.  

The menu dictates to its reader the exact quantity of Chasu you will receive as 3 pieces.  When some of our ramen bowls came out with only 2 slices, it was very disappointing.  These guys are so determined to meter Chasu to their customers and yet they still get it wrong.  I didn't mind because their Chasu was too tough in comparison to other ramen houses.  

Highlights to me were the quality-fried and well-battered fried chicken in the fried chicken ramen bowl.  Hint: get a small plate on which to extract the tender fried morsels from your soup and prevent them from getting soggy.  Then you can take your time enjoying them.

Finally, the soup in your bowl is customizable in it's viscosity.  I left my soup at default setting and it seemed just a touch too light on flavor, though not offensively so.  My friend had a "thick" soup base and she seemed to enjoy hers much more.  Their thick is like some other restaurants' normal ramen soup base.  The noodles have a good al dente feel and stays decently firm and chewy until basically the end of the bowl.  Although I tried my lady's ramen noodles after my bowl and they were getting soggy.    

In sum, a good bowl of ramen for downtown SF.  If the South Bay is not too far, around Saratoga there are some other great ramen houses.
author: Gersey C.

description:
On vacation in San Francisco, my cousin and his partner brought me to Katana-Ya and it was awesome!
Its a tiny little space but the food was amazing.
I ordered the Spicy Tofu ramen, it was to die for.
For the price, you definitely get your moneys worth.
The noodles weren't overdone, the tofu was just the right texture and the spice wasnt too hot, and wasnt too light.
author: Amy T.

description:
I can't believe San Francisco yelpers rave about this ramen shop. I came here with high expectations. 4 stars is a pretty solid rating, maybe not spectacular, but I was hoping to have found something decent. Well, no such luck. This isn't ramen! I don't know how you people eat this stuff. I mean it's edible, but it's just not right.

I've had ramen in Tokyo and Osaka, and this doesn't do ramen justice! I know it's not fair to compare a ramen restaurant in the states to Japan, but at least even Los Angeles has some good places like Daikokuya. And Ippudo in NY is great as well. Is this all San Francisco has to show for ramen?

Honestly, I'm so disappointed. I hope someone opens up a good ramen restaurant in the bay area so you can all see what you've been missing! I can understand the rating if you compare this ramen with cup-o-noodles, but this really, really pales in comparison to the real deal.

The closest I've found is Santa Ramen in San Mateo which has some delicious chashu pork. Otherwise, the shops in Japan town are so-so. Still, so sad that I've not been able to have good ramen in SF.
author: Bryan L.

description:
This place is a total hole in the wall but it attracts a large crowd. The line moves fairly quickly  so make sure you dont get skipped or you will have to sign up all over again. I know because it happened to me or the waitress that seems to hate her job is a bitch. 

The rolls are just okay so if you want a quality sushi roll go somewhere else. The ramen was the best part. I selected the Katana -Ya ramen which basically had  a combination  of everything in there, including fried chicken. I chose the miso soup to go in it and asked for it to be spicy. Loved it!
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Get the miso broth.

I first tried the Katanaya ramen with the shio broth... damn it.   It was not nearly as flavorful as the miso my friends got.  So after that time, I've always gotten the miso.  The miso is pretty comparable to the ones I like in LA.  

FYI, this place is suuuuuper tiny!  Tables are tiiiny.  Be prepared to rub elbows with the people next to you.
author: Kat E.

description:
Delicious. Heavy. Long wait, but it's worth it. I recommend the fried chicken miso ramen. Expect a line and don't go here with large groups of people. Tables are only four people or less and it'll take forever. Two is ideal. No reservations. They're open late, too. 

The sushi is also incredibly fresh. Best spicy tuna.
author: Raquel R.

description:
Totally average run of the mill sushi/ramen joint.  Not bad, not great... it was ok.  Sometimes you want to just go to a cheap Japanese place and that is what this is.  Nothing spectacular about this place at all, I can not understand the hype.

Ambiance = Nothing to write home about, more on the sloppy side than anything.  

Food = Meh.... it was alright.  I had a spicy tuna bowl, boyfriend had some kind of ramen.  My tuna was not good.  Boyfriend liked his ramen but I didn't love it, there are much better hole in the wall ramen places than this one.

The prices however I thought were good for what you got.

I might give it another shot if friends persuade me to come here, but my first impression was not good, not bad, just ok.  If I want ramen I would rather make the trek down to Santa Ramen in San Mateo, it is so much better than this place.
author: S. F.

description:
I had ramen and sushi here on my visit and I must argue that the ramen here is just okay.  Everyone hyped up this place so hard that I was expecting the above and beyond, but really, when I tasted the miso broth, it just tasted like normal ramen.  I didn't think it was anything special.  People have said that they think it's too greasy, but I think that it's the egg that gives it that rich and greasy feel.  If the review was solely based on the ramen, they would deserves 3 stars.  

Taking both ramen and sushi into consideration, I am still giving them 3 stars because I've been to places where I've had better ramen (maruichi's in Mt. View) and sushi, and prices were better, but considering location and the late hours they are open it's understandable.

I shared with my bf and had the salmon avocado roll, california roll, philly, lava flow, toro nigiri and the Katanaya ramen (the one with everything)

LIKED: Salmon and avocado roll was really good. Really fresh ingredients and the whole thing just melted in your mouth.  California roll was good too, but it was typical, nothing special.

NOT A FAN: Lava flow was just literally shrimp tempura, and spicy tuna on top - for $13.50 I just can't get over how expensive that was.  It was pretty good taste wise, but for that price I should have just ordered the alaskan.  Toro nigiri was just okay. I didn't think it was the freshest.  Philly roll - not a fan of cucumber would rather have avocado, it's  my own personal preference so other's might like it.

The overall experience was 3 stars because I feel like everything I ordered is I've had better.  They do have a HUGE menu and an assortment of selections, so I may have to come back to try other things before passing on final judgment.  But for this visit, 3 solid stars and nothing more.
author: Zu W.

description:
Went back and added the Kimchee Fried rice in addition to the still-best-combo of Fried Chicken Ramen, Medium Spicy Rich Miso. 
YUM YUM

Kimchee fried rice wasn't the best i've ever had, but it was tasty nonetheless. A little more kimchee would have made it perfect; It was quite a substantial bowl...nothing to scoff at. 

Went there at 1.30p on a weekday; no problem getting a table. 
Took leftover ramen home; it was Still good the next day

Love this place!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Solid, 4-star food with terrible customer service. 

First of all, we were kept the 3 of us waiting much longer than necessary--they crossed our name off the list without calling us (we were standing 3 feet from the girl calling the names), and didn't apologize when we called it to their attention (after they had seated 2 parties below us on the list).

Second: we're inside. There are 3 identical tables side-by-side: one has a party of 3, one has a party of 2, one is empty. The waitress tries to seat us at a different table (tiny, clearly made to seat 2). When we ask to sit at the empty table mentioned above, she says, "You can't--that's for a party of 4, only." However, as noted, the other identically-sized tables are seating 2 and 3, respectively. Also, there's no party of 4 waiting. I point this out, but, "No," we're told again, "that's only for a party of 4." RRRGGGHHH.

At this point, I've had it. I take out my frustrations on the head waitress-person, reiterating  and we end up sitting at the "table for 4" of our own accord. Thankfully, we get service. Slow service.

The food was good, though.
author: Ramon E.

description:
I'm drooling just looking at their menu from one of the other reviewers who posted the photo. It helps me to remember the ramen that I ordered was fulfilling, yummy, and pretty darn good. 

I went with a friend of mine who heard about the place and thought it would be a good spot for us to eat at for the first time. It was a close walk from my summer dorm apartment with the Academy of Art (a free three-week program they did a couple years ago and never did again). I'm glad I didn't drive because where it's located at downtown isn't really the friendliest place to find a parking spot without paying a good handful of dollars for.

It was a weeknight around 5pm and already there was a crowd of people waiting to go inside. The place is small and looked like it can only fit around 20-30 people if I remember right. The wait was about 20 minutes and we were seated towards the back at a small table. Our food came pretty quickly so it made our wait that much more worthwhile.

I look forward to eating at this place the next time I'm in town!
author: Jen May P.

description:
I have been coming here for about 4 years now. I come for the ramen, and home made gyoza. 

I have had the sushi on a few occasions and I will say that it was not memorable. I would say their sushi is more 3-4 stars. Everything was fresh and tasted good just wasn't amazing like their ramen.

If you are coming here for the first time I would recommend the Katana-Ya ramen with soy broth and an appetizer. I have tried all of their appetizers and they have all been great. I am partial to the gyoza just because it is so nice to find a place that makes them fresh. 

The Katana-Ya ramen is a combo of all of their ramens so you get a little of everything. If that is too adventurous for you I think the next best thing on the menu is the BBQ pork ramen. You get tasty noodles and some thin sliced pork chop, very tasty. 

They also have Japanese beer and Sapporo on tap which I enjoy. They are also open late, so its great for a late night out with friends. The place is small though and usually has a line. It is worth the wait though, just make sure to write your name on the list when you get there. 

They also let you make orders to go if you do not want to wait. Last time I did that the place was packed but my to go order got right into the kitchen and I was out of there within 10 minutes.
author: Monti Josh W.

description:
I came here on my last day visiting the bay area right before my flight.  I'm glad I came in when I did, because as soon as I got seated, the place got packed.

The ramen is good.  The fried chicken and gyoza is a litlte bit greasy and oily, but it tastes good.

It's reasonably prices and seemed like the best option for ramen around Union Square.
author: Spencer K.

description: This will be the second time we've been here and I must say it tasted just as good and satisfying as the first time. I orginally had the katanaya ramen with all the fixings but this time I ordered spicy tofu ramen and added the fried chicken to the side. Ev ordered the mabu ramen with kimchee added. My ramen had more flavor than his but very good overall. It was packed being that the weather was chilly and the place is tiny. Anyway, we got seated right away luckily and the service is quick and attentive just how I remembered it last time. Would come back although I would like to try other ramen places in SF.
author: Vanessa P.

description:
After seeing all the great reviews we decided to try this place out since we were going to be in the area doing a little shopping.

There were about 9 groups ahead of us, but we were able to get seated in about 30 minutes. For a ramen place it has a really extensive menu with all the different appetizers, side dishes and varieties of sushi. I was curious to see how the other stuff was but since we went there for ramen, that's what we ordered. I ordered the shio (salt) ramen and my husband ordered the miso karaage (fried chicken) ramen with a side of gyoza for us to share. 

Tonkotsu ramen is my favorite, so I have a really hard time giving any other kind of ramen stellar ratings, but the shio ramen was pretty good. I didn't think there was anything really special about it but it was tasty.

My husband enjoyed his miso ramen but didn't think it was the best he'd ever had. The gyoza was okay. There were only 4 pieces which I think is kind of unusual, but like the ramen it was good but nothing terribly special.

If we're in the area and we have some time or can put our names in early we'd go here again but we both agreed it's not a place we'd go out of our way to eat at again.
author: Cindy N.

description:
This is my very first Yelp review and coincidentally my very first experience with Japanese-style Ramen. I must say that when my boyfriend suggested ramen I was very skeptical. I associated ramen with those $.10 packages sold at Walmart. Boy was I wrong...I thoroughly enjoyed a huge bowl of miso based ramen with gyoza. Tasty to the 10th power...I went back 2 days later for some more.

The place is small but they run an efficient shop. If you go in the evening hours, expect to wait about 10-15 mins to be seated. There is a list outside where you can add your name, then you must wait to be called. I would not recommend this place for large groups. It appears they can accommodate a group of 6 though. Enjoy!
author: Regine N.

description:
YUUUUUUUUMMMMMMMMMMMMMMYYYYYYYYYYy

RAMEN IS SOOOOOO AMAZING! I love their katana-ya ramen thats salt-based with a just a little bit of spicy. This trumps all ramen I have had! Their combo things are a little confusing - the curry and their spicy rolls are good, but a little on the pricey side.

Usually you'd probably be very full after the ramen so I'd advise you to just get that and maybe one appetizer/combo thing and then gage after you're done if you want more.

Definitely another place I will and have been back to! 

Minus 1 star for the cramped space and the looonnggg wait and ghetto paper list. I advise you guys stay where u are because if you leave and miss their call you get forfeited and you have to start over!
author: Mona W.

description: I really enjoy this place. The ramen is very good, their sushi is well prepared, and their curry is just like that of my Japanese grandmother. The only issue is that the place is tiny and seating/wai is an issue; however, the food comes out quickly and is always very good.
author: James F.

description:
Went here with my mother and boyfriend. I always pass by while i'm on the 38 going back home. Always a crowd in front on fri-sun. My mother was in SF for the evening, and we decided to go here for dinner.

ordered salt ramen combo with BBQ pork don-  despite the small portion the bbq pork don was tasty i enjoyed it more than the ramen to be honest. The ramen was ok.

Pro's: 
-downtown easy access
-easy menu to select from, I'm a fan of combo's choose ramen, soba, or udon, with a variety of choices as the side dish w/ several pricing options depending on your side choice.


Con's:
-not that great, i assumed that because of the crowd i thought something was up with this restaurant, but really it's probably cause of the extremely tight quartered restaurant that it is.
-because there is a small crowd outside waiting to get in you definitely feel that pressure to eat and move out asap.
-it is very tight space not very comfy, had so little table room, and with big ramen bowls taking up the table there's no room for sides/drinks!
-service was a little iffy, took them forever to give my mother her single order of unagi nigiri, after being patient, we reminded the waiter twice before it came finally.

overall: probably won't be coming back here on my own.
author: vanessa g.

description:
The Ramen with the miso broth and Kimchee fried rice are not bad here, but service is harsh and so is finding a table. This place is seriously small; even the tables seem smaller than normal and the help is not very helpful. 

Other stuff like rolls were only average but the sashimi and rice bowls were decent.  

A friend of mine, Chris T. (Starvingsurfer.yelp.com) said it best in his review, "I assumed she wanted us to clear out quickly, the funny thing was that after we finished up of meal it took us a while to flag her down so we could pay the bill and even once she took it it seemed she forgotten about us."  

I would go back for the food if it wasn't during normal lunch hours.
author: Monlia W.

description:
Fried chicken was ok
Ramen was ok - pork has no fat
Egg - just a hard boiled egg.

I'll try something else around SF the next time I am up here.
author: Louis K.

description:
After several tries at other ramen joints, I was getting ready to give up.

Why?

Because broth was always too heavy, flavor a little off and I always felt like I either had an MSG or salt overload after. One ramen place in Burlingame brought me and my boyfriend at the mercy of the porcelain king.
So when my friend suggested we hit Katana-Ya up for lunch, I was reluctant. But in the end I didn't want to give up no ramen.

Overall, I was very pleased. They have earned their title of best ramen joint in SF.

I ordered a spicy ramen with tofu and ground pork. Their noodles are just the right consistency, firm and a little chewy. The broth was great! At first, as I was eating the noodles, I felt that it wasn't spicy enough. But with my second spoon of broth and noodles, I got that wonderful spicy kick at the back of the my throat. Also it had just the right balance of salty and sweet. Note: I asked for the broth in light. The soup also had just the right amount of protein to go with the noodles (pork and tofu)

Pros: Can get broth in regular, light or miso; staff is very friendly; light underground/midground hip hop playing in the background

Cons: long lines/wait; in the ghetto loin/downtown (lots of tourists and crackheads)
author: Karen U.

description:
Hands-down, my favorite Japanese ramen place in the Bay Area. A good gauge of how much I like a ramen place is whether finish everything I order. The two times I was there I did just that -- whether it's miso broth or spicy broth, I finished everything, including the soup. 

This is the closest I've had to good ramen places in Japan. But granted it is not for everyone -- it is good only if you like ramen cooked in a particular kind of Japanese style, a style that is different from soup noodle dishes you find around the city. The broth is strong and flavorful -- perfect for me, but a bit on the salty side for some of my friends. The noodles are cooked al dente -- again, perfect for me, but people used to Chinese style noodles might find it a tad undercooked. 

The place is tiny, and the wait is long. An eat-and-go kind of place.  Not a place where you can sit and chat for a long time.
author: Chris L.

description: This is my favorite ramen spot in the whole bay area. I've eaten at Orenchis, Ramen Dojo, and a couple other spots in the east bay and this definitely tops the list. If you get the Katana--Ya ramen it comes stacked with potstickers, corn, meat, chicken, and all the other traditional fix-ins. Their "spicy" is definitely a mild spicy, but then again I can handle the second level of spicy at Wing Stop. I do have to mention that for a while they had a consistency problem, but my last 3 visits have been all perfect. Location is small, so expect a 30-60min wait if you go during regular eating hours. totally worth it though.
author: Genica R.

description:
A wait list to get in on a rainy and cold Tuesday night in December?  You've got to be kidding me.  But I was able to wait inside and get out of the rain, so I waited.

And it was well worth the wait.  I had a couple of sushi rolls as well as some sashimi.  I spent a whopping $25 and was completely full!

There's a reason why they were crowded and on a wait list on a Tuesday night.  And that's because the food was so good as was the service.  The only thing that could be improved is the spacing of the place.  I like to have a little elbow room to spread out when I eat, and you just can't do it here.

Still, the wait list and the tight quarters are well worth putting up with in order to get the food!
author: Tony W.

description: ramen!!!!! yes please and more!!!!
author: Greg F.

description:
Katana-Ya is hardly worth the hype. 

Where great ramen broth has depth that delivers layers of savory flavors, Katana-ya's was flat. The "barbeque pork" is thin slices of unremarkable and somewhat tough meat. 

The noodles were cooked well and plentiful. They'd have to be, considering there were almost no vegetables or other ingredients aside from the pork.

Credit card users should note they don't take American Express.
author: Alex C.

description:
I eat here quite a bit.  I have probably eaten here 50 times at this point.  The bill varies depending on how much toro we eat, but overall the prices are pretty fair for what you get.

The california roll is solid, as is the hamachi.  The noodles are fantastic.  They are known for their ramen dishes.  I also enjoy the Lava Flow roll, which is spicy.  Seaweed salad and house green salad are both worth ordering.  The gyoza is fresh, but avoid the crab croquette as it is made from frozen.

There may be a wait since the place is tiny.  Just put your name on the clipboard out front.  It moves pretty quickly.  One of the best things is that they serve until 1am all week long.  This is a great late night spot.
author: Ryan W.

description: Great miso ramen and very authentic, slightly sweet and spicy, curry don. It reminded me of the teishoku and ramen shops in and around the Seibu department store in Tokyo. Natsukashii...!
author: Rebs W.

description:
My 3rd ramen experiences in SF. (First time Ryowa, Second time Dohatsuten, both surprisingly great!!!) 
This time I tried one of the most reviewed ramen restaurant in SF, Katanaya.I skimmed some reviews and yes, they are right.

I had shoyu ramen.
I agree yelpers mentioned that soup is good but noodles are horrible.
It was gummy, not chewy... and some funny smell...
And I didn't like regular boiled egg in my bowl...

maybe, probably, I'll try here again. 
nah, just dissapointed.
author: Jose R.

description:
I must say that the ramen is halfway decent here.  Not exactly a close contender to some of the other Ramen spots I've reviewed, but it is definitely respectable in taste.
