The miso broth is flavorful and thick as it should be.  The actual ramen itself is authentic, non-home-packaged-instant-noodle-crap.  Having been here twice, I'd say that the good flavor is consistent.  

The venue is quite small, leaving little room for elbow space if you show up with a group of 4.  There is often a line to get in, which is always a good sign.  

Overall, my ramen experience here is slightly above average, but nothing to get too excited over...
author: Johnson N.

description:
So...maybe it's a personal thing with ramen, but I don't see the excitement in lining up for 30 minutes to pay $12 for a bowl of noodles you could buy at the grocery store for 10 cents. (Seriously - ramen costs 10 cents at Safeway.) 

The food is "a-ok," as shown by my Yelp-star rating, but the venue is teeny tiny and frankly, just not worth the hype in my opinion. If there were no wait and I was craving something salty? Sure, this would do the trick. But we live in San Francisco! Land of 10,000 Asians! there must be something better out there.
author: Anna G.

description:
My favorite place for ramen in San Francisco. I tend to judge ramen by the quality of the broth, the texture of the noodles, and the tenderness of the roast pork. This place definitely hits all three of those notes perfectly. The broth is savory and full of flavor and could really serve as a soup all by itself, the roast pork is impressively tender, and the noodles always come out with just the right tenderness. You can also order the crazy trademark Katana-ya ramen that has just about every imaginable ingredient included.

As awesome as the food is, I should warn that the restaurant is very small and they do not take reservations. Even at ridiculous non-peak hours, the wait can be insufferable. Unless you're willing to stand around and wait for seating or put your name down on the list well in advance, I would have a back-up prepared.
author: Tian X.

description:
Ramen:  Amazing and awesome!
Spicy Tuna Roll:  Interesting; spicy but no mayo. 
49ers Roll:  Delicious! You should try it. (Salmon, tobiko, thin lemon slices, cucumber.)
Shrimp Tempura Roll: Awesome as expected

Price: a little on the high side.
author: Ashley M.

description:
I had lunch here when I was in town recently, and I loved it! The lunch menu is great, with lots of options for a couple of different set prices. I had some ramen and tempura. The food was awesome! The service was fast.

The place feels a bit like a dive bar, and there aren't many tables. We a short wait, but nothing too bad. There isn't much for ambience here, but it's a great place to get an awesome meal. Loved it!
author: Joseph B.

description:
So this is what ramen tastes like outside of the noodles that my poor-graduate student-ass has been use to eating since I grew up all the way to the days of not being able to eat them due to my heavy reliance of it in my undergrad days.

I must say that ramen still tastes exactly what it tastes like.  The noodles are a bit better since they aren't the same kind that are in the packages, but for the most part I think the flavor is pretty on point to that of the real thing.  The one major difference is that eating legit ramen has real meat in it, not just flavor!  I had the pork ramen, which was pretty good, but I felt that it wasn't anything special that made me wanna come back right away!

This place is hella busy though so come expecting to wait awhile since the place is pretty small, but hella folks love it.  I'll try coming back again and having something else outside the ramen part of the menu.
author: Mark L.

description:
SUPER delicious ramen!!! I ordered the Kimchee Ramen with miso base, and it was absolutely perfect. The noodles were the right texture with just the right amount of chewy, the kimchi was flavorful, and everything was just right. 

There was a wait - I was there on a Friday night and it was pretty crowded. We only waited about 20-25 minutes, and this place is definitely worth the wait and the squished seating inside. 

Ramen + Miso + Kimchi + Cold Sake = perfect Friday night meal.
author: Connie C.

description:
4 stars if it weren't for the 40 minute wait for two people on a rainy night. 

I got the regular ramen. Pretty tasty but tastes like any other ramen joint.  Choose light soy flavored broth. The next day I came back for take out which took also, 40 minutes. WTF right? I got miso broth that time. 

Stick w/ light soy broth.
author: Julie N.

description:
Oy! I wish they would expand, or set up tables outside! Went here for a late night munchie session after drinks at the Burritt Bar in the Crescent Hotel - it's literally a couple of blocks away. We were here around midnight on a Thursday...and we were in line for 20 minutes! Yikes! (I heard they had a line out the door during lunch that day as well!)

In the end, it was all worth it. My bowl of yummy ramen with budderrrrrrrrr, corn and seaweed was just what I needed to start off my trip in San Fran that week. We waddled back to the hotel and slept so well.
author: Lala L.

description:
Worst ramen in San Francisco. The big line outside are people who probably grew up on instant ramen like Nissan or Maruchan. If you want decent ramen go to Suzu in Japantown or Asuka on Bush near Union Square. If you want great ramen, go to Japan.

UPDATE: Asuka on Bush is closed. See my positive review of Ramen Underground. http://bit.ly/tiQp36
author: John T.

description:
Setting/Location:

The place is really small, which will cause a bit of a wait to be seated depending what time you go. I don't think it would be an ideal place to take someone out on a date seeing how small the place is and how close the tables are, basically no privacy. The service was great, drinks were refilled in a timely manner and food was served fairly quickly.

Food:
I ordered the Katanaya Ramen (Miso) along with a Dynamite roll the evening that I went. I thought the ramen was quite delicious, I had nothing to really complain about. I did let the gyoza soak a bit too long in the ramen, which caused it to taste pretty weird but a friend said it was fine if you ate it first. Just in case you didn't know, the Katanaya Ramen had fried chicken, gyoza, pork, and bamboo inside the ramen. I did wish the ramen had a bit more broth to it but I liked it any how. I definitely agree that this ramen place is the best one in downtown SF, but not the entire city.
author: Chris T.

description:
This place reminds of my memory of an awesome ramen house in Omotesando. So I'm biased towards it. I ordered their Katana-ya special ramen, and it's everything I could've asked for in a bowl of Japanese Ramen. Perfect portions of noodles and soup (I always have Ramens that doesn't have enough noodles for some reason) and the ingredients are all tasty.

Only gripe I have about the place is the wait, there's always a line around dinner time there, to me, it's more hype than food. I've been to super hyped noodle houses that would serve soba in a special bamboo box with strands perfectly combed and stacked, and that was only about 15min wait instead of the 45min I got from Katana-Ya. I let it pass this time since I had fun there chatting with a good friend.
author: Bo D.

description:
The only decent ramen place in downtown SF that I'm aware of.  That said, the quality and taste is still no comparison with the better ramen joints in San Mateo and Santa Clara.  But for a quick fix after shopping at Union Square, this is the place to go.  

I visited with two others this past Friday night with two others.  I ordered the Spicy Green Onion ramen with shio soup base.  It stated fine.  Again, nothing spectacular if you've had better.  It's got one slice of pork and some seaweed in and that's about it.  

The wait is always long so be prepared to wait in the cold air for 30 minutes for a table.  I wouldn't highly recommend this place but again it does hit the spot after shopping!
author: Chris C.

description:
Delicious ramen, but the wait is a bit too much.

I understand that for great food, you gotta wait in line like everyone else, but by the time I circled around the block to find parking, and then stand around for people to finish their food, I may have to pass and try some other places.

This is not a big place, so if you have a party of 5, it's better to split the group because the wait for a larger table takes awhile.

We broke up into 2 groups, one with 2 people, the other with 3. I was in the group of 3. The menu has alot of options, a la carte items, or if you are really hungry, get the meal where you get a couple of items. I chose the Katana-Ya Ramen, if it is their signature ramen, I had to try it.

The food for the table all came out at the same time. The egg was less to be desired in my bowl, but the noodles were good. I got the miso soup and it was good.

The table right next to us was done before we sat down, and were still there by time we started eating, that was about a 15 min gap, so good that the wait wasn't long, but sucky for the people still in line while these two people were holding off the table from new patrons. This is not a place to chat due to the small environment. So if you want to sit and eat slowly, this isn't the ideal place.

However, if you crave some ramen, and you are in the area, and you don't mind the wait, then this is a place you may want to stop by. 

Oh, and don't mind the homeless walking around the area, just acknowledge them like they are real people and help if you want, just don't get in a shouting match with them as with one event that we witness as we left. Or just ignore the ranting when you are outside.
author: Alen K.

description: I enjoy coming to this spot in the city after work on Saturdays.  Usually order the Katana-Ya Ramen as it has a variety of items mixed together with the ramen.  Has pork, gyoza, corn, onions, chicken and the broth, usually miso for me which is all very satisfying, especially on those cold SF nights.  The place is small, so it tends to get crowded real quick, but the service is quick, probably so they can get more turnover for those waiting outside.  The portions are fairly big, but very good.  I'll definitely end up back here at some point, just because I'm a ramen fiend and this one is one of the closer ones from Union Square.
author: Jeremaine R.

description:
Love this place! My favorite ramen restaurant! I recommend the fried chicken ramen with a soy sauce base. it's Delicious! 


***NOTE: don't get the sushi, it's NOT fresh.
author: Kezia M.

description:
I've decided to love this place just a little bit more and give it another star.

Yes, this place is cheap.  Yes, the ramen is good, but in my opinion, still not as good as Tanpopo.  Yes, even their fried rice is good, but, still, pales in comparison to Tanpopo.

But despite all this, I'm starting to get cravings for this place.  And I've NEVER gotten cravings for a so-so place.  KATANA-YA, YOU'VE GOTTEN TO MY HEAD.

This place is small and you have to beat the crowd in order to get seated quickly and to get decent service.  But overall, this place is good for the price and in a great location.
author: Tori S.

description:
Seeing a late night theater show? This place makes for a tasty after party....However...I feel like that's where I felt my joy for the place ended :/
I ordered a mix of sushi and while it wasn't bad...it wasn't amazing either...In their defense, it was late at night (probably 1a.m.) and lets be honest, where else can you find sushi past midnight in the Union Square area?! If you're seeing a show, check it out!
author: Ryan L.

description:
The taste of the ramen was pretty good.  I had the extra spicy ramen with a miso broth.  It was definitely spicy, but not overbearing (but I do like my spicy food)!  The noodles have a nice crunch to it, and not soggy.  However, they don't give much besides ramen itself (i.e. bamboo, seaweed, pork - 1 small piece in my bowl).  Even my friend's kimchi ramen barely had any kimchi. Also, I automatically knock off stars to a place that requires putting MSG in their food to make it taste good, and their ramen definitely has MSG in it.

Service is also quite slow.  They had 2 tables open and needed to be cleaned up, and took about 15 mins to do so.  Meanwhile, about 5 parties are waiting outside to be seated.  After we were seated, it also took another 15 mins for someone to come around to take the order.  Don't come here if you're looking for a quick dine-and-go meal.
author: Mon L.

description:
It wasn't the wait that I minded - because of the crowds I guess I had overly high expectations.

Sadly, my expectations were not met.  We had three different kinds of sushi and they were nothing to write home about.  

I guess I should have tried the ramen - nearly everyone had a huge bowl of ramen.  

It's a very busy place, very crowded, no ambiance and the food is nothing special.
author: Susan W.

description: I know people complain about the service and the lines, but when I got there there was no lines and the service was fast and friendly. The food was pretty amazing. I had the ramen and it was hella expensive, but it was sooo good! I'm not sure if it is worth the price, but it was the best I've had so far!
author: Kevin L.

description:
can't believe i haven't written a review for this; thought i had. 

anyway, this is probably the best overall ramen in san francisco. 

that being said, there are far better ramen shops work the drive in the south bay/peninsula (santouka in san jose in particular comes to mind). but if you don't feel like leaving the city, this is still good ramen.
author: Mark A.

description:
I'm not a connoisseur about ramen, but this place was pretty good. 

My boyfriend and I had our vacation in San Fransisco and we were looking for something light and walking distance of our hotel. I yelped the area and Katana-Ya popped up. It was a Sunday night and we waited about 20 mins. Sat at the bar and ordered the fried chicken ramen and the Katana-ya ramen with the miso broth. 
It was so simple and totally hit the spot. 
Def try this spot when your in the area.
author: Julie C.

description: My friends and I have been coming to this establishment for over 2 years now and one of the reasons we use this as our default "post bar drinking" food is because of it's consistancy. Sober or drunk, the noodles taste just as good as it did the time before, and really, is there anything more you can ask for out of a ramen spot? Dashi is mild, not over-whelming and the chicken karage is pretty tasty.
author: Russell A.

description:
I'm Sorry San Fran people I wasn't very impress with this place! I read all these reviews about it, and I wasn't impress at all.  I still have mad love for SF though.

Living in LA, I been eating a lot Japanese Ramen, and I love it. So I was very excited to eat some ramen in SF and reading all the good reviews I was eager to come.  The wait was about 15 mins, the place was pretty packed but the place is small. Not a lot of places to sit and eat but enough room for a small group.  We ended up eating at the bar which was fine.

Now to the food, for appitizers we order the gyoza which were pretty good, but they brought that out after our Ramen which is never a good idea.  I ended up ordering the Katanaya Ramen with Miso, which was recommended by the waitress.  It had a lot of stuff in it, pork, deep fried chicken and hard boil egg.  It look really good, but I just thought it kinda tasted like a fancy Instant Maruchan Ramen with a bunch of stuff in it with a kick.  I honestly didnt think it was soo great, and to top it offf it was the most expensive Ramen soup in there $13.50, and when i tasted my friend Spicy Green Onion Ramen I thought that was better! I really wanted this place to be good, but it wasnt for me!  I mean I would go back cause I always give places a 2nd chances maybe a 3rd but thats just me.

Happy Eating!
author: Freddy S.

description:
I don't remember what ramen I ordered, but I do remember that I finished it all, and my beer, too.

It must have been delicious! Glad they're open pretty late! We came in on a Sunday night (could have been early Monday morning) and no one was really there. They were able to seat our large party of 10 immediately.
author: Jae A.

description:
So we were super lucky to be staying next door to this busy place, after observing the place over a weekend, we decided to step into our last SF adventure before we returned home.  Timing is key out here, it was about 3:30 lunner time and we were able to just walk in and grab a seat, lines started right after, there was a line every night.  

The ramen is yummy, apparently what this place is known for.  They have combos with sushi, sashimi, rice bowls.  I chose the miso light broth with spicy tofu.  My fiance picked the the soy broth with a rice bowl side $14 my bowl was about $10.  I have to say the broth was yummy, very flavorful.  The portions were large, standard but the smell of steamy broth is what I'm bringing home.  

I have to admit, I feel fortunate that I have more options down here and the prices reflect that, too.
author: Mae-Lae L.

description:
Ok, so far, the best ramen I've had up here so far.

It's very much like Daikokuya in LA's Little Tokyo.  They also have a good mix of rolls and a good selection of sake.

The broth has layers of flavor without giving you that cottonmouth feeling that's characteristic of MSG.

They also give lots of stuff in the ramen so it's very filling and great when you've had a couple drinks.

The wait is terribly long and I would say it's worth a 45 minute wait, but any longer and I would want to move on.

Also it's a bit small so groups of 6 are probably about as large as you want to get, though 4 or less is ideal.
author: Jason K.

description: Never will I eat here again. I got food poisoning from eating their food here...not sure if it was the sushi or fried chicken in the Ramen that did it. Plus, they had our group wait out in the cold!!! Could be a snafu but don't tell me I didn't warn you.
author: Billy A.

description: After about 10yrs of living in SF, I must say that Katana-Ya was the best ramen I've ever had in The City.  I ordered the Kimchi Ramen, per a friend's recommendation and thought it tasted very good!  I chose the Miso broth and felt that it and the noodles tasted quite authentic, compared to other places in SF that serves Ramen.  I have been enjoying eating Ramen since I was a kid and although my favorite ramen here in the states was from this place back home in Honolulu called Taishoken (which unfortunately closed a few years ago), this one from Katana-Ya sure came close to it, in terms of the taste of the broth, the noodles and the garnishes!  Yes, the waiting in line was kinda long, but I thought it was worth it and if I'm craving Ramen again, this is the place I'd go to!
author: Kahanalei M.

description: Upon deciding to eat dinner at 11 pm Friday, we were stumped what was still open until my friend said he wanted ramen. I remember hearing that Katana Ya was open late - and it is! After getting parking right in front (this rarely happens people, I would not recommend driving here) we also were seated right away. We ordered soft shell crab as an appetizer. I only had a bite or two but it was fresh. I had spicy tofu ramen. It was definitely spicy & had lots of tofu. I would definitely order this again. My friend had the katanaya ramen, which I didn't like as much. It was light and had too many toppings for my taste. I'm excited to have this as a late night option!
author: Sara P.

description: This place sucks, smells bad, it doesnt even compare to the ramen houses in san mateo
author: Emerson G.

description: The restaurant is very popular at dinner time. My friend and I waited in line for about 20 mins to get in. I had the Katanaya ramen with meat broth. I think the deep fried chicken, potsticker, and BBQ pork taste good, the softness of the noodles is just right, but the broth can be a bit richer. Overall I like the place and will consider going again.
author: Cuting H.

description:
Food ordering lesson #107: don't order sushi in a place famed for udon (caveat: don't order udon in a place famed for sushi).

The sushi here is remarkably overpriced considering the hole-in-the-wall vibe and mediocre quality.

The Udon looked good.  Like really good.  But I can't comment on that, because I did not obey lesson #107.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Had their spicy ramen (and boy was it true to advertising), seaweed salad and the shaved ice dessert. Really liked the ramen -- noodle texture was firm and the broth flavorful (well, didn't actually drink much of it due to the level of fieriness). The salad was good, although it's hard to mess up seaweed salad and the shaved ice yummy. Definitely want to go back again
author: Alice W.

description: I'm a hugeeee fan of garlic and onions, and i absolutely loooove the green onion ramen. This place is a must for all ramen lovers! It is a really tiny restaurant, so you can always expect a wait. I've brought all my out of town friends here, and they all absolutely love it.
author: Heidi T.

description:
I love katana-ya! i used to come here so much that at one point one of the the waitresses recognized me. It could also possibly due to the fact i had my birthday "celebration dinner" here with a party of 10 and they were very accommodating. A funny thing, they told me, the birthday girl, that the birthday cake was ready to go. 

it was through katana-ya that I was first introduced to the fact that ramen is not just stomach filling/hunger quenching food. therefore, katana-ya will always have a special spot in my heart :) 

all their ramen is good. i usually get their katana-ya ramen with their fried dumplings and fried chicken with miso base.

all in all, it is well worth the wait...
author: Catherine T.

description: How funny!  When my mom and I visited a couple months ago we stayed at the hotel right next door and we always saw groups of people outside waiting.  We kept thinking this place must be good!  The long line always discouraged us and we were always out before the place opened.  Finally, this past weekend I got to try it!  My friends are locals so they knew it would be packed.  We got there at 11am on a Saturday (30 mins before it opened) and happily waited.  Soon after, there was about 5 more groups that joined us.  When they opened the service was very quick and prompt.  The ladies are so nice.  I got the Katana-Ya Ramen with the miso base soup.  It comes with the typical ramen egg, bbq pork, but with the gluttonous twist of potsticker and fried chicken.  Not the southern style fried chicken but the asian style fried chicken which oddly complemented very well with the miso base and noodles.  Who would thought?  But eat it quick or else it becomes soggy.  My eyes were definitely bigger than my stomach because I barely finished half.  I kept digging at it but no progress.  I should've shared this with a friend.  I'd definitely come here again but at an odd hour or right when it opens because this place is tiny!!  And the location is great because it's a block away from the beautiful union square.
author: Tammy N.

description: I love this place. I came about a few years ago and I really love this ramen. I usually order the miso katana-ya special because it has everything. Price is reasonable and portions are great. Their miso broth is Delish, nothing too over powering but very flavorful. Their noodles are firm right to the touch. i always recommend this place, the place itself is very small, wish it was bigger but yet again its the smaller places that are a big hit.
author: Lorena G.

description:
The ramen is great!  but is it worth the wait?  
Maybe for some people.  But usually when I'm craving ramen, it's because I'm cold, hungry and it's usually raining outside.  So to have to wait more than 30 minutes in the cold rain makes it an A-OK rating.  Maybe I'll give it one more star when the weather gets warmer...
author: S R.

description:
I loved this restaurant!!! There were so many ramen broth choices: salt, soy sauce or miso. There were tons of ramen to choose from but the Katana-Ya combo ramen was my favorite since there was an assortment of dumplings, fried chicken, and pork to flavor the soup. The bamboo and seaweed was a great addition to the ramen as well.

I love the fact that real sushi is also served here. They had a wide range of traditional sushi (hamachi, salmon,...), advanced sushi (uni, ankimo, amaebi....), and fusion dishes (hamachi salad,....etc). The traditional red bean and green tea ice cream shaved rice was a fantastic way to end the meal. 

Service is great though I'd say if you come here during busy hours (evenings or weekends), you should expect to wait around 20 minutes. This is a very small restaurant so groups larger than 4 have to squeeze. Overall though, this is still the best ramen restaurant in SF!
author: Annie B.

description:
I was dining solo so I just got my order to-go so I missed some of the experience but the food was great. I was there on a Saturday night so the place was packed with a group of people waiting to get inside.
I ordered a ramen dish and even after walking back to my hotel it was still piping hot. I chose the miso base and while it was a bit salty for my tastes, it was still good. Hopefully next time I'll get to enjoy the full dine-in experience.
author: Dow L.

description: How the heck did Katana-Ya get a higher rating than Santa Ramen or Dojo and other south bay ramenyas? The only good thing about Katana-Ya is that they open late for people stumbling out of nearby bars and in need of something soupy to soothe their uneasy stomach. Ramen joints in SF are below average. If they spend some time on perfecting the quality and  flavor of their soup base, ill change my tune. Just sayin.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
The chasu ramen is on the 7x7 list but I personally, prefer the heart attack-inducing goodness of the fried chicken butter corn ramen. YUMMY!
If you don't like soggy fried chicken skin you can ask for it on the side.  

The ramen is the best I've had in the city . The best I've had is from Daikokuya's in LA.  And I ain't going down to LA every time I have a ramen craving so this is as good as it gets for us SFers.  Texture of the ramen noodles is what I would expect from a great ramen place--non-soggy/mushy.  The broth is well-seasoned, too.     

Another favorite of mine to order is the agedashi tofu.      

Servers are friendly and fun to talk to.  One of the servers explained to us that pro athelets often dine there which explained the autographs lining their walls.  Another reason why I love this quirky little place and why it's my go-to ramen joint.
author: Donna M.

description:
I came here for lunch with my best friend on a Sunday and the wait was really long. 

I had the  BBQ Pork Ramen with corn and my friend had Sukiyaki Don and we also ordered a Salmon and Avocado roll.  The BBQ Pork Ramen was really really salty. The BBQ Pork was cut really thick and it was a little touch eating it.  I liked the Sukiyaki Don a lot more. Honesty I think the ramen was over priced ($11.00 for BBQ Pork Ramen). I like Maru Ichi in Milpitas a lot more.

I have been to better and cheaper places.
author: Sunny L.

description:
Either I am the dumbest guy or I'm not a big fan of ramen.  Almost every time I come here, I never get the ramen.  Instead, I get their mediocre rice bowls.  Why do I put myself in such pain and agony by waiting over 2 hrs for a table?!  

For sure, next time won't be curry bowls or pork cutlets.  I'm getting ramen and ramen alone! -_-
author: Alexander H.

description:
Loved the feel of the place. Makes you feel like you're somewhere authentic. lol. If you want a seat, definitely come during off hours, because we stayed at the hotel around the corner and there was always a line outside from 6pm-ish til 2 AM!

Ordered a mixed green w/a variety of sashimi on top--so much fresh sashimi for ~$9! Too bad the soy sauce based dressing could have been a tad more sour, then it'd be perfect. In the mean time, just squeeze about 2 slices of lime or lemon into it. so good.

Service- 5. Server was awesome, smiled the whole time while giving us suggestions on which soup base to try. I loved the SALT.

As for the ramen, it was delicious and broth was on point. Only wish the bbq pork had more flavor & fresher.

This place is perfect on a cold day!
author: Mindy P.

description:
wow, talk about hype. there's always a line outside this tiny place and most of the yelp review are raving, so we braved the lines and waited a whopping 70 minutes to find out just how good katana-ya really was. it wasn't.

i want my 70 minutes of a beautiful saturday afternoon back. while the food isn't terrible at all, it's also nothing more than a mediocre bowl of ramen -- huge, but mediocre none the less.

and my friend got the oh-la-la katanya ramen which has everything from corn, gyoza, and fried chicken all in it, so not worth it. the fried chicken was soggy -- but not soggy like duh! it's been placed in a broth but was once crisp type soggy, but the kind like it had been sitting out for hours or was wading in soup long before we ordered it kind of soggy. like the kind of soggy no fried chicken should ever be. 

i got the kimchi ramen which should have been a kick in the mouth. the broth should have been over the top tasty but it was not. it was underwhelming. i believe for the 2 bowls of ramen, we spent about $26. not terribly expensive, but enough -- coupled with the ridiculous line always out front -- to keep me from ever coming back. 

p.s. the service is also 'not terrible'. while friendly, they left us waiting for about 10-15 mins sitting idly before serving our drinks.
author: Melissa N.

description:
Since one of my girlfriends just broke up with her boyfriend, I was assigned task to plan something to get her mind off the jerk she was dating. So, it started with happy hour to get a good buzz, followed by  mindless shopping to keep the economy strong around the union square, and then headed off to some bar to warm our selves up. 

Starving from cardio shopping, we were about to order some appetizers but bar food just didn't seem to appeal to us. And then I remembered Katana-ya is just around the corner and although the other two girls complained that they just wanted to snack instead of eating a whole portion, they had no choice since I was the one driving. 

And off we went. After waiting in the cold for 26 minutes, we were finally seated in a tiny table. All three of us were petite asian girls, noone weighs more than 110 pounds or taller than 5'4" and we still have a hard time fitting in the tiny table. I wonder how four full size men would do in this table. 

Seven words. Chicken Karaage Extra Spicy Rich Miso Ramen. Nom Nom. Even those two girls who were about to eat "snack food", ended up finishing the whole bowl each. So much for determination. 

Anyway. Get the extra spicy ramen, it's the bomb. I know some people complain that the chicken get soggy if they don't get them on separate plate, but the spices from the chicken batter actually adds up to the broth taste and make them super yummy. Add a little bit togarashi because im cool like that, and it's goodness. 

So, an extra pound the next day for my girl, but thumbs up to her because she has lost the whole 180 pound jerk.
author: tee w.

description:
I went over the weekend for lunch.
The wait was probably 2 minutes.
It is a very tiny place but the service is very good.
I had the green onion miso broth ramen and my husband had the plain miso ramen.  We thought about getting the combo but it was too much for us.
I had ramen at many place around the bay and I believe this one is one of the best.
It is a long drive for me to get ramen but when I am in the city and need some conforting food, I will definitely think about Katana-Ya.
Of course no where compares to Ramen in Japan by the train station but this place it pretty good!
My hubby loved it and said it was by far the best he had in the US.
:)
author: Emy B.

description:
I'm surprised this place still has 4 stars with so many reviews... I guess ramen's not that great in the city?  Maybe I didn't order the right thing?

A bit of a wait in the cold at 7:30pm on a Saturday.  Oh and it's next to a Quizno's which is easier to spot because you'll drive right past it if you don't know what you're looking for.

I got the Katana-Ya ramen because I figure an order with the restaurant's namesake should be good.  I chose to have it with shoyu broth.  It was chock full of stuff!  Fried chicken, corn, pork, a generous helping of noodles... this bowl was huge!  The fried chicken was awesome, I'd order that on its own.  

I guess I should go back and order a simpler ramen and maybe try the miso broth?   

I don't know, maybe it was an off night, but I felt the ramen and the broth was overwhelmingly okay.  Not amazing, I'm not craving it.  It's more convenient than driving out to Santa Ramen I suppose?  

Oh but I did like how the toro was so cheap.  

I think this place is good for those random ramen cravings but I don't think it's really worth the wait.  I think I'll give it another chance but for now, 3 stars.
author: Becky L.

description:
Ramen has been on my list to try for awhile (as was pho, until recently), and I got the craving to try it today. I happened to be in Union Square for a doctor's appointment, and had an inkling there'd be a place with ramen somewhere in the nearby vicinity of the Tenderloin, Chinatown or Nob Hill. I texted some Yelp friends in ambush-foodie style, and luckily Gene X came to the rescue almost immediately! FTW! Quickly thereafter Keane L replied and validated Gene's recommendation. Hands down, both suggested I check out Katana-Ya. 

I googled the address and tried my best to sprint through Union Square (definitely my *least* favorite part of the city - too crowded and too many people who don't know where they're going or what they're doing) to get to the safety of the interior of the restaurant. Luckily, inside it was rather calm. I was also pleased to find out that everyone working there seemed to be Japanese, and they were speaking Japanese. The servers were both extremely friendly, and they were delighted when I told them my Yelp friends had spoken highly of their restaurant.

I ordered the Deep Fried Chicken Ramen, which I'm not sure is authentic, but I am sure that it was most definitely excellent! The bowl of tasty goodness was one of the best things I've eaten in awhile. I absolutely loved it!

5 stars for food, friendliness, and service.

p.s. To further validate this place's reputation, as I was eating, Tinna H replied and suggested I try Katana-Ya. The response from my Yelp friends was now unanimous!
author: Sally M.

description: We got seated right away the soup was okay I got the vegetable ramen it was kinda bland. Tried the cilantro soup was pretty good though! My friends got the katanaya ramen and the pork was a little dry. Service was pretty good too. Except they only take two credit cards per bill but they made an exception for us, thank you Martha!! They play really good music though!!
author: Kierstyn W.

description:
I knew I couldn't go wrong with over 1700 yelps but I had no idea. I had the fried chicken ramen at the recommendation of fellow yelpers but before ordering, as I usually do, I asked the waitress to point out a few items that are widely ordered. Before she could answer, a wonderful young woman by the name of Stacy said, "try the chicken fried ramen." Evidently, she has most "yelp check-in" to date for this place so I decided to take her advice. 

It was also suggested I try the sashimi when I return, which I plan to do several times this week since it's next to my hotel.

As I mentioned previously,  I arrived after 10 PM and was told that it can be difficult to get in if you arrive any earlier.
author: Art A.

description:
I got the Katana-ya Ramen which includes ALL-crispy chicken, pork, pot sticker, buttered corn, and egg for ~$12. A little overpriced for me for what it is.

The place is super tiny. The bar literally takes up 1/4 of the restaurant and its so congested you're literally a eating a foot apart from the next table.

For ramen lovers, its pretty good. But for me, its A-Ok and I'll probably go back only if its convenient
author: Denise W.

description: Excellent place. I like to come here often to get the Katana Ya ramen... The broth has a lot of flavor and the meat goes very well with the broth and the noodles. The noodles are chewy and tasty as well.
author: E H.

description:
Guy: Can you settle an argument for me?
Us: Uh. Sure. 
Guy: Do you floss first or brush first?
Us: Uh. Ok... 

And this is how our night started. A long wait in line for the BEST RAMEN IN THE CITY and then these two guys tried to make conversation. I guess I could have been nicer, but I was hungry, cold and grumpy. So was Jen... and Rick, who got lost while making his way to the car. 

The Ramen was excellent! I had the BBQ pork and it was perfect. Good sized bowl so you don't need to order extra food unless you can eat a horse. Jen had the Combo Platter/Dinner thingamabob. It was so fresh (and so clean clean!)

Totally worth the wait. Just make sure if someone tries to use a pick up line - to smile - unlike us.
author: Lisa L.

description: When I lived in SF in 2006-2010 I was a regular customer.  I would find any excuse to eat at this place. I even knew the right times to go to avoid the long lines.  That's how much I loooooved Katana Ya! So needless to say I was so excited to visit after two years and have my usual fried chicken ramen with katsu don.  But I gotta say as soon as they brought out the ramen I could tell right away it wasn't the same yummy goodness I ate two years ago.  *Tears!!!  The noodles changed and seemed lower quality (to me) and the broth just didn't taste quite right.  The Katsu Don was still pretty tasty but the ramen really let me down.  All in all it was so-so but not excellent the way I remembered.  So bummed :(((
author: Rhy C.

description: Ramen is great, though I like to order without too much fuss, there are too many selections!  Had some hamachi as well, very delicious.  With Ramen+sushi+coke I still got out for under 25 bucks.  NIce!
author: David S.

description: Great ramen, simple menu, clearly, you have a line of adoration out the door. Will come here again.
author: Shang S.

description:
This is probably the best ramen I've had - the soup is delicious, the noodles are fabulous, and the service is quick.  Alas it's a small spot, so there can be a wait when it's crowded.  Possibly the only drawback... today I had the barbecue pork and my friend had the deep fried chicken, and we shared the meats.  So so so so amazing!

Can't wait to go back and try other ramen choices.  I'm not sure if I'd get non-ramen because the ramen is so darned perfect.
author: Michael S.

description:
I kid you not, this was my first real destination in my first non-family visit to San Francisco. And how could it not be, boasting stellar reviews from 'professional' foodies and amateurs alike? As a Seattle girl I don't usually get the opportunity eat real, delicious ramen and so it was my goal to eat it as much as possible and from as many places as possible in SF.

Katana-Ya is a tiny little joint in almost-the-Tenderloin-district (or maybe it's not 'almost'-- I have no idea). The line was out the door when we arrived, with more people on the sidewalk and street than in the actual restaurant itself. We were forced to look in with sad, hungry eyes and watch as people delightfully slurped up their noodles and crunched on gyoza with the hope that we, too, would soon be members of the happy ramen-eating elite. Fortunately the wait did not actually kill me and I was able to plop down and order the house namesake ramen which has basically everything in the world heaped into the bowl. I chose the shoyu broth, being a little thrown off by the options between that, miso, and salt and I think I made the right choice. The fried chicken might have been a bit of overkill, as were the gyoza since we also ordered them as an appetizer, but I made it through the monster of a bowl and had to force myself to stop despite feeling like somewhat of an overinflated, broth-filled balloon. It was a little on the pricier side from what I recall, but for the amount of food you get I'm not going to complain.

The best part about Katana-Ya is that they serve food super late so all of you late diners can still partake in yummy ramen after the bars. Bonus for late-night dining is that the wait basically doesn't exist! I highly suggest coming with a hungry friend and ordering combos because nothing is more satisfying than being able to eat more things for less money.
author: Lisa N.

description: Good ramen. Not the best I've had but it will do. Nice little atmosphere within San Francisco too. Sometimes there may be a long wait.
author: David N.

description: A bit surprised that this place's ramen made it on the 7x7 list. They give big portions and the toppings are good, but the broth and noodles are just okay. The broth is a little salty and the noodles don't have a great texture. I actually recommend ordering the other things on the menu like curry or uni donburi.
author: Alice J.

description:
I can't say I've found a favorite ramen place yet in the Bay Area, but Katana-Ya ranks well in my book.  I'd say that I'd rate it a 3.5 or so.  Let's see the breakdown:

Ramen:
Broth was okay (3 stars)
Noodles were yummy - I like mine chewy and al-dente (4 stars)
Chashu - meh, not memorable, but I don't usually even care to rate that element...not a major ramen measure for me

Other stuff:
Long list of other foods - yay!  Impressive for such a tiny place!  Offers sushi and other stuff.  I liked that I could get a ikura/uni don for $9 - such a steal!  (4 stars)
author: Fontane L.

description: We got there right when it opened, and the tables were already filled within 20 minutes. The ramen is good, although the soup is a little salty for my taste, but all ramen is like that. I would return!
author: Natalie G.

description:
I went here for the second time last night.  Got the titular Katanaya bowl.   The broth was pretty tasty, and the fried chicken was good, but overall the experience seems not-worth-it.  We waited a long time outside with crackheads pestering us for a quarter.  Then paid 13 dollars for a bowl of noodles with a few small pieces of meat and hardly any veggies.  I also got some sushi last time I was there, and that was definitely not-worth-it.

Maybe I'm just not a ramen guy (this is actually the only place I have ever had ramen) but for the price it seems there are much better options.  For $13 you can get three Bonus Jack Combos just a few doors down!
author: Lenza M.

description:
Complete disappointment.  My bf and I came expecting some damn good ramen and what we got was overpriced MSG.   The only positive thing I can say is that the noodles had good texture.  The soup base was overly salty, and the ingredients that came with the noodles were minimal and not fresh.  

I also couldn't believe how overpriced it was!!  For 2 noodle combos, we paid close to $40.  I just can't justify paying that much for noodle soup.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Yummy yummy in my tummy! Liking noodles is part of being Asian. A friend of mine introduced me here and my taste buds were delighted! It's hard to find such a good noodle place. You'd think noodles are easy to make but it's all in the flavor of the broth and the tasty goodies you eat with the noodles. 
We had the soft shell crab appetizer, regular ramen with miso broth and sake. The crab melted in my mouth and I could have eaten 2 bowls of the ramen! I was sweating by the time I was halfway through because of the spices. A mango ice cream mochi put out the fire nicely.
author: Amanda W.

description:
This place is definitely overhyped and overpriced. I guess because I'm from So Cal and I've had better ramen in little Tokyo and in the general LA area.

There was a wait but wasn't too bad during the weekday. 

The ramen that my mom and I got was the one everyone had recommended. The soup was bland and the shrimp tempura in it was really soggy by the time we had gotten it. My grandmother got the California roll and it was mediocre. 

The only thing, I think , that earned them the 3 stars was their service. The Japanese girls there are really nice and one of them was really patient and explained their menu to my grandmother in Japanese (and actually chatted up with her. haha).

Over all, I would not come here again. The flavor was not worth the price for the food I had gotten.
author: Shirley H.

description: Easily the best ramen I've ever had. I usually pick the ramen out and leave most of the broth behind, but their miso broth was so rich and delicious that I found myself spooning out every last drop. I will definitely be coming here again.
author: Sophia B.

description:
-pretty good noodles
-prices are decent, not too much, not too little
-service is fine, no complaints

i'd come back
author: Steven L.

description:
I had been hearing a lot of good things about this place, so yesterday I decided to go because I wanted some ramen, and something nice and hot in my tummy. 

When I went it was barely 6pm, so of course the place didn't have the dinner crowd just yet. I was seated promptly, a guy came out to give me tea and water, and my waitress took my order after I checked out the menu. I had the spicy tofu ramen, and I liked it a lot. It was good. Although when I was ordering, I kind of had the urge to run out of there because it said on the menu they add MSG. And being on a recent "health kick" I didn't know if this was such a good idea. But I ordered the ramen, and it was tasty: it had a nice little kick of spicy, and the soft tofu was plentiful. I'm not sure if they make their own ramen noodles, but to me it didn't taste like it.

I did enjoy the food, but I think what I didn't like was the service during the end of my meal. My waitress didn't seem to notice me (even though there were tons of mirrors everywhere that I could see my own reflection in all corners of the restaurant). And though someone else came to clear away my food I literally watched my waitress pass me by about ten times catering to everyone else around me (by then the dinner rush was starting, and she just kept going around to everyone BUT me). I was done for almost ten minutes! She never came to check on me at all, and I didn't really enjoy that. And towards the end she finally realized I was done eating, and gave me my check... but someone else's! Ramen does NOT cost 20 bucks. Anyway, I told her, she said she was sorry, but by the end of it I wanted to get out of there. I was in there longer than I should have been.

Don't really know if I want to go back, to be honest.
author: Caroline L.

description:
I finally got around to trying this place out, and glad I did. I didn't bother with sushi or any of the other Japanese fare - just the ramen with all it's porky and soy-saucy goodness. 

The downside?

1. I'm pretty sure there's a way to pack as much flavor into the broth without adding MSG, but based on the crowd they pull I doubt the owners will bother to make a change.

2. Between the super-small space and the roar of the patrons, I found myself overwhelmed by the conversation the very drunk college kids were having in my ear. Is it appropriate to announce in public that later you're gonna squeeze your large white %$@# into the Asian broad's tiny hole? Ouch. I must be getting old. 

If you're not fussed by MSG and drunken racist banter then this is a 5-star dream come true. Otherwise embrace the chaos and enjoy the noodles. Or not.
author: Prattle P.

description: Having had really good ramen....I don't know what the hype is all about this place.  I ordered the set meal that came with ramen and curry rice..was not impressed.  I agree with other reviewers that say this place is over rated.  There is often a wait.  I would come back again if I was craving ramen and was in the Union Square area..otherwise..eh.  The place is super super small.  The sushi bar looked questionable...not really a fan but would give it another chance.
author: Helen C.

description:
I came here a long time ago upon yelp recommendations. This tiny hole in the wall place was packed and got there just to get a table by the door with the breeze. Service is ok and the girls just look at you so dont expect any good service here. I guess you would be stale and unhappy too if you worked in a joint like this! I second TOro E's review of the bitch ass japo waitresses hahah!
Onto the food...

Had the highly coveted ramen, I think spicy pork, and it came in a huge bowl with TWO thin ass strips of pork, some seaweed, corn and half an egg. Broth was forgettable, but for $9, come on!
I've been to japan and had really great $3 ramen in a strip mall and it was better than this! 

Didnt even bother with sushi or anything else. A total waste of time and $$. can;t remember what else we had...Highly OVERRATED FOLKS!!!
author: Petri Y.

description:
Delicious!!!
Had the salt-based, rich broth Katana-Ya (#12 i think), which I whole-heartedly recommend.  Been here twice now, and the food always comes within 5-10 minutes.  Very filling!  Whenever I get the ramen craving, I'm coming here and bringing all my friends (well not all of them, this place is a tad cramped and always packed).
author: Nathan R.

description: Don't be fooled by the crowds, the ramen here is average at best. We waited around 15 min for 2 on a Saturday afternoon, and I got a shio BBQ pork ramen. It's ok, but honestly nothing spectacular or great. I take my ramen egg very seriously, and the ones they have looked so overcooked that I decided to pass it up. I don't except to go back especially consider the line and the wait time.
author: Diana H.

description:
I WILL ADMIT that my first review was misguided. i did not have ramen the first time, and i was just young and foolish. the many people who are fans of my reviews (shout out to all 3.5 of you) know that i am automatically inclined to hate a place if it is really hyped up, but i do eventually sell out and change my mind. 

THE MUSIC IS STILL WEIRD AND FUNNY but i have come to love it like my own son. i've never felt more like a pimp from the future while downing ramen in my life.

THE KATANA-YA RAMEN is very delicious and sounds ridiculous because there is not only soup, noodles, and pork in it, but also crazy futuristic shit like fried dumplings and something else delicious that i forgot about. definitely good though. i also shared one of their hamachi rolls whose name i don't remember but it was actually quite tasty and fresh. i would definitely get these exact same items again in the future.

MORE WORDS IN CAPS. the wait sucks because the place is so small, but i must say this place has finally earned my legendary respect. all i have to say now is don't believe the hype, just eat it all. 

EDMUND OUT
author: Edmund C.

description:
Location, location, location! That's what makes this restaurant so popular. That and Yelp-induced inertia. 

I came early in the night with 3 small groups ahead of me ~30 min wait. I had the Katana-ya ramen w/Ikura-uni don.

KATANA-YA RAMEN: has chicken karaage, fried dumplings, chashu, and egg.. soo BOSS! Unfortunately, they failed at making any of those appetizing. 
The noodles were decent. Good noodles are of the thicker variety IMO and has a good al dente bite. Their ramen... was better than instant noodles. Their broth was also not memorable.
The kicker of the dish were the toppings -- but they were poorly done. It's a shame and an irony that the flagship/name-bearing dish sucks.
The key to having fried ingredients in a soup is to fry to perfection and serve IMMEDIATELY. Katana-ya got the latter half right. However, the fried pot-stickers tasted like hollow nothingness - no substance. 
The chicken was a poor excuse for karaage - was this pan fried or pan-reheated? 
The egg was plain and hard-boiled -- no flavor/not soft boiled? What ramen style is this? 
The chashu was overly lean and borderline tough. Seriously, what kinda style is this? Lean chashu? Show me the FAT! 


IKURA/UNI DON: The idea of this is awesome. Ikura-don is one of the richest side-dishes for ramen. Top that off with uni? Heaveeen right? Somehow, this rubbed my taste buds in the wrong way. Was it the uni? The ikura? Something had a metallic aftertaste. *puts bowl down*


NOTE: Don't come in large parties. The group that left after we got seated looked disappointed. The restaurant is too small and understaffed for them to make you guys happy.


CONCLUSION: Although I went with no expectations, I still found this place sub-par and not very memorable. This might taste better if you've already got a good buzz going late night. I don't know why it was on 7x7, but hey, if you're around, might as well try it.
author: Stanley L.

description:
Yelp fail. I don't understand how this place received 4 stars. It definitely shouldn't be because of the ramen.

It was freaking 90 degrees in the city these past few days. I know, it's my fault for craving ramen on such a hot day but seriously, A/C much??

Maybe I'm just a ramen snob but this was such a let down. I ordered the karaage miso ramen rich and my DB had the house special light. For $12.50 a bowl of the katanaya ramen, his ramen was the same as mine but with two slices of char siu and two fried wontons. My ramen wasn't rich, by any standards. They must have skimped on the pork bone or they didn't let it stew long enough. I actually had to add soy sauce just to make it bearable. Kikkoman to the rescue.

The good news is that they have kani kurimu kurokke (crab cream croquettes). They aren't on the menu and the receipt didn't have a breakdown but I think they were like $5.00 each. 

The cute japanese couple adjacent ordered some scrumptious looking shaved ice. If I ever come back, I think that's what I'll get along with some more kurokke.
author: Cindy W.

description: The food is great, the service is quick, and it seems consistent. That's a good combination.
author: Vivek N.

description:
Oh how I want to love this place.  I love thine spicy brew, and I love thine fresh tasting noodles, and I love thine creative stuff thrown into the mix.

However.

I don't like spending the evening and following morning in GI purgatory.

Katana-Ya is batting 0/2 when it comes to leaving me with a sturdy stomach, and I'm no finicky eater.  I eat pretty much anything and everything, aside from raw bananas - go figure.  One day I will again stand in that line, give away some change to the passers by, and enjoy that delicious ramen, though not until I find some good electrolyte mix for afterwards. :/
author: Joe B.

description: Tried the katana-ya ramen. It was a very tasty combination of all their specialty ramens. The broth I got was shoyu that was rich though not too complex. The quality of the noodles were soft and chewy. The space is very limited so expect to wait.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
So for my 3rd round of Ramen on my San Francisco trip I decided to give Katana-ya a try. The restaurant is very small and maybe has at most 8-10 tables and a sushi bar area. Definitely go early if you want to dine in as this place is popular.

With way too many choices to choose from (and an unlimited amount of combo possibilities) I decided to go with the Katana-ya special ramen. 

It had an egg, chashu, corn, seawood, fried chicken, and some gyoza. The supposed rich broth wasn't very rich and I seemed to leave a little dissappointed. I enjoyed the fried chicken (it really is hard to mess up anything fried), but the chashu was a bit overrated.

I wish I had the stomach space to try the other ramen but for now I have to give this place a 3.
author: Andrew C.

description:
We arrived at around 9PM on a weeknight and the wait was around 30 minutes.  The place is quite small with only two servers, several tables and a very small bar.

Our server was an Eastern European girl who had an accent and was very frazzled, even more so when we had a couple of questions.  She would then ask the people behind the bar, and the difficulties in communication escalated as neither party could understand each other.  To spare everyone stress and frustration, we gave up on questions and just ordered.

We got the Katana-Ya ramen with rich broth and a kimchee miso ramen, also rich.  The ramen was okay, I wasn't blown away by it.  It was about as good as Santa Ramen in San Mateo.  

We also ordered toro nigiri, butter fish nigiri (forgot what the actual type of fish was), and a few rolls.  The toro was SO good and was only $6.50; we couldn't help ourselves and just had to have a second order.  We also saw another patron's sukiyaki which looked good and made a mental note to try that next time.  Another thing to note, they put a smidgen of wasabi between the fish and rice on the nigiri.  I'm not a big fan of imitation wasabi (basically horseradish with green food coloring), so that was just a little annoying but no biggie.

Pros: yummy and not burn-a-whole-in-your-wallet prices for toro, extended menu, late hours.

Cons: very tiny inside, confused waitress.
author: Laura S.

description:
been back here a few times since my first review with a better trained palate on what to look for in a good ramen bowl.

this place is up there:
-huge hearty bowl
-chewy al dente noodles
-multiple slices of pork
-options for ordering depending on your taste (go for light broth)
-tasty broth with just enough fat, yet still has that "clean" flavor
-lots of veggies, think there's pickled stuff in there too
-open late

the only cons:
-limited seating
-hard to park
author: Josie M.

description: My fave place to go for ramen. Your choice of either miso, soy, or light broth (I almost always get miso) and depending on what you feel like -- there's fried chicken, corn, kimchee, spicy tofu, cilantro.. Their sushi is somewhat pricey though. Best time to go is right when they open if you're trying to get lunch...a line forms quick in this cozy establishment.
author: Nicha K.

description:
WOW, best ramen place I've ever been to in SF. OKAY, YOU GOT ME... it's the only ramen place I've been to in SF. Haha, but in comparison to ramen I've had in SoCal, this place had some really good ramen. It was perfect for a cold day in summer and it was deelish! I had the Katanaya ramen with miso broth (they also had salt and soy sauce broth to chose from) and the Chicken Katsu Don (separate trips). Both were money worth spending and reasons why I'd visit again and again!

It's a really good hole-in-the-wall place and super popular! It gets super crowded during meal times which totally proves the legitimateness of my 5 star rating. Must go! Must eat! 

P.S. Did I mention it was open until 1:15am?! Late night FTW! (You don't have to resort to Mexican food!)
author: Samantha B.

description:
Ordered Katana-Ya Ramen, consists of deep fried potstickers, chicken, corn, seaweed and ramen. I had it with miso soup base. It was too salty for my liking. I might have had high expectations going here. 

Ippudo in NYC is still the best! Orenchi in San Jose is good too! Tonkatsu base!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Talk about your typical case of a cult following...Though I aspire to live in the city someday, as of right now, I only get to experience bits and snippets of local culture. Katana-ya was one of those places I had heard of from multiple people and was really looking forward to trying...

Got there at 11:50 and the woman would not let us sit inside (away from the cold) and made us wait till it "legitly opened" at 12:00. Thanks, clearly customer satisfaction is in her best interest...We waited in a different store a couple doors down for about 10 minutes then came back...we were the first to be seated, but far from the last! By 12:15 there was a waitlist for seating (1. because the food was good 2. because the restaurant is SMALL). I guess thats why she didn't let us come early! She didn't want to cause a Nintendo Wii situation where people are camping out there because they want to get in right away as soon as those doors open....

I had the spicy tofu ramen (with miso broth) and my friends ordered the regular ramen (miso and soy), fried chicken ramen, and the chicken teryaki. I only tasted the regular ramen, and it was actually mediocre at best. The miso was too salty, and the broth was an interesting flavor that wasn't particularly tasty. The spicy tofu ramen, on the other hand, was a great choice. I loved the broth (perfect spiciness...not mild, but not intense) and the tofu chunks absorbed the broth exploding flavor into your mouth with every bite.

I do understand how people can love this place, I'm sure it gets better every time. And since this also doubles as a sushi bar, I'm going to have to guess their fish is super fresh--because this place smells extremely fishy. Still, I dig. Hope to find some more good ramen joints~
author: Samantha R.

description:
Eh, it's decent. The ramen wasn't mind blowing or anything. I got here at two(ish)? There was a waiting list, but it wasn't that long. When we got in side, my friend and I sat all the way in the back. IT WAS HOT. This place is freaking small and not to mention dark! I do like the xmas lights though! The waitress who sat us was RUDE. Gosh. She was cranky and grouchy. Geez. Thank god she wasn't our waitress. On the other hand, our waitress was extremely friendly and nice. She asked if we wanted to share the ramen. The portions were huge and not to mention PRICY. I mean, $11 for VEGETABLE RAMEN???? For the plus side, they have a vegetarian variation that doesn't use meat broth which was awesome. We got the miso styled one and it was just okay. I felt like it was overwhelming with all the flavors and such. I don't think I'll be back unless I'm really craving ramen. 

PS: Their california roll SUCKS!
author: Susie N.

description: One of the best ramens I've had. If you get the spicy soup it's even more delicious, but their chasu ramen (BBQ pork) is great too. Thier noodles were good, not great. THeir broth makes me want to go back again and again. Did I mention I live in LA?
author: Hae A.

description: Pretty tasty ramen. I loved that our group got seated right away, downstairs -it felt a little exclusive, which was cool. I ordered the Katana Ya special (comes w/ 2 gyozas  in the soup), and the chicken karaage. Though I was full and satisfied, somehow I feel like I've had better. The three stars reflect our amazing service. Our servers were very hospitable, accurate and quick -which our group of 9 very much appreciated!
author: Tricia A.

description:
Since this place is open till 1AM, my bf and I decided to hit this place up for midnight munchies.  Even one hour to closing time, we still had to put our name down on the wait list.  For ramen?  Crazy!

The restaurant is super small, so our wait was a good 10-20 mins or so.  We ordered the Sweet Corn Ramen (based on past Yelp reviews) and the Chasu Ramen (based on 7x7's Big Eat SF list).  I've had ramen only once before at a restaurant and really didn't like it too much, but I have to say Katana-Ya changed my mind about it.
Both the Sweet Corn and Chasu ramen were really good, but it was agreed the Sweet Corn ramen was better.  I recommend it, and will definitely be back for more of that!
author: Crys L.

description:
Sorely disappointed in San Francisco because this is the best raman they have to offer.  After going to Ippudo in NYC, I returned to San Francisco looking for a mean bowl of ramen.  I ordered several different raman bowls here, and it just didn't do it for me.  They don't even have Tonkotsu broth, only miso or soy sauce.  :(  They also don't have pork belly, only bbq pork.  :(

I guess it's a good bowl of ramen, but not what I'm looking for.  Instead I just go to Japan town and pick up ramen stuff and make it myself now, and it is so much better than Katana-Ya.
author: H. L.

description: I don't think this is the best ramen in town.  The noodle was al dente, but a bit thicker than I would like.  The cha-su is a bit fatty or is that how it is.  The miso broth was good, not too salty.  There's choices:  soyo, miso, or ?, light or rich.  I had the miso, rich, BBQ pork for $10.50.  This is not the same as the Chinese BBQ pork, more like boiled pork with fat.  I think I had better ramen. I have to say the salmon roll was delicious.  That was the best I've had.
author: Helen L.

description:
Katana-Ya is really good. Noodles are cooked to perfection, ramen portions are generous, and it's fairly inexpensive. I had the spicy tofu ramen--the spiciness was just right, not too overpowering, but enough to give it a good kick. 

perfect if you have only one other person with you, there's not a lot of space for groups.
author: Brian S.

description:
O...M...G!  This place was seriously amazing, my fiance and I have not been able to stop thinking of this place since our trip to San Francisco!  

Imagine the scene.  It was a cold November night...the night before Thanksgiving.  We had just had a few beverages down the street at  Amsterdam Cafe and needed a late night place to hit before heading back to the hotel.  I trust my fellow yelpers, so we walked (briskly) to Katana-Ya.  On a cold winters night in the city all I could think about was a big old bowl of soup - ramen to be exact.  The Japanese comfort food I was raised on!

We stop in about 45 minutes before close. I was VERY happy to read from fellow yelpers that we needed to make sure to get there early (even though they close at 1, they stop seating earlier).  There wasn't a wait - and the super cute, adorable and friendly Japanese waitress seated us at a cozy table for two.  This was my fiance's first experience at a true ramen shop (his prior experience had led him to believe ramen only came in the form of freeze dried packages with sodium packs).  I was soo stoked to school him on ramen.

We ordered a spicy tuna roll to start, and I ordered him the pork miso ramen.  For me?  Spicy Pork Shoyu Ramen.   Service was fast, friendly, and our orders were up in no time at all!  It was probably one of our best meals in San Francisco.  The roll was delicious, but the soup was what really melted us.  The miso ramen was full of flavor, and the spicy shoyu was by far the best of what we ordered.  It was spicy for my fiance (perfect for me - I probably could've used more spice) but I was able to add pepper to it.   So much flavor without being too salty.  Flavorful broth - you could taste the meat in the broth, kind of like a pho noodle soup where the broth is what makes the soup. Everything else is just fluff.  We never felt like we we had MSG headache or that greasy feeling on your lips after consuming broth made from pork or chicken.  The noodles were fresh, and to reiterate - the meal itself was pure comfort - especially on a cold windy night in San Fran.

Prices were reasonable we thought - about $9 for a bowl.  I feel like even though it was $9 for soup - it was a big bowl and we were in the city!  It was totally worth it!

I think what made everything so much more special was taking someone out for ramen who had never experienced it.  It was such a fun time - and getting to see the amazement at how good it was - Priceless!
author: Kristy K.

description:
I have gone here twice and have yet to actually eat in the restaurant.  Every time I go, there is a long wait.  The first time we were starving so we just ordered to go and ate it back at our hotel.  The second time, we weren't that hungry but the wait was ridiculous, so we decided again to just order to go.  
The first time I got the Kimchi Ramen with Miso base, very yummy.  Good spicy kick.  
The second time I got the Katana-Ya Ramen with salt base.  We also got a small order of Kimchi fried rice which was good too.  It was all good.  My friend got the Sukiyaki over rice which was delicious as well.  
It's hard to go wrong with Ramen, I just love it!
Hopefully next time, I'll be able to actually eat inside the restaurant!
author: Yvonne W.

description: Came back again for dinner this time and the wait was long. We got here probably around 9pm. I ordered the Kimchee Ramen, Miso base. I think it would of been better with added spiciness, but of course I didn't want to do that the night before our 5k marathon. But it was still pretty good. What I'm really giving 5 stars is for the Butter Corn Ramen, oh my goodness...its delish! My friend ordered this and let me taste the broth and just from that it was oh so good! I will be ordering that the next time I come back!
author: Lili Phuong C.

description: This place is very small !! Katana ya reman is tasty & rich !!!! Service is not so well for some reasons !! One of my classmates actually told me that waitress dont get chance to share tips so service is not good ( the boss gets tips )!! If this is true that all the waitress don't get tips I can forgive why they gave me a really bad service !! Last time I went there , I asked hot sauce , tea but they never answer me !
author: Anita J.

description:
Can I say YUUMMMM??!!!!

Writing this review makes me want to eat ramen. OK so this place is kinda small so you definitely wanna make sure you don't come during lunch/dinner rush because you'll be mad and hungry - not a good combo. 

I had the ramen bowl with gyoza and fried chicken - yes, I order this every time I come here. I "act" like I'm looking at the menu every time but I just can't seem to order anything else. 

At least I always order something else the side. I've tried their kimchi fried rice, and most of their salads. All soo yummy. 

Two thumbs up! The only reason why I didn't give it a 5 star is for the wait but the food is wonderful.
author: arlene r.

description:
Ramen is one of my favorite food, and the ramen here is only ordinary. They only appear to have a long line waiting because the store is too small and the waitress that day, no offense, too slow. There are plenty more quality ramen place around with richer broth and noodle quality. 

If you are not in the neighborhood, this is not worth the drive I guarantee it, no matter how solid of a 4 stars this place is being reviewed.
author: Chase L.

description:
Please excuse the honest, unadulterated tone of my opinion: Over-hyped.

I went here on a chilly, rainy Sunday afternoon - perfect for a hot bowl of soup - and there was a ~10 minute wait for a table. So I thought to myself, "this must be good."

When I was seated, the waitress was attentive and my $14 noodle-donburi combo came out pretty quickly. So far so good, but ...

The tuna donburi was at best "aight" for me, as I expected more tangy-spicy in my tuna. Not a biggie, as this is a ramen house, but ...

The flavor-factor of the ramen broth was probably the blandest of what I've enjoyed before. Now there's 3 flavor settings for the broth: light, regular, and rich - I ordered rich, but the flavor-factor was still below par. Portion size was acceptable, and I noticed there's a huge variety of toppings you can add to pimp out your bowl. But let's face it: The broth MAKES OR BREAKS the ramen.

STAR SUMMARY
+1 star for the attentive waitress.
+1 star for the snappy order.
+1 star after noticing from other reviews that quality here can be inconsistent (guess I came here on a bad day), so I'll give another star for the benefit of the doubt.
author: Ray H.

description:
The place is really small. I'm talking about elbow to elbow eating at a table. The food makes me come back though. One of the most authentic and best ramen I've ever had in the Bay. The meat was tender. The noodles were fresh. The broth was savory. My favorite is the fried chicken miso ramen.

Oh, and it's open late. Perfect to conclude a night in the city.
author: Katheryn H.

description:
I hate to be mean....but I really find this place overrated.
I have read and heard so many good reviews about this place and had high expectations for it to satisfy my ramen craving in the city.

Came here on a saturday night and had to wait 40 minutes for a table for 2. The tables are squishy in the small restaurant and its just very awkward coz you can pretty much hear the conversations of tables sitting next to you. They made us decide really quickly and order once we sat down, and the WORST PART, rushing us to pay the bill once we're semi-done (due to the long line waiting outside) We had just put down our chopsticks and 2 seconds later the waiter brought the check without asking (i was still considering in getting dessert at that time.....guess not!)

I ordered the basic shoyu ramen and i was sadly, not impressed. The The ramen noodles were not chewy at all, and the broth was just average.

Overall....the experience was quite disappointing. I really wish it could have been better since everyone said its the best ramen place in the city. Santa Ramen in San Mateo is still my absolute favorite. Its not that far drive from the city and at least you dont have to worry about street parking.

*Lesson learned: never fully trust  from what you read online and have any expectation before encountering (same theory that goes with first dates!)
author: Shirley H.

description:
Been there twice, nothing really memorable, so I'm going to say it's alright.  But maybe if I didn't have Himawari or Santa Ramen near me, I'd think this place was really good.  I took a couple of my friends from Texas there, and they thought it was great.  But, this was also their first taste of ramen not out of a plastic bag.

The first time I went, it was lunch during the weekday.  I waited for 30 min.  Not worth it.  It's super cramped inside, kinda uncomfortable really.  But, it's alright if you're craving noodle soup and don't have to wait for it!  And it's pretty conveniently located if you happen to be around Union Square.
author: Jennifer W.

description: A great selection of tasty Japanese food at good prices, especially the ramen, but be prepared for a loooong wait!
author: Yinnie L.

description:
so authentic you can cut the msg with a knife, ok not that serious but that kind of authentic. 

their Crispy Fried Chicken is tasty, especially in miso broth- and the breading on the chicken is definitely crispy. a little disappointed in the 1/2 of a boiled egg in my friend's Green Onion Soup she paid extra for them to add.. but times is hard i guess. 

their soft shell crab is good, but i'd like to go back and try the rest of the sushi so i can add another star. 

i love how late they're open until and how hole in the wall they are too
author: eVa J.

description: The katana-ya ramen is good, but it's loaded with wayyy too much MSG. I feel dehydrated like a raisin now...
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
I rarely come here because of the wait and the fact that no one wants to wait 10 to 15 minutes for a table. I came here a few times and always thoroughly enjoyed the food. 

I always get the kimchi ramen with shoyu. The broth is so good and easily one of the best broths I've ever tasted. The noodles seem fresh and the right consistency--how ramen is supposed to taste like.

I never tried any other dishes because I really like their kimchi ramen. I'm sure the rest of their dishes are just as fabulous, I don't doubt it. 

If you're an out-of-towner, my suggestion is to take BART and get off Powell station--it's about a 10 minute walk. Katana-ya is downtown and you will not find parking unless you want to spend a fortune in a parking garage, which won't be worth it.
author: K. E.

description:
sooo goooddddd

Best ramen ever!! I got Chasu Ramen (Soy Sauce base, medium spicy)

We had to wait a bit outside because it's a small cozy place, but it was definitely worth it. They also have pitchers of beer for a good price, so we all split one ramen each and then a pitcher of beer...yummmm
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description:
Katana-Ya to the rescue!  After a night of drinking too much wine at District and sangria at Mochica I was on the verge of puking my brains out.  Fortunately, Katana-Ya is open late for the after party crowd that migrate over from Slide and Ruby Skye.  Even though I wasn't able to eat all of my Chicken Karaage Miso Ramen, the light broth of my Miso soup kept me from hurling my Peruvian dinner.   

Katana-Ya is not only a late night spot, but it's a hot spot during the day as well.  Only a block away from Union Square, it's a great place to take a break from shopping or sightseeing.  We make our way to Katana-Ya anytime we're in the area.  The Chicken Karaage Miso Ramen is one of my favorites, but this is only one of the many dishes that make this place great.  They provide a nice portion of Cha-shu and the Ramen noodles are consistent...not quite firm and not too soft.  The great thing about Katana-Ya is they give you an option between rich or light broth.  If you're not a fan of Santa Ramen's thick broth, you will probably enjoy Katana-Ya's light broth...clean and delicious. 

Don't get me wrong...this place is really good, but if you're in a hurry you may want to skip this place.  Katana-Ya has an average wait of 10-15 minutes.  If you see people waiting outside in the cold that means you have a decent wait ahead of you.  It's worth the wait...and once you chow down on their Ramen....you'll be glad you waited.  Two thumbs up and a fist bump goes to Katana-Ya.
author: Brian S.

description:
I've been here countless times, and each time I am always bewildered at the location of the place. Amidst one of the most bustling and expensive area of San Francisco, a narrow and unpretentious ramen joint has fared better than most.

Ramen here is super, and there are plenty of reviews that discuss it in detail. I'd also note that the non-ramen dishes are solid too. I often get one of the rice bowls (usually oyakyo don) and also some different rolls. The sushi here is awesome - I never see that many people order it, but it might be some of the best sushi for the price in the city, and definitely for the area. If you're feeling aggressive, I'd split a sushi roll, order a small ramen and also get a rice bowl.

The main downside to the place is a) how popular it is and b) how crowded it gets. Don't think I've ever waited less than 20 minutes to sit down, regardless of what time of day I've been (even close to  midnight!). They do have takeout, though, which is not a bad outcome if you can track down a menu.
author: Nils H.

description: Tiny place, but solid ramen! Would not recommend parties larger than 4 at the absolute MAX.
author: Juliana C.

description: The only place I had dinner twice in my recent SF trip. Very small place but also very close by (Union square), good Miso Raman (salt is not as good). Sushi is all right, The down site is they don't take reservation and you will be waiting in the line if you have more than 2 people at night time. Also, they charge extra ($3) if you order the BBQ pork Ramam from the combo. Definitely will go back on my future trip.
author: Chris L.

description:
Most Ramen restaurants spotlight just their main course.  Ramen. Just that. Side dishes compliment the main course but everyone is there for the ramen.   

Then I opened the menu at Katana-Ya. Sweet mother.  Largest selection of food I've ever seen at a Ramen shop. Whether it's a good or bad thing to have so many choices depends on you.  I'm a libra.
