I have to analyze everything on the menu two maybe three times. You don't want to eat with someone like me with a menu that long.  

But the food I ordered. OH. so GOOD. 

Fried Baby Aji (my favorite appetizer here, it's these little fish about the size of your pinky)
Miso Katana-Ya Ramen (the one with everything in it!)
and a Salmon/Avocado roll (my delicious can't-go-wrong roll)

It's a great place to take people late at night when you're craving Japanese food in SF since they're open late! I'll say it again. OPEN LATE!  what japanese restaurant stays open that late?  not any i know that are as good as Katana-Ya.  It's a keeper for that reason alone.
author: Anita L.

description: Line wasn't too long.  Ramen dish was ok but what really disappointed me was the sushi, especially the Amaebi Sushi where the botan shrimp's head is suppose to be deep fried after it is lightly coated with potato starch.  It came "grilled" and tasted not even close.  They told me that the fryer was broken so I asked why they didn't tell me.  They tried to convince me grill is another style and as far as he was concerned, it properly represented Amaebi.  This argument went no where and I demanded an adjustment for the $6.50.  He took off fifty cents. - Will I go back? - never for sushi but the ramen is ok if you're stuck near the theatre.
author: Andrea K.

description:
I came here yesterday because I wanted to see what all the hype was about. I LOVE ramen so I was very excited to check it out. The place is a bit small so you can imagine the wait. We got lucky tho, we only waited 15 minutes. As soon as you step in you can smell all the yummy goodness that awaits us. There was a lot to chose from but I chose the deep fried chicken ramen and my boyfriend had the extra spicy ramen. The quality of the noodles was great and it was cooked to perfection BUT the soup killed it. It was very salty. I like that this place is close to union square but I definitely would go elsewhere to get my ramen fix. 

FYI-this place adds MSG to their broth.
author: Chinda P.

description:
Small spot, but definitely must try!  The ramen is good and not clumped up and the soup has substance.  I tried the bbq pork ramen, should've tried the special instead...I'll do that next time.  

+Fast service
+Good ramen
+Good sake choice also

*not recommended for groups more than 3-4
author: Alan L.

description: The ramen here is excellent.  Being used to places like Ippudo and Totto ramen in NYC, I often find it difficult to really enjoy a bowl of ramen.  Katana-ya however did not disappoint.  I thoroughly enjoyed their fried chicken ramen, but I must warn you to eat the fried chicken right away lest it get soggy.  I wouldn't say this is the best ramen I've ever had but it's a spot I'd definitely recommend.
author: Nick M.

description:
I love Ramen, so much I believe it to be proper to capitalize the 'R.' 

If you want a great bowl of steaming Ramen in the Down Town area go here! I have been on a week long hunt for a decent bowl of Ramen and with previous disappointments I went here with very low expectations. Oh boy Jeeeebus was it taaasssssty! I ordered the Beef Ramen with soy sauce broth and every slurpy slurp was just as tasty as the first, if not better. Although, I can say that the noodles weren't the noodles I was looking for, not that they were bad, but the broth made everything alllllright! 
What's great about this place is that custom ordered bowls of Ramen are highly encouraged! Awesome, no?! I've had the basic bowl of Ramen that proved worthy of several more visits to create my own tasty Ramen concoction.
author: Shar T.

description: I agree with other reviews here. Not exactly mind blowing ramen. The ramen was good but not out of this world. It's also somewhat distracting to have techno music played from the servers iPod at varying volumes thought your visit. I thin when I want my ramen fix and I'm in the area I will walk the extra few blocks for Ramen Underground on Kearny or Ajisen at Westfield Mall.
author: Phill R.

description: Not going to lie - the first time i went there I think I just ordered the wrong thing. I went again, by myself to take my time and enjoyed a beer with the katana ya ramen and had a much better experience. if you're a single waiting in line you shouldn't have a problem ( I waited about 5 minutes at 7PM on a friday night) and the service and food was great. if i have a craving, i know where to go.
author: laura f.

description: love this place! I've been so a lot of ramen place but this small hole in the wall place is still my fave! salt rich bbq pork ramen all the way!
author: Cherry S.

description:
So for Katana-Ya's 749th Review!!! I decided to deviate from the norm!
Everyone is like Mmmm the Ramen is soo good. Yummy Noodles..
Yummy Ramen. Soy Ramen, Yummy, Miso Ramen, Beef Ramen..mmm soo good.
Well...You know what...I came here...and did not get the Ramen....I said Neh to the Noodles in Delicious Hot Water.

Instead I tried to do something adventurous. I got the Chicken Teriyaki, with Rice with Miso Soup. BAAM!

The Chicken Teriyaki was Aight. The Miso Soup has definitely seen better days. And my rice was stickier than Velcro(If you don't like this analogy try BubbleGum).  In all, the Chicken Teriyaki Lunch Combo was A-OK. The lunch special also came with salad. Which is a couple of leaves topped with some yummy dressing/sauce. I wish they put more salad in their lunch combos. 

I recommend sticking with the Ramen. It seems like the previous 738 Reviews were onto something. I had a whiff of the Miso Ramen Soup, it smelled promising. I also had  the honor and luxury of sipping the Soy Ramen. I must say it was spicy, and it was good!!!!

Also, first impressions are a big thing in my book. The restaurant opened at 12:00PM. We arrived at 11:50AM. They made us stand outside for 10 minutes in the San Fransisco May Cold. Luckily Jack-in-the-Box was close by so we ended up avoiding frost bite by heating our fingers and noses there, while munching on Hot Fries. 

In all, the restaurant seems promising, maybe one day Ill come here and get the same thing that everyone else does!

Oh, and the restaurant smells like Fish.
author: Dmitry K.

description:
I always LOVE this place but never really have the time or patience to wait to eat since its such small place. I finally got lucky at 1am Friday night after seeing Aida and having a few drinks. We sat down immediately, and wanted to order everything on the menu. Katsu don was excellent, though a bit too "salty". Uni was yummy, sushi salad was very good. 
But I think we could do better ordering their ramen since that's what everyone else did. That will be on the top of my list when I come next time :)
author: T C.

description:
This was our first restaurant while visiting San Francisco from LA, and I can happily say, that our trip started off on the right foot!

I had their Deep Fried Chicken Ramen, which I thought was pretty good -- until I tried my wife's Tsukemen!  It was almost the same thing (aside from the broth on the side) at around $2 less!  Her miso broth was a little thicker than mine and I thought it had more flavor.  However, she thought it was on the salty side.

If this was what we were in for while visiting the city that's getting more recognized for it's vivacious eateries, I can't wait to see what else this place has to offer!
author: Mark D.

description:
I had the Ramen with deep fried chicken - amazing!

by far the best Ramen I've had in San Francisco!

Must try!
author: Sebastian Heinzelbecker H.

description: The gorgeous Asian male model looking concierge at Nikko recommended this place for ramen and he was right on. I had the Katana-ya ramen and it was delicious. The miso based soup was thick but not oily or greasy. The roast meat was tender, spicy dumplings spiced up the flavor, and the noodle was chewy and not overcooked. The waitress was patient and helpful (I was debating to get spicy or not). I was able to get seated right away at 6pm on a Wed night. By 7pm there was a crowd waiting outside. The next I went back for lunch with three colleagues, and they loved it as well. The only thing to be mindful is that the place is small, was barely able to accommodate our party of four. Not a place for large groups for sure.
author: Kitty S.

description:
Best ramen i have had so far! I live in LA and we have great food but I know i will be craving this place! The sashimi was not as good as the soup. Everyone around me had soup bowls for a reason...so i suggest a SOUP. Ramen was cooked perfectly. I ordered the Spicy miso(Med) and reg flavor....it was to die for!!! I did not drink but their Sake choices were amazing! 

-Ramen bowl and uni and roe bowl= $16 
-Hamachi sashimi $5
= $24.09

Not bad for stuffing myself! hehe! Enjoy!
author: Marlyn H.

description:
I was rawring for ramen all day long at the office. Unfortunately (and fortunately) I couldn't make it all the way to San Mateo for Santa Ramen so I used yelp and found Katana-Ya.

My coworkers and I headed over to Katana-Ya (let's call it K-Ya for short?) after work. Typically, a line out the door means good and promising things. The place was cramped but I guess it was cozy. We still got good conversation in and it didn't disrupt our meal. 

Sad to say this place was SO CLOSE to being my new mecca. They had 3 of my favorite things... ramen, sushi, AND shaved ice with condensed milk dessert. So, each of us ordered a big steaming bowl of ramen (even though it was sunny and 70 degrees out!). For a small appetizer we got tuna maki.

The sushi was a disappointment. Clearly this place is known for it's ramen. The tuna had bits of bone or cartilage in it and the rolls themselves were very small. Sad face.

Then came the ramen. Hot, steaming bowls of love (ew, that sounded wrong?). All 4 ramens were absolutely delicious, flavorful and filling. There was an interesting texture to the noodles but I really liked it. Super chewy and fat! More to love. The only downside is that I wish the menus stated what ingredients came with each bowl of ramen because I was hella coveting my coworker's bowl which had a little bit of everything. I mean HELLA coveting, almost to the point where I was just in her bowl eating with her. Anyway, before the slurp-fest began, we all tried a taste of each other's ramen choices. A little bit of this, a little bit of that. My favorite was probably the fried chicken ramen.

For dessert we ordered both shaved ice desserts. Both were good, maybe a little too sweet, but pretty damn good. I think this place is terrific and I would definitely go again. The only thing stopping me is knowing that there is indeed (dare I say it?) better ramen at Santa Ramen...
author: Michelle N.

description: great butterfish, toro, and sake nigiri. ramen is amazing too (they openly disclose they use MSG -- nonetheless still worth trying!)
author: vishal k.

description:
The best bowl of ramen in the Bay Area bar none. Its nothing fancy, just straight-forward, good-to-the-last slurp ramen.The place is totally unpretentious and the Japanese staff helpful and considerate. They aren't attempting to cater to some Asian fusion hipster crowd, just people who appreciate a decent bowl of ramen. 

I can't believe its taken me this long to find the place. It probably helps that I watched the movie Tampopo again last night which I hadn't seen for years. It reminded me as to the "right stuff" making up a good bowl of ramen. I'm not saying that Katana-ya is world class as Tampopo aspires to, but its about as good as it gets around here without taking the next plane to Narita.

They have a number of sushi rolls on the menu. It has nothing to do with authentic Japanese food and its just a distraction from making good ramen. As we say back in NJ, fogettabouttit!
author: David P.

description: Ramen and kim chee fried rice. Delicious!
author: Kathleen C.

description:
Ramen and everything in it is great! I would recommend getting the miso soup as the base rather than soy sauce if you like something a little lighter. 

I also got a couple of sushi rolls, the one with quail egg and a dragon roll, they were ok but there is probably better sushi out there. The main draw about this place is the ramen, especially on a cold windy day! 

The place is super small and there is no waiting space inside so be prepared to stand outside for a good 30 min or so.
author: Rona Y.

description:
There is nothing like a steaming bowl of kara-age ramen with shoyu broth on a cool and windy Saturday afternoon.

I sat at the counter by myself and slurped it all down with glee.
author: May T.

description:
There are some places that need just a dash of salt.  There are some experiences that should be taken with salt.  What the hell does that mean?  I don't know but I've got this salt shaker that I've been carrying around for decades and it never comes in handy.  Enough of this proverbial talk.

Previously, this place made me feel like Danielle Steele and her 8,000 pairs of shoes, living on her hilltop mansion looking down on all of us like the wicked witch.  Why did she have to write such a nail-biter as Zoya?  I am so ashamed that I read that book and LOVED it.  I loved it so much, I dated a Russian in college.  Worst idea ever.  Never date a species just because you like the way they are portrayed in trashy bodice-rippers.

Today, Lou and I managed to make it here for lunch.  Wow.  Lunch menu.  It looks different!  And it tasted different too.  Lou would definitely say it was not what he remembered.

On the special board behind Lou's giant head, one of the items was tsubugai (welk clam).  We nearly ordered that.  Maybe we should have since the entrees were so "different."  That's a nice way of saying: What the hell is this? 

The ramen came out in the usual giant bowl.  I specifically asked for it to not have too much salt or sodium.  If I wanted to go blind from dehydration and fat, I would eat at Chipotle.  The noodles were not as good a texture.  I don't think the water was hot enough.  The soup was SO SALTY.  And the tofu chunks were few.  But the broth still had that nice flavor....but different.

Ok, it was kind of suck.  Kind of suck no good.  I'd like to think that in this tough economic desert, everyone needs to cut the fat.  But if that was the case, why am I eating out?  What the hell happened to this place?  Was it because we came at 3pm and it was the "dead zone" of the day?  That is no excuse for mediocrity!  I could have gone down the street and purchased a whole serving of fried mozzarella balls!  But I didn't.  I gave Katana-ya a chance.  And now, I want my fried, salty, greasy balls.  

At least the leftovers will make a tasty tasty 2 meals.  There was enough noodle left over for 1 meal.  And enough broth to think out for 2.  Because of the concentration of the soup, I will give this place 3 stars.  

But seriously, whoever is out there reading this:  the quality of food has to remain high if people are going to justify eating out in such a bear economy.  If I wanted something I could make at home....I'd eat at home.
author: Christina C.

description:
This place is generally packed but if you want something warm like ramen it's worth the wait. I had the Deep Fried Chicken ramen which is basically a japanese karage dumped into a ramen. 

The ramen was pretty decent. If you really like warm food or the sensation of right out of the pan or pot this is the place. 

For hefty eaters I'd recommend getting the combo which might come with a donburi or some sort of roll.
author: Miichiko S.

description: Tiny restaurant just off Union Sq, was packed when I got there had to queue 20mins to get a seat, was it worth the wait....not really, had soft shell crap(soggy) & Ramen with pork & miso soup which was average & very salty. I could probably rustle up instant ramen with some left-overs in the fridge & it would be similar quality, albeit much cheaper than the $22 for these two dishes!
author: Gar Wing L.

description: What was I thinking when I wrote the last review? Sorry. This place is overrated and overpriced. Ramen should blow your mind, or at least warm your heart. Here, the broth is nothing to write home about. No distinctive flavor. And it's not a bargain. And it's overhyped. And you have to wait a whole lot. Don't go. Go to Osha. Go to Lahore. Go to Golden Era. Don't waste your time and money on this subpar place.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Late night with the group and they wanted ramen. I've been on an Asian food kick lately... Anyways, this place is small and crowded. Upon arrival, you sign your name on the clipboard outside (EVERYONE MUST BE PRESENT) and you just wait outside b/c there's no seating inside. 

Butter Corn Ramen- is my go to comfort food. Delish. I didn't know I had to order the egg as a add on. Definitely didn't pay attention. All in all...good meal.
author: Lola D.

description:
YAAAYYYY!! This is some good, heart-warming ramen. =)

The weather was cold (even though it was June. Stupid Bay area "summer"). We were hungry. We wanted ramen. And boy, did we get ramen. We got some goooood ramen.

Hot, comforting, soul-soothing ramen that makes you feel happy and at peace... That's what good ramen is. We got the Spicy Miso and the Shoyu - both were EXCELLENT.
We left the unassuming hole-in-the-wall treasure trove that is Katana-ya feeling very happy, very full, very satisfied, and warmed up enough to brace the cold winds of San Francisco "summer." 

Gosh, I love me some good ramen.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
After twice being thwarted by the long line, I finally got to try Katana-Ya on a Tuesday night. This place has the atmosphere of a dive bar complete with neon lights. Ambiance aside, they serve a satisfying bowl of ramen. I ordered the spicy green onion ramen with soy broth and medium heat. Most times I order medium spicy and it barely tingles my tongue - not here. The broth had the right amount of heat - the kind that doesn't embolden me to think that I could take more but doesn't scorch my taste buds (i.e. Goldilocks's hot). 

The accompaniments were the standard seaweed and bamboo shoots and a slice of dull roasted pork. I think that Momofuku spoiled me for slices of pork and boiled eggs in ramen. 

I would definitely head back to try the other types of ramen if the line isn't insane.
author: Monica L.

description:
BEST RAMEN IN SAN FRANCISCO! 
Katana-Ya kicks Santa Ramen (San Mateo, CA) in the A$$!!
This one guy in line feverishly stated (with a ninja-like tone)..."Katana...YA!!!!!!!!!!!!" 
I rolled my eyes and labeled him dumb.

3 reasons why Katana-Ya's ramen is better than Santa Ramen's ramen:
1) They give you more ramen.
2) The soup the ramen sits in is not salty as hell.
3) San Franciscans don't have to travel 30 mins south to get it.

I like Santa Ramen's idea of adding whatever you want to your bowl of ramen, but seriously, it can add up -- sometimes even to a $15 bowl of ramen!! GROSS! Katana-ya keeps it simple and already has bowls of ramen put together. You can make it spicy for $1. That's the only way you can specialize it. I think if you do any subsitutions to your ramen at Katana-Ya, they charge you a substitution fee since their kitchen is so small.

I had their corn butter ramen and was thinking I would get buttered corn with my ramen. I was so grossed out to find a chunk of butter floating in my soup, slowly melting away. I didn't get buttered corn -- I got corn AND butter. I quickly and swiftly scooped out the butter. Ew. 

I'm taking off a star for Katana-Ya because:
1) Parking SUCKS since it's right in Union Square.
2) Very small location, only accommodating up to say 20 people.
3) I had to be cautious everytime I would try and eat because the waitresses/waiters don't care if they bump into your elbow. This place is tiny so come here if you're not claustrophobic!
4) No reservation system. Just put your name and party size down on a list and literally WAIT.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Did you notice the "Whitesnake" autograph above the register?  Haha!   This place has a cult-like following.

There was a crowd outside on Friday night and I asked a person, "What's going on?  Is this place good?"   She rolled her eyes and said, "Is the sky blue?"  (DUH was implied).   I asked what they served, and with another eye roll, "RAMEN!"

So, the next day at 4:30 pm when there was no line, hubby and I came to see what the fuss was about.

This is a tiny place!  20 seats + a few at the bar.  

I ordered the house miso ramen- fried chicken topped + gyoza.   It was very good.  Not quite sure it was "I would wait an hour in line" good, but definitely hit the spot on the windy, chilly spring day.

Hubby ordered a huge fried chicken bowl with curry sauce.  Asian comfort food at its best.   

What else can I say?   If it's good enough for White Snake....
author: E T.

description:
After being told that this was a top restaurant in the Union Square area, I was  disappointed with this restaurant.  The restaurant is very small so we had to wait outside (and that is not my issue).  While waiting outside, I noticed it's many awards displayed on the window.  This restaurant is so not comparable to the good Japanese restaurants in Vancouver, not even to some of the mediocre ones!  The edamame beans were cold, the miso soup was not so good.  The sushi was nothing special.  We were told by the waitress that their salmon is farmed not wild.  If this is one of the best places to eat sushi in San Francisco, I will probably just pass on sushi all-together on my next trip to the beautiful city.
Oh, and the bathroom needs some help.
author: Krystina E.

description:
I have been to some good ramen places in Mountain View (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ramen-house-ryowa-mountain-view#query:ramen) 

, Santa Clara (Orenchi)  and San Diego. This one is one of the best! 

Cons: Small place, somewhat squished. But hey its SF it just adds to the charm.

Pros: Good ass ramen. Word

What more could you want. Give  this place a try. It's delicious.
author: AL P.

description: Pretty good ramen, a tad pricey, tends to be crowded.
author: Michael E.

description: Claustrophobically small. The MSG put me in a coma for three hours afterward. Not even a gallon of water could revive me. They warn you on the menu, but I was like how bad could it be? So bad I had to leave my friends before we could shop and go home to nap and sip on pedialyte to restore electrolytes to my system. The sushi was good though.
author: Timoteo K.

description: Was in town visiting some friends, and we stopped in on a Thursday.  We had to wait in line for a looooooooong time, but it was worth it.  I ordered the Katana-ya Ramen  and it had a lot going on.  The noodles were a bit firm, which was good, and there was a lot of vegetables and meat in the bowl.  And that broth!  Definitely worth the wait.
author: Michael C.

description:
Ok, sooo i maybe bashed this place a lil hard.. but i still dont think its that great.

However, I've been back once since the previous review and i have a lil more to say..

Dominus Ramenus Points:
+ open into the wee hours of the night... great after a bar night, or late night movie
+ katana-ya ramen (the big one) has a LOT of stuff in it.. which adds to variety, but overall ramen taste is still lacking

- katana-ya ramen is very costly ($12).  you cannot replace mediocre ramen with generous toppings.  I see through your tricks.
author: Dominus S.

description: "Vegetarians go nuts for this spot!" I think not, Yelp. Every time I come here, the rude wait staff screws up my order and proceeds to make ME feel bad for it, even after offering to pay for their mistake. The food is good but it doesn't matter since you will likely NOT receive what you ordered, if your food even comes at all. Their ignorantly offensive waitstaff coupled with the always ridiculous wait is a no-go. Skip this place and go literally ANYWHERE else if you value your sanity.
author: Dylan P.

description:
This place is OK.

I came here this past Sunday with my friend Nicole. This place had good reviews and it also made the "oodles for noodles" as 1 of the top 5 ramen places in the US according Maxim Magazine. 

I am not sure if it's the HYPE or the MSG that's in the soup (they state it on the menu) but I thought my spicy tofu ramen is just okay. It was definitely yummy but not anything special. I also did not see any ramen on the menu that I was DYING to try. All the choices seem on par with what most of the other ramen places I've been to would offer.

This place gets busy though. We were there 10 minutes before they opened for lunch on Sunday and there was already a line of people waiting outside.

If I were to visit SF again, which I am sure I will in the near future, I won't mind eating here again because the food is decent, but I would not call it one of the top 5 ramen houses in the nation. It's far from it.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I'd been here once before but left disappointed, maybe due to the Yelp hype, I don't know. Decided to give them another try and had a much better time this time around. It seems they've extended their menu a bit! Took me eons to decide what I wanted but simply settled on the regular ramen with a soy sauce base since the whole point of going to a ramen house is for their ramen...But anywho.. The last time I came here I got the miso broth which turned out not to be the best choice and not as flavorful as I had hoped. The noodles were a lot better this time as well! Last time they were clumped into one blob and it was hard to eat since they were't falling apart as they should've. 

I'm definitely gonna come back again to try the new expanded menu. And apparently afternoons around 2 on a weekday is the best time to go without the infamous wait! 45 minutes is such a hunger killer.
author: Jen L.

description:
This is probably the first time I've been completely underwhelmed by a 4-star yelp rated place. This is a tiny place but it's relatively convenient due to its proximity to Union Square. Arrived here 5ish so there was no wait although we had to get seats at the sushi bar.

~ Salmon Sashimi was good as the fish tasted fresh and almost melted in my mouth. 
~ Had the salt broth regular ramen as this is the easiest way to benchmark the quality of the ramen with other ramen shops. DISAPPOINTED! Broth was "rich" so a little thicker than the broth in other ramen places. No problems with this but it was bland and didn't have the deep flavor you get from having boiled pig carcass for hours - see Santouka in Saratoga and Santa in San Mateo for a detailed explanation. 
~ Single slice of Chashu that was ok tasting but somewhat thinly sliced.
~ Broth had a thick layer of grease which didn't add to the taste.
~ Only other upside as far as the ramen goes is that the noodles are not overly salty (I'm looking at you Santa).
~ No complaints about service.

I would've given them 2 stars really but the sashimi earned them the extra star. Haven't tried the sushi but based on the ramen alone, not worth the trip unless you're in the neighborhood shopping for new threads and you have ramen on the brain.
author: Norman S.

description:
This place is good for ramen. I always get regular ramen with soy sauce broth.  Last visited it was yesterday, we had lunch and ordered the lunch combo which i got regular ramen with soy sauce broth and a small bowl of kimchi fried rice. It was good as usual.

This place is quite small, so it might not be good if coming as a big group. Service is ok.
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
I'm not sure if this is the BEST ramen joint in San Francisco, but it's definitely near the top of my list.  Oh wait, I don't have a list.  Well, if I ever started compiling a list of my BEST ramen joints in San Francisco, this would be near the top of my nonexistent list.

I found this place on Yelp so suggested we eat here.  A and I headed downtown and walked around looking for it.  And it turns out it's right near Jack in the Box and Colibri!  I have never ever ever noticed this place.  Anyway, we went in and it's quite small inside with maybe eight tables.  We were seated right away since it was probably only a little after opening on a Saturday.  But, there was quite a wait outside when we left.  Sign your name on the list and wait to be called.

I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen with miso broth.  It includes chicken karaage, deep friend gyoza, pork, green onions, butter corn, and bamboo shoots.  I do not like gyoza.  I do not like them, Sam I Am.  So I gave them to A because he likes gyoza.  He said they were uber-tasty.  I liked the ramen noodles.  They tasted just right - not soggy and not super chewy.  The proportion was just right.  It looked like it would be too much, but it wasn't!

I don't know if I'd journey downtown just to have ramen, but if I were in the area doing some shopping or something and wanted some ramen, this would be the place to be!
author: Kris L.

description:
Katana-Ya is a small, unassuming spot on Geary. it's kind of dark inside...gives it an intimate feeling.

Service was mixed. Once it was very efficient and quick, the second time it was lackadaisical. Which was weird cause I went on the same day of the week and the same two servers were working both times.

They have super tasty chasu ramen. This is what we go here for. This is what you should come here for. I've also had their tuna poki which was good, as well as their sushi combo, which was also good but pretty standard fare (no complaints about that!). But if you come here, get the ramen. Really.

Now, if they were only open superlate, I'd be all set. Alas, no ramen for me after a night out on the town....
author: Tiffany L.

description:
What do you do when you find yourself shivering in your drafty San Francisco apartment and realize you're a) too lazy to go to the grocery store to buy food and b) too lazy to cook that food after schlepping it all the way home? Warm up with a hot bowl of ramen from katana-ya - No grocery shopping, schlepping or cooking required!

After waiting a few minutes for a table to open up my bf and I were seated at a small table by the door. It was a little chilly since they kept opening the door to call names off the waitlist but once my soup arrived all was well in the world. I got the spicy cabbage ramen in miso broth which was good but lacking in terms of quantity of cabbage and pork. My boyfriend got some variation of ramen in miso broth and his was good as well but once again...not too much meat to be found. Next time I come I'll definitely ask for extra meat. I think katana-ya has four star potential so I'll be back with an update soon! 

Don't be scared off by the line outside - it tends to move pretty fast!
author: Amanda R.

description: The ramen here is pretty cracking! or that I'm really drunk.. Only ramen spot i know that is open till 2am..
author: Christopher L.

description:
I'm a whore for udon. I'll sell most of anything I own for that broth I fill to the brim with spicy deliciousness, the wakame, those noodles that are thick and delicious. So when I see a menu half filled with udon and ramen itself, I'm set for life. 

Usually most udon noodle places are great for udon and bad for sushi, or vice versa, but Katana-Ya, tucked in across the street from the Clift Hotel on Geary has quite a bit to offer in both categories. 

Nestling into the corner during a busy dowtown lunch break, the boys and I ordered from the quick attentive waitress, and were fed in mere minutes. Cold ramen with kim chee and tamago. Fresh cold tofu and delicious little pieces of tempura batter was delicately placed on the fragrant noodles. Even the side salad in the corner of the bowl had a light and flavorful dressing on it and wasn't soggy, or overdressed which is one of my biggest pet peeves.

It's tiny, so be prepared for a possible wait, but the turnover is quick, as most lunching there need to eat and run. It's a great place to people watch, and I heard very little English in there, besides the three of us speaking, which is always a good sign to me when in an Asian restaurant of any kind.  

A perfect pit stop, it was ridiculously cheap, being that the bill was 25 bucks for us to munch a healthy quick lunch. I'm sold, so whenever I'm visiting my crew either at Neimans or the Clift, I know where to pop my head in and feed the machine, pre or post shopping.......cause ya'll know shopping for Blahniks conjures up quite an appetite.
author: Danielle S.

description:
i'm too nice, they're more like a 3.5 but i'll just give them 4 stars.

I came here because my friend said it was reallly really good here, and since i love ramen...i said suree why not.

I got the ramen with everything....forgot the name....had potsticker thingy in it, fried chicken like things...pork...yum lots of meat so i was happy. the noodle was the perfect kind of chewy! the soup though...was prettyy thick....has flavor...but iono, i think i'd prefer a more refreshing flavor...not tooo thick....we also got a roll....but we were too full from the ramen to even really eat it...but i tried one...it was okay...
the pricing is kind of steep for ramen....9 bucks?! ehhh, parking isn't easy! but after a full meal, and you feel like walking around.....the shopping mall is just a few blocks away! yay! maybe i'd come here to try another flavor one day...but for now i think i'm good off ramen.
author: Christine M.

description:
4 stars for the ramen.  I think enough has been said as to why Katana-Ya is so great.  Why the extra star?  TORO nigiri for less than $6?!?!
SOLD.
author: Mare C.

description: This place had potential, and the crispy chicken was good. After a fairly long wait, we sat down excited about our upcoming ramen experience. I could have used a little more guidance on the broths..I ordered the salt broth...spicy. It was too salty, and not very spicy. My husband ordered the regular salt broth, and it was pretty bad. Smelled weird, like the monkey house.Maybe its the salt broth? I think that the other broths would have been more our speed. The toppings, and noodles were great, but I'm thinking we will stick with our local Saiwaii's spicy tonkatsu.
author: Gwenn G.

description:
The ramen here is crave-worthy. My favorite broth here is bursting with strong flavors of miso and pork. My favorite is the butter corn! It's a little artery-clogging to see the piece of butter floating on top.. but I guess it's to bring out the flavor for the soft but crunchy kernels of corn. They have great sides in the ramen too.

However, there are two downsides, so that brings the rating down to a 4, sorry I've lost some of my love for this place over 4-5 visits. 
1) The service is excruciatingly slow. The place is tiny and cramped, so the wait is usually over 20 minutes. Painful when you're craving hot, delicious ramen!
2) The prices are high. A bowl fills you up, but it's pretty pricey. And the other menu options (sushi) are priced really high for a ridiculously small amount of sushi, say 8 pieces for $15. 

Still, it's definitely one of my favorite ramen places in the states.
author: Cathy S.

description:
This place has preeety good ramen. I like the variety and how you get so many choices with your soup. There's soy sauce, miso, and salt. Following that you can choose it to be light or rich. I had the deep fried chicken ramen with rich soy sauce. It was full of flavor, hot, and the ramen was nice and chewy. The sushi there is pretty good too.

One thing I didn't like though was how cramped it was in there. But it's San Francisco. What do you expect.
author: Megan C.

description:
A tear rolled down my eye when I had the Beef sukyaki and the ramen in Miso soup.
Service is good, place is a little small... but the quality of the food makes it up!
author: Christian P.

description:
The ramen isn't as good as everyone raves, I've had better according to my taste buds. I had the takeout ramen once, it wasn't bad but I got one piece of pork, what kind of bullshit is that, its not like a huge piece, it was a small ass one.

Service is cool, and its open till 1 am on weekdays so that's pretty cool. 
Theres nothing that special according to me.

Try Maijaku Ramen in Daly City or that one place in San Mateo I can't remember the name right now.
author: Steven C.

description:
4 star for food
-1 star for price

I came here because I was hungry in downtown and the place was on the 7x7 list. Honestly, I don't know what the hype is about this place. The ramen, udon, and soba weren't spectacular. Tasted about the same as the stuff I've had at a lot of other places. The regular ramen was $8.50 and it had 2 slices of pork. I felt really gypped when I left the restaurant. I guess the lunch specials are okay in terms of downtown prices. But I don't think this place should be on the 7x7 Big Eats list.

And this place is totally a hole in the wall. Don't come with more than 2 other people. Even on a table for four, you'll have trouble find space to put food down for three. If you really want ramen plus some sightseeing/random gift shopping, you might as well jump on the 38 or 38L and go to Japantown.
author: Lucy D.

description:
After reading all of these reviews, I decided to try this place.  I was expecting mouth-watering, over-the-top ramen.  It wasn't what I was expecting with all of the hype.  But, the broth was pretty good (not spectacular) and comes with your regular ramen toppings.  I'm not a big meat eater, but it would have been nice to have another piece of pork and maybe a hard-boiled egg.  The serving size is ok, nothing too big to make your belly on the brink of explosion, or too small to ask the server for a second-look at the menu.  I most likely wouldn't travel all the way to SF to eat here, unless if I was in the area and was craving noodles.  

A-OK for me, no more, no less.
author: Dennis L.

description: For a ramen place in San Francisco, Katana-Ya hits the spot. The wait is kind of so-so but they have pretty good lunch and dinner deals. The Katana-Ya ramen with the medium spice miso with the side is great on a cold San Francisco night, however, the space itself is quite cramped and you can't help but feel rushed when you have other patrons outside waiting to be seated. All in all, a decent dining experience.
author: Mirabella C.

description:
This review would have been much better except for the fact that all the noodles here have MSG in them.  I hadn't read any reviews about them that say that they use MSG, so I wanted to let everyone know. 

The noodles were good... I had the regular ramen, but substituted Udon noodles with miso broth and requested it medium spicy.  I liked it, a little on the salty side... but all in all they were good on a cold night.  I don't think this place is really worth all the hype on Yelp though and there have to be other noodle places in the city that are better, and without MSG!!
author: Jen F.

description:
This place is about a 3.5 star.  When you are looking for ramen there is probably no better place to look than here.  The only downside is that its reallllly small and if you come during the rush youre gonna be waiting a very long time.

Kimchi ramen with miso sauce and you cant go wrong.  It's a little pricey for ramen IMO.  Im too spoiled by the costco kimchi ramen.
author: Paran Y.

description:
Until I get myself to Japan, I'm just another clueless North American eating Japanese food. 

Having spent some time sampling ramen in NYC though, Momofuku and Ippudo I believe do it well. Katana-Ya was conveniently located, so I stopped in. 

Great lunch combo; a regular ramen (your choice miso,soy, other) and a choice of something like an unagi don or sushi roll for 11-13 bucks. 

The ramen are chewy and substantial, not bad, the soup base is thick and flavorful, surprisingly good. Cramped, small restaurant base but the ramen is definitely something to write home about. 

Good to see SF gets the chance to experience some quality ramen. Once the weather gets more chilly, even better to stand over a steaming bowl of quality ramen.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Katana - Ya has slipped since it became popular.
Someone on here wrote that this is the best ramen in California. This is at best a good place to satisfy a ramen craving when shopping downtown.

The miso broth is good. The pork is fairly flavorful. I'm not crazy about their noodles. They seemed to stick to each other in parts much like if they were over cooked or something. The egg is hard boiled which I think breaks some sort of ramen code of ethics. I'd go here over Ajisen Ramen in the mall (which isn't saying much) but if I can make it to Underground, ken ken or even to one of the better places down in the South Bay, I'd skip Katana Ya, especially in the evenings when the wait gets long here with tourists.
author: Mark R.

description:
Maybe I just don't know anything about ramen. Everyone else in the restaurant seemed to love it. 

I ordered the Katanya ramen, with miso flavor, medium spicy. It was just OK. I only finished half of it (huge bowl). I also ordered some edamame to munch on and it was really tasteless and cold. Meh.

But! On the bright side, the Japanese guy on the Seattle Mariners was sitting a couple tables away! Cool beans. I guess the 20-minute wait was kind of worth it. Not really.
author: Han C.

description: Wished they would be more friendly to take out orders. The staff kept on kick us out of the place...I get it's a small place but please ask vs yell. Plus by the time they notice the food sitting on the counter our noodles were completely soaked and inedible when we were home. They  should hv separatedthe broth like other places. Our agedashi tofu had no sauce.just not the same with sauce..ugh.
author: Ken L.

description: LOVE this place, I go here EVERY time I'm in town!  Spicy green onion ramen is my suggestion. Their sushi is pretty amazing too!
author: Ross B.

description:
I eat a lot of ramen and I am a fan of this place. Definitely try the karage chicken with miso ramen and ask for the chicken on the side (it gets soggy). The broth was rich and the noodles were chewy. The wait can be long because the restaurant is small and do not come with large groups because they cannot accommodate. 
I love ramen on a cold San Francisco day =)
author: Shirley W.

description:
i walk by this place everyday on my way to and from work and have always noticed the large crowd of people waiting to be seated around dinner time. i wanted to see what all the hype was all about so my buddies and i decided to give it a whirl.

the food comes out very quickly and it's reasonably priced. i really appreciate how you can get udon noodles as opposed to the standard ramen noodles!

on a chilly san francisco day, it definitely hits the spot.
author: Jae C.

description:
Trying Ramen round 2 and score! The Ramen here was by far much better than the last place I went to. They Ramen with the fried chicken and a bunch of other stuff was delicious. The broth had a brighter flavor than my previous experience and the ingredients were much more fresh. I'd definitely go back again.

The only drawback to this place is that it's small and its pretty popular but that is to be expected since the quality is there.
author: Hyung L.

description:
Decided on giving this place a try after reading some reviews on yelp, I liked the miso soup although it wasn't the best I've had. 
All of a sudden my friend starts saying "OMG OMG DO YOU SEE IT? " 
I looked over and a COCKROACH was crawling up the side of the wall  that was literally against our table!!! It was WAY to close to us and our food, the place is tiny and the table we sat at was miniature.
This place might want to have the place bombed for pest! 
Overall the COCKROACH made it a very unpleasant experience. 
Sanitary precautions need to be put into effect immediately. With that said we WILL NOT be going back!
author: Veronica C.

description:
Och, the ramen! O tempura! O mores!

Get the katanaya ramen. Alternatively, the spicy tofu. Eat it. Be happy.
author: Peter B.

description:
Maybe I'll come back soon and give it five stars... but at least I know I'm definitely coming back. A lot.

Had the butter corn miso ramen, a spicy tuna handroll and that fish and cheese appetizer. The ramen was the best I've had in the bay area, my tuna handroll did not dissapoint and that fish and cheese thingy was pretty tasty. I inhaled everything. 

I was really jealous of my gf's fried chicken ramen. I'm getting that next time.
author: Brian S.

description:
I've been here once a few years ago and I was there during one of the hottest summer days in SF for some odd reason.  A group of us guys came here after a hard night of partying and saw this place, given its location and our stomach was growling, we decided to try here.  This is the place I first tried Hiyashi chuka.  Man I was blown away!   I would make an effort to come out here if i'm in the Union Sq area. 

Only other fix I can get for Hiyashi chuka is at Mitsuiwa in San Jose.   I haven't seen this dish served anywhere else.
author: Grant L.

description: The minute we drove into San Fran we went straight to this cramped, microscopic eatery for lunch right when they opened.  The ramen was hearty, filling, and very flavorful.  The Katana-Ya bowl flavorful with soy was delicious and filled with little bits of everything, from seaweed, boiled egg, pork belly, fried chicken (tasted just like what you can find in Japan) and gyoza (something in it tasted off, almost very vile).  The prices were very reasonable, and they were even more reasonable if you get the combos, which included a standard ramen bowl and a side dish.  If I'm in town again I'll hit this place up just to have another bowl and hopefully try everything else here.
author: Enigmajic O.

description: Yummy ramen and sushi!  Expect a 15-30 min wait though. (It's worth it!). I recommend a miso base if you're unsure. The combo with spicy tuna or spicy BBQ pork don is a must.
author: Danielle P.

description:
I do enjoy going to this place. I'm not the biggest fan of ramen but it's good when you're hungry. I do like their deep friend chicken ramen with the miso soup as the broth.

It's quite small so there's not much space to sit down and since this place is such a popular place to eat it seems to be frequently busy and packed. I recommend going for a lunch date rather than doing a dinner and especially avoid later in the night when the party crowd starts coming out of the woodwork.

I guess after tasting actual Japanese ramen while visiting Sapporo, this place sort of is just meh. I do recommend this place for people who want a good bite to eat if they're ever in Union Square.
author: Simon L.

description:
The menu is terrific. I just wish their food was.

Okay. If you're looking to eat sushi, this is probably not the place. Keep in my mind, this is a ramen joint. I ordered spicy tuna rolls as my combo dish with my ramen and it was nothing spectacular. The rolls seemed like they sat around until someone ordered them. They were obviously pre-made and not fresh off the sushi chefs hands. The ramen, however, was decent. 

Unfortunately for vegetarians, they charge an extra $3 bucks for the veggie broth since they have to cook it separately from the meat broth. Oh, you vegetarians are a pain in the ass!

Not sure I'd come here again. But if I do, I won't be ordering any sushi.
author: Mary Anne R.

description:
Who would have thought the go-to college dorm room meal would end up being so tasty?

It's a couple of blocks down the street from where I work, so I go here from time to time with co-workers. So many options that it's hard to choose from. It's perfect for those typical, nice, cold, San Francisco days. 

It's a little small, thus, if you go here during the busy times, you're looking at a good 15-20 minute wait. The service is pretty fast though, so in a sense, makes up for it. 

Aside from my way too-easy joke at the beginning of this review, don't think this is your typical cup-o-noodles spot. It's way better. Trust me.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
Look no further- this is the place to come to when you need to satiate a (late-night) craving for hot, hearty Japanese goodness found in these noodles. 

I've only had the namesake ramen and I'm ok with sticking to that. 

My only gripe is that I wish it stayed open later. Closing at 1am may sound sufficient to some but give the late night bar hoppers a chance to have one last drink before slurping up the deliciousness from a bowl of your ramen. The city of San Francisco will thank you.
author: Christina C.

description:
The best ramen I have had in the city proper. I admit Ramen Underground is also solid but after someone told me their broth was on the salty side I started to agree. After two years of passing by Katanaya on the 38, one drunken attempt to eat there but discouraged after an incredibly long line, I finally decided to try my luck again on a Thursday evening after work this past week. To my surprise, at 6pm it is virtually empty but by 6:30 it was starting to fill up but we still didn't have to wait for a table (I did, however, have to wait for my party to get there). 

We sat down. Ordered the Katanaya ramen which is a combination of every topping possible. Great choice when indecisive. The fried dumpling, chashu, pork and egg are wonderful! What's even more awesome is that they allow you to choose density of broth -- light or regular. What??? Awesome. You also choose between miso, soy sauce or salt broth. I had light density miso.

When the food came out in its monstrous bowl, I tried the broth first. Solid and good enough to drink the whole bowl. The ramen itself was a good texture and properly cooked as well. It's a big bowl and a lot of food for $12. I couldn't finish everything.

The only random thing I must mention is that I actually felt legitimately drunk on my way home, sans any alcohol. I must have had the worst case of food coma because I passed out solid on my way home and could not get up for the life of me. Damn you, MSG. Lol.

I've decided I will only come back when I don't have to wait. Glad I finally came!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
What is so incredible is that this place has been reviewed over 1000 times and it seriously fits like five people inside at a time.  

I went to the opera for my very first time, and afterwards when asked to suggest a place to eat, I said lets get Ramen.  In our dressed up outfits and opera like attitude we went in the search for a hole in the wall ramen place.  

You see, I had watched Ramen girl a few days prior and suddenly had a huge craving for Ramen.  I wanted to see the whole world in a bowl the way they movie explains Ramen to be.  Now this is Brittany Murphy so I understand her Ramen expertise may be questionable, but I believed everything she said in that movie.

So we went to Katana ya because other yelpers suggested that this place is one of the best.  WIth the full restaurant and many bowls of ramen on each of the tables it seemed authentic in the very superficial way I assess these types of things.

After being a little overwhelmed by the complexity of the menu we finally ordered.  You have to choose from a scale of fattyness and choose the filling and choose the broth.  I was not expecting that because that is not how things worked in Ramen girl.

It was a little fatty but really tasty.  I can't imagine anyone can finish that bowl.  We ordered some sushi on the side and we were glad that we did. 

Only word of caution, this place is so small and always crowded.  Get there early, before you are hungry, and by the time you get a table you will be ready to eat.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
I love noodles.
I love broth.
I love spicy.
I love ramen.

Levels beyond packaged noodels with just-add-water broth powder.  Katana-Ya is the place to go for ramen or udon. 

Next time I'll ask for extra spicy and get the nose juices flowin'.
author: Jay H.

description:
I had very high expectations going in since reviews were pretty high and a Japanese person told me alot of Japanese people like this place.  I was disappointed at how average it was.

I was turned off by the fact that it said there was MSG in it, right on the menu.  I guess it's good that they're honest about it, but then it makes me think why do you need MSG if your ingredients were good.  I'm sure alot of restaurants have MSG but they just don't tell you. 

So putting that aside, I went with the regular ramen and asked the waitress which flavor she recommended.  She recommended the miso, which I thought was too salty.  The soup didn't have the rich pork taste in it like I would expect.  I've had ramen in Japan and this was not even close in comparison.  And I'm confused with the 3 flavors - salt, soy sauce, miso.  Where's the regular pork flavored broth?   The bowl cost about $10 too which seems very pricey for just a regular bowl of ramen.

I would definitely not go out of my way again to come here.  Even if I was craving for ramen that day and I'm in the area, I probably would drive to Japantown and go to Suzu or Tanpopo instead.
author: Irene C.

description: This was my first ramen experience and although i liked it, i would also try it in other restaurants. I got the Fried chicken ramen and KayanaYa ramen, both were great but not a whole lot of flavor on them. The wait can get long outside since they have limited seating and if you stick your elbows too far you'll hit one of the waiters while you're seated. Great for a quick meal and the experience.
author: favio p.

description:
i'm from tokyo japan and if this place was in japan, it would go out of business in a month. i came here as many people have good reviews and tried ramen with pork. noodle taste like a rubber band and the pork was nothing similar to what they serve in a ramen place in japan. i've even felt this place just is taking an advantage of the market abroad as normal good ramen taste is not acquired abroad. soup was very very boring. i do not like writing bad reviews abt places but this is not a ramen place. 
it came to my wife's profile for some reason. i'm her husband from japan.
author: anne o.

description:
& The staffs are helpful.
& The dishes I tried (ramen among others) are good. 
& I'd like the portion to be bigger, but it's understandable that everything costs more in the heart of the city.
author: Francisco S.

description:
We spent 4th of July weekend in San Francisco, and if you know anything about their summer - know that it's freezing up there.  My friend recommended this place, and it was quite the cure for the frigid temperature we sat through waiting for the fireworks display to go off at the cannery.

Everyone's right about the wait - it was long ... but so worth it.  (It really is a dine it and get out kind of place.)  I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen and oh boy - it was yummy!  I unashamedly scarfed my bowl down.  I told my husband it was 'cause it was so cold outside waiting for a table that it made my hunger level rise to extreme heights.  The fried chicken that they put in their ramen is probably the best fried chicken that I have ever tasted.  I don't know what they put in it, but it was just so good.

This place is a must for anyone visiting San Francisco.
author: Allison Mae C.

description: I ate here while visiting from LA. I ordered the salt ramen with extra pork. A good ramen is supposed to have a thick, milky broth after stewing in pork bits overnight. The pork slices are supposed to be ultra tender. The ingredients should all combine into a porky goodness. The broth here, however, is thin with little flavor. The pork strips are tough.   This is well short of the standard ramen haunts in LA (never mind NYC or Japan). It also costs more as well. If you're looking for great or even mediocre ramen, this ain't it.
author: Ryan O.

description:
Ever since I watched the spicy ramen episode of Man v. Food, I've been craving a bowl of noodles that would leave a ring of red oil around my upper lip and cause profuse sweating. 

Enter Extra Spicy Ramen from Katana-Ya.

Didn't  disappoint.  This was the best spicy ramen broth I've had in SF.  Lotsa heat and awesome broth.  Worried it would taste like a bowl of Sriracha, but it didn't.  Added kimchee, but I'll pass on that next time.  Only one piece of meat, which is fine for me.  Noodles were perfect texture.  B's cold ramen and hamachi appetizer were good, but paled next to my spicy ramen.

Sign in on clipboard directly to your left when entering.  Super tiny place with only a couple of large tables.  Menu also included sushi, rice dishes, and appetizers.  Shaved ice with condensed milk and red bean seemed popular.  All credit cards accepted except Amex.
author: Jennifer H.

description: I have recently moved from the East Coast, where finding good sushi did not involve hiring a private detective, and it took about a year to find something that even comes close to the quality abundant in the Northeast and the South.  This place has excellent sushi -- we are definitely coming back.
author: Jolly R.

description:
Great food! Amazing noodle texture!  Delicious ramen, but also an extensive menu of other Japanese food items.  Authentic and recommended. 

Quick service!  So happy I found another place in the hood I like besides Shalamar.
author: Gramme F.

description:
ive only tried one other ramen house, but i must say ive had better. dont get me wrong, katana ya is delicious, but there was just something missing. probably because i had one measly piece of cha sui. my friend on the other hand, order ramen with fried chicken, cha sui, potstickers, corn and god knows what, and didnt care to eat any of the meat! gooptron 3000. there was no wait, but boy was it hard to find parking. the broth was a bit on the salty side, but after adding lots of pepper flakes it tasted fine

 WARNING: after eating here, you WILL knock the eff out! so much msg!
author: Daniel S.

description:
I do not know why this place is so popular. I think ramen is good, but not beyond my expectation. I am sure we can find ramen with such quality so easily in other restaurants. Yes, definitely there are much better ramen in bay area.

Except for ramen, foods in this place may be below the average. I went there with my husband and he ordered buta-don and it tasted strange.
author: Machiruda Y.

description:
I'm not a big ramen person but heard about this place and tried it.

Had what the waitress recommended: spicy ramen with 'salt' base.  It rocked.  I think the salt base is a bit of a misnomer/mistranslation - don't worry this dish is neither overly salty or spicy - but all good.
author: Nate P.

description:
So there used to be a Katana-Ya serving up oishii (delicious) Ramen that was in Irving district back around '01-'03 that closed...Then on Geary another one opened up, the ramen was ma-ma (so-so) but closed down, I dont know if there is any affiliation with this one but this issome good ass Ramen.

The old spot was owned by an ex-sumo wrestler, and his Ramen and Chicken Karaage was off the chain!!!!  If they are affiliated then thanks for bringing it back like the old skool days because this is some good stuff.

Best ramen in the Bay that I have tried so far, plus they just added a donburi section to their menu, the sukiyaki is pretty good.  Only thing is I wanted shrimp heads, but could only get them when I ordered ama-ebi...sometimes I just want deep fried shrimp heads, Okay!!!!!

The wait can get a little long but the prices are worth it, especially on a foggy day in the Sucka-Free!!! Check it out.
author: Richard N.

description:
Disclaimer: I've realize that I am not that big of a fan of ramen in general so I'm not that enthusiastic in this review.

I would give this place about 3.5 stars. I don't find it that much tastier than other ramen places I've been to, but then again I haven't had ramen at many other places and I haven't had restaurant ramen in a couple years.

A foodie friend and coworker both recommended the fried chicken ramen, which is what I got, with miso broth, rich. The fried chicken is EXCELLENT. Crispy, tender, juicy and perfectly flavored (not too salty, not too flavorless). I almost just got some more fried chicken to go, but decided to control myself.

The broth was good and the noodles were cooked perfectly. They had a good bite to them. It was definitely a good bowl of ramen, large as well. I didn't even have room to finish all the soup!

I think it was worth it to at least come here once. The ramen was $10.50 (not including tip & tax) and I was wayyyy full of soup goodyness. The service was good once you are seated. (It was annoying that I was standing there for 5 minutes and nobody came to me to tell me I had to actually put my name on the list. Thus, another group put their names before me and the waitress seated them first even though she talked to me first before they got there. She also seated me at the bar when there was still a table open...).

Be warned that there is a lot of msg in the soup (I appreciated that they said "MSG added" in their menu!). I was drinking a TON of water for the rest of the night!

Anyway, if you love ramen, come here--AND COME EARLY!
author: Angela H.

description:
This is a little hole in the wall place located downtown.  I would never wander into that part  of geary to look for a good place to eat.  Location is not the best, but their ramen is top notch, well at least I think it is.

We ordered:

KATANA-YA RAMEN: we couldn't decide which ramen, so we decided to go for the most expensive one.  It had pork, bamboo shoots, gyozas, chicken karage, corn , half a boiled egg and some seaweed.  The broth was so good and it tasted so authentic.  The noodles tasted hand made and very fresh.  It was so fresh, it had a crisp to it.  Best ramen noodle I've ever had!  But what it came with wasn't all that great.  The gyoza was a little bit too salty, the chicken karage was soggy by the time i ate it and there wasn't enough corn in it.  Next time I'd probably try something more simpler.

CHICKEN DONBURI:  It comes in two sizes and we got the smaller size. Honestly, I don't remember much of it. I remember that it wasn't bad, but nothing outstanding either.  I hated the ginger in it.  They put too much of that in it. 

HAMACHI KAMA:  I usually have my hamachi kama's grilled.  When the waitress brought it out my friend and I were shocked to see that it was deep fried.  It wasn't bad, but we would have much preferred to have it grilled rather than deep fried.

I would definitely come here again, but not for anything else but the RAMENS.  It is absolutely DELICIOUS and affordable!!!
author: Sarah F.

description: AMAZING!!!!!!!! Me and my boyfriend came here for dinner and the food was so good! I got the fried chicken ramen and he got the miso ramen with tempura. The only down fall is the wait time, the place is TINY so wait time was about 30 minutes but completely worth it, will definitely be coming back.
author: Militza N.

description: It's midnight  and my little tummy loves to grumble and complain. Thats when I move my little fat ass down to Katana Ya. Nice for a midnight snack if you're a night piglet like me.
author: Cyndi C.

description:
An overdue review. I really wanted to like this place, but maybe my expectations were too high. Disappointed I was.

My friend and I came here around 1ish, small place, tables all full, and would be hard for groups of 4 or more to dine here. We got seated rather quickly, within 10 minutes, considering the lines I hear about from fellow yelpers. The parking sucks, but we were also pretty lucky with that.

I ordered the chasu ramen because it was on that list of things to eat before I die, but I think not and here is why--
+The soup was overly oily and a tad too salty.
+The chasu tasted rather dry and bland. 
+Nothing about this bowl of ramen stood out to me.
+I don't remember there being an egg in my ramen, which I like.

BUT I did like the ramen noodles itself.

Perhaps this could be attributed to me going on the wrong day or a bad day, but it was unspectacular that if you were to ask me to go back, I would have to think twice and ask you suggest some place else with an egg.
author: Dolores L.

description:
On this stretch of Geary (between Mason and Taylor) there are several restaurants, with Katana-Ya being the most solid.

It's a good sign that late at night there are several groups of Asians waiting for a chance to eat.  I've been here twice, once for sushi and once for ramen.

The sushi was mostly good, and reasonably priced.  It's a nice late-night alternative to Ryoko's, since it offers similar quality without the techno DJ blasting music into your ears.

When I came for ramen, it was again packed and I was at the sushi bar, but the ramen I ordered (can't remember which one now, something spicy) was very tasty.

I think the main reason it's hard to give this 5 stars is that it's not very comfortable.  It's tiny and crowded so there's no room.  Service was pretty good both times.

Oh, I had a shaved ice thing for dessert once, it was not very good.  Just shaved ice, condensed milk, and some strawberry syrup.  Maybe they have a better option, but this one wasn't so great.
author: Joseph N.

description:
Night started with me and a friend waiting to be seated.  A "homeless" guy comes up to me and asks for change, but he does it this way "Hey, can you spare some change, noodle?"  

FYI: This is a way to get me to hit you and throw you into traffic (in my head).  

Food here is decent,  I don't get the whole "Best Ramen in San Francisco"...maybe if you mean by actually in the city, fine, its pretty good.  

Portions: Portions are a bit small than what I'm used to
Parking: You may as well bart/muni in
Price: Reasonable 9 dollars (rough estimate) per bowl
Quality of food: So-so, soup is a bit salty and probably a lot of MSG.
Service: Not bad.  
Expect to wait, this place gets really crowded and its small inside.
author: Omar L.

description:
The search for the ultimate ramen bowl continues...

Arrived shortly after open, but there was still a short wait.  Good sign!  We sat at the bar instead of waiting for a table.

I had what was probably the basic bowl.  The noodles were perfectly cooked, pork was very good and my egg...was missing!  (boo!!  I had even confirmed egg was included when I ordered.  Oh well.)  The broth was good, but I have to say, Ippudo in NY is better and really tough to beat.

I would definitely go back, but wouldn't wait more than 20 minutes to get a seat.  It's really good, but I've had better.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Came here today for lunch after some shopping.

We walked in at about 11:20 and were greeted by an older male (who seemed to be the "dad" of the restaurant). He told us that they opened at 11:30, but we could have a seat and wait for the staff to ready up. It's a small place and there was a small group of people, roughly 6 people already seated until the "mom" of the restaurant came out and said, "What are you doing? We are not open yet. You cannot sit here either because if you do, everyone will come in and sit down. You can wait outside and view our menu as you wait." WOW. So we were then moved outside, door closed with menus in our hand. I like how they do business here.

After we were seated, we ordered quickly. I got the lunch special which consisted of Pork flavored miso soup with a side of BBQ Pork over rice. My friends got the deep fried chicken in miso soup broth with a hard boiled egg.

We got our order in about 5 minutes, and the bowls were slammed down in front of me and one of my other friends. Talk about service etiquette...

For the food - mine was good, nothing epic. I ordered a thick broth so it was richer, and a bit saltier than I'm use to, but it was still good. There was one piece of BBQ pork and a good portion of ramen with a few other veggies (seaweed, etc). I also tried a fried chicken piece from one of my friends which was also good. Everyone was satisfied with their meal. Service was not that great. Sorry to come early and give you business during a recession.
author: Tim S.

description:
So I just went to the gym today for the first time in years, my breath and condition after yesterday was...well...awful.
Bloody mary's and beer the day before you are planning to work out( no matter how good those drinks are), it is just a stupid idea.
.
FYI I forgot my training clothes and had a sweat attack when i met the personal trainer so I walked out of there looking dumb and no training more then acting like my neurotic mom, I mean WHO goes to the gym with a dress and boots?


After that hard exercise I needed some good food in my belly, so I was thinking sushi, went down to Katanya and had at least some expectations, I wanted to order the sushi but as I sat down in the bar I was not at all impressed by the quality of the fish just by looking at it ( I know my fish).
 since I started the day with a dumb move I figured I might as well continue with that trend, so i ordered Udon with tempura, I don't like tempura, at all, never ever but still there I was ordering it, and the Udon was OK, nothing special, the place was also just OK, the staff-OK.

The reason why I am giving three stars is because it is hard to be fair, I think I have to come here at some other time and try something different before I say nono to this place.
author: cecilia k.

description:
Great Ramen, Cute Restaurant, Cozy Atmosphere & Fast friendly service. We had dinner here after the Chinese New Year parade last night we decided that we give it a try the wait was about 30 minutes but when we left the wait was over an hour. There were five of us and we sat at a little table that was good for 4 people but didn't mind. With Sapporo on tap and fried Tofu for appetizer I was very happy to be eating so quickly then kicked the dinner off with a #12 Ramen with miso based broth, this was wonderful, it had veggie pot stickers in it, some fried chicken and port tenderloin also with some vegetables...
I'll be back...
author: David O.

description: Just tried this place for the first time and I love it! The first time when I try to come here for dinner, there was a really long line and decided not to stay. The second time I finally gets to order an try out their ramen. Their ramen are good. The soup is so flavorful and the noodles are so yummy. Definitely come back again if the line isn't that long.
author: Nhung C.

description: Comfort food in the bowl-of-noodles form. I had the spicy miso fried chicken ramen & had to consciously slow my ravenous slurping more than once before utterly inhaling the entire bowl. Absolutely delicious & certainly full of (caution: trendy word of the moment) umami. The girlfriend had the spicy miso BBQ pork ramen + a hard boiled egg & commented that ramen always had to have an egg. I guess I can see that. The only minor complaint is concerned with portion size. Just a little more meat & a bit bigger bowl overall would've completed the perfect feeling of satisfaction that this rich & flavorful soup offered with it's comforting deliciousness. The ramen at Katana-Ya is a great choice for anyone craving comfort food (particularly hot soup on a cold day), but if you have a really big appetite you may be left wanting just that tiny bit more.
author: John M.

description:
Hands down the best ramen I've had in the city. I always have a hard time diverging from my usual Kimchee Ramen....so I can't tell you what else is good except for that. I've also tried some of their sushi rolls, including the Red and White. They are made with very fresh fish and are a great compliment to your ramen. 

Be prepared to wait though. This place is always busy! I like to stare at the people sitting next to the window to make them feel uncomfortable, thus decrease the waiting time! Not sure if it actually works...but damn their food looks good.
author: Allan M.

description: Amazing Ramen! Want to try the udon here i've heard it's great- however i'm taking a star off for price. $18 for a bowl of ramen?? A bit much...was kind of caught off gaurd. Thought it was cheaper. Staff was amazing, place is small but great atmosphere and fast service. Their ramen really is awesome, but there has to be an awesome ramen/udon place that isn't quite as pricey.
author: Brittainie B.

description: I've always wondered why there are always so much people waiting in front of this tiny restaurant so I finally came here a couple months ago with my friend . I had their extra spicy ramen which was very yummy . I've had ramen at many other places and when they say spicy , it's usually not spicy but the extra spicy ramen here is actually spicy which is good . I also had the shiromaguro tataki which was not bad . Only bad thing about this restaurant is that it's super small so you might end up waiting some time if you come during certain hours . Other than that , I would definitely come back again .
author: Eileen L.

description: Good ramen... Get the combo w fried rice.... Uh mazing!! Butterfish nigiri to die for too! Be prepared to wait for a table, even if it just for two. We waited about 20-30 mins on a Saturday night around 8:30pm.
author: Wing W.

description:
It's funny how I've driven past this location along with watched a show or two at the Curran Theater, but never noticed this famous ramen restaurant!  I finally got to try Katana-ya after all the hype that 7x7 and friends have been raving about.  I went on a weekday night to avoid the crowd, little to know that the wait was still roughly 35 minutes for TWO people! 

Service was fast once we got seated.  I have to give it 3 stars because I am a hardcore fan of ramen and I didn't even have an urge to finish my broth and that NEVER happens. I loooove broth, but this was just so-so.  Did I order the wrong soup base?  Soy sauce...  Also, the soup wasn't hot when it came out.  It was warm, ready-to-eat temperature.  Maybe that's a good and bad thing..

Overall, it was an experience and another restaurant to cross out on my 7x7 things to try in SF list. 

However, I DO agree that this place is better than saltysaltysaltySanta Ramen! That place went downhill since it moved to its new location, but more on that elsewhere.
author: Rosanne L.

description: Came here last night before the theater (!) and was very satisfied.  I got the udon soup with the mixed tempura.  It was light and delicious.  The wife got the famous ramen but it had msg, so I declined. The sushi was so good (salmon nigiri) that we had to order more...so sweet and buttery!  Definitely worth the wait.
author: Lucia B.

description: We had to wait outside15 minutes for a table, but it was worth it! I'm not sure if I'd want to wait longer than though. We sat at the bar, and I ordered the kimchee ramen with miso broth - and it satisfied my ramen craving. Mmm...  It wasn't stellar, but definitely solid.
author: Yenie T.

description:
I love all things Japan. The people are friendly and hip. The country is clean. And the food is delicious. Whenever I can eat at a restaurant and get the feeling that I'm eating something from Japan, I know I've found a good place to eat. 

Katana-ya has the best ramen  I've tasted in the Bay Area. It's even better than Santa Ramen. Katana-ya's soup base has a nice rich flavor but isn't too salty. The noodles are also very nicely cooked - perfectly "al dente." Their sushi and hot food items are also quite good. I recommend getting the Seafood Salad, which provides a good number of sashimi pieces dressed in ponzu sauce. 

I would have given this place five stars. However, I was disappointed with the Katsu Curry - the katsu was dry and hard. Also, it took a little time to get seated. Plus, the restaurant itself is quite cramped. However, this was overcome with the quick and friendly service. Can't wait to come back to this place whenever I'm in Union Square.
author: Lael A.

description:
Not authentic Japanese, but not bad its in-authenticity.

Toro hand roll: okay sums it up.  Not the freshest, but wasn't expecting much since its not authentic.  

Regular ramen with soy base: basic noodle soup, nothing spectacular.  Bbq pork was on the fatty side. 

Curry chicken: nothing special, but the chicken was fried nicely.

Katanaya ramen: came with gyoza, bbq pork, egg, and fried chicken.  Added medium spicy to the soy broth and it was more of a mild spicy.  Noodles were cooked nicely though

The wait was about 30 minutes.  Would I wait again?  Not worth the wait or the money.
author: Constance J.

description:
Now THAT's what I'm talking about!

This venue is by no means a fancy overpriced Japanese restaurant.  It's a bit of a hole in the wall, in a not so peaceful location.  However they are open late, and manage to keep their tables generally filled.

Why?
Because their food is, surprisingly, quite good.

Now, I learned about this place when I was specifically looking for good Japanese ramen.  Being disappointed every time I ordered ramen in SF, I was somewhat on a mission to mark down at least one place that serves them right.  Katana-ya is that place.

We tried this place for the first time the other night, and we actually took our ramens to-go.  We ordered Cha-shu-men (BBQ pork ramen), one with light soy-sauce soup and other with rich soy-sauce.  We got home and opened the container to enjoy an explosion of amazing aroma of the soup.... it was a great sign.  We had our first bite, and YES, I was right.  Aside from the fact that the noodles got a bit stretched out inevitably from getting them to-go, the ramen was really, really, good.

Seriously, if you've had ramen around J-town and thought it was good, you MUST try this place.  You will realize that the ramen you've been eating in J-town was total crap.

And guys, do take a moment to browse the photos fellow Yelpers uploaded for Katana-ya.  Can you see how good all the food (especially the ramen) look??? Need I say more.... just try it.  

Born-and-raised-in-Japan Japanese girl approved.
author: Sascha O.

description:
Based on food only, I would give 5 stars.
Ramen is excellent, sushi is fresh and awesome.

I've been there a couple of times and have experienced long wait and difficult service each time, but last time was too much... and from past review I am not the only one to have experienced that.

The old lady (owner?) that does an awful job as hostess and even worse at writing up the checks is horrible. Mean, rude and deceitful.

I am half asian so I know people tend to see me "white" when I am in my white friends company and asian when hanging out with the Thai crowd.
I didn't get any problems at Katana Ya with white people.
Last time I went with my Thai girlfriend and they probably thought "oh oh, tourists... they probably don't know about tipping".
So they added 15% without telling us, and tried to deny when I asked about it even though IT WAS WRITTEN ON THE CHECK!!!

To be fair, the waitress was more embarassed than anything else... she actually did a good job when we ordered, even taking time to make some recommendation even though she was super busy.
But that old lady.....
Too bad, I would have left 20% without a doubt otherwise.

Oh, and I will never go back. And write a bad Yelp review.
If she's not the owner, get rid of the old lady and I'll add a couple of stars!
author: Vithiet L.

description:
I'm from the DC area and there is NO ramen to enjoy anywhere in this area. I think the nearest place for decent ramen is NYC!
