Anyhow, visiting the left coast, my wife and I were on a search for delicious ramen. Tried a place in Japan Town and it was decent. However, in the heavily commercial enclave of Union Square we find Katana-Ya.

The ramen was awesome! I had the standard broth and I believe I ordered it on the rich flavorful side. Oh boy did it deliver on that description! Whenever I think about it I my mouth waters. The noodles were cooked perfectly. The broth was soo tasty and the pork and veggies in the soup were added bonuses.

Well worth the wait but we were lucky. Go in between lunch and dinner for a shorter wait, say around 3:00pm.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Been craving for some yummy soulful ramen for a loooong time since my last SoCal trip.  They set the standard for all future ramen experience.  So I was stoked when my cousin and my cravings were on the same wave length.  Yum! After feeling disappointed by the spot in S.M. for their floury and powdery ramen (they've gone downhill with all the hype).  I was please to hear about this spot and the hype that surrounded it.  Lets just say they did not disappoint!

On Sunday, we checked this place out after my cousin's gf got off from work in the city, so convenient in terms of timing for dinner.  It's couple of blocks up the street from Union square and it literally is a whole in the wall.  The place is small and tight, limited seating, seriously limited.  Make sure to sign up on the wait list outside the door. 

Ramen - 4.5 stars
I got the miso katana ya ramen and it was deeeelish.  Broth had soul and it was smooth and deeply flavorful.  The ramen noodles were cooked perfectly, no excess flour, just the right texture. It is pretty much everything in a bowl, it had deep fried Gyoza (2), Chicken Karage (2), Sliced Pork (2), half boiled egg, and corn kernels.  YUM! Honestly, it is worth the money, the wait, cost of parking or bart fare.  Sooo much better than Santa Ramen.  

Service - 4 stars
They were very attentive, there is no excuse for them to miss up here given at any point in time they have only a few dozen patrons enjoying their savory ramen.

Ambiance - n/a
Let's not joke ourselves we don't come here for the ambiance. This place is quite raw but with lots of character.

Location - 4 stars
It is strategically placed within walking distance from union square and bart. 

Overall - 4.5 stars
I'm definitely coming back here again.
author: Sid E.

description:
The wait is crazy during dinner hours but the ramen makes it worth it.  Don't care too much for the miso broth, but the spicy soy with tofu is awesome.  The fried chicken is crazy good, but you have to walk up nob mill to burn it off.

I'm taking off a star because the service isn't all that friendly.
author: H L.

description:
I have been here several times and I must say i never had an outstanding experience which will make me rate this place any better than 3 stars. this is a relatively small place very close to many hotels, theatre and union square. Depending on when you get in, you might be lucky enough to snag a table and claim your territory or might end up waiting at least 25 min for this privilege. On my recent i ordered golden roll and a Hawaiian rule. Both roles were average. One really didn't have much of a kick while in the other i couldn't taste mango. 
Could be that sushi is not their strongest thing and that is why people eat ramen/ noodle.
author: Hasham Y.

description:
Having just spent some time in Tokyo, Katana-ya is very close to the real thing when it comes to the ramen.  

Food:  4 stars.  I tried the BBQ pork ramen and thought it rivals any ramen you can get in Japan.  The noodles are cooked nicely, the pork is flavorful and the soy sauce broth was delicious - I drank it all up.

Service:  3 stars.  The staff consists of two servers and a sushi chef who basically just stands around alot because the sushi orders don't  come around too frequently.  The service is just average, but my expectations were lowered to begin with for a place like this.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  Don't expect too much, but do expect sweaty people, cramped spaces, and heavy slurping.

Hits:   BBQ pork ramen.

Misses:  Cramped space.  

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Santa Ramen, Mifune.
author: Keith C.

description:
Katana-Ya was delicious. I was craving some ramen so I looked it up on Yelp and my friend and I decided to try it out. The storefront is really small so we had a lot of trouble finding it. Once we got in, though, we were immediately seated. It's awesome that so many people in SF still want food at 10pm! Usually the big stores close at 9 so that SF looks kind of empty. 

I ordered the bbq fried pork ramen and it was delicious. After eating at Ryowa, the ramen here tastes almost the same at $2 more. I would rather just eat at Ryowa.
author: Catherine S.

description:
Not your typical Japanese restaurant or ramen house, but damn its good!  Good variety of ramen and it is comparable to other ramen houses.  I had the Katanaya ramen which basically has everything, but the only thing was there wasnt enough corn!  Toro nigiri was SO GOOD!  Not a big fan of toro, but this was great!

The place isnt very big, but also isnt very small.  They just squished in many tables so your basically sitting next to the other table.  I guess they're just trying to pack as many people as possible, therefore DO NOT go with a big party.  You could be waiting forever to get a table even though you will have to wait anyway.
author: Gina S.

description:
Small place that fills quick because they make super tasty bowls of ramen.
Go for the miso ramen.
Pick yer meat and it'll be good.
And filling... Those bowls are huge.
The mixed fish sushi salad to start was also fresh and good.
I ordered too much food and walked around after eating there feeling way too full.
author: Kev M.

description:
Yum! 

Sushi here aint that great, but The ramen here are one of the more authentic ones in town. I usually get the egg katsu don as well, to share:) 

It's located near union square, hard to find parking, and hard to find seats (after work and other "rush" hours). 

It's small and hidden. Intimate and cute. Affordable for dates, casual and great location. Across from a bunch of nail places and some small theaters where plays are put on:)
author: Ying C.

description:
This was our second trip to Katana-Ya. We visited San Francisco a few months back and my boyfriend brought a chirashi bowl back to our hotel room because it was 12a and I didnt feel like getting dressed for dinner at midnight!

This time we put our names in at about 8pm on a Friday night. Party of 4 took less than 20 mins. Im figuring that we just barely beat the crown because by the time we were seated there were about 20 people crowded outside, waiting for one of their 7 or so coveted tables.

We were seated in a cramped booth near the front window. This is why I take away one star...I understand that Katana-Ya is a hole-in-the-wall, I love the, "We know we're great so why update anything," vibe. But, we were seated by an open door that led to a hallway holding kegs and what looked like some trash. This unappetizing view didnt discourage us because we already knew this place was a gem. But the other people in our party probably got a little freaked out. Nothing like a dirty sushi joint, ya know!

This time I ordered the Sashimi combo. 3 pieces of 4 kinds of fish (12 total) with miso soup to start. My bf again ordered the chirashi bowl and it was even better than I remembered. All cuts if fish were thick, not at all skimpy. Nice thick cuts of perfectly fresh fish, not even the slightest feeling of  "hmm-maybe-this-wasnt-such-a-good-idea," that I sometimes get when trying out a new sushi restaurant.

The rest of the table ordered, what they described as, "the best fried rice they've ever had," as well as a Philly roll and the Golden Roll, to which they added eel. Everyone thoroughly enjoyed their meals.

The cramped quarters were a bit uncomfortable but are also to be expected ina city so cramped (yet still incredible, SF is one of my fav. cities!)

All in all, a great choice for sushi. If youre looking for a romantic date spot or a place to impress the stuck-up in-laws, keep looking. But if youre looking for genuinely great sushi at very reasonable prices, youve found your place!!!
author: Brie V.

description: I like this place. The food comes out really fast and the food is really good. The staffs are really friendly. The only problem with this place is that it is small. REAL SMALL. It tends to be really busy at night. They forgot my order one time but I was fine. I like this place, its just like a typical ramen house in Japan. Small, cramp, quick and good service. I would recommend people to come here and eat.
author: Benjamin C.

description:
Came here tonight just for the heck of it... parking can be pretty difficult around this area since it's a block away from Union Sq.  The trick is to come a little before 6 and grab a free meter, and wait in your car til 6pm.  Ghetto right? but it works!  TONS of ppl do it.

The restaurant is pretty small, and cramped.  I definitely wouldn't recommend coming here with more than 4 people.  We had a table for two, and the table was so small and against the wall that I couldn't even extend my elbows out comfortably...  how do you expect me to eat ramen if I don't have any elbow room?  Well, I had to make do...

We got a dynamite roll, which is a mix of spicy fish.  Indeed, it was spicy... no wasabi needed unless you want more of a kick.  The fish tasted pretty fresh.  Although the roll was very simple, no sauces or anything, it was very good.  It cost $6 for 6 pieces.  Decently priced.  THeir other special rolls range from $11-13.50.

We also got their Katanaya ramen bowls.  What's nice about the ramen bowls is that you can choose the flavor of the broth:  soy, miso, regular and rich or light.  We got different broth flavors but same content.  I got the rich miso broth, and my friend got the rich soy broth.  I have to admit, I liked the soy broth better.  I kind of got sick of my miso broth.  It was very filling... I couldn't finish my bowl of ramen!  It comes with A LOT... The Katanaya ramen comes with 2 fried dumpling pieces, 2-3 pieces of fried chicken (no bone), and pieces of bbq pork or chasu.  The fried chicken tasted really good, but I like the bbq pork better.  The bbq pork was really soft and had a good flavor.  I wasn't too big of a fan of the fried dumpling... kind of had a weird taste.  This cost $12.90.

All together, the place is good, but I dont think i'd make a trip all the way out to downtown for it esp since the place is so small and parking is difficult.  Santa Ramen is a little better in my opinion, but this place is still really good.

2 bowls of Katayna Ramen + dynamite roll = $40 incl tax and tip.  This particular bowl of ramen is more expensive, but the other bowls are about $8.50.
author: Diane L.

description: I was very surprised to see that the rating of this place has been steadily dwindling.  Every time we're in San Francisco we eat here.  I really like the simple and fresh flavors of their ramen.  I hope to eat here again, and maybe find out why the ratings have been recently lower than before.
author: Dennis D.

description: It's the season for warmth-inducing ramen and thanks to my +1's suggestion to fill up prior to the Yelp Unwrapped! Holiday Party we walked up to Katana-Ya.  By some stroke of luck we managed to walk right in and sit down at a table for 2.  We had the house special with light miso, which included fried chicken, gyoza and not much in quantity of a few other toppings -- but the bowl was full.  Noodles had a nice texture and the broth was tasty.  My only complaint is the broth was on the cool side.  Especially on one of the coldest evenings in the City, you want that bowl steaming hot!  We also had a satisfying bowl of fried rice.  This place goes on my ramen list!
author: Sherri C.

description:
I few friends told me about this, but I realize I don't really venture out to union square much anymore.  I think it's because all you can really do there is shop, and money is a bit tight!

I finally came out to this little joint over the weekend and got there right when it opened.  Good thing too!  After we were seated, the place filled up and there was a line out the door.  I decided to go with the Katanaya ramen and I gotta say....hit the spot!  It was a nice big bowl of ramen in miso soup to fill me up.  The fried chicken was an interesting thought at first because its submersed in soup the whole time, but still tasted all good!  I think there was some pork in there too?  The more meat the better!  There's also a couple gyozas in there too!  It wasn't the cheapest bowl of ramen, but I left that place feelin' good.

This place will definitely be on my mind any time I stroll through hear after some shopping.  I can't come out here JUST for the ramen though...tempting, but no.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Yay! Ramen that I like!! Came here the other day with Jenny K. on a Friday afternoon. It was raining and cold and not to mention I was afraid of not finding parking. But thank goodness the parking gods were working with us because we found parking around the block! There was a line which was kind of surprising for a Friday afternoon. We waited for a while and then seated probably after about 15-20 minutes of waiting. I got the chasu ramen with miso broth. mmmm! The both has a hint of garlic flavor. 

The place is really small and I'm glad I was able to try this place on my first time coming!
author: Eugenia G.

description:
Nothing like a bowl of Ramen to fill you up on a cold morning. Unfortunately, this particular morning, after driving around lost in the city for 30+ minutes, we still managed to be 10 minutes early.  And, of course, they wouldn't let us wait inside, away from the cold.  So after kickin' it at Jack in the BOx for 10 min, we headed back, and were seated.

This place filled up QUICK!  Within 5 minutes of the restaurant opening, all the tables were already full.  It makes sense too.  The food was delicious.  I had the classic miso ramen, which satisfied every single craving.  I do want to try their other 'flavors', cuz Samantha R's spicy tofu tasted bomb.  Don't get me wrong, the plain ones are still amazing, but why not try a little twist from originality?

If you're thinking about coming, plan accordingly because there's gonna be a line.  And the wait makes sense. A good ramen joint this close to Union Square is hard to find.
author: Eric C.

description: If you can't give me meat at least throw me a bone! I guess I'm no longer mystified by all the hype about this place. I stopped by earlier to try their spicy ramen at the recommendation of the server. For $9, my bowl came with one small slice of pork, seaweed, and a few pieces of bamboo. The noodle was cooked to perfection with enough firmness to give texture but the miso soup base was something I can easily make at home. Similar to my last visit, the soup is still a tad too salty but it was better this time around. Tonight I sat at the end of the bar but only to witness that their fish was actually not as fresh as I had first imagined. I'm not terribly disappointed but 3-stars is a more accurate assessment after this visit.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I came here based on high recommendations for their ramen and they did not disappoint me. The first good sign was that they led their menu with the ramen and didn't overdo it with too many types of ramen either. Admittedly, the sushi bar would suggest that the sushi here is the star, but we'll save that for another trip.

I decided on an order of Katanaya Ramen, which I assume would be their specialty if it had the name in there. You choose your own base (another good sign) of soy sauce, salt, or miso, as well. The Katanaya Ramen is a rather large bowl of ramen (and costs accordingly, coming in at around $12) with noodles plus fried chicken and some deep fried gyoza in the bowl. Yes please!

Most people are often tricked by the actual ramen noodles though, if they get enough extras in their bowl. But luckily, the ramen was well done, the miso broth was great as well. Any bowl that has you continually sipping at it when the noodles are long gone is a good one, and this is what I did.

Unfortunately for this place, it's easy to miss because it's a rather unobvious store front, but I'm going to add it to my ramen rotation when I'm in the Union Square area. Tanpopo still wins because of it's location in J-town and much easier parking, but the places tie when it comes when to ramen and the service (great staff at both places).
author: Roland C.

description:
I had heard good things about this place, so instead of lazily going to the food courts after shopping with my sister, we decided to check this place out. 

The fact that there were a couple names before us on the waiting list before us boded well. (The fact that they were Japanese-- or J.American-- was a good sign too). It seemed like the staff were all Japanese-- the sushi chef had some kind of accent, but was speaking Japanese just fine. 

We waited about 10 minutes. My sister and I are both big fans of ramen so we had a hard time choosing. We finally decided on spicy green onion ramen (me) and kimchi ramen (her).  

The waitress said this was her favorite, and it was very good! It's not very spicy, and it's only when you hit the little bits of chili pepper that it has a little bit of a kick. I loved the bamboo shoots in there! Very tasty.

My sister's kimchi ramen: It wasn't too spicy like some kimchi ramens I've had. It had a very good kimchi flavor to it that was more than subtle, yet not nearly overwhelming. 

Both ramens had a couple nice thick chashu pieces (pork), which weren't fatty at all, which we appreciated. (You can ask for extra chashu-- they're really good!)

The ramen left a pleasant after-taste, which I find is rare with ramen shops. :)
Will be back! Will no longer patronize the food courts below Bloomingdale's!
author: Saori E.

description: Very nice Japanese foods! All are like in Japan! Fun and causal. The best causal Japanese restaurant in SFC!
author: Satoshi M.

description:
came here for lunch today (they're open for lunch saturdays and sundays from 12-4pm, and then dinner until 1:15am)... and of course they did not fail me!

we ordered sushi here for the first time, including the $10 roll combo which was a very sweet deal! you can pick from several basic rolls, but i got the hamachi and spicy scallop. the pieces were actually pretty substantial and big on the fish rather than rice. the hamachi roll had yellowtail, avocado, and some green onion, while the spicy scallop had huge chunks of fresh scallop and just a squirt of spicy mayo so as not to overpower the seafood. both rolls were delicious and hit the spot!

i also ordered the toro nigiri, which was rich and fresh, while my bf got the ramen set with shio/salt ramen and a side of kimchee fried rice, of course. it was a substantial amount of food and so satisfying!

will be back again for more sushi!!
author: Andrey C.

description:
Oh goodness.  I love it.  this place has something that something that no other ramen joint I have been has... Tsukemen.. it is basically dry ramen (cool) with karage chicken and a separate bowl of hot soup with pork and a boiled egg.  the idea is to dip the cold noodles to the hot soup.  so yummy.  The noodle stays nice and chewy.  Such a good deal, too, all for$ 8.90.  I love it.  Every time my coworker suggest we go, I think about it all week and on that morning, i eat nothing to save room to eat everything in front of me.  

The place is pretty small, but if you get there around 11:30am for lunch, you have a pretty good chance of getting seats.  I once got there around 12:15 and had to wait 15 minutes for a table.
author: Janet S.

description:
I enjoyed my kimchi ramen immensely. The kimchi was a little on the fresher side, so it didn't burn my tongue and was quite tasty in my miso soup base. A friend and I shared the butterfish (imagine a stick of butter swimming around), which was melty but a little stringy with the connective tissue.

You can order small or large little rice bowls to go with your ramen (used to be a set with the ramen, but perhaps no more?). I wanted some fish eggs and got the ikura. It's a smaller bowl than the other rice bowls, but you get a lot of fish eggs. Yum. If I worked closer I would get these little bowls as to go snacks.

I wasn't at all hungry but wanted more sushi! Good thing my stomach told my brain not to order or I would have exploded all over this ramen joint.
author: Amy N.

description: Amazing! Good stuff
author: Manny S.

description:
I came here with a friend because I heard this was the best ramen in SF. Ehh...I don't know about best but it was pretty good. 

First of all, if you're driving, you might totally miss it since the restaurant is pretty small. It's right next to Quizno's (to the left of it) and off Geary between Mason and Taylor. 

Anyway, the place itself is pretty tiny so we were really lucky to get the last table right before the lunch rush. Being an idiot, I decided to order the hot soba while my friend ordered the regular ramen. Okay, the hot soba is so bland that it became difficult to finish it. However, I did try my friend's regular ramen and it was very tasty. The broth is what makes the soup taste great. I don't know about being the BEST....but it's worth coming here to get. We also got the 49ers roll because the picture made it look great. It's good but it's not great. If you're going to order it, be sure to take the lemon slice OFF before you eat it, otherwise the lemon flavor will totally overpower your mouth. I don't even know why it was there. I also don't know if it was worth the price.

Overall, I can see why people come here for ramen. As for the rest of their food, you're better off going somewhere else
author: Diana Y.

description:
It was an overcast day in the city so I figured...ramen would be perfect.  This place was recommended to me by a friend of mine who is also into Ramen.

When we got there (about 7pm on a thurs) there was a bunch of folks standing outside (prob about 8).  Like another great ramen joint (down in LA), they had a clipboard outside where you put your name down.  We waited about 10 minutes (which is not bad) and got a seat at the sushi bar.  

The inside is nothing special.  It should be noted though that the place can prob only fit like 40 ppl.  The tables are stacked together pretty closely so expect to be elbow to elbow with ramen lovers (which is perfectly fine in my book).  Although the place was packed it wasn't loud and as a matter of fact it was pretty chill.  Pefect place for a date in my opinion.  

As far as the food is concerned, we were only here for one thing...Ramen.  They had other stuff on the menu but I didn't concern myself with that.  I ordered the Pork Ramen with Soy Sauce and my wife ordered the Pork Ramen with Miso.

The wait was pretty quick, prob less than 15 minutes which is good at peak time.  The noodles were perfect (al dente).  The soy sauce base however was okay. Middle of the pack if I compare it to some other places that I've been to.  The soy sauce flavor seemed to be on the lite site.  I was expecting this burst of flavor when I sipped the broth but it never came.  The Pork was also okay, I prefer the BBQ Pork at other places that has a little crisp to it.  If you're looking for crisp in the Pork you're not getting it here.  Overall though I enjoyed the combination of flavor.  I also tried my wife's ramen (with miso base) and I seemed to like that one much better.  The flavor in the broth was more present and it seemed to provide a creamyness to the noodles.

Overall I liked the ambiance of the place...small elbow to elbow and several different ramen choices.  I would definitely come back again but the next time I'll order the miso.
author: Brian T.

description:
I would give the spicy tuna roll 3 stars... and their ramen 2 stars. I'll round up because the waiters/waitresses were super polite and accommodating. 

Maybe I ordered the wrong bowl of ramen (extra spicy...salt broth) and it was far short of amazing of what I would expect from a restaurant with at least 4 stars AND 1000+ reviews. I guess yelp is a place where you can really over-hype a place that is just consistently okay. I'm sorry but I really didn't see anything special about this place. Maybe because it's known for ramen specifically? (as opposed to other japanese restaurants who may have ramen on their menu but not as it's *MAIN* thing?) I don't know.. but tbh, I'd rather pay about 2 dollars for a slice of pork and a package of ramen from cup of noodles and a bit of hot sauce for that 'extra spicy' flavor. 

Definitely NOT worth 30 bucks (after tax + tip) for 2 bowls of ramen and spicy tuna roll.
author: Joyce D.

description:
Long waits at this popular ramen spot in Union Square. The menu features sushi, donburi plates, appetizers, and their famed ramen. The "meat" broth choices are soy sauce (shoyu), miso, or salt (shio). You can have the soup "rich" or "light", which I've heard gives you either a richer pork and chicken stock, or a lighter chicken stock. Additionally, you can specify spiciness (additional charge). 

I ordered shio, light, and mildly spicy. I liked that the broth was thin and drinkable and found it very tasty, with an addictive kick. My friends tell me the regular spicy here is extremely spicy, with a layer of chili oil on top.

I went for the Katanaya special, which included two tasty kara-age, two gyoza (ok), two slices of pork (a little tough), a lone bamboo shoot, seaweed, half a hardboiled egg, and plenty of corn. The deep fried chicken was my favorite topping, but I wished they would put the fried items on a separate plate, to keep them from turning mushy. The texture of the gyoza suffered noticeably from being added to the soup. I didn't specify noodle doneness but they came out with a medium firmness and stayed fairly firm throughout eating.

Overall, I really enjoyed the bowl of ramen I had here, albeit expensive. I've been seeking out the richer tonkotsu broths whenever I've tried ramen, but I think now I'll stick with shio.
author: Derrick V.

description: Based on the FourSquare tips and 7x7 listing, the BBQ pork ramen was the item to get.  I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen, which included 'chasu,' but what my friend and I noticed immediately was that what Katana-ya calls 'chasu' was not what we Cantonese people normally consider 'chasu,' you know, the red flanks of pork with the coveted blackened tips you usually see hanging in the window at many a Chinese eatery or in BBQ pork buns.  It was a hearty meal for a cold rainy day, but it wasn't omg-mind blowing.  And it wasn't the first time I questioned the 7x7 list for Asian cuisine.
author: Jenn C.

description: This place is really good! It is small, so be prepared to split up a large group if you have a lot of people. I just had the regular ramen, and it was a great dinner. :)
author: Meagan T.

description:
Another day in the city! This time we ventured to Katana-ya for some ramen! I love ramen, and I heard this place has the best! 

I have to say this is one of the best in the bay, but it doesn't beat the ramen in Japan...close! 

Here, they let you choose with type of noodles you want (udon, ramen, somen), what broth you want (miso, shoyu), and what strength (light, regular, rich) which I thought was pretty neat! 

I went for the BBQ pork with ramen noodles miso broth (at the recommendation of the waitress), and regular strength. 

The ramen arrived in a timely manner and it was delicious! The broth was a nice, rich brown color and full of flavor. Not too salty, but just right! You could taste the love they put into it with every bite! 

The noodles were definitely not the kind that is frozen and mass produced. Well, not that I could tell anyway! They tasted pretty authentic and fresh. 

Just the right amount of BBQ pork slices and some seaweed thrown in. I'd probably would have thrown in some bamboo shoots, but hey, I'm really not complaining! 

Check out Katana-ya for some gooood ramen! 

P.S. this place is pretty small, so get there early to get a good seat. They serve sushi as well, but I just wanted the ramen.
author: Rachel N.

description:
One of the best ramen places in town. Leave your diet at the door because the tiny pieces of fat floating in the broth is what makes the soup so yummy. My usual order is a spicy miso ramen with light salt. The appetizers are great too but leave room for the ramen as it can fill you up quite nicely. Depending on the hour, this place can pack up quickly. An absolute must for those who seek good ramen.

The Good: Yummy ramen, friendly staff
The Bad:  The wait list
author: Yan W.

description: YUM! Whats better to get on a cold day in the city but ramen! My best friend introduced this place to me one afternoon after I had an interview in the area. The wait was only maybe no more than 10 minutes but it was understandable because once we stepped inside, the place was TINY! There were maybe only 6 tables inside! We first sat at the bar and ordered our food but then a table opened up and the waiter was nice enough to offer it to us since there were 3 of us. I ended up ordering the Spicy Kimchee Ramen with Udon Noodles because the Ramen noodles they used were made with egg and Im allergic, unfortunately. The udon noodles still did the job, nonetheless. The soup was delicious, not too salty, not too bland. It also came with kimchee, seaweed, and some meat inside too. The service was very friendly and down to earth, i like how they were very energetic, walking and interacting with the tables and customers while singing along to the macarena that was playing on the stereo haha. I am definitely keeping this place in mind for those future lunch breaks.
author: Marissa C.

description:
There was a time last year when I wanted to try this place but whenever I remembered I wanted to I'd be strolling out of Slide thinking, "Crap we should have left sooner so we could eat some ramen!"  But alas, we were always too late.

Finally one foggy afternoon, my friend who had been telling me about this place phoned in and said we should grab a bite at Katana-Ya.  I was elated.  I was destined to eat here.  So me and my buddy meet up and of course the ramen is piping hot and noodle-iscious.  Not only were the noodles freshly made so weren't goopy, the broth was rich in flavor of miso and pork.  If I could just have the stock recipe, I would make it at home and drink it constantly.

Then I went back with my brother and we got sushi, and even the sushi was good.  Wow, a double whammy.  Good ramen and sushi?  I got a salmon roll and a spicy tuna roll and my brother got a dragon roll or something, it's the one that has eel.  The name of that roll changes with every restaurant.  The suchi rice was also made every well.  Just sticky enough to hold the fish in place, but soft and only a little sweet as not to overpower the main ingredients.

I also went here for a quick lunch and got their curry.  Also, fantastic.  I love curry from every country.  I do, I really do.  The spot is just a little too cramped.  But other than that, it's a lot of fun in my mouth.
author: Susan C.

description:
This place is pretty good.  Definitely be prepared for a 30-45 minute wait.  Although I have to say...it may be because this place seats a maximum capacity of 20 is part of the reason why there is a wait.

If you have a group larger than 3-4 it makes it more difficult as well.  I'd recommend only 2...as that is the common party # that come here.

I've only had the Ramen and it's tasty.  The soup base is flavorful, but sometimes when I'm hungry I wish they gave more portions.

The old women that serves there (could be more than one) is awesome.  She's super friendly and happy and she'll even flirt with you - if that's your thang.  At first, I thought she was hiiiiiigh.  :)
author: Yup S.

description:
katana-ya is not a bad place to go. i have been here twice already and each time the lines were out the door. i mean the food was good but it's not really 'to die for.' the prices were mid-range as expected. however if you are an intense ramen noodle fan, i can see the allure; there are dozens and dozens of noodle bowls to choose from. 

make sure when you get to the restaurant and there is a wait, to immediately put your name on the clipboard. 

so basically, i would definitely come here again but it wouldn't be my first choice. it will most likely be because my asian-ramen-eating friends want to eat here. also, i probably wouldn't suggest this place for dinner to out of towners unless my guests are noodle-vores.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend on a cold rainy day, so a hot bowl of noodle soup was in order.  

People aren't kidding when they say this place is small.  It is squished and cramped to say the least.  Luckily, we got the seat to the right of the main door (you could say it was around the corner from the door), that had it's own separate-ish spot.  Like a nook.  It helped give us more leg room and also kept us from feeling the cold wind when people kept walking in & out to figure out how to put their name on the waiting list (I was one of those people).  

We ordered the miso green onion ramen and yakitori don.  The ramen noodles were long & had a nice firm texture, and the soup wasn't too salty (as it can often be).  The yakitori don was delich!  The chicken was moist, and there was a well balanced amount of sauce.  The rice wasn't too wet or dry.   To top if off, the price was cheap and the portions big.  

What's not to like?  Oh... well, maybe the creepy door that was the the right of us... that opened to the basement... that shot out a really really cold draft when the employees walked through.  Other than that tho, if I find myself in the area and hungry, i'm very likely to come here and eat.
author: Evelyn M.

description: Good ramen not really spicy to me. Huge portions. Could totally share if you don't have a huge appetite. decent price. About 15$ including tax. Pretty small. I wouldnt get the high density too thick for me and it take away from the flavors. But I would def go back again to satisfy my cravings. Sushi is pretty good so are the fried octopus! But one negative was that my soup didn't come out hot like how I like it. It was just kinda warm which does have an affect on the overall taste.
author: Lola S.

description:
service here was good. the food wasn't all that great. yelp fans gave great ratings and so did my friends who are from the bay. 

a girlfriend and i went to try it and ordered fried chicken ramen, mixed tempura, california rolls, and soba! nothing stood out to us. 

i'm sorry but ive tasted better. the place is quite small.
author: Lisa D.

description:
Like many others, I was pretty disappointed with my ramen at Katana-Ya. I expected so much for a 4 star 1000+ review ramen house. I think it probably should be a 3 star restaurant at best, but I gave it two stars to bring down the average (although I'm sure my rating did nothing to it!)

If this is truly the best Ramen in San Francisco, then San Francisco fails as a city! I've had better in LA and NY. 

Anyway, I got the Shoyu Ramen with extra Chashu. The waitress/kitchen got the order wrong, and I ended up with an extra spicy ramen. Had to send it back, and have them remake it. After finally getting my ramen, I felt the broth didn't distinguish itself from any other average ramen broth. Kind of a bland mix of pork broth and msg. My eating companion thought the gyoza and her ramen was just all right too. Probably won't be coming back here when I'm back in the city.
author: James W.

description:
Went here last night with a couple of friends for dindin after work. Didn't have to wait that long for table which was nice, but because the place is small, I can foresee having to wait longer if it wasn't for a slow Monday evening. 

We ordered the wakame salad to start and I had the BBQ pork ramen with miso. The ramen noodles were tasty and had a great texture to them with just the right amount of bite. I personally thought that the soup was a bit on the salty side, but then again I guess its supposed to be (and I have an aversion to too salty food anyway). 

My friend ordered the cilantro ramen and when it was served, his bowl had pork in it. He doesn't eat pork. Wait a minute.... didn't he order the cilantro ramen? eh, who knows what happend and whether you get pork with your cilantro ramen, he doesn't eat it, so can you please change it? The woman is confused and doesn't really know what to do. She takes it away and comes back ten minutes later (after my friend and I have already started to eat) with his bowl with vegetable based miso and ramen. 

So service wasn't on par, but the ramen was pretty good. Wish they offered grilled chicken or some other chicken with ramen instead of just fried chicken. I probably could have asked. 

I wonder if they do to go? Cause I would just buy the basic ramen and bring it home and add my own goodies.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
The shop itself is pretty small and dark.  Is that the trend in ramen shops in the city?   Ramen Underground looks the same.  Let me just start by saying I'm not a huge ramen fan.  But I do eat it alot, since my hubby is a big fan.  I think this place is pretty good. I would give this place a B+. 

What I like about this place is the non-ramen selections!  Ikura and uni don... yum yum yum!  It was a side order that came with the ramen.  I wish I could've just order that in a larger size and skip the ramen.
author: K W.

description: Food is really mediocre. Japanese owners and they have probably been at this establishment for a while. The service is ok, but it is a rather busy joint due to its proximity to union square. Also it is not the cleanest restaurant (table was sticky, carpet was soaked with dirt and oil, and the cutlery/plates/cups were not extremely clean).  I will not return and don't recommend anyone going. Much nicer and cleaner places elsewhere.
author: J P.

description:
I've been to this place about 5 times over the last couple of years. It's going to be difficult to write something that already hasn't been said since there's over 700 existing reviews, but I'm going to try. 

Ramen - above average. To be honest, I'm not crazy about the ramen outside of Japan but both Katana-Ya and Santa is a toss up, simply a matter of personal taste.  

Sushi - it's not the best sushi in SF but certainly above average in freshness and grade. 

What's great about Kantana-Ya is the fresh Sapporo Beer and large selection of dons. One of the best  is the Hokkai Don with Crab Meat, Salmon Roe, what more can some want! It can come as a combo with the Ramen, put a pair of chopsticks in it! It's on! 

Like any decent J-place, be prepared wait 30-45 mins. on a weekend evening. It's a cozy atmosphere, always some slow jam album. They play the whole album!
author: simon l.

description:
Wow, talk about a hole in the wall.  I say this in the nicest way!  After walking by Katana-Ya without blinking an eye we had to back-track a half block before we got to this cute little establishment.  I think this place seats 20-25 people at most ... it's dim and cozy, perfect for people who are on the run but want to warm up with a hot bowl of noodles. I know we annoyed our waitress by lagging on ordering and lingering longer than anticipated because we wanted to chat among friends, but she was really cool about it.  This place is really like a place you pop into for a quick bite to eat.  If you're on a date or looking to socialize or enjoy a leisurely slow-paced meal this place might not be the place for you.

Ramen, udon, and soba bowls are the specialty of the house.  There are numerous little combinations of meats and veggies that can be added to your noodles and even a combo bowl that gives you all three varieties of noodles and the ultimate medley of meats and tasty additions.  

Upon opening the menu I was a little disappointed since I was on a mission for intergallactic sushi omakase (but that is really MY fault, so I can't blame Katana-ya).  If I was in the mood for a mean bowl of tempura udon then this place would score five stars.

But sushi-wise, they are a three.  For the price it's good.  It's the kind of place I'd place to-go orders to on my way home from work so the hubs and I can watch Top Chef as soon as it comes on 7pm Eastern time (hehe).  So I'll compromise with myself and give them four stars since most diners come here for their noodles and not their hamachi sashimi.

P.S.  There is a surprisingly cute owl mural in the bathroom.  It'll remind you of the Tootsie Pop owl.  Hooty-hoooooooo!!! :)
author: Chris G.

description:
I'm a ramen newbie, but I thought this place was pretty darn decent. I liked the menu choices, and the sushi was serviceable. But obviously ramen is the main event here.

I had the fried chicken ramen, and I was initially disappointed because the broth looked rather plain and there was only 3 smallish pieces of fried chicken bobbing around. But I starting eating, and it changed my mind pretty quickly. I also ordered it without MSG, which they were more than happy to do.

The chicken was decent quality, but pretty well prepared. It was a little fatty, but the overall taste was good, if a little indulgent. The broth was "plain" for a reason. There wasn't much to it besides some chopped scallions and seaweed, but it was so packed with flavor, it didn't need much else.

And the noodles were the star of the show. These were no Top Ramen noodles. They were substantial and held the flavor of the broth well. There were just the right amount of chewiness, not mushy but not undercooked either. Just like baby bear's porridge, they were just right.
author: Jarrod B.

description:
Butter corn ramen with a hard boiled egg!

one star taken away for: greasiness 
 
one star taken away for: price... pricey pricey
author: Ivy S.

description: Hands down the best ramen that I've had thus far. I had the katana-ya ramen ($12.90) with miso broth and I paid extra ($1.40) to get it extra spicy. The katana-ya ramen comes with a little bit of everything, corn, seaweed, fried pot stickers, and fried chicken....the miso broth is very tasty. Everything blended we with each other and the noodles were just right. The portions are pretty big so for the price, I thought it was reasonable, especially for the quality. I highly recommend this place as I have dubbed this as my ramen spot whenever I'm in the city.
author: Leslie B.

description: I do Really like this place. Ive tried several different items and they were all good. There is usually a wait outside but it goes pretty fast. I usually get one of the combo meals.. The price is pretty ok
author: Ayana K.

description:
Mmm another good place to eat when I visit Union Square. My friend and I loved the noodle combination where you can choose between either their famous ramen, udon or soba....and pair it with various dishes (mostly rice dishes). I had the udon paired with salmon sashimi over rice and it was absolutely delicious. The udon was had a very good texture and the broth was flavorful. My friend's ramen and oyako-don were also excellent. 

They're super friendly and make sure your water is always filled. I'm glad that I discovered this small little gem just down the street from Union Square. Simple yet authentic Japanese food in the middle of the city =).
author: Chrys U.

description:
Comfort food transcends petty little things like politics & geography because my tummy is multicultural.  Sometimes I get cravings for ramen, usually after watching J-dorama but hey....  I've been pseudo-stalking Toro E's SF reviews because the foodie knows where it's at.  So after you've been savaged by a rogue dessert wine bottle, where do you want to go to lick your wounds?  The chummy little counter at Katana-ya hits the spot: friendly, quick, & you'll be so busy slurping up steaming hot ramen you'll forget all about that big fat bandage on your hand that makes people think you're wearing a maneki-neko costume.

Injured hubby, from now on to be known as Capt Hook, got the light miso broth BBQ pork ramen.  Can't imagine what the "rich" broth tastes like because this was pushing the oily factor, otherwise well seasoned without too much salt.  Delicious slightly chewy ramen [slurp!] with some greens to help cut through the impending food coma.  Since it was comfort food night, also got the katsudon which was just as it should be: breaded pork cutlet with green onions &savory egg custard over steaming rice & pickled ginger on the side to give your tastes buds a jolt every once in a while.  Just what a homesick tummy ordered.  Oh, & they have sweet potato shochu (imojochu) for any intestinal deglazing needs!

Like most places around here it's a small footprint but comes off cozy.  Shimmy in, put your name down on the clipboard & wait outside (there's no space inside) & they'll go out & call your name when they're ready for you.  Staff are nice & efficient.  The regulars are pretty friendly too even with the maneki neko pose.  That's Capt Hook to you, tho!
author: Cam T.

description:
Really? This is the best ramen in SF? Is this the same katana-ya that used to be on Judah/6th ave a few years ago? 

As far as "best ramen" goes, I don't know about that, I mean I thought it was good (I ate it all...kimchi ramen with salt broth) but I wasn't blown away by it. I'd order it again but I wouldn't go downtown just to eat it...it'd be more like going to union square to shop and THEN MAYBE deciding to eat here afterward. The chicken karaage was pretty nice though. 

At least it's next door to Colibri's (LOVE that place--I'd definitely go downtown just for their ceviche).
author: kristin e.

description:
Start of a new year! Time for resolutions to be made and for them to be broken! This year, I'm going to make a resolution I know I can keep and that's to conquer that list of 100 things you should eat in SF before you die. Although some have already been visited by chance, luck, and word of mouth, the quest begins with Katana-Ya. 

In all honesty, Katana-Ya was probably more of a 3.75 stars. I gave it the 4 stars for innovation and pairing uni with ramen. WTF? I've never had that before. 

The Setting: Small, cozy. Felt authentic.  Reminded me of the yakkatori strip on st. marks in NYC where pleasant memories were formed with pitchers of beer or one of the yakkitori bars in Japan. So 4 stars for the hole in the wall. 

The Service: Gave it a 3. The food came out slightly slower than hoped and I got ignored for tea refills by our waitress in a pretty much empty shop. To me, crappy service doesn't  bother me unless servers are pretentious a-holes or they lie about the integrity of what they serve. 

The food: Gave the ramen a 3 stars. I liked it but the ramen was tough in texture and lacking that bite of freshness that you taste when you eat fresh noodles. I actually preferred the miso broth over the soy sauce broth because it complemented the ramen better in my opinion. The soy sauce broth was really salty. 

The toppings on the ramen consisting of pork, fried chicken, corn, and potstickers really pushed the food worthy of 3.5 stars.  The bowl really was a melting pot of all comforts that I grew up with and eating them brought back fond memories. It is my belief that food is deemed good if it can bring you back to a happy time in your life. The toppings epitomized what comfort food should feel and taste like. 

What tipped it to a 4 stars was the use of uni and ikura don to complement my bowl of ramen. I was really wowed. the uni was pretty fresh and sweet to my surprise. I mean what kind of nigiri should i expect from a mom and pop ramen shop? The toro disappointed but the uni exceeded my expectations as well as my bowel half filled with ikura (a very healthy portion). 

Conclusion: On a night exhausted by drinking and dancing or a 40 degree rainy day in San Francisco, I'd definitely come to Katana-Ya for a feel of comfort.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Gotchisosamadeshta!

I went with my friend, Ritu's dish (spicy tofu) was stupid spicy.  I tried it and it made me cry joyous tears.  There were a lot of interesting looking oriental-asian folks there.  I had soy based soup with bbq pork... it was 90% as good as the ramen I ate in Yokohama, Japan... top notch.  Sorry no 5 stars here, my star ratings account for eateries across the globe.
author: Aaron S.

description:
SAAAAAAAAAAAAALLLLLTTTTTTT!!!!!

WOWOW I love hole-in-the-wall places! The portions are the size of yo' face, they don't skimp on noodles (but maybe a bit on vegetables and meat), and if you want spicy, you GET spicy! I ordered the spicy green onion ramen with salt broth and it was way dank. Next to try: butter corn ramen!! Don't be put off by the wait...just put your name down, go shop, and come back. Hopefully they won't have skipped you, like what happened to us. Be diligent...yes. 

Quite an eclectic little joint...and enjoy the tea. Or at least use it to warm your hands after standing outside in the wait!
author: Sony M.

description:
I've been here once before, but couldn't remeber how the experience was. So here I am back again, this time I brought a first time ramen eater with me! We wrote our name on the clipboard and waited our turn. We came at 8:00PM, right before a sudden rush of people came, which was great, because the place is pretty small. We waited about 30 minutes or so. 

I ordered the regular ramen with a light miso sauce. the first timer went for the whole sha-bang and ordered the Kayana-Ya ramen with a rich and spicy miso broth, which has everything in it! The food came out pretty quick, the first thing i did was taste the broth. My broth was yummy, and i tasted the other broth, also yummy with the spice in it but a bit too rich for me. I think the next time i go i will order the light and spicy miso broth. the noodles were great, i love bamboo shoots,seaweed, and the pork. Wish there was more pork though, but I guess the focus is more on the ramen noodles. The crazy SF weather creates a great ambiance for some great ramen!

Besides the food, the waitress's english was hard to understand and we were packed tight in there. Two ramen bowls for $23.90.


Consumed on 7/12/10
author: Nancy T.

description:
This place is great!  The wait was about 15 minutes, there was a bit of a line outside, but it was worth the wait.  The atmosphere of the restaurant is a little run down, and the tables are crowded.  (I really could care less about how many times the girl next to me was hit on last weekend.)  However, the food is good.  

If you're not from around SF and aren't familiar with the neighborhood - be wary of the man smokin' the ganja while spattering nonsense to himself in front of the restaurant while you wait outside in the cold, hoping he won't talk to you... or touch you.

My sister and I split the Spicy Salmon and Avocado roll, which came very quickly.  It tasted very fresh, and was great!  I would rate the sushi at a 5 outta 5.  I ordered the Spicy Tofu Ramen with Miso broth.  It was not as spicy as I had hoped, and for that reason - I'd only rate it at a 3.5 out of 5.  The ramen was good, but not great - I guess ramen is just ramen.  The service is OK.  Overall, I would definitely go back to try some more of their sushi, or have a bowl of ramen on a cold night like tonight, and recommend this place.  

Thanks for reading my review!
author: Christine Y.

description: Perfect little ramen house: delicious - and massive - bowls, at a great price.
author: Eric T.

description:
NOTE: I am a newb of Ramen because Ramen houses are not huge out in the East Coast. But I am appreciating it slowly.

Take-Aways: 
- This is the solid Ramen you eat when not in San Mateo/Foster City. 
- Rice dishes are surprisingly large for "Small," good bang-for-buck. 
- Place is a bit tiny, so expect the rowdiness. 
- You CANNOT take reservations, so prepare to wait outside in a line.
author: Abel L.

description:
Best Ramen ever! I love the Fried Chicken Ramen and the Spicy Tofu Ramen. The sushi too is nothing to sneeze at. There is usually a wait, specially on the weekends, but it's worth it if you have the patience. 
Highly recommend for all serious Ramen fans!
author: Liane N.

description:
My friends took me here last friday, and I'm already going back tonight (wed) with an out of towner. This is a fun hole-in-the wall place right by union square. We had a drink on the square waiting for the sun to go down, then walked over here for some good ramen. We went super early to avoid the line. If you have more than 4 people in your group you're probably in trouble.

I got the miso broth with veggie ramen (subbed soba noodles) and it was SO GOOD. I hear from my friends that the bbq pork is the way to go, and keep in mind that when they say spicy, they mean spicy (most of our group opted for medium). It's a HUGE portion and comes steaming hot, just how I like it. Fun, unique place to go downtown.
author: L C.

description:
The food here is delicious and can't imagine it being any better. The place opens really late... and closes somewhere past 2:00am. I've tried practically everything they have on the menu and the notable things I should list are:
Tuna Tataki, Agedashi Tofu, Spicy Miso Ramen (either rich or light broth).

The prices are great and very affordable. Although the dining area is quite small, it is well worth waiting in line for a quick meal.
author: Raymond L.

description: So-so.  The reviews made this place sound like it would rock my world.  But I guess I'm still looking for the west-coast version of Ippudo, and I expected a bit more from San Francisco.  Not bad, but wouldn't go back until I have tried at least a dozen more places.
author: Fabio G.

description: Broth issue seems to be fixed. If not, ask for a cup of hot water to dump in there.
author: Jim R.

description:
Stopped in this tiny spot for late night eats on a Friday night and they were packed.  We got seated right away since there was only two of us.  
We ordered beer and the glasses were kinda gross so we asked for new glasses and saw the waitress wiping off the new glasses - LOL.  I wasnt particularly bothered by it, but my boyfriend decided to drink straight from the bottle.
I ordered hamachi sashimi which was amazingly fresh, a salmon skin temaki - YUM and a soft shell crab, which was so-so.  The BF had fried checken ramen, a little spicy, which was actually super spicy, but really good.
They were fast and food was better than I expected so I would stop in again for a quick sushi or ramen craving
author: Jennifer C.

description:
The location of this place is in a very dense tourist area of Union Square,
so always expect a wait. The atmosphere is very small quaint. The ramen are pretty good (it's good ramen but not the best in SF and can be on the pricey side.)

2 bowls of ramen, an appetizer and a beer came out to $50 (tax and tips included.)
author: Tony N.

description: Best ramen in SF!  I always see people line up outside the store. Came here on a Saturday morning, tried Katana-Ya ramen in miso base soup. It comes in large bowel. The noddle is silky and chewy. The soup is very rich and flavorful. Not so fond of the toppings. Next time I will just order a regular ramen. Anyway, walked out store very satisfying.
author: Emmy P.

description:
Came here right when they opened for dinner, so no wait at all.

The server was very nice and attentive. I don't know if she was new, or what, but she seemed a little timid... Which wasn't a bad thing. 

Nothing super spectacular about Katana-Ya... but nothing horrible either. 

It's a cozy little restaurant.

They have good quality sushi. I ordered the chirashi. $18 for a lot of rice, and a moderate amount of sashimi. Only 1 piece of salmon, which is my favorite. Oh well. 

Their crispy roll (I think that's what it was called) was pretty good. Tempura, asparagus, avocado, and tempura crispies. Tasty yummy.
author: Cecille O.

description: The ramen is awesome, but sometimes if you get a combo meal the side dishes aren't as fresh as they should be.  I got a tonkatsu don on the side and the tonkatsu was cold...almost as if they premade it.
author: Jay K.

description:
There are two kinds of ramen: good ramen and booty ramen. Good ramen has some bite to it.  Dense.  Al dente.  It's also usually accompanied with several choices of broth (i.e. miso, shoyu, or shiro).  The broth is usually very rich, cloudy, and complex.  Good ramen is also usually served by an all Japanese wait staff.  Not that I believe for a second that in order to be fantastic, cuisine must be prepared and served by the people of its origin.  But I've never had good ramen served by anybody who wasn't Japanese.  So far, that's just the way it's been.  And it doesn't have to be expensive either.

Then there's booty ramen.  You may be thinking, "What's wrong with booty?  I love booty!"  But nobody likes ramen that tastes like booty.  Curly instant noodles, so light they're almost fluffy.  Broth that tastes like it came out of a packet.  Strange flavors that shouldn't be there.  And it's  usually served by Chinese people.  Not that I believe that Chinese people can't serve up a decent bowl of ramen.  So far, that's just the way it's been.

Katana-Ya serves good ramen.  I came here the other night for the first time.  It was a Friday night, and the wait kinda long.  The tables are tiny, and the dining area is small.  But it was still worth it.  Albeit with a few drawbacks.

I ordered the pork ramen with miso broth.  While the noodles and the broth were great, I wish there was more pork.  Two thin slices don't cut it.  My girlfriend has the chicken karage ramen.  5 chunks of savory, golden, deep fried chicken will make just about anything taste better.

Then there's the issue with eggs.  I ordered a hard-boiled egg.  My girlfriend ordered a hard-boiled egg.  My other friend didn't want an egg.  Somehow I got an egg, my girlfriend got two eggs, and my friend also got an egg.  Our waitress laughed and said she didn't know what happened,  which was totally cool since they didn't charge us four eggs.  And while the eggs were perfectly cooked (the yolk was a consistent yellow from the surface through the center), they were cold, most likely precooked and stored in the fridge and plopped in to order.  The inconsistency in temperature was a bit disappointing.

Nevertheless, this is still good ramen.  And while I haven't found that many places that serve good ramen in the Bay Area, the fact that Katana-Ya serves good ramen by Union Square, and is open 'til 1:15 is a blessing.  If you're in the area, or simply want to try some good ramen, order up a bowl at Katana-Ya.  If you want booty ramen, try Genki Ramen.
author: Tony L.

description:
This is a review of Katana-Ya's Ramen.

I went here with a couple of friends since I had been craving some good ramen and saw that this place had some pretty good reviews on Yelp. This place is not very big so there is always a line. The tables are also a bit tiny so be prepared to get really comfortable cozy with the person next to you. 

I got my Ramen with miso flavored broth and my friends each got the Shoyu flavor and Tonkatsu flavor. All in all, the Ramen was good. The noodles were the perfect amount of chewiness and the Ramen was a decent portion for the price that you pay. The only complaint I have is that it tasted like they had put a lot of msg in the broth and made it a bit too salty. My friends had the same complaint about their broth.

If I am ever in the area and craving Ramen again, I would definitely stop in to Katana-Ya!
author: Jessica S.

description:
The kimchee soy ramen was a pretty solid choice on a rainy Saturday afternoon.  But was it 1000+ reviews good?  I'm not convinced...but I'm willing to try again.  Especially since this rain won't let up.

My spoon also reached over to the house curry and unagi over fried rice.  Both also very solid.  The portions are quite generous for a Japanese place - and that gets high marks in my book.

I was shocked to see how quickly this place filled up minutes after opening and relieved that this did not much effect the wait for our food once ordered.  The waitress was notably attentive.  And although she looked kind of mean...it somehow worked for her.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I'm not a fan of ramen to begin with and I was hoping for Katana-Ya to change that.

What I ate was practically miso soup with ramen noodles on steroids.  The soup was oily and a bit overpriced.  I'd rather spend almost half as much for a bowl of pho.

I'd come back for sure, not definitely not for the ramen.  Maybe I'd skip the soba and udon too and try their curry.
author: Bruce M.

description: Pretty good ramen, but not great. I wasn't a fan of the potsticker or the fried chicken, and abandoned both after one bite. The broth, the noodles and veggies were all right.
author: Olivia P.

description: Came here for dinner on a Thursday night around 7:30ish.  Ended up waiting in a long line for about 30-45 minutes.  Place is small but very lively!  I ordered the katanaya ramen with the miso broth (which had everything from fried chicken to eggs to beef), spicy tuna rolls, and a glass of cold sapparo beer and it was very good!  Hubby LOVED LOVED LOVED it!  Overall, good eats at a cheap price.
author: Stella L.

description:
Sushi : Ordered sea urchin. It was fresh. Sushi rice was great. Gave orgasm in my mouth
Ramen : ok-ish. Broth is decent. The noodle is the kind that I love (Thick and chewy) but a little bit overcooked. Meat was not good. Way too salty and not tender
Service : It's not terrible but could be better. I waited for a long time to order because the waitress who (supposedly) wait my table decided to completely ignore me. Tried to order with another waiter but he just tried to get the waitress to get my order instead, which he failed to do so. I called them a few times before the guy gave up on getting the girl to get my order and called another waiter to do the job. 

Will probably go back to get more sushi when it's not their busy time.
author: Bobo V.

description:
Don't need to review too much as many have done so already, but last night really set the tone for all my extra spicey ramen experiences for the future.  My gf took me here almost two years ago, and I've been a fan ever since.

We both had the Fried Chicken Ramen, salted, extra spicy.  Initially, we were both taken aback by the heat (even coughing), but mind over matter was the key and before we knew it, the heat leveled off, and it was pure bliss.

To those who want a great bowl of ramen with great flavors, order this...highly recommended to all who also love spice.

btw: not as hot as proper Korean noodles though...that heat just keeps on attacking.

Please eat here, again!
author: felix c.

description: I've never been the type to go outside for a bowl of ramen because when I think of ramen, I think of the cheap, just add hot water packages. In addition, I've always been a bigger fan of pho. Lately, Ramen has been getting hyped up all over again, so now the quest begins for a good ramen spot. Somehow I avoided the long wait that everyone talks about and started off with Katana-ya Ramen Bowl, the thing I appreciated about this place was that my bowl was fully loaded, but at the price that it came at, it better be. I thought the overall soup was decent even if it should have been hotter, but it also felt like something I could have made with the packets at home with chicken, egg, corn etc. Also ordered the 49er roll which was disgusting because they put a lemon on top, not sure if they were trying to mask the taste of fish that probably isn't as fresh as it should be, but the lemon had to come off on my other pieces. Still, this spot did not change how I feel about Ramen
author: Limuel G.

description:
Katana-Ya has changed for the better. Bigger menu, more options. The ramen is great overall, and certainly one of the best within San Francisco. 

+ Wide selection of ramen. Including Negi, Kimchee, Extra Spicy, Karaage (fried chicken), and others. 

+ Choose Salt, Soy, or Miso broth. "Rich" or "Light" options as well.

+ Custom noodle options. Change anything to Soba or Udon instead.

+ Broader menu. Sushi is pretty decent and fresh. Other options including Katsu-don, Maguro-don bowls and the like.

+ Open surprisingly late.

- Small place, constantly packed.

- Service is always decent, never outstanding. "Ahem...more water?" "Ahem... Check please?"

My Top Ramen Joint Pick's: Himawari (San Mateo), Katana-ya.

Others: Suzu or Tanpopo (Japan Town), Hotei (9th and Irving). Suzu has great cold soba, hot soba, udon, and ramen. Hotei is best with udon and ramen, and the sushi is solid too, as it's from Ebisu.
author: Fran M.

description: Ok, I'm a simple ramen only eater and their ramen is good. But see the other reviews for more info. Tasty, affordable, and we didn't have to wait long to sit. It's crowded as heck in there with people crammed in like sardines. A bit squishy. At least the bathroom is spacious!
author: Gena U.

description:
I mourn for my old days of not having decent meals whenever I visited downtown San Francisco, and of thinking that there's no way I go to downtown to eat.

Just a couple of block from Powell-Geary, I found my new downtown's restaurant (saving Dottie for brunch).

Compact (careful for your elbows, dear) but since there were only 2 of us, we got seated pretty quickly.

Ordered fried chicken ramen in miso soup. So good!
Tab was $13 including tips. Cool!
author: Cliff T.

description: Decent hole in the wall japanese ramen noodle shop. The soba chicken soup was pretty tasty but I felt it was missing some kick to it. A little more spice would have enhanced the flavor. We also got the spicy tuna roll which was freakin SPICY but very fresh.
author: Alex G.

description: The ramen's good here and the service is good as well.  Unfortunately the quarters are cramped and there's probably going to be a wait most of the time.  A good place to escape to before, during, or after a jaunt around Union Sq.
author: Al C.

description:
Defeated and broken...
embarrased and shamed...
How do redeem myself?....

These are the thoughts running thorough my mind after I'm once again defeated publicly at Settlers of Catan. (jk, I just need an excuse to eat that late). So me and Joy A go to Katana-Ya for a hot bowl of ramen. Many plusses:

1. Centrally located on Geary.
2. Open late.
3. Reasonablly priced. 
4. Portions are very substancial.
5. Well ballance of taste; not too salty and not bland. 

I can only think of one thing on the wish list: expand and have more seating. The next time I was here, the seating took forever.
author: Angelo F.

description:
My new favorite ramen place!  Be aware that you may have to wait outside in the cold for a while for a table.  Even though it's a tiny place with mostly 2 - 4 person tables, the turn around is pretty fast.  

I was feeling quite greedy so i ordered the ramen with everything in it...the katana-ya special which includes corn, 1/2 hard boiled egg, 2 slices bbq pork, 2 pieces chicken karage, and 2 pieces gyoza.  

Everything was SO good but the only downfall is that my soup was filled with a thick layer of grease!  I would recommend next time asking for all the fried items on the side so 1) they stay crunchy as they should be and 2) you don't end up drinking a bowl of grease!
author: Tina L.

description:
My friend was cute, the sushi chef kept flirting with her, our sushi was made with love.

okay no, but seriously, the ramen? I've said this before and I'll say it again, GASTRONOMICAL.
author: Serena W.

description:
I liked this place a lot. The soup was really flavorful while not too salty. The wait is pretty long though and the place is super tiny.

I would only come here once in a while given the long wait and that there are other comparable places to eat around the area.
author: Linda J.

description:
On a cold rainy evening there's nothing better than a hot bowl of ramen. After reading numerous outstanding Yelp reviews I had to try this place. As expected the place is small and cozy. With limited seating there was a brief 10 minute wait for a party of 2. After being seated the menu exploration began. Rule of thumb, when looking for the best dish in the house order the one with the restaurants name on it (then ask the server). 

The Katanya ramen was basically of combination of most of the ramens. It included fried chicken (really good), 2 gyoza's (OK), seaweed, bamboo shoots, 2 slices of pork, (OK), half an egg, scallions, and corn (yummy). As suggested by the server the miso base was the way to go (choice of salt, miso, and I cant remember the last). The ramen itself was tender and delicious however the soup base could have been better. The bamboo overpowered the miso and became almost too "mustybambooish" its a real word I swear. 

As usual my eyes are significantly larger than my stomach so we decided to order the Alaskan sushi roll (shrimp tempura with yellow tail and avocado) as well. The roll was pretty good a 4 out of 5 star. Fresh, good rice to fish and shrimp ratio. Overall would order again. 

So, the recommendation is if you order the ramen I would go with the fried chicken ramen. From what I can tell the sushi is pretty good too. Not the best date place because of the wait and difficult street parking (expensive garage near by cab it if you can), but on a rainy day with a small party of 4 or less this is a good destination for major carbs.
author: Howard C.

description:
The excellence of the ramen at Katana-ya must be the worst-kept secret in San Francisco.  I see you nodding your heads in approval.  Why, even the yelp Japanese food experts like Nobu (http://www.yelp.com/biz/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw#hrid:WTHFCdhnwPWraj4pVdkSQg) and Toro (http://www.yelp.com/biz/F3bL-3Btko-JSupCC2pPAw#hrid:_FVBAT0bO6ACjkdMGiglLQ) think so.  

Do you want to know the BEST-KEPT secret in San Francisco?

I'm Japanese.

I know, I know, you're all shocked -- SHOCKED!  The scales have fallen from your eyes!  Ohhh -- TMI!  TMI!  I don't LOOK Japanese after all!  My Swedish features really threw you off, didn't it?  I mean, you were probably thinking that I'm about as Japanese as Douglas MacArthur.  

Well bitches, I live to disillusion others.  Truth be told, my drag name in college was Pearl Harbor, I'm yonsei (fourth generation), and let me tell you I look HOT like Gedde Watanabe (http://content.answers.com/main/content/wp/en/thumb/e/e1/180px-Sixteencandles.jpg) in my circular Tojo glasses -- especially when I'm bayoneting blonde babies and fucking over GM!!  Because that's what Japanese people do, RIGHT?!?  While, of course, slurping down some delicious ramen since I'm a multi-tasker.

So after some dude has slipped me the sausage -- after, that is, he's removed the gag from my mouth and untied the grosgrain ribbons that were binding my limbs --  I like to stumble down the hill at 11.30 pm, slide past the sketch, and walk into this tiny, narrow space with mirrors on the walls and a sweet staff of Japanese speakers.

I usually get the pork ramen in rich miso broth, though I also love the chicken karaage ramen in the same broth.  In both cases, the ramen has always been firm and chewy, the broth salty, and my angry, desperate soul comforted.  If I'm feeling like a real glutton, I'll get a noodle donburi combo and pair my ramen with a serving of curry rice.

Because I -- err I mean, we -- like curry, too.

4.5 stars
author: d s.

description:
Me: Whoa momma, you have got to taste this.
*bowls are exchanged*
Her: (in a slightly hushed revered tone) mmmm... that is so tasty. 
...
...
...
Me: Okay. Time to give it back. Seriously..... LISTEN WOMAN!! I AIN'T PLAYIN' WITH YOU! GIVE ME BACK MY RAMEN BEFORE I JUMP ACROSS THIS TABLE AND SHOW YOU THE BUSINESS SIDE OF MY HAND!!!
Her:...
Me: Daddy's sorry baby. You know I didn't mean any of it. It's the ramen. It makes me crazy and I just love you so much...

We stumbled into Katana Ya after a surprisingly cold morning of shopping in Union Square. I had the ramen and she, the udon. The dishes were hearty and fantastic. We both left rejuvenated and slightly warmer. Until the service is a little better and until the place isn't so dumpy or slightly dirty, Katana Ya gets 4 slurptastic stars.
author: Bucky K.

description:
So I had the best date last night.  

Attractive.  Witty.  Smart.  Funny.  Sexy as hell.  Basically the perfect package wrapped up with a pretty little bow.  

I couldn't peel my eyes away.  Pink, full lips.  Deep oceanic blue eyes.  Sandy blonde hair.  Too good to be true.

As we enjoyed our big bowls of noodles we rarely took our eyes of each other.  We both had Udon with Chicken in Light Broth.  Very good.  

The whole world seemed to melt away, and just when I started to dream of the babies, the minivans and the dog named Lucky a thick udon noodle slapped me in the face, and I realized that Katana-ya has too many mirrors.

God I'm fucking vain.  

Oh yea, Lauren and Sassy were there too.  But we didn't talk much.  Our reflections were far too mesmerizing.

I mean, come on.  Have you seen us?
author: Rachel G.

description: great menu for a small place. lots of parties ahead of us but the wait was not long at all. i'd definitely be back.
author: Lizzie B.

description: To me, this place is overrated. Now, I haven't tried Ramen Dojo. But I've tried the Ramen place in LA, forgot the name of it. Over priced & Overrated Ramen.  True, the Ramen is not like those top ramen texture. It's tender but not as good as the one in LA. Broth seems good in the beginning. After an hour or so, I felt really thirsty.   Place is so crowded and small. Couldn't eat comfortably. We paid $13 for their signature ramen which comes with 2 chashu,  one egg, 2 potsticker, & 2 chicken karage. I ordered the veggie ramen, which I liked but for $11 bucks?! The LA one has combos, 11-15 bucks (depending on what side you order) comes with Ramen & either sashimi over rice, pork belly over rice, & someothers which I forgot. My husband and I shared that one combo and we were soooo full! Not here. Not worth it at all!!!!!!
author: Alyce l.

description:
#5. Chasu ramen Big Eat SF (2009 & 2010)

VERY crowded on Saturday for lunch... you'll wait a good 20 min to sit 2 people and will be elbow to elbow with your neighbors!

Good Ramen, very hearty...not too salty, not too spicey... come hungry!
author: S V.

description:
Their broth is excellent.

Their noodles are perfect texture.

They offer free refills on your soda/ice tea!!!

The only downside is finding street parking, but it's worth it!

P.S. - My recommendation: BBQ pork in miso broth.
author: Nance W.

description:
My second visit to Katana-Ya was much better than my first - it was Friday evening, post DYL at Gold Dust Lounge and food was definitely in order. I invited myself along to grab some noodles and was quite pleased - my pork ramen was uber tasty and I tore through the huge bowl in no time. 

And service this time around was top notch...I'll gladly head back down to Katana-Ya next time I'm craving some noodley goodness!
author: phil h.

description:
I almost want to give them 3.5 stars because the service was really good and the food was good but not great.  Again, almost... but there was just something missing here, not exactly sure what.  Maybe it's because I do live in Southern California and to me, a top notch ramen place better be pretty darn good.

So of course, after reading all the reviews, I did get the ramen and again, it was good but not great.  Like that they give you options on how you want it and stuff but all good ramen joints do that.

Also had some sushi and again, was good but not great.  So if you're in the area and want a good Japanese place, I'd recommend but it's not going to blow your mind or anything.

Oh and yeah, really tiny place so maybe not a great place for bigger groups... I think our group of 6 was pushing the limits here.
author: Penn T.

description:
i've eaten here numerous times, yet i never reviewed. sinner.

first off, let me say that Katana-Ya was the first time I've ever had ramen, so it was quite mind blowing the first time. since then, i've tried numerous places, some good and some bad. katana-ya now just falls right in the middle.

the ramen is good, not great; i think i like the broth more than the noodles. the fish here is actually quite good. the combo meals are pretty well-priced. 

the fact that it closes at 1am gives it +1 star. konichi-wa bitches.
author: Sean L.

description:
Phil W. told me this is one of the better restaurants for ramen in the city.  He wasn't lying.  A solid 4 star restaurant.  Went here for lunch on Sunday with two of my friends .  It's in the heart of downtown and parking can be a pain in the ass if you are driving.

It's a very small restaurant.  Probably only holds 30 people max or 15 comfortably because this place is small.  If this place is packed, you will be rubbing elbows with other ppl..........which isn't really that bad unless you are claustrophobic

We had:

Fried Chicken shoyu ramen.  Chicken was moist and the ramen was great
Chicken Tonkatsu curry.....  My kind of curry for Japanese food
BBQ pork with miso and I added the extra spicy soup base.  It was more of a korean hot sauce.  It was good.  Wasn't too spicy for me but it hit the spot.  

Total bill was 35 dollars.  They have these lunch specials where if you were to pay a couple of dollars more you can add another side order.  I just wouldn't try the sushi here.
author: jason g.

description: This is probably one of the best ramen places I've tried in the bay area. Definitely worth the visit if you're in the area. I recommend the chasu ramen! I don't remember complaining about a single aspect of the bowl, kind of rare for me. Service was good, space was cramped but the best ramen places are like that!
author: Angie Q.

description:
Ahh... because one cannot survive day after hunger pangs on pho alone, God invented piping hot bowls of Japanese ramen.   

Katana-ya is located a few blocks from Union Square.  The small restaurant is kind of hidden and nestled in a busy block next to a Quizno's, but it isn't difficult to find.  What may be difficult is getting a table, as the restaurant seats no more than maybe 24 people comfortably and was packed during the lunch hour.  

We all ordered the Lunch Combination (priced between $10-12) which is a bowl of ramen, complete with all the fixings including a slice of pork, seaweed and bamboo shoots, and a side donburi of your choice.  My choice?  Tomago don, it was perfectly egg-y with the right amount of sauce.  But the Kimchee don was pretty darn perfect too.   

Like most Japanese restaurants, sushi is also served here.  But I recommend the ramen seeing how it's their specialty.  You have the option of three different broth flavors,.. shoyu, miso or salt.  And then whether you want it rich or light.  I went for miso light which was more than fatty enough for me.  But Alvin O. (with his amazing metabolism) ordered a miso rich.  I think he summed it up best when we finished our meals, "Dude, you know it's hella fatty when you don't even need Chapstick after you're done eating."
