Haha eww, but so yummy and satisfying at the same time.  

I know my arteries probably weren't happy with me, but my tummy sure was!  Yep yep..
author: Joan T.

description:
overrated unfortunately.  was recommended this place by a friend and my hubby and i went the last week of december while we were in town.  we showed up around 8pm and waited more than an hour to be bruskly given a menu and told to pick what we want before coming into be seated.  the host was also working tables so we was not in a nice mood.  he barely audibly shouted people's names out who were crowding in to hear if their table was ready outside.  we were seated at the bar near the cash register finally after being shouted at (with the rest of the crowd) by a surly beggar who decided to berate the waiting crowd about how "black people don't wait in line for raw fish" and then he saw me and said "ohpe, there's one, wait you're mixed, that doesn't count."  nice.  doesn't that make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside?  

i had the bbq pork ramen in medium spicy miso broth.  my hubby had the namesake ramen and we both got a maki roll just to try their sushi.  can definitely say that i've had much better and better rolled sushi.  the ramen was satisfying, but didn't blow my mind.  i do appreciate that they don't use the $.10 prepackaged noodles, but my bbq pork was nothing to write home about.  the portion size is great for the price and i can definitely see why people pack this place late at night after drinking, but i guess i don't understand waiting for more than an hour to get in while entirely sober.
author: Jen J.

description:
location:   halu
undisclosed yelper 1:   yeah man katanaya has gone downhill boss!
me: but what about those tasty, texturized, yummy, yellow noodles?
undisclosed yelper 2:   wtf?  you only go there for the cute waitresses anyways!!
me:   not really, but wako is a lil hawtie!!!!!!    riiiight(seong p  TM)??!!!!

2 hours later...
undisclosed yelper 3:   really tho, that katanya is like pre-packaged sh*t, all of my japanese-chef friends say the same(so he didn't really say this but i think you all know who i am talkin about)
me:   no effing way!!??
undisclosed yelper 1:   hell yah that shit is too fucking salty!!!!

3 hours later..
all: damn this is the fucking best ramen in SF!!!!!

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:  come to katanya for cute waitresses, owl paraphernalia and tasty noodles

for the best ramen in the city...GO TO HALU!!!!
http://www.yelp.com/biz/halu-san-francisco
author: omar b.

description:
There's no other place in the city that has ramen this late at night. Whether it's after a ballgame, after same late shopping, clubbing, or whatever your fancy, this is nice place to go to after.

If you're looking for Ramen similar to the ones in San mateo like Himawari, Santa Ramen, Ramen Dojo, or Ramen Parlor... or places in San Jose/Palo Alto like Halu Ramen or Orenchi, this is probably not the place for you.

The Ramen broth here is much more simple, but definitely hits the spot. Their simple salt favor ramen is my favorite. Although it may not cleanse your system like a good bowl of pho, it does a adequate job making your system feel good. I'm actually not a fan of all their other ramens cause I feel it's "just a bunch of toppings" thrown in together.

The size of their restaurant is both their draw and their setback. The small feel is the way a ramen place should be. This is how it's been in many places in Japan (at least from what I understand), where some places there's simply just a counter. That being said, it's terrible when it's crowded. so hard to get a seat!

All in all, the staff is pretty friendly, the food is good. (try their combos!) and it is by far the best ramen place in SF.
author: Robert L.

description: Getting over a hangover? You're at the right place! For some reason, Ramen always hits the spot. Whether or not it's amazing, it will always be a feel good food. That being said, I come here when I'm in the city and feel like a hot, brothy soup dish but don't feel like paying for Pho (b/c home made is always exponentially better). The line is never really THAT long of a wait. People are in and out within 30-45 minutes. Put your name down and try it. Order yourself a nice bowl of ramen with miso soup, extra spicy.  The bowl is about as big as your face, and we wouldn't want it any smaller.
author: Camille T.

description: very good ramen, the soup is very thick and big portion too. I normally have spicy kimchi and BBQ pork ramen,really good. Their spicy tofu is good too. I love this place.
author: Suabot J.

description:
I eat here more than I should be allowed to. The "Katana-Ya ramen", extra spicy, soy broth is my go-to ramen, but sometimes I'll come in and just order a large regular fried rice (not on the menu except for as a small side in the combos). The fried rice is inconsistent, but ranges from good to OMFG good. Order it enough times and you'll be able to tell a good rice day from a bad rice day. Some people "claim" my extra spicy ramen is too spicy. You might want to work up to extra spicy before diving in. Let the sliced pork soak as long as possible in the spicy broth and it becomes even better. 

The sushi is usually really good, but can very depending on who is itamae that day. The elderly itamae that is in most nights is my sign to order sushi on that visit. 

What don't I like about Katana-Ya? Well, as mentioned, the food quality can be inconsistent, but its never been bad. There is one waitress that works here that doesn't seem to know what Japanese food is and screws up my order each and every time. I avoid her whenever possible and keep hoping that the low tips I leave will encourage her to look for another career.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Narrow space, tiny tables, and a small sushi bar with only about 4 chairs.  The only thing that was HUGE in the place was our bellies after the tasty bowls of Ramen that were delicious! The soy and miso broth was incredible and the maki was fresh and delish. Everything that I tasted with Grace M and Joy A was really good and I would go back there anytime.

Thanks for the 411 on the place Grace!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
I wish I had something to compare my experience with Katana-Ya: I didn't have a grandmother who painstakingly took the time and effort  to brew the broth and strain the homemade miso or a mom who weaved fresh udon noodles from scratch or had a recipe that called for slowly simmering the pork to find it ultimately soft and tender.  Nope I didn't!

What I lacked in experience was quite evident  in the generous bowls of Chicken Udon Soup and Pork Miso Ramen Soup.  The broth was not too salty- balanced with the choice of miso (light- was just right for me).  The ramen noodles were slurpy-licious- and was not overcooked- the 4 slices of pork topping was tender and as flavorful as the broth.  The Chicken Udon- had a gelatinous consistency- smooth slippery that slurping was not only encouraged but expected:-)

PS- I've never been to a restaurant with wall to wall mirrors- but I think it only showed the  people enjoying the soup as much as I did!
author: Arissa C.

description:
After a few hours of shopping, my friend were famished, and had to get some good food fast. We decided on ramen, and headed wandered a few blocks over to Katana-ya. Tuesday night around 7pm did seem so bad, we only had to wait about 5 minutes. Small place, so there could always be a long line, so don't come starving because you might find yourself at the Jack-in-the-Box next door.

We ordered the Katana ramen, sunset roll, and some drinks. Maybe because I worked at a Japanese restaurant for four years, and lived on a steady diet of Top Ramen in college, but I thought the food was good, not great. I don't think the little potstickers was worth the 13 dollar price tag for a bowl of ramen, but maybe you will think it is worth it.

Service was good; lots of staff on hand.  Food came out quickly. I would give you 3.5 stars, but closer to 3 just because this place seems overhyped.
author: Brandon K.

description:
I was staring into the most shocking, Smurf-blue eye's I'd ever seen, trying to nonchalantly slurp my ramen without snotting into my bowl, as she gazed, ever so intently back at me. Our conversation flowed, her eyes never wandered, the soundtrack was unforgettable, the food was delectable and left me a little hot and bothered, if you know what I mean.

If you knew what I meant then you'd know I'm not referring to a super-successful lesbian date with a blue-eyed angel. You'd know that I'm really talking about sweating like a smoker on a treadmill as I slurped rich, meaty broth and spicy tofu and watched Rockell G. gaze at herself in the mirror over my shoulder.

Oh, and the unforgettable soundtrack, Lauren S. sitting next to me slurping noodles like a starving puppy and snotting almost as badly as I was.

P.S. I totally forgot to mention how unbelievably amazing the ramen was. Top Ramen was always my after-school snack back in the day (yes, I've always ate like that fat kid from "Bad Santa") and the packaged shit has nothing on this bowl of delicious, noodley, tofuy, brothy, dreamy goodness.
author: Sammy S.

description: Not worth the time, $$; very bland - don't understand how it got even three stars!  Save your money! The previous (negative) reviews are accurate!
author: Elliot I.

description:
This little piggy went to Katana-Ya
This little piggy sat at the bar
This little piggy ordered ramen rich with soy, bbq pork, and a salmon don buri
This little piggy ate it ALL
This little piggy's going zzzz zzzz zzzz when she gets home
author: Jill D.

description: Long wait (1 hour at 11 pm on Saturday) and bad service. Food was meh. We ordered the spicy tofu ramen and lo and behold there was kimchi in it. What?!  Totally not worth it. There are places with 100 reviews and 3 stars that taste better.
author: Adalia K.

description:
Maybe because it's been cold and rainy or because a lot of friends have been mentioning about this place. Either way, We had to go and check this place out.

It did not disappoint! We both had the katana ya ramen (friend chicken and fried pot stickers with other goodies). I had it with the salt light broth and the bf had it with soy. You can choose from salt, soy, or miso borths. The bowls are huge and very filling. The ramen is al dente like. Not too soft not and too chewy. Just PERFECT!
author: Irene L.

description:
I have finally found my Ramen heaven.

I have waded through Santa and Genki Ramen in the past, and finally battled thirty minutes of traffic with the St. Patrick's parade to get to this hole in the wall eatery.  I've managed to emerge victoriously against all odds at getting to this mecca.

Not as thick as Santa, and not as bland like Genki; Katana-Ya served spicy miso like I expected a great ramen house to deliver.  The ramen tasted fresh and my fried chicken was tender, even soaked in the soup!

I think what helped the experience was that the place was actually Japanese owned and serviced.  Either that or I was suffering from a hangover and haven't eaten in almost 24 hrs.  Yeah, maybe it was the hangover.
author: Alfred Y.

description: Order the Katana-Ya House Special.  Ramen w/ everything from the kitchen thrown in. Don't go during peak hours. The wait is rough.
author: Aaron I.

description:
Well, I'm not sick anymore.  Not like I think i was ever sick, well maybe sick in the head sick, but not cough cough sick....however, if i was, I'm not anymore.  The spicy tofu ramen went and took care of that by cleaning out my sinuses.  It was worth every napkin I used to wipe my nose, worth every tear that I shed, and worth the stares I got from my two lovely dinner dates, as well as what i had to see of myself in the mirror.  If you don't like to watch yourself eat...this place probably isn't the best choice for your dinner...the walls are lined with mirrors, and its everything you can do to STOP admiring yourself.  So, I just uglied myself up with a leaky nose and watery eyes, and I felt better than I had in a long time.  Fat, full and ready to party.

I don't know if i mentioned this anywhere in that review...but the ramen bowls are huge, delicious, and reasonably priced.  I'd most definitely come here again, but next time be aware that i wont be talking to my company...ill be talking at them through a mirror.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Katan-Ya hits all the marks for this class of Noodle shops:

-Great Ramen & Udon. 

-Excellent selection of combination plates including various permutations of sushi/ramen/katsu/udon, ad infinitum.

-Ingredients are fresh.

-Prices are excellent. 

-Open late - til 1:00 am and later most nights

-Location: walking distance to Union Square.

-5 Stars

**When the waitress saw I had quickly devoured my kontatsu and still looked hungry, she brought me an additional complimentary serving - saying I needed more because I'm a big guy.  Whoa.  5 stars X2.
author: Jack H.

description:
The Miso broth was was pretty tasty as well as the Kimchee Ramen but overall didn't have that great of an experience here. The service was super slow and not very friendly, our appetizer came out after our ramen and we never got one of the dishes we ordered. 

It just doesn't seem right to pay $10 for Ramen... when you can get 100 packs of instant ramen for the same price!
author: Thel D.

description:
The best bowl of ramen I've ever had was at a ramen house in San Jose's Japantown that was also called Katana-ya. The miso chashu (BBQ Pork) ramen was absolutely heavenly. When they closed a few years ago I was really sad and I haven't had a bowl ramen that could compare to it since (and believe me, I've been looking).

Enter San Francisco's Katana-ya. I have no idea if they are related to my fabled San Jose favorite (and neither did the waitress), but after reading Ed and Nobu's reviews a couple weeks ago, it immediately shot to the top of my priority list, and I've been craving it ever since. With all these five-star reviews, I just had see what it was all about.

After trekking over from the Conan O'Brien taping at the Orpheum, we arrived to an empty restaurant at around 5:30pm for an early dinner. We started with the Homemade King Crab Croquette and an order of Chicken Karaage. The croquettes were great; they were light and perfectly fried and paired with a side dish of katsu sauce...and I really love me some katsu sauce. The karaage was good but not great, and honestly, I've never found a karaage that I thought was completely satisfying. Well, a squeeze of lemon helped a lot, and so did dipping them in the katsu sauce!

I ordered my usual miso chashu ramen and my wife ordered the shoyu ramen. My ramen was really good, but it wasn't as good as I wanted it to be. The noodles were cooked perfectly, and the pork was great. The broth wasn't as rich as I'd hoped, but it was still pretty damn good. I tried my wife's shoyu broth, which I liked, but I'll stick to my miso broth. (For the record, my wife wanted her broth to be saltier.) 

The ramen here is also missing a key ingredient (at least for me) -- hard boiled egg. Bean sprouts aren't included either, which isn't a big issue for me as I don't care for them, but my wife really likes them in her ramen and noted that as a deficiency.

Overall, Katana-ya is great place for a bowl of ramen, but I think I found perfection years ago and it's going to be really hard to capture that magic again.

(sigh)
author: Arnold G.

description:
The first time I went to Katana-Ya, I didn't even know how to pronounce "Chashu" and the only ramen I'd ever had was the of the Smack and Maruchan varieties.  And now after probably a dozen trips here, I still can't get enough.  I dream about the umami-licious rich miso broth.  I wake up in the morning craving the thin slices of tender pork and the perfectly cooked noodles.  I even did research on the art and science of cooking my own authentic ramen (not easy).  You inspire me, KY.  

The place is tiny so you may find yourself waiting in the non-existent waiting area especially on weekend nights.  And service is truthfully not all that great.  Prices are pretty sold, though: a basic bowl of noodles is under $10.

This is also a place I love taking out-of-town guests who are around for a few days.  Take them somewhere iconic and/or fancy the first night, but go here the second.  It's no-frills, cheap, local and everyone should come to wash away their Cup-of-Noodle notion of what ramen noodles really are.
author: Eric S.

description:
4* for ramen, 2* for their Japanese entrees.

This restaurant serves delicious ramen, comparable to/better than many found in Japan.  There is a large selection of ramen, all come in two bases -- miso and shouyu and three levels of spiciness (costs extra).  The chicken karaage (deep fried chicken) is very tasty (this still strikes me as very weird), but I still prefer my traditional chaashuu (bbq pork) ramen with miso base.

Occasionally, the noodle are slightly undercooked, so I just let them soak in the hot broth a little longer, and that usually amends the issue.  I have recently learned that you could ask for a "kaedama" service, meaning additional boiled noodles in your remaining broth.  I have yet to try this.

I have also tried their oyakodon (chicken and egg over rice) and curry rice.  The chicken from the oyakodon was extremely dry, and some pieces of beef in the curry rice were cold.  In either case, I don't recommend ordering anything other than ramen.  If you are still hungry after one serving, say the magical words, "Sumimasen!  Kaedama onegaishimasu!"

This restaurant opens late every night, which has saved me more than one time (on the nights that Pearl's closed early).

(did you know yelp strips out non-ASCII characters?)
author: Bill T.

description:
I'm becoming a Katana-Ya regular without ever meaning to...

I can't tell if I'm a fan of Ramen or not, yet, but the extra spicy miso broth is now one of those things I can't go too many days without having. 

This could be a problem.
author: Jason R.

description: I will definitely go back - this place was delicious - it is tiny and parking is horrendous but it's worth it.  I had the Katanaya Ramen spicy and I couldn't stop eating it even thought I was full - yum num!
author: brittany g.

description:
Hoho. Can't believe I haven't write a review on this!

I LOVE this place.
My favorite is fried chicken ramen noodles. Gotta try this if you like noodles and fried chicken! Their sushi and rice dish is also delicious.

There maybe lines sometimes since the venue is compact, so be ready! It's a cozy place when you come during unpeak(is there such word?) time :)
author: Gabriele A.

description:
Stopped by here last night with a friend to grab a quick bite to eat before heading down to Market St. to see Wicked.

Service was way better than during my last visit here, possibly because we showed up pretty early and it was nowhere near as busy as last time.

The food was just as fab as during my last visit: I had an awesome maguro tataki salad ($10.50), with lots of good quality tuna and mesclun.  The futomaki was pricey at $7, but it was one of the most decadent, well-executed futomaki I had, filled with very nicely cooked eel and shrimp and some really good dashimaki tamago that was fluffy and subtle--most of the time dashimaki tamago is way too thick and sweet.

Still need to try out the ramen.  Next time!
author: James L.

description:
3.5 stars.

Husband and I went to Katana-ya after work on Friday. We arrived at 530pm and it was pretty much empty. Only one other customer.  Service was good. Non-bothersome and no nonsense.

Husband ordered the curry udon. I ordered, of course, the kimchi ramen with light miso broth. 

So, I thought my ramen was just ok. The noodles were a little tough/rubbery. Not a lot of toppings, very little bamboo shoots and very little kimchi. I had to ask the waitress for more kimchi, which she kindly brought over to us and did not charge us. I thought that was very nice. Husband liked the curry udon, but then again husband likes everything. I had a little sip of the curry udon broth and it tasted very rich and thick and curry-y. 

So, I had heard a lot of good things about Katana-ya, but, unfortunately it didn't pan out that way for me. I think perhaps it was an off evening? Maybe I've been spoiled by Santa Ramen? Maybe I ordered the least tasty thing on the menu? Or maybe my expectations were too high? In any event, I will try Katana-ya again soon and update my review. Maybe try the spicy tofu ramen next time. But for now 3.5 stars.
author: Caroline C.

description: Why do people like this place? It's crap! I think it's crap. My Japanese friends think it's crap. My friends who've lived in Japan think it's crap. My friends who have not lived in Japan think it's crap. Sorry but this is not good ramen. Grrrrrrrrrr!
author: Gregg T.

description:
broth thick, pungent and dreary....overwhelmingly porky..."rich"...tastebuds hinder....yet noodles fine..almost benign...fine.....ramen...udon..soba....choice...

freshness questionable....experience unsatisfactory....to mention "facts" be too traumatic....stray from fried....stick to basics...safest...ramen combo recommended..."only this and nothing more".....
author: Hen A.

description:
Hallelujah! I've finally found decent ramen in San Francisco!!!! Easily the best in the city.

I wasn't sure what to expect in this quirky teeny tiny hole-in-the-wall off of tourist trap Union Square, sandwiched between such quality (sarcasm, for the dense) eats as Jack in the Crack and King of Thai noodle. The interior looks a little shabby, but in a well loved pair of jeans that you've worn so many times that it's faded and slightly fringed kind of way. :P I noticed a cute owl motif. There was a drawing of an owl posted on the window, and I noticed the same owl drawn on the walls in the bathroom. They were playing reggae music, which sounds odd, but strangely enough, fits with the whole feel of the place.

The ramen comes in rich or light broth, with a choice of miso, shoyu, or salt. I went with the rich (always go for rich with ramen) shoyu. The boyfriend had rich miso. We both went for chashyu, but there were other viable options such as kim chee and chicken karaage.

The broth was excellent, filled with little chunks of flavorings, such as garlic and green onions. You know it's awesome when there's that yummy layer of oil, heh. It was full of flavor, as ramen broth should be, and totally "sippable" as my friend and fellow ramen connoisseur Horace K. would say.

The noodles were a perfect thickness and had the right chewiness. It reminds me of Santa Ramen's noodles.

The chashyu I wasn't as much of a fan of. I like my chashyu juicy and slightly fatty. (I know, oink oink.) The chasyu here is very lean, and a little drier than I'd like.

Service was fast and attentive. The waitress was very nice, and the food came out really quickly.

There was a very wide variety in the menu, not just ramen. I'm definitely going to go back and try more things.

Edit:

On a return trip, I found out the difference between light and rich broth is what they use as the base. Light = chicken. Rich = pork. Having tried both, I can't say there's that much of a difference, but I do prefer the rich broth more. Oh, and the chicken karaage was very good. :)
author: Bekki J.

description:
I like the ramen but the service made me want to leave even though I wanted some midnight ramen to take back to the hotel.  I would assume if you had two people who just wanted to place an order to go, and these two people were taking up the small walk way just waiting to order (the place isn't that big), wouldn't you simply rush over to take their order so they would get out of your face? I mean this in the most polite way possible because it just makes so much sense.

It took not one, not two, but three people who said "Yes, I'll take your order" to finally have the order taken.  I know it's busy and the staff is overwhelmed, but just because we're not sitting down to eat, we are still customers. 

Anyways, the ramen was pretty good but nothing over the top special.  We ordered the spicy tofu ramen.  It was flavorful but lacks soupiness that most ramen eaters enjoy.
author: Amanda L.

description: I used to come here a lot when I worked closer. This is a tiny little place so expect to wait during peek hours. Find a comfortable position when you sit because you'll be elbow to elbow with the table next to you. Food comes out pretty quickly here. I love their combos. I typically get the soy ramen with either tofu don or kimchi fried rice. This place really hits the spot on those cold SF days.
author: Adelina W.

description: It's tiny, so make sure you're sitting with people who don't mind being jab once in a while from a stray elbow. Also, you'll prob wait a bit before you get seated and I recommend looking at the menu and being ready to order ASAP. because the waitresses can get distracted. I felt just a bit jipped, but not too much. The broth was good, but their noodles were just ok. I wished that my dish had more toppings, but not even a sliver of fish cake in sight. Sadness. The shaved ice with green tea, red bean, and condensed milk was excellent, but I could prob make that at home. Over all its probably the best ramen you'll get in that area.
author: Theresa D.

description:
I saw a woman taking a photo of her bowl of ramen. I assume she's at home on her laptop Yelping Katana-Ya at this very moment. I don't blame her. I'm all giddy just talking about it.

I had the Spicy Tofu Ramen and it had to have been one of the best I've ever had. HUGE bowl that was the perfect amount of spiciness. My body determines if it's spicy enough depending on whether or not it makes my nose run. When I brought the soup spoon up to my mouth, I didn't know if I was drinking rich miso broth or runny boogers. I just kept on slurping and sniffling, slurping and sniffling. 

I tried some of the Katana-Ya Ramen which had a few deep-fried gyozas, a hard-boiled egg, vegetables, and some meat in it. A smaller bowl than the Spicy Tofu, but still tasted like a million bucks... or Yen. The Calamari was perfectly seasoned and salted and came with a little salad on the side. A little pricy for $7 and a tiny portion but at least it made me say, "Now THAT is calamari."

When I left, all that ramen was sloshing around in my belly and I think I went pee 5 times since. Next time I'll be sure to borrow my grandma's Depends just in case.
author: Jen Y.

description: Love love love this place.  The wait can sometimes be a killer outside, but the food is just fabulous.  I judge all ramen off of a hole in the wall place in Kauai, where the tires on my rental car come screeching to a halt after we pull away from the curb of the airport. (See review on Hamura's)  Katan-ya comes oh so close to eliciting the squeals of delight that I make when back on the islands.  The fried chicken ramen with soy base is wonderful and I particularly enjoy their spicy tofu ramen.  Prices are good for the amount that you get, and I hear their sushi is excellent as well.  This place is perfect on a cold night, which are numerous in SF, and I think I may go home and try to convince the husband to go here tonight.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I love this place and often make a special trip to eat here when in San Francisco. It's a hole in the wall with a line during rush meal times.  Eat at an off hour and you get a seat right away.  I really like the Ramen and was surprised by how much I liked the sushi as well!
author: Dennis K.

description:
Aaron I. swore by this place and dragged me out here last week for their, "Yo you need to try their Spicy Tofu Soup."  Out of the few times he's recommended a place, he was actually dead on.  Friendly staff that can get overwhelmed when they get crowded, but be patient because the food and the prices are worth it.  

About the soups... You get to choose between light or heavy broth, soy or miso base, then it comes down to ramen or udon noodles.  Make your choices and then add the words "Spicy Tofu" before you begin.  They have those crazy sushi rolls that in some cases I haven't seen before and sashimi you can trust regardless of what you think of the interior of Katana-Ya.  I'd pass on the oyster shooters, but I'd recommend the monk fish liver in ponzu sauce and grilled whole calamari.

For those that don't have time to sit down, they have a to go section filled with sushi and bento boxes.
author: Jason A.

description:
I have to add another star to my review.  Maybe because I haven't had good ramen for a while, and compared to everywhere else in SF, there are very few other choices for good ramen.  Still doesn't unseat Suzu for my personal favorite, but for "typical" ramen, I think of this place.

Drawback - it gets a lot of hype, which means crowds.  And it's a pretty touristy area which, again, means lots of crowds.
author: masa s.

description:
3.5 stars .

No joke, the ramen is pretty delicious... i've had the miso ramen, chashu ramen and the spicy tofu ramen (it's pretty much kimchi ramen w/ tofu in it) . all pretty good and definitely hit the spot!

why 3.5 stars?

well, I walked in all by my lonesome at 1:20pm, just wanted to grab a quick bite for lunch. Because I've been here several times, I knew that there was going to be a little bit of a wait. Sure enough, 10-minute wait, but I didn't really mind.

Now the older waitress at me at this little table by the window, then forgets about me... for 20 minutes. I was patient enough to not say anything, then when she finally walks over, she asked if the other waitress got my order. I said no, then she said, "ugh, she forgot..." ... um, no, YOU forgot.

So I ordered the spicy tofu ramen, and the three tables after me got their food before me...

yup, minus 1.5 stars for forgetfulness and mediocre service .
author: Lynn C.

description: Loved it so much that we wanted to go back the next day but there was a line. Why don't we have yummy varied ramen back east? Life beyond pork belly. I had spicy tofu with Miso and husband had fried chicken with soy broth.  Just trying to figure how to get back there while we are in town.
author: Margaret B.

description: This is the second Ramen house I've dined at since moving to the Bay Area.  I've had some pretty good bowls of Ramen at other places, but they were not Ramen houses.  I had high hopes coming to this place and I have to say; I was neither disappointed nor was I blown away.  The best part of the trip was hearing the a capella group outside the theatre as we waited for our names to be called.  The place was pretty clean but small.  I didn't care for the big pink and blue neon lights inside.  The broth was nice but lacked the richness and flavor I was hoping for.  The noodles were cooked well.  I just wasn't wowwed with the experience, but overall, it was aight.
author: Richie C.

description:
The four stages of eating Ramen at Katana-Ya:

1. Confusion: What the heck do I order? Miso broth? Light or dark soy? Pork? Chicken? Spicy tofu?? So many choices for such a simple dish (light soy is the best I've tried though). 
2. Acceptance: after you order, you know whatever combo you picked will be good.
3. Denial: You see the huge bowl and think there is no way you are going to finish it all. 
4. Guilt: after you polish of the entire thing, and drink the last drops of broth.

Definitely worth stopping in if you are near Union Square. It's tiny though so try not to go with large groups.
author: Rebecca H.

description: A-ok. I only had the sushi, but definitely didn't think it was all that special. If I was hungry, would I go in? Yes. Would I search it out and go out of my way to check it out? No.
author: Tami G.

description:
You know what?  I love Japanese food.  Almost as much as I love the three friends I shared my evening meal with tonight at Katana-Ya.

I had some assorted nigiri sushi - sake, maguro, hamachi and tai - and the rich, soy BBQ pork ramen.  It was excellent.  The ramen was hearty, the sushi was fresh, the company was amazing.

This meal - the company at the meal - was so necessary today.  Because I'm about to embark on a three-month adventure to the Midwest, where I simply KNOW (because that is where I grew up) that there will not be satisfactory sushi or ramen or Asian food of any variety.  Nor will there be Molly R, Drue C. or Ed M.

[Insert Kate-Pouty face here]

This meal was necessary.  These people are necessary.

I love Japanese food.  I love my friends.  I love San Francisco and am going to miss it every second I'm away.
author: Kate R.

description:
I finally found a late night place for sushi and ramen! Yeah!

Parking is a bitch around this neighborhood though - therefore take transit if possible - unless you want to pay for parking. 

The rolls are quite lovely - especially the spicy hamachi roll. Not too spicy, not too overly dressed. You can taste the quality of the fish.

The ramen noodles were just right. Not soggy and overly cooked. The soy sauce broth was tasty and not as salty as Suzu. Next time I'll get the miso broth. The katsu that comes with the katsu ramen is super juicy.

Got the red bean, green tea ice cream shaved ice dessert. The combo was delicious, but too sweet and the ice melted too fast. Next time I'll just get the green tea ice cream.
author: Judy L.

description:
Many great things going for this place.

They have amazing tasting ramen which you can choose soy, miso, salt flavored mild or bold. They have this amazing Katana-ya Ramen bowl that includes fried gyoza, fried chicken, and the pork. Yum! The noodles are boiled to perfection. And the broth I can slurp all the way down.

The sushi is beautifully prepared. We ordered the caterpillar roll which looked like a cute catterpillar with little sprout antennae.

They have nice sake/beer/wine selection. Ordered plum wine for the first time, and I now know what it tastes like--cherry cough syrup. Still a good experience though :) Thank you Katana-ya for popping my plum wine cherry.

Rather busy most of the time with line out the door, but that's how you know it's good. Kind of chilly at night, is the problem, but dress for the weather, persevere over the cold, and warm up to a nice beautiful bowl of ramen :)
author: Xavier G.

description: Very good rich miso broth...("rich" means it is a fattier broth).  Asked them to add a little heat...Excellent broth!  The noodles tasted weird to me.  I guess that's just how they are suppose to  taste ..Not my thing.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Brought the hubby here for an early dinner.  Luckily we only had to wait 5 minutes.  It's a very small restaurant so I wouldn't recommend it for a big group.  
I got the Katanaya ramen with soy flavor and everything but the kitchen sink.  It was definitely what I needed during a cold windy day.  The hubby got the 2 item combo of udon and uni ikura don.  He ordered another 4 pieces of uni nigiri.  He was a very happy fella.

Can't say anymore than what all the other reviews haven't already covered.  Katanaya is a little gem in the Tenderloin and I can't wait until i return.
author: Mel R.

description:
I'm going to give this place 4 stars because it's the only place that has ramen that actually TASTES like ramen. 

I have found my ramen house to satisfy those ever so often ramen cravings. 

WOOHOO!

I went there for dinner today got just the regular ramen and a side of gyoza = 16 and change including tip. 

Much better than paying 14 for crap at other places. 
I'm assuming lunch is a better deal 

I only wish I knew about this place sooner.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
1st time having ramen so I wasn't quite sure what to expect. They give you a lot of options as to how you want your ramen (strong, light, spicy, mild, type of broth, etc) so I liked that it's customizable. I ordered the Katana Ya Ramen bowl (the one with everything in it) and it was ok. 

Ordered sushi in addition to the ramen and again, it was alright. Service was great, place is small so it's hard to bring a big group there. Sake was good :)
author: Diana V.

description: Lady was rude & told us to wait outside in the cold, while her coworker said it was ok for us to sit at an unused table. Sushi was blah
author: Maria T.

description:
Katana-Ya for me was more of a Katana-Eh.

Don't get me wrong.  It wasn't a bad place, but it wasn't the best for me. Maybe cause I haven't been to many ramen houses nor do I find ramen to be anything special but food is food and I love to eat.

This place is a really cute small quaint ramen shop off Geary.  Very close to Union Square.  There are only a few tables so I'm assuming when this place gets crackin, you don't want to be left out waiting.  The hostess seated us very promptly and are very friendly. 

The menu itself had much to choose from.  It personally seems a little pricier but most Japanese restaurants are.  But I chose to go for something simple: soba and salmon don.  and my friend got ramen and tuna don.  both lunch specials.

The salmon don and tuna don came out first in little quaint bowls.  3 large slices of fish came with rice.  The fish seemed pretty fresh and the rice was delicious.  Midway through our bowl, the ramen and soba came out.  I had the impression that soba was cold but they served mine with a broth.  It seemed pretty general to me.  Ditto with my friends ramen that came with a slice of pork.  The noodles were made perfectly with the right tenderness and yea.  Unfortunately, the broth was eh.  It seemed kinda on the bland side.  Granted we got very simple ramen and soba. 

Maybe next time, if there is one, we shall try something that isn't so plain jane and maybe try the Spicy Tofu ramen or the kim chi ramen.
author: TJ S.

description:
I really don't want to say this... But, could anyone recommend one restaurant that's really good and not unreasonably expensive in San Francisco? There are numerous Ramen restaurants in the South Bay area that provide much better Ramen.

This one is just so so. Variety doesn't always make food taste better. We just want some Ramen with good taste broth, ENOUGH meat. Katana-Ya can't even meet these basic requirements.  

Don't order Combo. The combo makes you feel full by having something more, because Ramen itself is not enough for a meal . Again, simplicity is better.
author: June L.

description:
For a quick ramen fix, Katana-ya is the place to go in Union Square. Sure, you could head out to the Richmond District or Japantown, but why bother making the trek with Katana-ya is right here?

Miso ramen is my fave, and I usually up with the bbq pork, which most other ramen places refer to as Chashu. I'm sure the menu has been americanized due to it's location, but the food is still pretty authentic.
author: Annie T.

description:
Uhhh...WTF?

So, I woke up this morning with a big time yearning for soup noodles, ramen to be exact.  So I logged into the source, read the reviews and decided that I had to try Katana-Ya for myself.

We get there, and to my happy surprise we walk right in, 0 wait!!!  So far, so good...Then, I ordered my ramen flavored with shio, light broth with green onion, an order of chicken karaage as recommended by the many reviews here, and S.B. ordered the hot soba w/ veggie tempura.  The chicken karaage did not disappoint - crispy, hot and juicy,  the ramen was delicious - steaming hot, not too salty, noodles perfectly al dente, the soba was so-so - but that was not surprising considering this place is heavily reviewed for the ramen, and not the soba.  So at this point we are full and happy - good food, no wait, what more can you ask for?

Here comes the bad news...

As I noted earlier, I read previous reviews, so I was aware that this restaurant adds tip to the bill.  This doesn't bother me because I'm asian and I've been to countless asian restaurants where there is sketchy service so the tip is added on whether you like it or not (i.e. Koi Palace), but the food is so good that you deal with it and keep coming back anyway.  What I didn't expect was that they totally hide the fact they are adding the tip!  The receipt contained an itemized list of what we ordered w/ the individual costs of each item and then the just the total, they totally left off what the subtotal, amount for tax and additional amount of required tip!!!!  They probably cheat all unsuspecting customers with this cheap trick.

So bogus.  Too bad too, cuz the food was better than average overall, the service was good enough to warrant at least 20% tip without the cheat, and  I probably would have rated them a 4 otherwise...
author: Burrito M.

description: 3.5 stars. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing but I thought it was good but not that good.  I got the katana ya salt ramen rich. I think daikokuya and santoka in LA are better. I do think this is probably the best ramen in the bay area though. Will be back if I'm in the area. Came Sunday night and there was no wait.
author: Daniel N.

description:
We walked in late night, around 11pm, since we were craving for ramen.

Well, even for late night ramen, I would not go back here for ramen.
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
'I cant believe i ate the whole thing.'

Yes, every last broken piece of noodle, every drop of tasty broth. I've been looking for good ramen in SF and haven't had much luck over the years but the meal I had here could very possibly be the start of a beautiful friendship. (Thanks for the heads-up, Wakako U!)

Unassuming from the outside, I've probably walked by Katana-ya a dozen times without noticing the tell-tale Japanese red fabric awning with the Japanese word "ramen" right there! 

Huh? Wha? Where'djucomefrom??

Walked in and the first thing I saw was a marker board full of curly-casual Japanese handwriting with today's specials. Yep. Just like they do in Japan. This looks promising...

Glanced over the varied menu but I was on a mission for ramen so went straight to the chashyu (bbq pork) ramen in shiyo (salt) broth. Oh... and a side order of homemade gyoza since I was famished. Um... and a small Sapporo since I was thirsty. Perfect. The place wasn't too crowded on a Monday at 9:30pm so it took no more than 10 minutes for my meal to arrive. Now mind you, this was going to be my second bowl of noodles for the day (I had pho for lunch) but when I'm craving noodles, I'm CRAVING NOODLES and my attempt at noodle salvation earlier in the day was a serious letdown. I was not content and neither were my taste buds. So here I was, just 8 hours later at a different venue kicking off round two of the Jay Z "noodle-off."

Usually soups and broths from most places around town end up tasting somewhat bland to my palette, requiring the addition of whatever number of condiments, spices, herbs, and peppers to give my taste buds a kickstart but not this time.  The bowl smelled of light but flavorful hot broth with just the right amount of savory goodness (I want to say 'koubashi-sa') and salty kick - I was ready to eat! First slurp of soup, yum. First slurp and bite of noodle, yesssss. Ramen should have some 'bite' and texture (what the Italians call al dente) and shouldn't ever be pasty, starchy, gummy or slimy and Katana-ya delivered. The chashyu was rich with flavor as were the few slices of bamboo shoots that I lapped up.

I think this is my favorite ramen in San Francisco by far. And I've kept an eye out for decent ramen since moving here almost 10 years ago. I just didn't realize it would be so difficult. Only thing that keeps me from giving them 5 stars was the slightly disappointing gyoza, which although certainly looked homemade, tasted a bit too much of freshly chopped garlic. Don't get me wrong, I love garlic as much as the next guy but there's a savoriness (yes, I love that word) to food that comes from adding just the right amount of heated garlic that can't be beat. Unfortunately the taste of this gyoza was overpowered by the sheer raw-ness of garlic as if the flavors hadn't fused together in the mixture quite yet.  I'll give it another try it next time - hopefully it was just this batch.

So... yes, I finished every last drop of that bowl of shiyo ramen. The bottom of the bowl stared back at me and I grinned, totally satiated. 

And what of that bowl of pho from lunchtime? Oh, that was so "earlier-this-afternoon" it wasn't even in the same league.
author: Jay Z.

description:
I say 3.5 stars. The parking is bad, its cramped quarters and its in the freakin' Tenderlion. Ack, but nonetheless, I'll venture anywhere for good food.

The ramen (Miso) I had was not too bad. The flavor was good, not overwhelming, but very greasy. The boy had a chicken teriyaki which was mediocre as well. 

Service was alright. They were fast and efficient. All in all, an "alright" meal. I'll definetly go back with the hopes of finding my holy grail of dishes although I'd only go if I were in the area. I wouldn't make a special trip out to the Tenderlion for this place.
author: Shawn S.

description: I never thought much of ramen until I came here. I've come back quite a few times afterwards. The Katana-Ya ramen with spicy miso broth is the go to ramen. Such good toppings, noodles, and broth all in one bowl. You might think that all of the toppings will over power the broth, but it all complements it so well! One amazing thing is the chicken is still crispy in the soup.... yum.. Yes it is $12 and yes it does have a long line. But it's all worth it. You just got to try it for yourself.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Arriving at 12:15 for lunch, the four of us waited outside for a table for about 15 minutes.  I was excited to try the ramen that I have heard raves about.  I am basically a junkie for anything brothy with noodles. 

It pains me to write this but I was a little underwhelmed.  I ordered the combination of ramen with soy broth and pork and the 4 piece nigiri.  The sushi was surprisingly good and left me wanting more.  The ramen...  well the noodles were nice and chewey but the broth was too salty and very strong.  I tried my friend's miso broth and thought it was better than the soy broth - less salty.  

I still think the place offers a good value and I will be coming back for my ramen or sushi fix - it is quite close to work and it is a nice lunch option for the area.  Who knows?  These reviews are never set in stone.
author: mia s.

description:
be aware of the wait time!!!  the restaurant itself is extremely small with very small tables.  there isn't even room in the restaurant for people to wait.  so when you get there, be sure to sign the sheet and expect to stand outside along with everyone else waiting for their name to be called.

within walking distance from union square, this is a really great place to warm up after a day of serious shopping and if you don't mind a wait.  i ordered the katana-ya ramen which to me, was HUGE and i couldn't finish it.  it was chock full of corn, bbq pork, fried chicken, potstickers.  i am a big fan of that deep fried chicken- sooooooo good.  i really appreciate the variety of meats and the perfect texture of the noodles.  the broth is a cut above other places in sf, but it doesn't beat the miso broths in japan.  

after our bowls of ramen, there was no way we could fit any other food in my stomachs so i'm disappointed about that, but that's totally my fault and not theirs :)  next time!
author: Irene W.

description:
my first time here and i think my cousin hyped it up too much for me

i got the bbq pork w/ light miso soup

the broth was good. but there was nothing but a few pieces of seaweed and bamboo shoots.  i was hoping for a bit more veggies like corn or something for the price. 

parking sucks especially with the construction on stockton
author: JUDY L.

description:
This is a good, but small place to grab a hot bowl of ramen a stone's throw away from Union Square.

I'm not sure how my friends got a table for 6, but it seemed like we took up half the restaurant. I ordered the fried chicken ramen with miso broth, which was basically chicken karaage with ramen. Pretty good, although you really do need to eat the chicken first before the fried part gets too soggy.

The ramen and miso broth were both pretty good, although the broth seemed a bit too oily, so I didn't bother to drink all of it up. I'm a bit partial to Ryowa and Maruichi in MTV, but Katana-Ya would be a good option for ramen in SF, esp since it's near Union Square.

Service was pretty good, prices reasonable, and we stayed a bit to chat since one of our friends is in town for a rotation at a local hospital. Even though there were people waiting outside, we weren't once asked to leave, which was cool. We didn't stay too long though, but long enough for each of us to serially use the bathroom. lol!

There's a single bathroom in the way back. It's clean and tidy. :)
author: Kenny J.

description:
I like that they have combo meals where you can get ramen (with broth of your choice) and another item (a small bowl of either: tonkatsu, katsu-don, salmon sashimi don, tuna sashimi don, fried rice, gyoza, tempura-don... that's all I can remember for now. There were more items but I forgot) for $10.50. Not bad compared to other ramen restaurants in the bay area. I ordered miso ramen with katsu-don bowl. 

The ramen noodles were delicious but the miso broth was not what I was expecting. I arrived there around 4:15 pm, which is probably a weird time so maybe that's why the broth wasn't that tasty. It tasted like the bamboo shoots had sat in the broth for a long time. Another disappointment was that you only get one piece of pork, which was thinly cut. Next time, I will try to come at a normal time.
author: becky s.

description:
Luckily, living within a block of this place almost makes up for the police sirens, vagrants, and even the douchebag partiers at the Clift. 

Their ramen has to be in the top tier in SF, but their soba is better- I'm not sure if that's becuase I don't know any better or what. Only criticism is that the soup is a little heavy. Goes with Haku-Tsuru sake (in the blue bottle- yes I know it's $5 in the Chinese markets, but i say they earned the markup ). Very good sushi- i feel like you can usually judge a good sushi place by their saba, and it's one of the few places in the city where it's not messed up and tastes like a fishy rubber. Kind of crowded sometimes, but it's open late. Even their kimchi is good, and none of the staff as far as i can tell are korean. 

My sister visiting from NYC freaked out when she saw Ichiro eating here then like 30 minutes later Johjima (the mariners catcher) came in. i'm not sure what that means but if famous japanese guys will brave the downtown area (and the douchebags), it's definitely an endorsement of some kind.

Not sure about Scarlett's comment since in the years i've been coming here a few years ago everyone's been Japanese including their former sushi chef who i've known for 7 years...
author: Edward P.

description:
Thank you for being the only ramen place I know of that is open past 11pm!! On my last day of the week, I liking come here for my favorite extra spicy miso ramen with an order of sushi (which is surprising quite fresh at this hour) and my lemon sour.   It's also a very good sign that there are Japanese staff here.  

Bring back memories of my Tokyo trip recently...the ramen isn't as good as the one I had in Tokyo but it is pretty damn close.
author: Chris C.

description:
(This review is for the ramen only.)

Yet another mediocre ramen joint in the city. I think people who post on Yelp have a bad habit of handicapping their ratings to the tune of "not bad for San Francisco/Bay Area" because of the relative lameness of most restaurants that serve up ramen here (It's either that or they have no clue about what good ramen should be).

Well, screw that I say. Mediocre food doesn't deserve accolades.

Tried the shio (assari/light), shoyu (assari), shio (kotteri/heavy) broths in a negi ramen version.

First, the soup. While I could appreciate the tonkotsu base, the soup was oily in a bad way in both the assari and kotteri versions of the soup. While tonkotsu style broth is usually pretty hearty in nature, I think the kitchen is trying to use fat to compensate for flavor. There was essentially an oil slick on the top of the ramen.

I felt the shoyu soup tasted better than the shio soup, which I found to be really salty. Yes, ramen ain't supposed to be health food, but I thought the sodium content of the shio soup to be over the top.

Next, the noodles. Garden variety egg noodles. A little over al dente, which made the noodles a bit mushy. Maybe you can ask the waitstaff to have your noodles cooked so that it's harder.

Lastly, the fixin's. Regulation issue char-siu, thinly sliced. No menma, just some wakame. WTF is up with that? And the negi. Let me tell ya, that really put the last nail on the coffin for me.

I've eaten negi ramen in various parts of Japan (Kanto, Kansai, Kyushu), and the negi here at Katanaya sucked hard. Their idea of spicy negi was flaccid, flabby green onions sliced at about one inch intervals perpendicular to its length and tossed with what seemed like a mixture of sesame oil, chili garlic sauce, and/or sriracha.

A proper execution of negi ramen should have the white, thick cylindrical part of the negi cut obliquely across it's length to form long slices of concentric circles. The resulting negi should be tossed in some type of dressing, typically containing sesame oil (or chili sesame oil/la-yu) and some type of red chili preparation. The resulting freshly prepared negi topping should be placed on top of the ramen and NEVER cooked with it so that it retains its crisp, oniony, spicy goodness.

Okay, rant over.

Service was otherwise perfunctory. A young, genial Japanese guy tried his best to be "genki." Nice chap. There was also a young Japanese waitress who helped the young guy at the end, but she was obviously at the end of her shift and couldn't give a rats ass about mustering up even a fake smile. Kind of threw us the check and gave us our change.

If I were to handicap this place, it's just hunky-dory for hipster folk who just care about chowing down some fatty, salty food after a night of binge drinking in the 'Loin or something along those lines.

Hell, if you're drunk, your taste buds will be dead anyway so you might as well score some "gourmet" burgers at Jack in the Box (mmm Ciabatta Burgers!) just around the corner or a steaming bowl of Thai beef soup noodles at King of Thai Noodles next door.
author: Bono B.

description:
Having drooled all over Toro E's avatar for weeks, and avoiding Daikokuya in Little Tokyo a couple weeks ago because a couple of people warned me about their Ajinomoto induced comas, I was needing a fix in the worst way and ready to find a vein to take intravenously. My co-worker and I came here at 4pm, taking advantage of our short Fridays in the summer....we were only the 2nd table. We had the Miso Ramen with the rich broth....Cha Siu pork, marinated bamboo shoots and green onions and chewy Ramen noodles...perfection.

Update:  recently had the Cold Ramen...lots of veggies, marinated bamboo shoots, ginger, and had a good flavor, but missing the tang I'm used to....the real stars are the Gyoza....amazing!!!  thin outer skin that is so crisp....MMmmm, MMmmm, MMmmm!!!
author: Arlene C.

description:
I can't remember what it is called (rose roll?) but it is salmon, seaweed, rice, tuna, & tobiko. I had it after eating my fill of some equally lovely sushi simply because the couple next to me had it. So of course I needed to order it.

Kids, it's a rare day I will literally make myself nearly sick off sushi. Partly because it is one of the few foods I can eat when trying to lose weight & still feel satisfied but mostly because it is too expensive.

But the rose roll, or whatever it is, is dangerous. I could stuff my face with that all day.

Minus one star because at that same visit they took my order down wrong and charged me for it. Granted I ATE it but that isn't the point! I wanted something else! But shoot. I'll come back for the salmon wrapped in love any day.
author: Alexis B.

description:
After so much arm-twisting and promises that I won't pay a dime for my next dinner, I finally tried this ramen house in downtown SF. I was very hesitant at first, disturbed actually with my friend's fascination about their ramen noodles. I was contented with my .25 cent a pack Top Ramen. But then, there is ramen noodle and there is Katanaya ramen noodles.

One word to describe it: APRODHISIAC

You can choose your broth and combo (you can do without the combo, too). And the bowl is huge... and I mean HUGE! I can drown in it. No such thing as regular, medium and large like in PHO. 
Place was kinda small, but with strategically placed mirrors it was okay. Nice-servers (and cute, too!) who provided excellent service. Parking, uhh, it's in SF downtown so be ready to park in a 2-dollar per hour garage and walk 8 blocks, but heck who cares, it's worth it! Btw, I recommend you guys to just take the BART/Muni. Overall, I give it four stars!
author: Richelle Mae R.

description:
What's the day after Black Friday, Brown Saturday?  I'm still shopping for fancy axx clothes and shoes, and watches even.  I conned my brother into going by telling him we're trying a good ramen joint in the City.

Okay my bro ain't that stupid... we're twins after all, same DNA.  But he's all for humoring me with my new passion for fashion.  I promised myself I am not reviewing Yet Another Shopping Mall, so this is for the ramen joint... KATANA YA RAMEN yeah!

There was a line outside.  I walked in and asked how long the wait was.  The waitress says how many?  2?  Then sat us right down.  Later while looking at the menu, another gal asks if we put our name on the list.  Nope sorry.

Well don't know if it was language barrier or my natural charm and charisma, but we got to eat with no line... woohoo.  The shoyu ramen was good, nice chewy noodles and flavorful broth.  My bro got the super high octane shoyu broth and it was even more flavorful.  Two thumbs up for the ramen.

The homemade gyoza was loaded with garlic, probably killed all the draculas in a 10 mile radius.  The chicken karaage was good fried chicken but really didn't have that nice marinade flavor action going on.

But who cares, we came to shop, I mean eat ramen.  And it was darn good on this Brown Saturday.
author: Bryan K.

description: I came here to try the infamous chasu ramen that is on the 7x7 list. Since I've had Izakaya Sozai's ramen, that was what I was going to compare Katana-Ya to. I'm not typically a ramen person, but I think I can tell when ramen is good. This one was okay. I think the chasu meat itself was pretty flavorful, but I definitely did not like the noodles. The broth was good but not that amazing. So overall, it was just alright. I was pretty disappointed. Also, the service wasn't that great--not attentive enough. I also didn't like how crowded it was. It was a little awkward sitting at a table right next to the register, and very close to the next table. We could all hear each other intimately. Not sure if this should be on the 7x7 list again...
author: Vera W.

description:
I live within walking distance so I have gone here a few times. It is pretty good, but it does not blow my socks off. I would not take an out of town guest here, or proclaim it best food in the city. The atmosphere is casual, nothing spectacular. 

The ramen is the clear highlight of the menu, although the basic offerings will not disappoint. The fact that I cannot even remember what I order besides ramen should be an indication that this place lacks the wow-factor.

Mehhh?
author: Emmy L.

description:
DO NOT come here.  The people did not treat us well.  We waited an hour in line, and when we were finally seated, there was not enough room for us.  There were 5 of us, and we were seated at a table that could fit 3 at most.  They wouldn't let us link a small table to ours until we were adamant about it.  THEN, after we had already ordered, they said that they were going to charge us 20 percent gratuity.  Wtf???  When we got our bill, they charged us 23 percent.  

Who rated this best ramen in SF?  I've been all over Tokyo, and this place would not last a day in Japan.  They would go out of business with their mediocre quality.  The food was very so-so.  I don't understand why this place is so crowded.  Probably because it is so small, it gives the illusion that the place may be very good.  

Also, we saw the owner whispering to the cook, so I think they may have spit in our food.
author: Natasha L.

description: The fried rice is revolutionary. Normally fried rice is nothing special, but here it is incredible! They also have spectacular Udon, Fried Chicken, and Sukiyaki Don. I do not really like the ramen, I think that all of the different broths taste like dirt, but the noodles are great!
author: Emily M.

description:
This is the first time I've ever had ramen so I don't have much to compare it to unless you count those instant ramen noodles you cook yourself.  I ordered the Kayanaya miso ramen, and have to agree with everyone else who said it was really good.  It's a big expensive bowl, but it's got a lot of different stuff going on with it (pork, chicken, half an egg, corn, potstickers....very interesting).  Even though it's a big bowl, I didn't think it was impossible to finish because I didn't drink all the broth (which is really the most filling part of the meal because there's so much of it). 

Other than that, the servers are nice.  I often walk past this place and there's a huge line going out the door (it's a very small restaurant).  It was good, but I'm not sure I would ever wait in a long line to eat here. 

Time to go pass out now.
author: Michelle N.

description:
I got wind of this Katana-ya through reviews on Yelp. I love ramen, and when I heard about this place, I thought to myself, "Could this be the same Katana-ya that was in the Sunset?" I made a point to find out, and the answer is both yes and no.

The story, as I was told by the waitress at the store, is that the ownership of this place is indeed the same as the old Katana-ya that was in Inner Sunset years ago. The restaurant is apparently a "chain" and has another location on East Bay. The reason that Katana-ya disappeared for a while was due to move and contract negotiations, which actually even involved the space that is now Naan & Curry.

The menu is quite different from what I remembered of it. There is a lot more sushi than before, whereas the previous menu during the Sunset days were more focused on noodles and rice dishes. Also, the ramen is a bit more greasy than before, with one pork slice instead of 2-3, without egg or bean sprouts (as it did before).

That said, I would still totally come here again. My husband ordered the katsu curry. It is smaller than before but still very good. The price is also pretty reasonable and since it is right by the theater as well as Union Square shopping.
author: Irene S.

description:
I think this place is overrated. 10 bucks for BBQ pork ramen that was mostly fat? And the miso ramen was pretty salty as well.

For 2 bowls of ramen and a "home made" gyoza, we paid 30 bucks, and the automatically add the tip. How deserving....

The ramen at Oyaji is much better than this - 

Cute waitresses, I maybe back for that...maybe
author: B H.

description:
I love ramen and gyoza. There was a really great Sapporo style ramen place near my house where I grew up. My mom took me there occasionally. I can still remember the browned walls of the restaurant and the smoke from their heavenly gyoza frying in the wok. And the row of Japanese salary-men sitting at the counter alone, slurping away their ramen as if it was their last meal on earth. That was my ramen initiation at the tender age of 3 or so. 

Ramen & gyoza have a special place in my heart.

Anyhoo....so the ramen at Katana-Ya is not horrible. But it's just OK. And the gyoza is just OK. I did not get to experience the euphoria that many people seem to experience at Katana-Ya.

It's just a little step above Tanpopo, I think...
author: Aya C.

description: I come to Katana-Ya for their ramen and most of the time overlook all the other dishes on their menu. The noodles itself is what makes this place worth waiting for (since this tiny place only holds about 20ish seats, there is usually a wait during peak dinner hours). I enjoy their miso broth option over the soy sauce broth. This isn't the best ramen place I've eaten, but it's one of the consistantly good ones I've had in SF.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Katanaya is a new Japanese place on Geary between Mason and Taylor.  The sign has been up for awhile, and they finally opened a week or two ago.

The menu is pretty standard Japanese lunch fare.  They haven't started offering sushi at lunch yet, so I couldn't try that.  I did try the noodle and domburi combo with udon, and tonkatsu domburi.  The udon was perfectly done, and the broth was tasty, if a little bland.  The tonkatsu tasted good, and the breading was nice and crispy.   The meat was a good texture -- no gristle.  Sometimes I don't like domburi sauce that much, but the sauce served here was perfect.  

Service was friendly and very attentive.

The menu is pretty large, so I will definitely be back, working my way through more of the dishes.  It's a good neighborhood restaurant.  I wouldn't go across town for it, but if you work or live nearby, it's an excellent choice.
author: J S.

description:
Katana-YES PLEASE!  They serve some solid ramen here for reasonable prices, and they have a great lunch deal if you can make it out.  Hot soup and perfectly chewy  noodles are excellent on a cold day.

I'd say this place is up there with Santa Ramen in San Mateo and Ryowa Ramen in Mountain View.  Yes, I'm a Rameniac, and it's my life goal to find the best ramen in the western hemisphere....Looks like I'm well on my way!

Minus a star for being on the tinier side of things.
author: Kira K.

description:
i've given this place many chances to kick some ramen ass but it always disappoints.

i always leave with a somewhat upset stomach. makes me wonder what they put in the soups.  one guess would be MSG cuz i'm usually parched for a few hours afterwards. 

all of this AND there's usually a wait.  sometimes up to 20-30 minutes. makes me wonder who all is coming here...late night bar crowd? tourists? bridge and tunnelers? ppl who can't find izakaya sozai? (now they've got a ramen that kicks ass. it's just one flavor though, no choices there)

no more katana-ya for me.
author: Jill L.

description:
I have been dying to try this Ramen joint for awhile. I've had it bookmarked for over a year actually. I just always forget about it when I'm around Union Square. I usually just end up settling for lunch in the Westfield food court or at Wolfgang Puck's at Macy's Cellar. But one cold December night when I was meeting up my friend & her BF who were in town visiting, I decided this would be the perfect opportunity to check out this notorious establishment.

30 minute wait for a table later.... I ordered the Miso broth Ramen with BBQ pork. It was JUST okkkkay.... BBQ pork as a bit too "porky" for my taste. Not sure if that makes sense. But because of this.. I couldn't taste anything else in my bowl. The porkiness reeked into everything. Poke salad was super small! Finished it in 4 bites! But the 2 sushi rolls (forgot what they were) we got were delish. 

Leaving thinking... not even on the same level as Santa...
author: Sue Y.

description: Went here during the Halloween weekend. This place was packed at midnight with a long wait. Usually I would have ramen at home but I had heard so much about this place that I had to try it out. I had ordered the fried chicken ramen for bf, katana ya ramen for myself and a sushi to share between us. Guess the person taking the order did not get my order right and just got the fried chicken ramen, which had a miso soup base, and yes it was yummy. I had asked for a medium spice. I actually had to reorder my ramen, which was good. Giving it 5 stars cos of the flavors. Will surely come here again.
author: Deepti R.

description: I love ramen and their ramen is pretty good. I like the broth, the noodles could be a little firmer, but its pretty good.
author: Kyle C.

description: Katana Ya is a wonderful little hole in the wall restaurant. I have never been disappointed with anything I've ordered and ive been going for years. It's small and intimate which is great for dates. Wait times can get long but it's so worth it!
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Tiny little ramen shop, across the street from Curran Theater, with tables packed so close that you can barely move between them.  But, boy, does this place serves up some seriously good and piping hot ramen noodles or what?  Mine was a regular, rich soy broth, for $6.50 a bowl.  There's the option of ordering the ramen with choice of a side for only a few dollars more.  

My friend (who recommended this place to me) and I decided to share some sushi rolls and appetizer, on top of a bowl of ramen each.  We had the Alaska Roll ($5.50), Spicy Hamachi Roll ($6.00) and Agedashi Tofu appetizer ($5.00).  The sushi certainly did not disappoint - the rolls were artfully presented and the fish tasted really fresh.  As to the agedashi tofu, the texture of the batter paired with the softness in the center of the tofu was just about perfect.  

Bottom Line:  Fantastic place.  It's small, so it gets crowded easily.
author: David L.

description: Service is sucks and rudes.. you cant even wait in side the restaurant .. the waiter ask me to stay outside waiting and I just get in there and stay for 15 sec. And she yell and scream from the counter .. wtf ..
author: js w.

description: Good Ramen soup. It gets pretty packed so try to go there at around 4pm if you don't like to wait outside for an hour.
author: parviz d.

description: It's a Rainy Saturday afternoon and we're fresh from the matinee across the street.  We both order the ramen in miso.  Kia got herself the fried chicken, I enjoyed the eel side.  We split a beer and then floated off on a cloud to ramen land.  So good, I can understand why there is always a line here now.
author: Corey V.

description:
first off, I am not a ramen expert.  I visited Katana-Ya for lunch the other day after seeing good things here and the ramen was on the 7x7 list.  

i ordered the bbq pork ramen with soy broth.  the bowl of steaming goodness came out quickly and seemed really fresh.  the serving was HUGE.  the noodles were really good and fresh tasting. the pork was totally average, nothing stellar.  the broth had good flavor.  

there was a decent lunch crowd and it seemed like many were ordering sushi.  for me, the let down about this place is that lunch cost me $12-ish and all i had was ramen.  don't get me wrong, it was quite a bit of food, but it seemed a little pricey.  

i think i would try this spot again and try one of the other ramen dishes and give it another shot.  on a foggy, cold day this could totally hit the spot.
author: Annalea I.

description:
One of the few gems around Union Sq. for food. Come here on a cold day for a delicious bowl of ramen & and a cold Sapporo. You can pass on their sushi.

YOU COME HERE FOR THE RAMEN.

My fav is the spicy tofu ramen w/ light miso broth.
author: Phong D.

description:
I am so ashamed that I ordered off the so-called "white people's menu" at Katana-Ya. I earned that scornful look from Ed M.; I know I deserved it.

Everybody else ordered ramen. Admittedly, I was still feeling the effects of that fourth drink at Mr. Smith's, but that is no excuse for my having ordered the chicken teriyaki. Everyone else got a hot, steamy, delicious-smelling, head-sized bowl of ramen. I got bupkis.

It took a few minutes for my instincts to kick in, but then I nudged Adam M. out of the way and started inhaling noodles out of his bowl. He was sweet and saintly, saying that when my (unordered and thus imaginary) ramen came, we would share. He looked very sad when my tiny bowl of miso soup came instead, as well as when my mediocre chicken teriyaki came and I ate most of it instead of sharing graciously.

Adam, I am sorry I ate all your noodles. Actually, I am sorry to everyone that my chopsticks entered each of your ramen bowls unbidden. My name is Ericka L., and I am a noodle-klepto with no manners.

Aside from the delicious ramen that rightfully belonged in other people's stomachs, I also liked the narrowness of the space and I loved the kooky owl painted on the bathroom door. Also in the little dresser next to the toilet was a drawer filled with hats!
author: ericka L.

description: I'm not a huge ramen fan, but this place was pretty good. We ordered very traditional...gyoza and ramen. I ordered miso negi ramen, basic ramen and it was quite good. It was such a cold day that there was a line already at 6:15 on Monday.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Freaken pure awesomeness!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The miso ramen is delicious! The broth is flavorful and the noodle is cooked to just the right texture.  I would really go back, but the wait is the only thing that holds me back from returning....  I guess I will just go for an early dinner!!

Must go!! Best ramen in SF!!!
author: Karina L.

description: I always wait for a table here, but it is VERY good ramen... they make it spicy like I love it. Be careful, you will crave it..
author: Sarah P.

description:
It hardly seems necessary for another review of Katana-Ya, but I feel compelled to rave about the piping hot bowl of ramen I indulged in after having gone without a decent interpretation of this venerable noodle dish or so long.  

Had I been alone and unembarassed, I'd have cried when I first stared into that big bowl of miso-y comfort.  Hot, rich broth bubbling with thin sliced, greasy pork.  Apologies are due to my dinner company for eschewing table manners and diving head first into an orgy of slurping and lip smacking with occasional pit stops for a cool glass of Sapporo.

I only wish my belly was bigger so I could have finished the whole bowl ):
author: Damon I.

description: The ramen broth is always too salty, so I usually ask for a cup of hot water to add into the bowl. The ramen noodles are springy with a nice bite. Meat and veggies are scarce, but tasty, I would like to see more of that.
author: Robin H.

description: I love the fried chicken and the ramen is pretty great. The sushi is not that spectacular, so I only like getting their special fish/cuts of the day because those are usually really good. Oyakodon is really good, and the curry was surperb. It had me thinking about it for days. I wanted to go back and get it soon after, but I made myself go try Muracci's and I wished I had gone to Katana-ya instead. Now I know.
author: Joolie T.

description:
Order the Ramen.  not ankimo or any  other stuff
Shoyu Ramen, miso
yes, the broth is good (for sf proper), rich and oily.
salt can be ok in small amounts
cha shu lean and tasty, good noodles
bamboo shoots taste canned
get your ramen fix here, the difference between light and rich broth seems to be the salt content -- light works
really the better ramen is found in the south bay, but katana-ya is lucky not to have a lot of competition.
author: Rob C.

description:
Udon was good, tempura was good, kimchi tofu was pretty good too.

Service, however, needs work. I asked for an iced tea and got iced water. When we asked for the check, it took 20 minutes even though the place was not full. It was around 4:30pm on a Sunday so it was really slow but it took forever to get the check. The cashier, an American girl, was on the phone and it seemed as though she was handling her own personal problems and couldn't process our check. It was irritating to just watch our check sit on the counter. Our waitress, however, could tell we were getting annoyed.

I wouldn't go back.
author: T L.

description:
I had heard this was the best ramen shop in the city. I've been twice now. This place is tiny, so if I were you I would do yourself and everyone else a favor and not come in with a group larger than about four (or at the very least I wouldn't be picky about seating arrangements...Come on, people).

The shop was not very crowded when I was in recently at an off-hour, and I was happily accommodated while I waited for a friend's arrival. I have now sampled the Katana-ya ramen and the fried chicken ramen (both with miso broth, if I recall correctly) and found them to be excellent. The staff seem friendly, though I have to admit my interactions with them were surprisingly limited for a shop seemingly smaller than my (small) apartment. And it seems that most of the time the place is packed anyway, so it's not exactly suited for idle banter.

Anyway, love the shop, love the atmosphere. Not my favorite ramen shop in the Bay Area, but if you live in San Francisco, or are just visiting, this is absolutely the place to go. It's also good for a bit of a change (for those of us who eat more ramen than we should).
author: Mike M.

description:
Pros:
- The noodles are *excellent*
- Service is good

Cons:
- Can be tough to get a seat at times since it is a small place
author: Captain B.

description:
I've always dreamed of ramen like this.  It was very yummy and you'll definitely be full!  My husband and I split a bowl and had some sushi.  

Make sure that you are not starving when you get there because there was a long wait before we were able to sit down.  You will have to wait outside since there are only about 30 seats inside.  

Once we sat  inside, we had the table by the window and I felt bad seeing all the hungry people waiting outside.

But this is a must try place in SFO!
author: Carla P.

description:
I was a ramen virgin, but the continuously fabulous review of this place (plus the opportunity to cross another location off 7x7's The Big Eat SF list) had me curious.  

Katana-Ya did not disappoint.  I came having read up on all my options and went with the green onion ramen with the miso broth (light).  Good choice for a beginner!  I loved it and yet couldn't come close to finishing the enormous portions. 

There was a bit of a line on the street but even after we were told it could take up to an hour, it took only 20 minutes.   And was well worth it.  Thanks for the recommendation fellow yelpers!
author: Meagan C.

description: Clearly a very popular place... but I found the ramen to be good (I think I got the original or something...), not fantastic. I went with some friends that apologized profusely because they felt like this place was better before. Whatever that means. I'd like to come back and try something else... hopefully to add a raving review to the collection.
author: Natasha P.

description:
One word - Pork.

Every soup broth they serve is pork based, and there is no indication of that on the menu, you must ask.

I don't eat pork.

But I did.

"Ramen Noodles with Spicy Tofu" ? Sounds good. Wow, it  -was- good. Strangely rich for tofu soup lol. Sashimi is just fine.

Second time there, I'm with a Muslim friend and he looks nervous. So I ask the waitress, "what is the Ramen broth based on ?" 

And she of course says, "pork".

So we ate sushi.

Four stars because the Ramen was great prior to my discovery of the main ingredient.
author: Fattfreddie F.
