description: This is my standby ramen joint in San Francisco. I have waited outside for up to 30 minutes, and it's worth every minute. Past 30, and I don't know. I always get the fried chicken soy sauce ramen, and it never fails to disappoint. Their fish is pretty fresh if you decide to get sushi, and I dig their agedashi tofu. I've never tried dessert here, even though I love shaved ice desserts. I will update this review after I have tried dessert.
author: Angeline P.

description: Nothing better than a large bowl of nuclear hot ramen.
author: Tommy M.

description:
Maybe I'd expected too much, but the ramen here is okay. 

The noodle is not very chewy. It seems like the cook didn't rinse the starch off well enough, so my noodle was very gooey, which made my miso soup super thick. The bowl comes with only one piece of chashu, about a spoon of fresh seaweed and 3 pieces of bamboo shoot. I ordered kimchee ramen, so it also came with kimchee. 

The soup was oily, which was expected...but it was luke warm. I thought oil in soup suposed to keep the soup hot. The soup also left me very thirsty in the end. I gulped down two glasses of water after I finished. 

The service was pretty good. The waitress came by to see if everything was okay and came back to refill our water. The restaurant is small, so seating was kind of packed. I went in a group of 5, and they charged an an 18% gratuity.
author: Mandy C.

description: Probably one of my favorite ramen places in the city. It's a bit pricier than Asuka Ramen but has more choices. And bonus points for being open past midnight. I honestly think ramen tastes best in the middle of the night. It's very small though so I always take it to go. Seating is very limited and if you get stuck on the waiting list you have to wait outside for your table.
author: Sabrina C.

description:
YAY! i found an awesome ramen house not too far from home! i usually have to drive down to santa ramen in san mateo, but now i can just cross the bridge.

it's sooo good! it makes me feel like fuu (from samurai champloo) when i say that. she's always practically crying at the sheer joy of really good food! 

i ordered the katana-ya ramen extra spicy. it basically had everything, fresh corn, bamboo shoots, seaweed, slices of pork, gyoza, and fried chicken. i wasn't too crazy about the fried chicken, but everything else was yummy. the noodles were chewy and the broth was wonderful. and on top of it, they're open until 2am!!! god, what better way to satiate a drunken stupor, then a big heaping bowl of ramen. ah, such the comfort food.

next time i'm going the try their "special" dessert. it's shaved ice with mochi, red beans, mochi, and condensed milk.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place was great. Although I was drunk and it was late and someone else was paying. It might have been totally shit and the perfect storm of circumstances buoyed it up to amazing. Oh, well!
author: Kaleb S.

description: Hands down, the best ramen I've ever tasted!! SOOOO good!! I like the spicy Tofu Ramen with salt.. Soooo good!! Perfect for SanFran's cool weather.. Be ready to wait in the cold for a while tho.. But it's so worth it for me! :)
author: Chrissy T.

description: This was one of the first few restaurants I had ever eaten at in San Francisco and....it really wasn't very good.  The soup was overly salted, wasn't hot enough, and the flavors seemed a little off.  I don't know if it's because I'm used to the ramen in Los Angeles, but this place is really just mediocre.  I don't understand why the line outside the restaurant is always so long - probably because of the location because honestly, there really is no other reason to eat here.  Overpriced and overhyped.
author: Jessica C.

description: Korean ramen... If you are looking for Japanese ramen and never been to Japan, Ippudo in NYC, or Orenchi in Santa Clara, this may set the bar for you, albeit quite low.  The broth was super salty and the service was not good.  I should have expected that for a korean establishment...
author: Benny M.

description: Miso ramen !!! Just like Japan (made with OCD). So so so good. Always worth the wait.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Delicious Ramen
Slurp Slurp
Let me take off my hat so I don't dip it in my spicy ramen
(hat off, now on the shelf below the sushi bar)
Slurp Slurp
Chat it up with ramen buddy
Slurp Slurp

Leave satisfied
Looking for hat a day later
Remember by the yummy ramen memory I took it off not to taint it with hat brim
Called & received decent customer service to look for my hat
Waiting on the phone with my fingers crossed
"Sorry we don't have a Patriots hat but we have a Cal hat"

It's pretty gross to wear someone else's hat, but I hope they enjoy it as much as I have.  Karma will come and get you hat stealer.
author: Po L.

description:
Food was good but a bit pricey.
Highly recommend 49er sushi.
author: Shirley W.

description:
I'm definitely diggin' this place!   This review is only for their ramen as I'm afraid to try anything else besides what an establishment is known for.

I had the spicy miso ramen with everything on it.... fried chicken, char siu (chinese bbq pork), corn, seaweed and gyoza.  It's not a thai spicy spicy but rather an understated spicy that'll allow me to enjoy the flavor of the miso.  All the accoutrement were on point except the noodles themselves were a bit thicker than I would like.  Other than that.... a must go for those trying to sober up at 3am.....
author: Christopher P.

description: the only reason to go here is if it's late at night and you're drunk enough that mediocre japanese food & long lines won't phase you
author: Jeffry C.

description:
Delicious and reasonably price Japanese ramen in a low-key cozy setting - a gem hidden among all the other touristy, overrated, and overpriced places around Union Sq. 

Went on a Sunday evening around 8pm so there wasn't a wait but almost all the tables were full. You can order ramen by itself but they also offered cool combos of ramen and a side dish of fried rice, tempura, or a number of other items for $8-11. Ramen miso soup was yummy and I liked it since it was not as fatty as the broth in other places. Maybe I'm not a conosseuir of genuine Japanese ramen, but I don't enjoy seeing globs of fat floating in my ramen broth. The noodles were perfectly chewy and not too soft. I just wish they gave MORE BROTH. I barely got enough broth to cover my noodles - wonder if they were holding back because they were running low and saving for other customers. The grilled salmon don fried rice (in a small bowl) was really good and a nice side to have.

The place itself is small and cozy with 7-8 tables only but it works. They could fix up their ceiling where you can see all the pipes and wires - slightly distracting but not a big deal.

Bottom line: a new low-key fave in Union Sq area. But MORE BROTH PLEASE.
author: Jim C.

description:
katana-ya, katana-ya, i adored my first time here
patrick and i grabbed some dinner and some beer
the butter corn ramen with shoyu-based soup was quite a delight
be warned, this place is tiny and cozy, it gets crowded here at night

slurpy, slurpy, ramen soup i love thee so
i can't wait to have some more...who wants to go? :)
author: Felicia C.

description:
A lot of choices and everything is fresh and good. I will come back again, and this is such a good place for late night, easier to find parking and they open till 2am! Thankkk gooodnessss! :D 

Ramen is not the best but it is not bad in SF. There is always a wait tho, expect delays.
author: Sandy L.

description:
3.5 stars to Katana-ya, which was my favorite SF ramen place.

That said, it's friggin salty and nowhere near to the goodness that is Ramen in NYC. 

Why oh Why must all the best ramenya places be in NYC? I think us Californians deserve to get some more choices when it comes to Ramen. Once I moved to NYC, Katana-ya is a distant memory as I stuff my face w/ the goodness that is Ippudo and Minca.

BUT if you want good ramen w/ a fair choice of broths, I say Katana-ya is a solid place. I recommend the light or the rich broth, but you gotta get the karaage *yummy*. The sushi is decent...I think it's gotten better lately; it was a bit inconsistent in its freshness before.

I recommend this joint for those late-nite feed-fests...especially on those cold foggy SF nights...
author: Kris P.

description:
I thought these places only existed in Vancouver.. 

I love me some Ramen.  Seriously, who doesn't look a great bowl of fresh noodles, and yummy broth.  I think I'm in love... 

Prices are great.  You can get a combo with a reg bowl of noodles (ramen/soba/udon) and anything from sushi to unagi-don for under 13 bucks..  I got the nigiri, and for a place that concentrates on noodles, the sushi was actually pretty good. Plus they put real crab meat in the California Rolls and it's only $5.50.  Most places in SF charge up to 15 bucks. 

So much for my no carb diet.
author: Betina C.

description:
I lick the bowl CLEAN when I eat at katana-ya. Holyyy crap my mouth waters every time I hear/think of katana-ya. And when I hear ramen all I think of is katana-ya. katanayakatanayakatanayaaaaa. 

A small little hole in the wall. Their soup is amazingly flavorful and so is their pork! Usually at other ramen places my pork loses flavor because of the soup, but not here! It's a big plus that they're open late and serve beer!
author: Jessica W.

description:
Hands down the best ramen shop ever. We've tried other ramen shops just to convince ourselves out of our Katana-Ya habit, but nothing compares. Unlike other places that serve watered down broth, Katana's broth is so flavorful but never too salty. 

We usually get the deep fried chicken ramen with the salt broth and chicken on the side. Zack gets his spicy which costs $1.40 extra and we exchange spoonfuls of each other's broth to attain the perfect amount of spiciness. 

The only weakness (which to some may be a plus) the place is tiny, so the tables are very close together, so close that we were coaxed into carrying a conversation with adamant jewish law students who apparently can't hack it in the TL. Either way enjoy your ramen, conversion or not.
author: ZacKandMeL M.

description:
SOOOOOOOOOO SCRUMPDIDDLYUMPTIOUS!!! WOwowow. I got the spicy negi onion (green onion) ramen with light miso broth. Let me tell you something: It was tasty. The broth was deliciously flavorful and the perfect consistency.. not too thin, and not too creamy to be sickeningly rich. The noodles were yummy. The green onions added a nice crisp and hot spice to the meal. YUMYUMYUM!! The service was pretty great too. My friend ordered the shoyu ramen thinking it was vegetarian... Well when it came, there was a piece of meat (pork?) in the soup and it turns out the broth is made using meat. So vegetarians should ask for the vegetarian broth beforehand. Also, the restaurant found someone else who could eat the ramen instead of my friend, so they didn't charge him extra. Great service. The tea was lukewarm though. That is my only complaint.

I can't wait to go back!!!
author: O K.

description: These guys know what it means to make good ramen, because there is always a long wait to get seated, i guess that must say something about the restaurant if people are willing to wait in the cold for some ramen. I was told by a friend that this place was one of the ramen restaurants that famous japanese celebrities go to when their in town, they have prove with autographs hung on the wall like trophies for their customers to see. The ramen is good, the restaurant is a bit cramp.. but other than that.. katana-ya is definitely a good place to grab dinner one those days where you have that ramen craving !
author: Jeff C.

description:
unfortunately this place is not worth the hype.. 2000+ reviews? i'd recommend avoid the line and go somewhere else that has much better food. 

ramen is good but not great and it's a little on the pricy side. the good thing is close to union square and bart, easily accessible.
author: Joyce B.

description:
So far I am enjoying the ramen here as much as, if not more, than anywhere else I've gone in the bay area. It is not sweet with MSG (if you can relate to that).

Kudos to them for stating right on the menu that the soups contain MSG. *sigh* I love ramen but the MSG deal is gonna make me call it quits on da ramen. 

There can be a wait, but the waitresses don't jack you to save tables for larger parties. I've found them to be pretty friendly, too.
author: A D.

description: Definitely not the best ramen I have had in the bay area, but it's good for a late night snack.  If I was sober and could operate a motor vehicle I would much rather go to Himawari in San Mateo.
author: Chris Y.

description: We went there on a random Thursday night after work and got seated right away. My wife and I both had the KatanaYa Ramen. I had it with the miso and my wife w/ salt. It was good quality ramen and the broth was very tasty, but it wouldn't say it's the best I've ever had. I must say that the ramen at Izakaya Sozai is much better.
author: Steve K.

description:
So I like Ramen and I had to try this place.  I went there for a lunch and a dinner.  Both times, I had the cold Ramen noodle and was quite impressed.  Everything else was okay.  Haven't tried enough on the menu to say that it is either bad or good.  So I would come back and try other things.  

One warning, the waitress did not know how to split the remaining difference on the bill with two cards.  She put both on one card.
author: Carmen C.

description: Loved loved loved their signature ramen bowl, who would have thought fried chicken has any place in a bowl of ramen. Service was fantastic.
author: Ryan P.

description:
While visiting San Francisco, a friend suggested I stop by this place for some ramen and sushi.  It's conveniently located right next to Union Square, so it was also near my hotel.  I stopped in with some friends and ordered a small assortment of nigiri sushi, as well as some fatty tuna sashimi, and a big bowl of ramen to share.

Both the nigiri and sashimi were wonderful - the fish was succulent, fresh, and melted in my mouth.  The flavor was spot-on, and I ventured to try some new cuts of fish.  The ramen was filling, with the full assortment of tasty additions you'd expect to find in your good ramen shop.

Though a bit pricey for what you get, and very limited on space, this is definitely a good ramen restaurant to go to.  I'd suggest people try this out if they're in the area.
author: Garrett P.

description:
Well, I had wanted to give 4-stars to Katana-Ya, but....I still didn't really feel overly impressed by the place. Granted, I also still haven't tried the ramen here, which, according to Mellie P., is pretty good for ramen outside of Japan. 

Came here on a Sunday for lunch with a friend, where we had to wait outside for a little bit since there was a waiting list. Ran into a student from my school, and I think I also spotted Nobu K. (!) but I felt too shy to say anything (it was like seeing a celebrity, really!). Anyway, once my friend and I were inside, service was no-nonsense. Got our menus, when we were ready to order the server came over immediately. Our food was served probably ten minutes after we ordered (pretty fast), and our bill was given to us when we needed it right away.

Good, quick service. A nice place to come for a semi-quick bite off of Union Square. 

In terms of the food: Well, this time I ordered the Tamago Don and shared the Lava Flow Roll with my friend. I would have opted for the Katana-Ya Ramen, but I was still kind of full from a late breakfast, so a rice bowl seemed like the best choice for me at the moment. Tamago Don was tasty, not too salty. The Lava Flow Roll was supposed to be one of the spicy rolls, but....where was the spice?! I felt it was rather mild and was disappointed that there wasn't more spice. Then again, maybe my standards for spice has been shooting through the roof more since I sprinkle cayenne pepper on everything these days (well, on my omelets and on my buttered toast anyway). 

The desserts looked tasty; they had the pictures pasted on the mirrored walls and I kept eyeing the red-bean green tea mochi ice cream picture. It even had a smiley face! How could one resist a dessert with a smiley face? =P

I'll still consider Katana-Ya one of the Japanese restaurants that serve more authentic cuisine, though--no doubt in that. Next time, I will really try the ramen, since it seems the ramen gets more raves than anything else...

(Oh, and yes, the prices are fairly reasonable, at least for donburi and ramen. Some of the sushi roll prices were a little exorbitant though.)
author: Helene K.

description: Decided to eat here w/ my wife after many many reviews. She loves Ramen & me too. Got the deep fried chicken ramen. We chose the medium spicy miso.... One gulp of the soup ... And the rest was history. She ate every bit, something she does very rarely.It hit the spot for the both of us. Try it!! We loved it.. Will be back for some kimchi ramen next..
author: Tenzing N.

description:
Full disclosure: My inaugural trip to Katana-Ya came on the recommendation of the 111 Minna bouncer and occurred after a healthy night of imbibing.  So perhaps my taste buds were less exacting, my standards less stringent, than usual.  But I thought their eponymous Ramen creation was a revelation.  Two big chunks of juicy fried chicken.  Two delicious morsels of meat.  Two fried potstickers.  A half a fried egg.  It was bountiful.I agree, the broth seemed a bit off at first.  But I thought it got better as the eating progressed and the flavors intermingled.   

Seeing the numerous Katana haters on here, I see I'm gonna have to back with more of my wits about me to see if I've been duped.  But for now, I gotta show some love.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I've been to many Ramen houses in the Bay Area.  This is the most authentic Ramen house in San Francisco.  Located a couple of blocks from Union Square.  Parking is a pain in the ass, but if you plan on spending an hour at this restaurant, go park under Union Square for 2.50.  It's worth it!.

I've been here a couple of times and each time was great.  There is a sushi bar as well as small seating arrangements for couples.  It's not a large shop, so expect to wait a couple minutes during lunch and dinner.  

I sat at the sushi bar and ordered a Miso broth Ramen with Chashu (Pork) and a crab croquette.  There were two nice ladies sitting next to me.   We had a conversation with the chef about how long this place has been open.  I also got the lady next to me to try her first SAKE BOMB.  15 minutes later I get my meal, finished it and paid about 20 bucks including tips.  The broth was perfect and the crab croquette was crisp and delicious.

Go here if you are craving authentic Ramen.  I'm sure their sushi is as good as their Ramen.
author: Walter C.

description:
Decent tasting ramen and generous portions.  What more can you ask for?  I'm sure that people use the taste of the broth as their measurement benchmark of a quality ramen house.  I was satisfied.  I asked for the light soy broth and it was indeed LIGHT.  Many ramen places are way too salty/rich for my taste (even when I ask for light), and Katana-ya did a good job with the light taste.

I order the ramen combo with tonkatsu.  It's a lot of food; even for a big guy like me.  The ramen bowl is not as large as if you order ramen alone.  If you ordered ramen alone....THE BOWL IS HUGE!

By far, the San Mateo ramen places have better broth, but Katana-ya is decent enough to be satisfying.  The hours are good and location is perfect.  

Yes, this place is a dive/hole in the wall....but the food makes up for it's lack of decor.
author: Justin M.

description: I really only come back for the ramen combo with uni-ikura don (sushi rice with sea urchin and salmon roe).  Unfortunately, the ramen is just filler for me nowadays. The broth has lost its soul and the meat was chewy.
author: Mimi L.

description:
I was drunk and hungry and I had the urge, no...the need for Ramen. I live in the ramen deprived town of bakersfield and well...when I get the chance sometimes I just down right crave it.

This place delivered the goods at the right bat time at the right bat inebriation.

Something about hot noodles help you sweat out previous sins that also prevent you from feeling too sanitary. You just feel like a human again.
author: Don L.

description:
After a long evening starting from happy hour and hanging out with the boys...they convince us to walk to Katana-Ya - for GOOD ramen.  Honestly on the entire 5 block walk there, I was just hoping they weren't lying about the food, especially since I wore the wrong shoes to be hikng around SF in!

I was disappointed that the waitress seemed to forget two of our ramen orders, but while we were waiting I sampled my friend's Spicy Tofu ramen and couldn't wait to get my Regular Ramen (even though it was 20 mins later) just to eat some the perfectly cooked ramen noodles.  The other food - Donburi and Gyoza were decent also...I'd go back again for a late night snack.

Service is definitely high on my list, I give it 3-stars for service, 4-stars for delicious ramen!  Good thing I had some fun company!
author: Christine C.

description:
oi oi  look,  people that don't understand ramen houses, yes it's suppose to be simple. It's only suppose to be bout the ramen eh. and yes it's only 8 dollars. so why are you complaining with your 3 and 4 stars. Katana-ya has to be in the top 10 ramen houses in the Bay Area.

The owner is Japanese and some of the wait staff are also..but being in San Francisco the chefs and cooks at Katana-ya are not Japanese. How many Italian restaurants actually have Italian chefs at the helm, mostly it's your Spanish speaking folk running the kitchen. That being said. Skill and technique is the key to a great chef. 

When I eat here I tend to lean toward the fried baby Aji first -yum fried fish.
Kim-chee ramen please. Ken tried the butter and corn ramen -looked good.
author: John L.

description:
yelp has mislead me for the first time, quite disappointing

i remember the first time i had legit ramen was from oahu, thats basically all i ate on that vacation i couldn't get enough.  i didn't know so many japanese people lived on oahu.

but back to katanaya, i thought being the quote on quote BEST RAMEN in san francisco this would be some amazing ish,

I ordered the katanaya ramen which had fried wontons, fried chicken BBQ pork minus the corn and i picked the ramen base.... when i got it it looked appetizing, but to me it was just another bowl of ramne, i couldn't finish the soup cus it was too salty and the chicken was salty, it was just OK

i think i probably would have liked it if i got something spicer or something thats like a hidden gem on the menu.

i would definitely give this another chance since so many people love this place.
author: Ryan S.

description: taste is so good! I always order ramen(syoyu), my bf order ramen(miso) and fried rice. And sometimes gyoza(so big). He loves this place! He dosen't like Japanese noodle before, But he changed.  Everything good taste. We love KATANAYA. We just don't like wait so long... Always busy...
author: Ria D.

description:
My favorite ramen place in the city!

They're famous for ramen, but here's the real secret : their udon kicks ass, and they have some of the best sushi around. They also make a mean chicken kaara-ge (fried chicken).

Top picks: Uni Ikura Don, BBQ Pork Ramen in a rich miso broth, Hamachi sashimi, Udon.
author: Mary M.

description: Was great! Had the Kantanaya with ramen. Very filling! Was recommended to go back on Friday!
author: Louis T.

description: I really don't understand the appeal.  I've eaten here a few times and I think it's OK at best.  I live only a few blocks from here and really hoped that I would enjoy the ramen.  The only reason I would eat here again is if I was so tired and so hungover, that I couldn't make it much further than a few blocks from where I live and I was just dying for ramen.  Even then, I think I'd buck up and make it to one of the other many great places in the city.  The broth is just so bland and while I appreciate all of the "extras" you put in your Katana-Ya ramen, I just don't think you're on it with your essentials (broth, noodles, and egg).  Look at how Ken Ken does their egg - TAKE NOTE!  I wish you'd check out other places and improve so that I could eat ramen closer to home.
author: Noneya B.

description:
I usually travel to Japan once a year; Tokyo is one of my fav places in the world.  Katana-Ya brings me back there when I eat their food.  It's the most authentic Japanese restaurant in SF city.

    People complain about the service; I think it's fine.  What I especially love is that they're open until 2am!!!!
author: Snake, N.

description:
one of he best ramen places in the city and they are open really late
this is one of the few places in the world that i've eaten there twice in 1 day... embarrassing...
author: Christopher L.

description: With an excess of reviews, I will say that it really didn't, at least for me, live up tio the hype. I was disappointed with the quality of the broth, and I could taste the MSG, which says to me that they don't even aspire to fool you into believing it's a well-done broth. The menu is certainly diverse, but I felt the wait was unnecessary. Like Daikokuya in LA, it prides itself in its lines out the door, but really, when it's that small of a place, it's rather deceptive. The large bowls of ramen are a plus among the other options that they have, but for me, the ramen is what I come for. And compared to SoCal ramen hotspots, Katana-ya doesn't quite match up. Certainly better than J-town ramen, for sure.
author: Travis L.

description:
When we walked in and heard some great reggae, we knew this wasn't your typical Japantown shop. The place is small, and crowded, however, as in you can hear your neighbors' conversations, but we were lucky and didn't have to wait. 

Though the atmosphere wasn't Japanese, the taste of the food was. My Japanese wife enjoyed her miso ramen and chicken karage. My son enjoyed his miso ramen, Philadelphia roll, and chicken, as well. One of my few complaints is that, being a pesco-vegetarian, there was no (pesco-)veggie broth for the ramen offered, as you can find in many shops in the Bay Area. However, I thoroughtly enjoyed my soba, as it reminded me of the taste of soba in Japan. The kimchee tofu donburi was fine, nothing special.

The service was great - relaxed yet punctual.  Finally, though the food was great, it was pricey. We paid $40 for lunch for three, sans tip.
author: Chris S.

description:
The hostess was a little... well not friendly, not quick, just doing her job.  This is a tiny place, and those waiting for a seat stand outside the door.  As they wait they'll watch you eat.  Even worse, we had a young teenage couple that watched us eat and talked about it in their native tongue. Did I mention we were the only white people dining here?  A few words could be made out, and quickly the boss told them to wait outside like everyone else.  I could care less, but I'd rather not pay to have my sushi skills criticized by some bratty Japanese teen.

Fresh sushi, which isn't hard to come by in this town, with some creative rolls.  Miso was not noteworthy.  Everyone was ordering noodle bowls/Ramen and fried tofu.  

I'll come back, but I just wont sit near the front.
author: K M.

description: A pure pleasure, however brief...  showed up at 11:30AM right when the restaurant opened, and already the inside is full.  Small menu of assorted noodles, I went for the spicy tofu ramen with miso.  The enormous serving lived up to the hype - spicy, thick, chewy, piping hot.  About 2 minutes into my meal, there's a long line outside, and I felt a need to hurry up so others may enjoy this heavenliness.  Didn't think my stomach held that much fluid, but it did, comfortably.  Reasonalbe price, too.  This is going to be my new show-off joint whenever entertaining guests from out of town.
author: Peter C.

description:
My favorite ramen place by far. Been here a few times and every time it's a great visit. Aside from their wonderful ramen soup selection, they also have sushi. You can order a sushi-ramen combo for a really good deal (I believe $12.99). Not bad at all. 

The last time I came here was to celebrate my brother's birthday. I got the extra spicy ramen and  I don't remember what my bro and the Eggs got. 
My friend and my bro wanted to each order a bottle of Sapporo. In their mind, they were thinking of the regular one person Sapporo bottle, but the waitress came back with 2 huge bottles. Mind you this was a "school night" so we didn't feel like drinking 2 huge bottles of beer. We notified the girl that there might have been a mistake, but she refused to switch the bottles to a smaller size because "it's been opened." Irritated, we decided to forget about it and just move on. Little did we know, the manager (he's Thai) saw what happened. He walked over to our table and grabbed our bottles. He said that he was sorry and he switched our bottles. Of course we appreciated what he did and we were happy again. We ended up conversing with him. He was a genuinely nice guy. We ended the night with good food, good service and a happy belly.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I have been to Katanaya a number of times since their new reincarnation in Union Square. The first couple of times i went i was hugely disappointed, granted it was the first month it had opened. Their soup was watery and had no koku(a certain je ne c'est que) at all. Aside from the ramen, the katsu-don was great. Which was a shame because i had been to the other Katana-ya near UCSF a couple of years ago and loved their ramen. 

However, being a deligent ramen fiend i found myself here again and was glad to see/taste that they had upped the anty and had a hearty, bold favorful, koku-filled bowel of ramen waiting to be devoured by moi. 

The decor is dingy and dark but its Union Square and i am very thankful that they are there and open late, no less. 

Oh and also Katana-ya featured in an epic night out involving my friend Mooj, 2 trannies, a slide and match.com girls, all culminating  in Mooj getting some "sexy-time" ..with who? well, that'll be telling and  all because i wanted some ramen at Katana-ya.

Cheers Katana-chan
author: Tak H.

description:
My love for Katana-Ya grows with every visit. And this is only my second. (I may  need a 6th star next time, Yelp.) I will keep my update brief and simply relate that, after bravely straying from my usual order (Miso and Spicy Tuna Don) to venture into Udon-ness (with the Spicy Tuna Don still, of course), I am officially converting -- and recommend you do as well. I'm pretty sure those noodles are daily UPS'd from Heaven. Right into your bowl. 

Amen.
author: G. J.

description:
In the words of Joey Tribiani, "Mm... soup.  I mean noodle soup!  I mean soup!"

Came here after a long run with my favorite running pals and was starving and really craving ramen.  I really do love my ramen, granted I can make a bowl for about 75 cents or so, but this was worth it.  Unfortunately, we had to wait awhile because this place is so popular and we had 7 people in our party.  They told us 15 minutes to wait, which turned out to be about 30 minutes outside freezing.    

I ordered the deep fried chicken ramen with miso broth.  The chicken was really good and the miso ramen was excellent.  I also tried chicken udon too.  Topped off the ramen with a pitcher of sapporo, which I actually liked, although I'm not much of a drinker, contrary to popular belief.  I just love ramen places - it's not like a pho place or a chinese won ton noodle house.  It's just ramen and so worth the wait.
author: Stacey C.

description: Ive been to this place twice now.  After eating it for the second time its safe to say its overrated.  The only reason why this place is ALWAYs busy is the space is smaller than my back fat..  The ramen is the only thing worth trying here.  All other food here sucks.
author: Fatty A.

description:
A very charming little restaurant, with fun decor--flashing Christmas lights, abstract art, and live lobsters. The bathroom is also interesting to look at, with a mural of giant owls and trees.

The two of us were seated immediately, unlike many of the others who came at 7 or later on a Sunday. The waitress brought us cups of steaming, delicious barley tea. The menu wasn't huge, but had a decent variety of appetizers, special rolls, sushi, donburi, noodles, and ramen. I settled on the Regular Ramen and we shared an appetizer of Gyoza.

Ramen bowls are slightly under $10 and come in three different flavors of broth: Shoyu, Miso, and Salt. I chose Miso, and was not disappointed. Our ramen came promptly--mine included bamboo shoots, seaweed, green onion, and one slice of BBQ pork. The BBQ pork was nicely flavored, but I do wish they included a larger variety and a larger amount of toppings. Not enough Veggies or meat! Eggs please?

The noodles, however, were delicious. Very chewy...not so good if you like your noodles well-done or soft, but they suited my taste.

The "home-made Gyoza," however, was not that great. The vegetables in it had a strong and overwhelming taste, and the filling was not juicy. Also, instead of standard dipping sauce, we received spicy oil stuff and spicy vinegar. I prefer the standard.

But it was a yummy meal...I looove my ramen, especially on a gloomy and cold day like this one.
author: K W.

description:
I've tried many ramen places, but i'd have to say that this place, by far, has the best ramen!  I ordered the ramen lunch special and chose the kim chi fried rice as my side. The broth is flavorful and yummy, and the noodles are cooked JUST right!  

The only, but super annoying part is that it's UBER small inside.  I went with 3 other people and we were pretty cramped at our table.  There was just enough elbow room to eat, but the table is sooo small that it couldn't really fit all the stuff we ordered.  Good thing we eat fast!  :)
author: Linda K.

description:
I don't get the fuss. 

The noodles are fabulous -- the best I've had outside Japan -- but the shoyu broth tasted like chemicals and was overloaded with grease. 

I'm definitely NOT one of those "ew, this meat has fat on it!" girls; I like fat and rich food, but this was actively greasy.  Even swirling away the grease didn't help. Yuck.
author: anita c.

description:
A primer: I've lived in Tokyo for a while, so I expect a good bowl of noodles  even at 1:30 in the morning. Actually, *especially* at 1:30 in the morning. My expectations are pretty high of ramen in general, and the only remotely ok ramen-ya that's ever touched my palette in this side of the Pacific Ocean is Santa Ramen. 

Ambience: 
I waltzed in one weekday evening at about 1 am. It looked promising...like a hole in the wall in any Tokyo train station place. Nostalgia hit as soon as I saw the bar area where food was also served and another Japanese patron was chatting it up in Japanese with the waitress. I went with a couple of Cantonese ppl (cousin and his friend). So far, so good. 

The FOOD: 
ROLLS: Underwhelming. No spectacular flavors. But they get a star for rolling it out at that hour. 

RAMEN: Shio-base -OILY and chunks of coagulated fat floating on top! 
Miso-base -it tasted like they used old miso. Not enough kombu in their dashi. UGH. 
Noodles - stringy and rubbery. 
In summation: the bowls of noodle lacked soul. Underseasoned and fatty without any layering of flavors. 

Service: ROUGH. I saw this couple pay for their meal and leave. The waitress complained about the small tip in Japanese for a full 5 minutes, ignoring my quest for another bottle of beer. 

All in all - two stars and I'm being generous.
author: Wing L.

description:
Yummy fried chicken!  Yup, I would actually go here for their fried chicken, forget KFC!  :)

Ok, so this place is obviously a Japanese style ramen noodle place, however, I found their fried chicken to be quite delicious!

I'm Korean and we do eat a lot of ramen noodle soups (well, any kind of noodles, actually), so I do get somewhat picky about my noodle soups.  Well, Katana-ya definitely has some satisfying noodle soups but I do find their broth (miso ones) to be a bit too rich (meaty) and since I'm not a big fan of the bamboo shoots, I do find it a bit stinky (but you can ask them to take the bamboo shoots out). 

Still, great fresh ramen noodles, and some good choices for the toppings (BBQ pork & obviously fried chicken, being my favs), I usually finish the whole bowl.

They're open late so it's a great place to go to after an evening of drinking.
author: Sophia F.

description:
Confession of a Yelper

Dear Katana-ya,
I've been an avid patron of your msg laden ramen for quite some time now and I must say that I still dont drink as much water anywhere else but your abode. 
I had come to once again fulfill my cravings of your special bowl some days ago and was assisted by one of your waitress who remarkably resembles actress Ming-Na.  I was complimenting her though she had no idea to who this actress was.  Anyway, after the appetizers and warm sake was consumed,  we were greeted by a warm aromatic wisp of the ramen bowl which my friend and I happily shared.  A minute had passed and there was the arrival of yet another bowl of a different noodle.  I only meant to order one bowl though I recall that when I was placing my order, Ming-Na have asked to which kind of noodle I'd have TWICE.  I scratched my head and looked down to my share of ramen.  I spooned some broth with a lil bit of seaweed and corn, chewed then swallowed.  Gravity and throat muscles did not help it go down any easier as guilt was building and acted as sharp speed bumps down the food drain.  Oh mercy.....

...on the bright side,  dinner is on the house for yet another employee.
author: Rovie T.

description:
The good: solid ramen (but skimpy portions), good sake selection, attentive service. The bad: average rolls, salty edamame, somewhat pricey.  

I'll start with the main event: the BBQ pork ramen ( # 5 on the 7x7 Big Eat SF list, see http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die) was my introduction to restaurant ramen in San Francisco (I'm more familiar with ramen shops in NYC). I ordered it with mildly spicy rich salt broth; the broth was pleasingly savory and rich and had enough kick to satisfy without overpowering one's palette. I also enjoyed the springy and tender noodles. However, I was disappointed with the skimpy portions and the provision of a mere three slices of pork and a modest sprinkle of green onions and seaweed. Plus, why charge an extra $.50 to make it spicy? I don't get it. Overall, the ramen was good, but not great. My pursuit of excellent ramen in the Bay Area continues! (any suggestions?)

Back to the rest of the meal:

Sake: The sake menu is impressive and comes complete with pictures and succinct descriptions. The unfiltered Junmai did not disappoint - it was fragrant and sweet with just the right amount of alcohol. 

Appetizers: The gyoza was crispy on the outside, but I found the filling a bit too mushy. The edamame was excessively salty - probably the saltiest edamame I've ever had and too salty to finish.

Rolls: We got the baked salmon, shrimp tempura, and caterpillar rolls. Overall, I agree with Jennifer R: the rolls were overpriced and average. But I should note that the baked salmon roll, which came with a piping hot baked salmon center surrounded by sticky rice and an egg wrap, was tasty and somewhat unique. 

Random observations: Street parking is nearly impossible. The restaurant is open until 1:15 am on most nights, which is later than most places. Lastly, you should check out the bathroom mural art - kind of funny and creepy. I like the owls, but I'm curious about their origin.
author: Chris T.

description: Great ramen spot in an unexpected location. The sushi itself is not bad, but really not worth the long wait. Get the Katanya Ramen. This place gets super crowded, so if you have the chance to come here on off-peak hours, take it. The restaurant is really small and can only seat a handful of people eating steaming soup and trays of sushi. Service is also not the fastest, so expect to wait after leaving your name on the list. This is the best Ramen that I have had San Francisco.
author: Claire R.

description:
Five stars!  The extra spicy ramen is a gut-busting, pay for it later tonight affair.  However, it sure does put Tanpopo's version to shame.

I've been coming here since it opened when they hadn't started serving sushi and the menu was 2-3 sheets of paper stuffed inside plastic holders. I love how Katana-Ya is a perpetual work in progress both food and decor wise.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
katanaya isn't bad.  but i wouldn't say i would go out of my way to eat here again. @dho recommended this place because it was between nob (where she works) and civic (where i work).  it was a blustery day so it was nice to have some hot soup. 

i had the fried chicken ramen with miso strong base.  the noodles tasted like they were out of a plastic package.  i'm originally from socal and perhaps i'm a bit spoiled with japanese ramen (shout out to my westminister folks).  the soup was alright.  very oily.  i did ask for strong - but it was a little meh on the flavor.  i would say so-so.

the place is really tiny and the tables are super packed together.  i noticed that most other people there were dining away on sushi rolls.  made me think that perhaps we should have gotten a couple of those.

the fried chicken was pretty good.  actual good chunks of chicken and lightly battered.

i would say it's a 2.5-3 stars.  price was reasonable and it was a good size bowl.  not too big but not too small.  i don't know of any other ramen places in norcal so i guess i might recommend it if someone was thinking about japanese style ramen.  still may have preferred a good neoguri (korean package noodles) at home.
author: Kimmy C.

description:
One word. OVERRATED.

Just because this restaurant has been on the 7x7 list for some time doesn't make it that great.

I'll put things into perspective.

First of all, this was one of the early ramen houses in San Francisco. The ramen crazy exploded in 2005 or so in the Bay Area when ramen house after ramen house sprang up. I heard of Katana Ya by 2007, but it wasn't a big thing til the 7x7 list.

If you know the South Bay, you know the demographics. There's a huge Japanese population. It's just like why the best Dim Sum will be close to SF or Oakland and not in the South Bay. That's why some of the best ramen houses are down there. Santouka, Halu, Orenchi, just to name a few. There's other ones that are at least mediocre.

When I first heard of this Katana Ya being on some godly 7x7 list I expected the best. I just came from weekly trips to Santouka and Santa, so I decided to line up with my gf for Katana Ya.

Was it worth the 2 hours? No way. This place ranks mediocre at best. BTW, I'm not taking points off for the wait. This is solely about the food.

A ramen place is all about the broth. This goes with other specialty noodles like pho. Ramen broth is supposed to be thick, greasy, and filled with flavor. This is NOT the case with Katana Ya.  I tried the Miso while my gf tried the salt. I also tried the soy on another day on my own. I feel like the broth here is very bland and the attempts at spicy broths or extra salty broths are just to cover up the lack of flavor. Spicy broths aren't even very authentic Japanese. Kim Chi? Are you kidding me? Usually on a cold day you should be able to sit in front of a bowl of ramen and just take one spoonful of broth before feeling satisfied. That one spoonful should have so much flavor it arouses all your senses and gets your stomach growling with hunger. It never came close to this at Katana Ya sadly enough.

I thought tossing fried chicken into ramen is just excessive too. It's not really what Japanese ramen is. To me it's more a desperation attempt to get more flavor in the noodles/broth than anything else. I see it as trying too hard to give some character in the ramen because it isn't great as ramen alone.

Compare this place to other famous ramen shops like Santouka, Santa, Halu, and you will see that the other 3 places have very thick and rich broths. Katana ya feels very plain. Compare this to other places like even the mediocre Kagetsu Arashi from Japan or Daikokuya from LA and Katana Ya completely pales.

I honestly think that people have hyped this place to beyond appropriateness. I'm not saying it should be off the 7x7 list, but even if this is the best the city has to offer in terms of Japanese ramen, let's not act like this is mecca of ramen in the Bay Area. There's far better places.

The Ramen Queen Melanie Wong at Chowhound has put Katana Ya at #21 in this list (scroll down a bit):
http://chowhound.chow.com/topics/681436

For someone who's tried 15-20 ramen places too and in an in depth manner, I'd like to say that Katana Ya ranks somewhere on the bottom half of my list. It's a notch above Maru Ichi or Ryowa in my opinion, but can't touch Orenchi, Santouka, Santa, Halu, Kahoo, Ajisen. BTW please don't mix up the legendary Halu of San Jose with the terrible Halu in San Francisco.

Once again I emphasize my motto: perspective. Look at the South Bay ramen places. Those are the places you really want to go to. Santa isn't in the south bay, but it's truly a wonderful place too. I feel like San Franciscans are too wrapped up in their bubble of the 7x7 list and too amazed by a mediocre ramen shop that this place has exploded to way too many Yelp stars.

If you haven't had good ramen before and only had Top Ramen, this might be paradise, but if you know what Japanese ramen is, head elsewhere.
author: Dennis M.

description:
BEST bowl of ramen ever!!!  Ramen is the ultimate comfort food and my spicy tofu ramen at Katana-Ya definitely hit the spot. 

We came here for lunch on a Friday and beat the lunchtime rush... thank goodness because it is a small restaurant and fills up fast. The menu is extensive and everything looked really good but we ended up getting Spicy Tofu Ramen in light miso, Chasu Ramen in rich miso, and a California roll. All REALLY good. The broth was all done perfectly with the right amount of ramen (very plentiful) and tofu and pork. Soooooo satisfying. 

As for our roll, all the sushi looked too good to pass up so we decided to go with something small which was a good ol' California roll. It was freakin good!!! Very fresh - perfect balance of the crab and avocado and rice - the way California rolls SHOULD taste. 

I'm very impressed with Katana-Ya. It seems like they make every item on their menu delicious.
author: Sandy K.

description:
Okay, so maybe I was wrong. I've been back several more times and it is delicious. I've had both the miso and shoyu ramen, but I never order it rich or light, just default. I would suggest the miso, just thinking about it makes my mouth water.

There is always a wait, but typically people get in and out pretty quickly. The bowl is huge, not overwhelmingly huge but just right huge. The ramen comes with the basics (pork, seaweed, bamboo) but there are different things you can order or add to your ramen.

The place isn't very roomy, it's actually pretty small which is partially responsible for the constant wait but since the wait typically isn't very long and there's a Starbucks just a few storefronts down it's not bad at all.

If you want delicious ramen and are willing to wait, this is your place.
author: Tiff L.

description: The restaurant is small but the food is reaaaaally delicious!
author: Buyi Y.

description:
Pretty good ramen place! Not the best but we'll go to this place if we are in the area. 

Pro- lots of ramen selections
        Delicious
        Fast service
        Not so cheap but not so expensive

Con- salty which made me crave for drinks all day
          Small place with no high chair! Not recommended for people with a baby! 
          I would never go back to this place(or any small Japanese restaurant) with my baby
author: Sunny K.

description: I agree with David T - 1648 yelpers might be wrong.. It was ok, but nothing better or more outstanding than Boom Noodle.  It's better than packaged ramen for sure, but it's not that fantastic.  I can make a pretty good ramen at home, this didn't compare.  Not a fan, don't plan to return.
author: Monica N.

description:
After reading all the awesome reviews on Katana-Ya, I have to say, I was not all that impressed with the bowl of ramen that appeared before me.  I hate to say this, but Genki Ramen might be better and that is just kind of sad. 

We started with the fried shrimp appetizer, which came with a little salad.  This was tasty!  The shrimp was covered with a light batter and a spicy, creamy sauce.  Yum.  I ordered the shoyu green onion ramen.  Good thing we ordered an appetizer because the portion was not all that large and my ramen only had one slice of pork.  Sad because I adore the pig.  Also sad because I was starving and was really looking forward to a yummy bowl of ramen noodles with lots of pork.  My friend Linda who was with me said the spicy ramen she ordered last time seemed to have more included...I guess I'll have to try Katana-Ya again to see if that is true.
author: Mitzi C.

description: The portions are great.  The sushi as expected isn't superior.  The ramen on the other hand is good.  The location is not exactly a prime spot.  The nice thing is that it is only about 1 block from the Hilton San Francisco.  I had the Katana-ya ramen, it had good dumplings.  I wasn't expecting the chicken to be breaded, but otherwise overall a good value.
author: Kent H.

description:
I gotta say, I agree with everyone here.  This is a hidden gem that I cannot believe i did not try until recently.  The ramen here is out of this world.  The soup is very tasty esp if you love miso ramen.  The ramen itself is cooked very well, might even be house made not sure.  But the texture is amazing.  The sashimi and sushi here is also surprisingly fresh.  

The best way i can sum this place up is, if you are craving good ole jap food, screw fighting your way for parking in J town, or ordering from sub-par plcaes like Sushi Rock, come here, and enjoy the great food.  Prices are not cheap but you are willing to pay it once u try.
author: Charles C.

description: A slightly-above-average bowl of ramen, it really was not mind-blowing as everyone claims it is. Broth and noodles are just okay... bland maybe compared to just about every other ramen shops that have popped up in the last couple of years. Too little meat.
author: Tina L.

description: This place is highly overrated!! And might I add, overpriced!! Tiny little place, not worth the wait! For $8, I got a bowl of solely udon noodles (just noodles & broth!).  For $9, my friend got ramen that came with broth and a few tiny pieces of fried chicken separate.  I couldn't say the ramen was good either.  I suppose the broth is tasty, not too salty... Overall, this place is just A-OKAY :P
author: Tramy V.

description: The ramen is fine by San Francisco standards, however, the service is unforgivably shoddy. They are popular and the wait is long. Apparently this has given them permission to be rude to customers, to bring the wrong dishes, to forget to bring dishes -  all without apology. This crap service is something I have experienced fairly consistently there, and while I get that this place is a hole in the wall and I am not expecting the type of service I would get at a fine dining establishment, I do expect not to feel like I am a problem for the staff.
author: Claire B.

description:
I finally got around to trying this place and I'm glad I did. Overall this would have to be my favorite Ramen House to go with friends... However, I've had better Ramen in the Bay Area.. most notably Santa in San Mateo.  I've also been to Rwoyo in Mountain View many times and they are pretty good.

TANPOPO in Japantown is my go to place for Ramen in San Francisco. overall I think they have the best Ramen...good flavor and nice texture on the noodles.  Suzu is not bad. Genki is extemely mediocare...  Mifune is OK.  

If a Japanese tourist asked me where to go.. I would put my money on TANPOPO or Santa..  If a bunch of young tourist backpackers asked me the same question.. I would tell them to go to Katana Ya... then tell them they will probably like TANPOPO better.

In the South Bay.. there's a few good ones in Cupertino.. nothing amazing.  

My next visit with friends would be Katana Ya.  YOU DECIDE!!!!
author: Demanding T.

description:
This place had some pretty good reviews, so I decided to check it out.  I can say, I was pleasantly surprised.

Let me preface this by saying that I am a huge fan of ramen.  I have even been known to settle for sub-par ramen when there is no alternative... but happily, this was not the case with Katana-Ya.

This place was actually pretty good!  Sure, its a little small and dingy, but hey... so are many of the best ramen places in Japan, right?  I'm not  gonna go elitist here... look, Ramen in Japan  is wonderful, but it's unfair to make direct comparisons to their American counterparts.  I'm sure there is some place in Shibuya that has mouth watering cha-shu, blah blah blah...  Sure... we all know that... But we are here in the bay area, so we need to scale our critiques.

That being said:

Noodles:  Chewy and springy.  Cooked slightly Al Dente as it should be.  Great texture, and perfect egg-noodle flavor.

Rich Shoyu Broth: (there are other options, but i haven't tried them yet)
A little on the salty side, but definitely tolerable, and still in the delicious range.  Good flavor, and not overpowered by the negi.

Cha Shu: not too soggy, and virtually melts in your mouth.  Not the best I have ever had, but it was damn good.

Tea:  Who cares... you came for the noodles right? ^_^

Summary:  Hands down the best ramen place in down town SF.  I work here in the city, so its very convenient for me.  I wouldn't come to San Francisco specifically for this though.  I would just say, its great ramen done right  in an area that has few other options for ramen.

NOTE:  If you are looking for the best ramen in the bay area... do your self a favor and head on over to Santa Ramen in San Mateo... I know you have heard of it.  But if you happen to be in the downtown area, Katana-Ya is a solid recommendation.

"Itadakimasu"

~ E


*** UPDATE ***
Went back and tried the (Rich) Miso broth, Cha-shu ramen
Really Good!  Katana-Ya Rocks!!!
author: Erich R.

description:
DAMN !
Pretty Good Sensei !  The ramen is rockin', and the sushi makes me wiggle like a fan at a Metal concert.  The interior looks like a Vegas casino on crack. The prices are reasonable considering its location near Union Square. 

I gotta take 1 star for the service, staff seemed more confused than a marina girl after happy hour. I'll be back again to see if the girls were just hungover or if the staff is indeed the result of overpopulation and bad interviewing skills.

Try the Sushi bar if you don't mind talking about your life to the chef. He's funny, has a script and everything. Otherwise sit at the window table just to the right after entering the door. It's great for people watching.

CHOMP IT, SLURP IT, and SUCK IT DOWN.  Noodles Rule !
author: Mark B.

description: Was expecting a bit more here. People were friendly, and ramen was OK, but sat at the sushi bar and there was a rather nasty smell lingering around. The little place on kearny is better, imho.
author: Bob R.

description: Came across this place after a long search of places to dine in after work during the later hours of night. This place was open after 12 so I was all about it. I been turned on to the ramen craze recently so I had to see what they had to offer; and I was pleased. I always go for whatever they suggest or what they put their name on it for, so of course I tried the Katana-ya Ramen, spicy!. It had pork, fried chicken, fried gyoza (appears to be homemade), wakame, bamboo, boiled egg and corn. Great combo considering I'm sucker for fried food, and in soup on a cold night cut the cake. The portions are great and I was filled to content. I've had this combination at other ramen places so I can see why they put their name on it, but wheres the originality?  I'll will probably be back after another long night of work, and maybe for some sushi next time ;)
author: Christopher P.

description:
INCONSISTENT
This is my favorite ramen shop in the city and twice...I did not enjoy it as much.  So sad.  The fried rice even lost its flavor.  I wonder if the chef is no longer there.  :(
author: Elisa O.

description: I was brought here by Nate R below who raved about how good the Ramen is.  I found it mildly disgusting and way over priced.  Knowing that they have to put MSG in their food (they say they do)  means its has no flavor by itself.  Not a fan unfortunately.  Service was okay and wont be on my list of return places.  Different strokes for different folks I guess.
author: Ray A.

description:
The actual ramen isn't bad, but paying $10 for Kimchee ramen with ONE SLICE of BBQ pork is pretty sad. I don't think this place deserves over 3 stars. If I am around the area again I would probably go to one of the Thai noodle soup places instead of getting ramen here - it's cheaper and you get more than one slice of meat for $10. 

The wait is annoying. It's really, really small. I don't know about the supposed good-looking waitresses either.
author: Leily P.

description: Was in town for B2B (first race ever and I hate running but seeing drunken, naked people apparently is fine with me) and was at Union Square for the Taiwanese American Heritage Week Festival and a friend was starving since he hadn't eaten anything and it was already late midday. So we asked some of our local friends of good recs around the walking area and some folks recommended Katana Ya.  There was of course a wait and we saw a lovely dramatic show/fight with some unstable folks outside of the restaurant.  After close to an hour wait, we got a seat and since I thought might as well eat my early dinner now before the race ordered the shoyu Katana Ya Ramen, which was pretty good but very filling and I couldn't finish the whole thing, my friend did since he was starving and young men have ridiculous metabolism, women my age envy.  The ramen was decent (I wasn't super hungry when I ate) though next time I might try shio or miso. His friend also suggested the hamachi kama, which was pretty good.
author: Jen K.

description: Week end before last, my friend took me to lunch at kataya. The wait staff was WONDERFUL as my friend was in an electric wheelchair. They sat us quickly and without much ado. The food was a real treat....best tempora i have had in years....a wonderful experience all the way around!
author: Marianella M.

description: Had the Katana-Ya Ramen which was pretty good because it had all kinds of random, unique items in it, though I would have preferred if the ramen was a bit more dense/chewy. Soup was good and yummy, didn't taste too MSG-y. Couldn't find a seafood ramen type on the menu though. Overall, a decent place, though not worth the 1.5 hr wait (we were standing right by the door, but they didn't call out our name loud enough. Twice, after we asked them about the long wait.. twice.)
author: Jason N.

description:
Ramen is not my favorite food to eat, but the fried chicken ramen is pretty good, but a little on the oily side.

The tuna sashimi with ponzu sauce is great starter (the sauce is tasty), but I would order it with no onions or easy on the onions (unless you are into onions, which I am, but found it a bit much).

The rising sun roll and hawaiian roll are very good because, in general, the fish here is delightfully fresh.  So if you are a fan of the raw, can't really go wrong here.

The place is very small, so the wait might be a bit longer than you would like (but let's face it, in San Francisco, for most good places--and even plenty of mediocre places--patience is required).  However, even though it's small, busy, and the tables are close together, I find it still somewhat intimate--perhaps it's the lighting, or maybe because it is small and therefore you are sitting close to your own party.  

The other great things about this place is that it is open until 1:15 a.m. and the prices are reasonable.  And it's close to BART.
author: Trix L.

description:
9, yes, 9 of us went here for a quick bite. there was a wait, but its okay since good company was around.

i got the regular rich soya ramen with gyoza and a small draft. i mixed about this place. the ramen was good, but my noodles were stuck together. the soup base was okay, but it wasn't amazing. the gyozas were fresh, but it wasn't the ones i'm used to at a ramen shop. they were more like man-du.. yep, korean dumplings. they were half moon shaped and had glass noodles inside.

thumbs up: great for a quick ramen fix if you're in the area... esp late night.
thumbs down: service was kinda slow. no place settings, missing water for awhile, but its not a big deal.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
It's just an okay place for food. $10 a pop for $0.39 worth of ramen and $1.50 worth of chicken, eh, I can cook it myself.

Wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Keit K.

description: Thick soy regular ramen was so delicious.  fast service.  ummmm  i want to have another one.
author: Minori S.

description: Again, not a fan of ramen, but their spicy miso ($8.50) is too flavorful to miss out. Probably has a lot of msg and salt, but WOW, spicy deliciousness. The chicken karage (fried chicken) ramen looked really good too. Gyoza were okay, nothing special. Be prepared to wait during peak hours, this place is really small and easy to miss.
author: William H.

description:
Salt miso broth.  Doesn't sound very appetizing at first glance, but once you taste the soup, you immediately go back for another scoop!  I ordered the fried chicken ramen with salt miso broth.  I remember Katana-Ya being good the 1st time I came, but I don't remember it being this good.  I was pleasantly surprised at the portion size and was sufficiently full off of the one bowl of noodles.  We also shared a house salad, a poki salad and kimchee fried rice, all also very delicious.  

Plan to wait in line to get in at prime dining hours, it's a tiny restaurant but they serve you quick so I imagine that turn around is fast!  It would be nice if the prices were a tad cheaper, but I'd splurge every once and a while to get some good ramen!  I'll be back for sure!
author: Christopher W.

description:
Ramen is pretty good, a lot like other places down in the south bay, Halu, Santouka, etc. What puts it over the top is the other options you can order.  I always get the chicken karage.  sashimi and rolls are decent too. Rating benefits from being open till 1AM.

Wait is super long, like every other popular ramen place.
author: Andy C.

description:
This is one of those places I can always rely on for good food to fill my tummy.  I like the ramen here a lot, and their combination menu is so awesome!  For about $9, I get a big bowl of ramen (I like the light miso soup best) and a tasty bowl of Kimchi Fried Rice.  I've tried other items, but I find the Kimchi Fried Rice to be very delicious.  It's more than enough for me, but I can't resist a good deal like that.  

The place is tiny--10 tables max. with 4 or 5 bar seats--but I've never waited more than 5 minutes for a table here.  It's also a good sign when you see Japanese natives eating here, so you know the Japanese food is good.
author: Diane L.

description: This is probably my favorite ramen restaurant in SF.  Their sushi is also very fresh.  The last time I came here, I had the chicken karrage ramen...really the best of both worlds.  Minus one star only because it's a pain in the arse to find parking & there are usually LONGGG lines.
author: Helen F.

description:
I have been deemed "Broth boy" by the gf so I feel that it's only appropriate to write my "Comeback review" on a ramen shop!  A few days ago my girlfriend had come to visit me from the south bay and we were of course.. hungry! 

It was a really rainy day which means I needed a good broth to get me through the cold! But we're driving through SF and can't decide where to eat, so I tell my gf to open up her yelp app and pick some place that sounds like it fits the weather; 3 minutes later she points out Katana-Ya! The moment I heard it was ramen I immediately responded with "directions. go!" Within a few minutes we found out the locations, then looked for parking for another 10-15 minutes, ridiculous, but it's in SF! As we stepped up to the entrance we noticed a line, stood in it for a bit then realized there was a sign up sheet, duh! We stared at the menu for about 15 minutes, huddle under the canopy and stared at the menu; even after being seated we were still unsure what to get, everything sounded so delicious and we were stuck on the combos; ramen with sashimi, ramen with curry, ramen with kastu?  Or even soba with katsu?! 

In any case we felt bad because we asked the waitress for more time twice and remembered that there were other outside in the rain =X! I ordered the Katana-Ya special which pretty much came with meat they offered: chicken wings, chasu, pork and an egg in a miso broth plus a spicy tuna roll (because I love spicy tuna); and my gf got a regular ramen, salt flavored and combo'd it with a chicken katsu bowl. 

Within 5-10 minutes we got both our bowls of ramen....weird..where's her katsu? Oh well, we dove, the aroma of the broth overwhelming me I started slurping away! Out of the corner of my eye i noticed that my spicy tuna was dropped off; but where's the katsu bowl?! I quickly notice the fried chicken and avert my attention. LoL! Getting down into my bowl I started to realize that more isn't always better. The fried chicken was actually fried, so having been sitting in my broth even for the few minutes before I got the bowl they were already soggy and I've got to be honest the batter was really yummy, but it was just a fried chicken; my gf and I were like "let's get some wings @ KFC after this." The broth was flavorful, you could taste the miso with the inclusion of all the meats, but I thought it was a bit oily compared to other broths I've had that had more of a refreshing taste. As for price to bowl size ratio, I felt that my ~$11 bowl which was pretty much a combo bowl was worth it given the contents. As for the spicy tuna roll, it was really spicy and didn't have a frozen taste, I was very satisfied =D

When we both finished though, we still didn't have the katsu bowl. I asked the waitress to check on it and she told me that they were preparing it just then...20 minutes after we got our other food and finished.... I cancelled it, we were already full; we were disappointed, she really had a katsu urge. Overall, we both agreed that the restaurant served pretty good dishes, not the best, but certainly not the worst; if you're in that part of town try it out! But be weary they can get really busy; probably why our dish was forgotten =X
author: Jon K.

description:
If you're craving good Ramen noodles in San Francisco, this is the place to go. This is a small hole in the wall restaurant, so there is no stretching out, or quiet conversations.  The Ramen is delicious!!! I make a point of eating here at least once every time I'm in town.

Make considerations for parking if you are driving here. I left my truck in a parking lot because the street parking was awful ($28us).
author: Digital A.

description:
**Update**

I gave Katana-Ya a second chance to see if they were having an off night the first time around. In addition, to the ramen, I also tried things from the sushi bar.

GOOD:
- The ramen noodles were still good.

JUST OK:
- Uni ikura don was not very good. Ikura was mushy and the eggs were a little dried out instead of bursting with juices. The uni was not as bad but average at best. 

BAD: 
- The ramen broth sucked again. I got the salt broth this time around and it was on the oily side again and was still bland overall. The broths here are a total disgrace (see my prior review).
- The chirashi was a horrible value. For $19, they were very skimpy on the sashimi (only like 6 pieces), which was average quality at best. 
- The sushi rice had too much vinegar and was sour. It was also served hot, which warmed up the sashimi that was sitting on top of it.

CONCLUSION: I have no idea why other Yelpers love the ramen here. Even the ramen places in Japantown are better than this and those places aren't even that great either.
author: Alex P.

description:
Katana-ya on Geary is the answer to "what the hell happened to that homey corner Japanese spot that was on 6th and Judah." After being deprived of this little gem for a few years, I got a tip from my friend that there was a sighting of the same Katana-ya chef at this Geary location. 

I don't know if this place has any relation to the giant Japanese retaurant/steak  house or something on O'Farrell (?), but this Geary spot certainly is that cozy homestyle joint that was near UCSF that served up kick ass chicken karaage. Perhaps katana-ya is a common name....

I came here early on a Friday night, party of two, the place was quiet. It has kind of  a moody atmosphere because they were playing some chill out tunes of the late 90s variety. It was a bit hard for me to decide since there was a lot to choose from, so I set my mind on their ramen and maguro don combo. 

I wasn't sure how the portions were divvied up, but if you order one of their ramen/soba/udon combos, what you get is a large bowl of noodles with a small portion of whatever side you choose. In my case, I got this giant bowl of ramen in a thick and slick miso broth with a slice of chashu and some bamboo shoots, and a petite bowl of fresh maguro over sushi rice. 

Now, the miso broth is indeed greasy, and you shouldn't have it more than once a week and definitely high in salt, but it definitely packed a lot of flavor. For the price of this, I could have used 1 more slice of chashu. But oh well! The noodles had good body.

The maguro don was probably the better part of my meal. The tuna was flavored, cut in thin slices and it was damn good. They didn't overlook their sushi rice as it was damn good x2. Having the combo satisfied cravings as I always want to order something that comes with a bunch of stuff, and it was actually just the right amount of food.

I also tried their california roll. It kind of looks (a bit more rice and sliced too pristinely)  like the kind you get at a supermarket but upon taste, it was pretty damn good. Comparable to the ones (ugliest but best in my book) from Tani's Kitchen in Daly City. 

The chicken karaage looked the same as before, but I was too full to try a piece of it. 

Katana-ya filled up over the course of our meal, and it was full by the time we left. Good to also know that it's open pretty late.

Their food is solid, but because I think the prices are a bit inflated, my 4 stars is actually a 3.5. 

Damn them downtown real estate prices!
author: Faffy L.

description: This is without a doubt the best ramen/sushi/oriental food location that I've eaten at. In San Francisco for vacation with no idea where to go for a great dinner, and luckily this excellent spot had great reviews and I can't get enough sushi, so we gave it a try and sure enough it didn't disappoint. The prices are quite reasonable, especially for the portion sizes and atmosphere; it's a lovely setup with haunting aromas and colorful decorations. Definitely a great stop in San Francisco!
author: Anthony G.

description: I love the ramen noodles here! So good! The place is tiny though, so order out or be ready for a wait. Spicy ramen noodles with everything are amazing!
author: Crystal K.

description:
Ramen for people who've never had real ramen. They don't have Tonkotsu ramen on the menu and admit freely that they liberally use MSG. There's good reason why you won't find Japanese clientele at this ramen shop.

How I miss Ippudo Ramen in NY...
author: Theo K.

description:
Regular shoyu ramen and kimchi fried rice combo: $13
Lunch satisfaction feeling: priceless
The noodles here are fantastic. That kimchi fried rice... omg, yum.
I'm definitely coming back again to try their other noodle soup offerings. Had a taste of the curry udon; pretty tasty. Looking forward to it!
author: Jessica L.

description: Just came back from another nice fulfilling lunch at Katana Ya. Instead of a hot bowl of yummy ramen, I decided on the Roll Combo. You get to choose any 2 rolls plus miso soup for $10 bucks! Can't beat that with a bat. I'm all over it. What a great deal and not to mention...cheap and good!!!
author: Anne E.

description:
A cold day in SF, a high recommendation from several people, and a great location close to my hotel.  I went for a late lunch hoping to avoid the mobs.  It is a tiny place but at 2 pm on a Wednesday I was seated easily.  Half the tables were full and all were slurping big bowls of noodles.  I ordered the ramen in a miso broth.  That was my mistake.  The ramen themselves were al dente tender, chewy and tasty but did not meld with the miso.  At twelve bucks for the bowl it did not sit easy on my wallet or my tummy. :P
Service was straight forward and quick.  Hope to return and try one of the other broths - maybe change my rating.
author: Ash A.

description:
Coming from Los Angeles i was like a kid who just experienced their first candy rush when i came in San Francisco. I've been here a few times already but have had the unfortunate incident to travel with others who are not avid food eaters :( THIS time was going to be different! I came with my boyfriend, and of course with our luck, the night before he got food poisoning. (Poor thing.) Luckily, it only lasts about 24 hrs so when we landed, we were already past the 12 hr mark and I'm secretly thinking, "Hurry up and feel better 'cause I wanna be fat and happy damnit!" I'm such a good girlfriend.
So it's about 4, 5pm and he states he is starting to get his appetite back. (Yay!!!) We go on Yelp, type in "Ramen" in the search box and the first place that comes up is Katana-Ya. 4 Stars and over 1,900 reviews? Sounded great to us!

Customer Service (part one): We arrive and the place is really small, no big deal; it's expected. No line = no wait. Awesome! 3 employees were talking in the back so we just took that as a hint that we needed to seat ourselves. I overheard them speaking Japanese to each other and I'm fluent in Japanese and it's so much easier to order; not to mention getting your order right!  One of the girls comes over, asks what we would like and i start ordering in Japanese... i looked up from the menu and she just stared at me like i had a severe case of something or another. I instantly became uncomfortable.. there was about a good 5 second silence. She didn't say anything; just stood there with her pen to the pad and giving me a blank look. After i realized that maybe she was just a fimbot and she was short circuiting, i repeated my order again; this time in Engrish. She jotted it down and walked away. We should've just left then but with all the reviews we were really here for the food and looking forward to it.

Ramen: Oh Thank God it's here!!! :D It looks awesome and smells heavenly and I can't wait to dig in the forget about the incident that happened with our waitress. They looked like Toyko Style noodles and I had ordered it with the Spicy-miso broth.. the bf got the same broth and had bbq pork tossed in it too. Ok, first bite in and... What. The. Fuck. These noodles SUCK. They were entirely too gummy like they had either been sitting out for a long time or someone tossed them back into the microwave to re-heat them. Damnit but i'm sooo hungry!! Correction: We're so hungry!! My bf and i were discussing how disappointed we were with the noodles BUT the one thing that was awesome was the broth. At least they had that going for them. Zero on noodles but 5 stars on the broth. Can you really give a good review on a polished turd?

Customer Service (part deux): We had to flag our waitress down to get our check, meantime I'm starting to doubt myself. "Maybe that wasn't Japanese I heard? Maybe she wasn't speaking Japanese in the back with the other two employees?" While she was getting our check, my doubts were completely dissolved. Oh ya, she was speaking Japanese alright. I couldn't catch their conversation since we had a party between us but she was talking about something being super big.. "sugooi ookii na-" and that's all i caught, but i heard words here and there,  "uso"- liar, "kawaii"- cute, "nande"- why.. 
Ugh, i think it goes without saying. Zero on the customer service.

In conclusion to this novel I realize that maybe we just came at a really bad time. I mean, there was no line so we didn't have the freshest of noodles, i would definitely like to try this place again but i can't bring myself there after the customer service experience. D: Plus there is much better noodles and customer service in the LA/OC area. Not to brag or anything ;)
author: Janet P.

description:
I have finally found my ramen spot in the city. The noodles are nice and chewy, the broth is clear and tasty and not like that weird milky stuff Santa Ramen has, the pork is tender and yummy. 

Now I don't have to trek to Japan, B.C. or Hawaii to get some decent ramen. It's a little pricey but I don't have to get on a plane when PMS hits and I'm craving ramen. 

The search is over.
author: Wendy B.

description: This is the best ramen I have had in the U.S.  We had a long wait and the table was really really small for four people with drinks.  We were uncomfortable sitting so close to other tables on small seats, but the ramen was great.  The soup was so delicious.
author: Olivia S.

description:
I absolutely love this place. I always bring my friends here and love that they open late. I highly recommend it. 

The ramen here is really good. I love eating spicy so I get my ramen extra spicy, although, i don't really find it spicy. It just looks more red than the actual level of spiciness. 

Plus! all the workers there are really nice. Especially the sushi chef! =D
author: Tina T.

description:
"Katana-ya, Fuck yeah!"  (sung to the tune of 'America, Fuck Yeah' from the movie Team America).  
Checked this place out last night at the recommendation of my fellow yelpers.  Amazingly, we got parking right across the street, which made it all feel more serenditpitous.  It's a small place, darkly lit, tables close together, and a small sushi bar.  
We were on a ramen kick, so despite how good the sushi looked, we both got the BBQ pork ramen.  I had the light broth, and the boyfriend had the rich broth.  I liked the light broth better, I thought it was perfectly flavored and not too oily.  The rich broth was (obviously) thicker.  It was also more oily and dense.  The pork was delicious and the noodles were not mushy, but done just perfectly.  It cost just slightly more than I'm accustomed to paying for ramen, but totally worth it.
author: Jessica L.

description:
