Literally a hole in the wall. But it's pretty frickin' awesome. I like it. 

So it's really...um, fucking small on the inside. I was practically hitting the person next to me. Anyway, the food is pretty decently priced for all the Japanese food I have seen. There are some super expensive rolls (which I didnt order) but looked really good. 

We started out with edamame, which is meh for me b/c I dont like it. I got the Unagi-don and the Tempura roll and my friend got the Spicy Salmon roll and the Kim-chi-don. The rolls were very deelishis and tasted very fresh. The tempura roll wasnt soggy at all, which can sometimes happen. My unagi don bowl was okay, not the greatest, and the rice kind of tasted weird. However, they get + stars b/c they offer the choice of making it small or large, which to me is great. Sometimes I dont feel like eating the whole fucking thing, but this allowed me to get a little something or everything. Or so they say. 

My friend said his as very good. So yeah, cheap, decent, and cute place to go. I will probably be coming back if I am ever in the vicinity.
author: Dustin H.

description:
Very good ramen. I've been to Toyko, and this place is legit. When I saw Japanese people working at the restaurant, and japanese people eating there, that has to be a good sign. Portions are good, noodles are cooked perfectly, and broth is delicious. 

Will definitely go again, so I can try the many many different tpyes of ramen. Prices are reasonable too.

Place is small, so there might be a wait list.
author: Eddy N.

description:
We went here for my birthday dinner around 9:00 on a Thursday night. It was busy but also because it's so teeny tiny, it seemed even more packed. There's absolutely nowhere to wait and the tables are squishysquish. There was one particularly obnoxious group of 5 near the door who sat there FOREVER and had the audacity to order dessert after their meal. Order your f-ing mochi somewhere else! Better yet, just pick up a box at TJ's and let me order my ramen! It didn't help that when he left, the biggest d-bag said, "Are you guys ready?!" to the group ahead of us. They nodded emphatically and d-bag said, "Yeah, well we waited a fucking hour in the cold!" Good for you, did you also have to wait for a group of d-bags like yourself?

Anyway, the food was brought out pretty quick and it was delicious. They actually had butter corn ramen! Usually when I first eat at a ramen place, I'll go for the shoyu as a test but I absolutely could not pass up the butter corn (with the salt broth). The noodles were perfect, just as good as Suzu; broth was better; and char-su was about the same (small).

Even better about this place? The sushi is actually good! Usually when a ramen place combines with sushi, the quality / serving is pretty crappy / small. I was super stoked on the rolls (hawaiian i think) and nigiri.

They need a better system like they have at Ryowa or Santa. Sure, you might feel like cattle but at least the food is there when you get to your table! Our actual waitress was pretty nice but they seemed nonchalant overall; since the place was busy they weren't too preoccupied with impressing anyone.

As a tip, come as a two top! You'll get seated much quicker as they have very few big tables.
author: Salina Z.

description:
I'm definitely no ramen expert, but my usual visits to other ramen places don't end with this feeling: unsatisfied. I gave the skimpy-looking bowl of ramen in front of me the chance to prove itself. Sadly, it started off being too hot to handle and too hot to enjoy. The miso broth was overkill with way too much salt/msg. If it were an outstanding bowl of ramen, I would forgive it for only having one piece of pork, two measly pieces of bamboo shoots and a dash of seaweed. My second visit was no better with the fattiest slice of pork in my shoyu ramen. One bite of edible meat was all I had. Blah! I left again feeling like I just stepped out of a salt shower. 

Sorry, I think I'll pass.
author: Sara N.

description:
Shoyu chasu hit the spot on a blustery, bone-chilling San Francisco winter afternoon.  A little hint of fish to the hearthy rich broth, the pork was tasty but not overdone (though not terribly fatty), and the noodles were perfectly chewy.

So porky I think a pig drowned in it.
author: K M.

description:
Ramen with tons of different meat in it.  Pork bones?  Chicken something?  First for me.  I think I'm going to have to stick with basic ramen.  The experience of ramen for me is coming home and eaten that warm salty bowl of joy drunk as a skunk.  

I did, surprisingly, love the soggy pot stickers in the ramen.  That is going to be my new staple.

Definitely want to go back and try the onion ramen...looked so good in the picture.

Sushi (both spicy tuna and sake) was good.  Nice and fresh.  Nummy!

This place got really packed.  People really seemed to like this place. The family next to us enjoyed their meal so much that it was their second time eating here in two days.  That says something.
author: Justine D.

description:
There are so many reviews of this place I can't help but feel kind of redundant. Nevertheless I'm compelled to add to the heap because I don't see anything about the combination lunch specials! Ranging in price from $10-12 for a bowl of ramen, served with your choice of broth and fixings, plus a donburi of your choice, it is a pretty good deal in comparison to other Japanese places. I can't remember when exactly the lunch hours are, but it does go pretty late. I got there well after 1 in the afternoon and they were still serving. 

Unfortunately the miso ramen I ordered was way too salty. The katsu-don was good, if not particularly special. Next time I go back I'll have to get a bit more adventurous with the second half of the combination. Also, as an aside, I really enjoy the small "cozy," space the restaurant is hosued in. I've probably passed the place hundreds of times riding the 38 Geary but I've never noticed it until reading these reveiws.
author: Alan L.

description:
WOW!
*say "Yes!" to the Fried Spicy Tuna Roll!
*Spicy Tofu Ramen in Miso broth was outstanding!
*Katanya roll was good, Hawaiian was better.
*Butterfish nigiri was delectable!
*cold, sweet un-filtered saki complimented this hot, spicy fare perfectly.
**note: seating is limited - but at 11 pm on a Fri, we only waited aprox. 10 min for a table!
author: Anna S.

description:
A crazy busy small japanese restaurant that get packed for lunch and dinner, 

People come here for the well known RAMEN, but they also serve a variety of sushi and many appetizer that changes frequently, Food is good but you don't come here for an intimate dinner.
author: Giu G.

description: Delicious. Make sure you get there early cause there is always a bit of a wait. The portions are very generous too.
author: Kevin L.

description:
** this posting was edited because today I went to Katana-Ya and had the lunch combo of spicey tofu ramen with tempura over rice. The tempura was actually very good, and covered with a yummy sauce. Five stars for Katana-Ya, my new favorite lunch spot!**

I went here for the first time today. I work near Union Square, and "cheap" lunch places are few and far between.

My friend IM'ed me saying that he had a hankerin' for some ramen and decided thats what he was going to have for lunch while on Muni this morning. I exclaimed "OMG! I've been dying to try this ramen place by my office. Let's do it!"

We spent the next two hours IM'ing back and forth about how we were so excited to eat noodles & reading the Yelp reviews.

Boy! I don't know squat about ramen or noodles in general (Chuck had to show me how to eat it correctly) but this stuff was great! I had the ramen in a light Soy broth with spicy tofu. It was delicious! Chuck had the same thing, and he liked his too.

Next time I am totally trying the curry noodles. I can't wait!
author: Tala D.

description: Pretty good ramen and opened late.  We come here after a show or a night out.  Usually get the regular ramen, miso base while the hubby gets chicken kaarage, soy base.  Doesn't compare to Ippudo in NYC but one of the best in SF.
author: Ren C.

description:
BEST RAMEN JOINT EVER!!!!!!!!! I always order the Butter Corn Ramen with the Soy sauce broth. Extra spicy too! IT NEVER FAILS... I live in the East Bay and I can say that the traffic and the wait in line (if there is one) is worth it! 

The noodles and broth, alongside with the vegetables are definitely fresh. Each bowl is always even and well-balanced , so you can distinguish each component from one another; but at the same time, when combined, you can enjoy the wholesome taste and perfect marriage of all these elements -- such as the noodles, corn,  pork, bamboo, seaweed.. Ahhh!  Every bite, every sip and every slurp is just amazingly and utterly sensational! 

This place is open until 2:00am. I can say I have been here at midnight with a few friends for a late bite to eat after shopping during the holidays and despite having a long day at work, their service remains outstanding!

Caution -- This place is very tiny. It probably sits about 25-30 people at max, mostly consisting of tables for two. My group, each time I've gone had 4-6 people and left us cramming and hovering over these tiny tables. But hey, with the excellent food and the contagious smiles from the polite and handsome waiters, you get over your claustrophobia. And If anything, this place, offers you and your group a very intimate and cozy setting :)

Bravo Katana-Ya! See you soon!!!
author: Jenny S.

description:
The fried chicken ramen (miso flavor, spicy), is one of the best dishes ever.  

Better ramen than the places in Japantown or Orenchi in Santa Clara.
author: Chris T.

description: This is the go-to place for ramen in the city! Whenever I'm near Union Square and I get the craving for some hot ramen I just take a short walk to this place and fulfill my craving. The shop is pretty small so the wait can be pretty long if you go during lunch time but its worth it. I recommend ordering the Katana-Ya ramen.. my favorite!! It pretty much is their specialty and comes with a little bit of everything! Sometimes the portions are too much but to any hungry person thats always a plus! Its definitely my favorite place for ramen in the city.. so far..
author: kristel c.

description: The ramen noodles are alright and so is the broth but the pork was super dry and chewy.. kinda like old beef jerky.  Ordered extra noodles with my order and it took awhile... so by the time we got them the broth was cold.  Also, it sucks when the waitress tells you to sit wherever.. and then you sit at the bar or somewhere you want to and they ask you to move...  not very good service!
author: Jen L.

description:
So I've been to another Katana-Ya in El Ceritto a few times and found it decent. I am very experienced with Japanese food as I have been to Japan many times and my mother is Japanese. The food here was pretty good. The ramen was better than I had expected for an American Ramen place. The sushi was pretty good. Pretty fresh.

I give it four stars because it is definitely over priced. There food is good, but not worth the price. It's nice to go if you're willing to pay for an overpriced tastely bowl of ramen.
author: Lily V.

description: Try to get there early or else you will have to wait.  Fresh made noodles and For Uni lovers it's fresh sweet and smooth.
author: jennie r.

description:
This place was crowded when we came here to eat around 11pm, but the place is teeny but the food was well worth it.  

I got the chicken karaage ramen made spicy, and it was pretty spicy but not the kind that lingers in your mouth.  My friend got sushi, which to my surprise was really good and melted like butter.  It was very unexpected that the fish, which was hamachi, would actually taste that good in a place where the reviews for their sushi on here were just average.  The service was excellent too.  It was a little pricey but it was worth it.
author: Raymond L.

description:
One of the better Ramen joints in the city. SF is not known for Ramen, and most go down to Santa in San Mateo, or down to San Jose for a good bowl. But this place is surprisingly decent for the city. Corn butter ramen is a nice treat. I like the option to choose between light or dark soy or miso broth. 

Sushi is mediocre. Go for the noodles. Bonus points for staying open late.
author: Chris M.

description:
MMMMmmmm...yummy Ramen.  i had the thick miso broth with spicy tofu and it was really good.  the noodles were just the right texture and the broth was rich, but not too rich and it was as advertised - spicey.  

also had an oyster shooter which in my opinion was good but not something to write home about.  i did like how the tiny fish eggs were like little garlic pop rocks that occassionally unleased a spark of garlicky goodness into my mouth lingering into the play i watched i across the street. =)

it was great meal for the cold windy night as is usual is sf.  will definitely be coming back for more ramen.
author: craig m.

description: Long story short. Ramen only, no sashimi, no sushi out was frozen. Ramen I give  4 stars.
author: Kenneth F.

description:
Came here one night when parents were in town and wanted some comfort food late at night. We walked here from the Fairmont, and they were happy happy happy.

Got 3 Ramens, one with everything, one seafood, one spicy miso BBQ pork. I liked the broth, though it was on the salty side, didn't care for the noodles. 

Just wondering...is this the best Ramen you get in SF? 3 stars for the food, 4 stars for the price. So cheap that's worth the trip and the annoyance of the tourists in downtown there.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I love ramen.  I spent 2 weeks in Japan and whenever i come to Katana ya, it reminds me of that wonderful experience.

5 stars for them being open till 2 am, although they can close early or stop serving depending on their mood.  They have a great sake list as well.

I always get the extra spicy ramen with pork and some gyoza and some other stuff.  But the food is so good and the soup is so good that i empty my bowl.
author: Terence P.

description:
I came here last night with 3 friends to see what the hype was all about.  I got there at 6:40pm, put our names down on the waitlist, and luckily, a table was ready for us by 7pm.  I got the Katanaya Ramen because it comes with everything, and that's what most of us got.  I got mine with soy based broth, but I also got to try the miso broth from a friend.  At $12.90, this is a very expensive bowl of ramen.  I'd say that it was very good, but I wasn't blown away by the flavor.  Maybe my expectations were too high because this place has over 2000 reviews.   I was expecting something amazing, like Orenchi ramen down in Santa Clara, but the broth here was nothing special.  I also thought that the chasu was flavorful, but not as tender as I'd like.  On the plus side, the fried chicken and the fried dumplings in the ramen were both very good and a cool addition to the dish.  The chicken was moist, tender and tasty and I would be happy with just a bowl of that.  The fried gyoza were also delicious.  We also ordered a side of the spicy tuna roll, which I also thought was very good.  At $6, it is steep for spicy tuna, but it is one of the better spicy tuna rolls that I have had.

I think the food here is good, but a bit overpriced.  However, I don't think it's so amazing that I'd go out of my way for it or wait in a long line for it.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Katana, Yah Dude!! Ok that was lame. But the ramen here definitely ain't. First off, I love the location. It is right by Union Square and very accessible. Then of course, there is the ramen. Wow!! Delicious. I've tried the Shoyu and Spicy Green Onion. Both are excellent. And I love the fact that you can order a light broth here. Helps prevent that I-gotta-loosen-my-belt post-ramen bloated feeling. 

You might have to wait a bit to get seated, but trust me it's worth the wait. This is currently my favorite ramen joint in the Bay Area.
author: Henry L.

description: I can see why my girl likes goin here so much. She suggested to try the Katana-ya ramen soup.  I got to say its pretty darn good.  It was pretty good size bowl they give you as well.  The down side to it of course is the wait and limited seating.  Parking can be difficult unless u want to pay like 10 bucks in the near by garages.   We also tried the crunchy spice tuna roll. It is served on a bed of greens. Overall taste was good but cuz they deep fry the roll the tuna was cooked. So ehh...I dnt like cooked tuna in my roll.  But over all experience is good.
author: Christine M.

description:
Katana-Ya is a very cute ramen shop in SF but it's very cramped just like any other ramen shop. Their was a wait but it wasn't too bad about 20 minutes. They have a huge variety of ramen though which is awesome. 

I had their BBQ pork ramen and I kind expected their to be a different kind of pork meat in my ramen but it honestly looked like the meat you usually get from all the other ramen dishes but just with more. 

It was good but it was kind of below my expectations, but I think I'll get their special next time.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Good place. Udon was the best that I have had in years, ramen was very tasty. We also ordered toro, which was melt-in-your-mouth good. They also have a wide array of funky rolls, which I like. My wife is more traditional in her sushi fare, but still liked this stuff. 

The decor was off-putting, the service awkward, but this looks to be our go-to noodle house in SF.
author: Benjamin T.

description: A lot of hype, wasn't really impressed, the tiny hole in the wall Japanese places off of Clement and Geary do a better job at a fraction of the cost!
author: Janette P.

description: Literally my first stop every time I land in SF. Miso ramen + chirashi sushi or salmon don =) perfect for cold rainy days. Be prepared to wait - make sure to put your name down, its a small place, but worth it. Open till 1am, even on weekdays!
author: Lonny Y.

description: Today, I tried the salmon teri plate, it came with two generous fillets of sweet tasting salmon; the rice was flavorful, not to sticky or starchy. Also, the side petite salad was fresh if tiny. My friend enjoyed the miso flavored ramen and said it was very good. Good customer service. Low key. Cool 70' R&B classics gently massage your ears and elevate your appetite.
author: Bert K.

description: This place is wayyy overrated. Service was bad. Took them super long time to get the drinks out. How long can they take to serve two cups of water? Katana-Ya ramen wasn't as good as rated. Soup base was too oily and salty, noodles were soggy and overcooked. There're bamboo shoots, gyoza, chicken karaage, charshu, corn and seaweed in the ramen. bamboo shoots smells like cat food. Sf has better place for ramen instead of this overrated and expensive place.
author: Erin N.

description:
It's been a few months since I've been here, but I went back last week and was disappointed that they no longer have their combo menu for dinner. Combo meals were the best - pick from ramen, sushi, tempura for under $15. Ramen's delicious but now kind of pricey at $9 a bowl. 
My guess is that money has gone to updating the dining room, as they've redone their walls and added more decor to make everything look more presentable. Still my go-to-spot to eat when downtown, but not sure about the changes.
author: rosanna c.

description:
First time visitor should just try their Katana Ya Ramen. It's kind of like a combo ramen set which gives you a bit of everything.

Place is small and you will probably need to wait between 10 to 15 mins for a seat during peak hour.

The wait is worthwhile because the food served is really tasty.
author: Jason C.

description:
This was the first ramen place that I have ever been to.  I had nothing to compare it to so it was really good to me.  If I had reviewed it back then - I 
would have given it four stars.

But since I ate at Ryowa and the ramen place in Sydney, Australia.  I would say this place is okay.  Since there aren't many selections in SF - I would come back.  You can get combos so - Ramen and a side of don.  I usually get the miso broth based.

I read a few reviews and they said the sushi was fresh... Ummm I don't know about.  So this is place is pretty relative - good decent food and at a good price.  If that's what you're looking for and you're in union square go try it.
author: Bess N.

description:
I came here on a warm Saturday afternoon and luckily, got seated near the door because this restaurant was really really warm.  Not sure if they have AC...  

I ordered the sashimi combination and my dining partner got the pork ramen with soy sauce broth.  I felt like everything was very high quality and tasty (and the service was good) but I wasn't completely impressed and wasn't sure why it was worth the drive out.  I couldn't really taste the difference between this place and Maru Ichi in Mountain View.  Later, I talked to my cousin and she said that I have to get the ultra spicy ramen or something and her eyes lit up like a kid on Christmas so I guess I'll be returning to give this a try.

I guess this was just a little overhyped for me after reading up on all the Yelp reviews.  I'll try it again and see if my opinion is changed.
author: Jennifer D.

description: The food was too salty for my liking. I felt really thirsty after eating their ramen.
author: Forest T.

description:
I can't stand by any longer and have the good name of ramen be so denigrated and molested in such a flagrant manner. I'm not saying this isn't good ramen for SF now granted, us ramen lovers have a very "limited"  set of options when it comes to ramen (here and basically Suzu are the only edible ramen houses). BUT that doesn't mean there isn't good ramen outside of SF which we should have a responsibility to rate against. We musn't let bland (or salty ) ramen be excused as "good in sf" and miscategorized as "light" or "flavorful." The soup lacks the depth that ramen is known for and they skimp with 1 to 2 slices of chasu which was very good and flavorful a surprising contrast to the soup. 

The wait on weekend are horrible compared to shin shen gumi or even Da Hey Jia (the big black house) in LA . Oh and the seats are uber cramped so like unless ur 5'2 and 100lbs soaked u better hope ur a transformer and can transform in to a small asian girl.
author: Bryant Y.

description:
It was a long day for my travel buddy and me in SF -- we tandem biked the Golden Gate Bridge from Fisherman's Wharf to Sausalito. We thought, "what better way to see the landmark than to bike across it," right? Yes, it was breathtaking. Yes, it was magnificent. But, oh what torture on our lethargic Texan bodies accustomed to only waddling to our cars and from our cars to the nearest BBQ or fast food joint. 

Pale-faced and deathly-exhausted, we walked to the nearest cable car (Powell-Hyde) and unexpectedly waited another 45 minutes clad in summer clothing in the freezing cold (50 degree) night -- who would've thought tourists would be lined up for cable cars at 9:30 PM and WHY was it so bitterly cold in the middle of summer? To add to our wonderful day, I then got crapped on by a pigeon, but let's not bask in my misfortune. Despite the amount of tremendous pain, physical torture, and nature's gift of feces, it was all forgotten once the first bite of hot, spicy ramen rejuvenated the deprived palate at Katana-ya. 

We started our recovery with Temaki hand rolls. One order comes with three rolls - spicy tuna, unagi, and salmon (I think) - all of which were pretty solid and refreshing. Nothing spectacular, though. 

My friend ordered the spicy tofu ramen and I ordered the BBQ pork ramen extra spicy (no other way) -- both miso based. Her broth was thick, not too spicy, and full of flavor. I've never had thick ramen broth before, so this was quite unusual for me, but it was surprisingly delicious nonetheless. My broth was also thick, but completely red. They weren't messing around when they meant extra spicy. It burned my mouth, lit my esophagus on fire, and warmed my body from the inside out -- it was bliss. Even through all that spice, I could still savor the full flavor of the ramen broth and enjoy the hint of pork aroma. What really sets this ramen place apart from others is its ramen noodle consistency. To me, it wasn't rubbery or too soft, but cooked just right so that it had solid texture and great bite feel. I knew this was just as satisfying to my friend as it was to me when I saw life flow back into her nose and cheeks. 

To say that this was the best ramen I've ever had would not be a gross overstatement, but it is ranked very close to the top. This place is best after a grueling day or during a cold night, thus every night is a great night for Katana-ya in SF.
author: Stephen M.

description:
What I like about this place is the location since it's near to Union Square.  It can be convenient if I'm downtown shopping on a cold day and don't want to trek to Japan Town. I'd go back.  I tried this place after a party at the Westin St. Francis (Yelp party).  The wait was long and had it not been for the good company, it may have not been worth the wait (my memory may fail me but I think we waited approx. 30 min).  It is a quaint place, ie. small.  I got the Extra Spicy Ramen and ordered soba noodles vs. udon and chose the shoyu vs. miso broth.   The broth was hot, and tasty and I really liked the noodles (it's not that spicy where your tongue/taste buds becomes numb).  I have a large appetite and I couldn't finish my bowl.  IF your in the area by foot, and have a craving for ramen, I'd def. recommend a stop in.

Next time, I want to try the Kimchi Ramen.
author: Sheila W.

description: Worth the wait.  Although their specialty is rightfully ramen, the sushi is surprisingly high quality, and the servers are always sweet.  Food comes out fairly fast, the beer and sake flow freely, and they are open late into the night.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Ate there this week with a few people since the other restaurants were still slammed with the pre-theater dinner crowd.  

Overall the food was a mixed bag.  My ramen (light, BBQ pork, soy) was very good.  I enjoyed everything about it including the inevitable spot or two on my white shirt (Murphy's Law 528 - you will almost always get a spot on your shirt while eating Italian or anything with broth if it is white).   In fact, the broth with some crusty bread would an ideal late night food after an alcohol-fueled Friday or Sat. night.

The rest of our meal was not quite as good as the ramon.  There was some interesting sushi options on the menu but I wasn't crazy about what we ordered.  Quality of the seafood (yellowtail tuna, scallops) was so-so and presentation was a bit sloppy.  Plus, our orders arrived ad hoc and not at the same time.  

Service was definitely not a strong point.  Waitress was friendly but she was just not on top of anything.  Our orders came out at different times but that is probably an issue with the back-end of the restaurant. I know from previous experience as a waiter.  It can be incredibly frustrating to deal with especially if customers don't understand that.    

What bothered me was that our waitress seemed lackadaisical.  Didn't come back to check to see how our food was or refill our water glasses once.  Maybe she was spread a bit too thin.  Still, she definitely wasn't making much of an effort to hustle even if that was that case.

I would come back here again but I know to only order the ramen (including trying the miso which I sampled and was pretty solid).  Plus, I will make sure to come here at an off-hour because the service was not a strong point when this place was busy.
author: Matthew G.

description:
So I somehow had the bright idea to *drive* down to Union Square and get take-out from Katana-Ya.  On a rainy night.  In the full swing of holiday season.  With a sick boy who didn't want to have to park and walk more than a block away.  We happen upon it with not much ado; naturally we drive by Ruby Skye with the line curling around the block.  We see Union Square with the hordes of shoppers and tourists wandering about.  We drive along the jammed street parking with nary a space except for the hotel unloading/ loading zones. We make a halfhearted attempt to enter the Post-Taylor garage to park and back out immediately nearly killing some pedestrians after reading "$5.50 ... first 20 minutes..."

So the boy gets dropped off and I begin to circle.  He reads me the menu over the phone and we make our selections.  And I circle. And circle. And circle.  Eventually I park illegally in a white zone in front of the Donatella Hotel - across from that crazy wraparound Ruby Skye line.  I wait.  I text the boy.  I see a message on the Crackberry that reads "Parking. Hurry."  Springing into action I round the corner to see the boy waving me into a spot that appears to have just opened in front of the ramen house.

As I pull in, I see someone run out of Katana-Ya with our dinner, hand it to the boy, who gets into the car.   "I almost got nailed by someone who wanted this space.  He was so mad that I wouldn't move he chucked a full water bottle at me."

Was it worth it?

2 ramen soups (shoyu, one with pork and light, one with negi onion and rich, both very redolent of konbu and bamboo shoots); 2 sushi rolls (albacore + maguro over cali roll); I sake nigiri; 1 seaweed salad = around $60 with tip.

Was it worth it?
Not so sure... we may be back someday, definitely sans car... perhaps if we somehow have to be in that Ruby Skye line ...
author: Claudine C.

description:
This is an inferior restaurant that may appease the touristy homiez that it obviously attempts to cater to with its proximity to Union Square, but every Japanese person I know (myself included, and not to be ethno-elitist here) pretty much finds this place slightly revolting.

The first time I came here, unaware of the reputation it had garnered on Yelp and other "foodie" publications, I ordered the katsu-don and my homie had ramen.  The pork in the katsu-don was approximately 60-70% gristle; needless to say it was rather disgusting and nearly inedible.  However, I ate it, not wanting to seem rude.

Also, the service was horrible; at around 4:30p on a Thursday, the restaurant was nearly empty, save 3-4 waitresses who neglected to retrieve our drinks after we had ordered them, and gave us some very pouty-faced attitude when, 10 minutes later, we inquired as to where our sake was.

Unfortunately, as a result of outside influence (becoming aware of the aforementioned "foodie" publications who generally give Katana-ya a positive review), I decided to go back in order to try the famed ramen.  Again, I was disappointed, albeit not as disappointed as I had been with the katsu-don, but at least the shoyu flavor ramen was edible this time.

I generally don't consider myself a playa-hata, but I have developed a strong disdain for this restaurant, and I have a difficult time understanding the cultish following that it seems to have garnered among many people.

Santa Ramen in San Mateo carries a far superior product even though they often run out of food and also have spotty customer service.
author: Peter L.

description: There are not that many broth choices to pick from.  Normally, other ramen places would have tonkotsu, shoyu, or miso.  All they have is shoyu.  That is a bit boring.  Also, the broth is too salty and the ramen doesn't feel bouncy to the bite.  I will have to say this place is way overrated. However, Katana-Ya seems like the only ramen place in this area.  Visit the South Bay or the Penisula for better choices.
author: Ernesto F.

description: Four of us foodies went there today because my husband had read about it and was curious how a good ramen place would be. I got the #1 ramen soup with a miso base and a slice of pork and scallions in it. It was okay; edible; but nothing to return for. I will say the noodles were of an excellent quality, but when I want to have a carb fix, ramen is about the last thing I would spend those weight watcher points on. I would much rather have excellent pasta or a slice of excellent pizza any day of the week. The atmosphere (it is a tiny place) is charming, but the tables for 4 are really only big enough for 2.
author: Barbara S.

description:
My co-workers swear-ed this was the best ramen place in the city, so we waited for 1-1/2 hour for a table. We ended up splitting up the party because a table for 5 was impossible and we couldn't wait any longer. 

Was it worth it? YES! 

The ramen was super yummy. The homemade noodles were delicious. I got the spicy tofu ramen and it was pretty spicy. The tempura and goyzas were also tasty. 

I went back the following weekend with another friend, there wasn't a wait and we were seated right away. I had the miso broth with tofu and pork. The pork melted in your mouth. It was awesome. 

If you like ramen, this is the place for you. Just expect a long wait if you go on a Fri/Sat nite.
author: Gladys C.

description:
I remembered that I came last time just to get ramen late in the evening after drinking in the area.  :p

Since I went there in the mid afternoon, I was able to get in without any wait.  During the lunchtime, they have this combination meal - ramen, udon, or soba + choice of rice bowl for $10.  I chose shoyu ramen (per their recommendations) + veggie tempura rice bowl.  

Noodles were okay, but I did not care about the broth - it did not convince me to finish the broth.  Veggie tempura rice bowl was good though. 

Even during this non-peak hours, they looked to be busy.
author: Hiro S.

description:
In my opinion the best Ramen Spot in San Francisco! It's not all about quantity in this place but it sure is great quality! My favorite is anything with the miso broth. The broth at Katana-Ya is delicious and hearty. Noodles are cooked just right and the pork is tender and flavorful. I used to go to this place back when it was in the avenues and I was totally devastated  when they closed down. The moment I heard they had reopened I went there soon after. I rarely order anything else other than Ramen, but the tempura batter is light and crispy and their fried rice is pretty darn good also.

It's very difficult to find parking so I don't always go, but if I'm spending a day shopping in downtown I'll most likely end up here for dinner. A good thing is it stays open til like 1:30am or something so shop til everything closes and make your way over for some delicious Ramen. A small shop but well worth it. If Ichiro Suzuki eats here when he's in the bay area  playing against the A's that's got to say something to you about the authenticity of their Ramen! and yes I did see him there!
author: Kazuaki K.
M. F.

description: Always come here at least once during our SF visits. Small and quaint. Best spicy ramen we have had so far up here!
author: Lily L.

description:
I'm a restaurant bigot. I judge ethnic eateries by the proportion of native customers to Americans. Last Thursday night, Katana Ya had natives in spades. Among the eight tables squeezed into the cozy dining room, four of them had Japanese patrons. How this statistic correlates to food quality is debatable, but for Katana Ya it says something good.

My companion and I both ordered ramen. I chose the spicy onion, which comes with a slice of pork. (Vegetarians: take note.) The spicy onion fragrance is delightful. The dish has a nice balance of textures; the supple noodles are complemented by crunchy bamboo. My friend got the pork bowl, which had a few more slices than mine. The portions aren't huge, but the ramen is still priced reasonably--for the neighborhood.

On this Thursday night, we arrived at 8:30 and waited 15 minutes for a table for two. The restaurant can accommodate groups of four comfortably. At 9, a party of Japanese girls swept in without a wait. They were greeted with a smile by the hostess. Getting back to the native-to-American ratio, it says something, too, about a restaurant's ambience. I like to hear the sounds of the restaurant staff happily chatting in their mother tongue with the diners.
author: William L.

description:
This troubled shoyu ramen addict has finally found a spot in San Francisco to establish herself as a regular. After an arduous and hungry search for a city ramen joint who can rival their Peninsula competitors like Santa, Himawari and Mariuchi's- and a brief stint where I was going to Nijiya and making ramen myself from the instant packages, complete with authentic shoyu pork, bamboo shoots, seaweed and a boiled egg- Katana-Ya has definitely made it in the running. 

YAs: (1) The shoyu broth is rich and heartwarming, and the pork is tender and a bit on the fatty side; (2) They offer other stuff on the menu if you're not into ramen (God forbid!); (3) Great location, right across the street from the theatres and next to several snazzy bars; (4) Opens late, and nothing beats ending a night of druken fun than dunking your head into a bowl of ramen; and (5) It's CHEAP!

NAs:  (1) The place is tiny and gets packed quickly; (2) The serving size could be more generous- they bring out your bowl only half-filled with ramen. Either give us more broth or get smaller bowls. They also leave out the boiled egg, which is essential; and (3) The waitresses are LOUD! They like to yell out a banshee-like cry goodbye from wherever they're at in the restaurant when you leave,  making the diners around them jump in fright and choking on their noodles. But hey, as long as no one has to perform the heimlich on me because of this, I will continue to be a big Katana-Ya fan.

**UPDATE ON 4/19/08**
The portions have definitely gotten bigger, and the waitresses quieter, so it gets the last star!
author: Alice P.

description:
After being stuck in bed all day Saturday due to my stupid summer cold, i was getting a little stir crazy and begged my hubby to get some ramen on Sunday.  Yes it was freakin' cold in the city but hey, ramen is good for those kinds of days. Hot yummy broth and perfectly cooked noodles.

I have bumped Katana-ya up from 4 stars to 5 stars. Yep, I, who rarely gives 5 stars must give Katana-ya 5 stars.  Why? because any place that can taste so freakin' awesome to a sick person with no tastes buds definitely deserves it!
author: Mary L.

description:
Katana-ya is a little hole-in-the-wall in downtown San Francisco, not far from Union Square.  

It's run by bustling Japanese nationals.  The food is good.  I always get the deluxe Katana-ya ramen with all the extras in it.  It's significantly more expensive than other ramen places, though, and there's often a long wait.  

Overall, I'd go back again.  Their extended late night hours is a big bonus.  But overall, I'd definitely give the edge in flavor and deliciousness to Suzu in Japantown.  I like their ramen better, and in fact think it's the best in all of San Francisco of the places that I've tried so far.  Their prices are lower, too, but they also have a significant wait all the time.
author: Dave N.

description: I came here and there was a wait. While waiting I saw stickers on their window say "people love us on Yelp" which apparently is true as it is highly rated. I was not as impressed as their sushi was good but not fantastic. I guess I should have tried the big bowl of ramen which I heard was delicious. Overall, a good sushi place.
author: Jason F.

description:
Ramen is the perfect solution on a cold, windy, (or rainy) day. I had the combo of regular ramen with soy broth and katsu don. The proportion was just right (but might be not enough if you eat a lot like me) and the taste is pretty authentic.

But to be honest I'm a biased customer who is used to the taste and portion of Daikokuya in Little Tokyo. Katana-Ya's proportion is too small (for me) and the ramen doesn't come with an egg (or fat big pieces of pork)! Nonetheless I'll be going back to Katana-Ya on rainy days until Daikokuya comes to SF someday.
author: Kelly G.

description: Ramen was okay. Definitely had MUCH better in SF and LA.. The chicken karaage was just okay as well. The sushi was pretty good. If I had the sushi alone I'd prob give this place a 4/5. But the mediocre ramen (what they're supposed to be known for) combined with such a small eating space (a 2-person table turned horizontal for 4-full sized people) give this place just a 3. Actually, the service isn't great either.. Being that we were squished in a horizontal 2-person table, we asked if we could occupy the empty table next to us as well (half the place is empty) and they said, "no, sorry". !@#$#.. Not likely to come back..
author: Sabrina T.

description:
I wish I had known about this place sooner. I would have gone here instead of the mall food court in the past.  When I went last night, there was always a group of people waiting to eat in this tiny place. I think the entire restaurant seats a maximum of about 30.  

The prices are great and portions are bigger than average. The ramen bowl's equivalent to 2.5 packages of top ramen...but the quality is much better. I had the katsu don which is possibly one of the best I've had. the Katsu was krispy and the sauce was savory.  

The next time I'm cold while shopping in the city, I'll make sure to remember this place for some warm ramen soup and tasty katsu. mmm.
author: Jay M.

description:
Sure.  You can eat Ramen someplace else.  You can tell yourself that the other Ramen you are eating is just good enough.  It's consistent.  It treats you nice.  It provides for you.  It works hard and wants to make you happy.  So what if there's no chemistry. Chemistry is overrated.  Not everyone finds the Ramen of their dream. You'll settle. That other Ramen will be fine.

Or you can eat at Katana-Ya and know what it truly means to find a Ramen that will make your spirit soar and your heart sing. 

Really, it's your choice. 

P.S. BBQ Pork Ramen in Miso Soup rocks. Spicy Ramen could have been spicier but it's a minor flaw in perfection.
author: Aron L.

description:
On a cold, rainy night in SF, Katana-Ya really hits the spot and unlike most other good ramen in the city, is easy to get to.  The spicy tofu ramen with miso base is awesome and I really like that I can get it sans MSG.  

Minus one star for the extreme squished-ness our table felt and waiting outside in the cold.
author: Olivia T.

description: Good value for the price! For $14 I got a ramen and curry don. Deff worth the price if you're around the area
author: Amanda L.

description:
idk if Katana-Ya truly serves the "Best Ramen in SF", but i do know that it was not very good... so if this is the "Best Ramen in SF", I am very disappointed...

from my experience, it seems that Katana-Ya has been over-hyped and people continue to rave about it just because they like its pretty lights, extensive sushi menu, and late night ramen. I tried the ramen, the katsu, and the sushi... nothing blew me away: the ramen was alright but the broth was boring and lifeless, the sushi was way overpriced, and I would say the katsu was the best thing I had all night

but really.... really SF, is that the best you've got?! I shall continue by quest for good Bay Area ramen.
author: Lana N.

description: I was very happy with this place. It is SMALL. I guess that is somewhat normal for downtown SF. But you would be lucky to be able to have a big group go there. The food was great. There is attention to detail of the food. I really need to go back to try more items. I stuck with the sushi rolls, but everyone around me was eating soup. Is there something I am missing here? Maybe I should try that next time.
author: Kevin D.

description:
Came here because it was on the 7x7 The Big Eat SF. Meh, it was okay. But maybe I just can't find any reason to think that ramen is spectacular. If I'm paying $10 for a bowl of ramen, I'm expecting to be blown away. The place is tiiinnny. I didn't quite enjoy that because I felt too squished. 

The ramen was just... ramen. We ordered the BBQ pork and the fried chicken. There's not a lot of meat in there, again feeling ripped off by a $10 bowl of ramen. We also ordered a rice bowl with chicken and egg. It was decent, but again not worth the money.

The place is not bad, but I wouldn't go back again.
author: Mei C.

description:
I have to boo Katana-ya... I was all hyped and walked 8 blocks to arrive at this place last week, the service was horrible and the food was no more then 2.5 star. 

Appetizer choices were halibut collar and gyoza. 
Dinner choices were eel over rice and BBQ pork with shio ramen. 

The shio broth was decent, but the ramen noodle was over cooked, hence mushy. The eel was microwaved item, just like most Japanese restaurant in the USA so there is nothing be critical about. 

Gyoza is one thing the restaurant has to master and the taste has to be distinguish because this dish is so common in Asian cuisine that anyone could make gyoza at home.
author: Ada L.

description:
I came back here once again with my friend on a very late Tuesday night and we picked this place because they were open late so we wouldn't feel rushed about closing time. This review, however, is not about the food (I would probably give it a 2.5 stars for the soy ramen with deep fried chicken; it was far too salty), it is about the service we got from one particular server.

We get seated and we pretty much decided relatively quickly what we wanted but the server doesn't come around so we chatted until our server came around. She asks us what we want and my friend orders his ramen and he had to repeat himself three, yes, THREE times to her because she was spacing out and it wasn't even like we weren't responding immediately after being asked what we wanted; it was like she asked us what we wanted and decided to just not listen. Then she would apologize and ask him to repeat himself and again, spaces out... and then again... Now, I understand how this may be a problem for someone who speaks at a lower volume but I can assure you, my friend was speaking more than loud and clearly enough for this to be a non-issue.

Then I'm like whatever, so I order my ramen and she asks us what we want to drink; my friend orders a beer and I just get water. The server then turns around and I kid you not, this was something out of the movies or TV commercial; we hear this very loud "OH MY GOD!!!", we turn to see what was going on and she has a friend as a customer and they were hugging and telling each other how good each other looked and all I had to do was roll my eyes. Now, understand this, I do not care if you socialize with your friends after we have been taken care of but do notice that our orders are still in her hands at this point and she is completely oblivious to that fact; she continues to chat with her friend for probably five minutes (if not more) while still holding our orders in her hand.

One of the other servers then come to us and asked us if we were taken care of and yes, this THING that our server was going on and on for was going on for this long that a person, who, by the way, were not responsible for taking care of us, have noticed that our orders are not in yet. We tell him yes, but our orders have not gone in yet, pointing to our server. He then is kind enough to ask us what we ordered for drinks and we tell him a beer and water and he was kind enough to get us that while we waited for our server to be 'done'. The server then goes in and brings out our water and beer and you guessed it, our server still has our orders in her hand, chatting away with her friend. By now, I'm extremely irritated but I let it slide since I'm not usually one to complain and it was late so I don't think there were any managers around even if I wanted to and if there were managers around, I'm sure he/she would not allow this THING to go on for as long as it did.

Finally, our server is "done chatting", brings our orders in and then comes out with a beer and water in her hands, completely oblivious to the fact that someone else has already done that for her. Halfway to our table, she sees that we already got our drinks and she walks away, no apology... nothing. So we wait some time for our food to come and another server brings out our food. While eating, our server is just chatting away with her friend, not bothering to check in with us once and if I didn't know any better, didn't even bother to look at our table. Again, I'm not going to fuss about being checked in on every 5 minutes but maybe once would be nice. We get done eating and we get the check from our server and it is by this time, I wonder if I should even tip. I do tip, and rather generously too since I'm usually not one to be stingy about tipping, I only hope that the tip is being split among the other server because he certainly deserved it more than our supposed server.

I rarely, rarely ever dislike the service I get and even less so to the point where I am compelled to write a review about as I feel it shows poorly on the restaurant and the quality of their food, however, this was unforgivable. If management do read this, I genuinely hope they address this issue because the service we got that night was far beyond poor - it was non-existent. All she did was take our order, hold it in her hands for MUCH longer than was acceptable, paid no attention to us and then got paid to do that while chatting with her friend and note that she wasn't even the one to bring us our food. We would have gotten our food faster if we went into the kitchen and made it ourselves. I'm not sure I want to come back here unless nothing else was open with service like that.
author: Richard C.

description:
I get a call from my friend in New York and he tells me that he just had a big bowl of ramen from Momofuku.  I immediately salivate.  Man, I haven't had a big bowl of piping ramen with Berkshire pork and veggies and a poached egg since I've moved out West. 

So I went here, and ordered a kimuchee bowl with shoyu sauce and the first few slurps were amazing.  The kimchee added the right amount of spice to the bowl, the pork was tender, and the broth had just the right amount of saltiness.  After a minute I began to realize that it was no longer spicy and there the pork was no where to be seen.  What?? Can it truly be that there were only a few slivers of kimchee and only 2 thin slices of pork?  Huh?

What happened?  I was left eating big-ass bowl of broth consisting only of ramen for the rest of the meal.  Dude...that first minute of eating was really nice though.

I also had hamachi - pretty fresh and buttery-like.  AHHH HAMACHI!
author: Guava C.

description:
I got Katana-Ya ramen here. It was very good-especially the chicken and meat. They were very tender and flavorful. The dumplings, eggs and noodle were nothing out of ordinary if you have had ramen before. The soup had lots of msg-it's very salty and makes you drink lots of water. Furthermore $12 a bowl is pretty pricey for ramen if you've had ramen before.

Perhaps this is the best ramen place in SF-which would mean that SF doesn't have much ramen. It wasn't bad-I thought it was good but I've had better at a cheaper price.
author: Grace S.

description:
I have been here like 20 times and it is usually my fault for thinking I will be seated anytime soon.  If you want decent ramen this is the only place in the city worth visiting, at least that I have discovered so far.  I feel like the have a monopoly on my business b/c when I get the craving for ramen this is the only place to go (forget Genki - would you want the French making your chinese food??).  I would give them 4 stars but they have don't things like combine a table for 2 and 4 to make it accommodate a party of six that showed up after my guest and I.  

The miso ramen is decent, the gyoozas are hit or miss, sometimes overcooked, sometimes undercooked.  One plus is that they have "Japanese" beer on tap (unfortunately it is imported from Canada).  How I wish I could find a place with Eichigo beer on tap...
author: Frank F.

description:
Noodles didn't taste that fresh. Only had few pieces of meat, felt like a rip off paying $10 for a bowl of ramen. I literally got full from noodles and soup. After eating the ramen, I was dying of thirst. 

I ordered the gyoza, which was really yummy. but WOW $6 for only FOUR is like extortion. 

Parking sucks but it is in downtown. I feel that the time I find parking, I can already drive to Maru ichi, which have fresh noodles.
author: Willa L.

description:
For some reason, San Francisco is almost totally devoid of good Japanese food.
(That's right, even though there is a Japan-Town etc.)

Katana-ya serves real decent Ramen , made of some great broth, probably the best in S.F. 

The next best would be Santa Ramen in San Mateo.
author: Lisa M.

description: Salt flavor pork ramen from Katana-Ya is my favorite. Actually the best ramen IMO in bay area. Ipudo in New York is definitely better, but if you don't have the luxury of flying all the way to NY and wait for hours, then Katanaya is the second best place for some tasty ramen.
author: Larry C.

description:
Good God, they must put crack in this stuff. Or, maybe it's one of those hardcore combos of crack, heroin and msg (isn't that what they call a speedball?). You can't stop wanting to go here. I so fancy it, I crave it once a week, and am happy to make the drive into old SF just to have lunch here with my friend (not even for a night out!!) This stuff is so addictive after one try (hmmm... just like heroin.) 
And it's not just the ramen either! I get the combo meal with the kim chee fried rice just to save the fried rice for lunch the next day-- or maybe even for the drive home across the bridge. 
Further proof that the best places to eat are the holes in the wall joints in sketchy hoods.
author: N. P.

description: A local San Francisco friend took me here for ramen on a nippy, and cold weather. Their Katana-Ya and Fried Chicken ramen is deliciouss in either miso or soy sauce. In terms of BART convenience I end up in Powell a lot and if I don't want to eat mall's food court this is one of the few places outside of the mall that I do love to eat at. Their sushi is not so bad either. It is a popular place and you are in luck when you do get there without a line! I wish they would expand!
author: Chanel A.

description:
This is my first Yelp review. I've waited this long for the right restaurant, and the right time. Tonight, I decided to give it away to Katana-Ya. I'm so nervous.......let's begin.
Katana-Ya gets 5 stars from me because it is 1.Delicious 2.Priced Well 3. Consistent. 

The food-
Ramen: The Katana-Ya ramen bowl is amazing. The noodles are generously portioned, as is the pork and corn. The seaweed and miso broth is mild and flavorful. The kara-age chicken and won-ton are surprisingly tasty and remain fairly crispy throughout. I've had it twice and it was consistent. 

Sushi: Plain old Salmon nigiri was surprisingly good for a place specializing in ramen. Higher quality than my usual haunt Sushi-boat, if not somewhat more expensive. Second time I had the futomaki, and I was somewhat less happy. The flavor was decent but seemed somewhat small.

Service-
This place is pretty notorious for the long waits. It really is just a hole in the wall, and depending on your hunger, the 20+minute waits can be a deal-breaker. On the one hand, they very efficient for a small location (ordered lists, menus handed out to upcoming parties to speed the ordering process). On the other hand, it can take upwards of 30 minutes to be seated, and on a chilly night, that can be miserable. Overall, I think it is worth the wait, provided you aren't starving or have some weakness to frost. 

Bottom-line: Great ramen downtown. A safe bet if you are expecting good food and a wait.
author: Nick R.

description: Finally got to try this out for the first time last weekend. Didn't have to wait very long at all since we came at an odd time. Ordered the ramen combo with uni/ikura don. I haven't been taking care of my noodle cravings as well as I should be and this noodled me ever so nicely. The uni and ikura were pretty satisfying too. Went a second time just 2 days ago too and ordered the exact same thing. So glad it's only a 15 minute walk from my place. Although I'm not quite sure if it's the best ramen I've ever had. I just really like the bountiful combos you can choose from.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Awesome place.  The ramen is great, the sushi is fresh, and the sushi chefs are so friendly.  Come early and don't be picky at sitting at the sushi bar. If you are waiting for a table it wll be awhile, since the lines are long during the rush!
author: James M.

description:
Let me start by saying that the most perfect bowl of ramen in the United States does not exist in the Bay Area, but is located in the East Village in NYC, at Momofuku.  All ramen is compared to that one bowl, where the pork is Berkshire, the soup is perfectly seasoned, the toppings are extensive and satisfying, and the noodles exactly the right texture.  So, having described my perfect bowl, I've got to say that Katana-Ya doesn't quite reach perfection and instead, rates just an "okay."

Having waited just about the entire afternoon for our rush tickets to "Jersey Boys" across the street, my cousin and I were really excited to go to Katana-Ya for a warming bowl of ramen.  We decided to start with their homemade king crab croquette and then, because we were really hungry, try their ramen combination, which is a bowl of their ramen with your choice of soup and a piece of chashu and a smaller dish- tonkatsu, kimchi fried rice, katsudon, and tempura-don being some of the choices.  I decided to go for the katsudon and my cousin, the tempura-don.  We both decided to try the same kind of ramen- the rich, soy broth.  

The crab croquette came first- 2 lovely, deep-fried, crisp pieces with a side salad of mixed greens with ranch dressing and some katsu sauce.  Honestly, I couldn't really taste much crab, but the inside of the croquette was creamy and smooth and really tasty.  It was awesome with the katsu sauce.

Next up was the ramen, which was a bit of a disappointment.  The broth was very warming, but it was unbalanced and tasted way too salty.  The ramen noodles seemed a little underdone - I like some texture to my noodles, but these bordered on being hard.  The one piece of chashu we did get was really fatty and really, really salty.  The pork was really unappetizing.  The two rice bowls were nothing special- the tempura-don came with a piece of shrimp and one each of mushroom, green bean, and pumpkin.  Tasty, but nothing exciting.

Overall, the meal at Katana-Ya was very filling and a great way to warm up from the demon Bay Area winds that whipped up yesterday.  Ramen was just okay, while the crab croquettes were wonderful.  I may be back, but only if I'm in the area and craving ramen.
author: Angela H.

description:
Nobu-san was spot on.  Our late night hunger disappeared as we slurped on shoyu, shio and miso ramen.  I got mine with a side of curry rice (a Japanese staple) and my sister got kimchee fried rice.  Then my youngest sister continued her quest to find the best chicken teriyaki dinner set which is a mission she started ever since she was 12.  (She would only order the same meal just so she could have a common way of ranking every Japanese restaurant she visited.)  The California roll that came with her dinner set was very good and the imitation crab meat fooled me!  Gyoza was tasty but a bit too large and garlicky for me.  I like mine small and love it when they melt in my mouth.  

I'd have to say out of all the different types of ramen the miso was the tastiest and the broth was the most well balanced.  You have the choice of ordering your ramen light or heavy.  I prefer heavy which pretty much means the soup is going to be more dense, creamier and full of flavor.

Nothing is better than a hot bowl of ramen, gyoza, fried rice and an ice cold beer on a cold San Francisco night.  This place is perfect for a late night dinner.  We are staying at the Nikko Hotel and Katana-ya was like a 3 minute walk.
author: Shiho F.

description:
Been here two times now and its still one of the better ramen shops ive visited. Fast service, hot food. And most importantly, it tasted really good. A bit overpriced for ramen though and needs more meat. The noodles are a perfect al dente. 

The place is tiny, a table for four is more for two. You can hear all your neighbors conversation and even smell their food. Unfortunately for us, we had people in the back that spoke loud and laughed a lot. It was annoying when all i wanted to do was enjoy my food with family. 

The spicy tuna roll was good too. Fish was fresh, a nice deep red color. Not overly spicy like some places where you cant taste the food. Fish was in pieces, not mashed up. Rice was perfect. Soft and tasty.
author: James T.

description:
good to know when i'm in the area since open every day till 1:30 am but wouldn't go out of my way since parking's a bitch.

FOOD: shoyu ramen had really really really good broth, but they were so stingy w/the (yummy) noodles, & i only had 1 slice of char siu (which was heavenly)! not much else in there besides 3 bamboo shoots, a few slivers of seaweed & green onions. i mostly wanted more noodles. maybe next time i'll order the char siu ramen b/c the meat was that good & ask if they can add extra noodles & a few slices of kamaboko & i'll just pay extra. it's already really pricey, but i guess it's for the union square tourists. better deal @ suzu & ramen is just as good! not sure if i'd try the sushi there, the plc doesn't exactly scream "freshness."

DECOR: really dark, makes me think everything's dirty. my elbow kept knocking against the wall siding & snapping it. the ceiling has no panels so all the wiring is hanging out. is this intentional? i don't like the decor.

SERVICE: the waitress/hostess never smiled. i'd be unhappy if i worked in a cave w/exposed wiring, too. she doesn't look japanese but speaks fluently.

BATHROOM: i like the owl & stars painted on the wall, but it's stuffed w/stuff. i guess they don't care how it looks.

OVERALL: i wouldn't go out of my way to eat there since parking's a bitch, but if i was in the area & craving ramen, i may stroll on over.
author: miss b.

description:
Supposedly, there are rumors this establishment is/was related to one of my favorite ramen joints located in the inner Sunset.  That Katana-Ya closed a few years back and I've always lamented its loss.
I cry sometimes at night because that Sunset restaurant had a spicy tofu ramen that was a thing of beauty.  A bowl of perfection served-up piping hot for me and wifey to enjoy.
Oh, how I miss that place!!!!

When I heard that this downtown location might in some way be related to that magical place, I rushed down as fast as my two little feet would carry me.

Katana's a tiny place a few blocks off Union Square.  Staff are friendly and pretty quick (it's hard not to be when the restaurant's the size of my living room).

Wifey and I order the spicy tofu number and a miso-based ramen and wait anxiously for the nostalgia to wash over us.
When the bowls hit our table, we immediately know something's amiss.  The color's off, the tofu's not nearly as firm as it should be, and the broth is way too salty.  The end result is not even close to the version we remembered.

We inadvertently make the broth saltier with the wave of tears we shed.

My miso ramen was competently made.  Broth was okay.

As far as ramen goes, Katana-Ya will do if you've got an urgent ramen emergency.

Some advice though, NEVER
NEVER
NEVER
NEVER
NEVER order the curry rice!!

Never....
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
This is a very choice ramen restaurant. I would say that it is possible to have better ramen, but Katana-Ya is a place that seems to have a consistently good bowl of noodles.

In a way, I trust this more. If I'm in the mood for ramen, I would rather go here and get some good broth and veg for $6 than try some new place just cause it's got a gnarly goat dude as a chef.

FYI, seating is limited, so be prepared for a little bit of a wait. It's worth it though.
author: Mark H.

description: I've only eaten here once so far, but I've got to say it was the best soup I've had in the city. The Katanaya ramen was AMAZING - crazy mix of ingredients and superb broth. Very nice wait staff too. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Brian H.

description: delicious noodles delicious katsu-don kinda overpriced but so good mah friend
author: Liz R.

description:
Hooray for drunk people food. Food that hits the spot late at night when you're drunk, but aren't too good otherwise.

Unfortunately, I came here sober. I ordered the salt ramen and fried rice combo ($9). A good value if you just consider the portions, but not terrific considering how bland the ramen was. Fried rice wasn't bad, but I seem to have very low standards concerning ramen-shop fried rice.

Service was very, very average.
author: Ryo M.

description:
Like most ramen places, it's advisable not to go here in a large group.  If you do, you're asking for trouble unless you're going at an off-hour.  The tables were super packed together and even the tables weren't exactly that big either.

Anyway, I ended up trying the fried chicken miso ramen.  Can I say AWESOME IDEA?  The broth was flavorful and the chicken was just delicious.  Mixing the two was even better.  I'd definitely come back, but it's not cheap either compared to other places I've been to (~$10 for the bowl).
author: Brian N.

description:
when i'm craving ramen...i'm here. 

I always order the katana-ya special. All the standard toppings with corn, gyoza and chicken. Portions are filling and very tasty. Sushi is great here too.

The only downside to this great place is that this place is very small and there is always a wait.
author: Aileen F.

description:
When I think of spicy ramen, I envision myself pigging out on a steaming bowl while sweating bullets. Why I like spicy food? I don't know, but I love it - even though my tolerance is kind of low (see my review for spicy town). 

I ordered the spicy tofu ramen with miso base. It had ramen, and miso soup... and tofu... and was NOT spicy. I can honestly say that b/c my tolerance honestly is kind of low for spicy food. I was sad... I suppose next time I'll have to try their super spicy ramen, the one that looks like it has napalm in it.

Place is small, tables fit 3-4. Counter seats don't have backs, so ladies, don't bring purses unless you want to stick your purse on the ground.
author: Jessie H.

description: The best spicy tofu ramen!!!!!  Delicious!!
author: Maria M.

description:
First time be here...will absolutely come back...

like their soup...like their green onion...hahaha...
like the bamboo shoot...
o wellz...like the whole thing...

will come back...did i say that already?
author: mui chu C.

description: Delicious! The 30 minute wait was worth it. I had the ramen noodles with fried chicken and dumplings. Mmm.. I want more!
author: Ryan G.

description:
Best Ramen in SF
Not that expensive when it comes to good ramen (100 packs of 25c ramen hasnt got anything on this - except the 100 has more msg).  Very small place so there can be a wait but it is always worth it.  The menu is pretty good, but the seasonal menu on the wall is golden.  Great staff, friendly and make you feel like a regular.
The new Spicy Ramen is one of the hottest ramens i have ever had AND it still had taste.  The Spicy Onion Pork Bowl is great, but this is a place to come for ramen...
Ramen is king.
author: Nathan H.

description: The long wait was annoying, but then again it was a Friday night, and a long line usually equates to a good meal.  I was not disappointed once inside.  The ramen here was very good.  Not as good as my favorite ramen place in NYC - Ippudo - but close.
author: Dan M.

description:
My first time here in this easy to miss Union Square spot.  I love ramen and this was a perfect spot for a nice hot bowl of noodles on a misty winter day.  I had the kimchi miso ramen.  The broth was nice and thick and while spicy was not overpowering.  The flavoring of the broth was excellent as you can tell that the soup base was cooked for quite awhile.

This is an affordable bite and a much welcomed change to the typical Thai noodle shop that seems to pop on every corner in Union Square.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Warranted or not, I'm kind of a ramen snob.  I can gauge my affinity for a restaurant's ramen offerings by measuring the intensity and interval between cravings for it.

For my all-time favorite place in LA's Little Tokyo, it would be a scant few hours before I would begin salivating for the rich broth; and firm, slurp-friendly noodles; and melt-in-your-mouth pork and...  Oh god, now I'm really hungry.

Anyway, after selecting the BBQ Pork ramen + salt flavor + rich broth (they give you choices), I will probably end up craving a visit to Katana-Ya about once every two weeks, and I admit that it'll be pretty hard to ignore.  I anticipate that going an additional week without satisfying the craving will probably be pretty agonizing, likely leading me to drop dozens of IMs,SMSs, and tweets about how much I want ramen.  All told, that's pretty damn good.

fwiw, we also had a bomb agedashi tofu appetizer.
author: Richard E.

description: Ordered the miso ramen. The waitress brings a bowl of hot, steamy noodles with just the right amount of chew. Plenty of scallions and seaweed in my too salty broth, but only one piece of pork and one piece of bamboo shoot.  Came in around mid lunch hour on a Friday and did not have long to wait since I was willing to share a table. This is not my experience from weekend lunches.
author: P K.

description:
Wow, 700+ reviews for this place, almost makes me wonder if I need to even write a review.  Well, I do because this place is just too damn good (I'm sure that's what everyone else thought as well).

I'm not sure if it was because I went under optimal conditions (cold weather, extremely hungry) but the meal I had here was perfection.  I ordered the chicken karage and chasu ramen.  

The karage was nicely deep fried and not too oily.  The chicken was moist (I HATE chicken karage that ends up dry) and the flavor was great with a little bit of lemon juice.

Everything about the ramen was perfect.  Noodles were cooked just right: firm and bouncy.  Miso broth (with added spiciness) wasn't too hot or salty.  Pork was tender and flavorful.  Ooooo boy, it was awesome.  I've had ramen at a lot of places and this is by far my favorite in the Bay Area.

Hint:  This isn't a huge place, so you might be in for a wait unless you don't go during peak hours.  If they have bar seats available, take it.  It may be a little cramped, but just keep you focus on eating the ramen and you'll be okay.
author: Brent T.

description: The smallness of the place makes you feel a bit cramped. I had the raman noodles in miso broth and it was not something I'll get again. I will try the other noodles, of which there is a long list.
author: Tom A.

description: There always seems to be a big line for this place and now I know why. This is the best ramen I've ever had (it's also a tiny restaurant). The portions are huge, it's easily two meals. I went with the miso ramen and fried rice, which was also the best fried rice I've ever had. It doesn't matter how you order your ramen, you can't go wrong especially with these prices. You will definitely see me standing out there with the crowd more often. Give it a try and you'll see why.
author: Spencer C.

description:
7x7 Big Eat List: #5 Chasu Ramen

I first went to Katana-ya the day after getting back from Japan.  Japanese food is absolutely amazing and I can eat ramen and curry for the rest of my life and not get sick of it.  Apparently, neither can my roommates, we all had a serious case of ramen withdrawal.

The place was small, the air was cold, the noodles were just the right amount of chewiness, the broth was hot.  AHHHHHH... satisfaction.  The only difference between Katana-ya and the real thing in Japan was that I could actually converse with the servers and not have to point at pictures or plastic food to order.

CUT TO this past Saturday night.  We are on a 7x7 rampage all day, so we decided to ramen it up.  The chasu ramen with light soy sauce soup was absolutely incredible.  The chasu was flavorful and had a lovely consistency to it.

The only thing I would have to say is minus 1/2 star for the pushy waiters.  We wanted to take our time to make sure we ordered everything just right, but the waiter literally came up about 5 times within 7 minutes to take our order.

Anyway, I will always come by here for a bowl of ramen on those cold SF days.  OISHII!!!
author: Melissa L.

description:
A new hole-in-the-wall ramen shop downtown, and the hole-in-the-wall kind is the BEST kind.  My Saturday eve visit showed everything in place: chock full of Japanese families laughing with sprightly owners, steamy smells of broth and fried-ness.  To great disappointment, however, the eats were a bit shabby.  The miso ramen was topped off with a mere two knobby pork cutlets and miserly few bean sprouts and bambo shoots (though, indeed the soup was delicious and oily).  The gyoza was the main culprit.  I expect, for more than a buck a gyoza, that the insides be solid and meaty, and taste better than stinky wild onions.

Update 11/06: Wow... the ramen here has improved DRAMATICALLY.  It's actually as good as--dare I say BETTER than--Santa's in San Mateo.  I must have gone too soon after they opened to make a good judgment call.  The spicy tofu miso ramen is fantastic, especially on a chilly day.  Oh, and don't go for the "heavy" broth, unless you really know what you're doing.
author: MScott S.

description:
Katana-Ya serves some of the best ramen and udon I have had in the San Francisco! The shouyu (soy sauce) ramen in Katana-ya fixes up my noodle craving with an almost-perfect batch of firm noodles and with a few but satisfying pieces of meat to top the bowl off. Katana-Ya's "regular Udon" comes off as an equally satisfying bowl with firm noodles. The gyouza is a perfect appetizer for two or three people.

Katana-Ya is a fantastic restaurant for those Japanese noodle craving many of us have. If you want Japanese noodles, come here.
author: Steven S.

description:
I equate a bowl of ramen as the asian culinary equivalent to a plate of mac and cheese; both are considered "comfort" foods in their respective cuisines, and neither are exactly very healthy for you - prefried noodles and salt based broth, and mounds of cheese.  That said, I love both of them, and while Katana-Ya doesn't serve the latter, you can find a hot steaming bowl of delicious noodles worthy of devouring in large gulps.  That last line sounded borderline sexual, and food can be, although I don't think ramen exactly qualifies.  I digress.

My favorite bowl to get at KY is their miso based spicy tofu ramen, which is a wonderful concoction of miso soup, kimchi, and tofu all complimenting a serving of tasty ramen noodles.  The sushi is there is fresh and of good quality, but not the best in the city.  Also good are their a la carte style tempura/chicken katsu/other stuff don bowls, which are like small rice bowls topped with an endless choice of toppings.  Their menu was revamped recently, and is much more extensive.  That said, one should always try to have a sense of gastronomic adventure, but it's the noodles, stupid.
author: Michael P.

description: I've had ramen only a couple times in my life (the little packages don't count) and the only yummy ramen I've had was in SF. This place was near my hotel. When we tried to get a table, it was almost impossible. The restaurant is so tiny and cramped, full to the max with patrons. Finally got a seat and was not at all disappointed. SO GOOD. You can customize it however you want. I got the katanaya where they dump everything and anything into it like dumplings, egg, tempura, corn, seaweed, bbq pork, etc...  My friend is vegetarian and got a spicy tofu and rice dish that looked really good too... I wanted to take a bite but I could tell he was hungry :) If you're in SF and nearby, do yourself a favor and stop by!
author: Julie N.

description:
After reading yelp reviews I thought this place was going to be phenomenal but it fell short.  Maybe it was what I ordered, but I thought the ramen was just was OK.  I was expecting something more taste wise.  I think Orenchi in San Jose is definitely better if not just as comparable.  I'll probably end up here again sometime soon, my cousin lives close by.  Maybe then I'll try something different.

Regarding the wait... my husband and I actually went early.  We showed up at 6pm and there was one table available.  There after a crowd started to form outside.  So the earlier you go the better.
author: Vanessa F.

description:
disappointing.  how can you yelpers give this place 4 stars?  the ramen was average at best. it wasnt any better than the ramen packet i make at home.  the best dish was the seared albacore salad believe it or not.  if you think this place is better than Tanpopo you dont know ramen.  im not saying Tanpopo is great buts it far better then this place. i ordered the char sui shoyu ramen. if this isnt good forget the rest.  this is the basic ramen - and it was not good. i dont understand why SF doesnt have a good ramen ya.  the only reason for a long wait and line out the door is because of the inept servers and the tiny space.  its really not worth the wait.  waaaaay overpriced and an embarrassment to calling itself  a ramen ya.  checkout Ippudo or minca pics in NYC to see what REAL ramen should look like.

oh right.  They use MSG too clearly advertised on the menu.  Really??
author: Grover G.

description:
** Update: I visited Katana-Ya again recently and was disappointed in both the service and the meal. My Ramen was good but as usual I ordered the combo and my first choice, Katsu-don was unavailable. I decided to order the Tempura, which I've had many times before and it was bad. Soggy, and the vegetables tasted as if they'd been micro-waved.  I'm taking away 1 start. Pleh!
Rich, Soy, Karaage Ramen w/ Tempura 


Ramen everywhich way you can imagine. Their lunch ramen combos are the best in SF.  I love the fact that I can walk here for lunch whenever I get the itch for Ramen. Believe it!

So Far I've had:
Light, Miso, Pork Ramen w/ Tempura
Light, Salt, Pork Ramen w/ Kimchi rice
Rich, Salt, Pork Ramen w/ Unagi don
Rich, Soy, Pork Ramen w/ Tempura ****

P.S. One of these days I will try the sushi but it definitely won't be for lunch, because there are enough different Ramen combos to keep me going for awhile without repeating myself.
author: Johnny H.

description:
Decent option in a busy and pricey area.  Good for pre-show meal if you're not interested in fine dining.  Ramen is not up to Tokyo standards, but hey you can't fly to Tokyo before a show.
They seemed understaffed- service was spotty and missed the order completely such that my appetizer and main came out well before my companions' appetizers.  
We all got the ramen combo
nigiri- fresh and tasty (rice was a little mushy)
unagi don- succulent and juicy on rice and seaweed

rich broth-complex
