miso vs soy both were tasty- soy seemed salty at first but richer and had more depth than the miso once my taste buds adjusted. 

topping seemed minimal
spicy tofu 
chicken karage 
bbq pork- slightly anemic and tasteless (i would not order this again)

I'll definitely go back, but  only up to 4 people max.
author: SatisFahYing A.

description:
Hands-down the best ramen in the city. 

I crave Katana-Ya all the time and for the countless times I've been there, it never disappoints. I leave stuffed with yummy ramen, refreshing Negori sake, and sometimes some delicious rolls and barely a dent in my wallet.
author: lily l.

description:
Bummed. I have never experienced worse customer service. From forgetting about our table to blantantly ignoring us and the people next to us.. Its just all bad. I'm bummed because their sushi and ramen is great. But everytime I eat there I swear it's the last time. Maybe they will perk their staff up? I know the people next to us complained about the rude-ass waitress so they might take it seriously.

I'd consider their take out if I were you!
author: Natasha T.

description: Second time going here and it definitely will not be my last. The katana-ya ramen is so good
author: Danny C.

description:
We keep coming back here for their Siromaguro no tataki (roasted albacore carpaccio). Their Ramen are also very authentic and good. If you don't mind eating mix fish (no problem with the fish found), the dynamite roll is a good deal for $6.

Friendly service and located one block away from Union Square so it's my favorite place for a cozy homey dinner after shopping in downtown.
author: Lance C.

description: I like this place a lot!  I have eaten at Katana-Ya at least ten times and every single time there has been a line.  Luckily I have an awesome friend who always gets there early and snags us a table.   The Ikura is one of my favorites and always fresh and tasty.  The sashimi tempura combo which comes with soup, salad and rice is also delicious and a great deal.
author: Nelly M.

description:
Katana-Ya, 

I tried you for the first time on Tuesday and I was thoroughly satisfied! After wandering around in the cold and dodging the throngs of tourists at Union Square, I finally found your nondescript restaurant and was welcomed and comforted with a hot and hearty miso-based broth with fresh thick ramen noodles. It truly warmed my soul! I'm a big fan of Genki Ramen, but I actually think that your ramen is better because your noodles are thicker and feel heartier, in contrast with the thinner and softer Genki noodles. 

What was the meat in the broth? I think it was pork, but whatever it was, it was good! It was tender and it gave the ramen a good meaty taste. 

I also ordered the curry with rice as a side dish, which wasn't all too great, until I dumped some into the broth...and then it was special. I love mixing rice with soups, and the curry gave it extra flavor.  

Overall, I'd say that you do a damn good job. I had a solid meal and I'm definitely going to come back to try some of your other dishes. 

Thanks! :) Yuh-Tah!
author: James C.

description:
I'm usually not a fan of cold ramen... but I'm a fan now!!  Not that the hot ramen is lacking!  
The people working here are nice, the environment is cute, portions are good, the price is right, and I can walk here!!!  What more can  you ask for!!
author: Karena L.

description:
Who would have thought that a delicious Ramen place would be tucked away somewhere near Union Square?  It is a gem!  My friend and I went here on a weekday close to the end of lunchtime.  We thought we would be able to beat the lunch rush but, we still had to wait.  (No longer than 10 minutes though.)  We weren't surprised because the place is definitely really small! 

I ordered the soy sauce pork ramen and my friend ordered a spicy one.  This place gives you a lot of ramen noodles and the soup was not too salty.  The only downside was that we didn't get eggs in our soup!  We also added a sushi roll!  Don't remember what it was called, but it had butterfish on it and it was SO good!  The ramen and the roll definitely did not disappoint!  

Will be back again =]
author: Helen V.

description: Not the greatest ramen I have had. Broth lacks taste and noodles are not firm. I will not come back.
author: Ken C.

description: Definitely one of the better ramen places I've had in the city. Dare I say even better than any ramen place in JTown? Yes I will say it. It's a small divey little place which is NOT good for groups bigger than 2 or 4. It also has a sushi bar if ramen isn't what you're looking for. I usually go with the kaarage ramen or the one with everything in it but that one costs a few bucks more but what's a few bucks more for extra goodness. Their agedashi tofu is a good starter. If you're really hungry you can get the lunch combo which is their regular ramen and your choice of plethora of items ranging from kimchi fried rice to tofu dishes or sushi dishes. This lunch combo is usually $11 or $12. Good bang for your buck.
author: David C.

description:
Not the best Ramen I've ever had, but it's not bad at all. 
Love the soup base, not the noodles, which are a bit too thick for me.
Wait will be long, beware.
author: Wayne T.

description: I love making soups and stocks and only dream I could make a broth as crucial as the one they make here. Killer.
author: Roger H.

description: This is for their regular ramen.  Soup tasted bland and the egg was a hard boiled egg.  I've eaten in other ramen places and I thought the half-done ones are the norm.  Anyway, meh.  Maybe I'll try something else since they have so many items on the menu.
author: Peggy M.

description:
I'm sorry, I love ramen but I can't give a 4/5 let alone a 5/5 to just anyone.  But I do love this place, and I do go back regularly..so dont let the 3/5 scare you away..  

I've tried almost every Ramen they have (being that I love ramen) and here are my thoughts:

*(drumroll...)*


Pork Ramen w/ Soy Base Soup Light Broth (3.5/5) - The broth is average, the Pork is well seasoned but could be better as any dish in any restaurant you goto.  But the ramen is the best part.  The Ramen is chewy yet soft and goes very well with the pork & broth.  altogether, not a bad choice.

Chicken Karage Ramen w/ Miso Base Soup Rich Broth (2.5/5) - Too much fat..too much richness to it and the Karage is in the soup so it's all soggy by the time you eat it because it's too steaming hot to eat right away.  (By the way, all the stuff you order here when received is usually straight from the cooker, so it's probably a good idea to let the hot food cool down a bit)  Anyway..I think this wasn't the best choice, even though the ramen was good as usual, I was in search of a better flavor for my tastebuds.

Kimchi Ramen w/ Soy Base Soup Light Broth (4/5) - I know its a high rating, but when i got the order...the soup had pieces of pork in it!  YESS! BONUS!!...wow that sounded really mature...=/  But anyway, it's good cuz i like spicy food.  I was very satisfied with this ramen choice.  

Spicy Tofu Ramen w/ Soy Base Soup Light Broth (4/5) - This is just as good as Kimchi Ramen because it has ..KIMCHI in the SOUP!  YESS!!  Spicy is good and tasty.  And I give this one a thumbs up for sure.  At least for San Francisco's Ramen Standards.

Final Thoughts: I like this place...the only reason i give it 3/5 is cuz there are other ramen shops that out do this place anyday.. but if you're in san francisco and are near a bart station or are in search for ramen near the financial district cuz you work there but you hate your job.  Then come on over to Katana-ya..It's just a hop, skip & a jump away from Powell Bart Station...and just a short walk from macy's.

FINAL FINAL FINAL THOUGHTS: I give this place a 8/10 for being convenient and for serving ramen.  THANKS GUYS!  ...ooo and i almost forgot...this is not a break your wallet restaurant, so if you're thinking about it...GO FOR IT!
author: Jack N.

description:
Honestly this is one of  THE worst Ramen House i've ever been to. You can tell that most San Franciscans are ramen amateurs and haven't experienced true ramen, Cause this ramen taste exactly like the 3-pack ramen that's sold at your local japanese supermarket. Hell I think the supermarket ramen taste better than this!

Anyways, flavors come in Shoyu, Miso and salt.... yep. Usually good ramen houses actually have unique signature ramen flavors. Flavors like Kuro (black sesame oil base flavor).

There's a "wide" variety of ramens like "green onion" ramen. Which is chopped up green onion on ramen for $10. That's just robbery to charge someone $10 for some crappy soup base, noodles, and green onion. 

Oh yeah, I also have to mention the service there. It sucks very slow and biased. Japanese people usually get better service than say... anyone that isn't Japanese. Usually there are attractive Japanese waitresses, but they change SO often since alot of the kids that work there are only temps looking for quick money. 

overall this place is overhyped. The only reason why people love it so much is cause its the only ramen house around the area. So they can basically piss in a bowl for you and tell you its ramen just cause. 

If you don't believe me try it yourself.
author: Will C.

description:
Katana-Ya is really famous for it's ramen but it's also got sushi and other japanese dishes.  I have to admit, the ramen is top notch.  I tried the deep fried chicken ramen and yeah, the ramen was insanely good but what really hit the spot was the chicken.  I have never tasted chicken so tasty and delicious.  It was so tender and the skin was so amazing.  It was the best thing I have ever tasted.  The noodles were also extremely tasty as well as priced well for the amount served.

One recommendation on their sashimi is the Red Tuna Tataki.  It's one of the best I've ever tasted.  Their sushi is also of very high quality.  I also really like their Tonkatsu as the chicken looks slightly raw but that's what good chicken is supposed to look like.  The breading is fabulous and their onions in it are really tasty.

I highly recommend this place and would definitely keep coming back.  It's really close to union square but the only problem is the seating.  It's kind of a small place and it's reputation doesn't help with the large lines or customers going in and out.  The sushi bar is kind of cramped but I think it's the size of the man next to me.  He took up two bar stools...
author: Bobby Y.

description:
I would say it's on par with Ryowa in Mountain View, although Ryowa feels more authentic (funny since Ryowa is owned by Chinese people and Katana-Ya by Japanese, hm...)  

Ordering ramen can be little confusing, I thought.  You first pick the soup flavor (soy sauce, miso, or salt) + the type of ramen + optional spiciness (extra spicy, medium spicy) + "lightness".  We ordered Soy Sauce Regular Ramen medium-spicy, and Miso Spicy Tofu Ramen (which was less spicy than the medium-spicy regular ramen, strange...)  Both ramen's had very flavorful soup, with very little hint of pork broth (which was good since I don't eat pork).  Spicy Tofu ramen had some kimchi in it, but it wasn't fermented (not so good).  Much less number of ingredients compared to Ryowa vegi-ramen.  

We also ordered a Winter Roll (squid) which was very good.  Rice had more vinegar, which I liked.  

Overall, very good as far as a ramen place goes.  If you don't mind the wait and cramped seating, you should definitely check it out.  We plan to :-)
author: Min L.

description: Totally don't understand why this restaurant is rated w avg of four stars with more than 2k ppl. It was tasteless.
author: Apple C.

description:
I'm not a big fan of ramen in general, maybe because I just love my pho too much.  Either way, I like Katana-Ya enough for what it is, and I like the cold ramen that they have. When I went there this week though, it was extra soupey (not supposed to be at all) and was a little more...sour?...than usual.

My friends like the fried rice and the other ramen is good for what it is.
author: ML N.

description: I've heard so much about Katana-ya and knew we'd be waiting for a table for while.  It's the perfect location if you're planning on going to the theater and on a cold day Ramen was going to hit the spot.  After being seated at the bar i ordered the butter corn ramen.  This being supposedly the "best" ramen in the city i was excited.  I'm guessing i shouldn't have built it up so much.  My ramen was just OK.  It hit the spot but i've had better.  There wasn't anything that stood out, noodles okay, broth tasty.  Service fast and friendly.  I'd go back if i was in the area.
author: Susan Z.

description:
Ya! Ya! Katana-Ya!

This is so authentically Japanese-y, except for the fact that they serve more than 1 kind of Japanese dish *sidenote: In Japan, a ramen shop ONLY serves ramen, in a sushi place, they ONLY serve sushi, etc, etc.

Uber fresh sushi.

Yummy ramen--try the spicy one! Or the bbq pork.

Be ready to wait b/c this place is tiny. 

Oiishi-yo!
author: Misha F.

description:
Amazingly great ramen -- probably the best ramen spot in San Francisco. Here's a tip -- go around 6 p.m. An hour or so later, and you'll be fighting the pre-theatre crowd for a spot. 

I usually get the light soy broth with either the chicken karaage and the pork when ordering ramen. But the sushi here is also surprisingly good -- I really like the fresh fish. The hamachi is my favorite, though the Tuna Lovers package is great as well. 

Unfortunately I have to take a star off for the spotty service. It's usually pretty good, but when things get really crowded, they're not able to handle the situation well. I once had to wait for over 30 minutes to even get a waitress to take my order because they were too busy dealing with the new customers -- they actually got their order before me even though they arrived 15 minutes later. 

Other than that, the food is great. So I really recommend going during non-crowded times so you don't get the bad service.
author: Nicole L.

description: Health wise, this is significantly better than instant ramen.  Taste wise ... it is about the same as instant ramen, at least the good Korean stuff.   I really should take off one more star because they don't know how to do a soft boiled egg here, which is pretty much half the reason to eat ramen.  Sorry, nothing did it for me.  The ramen's not as chewy as I'd like, and broth is boring and salty.  But the wait is really not that bad, they move quickly.
author: Biqi C.

description: I had the takeout fried chicken ramen. The broth was great. Noodles fresh. Loved the fried chicken, lightly crispy and goes well with the broth. Mmmmm....great find in downtown where everything is so pricy. My husband, brother lived it too.
author: Joy C.

description:
Got a hankering for some Ramen - Katana -Ya is it!
Love the light miso -ramen with spicy tofu! I recently did their lunch combo and got a tonkatsu-don with my ramen..and it was really tasty.. The pork cutlet was nice and breaded...Wifes Salmon don was super yummy too.

But really this place gets its recognition from the tasty broth and noodles it serves up. I just wish parking around here was easy...

Love you Katana- YA!
author: Christian S.

description: My fave modern style ramen house! Their ramen with everything in it is the bomb. It's packed with lots of goodies but my fave part is the fried pork, it comes out still crispy but wet from the ramen soup. The noodles feel fresh and has just the right texture to it, doesnt feel cheap like how some ramen houses taste like instant ramen noodles, hate those places. Love the ramen but the wait can be a killer, think once I waited almost over an hour to get in. But still worth it ;)
author: Patrick L.

description:
Over Rated.

I was initially happy when I stumbled upon this restaurant because I had heard stories about how great the Ramen was and how there is always a super long line. It's in a row of restaurants so it doesn't stand out too much but we noticed it because there was a huge crowed in front of the door. Usually, crowd/line = good food. Using that philosophy, we decided to wait. There is usually a wait because there are only a few tables inside. It's a pretty small shack. We waited about 10 mins before getting seated. Service is good. Kind of an IN & OUT type of joint. 

I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen w/soy because the waiter had recommended it. I am glad I ordered it w/soy instead of miso because the Miso makes it a bit salty. I also added "EXTRA SPICY" to the bowl b/c everything tastes better spicy right? There was too much going on in my bowl of Ramen. Should have known that fried won tons & fried chicken wouldn't taste that great w/ramen but I wanted to try something new. The "EXTRA SPICY" was EXTRA NOT SO SPICY. I was disappointed. The bowl came out red like chili but lacked any spice. They charge you $1.50 to add spice to your bowl, but all it did was change your soup color from bland to orange. The noodles they used didn't feel like Ramen noodles to me. Felt like they were the same noodles used at pepper lunch. Maybe that's 'rea'l Ramen, maybe it's not. I'm just use to a softer noodle in my Ramen.  For $14, I expected better results from a 4 star Ramen joint and for them to master the art of making spice. 

We also ordered tuna sashimi as an appetizer. It came out looking fresh and delicious but when we bit into it, it was different. It was pretty chewy, from beginning to end. $10 for 5 pieces, a little pricey. 

I've had better for cheaper.
author: Katherina H.

description:
Hands down the BEST ramen I have ever eaten. I always get the Karage ramen. The broth is rich, on the thicker side, and loaded with flavor. I'd go for the light version though because I can see how the thicker broth can get overwhelming. The noodles seem like they are hand made and as fresh as I've consistently eaten with the soft texture and enough to soak up the flavor the broth. The Karage is just the icing on the cake with the crunchiness at the beginning and softens up after soaking in the broth. 

I'm always on a ramen hunt wherever I go, and this place still takes the top spot for me. Even if you don't think that it is the best like I do, you still won't get a bad meal.
author: vic w.

description: Not sure why there's line-up for this place.  Regular ramen was just....noodle on common miso soup.  Donburi came out with cold rice...urgh..
author: Tony K.

description: Spicy green onion ramen.  Whoa.  The broth was rich with the perfect spicy nuance and the green onions crisp and plentiful.  The pork portion was small, though tender and the noodles unbelievable!  A little pricey but worth it.  Yum (rivals Daikokuya!)!!!
author: Sarah G.

description:
3.5 but not going to round up for Katana-Ya.  I had pretty high expectations after hearing that this place is often compared to Santa Ramen.  We had a party of 6 so it took a while to be seated, but the waiting wasn't too bad.  i ordered the BBQ Pork Ramen with light soy sauce broth.  At first it was a bit conflicting because every other ramen choice came with meat too (except for the spicy tofu ramen) but meat in my ramen is a must.  I was satisfied with the amount of pork, but the non-wavy ramen noodles threw me off.  I know I shouldn't let the look of the ramen affect my experience, but it does and I can't explain it.  Anyhow, the broth was good but I've had better.  It was a satisfying meal and I even found a piece of pork at the bottom of my bowl to my surprise, which made me very happy.  But 9.80 for a bowl of simply satisfactory ramen?  I'd rather go to Kahoo.     

On another note, they charge .50 for butter so if you want the butter corn ramen sans butter, it's 50 cents cheaper!  Also my friends were kind of sad about the meager one piece of pork they got in their bowls.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Great place. Was looking for a place to go to when the midnight hunger bug crept up and didn't want to drive anywhere in union square. We were staying at the HIlton and was so glad that I found the reviews for this place. It was just a block away and man it hit the spot. The fried chicken ramen was good although my wife got the regular ramen and it didn't have enough veggies and meat in it (1 slice of pork). The bowls are huge. So big you get a ladle instead of a spoon. 

What we were surprised with was the sushi. $5.50 for two pieces of Toro and $6.50 for Mixed Fish salad. Both good. Check the specials board. The place is pretty cramped but we didn't have to wait. The service was good too. All in all a great place for a late night sushi and ramen run.
author: Michael D.

description:
Not sure why this place received such high ratings. Personally, I've had better ramen. 

I ordered the BBQ Pork Ramen with Miso Soup flavor...meh it was just OK. Nothing special...I like Daikokuya or even Maruichi better. I guess the plus is that you can pick the different soup flavor (soy sauce, miso, and salt) and also the softness of the noodles. Since I like spicy, the downside of this restaurant is that you have to add $1.40 to make it spicy! What the freak?!?!! I hecka load up on the chilli flakes (that was provided on the table) that night. hahaa 

I don't think I'll be coming back here...I'd rather walk a few more blocks up on Geary to Osha's!
author: Natalia H.

description:
This is a legitamte hole-in-the-wall japense noodle place, and it's a good experience... if you're not with a large group of people.

The servings are very generous--good luck finishing! The food is very tasty, and infused with many spices and flavors.  One grievance is that the miso soup seemed too oily.
author: Ivan C.

description:
IMHO, probably the best ramen place in San Francisco ... 

I usually have shoyu ramen here ... I like their noodles since its on the al dente side (unlike Ramen Club in Burlingame and Magic Ramen in Daly City) ... and I pretty much enjoy the broth.

Not to mention getting a small combo dish next to it (Katsu Don! of course Dojima-an down the road has the best Katsu Don in town) ...

Prices are a little bit on the expensive side, considering its a little hole ... but I suppose its Union Square, gotta pay for something.

This place usually takes care of my ramen cravings ... I swing by to this place every so often for ramen ... and maguro natto :)

Not to mention ... they close at 2 am everyday... that helps your cravings ....
author: Ari G.

description: If you are in search of good ramen/udon/soba and you are around Union Square, come to Katana Ya - WARNING: Come here 45 mins before you are hungry!!! But it is worth the wait. This place has over a thousand reviews on Yelp! The diner inside is small and should only be good for groups no more than 4 really, but that night we managed to squeeze 10!
author: Angela A.

description: Had the cilantro ramen in a spicy miso broth on Sunday.  AMAZING.  I plan to go back this week.  I might be addicted.
author: Christina S.

description: I came here for the ramen, and I don't understand what the hype is all about and why the line gets so long!  I thought the broth was too oily and I like the noodles to be more springy and chewy.  It is good enough to get my quick fix of ramen, but if there is a line - I would opt to pass.
author: K K.

description: Since I work part time a block away, I have frequent this restaurant about twice now. I have had the kimchee ramen and the miso ramen. The miso ramen is very good. They are very busy at lunch time but the service is quick and very friendly. A good spot to pick if you are craving some ramen!
author: Tossama C.

description:
This is my 83rd review. I'm yelped out of words. In how many ways can you say "ramen that hits the spot", "can't believe its so close to my workplace i can come here on a weekday and beat the weekend crowd", "pretty generous portion", "i recommend the rich miso broth", "good selection of other dishes besides ramen".

There. I said it. Now I'm gonna go there for lunch. *licks lips*.
author: Nancie T.

description:
*my bf and i both had the green onion ramen seasoned with salt in light broth. place is pretty tiny. very busy on halloween but on regular nights not so much. ramen was very good...so good we ended up coming back two days later! definitely kicks genki ramen in the ass! i'll never go back to genki for ramen again!

*we came here another time and i decided to order kimchee fried rice instead of my usual ramen since i've always wanted to try kc fried rice but i didnt find it to be as kimchee-y as i would imagine and it did not satisfied my craving. now i know to just stick with their ramen!
author: Helen L.

description: Great ramen. Noodles had a good thickness to it and ramen base was just right. They do mention that they use MSG. So, if you don't like that, I'd stay away. The place is a bit small. It does get packed and the line does go out the door. It can be a long wait, too. Service is good. Good luck with parking though. We were lucky to find a spot in downtown SF. I'd say take Muni there and walk it or if you must, garage it, if you're not one of the lucky ones to find parking out there.
author: Shall P.

description:
def one of the better ramen places in sf!!! ramen isn't one of the foods i like to go out and eat because i feel like it's so easy to make at home buttttt katana ya is DEF a must try!

i've had the chasu, shoyu and katanaya with miso broth and spicy miso.  THE SPICY MISO IS SO. ON. POINT. sososososoo good!!!!

The price is a tad bit expensive for ramen and the wait is kind of ridic as well as the seating inside.  Parties of 2 recommended, 4 max.  

To say the least, it's the only ramen that I can finish all the way. harharhar.
author: Anna C.

description: Katana-Ya Ramen, extra spicy, with miso broth is perfect for a cold night in San Francisco. You may have to wait a few minutes for a table, but it is always worth the wait.
author: Slim P.

description:
I really want to give this place 5 stars but there are some flaws that I just can't get over. I'll get into those reasons later but let's start out with the positive points. It's open pretty late so you can go here after a rough night of drinking (although I've never actually been here after drinking so I can only imagine that it would be a good recovery area). The reason why I've never been here after drinking is that I like to catch the lunch specials and I don't get plastered during the afternoon. Anyways I like the miso ramen and curry or kimchee fried rice. The miso ramen looks and has the texture of mud...but this mud is AMAZING. The thick salty miso coats the ramen so well that half the soup will be gone even if u don't drink any. Add extra spicy to the base and you will be in for a real treat. The first time I had it, I thought it was pretty weak. As I drank more of the soup I realized that I no longer had miso in my bowl....I had a bowl of lava. My face dripped with sweat and my nose ran like a faucet. 

As  much as I love torturing myself with spicy foods here, there are some flaws here. It's located near Union Square so parking will cost an arm and a leg if you don't finish in 1 hour. Assuming you come here during lunch time, you will be here at LEAST an hour because of the massive line due to limited seating. Also even with the lunch special, the meal will not be cheap since prices have risen of the past couple of years. Finally they took curry off the lunch special! I came here one time deciding if I should get kimchee fried rice or curry with my miso ramen and was GREATLY disappointed to see that curry was crossed off the list! I was leaning towards kimchee fried rice anyways, but not having the curry option made me want curry instead. I ended up getting only extra spicy miso ramen.

I really like this place but I don't like the prices and how it's so packed during the day. I would definitely recommend this place for a date if you want to heat things up.....with a bowl of extra spicy ramen.
author: Michael Y.

description:
When I want ramen, I come here..even if there is a wait. It's well worth it, and very addicting, and I often crave it...  I only come for the ramen (because it's just that fan-fuggin-tastic).  However, on occasion, when I am hungrier, I order some rolls to accompany my soup.  

Eat on!
author: Rachel B.

description: Broth great.  Noodle could be more al dente.  Very traditional ramen.  5 stars for ramen.  Other dishes 4 stars.
author: Marian C.

description: The KatanaYa Ramen is ridiculous. Fried potsticker, fried chicken, pork, egg, corn and seaweed in  delicious broth of your choice. Go for the salt broth, light and extra spicy.
author: Scott M.

description:
Chasu (BBQ Pork) Ramen............

AWESOME!!!!!
author: Rich T.

description:
It must be the open hours that they are so popular.  Nothing spectacular about the Ramen they serve.  My friend had Katanaya Ramen and I had Kimchee Ramen.  
I really don't like their noodles and it's personal preference - I like it thinner.  

Tasted like they put a lot of MSG in their soup.  That's what we do in Japan, though.
author: Yuko K.

description:
This place did not disappoint!  I was craving some ramen and saw this place had some good reviews.  I had no idea if my expectations would be met, but convinced my hungry roommate that it would be worth a try.  There was about a 20 minute wait, which can be torturous when you are extremely hungry and there are convenient pizza shops all around - but just hold out and it will be worth it! (Or, like my roommate you can get 2 tacos at Jack-in-the-Box as a snack to hold you over). 

I got the pork ramen, and my roommate got the spicy tofu ramen.  We were both very happy with our selections - I loved the soup (miso) and it was a perfect warm meal for such a cold night.  I also tried the toro sashimi which was very yummy (it was a special that night) and for dessert had the strawberry flavored shaved ice w/ condensed milk.  I could have done without the dessert, but I couldn't help myself after seeing the appetizing photo of it they had near the door.  

This place is great (not the BEST), but enough to satisfy a craving for some good ramen.  Definitely worth a try if you are in the area.
author: Amber L.

description:
This is a great place to go to get a warm and tasty bowl of noodles.  I had the Chasu-Ramen with a light miso broth.  It was awesome and filling.  My belly was sloshing with miso after I stood up so I was definitely full.  

A standby app of shrimp and veggie tempura did the trick while I waited for my bowl of noodles to arrive.  That with a pint of Sapporo made for a great meal.

I didn't have any of the sushi since it got such negative reviews.  That was ok since no one else at the restaurant got it either.
author: Peter C.

description: Went on monday around 1pm and found parking right outside.  Waited till about 1:30 for at able for 4.  Ordered the rainbow roll to start and it was really good.  Shortly after that our katana ya ramen arrived.  A lot of food and it was pretty good, lots of different flavors and very filling.  Parking is pretty expensive in the city (3.50$ for an hour) and the place is tiny, and there wasn't much room at our table (wasn't comfortable).
author: Kevin C.

description:
taste are good and service are good. but the price is depend. if get the combo set is good but the individual bowl of noodle is not that nice. their ramen is awesome. the miso flavor is balance, the ramen is prefect not too soft or too hard. 

the undo is good  the soup is delicious and noodle is prefect!!
highly recommend !!!
author: Samantha C.

description:
3.5 stars, knocked down to 3 for the service.
Our group of 6 came here for dinner last Wednesday night. We knew that we would have to wait a while because of our large group and the small restaurant, and we were okay with that. The waitress initially asked us if we were willing to be split up into two parties, but since the point of dinner was to eat together, we told her we'd wait instead. The problem was that we ended up waiting nearly 1.5 hours, while they seated and turned over at least 10 tables of 2 who came after us. Basically, they wouldn't hold any tables open at all to even try to combine two tables to seat us, even though there was another group of 7 waiting behind us on the list. It wasn't until my friend told the waitress that they had not been accommodating until they finally held a table for us and seated us within 10 minutes.  Not only that, but the waitress gave us attitude when we expressed how long we'd been waiting... basically she asked us how we expected to eat with so many people at such a small restaurant. I understand that it's more profitable for a restaurant to seat smaller tables that turn over faster, but seriously, do you ignore customers for over an hour and wait for a large table to magically appear? I didn't understand that logic.
And to be completely honest, the chasu ramen was only okay. It's supposed to be the best ramen in the City, but I'm a little skeptical. The ramen was nice and chewy and the miso soup was rich, but not really worth the wait or drive to me. Personally, I've had comparable ramen at Maru Ichi in the South Bay for a much shorter wait (and less attitude). 
Come here with 3 or less people or else expect to wait forever.
author: Jen T.

description:
Slightly doughy krinkly long-ass ramen noodles in light miso broth with 3 ginormous pieces of chick karaage.

Sew gewd~

Most under 10 bucks.

Sew nighssssssss~
author: Joyhan S.

description:
I've heard raving reviews about this place from family and friends.  Thanks to Ian L. for taking me taking me to dinner here one Sunday night.  After seeing an awesome movie (The Dark Knight) in theaters with friends, Ian and I headed back to his neighborhood for food.  We were both craving sushi so we fulfilled our cravings by going to Katana-Ya!

We started with a pitcher of Sapporo.. yes, ice-cold Sapporo on tap is a big plus in my book.  All the rolls, including special rolls were very delicious -- filling and good portion.  The Hawaiian Roll is spicy and tasty. Rock n Roll is always rockin' good!

I had the Chirashi, a bowl of rice with various fish (mackerel, shrimp, egg, salmon, tuna, yellow fin, squid) on top -- with wasabi all around the rim... that was HOT!  All the fish were fresh and non-fishy especially the mackerel, it's the fishy-ess fish I know of...

The hot, steamy, noodles (udon, soba, ramen) is definitely the costumer's popular choice, every table seem to be ordering it -- will definitely order next time.  Service was decent, waitresses seem nice, but they never smile... what's up with that?  I can only imagine how hard parking is at this area -- take the bus, the 38-Geary stops not even a block away.  Be ready to wait a while, it gets crowded.
author: Celeste M.

description: Good location. It is walking distance from the hotel Westin St Francis where my family stayed for 3 nights. The Service at Katana-Ya is really bad. Base on the quality of food and service, this one is extremely overprice when compared to Westin. Avoid this restaurant if you have family unless you are OK to wait for an hour (even at 6:00pm) or be seated separated from your kids. The soup is too salty with MSG. The ramen is overprice considered its quality. I have better ramen before in other place that costs only half the price.
author: Fatchi C.

description:
its 12:00am, and you're hungry, but you dont want junk food or dessert.  This place saves my tummy on a late night meal!  the Ramen isnt the BEST here compared to Santa Ramen in san mateo, however, i love how they stay open late past 12, even later on the weekends.  i've tried their sushi, but its not worth remembering.. 

come here for the Ramen, with miso
author: Anna W.

description:
Yelp, sometimes you confuse me (hellooo, Street and Burma Superstar). Sometimes, you just get it right. With Katana-Ya, you hit it out of the ballpark.

LOVED the ramen. Regular ramen w/rich miso broth was enough for me - simply amazing. Better than Hotei and Santa Ramen, IMO.
author: Adrienne C.

description: Best ramen in the city - only place better is ramen dojo, but that requires a drive to san mateo. char siu, miso, rich, spicy is the way to go - i find the katana-ya ramen too mixed up, though my husband loves it. they have a permit up to expand into the space next door, which will be killer because hopefully it will reduce the wait time. slight gripe: i wish their eggs were runnier rather than fully hard boiled, but it's a minor issue.
author: Erica W.

description: Katanaya Ramen is killer. I think the ingredients include: ramen, corn, fried chicken, friend pot stickers, seaweed, scallions, BBQ pork, boiled egg, 3 slices of pizza, red peppers, hot sauce, spaghetti and meatballs, an eclair, a gyro, a can of coke and whole nuther bowl of ramen.
author: Bernard W.

description:
My boyfriend read about the reviews a while back and we finally got to try it last Saturday when we came to the city to do some shopping. 

The place was packed on a Saturday afternoon around 2:30. There were a few couples before us, but the 30 minutes wait was worth it knowing that the food you will get will be so satisfying. While waiting, I studied the menu posted on the window and looked through the window to peek at what people ordered. There was this couple that sat by the window that ordered 4 different dishes. The ramen bowls themselves were gigantic, but they also got some curry and katsu rice bowls. My eyes were amazed by their big appetites. 

Ironically, we got seated by the window table. People who were waiting outside probably think and did the same thing as I did..haha. I ordered the spicy tofu ramen with miso broth while my boyfriend got the lunch special - the regular ramen with miso broth and katsu-don. So the couple who sat by the window before us ordered this special lunch menu, but you really need a big appetite to finish a bowl of ramen and rice. The price is attractive though and you can always pack the rice bowl to go to eat it for another meal if you can't finish it all.

The food was delicious with some drools just looking at it. The miso broth wasn't too rich and oily. The regular ramen was missing some corn though, otherwise the crunchiness of the ramen and corn together would be the perfect chew. The katsu-don was decent, but wasn't the best. I think my spicy tofu ramen was the best of all the dishes we ordered. It was spicy, but wasn't too spicy that overwhelmed your taste buds. The tofu was silky but chewy. The broth was spicy and sweet with lots of fried garlic flavor. I couldn't help to drink one spoon after another and forgot to eat my ramen. I was so full from all the broth I drank when I got up to leave. I wanted to take a nap rather than shopping to dream having more spicy tofu miso broth.
author: Irene C.

description: Great Ramen.  Come here all the time.  Service isn't the best, but food makes up for it.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Yes. Love this place. 
Best Ramen I have found in SF. 

Sweet butter corn Ramen with miso broth. So delicious! This restaurant understands the art of ramen. Watch Tampopo and you too will understand.
author: S. S.

description: Well being spoiled at Ippudo in New York.....this place is aiight.  The taste wasn't there it felt like someone just threw some crap in a bowl and here you go.  So, for me not so much.  Probably good for a drunken night where you really don't care about taste.  The place itself is cramped...you'll be bumping elbows a lot.
author: Chris L.

description: Long wait, mostly worth it. Fried chicken in ramen turned out to be one of the best things ever: the chicken was straight out of the fryer and piping hot. They are open pretty late and the crowd sort of tapers off after a while, so have a late lunch and hold your horses.
author: Nick W.

description: The wait is the only bad thing cuz the place is really small, but the spicy katanaya ramen with extra noodles were SO good and perfect for a cold night.  I highly recommend it!
author: Modern L.

description: My husband was dying to try this place because it was in Maxim magazine and he loves ramen. I'm not a big fan of soupy noodles so I got the sushi which was light and good. One roll may not fill you up. I would avoid the calamari because it was all tentacles and did not look appetizing. My husband and our friend liked the ramen and they give huge bowl portions.
author: Sheena S.

description:
We've been here several times over the years.
Luckily today, there was no wait (actually Union Square was fairly empty for a Sunday).
Unfortunately today was not as memorable as I recalled several years ago.
The price has increased and the portions slightly smaller.
The 4 slices of pork was thicker than other ramen restaurants but also drier- over cooked.
The soup base, though not as oily as Santa Ramen in San Mateo, is it definitely not as flavorful. 

If you were to order the ramen - the fried chicken is the one to get - still quite good though fewer pieces than before.

Overall it is okay - we prefer Santouka in San Jose ("refined" ramen) and Santa Ramen in San Mateo (they have pork broth which is oily but so good! Some places do not have the pork broth option) in that order.
author: Pat L.

description:
Forgetting that I've been here on a business trip two years ago, my friends and I went here for some good ramen. 

The ramen was alright, I got the Crispy Chicken Ramen with miso soup. I wouldn't say its the best ramen I've had since I think Santouka in West LA is way better than the one they served here. 

However, when we got there it was around 6 pm on a sunday evening, and in less than 10 minutes the place filled up and there were hungry people waiting outside the restaurant.
author: Sophie S.

description:
I never thought I would go out of my way to eat ramen, because it's basically all I ate in college (and sometimes now when my shopping gets out of control).

Can't find Katana-Ya?  Look for the line outside one of the smallest restaurants you'll see in Union Square.  The line is there for a reason.  Reasonably priced, and wonderfully comforting and delicious.

I had the lunch combo of ramen and tempura, but I could care less about the tempura!  The ramen was SUBLIME: I opted for the pork in the rich (you can specify the level of your broth) soy broth.  Yes, there wasn't a lot of meat but that's how I like it.  The noodles and broth...yum.  Slurp-errific!
author: Courtney B.

description:
After a long week I decided to stay close to home this evening, and took short walk down to Katana-Ya for their ramen.  After what seemed like a painful one-hour wait outside with a bunch of other folks I finally made it in.  A little  tip for those dining in small yet popular restaurants:  When you finish eating, don't converse for another half hour before you settle the bill.  Have some mercy for those out in the cold waiting to get inside.  If you want to enjoy your conversation, find a cafe and continue talking.  Enough said. Back to the food.

Thought I'd try their well known BBQ Pork Ramen (soy broth) and a small order of fried rice, aka the Ichiro special. The noodles were quite good, and the broth was okay. The pork, however, was a bit bland and dry.  The small side of fried rice was a surprising treat.  Light yet well flavored with pieces of beef and ginger. Overall the ramen quality is below that of Daikokuya (in LA), but Katana-Ya is a place I plan to return on occasion.  Three and a half stars.
author: Gregory C.

description:
Excellent. 

Sushi is very good and as other have said, this is the place for ramen. I don't have any complaints. I highly recommend it. One of my favorite if not my very favorite Japanese place in the city.
author: Anita B.

description:
With 400+ reviews, I feel like I must be a broken record for expressing enthusiasm for this place. This hole in the wall is great for a satisfying bowl of ramen. I was hungry and splurged with the Ramen + Uni/Ikura over Rice, and it was really a great meal. Service with tea was slightly slow at times, but that doesn't affect my recommendation. 

Definitely a place I'll be back to.
author: Fred C.

description:
Japanese owners - check
Japanese cooks - check
Japanese waitresses - check
Having lunch here every week w/ a half-Japanese person - check

Katana-Ya has really good ramen, and I've only realized this after visiting some of the other ramen houses in the city.  This place is actually the spot where I first had real ramen (not the instant kind).  Unfortunately, this was after I came back from Japan.  I completely forgot about trying it there! =(  So for the sake of saking, Katana-ya has the best ramen I've had.  I usually order the fried chicken ramen with salt broth.

The sake is pretty good here as well, however, I don't remember which one we drank.  :\

A big plus to this place is it's open until 2am for those late night ramen cravings.  Around lunchtime (noonish during the week), there's usually a line, so you need to sign-in on the wait list.

The only problem I have with this place is that it's a little incognito and it's easy to walk right by and miss it, so when I'm telling people where to find it, I just tell them it's across the street from the Curran Theatre.
author: Casey F.

description:
Omg.  Good ramen.  In the city!  It's not the best ramen ever, but hell, it's in the CITY.  And open late!  

Broth is a little oily-rich for me, but I can live with it.  Gyoza are excellent.  Service sucks - waitresses are definitely too cool for school, and not sure why there are russian chicks with attitude working at a ramen place frequented by Japanese nationals.  That fifth star up there is definitely because this place is located in the city.  Let me reiterate: IN THE CITY.  Hallelujah!
author: Riya K.

description: On our visit to the bay we ended up here since it was down the street from my hotel and I was really amazed about how good it was. I really like how the broth tasted it was just right. The portions here are perfect and the combo is the way to go. I understand why this place always has a crazy wait its probably since its so cold you have to find some way to stay warm.
author: Jerald S.

description:
this place has been recommended as a good ramen place by no less than 3 actual japanese people.

I've been here maybe 3 times.  Each time it leaves me with that uneasy cognitive dissonance of thinking it kinda sucks but then why would these japanese people keep recommending this place that sucks?  is there a back room? a secret menu?  

they are usually so right about these sorts of things.  

anyway, it appears many people like this placel, maybe they too are wrestling with their internal rejection of their own japanese friend's recommendations.

i like santa ramen in san mateo better, which is most like a bowl of ramen from one of those stands in Osaka or Nagahama.

himarawi too in san mateo which is more like this style of ramen, but much better.

this place has ramen that is more like... haru in cupertino
or tampopo in japan town. like little ribbons of plastic tubing, and thin soup.

just not that good, but i guess if you are downtown, and want a bowl of noodles, then sure.. why not.
author: Irvin S.

description:
I'm pretty sure there's a place like this somewhere between nishi-magome and togoshi. The workmen with dark tans break from the job site for lunch, rub the white towel around their neck, pull the toothpick out to ask which type of soup she'd recommend. The waitress answers with a look that could intentionally be mistaken for having been distracted and not heard the question, but most likely means I-dont-know-I-just-work-here. His buddy with bleached orange hair  gripes in a southern accent that they don't have tonkotsu ramen, anyways, so whatever just order. The first guy orders a noontime beer and ends up getting gyoza and fried rice.

Katana-ya is pretty much like that place, but the waitresses are nicer and they speak English.

And if Nobu can't complain about it, then I can't either.
author: Trevor S.

description:
Never go to NY or Japan. Finding comparable places for ramen in SFBA is torturous and constantly disappointing. Every place has at least one crucial element missing. 

Katanaya is missing the ajitsuke tamago, you know, the boiled soaked egg. Jesus Katanaya, you're so tasty, you're almost there. just add the damned egg. How hard is that? Wouldn't it be great to be called the only authentic ramen in SF? Just freakin do it. How hard is it? Just put the egg. One star off for the egg. Please put the egg.
author: Jay N.

description:
YUMMY!

  I love soup. If it's an ethnic variation, I love it even more. If it's served in a restaurant that makes you feel like you left SF, I'm in heaven. Katana-Ya was a perfect melding of all of my favorite attributes for ethnic dining. . I have to admit I arrive late for dinner and my friends had already been seated and the meal was about to be served, Yikes! I had the buttered corn ramen ( on a friends recommendation) which was was full of fresh corn kernels and tasty noodles. I didn't really get a chance to take a gander at the menu so I can't say much to that. The service was quick, but almost to a fault. I received my food at almost the same time as my friends but we felt rushed and pushed out the door by meals end. Bummer. I will definitely come back again and hopefully next time I'll have time to peruse the menu.
author: chelsea b.

description: Although pricey, I thought we got quite a bit for what we paid. Cool wheel thing where you can choose different food combinations for the combo deals. It's definitely not the BEST ramen I've ever had, but I thought it was pretty decent and with a good, central location in SF. If you can walk up and be the first in line or go right in, then get it. But I don't think it'd be worth waiting over 20 minutes for, especially if it's cold (you have to wait outside) and you're really hungry.
author: Brad Y.

description: Had an opportunity to visit this place when I was in town to do my passport.  It's a nice convenient place down the street from union square.  The broth is was tasty and noodle nice and chewy.  Not as flavorful as other place I tried, but was good.  A bit pricey, but I guess that it's ok for downtown SF.
author: Johnny T.

description:
OK finally found my favorite ramen place in SF.  I was hesitant to check this place out since it's all Union Square-y and all, but man they delivered.  I knew it was a good sign when the staff were really Japanese and talking in Japanese and once I got my Spicy Tofu Ramen and dug in, I knew I had finally found my favorite ramen spot. 

Inside it's pretty cozy even though it's hard to tell what to expect from Geary Street outside.  I sat at the sushi bar and ended up ordering some sake (salmon) just to try the nigiri and it was pretty good, but I was there for the ramen.  I started off with some seaweed salad although I was tempted by a ton of other stuff.  The seaweed salad was nice and fresh and not too much so it was just perfect before the bowl arrived.

Overall a nice spot and I know I'll be coming here a lot once the rain gets more constant and I desire a nice warm bowl of ramen!
author: Gene X.

description: I was going to rave about how good their food was, but then a cockroach fell from above us and it ruined our appetites. Then, as we told their manager about it, he just said they'll get a terminator on Monday. Highly doubt they will.
author: Michael I.

description: I've been here several times since I started working in the city and have always had good service, hot ramen, and a short wait! (Maybe I'm lucky on the wait time part...)  My favorite is the Butter Corn Ramen Shio flavor, or the regular ramen w/ Shio flavor.  I don't think it's my all-time favorite ramen place, but considering I haven't found another one near union square, I definitely think its worth adding into my regular lunch rotation.
author: Tracy N.

description:
This place gets very crowded during the dinner and lunch rush. What I do love about this place is that it's open very late, so on those late drunken binges, as well as the late night cravings, this place beats calling in for pizza.

I've been coming here somewhere between the last 2 or 3 years, and one thing never disappoints; it hits the spot when you need it. This joint is a definite step up from Genki Ramen on Geary and also a definite step up in the price.

What has been constant with Katana-Ya is that it's really good every other time. Don't be led astray by your dining experience here if it's just 'OK'. Next time, it will be grrrrreat!

Their Katana-ya Ramen is loaded with pretty much everything in the other ramens, but really, keep it simple. Stick with the BBQ pork ramen.

The rolls and nigiri sushi are good, but a little pricey. I'd go for those things somewhere else for the same price.
author: Chris E.

description: The ramen here is delicious.  Ramen quality is comparable to Totto Ramen of NY (I do like Totto's ramen slightly more), and there are a lot more options to choose from outside of ramen.  While there is quite a wait - I came here on a Sunday night - it is (mostly) worth it.  Add to that its excellent location and I would definitely come back for more.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Really good broth and chewy ramen noodles - get the fried chicken one!  Yum!

$10ish for a bowl of ramen is pretty standard around the bay area I'd say.  I have no issues whatsoever with the prices.

The only down side is that for dinner, there'd definitely be a wait.  Saturday night is pretty much out of the question.  But arrive at 11:45am for lunch on a weekday and you'll head back to work very happy and satisfied.
author: Maggie T.

description:
Four star average?  Hmph.

Service was whatever, food isn't that great for the price you pay.
author: Tim K.

description:
Went here for lunch the other day and the Ramen was Amazing.  I would have to say for me it was better then Santa Ramen in San Mateo. Can't wait to go back!

But beware, this place is very small and the wait can be long!
author: Susie S.

description: The udon I got was really good, but more expensive than I expected for it.  Liked the interior but I got take out so didn't get to appreciate it long enough.  I think it's worth going back, maybe when I have time to eat in...
author: Today Y.

description:
I wanted to write a rave review after reading all the good stuff bestowed upon Katana-ya from other yelpers, but I'm an honest man, and as an honest man, I'll say "yeah, it was pretty good". Not amazing, but yeah, I'd eat there again. The price - a little pricey, but it's union square so I'll accept it. The wait - a bit long, but what's the rush?

The coolest thing about this place is their bathroom. Now, I'm not a big bathroom guy or anything by any means, but it was clean (this place borders the tenderloin, I've seen far worse), and bizarre as it may seem, it's got painted owls and trees and stuff on the walls. I'd meditate there.

p.s. had the soba + katsu don combo. pretty freaking good katsu don
author: Reman C.

description: The waiting list was long as any good Ramen place.  So get there a little earlier before you actually will want to eat so your not starving.  Wait can be 15 to 30 minutes.  Once you get in its hella small!!!  We had the Spicey Ramin Regular and the noodles were really good.  The spicey broth was flavorful too and the pork was tender and delicious.  Wash it down with a nice cold Sapporo beer.  The egg that we got in the Katanaya Ramen was overcooked.  I've seen once place that does that perfectly.  Where the egg white is boiled and cooked but the yoke part was slightly cooked and still oozzing on the inside of the yoke...That is the best!!!  Still good tasting broth and fresh noodles here too.
author: Jeremy K.

description: This was really good ramen.  I got the katanaya.  The flavor and the seasoning were perfect, the portions were generous, and the music was off the hook.  Expect to have wait a bit since this place makes the best ramen in town.
author: Tony D.

description:
Yummy ramen! Big bowls, hot brothy soup and good noodles. I ordered the Chicken Kaarage which is perfect for any fried chicken lovers - a bit too fried for me - but broth was great and noodles were pretty good! Best test of ramen's quality/authenticity is broth + noodles.

Tiny place was packed with small groups. 80% Asian, many were Japanese.
author: Debbie L.

description: Wow this place get 2000+ reviews? Ramen here is not great at all. The waitress was rude to me n my bf. Overall ramen here r ok. U can't call it great.
author: Aniko N.

description: I came here a few times and yesterday was the worst.   We had a party of 4, which meant we got last priority because 8 other couples that came after us, got seated before us.  Oh and they tried to charge me $15 for a coke.  I'll still come back though, because they close late and I love my ramen.
author: Roger W.

description: You can forgive the long wait and poor seating arrangement once you try the food.  Fried Chicken Ramen with spicy miso broth FTW. The sushi is ok but if im going to wait to get into this place im not wasting stomach space on it.
author: gabriel r.

description: my friend in LA dreams about this place, but i don't get why. to me it's good but not the best.  but the ramen is super big. i had no way of finishing it. if you have a big group of friends you are going to have to squeeze, because the places isn't so big.  i've been here several time, the last time i came here we got sushi. as well as appetizers. the age-dashi tofu was good, i loved it. but beware, the tofu is super super hot. wait awhile before you put it in your mouth.  i dont' remember what we got, but all of the sushi was super good. most of the sushi comes in 6 pieces so it's best to order a lot and share it. and in the end we got mochi!  (mainly because my friend burned her tongue from the hot age-dashi tofu) the mochi ice cream was fresh, and i recommend the green tea one and the mango. their hot sake hereiwas pretty good, it was my first time ordering hot sake. it had a dry taste to it.
author: Belinda C.

description: The ramen was delicious!!!! The sushi was good too! Loved the extra spicy Katanaya ramen!!! The place was small though but it was worth it to stay and eat :)
author: Maria P.

description: DUDE EAT RAMEN. All of them are good especially the fried chicken one. If you are really hungry get the big combo bowl with everything. If the wait is long, fuck your life up and get a margarita next door for 12 bucks.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
after hearing from everybody that this place was good i finally got the chance to go. ordered the miso ramen with the chashu. it was a little salty for my taste and i wasn't too impressed. it didn't really stand out to me....

it is nice how you can choose how thick you want your broth and the volume of  your noodles.

otherwise, it's a small restaurant, always people waiting, but you'll come out full
author: Ely K.

description: Came here at 10:30 pm on a sunday and waited about half an hour to get a table at the Bar/Counter. Had the Katanaya Ramen, which kind of throws all the options into one bowl. Was the first time I've had fried chicken in ramen, and now I can say it's a pretty good idea. Broth was pretty good. Decent meal but if I lived here I probably would find a place with a shorter wait, or come at less busy hours.
author: Tyler H.

description: The line is long.  They don't take reservation, so you will have to put your name down on their list when you arrive.  The servers do try to hurry you up, but that is expected from a high turn-around type of restaurant.  Overall, the wait was worth the food.  You must try the ramen.  This is the best I have had so far in SF.
author: Brett F.

description: Their vegetarian ramen is decent and priced the same as the meaty ones. It comes with cabbage, nori, and onions. Where's the bamboo, mushrooms, or tofu? It tastes cheapie but costs as much as the meaty ramen. Vegetarians beware.
author: James P.

description: I bookmarked this as a place to try thinking it would be just a ramen place. It turns out their menu is complete with sushi and other Japanese goodies. I went for their spicy miso ramen, which as usual was very fulfilling. The service was a bit inattentive towards the end when I was awaiting by check. It was a Friday evening when I went, so I guess I can forgive them a bit for that. Decor can be better, or that's my opinion.
author: H K.

description:
i like noodles
i like soup
i like corn

done.

the wait wasnt as bad on a rainy day. there were about 5 parties of 2 or 4 in front of us, but with great company, time flies. before we knew it, we were seated in the small restaurant and cozied up against one another.

the waitress who took our order was very nice. the waitress who brought us our noodles--not so much.

i love that there's an option for heavy or light flavoring. i've had "authentic" ramen in berkeley and the flavor was too strong for me, semi-scared me from any "authentic" ramen.

the restaurant's really small, so expect wait time, especially during meal times. they also close at 2p, so if you're out in the area, it's an amazing late night snack.

fried chicken ramen, you're next on my list.
author: Rena Y.

description: Ehh..... it was okay. Sunday around 6pm, waited around 20mins for a table for 4. Place isn't that big. Usually long lines. Pairs were getting seated quicker than tables. Service was okay, however they forgot our utensils, we were seated and ordered, food arrive, and we had to remind them that we haven't received out utensils yet. Food was okay. Still worth another visit, since there aren't many ramen locations at all in SF. Had the miso broth, it did taste really buttery, good/bad, depends how you like it.
author: Robin L.

description: This place has one of the best ramen in the bay area.  I've never tried the sushi here so can't speak to that.  I always get the Extra Spicy Ramen in salt flavor and it is hella spicy but good.  The only knock on this place is that they will combine the noodles and soup together in the same container when you order take-out.  that really bugs me.  I know a lot of ramen places do that but that doesn't mean it's a good thing.  By the time I get home, the soup is half gone because the noodles have soaked it all up already.  Anyways, other than that, this place gets 2 thumbs up from me.
author: Jax H.

description:
and the search for my favorite ramen in the city continues.  we're not there yet.  

came here for an early dinner on a sunday so our wait was less than 10 minutes for a table.  small, crowded, but in this city that often translates to good food.

i started with the spicy scallop roll.  i love me my spicy scallop and katana-ya impressed me with their large portions and fresh fish, making for an overall above-par spicy scallop option.

for my ramen i opted for the spicy green onion with the soy broth.  (does anyone else find it odd that to make a ramen 'spicy' you add $1.50 to the price, but the cost of the green onion ramen and the spicy green onion ramen on the menu are both the same?)  my ramen partner-in-crime summed up his experience with dinner as good noodles, but a broth that leaves something to be desired.  I agree.  Coming off of bad ramen noodles last week, I liked the quality of these better.  I even liked the broth better too, so I felt pretty good, until I realized that the broth still wasn't exciting me as much as it should.  Credit is due for a pork slice that was actually visible (and thick at that) floating in my soup.  

So not bad, but my search continues for a better broth.  (this post goes out to stephen a., one of the most dedicated self-yelpers i know)
author: Anne Marie B.

description: Very delicious. I'm used to Orenchi and Santouka since they're close by but sometimes it's fun to venture out a little further when time permits. It was definitely worth the drive out to San Francisco. It's a tiny spot and you might wait a little. It was definitely worth the wait. Worth the time and worth the travel if you like Santouka and Orenchi you'll enjoy the Katana-Ya.
author: Panha T.

description: LOVE this place. Great ramen with spicy miso broth for me, udon and gyoza for my girl. Good comfort food. Haven't had sushi here, but it looks good. We've been several times (when we used to live in the area) but now go when we are in the area.
author: Sam P.

description: This place was good, but after hearing the negatives about Tanpopo, I was expecting a lot more. Now that I have compared both, I have to say that the soy broth in both was the same, the noodles were the same, but they give about 8-times as much roasted pork at Tanpopo. I haven't tried the sushi here, but the sushi bar looked so-so. The cost though, was higher here, so I'll go back to Tanpopo next time.
author: Brian J.

description: Rumour has it this place is pretty authentic. If you love Ramen, Sushi and stuff like that you'll love this place. The prices are decent and the staff seemed pretty friendly. It's one of the better deals in town. And hey, they stay open late which is always a bonus.
author: Amy J.

description: The best ramen that I've had in a city where you'd think would have better Asian foods. Extremely small, Katana-ya is really a hole-in-the-wall type of restaurant. Although their ramen is very good, I wouldn't recommend their homemade gyoza because it's a bit different from the "normal" gyoza and is loaded with just a bit too much garlic. But hey, if you want ramen, go here.
author: Barrett I.

description:
Really BAD customer service!

The noodles are not bad, a little bit salty and small in size, especially, if you ordered the noodle with pork, expect to get only a small slice piece of pork but you can add $1.5 for another piece.

I have gone to this place many times since my gf likes their Udon noodle but most of the time, the customer service is terrible. My last experience was when I asked to put in an order after 10 mins sitting there trying to get the waitresses' attention. I got harassed and was almost lost my temper since I thought I supposed to be served as a customer, not as a beggar. I got comment as, "I am on break" after she just took an order and "you can't wait, hmm" with dirly looks. In addition, I got shorted change once for $5 so make sure to count you change in this place.

Overall, I don't know how long I can tolerate their bad customer service for the noodles...something got to give and I think I will cross out this place of my list of restaurants to go to in SF.

This is very unusual for a Japanese restaurant since Japanese is well known for customer service.
author: Dennis P.

description: Four stars that could have been five if not for somewhat indifferent service. I had the BBQ pork ramen and Hokkaidon combo. Very, very good all around. The Hokkaidon was a pleasant surprise and despite its diminutive portion was quite enjoyable. The ramen was very good but why not offer true chasu?
author: j w.

description:
I was really looking forward to checking this place out while I was on San Francisco this past weekend and all I can think of is....MAJOR disappointment.

The restaurant itself was pretty tiny but we didn't have to wait very long (15-20 min) since we got there early.  

This place received so many great reviews so I expected better.  I tried the Katana Ya Ramen and the soup was bleh and filled with MSG.  The noodles and pork were tough and I didn't even bother trying to bite through the pork.  The fried chicken was flavorless.  Only the fried dumplings and boiled egg were good. 

I don't think I'd come here again with so many other great food options in San Francisco.
author: Lilly M.

description: Disappointing! I've gone 3 times and it's never come close to wowing me. One of those unfortunate situations where before I ever tried their food, every time I'd pass by, I'd see a massive, massive line and think, "my god, people are really going nuts for this spot. I bet it's great." Well, like I said, I went several times and it was never great. In fact, it was barely even mediocre. It's actually been a while since I was last there, but I remember having their house Chashu Ramen or whatever their signature dish was and just feeling let down. Also, I remember one of the times the service was awful. That probably affects my rating. Waiting 30 minutes + for a bowl of ramen is ridiculous, especially when you  people who sat down after you got their food first. I will admit that part of my disappointment might derive from the fact that I'm from Los Angeles, and that I spent most of my life being spoiled by the fantastic selection of ramen joints throughout the city. Maybe compared to other joints in San Francisco this place is more of a 3 or 3 and a half, regardless, I have to stick by my guns and just say, this place is subpar, sowwy. Not recommended
author: Bobby R.

description:
The ramen here is SO good. Texture is perfect and there's just enough noodle to satisfy. The broth...is heaven. Really. It had a lovely silkiness to it and depth. People, I don't talk about soup like this. It was just so good! I had what they call a regular ramen with miso. I don't think I indicated whether I wanted a light or rich broth (it's an option) so I'm guessing by the look of the broth it was rich.

I absolutely can't wait to come back and try the many other ramens.

It's a very small little place and it fills up fast. My only tip would be to go before noon or after 1 p.m. if you're angling for a lunch date.
author: cyndi L.

description:
What's theover-hype and over-rated over the this place?

For the long wait, one would expect good ramen. Honestly, the ramens are ordinary, msg based. Not worthy of the wait at all. Convenient location though. 

Go to Izakaya sozai or south bay's ramen places instead- seriously. Meh..
author: foodie g.

description: wait was a good 45 minutes for 5 people. we didn't even get sat at a table for 5. it was a table for 4 with people squeezed together, but whatever! food was DECENT, i was starving so i thought it would be amazing but it wasn't as it was hyped up to be from the long wait. the fried chicken is pretty good though! soup was WAYY too hot, burned my tongue and i was pretty careful with it. not a bad place but with a wait like that i expected better
author: Jon T.

description:
I think its a good place for ramen and noodles. Lots of choices on the menu with pictures. Its is kinda expensive. PArking is a pain too. If you gonna come here, there is a 2.75/1/2 hr hour valet parking garage on mason. Then you can walk around the block. I went there around 3pm hoping there wont be much poeple in there. To my surprise, most of the tables were full. The bar was empty. Most of the poeple there were japanese or asian students or something. They sat me at the corner near the entrance. 

I think there was too much soup broth and not enough noodles and ingredients. When the bowl of ramen came out, I could only see broth.

Then had the side - the ikura-uni don. No good.  tasteless

Service wasnt bad. Oh also they include the tip with your bill I think 15%. I dont know why they do that but they do it. 

For the ramen and uni-ikura don + tip it was like $25

CRAP. oh include the parking almost $30! I can honestly make a better bowl of ramen with the same or better ingredients than what was served.
author: Tony W.

description: Good ramen at reasonable prices.  Place was packed when I went on a Saturday for lunch, but I was able to find a spot at the bar.  Staff were friendly and service was excellent.
author: Charles C.

description: I am not a fan of Ramen, but this place is amazing. My friend Jessica had brought me here and I actually crave it sometimes! I ordered the extra spicy ramen because I have a huge taste bud for spicy food. It hits the spot every time! All my other friends always get the pork with eiher soy sauce soup base or miso soup base. Both yummy.
author: Angela W.

description:
Cold Ramen is yummy!

Usually there is a line but we always seem to sneak in without waiting too long.  Pretty dependable place.
author: Rob S.

description:
the first time we were here, the line was out the door ... so we passed it up. 

the next time we were here, the line was still out the door. but we waited... and were sat within 20 minutes. first at the bar, then moved to a table without explanation. wth?

i ordered a couple of rolls that were ok. my PIC (partner in crime) ordered the katana-ya ramen. oh, how i wish i got that instead. so much to try, especially for the one who can't make up their minds. 

the place was small, so i'm not sure ramen is worth the wait, but i think i'd give it another go just so i could order the ramen instead. 

lesson learned: who goes to a ramen house to order sushi?!?
author: Milly S.

description: This place is so good...and super popular! So popular that I have to say...good luck getting a table! I have introduced Katana-Ya to about 3 dozen people, and they all agree that if really yummy!
author: Hello M.

description:
Frankly, I do not get the hype about this place. I think people primarily go here because they are not familiar with the alternatives. I was stunned to see so many Nihonjin there given the far superior places they should know about.

I got Hamachi kama, which was fried rather than grilled and not that great.

I got Shio Chashu ramen. The broth needed more shio and tasted watery. There was about a half pound of scallions on top(WTF?). The ramen were stuck together in a massive clump. On the positive side, the Chashu was delicious. I would not rate the bowl of ramen I had there in the top 100 bowls I have had, but acceptable. It is in the top 50 bowls I have had in the US, maybe. Perhaps if I had been trashed, I would have had a different opinion--I was just ravenously hungry having come from a huge workout.

On the positive side the Nama-biru I had was fantastic. Additionally, the waitress was very pleasant, attractive and had a nice Yokohama accent.
author: John D.

description: went here cuz of yelp and i'm glad i did. I ordered soyu ramen with the tonkatsu as a lunch combo. when i got the order they gave me miso ramen instead which i didn't mind at all because it was delicious! i didn't feel like complaining and i figured i mite as well try something new since i always get soyu ramen at other ramen places. the tonkatsu was a perfect. i cant wait to go back and try fried chicken soyu ramen! my fiancee ordered udon with california roll as the combo. the sushi was fresh...he regreted not getting ramen doe because it was obvious that my ramen looked way more better than his udon.
author: Ruchell F.

description:
Super tasty ramen. The place is a bit small so expect a little wait to be seated if you come here for dinner, but it's worth it.

The staff are really friendly and they have personality! :D

Sushi chef is a true artist. Haha~
author: Ringo M.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. They have the best ramen. I try to come here almost every week. I keep missing their delicious noodles. My favorite is the extra- spicy ramen, with additional crispy fried chicken. 

They offer 3 different sauces for the ramen broth: miso, soy, and salt. i love the soy broth, the the miso is also pretty good. 

So far, i like this place way more than the noodle places in Japantown.
author: Libby K.

description:
The location is a bit from ideal as it is situated in Union Square and driving in the area at night is a pain.  

On a chilly, rainy day, ramen is an inviting meal.  It was toasty inside and the service was just as warm.  We were seated at the bar and the chef behind was nice enough even though I didn't order any sushi.

I ordered a bowl of miso ramen with light broth but there was still a good amount of oil in the soup.  Overall, I thought the meal was decent but nothing spectacular.  I prefer my local Shin-Sen-Gumi.
author: Jun H.

description:
I was originally going to eat some sushi here but my gal pal suggested that I tried either their udon or ramen. 

Udon w/ Curry soup = Heaven.

I devoured my udon and soup along with the poki salad. Yum!!! Totally hit the spot.
author: Joon Y.

description: Besides the bad parking and a big line more often than not, this place is pretty darn good for SF ramen. Not quite as good as LA, but decent. I always get the Katana-Ya extra spicy ramen. The sushi here is not bad either.
author: Minh V.

description:
yep a Ramen house!  Me and my coworker hit up this spot once a week at lunch time usually before the rush at 12pm.  If you like ramen noodles like us asian kidds do then you gotta give this place a try at least once.  I like the small ambiance of the place thats why its always jammed, not enough seats in a small area.  So whats good?  I like the spicy onion ramen, the cilantro ramen, the spicy other ramen.  The sushi orders are also good I have had spider rolls that are on hit!  Havent really tried the whole menu yet but that'll come in time. 

 Overall its a great certified asian noodle house joint downtown.  So if you are downtown looking for a spot to eat then you know what to do or maybe not, ehh its up to you do what you gotta do to survive in the food game.
author: marcus o.

description: Too many times I've traveled to San Francisco, gotten off the BART at Powell Street Station and eaten in a tourist trap with bad food.  This time, I checked Yelp before my trip and found Katana-Ya mentioned.  What a discovery!  I could tell that it would be good food when I arrived (after a short walk from the station) to  find a large group of people waiting outside in the cold before the place was even open.  The ramen was well worth the wait.  It was by far the best I've ever eaten.
author: Tom T.

description:
Love the ramen!!!! it's probably loaded with tons of MSG, but hey what's not these days?!?!? one thing i LOVED about this place was that their spicy broth was actually SPICY! i was kinda skeptical at first because their broth is really thick.., but oh man is it yummy...i ordered the one with all the stuff in it- chicken, pot stickers, chasu, and corn. the meat soaked up everything perfectly! 


Place is very small. Expect a 20 min wait.
author: krystina ann r.

description: I seek out ramen.  if you read my other reviews, I go love ramen...LOVE.  Do any of them compare to the Japanese ramen houses?  No, but we're not in japan!  Katana is pretty close.  seriously!  Simple salt ramen with their pork, yum-o.  tempura is pretty tasty...as well as the agedashi.  small tables for sure, so make sure the people you're dining with are your good friends.  can be too close for comfort.  overall, happy face.
author: Sonia C.

description:
I went there yesterday cuz I was craving for some traditional ramen. I have to say I am almost a frequent customer here given that I live in East Bay. The ramen here is the best out of all the ramen places I've tried so far. The thing with ramen is that it needs to be balanced. If the soup is outstanding and the noodle is meh...the ramen is destroyed in my opinion. Anyway, the ramen here is very balanced and tasty. I don't really recommend getting sushi here. I usually go by myself and sit at the counter. The fish does not look fresh at all.  The price for the ramen is really reasonable. Writing this makes me want to go there again. A hot bowl of ramen in this cold weather = heaven.
