Note on the waitress: It seems to me that they switch waitresses a lot. I have not seen the same waitress there twice...haha.
author: Erik T.

description:
some tips:
 - clipboard hangs outside to write your name down which can tell you that you'll most likely will be waiting OUTSIDE.
- don't go with a big group. this is a classic ramen style shop so it's best to come alone or with another person.
- great for something short and simple. not recommended if you want to sit and chat for hours. 

they gave me free hot tea which is what i think a japanese restaurant should do although i  didn't really enjoy their tea. i was not floored over their ramen menu but they do have a variety and with a selection of spicy ramens. you can choose what broth you want, either miso, shoyu (soy sauce), or salt. i had the miso and it was okay- it had a good flavor but again, did not impress me. 

they offer a lot of combinations which is always fun, along with sushi and japanese dishes. i was also suprised that they do offer udon and soba, which made me question if  this is a ramen shop trying to do too much.
author: Chanda I.

description: I LOVEEEEE KATANYA! It's always a great way to end a 12 hour work day! I love my Katanaya Ramen with Udon instead! You got to try to fried squid legs.....probably the best in the bay!
author: Brian P.

description:
3.5 stars, actually.

I've been here 3 times now mostly because I can walk here from my apartment, and their food seems pretty consistent. I've had their katana-ya ramen the first two times, and a combination regular ramen + small katsu curry with rice.

The ramen's decent, it won't compare to ramen giants like Santouka in LA and San Jose, but overall it's not bad, I'd say maybe a bit below Orochon in LA. 

The "BBQ Pork" is just chashu, and here it's a bit more chewy than I would've preferred, but taste-wise was alright. The soup broth is pretty good, I happily drank the whole damn thing every time. The Katana-ya ramen is really just a whole bunch of random food (potstickers, fried chicken) piled into the soup, and is really only there for the novelty. You pay a bit more for it too, so I would suggest just getting the regular or "BBQ Pork" ramen for less. Standard ramen topings are included.

The only non-ramen dish I had here was the Katsu curry rice, which was a bit soggy, but the taste was decent. I was really hungry that night, so I ate the whole combo meal pretty quickly while the guy next to me looked at me funnily.

Service was fine, though if you're not a single guest walking in, you will most likely wait quite a while to get a seat. It is on the 7x7 100 things to eat before you die list after all...
author: Bobo L.

description: For me katana-ya was an okay ramen place so maybe a two star is a tad tough. For their original ramen, I really did not like how the pork was done. The ramen itself from the noodles to the broth was very good. I couldn't really eat more than one piece of the pork though.  They seem to either grill the whole piece and just cut it up and it almost tasted like pork out of a processed bag. I like char siu pork where they actually fire each piece right in front of you.  So that was disappointing.  I don't know about their other dishes though since we only had ramen.  Doubt I'd be returning (unless someone drags me or I seriously run out of places to try) as having only good broth and good noodles simply isn't enough.
author: Li Y.

description:
I decided to try this place out on the recommendations from Yelp and it hasn't disappointed.  It's semi-difficult to find a place that will serve hiyashi-chuuka; in Berkeley it's only served at one place and only in the summer.  Now I can eat cold noodles on the rainiest, coldest winter day and just get a weird look from the waitress rather than a flat out "hell no we don't have that."  The miso ramen is quite tasty too; the broth is on par with Santa ramen in San Mateo, but this place is free of the overhyped wait-in-line-for-an-hour atmosphere.
And the final plus is that it's run by real Japanese people!
author: Forrest Y.

description: I don't get it, it's noodles in soup..noodles in soup. And yet I can't stop thinking about this place. Must be the MSG. So I get the regular ramen with rich miso. So..So good. My bud tends to get the Spicy Green Onion, another solid dish. Really dont know what it is about this place, the flavors aren't complex but they are clean and simple. Guess the beauty is in the simplicity. Check this place out when you're in Union Square. But don't go during lunch hour, you'll have to wait.
author: Shreya C.

description:
I first showed up here after a night out in SOMA (sober, don't worry) on the recommendation of a friend who said they had great ramen and food. We had already eaten a large dinner that night so a bunch of us shared two plates of fried chicken.

It was perfect: crisp and not greasy.

The staff was great, too. Ten minutes after the kitchen had officially closed we were able to talk them into bringing us some additional food.

Later that day I found myself back in the area and gave the spicy tofu ramen a shot. In miso broth, the ramen was flavorfully spicy with generous chunks of tofu. The morning workers were just as friendly as the late-night crew.
author: Joel P.

description:
This was really good. I got what I believe was called katana-ya ramen. She asked if I wanted it extra spicy and I said, "Sure!".

My mouth was burning, but I loved it. I can't wait to come back here.

It was busy with a small waiting list, I took that as a good sign.
author: Nathan M.

description: Long wait but worth it. Their sushi is amazing and the ramen is good too! Some are pricey but some are good deals. Tiny restaurant. I wish they would expand. Good service too
author: Carolina T.

description:
Amazing Ramen.  I am a frequent visitor.  Always order the spicy tofu ramen, miso base.  Kind of a long wait, but well worth it. 

As a caveat emptor, ordered my usual one day a few months ago and found a half eaten shrimp in my tofu soup which led me to believe they 1) reuse their soups taken from cleared off tables, 2) reuse their noodles taken from cleared off tables, or 3) reuse half eaten shrimp taken from cleared off tables.  

I've still been a regular patron since as 1) I'm not vegetarian (so the shrimp in my supposedly vegetarian dish did not induce vomit) and 2) I'm well versed in the unsanitary atrocities that happen in the kitchens of America's favorite restaurants (as I've seen big dead bugs, pubic hair, and lots of ants in numerous restaurants so the half eaten shrimp paled in comparison). 

So yes, you should go, but just look in your soup bowl for half eaten anything before starting.  Then slurp away.
author: Tiff T.

description:
Another killer restraunt that hit the spot late night at like midnight. Neither of us got ramen (seems to be the thing to talk about), but loved the sushi and udon bowls. I mean--heads up, you're going to get a big bowl of soup. 

Small space, so don't expect to bring like 5 of your friends, but its one of those Japanese restraunts that you know you're going to enjoy, seeing Japanese customers there loving the food.
author: Kyle S.

description:
I thought I'd give ramen a try in the city, but I guess I thought wrong. We ordered some sashimi which turned out to be pretty decent, but when our entrees came out I was a bit disappointed. I tried the regular ramen w/ soy sauce and my friend had the bbq pork ramen. As the yelper below mentioned, mine literally came with 1..may I repeat 1 ever-so-thinly sliced piece of pork. Booo....luckily I was able to mooch some meat off my generous pal's bbq pork ramen which btw, I couldn't really tell the difference between the two meats? 
Anyway, the soup was simple, and the noodles chewy which I don't mind, but I was still hungry after this meal. Hence, the birth of my 2nd dinner..yes, surprise surprise (next review). I know everyone has their own preferences when it comes to ramen, so it is hard to rate, but I'll be sticking to the South Bay for my future fixes.
author: Irene B.

description:
Delicious. The wait looks intimidating but out of the 4 times I have been there I have been seated within 20 mins.

Food: 5- Try the fried chicken ramen, it is hands down my favorite.

Atmosphere: 4- Nice enough, music selection not the best, not good for groups bigger than 6.

Wait staff: 4- Don't bother you and give you what you need.

Overall a good place for cheap yummy food, definitely a fan of that.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Ryry and I really enjoyed our visits here.

Ryry got the Miso Ramen and I got the Spicy Tofu Ramen. Delicious, thick, perfectly seasoned. 

Cute, quaint little joint. Perfect after a long day of shopping in Union Square or whenever you feel like a good bowl of ramen and can't go to Hawaii.
author: Christine C.

description:
I enjoyed my lunch at Katana-Ya. However, if I didn't realize that this place was supposed to be a big deal in SF ramen world, I would have been pleasantly surprised. Overall the ramen at Katana-Ya is very good and above average for what you will find at most places in SF. It isn't as good as the ramen you'd find in Japan, but we're talking about SF, not Japan.

Very good choice for a reasonably-priced way to scratch your ramen itch. The service is also very quick, which is nice when you go at lunch.
author: Charles H.

description:
I went for the first time with two friends on Friday night. We got there around 6pm, which was really good timing since we got seated right away. After that, the line started forming outside. Our table was small for three people and almost couldn't fit all of our waters, noodles and one sushi roll. Expect to knock elbows if you're going with 2 or more other people. 

I got the katana ramen with miso broth for $12 and it had 5 pieces of fried chicken, 2 fried gyoza, pork, and some other vegetables. I didn't expect that much food, and the quality was very delicious. The noodle was well-cooked with a bite to it. The broth was thick and flavorful as well. The roll we ordered was a tobiko roll, although we shouldn't have ordered it since our ramen was food-overload already.
author: Rosa C.

description:
I guess I missed out. It seems like the thing to get here is ramen. I came here for sushi, but the sushi definitely did not disappoint. The sushi was extremely fresh. I believe I had the Katana roll and the Sunrise roll. Both were really good. The sunrise roll had a raw egg right in the middle of the roll. I wasn't sure if it was just a garnish, or if I was supposed to eat it. I ate it. It sucked. That was the only weird part of the rolls, but other than that, there was nothing for me to complain about.

The restaurant is small, but yet there were many people waiting outside to be seated. Try to come early to avoid the line, and don't come if it's raining, because there are no waiting areas inside.
author: Aaron C.

description: Servers horribly rude. Against eating any where where service is terrible.  I would recommend Ramen Underground or Lava Lounge which are bright vibrant and better quality food.
author: Daniel P.

description:
It's definitely a no-frills place, but it makes a good ramen with a thick broth.  I had BBQ pork ramen with Miso broth, and I was very happy with it.  I came at noon on Sunday, and there was a considerable lineup.  

I found it just a touch on the oily side but I seem to say that about a lot of places, so maybe you should pay this no attention. Still worth 4 stars.

Come here in a small group - There are only about 3 tables for any group larger than 2, and it would be pretty much impossible to seat a group larger than 4. There are maybe 30 seats total, including 5 at the little sushi bar.
author: K. B.

description:
This is my first time experience at this restraurant. I ordered Unadon.

Assume how common this dish is... since people usually get unadon early summer as a part of their tradition, I assume this is not a difficult dish to make.

1) Eel was over cooked. Eel skin looked burned. It taste very bad with little source on it.
2) Rice tasted like 60-70% cooked. It's so hard to chew.  Maybe it's just because they didn't put enough water to steam; also the rice might be over night.
3) Too few waiter/waitress. They keep you waiting FOREVER. no smile. no stopping in the middle and ask if things are okay. I'd rather pay at the counter.

I order Unadon almost every Japanese restraurant I go. Won't go to this one again.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Doesn't compare to LA ramen but not a bad substitute.  I guess I'm just used to the toppings in LA so I found the toppings for their ramen a bit deficient.  

Not the greatest, but not the worse.  It'll do.
author: Vi T.

description:
the restaurant is pretty small, once you put down your name they ask you to leave, and wait outside. 
the crispy spicy tuna was pretty good in terms of flavor and texture.
the ramen was edible, definitely not the best in sf. we had the extra spicy ramen and the katanaya ramen. there was nothing special. the pork was dried and tough, bamboo shoots were too salty, and the fried stuff on the ramen wasn't very flavorful either. the ramen was so so, edible but not really worth going back for. especially since it is a pain to find parking there and their service was not too pleasant. one of the wait would see us wave with our hands up and then just ignored us. 

in terms of price and what I got, not really worth it. I would probably not come back on my own.
author: George L.

description: Given this price and place, their ramen is unbeatable. I wouldn't say it's the best ramen ever or but it's definitely decent. The store is small though, not good for a group of people; more suitable for one or two peeps.
author: Frost L.

description:
It hits the spot when you do not know what you are craving.

Big bowls of RAMEN! Had light miso & hubby had light soyo - could not stop eating and I'm typically not a big bowl of soup person (even w/ Pho).
Side orders we had:  chicken/rice curry & king crab broquette
Love the Late hours


I love hole in the walls & this joint is really A HOLE IN THE WALL - easily missed.

Would easily come back again b/c it beats your late night greasy eateries!
author: Stel D.

description:
Perfect 10 Destination for great and fulfilling Japanese Food. 

I was companied by a Japanese friend, and this place was proven of its authenticity!! Even the place is Japanese-like compact and cozy!

The FOOD..... GOOOOOOOD!
The PRICE.... GREEEAAAAT!
The CHOICES... Oh My~~~~!
The SERVICES... NIIIICCEE!

And it is certainly not a secret hide out place..... 
So, this place is popular... and since the size of this place doesn't really quit hold up.... so it is a "beat to buzzer" place!

But you know what? This place is SO worth the wait.... !
author: Andrew W.

description:
I love love love this place.  Especially their ramen.

It's a cozy, casual place hidden on Geary Street across from the Redwood room.  It's open late and the food is fantastic.

I always order the Ramen and consistently leave with an ear-to-ear smile.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
OMG! I love this place! Its sooooo perfect. Tiny little restaurant tucked away in Union Square. I went there on the first day of my week long trip to San Fran. It was also my last meal there :) 

First time around, I ordered the box meal thingy with chicken teriyaki and tempura. Amazing!

Second time - Ramen with fried chicken in miso soup. Even more amazing!

Y'all have got to go there just once and you'll be addicted!
author: A T.

description:
Dinner at the counter at Katana-ya.  Fried chicken miso ramen soup.  Nice noodles, good broth and hot fried chicken.  Enjoyable reasonable priced meal but I don't think I would take muni across town for it.

It is hard to get the attention of the waitstaff, even though the restaurant was only half full.  Half the people at the bar were eating sushi, which I thought odd at a ramen specialist.  Age dashi tofu maybe but not sushi.

Maybe I'll have to go to the south bay for the ramen of my dreams.  I would not come here with more than 2 people as the restaurant is quite small.  They have Japanese beer on tap, which is a plus.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Great little ramen shop. Spicy seafood salad is delicious, but definitely spicy.

Their broth is exellent, noodles have a great texture and they give you plenty. Best of all, the Sapporos were ice cold.

There are only a couple of tables and a small sushi bar, so expect a bit of a wait. The place was absolutely packed when we were there, but the staff was pleasant and attentive.
author: Jason C.

description:
Been there twice. I love Ramen, and this is now my favorite downtown Ramen place. Portions are decent and prices are reasonable. They have a special spicy Ramen, which is dark red :) and a good choice if you love spicy food.

Haven't tried the sushi yet.

The only thing to look out for is that they are small. First time there, it was 2 of us and we showed up at 7:30 pm on a weekday, and there was a 20-25 minute wait.
author: Abid M.

description: I'm from Toronto. And damn, these ramen are beyond amazing compared to the ones where I'm living. I came here with my mom, my brother in law and his parents. Waited a while for it, we didn't know we need to go inside to sign up for seatings. They should put a sign up for that. But we got seats eventually downstairs. The prices are great, portions are great, the choices on the sides for combos is great, and their sushi is great! Ugh, you San Fran peeps, you guys are so lucky. $14US for a ramen with sides? Yea, def worth it. Best tasting broth and food ever.
author: Mannie W.

description:
yet another yelp hype.

current day katana-ya is not that great, definitely not worth the parking, the wait, and the trouble of getting a seat.

perhaps it's my so so review that ruined this place for the gf (sorryyyy), i just think you can get better ramen elsewhere in sf and in the bay.

i got the katana-ya ramen, which had a lot of toppings but not a lot of flavor. i find the broth bland and the noodles a little too soft. 

i recommend going to japantown in sf for ramen.
author: Phu N.

description: Do not believe all these people saying the ramen is good here! This is a cool restaurant with fun ambiance in a nice part of town. But please do not be fooled. The soup is nothing compared with an average place is jtown. Also the gyoza was tasteless.
author: Jeremy R.

description: I wasn't too impressed having to wait for so long to be seated to eat some midioker ramen.  Maybe I just orded the wrong one, but my boyfriend seemed to enjoy his bowl of ramen.  I'll probably go back when the weather is nicer.
author: Paige L.

description: I wasn't feeling too good so my SF friend took me to this place. The ramen hit the spot and I felt allll better. Choose your broth (rich/light, soy/miso/salt) and your meat or veggie..ENJOY! Very unassuming, tiny place.
author: Natalia K.

description: Maybe I'm a jaded New Yorker, but I found the company much better than the food.  Do they make their own noodles? No, they are pretty much generic.  Granted, I was with 7 people but this does not excuse the fact that they neglected one ramen order in the bunch.  Broth wise, it was decently rich and salty enough, however it lacked the depth of flavor that spicy miso ramen warrants (I had the katanaya ramen).  This place may be popular but I bet there are better places in Japantown.  Sayonara!
author: Anna M.

description:
Small, very small restaurant, so there is always a line.. Tables are small too, I guess the idea is to eat and get out! No time to sit and chit chat when there are people waiting, but of course, there are people oblivious to this fact....
The bowl of ramen is huge! I was defeated, I just cannot finish! But then I did order the combo bowl, which has everything: pork, egg, bamboo shots, gyoza, fried chicken... The noodles are chewy, so I like that. 
I will be back, to try different flavors, but not the combo again, I was too stuffed!
Service is decent, you get tea or water, and the check fast enough.
author: lovetoeat a.

description: Decent ramen, a bit on the salty side. But hey, where else are you going to find late night ramen?
author: Judy L.

description: The Katana-Ya Ramen is excellent. Spicy, salty, boiling hot, and with the better part of a small farm thrown in for good measure. I'm a fan.
author: Ziad E.

description:
omg, i think i just died and went to ramen heaven.

this place has some of the best ramen in the city. the bbq pork shoyu ramen is amazing. i never get anything else. the noodles are cooked perfectly. the bbq pork is so flavorful and tender.  and the soup is so delicious. not to salty, but just right.

the only thing about this place i don't like? the chopsticks. you would think, will all the business they have, they could spring for some higher quality utensils. they're the crap kind that never break down the middle and give you splinters all throughout your meal. it's a little thing, i know, but if you can deal, the food makes up for it tenfold.
author: Michelle P.

description: The place is always packed. Waited about 30min for a table for two. We had the katana-ya miso spicy ramen. The broth was very flavorful and the ramen noodles was chewy, just the way we liked it.
author: Henry P.

description:
Yum.

I've been here a half dozen times now, and feel I can give a fair review (reviews after one or two visits are a bit silly IMO, unless you had a really bad experience  - everyone has bad/good days).  Their soy broth is pretty good, as are their karaage and katsu.  I wouldn't go way out of my way for any of it (though places that fall in to that category for me, I could probably count on one hand), but if you're in the area, it's perfect, especially after walking around shopping in the cold - a nice warm bowl of ramen really really hits the spot.  

I'm not sure why people consider it a greasy broth.  Sure, there's a bit of oil floating on the top of the soup, but nothing really noteworthy, at least all the times I've been there.  That actually sort of got my hopes up after reading the reviews here before going there the first time.  I was hoping for a really rich tonkotsu-y broth like I've had multiple times in Japan at places like Jangarra Ramen in Tokyo.  None of this lightly brown tinted clear broth.   I was hoping for some nice opaque soup with some body.   That said, I'm not really an uber-ramen-afficionado, and haven't really tried ramen at a whole lot of places around here, so maybe that's how they make it around here.

Whatever the case, any time I'll be shopping around Union Square, or if I feel like taking the long way home and slurping up a bowl of steaming ramen, I'll be dropping by here.
author: T C.

description:
This is truly a wonderful gem of a restaurant.  Prices are great, food be plentiful, sodium overload quite lasting!  :)  But, hey... we're talking Ramen with either a Miso or Soy based soup.  It automatically puts your system into sodium overload. 

Went there with the girls and we got to try a number of things.  Had their combo meals - Katsu don and ramen (with miso) for $9.75.  The portions were so large that I could take it home and make a second meal out of it.  The ramen's texture had the requisite chewiness but was not quite that of Japan.  But, the bowl of noodles was pretty much the size of a sink!  The katsu do came with about 5 pieces of crispy katsu. 

We also had the crab croquette as well.  Very creamy tasty and comes with a great sauce that reminds me of Kagome.  (it may or may not have been).  

Just be warned, this place is tiny!  but you will not go home hungry.
author: H. Q.

description:
Tiny, unassuming place near a large shopping plaza....

Crowded sushi bar....

Excellent rolls from dynamite to hawaiian....

Variety of hot and cold noodles from shoyu ramen to soba...

Line outside the door, even in the rain....

No one speaking English inside...

Ah, just like my experience in Tokyo, except in America!
author: James C.

description: This place is great although Ramen does not seem to be this place's primary specialty.  There still isn't a lot of places that serve good Ramen in the Bay, but thankfully this is one of them.  There isn't a grand selection of Ramen, as there are probably only a dozen varieties with the typical three types of broth (miso, salt, and soy).  The broth was very flavorful and had the right texture, and the noodles were good.  I'd take this place over Santa Ramen (on most days) because there isn't a ridiculous wait and it's closer to Daly City.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
ramen was lukewarm at best... good for US standards but nothing close to the bowl of delicious-ness you get in japan. Santa still tops the list as coming the closest to the real deal.

I ordered the chrashi, which is suppose to be the benchmark for all japanese restaurants. Sashimi was fresh, except I bit in a sour tasting cooked prawn. 

The place to owned by chinese people and the chefs are from Hong Kong. Not very authentic Japanese, but tasted alright. except the shirmp that wasn't fresh.
author: Scarlet S.

description: Crowded little spot that if you blink when you walk by you will miss. Walked right in and sat at the bar. The sushi chefs were nice. The bf had a rice/pork bowl that he really liked. We had a few rolls as well. They were decent. Interesting, however, was that our rainbow roll had octopus on it!
author: Dee I.

description:
So after reading so many stellar reviews - I walked over after work on my way o the BART station. 3pm on a Wednesday, I was surprised that the place was empty. Very friendly hostess and waitress. I ordered two soups to go (didn't want my honey to feel left out). The light/soy/green onion ramen for me and salty/rich/bbq pork for him. After my trip to San Bruno our soups where still HOT! tender little slices of pork, perfectly cooked noodles, savory brothy delicousness.

Impressive, delicous and perfect for a foggy day
author: Rhiana M.

description:
Can't believe I never came here before. Always on the lookout for great ramen in SF, I never thought I'd find it near union square. And if I did, I surely never thought it would be reasonably priced. 

I can only speak on behalf of the ramen but it is absolutely worth every penny. And it's open late. Definitely on my short list of great values in the city.
author: Jon N.

description:
This is NOT Santa Ramen by a long shot.  The ramen is fine, but nothing special.  And for the prices they are charging, the broth and noodles should have been much tastier.  I would not go out of my way to eat here again.  

The restaurant itself is also very small.  So if you think this is a good place to go after shopping at Union Square with all your shopping bags, you are wrong!
author: Dana H.

description:
hi-YA! katan-YA! 

fun name. fun food.  it works.

was in town for quick bit and met up with my girls near my hotel. for union square to be so uberly touristy, a sunday night,.. food is a bit lacking.  but it was chilly san francisco night, perfect for some fancy ramen.

we basically ordered a buffet.  three "small" ramen soups.  first, these were not served in bowls, they were basins.  who were they kidding with these little tables, and this tiny place if they were serving bowls this big! but hello! soothing yummy broth! and all around delish!

we ordered an assortment.  the miso broth was just yumminess! nicely seasoned, earthy, not too salty, and the ramen was well cooked.  not too mushy, and stayed true to form.. kept its crimped like nature. my friend got the fried chicken ramen which seemed just wierd, but i think she won for best pick among us. the chicken and the soup broth was a nice blend of salty and savoriness. 

we also did a couple rolls and a tofu dish too.  all, very nicely priced and really good.  

when we chose this joint, i was definitely worried, because the wait was atrocious.. but they moved you in and out.

this is just short of 5 stars for the following reasons.  (1) a bit too cramped.. my goodness. i might as well be dining w/ our neighbors; (2) the most annoying three older ladies/cougars next to us who were shrieking and bumping i our table [technically not the restaurant's fault.. but come on ladies!]

but as long as you keep those three cougars out, i'll be back for sure in no time!
author: Natalie G.

description: Loved it.  The ramen was excellent, I got the Vegetable Ramen with miso and spicy.  I also tried the shrimp tempura appetizer, spicy tuna don, and shared a pitcher of beer.  Good prices, and open late.  We arrived after 11:30 pm.  Can't wait to return to try more on the menu!
author: Alexander B.

description: ramen, sushi, & shabu shabu that stays open till 1 am! & next to ruby skye!! win!! win!!!
author: Wooodis D.

description:
Best broth of any ramen joint in the Bay Area.  That said, my bowl of shoyu was lacking.  The bowl was rather small, compared to other ramen eateries around here.  And they skimped on the toppings.  My noodles resembled udon, but were cooked perfectly.  An above average bowl of ramen, but overall not better than Berkeley Ryowa.  My gyoza was tasty, but undercooked.  No Kirin Ichiban, either?

Expensive--$22 for a bowl of ramen, 4 pieces of gyoza, and a large Sapporo.

No Wi-Fi.  Non-existent parking.  And oh my, this place is *tiny*--not very comfortable seating at all.

Good, but I'm not going out of my way to eat here again.
author: Tom B.

description:
Noodle was not cooked well. I got a big lump of noodle in a bowl. I had Shio (salt) soup but it tasted like salted cheap chicken bouillon. Ran out of draft beer and 2 min. later they put a new keg. Didn't ask if I would wait for 2 min but pushed me to change order to bottled beer.  

Menn ga katamari nannte ohanashi ni narimasenn
author: Akky M.

description: I really like this small place.  It's my asian comfort food.  I've never been disappointed so far.  It's open reasonably late.  It seems very popular.  Only acceptable downside is I almost always have to wait for a good while to get a seat.
author: Mike S.

description:
We were frantically searching for RAMEN RAMEN RAMEN and this Katana-ya knowing that it was popular for its ramen..never rely on my brain to remember places!!! after a tour de tenderloin, we finally bumped into it! unfortunately, the place is small so don't expect to find a seat right away if you get here after work!
anyway, we didn't get ramen...but others reviewed it so read the other reviews for that! after all that walking and waiting, cold sapporo was the answer! the rest is a bit blurry and the sushi was ok. I suppose I expected better quality since the staff is for the most part japanese.

perhaps I'll stick to the ramen next time! and read Yelp maybe?
author: Paolo D.

description: I came here for dinner last night mostly because I was craving soup and my boyfriend and I are (slowly) making our way through 7x7's 100 Things to Eat in SF list.  I have to admit this was my first experience with ramen not of the 'top ramen' variety so I don't have much to compare it to.  I got the barbeque pork ramen in miso broth and it was pretty good but not a highlight of the Big Eat list for me.  It was certainly better than top ramen but nothing about the flavor, noodles or meat stood out as particularly noteworthy for me... but perhaps I'm just a ramen-amateur.  We got there pretty early (a little before 6) so there was no wait.  It was a fine experience overall but nothing I'm in a rush to try again.
author: Heather D.

description: super small place, so be prepared for a wait if you come here during peak dining hours. i expected a lot from this place after hearing so many good things about it. my date and i both got the katana-ya ramen. when in rome, right? it was good, broth had a lot of flavor and there was a little of everything in that bowl of ramen. my only gripe was that it was super oily. our eyes were a little bit bigger than our stomachs and we had also ordered the hamachi kama and chicken karrage appetitzers. both were really good but ended up being too much food. food came out quick and its nice that this place is open late. i'd come back if i was in the area.
author: Linda N.

description:
I feel like I'm wasting my time writing a review about this place... I mean they already have 2000+ reviews on how awesome they are. 

But yeah.. they're awesome. If you love ramen noodles, you come here and eat it. Ok? Only if they had this in Chicago... man... I'd die from ramen overdose.
author: James C.

description:
spicy tofu ramen!

on a very cold sf day, katana-ya hits the spot.  if you're in the mood for soba or udon, you can substitute the ramen for soba or udon noodles if you like the other broth varieties instead.
author: Carli F.

description:
if you have a love for ramen, you should really check this place out, but be ready to wait in line. i stayed at the hotel next door to this place, and everytime we walked passed it, there was always a line! we came in around 1:00AM and there was still a wait! it's a small restaurant, so if you have a big group, chances are, you all might not be able to sit together.   

but the ramen in this place really is yummie! you really can't go wrong with any of their ramen! i shared the house ramen with the girls i came with, but in the end i actually perfer the kimchi ramen my sister ordered. i also really like their spicy sashimi salad. the calamari was just okay.
author: Vivi L.

description:
Completely ordinary soy sauce ramen, dishwater miso ramen. reasonably good noodles, very nice people, good feeling place, convenient location.

I was quite surprised given the enthusiastic reviews, this is not very good ramen.  Had we not ordered the miso ramen I would have given the place three stars
author: George S.

description:
Katana-Ya, I've given you so many chances to redeem yourself, but your ramen just doesn't cut it.  I've tried your miso, your soy sauce, your light, your rich, and nothing has done it for me.  The miso is definitely better than the soy and the soy has a very odd aftertaste that reminds me of a mixture of the seafood section of a 99 Ranch Market and diapers.  The broth doesn't have the richness that I normally love in a bowl of ramen and tastes like the do-it-yourself ramen packages that I've purchased at Japanese markets.

Your service is attentive, and your non-ramen dishes are actually quite good.  I enjoy the spicy bbq pork bowl and tofu bowl, which are actually spicy.  Yum!  The tataki salad is delicious as well.  The kimchi fried rice is sweeter than a Korean would normally eat it, but it's still good.  The sushi is fine, not amazing but is above-average.  The place is super tiny, but I don't mind because it adds to your appeal.  I would never wait more than 20 minutes though.  And I don't think I'd ever get another bowl of ramen from you again.

Ramen - 1.5 stars (it's not good, but at least it's edible)
Non-ramen items - 3 stars
Service - 5 stars
Prices/portions - Not bad for the portions but not cheap. 3 stars
Overall - 3 stars

Sorry, Katana-Ya, but you're only average in my book.
author: Justine L.

description:
Visited my brother in San Francisco, got out of the airport at 1 in the morning (4 am to my body) and went straight here to eat what according to various sources one of the best ramens in the country.  My expectations were wearily high.  Lucky for my belly, the Katanaya ramen proved every bit as good as I could possibly expect!  

The loaded broth comes thick and murky, with rich concentrated savory flavor.  It's a very hearty style of ramen -- my favorite kind!  I read that many enthusiasts preferred the shoyu ramen here, but I did not try it.  Noodle texture is perfect.  This particular bowl gets a bit oily as it has the fried gyoza, fried chicken (karaage), as well as BBQ pork and buttered corn.  All had great flavor.  If I actually lived in San Francisco I'd probably go for the less orgiastic options for casual eating and switch between rich and light broths, but I only had a short time to stay so I wanted to try as many things as possible in a bowl.  The end result is mind bogglingly rich, probably injurious to some people.  Good thing I happen to enjoy extremely rich dishes.  It is definitely better than any ramen I've eaten in Atlanta.  I am envious also that this good stuff (plus curry rice and donburis, mmm) can be gotten at 2 in the morning.

I liked it so much I ate here again the night before flying back.  Next time, I will try some South Bay ramen places.
author: Kozmo C.

description:
I had been putting off coming to eat here for the right evening.  Needless to say there had been much anticipation, excitement, and yelp research done in the meantime.  I don't know if I had elevated my hopes way to high, hoping for the slurp of pure bliss broth and noodle that I had been reading about.  I really hate to say that I was genuinely disappointed with my vegetable ramen with miso broth (no specified richness), which I've had at pretty much every other ramen place I've been to that serves it.  It's, I think, about the 3rd priciest ramen, so I was thinking sweeeet, cook loads of veggies. Instead I got julienne zucchini and onions, and endless julienne carrots.  The sweet cooked carrots must have released way to much sweet into the broth, because the miso broth was just mehhhh and a little sweet.  No umami euphoria for me.  I was really sad to say that it wasn't my favorite.  The noodles were pretty tasty, but out of habit I compare every noodle to J-Town's Sapporo-Ya, and these didn't rock my little ramen socks.

The two empty stars I'm leaving blank for now because I want to give it another shot.  My boyfriend had the Katana-Ya Ramen with shoyu broth, and that broth was pretty flippin' tasty, definitely another dimension of yum.  So the stars I am giving are for HIS dish, and I will return to try the soy, shoyu with different richness and different topping in the ramen. I know there is potential... ?  Oh, good noodle:broth ratio too. The service was all right, wait was not terrible for a Thursday 8pm. I also love the no-shame-"MSG added" blurb on the menu, awesome, no fronting here.

So I had decided already when I was there that I'm going back, I have to, I really want to like this place, I'll mess around with the richness, lightness, broth flavors, toppings, etc.  But if after the 2nd or 3rd time I'm still not impressed, the next review won't be as hopeful.  I really want to experience what these ~1700 people are raving about.  Idk, personally I like my ramen in very traditional settings where I know, see, and can feel the freshness in the noodle and the broth.  Please make me happy next Katana-Ya, I know you can do it.
author: Rachelle F.

description:
The tonkatsu don is okay, a tad dry and I could've sworn that was Heinz mustard they used. But what made up for that was the salt ramen (rich) which was really delicious. A paltry one slice of pork, but that tasted pretty good too. Very cramped in here, best if you're a group of two (you'll probably get seated faster). Usually a long-ish wait.

If the ramen wasn't anything spectacular, it would've been a three-star joint.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I like the cha shu ramen extra spicy and albacore tataki.  I wish they would cook the noodles just a little less.  Friendly service and tasty food, one of my favorite ramen places in the Bay Area.
author: TopCat W.

description: Ventured out to San Francisco to Katana-Ya for ramen after having yet another craving of a piping hot bowl of ramen.  It's a easy to miss hole in a wall location with cramped seating.  I ordered the kimchee ramen with soy broth.  The broth was missing a kick to it and the noodles, missing that nice elastic and fresh texture to it.  It was okay, no complaints, it just wasn't a clear katana cut experience on whether I'll go back or not.  I would still venture out to seek another ramen joint that will have a punch to their broth and keeps me drooling for more.  After watching the movie "Ramen Girl", I'm hoping I'll find the ramen store that makes ramen with spirit like they did in the movie; in the meantime, a nice instant ramen bowl of Myojo ramen will do just fine.
author: W. L.

description: The miso ramen's pretty good, but not the best.  I don't think it's worth my 45 mins wait.  I'll come back if I don't have to wait.  Ramen House Ryowa in Mountain View is still my Queen of Ramen in North Cal.
author: Vincent C.

description: Why is it that GREAT food comes from most if not all small, hole in the wall joints? WHY?! My boyfriend & I were walking around the city of Frisco, when we noticed that there's a line of people lining up right outside of this hella small restaurant. Curious, we yelped this place up, and of course not to our surprise 4 stars with 800+ reviews. So, we decided to give it a try. Yelp never fails us once. This place is hella BOMB. We ordered two bowls of Ramen and two rolls of sushi. We were very satisfied.
author: Thao A.

description:
i eat here at least once a week.  the ramen is the best i've had in SF proper.  real ramen noodles, not those crap "fancy" "gourmet" noodles that look like somen noodles and turn to mush in piping hot broth.  [hapa ramen, i'm looking at you.]

their home-made gyoza is also delicious and their beef curry does the job, but i can't comment on most of the other dishes b/c this is where i go to get my ramen fix!

for what it's worth, i lived in small-town japan for a year and spent a lot of time in ramen shops with japanese coworkers slurping noodles.  good noodles, slightly al dente, chewy and a little dense, are key.  katana-ya does it right.
author: Dao H.

description:
katana-ya is a tiny hole in the wall japanese restaurant with delish food. the prices were decent minus the hand roll (udon+uni bowl: $16, ramen: $11, hand roll: $9.50). i'd definitely go back for the ramen. 

The ramen broth was clean but hardy (it didnt have the oily grease from the meat floating on top unlike other places). Whats cool is that you can ask them for lighter or richer broth depending on what you like. 



#5 of the 2010 Big Eat SF: check!
author: Joanne C.

description: The bathroom was the most pleasant surprise of the meal. Giveaway: There's a painted owl! Everything else was just okay. I enjoyed my meal but didn't find anything above average. The ramen was alright and my miso broth was alright. The best thing is that they give you a lot. Ramen will always leave me with a burned tongued and a satisfyingly bloated stomach. Come for lunch but watch out for the packed house. Don't forget to sign the waiting list.
author: Michael H.

description: ehhhh for the price, this place was not as good as I'd thought. Everyone keeps on talking about katana ya but between the wait and the mediocre broth, id stick to south bay's ramen...
author: simon c.

description:
Since Katana-Ya is known for its ramen, I went with just that. I got the fried chicken ramen in miso broth. It's an extra $1.40 to make it spicy. FUUUck...what is this extra cost bullshit? Jk, it was worth it. You also have the choice to make your broth rich, which the server said meant "more oily." Of course I made mine rich. Gimme them calories. More rich, more flavorful. I initially was skeptical about the fried chicken because I knew it was going to get soggy in the soup. The 3 chunks of chicken (dark meat) I got in the soup turned out tasty. I love the yellow egg noodles that are perfect in texture with its right bite of chewiness. 

Pho is good and ramen is a great alternative-- flavorful, hearty meal in a bowl. I will definitely come back because there are so many combinations to try.  You can try the different types of ramen (pork, chicken karaage, etc.) in various flavored broths and either hot or cold, spicy or not, and rich or light. The appetizers, rolls, and other bowls on the menu look amazing as well.
author: Regina L.

description: We just came in 3 minutes before it opened and about 5-10 minutes later, the place was jam packed with people waiting outside for seats! I had the chashu(bbq pork) with miso base ramen. It was so good! The ramen was cooked to a good texture and went well with the miso soup base. Only problem is the parking...the meters were broken and they charged $3-4 an hour. We paid for 50 minutes of parking and when we came back after 40 minutes there was still 35 minutes left!
author: Karina C.

description:
like most good places, be prepared to wait.  we came here on a sunday night at 10pm and we still had to wait an hour.  it's a very, very tiny place and we had a party of 8 so we waited extra long.  there's a sign up sheet in front and they call out your name when it comes up on the list.

the BEST ramen in the city, imo.  i got the friend chicken ramen which was a huge bowl of ramen with boneless friend chicken pieces in it.  i chose the Miso broth (the other two you could choose from are soy and salty) and it was soooooooooooo good!!  i wish i would've got mine extra spicy like my cousins did cause it looked even better than mine in that bright red broth.
author: Ray R.

description:
This place in City it totally over-rated.......
We went there yesterday around 5.30pm to avoid the crowd. Of course, as usual, there was still a 30 mins wait.
We then ordered the ramen and rice combo - $18 to get a ramen with Uni over rice. Since every one recommended the "everything ramen", so, we upgraded the order (Additional $4 - total $22) to give it a try.

Taste: 3 stars on ramen & 1.5 stars on Uni over rice:

The "everything ramen" broth was okay (we got rich) and the ramen was just okay as well. (I had better in another place)
The Uni over rice. First, they only gave ONE piece of the Uni and with some fish roe. The Uni was absolutely NOT fresh!!! Then the rice was "hard" and "dry"...(you can tell they were serving old rice). Only thing good is the fish roe. Not much special. Therefore, onlyt 1.5 stars. 

Price: 2.5 stars
with total $22, that means the Uni over rice is $10 and ramen is $12 (all I can say is I had much better Uni rice and ramen and better price at other places)

I don't think I will go back again and definitely not worth for the wait!!
author: Phe M.

description: Best ramen I've had. Perfectly seasoned broth with ramen noodles just the way I like them. Curly. I don't like the straight noodles. That's not ramen to me. That's too Chinese, chow-mein style.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Shame on me for not trying the famous ramen at a ramen restaurant. For some weird reason I was craving rice so I went for a sukiyaki bowl. It was ehhh...I've had better for sure but that makes sense b/c uhh...Katana-Ya is for RAMEN not sukiyaki. What the hell was I thinking...

Anyway! L.C. ordered a bowl of vegi ramen and it looked fantastic. The bowl was huge first of all...plenty of noodles and broth. The whole restaurant smelled delicious. We also ordered a tuna appetizer which was pretty good..generous chunks of tuna sushi...would could complain? (Okay, chunks may not be the most appetizing word but trust me...it was good).

Yes, you'll probably have to wait in line since seating is scarce. 
Yes, you should definitely get the ramen if it's your first visit. 
Yes, service is quick b/c they want to turn over the tables as much as possible.
Yes, I'll be back...and
Yes, I'll be getting the ramen!
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: We are regulars at this restaurant.  There is usually a line, but it can move pretty fast.  It's pretty crowded inside, but the yummy-licious food makes up for it.  They have great ramen choices and sushi choices!  My two year old daughter also loves it!
author: Jen J.

description:
since i'm a ramen but more so ramuyn aficionado, i haz been tasting ramen since the age of born, i found this place to be authentic but on the smaller bowl side. does anyone agree with me? im used to big bowls of heaping hot broth. i don't care if its the same amount, i live for the presentation.

i give it 3.5 but rounding it up because of good times and open LATE!

suggestion:
when trying a new ramen place always get their basic shoyu ramen then deviate once you like the first bowl like the other crazy, i don't really care for, shit.

i'll go again! but not for the rice bowls-- this place is strictly for the noodles.
author: curi k.

description: We came here Saturday for lunch. I ordered the Katana- Ya miso broth spicy Ramen. Boyfriend order the Mabo or was is Mapo Tofu soy broth Ramen. Both broths were very flavorful & delicious. Mine was not spicy at all so I had to add more red pepper flaked to it. My boyfriend's dish had a good amount of spice in it didn't have to add anything. Good amount of chewiness to the ramen. Overall very good ramen. Very busy little quaint restaurant with long lines.
author: Cammie T.

description:
food:4/5
service:5/5
atmosphere 5/5
Would come here again. 

Katana-ya is a great hole in the wall restaurant that serves various types of ramen. The place is very small, can only seat about 25 people max. I came early, about 5:30pm, and the place was almost all filled. I had the katana-ya ramen, which was very good. However, it was a bit on the salty side. I thought the balance between the fried chicken and the ramen noodles was great, even when the chicken was a little soggy. My ramen bowl had fresh ingredients and tasted great.

The service was good. My waitress was very friendly.
author: Cecile S.

description: I passed by this place so many times and kept telling myself I would try it.. so I finally did. In short: delicious ramen noodles but slightly overrated. I waited a good 20 minutes before being seated and didn't feel entirely satisfied when I left. It might have been better had I drank or dined here post drinking activities.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Not sure why people were negative on the ambiance.  Yes its a hole in the wall, but inside Nina Simone singing, dark but not too dark lighting, friendly girl seating you, delicious spicy tofu ramen transporting you away from the daily stress.

The wakame salad had a surprisingly sophisticated presentation with tobiko topping.  

Warning, ladies unless you are Fu from Samurai Champloo, split the ramen with a friend.  The portions are way too large for one person.
author: James Y.

description:
I went to this place on the recommendation of Yelpers while visiting San Fransisco and with a craving for good Japanese noodles.

Compared to many of the Japanese restaurants I have visited in the DC area (and I know it's probably not a fair comparison), Katana Ya was pretty first rate in the Ramen department. I had the Shoyu Raman with Tofu and Kimchi in it, and the broth was flavorful and just enough saltiness to be comforting without being overly salty (a common problem I have found). As others have noted, you can order the broth rich or light. I ordered rich, and I expect this means it contains a significant amount of pork fat stock or pork bone stock to give it a bit of an oily, hearty meaty flavor. I am more used to the lighter stock and would probably order that in the future, but I wanted to try something else, and it was still very good, but probably heavier than I would want on a regular basis.  

I had two pieces of nigiri sushi, which was pretty good. The rice seemed a bit dried out, but the white tail was fresh and tasty.
author: Marc R.

description:
The good:
(1) Ramen is good, but SANTA is still KING
(2) No long lines.
(3) Price of ramen is decent

The bad:
(1)  No place to hang your coat.
(2)  Small spot

The Ugly:
(1)  Ordering your RICH ramen and seeing all that oil......
author: ronzilla x.

description:
Kinda too tired to go out and get food, but intrigued by the Yelp reviews and damn hungry, I ventured out to Katana. Love this little family-owned divy spot right in the middle of commerical business neighborhood. anyway, i did as recommended - I ordered the ramen - tofu (not spicy) with light soy broth. 

the bowl was giant!! seriously,  it was like some sort of spa treatment -  the steam from the soup opened my pores and my sinuses as I was slurpped with chopsticks and spoon.

in all honesty, I guess I'm not too much of a ramen fan, cuz i thought it was ok. very filling, tons of chewy noodles and nicely soft squares of tofu in a basic fishy salty soy broth. that's it. with a bit of seaweed. simple basic stomach filling food. $12 (with small beer) later and done.

def go if you are in union square and just need to be in a place that is not 'branded'.
author: Sheviche R.

description:
The shio ramen left much to be desired, and to my surprise, it was spicy tofu ramen that saved the day.  The spicy, yet mild, miso broth was creamy, savory and good to the last drop. I never thought I'd see the day when I would enjoy tofu more than pork, but for now, I can't fathom having my ramen any other way.

The agedashi tofu - deep-fried, pillows of silken tofu floating in dashi broth - was also very delicious.
author: Vivien P.

description:
Another regret in life: never cared to eat at the old Katana-ya while it was conveniently located on Judah and 6th.  Now we have to travel all the way to downtown, and endure a long long wait for a bowl of ramen noodles on a cold Friday night.  

It was pretty darn good!  (now filled with even more regret)

I had the spicy tofu ramen in light miso broth like some of the yelp reviews suggested.   Spicy tofu was excellent and noodles were chewy and yummy.  But next time I would get the soy broth, because it's less salty.  The Combo seems to be a good value.  My friend got unagi don AND a large bowl of ramen for, I believe, less than 10 bucks.  He wasn't too impressed with the unagi, but I mean, this is a noodle shop, so I wouldn't even bother ordering what's not noodles.  

Extra points for opening late and fast service.  I can just imagine how good a bowl of ramen would taste after a long night out.
author: Candice B.

description:
This place is AWESOME.
The sushi is absolutely excellent, but what I like the most there is the donburi/noodle combos. They are cheap, and plentiful. My favorite is the soba noodles, but I have had the Udon, and the ramen, and everything is good. They give you an immense amount, and alongside you have a choice of a mini donburi bowl.
It's just such great quality for the price, really comparable with much higher end Japanese places. It's small, but you have plenty of elbow room..
I would have given it all five stars except that the wait is sometimes ridiculous, and there are a couple waitresses that are pretty much out of it all the time.
author: Caro T.

description:
I love ramen, especially on such a cold night as tonight. It warms my belly, radiates out to my phalanges, and clears the sinuses... leaving me with a barrier to the bitter chills that winter brings (kinda like a beer blanket, but without the hangover). 

Having finding from fellow yelpers calling this place the best ramen in SF (and it being so conveniently close to union square), I just had to give it a try. I was there before my friend, and the hostess kindly showed me to a seat at the bar quickly. The space is small, but cozy. It has a nice ambiance (if you try to ignore the inevitable tacky Christmas lights). My friend arrived, and we chose our grub: I got the ramen with light soy broth and chicken karaage; he got the combo of 4 pieces of nigiri and ramen with salt broth (it comes with pork slices). 

I can't begin to tell you the love I have for Asian noodle soup, no matter what country it comes from. I am an equal opportunity nood-slurper. The keys to great noodle soup are the basics: the noodles and the soup. I like my noodles perfectly cooked, and for ramen, it has to have some chewiness to it. These ramen were cooked just right, not too soggy or too undercooked. The broth has to have full flavor, which either takes MSG (tsk tsk) or time and effort. The broth was a bit salty for my taste, but it was full flavored. If you just ate the noodles, it was perfect, with just the right amount of flavor riding along with the noodles. The broth must also be hot enough (temperature-wise). I personally like my food screaming hot, and this was tongue-burninatingly hot.... just the way I like it. 

The ingredients themselves were decent. I got 3 pieces of fried chicken, which were good. There were a few pieces of seaweed and a pickled daikon floating around. The ramen didn't need a lot of ingredients, as the soup flavor married with the noodles took the main stage. 

It wasn't as mind-blowing as the $6 bowl of ramen I had in Japan, but that's the real thing... and a long flight + hundreds of dollars away. You don't have to stumble too far to get to a good, comforting bowl of warm noodle soup. Katana-Ya will definitely be a stop for me whenever I'm wandering the Union Square area.
author: Joy C.

description:
My boyfriend and I are on the hunt for the best ramen in the bay area. 
We've been to a lot of ramen places, even a couple in SoCal. 
So far our favorite is Halu Ramen in San Jose. But............
Recently, we went to Katana-Ya with our friend. 
I must say, Halu has met its match. 
I ordered the rich Shoyu ramen, with BBQ pork (cha-su). 
The noodles were just the right amount of chewy.  The broth was tasty and had a light and crispness to it; not so heavy. 
My boyfriend and his friend ordered Rich Miso ramen with BBQ pork. 

I like that this place also has sushi and other Japanese entrees and appetizers. 

The service is ok. They serve Pepsi products. ( I like coke) So I ordered an ice tea instead. 

The wait to be seated was long, about 30-45 min.
It was busy. I also liked the atmosphere; neon lights at the bar, and lowlit. I would so come here again
author: Joanne C.

description:
I love Katana-Ya! This place has the best ramen, good sushi, and it is CHEAP! 

The atmosphere is crowded, uncomfortable at times, and leaves a lot to be desired, but the food makes up for it. Plus, it is usually filled with Japanese people, so you know the food is up to par.

Go here, trust me!
author: Jamie C.

description:
Excellent ramen place.

RAMEN:
Got regular ramen with salt broth.  Was definitely in the upper echelon of ramen places.  Had:
- chewy yet well-cooked noodles... these are the classic, machine-made, medium-thick noodles that are a little wavy
- well-marinated, tasty pork
- flavorful broth that wasn't overly greasy or oily

Don't know that it's worth a trip to the city if you're not a SFer, but this place is definitely one of my new favorites.

EXTRAS:
- In 100 degree weather, the icy desserts really hit the spot.  Is just shaved ice with some combination of green tea ice cream, condensed milk, and red beans.
- Very large water cups with plentiful refills.
- For a ramen place, everything was very affordable.  About $10 for ramen, $6 for dessert.

EWW:
- One friend ordered chicken donburi.  Told him not to order it at a ramen place but he said it was too hot for ramen.  It looked really good but the chicken came entirely raw.  After he returned it and they brought it back, it looked like they had just microwaved it.  Also, don't get the small donburi as an entree expecting to save a buck.  It comes in a tiny rice bowl and is definitely intended as a side.
- These dudes with motorcycles outside were showing off how loud they could rev their motors.  So, every couple minutes we'd catch a wiff of motorcycle fumes.  Yay.
- The place is small is don't come in a large group on a busy night.

Oh well, get the ramen and come in a small group on a non-busy night and you'll be very satisfied.
author: Wayne K.

description:
This place was an OK experience, but nothing spectacular.  I guess my expectations were too high, based on the other Yelp-ers' reviews.

Food - the ramen is definitely too oily.  The texture of the noodles was decent, but the oiliness of the noodles and the soup base just detracts from the whole experience.  plus, the portion size of the ramen was pretty small, especially for a $9 bowl.  i could've easily eaten another bowl.  

Atmosphere -- good, friendly, nice setup
author: Robyn F.

description:
Wow. And I don't even like ramen. 
All I know, is that I am a sushi/ramen/japanese food snob....but if I see japanese speaking patrons in the restaurant ....its more than a good sign.
author: Cin H.

description:
I wasn't expecting anything special when I walked into this place for lunch.
Their ramen turned out to be pretty good.  Personally I like Halu, Kahoo or Santa better, but I guess this is one of the few places in downtown SF that serve decent Japanese ramen.
author: Durif M.

description:
Seeing the amount of stars for this place I have to admit, I was getting pretty excited. I love Ramen, in fact I go to san jose for some really good authentic stuff once in a while, but this place may be a good alternative now. 

I ordered the more expensive item, hey- I'm all about trying the best they've got if people are recommending this place. It was the Katan-Ya Ramen btw, its like 12 bucks but they definitely pack it with a bunch of stuff - fried chicken, potstickers, pork, corn, plus the ramen and soup of course. I recommend this place, not for big groups since this place is so tiny but for a couple its great. Make sure to sign your name on the clipboard so you can cut ahead of a all the new people going up to the front trying to get seats
author: Mike B.

description:
the quest for the best ramen in the bay area continues....

got there with a friend on a weekday evening and it was already so crowded! i can see why. there's not much space in the restaurant. after i wrote my name down, we stood by the building and waited. my name was called after .. less than10 min?? it was quick! 

shared a shoyu ramen, cilantro miso ramen, and spicy hamachi sushi. the ramen was good!  perfectly AL DENTE (thanks alli n. for grammar correction! this is what 6 years out of school does to me) and slightly fatty pork. There's no difference between the regular and cilantro ramen. $1 for an added herb??

i don't usually get the miso broth because it's usually really salty at other places, but this one was good! it was creamy deliciousness.

the spicy hamachi was ... what's the best word to describe... MEH... BLEH...  bland. probably because our taste buds were satisfyingly swimming in broth that it completely rejected the sushi. 

they have a bunch of other random things on their menu too.. including shaved ice!

YAY i found another good place to eat around union square (this and 'out the door' in the westfield mall basement) that isn't touristy, a chain or in a shotty area! i feel pretty safe walking around here
author: Marian C.

description:
I've gotta say; I was completely underwhelmed.  Did I order the wrong thing?  Should that even be possible at a place that averages four stars with almost 900 reviews?  On the upside we walked right in and got a table with no waiting; that was lucky as we watched the crowd grow outside (*note to crowd; I know you want to come in and you're eager and all, but it helps if you actually STEP ASIDE and let me out when I'm trying to leave.  It's really in your best interest, promise.)
The sushi was okay, but I was too distracted by all the little flies flying around and attempting to get into my mouth every time I opened it to shove a massive roll into it.  Fecking things.  We had the toro sashimi, hamachi roll and lava roll (which was way too huge for one bite - can't sushi come in sizes?  with smaller bites for ladyfolk and children?).
The noodles were disappointing.  I got the bbq pork with soy based broth and it was meh.  There was a weird aftertaste.  Give me Suzu any day, or at least post the "secret" delicious noodle bowl that I should be ordering to get the "omg Katana-Ya is the best noodle place in SF" experience.  I didn't drink all of my broth, but the noodles were fine and I liked all of the green onions in the broth; they added great flavor.
I'm glad that the noodle place I like better is so much closer to my house, that works out well for me.  You guys can keep Katana-Ya.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Went home sick today. Called the hubby on my way to the health food store to tell him i was on my way to pick up some tea, fruit and soup, did he want anything. He responds with, want me to get you something off 'the list'? (the 7x7 list that is our current obsession). No I say, I'm really not feeling well. Isn't there a good soup spot on the list? Hum.. I think about it and look it up and figure some nice hot ramen might just hit the spot before I head to bed. So we gets me a spicy tofu regular ramen (no meat was my request) and the spicy was the perfect amount of spice to help clear up the sinus' without giving me a full on runny nose. The noodles were perfectly soft without being mushy. And it was a pretty big serving. Really yummy, I'm sure I'll be back for more. But for now it hit the spot on my sad sick day and now it's off to bed.
author: Audrey V.

description: This was the greasiest sh*t I have ever eaten. Plus there was a black hair in my ramen...wtf?
author: Nicole R.

description: Came here again late last night bc its the only ramen place around that I know of that opens late. I got the green onion ramen this time. It was VERY good in the beginning.. I was like.. "i think I love katanaya now" but then somehow.....again... it just got saltier!!! how the hell does that keep happening? every single time!!! hella sodium.
author: A L.

description:
Someone in my office was cooking Top Ramen this week and it smelled so good that I instantly started craving ramen so I went in search of the best ramen place by my office.    After reviewing Yelp, it was clear that Katana-ya was the place to go for ramen so there I went. 

I've only had authentic ramen a handful of times so I was a little overwhelmed at first by the choices.  Therefore, I decided to stick to basics and ordered the BBQ pork ramen with soy sauce.   

Let me just say the 6 block walk back to my office was torture. I could smell the broth through the bag the entire way and let me say it was worth the walk.  I am officially a ramen convert and have been craving it ever since.   

My only issue was that there wasn't too much pork in the soup, but the noodles and broth were enough to carry the dish.
author: A T.

description:
If ramen is your poison, then this is your place. For newcomers, try the Katana-Ya ramen, it has a bit of everything. The Extra Spicy ramen is not for the faint-hearted. Only try it if you have the stomach for spicy food (or if you are Asian).

 This place is really small so expect a line during popular hours. Come in smaller group to avoid waiting long.
author: Ronnie L.

description: One of my favorite ramen places in San Francisco.  If Santa Ramen is too far, Katana-Ya or Suzu are good alternatives.  Beware the lines, however!
author: Corey C.

description: It's funny that for the past two years I've come to downtown every weekend wander around and always don't know where to have my lunch or dinner. I guess I did not go far enough. The furthest I've gone was Naan 'n' Curry, until recently I found this place. Check it out intermediately and fell in love instantly :))))))))) Fried Chicken ramen is the best!  Love the rame love the broth and LOVE the chicken~~ Can't wait for next visit.
author: Marlis T.

description:
Visiting from out of state, used Yelp to search for a good local place to eat, a little off the beaten path. SUCCESS! 

Location- very close to our hotel in Union Square. It was like a 10 min walk for us. Right across from a huge theater. so look for that. The Front is very narrow, we almost missed it. 

Service/atmosphere- just go in the door and sign your name on the wait list, the go wait outside. They will come for you. We waited about 15 mins around midnight Friday night. This place is very small... maybe 35-40 people at a time. The service was adequate, but not superb. Get your order in, get food, get out. Only took about 10 mins to get our food. 

Food- 
App- salmon skin salad
Entree 1- Regular ramen, miso broth (you choose between soy sauce, miso and salt broth). Came with scallions, seaweed, bamboo shoots and pork. 
Entree 2- Katanaya Ramen, miso broth.  Came with fried chicken, potstickers, bbq pork, boiled egg, corn, scallions, seaweed, and bamboo shoots.  

Salmon skin salad was simple but tasty, I would get it again. 

The  regular ramen was AMAZING. The broth was rich, but I needed to add a lot of chili powder. If you like spicy, pay the extra for the spicy version. The noodles were chewy... in the good way. The pork slices were AWESOME. I was trying to spoon the ramen at first but then I just gave up and used my chopsticks for the noodles. Dont be afraid to slurp.


The Katanaya Ramen was good, especially for someone who doesn't normally eat Japanese.  The extra bit of meat helped to familiarize it so it wasn't too big of a shock at trying something a little different.  The portions are huge and I definitely had a hard time finishing.  For the price you get HUGE portions.  The fried chicken was very tasty and the potstickers were perfectly prepared .  The seaweed texture left a bit to be desired, but like I said I don't eat Ramen often.    
  
If I come back to the bay area, I am definitely going here again.
author: Tara G.

description:
This place is great for noodle soups!  It is a bit pricey but it's totally worth it.  The sushi is really REALLY good.  It's fresh and tasty.  

There's always a wait time though which kinda sucks but if you want some good ramen, it's worth the wait!

Small place so it does get a bit busy in there, but it's one of those small places that everyone loves to go to.  Not good for big groups!

Definately go here for ramen soup!
author: Erika C.

description:
easily the best ramen in the bay area. it's the typical americanized selection, but the quality is amazing. good cheap sushi too.

it's incredibly crowded most of the time, unfortunately. they need a bigger space.
author: Eric G.

description: I had the miso "rich" broth extra spicy ramen and the spicy tuna roll combo for $14.  The sushi is so-so but the ramen is the best I've had to date.
author: Mark K.

description:
It's a small place, so get there early or expect to wait!

I enjoyed the green onion ramen I ordered because the broth was flavorful but not heavy. My companion thought his spicy broth wasn't as good as my non-spicy broth. He also likes heavier broth, which means he prefers Santa Ramen in San Mateo.

I don't often see salmon skin rolls on the menu, and had to try it out. It was crisp and yummy. My companion never tried it before and seemed to enjoy it as well. I wasn't impressed by the cold tofu appetizer we ordered. It didn't have much flavor to it.

I'll definitely come back to try more of what's on the menu!
author: Ellen S.

description: Waited for a day to check out this 4 star rated ramen place with so many reviews. Been on a conquest to find great ramen! Very small hole in the wall. Place only has soy sause, miso, salt base soups. Chose katana ya ramen, miso, rich, no MSG, fried chicken n pot stickers on da side.  Noodles were fine, soup was bland, bowl prep was like a bowl of pho(all thrown in).  Fried chicken n pot sticker in a ramen noodle soup?  Don't think it mixes well. Pork was ok. Egg was served in two pieces hard boiled, not the usual liquidy in the inside. Best prep so far for me has to be ramen dojo in San Mateo(worth the drive if u live in sf) Orenchi (in sj)my best in the area so far as they get a extra point for being closer.   Definately the 4 star rating is not for their ramen as they serve sushi and alcohol.  One star for good noodles n for friendly service. Wouldn't come back.  Anyone looking for great ramen should look elsewhere unless ur comin out if a club and craving noodles.   Should've believed the other reviews but had to try it for myself. :( another place for "been there, ate that, never again!"
author: Winston C.

description: Ok, first time here. Got in around 6pm for dinner after a quick 10ish minute wait. Cozy place with a japanesey atmosphere. Service was good and we were pleased. We ordered the shiromaguro (seared albacore tuna) tatake which was, passable. It was a bit firmer than what I'm use too. I'd pass on it for the next go round. This place isn't really known for their sushi selection. The ramen ordered (katana-ya) was their specialty item which had some karaage, fried gyoza, salty bamboo shoots, salty seaweed slivers, and some corn nubbies. All in all, it was pretty good. Not the best I had and definitely not the worst. The broth was pretty basic but the ramen noodles were nice ( served al dente). It was not as rich and creamy as I like, but I did order their "regular density" style. I did the salt broth and opted for the "regular" density. Next time, I think I'll try salt with the rich density option. Overall, it was decent ramen but not something I would drive to the city for.
author: Adrian P.

description:
Party of 2.

Went there last night and had the soy broth.  Delish.  Also had the spicy tofu ramen and was amazed at the balance of heat since some places tend to try to burn your tongue and make you sweat.  I would say it was better than Suzu's in J-Town.  

I had sushi for the first time, very ricy, but definitely had originality, but not the best that I have had.  It wasn't crowded tonight, so definitely an additional plus.
author: Michael L.

description:
Love the hole-in-the-wall feel to the place. 

I had the regular miso ramen and kimchee fried rice during lunch--all for $11. Next time though, I'd just do the ramen (under $8). The portion was generous and I was stuffed by the time I got to my rice. Plus, the rice wasn't spectacular. The ramen was though!

I'd go back and take a friend, especially on those cold winter days coming up when you need to warm up with some piping hot soup!
author: Ava C.

description: I have not found a good ramen place yet and this place was actually.... good. Tiny place and gets REALLY busy during peak times so make sure you get here before the rush. I had the fried chicken ramen in miso soup. The chicken was really good! The fried part of the chicken in the broth gives it a good texture. I suggest getting the mild spice because it was kind of bland and I tried my friend's mild broth and it wasn't too spicy.
author: Lisa T.

description: I love this place!  When I eat here I feel like my stomach becomes a bottomless pit and I'd like to order 5 bowls of ramen.  My favorite Ramen?  Right now I'm on a Spicy Vegetable Miso Ramen.  The Green Onion Ramen is fabulous as well!
author: Kattya B.

description: Gone here a few times for late night ramen.  I would say that this place is only worth going to when nothing else is open.  The broth lacks flavor and is spiked with MSG.
author: T Y.

description: Katana-ya is where I discovered that ramen can be something far greater than the little salty noodle bricks that I used to prepare with hot tap water and eat in college.  The majority of my "real" ramen experiences have taken place here and they've always been good ones.  I especially love the spicy miso broth - I think they put an addictive chemical in it that makes you crave it fortnightly (at least).
author: Melissa O.

description:
MSG added! for those of you who think of msg as taboo, do your research. It's not scientifically proven to be any worse for you than salt. Although some people who have allergies to it, will get headaches after eating. 

So, i went here a few times with my coworkers and we beat the crowd. I wish the bbq pork had more flavor in it to distinguish it from the flavors of the broth. Otherwise, it was pretty awesome. Noodles were perfect. Service was good. Just enough food to fill me up. not too much and not too little. Just right. I kept slurping the broth while waiting for my coworkers to finish.
author: Tawn W.

description:
We ordered extra spicy ramen and a beef rice bowl dish - I forget the name of it, and a super spicy fish roll. The spicy ramen was so-so, not the best. There were only two pieces of meat that came with it.

The beef and rice dish was good, I give it a 7.5/10. The spicy fish roll however - that was just very very bad. It was poorly cooked, some of the rice was burnt to the foil it was served in. It was also so spicy that I couldn't taste any of the fish. We had to send it back.

On the plus side, they were very accommodating, and receptive of our complaints. They did not charge us for the super spicy fish roll.
author: Josh C.

description: Waitress mixed up order of katana-ya ramen and shushed me when I was trying to explain the mix up. Ramen was delicious service was horrible. I have a feeling I won't be coming back.
author: N M.

description: A little whole in the wall place that offers good ramen in the middle of the union square!  wait is long but it's worth it.
author: Lian F.

description:
As we were strolling around downtown SF on 2-13-11 late at night, we saw this restaurant.  It was pretty crowded so I look at the menu and thought what a great place to try on 2-14 before we all head to the airport.  It didn't open until 11:30 am so we were the first customer.

I have to say it was the best Ramen/Udon/Soba place I have so far.  There were so many choices and the broth was very flavorful no matter what you try.  I had the Ramen, soy sauce, rich with Spicy BBQ Pork Don.  It was more than enough food.  I love every bite of it.  

Out of the 5 girls, everyone had something different, but looking at the empty bowls and plates; they must love it.... Service is great.
We were just relaxing there, but when it got busy and a line started, we got up and left. 

Will definitely come back again if I am in SF.
author: Lile C.

description:
Not what it used to be...

If Gary the sushi chef was still working there, I would have rated this place 5 stars. The quality of food went down immediately after he left. The portions became much smaller but the prices still remained the same.
They replaced Gary with one of the eastern european waitresses. Yeah she is cute but that is all...

I would only stick with the ramen at this point.
author: Evan W.

description: This place seems to be always busy.  Came in for a late lunch/early dinner at 4 pm and it was packed.  With good reason.  Was I just hungry?  Was I just cold and wanted some warm ramen?  Doesn't matter as the Katana-ya Ramen miso style with regular noodles was real tasty.
author: A C.

description: A trusted foodie friend ( TFF!) took me to this place just a couple months ago. In almost 4 years of living in SF, how in Zeus have I never seen nor heard of this joint? For one thing, it's super easy to miss. It's nestled in the loin-ish side of union square ( Union-Loin? Tender Square?!) with a totally unassuming front. You will recognize it by the crowd of skinny asian people gathered in front impatiently waiting to be seated. There's the rub, the place is tiny and you have to put your name on the list outside to get seated. Once you get in, order the chicken karage for apps and the kimchi ramen with salt broth. SHO GOOD! It's totally worth the puffy after-face you will have from all the sodium. TRUST.
author: Lummi B.

description: From the thousands of reviews on Yelp, I expected a lot better.  We arrived Sunday night around 10pm to a 15 minute wait.  The ramen was NOT worth the wait.  Broth was amateur compared to other places, and there was nothing impressive about the noodles or the toppings that justified either the price or the wait time.  Am not going back.
author: Han L.
