description: Katana-Ya is two blocks away from the ghetto motel I was staying at. We walked up to a line of people waiting to be seated. Looked inside and the place is tiny. In a fun hole in the wall kind of way. I ordered a pork ramen. Pork was super tender and broth had many different layers. My seat was sticky (?). Whatever, they were busy. Good prices too.
author: Chandra W.

description:
A place my friend and I have repeatedly come back for some warm delicious ramen. I had a Rich Soy Leek(onion) ramen with an order of Chicken kaarage while my friend got an order of Chicken kaarage Ramen(overkill w/ the chicken) and an order of gyoza and Calamari( I know were ballin'.) The soup was good, but I was hesitant whether or not to finish the soup b/c it was a little bit oily, but I guess it was suppose to be that way. Chicken Karaage, Calamari, and the gyoza were all very tasty and I was content at the end of my meal. The price was very good considering this restaurant was borderline TL and Downtown. Atmosphere was decent, but a little dark and I felt somewhat Brokeback b/c I was there with my friend and we sat at a candle lit table, but w/e its all about the food.

Food 4/5
Atmosphere 4/5
Price 4/5

A decent place for Ramen in SF. Id recommend this place. This place is esp. good on cold days  , such as  it was a week or two ago. 
and remember to say "GOCHI SO SAMA DESHUSHDE!" at the end.
author: Jimmy K.

description:
I started checking out Yelp as a last ditch effort to find a decent ramen place in SF, and you guys didn't disappoint! Katana-ya was consistently one of the highest rated ramen joints, and after making the trek out there tonight, I have to agree.  

I had the negi ramen in the light shoyu sauce, and my wife had the light miso.  Both broths were satisfying (i preferred the shoyu), and I liked the kick that the negi (spicy green onions) added.  We thought the ramen noodles were a bit harder than normal, but we grew to appreciate them.  Also, the california rolls and spider rolls were not particularly objectionable, which is all I can expect at a noodle house.  

Overall, it was not as good as Ryowa in Berkeley or Maruichi in Mountain View, but it's a prefectly acceptable alternative for those of us lucky enough to live in SF. 

Oh, I thought it was cool that they were playing a Cocteau Twins CD-- don't hear that at Ryowa! In honor of this place, I'm renaming my dog Montana-Ya.
author: Kelvin L.

description:
Ramen noodle houses are only things you see on the Travel Channel and dying to hope "hey, i wish they had that here" knowing that we probably don't. Then came along Katana-ya, some small hole in the wall, i mean literally, someone put tables and a sushi bar between 2 buildings... Walking into Katana-ya for the first time, i knew why i was here... Ramen. Im not talking ramen in a bag with a pouch of soup base, I'm talking stuff i see on the travel channel.

I ordered the Miso ramen with roast pork. The miso broth was a bit salty, but salty in a good way (the soda was on free refills kinda good way) The roast pork was to die for, it complemented the broth like marriage between 2 high school sweethearts (sorry for my being cheesy, I'm new at this). The noodles were chewy and gummy, it didn't have the over cooked rice feeling texture of instant ramen. I only wish they had hard boiled eggs and nori thrown into the soup like on the travel channel, but its still cool. The table service was great, and the mirrors on the wall made the place feel like was it huge.  No claustrophobic feeling for a hole in the wall.  The candle on the table was cute too.

The pricing was moderate, 10 bucks is how much I've spent each time I've been here, and the combo ideas are great, the kim chee fried rice was awesome, and it came with a spoon, I thought that was cute.

I've been  here 4 times now, and I'm an instant fan. I just wished this place had a parking lot nearby, being in the middle of downtown made parking a bit tough, but who cares, its worth the walk from any downtown parking garage.
author: Jeffrey B.

description:
Service: Good
Time Served: Very Good
Amount of People: Crowded
Size of Resturant: Small
Flavorful: Very Good Ramen Soup

Items:
Chicken Ramen
author: David C.

description:
The place was small, kinda smashed between a bar and another King of Thai Noodle (is "tiny" like the stock size for a noodle place or something?). Well, in any event, I know way too much about the folks seated around me now....shh..they're lookin at me.

Anywho, as an appetizer I ordered the salmon which was served with a small salad. This had a nice light taste and was not overwhelming.  

I also ordered the regular Pork Ramen with rich miso soup. Very quickly I thought that the bowl should've been bigger but instead the amount was just right. The star of the show is the noodles.The soup has good flavor but the noodles up the taste factor.

We were seated right away and service was prompt and kinda attractive. Parking wise, go here before 1:00am or battle the Mason Street party people. 

Another yelp find.
author: Brian A.

description:
I was very disappointed by this place.  While nothing was particularly bad, nothing was good either.  There is much better ramen out there in this world, I just haven't found it in San Francisco yet.

Unless you're stranded on Geary and Mason, I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Karla R.

description:
In the past year, 2009-2010, this place has tanked.  The ramen, sushi, service, everything has sadly plummeted....

Read below for my 4 star rated review during the glory days pre-2009...

=================================================


the quest for the best ramen in the bay area continues.

upon the recommendation of a friend i checked out this ramen joint on a raining evening this dec 2007.

to my utter amazement i quickly found that all elusive downtown parking space close to the actual eating objective, so lady luck was already smiling on me this eve.

we plunked ourselves down and ordered up a cold beer, 2 bowls of ramen with the chasu pork and clinked our glasses.

mmm...not bad, in fact better than any place we've tried in j-town.  friendly service, cramped seating, and pretty darn good ramen for SF.  the chicken karage side plate was very good too.  there was actually chicken inside the nice crispy crust, unlike genki's version.

this is my first choice now in SF for ramen, and they're open late; bonus points there.  

jangara is still king, however, but that's a $800 rd trip ticket.

for the more dedicated local ramen pilgrimage, santa ramen still reigns in the bay area.

*had to update this review as i have become a semi-regular to this joint.  i go now at least once a month.  i have learned the sushi here is a hidden gem. greg their sushi chef is a friendly guy crafting up very enticing morsels and we now always make it a point to supplement our ramen bowls with pre-noodle rawfishdish(es).  this place has grown on me as one of my fav late night eateries. :-P
author: Patrick M.

description:
I thought the food here was good- not great.
I think what rubbed me the wrong way was the fact that they charged me for kim chee. ....$3.00 for like 4 pieces!
REALLY?!!!
OMG. 
In So. Cal korean resturants whore that dish out like Linsey Lohan and well..nm.
Oh yeah and did I mention that the kept playing JUSTICE over, and over and over and over....
I got the Deep Fried Chicken in the Miso Ramen...wasn't very inspired by it. 
Maybe I should have gotten something else..
author: E C.

description:
Good noodle spot to cozy up to fellow Union Street tourist/shoppers and have a nice warm bowl with Sapporo or green tea.  The sushi is okay, certainly not Sushi Ran, but nice on the side.  Tuna salad as a free appetize rather disconcerted me.  It can get crowded on week-ends and late night due to its hole-in-the-wall size, but on weekdays it's no worries.  The noodles aren't as wellmade as say Suzu Ramen in J-town, or Santa Ramen in San Mateo, or in the Ebisu district in Tokyo,  but they certainly fill the belly with carbs, if that's your aim.  An interesting point that a friendly young woman  I met there yesterday evening noticed:  they were playing mexican music up in there.  Odd juxtaposition that actually added a surreal quality to the surreal decor.  
Kanpai !
author: Roland C.

description:
The first time I went to Katana-Ya, I ordered the Japanese curry. I wasn't impressed. It was small, and it didn't have enough meats and veggies. 

But, I went back a few more times and ordered the ramens. They were very good. The portions are large, and the noodles are chewy. My favorite is the kimchi ramen....YUM! I'll go back for the ramens.
author: Mina P.

description:
If you watch Anime you've probably seen episodes dedicated to Ramen (Naruto). I never quite understood what the big deal was, that is until I got my hands on a bowl! 

Since every Ramen House seems a little different I won't bother trying to compare, but I wil say that Katana-Ya knows what it's doing! The broth was like butter infused with amazing chicken flavors and the noodles were slightly chewy, perfect! 

It's also a TINY-LITTLE-ITSY-BITSY restaurant, so please don't show up with an army. Next stop, Japan!
author: Venatius P.

description:
I went here with my family of 4 at about 8:45 on a Monday night, and although there were about 6 parties ahead of us (alternately 2 or 4 people), we were seated within 20 minutes or so.  We ordered gyoza as an appetizer, and each ordered a ramen: all rich miso broths: one regular, one chicken, one deep-fried chicken, and one BBQ Pork (mine).

So basically, come here for the ramen, and it is amazing.  I'm not a ramen connoisseur, but I know good food, and this qualifies.  The gyoza, on the other hand, left a bit to be desired: I agree with one reviewer who stated that the vegetables are overpowering.  Avoid the gyoza.  But for the ramen, major yays.

We have to lose a star here for the quality of service.  We were seated, given menus, and about 5 minutes later, the waittress came back to take our orders.  All well and good.  She brings us our drinks and then comes back a bit later with the ramen.  All well and good, except that the gyoza didn't come out until we were about halfway through the ramen.  We got no refills of our tea the entire meal, and the second that the majority of us were finished (I'm a slow eater), the check was rushed over, the implication clear that we were not to linger any longer than necessary.

It's a little crowded (especially if you're a party of 4), but it's great ramen, so come here for that and look no further!
author: Alex B.

description:
YES! A big ol' bowl of noodley goodness on a cold evening that's right down the street from me?! Count me in!

This tiny little place is now one of my favorites, I think I'll make it a go to in my arsenal of awesome food when I'm showing off to people who come to visit (its small though...so maybe only when a couple friends are in town, I'm not gunna try and squeeze my whole family in this joint). Their miso pork ramen and curry don was enough to leave me craving it the next morning. The boy ordered the salt broth with chicken and the spicy tofu and green onion don bowl, also super tasty. We had demolished everything plus our beers by the time we left the table and i think we might have hurt ourselves, in the best way possible. :)

Service wasn't awesome, so I wouldn't go expecting it, but who cares! RAMEN IS WORTH IT!
author: Tara O.

description:
no complaints about the food there. The ramen was great! cooked exactly right, not too soft and not too hard. The price was also decent for the combos. Kimchee fired rice and the uni rice was greeeeeeeeeat! i love it! The sushi rolls were just ok. 

overall, my experience there was good.

-1 star for the service, or lack-thereof ( i was even charged 18% gratuity for - they automatically charges that with a party of 5+)

-1 star for the ambiance-this place could sit like 20 people or so comfortably. I have seen a party of 5 get squish into a table for 2. this is not a place for a party over 4.
author: Sofie D.

description:
I was up in the city shopping with my gf so she took me to this place. It was a real hole in a wall place and really small. I had the ramen with chicken karaage but asked the chicken to be on the side. I'm not a fan of soggy batter. The batter was light and crisp. The noodle was simple yet yummy. I'm getting HUNGRY just thinking about it!!! The broth was just right (not too salty for me) yet full of flavor. I went with the original broth but supposedly if you order the rich broth, they put in more pork fat. 

I was tempted to order their red bean shaved ice but I was sooooo full, my stomach couldn't handle it; neither could my gf. 

Their ramen is about 9-10 but if you get the combo, it can vary from 9-15. The combo comes with some donburi. Good thing I didn't order it cause I wouldn't be able to eat it and I hate wasting food. I rather order less than more. 

If I am ever there shopping at Union Square, I definitely would go again and try out other things on the menu.
author: Alice L.

description:
On a recent visit to the Bay, my husband was craving sushi, but wanted to stay near Union Square. Of course a friend who would be dining with us yelped a couple places and found that Katana-Ya had a pretty good rating and decent prices. 

We made the short trek to Nob Hill and opened the door to be greeted by a table. Dang, the place is tiny!! Luckily one of the waitresses shimmied over  to seat us at that same friendly table by the door. 

We ordered yellowtail, salmon, spicy tuna, and fatty toro sushi. Sushi was good, but not spectacular. We also had a couple drinks-nigori and plum wine-good stuff, but nothing distinctive.

Service was pretty good, the waitress checked on us a lot. The waitress even provided us an extra drink (on the house). Nice!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
In my several weeks in San Francisco, I have eaten Japanese ramen at least once a week.  It wasn't completely intentional; I was actually looking for sushi on most of the occasions, but I was surprised by how common ramen is on most Japanese menus, and I couldn't resist the temptation to tuck into a steaming bowl of noodle soup on a cold, foggy night (...and a crisp summer afternoon...and a warm, sunny evening...)

The dining scene in San Francisco is much more calm than New York.  While people do get excited about good food and new restaurants, I don't think there will ever be a ramen stir like Dave Chang caused with his Momofuku empire.  Service in San Francisco can be extremely relaxed, sincerely friendly, and sometimes the servers are even affectionate.  However, restaurants are usually small, dirty, and one is required to ask for a key to the washroom, which is often attached to an embarrassingly oversized doodad that I am embarrassed to carry across the dining room.  This bothered me tremendously.  I wanted formal service, clean facilities, and I didn't want to be seated next to boxes of hot sauce and paper towels.  

Such was the case with Katana-Ya.  Tiny, stale and crowded, I wanted to turn on my heels and go to St. Elsewhere. But snobbery is unacceptable in this town, so I selected the Spicy Tofu Ramen and tucked into a tiny table in the corner.  I expected a watery, vegetable broth and a few scallions, but instead was treated to an over-sized bowl of creamy soy broth with subtle spice, firm tofu and slurp-worthy noodles.  Of my many bowls of ramen since arriving, Katana-Ya makes the most satisfying and authentic version yet.
author: T. L.

description: Yum. I opted for the soba with tempura veggies, since that is what i was craving, but the ramen looked amazing. After living in Japan, it's hard to compare, but this is pretty close to the truth. Noodles are not made in-house but are good. I would have gone back for another meal if I'd had the time.
author: Jess C.

description: I want ramen right now. It was amazing. Granted I was inebriated the first time I went and so thankful there was not a line. All of a sudden there was a steaming bowl of delicious noodles sitting in front of me. The fried chicken ramen was beautiful! I was slightly confused because I had only one piece of chicken and a boatload of noodles, which I couldn't finish. So my ravenous friend ate his bowl of ramen and then ate the rest of mine. Easily. I found out the next day that my two companions each snuck a piece of chicken, which I obviously did not see. Makes sooo much sense now. I liked the miso soup a lot. Packed with flavor....now I'll be obsessed thinking about my next meal there. *Sigh*
author: Faye P.

description:
I've been here several times and initially only ordered the sushi, sashimi, and sake.  The sushi is very good, reasonably priced, and the place can stand on it's own as a sushi bar.
So while it was cold, windy and rainy in SF, I figured it was a good time to try the ramen.
I've gone through the shoyu, miso, tan tan phases and now find myself ordering shio ramen.  The taste of the shio is typically not overpowering and it's also not easy to find a ramen shop that makes a tasty shio broth because it'll either be too salty or too bland.  But I've found a great shio broth at Katana-Ya.  It could have been partly because it was so cold outside, but the shio ramen with vegetables was excellent.
The downside is the price.  $11 for a vegetable ramen.  A little pricey, but worth it.
Can't go wrong with this place ordering either the sushi or ramen.
author: Greg S.

description: This is hands down the best ramen I've ever had. The miso & soy broth are both good, its open late and for being in a tourist heavy location the prices are pretty reasonable. There is a wait at times since the location is tiny but the ramen more than makes up for the wait. Try the Katana- Ya Ramen which has a little bit of everything in it, I've left bars early just so I could make it before the 1am closing time.
author: Chong K.

description: Not sure where to really start. Maybe I should really put 1 star but am feeling generous right now?! It's actually a difficult review because it is forcing me to remember the horrid experience. I don't know what locals are thinking is good ramen, but it sure isn't this place. Not only was it ranked high on Yelp but also ZAGAT, TripAdvisor and even on ramen specific rankings! Are you kidding me?! This was perhaps one of the worst ramens I've ever eaten! It is insanity to stand outside waiting for a table (in the cold!) for a bowl of nasty. The noodles has a very strange taste and texture to them. The soup was bland. The portion of the ingredients was decent. Also, having a larger group, they threw us down the basement (which at first seemed like a good thing after all) but then they turned on their sound system and had dance music booming as if it were some underground rave party. Was this some kind of joke?! Who plays bass thumping music like that at a ramen shop? Food and ambiance already killed ALL of our experience here. It can't get worse right? Wrong! The service is lamentable. Our server had no clue what he was doing. Either he was new there or just an airhead. Maybe he was overwhelmed by the 4 tables he was serving downstairs in the basement? It is very irritating though (anytime but especially after already having had a bad dining experience) when the dining guest needs to wait 1) to receive the check and 2) to have to wait around to pay the check after having received it!!! Okay, enough said, I am starting to relive that torment of the experience.....it is actually worth only 1 star! And that's a generous star too! You'd have to be hammered drunk silly and out of your mind to go here and enjoy the ramen! If your sane, stay away. If not, give 'em a try and find out the way we did, we are insane!
author: Roland P.

description:
Katana Ya Ramen with Miso Broth. Simple as that.

Been to this hole in the wall restaurant twice- both times put my name on the sign in sheet, both times was seated without them taking a glance at that sign in sheet. Definitely be wary; sign in, but flag them down also!

The ramen is reasonably priced and filling but really nothing special unless you get one with the fried chicken (aka fried chicken ramen or katana ya ramen). I've never had fried chicken in my ramen before and though it certainly isn't traditional- it is GOOD. 
The butter corn ramen is also one of a kind. You can see the sliced stick of butter floating and melting into the broth with corn bits and while it may not sound appetizing, is actually pretty good.

Oh and if you're planning on going on a hot day- they do NOT have strong air conditioning, if at all so keep that in mind. Hot ramen on a hot Californian summer day.. tasty but not always the best combination.
author: Emily C.

description: Really cool atmoshere that takes you off too a place in downtown Japan right there in the city. I was in town for the night and wanted a nice comforting bowl of ramen. This  was authenticity and greatness all in one. It speaks for itself and I can't complain about a thing. I tried a bottle of sake and it was perfect with the meal. The food was good even though I took out some of the meats in my bowl because it was a bit more meat than I needed in my already bowl of a 4 meat variety. It was a perfect after hours place and I can't wait to come back!
author: Tifanny E.

description: Best Ramen I have had in S.F. I really enjoyed the miso soup broth was simply amazing! I would recommend not coming here starving because the wait is atleast 45 minutes but so worth the wait! Def. a must try.
author: Yadira G.

description: Rocking Ramen round Union Square. Check it out SF! Shoyu.. try some of the other dishes and you won't be disappointed. Hole in the wall but good times all the same - it's more legit that way anyhow... get lost in a pastime paradise - ram-a-la-la-sha-la-la-la-shangri-la... well maybe not.. but it is California.
author: Gregory H.

description: Great Ramen!  I had the soy flavor BBQ pork. Make sure to get it rich. This place is authentic - just like in Japan!  Another highly recommended Ramen shop in the Bay Area.
author: Matthew A.

description:
My mom, the kids and I were staying at the Westin St. Francis and were tiring of the room service food.  We started to crave noodles and I found this restaurant on Yelp.  It did not disappoint!

We popped in to order the food to go.  The restaurant is TINY... So tiny that our stroller didn't fit and I had to park it outside!  Luckily there were few customers so we were able to sit at a table while we waited for a very short time (10 minutes or so) for our noodles and sushi.  The staff were very friendly and helpful.

Among us, we ordered udon, ramen (of two types), and soba.  They were all AMAZINGLY good, so savory and tasty.  My sons, 10 and 12, devoured their noodles with gusto.  The broth was tasty, and the noodles were well cooked but not mushy (a pet peeve of mine).  The sushi was also great -- freshly made too.

We are not often in San Francisco, but you can bet we'll come back to this restaurant next time we are in town.
author: Rebekah S.

description:
Katana-Ya is one of SF's many awesome hole-in-the-wall finds, but a good landmark for it is the Curran Theater (currently playing Dream Girls) located directly across the street.

This place is delicious, and as a result, uber-packed all the time.  Actually, you can probably get in with little no wait at lunch, but definitely count on being quoted the wrong wait time and waiting at least an hour for a table at dinner.  I went Saturday night for a friend's send off dinner--and we ended up waiting 1 hour and 50 minutes.  That would be a deal breaker for me, but the friends I was with are fiends for their ramen.

The wait wasn't too big of a deal for us because of the convenient coffee places available to fend off the cold San Franciscan night while we waited.  We chose Starbucks--green tea lattes are good for the soul and no one rushes you out of a coffee shop.  Good times and good conversation are part of the dining-out ambiance, and if you're getting pissed off about waits...I challenge you to question who you're spending your time with.

On to the food!  I like how you can customize your broth-- central options include a miso base which is good for bland soups, or a soy base if you're the type you can't stand anything too salty.  That knowledge helped us all order what we were after.  The menu says that only meat broth is available for the ramen, but the waiter told me that wasn't true and he totally hooked me up with a custom veggie broth--scoorre!!  He warned me that it would be on the bland side, so I ordered it extra spicy and it ended up coming out perfect.  Our Ramen was bomb, the agadashi tofu was on-point, and the tempura was decent.  I would recommend substituting the buckwheat noodles because the ramen was kinda meh.  My friends were horrified at how bright red with spices my soup was, and were convinced that was why I wasn't enthralled by the flavors of the ramen noodles.  Go try it for yourself and be the judge of that.
author: Jatinder S.

description: The spicy crispy tuna roll was amazing. The soup was really tasty but not the best I've had in SF. Broth was bomb but the pork was too fatty and tough. The service was a little slow but overall the atmosphere was great. The lunch specials are where it's at. Definitely worth a shot but I don't think that I'd put in the time for the wait to go back.
author: M L.

description:
Katany-Ya...

How I love your extra spicy miso ramen via takeout. How I loathe the guarenteed one hour wait during peak hours for dine-in.

Ramen is close to being good / excellent, especially the broth and home made noodles. The only gripe is the long wait outside which is certaintly guarenteed around dinner time. Also +1 star for being open late to accomodate a heavy night of drinking on any given day!
author: Brian C.

description: The noodles are the right firmness and the miso broth is rich and satisfying. This is my go-to place for a hangover cure. I love the pork ramen but if you want to try it all get the Katana-ya ramen because its jam packed with goodies! My one tip is to actually go by yourself if you don't mind because the wait is long but the sushi bar seats very quickly. Great service!
author: Ryan B.

description:
I'm an absolute huge fan of noodle soups.  I've been to this little hole in the wall place probably about once a month since I discovered it last year.

This place has gotten more popular over time.  So be prepared to wait awhile outside, especially after a day of shopping in downtown.

Definitely come here to have the ramen.  Other than that, everything else is just extra items.
author: tina c.

description:
ok, i've only tried this place once, heard about it from my uncle, who raved about it.  i tried over the course of a few months to get in, during lunch, but didn't want to wait an hour.  it's hugely popular; it's located right off union square, so it gets floods of tourists and locals.

so finally one day went back again, and miraculously there was a very short line.  so i waited.  and finally got a seat.

the place is tiny.  really limited seating.

i ordered the fried chicken ramen.  when i got it, i was disappointed because the amount of chicken was miniscule, just a few pieces.  they could've put more meat in there, you know what i'm saying?  the broth was indeed tasty, and so too the noodles.  but that was all in terms of toppings.  no veggies.  it was very plain, and simple.  i think too simple.

and it was kinda pricey, for ramen.  over 10 bucks.  

so if you go, be prepared to wait a long time for a seat (and that's outside because it's too small inside), and to spend more money than you would usually spend for ramen.

i'll go back again, and hopefully the food will be better, and/or match my expectations.
author: Ramon C.

description: This was a treat while i was in Frisco for the day. Was walking around and looked up Ramen on Yelp... And BAM! this spot popped up. It was really tasty with huge portions. Will be coming back here next time in the Bay Area.
author: David R.

description:
hands down ... longgg wait ... all worth it!

if you come in big group, you will wait a lot longer...
author: A T.

description:
I was visiting SF for a conference and this place was recommended by another conference-goer.  While I am not an expert on ramen, this place wasn't so terrific that i would have to go again or now absolutely love ramen.  it was just ok.  although the noodles were better, there was probably more sodium and msg in this ramen than the dried ramen packets i used to eat in undergrad.  

we ordered some sushi rolls. they weren't anything fabulous and the fake crab was pretty nasty.  for dinner I had the vegetable ramen and while i am not a vegetarian i am glad i got a meatless item based on the appearance of the "meat" in other people's ramen.  barf!  there was a vegetarian in the group and he wasn't able to find too many vegetarian items.  the ramen dishes are made with a chicken broth base, so i think he ended up with a bowl of spicy rice and vegetable tempura roll.  he would have probably given a one-star rating.  not a good place for a vegetarian.

this place isn't a good to go with a large group.  we had six and waited about forty minutes at 6pm on a thursday night.  i presume it would be much worse on the weekends.
author: ellen s.

description: I don't know if it's the cold weather, but this ramen hit the spot! I got the katanaya with spicy miso broth, this ramen has everything....corn, bamboo shoots, chicken karage, pot stickers, egg, and who knows what else.  Luckily for me and my party, we only had to wait 10 minutes or so, which was nice, considering this place is small. Also, make sure to get your ramen spicy, it's worth the extra $1.50.  Anyways, next time ur in Downtown looking for a great bowl of broth on a cold day, stop by Katanaya-ya and enjoy.  Bon apetit!
author: David M.

description: I work downtown. Once a month, for lunch, I come here to order the karage ramen with shoyu base. The shoyu base is less salty than the miso base. The karage chicken is very moist. This bowl of ramen totally satisfy my ramen cravings and replaces Santa Ramen in San Mateo.
author: Helen L.

description: Definitely a place for slurping noodles.  Comfort food on a chilly day.  If you want basic, hot ramen soup, this is your fix.  Beware though, msg added and be prepare to wait a bit outside, the dining room is tiny.
author: Heather H.

description:
had really high hopes for Katana-Ya, but i didn't think is was 'all that' 

i had the Katana-Ya Ramen - which includes everything.  But the broth lacked flavor, and the ramen didn't have that bounce.  It's also a pretty expensive bowl of ramen too! hah.  
The salmon rolls i had were okay.

my buddy had the ma-bo ramen..  it seemed much more tastier.  

i'm sure i'll visit again, because friends will visit SF.. and want to try the famous Katana-Ya.  i'll definitely try the spicier ramen next time, and hope that it'll be much better for me!

small place, long wait, big price.
author: Ryan C.

description: Its Japanese food with a lot of hype. Its good ramen and decent rolls, but nothing soul shaking.
author: Alex H.

description:
yay!  T H E  W O R S T   F O O D  I ever ate in my life. 0 star, not 1.

FOOD:
Spicy Seafood Don $9.50 is GROSS. Chopped out mysterious chunks of seafood thickly tossed with Chinese Takeout Hot Sauce (Yes, that red one in a small pouch.Tastes exactly the same.), bedded with the apparently mistakenly soft-cooked rice. Isn't "spcy seafood" in US generally means flavored with Wasabi? Even from a tube? They're mysterious because 1. this Chinese red hot sauce hides the look and tastes of them completely. Chunks of gooey stuff, which makes me wonder they were actually gummy candy or rubber toys. 2. The lighting of the store is dim and colored in pink. Will talk about it later.

Katana-Ya Ramen $11(+$4 for combo) must be a JOKE. All kinds of apparently either canned or factory precooked food thrown in the bowl filled with MSG soup. Noodle is typical boring non-tasting one you always see at cheap chain stores. Wet fried dumpling and fried chiken ... oh why would you do that? This came with mini Tofu-Don, which again bedded with gooey rice with few slices of tofu on the top ... covered with awfully sweet sauce taste like straight out of cheap Chinese sauce jar. $4 for this? Got to be kidding.

STORE: 
Pink lighting sucks. I don't care the the tininess and nasty restroom as I know tons of great Chinese restaurant is always with it. They at least have reasonable price and bright light that let me at least understand what food served in front of me.

PEOPLE:
Misleading, immature, nonprofessional. The waitress came to ask "Ready to order?" every 30 sec. Misleading answer for the question  about which ramen x don can be a combo. She just said "You can choose anything !"  - but actually not. We ended up paying $5 more than expected. Chatting among them most of the time so we kept staring at them to get their attention for 3 min in that tiny store.

If you know how the ramen is either in NY or Japan - ha, don't bother, they are surprisingly Japanese own restaurant, but with no proud.
author: M O.

description: Places like this really make SF dining what it is... tasty fresh food, energetic frills-free vibe, and on the cheap.  I had the spicy tofu ramen twice:  It was incredible both times... thought it was veggie the first time but realized later that the broth wasn't.  Went back and had it again with the vegetarian broth... I'll admit that it was a little more flavorful the first time, but it was still super duper tasty and probably healthier with the vegan/veggie broth.
author: seema s.

description: Had to get the chasiu (bbq pork) ramen since it was on the 7x7 Things to Eat in SF list....I chose the soy (vs miso) soup. It was pretty awesome and the perfect 12pm breakfast after a nite out. The only thing is that I've never paid $12 for ramen before....how do they get away with that?
author: Kelley N.

description: Compared to most ramen places in San Francisco, this is definitely a 4 stars, however, I have been to other cities' ramen places, so I have experienced better ramen.  I'll come here if I'm craving for ramen.  The shaved ice with red bean and green ice cream was pretty good.
author: Elena L.

description:
There's a wait, even at lunch time but it's not as bad as dinnertime. 
The first time I came here, I was so lucky to find a parking spot right in front of it but I was short on change. I ended up having a time limit of 40 minutes and counting so I walked over to the place and I was lucky again since I didn't have to wait at all! It was the first time I've ever had ramen, and it was so delicious. I had #12. My order came out pretty quick. Plenty of noodles with the right amount of saltiness. I almost sipped the entire bowl of soup but I was too full since I had a Dr. Pepper to drink with it. I didn't really know how to order it- miso, soy etc... the waitress was quite helpful with that. I was on a time limit so I had to down that bowl asap! Lots of ppl had their eyes on me since I was slurping the shit out of that bowl. I'll say it again, it was very delicious. I quickly paid for everything and left the restaurant and came to the parking meter to find that it just turned from "0 minutes" to the flashing red "expired". I got in my car and I felt like a champ.
The second time around, I waited a bit and got to sit at the bar. I ordered the same thing and it came out quickly. Same service, same quality food. I came hungry and left happy. I'm glad to say that my first bowl of Japanese ramen was from Katana-Ya.
author: Nandiya A.

description: Recommended by a friend. Fresh Sushi. Love their butterfish. Extra spicy ramen with the miso is our usual order and we love it!  Just wish they give more meat and other ingredients other than noodle. That's the only complaint.  Oh, and go there 15 mins before 6pm for dinner or else it's gonna be a 30-40 min wait (or longer).  Place is small but to me it feels like a real sushi bar in Japan so I don't mind.
author: Sassy G.

description:
People are allowed to jump the line here -- a No No in my book.

Around 9:30pm last week we were already standing ~30 min in line. Then, some people who missed their spot (there were already 5 people ahead of them) tried re-entering (cutting) the line, saying "they were here before". 

The crowd in the cue grumbled, but the restaurant managers allowed this behavior. 

We saw this and left;  (no "sunk costs" for us), and made a note to write about the negative experience on yelp
author: Oori H.

description: Nestled away in this tiny space lies an amazing Sushi joint. Cute, small and packed! Ate there during lunch time - great menu selections and seemed very authentic. Japan-like! (Oh I miss it!) Ordered the special roll which put my mouth on fire as well as the curry bowl. Huge portions, reasonably priced. Would def come back and dine there again.
author: Thao L.

description: I thought I'd give it four stars but after sobering up it doesn't really warrant four.  It was good but not great and of course there was a pretty decent wait before we got in.  We all had Extra Spicy Ramen except for Rebbeca D who wussed out and got something no soupy.  It was spicy but not too bad so don't wuss out, go for it.  They where skimpy on the meat.  I know it's not supposed to have a lot but they could do more than one small piece.
author: Jason S.

description: Always great service and great taste. I come here at least every another day, no kidding... lol take out, dine in, around all kinds of time. YUMMY!!!! Don't really need to say more about it. ALL good! Had crush on this place for about 3 years, big time! Everyone who haven't tried out, shame!
author: Flora F.

description:
Came here on last Firday for dinner with few friends, we had to wait outside for while cuz there was a waiting list. Anyway, once my friend and I were inside, service was no-nonsense. 
Good, quick service. A nice place to come for a quick bite off of Union Square. 
For the food: Well, this time I ordered the tofu ramen, that is really small.  so a roll seemed like the best choice for me at the moment. my spicy tofu ramen was tasty, not too salty. The Rock'n Roll was good, but....where was the spice?!  ha
 The desserts is very tasty
author: virginia y.

description:
I will preface this with it has been next to impossible to find good ramen in the city. Best place I've found so far is in Berkeley. This place is delicious! I love the food and it's soooooo great to have found quality ramen without having to cross the bridge or go down into the peninsula.

The reason this place gets 3 stars is because either the waitresses really didn't like us on a personal level or the service is just garbage. We were kinda in a hurry to get to a movie and still waited politely for 15 minutes or so to finally signal to the waitress that we were ready to order and after that we didn't see them at all until we had to signal them again for the check. Small place with just a few people means that we were being ignored. Not cool.

Still, I'll go back because I'm a ramen fiend. Maybe it was an off night.
author: Jenni C.

description:
I think their sashimi here is great and fresh, but my bf thinks the ramen is bad. I wonder if he just ordered the wrong thing.

I can't really give an opinion about the ramen, because they use pork broth and I don't eat pork. But based on my good sashimi (4 stars) and my bf's ramen - I trust his taste most of the time (2 stars)... I'd give this place a 3.

If you hate waiting in line for food... don't come here. But if you still insist, just write your name, and walk a couple blocks away to get drinks at a hotel bar (you'll see some options), mingle, get a little tipsy, and then come back to Katana-Ya for your supper.
author: dub m.

description: So far it's just okay. But like good music, it needs to grow on me. It's a small place but we went in the afternoon, on a weekend. There wasn't a line but if there is, there's no need to wait. It's hard to review this place because I've had better ramen in San Mateo and Burlingame but if you're in the city and have the craving, or want the hangover special, Katana Ya is not a bad place to be.
author: Vien T.

description: I love a place that makes you feel like you're in on a secret.  Solid ramen.  Sapporo on tap.
author: Jessica G.

description:
I've read the whole history of Japan, and trust me, the ramen here is the best. Ever. You'll be sweating broth for the next couple days, but it's totally worth it. It kind of tastes like you're drinking butter, but in a good way. 

Open late, and they always have Nina Simone playing!
author: Steven H.

description:
This was my first time going to a restaurant and ordering ramen and it was a very good experience.  The place is pretty small so do not bring a group of six of more because it can be congesting.  Anyways, I ordered the regular pork ramen with soy and light broth.  What stuck out for me was the noodles, it's way better the Top Ramens noodles you cook at home.  It soup itself was very good but the noodles stuck out to me the most.  
Another plus is their hours, they open until two in the morning so not only you go here for lunch and dinner, but also for a late night meal probably after going out or just the urge to go for ramen at midnight like I did.
author: Kris A.

description:
In terms of Ramen, it's on par with Ryowa, but not as good as Ramen Halu or Santa.  

However, you can get small Don + full-size Ramen combos for about $10!
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
+1 here for the good Ramen in SF. Still, I can't understand why we can't get a Ramen place on par with a Santa's, or even a Ramen Club or Himawari, in San Francisco. 

Anyway, Katana-ya has additional pluses and minuses. They've got good appetizers and very good karage. The servers are nice, but it can get kind of slow. And the seating is very tight, to the point of being uncomfortable sometimes. Being basically in the Tenderloin, it's not the most attractive place to hang out waiting for a table either.
author: Jon W.

description:
I tried this place out since so many people gave it such glowing reviews.

I can't help but think that those people have never had real ramen before. This is nowhere near close.

Ordered a regular ramen & a sushi appetizer.....the ramen was decent but was too small considering the price, and the sushi was outrageously expensive (though good).

on the plus side the staff was nice

It's worth going here if you want a meal under $10...but don't expect much

If you happen to be in the Mountain View castro street area in south bay, Maruichi is considerably better if not totally authentic
author: Stephen L.

description:
My cousin, who will probably review Katana-Ya shortly took me here this past Monday.

We ordered 4 items in total, gyoza, rock shrimp, shoyu ramen and kara age miso ramen.

I ate or tasted 3 of the items.  

Gyoza - nice skin, nice crisp, where's the meat?

Rock Shrimp - too much mayo, the mayo is quite vinegary but the shrimp was fresh

Shoyu Ramen - while the noodles are thick and well executed, the charsu wasn't great.  No smoky flavor, 2 very thin and dry slices.  The soup..took three sips and I was craving Ippudo.

Of course, it costs about half of what Ippudo would run you, while good, I think I'd rather pay more so I can have the Ippudo broth.
author: Lawrence Y.

description: I still really like this place.  The combos they offer are nice when you want some variety.  I still absolutely love the spicy tuna don.  I had the ramen bowl when I went again this last weekend.  This time it was just ok.  The main thing that I didn't like about was that the bamboo shoots in it were rather tough.  Other than that, I still really enjoyed my meal there.  The service was quick as usual.  My fiance got the katsu curry, and I had a little food envy, cause it was sooooo good.  The bill was pretty reasonably for all the food we got.  I also really like that they have low sodium soy sauce.  More and more places seem to be offering this, but I appreciate it just the same when restaurants do have it available.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Ive been looking for a place just like this for so long. Much tastier than the noodle shops in japantown. Could be a little cleaner but the soup was just what i wanted :)
author: Sara S.

description: had their extra spicy ramen and it was sooo good! come try it if you can take spicy!
author: Kapo T.

description: Craving ramen? Come here! They also have ankimo! And creative sushi rolls, sashimi, shaved ice desserts. We went on saturday so parking wasnt too difficult to find, but be ready to wait awhile as the restaurant has a capacity of only 20 guests.
author: Oanh N.

description:
Good stuff... I'm a little bit particular when it comes to my ramen. A good bowl of it on a cold night can turn the night into a cozy comfortable night.

This is my favourite place in the city (true I've only really been to one other ramen specific place), but the stingy and the crowded table setup in a tight space is exactly how ramen restaurants should be arranged. Extra points for that.

In terms of the raman they offer their choices with a miso or soya base (I always go miso). Its good, it fills you up and leaves you nice and sedated. I've tried a few different choices on the menu, the spicy onion, buttery corn (they just put in a little brick of butter when served with the raman... its awesome), extra pork and fried chicken ramen. The least pleasing of these choices was the fried chicken - it just does not sit well in the broth, becoming soggy.

I really liked the extra pork and buttery corn. They both left me feeling happy and relaxed.
author: Krishnan S.

description: This place made me a RAMEN believer! After dining here I developed a ramen obsession for almost a month, I was on a mission to find other ramen places....and nothing I tried ever compared to the greatness of Katana-Ya! The wait to be seated is well worth it!
author: Eisa m.

description:
After a bit of Downtown shopping, hubby suggested ramen at Katana-Ya, a place he tried in the past.  We had to wait about 20-30 mins for a table, just past noon.  Slowly and surely, a small crowd gathers outside the restaurant and more names are added to the outside sign-up list.  A testament to the power of Yelp, I overheard 4 young ladies waiting, remark about how one of them learned about this place thru a friend via Yelp.  

With John Legend music playing in the background, Hubs and I dined on 2 pieces of hamachi nigiri ($5) which was disappointing. The hamachi was not as good as what we enjoyed the night before at Yoshi's Oakland and the rice immediately fell apart while hubby tried to dip it into the soyu.  My katanaya ramen ($12.90), the costliest of the ramens (others range $8.50-$9.80), was not great either. I had the miso broth and found it salty and oily from the 2 pieces of fried chicken karage and 2 fried vegt. gyoza.  There was chopped spinach, some kind of gourd? which had a displeasing odor, 1/2 an egg, corn and a slice of pork in the soup.  The ramen was OK, not great.  We tried the fried calamari legs served over a very small spring salad. The batter didn't adhere to the calamari but tasted good with the mayonnaise-like dipping sauce.  There's a sushi bar which seats about 4 persons.  Seems to be a popular place for the younger set and has great hours for night owls as they're opened until 1:15AM daily.  The bathroom is uni-sex and has owl pictures painted on the walls.  Hoot-hoot-hoot.
author: Ry T.

description: Good japanese ramen is pretty hard to get outside of Japan.  Katana-Ya almost hit the spot.  I had the Katana-Ya ramen, and it's the perfect hangover cure or pre-game food for those long nights out.  The sushi rolls were decent but not the greatest.  The main point of this place is the ramen, and it's definitely the best I've had in downtown.
author: Koh K.

description: My miso ramen was delicious as was the spicy tuna don that I had on the side. I at there last night, and I just stopped feeling like I was going to explode from fullness. Sooooo tasty. There was a fifteen minute wait during which I contemplated the most effective way to stop the inane chatter of two fools who appeared to attend academy of art. Right before I settled on violence, my friends and I were seated. It was worth the wait and the inane chatter.
author: Carolyn B.

description:
You want good ramen???
Next time you're in NY you'll have some.

If you're a NY'er whose had good ramen this won't at all leave you satisfied. 

Katayana Ramen bowl was disappointing. The egg was overcooked. The pork was hard and lacked flavor (it should have melted...). 
The broth was alright.... and the noodle's were okay.
author: carmen l.

description: My friend recommended this place to me since I love a nice bowl of ramen. I tried the Katanya Ramen and I got to say I could not even finish half of it. It was a disappointment! Low quality ingredients, the broth was not very good and packed with MSG! The noddles had a slimy texture to it. This is probably the worst ramen place I've ever been to and the first that does not make their broth out of scratch and quality ingredients. What a disappointment.
author: Bruce L.

description: Tasty, but broth is somewhat less complex that competitors Izakaya Sozai or Mitsuwa joints
author: K C.

description: This place was right across from the hotel we stayed in, and there was always a line up, so we thought we have to give it a try. But have to say not worth the wait. When we reached there it looked like they are famous for their Ramen. So we thought of ordering that. But the Ramen was 99% ramen noodles with some meat in whichever breath u choose. I would not go there again. There are lots of other places in SF which are better.
author: Ashok S.

description:
So, I'm a little scandalized to learn that Katana-Ya adds tip into their bill... those bastards have likely gotten a double-tip out of me when I've been there.

That said, I'll be back.

They make good ramen. Very good ramen.  Highly recommend both the kim-chi and the scallion version.

Though I will say that the gyoza leave something to be desired.  Stick to the soup, don't add a second tip, and all will be well.
author: David K.

description: Restaurant is very small. Menu is great- tons of selection and pictures. Service is nice. I got the sashimi dinner combo. The miso soup is way too salty and strong, and the sashimi fish did NOT taste fresh. I do appreciate that they are open super late though.
author: Julie S.

description: Brilliant me, decided to eat at this place on the hottest day of the year. There we were, eating our ramen and sweating up a storm. At one point, I had to walk up and go outside to cool down. My friends ordered a pitcher of cold beer to try to cool down, but I don't think it was successful. Since it was such a hot day, it was still busy but we were able to get a seat without the usual crazy long wait (we had 4 people, they start charging 18% gratuity if you have 5 or more). I ate the regular ramen and it was just average to me. This was my 3rd time here. Not sure why some people are so crazy about this place. I don't think it's worth waiting for if there is a line.
author: Sizzi K.

description: Honestly, if there's higher rating than 5 stars, I would totally go for it! I have never paid someone else to make ramen for me, just because I think the instant one is just as good and I can totally make that myself, but since my friend highly recommended this place, it got me curious how good it can be...at first, I was pretty upset by the long wait (more than 20 minutes in the cold and rain) even after 11pm, but then once I got my table and my order, my frustration totally went away. IT WAS SO GOOD, to the point that I couldn't help but stuffed myself with everything I got in the bowl, bottom up! I highly recommend the miso soup base light version, it's very rich and flavorful, so you really don't have to get the rich one to get that taste. If you are ever going to pay someone to make ramen for you, please go there, it won't disappoint you!
author: Anna H.

description: I ordered Sushi here even though this place is famous as ramen. This restaurant itself was small but the location is nice because it is pretty close to Union Square. I was waiting to go into this restaurant for 10 minute since it was on Sunday. But, I could wait for 10min. It was not so long. I try my friend's Salt ram en just one bite but it was really salty. It was way away from genuine ramen in Tokyo. But still it is considerate taste. Not baaaaaaaaad.
author: Kozy T.

description: YUM! My go to spot for ramen.  Good broth, home-made noodles, hearty portions.  Can't ask for more! Get the Katana-ya Ramen (the works) and add "Spicy." You WILL thank me later!
author: Tim W.

description: The place was a bit small, but the soup was very good. I would recommend the Katana Ya Ramen. It has everything from BBQ pork, corn, eggs, even fried chicken. Very tasty soup especially during the cold weather months in San Francisco. Very affordable.
author: Shane R.

description:
After hearing so much rave reviews about this place, I decided to try it with my friend. We both got the katanaya ramen with miso broth. 

The broth was good & rich, but could tell that much of it was influenced by the use of msg. This was especially noticeable after dinner since I had that type of thirst you get after eating packaged ramen. The toppings were interesting..fried chicken and potstickers in the broth. I appreciate the variety of toppings, but if the fried items aren't eaten quickly they get soggy.. and what's the point in soggy fried food? The quantity was just right for me, but for the price I would've wanted more. 

in the end, It was good...but not 12.50 + tax good. The most I would pay for this would be 9 dollars. After trying several different ramen places in the bay area, Katanaya hasn't made a lasting impression on me. I probably will come back from time to time in the future, but it's nothing I would crave or seek out purposefully.
author: Jim Y.

description: Whenever I have a craving for ramen, I head over to union square for a meal here. Their ramen noodles are tasty with great texture, remind me of the real stuff I got in Japan. The broths, miso and shoyu, are rich and filling. The food comes out fast and the service is efficient, but friendly. If you are looking for something fancy with atmosphere, this is not your place. If you are looking a restaurant that reminds you of a quick ramen shop in Japan, this is your place. It, unfortunately, is a bit cramped, and there is usually a line and a wait to get in. Put your name on the list and get ready for some good ramen.
author: S M.

description: One of my fav's. Double-pork miso-rich ramen or the mabo ramen. Sushi is also good. Only wish they doubled the space as opposed to creating a Shabu Shabu next door.
author: Jeff W.

description:
mm mM mmmmMMmmMm. nothing really beats a hot, salty, spicy, FLAVA FLAAAVE bowl of ramen. the katanaya ramen rocks my socks. mildly spicy, soy sauce, rich broth. gyoza, bbq pork, AND chicken.. dayum! the chicken is SO GOOOOOOD. even after being soaked and dunked in the soup throughout the meal it was still dericious. i rike it. arot. ramen noodles were practically infused with the broth so bite after bite it was unstoppable. rolls are packed solid. 

small, almost tiny space, but legit. polite staff that wont put your check down in front of your face as soon as the dishes are cleared.. instead they calmly wait for you to ask for it. affordable prices. 

accepts mc&visa. YES.
author: Yui K.

description: Just adding a note: We ordered the Lava Flow roll tonite after going back with a craving for their ramen as well. I will probably opt to not order sushi here again. It wasn't that great, and it's pretty expensive for what you get.  The Dancing Bonito was pretty good, but I don't remember it being worth what we paid.  I did have the kimchee ramen this time. YUM!
author: Jen T.

description: Easily my favorite ramen spot in the city. There is usually a wait of some sort...so put your name on the list and hang out, it's definitely worth it! I'm a creature of habit, which means I always order the KatanaYa ramen in a miso base, minus the egg. Those delicious fried chicken pieces, gyoza, and bits of corn always hits the spot. Perfect for de-thawing my freezing ass on a SF cold night!! Is it as good as any of the ramen spots I used to frequent in LA? No. But it's as good as it gets out here. And beggars can't be choosers.
author: Alah R.

description:
I decided to check out Katana-ya tonight since I didn't feel like going all the way to Japan town to get Japanese food.

First, the service is pretty terrible. The hostess wasn't very courteous. 
I went around 9PM solo so seating wasn't really a problem.

I ordered Negi ramen and gyouza (pot stickers). 
They were both edible but not outstanding by any means. 
Actually, I thought the ramen was pretty horrible because the broth was incredibly heavy, loaded with oil.

I consider myself a ramen connoisseur. 
I am Japanese and travel to Tokyo 2-3 times a year.
I have eaten at some of the most renowned ramen joints in Tokyo e.g. rokurinsha, ramen jiro, taisho-ken, and etc just to name a few.
This doesn't even come close to real ramen and I'd rather eat some instant noodles (i gotta warn you though. real japanese instant noodles are 500x better than cup noodles)

users who are raving about this place have not obviously had real ramen...

2 stars for convenience. Pretty bad otherwise.
author: Sh I.

description:
I struggled over whether to give 3 or 4 stars as this really is one of the better ramen joints in SF.  Thing is...the state of SF ramen is pretty sad.  So, I went with the absolute rating as opposed to a relative one.

The broth is on the heavy side, which I like, and the noodles are fair.  All the stuff they pack into the Katanaya Ramen is kind of entertaining but, well...the end result is a bit desperate and unfocused.  Like a rudderless teenager, Katanaya's ramen has potential but doesn't quite know who it really is.
author: Joseph S.

description:
i'm not an expert in ramen by any means but i do know that this was flavorful tasty stuff.  i've been here twice and have tried two different broths (soy sauce and miso broths) and can say that i love the miso broth.  it has a lot more flavor and depth than soy sauce.  

the first time i went i had gotten the katanaya ramen w/ soy sauce broth.  this should be called "the kitchen sink" since they throw in literally every fixin they have.  good stuff but i think the soy sauce broth was a bit too salty for me.  the next time i got the spicy green onion ramen w/ miso broth and this was outstanding.  the flavor of the broth, the spicy sauce and the green onions all worked very well together.  both times the noodles were very very good w/ a nice bite to them.

word to the wise, this place gets crowded at lunch time around 12:15ish so get here early!  can't wait to try the other varieties!
author: Swarup B.

description: How can ramen taste so good?? Although their prices could be $2-3 cheaper (I should be able to get a simple bowl for $10 including tax and tip), the food was well worth the wait. Try the extra spicy ramen on a cold day. Yum!
author: Morin O.

description: Good and satisfying but not great ramen. We ordered both the Katana-Ya special with rich miso and rich soy sauce broths. This special consisted of butter corn, fried chicken, fried gyoza, chasu pork, green onion, and bamboo shoots. It's basically their ramen bowl with everything and the "kitchen sink." While this special was very toppings heavy, it worked well with the very flavorful broths (both the miso and soy were complex and flavorful). The service was also friendly. Why not 5 stars? The noodles were okay...we favor the chewier and curlier shaped version. This version is straight and thin like vermicelli. The noodle's thinness changes the texture and body of the chew. The broths were very tasty but also are made with MSG (they state this on their menus. Why do they need this shortcut?). Lastly, they have red pepper flakes on each table but it lacked any punch. I must have put 2 teaspoons of it in my bowl and it barely registered any spiciness. If I was around SF and Union Square, I would go back and try some other choices. Overall, good and solid ramen experience but it lags far behind Ramen Dojo and Orenchi.
author: H E.

description: This is a small little place which is packed most of the time but they have the best RAMEN and CALIFORNIA ROLL ever! I usually get the fried chicken ramen because the chicken is mouth-watering and flavorful. The ramen is also very good. Cooked to the right texture with an addition of seaweed. You get to choose to get miso soup with you ramen or soy sauce. Both are delicious and very good choices. One thing that amazed me were their California Roll. I know it's simple and a lot of people don't like that but at this restaurant, they make it with real crab and you can definitely taste the difference. It is SO GOOD. They have other rolls also but I don't really order those. I'm fine with my California Roll. Best ramen place in SF!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
starving after getting our hair cuts at public, so we decided on katana-ya since there were no queues.  last time we attempted to eat here the people were spilling out on the sidewalks, and we weren't in the humor to wait.

i ordered the curry tonkatsu, and he had the katana-ya ramen w/soy flavored soup.  both were tasty.  while we've had better ramen and japanese cuisine, this place does the job when craving for japanese while in the union square area.
author: Sheri N.

description: Bad service. I don't mind waiting because I know that this restaurant is always busy. But what's not right is that the host let 2 groups of people who were on list like over 10 before mine which already got crossed out went inside first. Skipped the line and let people who came after got inside first. The food is okay but the service mind is BADDDDD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Beeme K.

description: From a professional Japanese restaurant evaluator point of view, their Ramen is okay. The noodle they use is thick type and soup is not that profound.
author: Soo S.

description: Best Ramen noodle in the city. Go for the kimchi ramen with miso base. Yum!
author: R M.

description:
ok, seriously, this place has the best ramen in all of sf?!  that's really sad, because the ramen here sucks!  i consider myself extremely lucky to live near santouka (inside mistuwa market in san jose), which hands down has the best ramen i've ever had in my life.  just talking about it makes me want to go grab a bowl hahahaha.

after waiting outside for about 20 mins, we finally got seated inside.  i glanced around, and the place kinda looks like it had once been a shady massage parlor.  the interior was dark, and decorated with christmas lights and mirrors...  i did, however, like the owl and tree painting on the wall inside the bathroom.  the stars and tree go from the wall onto the ceiling, which makes it feel kinda 3d.

we ordered the katana ya special ramen and the shio ramen, both of which lacked flavor, and the ingredients were disappointing.  the pork was tough n chewy, and the gyoza were hella old and had been microwaved.  we even tried adding soy sauce to add flavor, but it just couldn't be saved.  maybe their sushi is better, but all the reviews talked about ramen, and most people inside had ordered ramen...
author: Angie L.

description:
Since I've (temporarily, perhaps) forsaken Tanpopo, I've been looking for another decent ramen place in San Francisco; and now I've found it.  I had the straight miso ramen -- no extra pork or chicken karaage or anything -- and it was really good.  The broth was deep and rich and satisfying.  Maybe too rich for my taste, but that's okay because they have a 'light' version of the broth as well.

Anyhow I agree with Arnold G that a hard-boiled egg would be a nice complement to the ramen.

I saw they have a curry udon on the menu, but not a curry ramen.  I'll try to order curry ramen next time anyhow and see what they do.

--

Well, they can't do curry ramen, but boy, the crab croquettes are really good.  They're fried, yet maintain a pleasant mellow lightness.

Five stars!
author: Eric W.

description:
Well, this is the first ramen place I've ever tried, so I dunno about the taste, but I think most people seem to agree that this place serve pretty good ramen.. and I'm not complaining either, lol!

Reasonable price for the huge ramen portion (well, to me at least), but if you wanna eat more, they provide this combo stuff, that should take care of it..

The place is small though (prolly could only fit like 25-30 people), so don't bring a big group in..
author: Erik C.

description:
Great little restaurant that opens late in the Union Square area.... parking sucks.  It's pretty small, so can get packed making the wait rather long.

The sashimi combo was  fresh.  The chef's selection was great.  Ramen was tasty.  The price was very reasonable.

I wouldn't say the food was to die for, but I would come here again.
author: mardou o.

description:
tad bit overrated

We had the crab croquette, combo meal of shoyu ramen/tonkatsu and shoyu ramen/tempura don. The broth was way too salty as is w/out any adjustments for my taste. There was only one piece of meat in the ramen. They could've easily given at least two. The croquette was the only thing that was good.

My search for the perfect bowl of ramen continues. I won't be back here.
author: Veronica H.

description:
I work in downtown SF and while it is def a walk to get out to Katana-Ya for me, when I have a need for Ramen (which is often) this place fills it perfectly.  My Ramen has always been amazing either when I eat it there or take it back to the office.

Gotta love it.
author: Ed F.

description:
I was craving ramen and decided to check this place out seeing as how it's pretty close to where I live.

I got the kimchee miso ramen.  The kimchee didn't taste like kimchee at all... it tasted like plain cabbage and I was pretty bothered that they only gave me one piece of chasu.  They charged us $2 for a small bowl of extra green onions.  Soup was too salty but the noodles were decent.  

Everybody else I was with ordered the fried chicken miso ramen (wth) and seemed satisfied enough.  

If I ever come back I won't be getting the ramen.  The don bowls looked good though.
author: eugene p.

description:
This place is listed on the 2010 Big Eat SF - 100 things to eat before you die. So I went and had their Chasu Ramen.

I can never eat Chasu Ramen at another restaurant anymore.

...need I say more?

GO! TRY IT! LOVE IT! :)
author: Daphne L.

description: I'm only giving this place 4 stars because of their steep prices. The food is spectacular. Sashimi: Fresh. Soba: Delicious. BBQ pork: Tender. End result: A happy tummy. This place is a must-try.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Me and my girlfriend went there the other night at bout 12. Tables are full. We were ignored of helping by the waitresses. We had to talk to one whos helping other diners. She used her chin to point at the door and said " Write your name on the board" So we went out and found there is a board where you write your names and wait. That ruined all the mood and the appittite. I wont go there again for the rude and bad service
author: Bryan Z.

description:
Couldn't wait to try this place out. Yelp had some great reviews and it came highly recommended by some people i know.
My husband and I decided to give this place a shot after a nice long morning at the California Academy of Sciences. We had a snack at the Cal Acad because we really wanted to save room for all the goodness we were told about here.
Having arrived on cold raining Saturday evening, the wait was over an hour, and there was only 3 small groups in front of us. After getting seated in a tightly fit window area which was cute and had more room than the rest of the tables, we ordered!
my husband got the Katana Ya Ramen spicy... okay size, the spice was just hot oil, and had way too many things going on to be able to taste the goodness of the ramen. I ordered the regular pork ramen combo with sukiyaki, my ramen was ehhh at best. it was bland, salty, and the piece of pork was 99% fat with a tiny strip of meat. The sukiyaki donburi on the other hand was well done, aside from the meat being chewy and hard to swallow, the flavors were there.

i gave this place 2 stars because i have experienced better. I give them 2 and not just 1 because it was cold and i was wet and hungry, the food was hot. The bathroom was the cleanest Ive seen in any SF hole in the wall place and i think my expectation of it were way too high based on what Ive been told and read.

i probably wont go back here unless for some strange reason i happen to stumble out of ruby sky, drunk and in need of food other than fast food.
author: Nat B.

description: Their ramen is just okay.  I tried the extra spicy miso ramen and it was decently flavorful, but nothing memorable.  I didn't like that their broth was grainy.  I would hope that there are better ramen places in SF, if not, I'll be a very sad soul.
author: Kristine B.

description: I had my first experience at Katana-Ya and it was pretty awesome! I had the original ramen and the broth was so flavorful! Good noodles and scallions. Seating was very limited at lunch time and there was a long wait. Service was so so but the food made up for it. not good for parties of 6 or larger. I will be going back!
author: Adrienne P.

description: Absolutely faboulous food! I went here with my girlfriend an we ordered the soy ramen and a little salmon chirashi, and both were absolutely fantastic, the ramen was full of flaver and the salmon bowl was so fresh and tasty. It was without a doubt the highlight of our trip
author: Matt R.

description: To put it simply, I am not going to forget the meal that i had here anytime soon! It was SO fricken good!! I have to admit this was my first time having ramen, but I crave it now because of this place! I had the BBQ pork ramen with the light soy sauce broth with added corn and hard boiled egg. I thought that the broth was going to be really salty but it was perfect and delicious. I believe it is all the different components of ramen that make it taste exceptional from an instant package from the grocery store. The pork was nice and tender and they gave you four big slices of it. The noodles were great as well and had the perfect texture. I would definitely come back here or recommend this place to friends.
author: Chelsea M.

description: Best ramen ever!!  Too bad we didn't come here till our last day in SF.  This will be a new must go to spot when we are back in SF.
author: Dannie W.

description: We chose Katana-Ya based on cuisine, location & Yelp reviews. (GO YELP!) We stopped by on a Saturday night for a late dinner & waited for an hour after putting our names on the wait list. It is a very small place with very tight seating. Neither the wait nor the tight quarters bothered us though. Katana-Ya was great right where it counted. The service was friendly & speedy and best of all, the food was tasty! We had si min & sushi. We will go again, but probably when there's no wait.
author: Rod K.

description:
awesome bowl of ramen; even better with the lunch special!

-regular miso ramen + small unagi bowl = $12.

 the mixed sushi salad, also excellent with ponzu sauce.

i gotta come back here, try the chashu ramen; passed on it for the lunch combo.
author: Ethan L.

description: One of the better ramen places in the city, the food is pretty delicious and the interior makes you forget you were ever in the Tenderloin. The staff is very attentive and friendly, they even accommodated my camera-crazy friend by snapping a few pictures of us eating. But try to get there by 5:30 or 6, the line begins after that and wraps around the block by dinner time. I actually got there a half hour before my friends and even without ordering anything, my waitress routinely filled my water and smiled to me as if to say, no pressure, relax as you wait for your tardy friends.
author: Anthony C.

description: I didn't really get to try the ramen here but I heard its great. I was really craving a rice bowl so I got a Beef Sukiyaki. It was good. I remember burning my tongue because I was so impatient with wanting to taste it. The place is a tad small and we did have to wait a while for a table of 2. The actual table itself was also very small.
author: Angela C.

description: I gave katanya a 3 out of 5 because the overall flavor is pretty decent. I think the best part about the place was the noodles. They were done right. The broth was pretty generic and lacked any sort of "wow" factor. The price was a bit much for just noodles/size. I think overall this place is a good place to head to if you need your noodle fix but it wouldn't be my top choice for noodles.
author: Brian K.

description:
a 3.5.

not the best ramen in the world, but probablythe best i've had in the city... and that counts for something!

note: i had the corn butter ramen with soy sauce.
author: Jill k.

description: Ramen is really awesome! Sushi are great too. However, their building is so small that you might have to wait for 20 minutes to get in!!! Which is not good if it's cold outside.
author: Volodymyr L.

description:
BEST RAMEN EVER!

Although I am not sure about the rest of their food selection, the ramen here is probably the best you can get in the city. Even their plain miso ramen fills me with happiness and I try to convince whoever I'm with to make a stop there whenever we're in the neighborhood.

The service on the other hand is a little hit or miss. Sometimes they're pleasant and sometimes they're very cold depending on who is working, but they're pretty quick to take orders and serve food so it really doesn't detract from the experience too much. Plus the delicious, delicious ramen more than makes up for it.

Definitely recommended!
author: Cristina G.

description: This is one of the best ramen joints in the Bay Area and pretty authentic. I wouldn't get sushi with it but this is a meal that goes well with a good cold beer.
author: Justin C.

description: Good but not great ramen. Since this place is pretty small, I'm not surprised that there is usually a wait for a table. I went on a Saturday night and luckily one of my friends got there early and we did not have to wait too long for a large table. I liked my ramen but I did not think that it was spectacular. I still like Tanpopo in J-Town better for ramen. I would come back again if I was in the neighborhood but I wouldn't mind trying some other places known for ramen first before returning.
author: Lisa M.

description: Best miso ramen and beef curry over rice in the bay area.
author: Carlos M.

description: If you're looking to impress some picky eaters, Katana-Ya needs to be on your list. Options are simple for comfort food eaters like myself. I often go with the Fried Chicken Ramen with the Miso broth, which I'm way too comfortable with. I know I still have to try others. Though everyone usually raves about the ramen or donburi, don't pass up on their specials like the oysters or crab croquettes, which deserves some stars on Yelp too. Hey newbies, please don't bring large groups to Katana-Ya. This spot is very, very limited in space.
author: Leroid D.

description: The workers are super friendly.  The big bowls of soup and ramen rock.  Very satisfying and tasty.  About $7-$9 for one bowl.  Might take you a little bit of time to get in though, it's a samll building and it's always bene busy so far from what I've seen.  Worth it though!
author: Mason P.

description:
The food is very good. One less star because the place is very small and our table was extremely crowded.  Got there around 8ish on Saturday and got seated around 8:40PM.  

I got the butter corn ramen, salt favor with mild spicy, which was very delicious and flavorful.  We also got the grilled whole squid as appetizer, very tasty.   The sushi was so-so.   Nothing great about it.   Overall good experiences and will come back for sure.
author: Maggie L.

description:
If this is the best ramen in the city, I feel sorry for all San Franciscans.

Went with a friend and ordered their signature Katanaya ramen.  The noodles were soggy and the soup was incredibly oily (in a bad way).  Perhaps I should have ordered my noodles katame.  If it weren't for their plum wine and the fact that I was incredibly hungry, I probably wouldn't have eaten it.

I hope I find something better next time I go to SF.

Peace
author: Deric M.

description: I love this place.  On a cold and foggy day, there's nothing better than a steaming hot bowl of ramen.  I really like the one with fried chicken.  I have had better ramen (try Santa Ramen in San Mateo), but I still love to come here.  The place is tiny, though, so be prepared to wait.
author: Aaron L.

description:
We decided to visit this place because it has 'the best ramen in downtown SF".
Doesn't live up to its hype.
Much to our dismay, the ramen was tasteless..
And the rolls didn't taste that good and were really overpriced.

The restaurant was really dark and small. We couldn't eat in peace because the waitresses kept brushing past us every few minutes and the tables were awfully small.

Needless to say.. we're not coming back here again.
author: Roland R.

description: Ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen: out of this world! Fried chicken, fried dumplings, corn, pork, boiled egg in a delicious spicy soy based broth -- heaven. I will come to SF just for this ramen. Also tried the monk fish liver: very delicious as well.
author: Ha N.

description:
i happily make a weekly 15 minute trek in search of the perfect bowl of ramen. i don't mind this walk, even though it's straight through the heart of Evil (more commonly referred to as "union square"). lunch tends to be my best meal of the day, it's worth it. 

last fall i had the pleasure of doing a "ramen tour" in tokyo, japan and was able to chow on the best of the very best. it was delightful. and ever since i have searched for a worthy adversary, some place to match tokyo's skills. katana-ya is the place. i was told they make their ramen in house. if true, i am not surprised. the texture and flavor are second to none. i highly recommend the "corn and butter" ramen with soy sauce broth. 

i have no idea what "katana-ya" means, but if it doesn't loosely translate to "best ramen in san francisco, bitchez!!!"... then obviously something is lost in translation.
author: vuForce Fresh n.

description: Ramen was humungous. if you dont know how to order ramen, try and learn here. but really good ramen and too bad they dont have good parking around and that its in a shady area.
author: A L.

description: This cold weather reminds me of my favorite foods that warm me up. Spicy Miso Ramen is one of those foods. Get it with or without the fried chicken - either way it is delish. The past few times we have called in and ordered for pick up. Speedy and you get to avoid the wait.
author: Rachel S.

description: Fantastic little mom-n-pop style Japanese restaurant specializing in noodle soups near Union Square.
