The menu has an entire page dedicated to different broth, noodle-types and meat/tempura/vegetables. They also have a huge selection of donburi, sushi and most importantly, sake. Prices are about average, service is polite and quick. Food is delicious. Curry soup with soba is fantastic as is the Udon soup with chicken. 1 bowl of edamame, 2 soups and 2 bottles of sake - bill was $42. The place is small, so expect a wait, but the line moves quickly.
author: Maren P.

description:
OK, I will be honest with Ramen at Katana-ya.
When I tried it for the first time, I was very satisfied just because I haven't eaten Ramen for 6 months. I love Ramen and when I was still in Tokyo, I used to eat Ramen maybe 3 times a week.
Anyways, I rate Ramen shops in several categories so here they are.

Soup: strong soup with some se-abura(fat from back of pork). But soup is too hot and it doesn't allow people to taste soup very well.

Noodle: This is one of those dried noodle and I wish they could get a machine to process their own noodle. Probably, chijire-men (stronger noodle) would be better match for its strong broth. I like it al dente but noodle with poor quality doesn't make much difference how it's cooked.

Topping: Chashu (BBQ Pork) is too thin and too small. I personally need Ajitama (marinated boiled egg) and boiled spinach.

Customer Service: In Japan, I will consider this category as well. But in this case, it doesn't apply cos there are no other Ramen shops.

Overall: Again, this is like the only place where you can eat Ramen in SF so I would say it's worth trying. But if this is in Japan, I would not come back for it.
author: Shumi S.

description:
I miss their old location in the Sunset near UCSF (and their unique spicy fried udon).  I miss their cool staff, and seeing the chef/owner make food in view of everyone.

This new location has not-friendly staff (but not un-friendly), doesn't have spicy fried udon, and smaller portions than I expect.  If you like salty, fatty broth and decent noodles, this place is perfect.  Their kimchi fried rice is more like fried rice with some kimchi.  

Katana-Ya gets two stars (out of three) because I would only come here if I was in the neighborhood, and craving something salty, fatty.  They have much to improve.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description:
This place is awesome. I haven't had ramen noodles this good in San Francisco ever. 

It's in a weird location, and it's a bit of a hole in the wall, with people crammed in close together -- exactly what I look for in a noodle joint. 

I ordered the spicy tofu ramen in miso base, and it was fantastic. A perfect blend of salty and spicy. I couldn't stop slurping them up, even after I was full. I also tasted the regular ramen, and it was pretty solid, with a rich, complex broth. A little light on the vegetables for my taste, but I'm sure they'd be happy to add them upon request. 

I didn't try the sushi, but the tuna behind the glass on the counter was the size of a log and the color of flipping-this-morning. I may never taste it. Who needs sushi when the noodles are so divine?!
author: Denise B.

description:
Why does bad things happen when you're tried?
So I just got out of work  and walking home when I past this place. Past it alot on my way home but a sushi craving hit me and I found myself going in.
I thought "ok, if i order togo, it shouldn't take long" and order the "American combo". a CA roll and some nigiri.
Ask them to make the CA a Philly and waitress said yes.
I sat  and waited 10:15pm. waited. waited. waited. ok now it is 10:25pm. saw the waitresses talk to themselves and motions .

She forgot to put in my order. Ok this happens I know but they didn't tell me.

sat and waited.waited. ok 10:30pm. I ask (wanting to see what she'll say) why is my order taking so long. She says "um, uh It's coming" 
this piss me off. I was watching the scene and know she forgot the order but yet she tries to play it off.

so I sat and waited. waited. 10:45pm Ok the second waitress comes over with the order and is about to leaving. I ask (wondering what she'll say) why did my order take so long. She explains that the other waitress forgot the order.

I walk out with a 12 piece combo that took half an hour to make and no apology.
Oh and just so you know it was not busy at all and my second time here. Last time was a while back and nothing memorable. 

So 2 stars. One for the late hours. Two for the decent price.
I was going to give it three till I open the box and they gave me a CA roll instead of Philly. I gave them half a hour and still they got the order wrong.
author: P.V. H.

description:
The food used to be somewhat decent here, but now it's gotta worst.
The last time I was here, I got diarrhea from eating their food.

This place is nothing special compare to ramen places in tokyo.

The new waitresses here are unfriendly also compare to before.  The place was almost empty and they seem to want to rush me out.
I got the check in the middle of eating still.  No greeting or thank you.

Update: in response to kiyomi's comment above about japanese customers and me, i've been living in tokyo for 6 years and speak fluent japanese.  But if you like going to restaurant that give japanese customers special treatment like kiyomi claims, then this is the place for you.  I stand by my earlier review, this is probably just one level better than instant ramen, but nothing special plus rude staff
author: Allan K.

description:
The ramen noodle soup alone is worth the trip there. Had the "rich miso" chicken karaage ramen. Best I've ever had.

P.S. really good for a hang over too!
author: Sal P.

description:
Granted parking isn't the best and the place is small but.... if you happen to be out shopping down in Union Square Katana-ya  is a definite must!  It is one of those small ambiguous "hole in the wall" restaurants but the food is good and reasonable in price. 

My friend and I stumbled upon Katana-Ya one day because we were so hungry .    I can't say that I'm an expert  food critic but the MISO RAMEN is perfect on a cold and rainy day in the City. The Soup and small dish combo on the back of the menu it hits the spot.  The sushi is just as good.  

AGH!! Now I'm craving it just writing about it.
author: Nerdy G.

description:
Katana-Ya is a small little place at Union Square with good ramen and pretty good sushi too. Better known for its ramen, I've been frequenting Katana-Ya for sometime. Each time, the ramen has been consistently  good along with the side dish. Usually some variety of donburi or a roll. 

The place itself is pretty small, so it can get crowded pretty fast. Its nothing fancy, but its good for what it is.  If you do go, keep a sharp eye out, Katana-Ya is pretty easy place to miss. My only gripe is occasionally the waitress staff isn't always on top of things. Even when its slow, they aren't always there for you when you need them. 

Overall, its a good place to grab lunch when you're at Union Square if you're in the mood for some Japanese and don't want to hop all the way to J-town or the pseudo Japanese restaurants in the malls.
author: Ivan M.

description:
I was not very impressed by their sushi. Prompt but unfriendly service. The place was very small and even though I'm not claustrophobic, I felt a little uncomfortable in there.  

Their dessert menu looked interesting. Typical Japanese stuff that I haven't seen in other Japanese restaurants in SF.
author: Mia D.

description:
A wonderful hole-in-the wall Japanese restaurant. I thoroughly enjoyed the sushi combination and a tako nigiri. Also, excellent service, and free hot tea!

The sushi chef was very nice and chatty. The Nigiri is extra large, definitely worthwhile. Was pretty full at lunch today but is usually packed when I walk home from work in the a.m.

Overall a great place.
author: Cortland T.

description:
even the possibility of waiting out in the cold for a seat in this place doesn't knock off any stars. it really is good.

the ramen is yummy and surprisingly the sushi is pretty damn good too.

only complaint is that its small so there is often a wait, this place is rarely with a table empty--but its justified.

open late too
author: Whitne Y.

description: I'm on a ramen kick right now so I ventured to Katana-Ya to see what all the hype is about. I ordered the fried chicken ramen miso broth extra spicy. It was GOOOD! They give you a lot of noodles with 3 pieces of fried chicken, seaweed and bamboo shoots. Very tasty. They have a lof of ramen varities here which was impressive to me - I will be back to try some more!
author: Julie F.

description: The place stunk of old fish and oil. The waitresses were rude. The ramen was not flavorful. And oh yeah...the place stunk of old fish and oil. I really do hope that this isn't the best SF has to offer in the way of ramen.
author: amara k.

description: Tiny little restaurant.  We made it there 15 minutes before lunch opening.  There were already a couple small groups waiting.  I had the Butter Corn Shoyu Ramen.  So yummy!  I do miss having a perfectly medium boiled egg in my ramen and maybe some seaweed slices to go on top.  I love the broth!  I also tried the katsu curry don, also very delicious.  Though, I would much rather have ramen.  I ordered a plate of gyoza, the filling was a little lacking.  I would like to have a little less air inside, if you know what I mean.  Overall, a good lunch spot.
author: Marilyn Y.

description:
I don't care if the place is small. I don't care if its crowded. I don't care if I have to wait a long time because it's SO worth it. This is probably one of my favorite places to eat right now, even if I have to make the trip all the way from Marin. My favorite is the butter corn ramen with fried chicken. Absolutely delish.

If the owners ever read this, PLEASE OPEN A KATANA-YA IN MARIN. Marin needs a place like this! You will not regret it.

Great sushi, too.
author: Shakti S.

description:
After moderate drinking.....Ramen always taste good!  Rich pork broth and yummy tender BBQ pork.....  So!  We decided to give a try this Ramen shop that I have been waiting to try.  A friend of mine told me there is always a long line so I was prepared to wait and that's a always good sign for a good food which is worth while waiting!!  We waited about 30 minutes and finally got a table for 4 for 5 of us.  I ordered regular ramen (seaweed, bamboo shoot, 1 slice of pork and green onion with choice of broth salt, shoyu or miso - pretty standard) and shared home made gyoza (4 pork pot stickers) and kimchee fried rice.
I had salt broth and it was pretty good although I regret that I did not ask for "rich" broth.  My husband had fried chicken ramen which I found surprisingly good!  The gyoza was very tasty (it came after ramen - was hoping to have it before ramen soup :D) and kimchee fried rice was spot on!!! I wish the noodle was not so over cooked and not so taste like store bought.  But overall, it was good!
author: Mika H.

description: It was kinda pricey for the neighborhood and other than the crowd not that great. No cheap beer. And the sushi got my lady extremely sick. Will not be going back. And this is in my neighborhood. I'd rather travel to sushi rock. Or pretty much anywhere else. The service was ok. I just didn't see the draw to this place.
author: John C.

description: We were seated relatively quickly for a Saturday night and got our drinks quickly. After reading reviews about the superiority of the ramen over all else, we decided to branch out. We started with the 49er roll, which was well executed and delicious. My friend ordered the favorite fried chicken ramen and I was delighted to find udon on the menu. Our bowls arrived and we agreed we enjoyed the udon better than the ramen. So, give it a shot. It is my new fav there.
author: Angela S.

description:
holy shittersticks the ramen broth is SO salty!!!!!   i was unaware there was a "light" option.  so make sure you get that or your entire body will go into shock w/ sodium overload and you will have puffy fingers from the sodium inbalance.

i came to katanaya as a visitor...coming from nyc where i hold ippudo in high regard as GOOD RAMEN.

now, katanaya might be considered good ramen in SF.  so don't get me wrong, sorry SF if this is your "best ramen".  but in the land of the ugly, the one eyed monster is king right?

if you order the fried chicken ramen, get the fried chicken on the side so it doesn't get all soggy in the broth.  no one likes soggy fried chicken.

we also ordered some appetizers.  all were cooked.  we ordered fried yellowtail.  fried tuna.  not bad but not spectacular either.

the prices are good though!!!  esp the ramen combos- those are good deals.  but would you sacrfice blood pressure from high sodium for a few bucks?
author: Betsey L.

description:
the good: their broth is certainly tasty and their variety is different kinds of ramen is pretty good. i myself got the katanaya ramen with salt broth. this included some fried potstickers, fried chicken, stewed pork, corn, and seaweed. noodles were done well. they are also open late so u can grab that late night quick bite of ramen goodness

the bad: this place is SMALL so the wait is kinda long if u have a big party. i just came with my friend and we were stuck on this tiny table right up against the wall.. not the most comfortable place to eat in. since its in the middle of downtown its better to not drive if u can avoid it. i was lucky enough to grab a spot right around the corner but that was after circling for about 30 mins. this place also has a lot of tourists so its almost always busy. btw MSG is added.. it says on the menu

would i come here again? sure i guess but only for special occasions
author: edward k.

description: So yummy! Got the traditional ramen in soy broth and added chicken and spicy-ness. So good! Also added some sriacha and was soo happy here! Thinking about going again before leaving San Fran.
author: Annie A.

description: The first time I ate at Katana-Ya about a year ago, I hated it. I don't remember what type of broth I chose, but it was very heavy and overpowering of the other flavors. I also got really sick after that. However, I had a very good lunch there today. I went with the noodle soup combination: your choice of a small bowl of ramen, udon, or soba, along with a small serving of any of their rice dishes for $11-13. I had the regular udon and tonkatsu don (pork cutlet). The udon was good, had lots of green onion, seaweed and tempura flakes. Good amount of noodles, not overcooked. The pork cutlet was hot and crispy, and drizzled with a sauce I really liked. It also had a little spring mix salad and dressing. I think I'll be getting this combo from now on!
author: S. D.

description: I thought it was okay, well good for San Francisco standards, but just okay for everywhere else.  I mean I really like Maru Ichi in Mountainview.  I think their broth is better and so are their side dishes.  I mean this place was okay for ramen, but I wasn't particularly impressed nor do I think I would go back for ramen.
author: Connie L.

description: When you're craving ramen, Katana Ya is where it's at. It's tasty, lots of options (even for vegetarians like moi!), big portions, and decent prices. It's exactly what you want on a chilly San Francisco evening. The only negative can be the wait time during the rush dinner hours, though I'd say it's worth it!
author: Shikha K.

description:
Decent food..I've had better ramen.  But I'll never go back because of the  horrible service and wait times.  

Wanted to grab a quick bite so I went down to Katana by myself.  Waited five minutes to put my name down and waited curbside.  I watched two couples came by and put their names down.  After about 20 mins, the waiter seats both parties.  WTF!!  Another couple gets their table after about 10 min.  Now I'm steaming.   

I ask the server how long it the wait will be.  Shrugged me off and told me not sure.  A few more small parties get seat then I gave up after an hour.   Should have cooked instead.

I understand you'll sell that extra bowl in that precious two-seater.  But really? After an hour of watching people who came after you eat, I promised myself I'll never go back again.
author: Ed Y.

description: Stopped by recently for another ramen visit. The noodles and broth were still delicious but there was only 1 thin slice of pork and 2 teeny bits of bamboo shoot in the broth and that was all the ingredient. The bowl was large but the soup and noodles did not fill the bowl. A bit pricy for so little food i think. Waitress was not too friendly. 2.5 stars this trip.
author: M Y.

description: Good ramen that should not be missed in San Fran! Although the line was an hour wait but was definitely worth it. The ramen set meal comes with a don that will make you full. Ramen itself was awesome, comparable to ramens sold in japan! Yum yum!
author: Ting Chieh L.

description: LOVE. Ditto to what everyone else has said. The wait is a bit brutal, but worth it, just take a walk around the block a couple times. It's a bit cramped inside, so good luck to you if you're in a party larger than 2. Otherwise, goooooooooood food. If you're feeling especially hungry, the sushi is ok, but the ramen and a large asahi is all you need.
author: Leslie G.

description: Tasty ramen noodles in pork stock, good katsu curry, decent sashimi and delicious fried rice. It's not first rate like Daikokuya in LA because I don't think it's nearly as consistent or quality in their delivery but it's a decent substitute and right in the heart of the city. Prepare to wait up to an hour after 7 pm. It's very cramped and you'll rub elbows with your neighbor, so it's somewhat of an authentic experience, too.
author: Y K.

description: I'm fairly new to the whole ramen thing, and noodles aren't always my first choice. But today, they were. Must be the weather. I ordered the katana-ya ramen (you get a little of everything) with soy broth. I normally cant finish a bowl of noodles, but before I knew it... the bowl was empty and my belly was full! Past meals here have been solid as well. I've had the green onion ramen and the katsu curry, which wasn't the best katsu curry I've had, but it wasn't bad either. All in all, katana-ya is fine by me!
author: Meredith K.

description: Hands down my favorite ramen place - I always get the Katana-Ya Ramen with Miso broth - Noodles are so important when it comes to ramen and this place has it down.  Their non-Ramen menu items are good too.  It's very hard to find good Uni - and this place has some of the best Uni I've come across - they give you a lot on each Nigiri.
author: Nin J.

description: Best fast japanese in san francisco
author: Nick M.

description: I hate to say it, but the ramen in Honolulu tends to be better than in San Francisco.  But this place is the best I've had since I moved back home.  Definitely worth the trip.
author: ryan g.

description: Excellent ramen shop. Really has a look and feel of something from Tampopo! Like taking a mini-vacation to the Old Country. I had the spicy green onion ramen in miso broth, with the Kurobuta sausage appetizer. Oishii !!
author: jim b.

description:
I thought this was the katana-ya that served the pork broth ramen that used to be on Parnassus.  It's not- don't be fooled.  This Katana-ya only serves miso, salt and soy sauce broth ramen.  The noodles were well-made, but the BBQ pork was salty.  

I am still searching for the elusive pork broth ramen.
author: michelle d.

description:
Everytime I come here, ther's always a couple of people waiting outside (esp. weekend!).
I tried Ramen with Chicken karage. They have 3 choice of soup for the ramen. I chose the salty one , it was deliciouss.........!!
I ate also kimuchi rice + salmon rice, it was fabulous!!
fabulous!! tried to drink the sake champagne pink it's really expensive $14 (but i like to try i don't care).
This place is one of my faves in japanese food!
The staffs r ok, no prob, just when i waited for the chek it was kind of long............
but anyway i would come back again..........YUMMMMM.......................
author: Ms C.

description:
This place takes the crown as my favorite ramen spot in SF.  Their broth is rich, delicately flavored, and filled with savory noodles.  Also, you can't beat their lunch combo of ramen and donburi. 

This place also has great ambiance.  It feels like I'm in a tiny tokyo sushi bar, but they could stand to squeeze a few more tables in the place.  When I'm craving a big steamy bowl of ramen, it's never fun to stand around waiting for a table...
author: Josh Z.

description:
Wait was long (not waiting to get in, but rather to get our food AFTER it was ordered).

However, the wait was worth it. Their lunch combo's are reasonably priced for Union Square area. Ramen very tasty, so be prepared to eat alot if you do the lunch combo's (about 10 bucks before Tax/Tip).

Would recommend for anyone looking for good "homestyle" japanese food if you're in the Union Square area!
author: Phil L.

description: i got a bowl of chasu ramen for dinner- service was fast and good and the food was out within a few minutes.  the soup wasn't quite as hot as i wouldve liked, but the bowl of ramen was solid- tender, flavorful meat, nicely textured noodles that definitely was not overcooked, and really tasty (though quite salty) broth.  i would come back here for ramen if i were around, but it definitely is nothing compared to the ramen at my favorite san mateo joints.
author: Lisa C.

description:
again prompted by the top 100 list, my bf and i decided to try the ramen at katana-ya.  we are picky about our ramen and admittedly harsh due to how much we miss the ramen in japan.

i got the shoyu regular ramen and curry rice.  the shoyu broth is reminiscent of a deep, flavorful broth that my grandma would make that tastes like it has been simmering for hours.  i am immediately surprised by the familiarity of the chinese taste.  the noodles are the perfect texture - not super soft and not undercooked.  the pork was reminiscent of chinese roast pork - a little more salty and dry than i prefer but it was still good.  the curry rice was unmemorable - typical golden curry flavor, although it was thinner than i'm used to.

bottom line: the broth passes the i wanna slurp up all of it, leaving no drop behind.  check it out, you won't be disappointed.
author: erika n.

description: This is my favorite ramen place in SF so far and one of the best I've had ever.  I recommend the Katanaya Ramen or the Mapo Ramen.  Their soy and miso bases are equally good.  The servers will typically recommend miso if in doubt.  Service is average and the place is small and cramped.  I typically go when they open at 11:30am Saturday mornings to avoid lines which soon follow.  I can't recommend their sushi as it seems very hit and miss.  Also, the prices are a bit on the high end.
author: June P.

description: HUGE rice bowls of tasty katsu. Too big, in fact. Get the udon noodles.
author: Rob T.

description: I stumbled upon this ramen house while just wandering around downtown one evening, and was pleasantly surprised. Their sushi was delicious, but the fried chicken ramen was exceptional. My party was lucky enough to get there when there wasn't a line, and while the place is cramped it's well worth it. I'm heading there for lunch today, and thought I should let people know that it lives up to the hype!
author: Adam A.

description: Great food-ramen & sushi rolls. Went on a friday evening, waited for almost 45 minutes though.
author: Mary Y.

description: Having had Kahoo in San Jose, I need to downgrade Katana-ya.
author: Seong P.

description:
whew! all these holiday cocktail parties and we needed some solid fast food.

the interior was tiny and we were seated next to the door but since i ordered the kimchi ramen and hot sake, i was already sweating away.

can't say that this was the best ramen in the city.

you could use a fork to pick up the balls of oil and fat in the broth but my alcohol filled stomach was in need of carbs so i probably ate more than i would normally have.

i have to say though that the agedashi tofu (lightly fried tofu) was very tasty.

for me to come back...the stars would have to be aligned with me being in the area late night, drunk, and cold.  something tells me this is highly likely.
author: Anh V.

description: This place is excellent! Be ready for a wait, though. Order the ramen, and remember your eyes are bigger than your stomach.
author: Eric M.

description:
my favorite ramen place in the us!

the msg level of the broth is perfect - always need to drink a gallon of water after eating here. their variations of ramen are extensive and unmatched, and they can accommodate non-meat eaters. i love their spicy tofu, kimchi, and veggies with fish broth, and my boyfriend likes the katana-ya ("everything") ramen. their sushi is good but nothing outstanding. they have a good selection of sakes; the few that we have tried were pretty good.

the decor and ambiance are authentic ramen shop.
author: huong n.

description: Phenomenal Kim-Chi fried rice and the fried chicken they put in the ramen tastes like something my grandmother would have made. So flavorful and rich. There's always a wait but it's worth it, not only for the food but the atmosphere as well. My favorite place to eat in the city.
author: K. H.

description: They have the best ramen! I got the katanya ramen here.. It was good! The only bad thing about this place is it's very little and when it's busy there's a long wait..
author: Shay C.

description: I went with a gf this weekend and decided to compare it to Ramen Dojo.  We both opted for the Katana-Ya miso ramen, and really liked it.  I dont know if i loved the idea of having fried chicken and fried gyoza floating around in my broth but everything in the ramen was delish. They give tons of noodles which was overwhelming, so next time we are asking for half the noodles.  My favorite dish was the agedash tofu app which was to-die for!  I can't wait to go back and try one of their donburi dishes.  Service was excellent!
author: Ruthie J.

description: Get the miso broth.  If you're following the 2010 100 things to eat list, the Chasu Ramen is the  pork.  Also, try the Katana Ya bowl (it's a little bit of everything).  All in all, very good ramen place, especially for the price.  Well worth it.
author: Jessica J.

description: I came here at the recommendation of the 7x7 list. It was very good Ramen, probably the second best in the city (next to Tanpopo near Japan town). I prefer Tanpopo as the quality of the Ramen is just as good and the prices and location are slightly better.
author: foodiewithadrawl S.

description: Had lunch here with a friend a little over a week ago. It's funny, I've always passed by this place on my way to my brother's apartment, but never stopped in for lunch. I figured it was a small place with limited seating since I would always see people standing outside. Well, it is a small place- only ten tables. So my friend and I were craving ramen after the movies and instead of trekking all the way to Japantown, she suggested this place. Good choice! =) I love ramen, especially when there isn't a lot of msg in it. You choose your own broth- miso, soy sauce, and....house broth (?). Then there are the different combo ramens to choose from. I decided on the fried chicken ramen with miso broth. Basically it was Karaage and ramen...and something else which I can't remember. I do remember though that is was delish!!! The ramen was chewy and tasted fresh. The fried chicken stayed crispy for the longest time...until I devoured it all...of course =). The broth was perfect and not bland or too salty. It was yumilicious! =)...yes, I made this word up! My friend had the house special (?), which is basically everything, but the kitchen sink and asked for kim chee with it.  I should've asked for kim chee with mine too, but I figured it might be too much. I just added the hot pepper which was good enough for me. One thing I was worried about eating ramen was the MSG. I get a bad reaction from MSG. Very bad headache and bloatedness....not good!! Thank God I didn't have any side effects after eating here, so either they don't add MSG or just very, very little! In any case, their ramen was good eats!!! =)...YUM!!!
author: Neni E.

description: 5-star food, good service, but just a liitle bit of cramped quarters for me. Otherwise, this place is 5 stars all the way!
author: Dean I.

description: Yummy ramen downtown, good lunch specials. Tiny little hole-in-the-wall place. Very cool.
author: T H.

description:
i haven't tried many ramen places, but this place is definitely the best so far. 
the wait is pretty long and a friend's curry dish order was delivered after he asked about it. by the time he got it, 4/6 of us were already done with our meal.
author: Kenneth H.

description: Downgrading as I've been here a few times and I'm seeing a steady decline in the quality of the sushi here.  What is it with San Francisco and sushi, anyway?  I've found one place so far that serves good stuff.  The ramen is still quite good, the service is still a little off, but it's a decent hole in the wall type place.
author: Scott S.

description: Often, when you visit a restaurant few live up to the expectations and the hype. Katana-Ya is definitely not among those. The ramen was delicious. I will definitely come back.
author: Ignacio A.

description: We tried Katana-Ya on the suggestion of a friend, and at first I was a little sketched out. It's a tiny place, so I wouldn't go with more than 4 people. The location is a little troublesome (you will be hit up for change while you wait for a table to open - both are inevitable), but the food is worth it. The sushi was amazing, and the ramen made me a believer.
author: Jessica V.

description: I'm obsessed with ramen and this was recommended by my cousin. Went at 4pm on a Sunday and was seated immediately. I had read there were longs waits and was glad we arrived during an off time. We both ordered the fried chicken ramen with miso broth (thanks yelpers for the recommendation) and the crispy tuna roll. The tuna roll was a sushi roll with no rice, fried in a tempura batter and served on top of salad greens with a mayo dressing. It was okay but I was saving my appetite for the main meal. The soup came out in 10 minutes and it was heaven. The broth was warm and flavorful, the chicken was tender but crunchy and the noodles were a perfect al dente. It was everything I wanted and more! I'm actually wishing I had some right now! P.S. Service is all right. They aren't rude, just busy.
author: gail c.

description:
This has to be one of the most authentic Ramen houses in San Francisco.
It has been around for a long long time. It is well supported as most really good neighborhood joints usually are.
I mean think about it, you leave a club comedy, theater or dance take your pick and the hunger pangs kick in. Where do you go at 11:00 at night? 
The location is kind of tough to find parking being Union Square and such, but is well worth it. Go park in am all night garage and walk a few blocks for crying out loud.
Great  menu and unlike traditional Ramen joints, this place has both udon and ramen, and their udon and unagi combos were good.
Located a couple of blocks from Union Square, they serve generous portions of sushi which is surpisingly pretty fresh as well as serving Sapporo and Negori sake.
Fair warning, this place is super small and can get very congested.
You have to check out this place.
author: Charlie C.

description:
My boyfriend and I was in the city and we were originally going to eat at the King of Thai but stumble two doors down to this Japanese resturant that seem to be very packed.  We walked in and check waiting time and was told that it might be 5 minutes.  There's a guest sign in sheet on the left of the shelf as you open the door to the resturant.    You have to sign in by yourself to get seated.  

We waited for about 3 mins which seemed pretty good.  

The services was good and fast.  Although they forgot to place my Salmon Don,  I'm not complaining because we always over order.  I just cancelled the order at the end and they weren't upset.  Sometimes, resturant gets upset when you cancel an order even when they forgot.
The Salmon shisimi was very fresh.  That's our favorite.  We order a slice pork Don and it was really good.  The sauce they used was so good and all the slivered onions mixed it was so delicious.  Resonable price - even during dinner time.    

I would recommended for anyone shopping around Union square looking for a great japanese place that is not overpiced.  

They do have a large selection of Ramen and Dons when compare to other Japanese resturants.
author: Jenny L.

description:
For authentic Japanese ramen, this is it! You can tell they are serious about it. The broth is so delicate, yet flavorful it is made with care. The noodle is perfect (texture and size). The toppings are tasty and hearty. Pair it with a bottle of Kirin or Sapporo or simply a cup of steamy Ocha. And if you're lucky, enjoyed it on a foggy/rainy/cool San Francisco day.

Pepper Sichimi Togarashi liberally to escalate the experience and bring some patient coming in, because the place is small and the wait is long. Personal fav: Spicy Negi Ramen/Light Soy Broth
author: imdan a.

description:
good ramen. okay service.

came here with the bf yesterday. it was a monday so you'd think that it wouldn't be too busy..but it was. just a little.. we only had to wait 15 mins for a table, but other yelpers are right..this is a small place.

i had the katanaya ramen (i think..its the one with everything in it) and the bf had curry katsu over rice. and we shared a fried calamari, overall we thought it was good food.  

only thing that kind of bugged was that it took about 5 minutes before 
we could get menus and then it took a little while for us to get someone to order for us.  then we ate..not once did anyone ask how we were doing or refill our tea/water/soda. then they brought us the bill with the obligatory "take your time."  then when we paid (we were still eating) they took the money and just assumed that the change was tip. 

i guess it was busy so i could forgive them for their inattentive-ness to assume that the change is yours to keep is no good.
author: Elaine G.

description: Great ramen - the broth and noodles are flavorful and delicious.  The sushi is fine, but the ramen is the standout.
author: Melinda C.

description: The ramen was pretty good, but maybe a little pricey. Worth it, but not a bargain.
author: Ben C.

description: got the katanaya shio ramen. broth was okay, light and not that rich, noodles were aight too. plus points for it being loaded with stuff because we were getting ready to go out drinking after so needed something filling.
author: Phuc B.

description: I was spawned on ramen after watching a movie with the late brittany murphy. So i went with my best friend. we saw other reviews and decided, Why not? Well it was great we got their signature ramen. and i moaned and ooh at the various items. I am still talking about it months ago. I am in love and it's summer and i will sweat out my chills weekly even during a heat wave.. Fried chicken in ramen... is like death by chocolate!
author: Maiku B.

description: This place should be a solid 3-star, no more no less. But since they are way overrated now, i am giving them a 1 star hoping to getting back down so other yelpers won't be misled.
author: Oyster K.

description: Can't believe I have not been here before! Perfect place to stop after a long afternoon of holiday shopping. Had the fried chicken in miso and it was heavenly. Also has the tofu appy that was great. Would love to go back for dinner and sample some rolls. Great way to warm your tummy and best ramen I have ever had!
author: Katie M.

description: People really rave about this place but i think its not THAT GOOD granted it is one of the best in the city. I think the thing that makes it stand out is that their ramen bowls are LOADED. Again this is a place that has quite a large menu to satisfy your every craving. I am leaning more towards 3.5 because getting a seat here is HARD, lines are long you pretty much just got to be lucky. We came when the line was gone but as we sat down the line exploded! Anyways I do recommend coming here, just expect a wait Order the katanaya ramen bowl, it has EVERYTHING!!!!
author: Dang L.

description: I heart Ramen noodle soup in Hawaii, and I couldn't find any place in the bay area that could compare to it until i tried Katana-ya.. WoWW, I finally found it. Katana-ya is not only good at their Ramen soup but also most of everything on their menu. I couldn't have enough so i bought it to go. And I can't wait to come back again..
author: Christy N.

description: What the heck have I been eating! This place has ruined me for all other ramen. I had the regular ramen with miso served extra spicey. It came with the most delicious hell broth. And the noodles were perfect. The place is tiny, but I loved the atmosphere.
author: Milan R.

description: 3 stars for the Venue but 4 stars for their fried chicken ramen. I have been meaning to coming here for awhile, but every time I walk by there is always a long line so i never wanted to go in and wait because those who know me know I  HATE WAITING. i am the most impatient person ever. Late one night my friends and I were walking around the area and since we were bored we decided to eat granted it would be our fourth meal. i know fatties. ooh so lets say the fried chicken ramen was oh so tasty. bf was hesistant but when he tried it, he loved it. we all drank so some soju and called it a night. ps if you go to katana-ya please try their fried chicken ramen
author: bella h.

description: This was my first time at an official ramen place. Judging by all the great reveiws, it seems like it must be the best ramen ever. If that is the case i guess i just HATE it. I thought the food was disgusting and the service sucked. I do not understand what the allure is. Anytime ive gone somewhere & hated it, i will at least try it once more before i write it off, but not here. I guess the only ramen I'll ever eat again is insant.
author: Sarah L.

description: I am  very full on ramen as I write this. Very full! Very satisfied, but so very full. I think I should not have gotten the maguro don combo. I think it sent me over the edge, because once I started eating I couldn't stop. This place does a mean ramen. One that will have you rolling home like Violet Beauregarde if you are not careful. I think I might explode.
author: Drue C.

description:
whoa?!?!?!?!

yes

so last time i went. the broth was a bowl of misoy warm water with a film of oil on top. the noddles were mush. 

i did notice all the new specials, which were great, but ramen is there thing no? thats why you come here!

*waiting to go again*
author: Euge L.

description:
The ramen broth here makes me high.  I feel so good and I want to hug my delightful giant bowl of shoyu ramen. I can conquer anything. I could climb mountains. I can get over every man that's done me wrong, my parent's guilt tripping and my fear of failure as well as fear of success. I could gain direction in my life and stop wandering aimlessly and I could stop looking for self worth through excessive drinking, social networking sites and one night stands. I could be anything I wanted to be, as long as I could continue slurping this absolutely amazing broth. I seriously wanted to dump the noodles (even though they were awesome) and go straight to MORE BROTH and more pork.  I even disregarded the staff's bantering in Japanese, which usually makes me uncomfortable (for sure they are talking about some faux pas I am commiting that I am not aware of) but the ramen was so good they could talk major smack about me in every language on the planet, I didn't care. Just give me more broth. Please.   

(SHOYU is the ramen broth to get here, the shio/salty broth was good, but the shoyu is the shining star. Defenitely get the home made gyoza & outstandingly tender chicken kaarage. If you're not a sucker, you will get the combo, where you get the same amount of ramen plus a little something something on the side. I usually get the the katsu don and it is pretty good. )
author: Maria D.

description: The regular udon is WONDERFUL!  Kurobota sausages are one of the special items right now (such savory and sweet porkyness, served with some salad greens and mustard!) so... get it while it lasts!  Their take-out containers are microwaveable too---HECKA USEFUL!
author: Grace M.

description: After some good reviews, I was excited after visiting union square.  The restaurant is a dive but I wasn't here for the ambiance.  Well, I had the regular miso ramen and was sorely disappointed.  It is average at best.  It lacked green onions and didn't taste fresh enough for my palate.  There are better ramen places out there.
author: Kelley N.

description: Nice little spot with affordable prices and tasty food. I had the regular shoyu ramen and it was pretty nice and plenty of food for me. It was tasty, and I would go back if I was craving ramen and I was in Union Square, but I would rather go to Ryowa in Mountain View if I really really needed to eat ramen.
author: Reese W.

description: For all the great reviews this place gets, I was disappointed with the actual result.  It's very average ramen, and not much of a selection (they have plenty of other stuff though).  Three broth flavors, and a list of different things you can have them throw in there, all around 9-12$.  The noodles were too chewy, and the basic ramen is very basic - just noodles, scallions, seaweed and one piece of pork.  Meh.
author: Stephen D.

description: The spicy tofu miso ramen was so deliciously hot and slurpy on a cold winter day of brutal xmas shopping.  I was down on my luck with the shoving and the indecision, so such a giant bowl of warm hearty refueling was much needed, and very helpful. I went on to conquer xmas with style.
author: Liz S.

description: Probably the best ramen I've had in the city thus far. Had the shoyu ramen.  Also ordered an uni chirashi which they forgot to bring so I can't review their sushi.  I would almost give 5 stars for the ramen but it's pretty pricey and the amount of cha su is pretty skimpy.  I prefer this place to Santa  Ramen in San Mateo.
author: Amina B.

description: Love this place!  Best ramen I think I've ever had.  I typically get the kimchee ramen...request an egg in it, you will be glad you did!  I've had the sushi before too which was also very good, but I can't come here and not order the ramen.  The place is pretty small and usually there is a line out the door.  Worth the wait though!
author: Lesley W.

description:
sooooo goooooooooood....sooooooo goooooooood...i lub ramen... *droool*

bbq pork ramen~
fried chicken ramen~ sounds kind of funny but the chicken was yummy...

Finally a ramen place I can give 5 stars to. Yes finding parking can suck, Yes there can be a wait, Yes the place is small and someones butt might hit your elbow while eating but it was just soo good...

and the waitress was nice and funny~ ^_________^
author: phillip w.

description: I've been here many times, and all the other ramen places I've been to just pale in comparison. It's so good that you kind of forget you're being stuffed into a really tiny hole in the wall. At the same time, I don't really mind it because I like feeling kind of badass. I've had the regular ramen, green onion ramen, spicy tofu ramen, katana-ya ramen; each time just gets better.
author: Alex Y.

description: Not only does Katana-Ya have the best ramen in the city, they have the best agedashi tofu!  I'm a faithful fan of the corn butter ramen.  Plus, they serve butterfish sashimi!  They open for lunch, dinner and late night dining (but make sure you arrive by 1:15 AM).
author: Kimberly J.

description:
NOT FAMILY FRIENDLY!!! BEWARE!!!!  

A star only because YELP wouldn't except NO STARS!

**** WHO DOESN'T HAVE HIGH CHAIRS?! ****

We really wanted some good Ramen and after Yelping decided to travel from So. SF via BART w/ our 15 month old to Katana-ya. NOT ONLY WERE THEY RUDE, but they aren't prepared for a family of 3, 2 adults and 1 small child. SO DON'T even think about dining here if you have a child that can not sit in a regular seat. 

* MIND U, we normally bring our own chair for our child, but seeing as though we ventured out and used public transportation....carrying our own seat just wasn't possible.

Let's just say....in this economy you should take all the business you can get, and if that means investing in a highchair so families can dine at your restaurant, well then you probably should.

We simply walked out while diners looked on with astonishment....to the CHEESCAKE FACTORY and enjoyed a family dinner.
author: ER RN X.

description: I have been wanting to eat here for the longest time. I finally got some take out and ordered ramen with chicken katsu. Now I am not a wuss when it comes to spice but was seriously frightened to see the molten lava they called soup. It was dark rich red quite reminiscent of hot oil. I dove in and it took my taste buds on a journey far far away where the angels rejoice and sing. YUM!
author: Sophia C.

description:
We finally got to eat at this place. 

We ordered a regular ramen which was very disappointing. There was plenty of noodle but only one slice of pork and fewer than expected bamboo shoot and spring onions.  

The California rolls were warm and not even. Some pieces were small and others were big. Japanese food is all about balance and perfection. This roll seemed rushed. Furthermore, we were not given small plates so we had to eat using our napkins as our plates. 

The spicy seafood rice bowl was nice. The rice was nice and so was the tuna and salmon. My only criticism is that on the picture they had fish eggs on top and mine did not. 

The service was also disappointing. I appreciate that this place gets really busy but showing some courtesy goes a long way. 

This place is over rated and needs to go back to its roots to reflect.
author: Benjamin L.

description: The ramen noodle itself was well cooked. The broth was so-so. The wait was long, so if you go be prepare to wait. Definitely not good for group dinning. The sushi is decent but I would stick with the ramen.
author: Vinh T.

description: Best ramen place I tried in the city been craving it since the first  time I was here
author: Sandy L.

description: Most people will tell you about their fantastic ramen... But their sushi is super fresh as well!  I love the shiro maguro tataki, it comes with a bed of greens which makes it a nice salad appetizer. I also love their spider roll, gyoza... pretty much anything.  The service is quick and the food comes fast! The restaurant is small... But any squishing you do is well worth it! :)
author: Stacy S.

description: Got the regular ramen with miso and asked for it spicy. It was not very spicy and lacked toppings, it was mainly noodles.  Nonetheless it was still delicious as I love soup noodles.  The broth was a salty and left me yearning for water all night.  Next time I will ask for light miso.
author: Skye W.

description: I love this place! I love their ramen! The Tsukemen is the best! the sushi? hmmmm...not bad. The servers are nice and the sushi chef, too. I eat here at least once a week.
author: E-lie P.

description: I got the Katana Ya Miso Soup.  It was pretty good.  Nothing all that great but pretty good.  The bill came to 16.00 for a bowl of soup.  Seemed expensive for one person and a bowl of soup.  The places around this place are much more expensive though.
author: Shawn L.

description: The ramen was a little disappointing after seeing the ratings/reviews on here. Soup (I had the miso) was good, noodles and other bits and pieces were very average. The noodles were not cooked well, the meat was straight out of a plastic wrapped sandwich meat pack (or so it tasted - that dry tasteless sandwich pork). Wouldn't queue up for it again.
author: David P.

description: I am on a constant search for good ramen and always try to find the best in any town I visit. I read amazing reviews on here and was not disappointed! I had the Katanaya ramen, extra spicy..it was perfection. The noodles were super fresh and the miso broth not greasy or too heavy. The dumplings and fried chicken in there were delicious as well. The wait was not bad when I visited, around 7pm on a weeknight..no longer than 15 minutes. But would definitely wait an hour for it!
author: Sue C.

description: I really wanted to like this place, especially after reading all of those great reviews but the light shoyu ramen was forgettable. Nothing struck me as above average from the noodles to the broth.
author: Cate D.

description: Great ramen. I'd say best in SF, but I haven't tried everywhere (or have I? There is a severe dearth of ramen in this city). My standard is BBQ pork with Miso broth. The agedashi tofu and gyoza are good. The wait can be painful though. Having a sushi bar is kind of weird too.
author: Derek B.

description:
Eager for some piping hot ramen after a period of hiatus, we decided to check out Katana Ya before hitting the shops.  As far as ramen goes, it wasn't bad - it's all that you can expect of a ramen place (long and narrow room cramped with little tables and stiff-backed chair).  Yet, it would take more convincing for me to give it the four star rating this place has averaged at.   

Can't complain about the price - $10 gets you a bowl of ramen (with three choices of soup base - soy, salt, or miso) and a small bowl of fried rice.  

People with high blood pressure might want to think twice before coming here - both the fried rice and the soy ramen are on the salty side.  

And yes, I would come back.  Partly because of the lack of other good quality, cheap eats alternatives around the Union Square vicinity (Lori's diner? seriously!)
author: Ange L.

description: maybe I'm bitter because this used to be my go-to spot three years ago whenever I was shopping around union square and I'd get that unsuccessful shopper's drowsy, and some steaming noodles in broth sounded just perfect.  maybe yesterday the chef was on vacay and all they had left was frozen stock. either way, I went in yesterday for some massive disappointment. everything looks the same, the neon decor, the heavily accented servers, the upbeat music, and even the menu. but when I ordered my usual, the regular shoyu (soy sauce) ramen, i was surprised to find my broth painfully thin, like super light chicken broth with a touch of soy sauce flavor. I won't complain about the noodles--they were fine--but ONE single millimeter-sliced slice of meat?? really? most places at least give two, even the cheap skimpy ones. other than that, the bowl included some lazily cut (it was still one giant tattered piece) of wakame, and some really strong tasting (like fresh from a can) bamboo shoots. and not a lot of them, either! I was very bummed. so bummed, I thought maybe ordering an egg to put in it would help. and guess what! it really didn't. the eggs here are completely boiled through and look like either the person who peeled them was really poor at peeling, or they purposely carved down my egg for something else. I had the combo deal with the salmon don too, jumping my total from nine something to fifteen dollars, ish? nottttt that worth it. wasn't bad, but wasn't remarkable either. on that note, I have paid my last visit to katana-ya.
author: Alice L.

description:
Best ramen in SF. The best ramen in hhe US is in New York, but this is pretty close. It's the closest to Japan you can get in the city. 

My usually is the miso light with kimchee. If it's your first time, try the soy light Katana. If you're not used to Japanese ramen, it can be a little salty. But oh so good.
author: Chanh N.

description: This place has really good ramen at very reasonable prices. I love it when ramen joints have ramen combos, because sometimes a bowl of ramen just isn't enough satisfaction. I always get the miso ramen with either the bowl of kimchi fried rice or the curry chicken over rice. It definitely hits the spot. One bad thing is the size of this place -- it can only seat like 20 people and there's always a huge wait. It's so crowded that when i'm eating, people's asses are always knocking over my drink when they're trying to get through. Maybe they just have big asses, I dunno.
author: Roy C.

description:
i went to katana-ya for lunch with a few of my friends, and we ordered a sh*t-ton of food: two bowls of ramen (soy sauce stock), curry rice, nigiri, seaweed salad, and sunset, dragon, and salmon rolls. 

the ramen here is definitely better than both ryowa and maru-ichi (both in Mountain View), and is a big reason why I'm giving this place 4 stars. the noodle is chewier, the stock more flavorful, the meat thicker (why'd they only give me one piece though?). 
as for the rest of what we ordered, the curry rice and seaweed salad were both alright, but i don't think the sushi here is that great. the fish doesn't taste that fresh, and the rolls are kind of sloppy. not TIGHT the way i like it.

i imagine this place would be a bomb late night spot, though.
author: Shirley H.

description:
More like 3.5 stars. The Sapporo on tap was a good touch, the chicken karage is very tastey (squeeze some lemon on them) and the ramen portion was just right.

Maybe bc I love cheap Korean ramen or because I'm not used to paying so much money for noodles but I just can't love this place as most do. 

I guess I'm just not a high quality ramen kind of guy. Wait time on a Friday night at 915pm was around 20-30 min and it was kind of raining. Would probably come back if I had a friend asking bout a good ramen spot but I wouldn't do so otherwise.
author: Eddie L.

description:
i LOVE ramen.  and to be able to get authentic ramen in union squre out of all places at a fairly reasonable price is awesome.

i came here on a sunday late afternoon around 5ish to have an early dinner before watching rent and had to wait about 15-20 mins.  the place is tiny and ghetto looking but i'm not on a romantic date or taking a client out so i could careless.

i'm giving it 4 star for:
1. convenient location - just a very short walk from all the shopping in union square, AND right across the street from the curran theater!!

2. menu - other than ramen, it has quite a lot of other selections to choose from such as rolls, rice dishes, and plenty of appetizers.  

3. food - 
a. chasu ramen with (light) salt broth: great ramen texture, good broth (still a bit greasy), and very well cooked tender pork, 
b. katana ya ramen with (light) miso broth: the fried chicken was surprising excellent in the ramen, and i like how you get a little bit of everything in it. 
c. hamachi kama: i was really surprised to see that it was fried.  it wasn't something that i was crazy about but it was tasty.  

as i came out of the theatre, i was tempted to go back for 2nds since the place is open 'till 1am or something. haha.  

overall, i can't say that this will be a place i will make sure to visit when i'm back in town, but i can see myself coming in for a quick ramen fix in the cold winter days while shopping in the area.
author: Cari H.

description:
I have never been a big fan of Japanese food and Ramen in general but this place has really good ramen!! and my Japanese friend suggested that it is one of the best she's ever tried in the East Bay.

The only reason why I don't give this place 5 stars is because it is so tiny and cramped... I went with 3 other people and we barely had room to fit our bowls and plates on the table... It also felt like our neighbors were eating on our table as we were so close to each other... But I guess some will argue that it is part of the experience.
author: Vincent S.

description: They should rename this joint to Katana-Hell-Ya....located about a block from Union Square and its nice and warm inside...if you're walking in there late at night and forgot your jacket....I had been drinking and I was starving....trying to go through the menu was beyond me....everyone kept recommending the Spicy Tofu Miso but I wanted some meat and opted for the chicken karaage soup...the bowl was huge....the broth was delicious....I ended up burning my mouth .... after devouring the soup I started eying some spicy tofu and scored....let me tell you: chicken karaage was a bad choice....I should have gone with the spicy anything...next time! And this place is open late!
author: Summit S.

description: I love going here for ramen. i've had ramen at a few other places in the city that some claim are better than Katana-Ya, and i do not agree. I have not had better ramen anywhere else. the fried chicken is really awesome. my favorite lately has been kimchee ramen add fried chicken. so good. i also recommend the katana-ya ramen and spicy tofu ramen. with soy broth. anyway, this place gets 5 stars until i find a better place, although i really doubt i will. they also have monk fish liver sushi which is yummy.
author: Geoff B.

description:
I had to check my debit card transactions online to figure out the name of this restaurant. To me, its just that little Japanese place with no ceiling that saved me from having to continue to take my lunch breaks at Quizno's. Prices are reasonable, good Katsu Curry, not-bad at-all maki, great noodles, big, if not artful, slabs o' sashimi. Yum. Basically, Katana-Ya's menu is one of Japanese comfort foods.
All of this would probably have earned only three stars (OK, I'm star-stingy), but add one for kick-ass accommodating service. One afternoon I asked that waitress if they'd ever consider putting gindara on the menu (gindara is izumi tai marinated for a couple of days in miso). She was surprised that I was familiar with it but said that it would be a good thing for them to consider. Next time I went in, the same waitress was there and guess what was on special? Mmmmm, nicely prepared gindara. This is definitely a great little sushi bar and noodle shop.
author: Daniel W.

description: waitress rushed me while i was taking my order, got my order wrong then yelled at me for it, i walked out
author: James C.

description: I got a Katana ramen it was pretty good and the price is good. the parking is not good but the wartiess is very nice. they are real Japanese people serving Japanese food.
author: Li L.

description:
plane lands at 10:30p and i'm hungry.  it's chilly and damp outside, and i get a craving for a big bowl of hot, slurpy, spicy, noodles.  i head straight to katana-ya.

ramen hits the spot exactly.  you can pick your soup base, rich or light, and the ingredients. it's comes out quickly and is delicious.  the place is tiny and you put your name on the list outside as you arrive. expect to become cozy with your neighbors whether you're at a table or at the sushi bar. (surprisingly good sushi here too!)

open til 1:15a (they;re closing a bit earlier than they used to!).
author: Dora F.

description: Mmmm we were craving ramen before going to the theatre across the street so we went to katana-ya.  You write your name down on the board located outside the door and the waitress calls your name once they have a table. the place is tiny, maybe sits 30- 40 ppl max in a cramped place. Their ramen is worth it though! Mmmm!!  You choose the type of ramen you want, and choose broth type.  Get light miso broth. It's already so flavorful, i think rich broth will be too strong/nauseating. We got a couple of rolls along with ramen which were good too, but their ramen is just amazing.
author: Jen K.

description: Yelp once again did not disappoint. A friend and I had the corn and butter ramen, butter fish and seared albacore nigiri, and spicy scallop roll. EVERYTHING was amazing. The nigiri pieces were larger than average and at a really reasonable price of $5/2pcs. I know at least it's good prices compared to LA sushi joints but I haven't been to enough sushi restaurants in SF to compare. Definitely get both the ramen and sushi. It's a small place and there's a wait even on a weekday night so be prepared to wait about 20-30minutes if you go during prime time (6-7:30).
author: Cathy Z.

description:
TINY.  And easy to miss on the visually painful & cluttered section of Geary. It's directly across from the Curran Theatre, smushed next to Colibri's.  
It was all about the Ramen tonite - one of those freakin' WINDY San Francisco evenings. You could be walking along just fine, then hit a wind tunnel and OH MY !#@$&*! GAWD IT'S !@#*% COLD!
Ramen being ramen, it's nothing mind-blowing, but I thought Katana-Ya has the best noodles I've had in my limited experience.  Their ramen's a smidgen thicker than at Tanpopo's or Genki, and quite flavorful all on its own.  I was kinda disappointed at their small selection of 5 or so ramen soup options, though their menu was packed with many other bento stuff, cooked apps and sushi.   I'd like to come back and try their other broth options of miso & salt.  While I thought my soy broth, light version, was already pretty oily and flavorful, my companions didn't think it was salty enough and poured, POURED more soy in! Wow.  
Contrary to it's description - the fried tuna app is a salad, with some tempura battered tuna pieces.  Gyoza was pretty good, too, more cabbage than meat, but tasty.
Service wasn't bad, but wasn't stellar either. Prices - ehh - on the high side for ramen.
In the end, our apps were gone, and my ramen bowl COMPLETELY emptied, and I'd regained some of my core body temperature.  
3.5 Stars

Update 5/29 - gotta bump them up to 4 stars for being open late on a Tues night, when most other downtown spots are closing down and leaving me starving after a long-ass 13hr day at the office.
author: CINDY K.

description:
Disappointing.  OK, the broth (I got miso) was genuinely excellent.  Hot, rich, not too salty.  Despite being miso it wasn't overwhelmingly fishy because it was (I think) a pork-based broth.  I tend to find things that tasty fishy that arent fish a little fishy  I don't like bonito flakes, for example.  Since they (sometimes) use bonito flakes to make miso, you might think that me ordering the miso broth in the first place is a little fishy itself, but I digress.

So anyway, the broth was good.  That's a good start.  If only the noodles didn't fuck it up.  (I bet the broth is pretty pissed right now.)  I'm willing to cut the noodles some slack though since I think it's mainly personal taste.  I like mine a little thicker and more QQ, as the chinese would say, which  am totally justified in using to describe this Japanese place since they call their bbq pork "cha siu"...so there.  It's not that they weren't chewy or properly prepared, but just they were pretty thin so there wasn't much bite to the texture.

My main complaint?  No kakuni (stewed pork)! Kakuni is without a doubt the best thing you can put in ramen.  It's genuinely a hard decision for me whether I'd rather have ramen without noodles or ramen without kakuni.  For those not paying attention, btw, ramen == noodles == delicious == mr pibb + red vines - crazy. 

In case you've never eaten ramen before, let me describe the process for you.  They hand you a bowl with some yellow broth in it.  There's probably some stuff on top of the broth.  Steam is drifting into your face.  If you're in Japan there might be a separate bowl of noodles, but otherwise the noodles are probably already in the bowl.  So you take your chopsticks and you're like GIVE ME FOOD and you stuff some noodles into your face.  And you're like "yum, comfort food".  Then you're like "me man.  me eat meat.  me grow strong like bull" and you go in for the roast pork.  You eat the pork and you feel your body breaking down the protein and building your massive muscles.  Then you're like "me man.  me eat MORE meat" and you see the stewed pork in your bowl.  You eat the stewed pork.  Then you think "holy shit, that roast pork pork was tough as fuck compared to these tender, delicious, wonderful, perfect, beautiful, amazing stewed pork".  Then there's a lot more eating, some love making to the stewed pork, and some sipping of the broth to make sure you don't finish too quickly.

So you see, when you take away the kakuni from ramen, it's sort of like hanging out with your girlfriend but taking away the part where you have sex.  And it's like, even if your girlfriend is smart and funny and you like everything about her, are you really going to stay with her when you could just go find another one and get laid every time you wanted?

No. you're not.  You're going to get your kakuni.  Even if you have to pay a little extra.

P.S. No, I'm not a shallow bastard, but I didn't say what I would do in that situation.  I said that's what *you* would do, you sexist pig.
author: Jack S.

description: i love their spicy green onion ramen
author: Tobi X.

description: The ramen here is pretty good, but the wait is way too long.
author: Andrew H.

description: I love this place. Best tempura udon in the city! The lunch special where you get your choice of ramen plus your choice of donburi is very reasonably priced and quite good. I love their spicy tuna roll and salmon sashimi, and it's great that they're open so late. Service can be a little slow, but it's very much worth waiting.
author: Jane P.

description: Fan-bloody-tastic ramen. Better than similarly-priced ramen I've had in NYC.
author: Adam K.

description:
A friend of mine visiting from Asia took me to her favorite restaurant in the city, Katana-ya. I thought it was funny she had flown thousands of miles, was here for a limited time, and really wanted ramen. Seemed kind of like Gilligan eating coconuts once he was back in civilization.

When we arrived, the place was packed with quite the assortment of noodle eaters. There were couples at tables, a couple of larger groups, and of course the ubiquitous loner eating a bowl of noodles while reading a graphic novel. 

It took about 10 minutes to be seated and after that service was friendly and attentive. I would have preferred if they believed me when I said I wanted the spicy noodle, but hey, I'm white, I get that a lot. 

The ramen ended up being delicious and the two sushi rolls we tried were good too. If I lived in the area, I would be a regular.
author: Matthew C.

description: Tasty ramen, but I wouldn't wait in a long line for it.  Got the miso broth - good, with the ramen with tons of toppings - which were good, but I would have liked fewer toppings just as well.
author: L K.

description:
my friend and i went there around 9pm on a Monday night and it was packed with people. i guess it's always a good thing to see a restaurant full of people. 

we ordered several different kinds of rolls. the sushi was fresh and made very well. nothing too special or out of the ordinary. decent for a late night dinner. clean and super friendly servers. 

the only thing i didn't like was that we were seated by the restroom. kind of unappetizing, but they were busy and it was just the two of us. 

im sure there are better japanese restaurants in union square but this one was the closest to our hotel. AND we were starving.
author: Sharon O.

description: The broth was delicious (perfect balance of flavor with minimal oil), the chashu was cooked until the meat was tender, and I left with a feeling of extreme satisfaction. This place is second to Shoki Ramen House in Sacramento, but it's still extremely excellent if you're in the city! They could learn a few things from Shoki Ramen House, though.
author: Alexander M.

description: The first meal I've had in the bay in years and what happens? Yelp reviews have sadly lead me astray. I don't know if this place is good by SF standards, but the food was mediocre at best. many of the flavors were off and the food was not harmonious. In short, 15 short minutes after eating, no longer is there a taste lingering at the tip of my tongue, no longer do i remember the full flavors of the meal I had just consumed, long story short, there is better out there.
author: Jeff V.

description: If you are hungry and have a ten spot burning a hole in your pocket, then this place is a great deal. For $9.95, you can get a soup and donburi combo that will not leave you hungry for much longer. The bowl of either ramen, udon or soba noodles (your choice) is large enough for a meal by itself, yet it still comes with a nice medium sized rice bowl with your choice of toppings on the side. They also have a good selection of entrees or soups by themselves, along with sushi that didn't look too bad.  It's a bit of a hike from the office for me, but I'd say it's worth it for a good bowl of miso ramen at lunchtime.
author: Tom H.

description: Finally! After g r a c e m.'s tasty ROTD I had to try this place. My friends have been looking for a good ramen place for some time and we were finally able to come to this little place and eat non-instant-noodles. It's been said before but I want to reiterate, this isn't the fake ramen you find at the grocery store, but it is the closest thing to real ramen here in SF. This place is a little far from my work to take a lunch break, but I come here when my boss isn't in and I can afford to take a long lunch. Oh man, the ramen here hits the spot every time. The sushi is good too, but the ramen here is the star of this place... and maybe the owl drawing in the back.
author: LM M.

description:
okay...
so, this was good ramen. and i love my boyfriend for bringing me here, I LOVE YOU CHESTER!!

but...i got an INSANE stomach ache from this place. i don't know if it was something in the ramen or in the uni rice bowl we got but i was literally keeled over in pain for the rest of the night after we ate here.

the ramen itself was greats...at the moment i was chewing it and about 5 minutes after i finished it. but that was the end of the magic of ramen.

i cant write anymore because it is bringing back some horrific memories. 

i will try to go back in a couple months maybe...give it another go
author: Diana C.

description: i use to love this place, i just feel like it does  not taste  good as before, the broth was salty, noodles was chewy, they used to have tonkotsu ramen, (i don't know when was that since i have not gone here for ages), it's a shame that they don't have it anymore. this place is not great but it's ok. i don't even think i'd come back here, they heluh jacked up the price (of course they will, but i don't think the quality of the food cost that much). if you're around the area you should still try it out, it's an ok but not great ramen.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: I work downtown in union square and i am always looking for a quick yummy bite to eat. To start off i love love love japenese food and all it has to offer.. I was told about this place by a good friend and the first time i went in i was blown away. The RAMEN is so delicious i could die. The menu is great you have lots to choose from and its all so very tastey. i would recomend goin here if your in the downtown area looking for some great japanese food.. Although if i had one bad thing to say about this place its that since its such a small place you have to wait for a table and the wait is a lot longer and night ... but the wait is worth it.
author: A R.

description:
Big, big surprise!  

I always passed in front of this restaurant thinking "Ah, this location next to Union Square, must be a tourist trap..." and never got to try the ramen here.  But I read some reviews on Yelp, and it looks like it could give me some surprise...  

I tried "Kotteri Miso Ramen", which is "Rich" "Miso Flavored" Ramen.  (You have a choice between Rich or Light, but I like my ramens always rich, or even greasy...) and wow!  It was THE BEST RAMEN IN THE US SO FAR.  

I was awfully disappointed at ramens in the US so far.  I found some great sushi restaurants but this culture is still not very wide-spread in the US.  And I can understand why: 

1) Ramens have to be served very hot - almost you could burn your tongue
2) Ramens have to be eaten very quickly - otherwise the noodle gets soggy in the soup
3) Ramens are considered as the stuff you can buy at Walmart for 20 cents, like Maruchan (it's too bad that this is also a Japanese company too.  They only thought about making money rather than spreading the real culture) 

So yeah, this Katana-ya had all of above.  Again so far the best ramen I've ever had in this country, although it's not as good as ones in Japan.  To me it's great.  You should go there if you appreciate this huge culture from Japan.  If you have been to Japan and you miss real ramen, you should check out this place very near Union Square.  

I did not try their sushi and I don't even feel like trying - because for me this place became a ramen-ya.  The decor is very ugly but I can understand that considering the price of ramens here.  (But still it's a bit amazing to me that they have lamp shades made of aluminum foils!!!)  To make the real broth like this, you have to cook so many things in the soup for a long time until everything melts into it.  You don't see any vegetables, meat, fish or bones in the soup but you will only feel the depth of the flavors from all the ingredients!  

Now Tanpopo in Japantown is completely dead in me.  They have terrible service provided by Japanese ladies misunderstanding the Country of Freedom.
author: T T.

description: As I've said in other reviews Katana-Ya's ramen is very delicious and soothing on a cold day, but is still no match for Santa Ramen out in San Mateo. What makes Katana-Ya wonderful is the great selection of sushi and other dishes that you can order whereas a place like Santa Ramen is mainly known for ramen and no sushi. The sushi here is pretty good too and it is definitely cheaper than Santa Ramen as well. So if you are looking for a fairly delicious still satisfying bowl of ramen and some sushi to go with it, this is a great place to come. I would recommend this if you live closer to San Francisco, but if you are farther out parking is somewhat difficult as it is pretty close to downtown.
author: David Y.

description: Katana-Ya is a small Japanese restaurant specializing in ramen. Located where Union Square meets the Tendernob, it is rather easy to miss (as I apparently did). Inside is cute and crowded. People come here for the ramen obviously, and next time I will too. I ordered the udon with chicken (also asked for extra vegetables) which was decent, but nothing extraordinary. The broth was not terribly flavorful so I seasoned it with soysauce and pepper powder (not spray). Inside the decor is eclectic, various art lines the walls (also in the bathroom). We also ordered edamame which arrived late, were a bit cold, and not particularly good. In any event, if I find myself craving ramen, I will definitely stop here first, and hopefully then I'll be able to give it a higher rating. As for now, I wouldn't recommend it for udon as I think that Hotei does a better job.
author: Kate A.

description:
looks are deceiving.

as katana-ya is on geary @ mason, i had to dodge a couple of shady dudes before being able to duck into this small restaurant.  from the outside, it's very nondescript, and looks like a hole in the wall.  inside, it's pretty much a hole in the wall, and i started to get nervous about eating  here, even though the yelp reviews were pretty good.

but the waitress greeted us in a friendly manner, and quickly seated us (although there were only 2 other people there, sitting at the sushi bar. but then again, this was at about 2pm on the memorial day monday).  we took the table by the window and ordered one regular shoyu ramen and one spicy negi shoyu ramen.

we were starving so the 5 mins it took for the ramen to come out seemed long, but it reallly wasn't.  the steaming bowls were placed in front of us and although they were visually appetizing, i thought there weren't enough noodles, and was a little disappointed.  as julia roberts says in pretty woman, "bi~g mistake.  huge!"

the broth was rich in shoyu flavor, with a deep sweetness to it, although i bit on the heavier side (depending on my mood, i think i might like suzu's broth better, as it is lighter).  the noodles were firm and a bit on the fatter side (again, suzu's noodles are a bit lighter, as they are thinner than katana-ya's). the charsiu was perfectly cooked, very tender and almost falling apart.  my friend's spicy negi ramen looked pretty much the same, but had a bit of the slivered green onions on top.  it definitely could've used more negi, although the flavoring was great - a spicy sesame oil.

like i said, although the noodles didn't appear to be voluminous, i was definitely more than stuffed at the end of the meal.  in fact, i had a hard time trecking uphill 3 blocks to my car.

overall, great ramen.  and the price?  $15 for 2 bowls.  can't beat it.
author: Reina M.

description:
katana-ya was kind of disappointing. the ramen itself was alright but i was expecting better. it's great probably only because it's one of the only places that i've found in the city that serves ramen w/a pork based broth. 

other than that, the service left much to be desired. took at least 20 minutes for them to take out order - the workers were just chatting in the back. it's great for people like me who are up late all the time and still wanna go somewhere to eat. BUT, because of where it is you get random homeless people or crackheads coming in and creating drama. (like the day i was there.) 

i love ramen but i'm really iffy on whether i'd come back.
author: Mel L.

description:
hot rich soy ramen
fresh salmon donburri bowl
no yelp sticker yet

As my ramen inspired haiku suggests, the food is delicious at Katana-ya whether you are getting sushi or a donburri bowl or the steaming bowls of ramen they are known for. 
You can either get rich or light ramen, soy, miso or salt(?) flavor and you also have the option of getting soba or udon. 
You can rock some spicy tofu, bbq pork, chicken, whateves.

Delicious. They don't have a yelp sticker, but they were fired up when I told them I found them on Yelp and they really want to know where to get one. 
I directed them to the Yelp website, how else can i hook them up?

Bonus: I left my cell phone and they had it waiting for me when I ran back. hey, not so relevant but it helps.
author: Gabe b.

description:
Anger. Frustration. Psychologically scarred.  

WE WERE KICKED OUT (only to be let back in shortly afterwards). But regardless... it brought up painful memories of people in my party who had been rejected from other establishments before (ie TAO). Granted, we aren't the prettiest people in SF, but to be rejected from a noodle joint, al biet a popular one, truly plays on ones self esteem. How can a restaurant seat a party and THEN unseat them? I don't care if the other party didn't hear their names called- THAT'S THEIR FN FAULT!!!  

Upon being scooted out the restaurant, the party I was with began plotting on how to get back at establishment. How best to get back at these people? Throw the bucket outside through the glass window? Go to another noodle restaurant? Tear the sign in sheet apart?
