The nefarious activities we came up with were few and unimaginative (bordering childish), but they would have let the restaurant know that they had wronged the wrong customers. Being the only voice of reason, I calmed everyone down, and thankfully nothing unfolded that night (in fact, we ended up giving them a pretty fat tip). 

Needless to say, I will be back. What, then, was the purpose of this review you say? I write this review in hopes that the other party who sat at our table reads this. If you didn't notice, we had our food served before you. In fact, we were done with eating before your entire party had received your food. Yea, take that.
author: eric h.

description: Katana-Ya will become a definite stand-by for me amidst the slim choices of the Union Square neighborhood.  Not a tourist trap, and close to shopping and the movies, hard to ask for more.  But there is more.  Well priced staple for Udon or Ramen, sushi too, though from our seat at the bar it looked like it had been some time since flipper had been in its native habitat (wait, flipper was a dolphin I think....this place does not serve dolphin).  Big star for the cheapest Uni I've seen (which looked fresh and properly stored), normally a luxery, but highly affordable here at around $6.  Uni and Ramen lunch, yes please!
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Had dinner here a few nights ago with five friends....
I was wondering if I should write an update.... 
Of course I should.
We waited a good 45 minutes for a table.
NO PROBLEM.
The place is tiny, and its hard to accommodate a party of six.
When our time came, it was our table together, an open table for two
next to us, and a "three-top" waiting outside.
So, they break our table up.
Four on one, give us the deuce next to us for our other two friends, and seat the three people waiting after us on what used to be part of our table.
NO PROBLEM.
Even though my best man gets to eat with his back facing me.
At least we're all together eating a meal.
The check comes.
"We add 18% gratuity for parties of six or more."
PROBLEM.
So, you don't let me know this ahead of time before you break our table up to a party of four and two.... but of course you conveniently add your gratuity without prior notice.  
Don't you know that shit is illegal?
Doesn't matter.
Your classless act saved me an additional 7%.  
Assclowns.
author: Barry A.

description:
summary: spicy tofu good, bbq pork ramen good, all three soup bases are good. worth eating. the bottom paragraph is just more details



Me and my close friend, and his friend from cal came to eat today around 7:20ish, we got seated fast, but then other people later had to wait. I got the famous bbq beef ramen, miso soup based, thick? i dont remember but the non light one, my friend got the normal ramen salt based combo with spicy tofu don, and other friend got normal soy sauce based combo with curry don, i thought the curry was ok, didn't try that much lol, the tofu was good, my friend who ate a lot of tofu, said it was pretty good, the texture, flavor, hint chewyness, was good. my friend who got the soy sauce based like my miso based the best, which is for drinking, and he said the soy sauce based made it really saltly, and overbearing over awhile. I tasted all three broths, and they all tasted pretty good, and the salt broth taste pretty good too, i thought the bbq pork wasn't out of the ordinary, didn't wow me or dissappoint me, but ramen friend who had a lot of ramen said it wasn't bad, it was pretty good for ramen, and had a hint of sweetness. Also my ramen friend said the ramen was pretty good, he likes the thickness, and how strong it was. i thought the ramen tasted pretty legit, and good, and the soup base was pretty good, i wish they just add or include more stuff in the ramen, only had bamboo shoots, and some seawood.
author: David L.

description:
I miss Japan.  I miss Japanese food.  (No, not just sushi.)  I've been on the hunt for good places for Japanese basics (ramen, yakitori, etc.) and I've come up empty so far.

I have yet to meet a single Japanese person who likes this place.  I mean, I was raised here (in the U.S.) and even I wasn't particularly impressed with this place.  I've been to enough ramen places back in Japan to know that it shouldn't be this hard to get a good ramen for a decent price.

I'm giving it two stars because even if I wasn't impressed, it wasn't inedible.  If you're downtown and get the craving for something hot, at least this place won't kill you.
author: F. H.

description:
i wish i could give half stars for a 3.5
so my friend and i were craving food after catching a show @ golden gate. by 12am, there are limited dining choices available...katana has gotten such raving reviews i figured it'd be a sin to pass up this opportunity. i was kind of apprehensive at first because the menu seemed more like a fusion of asian foods but just then a couple of j-boys walked in and ordered nama beer and ramen--so i calmed down.
the shoyu chashu ramen had a surprisingly clean and flavorful soup. the noodles were cooked perfectly...i wish i could say i liked them, but they were cut on the thick side making them extremely chewy. overall though, its probably one of the better ramen joints around
author: Myra C.

description: i love japanese ramen and katanaya is my favorite.  it's small and popular, so usually you can expect to wait, but the ramen comes out quickly and its huge!  i've always split it.  the katanaya ramen is fun because of all the extras...get it spicy.  yum!
author: Christy C.

description: After reading one of yelper's review on this place I decided to give this place a shot.  I was skeptical at first b/c it is so near downtown Union Square and most of the restaurants aren't really authentic and it's just there to get tourists.  But when my bowl of ramen came out, it smelled wonderful.  The broth was full of flavor.  Maybe it's only a lunch deal, but it's only 10.50 total for a bowl of katsu don too, so my sister and I shared both.  Both were delcious.  We are def. coming back.
author: AhLin C.

description: Like people have said, it is one heck of tiny place but the service is fast and the sweet. How do you pass up on the deal of a big bowl of simple miso based ramen and a side of tonkatsu?
author: Christina Y.

description:
TIME CHECK: 50 min. until showtime. Our mission was to just grab a quick bite before our 2p show of RENT. The usual choices across from the Curran Theater for something quick and easy were: Quiznos, Pizza by the Slice, Jack in the Box.. already the thought of eating any of those made me feel my leggings getting tighter!  Thankfully, we noticed the group of folks waiting outside of Katana-Ya (including a bunch of Nike Women's Marathon finishers... I wish I did it too, darn!) and the sign for "Best Ramen 2008 in SF" (I'd also say 2009 ;).  Time restrait or not, we HAD to eat it. 
TIME CHECK: 40 min til' show time, we took the risk and asked for a table for two. Although the place is rather small and there was about 5 "party of twos"  in front of us, we were able to get seated rather quickly in 15 min or so. 
TIME CHECK: 25 min til' show time. We decided to share a Spicy Green Onion Ramen. w/ Rich Miso Broth... (they had the usual broth types as well: Shoyu, Salt, Miso.. light or rich). We also asked for extra pork and a side of Gyoza. We got all the food in about 10 min..
TIME CHECK: 15 min til' show time...and the marathon grubfest began. I'm a ramen snob, so for me to say the ramen was awesome, says a lot. The spicyness was perfect, not over-powering (they do have a Super Spicy Ramen or something like that that I seen and was really red). The pork slices just melted in your mouth and not too much fat nor any bit of dryness. The gyoza was average... nothing special.. and was $6 for 5 pieces, so a bit pricey for what it is. The ramen I think was $9, but came up a little more since we added the extra meat. No big deal.. still a great value for good ass food. We sat there satisfied and asked for the check. Service was prompt and very friendly... 
TIME CHECK: 5 min until show time... We dashed across the street, got to our seats w/ 2 min left until curtain-call and enjoyed the show, full and warm from Katana-Ya =) 

Next time, I'd like to try the Katana-Ya Ramen and also the Chirashi which looked nice and fresh.. We must go back very soon so I can sit there and take my time to enjoy each slurp and bite of the yummy broth and noodles vs. scarfing it down like a maniac!  If the gyoza were good, I would have given a 5.. but since we only ordered 2 things and 50% of the food was only average.. had to bring it down to a 4 or maybe 4.5 even... One last note: they are open until 1:15am.. so great for a late-night meal.. esp. after the bars/clubs. Dang, now my mouth is watering just re-reading my review.... doh! 

(RENT was awesome by the way!)
author: Lelly L.

description:
i like ramen. not too picky. heard about this place so wanted to try it out =)

Came here after work for dinner one night. It was pretty busy already , even on a weeknight, but I was seated fairly quickly because it was a party of 2 and the other member of my party already put our name down before i got there. 

I ordered the kim chi ramen and it was good. But not too long afterwards both me and the other member of my party got stomach aches... which is kind of weird since I don't really get those unless i ate something bad.

so taste was just ok. price was a little more expensive than what im used to paying for the same food type/quality/ambiance. food prep seems to be questionable because of the stomach aches. so guess i'll have to try again some other time to see if it happens again =T but other than that, not really a place i would crave to go to...
author: Nhi T.

description:
I had been hearing about this place from a lot of people..it is even featured on the 100 things to eat & drink before you die in SF.  So, I decided to try it out.  I have to say that the chasu ramen is pretty good, but I tried another ramen place back home called Fuji Ichiban and i have to say katanaya is just another ordinary ramen noodles house.  The ramen is good! (don't get me wrong) but I can't say its f***ing delicious! 

The service wasnt that great either here is why I say that...My friends and I decided to put two tables together because the table for 4 that they have can actually fit only 2 (i need my arm space when i'm eating specially using chop sticks and room to breathe)  It was working out for 5 minutes but a group of 4 came in and the ladies were pregnant.  They ask the waiter if they could do the same to their tables and the waitress said "NO we dont do that here" We felt bad for the two pregos so my friends and I decided to give them our table and move to the corner table in front of the cashier.  The table was so tiny that the food we ordered didnt even fit.(we ordered chicken karage for appetizer and three bowls or ramen)  The waitress didnt even say sorry or thanked us for accomodating their customers.  To top all that she was really bitter and mean...no smiles! I flag  her  for some drinks and she totally ignored us.  We had to wait for 10 mins (until we got her attention) to repeat our orders.

But besides all that, If you are craving for some ramen try this place out and seee for yourself.
author: Vanessa E.

description: We ate here three times this week - the sushi is fresh and yummy, grilled mackerel was delish and the ramen is the absolute best I've had - both cold and hot. The Katanaya ramen with medium spice and soy base is fabulous - fried chicken in ramen is some serious evil genius.   The mochi ice cream is so yummy too.  The place is small, but if you time it right, the wait isn't long.
author: Jennifer M.

description: I haven't been to many ramen places, but this is by far The best ramen restaurant in the city! OMG the katana ya ramen is absolutely delicious! Their other options such as the sushi is decent, but everyone comes to eat the ramen here anyway. The only problem is that the restaurant is quite small and cramp, and the wait can be long at times. However, considering how amazing the ramen is, it is definitely worth coming here multiple times.
author: Luis O.

description:
We came here before watching Rent at the Curran theatre.  For such a small place, we had a rather large group at 6 people.  However, we beat the big rush by coming at 6pm. 

I ordered the Katana-Ya special which included 3 gyoza, chasu, karage, and corn.  It's the most expensive ramen on the menu but it had everything I wanted.  We also ordered some rolls to share amongst the group.  

There are big pros for the speed the food comes out and the quality of it.  Both the ramen and the broth are very good.  The service was really fast up until we wanted to pay for the bill.  I would highly recommend getting any roll with the butterfish in it.  You can also ask them to make these rolls non-spicy.  

Can't think of any cons.  I'll be back here for sure.
author: Scott L.

description: Good ramen.  The ramen is not soggy and cooked just right.  The miso soup taste better than the soy sauce.  I ordered the regular cha siu soy sauce ramen with corn added in it.  It's a large bowl but a bowl cost around $9 which is quite expensive, but then again its SF.  Be careful of the fried chicken!!! My friend burned his tongue biting into one!! We also ordered their hamachi kama which was cooked completely different.  I do not enjoy the batter they they used to coat the fish.  But pretty good.  Not as great as Santa Ramen in San Mateo but still good!
author: Crystal L.

description:
after eating out so much for the past few days out in SF, i was craving good old comfort food, which to me can range from steamed rice and kimchi to duckfeet. (NOT)

alas, asian food, here i come. after yelping ramen for lunch, found katana-ya.

EW!

this is NOT authentic ramen. O MY! SHOOT ME. YUCK! PASS.

how did you even make it to the best ramen in town in the 7x7 magazine?
author: Jennifer S.

description: I'm not sure what all the rave is about, I didn't think the ramen was that good and the portion are very small, and I def. would not wait in line to eat here.  On top of that, there sushi roll was over price and the rolls are so tiny. We wouldn't mine paying 13.50 for a roll, but after looking at how small the portion is I would never order from them again.
author: Angela T.

description:
Katana-Ya has been recommended to me innumerable times as the "Best Ramen in San Francisco!" I've been there a few times with friends, and I have to say, I'm thoroughly unimpressed.

There is always a line out the door for this place; the staff usually act vaguely annoyed that you've decided to eat in their restaurant, the seating is very close, and the atmosphere very busy. The service is functional, if not friendly; they get to you when they can, and once they've given you your food you seem to evaporate from their worldview altogether until you ask to pay your bill. 

The food could really be the saving grace of a place like this. Problem is, it isn't. The last time I went there I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen. What came to my table was a steaming bowl of ramen cunningly concealed beneath a 1/4" layer of oil, all of which was topped with a gaggle of meats fried into unrecognizable greasy brown hunks. I tried to eat it, taking two sips of the greasy 'broth' and a bite of one of the brown hunks perched atop the mass of stewed noodles, but the greasy texture and abysmal flavor made my gut churn. The noodles were rubbery and bland, the broth tasted like old Crisco, and the other bits and pieces in there were pretty much cooked well beyond edibility. I called the waitress over and asked if I could just have a regular old Shoyu Ramen instead, to which she replied, "But you ordered THAT!" When I finally convinced her to bring me another ramen, it too was covered with a layer of grease and the broth was clotted and odd-looking. I took a few bites of it, but it was almost as inexplicably poor as the first ramen I'd ordered. I paid for everything and left the restaurant still hungry.

I love ramen, but I'm no expert. Still, when I order one the last thing I expect to get is clotted bowl of oil and chewy noodles. I've had better ramen out of a baggie.
author: Kele T.

description: I don't know why this place is that good.  Overrated and expensive.  I had fried chicken ramen.  I thought I was driving down highway 5 past Harris Ranch.  Seriously, I didn't know food can smell like that.  I sat there thinking who deal a big one.  The rolls are tiny for what you pay.  The service definitely needs help knowing what is on the menu and responding to your call.
author: Rich P.

description: The ramnen is al dente and is perfect if you like it kinda springy.  My first impressions of the place was that the place didn't look like anything out of the ordinary however the place was packed...at 11pm!  It's a great place to grab some ramen after a drink since last call is at 1:00am.  The quality of their sashimi is great if you want something else other than soupy ramen.  The cold soba noodles are done well too so give it a try.  You can't go wrong at Katana-Ya.
author: Alvin L.

description: Katana-Ya ramen is very flavorful and tasty, the chicken is huge and tender.  It gets a 5 star if I am only rating the ramen.  However the sushi here isn't that great.  So I am dropping a star.  I like how it opens late and is right next to union square.  Really close to walk to Bart.  However, there is usually a long line, you would be lucky to get in with a 30 minute wait.  Its usually worth the wait and the food comes out fast after you ordered.
author: Jim H.

description: This is one of those places where Yelp Reviews seriously let me down. Maybe it was an off night for Katana-ya, who knows. But this was by far the most disgusting ramen I have ever tried in my life. And it smelled like dirty socks. In fact, the dirty sock smell wafted throughout the restaurant and finally we pinpointed it to the ramen noodles. Gross.
author: Jenny C.

description: a yelper brought me to this little shop, so i knew it'd be good.  Many choices of udon at cheap prices.  It's fast and tasty (good stop during a full evening/night of drinking.)
author: Vinnie L.

description:
...so after making it to our car, which was at a friend's in potrero, we drove ourselves to katana-ya in an effort to eat hot soup and ramen after freezing to death.  by now, it is basically midnight...2 hours after we attempted to leave treasure island.  we found parking quickly and ran into the restaurant.  wakako and i had been talking about ramen all day, and she knows that i had been talking about it all WEEK.  

we get to the restaurant, and it is STILL freezing, so i ask that we please keep the front door closed.  then we asked for hot tea, and it was TEPID!!!  i thought i was never going to thaw out.  

finally, our ramen came.  i ordered the spicy tofu ramen w/ light miso broth, and wakako got the spicy negi ramen w/ rich miso broth w/ a side of fried rice.  that bowl of ramen was like a warm blanket wrapped around me and was the biggest relief i have ever felt.  the ramen was perfectly chewy, and the broth was so delicious.  it was just what i needed.  i was sad when i was done, b/c i wanted more.  i can't wait to go back again...

update 9/19:  ...and i did come back again last night!!  this time, i tried the spicy cold ramen w/ tofu instead of pork.  you can request the tofu if you don't eat meat.  the cold ramen was soooo good!!  it was topped w/ kimchi, tofu, cucumbers, hot mustard, tempura crumbles, and some other good stuff.  the bowl was huge, yet i still managed to eat the entire thing.
author: Helen T.

description:
love, love, love kataya-ya!  

i started going here a couple of months ago.  some weeks, i come to katana-ya twice or three times a week.  

service is fast and efficient.  all of their ramen dishes are yummy, and their sushi is super fresh.  

favorite dishes:
- spicy tofu ramen w/ miso broth
- katana-ya ramen w/ miso broth
- regular ramen w/ soy sauce broth
- tataki salad
- scallop nigiri
- fresh spanish mackerel nigirl
- uni nigiri

i've had their soba, and i don't think the broth is that flavorful - but i don't think soba and udon are their strong points.

also - the place is tiny!  so i'd only recommend that you go if you are a party of 3 or less.
author: kim n.

description:
I first went to Katana-Ya to meet some old college friends I haven't seen in years so the event over-took the food. I enjoyed it, but the cramped seating kind of got to me. I'm used to this in Japan, but sometimes I prefer the giant booths you'd find in a regular Denny's restaurant. But the ramen was good and I did find it reasonable to go again.

On my second trip I went there and tried the spicy ramen. That was pretty awesome. The flavor was rich and the broth was thick with lots of seasonings. There really isn't much to say about it because many other people would've told you by now that Katana-ya is THE BEST RAMEN place in San Francisco (or the Bay Area as alleged by some). Go there and you can't go wrong with the food.

But anyway, on my second trip I appreciated the decor a bit more too as the meal proceeded. The room only fits like 10 tables and it creates a narrow pathway for the waitresses to move around. The chef looks like he's really Japanese, but I didn't want to make conversation with him. There is a counter for patrons to eat ramen in and behind the counter they hung a giant gilded Japanese screen. It was actually gorgeous and I felt it out of place for a Japanese restaurant. What made it even more weird were the christmas lights and the gaudy halogen light bars. I wasn't sure if I was in a Tokyo street vendor or an esoteric Japanophile's basement. There actually was a pair of Katana blades there too. To complete the look they should've added a train set like Izakaya Mai's. Either way, it was entertainment for the amount of time it takes you to finish ramen. The people come and go quick, so you'll have a fun time people gazing also. All in all, a winner for the people of San Francisco.
author: William H.

description: I've been here twice now and I'll probably go back. let's start by saying that this is not the pinnacle of ramen, this is not the happy hunting ground of chashu and butter corn, no, not even close, but it is probably the best ramen that we have in San Francisco. It seems to me that we have better sushi in SF than LA but LA has the market, something fierce, on Ramen. If you're hungering for some noodles and chashu then this isn't a bad place to go but don't expect an Ipuda like experience.
author: Len S.

description: Seriously- I  ate ramen in Tokyo and  Kyoto, Japan, and Japan Towns SF and SJ, other SF  and Bay Area ramen houses.  This is the best in the BAY Area! (The old Tokushima Ramen in the Mitsuwa Market of  S J was better but they are gone due to retirement.).
author: Johnson F.

description: The Ramen...  Oh, the Ramen!   The Ramen at this place is so rich and flavorful that it stopped conversation completely between three talkative friends and we just eat in hallowed silence.
author: Chad K.

description: I had the combo ramen with light soy and side of veggie tempura. Yum! I was nervous to try to miso ramen because sometimes it can be too much salt overload, but after trying a bite of my friend's, it turned out to be rich, creamy, and a tad of sweet. Next time I come with a hefty appetite, I'm definitely going to for the miso. Veggie tempura could have been better but I didn't expect much since it was a side. Plenty of food for the value!
author: Susan L.

description:
i love this place!

i will wait however long in the rain with a broken umbrella to eat here because my belly is oh so satisfied every time i go there!

the fried chicken in an extra spicy miso broth is deliciousness all the way!! gyoza and sushi is all goodness as well.

the service may not be the super best, but it works, small space large amounts of hungry people, can't blame them for not smiling 24/7.. they are still courteous....

over all for sure one of my favorite spots to eat after a long day of shopping!
author: sue k.

description: One of the better Ramen Restaurants in the city.  Seating is very limited so be prepared to wait or go to another restaurant.  Parking is also a pain unless it is late at night.  Their Chicken Karaage is good, and some of their non-Ramen items are not bad as well.  I come back occassionally.  Much better deal than Santa or some of the other over-rated Ramen restaurants.
author: Cory C.

description:
omg service is such a non-issue compared to the taste and quality of food, and that's saying a LOT. i got the katana-ya bowl with light shoyu and that shit was just stOOOOpid good that i actually pinched my bowl after the first taste to see if it really existed. then i felt my face. yep, this is really me. this is really me in complete tastebud/ olfactory heaven.

two deep fried dumplings (the texture was a bit thicker than regular gyoza), 4 thick slices of well-seasoned pork, and just the right texture of ramen noodles really made this a hit. the broth, in my opinion, was the absolute star of the show. take what you know of ramen (not the brick kind, but the restaurant kind) and ramp that bidnezz up ten-fold. then you will prolly get a good idea of what this bowl tastes like.

i also tried the ocean roll, which was a great precursor to the ramen. "the pearly gates", if you will. wakame salad on top of hamachi maki. i think there was another somn-somn in there, but it eludes me right now. it came with a spicy sauce on the side. operative words: on the side. 

i hate when my sushi's drizzled with all kinds of funky sauces and shit. i'm a simple girl (with impeccable taste) who values free will (read: i like it my way only and everyone else can STEP). i'm all about sauces being "on the side". how very how harry met sally of me, yeah? :P

we didn't have a problem with service at all. our drinks came promptly and finished dishes were taken away promptly. drinks were refilled. napkins were given quietly and quickly even if we didn't ask for them. if you want ass kissing and coddling, go to benihana or tgi fridays. but seriously, the service is better than you come to expect when you eat in awesome holes-in-the-wall places like these.

an afterthought: i ate here during one of the recent hot-as-hell weekends and i really wish they had a/c. the dinky floor fan they put out was just laughing at all of us eating steaming hot bowls of ramen in 90-degree weather.
author: Vanessa D.

description: Horrible horrible service. The ramen is just decent for SF standard, but nothing to rave about or wait in line for. You can definitely get better in the peninsula.
author: Francis D.

description: I love this place!  I like Tanpopo a lot, but I like this place even more.  The Ramen is great.  I ordered take-out from this place last Wednesday for dinner and liked it so much, I brought a business colleague from San Diego here for a meal at 10:00 pm ... twice in one day!  My wife wasn't crazy about the Teryaki Chicken, but I liked it.  Can't wait to back to try other things ... maybe the curry.
author: Rod C.

description: This place is the shit. Got this place recommended to us by an old school noodle restaurant owner in Japantown after we tried to get some ramen after they had closed. This restaurant beats any noodle place I have found in LA considering it has more on the menu, is open late, and serve booze. I found out that ramen and sake go well together and was pleased with the options for the broth. Everything hit the spot. Definitely worth a trip back.
author: Eugene S.

description: The ramen was really good...probably one of the best I had.  Small place good service but very hard to find parking and had to park at the parking lot for $7!!!  $12.50 for a pork ramen might be a little high maybe cuz is sf.
author: VICTOR T.

description: Pretty good.  I ordered the Deep fried chicken with ramen.  Overall it was a good hearty meal and decent.
author: Joseph C.

description:
Everything about this place has already been said, with that....

This place is awesome, especially if you are in the area. The prices arn't too bad, especially the combo special - one ramen/udon/soba bowl (its actually a whole bowl! I thought it was going to be half sized), and another rice dish. 

We decided to go with the combination  - regular ramen and a beef sukiyaki bowl. We supplemented that with the katana ya ramen bowl; both had the miso soup broth. 

The miso soup borth was very rich, almost too rich. I think HALU in SF is still my favorite. 3 stars. 

The ramen here is sooo good though! +1 for the noddles. Perfectly cooked, not soft or mushy, and not too hard and chewy. 

The thing I  liked most was actually the beef sukiyaki. It was great! I just wish it had a little more beef. 

I'll be coming back again. 

*Tip, Don't come here with more than 4 people! This place is cramped. Even a table of 4, you will get to know your dinner mates very well.
author: Josh M.

description:
After all the hype and talk from friends about how GOOD the ramen is and how it's "NOT the same" as Top Ramen, i'm glad to finally get to try this place. 
When it comes to making my own Top Ramen, i consider myself a culinary artiste - using all my bland leftovers in the fridge and combining them into one delicious concoction. But after eating here i realize i was seriously mislead. The soup and quality of the ramen were delicious, and totally worth the $10 that i could use to buy a whole months worth of ramen for. The ramen had a nice thick and chewy texture. The soup options are either Miso or Soy, which are both good, and you can either get them light or rich (meaning "more flavor" says our waitress). 
One things that could use some improvement is the amount of meat. I was done with all the karaage in my ramen in the first couple minutes. Second, DON"T go with big groups. I would say it's good for couples only. I went with 4 other people and the wait was 40 minutes outside in the cold. Maybe that's the trick to making their ramen taste so good. But once you sit and order, they make up for it by bringing out your ramen in a few minutes.
author: Douglas F.

description:
Meh is right. After all the amazing reviews and the line out the door. My husband and I thought we had find the new ramen spot in the city. But we were really disappointed. Part of the problem could have been that we just got back from Oahu where the ramen is better. But the food at Katana-Ya was very bland/boring. 

The service is very quick, efficient and kind so I don't knock them on that at all.
author: Sug L.

description: Went here on a Sunday night, after having just flown into town. I ordered a karaage ramen (fried chicken) and an order of uni sushi. The uni was ok, not bad, but not amazingly good either. The ramen was very good. Chewy noodles, fried chicken was not too soggy. It came piping hot and there was a thin layer of "oil" floating on top of the broth, but it added to the overall meatiness of the dish. Will definitely be back.
author: Charlotte T.

description:
Just went here tonight - my 3rd visit and found out that they did away with their Combo menu - I guess good deals are fading away around Union Square. Boo :-(

Their Fried Chicken Ramen with Miso is still good, not too salty unlike other Ramen joints. Spicy Tuna Roll was fresh.

Overall, the food didn't change as the quality is consistent. The only change is in the value.
author: Caryn L.

description: I love this place. The only reason that i took off one star is the tataki salad was little be salty. All the sushi and ramen are really great!
author: Jenny C.

description:
my boyfriend and i came here for lunch one day while we were in town. it was pouring rain outside but the restaurant was still packed! you write your name and how many people you have on the clipboard hanging outside the door and wait for the hostess to call you. there's a teeny bench to sit on inside the restaurant while you wait. 

we both got the katanaya ramen with a miso soup base. it came with fried chicken, gyoza, bbq pork, bamboo shoots, seaweed, and sweet corn. 

the fried chicken was crispy on the outside, tender on the inside, and had a good flavor from all the seasonings they put in. the gyozas were vegetarian -.-' a bit disappointing but edible. the bbq pork tasted a bit gamy. the bamboo shoots and seaweed were pretty standard and the sweet corn was soft. 

overall a good bowl of ramen. if i'm ever back in SF i'll definitely stop by again for a bowl of fried chicken ramen
author: Chris W.

description:
Cramped tacky-looking space, but this place is more about the ramen than the ambiance.

There are other places (Santouka, Izakaya Sozai) with a richer broth, but the noodles are firm and the broth is still well-developed here.  The portion size is also pretty massive, especially if you get the Katana-Ya ramen bowl with every topping.
author: S L.

description: Always crowded. Can't say the food is really worth the long wait, so 3 stars.
author: George M.

description:
It was alright.

Rubbery noodles.

Broth was weeq.

Santouka is still the best in the whole Bay Area.
author: Brian S.

description:
Oh Katana-Ya
Has most delicious ramen
Miso broth is best.

-A Haiku Review 
 Eat delicious Japanese
 Food. Or you may die
author: Peter B.

description: This place has nearly 1,000 reviews (as of today)! That alone tells you how passionate people are about this fine little spot. And little  is correct - only about ten counter/diner seats and 7 tables - so plan on waiting and not having much room when you finally do sit down (so only dine with people you don't mind getting close to :-). But it is worth it, especially on a cold San Fran day.  You can eat here 3x/day for a month and probably not sample all the items on the menu - but it would be fun trying. I may try it.
author: M D.

description: SOOOOOOOOOOO good.  Totally worth the wait! Sushi and noodles are amazing!  Get the spicy ramen...soooooo good! LOVE This place!
author: Lexie S.

description: I was expecting to be blown away by the ramen, so maybe the 3 stars is more of a result of expectations set too high.  Got the fried chicken ramen.  It was good, so I definitely recommend trying this place out, especially if it's more convenient than getting over to Japantown.  Curry rice was good too.  The sauce was flavorful and thick, just like Mom used to make (from that gold box).  Not a whole lot of veggies and meat though.  Also got the Hamachi-kama (collar), which is my absolute favorite thing to get at traditional Japanese restaurants.  It was slightly breaded and fried as opposed to grilled, which dried out the fish.  Overall, I'd go back to satisfy my ramen and "fast-food" fix (i.e., curry), but wouldn't order the hamachi-kama again.
author: Ji-In L.

description:
the first sip of the broth was so delicious, the second sip was a little salty after drops of tear fell into the spoon.

it also opens until hella late.  fo shizzle.
author: Andrew P.

description:
if i'm in the mood for ramen, this would probably be one of my first picks. the space is teeny tiny, located about 2 blocks away from union square and tables are cramped and crowded so come prepared to wait just a bit (its worth it). 

its a truly authentic japanese ramen house serving ramen, and some other items such as sushi, donburi, and various appetizers. they allow you to pick from a variety of soup bases and you can customize the seasoning to your liking. so you can choose from three broth bases. either salty, shoyo, or miso. and then you can choose either rich, or light, with the latter being low sodium and chicken based versus the thicker, rich meat based version. you can pick your noodle, either udon or ramen. the ramen noodles have a wonderful texture, and go well with the perfectly seasoned broth. their chashu (pork) is a good choice if you prefer meat, or you can go with kimchee, tofu, and some other toppings. its perfect for a chilly evening or for concluding an evening of boozing up, down, and across the street.
author: helen l.

description: You know, people say Halu or Oyaji is the best ramen in the city.  I was left a bit disappointed with them.  Frankly, I like Katana Ya better.  You have to get the Miso broth with the extra spicy add on ($1.50).  It really is just the broth that makes it so good.  Also, the bowl is in reality a lot bigger than it seems in the pictures.
author: Bert N.

description:
the ramen here doesnt get much better. a perfect place open late after some drinking or just for a nice dinner. my only complaint is that i wish the restaurant was a little bigger b/c i had to wait in line for about 15 mins for dinner. I'm not (really) complaining though, it was totally worth the wait.  
I had the cold ramen which was really good, perfect garnishes. Also the gyoza are tasty as well. It's definitely some of the best ramen I've had (and i grew up in hawaii which says something) and one bowl will fill you up and leave you satisfied :)
author: Margit H.

description:
Love, love, love their ramen.  This is the spot to go to if you've been hanging around downtown all day or plan on hanging around downtown after dinner.  The only 2 complaints I would have is how crowded and small the restaurant is and that their spicy tuna is a bit too fishy for me.  Maybe it wasn't seasoned enough.  I'm a lover of raw fish but this happened to be a bit much for me.  After my first failed experience with sushi with them, I decided to just stick to their main staple, ramen.  Their delicious salty thick broth and fresh ramen noodles have yet failed me.  I frequent the spot usually during cold winter nights because going all the way to downtown to eat during a regular day doesn't appeal to me.  I like checking out downtown during Christmas so I can shop, check out the sights, and then have a big bowl of hot ramen!  They also let you customize your ramen so that you can choose what type of soup, ramen, and meat you want.  I always get the heavy broth 'cause I like having hearty noodle soup.  They have a large variety of different types of ramen and I keep getting the original with chashu.  The kimchee ramen looks promising and adding deep fried chicken to your ramen seems so wrong but it tastes so right at Katana-Ya!  I'd eat a piece of my friends chicken everytime she gets it but I'm still going to stick to my chashu.

I'd recommend this spot for small get togethers and dinner dates, maybe not a first date though because it is a bit noisy with the crowd and all but it's a really fun and lively environment.  

Pros: Yummy FRESH ramen for decent price
Cons: Gets crowded, long waits

It's located next to a few different parking garages so if you can't find parking on the street, which is more than likely, you can park in the garage.  Can't determine whether that's a good or bad thing since you're guaranteed parking but then again you have to pay for it.
author: Ivy Z.

description: I love ramen, and Chowhound says Katana-Ya is the best ramen in San Francisco, so I expected to like it. But it was a disappointment. At 8.30 on a Saturday night, I waited a full hour for a table for two, and the ramen turned out to be fine, not great. If it wasn't for the long waits, I'd be a regular, if not particularly enthusiastic, patron. But the lines are just silly: it's embarrassing to wait so long for something so mediocre.
author: Susan P.

description:
i went here with a girlfriend about 2 weeks ago and enjoyed some really good sushi... we got a few different rolls but i don't remember which ones. sorry! i eat too much sushi to keep track of what i get. :) it's a smaller establishment but it was pretty busy for a monday. it is in the heart of the city! 

the sushi had perfect texture, was fresh and came quickly considering how many people were dining. we had to wait a bit for the tea. i think the waitress forgot about it... and they did mess up one of the rolls but they fixed it quickly. i'd definitely get in here and check it out if you're a sushi fanatic.
author: Ash G.

description: Pretty pricey for an average ramen place.  Wife ordered the Extra Spicy Fried Chicken ramen and the spiciness tasted like Mexican hot sauce.  Boo...I expect more for being charged $1.40 for the extra spiciness.  I had the Spicy Green Onion ramen and that was okay, nothing to brag about.  All in all I don't think the average ramen is worth the 30-40 minute wait at times for this place.
author: Regan W.

description: MISO ramen is far tastier than their Soy Sauce based ramen. Go for the miso!
author: Madelyn Y.

description: came here twice...i had the curry karaage ramen and it was absolutely delicious. the broth was just right in flavor it wasn't too much nor was it too little. i would definitely come back here again and eat the ramen. it was sooo goood!
author: Stella J.

description: This is the only place bob eats ramen.  Thank god this place didnt close down.  It just moved without me knowing.  Ive never been to this new location, but if it is the same katana-ya that used to be on judah, this is the best.
author: Hen A.

description: Loveeee the ramen here! My fave is the katana ramen which has all the goodies pork, bamboo shoots, corn, and fried chicken. The sushi is also really good, but if you want to eat here be prepared to wait in line cause there is often a bunch of people trying to get into this tiny ass restaurant...and I mean TINY!
author: Jackie M.

description:
It's one of the best ramen restaurants I've been to.  The restaurant is ridiculously small, and the quarters are ridiculously cramped.  You definitely get the feeling you're in Tokyo...if you're in a big group you have to alternate taking a bite over your bowl with the person sitting next to you haha.  The wait is painfully long, we waited from 8pm-9pm.  I bet that plays a factor into why we felt the food was heavenly...we were starving.  They're open till 1:15am...probably because of the wait.  

Most of us ordered the miso ramen with the beef sukiyaki combo.  The noodles were super Q and the soup base was flavorful yet light.  The beef sukiyaki came in a separate bowl.  The portions were very generous for the price.  We also got some gyozas...the filling was more leek than pork, but it was nevertheless tasty.  Sooo good.
author: Will C.

description: 3 Stars...I decided to go on the lower side of being inbetween a 3 and 4 because honestly the ramen was tasty, but I've had better.  Even though I've had better it definitely isn't 2 star worthy, and you get good portions for a good price.  I kind of felt like my noodles were a little bit on the thicker side and just didn't taste like what I was expecting.  Also, because it's near downtown it means parking is a pain...In concluding not a bad spot, I'd come back to try again.
author: Brian Y.

description: I love the ramen at this place, it can be very crowded but why should they not use every space in their little restaurant when they can. It is perfect for some late ramen, the kimchi rice is very good. Didn't have a better one so far and tried already a couple. The girl from Estonia working there is very nice and remembered us after going there after a couple times which is always nice. She does a very good job. I definitely go back!!
author: Anna K.

description: It was ok.  Hard to find parking and very tight inside.
author: Nancy L.

description: Best Japanese sushi in San Francisco....
author: Joel Santos G.

description: I had the spicy fried chicken Ramen and it was fantastic. This is a fun little spot, with lots of people squeezed into a small area (in a good way). We had to wait just a little bit for a seat but it seems the tables turn over relatively quickly so not a problem. Can't wait to go back.
author: Brian W.

description:
This was the second time that I have been to Katana-ya.  
If you like chewy (undercooked), hard noodles and 
salty broth, then this is your place.  I tried the miso 
ramen and miso chasu ramen and the difference 
between them is you get one slice of pork in the former
and 2 more slices in the latter.  As ramen goes, 
the fixings are minimal- some bamboo shoots, pork, 
and spinach.   People say that this is the best 
ramen in the city but that isn't saying much
considering there aren't that many good ramen 
places to begin with.  There was a time when you 
could get at least 3 slices of pork, plenty of spinach, 
bamboo shoots, and a sliced boiled egg but most 
ramen places in the city have gone downhill.

As for service, it is slow and lacking.  They didn't 
tell us that the seafood fried rice would take awhile 
and when we inquired about it - they said it was 
coming.  No apologies for lateness- I had finished 
my meal while my wife was still waiting for hers.  
3 other tables that came after us had their meals 
served. At the very least, they should have told us 
it takes awhile.  We know the order went in soon 
after we ordered 'cause we heard the waitress 
place the order in the kitchen in Japanese.  But 
we weren't the only ones with slow service.  
For another table, the customer went up 
to the cashier to say that they hadn't gotten 
menus.  The waitress  just bypassed him 
and left the menus at their table without even 
an apology.  He later had to flag them down 
yet again to get their tea/water refilled.
author: S L.

description: I stopped here for a quick bite on my lunch hour at work.  Their lunch special is 2 sushi rolls plus miso soup for $10 - what a deal!  The sushi is really tastey and the staff is friendly.  I would definitely go there again!
author: Carly P.

description: I came back with a group of friends and we all pretty much ordered the Katana-Ya ramen.  I got it with the miso broth and no MSG.  It was awesome!  The best part is the fried chicken... so freaking good!  It was a little pricey (~$18 with tax and tip).  I'll probably be back a few more times since I live two blocks away, but I won't be here every week.
author: Cersei T.

description:
I have come here several times and i'd like to give 4 stars.
I always order chicken karaage ramen. taste good. the bad thing about this place is 1) very small restaurant
                       2) the distance between one to another table is very closed. you can't even move your chair to have more space....
                        3) you will have to wait longer if you are in a big group.
you will no need to queue if you come around 6 o'clock.
author: Elisabeth T.

description: What can I say?! I LOVE ramen and I LOVE spicy food!! and this place has decent spicy ramen!! I don't have to dream about the spicy ramen I used to very much enjoy when I was in Hawaii. This could be it!! although it's a little on the pricey side and it's in rather not so good area of the city. But, for once in a while craving, it will do!
author: Daisy S.

description: I'm a noodle-woman.  I love this place!  The soup base and the noodles are awesome!  I almost finished all the soup.  They have sushi and sashimi which have pretty good deal.  Toro nigiri for only $5.50.  I thought it was a crap but it wasn't.  The akinmo was pretty fresh too!  This is a very small restaurant and there's always a line, but I wouldn't mind waiting!
author: Jen C.

description:
Brought my husband here because he's been looking for that flavor of ramen shops in Tokyo - the ones where you pay in the vending machine outside. Well he got his ramen and he claims it is very close what he's been searching for. 

Unfortunately they do not have a vegetarian broth so I got sushi. Avo roll, inari and tamago. The avo roll was OK - the seaweed was a little tough. The inari was pretty good and the tamago was excellent - nice and cool and sweet, almost like an egg custard. Overall, I'd come back when he wants ramen but it's not the best sushi. The price is a little high but the service is pretty good.
author: Sarah J.

description:
I am a noodles kind of guy.  I don't like rice but I love noodles...

After saying that, this place is heavenly. I do not remember exactly what I ordered but the ramen was cooked perfectly.  The gyoza and the chicken within it just added to the experience.

The only down side to this location is its popularity.  When we got there, we waited about 20 minutes to get a table.  I distinctly remember a couple walking past and stating... "lets eat here... a wait line means its not only worth the wait but you know the food is good."

Other Notables:
Service - Was as good as it gets.  With a busy dining area, I expected slower returns but this place never let my cup go empty.
Location - Definitely a walk to location since parking in SF, especially so close to market is something that you do not expect to have.

In sum, I would go here every day if I worked close to this location.
author: Michael C.

description: Great lunch place.  Had the Soba with spicy tuna over rice on the side.  This place is s definite repeat.
author: Rob P.

description: Pretty decent ramen, especially the thick shoyu soup (pork base) with spicy negi for San Francisco.  Open till 2am and a few blocks from my work, I may just have to go back again soon.
author: Haru K.

description: Not as good as Suzu in J-Town, but way more convenient after a long day of shopping in Union Square. If it's my first time at a ramen place, I will always go for the basic ramen with BBQ pork first. The broth was pretty salty, but the portion was generous and the noodles were a perfect consistency. I wasn't a fan of their gyoza though, so I would opt for a different appetizer. They also had an extensive list of sushi, but it doesn't seem like a place where I'd want to spend upwards of $10 on a dragon roll.
author: lindsay w.

description: Went here late at night, think they actually close at 1:30. This place is really really tiny, and is easy to miss if you're driving by. Almost all their tables seat 2, so definitely go with no more than 4 people unless you want a long wait. I tried the ramen, tempura, sushi, sake, mochi, (yes I had all of that for myself) all were good to very good. I've probably had better at different places before, but you can't find this type of quality after 12. For a great late-night meal, I definitely would come here again.
author: Bill K.

description: The food was great, service was good even they were quite busy on a Sunday night.  Price is slightly high.  I enjoyed the food a lot, the flavor was great.   The biggest problem is that there's MSG in the brooth.  At least, they are honest about it and put in on the menu that the food contains MSG.  I don't think it's that hard to make the food taste as good without using it.  May be it would take longer to cook the brooth, may be more bones...  Taking a shortcut by using MSG just shows that the chef is lazy, in my opinion.
author: Dee L.

description:
i'll be honest; i've never had ramen before.  but we went here the other night and it was awesome.  it makes me wonder why i've never had it before.  i followed my friend's lead and ordered shoyu raman with a takatsu donburi.  i have nothing to compare this to, but it was delicious. 

also, the people who worked there were super friendly and it was cute;  we were seated right by the door and the draft kept coming in, so that bummed me out but it wasn't their fault. 

also, i've been on an iced tea kick lately and theirs was wonderful.
author: Nora B.

description: Spicy tofu ramen... Great. That is all that I have to say.
author: David M.

description: Perfect combo of price and portions with a relaxed atmosphere. You may find better sushi, but if you want something quick & easy this is your spot. Plus where else can you get ramen? Compared to the overprice tourist traps nearby, this is a good bet when you're in the mood for sushi, noods or the like.
author: David V.

description: This place has the best noodles in The City. I love it. the prices are more then reasonable for what's delivered and the portions are huge. I highly recommend any of the noodles. I especially like the "rich", miso broth. I wish that I lived closer to this joint. If I did, I would eat hear for lunch every day. It's that good. The service can be a bit slow, but the waitresses are very nice and apologetic for any inconvenience rendered. It's well worth the wait.
author: Gabe T.

description: We came to the city and had to try this place on a recommendation, and I was glad we did.  The pork donburi was excellent, as was the fried chicken ramen. It is a tiny place, but the atmosphere is pleasant and the service is good.  You can't beat the prices and the generous portions.  I would definitely seek this place out again to try other tasty offerings from their fairly wide ranging menu. Be Advised: Not the best place for a large party, our party of four was a large group for this tiny place!
author: Jan C.

description: Being a Santa Ramen in the Peninsula lover, I had to try out this SF ramen place. I wished I went with more than just one person because we could have ordered more but for the fried chicken and pork, shoyu ramen I got, I thought it was good. We got there early since I figured if this place was so good, there would be a wait so we got a table pretty quickly for lunch on a weekend afternoon. The service was good and the food came out fast. I just felt the broth wasn't as authentic as Santa but I did enjoy it. Next time I'm in that area, I'd go back for a ramen fix.
author: Vivian L.

description: On a recent lunch trip with some friends I ordered a chicken teriyaki bowl. I was nauseated by the smell of fish (I despise the look, smell and taste of fish) when my meal arrived. FYI- it is not OK to pile a glob of stanky seaweed on an otherwise tasty dish just because you have some in the kitchen.  My advice to Japanese restaurant owners: if a customer orders a non-fish meal from a restaurant that mainly serves fish (hello? Japanese=sushi) then it's probably safe to say that that particular customer doesn't want any fish or fish-smelling items. At least the waitress could've asked me first. To all fellow fish-haters: beware of Katana-Ya! p.s. I don't hate fish, I just hate being forced to smell and/or eat them.
author: Melissa B.

description: They just started offering some new mini-donburi menus.  Our favorite is the uni and ikura donburi.  A small bowl, however, and a bit pricey at $9.  Service here can diminish rapidly when things get busy.  They forgot items we ordered and messed up on our billing.  Still - the best ramen in the city so definitely will be back regardless.
author: J M.

description: After reading all these fantastic reviews, I guess my expectations were set too high for this place. Yes there is a wait to get in but that's expected for a small restaurant. I can't remember which ramen I ordered but I just remember the broth being really oily. The flavor wasn't mind blowing but it wasn't bad. It was just okay. Maybe I just need to order a highly recommended dish next time so I can see what everyone else is talking about.
author: Kit K.

description: one of the best ramen places in the city!  the wait wasn't long either.. only about 10 minutes.this tiny little place only probably has seats for 20 people. the katanaya ramen is the thing to get here... with extra spice.  the miso broth is rich and creamy, with all the fixins including boiled egg, seaweed, corn, bamboo, fried chicken and potstickers on the side. also the noodles are chewy, not mushy and they give you a ton!  the sushi was also delicious and fresh tasting.  one of the best spider rolls i've ever had !  extra crispy soft shell crab.. not soggy.  spicy tuna was also excellent.  prices are little higher but still decent for a very filling meal.
author: Margie C.

description: Amazing RAMEN!!! Nice and spicy. Staff was great too.
author: Ashley C.

description:
very cozy place, feels tight only because the tables are closely put together and not as spread out and this place does get packed so come early!

the ramen was good, i especially like the miso soup base but i'm more fond of the ramen at majikku.  the fried rice was was ok, not much to my liking.
author: mea f.

description: Quite simply the best ramen house in San Francisco.  The sushi, however, is below average.  One nice thing is that you can park in one of the shopping lots nearby.
author: J L.

description: this place is my favorite ramen spot... i always order their katanaya ramen miso/med. spicy.  it totally hits the spot whenever i'm in need of a ramen fix.  their spicy crispy tuna is very good as well.  must try!
author: Kae B.

description:
I would starve if it weren't for Katana-Ya....really, I would....not only is the food excellent, and by food I mean the ramen..mmmm....but the service is always friendly.
Honestly, there are so many nights I'll be walking home from work, thinking what might be in my bare cupboards, when a little glimmer of Katana-ya catches my eye...and in I go. The "Spicy" ramen is excellent, and while I think it could be spicier, (I add pepper), it is delicious and warms me through and through on our cold foggy San Francisco nights.
I think I have tried almost all the ram en now, and while they are all pretty good, the spicy wins in my book. Now, you may ask why I don't just buy ramen for .$89 at Safeway and make it myself....well, this is NOT that kind of ramen. The ramen is flavorful, "meaty' ramen noodles, and you are left feeling full and happy.
When you come here, expect a wait, sadly, everyone else seems to know about my little hole in the wall restaurant...but it is worth it...believe me....
Not only is the ramen delicious, but the shaved ice with red bean and condensed milk....YUM! On multiple occasions I have considered ordering this first so that I'd walk home with the warm ramen,as opposed to the icy chill of the ice....but however you order them, get both the ramen and the shaved ice....I'm drooling....
author: Bianca L.

description:
this is my 2nd favorite ramen place in SF.  to me, the noodles feel a bit under-cooked, but it's really just the consistency of them that i'm not a huge fan of.  the food here is quite good.  they used to have combo's that were a steal - unfortunately those are now only offered during lunch.  

the wait can be onerous, especially at hours after 9pm.  but the wait at least gives you something to look at - the panhandlers and drunk people outside . . . parking is always tough, so take a cab or bus.
author: Jason J.

description: Awesome, and great portions.  So much to eat and definitely worth the wait.  I recommend any one of the combos with the ramen and sushi.  :)
author: R R.

description: Pretty good for a Ramen place. I went on a Sunday at an off hour and was seated right away. The food came pretty quickly. I had the spicy tofu and it was seasoned well. I would have liked it better if they had pan-fried the tofu, but that's not a biggie.
author: Priyam D.

description: I agree with everyone else, Katana-Ya has the best ramen out there. There has always been a line every time I've been here. I can't find another place that puts fried chicken in its ramen, which I love. This stuff clears my sinuses, while at the same time satisfying my craving to clog my arteries with fried yummies. Minus points for sucky service. OOooo I want some now just thinking about it.
author: Lisa H.

description:
So the food here has always been real good, but the service is always ify. 
my parents were in town so I took them here because they spend some time in Japan and I thought the would appreciate this. 

Well the place was super unorganized and they sat the people who came after us first. (no big deal the food is good) 

Then we ordered and they brought our beers (it's going well) 
Then they started to bring everyone Else's food. Wait I ordered the same thing as that guy but he came 20 minutes after me. 
Okay that's it..... 

45 minutes went by and I'm hungry so I went up to the counter 

me: Excuse me how long for our food.... 
her reply: oh...oh..... 
me: can I speak to the manager 
her reply: Manager? (I don't think she understood English that well) 
me: nervermind I'm going to leave (now she understood english) 
her reply: hold on (her english got a lot better and she look back at the waitress behind her) Go cancel their orders they are leaving (some girl ran to the back) 
Then she said: 16.75 dollars for your beers 
me: are you kidding me (she forgot english again) 
gave her 17 dollars made sure she gave me my quarter back and I will never come back....
author: R R.

description: A friend recommended this spot. I am up in The City to do some shopping with a friend and we wanted to grab something to eat. I got the miso based Katana ramen. The Katana ramen had a little bit of all the toppings: fried wonton, chicken, pork, corn, bamboo shoots... But what does it for me is the broth. The broth was rich and full of flavor. The toppings complimented the ramen well. The fried wonton gave a nice crunch to it. When I am back in The City, this is my spot for ramen!
author: Peter T.

description:
my boyfriend and i came upon this place over the weekend. What a relief becuase we really enjoyed our ramen here, and if we hadnt found it, we woudl've gone to our other choice of fast food - since we had to make time for a show afterwards. 
One thing i love is the atmosphere. i know its not much, but its one of those hole in the wall places thats inviting, rather than an obnoxious fancy place that makes me feel like they are going to charge an arm an a leg for mediocre food. I like the feeling of thinking all my money is going to go into the good food. 
The prices are a bit higher than the ususal ramen joint, but the portions are huge. i could've shared my bowl, as i was only abble to eat half. my broth was a bit thick and rich, i had the spicy tofu with soy sauce broth. but the noodles were good, and the broth was boiling hot. all good signs of a good ramen place. 
i cant wait to come back and try a different variation on the ramen.
author: Mai T.

description: Stopped in on the way home one day cuz  I was dieing of hunger.  I had especially low expectations which were quickly flip-flopped by great service, fresh fish and affordable prices.  I'll be back if the stars align.  Next time I'm getting some ramen cuz ya'll are raving about it.
author: Chard M.

description: I like their ramen because the noodle is yellow with good texture.  As a good ramen should be, using "kansui" giving it the texture and the color, or perhaps they substiute with egg?  Either way, we went back a few times just for ramen.  Had their poke salad once, tasty but we got sick afterward, so we'll stick with the ramen.
author: MooMoo L.

description: This might be the best ramen place in SF probably cause its really one of the only ramen places in SF. If you have a car definitely checkout Santa Ramen in San Mateo, which blows this place away by comparison. I've want to like his place bad and its one of the decent places to go if you are in the union square area, but really its just very average.
author: Artur R.

description: I trekked many blocks through the TL to get a bowl of ramen at Katana-ya. . . and I left disappointed.  I ordered the bbq pork ramen.  The portion was rather small, the soup (miso) was too strong (like it was coming from the bottom of the pot that had been simmering all night long), meat too hard (not tender at all), and the only toppings were seaweed and green onion.   If you're a ramen fanatic and live in SF, then it doesn't matter what I say since you'll probably want to check it out anyways.  If you got time on your hands and a car, then check out the place I recommend in Mountain View.
author: David L.

description: awesome, cheap, tasty and fresh!  the ramen is excellent and i don't even like ramen.
author: tiana w.

description: I still like the cold noodles, but the two other dishes I had here -- ramen and chicken teriyaki were not that great. The ramen was okay, if somewhat boring -- i wish there were more options and that the bowl had more toppings (think tampopo) and the chicken teriyaki was inedible -- fatty, too soft, chewy, all thigh meat (?) that had not been marinated for very long, if at all and just gross. I left hungry and sad that I just spent $15.
author: Melissa G.

description:
I like Katana-Ya because a) it's one of the few Japanese places in SF owned by actual Japanese people, b) it has AWESOME lunch combo deals at affordable prices, c) I always leave with a satisfied (sometimes too much) tummy and d) it's open late!

Of course I also leave feeling like I inhaled a large jar of MSG, but what the heck, it's worth it.  This most recent time I went, I had the combo with miso ramen and a hokkaido-don (with real crab, salmon sashimi and ikura).  I was expecting the portions to be small given the price but nope, they were full-size!

Not the best ramen I've ever had, but definitely worth trying especially for the price.
author: Lilo F.

description: The first time I came here I had the cold ramen, it was good but not as good as I felt Sapporo ya in Japan town was.  The 2nd time I went there, I went with my boyfriend and we both ordered combo ramen bowls, so we got to try the chicken katsu, the miso broth, regular ramen, tthe portion of chicken was suprisingly pretty hefty, and the buckwheat noodles, soy broth...it was all really good.  It's a little tight in there, it's been busy too.  It's a hip little spot, I'd go there more often if the food came out faster, but I guess it wouldn't be as good if everything was sitting around ready to go.
author: Charla M.

description: Dined twice. Ramen was consistently flavorful. Service was also consistently bad.  Better off to pick another ramen shop next time.
author: Jai R.

description: My husband and I were in the city this past weekend and had lunch here on Saturday afternoon.  The place was packed but there were some seats at the bar.  We ordered a spicy tuna roll and some mackerel.  Both were really yummy.  The spicy tuna roll was actually spicy compared to the many other rolls we've had at other sushi restaurants.  We also each got a bowl of udon with vegetable tempura.  This soup was really good...full of flavor and nice textured noodles.  Will definitely go back next time we're in SF.
author: Gabriella G.

description: Ok so maybe my bar is set pretty high for ramen so I won't gush but this is a decent hole in the wall place to go for dinner before or after the theater.  Noodles with a rich broth.  I picked soy sauce with chicken and the unagi don on the side.  My ts the picked miso with barbeque pork (give that topping a miss) and nigiri on the side, friend b picked miso with spicy tofu and nigiri on the side.  No reservations so depending on the time of day you could have a little wait and they're not really set up for large groups of people.
author: Gwyneth T.

description: i had been craving noodles for months, especially ramen...the spicy kind, the kind that makes you sweat and your nose run.  there was a line when we first got there but since we were expecting to wait, we sucked it up.  we loitered around the sidewalk staring pathetically at the couple slurping away in the window seats.  it was all worth the wait, the best ramen, worth paying over $10 for.  i ordered mine extra spicy and it was perfect (although it is probably WAY too spicy for the general pop).  the servings are huge, but i loved it so much that i slurped every last drop.  a few days later we went back to get our ramen fix again.  in fact, my mouth is watering right now as i write this.  this place is definitely turning into one of my favorite quick/cheap eats in SF.
author: Nana S.

description:
Rich crafted broth with real fat drippings. Yeah, sounds gross but if you're a real farmer working from sunrise to sunset, you need this amount of fat to last the day of labor. But, since many are now pale barely exercising office workers, it means NO deluxe broth but yes to the basic which is mostly skimmed. I find on weekends, there's little more fat floating around than I want so I avoid weekend dining here. It's nice that it's open till 2am. 
Portions are not as generous as I would like so I add $2 for extra noodles. I love these al dente noodles. J-town has more Ramen restaurants but a lot of them pre-cook the noodles to be able to quickly serve them which results in a mushy noodle. THis place is generally  cook to order. The pork is nothing to rave about and personally, I'd rather have some thing else instead in the basic. Basic is a few bamboo shoots, 1 slice of pork, green onions and some other stuff. Light on toppings, rich on flavor. I can no longer eat the watery broths at my former favorite ramen places in J-town now that I've learned of Katana-Ya from Yelp. Lunch combos are OK but go up a few more dollars for dinner. For that I'd rather dine on noodles ala carte and spend the $6-8 side item fee grazing on another item in another place later or on another entire meal at the nearby King of Thai. The chef brags about his gyoza being the best. It's very fresh cabbage, still sharp with sulfur (that's how fresh it is) with the thinnest of gyoza skins and tasty bites. The salmon flower for lunch is 4 slices with a small bowl of rice which complements a basic ramen nicely. So I recommend the ramen because the noodles are cooked to order and al dente. If you're not sure about ramen, watch the foodie film Tanpoppo sometime. It's a hilarious search for the perfect bowl of ramen. For staff, you gotta realize it's efficient but not super. No traditional follow up checks after the food is delivered to your table. If you need anything else, just get the server's attention. No goodbyes, no thank yous, heck, I usually see them turn their back on the entrance. However, richly flavored al dente ramen soup is what you do get. If you're friends, then you also get more smiles.
author: L P.

description: We were at the restaurant 10 minutes before it opened because I was told it would be crowded.  (There was already a short line at the door)  We ordered 2 BBQ pork ramen combos (one with kim chi fried rice and the other with katsu don).  The waitress brought an extra bowl so we could share the ramen.  The ramen was chewy and the pork was tender.  The salt broth was a little more salty than preferred, but overall the ramen was good.  The katsu don was ok.
author: M. D.

description: Who in their right mind puts fried chicken in ramen? This is not traditional ramen but a hybrid with Korean influences. I did not enjoy it.
author: Hawaiian B.

description: Not much of a selection when it comes to quality ramen in the city.  The best I would say would come from the south bay.  Broth and noodles are pretty good.  Sushi's okay, not the best.  Great hours, great go to place late at night.  Pretty packed most of the time.  But the turnover is pretty quick.
author: Chase F.

description: Yelp recommendations continue to bat 1000.  I enjoyed my lunch at Katana-Ya.  I had the ramen soup with spicy onion and miso broth.  It even came with an unexpected slice of tasty pork (vegetarians beware).  After $10 (inc. tip) I left full and happy.  The portions are really big.  If I had gone with another person we might have ordered one soup and one smaller appetizer and split both.
author: Adam M.

description:
I debated on whether to give them a one star or two stars.  After reading some of the other Yelper's reviews, namely others who are Japanese, I thought we would give them a try since my sister, my mom and I were planning to be in the city for the afternoon.

Living in the East bay, my husband and I go to San Jose to eat ramen at Kahoo Ramen.  In my opinion they have the best ramen package.  The second choice is Santa Ramen in San mateo.  The noodles at Kahoo are chewy and they include good chashu.  I typically order the shoyu ramen that comes with spinach, bamboo shoots and egg.  The soup is not too salty and it tastes robust.

At Katana-Ya, I ordered the shoyu ramen with a side of veggie fried rice.  The ramen noodles were ok, not quite al dente.  The shoyu soup must have been very salty.  I was thirsty all afternoon.  The ramen was not satisfying at all.

The fried rice had no taste.

My husband was planning to meet his son at Katana-Ya for dinner tonight since his son lives in the city.  I told him he would be very disappointed.  Even though I am sansei and he is a gaijin, he is the true ramen fanatic in our family.  I convinced him to make other plans.  I don't see any point to drive to the city to eat ramen at Katana-Ya.

My sister also had the shoyu ramen and she thought it was just alright.  My mom had the cold ramen.  She didn't have much to say (usually a bad sign).

A Japanese lady that works in a Honolulu ramen shop told us that she could not find any good ramen when she was in SFO.  Sadly, I have to agree.  With a city this big, that has a lot of food options and that has a Japan Town, one would think there would be many great ramen shops.  I don't understand why there isn't one.

:(
author: Jane N.

description: Very touristy location.  The ramen was littered with floating white specks, is that tempura batter bits? nope it's just lard.  A bit too salty for my taste, I would rather drive down to Santa.
author: Big e.

description: I went here to see what the hype was about in SF... the noodles tasted like spagetti.. Yuck! I just dont get the hype! the broth was okay but I couldnt compare it to the chewy noodles made at Shoki house in Sactown. I had bamboo in my ramen and it was hard old bamboo that i couldnt swallow.  the place was soo squishy and i had to sit elbow to elbow with other customers.. uncomfortable.  our wait was like 15 min outside... the waitress was agressive and then I saw some customers finish their food and they were just chilling for literally a minute and the waitress already went to kicked them out because people were in line, i get that but thats... awkward.... and you betcha I ate quickly and wont be BACK!
author: Mimi G.

description: My friend suggested this place for me to try because he told me that it was better than Santa Ramen and everything here taste good. I went to try it and was not disappointed. Got here around 6:30pm on a weekday and easier found parking and got a table for two at Katana-ya. I ordered the tuna tartare salad (good--light and fresh tasting), $12.00 spicyshio  ramen (chicken, veggies and chasu and it is very good--texture is chewy and very good), spicy tuna roll and the caterpillar roll. The spicy tuna is pretty fresh and the caterpillar roll is pretty good. Total cost for dinner was $46.00 including tips not bad for Japanese. I will be back and is going to bring more reinforcement so I could try more variety.
author: Allison H.

description:
there is nothing in the world (or is there? i guess maybe there is and i just don't know about it) like katanya ramen. the dish, not the restaurant.

ramen in miso broth with everything you didn't know could be put in ramen. fried chicken? check. fried dumplings? check. meat? seaweed? mushrooms? check x3. and the weird thing it, it doesn't get soggy! i think the combo itself makes a trip to katana-ya worth it. 

however, if you're just up for traditional ramen, this may not be the #1 spot. the miso broth was a little too heavy and salty, and the ramen itself was just eh. but put fried chicken and dumplings in it?!!! GENIUS!

yum.
author: Linda T.

description: My Favorite Ramen place in the Peninsula!!! I love everything they have there, from the corn butter ramen to the awesome kimchi fried rice.
author: Stephen C.

description: Excellent Ramen and solid if unspectacular sushi. Very good value and friendly staff. I used to live in the hotel Monaco across the street and would go here at midnight every Sunday after my flight from the east coast. They were always happy to feed me, even if there was no one else there.
author: Lager K.

description: Three words: Sapporo on tap.  :)  Ok, but in seriousness, miso broth here is tasty, especially with the katana-ya ramen or the fried chicken ramen.  I've been here three times and this place is packed each time.  I've had success in finding a table for two quickly during the 1-2pm lunch slot on a Friday.  A bowl of ramen with some Sapporo makes for an awesome Friday!
author: Olivia L.

description: I crave soupy soups - actually every once in awhile, or actually every week, so to satisfy my cravings,  I came here and ordered the miso broth flavored fried chicken. It was really yummy at first, but too salty and thick when everything settled, that's why they only get 3 stars, but deserve 3.5. I probably should've asked for a lighter seasoned broth. However, the chicken was really tender and tasty.  Will I go back? Yes probably and try a different flavor because I love noodle soups. Yum!
author: Natalie S.

description: We have a winnah!!!  My husband has been on a lifelong search for the next best ramen to his favorite place in Southern California and I think we've found one!  Their salt broth and miso broth are both yummy.  I had the kimchi ramen that had a nice spicy kick that seemed to clear my sinuses and pores all at the same time.  Paired with some gyoza and a cold glass of beer, I had a good meal.  Be prepared to wait for a table and you should probably take Muni or walk there because it's in the middle of Union Square.  Highly recommended.  I'm gonna have to go back for their other dishes.
author: Nina L.

description:
Take the advice from all the yelpers...get the ramen!  It was mmm mmm goooood.  Although I wasn't sure which flavor to pick out of...soy, salty, or miso.  So I went Eeny, meeny, miny, MISO (suppose to be Moe).  Rich miso it is!  I had it with the small bowl of tempura.  The tempura was pretty good too although next time I would rather pick something else, maybe the kimuchi fried rice or something.  The california rolls my fellow yelper had wasn't all that great.  I won't deduct any stars for that since only noobs order california rolls at a place that's known for ramen!  Well she had the ramen too.  

-1 star for unattentive service.  My water needed refilling!

I'm sure Naruto would give this about four stars too.  He'd probably take away half a star for lacking the swirly fish cake things and maybe another half a star for the lack of the egg.  I think the ramen place in J-town actually has those.  The price is great too!  It would only make a small dent in Naruto's frog wallet.  Naruto would probably want seconds after all the hard training he does to become Chuunin or Jounin.

ITADAKIMASU!
author: Nelson W.

description: If you are craving ramen, this will hit the spot, but I wouldn't rate it in the top ten of Japanese joints in SF. We had the spicy green onion ramen and the K-Y special so I think we ran the gamut. I don't think that Katana-Ya deserves all the hype it has, maybe it's because it's really the only decent ramen joint inside the city limits. What is worth the wait, the time and the gas? SANTA RAMEN. ooooh, I salivate just thinking about it.
author: G Z.

description: I was a regular at Katana-Ya years ago and loved their ramen.  It was hearty, rich and you can actually see bits of meat and know that the broth was made from actual bones.  I went back last weekend and was sorely disappointed.  It was overly salty and thin...like they used an MSG packet and a ton of soy sauce for color.
author: C L.

description: There are currently 425 reviews of this place, so I'll just add that it was yummy and quick. Done.
author: Leigh M.
