description: Who knew a place that looked this divey could be so good?  Came here because I was going to see Jersey Boys across the street in the Curran Theatre, and ran in here to grab something to eat before the curtain went up.  The place is kind of sketchy looking from the outside (and come on, who names a restaurant "knife shop" in japanese?) and actually kind of sketchy looking on the inside too.  But the ramen is top notch, and the roll special (2 rolls + miso soup = $10) is totally reasonable.  The bf was transported away into memories of Japan, while I thoroughly enjoyed munching on my spicy hamachi and salmon avocado rolls.  The wait staff is authentically Japanese too.  We were absolutely pleasantly surprised.
author: Rosalind C.

description: finally got in here to give it a try... straight up awesome and enjoyable.
author: Matthew S.

description: SLURP SLURP SLURP! Breath ...Chew.. swallow......Breath... SLURP... SLURP.... SLURP!!!!  That's all I do in there. The broth flavor is complex and the pork is very soft. Miso is still my favorite broth. The noodles are bouncy and a little bit chewy. Just the way I like them. I wish they have more bamboo and seaweed but that is just my choice. THIS PLACE IS GREAT! I think Katana-Ya is the only place  you can find that have good ramen and serve sushi at the same time. Plus this place doesn't put a hole in your wallet. Way better than santa ramen in my book! =D
author: Aylee G.

description:
I am giving this place 4 stars only because I have not had ramen from Tokyo.  After that disclaimer I can say, I think this is the best ramen place in San Fancisco.  I have not had the chance to go to Santa Ramen but thats not really in San Francisco so i can still  claim that Katana-ya has the best ramen in the city. 
 I went with my boyfriend who doesn't really have or understand the "Asian craving" for a bowl of noodles in soup.  For some reason he never understands my extreme desire to have a bowl of noodles in delicious broth, but he faithfully takes the trip with me to this hole in the wall to have the mouth watering dish of my culinary desire.  I explained to him that there are 2 types of broth rich and light.  For those health conscious and/or for those who gets nauseous at the sight of fat, do not order the rich broth.  The light broth is a little less fatty and oily but equally tasty.  I prefer the rich broth myself and ordered the perfect lunch combo of maguro don and rich shoyu ramen.  The bf had the tonkatsu don and rich shoyu ramen combo.  
They first brought out the tonkatsu don and maguro don which were both absolutely delicious and was at our table almost as soon as we ordered it.  The tuna was very fresh and the sushi rice was perfect!  After inhaling these two dishes, they brought out the object of my desire, and like pavlov's dog i was salivating at the sight of the bowls coming to our table.  My only disappointment was that it did not come with an egg or green onions!  I can live without having the sprouts, but i was almost shocked when i didn't see the egg and green onions.  But as i tasted the broth i forgot my gripe with the missing ingredients and was immediately placated by the delicious liquid.  
The house made noodles only added to my satisfaction.  They were perfectly al dente and had the right color of well made noodles!  
The total for this meal for two was just $22.50 not including tip.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
UPDATE
This place deserves 5 stars in my book Sill haven't been to tokyo but Katana-Ya and tokyo ramen places can't be compared (had a brain fart )....seriously, because I pinky swear that i ate here 4 nights in a row with different friends (not too many people i know love ramen like i do), and got the same regular ramen and maguro don combo, and i could have gone back for a 5th night.  Haven't found better ramen in this city yet.
author: Maria B.

description: Ok so I committed a total travesty, I went to katana-ya and did not get the ramen. Oops..... What can I say, I just wasn't in the mood for hot, delicious, tasty soup. Uh, what was I thinking? Anyway, we got the sushi and some snack type things including Alaskan king crab croquettes which were really tasty and the spinach with sesame salad which was also really yummy. The sushi was pretty good as were the rolls. They do have some more original rolls that I haven't seen before. Overall, good food, good service and I will definitely be back to try the ramen.
author: Cathy T.

description: Not my type of ramen place.  The soup was ok, but the noodles are way too thick and rubbery!
author: Mami S.

description: I had the shoyu light ramen. The noodle was very good, very chewy, but the broth was so so. The spider and california rolls were good. While the fried tofu's outside batter wasn't good, it had this weird chewy consistency.
author: Erica B.

description: I'm not a huge fan of ramen, but Katana-ya makes a pretty good bowl of udon. The broth was tasty and the noodles were well cooked and not soggy. Wasn't much in the way of toppings though! Just a little bit of wakame and green onions... could definitely use something else, perhaps some kamaboko.
author: Will A.

description:
Reasonably priced meal that satisfies every time - my weapon of choice is the extra spicey ramen + char shu, or fried chicken ramen extra spicey. Other than that, I'm a fan of the kim chi fried rice, but not so keen on the gyozo. Or the wait time during peak hours.

Not the best bowl of ramen you will have in the US (Ippudo in NY or Yotteko-Ya in Honolulu come to mind), but consistently good every time.
author: Brian S.

description: i was in a rush so couldnt have a whole bowl of ramen and was not that hungry anyways. so i had a yellowtail sashimi appetizer plate. service was awesome! they brought it out so quick! and even tho i wasn't hungry, i thought the sashimi tasted great! (i pretty much will like anything if i'm hungry :/) and there was a whole pile of it! not just a handful of pieces. it was a totally memorable mini-meal. want to come back and try the ramen!
author: Van M.

description: This place was supposed to be "so good", and I almost believed it based on the mob of people waiting outside for a table. But the service is poor, they ignored our name on the wait list for 45 minutes, and the inside is uncomfortably small. Add jacked up prices and so-so food, and you've got a recipe for disappointment. The kicker was when we ordered our food and was told they ran out of rice. Let me say that again: THEY RAN OUT OF RICE. Really? I will not be returning, and will not recommend. Go to any sushi restaurant in Japantown for better food, prices, and service.
author: Doug T.

description: Tiny joint but big portion sizes. Make sure to sign up on the waiting list first thing you get there, and be prepared to wait at least half hr. I had the miso katanaya ramen which is topped by karage and corn, a bit on the salty side but quite tasty. The ramen is fresh and chewy. I especially like this dish on cold days.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
I got an email from a co worker this morning:

Ramen?

Here was my reply:

So my wellbutrin was stolen on Friday and I've been feeling blue. Justine (my gf) , the sweet thing that she is kept trying to make me feel better. I mentioned that I had a hankering for Ramen on Sunday, but we were at home on Oakland and after searching on yelp, I could not find a guaranteed good bowl of Ramen in the East Bay. I was about to get into my car and drive across the bridge to to go to Katana-Ya when she brought me a mug of hot green tea. The green tea totally satiated my desire for hot Japanese soup so we went for just sushi instead. I ordered a bowl of Udon and it was craptacular. The sushi was great though. Yesterday, I drove in to work, and while walking towards Zeum, I felt that craving for Ramen so I turned around, walked up the block and then turned around again when I remembered why I was in the city and that I really needed to go to Zeum to check on things there. I made it half way down the block, and my cravings kicked in again so I turned around, walked back up the block and then kicked myself for being so impulsive and turned around again. I made two complete circles on Mason Street. Cut to the end of the day and there I am sitting in Katana-Ya slurping a bowl of hot Ramen with BBQ pork in Salt broth and a side order of Salmon Don. 

So, do I want Ramen today?  Hells yeah, but timing may be an issue. I'm not hungry right now and I have a meet and greet at 1pm. If your still hungry later, then let's go."




Jared
author: Jared H.

description:
So I arrived here on a rainy Sunday night 9 o'clock ish with 2 of my girls, got super nice free-SF-Sunday parking right across the street, and was happy to see there was no crowd of people indicating the possibility of a wait.  I guess we were the first ones to be waiting because it would be 10-15 minutes of torturously salivating at everyone's food while standing awkwardly where there really is no room to stand.  If it weren't raining, I'd have made a quickie shopping trip a couple blocks down to Union Square.  Finally seated, we didn't receive a ricebowl menu, but hearing about the Uni-don, I inquired about it.  The uni was on the special menu....and according to a supposed "fresh fish market days" rumor I'd heard, it wasn't a good day to eat sushi, so I opted for the Katanaya ramen with rich miso.  Girlfriend 1 got Tonketsu ramen with soy broth, girlfriend 2 got the spicy green onion with light salt broth.  

Katanaya:   Sizzling hot gyoza!!!  I resent you for burning off my taste buds so everything else tasted painfully dulled!!  Sigh.   I could still tell everything was pretty good..but oddly, the richest broth (mine) was the most bland.  The spicy green onion was good--just  t he right amount of spiciness and saltiness.  Tonketsu..was OK.  I don't think I'm into the whole dipping thing.  Piling noodles neatly into a spoon then balancing it with just the right amount of broth until i can catch the whole thing with my mouth without leaving a trailing piece of noodle sticking out is enough work.  Dipping noodles confuses me..how much soupiness is the right amount for the right taste!?  shrug.  

Anyway, the only thing about this place is that it's SO small..conversations become contagious.  As in, we would be talking about something or other, and then later the table (very)next to us would strangely adopt the same topic.  Granted we were eavesdropping too in order to catch that but....still.  Kinda awkward.  Not a place for intimate conversation I guess.  

Planning on returning here again for the sushi and some other type of ramen something reallllly soon.  Prices are friendly.  I was careful to watch out for the tricky-tip included thing according to other reviewers here but it was fine.
author: Tokki M.

description: Now, I'm not a ramen connoisseur, but this place did not impress me.  I love asian food and I am a big fan of most any kind of noodle.  I've tried this place twice now and been less than thrilled both times.  I ordered the spciy tofu ramen once and the green onion another time.  The food isn't bad and the service is decent but it is not the kind of meal I'd go rave about.  After the great reviews this place gets I was hoping to love the ramen here.  To me, it doesn't live up to all the hype.  I'd opt for a bowl of Pho anytime over this.
author: Laura B.

description: Just savory delightful bubbly broth....my favorite is the soy base ramen soup. Just UMAMI -wow.  You can tell the stock is reduced, layered and just warmingly delicious and yet affordable. Under $10 dollars for a bowl of ramen.  I love this place!
author: girl e.

description:
delicious and toxic. i always arrive drunk and leave full...which is to say i always feel way better on the way in than i do on the way out. some might call that my fault, but all im saying is, its not my favorite mistake. the other thing im saying is its a mistake im willing enough to make again and again.

the fried chicken ramen and katana ya ramen are where its at. definitely go extra spicy with miso. but then again, maybe im just a glutton for punishment [thats at least half right].
author: Jon W.

description: we came here because it was the "best ramen in the City".  the reviews weren't wrong, excellent soup base, good texture in the noodles and just enough toppings to where you will have some with every bite.
author: Wayne L.

description: I'm not sure how authentic it is, but I really enjoyed the ramen here.  I got the Katana-Ya ramen, so it was ramen with chicken, chashu, egg, some other kind of meat, seaweed, corn and maybe some other stuff.  Everything was so delicious, but my favorite part of all was the ramen noodles.  They were cooked to perfection - firm noodles that had the right amount of chewiness.  The wakame salad was good, but was pretty standard except it had salmon roe on top and rested on a bed of greens.  I tried some of the udon noodles, but didn't like them as much as the ramen.  Definitely going back here.
author: Linh N.

description: Ate here the other night, and thought it was good. The soup was tasty and noodles were thick and chewy. We waited in line for 30 min, but our food arrived quickly after ordering. Would've given this place 4 stars, but it's pricey and felt like they used a little too much MSG.
author: Mike L.

description: Visiting my sister in the city last night & got a craving for ramen at 9pm. The wait wasn't long, only about 15 minutes.  Everyone outside & inside was friendly. We both had the #12, I chose the miso & he chose the soy.  Both were delish.  We also had an order of uni which was very good.
author: Kathi S.

description: Bf and I decided to take our chances here for dinner on a Saturday night before seeing an Improv Show at the Shelton Theatre a couple blocks away. We were lucky enough to find parking a few blocks from Katana-Ya after parking meter hours were over. We only waited about 20 minutes before being seated at the bar. The space inside is extremely small and only holds about 8ish small tables. I had very high expectations for this place since the boyfriend kept raving about it, but I was slightly disappointed. The only thing that didn't disappoint however was the chashu. I ordered the Katana-Ya ramen, but I think next time I'll just opt out for the chashu ramen which comes with about 4-5 pieces of chashu. It practically melted in my mouth and I've never had anything like it at any other ramen place. The broth (miso) was okay, and the noodles were okay. The waitress said that the miso broth is more popular, but I think the soy broth is tastier. Not a bad ramen place, but I wouldn't come all the way to downtown JUST for Katana-Ya.
author: Lily Z.

description: got the shoyu ramen twice.  You cant go wrong with this dish since they are pretty much famous for it.  Add some ramen spices to the soup too; it will make it taste so much better.  Disappointed that the place is pretty small and the wait is pretty long.  But dont let that scare you away; it is worth the wait.  Will come back again definitely.
author: K L.

description: This restaurant doesn't actually close at 2;00am as stated on yelp, it actually closes at 1:15am. Me and a couple of friends arrived at 1:33am and was denied service.
author: Andy W.

description: as good a ramen as you can get in SF - lots of combos. too bad the wait is so long
author: David G.

description: I wouldn't come here for the sushi - we shared the Unagi Don and it was just ok. I base all my opinions of sushi places on the Unagi, and I've had better. We got the tempura curry side, and it was also ok. The curry sauce was so thick and pasty? The rainbow rolls were really unimpressive; the shrimp was tough, and some of the rolls tasted fishy. The crab was saturated in mayo, and tasted like fake crab. We also got two kinds of ramen. Ok, I finally understand why people like this place. We got the miso broth, and it was tasty. I guess I judge places based on whether or not I would ever crave it enough to come back. I would actually come back here for the ramen - it was a huge serving, salty with a big slab of pork. I had to strong-arm the waitress into bringing us the dessert menu since she was forcing the bill on us. Suddenly, we had a different waitress, who was so sweet. We ordered mochi green tea ice cream, and it was gross. I wouldn't recommend getting dessert here. Stick with the ramen.
author: Merrilee T.

description: I'm only giving Katana-Ya a four because they have the best Japanese ramen I've had in SF but they really deserve a three. The place is a bit grungy and there are a few shady people one has to dodge along the way to get a steaming bowl of their springy ramen.  I like the negi ramen the most.
author: Amber L.

description: What a tiny little place. I could seriously observe/eavesdrop on everyone else thanks to the mirrors. There was a good flow of people coming in despite how little seating there was. Kind of a weird atmosphere/crowd but the food was good. We had the soba noodles, salmon donburi, caterpillar roll, and baked miso eggplant. Service was pleasant and everything was yummy.
author: Resa W.

description: Very small place but cute.  Not only has ramen but also rice dishes, sushi and soba noodles.   Large portions for ramen.
author: Link N.

description: Went here a couple of times and would go back again for their sushi.  Yummy and served fast.  It's a small hole in the wall restaurant where not much tourists go so that's definitely a plus!
author: Melissa M.

description:
went there once for japanese...didn't really know it was basically a ramen place. I got the regular with soy based broth.

My friend asked me how it compared with Maruichi at Mountain View...which is kinda hard to do because I'm not Japanese, never been to Japan to eat ramen, and I've only gotten one ramen dish in both places. I think the one i ate at Maruichi is tonkatsu broth based...kuro ramen

I like them both for taste alone, but I would have to say Maruichi wins since it comes with hard boiled egg with slightly undercooked yolk, which I like so much. None in Katanaya's. Also, Maruichi has black garlic in it which is supposed to be good for you. Although, I did appreciate the seaweed in Katanaya's...since that's suppose to be good for you, too. But the amount of chashu was a big nono. There was too little, and it was a bit chewy compared to Maruichi's. 

Alas, I see myself coming here more often though since I live in SF, not in Mountain View.
author: Nayeoung K.

description: Not bad, small place, had the tonkatsu don and some sushi, good, would go back. want to try the ramen, looks great but wasn't in the mood for it.
author: Phillip K.

description: Honestly, I'm not sure if this place was so good bc I was craving some good day-after-drinking food or it was just that darn good.  I tried the katana-ya ramen and the pork cutlet curry on rice and they were both very good.  FYI - The portions are pretty big so if you're not that hungry, you could probably split either dish with another person.
author: Jo W.

description: One of my favorite places of all time.  I haven't had ramen in Japan yet but until then, I will worship this place. My favorites are the spicy green onion, and the fried chicken ramen.
author: L C.

description: The ramen noodles were still a little under-cooked when it was served to me. The broth is better here than Tanpopo, however Santa in San Mateo still reigns supreme in my book.
author: A B.

description:
not sure why i'm reviewing this place, since it's already wayyyyyy too crowded and i don't want to attract any more attention, thus causing my wait to be even longer! :P  

*sigh* ah well . . . what can i say, this place is quite tasty indeed!  much like my view on italian food, i can't stand mushy ramen noodles (*ahem* sushi rock you have much explaining to do . . . ).  luckily, katana-ya manages to get it just right, with noodles that are firm and chewy but not undercooked.  spicy tofu miso could stand to be a LOT spicier though . . . i can barely taste the heat at all, even after asking them to make it extra extra spicy

don't get the kimchee fried rice (i should have known better) it's very  . . . bleh
author: Vicki Y.

description: Finally I found a good ramen place downtown that's not pretentious. The noodle is good, maybe need to improve on the broth a bit, but it's good enough for me. The sushi here is good too! I was waiting for a friend and already starving to death so I ordered sake roll just to nibble a bit, and amazed that it was good. My friend usually fusses how good sushi should have even, rounded shapes, and Katana-Ya make just that. I think it was really worth the price. I went during lunchtime and there's only this one waitress for the whole restaurant and she did a good job serving us!
author: Maria H.

description: Very yummy although no veggie broth, but I guess you can't have proper ramen made with veggie broth.... So I get non-veggie broth with spicy-tofu as a compromise... it was very yummy. (a tad salty perhaps?)
author: Janel A.

description:
i like the small, cozy feel of this place. slim tables, red lighting, and ramen - its like someone set the whole thing up just for you.

some very tasty cuts of fish, and although the menu is a bit sloppy, it just encourages you to go nuts and just start ordering things off the top of your head.  as for beer, all they serve is sapporo.

being that its so small, dont bring a group larger than four, and be prepared for a wait on the weekends. oh and i saw something about being open till 2 on some days.
author: Darrell L.

description: This place was awesome!  L.M. brought Chris and I here after watching No Country For Old Men.  We've all been on a ramen fix lately so we all ordered ramen.  For starters I had som deep fried hamachi neck.  I ordered the Cha Shu Ramen with a miso soup base.  I combo'd it with a small bowl of chicken katsu over rice.  The place is pretty small.  Half of the small restaurant is tables and the sushi bar takes up the other half.  The room is painted red, and in the back is decorated with owls.  I found that rather amusing. Overall it was a good experience.   I'll definitely come here again if I'm ever in downtown SF hankering for some Japanese food.
author: Norm P.

description: One of my favorite Ramen places has seemed to be going downhill as of late.  So when my good friends took us to Katana-ya I was happy to have found a solid replacement.  Only been there once and it was great so I hope they are consistent.
author: Terence D.

description: After my first visit, I came back the next day and ordered the same thing I did the day before (spicy tofu ramen in miso broth).  The dinnertime rush on both nights dissipated around 9pm, so it was easy to find a table.  Better yet, I'm thinking about ordering take out next time and enjoying it in the square, which is just two blocks away.  I encountered some spotty service, but the food is good enough to brush it off.
author: Andrea U.

description: Ohmygoodness - I had THE BEST ramen here!  I've tried a couple of other places, but they definitely don't compare to the ramen here.  It's so flavorful.  I had the miso flavor and it wasn't just broth - there was texture to it.  I also indulged and had the "ocean roll" which was WAY too good.  The place is small, but cute and quaint.  I've already recommended this place to everyone I know...
author: ThaoLinh B.

description: Based on the last few visits here, I would upgrade the place.  The soup stock much tastier and on the money.  It is a small place which means you will likely have to wait.  Ramen that tastes deliciously wholesome - ganbate!
author: Teresa T.

description: One of the best ramen I've experienced!  The line and wait outside will speak for itself.
author: Brian F.

description: I have been there for many times!! I am a BIG sushi fan so I always go to get dinner with my friends! Also, there offer some noodle that is soooo good, especially, i like green onion and extra spicy one!  I know a chef "Gaddi" who is sooooo nice person! Katanaya is fabulous place! if you wanna go somewhere to get a great meal,  just go to KATANAYA!!!
author: Yin-Pei S.

description:
This place doesnt compare to Suzu in J-town. The soup is bland, I needed to use hella of the spicy stuff to make it have some flavor and the soup was so oily. what's up with that?!! I also tried their spicy salmon roll and that tasted better than the ramen! sad.....

I only waited 5 minutes since we sat at the sushi bar. Ok spot, but if I woke up earlier I could have gone to Suzu for dinner..tear
author: Crum B.

description:
Katana-Ya does one thing well: Ramen.

And only Ramen. 

If you're looking for anything else, I wouldn't come here. I've been here for lunch and dinner, and the wait is always long. I wouldn't come here with a big group because the seating area is tiny. The service is also slow, and you'd think they'd be fast at making bowls of noddles, but they're not. 

The Katana-Ya Ramen is bit more expensive than the rest of the options, but I like how it comes with a bit of everything. Definitely very tasty. That being said, Katana-Ya is a bit pricey for Ramen. If you just want a good bowl of noodles, head down a few blocks to little Saigon and get a nice bowl of pho for 6 bucks.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
KatanaYa has EXCELLENT ramen. they make ramen EXACTLY how ramen is supposed to be made. the little more "american" people should understand that in REAL japanese ramen

Pork = 1 slice only! no theyre not being cheap thats exactly how pork ramen is supposed to be (if you want pork soup..go to the pork soup store?) of course there should be more noodles (ramen) and soup.

BBQ pork = 4 slices once again. EXACTLY how bbq or chausu pork ramen is supposed to be. go to japan and see for yourselves!

and just FYI ramen is supposed to be a bit "oilyer" (Excuse the poor grammar) then regular soup..thats how its so rich!

so now that you got a little bit of knowledge on how good ramen is supposed to be u can stop and appreciate katanaYa's EXCELLENT a little bit more!
author: Duck M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place and granted I ONLY tried the ramen.  I felt the soup base for the ramen was a little bland and not too flavorful.  Their noodles weren't the best, but I didn't feel this ramen stood out at all.  

I did feel like it was a little expensive for what it I got.  

I went there on a weeknight and had to wait about 30 min.  I didn't think the ramen was worth the wait, but I do hope to try some of the other things on the menu.
author: Leslie C.

description: Ever since my trip from Japan Ive been searching for the best ramen. So far this place I would say is amongst the best! A hole in the wall but big on quality and flavor. I am definitely coming back for more.. did I mention that they also had Toro!.. 4.5 Stars!
author: DON G.

description: I didn't care for the miso soup, but that may be just that I ordered the wrong thing for my tastes.  I loved my sushi, and my daughter ordered a second round of the chicken karaage-that's how much she loved it.  Directly across from the Curran theater, so it's a great pre-theater meal.
author: H A.

description:
As the story goes, there used to be this Katana-ya on Judah and 5/6th and that was an amazing ramen place and tops on my list. I had been introduced to that by my cousin Andy who lived right around the corner and whom I was insanely jealous of since he lived in such close proximity to taste heaven. I would order the Yokozuna which was the special and it was enormous, being filled with pork, gyoza, chicken karaage, bamboo shoots etc. etc. It was simply an amazing meal.

Now why am I talking about that place in this review? Because it is now CLOSED!!! I was horrified when I heard that it had closed and I did not believe I could mourn the passing of good food. But I did. 

While searching a couple months ago for ramen places, I came across this thread on Chowhound that mentioned that the owners had moved to Geary which brings me to the present. 

Upon further reading, I was seized with the desire to find out if this was indeed the place on Judah. I met up with M for lunch who as usual was wondering why I was dragging her to a different place for food. Once we got there, I looked with great anticipation through the menu. I was disappointed to see that the menu was different but no matter, I decided to order the tonkotsu ramen (light) and M ordered the miso ramen. 

Once the food arrived, we dug in. Up to this point, I had never seen M remain completely silent while eating her meal. All I got out of her was "This is soooooooooo goood!" 

Verdict? I am not sure if this is the successor to the Judah place (5 stars definitely) but it's not the same thing. It is greasier and to top it off I was not able to order the Yokozuna. That said, it currently tops my list of ramen places. So do yourself a favor and check it out.
author: Jauder H.

description:
Last week this place was quite the revelation. When you walk in, the first thing you think is that the place is small. The next thing you notice is the customers are all speaking Japanese. This was my first time, but realize that Katana Ya is nowhere near J-town (that's Japantown to you). I ordered the mabo miso ramen which is what I'm currently fixated on in all Japanese food. The tofu was done to perfection (not over heated and not too soft), and the spicy hotness was just hot enough to make you sweat. It may come as a surprise if you think of ramen as an instant meal from your college days, but this is serious stuff. I look for a good noodle dish wherever I'm eating and this place is doing it well. I opted for the "rich" broth over the "light". I recommend the former if you like your ramen salty, the miso was full flavored and tasted homemade. The noodles were chewy enough, but not underdone. I opted out of the "combo" for something like $0.50 more, but I should not have missed out. My buds went for it, I wasn't hungry. The extra change gets you a small bowl of rice with your choice of a small entree, like tempura, or cutlet, sushi ($), typical Japanese appetizer-entree selections. The choices are many and varied. I gave it four stars, because I'm a fan of Suzue, but this place is Japan-legit. 

One minus: the location isn't a place where you can find street parking, so it helps to be in Union Sq. for shopping and coincidentally drop in. Sutter Stockton is nearby, so no big deal. There's plenty of other garages, too.
author: Patrick L.

description:
so, my friend is over at our house.  and he keeps going on and on about this awesome ramen restaurant that he claims is "right nearby" on geary.

so, finally, the boy decides fine. fine.  let's go.  after much debate of WHERE powell and geary exactly is, they decide it's not nearby at all (hour walk... at least, at 12 am.)  so they hop in the car, as i make my way to bed.  (stupid 9-5)

when the boy gets back, he actually wakes me up to tell me how good it is.  he risks his life and limb to tell me, "geo, so gooood soooooo goood."  i grumble and roll-over, unaware at how true it was.

next day, boy and i are wondering around by the moma thinking about food after i am done with work.  there is nothing really decent around the moma... so we walk and walk and find ourselves nearish to union square so we decide to ramen it up.  and i am glad we did. 

this all happened last week, and i have been back already after a night of some heavy drinking, we didn't like the club we were at and thought "ramen."  called up the "ramen crew" that we have now assembled and hauled ass to make it there before they closed.  even though we squeaked in right before they closed at 1-1:30 am, the staff was very friendly and did not rush us at all.  in fact, they seemed to enjoy us enjoying the food or they were very good at pretending.  either way, it was the perfect end to what would have been a very mediocre night.

i am now addicted to ramen.  i want it.  i want it hot with tofu and with kim chi.  i also want an order of fish cheese.  i also want an order of the pork spicy fried rice.  and i want some sake too.  yes, that will be all.  thanks.

i officially throw my hat into the let's-find-the-best-ramen-in-sf team.  so far, this is my favorite place.  i love the hole in the wall, and i love that everytime i have been we have been the only non-japanese people.  i also like that the waitresssaid "hai" instead of "yes" then correct herself.... for our benefit.  it made me tip her an extra $5 automatically.  

(note: the sushi isn't that spectacular, it's not bad... but you are here for the ramen, not the sushi.  c'mon, ramen!)
--------
edited to add: try their ceviche with halibut.  fantastic.
--------
edited to add: they have changed up their menu.  it's all extensive now. and yummy. and the sushi has definitely gotten better.  the ramen is... almost better than it was before, though throw cilantro in anything and i will leap off a tall building for it. 

the seaweed salad rocks my world and so does the fried baby mackerel. yuuuuummy, yummy yum yum.
author: Ge O.

description:
i really like their ramen even though

1) the waitress hated us for no reason and attempted to get us to go to another japanese restaurant nearby when there was clearly 4 seats available for us for lunch. my friend nicole responded with, "but we want to eat HERE, we dont want to go somewhere else." yea so we sounded whiney but i like this place and i was not trying to get kicked out for no reason!

2) lunch wait can be sucky, and parking there is even worse! tons of meter maids roaming on foot..we scored a close spot a block away but my boyfriend had to bounce early so he could sit in the car and wait for us to get finished paying and this was after leaving once we ordered to put more quarters in the meter (1 hour=6 dollars or something crazy like that!)

the ramen is oily, but i like it that way. ive been here 3 times with 3 different groups and we always left satisfied. the last time we got the chicken tenders (sorry i dont know the proper name) and they were really good. bonus: the nice chef came out and was sweet to us as he was clearing some tables. kinda made up for the crazy waitress.
author: karen n.

description: Excellent ramen.  I love the choice of light to rich broth, and simple miso, soy, or slat flavors.  Good and hearty food, no BS.  Especially rewarding on a cold SF night.
author: Jiajia C.

description: Within the city a pretty strong option overall - I pretty much go with the shio rich flavor ramen but my friend also likes the kim chee ramen too. I am not a big fan of the soy flavor. Noodles are normally good as well (only once in the last 10 visits was it a little overdone). As for the other dishes, curry is ok, maguro bowl is good, but in reality, I am often just enjoying the shio rich ramen and a beer.
author: Joe M.

description: This place is pretty good - been here a few times. It's not the best ramen, but pretty damn good for the neighborhood. I haven't found any better. They have excellent gyoza and the nigiri isn't bad.
author: Alton Y.

description: Most of the Japanese places that I've been to so far that serve noodle soups only serve udon, but this place has both udon and ramen, thank god.  They have a few broths to choose from...so far I've had the miso and it's so rich and flavorful.  I crave it once a week when I need a salt fix and it does wonders for hangovers.  Their sushi is good and they serve monkfish liver and uni below market price.  To top it all off...they're almost always playing sweet tunes.
author: Victoria G.

description: So far, the most authentic japanese ramen in San Francisco.  I had my favorite kind; good 'ol Miso Ramen. They even serve Houji-cha, instead of the usual green tea! The one thing I wasn't too fond of was the service here.  The waitresses were a bit gossipy about their customers.   Other than that, so far so good!
author: Mellie P.

description: I tried the Katana-ya's cold Ramen, Ankimo, Hamachi Kama and Spicy Tofu Ramen with my wife last week. The cold Ramen and the Spicy Tofu Ramen were so delicious, personally, i like the cold ramen the most. But, my wife liked the spicy tofu ramen more. However, the Ankimo was not the one we expected, it was not creamy than other one we had in other Japanese Restaurant. Also, I prefer the Hamachi Kama in Grilled style than in Deep FRY style. Over all, Katana-YA's Ramen is highly recommended.
author: STUSSY Dude E.

description: Can I give zero stars? The service was quite possibly the worst I've ever experienced. The staff was incompetent and very rude to us when our ENTIRE order came incorrect. We ordered tekka roll and asked for the rice on the outside. We also ordered soba noodle miso with BBQ pork. First a small bowl of rice came out and we thought "oh, the noodles must come with a side of rice" and dug in while we waited. A sushi roll came- not a tekka roll, but something quite elaborate with fish on top a "katana roll". We told them it wasn't ours (assuming maybe someone else ordered it). They insisted that's what we ordered and it took about five different people coming over to convince them we ordered a tekka roll. Meanwhile, our noodles came and they brought soy sauce based broth (which I cannot eat because of a gluten intolerance). We again corrected them. This time the manager(?) came over and was VERY annoyed with us insisting that this is what we ordered. He repeated our entire order that the waiter had written down as "katana roll, soy sauce bbq pork soba noodles, and a side of rice." We corrected the order and told him we hadn't ordered rice, but it just came and we assumed it was complimentary. He reached across the table and snatched the half eaten bowl of rice, "I'll take that!" and walked away in a huff. When the tekka roll finally arrived, it was not rice on the outside and the roll was filled with almost a tablespoon of wasabi (inside!). It was inedible. After one painful bite, we got up and said to cancel our order because we were unhappy with the customer service and our order was still wrong. The manager yelled at us, arguing that we still had to pay for the tekka roll because we took a bite. As we left, not 4 minutes since we'd corrected the order, our new soup was coming out of the kitchen (how on earth could they possibly have remade it that quickly?!) We threw $6 on the table and walked out. Rudest wait staff I've ever experienced. Nasty food. Horrible all over.
author: Sarah N.

description: This place is a stable in our places to eat. We are HUGE fans of ramen, and they do it well. About as good as Himawari & Santa Ramen in San Mateo but definitely not as awe inspiring. We will keep on going back there as there its the only ramen place in the city. Place is small, service is always good. We have had sushi a few times, nothing spectacular, stick with the rice. My Asian BF loves the kimchi fried rice, has to always get that (and the ramen). There is always a line, but it moves quickly. Again, ramen is good just not great. (Yeah I am picky)
author: ORLA L.

description:
No way is this place 4 stars and worth the hype!  Went here a few weeks ago on one of the really cold nights. Find many hipster types waiting outside. When I ask about the wait, a guy sneeringly directs me to list (which I'd already seen) and says something about " obviously gonna be a while."  Er, I may not be hip, but I sure the hell ain't stupid.  No way I'm standing out in the cold for 30+ mins for some ramen.  We went and tried Asuka up the street. That was my first non-top-ramen, and it was plenty tasty.
Yesterday I decided to try Katana ya for an early dinner. No line, 1/2 empty. Cramped in there for sure. Ordered the katanaya of which everyone writes. Yeah, unhealthy soup for sure. 2 little pcs. fried chicken, 2 gyoza, a slice of pork (didn't seem bbq'd), and 1/2 an egg.  In a miso broth. First they bring me one with a spicy chili broth, which I definitely didn't order. Okay. The place starts filling up.
My correct soup arrives. It's nothing special. It's actually quite a disappointment after all the raves here. Wtf? It's ramen noodles with some fried and fatty foods dropped in it. The gyoza were good, as far as soggy fried foods go (they're in soup, of course they got soggy!). The fried chicken was fried. and it was chicken. The egg was actually not very good for some reason. Odd texture.
I'm kinda complaining for two reasons: 1) does NOT live up to the yelp hype and (perhaps more importantly) 2) the PRICE!  OMG!  A bowl of noodle soup with small amount of fried appetizer-type food in it cost $14 with tax. with tip I paid $16+ for a bowl of ramen?? 
And what REALLY gets me is that Asuka's ramen, with more pork but sans the fried bits, cost about $6.50. It was a bigger bowl. It was actually much more satisfying. 
WHY are people raving about the katana ya ramen? I don't know. No, I've not been to Japan and I'm not a ramen officianado, but damn if anyone can justify waiting in the cold for 30+ mins just to spend $14 on a bowl of fried chicken noodle soup that only rises to the level of "ok."
author: Allucaneat G.

description: Been wanting to try this place ever since a friend, who's very picky about her ramen, suggested this place.  So, based on yelpers suggestions, I went there early with another friend (at noon), got the table to the right of the door, and ordered ramen in the rich miso broth.  Delicious!  Ramen was nice and chewy, like freshed pulled noodles, and the broth was very nice. My only mistake was that I had order the buttered corn ramen thinking it was "buttered corn" and not corn with a tab of butter melting in my broth.  I had to fish the butter out before it made my broth too rich.  Other than that...this place gets crowded fast! Wait staff was nice and patient, no matter how busy it had become.  Def will go back, but only when I can beat the crowd there.
author: Aimey T.

description:
hateee this place. 
i just went down there for lunch and my experience was horrible. 
i come in all excited and waiting for one of the two girls standing around to help me..no one came by..and if u ever think of gong here ...its small...really really really small..so with that said the girls weren't far away and they saw me..so why didn't they come over? 
another thing...they were kind of rude..the gave me the menu and walked away before i can ask any questions. i ended up getting up and leaving.. 

i went to lefty o doules ..how ever you spell that.. 
food there is amazing...and cheap..
author: Nelly L.

description: i thought this place's miso fried chicken ramen was much better than ippudo in ny's miso pork ramen. the broth was much better. this place indeed is crowded, we waited about an hour and a half or so before we were seated. the size of the table was for 2, but 4 of us were seated. get ready to meet your neighbors whether you like it or not. but that's ok, because the ramen is totally worth it. i got the fried chicken miso ramen, which is making my mouth water as I think about it... i shall be back soon.
author: S Y.

description: The noodles was fresh and the broth tasty. But I can get similar fresh vietnamese and chinese noodles with much more stuff for 1/2 or 2/3 the price. I really don't understand all the hype about ramen. I also don't appreciate the automatic 18% tip for party of 5 or more. The plus is that their tea was complimentary.
author: EnjoyGoodFood Y.

description:
This place was recommended to me not by one, two, or three food connoisseurs, but FOUR (two of whom are Yelpers--bonus points). First things first--you gotta beat the rush. Get here early and get your name on the list. This place is tiny and fills up quickly! It was recommended to me to try the fried chicken ramen in Miso soup, but I ordered the salt flavor because that is what I usually get at Santouka in SJ so I would have something to compare it to. Ramen was cooked well, not too soft, but not as chewy as it is at Santouka. The soup was good, but not as great or brothy as the tonkotsu ramen. I know they're different types of soup, but I think I prefer the tonkotsu broth more--I will definitely get the miso soup next time. The spicy broth also intrigued me and one day I will dig up the courage to try it.  Deep fried chicken deserves 5 stars alone--crispy on the outside, flavorful on the inside. And when it was soaked in the soup--OH BABY! I also ordered the fatty tuna hand roll. Their sushi's not anything to write home about--this gets 3 stars out of 5. Overall, they get 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4. Will definitely come back here again! 

Final Verdict: I was told this was the only good ramen spot in the city, The noodles were chewy and the broth was not at all shitty. The fried chicken is the must-have dish, next time I'll get the broth as spicy as I wish!
author: Dana F.

description: Best Udon! Love this place!
author: C J.

description:
They've got ramen and sushi. They're both really good. The last time we went, we got the standard ramen, which was filling, tasty, and not too salty. The sushi rolls are also really tasty--you can taste all the ingredients instead of a mash of squishy bits like a lot of cheaper sushi places--and the prices aren't bad.

Plus the sushi chefs are fun and gave us two hand-rolls just for fun.

Like other folks said, don't come here with more than 3 people, and be ready to wait a bit outside.
author: Emily R.

description: Katana Ya is a nice lunch spot in a great location near Union Square.  They have great lunch specials featuring their heartwarming ramen and an entourage of their delicious sides.  We arrived just after 1pm on a Sunday to discover a wait to get in.  The tables turned over quickly and in just five minutes we found ourselves tucked into a cozy windowside booth.  They feature ramen with a choice of soy sauce or miso based broth.  You can modify the density from light to regular to high.  For lunch, they offer bowls of their ramen with a choice of a side.  We selected the tempura (hey-its what we were craving) and the kim chi fried rice.  The tempura was pretty standard, but the kim chi fried rice was surprisingly delicious.  The ramen was also great - a deep flavorful broth, lots of noodles, a handful seaweed and sprouts, in addition to succulent slices of pork.  I only wish that they had more condiments on the tables to modify the bowl, such as bean paste, chili paste, sesame seeds, and garlic.  Regardless, it was a good bowl of soup and I'd be happy to come here again.
author: Thomas S.

description: The Ramen is good. The broth is a touch too oily. The regular ramen, extra spicy and fried chicken ramen isn't as good as Suzu's ramen, spicy negi and karaage, respectively. It is good though and a solid choice.
author: Andy L.

description: great ramen place, by far the best in sf (& on par with santa ramen in san mateo). it's a tiny hole-in-the-wall and the wait can be long, but the ramen is always piping hot, tasty, and hits the spot. i'm a loyal fan of the extra rich broth.
author: lois j.

description: I would never have known about this little gem if it weren't for Yelp, once again!! I'm always on the search for what 'real' ramen and this has satisfied my curiousity.  Not to be confused by the KatanaYa in El Cerrito, which I also left a review for, but this one is way better.  It's such a TINY place with TINY tables which was slightly uncomfortable and rather hot.  We all ordered the KatanaYa Special which I highly recommend because it has a little of everything.  Potstickers, corn, seaweed, mushrooms, and BBQ meat-- it was everything I could ask for.  I got the miso (light) which was perfectly delicious, but for you spicy lovers out there, just ask that they make it spicy and you will get just that.  My friend's soup came out RED but he sure enjoyed it (while sweating)!  There are tons of noodles which I couldn't finish, so don't worry about it not be filling enough.  Definitely coming back for more ramen!
author: Nicole G.

description: This place is terrific!  Although its hard to spot on the street.  It's a bit small, but thats not necessarily a bad thing.  There were tons of people waiting in line for our spot at the sushi bar, and we definitely had a GREAT meal with our ramen and ton katsu.  The ton katsu was so tasty, thick and satisfying.  The corn/butter ramen was alright in terms of flavor, but the noodles made up for it.  I felt the prices were reasonable, and the food was solid.  Love it love it!
author: Evan T.

description: Easy: you want ramen, they have the best, simply enjoy !!!
author: Alex A.

description: All and all, pretty good noodles and sushi, but I wouldnt lose my head over this place.  As mentioned in other reviews, the service is in need of help.  Perhaps the true glory of this place shines when its 2am and you're seeing double...
author: Porfirio R.

description: This is a 4-star Ramen shop for me because of its location, late hours and solid Ramen.  It bugs the hell out of me when reviewers slam a place for disappointing items that are not central to the menu.  Don't go to some cheap neighborhood diner and then slam it for using pre-made Hollandaise sauce.  That being said, the gyoza I had was without question the worst I have ever tasted.  The exterior was doughy and barely sealed, such that the contents were falling out.  Also, the filling was a sulfury, bland mash of cabbage and some other unidentifiable sludge.  I gave 4-stars because this is a Ramen place and the shoyu Ramen with Char Sui I had was excellent.  Stick to the basics and this noodle shop will not disappoint.
author: Kenneth N.

description: I love ramen! The soup is perfect and the noodles are slightly chewy. Light miso is the way to go. It is cheap (for the Union Square area) and the service is super-dooper fast.
author: J K L.

description:
ok...so um...yeah...its like good and stuff.



seriously though, there isn't really much to add to the previous reviews. i got ramen with the salt broth and fried chicken (food for the soul, not for the heart) and it was like ::turn on borat voice:: sex in mouth, high five! ::turn of borat voice:: for less than $10.

spicy onion and tofu don buri was pretty good (not quite sex in mouth, but pretty good) and was about $6 for a small bowl.

I like the combination of a ramen dish and a small don buri dish, very filling for under $15.

The only 'negative' would be the size of this place, but I didn't mind it since it added to the atmosphere. It was like 10-15 feet wide and maybe 50 feet long and the chef cooking area took up about 40% of that space so i'll leave it to you to figure out how much space is left. we came on a thursday night around 8pm and only had to wait 15 minutes for a 2 person table though.

also i think they really like beyonce at this joint cuz they played her entire triple platinum 2006 B'Day cd. also they played michael jackson...im not too sure to take off or add a star for these choices. i guess it was cool since i was tempted to dance and eat my noodles at the same time.
author: Varun ..

description: Don't get me wrong, I did honestly enjoy my bowl of ramen.  However, the wait and service is what I remembered, and I was not a happy camper.  A table of 5 of us had to wait 30+ minutes for a table on Sunday night, which would have been fine if the waitresses had been nice about it.  But after we waited for the table of 6 before us to finish, the waitress tried to split up the 2 tiny tables that had pushed together for the previous group of 6 and make the 5 of us sit at one.  All of us just chuckled at the ridiculousness because I don' t think 5 ramen bowls would even have fit. Then after one of my friends asked if we could push the tables back together, she tried to argue with us, then rushed off to talk to another server, complaining in Japanese about us.  Ramen's salty enough, we didn't any more from the waitress.
author: Anny T.

description: AHHH!! Ramen!!! This has got to be the best place in the city. I still dream about it, the delicious miso broth, the perfectly cooked noodles, not too soft, not too hard, the bamboo shoots, I'm getting hungry just thinking about it! Really great price for a bowl of ramen alone and it's a LOT of food. Staff it nice, place is small. You might miss it just walking by. They close at 2AM for clubbers (Ruby Skye is right at the corner). Last time I went was during lunch after shopping and a waitlist was starting. Is it worth the wait? DEFINITELY! Try it out! I had the regular ramen, and the ramen with the fried chicken. Both great! Can't wait to go back and try more. I'll probably save my next trip on a rainy or over cast chilly day
author: Sarah T.

description: Yummy! I love the tasty sushi and ramen here! They have the freshest fish I have ever tasted in SF. The only downfall is that the restaurant is a bit small and the waitresses are overwhelmed with the customers. When dining here we anticipate that we'll be there for quite awhile waiting for our check. If only they could expand everything would be perfect. Nonetheless I still crave their tasty entrees.
author: Sheryl F.

description: Based on the 4 star recommendation, I tried with my family (including 2 young children).  However, we got there by 8pm and ended up waited 1 full hour before we could be seated.  We tried the dragon roll, spicy tofu ramen, chicken udon.  All yummy except the chicken udon was so so.  Downside was the wait due to the small size of the restaurant and no waiting area.  Next time, I will probably arrive either earlier than 7pm or after 9pm to beat the dinner crowd.  Absolutely worth a try.
author: Wormy R.

description:
i'll give the little place 3.5 stars but i'm going to take away half a star for being so got dang dark inside.. so dark you can't even read the menu.. and i'm going to take off another star for the moody ass waitress we had.. she was Caucasian but fluent in japanese. shes got a huge attitude. i definitely would never come back here again.

the food is okay. its not bad by any means, but it taste generic, definitely not authentic nor even close.

bill came out to be 38 dollars for two people for 2 lunch combos and a glass of sapporo.
author: Michael A.

description: I found Katana Ya on Yelp after moving to San Francisco. I am a big fan of ramen and Japanese food in general so after reading all the reviews, I decided to check this place out. Katana-ya was easy to find, located at the corner of Geary and Mason. The place itself is very small, crowded...  Decorations are simple. The food is DELICIOUS. Anything from chicken karaage to monk fish liver, you can find a variety of dishes that suite your palate. The rolls are great, the ramen is one of the best I've ever had! Try the spicy option if you can handle spicy! Katana ya also offers a variety of sake and beers at reasonable prices. The place also opens late which makes it a perfect spot for some late night after going to the bars. Over all, I have to say Katana ya is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants! The only down side being, they do not accept reservations and there usually is a 20 minute wait around dinner time.
author: Ruilin X.

description: Best Ramen in town!  Make sure you ask for your soup base to be lite otherwise you'll be drinking water until you form a small lake in your belly.  The only reason I am docking a star is because they use MSG in every soup base.  If they could catch up to the times my eliminating that I wouldn't need the Oompa Loompas to take me out and squeeze all the water out of me!
author: Jeremy R.

description: after a wild wednesday night of drinking, thursday morning was just one big hangover.  i was hungry, but for what i did not know.  my friend suggested ramen and well all met up at katana-ya.  this little hole in the wall place was super small and super packed.  i ordered the katana ya special ramen with everything and it was DELICIOUS.  perfect for hangover.  i was wary of fried chicken in ramen at first but my was it awesome.  love katana ya and they're open late too!
author: Loan H.

description: I think I've had better ramen and sushi before. First of all getting here by car is the worst idea ever as parking near here will be near impossible. On top of that, you may have to wait maybe an hour to get your food. I ordered the katanaya ramen, spicy tuna roll, and the unagi roll. The quality of the ramen ingredients that include the pork disappoint. Also the sushi was a bit soggy and not as fresh I would have liked it. I would recommend Izakaya Sozai over this place as they have better quality ramen and appetizers. However, Katana-Ya does have more variety in their ramen.
author: Dave Y.

description: m.. ramen just ok, another stuff are very bad..
author: Roy C.

description: All other ramen restaurants are now ruined for me.  The ramen here is fantastic.  The sushi is also very fresh.  Reasonably priced.  Small space, but you'll get over that quickly.  I will definitely frequent this place!
author: Thomas R.

description: I do not understand the hype this place gets. I was greatly underwhelmed. If I wanted warm, flavorless water with cabbage floating in it, I would have made it at home for pennies. I had the vegetarian "ramen," and my husband had the katana ya ramen and he thought it tasted like dirty dishwater. So...the ramen gets no stars. But I do grant one star for the vegetable tempura, which was edible.
author: E J.

description: People kept telling me that I have to check this place out because I'm trying to find really good ramen.  I had the shoyu, friend had the spicy and other friend had the salt butter corn.  The shoyu broth was light, nothing super flavorful.  The spicy was super oily -- there was a layer of red oil sitting on the top of it.  The salt butter corn was OK, nothing spectacular.  For great broth and a super great egg I'd go to Orenchi in Santa Clara.
author: S S.

description: Their ramen is good, but not the best I have had.  I like the three ramen places (Dojo, Himawari, Santa Ramen) in San Mateo all more than any in the city.  I have tried all of the top ramens in the city and Katanaya is among the better ones.  The price is normal here or more on the expensive side for ramen and there usually is a wait during busy times.  The last time I was here, I was annoyed because I had asked the waitress about the waitlist and she was aware I asked and then a couple just walks in and went straight to the bar. the waitress didn't do anything until I let her know, but we got a better table which was cleared up not too long after so I accepted the wait.
author: John L.

description: I would give it one more star if it would be available!  My favorite place for a few month now! After eating there for a wile - I can't eat in other restaurants! The food is very good and I love the atmosphere there! Many Japanese people work there - it is a good sign for Japanese restaurant ... Ramen is great there as well as my favorite - uni-ikura don! Everything else is great too!
author: Vera S.

description: Pretty good ramen.  My 3-star rating is in no way a bad rating: for me it means It's not the best ever (5-stars), and I've had better at other specialty noodle shops (that I rated 4-stars).  But I'll definitely be back.  The service was good and the soup was tasty.  The rich ramen was super-rich and very tasty.  I will definitely be back and would recommend this place.  It is about $9-10 dollars for a big bowl.  The udon is also good and a bit cheaper.  Open until 10:00 or so.  Perfect on a cold and rainy day.
author: A A.

description: Dang - I love the ramen here.  I just wish it wasn't so hot inside because when I eat the ramen my temp rises even more.  Oh well, the walk home always cures this and the full belly from this place.  Don't forget to get the kimchee rice and the addition of the bbq pork to the ramen.
author: cristina t.

description:
Is this how "real" ramen was suppose to taste like? If so, then can I order a pot of bowling water, a bowl and a request to not throw me out while i cook my packaged ramen in your restaurant?

I went with a couple of friends because she loves this place and I will try anything new once and since she's like a crazy food critic, i knew this place would be good. As we got there I asked her to help me order, because i'm not really picky about ramen, so she ordered me a miso, bbq with egg. Before i got my ramen, i had the chance to try out their chicken katsu lookalike and it was badass. The chicken had a wonderful flavor with just enough salt and spices and the sauce was tasty. The butterfish was also really good and everything else was delicious. Okay now i've been waiting for about 20min and i still haven't gotten my ramen. My friends are either done eating or almost done eating. Another few minutes later my ramen came and my eyes gleamed up. Woohoo, ramen finally i yelled out (well i didn't really yell but i was happy inside like a kid playing in the snow fields, or playing with needles and fire, depending on how your childhood was) I took my first bite and --------------wat the hell was this? The soup was just salty, it doesn't really have flavor, it was just salty and the noodles was undercooked so every bite was like a tug o war. I just ate the bbq pork which i thought would look like the red chinese ones because i loved those and that's about it. I left the undercooked noodles to dine in hell with the salty mixture of water, some blackness and buckets of evil known as salt. I would've given this place a  2 star if not for the pretty waitress there, the pretty one, not the old one. Although i'm pretty sure she was quite the hotty when she was in her 20's.
author: Will C.

description: Went with some friends at night to this tiny place.  It's really cramped but serves some really good noodles :P.  I ordered a Chicken Karaage with rich miso broth and it was delicious.  Pretty close to what I remember when I went to noodle shops when I visited Japan.  Sushi was also very nicely presented with two sauces along with the usual wasabi and ginger.  Yum!
author: Patrick C.

description:
cleanliness: 4/5
food quality: 3.5/5
service: 3.5/5
cost: approximately $10
other: nothing special, but they are open late! =)

what i ordered: ramen combination with chashu donburi

I gave this place a 3 because they weren't great, but they weren't horrible. If the location were better i'd probably go back. It's nothing i'd write home about, but it's not bad either. Because there were a few unusual/unexpected incidents we had to wait a rather long time for such a small place.

I'm not a ramen expert, but i've had my share of ramen. The combination wasn't a bad bargain for a small donburi and a decent sized bowl of ramen. I thought the base was a little thick (but hey i ordered heavy on the base). The portions of the chasshu could have been better and the taste could be better too.

Despite the average in service and food, my experience hear was topped off by 1.) a weird homeless person who came in and caused a scene but luckily there was a local worker eating and stopped her from making a scene and kindly guided her to the door and 2.) a tourist (?) forgot her wallet and could not pay. She told them she would go back to her room and get her wallet or otherwise it had been stolen. i was expecting her not to come back, but 15 minutes later she came back. 

I guess my overall experience wasn't great and will try to come when weird things don't happen.
author: edie t.

description: Metcha umai!!! the absolute BEST noodle shop, if you speak Japanese.  You'll get crap service if you walk in and ask for californa roll, and may spit in your food, diarrhea boy.   Go there, and know what you you want.  Go to Bennigans if you want smiley friendly chatty waitress.  Go here if you want the taste of authentic kote kote miso ramen.
author: Kiyomi M.

description: The ramen here is okay--better than instant but not really that great.  We went once for dinner and once for lunch, and we only tried the ramen.  The broth is a bit oily, and on our second visit both our soups had an odd metallic taste--and we had one miso and one salt--and the noodles were a little undercooked.  The kimchee in my ramen was excellent both times, and my husband liked the chicken karage in his soup.  The prices are pretty typical for the Bay Area, and the service is fine.  The restaurant is tiny, and it looks better in the dark.  The ambience could definitely use some tweaking:  indoor/outdoor carpeting, not good paintings, loud music.  We're on kind of a noodle kick, but next time we don't have time to go to Santa we'll stick with Jtown.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Ordered the bbq pork ramen with salt broth.  Delicious broth and perfectly cooked ramen.  Minus one for the service, but who needs service with ramen this good?
author: Derek C.

description: Delicious and pretty damn cheap.  Two people for ramen, kimchi & gyoza appetizers, sake, and a beer, with 20% tip and tax: $48.  And it was absolutely delicious.
author: Nils J.

description: For those who appreciate the charms of late night noodles, Katana-Ya is your place. While the space is cramped, the main attraction is the ramen and the  beer.  The miso based soup is rich and soothing, like a velvet blanket for your tongue.  The shoyu soup base is pleasantly tangy and pert.  While this is not the best ramen that I've ever tucked into, it is certainly one of the most accessible and convenient for those out and about in the Downtown area of San Francisco at night.  Part of the charm is the ceaseless jpop background music, replete with Utada Hikaru and Yuna Ito songs.
author: bryan o.

description: Ask anyone that knows me.  I'm not a fan of ramen so this review will be based on a non-ramen experience... which turned out quite well.  I recommend the king crab croquette and curry chicken udon but stay away from the eggplant dish (I forget the exact name).  It's like eggplant puree under a heavy layer of over salty sauce - can't even taste the eggplant.  All in all a good experience though and I would def go back.
author: Yve T.

description: I first came here maybe two months ago and I think I've eaten here 5 times since  - that's how much I love it! It's conveniently located at Union Square and the noodles are delicious. I've tried several different ramens and the udon and all of them hit the spot. The one downside is that it's small and you often have to wait 15 minutes to get a table. I think groups of 4 or more will have a much harder time getting in, but with 2 or 3 people the wait it totally worth it.  YUM!
author: Carolyn C.

description:
before dinner - 

Waitress: Are you ready to order?
Me: Yeah, can I get  pitcher of Sapporo?
Waitress: Sure. Is that it? 
Me: *a straw for my pitcher of beer?* uhhh, yeah?? 
I came here to eat too. Not just drink

after dinner - 

Waitress: are you done with your ramen?
Boyfriend: yes, I am. Thank you.
Waitress: Do you want to keep your chopsticks? 
Boyfriend: *for what? souvenir?* uhhh, no thanks.

The food was good, but as you can see the service was a bit odd. lol. 

My boyfriend and I both ordered the Green Onion Miso Ramen. It was very good, but the waitress didn't ask if we wanted Rich or Light Miso and I think she gave us the rich miso. (at least I hope it was the rich miso)  It was a bit salty (so I wonder how salty the "salty flavor" would be). My friend ordered the Poki salad and it looked good too. We ordered the crispy spicy tuna for appetizers, which came after we were almost done with our soups... but it was still good. 

The place is kind of small. I don't recommend going with a large group because most of the tables only sit 2-4 people. 

I would definitely go back to try the rest of the ramen flavors. It'll have to be on a cold night though. :)
author: Linda I.

description:
I like it very much. I went with my peeps from work for lunch. I got sushi that hit the spot, although it wasn't the best sushi I have ever had.

The goyza were to die for and so was the fried tofu appetizer.
I tasted some of the ramen soups that my friends got and it might be the way to for me next time... unless I just order 3 orders of goyza.
author: Lucie T.

description:
so far the best sushi i've had in SF, and i've had a lot of sushi. my friend and i went about a week ago and had the hawaiian roll- 2 pieces each of bbq eel, butterfish and tuna, which was fantastic. i wished i had ordered 2. 

they said there'd be a 30-45 minute wait and there were about 15 people waiting outside. we put our name on the list and headed down the street for a post-work dirty martini. we decided to check back in 20 minutes and we were instantly seated. 

we ordered, the food arrived 5 minutes later and the wait staff was friendly. she even told us that the larger size katsu was probably going to be too much food for us if we ordered a roll and soup. i wish more waiters would do that. she wasn't condescending and i didn't think she was calling us fat. just helpful.
author: Heidi J.

description: Rainy Day calls for a hot Ramen in the City of San Francisco.  It was okay.  Place is too small.  A little overpriced but again, it SF.  I ordered the Ramen with everything in it and it tasted good but NOT oooohhhh, yummy! I would've given them 4 stars if it wasn't for the snobby host/waiter who would literally push you outside to wait (I guess it's like Japans' subway! LOL!)  Not a smile or greeting of Hello, Welcome, or Please.  Not sure if they are really Japanese 'coz that's not a Japanese etiquette for a restaurant.  May go there again if next door restaurant is full and they have less wait time.
author: Lauren C.

description: Best Ramen I ever had. My wife and I ordered a Ramen each. One with soy sauce and the other with Miso. Both were really good, though we both personally liked Miso better.
author: Mohit K.

description: This place is great for ramen :) It's a small place but the ambiance is great and social. Love the cilantro ramen or the regular ramen both with miso flavor.   Oh and the Kara-age and beer are awesome as starters.
author: Isaac V.

description:
I just ordered 2 BBQ ramen with miso and extra bamboo tonight at around 9.
Little did i know when i came home, i found no bamboo in my ramen, but they gave me extra seaweed instead. they charged me $2 extra
One BBQ ramen came with stinky BBQ pork,
I mean smells like the dirty intestines, it reeks, i can't even put it in my mouth.

This is the second time i order from this place and i swear i will never go back again.  Tonight, my gf and i have resorted to go to McD for dinner.
Thx a lot .
author: Dexter C.

description: I went here, because my brother told me about this place.  I really didn't think it would be that good, but I have to say, the Miso Ramen Noodles, were really really good!  Service was adequate, and they bring the food out fairly quick.  I would love to give this place 5 stars, but I think it lacks in size.  Luckily I didn't have to wait for a table, but I can see if gets busy, you might be waiting a while
author: Steven L.

description: Pretty reasonable pricing, great selection of dishes, surprisingly hip and friendly atmosphere, and quick and prompt service.
author: Eric W.

description:
i love this place's location! walking distance from union square and right across the street from curran theatre!! be warned though, there is usually a wait, so if you're trying to catch a meal before your show, make sure you get there early. however the service is great and the food comes out fast, which is perfect  if you're running short on time..

the first time i came here, we put our names on the list but was running close to our show (rent).. so we ended up ordering a couple rolls and eating it inside! totally ghetto and unclassy i know but we were starving!! anyways, i forgot what rolls we got, but it was not very good... perhaps we just didn't know what to order... 

the second time we came here, we had tickets to watch in the heights and go there an hour before and waited about 30 minutes. we got seated right as we were about to lose hope and go somewhere else. we were smarter this time and actually read the yelp reviews before coming and found out they were famous for their ramen! thus, we ordered: 
-- their special/combination ramen with everything in it (forgot their official name) - the ramen good, the soup good, the toppings good. what more do you need? 
-- small sashimi donburi- it really is small but it was SOO good. it had sashimi, fish roe, crab on top of rice!! 
-- kim chi fried rice - not too spicy. this was just ok. 
-- warm sake - oooh i wish i knew what kind it was so i could have some at home. but it went down so smooth! so delicious! we ordered a small and between 2 people, i think we had about 5 cups each!! so it was a good amount. it was not strong either, cause if i had 5 shots of vodka i know for a fact i would be feeling it, but not sake! 

the service here is great! the waitresses are very helpful, as we had asked for recommendations. and the food comes out so fast! it is a bit tight for seating because the restaurant is so small and they almost always have people waiting outside but i never felt rushed. definitely worth the wait and i want to come again! :)
author: Jen S.

description:
Small place, expect long waits, but food is good.

We got a good seat after our 30min wait.  The service was alright and the food was really good - spicy ramen dish rocks!
author: RT M.

description: Good ramen. I had the combo miso ramen and tonkatsu. Both were solid and plenty of food for the price. Would definitely go again. Would put it on par with my other ramen fave, Ryowa in Mtn View.
author: Mike C.

description: Sushi okay, rice okay, ramen good. Price good. Quick service, nice waitresses.
author: Heidi P.

description:
i completely agree with Toro E.  It is the best ramen shop in SF. i tried the rich flavored shio chashu ramen.  i liked how they give you lots of noodles and fatty soup!! love love love it!!   

i'm definitely going back there to try the other stuff.
author: E S.

description:
yesterday, i went out to celebrate my birthday with some friends. the servers were kind and efficient. we were seated quickly even though we had a large group in a small restaurant.

the food was great and there was a lot to choose from. i had the regular udon and i was also able to try the kimchi ramen and bbq ramen. others at my table ordered the unagi over rice. i am often disappointed in ramen places because paying $7.50 for something i could buy and boil for 59cents is frustrating, but this place is great. i will definitely go back again.
author: Katherine F.

description:
This is definitely the second best ramen in the city.
The soup is delicious and so are the noodles.
I almost always get a miso chashumen, but thats just me.

I had to give this place 4 stars for the following reasons:

The recently changed their menu to a "dinner menu" which means the same thing I used to get costs me $10 more... I still go almost weekly.

I say its the second best because the best is in japan town (tanpopo), and only because they have Tonkatsu ramen (it doesnt call it that in the menu, its some other name, ask for it, its delicious).

But this place is definately worth a shot or two, I go here weekly because it is a few blocks away from my house and they are open til 1:15 - I get hungry at night :)
author: Tenkai K.

description:
Spicy tofu ramen with miso broth. Yum. 

If you like ramen, you'll like Katana Ya. 

Service isn't quite 5 star, but not unfriendly. The ramen more than makes up for it.
author: anna l.

description:
ok so i've had better ramen. i should start this out with that confession. like i've had wayyy better ramen. this place in san diego, tajima.... omg that place rocks! 
however, putting tajima aside, katana-ya is good ramen. it's good ramen for where it's located. it's priced decently for being right next door to union square. the noodles are chewy yet light. i'm not a fan of their broths.... they smell slightly... off. 
personally, i'm a big fan of their oyako don. it's such a simple dish but so many places can jack it up. this place does it really well.
and the atmosphere is appropriate: crowded, steamy, talkative, and homey. just like how all of our family parties used to be with the variety of asians chatting up a storm.
author: rachel b.

description: Had the Kimchee ramen and gyoza. Absolutely fabulous and definitely hit a spot especially on a cold foggy afternoon. Get there earlier to beat the lunch crowd.
author: Maye C.

description:
Delicious substantial (in that great chewy but firm way that only ramen can be!) Ramen! They will even make a vegetarian miso broth if you request it. (Not so "authentic", I know - but hey!) 

Cheap sake - $7 bucks for the large carafe.
author: Nors P.

description:
great ramen! loved how I could choose how rich or light the soup would be.. this is good as I didn't really like ramen before as it's always too salty.. this is way better.. 

there's a part of the menu that is a bit confusing since they give you this pie chart of options.. but, if you have time..go through it as I my friend said it gave her a lot of choices.. or you can just order from the non-pie chart side..

would definitely go back..however, the place is small.. the wait is long..especially if you have 4 or more ppl! the key, go by yourself or go as a pair..
author: Linda Y.

description: The place is pretty small, perfect for parties of 2, good for parties of 3-4, and okay for 5 or 6. My friends and I ordered the Katana-Ya Ramen and were pretty impressed by the taste. Crunchy gyosa, savory miso broth, tender pieces of pork...all made up this oralicious experience. I would have hoped that they had more spicy options or incremental levels of spice....and offering Siracha just won't do. This place also offered sushi rolls, but I would rate those alone on average, wasn't WOWED by them. I would definitely return to try their ultra spicy ramen.
author: Jamie S.

description:
A convenient location near Union Square, and what I consider to be above-average ramen for SF. I noticed a Chinese chef behind the counter (one of my pet irks). 

They're open late, and there's often a small line depending on the time of night.
author: Josh L.

description: the miso soup is perfect and the ramen is exquisitely executed.
author: Regina C.

description: I come here on occasions with my co-workers and friends when in the city, I love the fact that they open late and the atmosphere of the restaurant makes it perfect for lounging and enjoying a good meal after a long day at work, even though people are waiting outside for seats. I love the grilled salmon don (comes in small or regular). I usually get the regular cause' I'm a girl with a big appetite =). It's crunchy and you get this taste of ginger. I don't know what they put, but I'm hooked on it. Another thing to try is their e x t r a spicy ramen!! If you like spice, go for it!! It tastes so good with the miso broth and the one piece of meat they give you, the best f***ing meat I have ever tasted!! I like sitting at the bar too, makes you feel cool. I give this a four star because sometimes they forget to give us menus and take awhile to get our order, but it's understandable because they can get real busy. Also, they don't have salmon t e r i ya k i!! Like c'mon, what kind of Japanese restaurant does not do salmon teriyaki? It's like the one thing you can't ever miss seeing on the menu.
