But overall, I love the place and it's always great for people who love late night eateries and super good ramen. Cheers to Katanaya for keeping the place awesome every time I go!!
author: Genatan O.

description:
By far the best ramen in the city.  I found this place on Yelp a few months ago and have been coming back nearly every week.  The sushi is pretty good but honestly the showpiece here are the noodles.

Since they're open late it's the perfect place for a late night meal.  I highly suggest Katana-ya.  In fact, I may see you there tonight!
author: Elijah T.

description: I've had a lot of ramen in both Los Angeles and New York and the ramen at Katana-Ya is good.  I was put off by the MSG mention on the menu.  I had the spicy tofu ramen with soy broth and I appreciated the flavor rich broth, which is really what makes a great ramen great, but I wasn't blown away.  Expect a wait outside (which, really, any great ramen place will have a wait).  It was a nice little experience but I wouldn't frequent this place.
author: Tabitha S.

description: good ramen. fast service. long wait. well priced. not so nice with customer service but ill let it slide cuz theyre always busy.
author: jenn h.

description: I am definitely a fan of this place. I love the 49er roll and Extra Spice Ramen with miso Flavor. Delicious!!!! Only down-side to this place is their wait time. The line is pretty long at night, mostly because the restaurant is tiny but definitely a local place, with couple of tourists that are attracted to crowds.
author: M L.

description:
Food: 90%
Service: 70%
Decor: 85%

I miss Japan, and how you can get all the soup you want in a ramen house. Lately, other than Ryowa, the only ramen I've had was the kind we all ate during college. Luckily, my GF was craving ramen, and we stumbled into this place. 

Damn..this place hit the spot..the ramen was flavorful and delicious. The giant sapporo went down well with the ramen and the crunchy spicy tuna roll. Great ramen shop..The decor was like a hole in the wall, but I'd say itd a great date place due to the dark cozy atmosphere (assuming your date is down to earth and not a gold digger). Service was a friendly, but they did take their time..Also, I think I was overcharged. Thank you Corporate credit card.
author: Adrian G.

description:
It was a cold and wet night last night and we decided to see a movie.  during the movie my stomach growled and everyone turned to look t ofind out the noise.  After the movie , we decided to feed my hungry stomach with a nice warm hearty bowl of ramen.

The noodles were great and plentiful and the broth was well brothy.  You had 3 to select from: Salty, miso  or soy.  I did not know what salty was and soy would be too salty and miso=salt so i picked the less salty one which is miso.


I will return.
author: kenny l.

description: I went here last Tuesday night. The food was ok here, and I had BBQ pork ramen. The soup was ok, but the pork was quite tasty. Very small place, if you want to try, avoid the regular eating time. P.S. if you go by yourself or one friend extra, that's ok. their table are mostly for two customers, and they also have bar seats.
author: Jerry H.

description:
Stopped in here for some allegedly great ramen soup - blech, was I disappointed.  I ordered the tsukemen and edamame.  The edamame was OK, nothing special.  To me, when a restaurant is actually making an effort the edamame is served slightly warm with a little soy or salt on it.  This was just cold and plain.  But I can live with that.

The Tsukemen was very disappointing.  This dish is served with noodles and chicken in one bowl, and the broth in another with a hard boiled egg.  The broth was GREASY and heavy (imagine the brothy goop you get when you roast your thanksgiving turkey, and you have to separate the grease from the good stuff to make your gravy - this broth was like the pre-strained version of that).  I couldn't really taste the broth flavor beyond the greasy taste. The noddles were in a big clump in the bowl, which made it very difficult to get a bite sized piece to dip in the broth.  Even after picking up a clump and getting it in the bowl, it was very hard to get an edible sized portion without splashing broth everywhere.  The "chicken" was pretty much an unidentifiable looking piece of deep fried something or other.  As for that hard boiled egg, how the heck are you supposed to eat a hard-boiled egg with just a pair of chop sticks and a spoon?

Overall, this dish left me with a pit in my stomach even after eating only a third of it.  It was so greasy I had to go get a frozen yogurt just to cut the greasy feel in my mouth (then brushed my teeth when I got back to the office).  

The topper was the guy squeezed in elbow to elbow with me at the bar, slurping his noodles with great noisy abandon.

Yuk, I won't try this place again.
author: Kathleen B.

description: Great ramen noodle soup by far.  It's definitely not a place for sushi.  I never see people who works there ever smile.
author: Nume C.

description:
+'s: good slurpelicious ramen.  fast unpretentious service.  reasonable price. 

-'s: servers bad at giving directions.
author: apurba p.

description:
hungry?

katana-ya is your answer.  they serve HOT and HEARTY bowls of ramen leaving you satisfied and smiling.  mmmm i slurped up every last noodle in the bowl and was about the pour all the soup down my throat, but luckily my sodium conscience stopped me.  i had the kimchi ramen with miso soup and it was great!!! not too salty and not too spicy.  also had the osha(?) roll, spicy with lots of seaweed on top! yummmm

geez i think i just worked up my saliva glands...

PRICE:  the ramen are around $10 and the sushi rolls are largely under $10.  their rolls are also a good size.

SERVICE:  they were very nice.  no complaints.

AMBIANCE:  really small, cute, modest place... yet clean and neat.  darkish with a sprinkling of festive lighting. i like.

Highly Recommended.  i'm sure coming back!
author: Christina L.

description: I thought this place was pretty good.  We stayed at a hotel only a block from here and every time we would walk by there would be a huge wait outside, so you know it's popular.  Our wait was about 20 minutes or so and we didn't mind even though it was raining out.  The host and server were friendly to us, didn't feel out of place or uncomfortable.  We were seated at the sushi bar but they offered us a table where a couple had just finished.  We were fine at the bar.  I've been to four or five different ramen places and my favorite noodles and broth combo are at Santouka.  This place would be a close second in my book.  The noodles were good, but different from Santouka.  The broth was excellent.  I opted for the rich miso with a bit of spice.  I ate it all.  Hubby had the light version with extra spice.  He ate it all.  They had this really good plum wine, too, kinda sweet in a small bottle, very tasty!
author: Francine Z.

description: Good ramen! Terrible wait time. Prices were fair, broth was great, noodles were fair.
author: Sean Y.

description:
I like the food and atmosphere.  Service is fine.  Salmon skin salad and agedashi tofu are  both good here.

Advice to owner/manager:  get the sidewalk and entrance washed or hosed daily!  I've had more that one appetite killing whiff of stink when the door is open.  Anyone who has been there knows why it is so smelly outside, I won't go into it.  Just keep the stink at bay and this place would be much nicer.
author: Slim B.

description: Ramen here is tasty but a bit on the salty side for my taste.  I wish they give you more noodles and pieces of fried chicken in your noodle soup than the regular three pieces.  Maybe they can offer extra large option for hungry dinners as I still feel hungry after a bowl of ramen.
author: Daniel L.

description: on a sat night. 1.5 hr wait for the table and another 1 hr wait for the KatanaYa ramen which sucked, greasy broth and fat trap ingredients...dislike.
author: Gracee G.

description: The ramen here is excellent. I just wish the line was not so long. Great place to get ramen downtown.
author: Jason E.

description: I love everything about this restaurant including its location in the heart of the tenderloin and tiny, hole in the wall charm!  The shoyu ramen is perfect. The noodles are perfectly chewey and the broth is flavorful and just salty enough.  Also ordered the gyoza appetizer. They were fried perfectly and the dough was paper thin. Unfortunately the filling was a bit mealy and mushy. What a bummer! Aside from the gyoza, I'll definitely be back for my noodle fix. Thanks, Katana-Ya!
author: Jenni L.

description:
I've been here twice and both times got ramen. The portion size was just right for me. And the ramen noodle itself was very yummy. Toppings were on the skimpy side but for the price, I can't really complain. The table service was quick and efficient. 

My note of caution to someone going in for the first time would be to be wary of the "rich broth" as it really is VERY rich. (Oh so tasty! But oh so very rich!)

Overall, I like the place. It's convient when shopping in Union Square. And it has yummy ramen for a reasonable price.
author: Tara C.

description: This is where we got idea for tofu-don. Japanese ramen with a little Korean taste. Hugh liked a little more than Miki.
author: hugh k.

description:
We used to go to this place for years since they had the old place across the street from Hilton hotel. But now we've decided not to go this place anymore eventhough we really like their miso ramen. Do you guys wanna know why? Because their weekends staff sucks.
( But now we found the new place for miso ramen is Suzu @ Japan Town, it's another reallly good ramen in SF after the one on Judah @ 7th Ave. was closed)
author: Nina L.

description:
It was a cold and blustery September Wednesday. Yeah, it was yesterday. If ever there was a Wednesday that felt like a HUMP day, yesterday was one for the record books. From the weather, to the long work day, to the people not understanding the rules of the road ("Dude, that was the 3rd time that SAME taxi has been circling the block with us and cut us off!"), it just FELT like, well, .... that people were getting humped in one form or another.

My friend, (Ben T.) and I stumbled into this little hole in the wall establishment on the recommendation of one of my other ramen loving friends, (Kevin M.)
(I converted him from the idea of instant "ramen" via Santa ramen and Sapporo-Ya)

As soon as we walked up to the place, there was a group of 8-9 folks loitering in the front and conversing in Japanese. Not a bad sign in my book, especially for in front of a Ramen place.

As soon as I walked in, my glasses fogged up (serves me right for not wearing the contacts yesterday) and I was bombasted by a cacophony of conversation. Again, not necessarily a bad thing, at least, it meant the place was full of people, and they were happily shooting the breeze. As soon as I cleared my lenses of the steam, I peered around to check out the crowd, and was pleasantly surprised to see the dining folk were as diverse as the people waiting outside for the 38 Line headed home. (except without the whole body odor and urine smell).

A waitress swam over to us (literally, she did that whole, across the body crawl stroke past a customer or two in the packed place, and asked how many of us there was, and promptly offered seating at the bar. 

After figuring that two of the items were deep fried, I just went with the salt broth, instead of the miso and soy based. Double checking with Ben about what he was going to get he decided to get the same ramen, but with miso, since he enjoys its savoriness

Anyways, when the waitress came by, she brought out some tea, napkins and chopsticks for us. In doing so, she accidentally poured some tea on poor Ben (he'd been havin' a craptacular day up to this point) and walked away. Ben proceeded to conspiratorially lean over and whisper, "She spilled some tea on me." I leaned over to dead-pan, "Maybe she likes you." At this point, the same waitress ninja'd over and started to dab at Ben's pants with a couple of napkins and apologized while smiling at him. Funny how that works.

We ended up getting two Katanaya Ramens, one with salt broth, the other with miso, the spicy tuna roll, the spicy salmon roll, and the regular salmon roll. (What, I was hungry, sheesh)

As we returned to our deep conversation about life, work, and girls (What?!), we watched the sushi chef receive our order and get to work.
Literally 3 minutes later, (about 6 minutes from when our order was taken), our rolls were ready, and the chef looked confused as we looked up expectantly at our rolls until the waitress pointed down the bar at us, and the chef handed down or dish of sushi. Before we could start on THAT, our ramen came out. Talk about speediness. Awesome.

After we started digging in, I started to take apart the bowl of noodles in front of me. 
I saw the fried chicken and started with that (I hate how soggy deep fried things get after sitting in the broth, what would the point of deep frying it if it gets soggy in the broth. I had experienced the deep fried chicken at a few of the other ramen places (Genki, Santa, etc etc) and hands down, I liked this one right off the bat. It was crispy (until the broth got to it -sigh-), the chicken was juicy, not fried dried, and the batter didn't taste funky. I killed the dumplings next. 
They were tasty in their own right, but alas were soggy already. Admittedly, I couldn't identify the meat mix inside by taste and texture, but it was still tasty, and at that point I didn't really care anymore. 
The sliced pork was succulent, juicy, and all around tasty with a bit of fat across the edges. I'd go back again just to try another ramen bowl with this pork topping it.
The rest of the toppings were pretty standard fare, and not too noteworthy otherwise (Seaweed, canned corn, bamboo strips)
The broth was nice and light, as I expected, and a good foil to the grease from the chicken and dumplings.
The noodles looked like machine made packaged noodles, but it was made to my personal preference. It was "Soung", a term in Cantonese I like using for the texture of noodles when they bounce back JUST enough when you bite into them. It's a sign of being al dente, according to my adoptive Italian grandma.

The sushi was pretty standard fare, honestly, and nothing to write home about. Actually, I found a fish bone in one of the rolls and prompty lost most of my enthusiasm for them.

But the ramen was all in all very good. I can't wait to try the other ramen options when I'm in the packed downtown area next.

I give this place a 3.5.  Sushi was blah, but the ramen works for me.
author: Patrick K.

description: My wife and I are huge fan of ramen noodles.  We ate them every other day when we were in Hawaii and Guam. Personally I prefer ramen noodles that are wheat flour based.  The noodles here are fresh hand pulled, but its tastes and looks like a thicker verson of the egg noodles you would find in a won ton noodle soup.  Broth is so so, slightly on the salty side.
author: John N.

description: when did an overabundance of salt and msg count for seasoning and flavor?? does not live up to the hype!
author: natassia s.

description: ever since i found this place i've been dragging friends here for some post-drinking eating. not sure if thats a good thing!  can't decide which broth/ingredient combo is my fave yet since theres so much on offer.  they lose 1 star because i wasn't a fan of their seaweed salad, they mix it with wakame and lettuce which is a bit of a slimy combo. otherwise, this place is noodle heaven.
author: yolanda f.

description: I never had real japanese ramen until I came here. My friend is one of the waitresses and recommended that I come in since I love japanese food so much. I was so used to eating top ramen, and it's nothing like REAL ramen! It's so tasty! full of flavor, maybe just a tad too salty. It's a small place, but worth the wait. The prices are maybe a dollar or two more than what I expected, but if you're really hungry for some good japanese food, it's the place to go! Oh and they need to clean their menus, mine was sticky last time. And I noticed they don't offer free hot tea in the beginning, i'm just so accustom to it. I also like the variety they have in their menu, you can mix and match for a combo, and their bento boxes are quite filling.
author: kirehleen f.

description: personally, any place open late that puts a large piece of fried chicken in your ramen automatically wins.
author: Andy P.

description: You know you are at a "hole-in-wall" place when the inside of a place has a bunch of mirrors to make it look bigger.  This place is nuts!  The wait is about 45 minutes for a table on any given night.  It's crowded and you'll see 4 people sharing a small table that was probably meant for two.  With that being said, people still wait!  It's all about the Ramen at Katana-Ya.  The place is easy to miss.  I come to San Francisco all the time for business and have probably walked passed this place several times.  Last night, I tried the Kantanya Ramen for the first time.  This ramen has everything from fried chicken, BBQ pork and fishcakes.  It was delicious!!!  However, you have to be a noodles lover to really appreciate it.  You have the option to choose a miso or spicy broth.  I chose miso because the spicy looked right red.  Not too sure I could have handled it.  Also, the servings are big.  I couldn't finish it all and believe me, I can eat...why else would I be a yelper?  Try this place if you like ramen...but if you don't like ramen, there's a good slice pizza place next door.
author: Richard K.

description: long lines, but worth the wait. follow the rest of the reviews and go straight for the ramen. fried chicken ramen is very tasty. the menu makes full disclosure that MSG is added. when you arrive, put your name on the clipboard yourself and walk around the block to kill some time
author: Kris B.

description: love the miso ramen and enrich the broth really hits the spot
author: Allan K.

description: I love when places are open late! AND they serve sushi! I feel there should be more restaurants like these where they are open late and serve sushi =P .. I came here the other night at around 11 or so. We got our table right away, but after I did see that some people have to put their names on a waiting list outside. The place is a bit small so I don't recommend mobbing the place with more than 4 people. Their sushi seemed decent and I enjoyed the sukiyaki. I'd definitely come back here again if I'm really craving some late night sushi or some sort of Japanese platter.
author: Jessica P.

description: Went there this weekend primarily because of a hankering for some ramen noodles and previous reviews here on Yelp.  Wasn't too hard to find but finding a place to park (even on the weekend) was a pain...  Very small restaurant and the 4 of us (2 kids) were squeezed onto a small table.  3 of us ordered a bowl of the bbq pork ramen with shoyu broth.  Ramen and broth were pretty decent - almost on par with Santouku's but the pork slices were a BIG let down, being as tasteless and tough as shoe leather.  Guess I need to make a trip down to SJ for my next ramen fix.
author: H C.

description:
we went to katanaya this past weekend after shopping in union square.  when i heard they reopened, i was so excited and couldn't wait to have yummy ramen in the city again.  we use to frequent their old location in the inner sunset.

we got there early around 5:30pm.  they place was pretty crowded, but it is a small place.  there was one table for 2 right in front of the widow and there was space for a baby stroller.  score!!!  as i sat in my seat, i noticed a smell of human urine.  i told my hubby and we tried to move to another table since the place was clearing out.  the waitress told us to take the table at the window but my husband told her , in japanese, that it was nasty smelling.  she rolled her eyes at us.  we tried to fit into another table, but the waitress was less than accomodating.  everything we wanted to try to make space for the baby stroller, she had a reason to tell us it would not work.  no help at all!!!! the restaurant was nasty, looked like they did NO renovating at all since the old tenant had left.  very unappetizing.  we didn't get a chance to eat at katanaya and my husband was bummed.  i will never go back there again!!

 i'm so tired of snobby japanese who think everyone just LOVES their food and that they can treat people however they want and they will still come back.  sorry katanaya, i will never be back and i will be sure to tell everyone i know not to go there and go eat at santa ramen instead!!!! 

i was there on saturday, september 15, 2007 around 5:30pm.  if you were the waitress there, it's obvious you don't have children and i wanted to tell you to go f-yourself as we left but i was with my baby, so i will tell you now.  thanks for the awesome service byatch.

if i could give them no stars i would have.
author: Christie Y.

description: Ok, update.  I just waited by the door and was ignored for a full 10 minutes, and the waitress sat the two white gentlemen standing behind me.  Is this one of those joints which doesnt acknowledge yellow ppl?  wtf?  anyways, FINALLY a waitress walks over and asks if I wanted to be seated.  I say, yes, and you just sat the guys who walked in after me.  Then she said sorry, stared blankly with her dumb baby doll look, and said, that will be 5-10 minutes, when there was clearly a table open, it was thursday night at 9pm, and she had ignored me.  Do you want to wait, she says.  Hells no, I think, but I say, no probably not, and leave. The food is not worth dealing with dumbass wait staff.
author: M K.

description: My boyfriend & I are visiting SF and headed to Katana-ya after he told me that it got positive ratings on Yelp.  However, I should've read all of the reviews before agreeing to go, because it was definitely not worth the 40 min wait. I have to agree with Elliot K's review ... This place is NOT sanitary!  We were seated at the sushi counter & all I can say is that I'm glad I don't eat sushi. I personally witnessed one of the sushi chefs lightly pick his nose (no, I am not exaggerating) while taking a short break from preparing the sushi. He then proceeded to rest his left hand (the one he picked his nose with) on the counter. He then proceeded to prepare more sushi without washing his hands!!! I work in a hospital so I am fastidious about washing my hands. I subsequently felt like throwing up after witnessing this horrible event. The food was also very mediocre...they do ramen better in Honolulu than here. I wouldn't recommend this place at all and would give it zero stars if I could.  All I can say is ... Ew!
author: Chad O.

description: i am no ramen connoisseur by any stretch, but i do enjoy a good bowl of noodles from time to time. and katana-ya offered up a pretty good one. the light miso broth with bbq pork ... good! and good thing they called it "bbq pork" on the menu (even though she said "chashu" when she took the order), because otherwise i would have expected some tough, marinated red meat instead of the soft tender slices of white pork that arrived in my bowl.
author: spiff e.

description:
i wanted to like this place, unfortunately the service was beyond terrible.  the beef curry i got was not bad though. so this rating is for service alone.  

my friend and i went there on a week day around 3pm.  should not be busy and it wasn't.  there were two waitresses, one japanese and an european girl who apparently can speak some japanese.  that must be why they hired her because she had terrible customer service skills. didn't bother to come take orders until we flagged her down and didn't come by again.  come on, there were two other tables there.  waited forever for our food and ended up going up to the counter to ask for the check ourselves and wait there so we can just pay and leave.  we don't have all day.  the girl just looked at us like "what"? ugh..just such terrible attitude, she shouldn't work there if she hates her job.
author: Silver C.

description: great Ramen!plus you can mix it with anything on the lunch selection...the place is small but  service was good.will be back soon!!
author: Ces T.

description: this place is thje ish  man!!!!  I had the chicken fried ramen and it was the best ramen I ever had!!! yummy must go and check it out!!!
author: philip l.

description: had a late dinner here. got the regular soy sauce ramen - light. the noodles were excellent. the broth didn't quite match up to santouka's in la (currently my #1 and the broth by which i measure all others), but it was still good. if i'm ever in the area looking for comfort food, i'd definitely go back. too bad it's in the middle of tourist central.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: convenient location, but not worth the hype.  The sashimi was admittedly amazing considering the location and appearance of the place, but the ramen noodle soup, which they are KNOWN for, was gross and so bad that I couldn't finish it.  I would say that it was just me, but my friend had the same experience.  The service was sub-par.  My tea was constantly empty and even after I asked for a refill, it would take way too long, even when they were not that busy.  The kicker was that the power went out not once, not twice, but THREE times during our meal that lasted less than an hour.  Nowhere else on the block had a power outage, so I am led to believe it was faulty wiring coupled with overloaded circuits.  That does not add to my comfort level for a restaurant that serves raw fish and other such things so dependent on reliable refrigeration.  Next time I'm in need of a quick, inexpensive bite to eat before the theater, I think I shall look elsewhere.
author: Geri-Ayn G.

description: During the lunch hour it becomes a rush hours instead. Many business workers come here to enjoy the fine taste of Ramen. It's good ramen for the price coming with a side dish. My only concern was that my arms touch the individual next to me. Find a better time to dine here because it is like a jungle during lunch.
author: Kevin N.

description: This place would totally rock it in the 70s when white people called all things Asian "Oriental," shag carpet screamed "classy" and "The Love Boat" passed for travel TV entertainment.  Why?  Because they use MSG in their noodles. MSG!  Um, what Chinese restaurant calls out the use of MSG so blatantly as these clowns.  Um, no one.  After listening to my friends talk up this place for weeks (people with particularly refined palates, one of whom is a CIA-trained chef) I was horrified when I opened the menu and read about their use of MSG (written in big bold letters).  Now I can be a swinging adaptable fellow when the moment calls, but MSG?  She of the palpitating heart rhythm and painful all-night headaches?  Um, no.  So instead I ordered what turned out to be a very indifferent curry dish where the best thing I can say about it is that its texture reminded me of that glue I used to eat in crafts class in elementary school.  If you like MSG this is your place. If you don't, try Volcano Curry.  Cheaper and far tastier and even better - no heart palpitating, head-splitting MSG.
author: Chris K.

description: i'm not sure what the heck most ppl that's reviewed here are talking about, but this is one damn good ramen shop.  and believe me..  i've been to hundreds of ramen place..  fact that they're open till 1:15 am.. is just amazing.. i'll choose katana-ya over "santa anyday fools
author: Ryo I.

description: good, affordable food, that is available late at night...  more than likely i order the spicy tofu with miso broth ramen.  from a recent visit, the aburi toro and salmon skin handroll were excellent. the seaweed salad and agadashi tofu were also good.
author: jane d.

description: Great ramen served here. The broth seasoned just right; noodles are cooked to a near perfect texture. Highly recommended ramen joint if you're in the Union Square area.
author: tony n.

description: This is my first review on Yelp.   But, I am not a novice.  I pretty much find out all the information I need to know about pet hospitals, dentists, and of course, restaurants on this fine website.  Anyways, I don't really get out much, what with work and such, but I do enjoy a good meal.  I am really interested in Japanese cuisine, and I love a nice heaping bowl of Ramen, so, along with that and all the rave reviews I've read on Yelp about Katana-ya, I decided to give it a try.  My boyfriend (he is a bit of a picky eater, but I know when he thinks something is good, then it is really really good) ordered rich miso ramen with pork, and I ordered the same, and a little bowl of curry and rice.  Both were incredibly delicious.  My boyfriend LOVED the ramen.  The broth was so rich and just yumtastic.  I wish I could have some right now.  And the curry was the best curry I've ever had in my life.  I docked a star becuase I ordered iced green tea and it was luke warm, but I think that is becuase they don't actually have iced green tea and she made it on the spot for me, which I appreciate, but it just wasn't as refreshing as I had hoped.  All in all, it was a very nice experience and I fulfilled my ramen and curry cravings.
author: Red F.

description: I love the ramen and everything else that I've tried here.  I travel to SF for work, and i go here every time.  The food is great and the staff is nice.  It gets really crowded, but I usually eat solo, so it's not a big deal for me.  When you get there, write your name on the list outside, and start salivating.
author: Evan W.

description: it should not be legal to have kim chee fried rice that good.
author: Michelle C.

description: This review is for the service we received and not for the food.  Came in here during lunch time with husband and daughter and we were seated at a table for four.  We receievd our menus and were ready to order when three other ppl came into the restaurant waiting to be seated.  The waitress told us to move to a smaller table in the corner so she could seat these three ppl at the table we were at.  We walked out of that place seconds later.
author: cheesecroissant k.

description: i don't claim to be any sort of ramen expert nor have i visited that many ramen places in the bay area. but katana-ya has the best bowl of ramen i've had within sf city limits (beats out tanpopo by a looong stretch), with thick, chewy noodles and a rich, fatty soup. their broth (i chose the 'rich miso' version) was so rich and so porky that if someone told me they actually liquefy a piece of pork in there, i would have believed it. on a chilly sf night, nothing fills your tummy better than liquefied pork...mmm...
author: Angi C.

description: so one star might be strictly based on the fact that it was in the context of what was otherwise an awful culinary weekend experience but this was super cheap ($10 lunch special = 2 rolls + miso), incredibly soft (its a good thing--no better way to describe the rolls), and the perfect meal on a sunny day in san francisco. great find, glad i waited for a table. very content all around. playing great reggae an added albeit unexpected bonus.
author: Nassim A.

description: Yet again, I ate here with Darren S. It really is more of a family dinner than anything else, so don't get the wrong idea. The miso soup was really good, no tofu in it which was surprising but tasty nonetheless. Next was the Tiger Eye Roll, which was awesome! Avocado, wrapped in salmon, wrapped in ginger. Happy. In. The-Pants. (a quote from Justin H.) We also had a fresh water Halibut sashimi that was to-diah-for. I'm blanking on the last roll but just those three items will make me come back again and again. The service was good and quick, I think we were there less than an hour and the whole time there were people rotating in and out on a Tuesday at 10PM! You know it's good. Thank you bum on the corner for telling us to go there (I gave him a few bucks for his service). I think next time I go I want to try one of the bowls, not only did they have a page menu dedicated to the noodle bowls but every staff member I saw ate a bowl of some sort.
author: Dustin S.

description: This is a simple review. Great ramen, too expensive. This is no longer the cheap ramen hole in the wall that it used to be. Popularity has nearly doubled the prices. If you are going to go here, get something more exciting that the cilantro ramen or green onion ramen, it's not worth it. I recommend the kimche ramen and the himachi appetizer is delicious.
author: Vanessa W.

description: as close to authentic japanese ramen as you can get.  the wait can be horrendous on busy nights but thankfully the restaurant opens really late.  beware of the SMALLLLLL space.
author: Angela Q.

description: Good, solid, not great, but probably the best I have had in the Bay area. I have become a real fan of ramen. I travel a fair amount, so I am lucky enough to sample ramen in many cities. NYC has the best (Ippudo in the East Village). Seattle has Samuari Ramen in the International district. KatanaYa was tasty, satisfying, very good, maybe even delicious...but not to die for...and definitely not to kill for! I will return when I am in the neighborhood.
author: RJ T.

description: I love the food here... it's cheap and good. it's my favorite place to stop by after the bars as it closes at 2am. I'm actually not that big of a fan of ramen in general, but it's as authentic as anything you'd find in Japan (as I'm told). I especially love the sushi (like the Alaska roll), but nothing beats the ice dessert with green tea ice cream and red bean!
author: Amy L.

description: Such a long line. And it took probably 30 minutes until we got the table. However, the service was good, and the food came very fast. The ramen was good, not great. Don't order the rice though because it's really mediocre.
author: warakant j.

description: i'm a fan but i'll tell ya, this place is as good as menkuitui in manhattan but not as good as rairaiken or momofuku noodle shop.  that being said, this place is popular and it has a nice cozy feel to it which takes me back to nyc.
author: Bing S.

description: 4.5 stars. Great food at decent prices. They have everything from ramen, sushi, sashimi, etc. Try the strawberry shaved ice! This place closes late so its a big plus if you want to avoid the late night heartburn from burritos!
author: Diana B.

description:
had BBQ pork Ramen in miso for lunch today. nothing extraordinary. 

I admit that the first sip of the soup was surprising.. however, it's too oily when it cool off a bit (maybe after 5 mins). the texture of the ramen isn't the best... if you've tried hand made noodle, you'd know the different.

probably my first and only time visiting
author: Alvin C.

description: This place is just OK compared to the ramen houses in the South Bay... but I do appreciate the fact that it opens til 2AM.  The soup was a little salty and the noodles were average.
author: Carrie F.

description: tiny place - then again what isn't in this city-   Had the bbq pork ramen with miso soup.  It was good.  yum.   now granted i was drunk and it was proably better at 1am.  but in any case it was good.
author: Joey N.

description: Although I hate noodles, I really fall in love with this restaurant. They have the best Ramen.
author: Nan J.

description:
i freaking love this place.  i really do.  it's great ramen.  i highly recommend getting the spicy tofu.  add a plum wine.  totally hits the spot.  

i can't count how many times i've been here now b/c i've lost count, but all i have to say is....

love love love.
author: H. G.

description: their ramen used to be very good when they just opened. i tried miso ramen recently and my tongue got namb because of msg (i assume...). they may have changed their recipe (or chef??)... as for their service, i think un-friendly service is as good as it gets here...
author: Superhiro M.

description: One of my favourite sushi restaurant in SF. Ramen is amazing and sushi roll too. The 4 star because the place is very small and when is full...became to loudly. Try it...you`ll love!!!
author: Lorenzo D.

description: i had the soy, light, bbq pork ramen.  i thought it was decent.
author: Dorothy L.

description: Thanks to all the previous yelps that led us to this place.  There was a small line when we got there a little after 6 pm.  By the time we got seated (10-15 min) the line was lenghty, and for good reason!  We both ordered the Katanaya Ramen.  Mine was with miso, my wife's with soy.  I got mine a little spicy, which was good.  I usually go for super hot, but wanted to taste my bowl today instead of burn my mouth up.  The Katanaya comes with pork, gyoza, corn, shoots and some other garnishes.  It was great!  Highly recommended if you like Ramen!
author: Chuck S.

description: No need to read the rest of the 984 reviews. Just go to this place for the best ramen in San Francisco. Ramen is perfect, soup base is spot on.  There is a small wait cuz the place is so darn small. But trust me, it's worth the wait.
author: HonestTruth M.

description: what rude wait staff! i wanted a to-go order and stood by the cash register for 15 mins waiting for them to take my order. at one point, the waitress was ready to take my order but the waiter told her to just tend to the tables. after waiting another few minutes, i left. i wonder if it's because they don't get tips on the take-outs so they rather spend time on the tip-paying customers. terribly rude. was a loyal customer but no longer!
author: bella s.

description: Great little Ramen restaurant. It's a small place but worth the wait. The noodles are cooked just right, not undercooked, nor too soft. The soup is flavorable without being overly salty. The BBQ pork is cooked to perfection. They also have some interesting varieties of ramen you wouldn't expect like spicy tofu, and deep fried chicken. I'll make it a point to try these, and the sushi the next time i'm there. The wait staff are very friendly as well.
author: David Y.

description: We went on a Friday evening at about 7:30, and waited for a two-person table for about 20 minutes. It was worth the wait for the ramen. My friend and I know Japanese food fairly well (we've both lived in and traveled across Japan), and though we were initially skeptical of the place given its unusual name in Japanese, we were happy to find that the Yelp ramen reviews were pretty accurate. We ordered the BBQ pork ramen, spicy miso green onion ramen, and the Dynamite spicy roll (mixed fish). The roll was slightly above average: The fish was fresh, but the rice was too sticky and did not hold together well. If you're on a budget, I'd suggest skipping the fish and just spending your hard-earned cash on the ramen.
author: Lizzy B.

description: Sorry I don't have any pics.  This place is solid.  I had the ramen while my girlfriend had a chicken donburi.  The ramen noodles have a good bite and there is plenty of it.  The broth was very strong and creamy.  I like shredded pickled ginger in my ramen to balance the intense flavor so I stole it from my gf's donburi bowl and then asked for extra.  I would say this ramen tastes something like Los Angeles' Daikokuya or Orange County's Santouka Ramen.  Probably the best chicken donburi I have ever tasted... perfectly cooked chicken, egg was runny (a good thing) and the best part is that the sauce they use is not overwhelming.  Many times when you have donburi, they overuse their sauce and it gets all over the rice and it's too sweet.  Rice is like a neutralizer for me.. something to cleanse the palate for your next bite of whatever you're eating.  We had some sashimi for appetizer... hamachi and some toro... the cuts of sashimi are really thick.  My toro had a line of chewy tendon in it which I didn't like too much but for the price of less than ten bucks for two pieces, who can pass up that deal!  It is great that this restaurant opens so late... last call is at 1:15am so if you're staying around Union Square and need a bite before you fall asleep, I suggest you give this joint a shot.
author: John N.

description: I expected a lot after reading the reviews on yelp and the ones posted in Katana-Ya's window - but the fact that I'd had ramen in Tokyo pretty recently probably stacked the deck against them. It wasn't Tokyo ramen, but save for the oil slick on my miso broth it was decent. Once you got through the oil, the flavor was alright, but I probably won't go back again until I've forgotten what ramen in Tokyo tastes like.
author: bm p.

description: I love the miso ramen.  It' the best in Downtown/Union Square area.  I also love the spicy cold ramen.  Just make sure to read the check carefully.  Service charge is already included even you have less than 5 people in your group.  If you did not pay attention, you might double pay the tip.
author: Aggie Y.

description: Great very authentic japanese food. The tonkatsu don is very tasty as are all the different kinds of flavorful ramen. Service is very friendly.
author: Joon L.

description: ths sushi is not ok..... the ramen... is ok. i didn't think this was as spectacular as everyone was raving about, but i will need to try this restaurant again
author: C M.

description: We just happened to be staying two doors down from this place at the Hotel Diva, so we decided to get some take-out. So good. Just could have been a little more spicy seeing as I was eating spicy tuna roll and not feeling a thing lol.
author: Kimiko S.

description: its ramen the way that ramen should be.  so far i have tried the original and now the spicy green onion, and both are delish.  i havent tried the sushi or really anything else, but do you need to?  you come here for ramen.  i also got tonkatsu don and that was pretty tasty too.  the last great thing about this place is its location...close to union square, but overlooked much of the time because of tourons going to eat at cheesecake factory or something.  never a wait for me!
author: Robert S.

description: Small place with good ramen. I like them being open till late.
author: N J.

description: The spicy ramen with miso broth with added fried chicken is really tasty. You should definitely try it out and the location is key!!
author: Cubalicious P.

description: I just realized today that tips are already included in every bill here!!! Even when you are there by yourself. Be careful everyone, look before you pay so that you won't get overcharged for this place....tips don't go to wait staff but the owner.
author: W M.

description: Ramen = 4 stars; sushi = 3 stars.  great place for huge portions and excellent ramen.  small restaurant so expect a wait if you go during peak dinner hours.
author: Stacy N.

description: Best ramen I've tried in the bay area.  Went on a Saturday night and waited approximately 15 minutes (table for 2).  Place is small and the service is so-so but the ramen (noodles + broth) really hits the spot.  I ordered an appetizer that never came but they quickly took it off the bill when I pointed it out to them.
author: Amy C.

description: i love this place!    I always order the regular ramen, light, miso.  The only difference between the BBQ pork and regular is that you get an additional pieces of pork (3 to be exact).    I have ordered the ceviche, rice plates (bento combos) and the sashmi there, they are all pretty decent.  Not cheapy sushi (like the packs at Bistro Farms supermarket) but not the absolute best.  i've heard that Santa over in San Mateo is better but I haven't been able to make it down to Santa in a really looong time!  It's the best ramen place in San Francisco City that I know of.  The serving sizes are perfect, I have no need of large american-sized plates  but I have to admit that the prices charged for a small plate does rack the bill up quite quickly for a hole in the wall joint.  As for food goes, I could eat there twice every week and that is saying a lot!
author: tc h.

description: i didn't know what ramen could be before someone pointed this place out to me.  delicious, wonderful rich broth.  we're lucky to have this shop in SF.
author: Lita F.

description: Awesome.  Felt very "authentic" and I write "authentic" in "quotes" because I've never been to Japan and wouldn't know what "authentic" "is".  Some guy looked like Elvis.
author: Brandyn B.

description: I love their extra spicy ramen. I was recommended by my friend for lunch and quick dinner hour. This ramen place definitely offer one of its own kind. The chefs are very personable and approachable. However, the young japanese waitresses there tend to be slow and chitchat a lot. sometimes, they forget about customer's order and serving customers who are waiting to get a table. It is a small but very busy restaurant. There is always a line waiting to eat there.
author: CC C.

description: Had ramen combos here twice. Ramen is edible, but nothing special. Combos are a good deal because you get a lot of food for your buck. However the food is all pretty average. This place is only good for a quick cheap Japanese lunch.
author: M. W.

description: i used to come here pretty often for late night ramen!  the ramen here are hella good!  probably the best ramen i have had!  im ALL ABOUT SERVICE.... there was a handful of times where the overcharged me!  we're not talking about just a few dollars here... more like a friend and i both had a comno, shared a roll and beer... normally should come out just shy $40.  but this one specific time, that bill came out $79 and change!!!  when i waived the waitress down, i didnt even have to explain to her, she grabbed the bill and said she would recalculate it for me.  like she knew and was waiting whether or not i'd say something!!!
author: Yukio W.

description: A great place to grab ramen outside of Japantown.  The location is easy and the ramen is good.  I first had ramen here about a year ago and even though I enjoyed it... I just forgot to go back.  I recently re-discovered this place and I'm addicted.  I love ramen and the prices are reasonable.  I most enjoy the shoyu based broth (heavy) and the bbq pork ramen.  I also like the miso broth.  The green onion ramen is tasty as well.  I always opt for the ramen style noodles. I have also had the sushi here which is decent but this is definitely a ramen house.  I dig the bamboo shoots they put into the mix.  I like this place a lot and I'm happy that it's around.  I'm determined to try all of the ramens in the next couple of months.
author: Allison M.

description: not as good as i excpected......overall it's ok in SF..coz not many good ramen place in sf..
author: Jun S.

description: the food is not as great tasting as everyone makes it sound. solid 3 stars for ramen.
author: Ryan K.

description: decent ramen but a little expensive.  near the hostel.  wouldn't eat there again.
author: Benjamin C.

description: We had several dishes which were all fair.  We had the soft shell crab which didn't have much flavor.  We also had the sukiyaki which was good.  We had the dinner salad which had a great dressing.  We had the tempura which was just so-so.  The service was nice.  Nothing special.
author: Brian L.

description: REALLY!!!! Four stars? This place is really, really, really bad and I'm not a food snob by any stretch of the imagination. Waited for about a half hour with high hopes. The first really big red flag was "MSG ADDED" at the top of the menu. All downhill from there. I ordered the butter corn ramen and swapped the pork for tofu which cost a buck. Canned corn. Really weak seaweed. Bamboo shoot was limp and dead and all alone floating in the bowl. My girlfriend ordered grilled salmon over rice and didn't touch one bite. The salmon looked and smelled like cat food. Meow? I'm not sure how they grilled a pile of ground-up salmon or how you can justify calling microwaving "grilling". Booty. Don't waste your time. Ten-dollar cup of soup with a long line of suckers. I imagine the high reviews are due to the fact that SF doesn't have late night choices and many who frequents this place are drunk or desperate and dizzy from the MSG. I expect Japanese food to be made with care and pride and this was not that. MSG in $10 ramen???????????????????????????????????
author: Matt P.

description:
+
noodles (ramen)
broth (light, soy)
location
taste

- 
service (slow to refill waters, spilled 2-3 hot teas on the back of a friend-  doh!)

sumee mah-sen!!!
author: Henry F.

description: I got hooked on saimin (Hawaiian-style ramen) after eating at Hamura's Saimin on Kaua'i in '06. Since then, I have been in search of re-igniting that summer love with various places serving ramen/saimin and all have failed me... at least until last week, after a friend who raved about the awesome noodles and broth at Katana-ya brought me to this little ( and I mean itty-bitty) place near Union Square. I was set up for disappointment and happily stand corrected. Although their noodles aren't exactly saimin noodles, the ramen is delicious!!! And their broth is killer! So complex and rich, it'll make you have dreams about it.  I've been craving it so badly that I'll be back tonight, less than a week since the first time. Yum!
author: M S.

description: their ramen is one of the best i've had in the bay. i would recommend it.
author: John A.

description: Love the fried chicken ramen miso base soup. Best cheep eat near Union Square.
author: Gene P.

description: Great service and really excellent sushi.  The best in the city!
author: Ian L.

description:
As a local San Franciscan who's been to Katanaya when it first opened close to a decade ago a few blocks up on Geary and Leavenworth as a half noodle, half Henry VIII steak restaurant at what's now known as the Ambassador club, I'm nostalgic for it's old location & flavor.  My favorite ramen; Karaage ramen still exists but no longer tastes as it once did nor is it as cheap as it once was.  
The current place is tiny but has great FengShui as it is right smack in the middle of downtown neighboring Jack in the Box.  The waitress staff is hit or miss and like most restaurant workers appreciate good tippers and hate cheapskates and jerks that argue that they didn't order something when they in fact did.  The sushi chefs when Japanese are pros, when Chinese are sloppy and don't capture the essense nor taste of sushi.  Can you blame 'em?  I don't know why any self-respecting Japanese person would hire any non-Japanese to cut sushi.  Non-Japanese waitresses are cutting it close already.  
Shaved ice is a recent item they added to the menu which continues to be popular with the young crowd.  Some advice: don't go there if you're gonna be cheap and troublesome to the waitresses because you're too good to wait, try Jack in the Box.  If you're going with an Asian chick make sure to pick up the check, they tell me more often than not Asian chicks who go with non-asian guys end up paying.  Try to make an attempt to pretend you're paying if you're a cheap loser guy like signing the Asian girl's card or passing her some counterfeit bills so she can pay with her card and get the reward points.  Lately, there's been a lot of Asian guys taking white girls there to eat, that's a welcome sight from the usual opposite.  Lastly, be prepared to wait and go there with that attitude because Katanaya is worth it.
author: David K.

description: This review is not going to deviate from the majority who love it.  This is a great little Japanese place close to Union Square.  The restaurant is tiny, seats maybe 25, but the turnover is quick.  The sushi is always the freshest and the noodles are great.  Their menu is extensive and they've got some great specials on the wall.  Every time we're in SF, we stop by because we know that the food is consistently good and it's very reasonable.
author: Nancy L.

description: we got the katana-ya ramen. rich, salt broth. a little salty. but delicious.  the fried chicken was great. pot sticker a little oily. but can't wait for try the other ramen.
author: Diana L.

description: I went to try Katana Ya with my boyfriend last Friday and we ordered soft shell crab for appetizer, fried chicken ramen with miso soup and katanaya ramen with miso soup.  Because Katanaya ramen also comes with fried chicken & pot stickers, so I specifically told the waitress to put the fried chicken & pot stickers on the side.  Then, the ramen came and everything was soaked in the soup with ramen.  We told the waitress and she made a comment that the kitchen must have forgotten.  So she brought them back and about 5 mins later brought back the ramen and fried chicken & pot stickers on the side.  However, we were disappointed because the only thing they did was refrying the same pieces of chicken & pot stickers again, so they tasted soggy & greasy.  This was their fault but they were too cheap to fry new pieces of chicken & pot stickers for us, so this was our 1st time and will be our our last time there.
author: winnie l.

description: We've been on a noodle mini-marathon the last few days so we decided to continue the trend with some ramen.  After a long day shopping at Union Square, we decided to revisit this place...it'd been a year or so since the last visit, which from what I remember was good but not great.  We ordered the spicy tofu ramen ($9), regular ramen ($7.50), and the small portion of curry donburi ($5.50).  The noodles were well cooked but the spicy tofu miso broth seemed a bit oily.  It also seems odd that you have to pay extra for spicy additions to the regular ramen broth.  The curry donburi was a pass -- tasted like curry you could make from the box and the accompanying salad was soggy and overly doused with creamy dressing.  Overall, not a bad option to have while in the Union Square area though it seems pricey for what you get.  Also make sure you check your bill carefully... we were charged incorrectly twice and the bill came up $10 more than it should have been.  However, the staff was very friendly and willing to correct their errors.  Visit #2 to this place was good but not great.
author: joyce h.

description: went there again today.  the age dashi tofu was great. so was the natto roll.  the servers are really nice.
author: Yelper S.

description: this place has good ramen with decent prices.  the noodles arent as good as suzu's, but the broth is tastier.  its about the same size as suzu, but feels more crowded due to its narrow lot.  they have a great selection of both ramen and sushi, however, i did not try the sushi.  this is a place i'd visit when roaming around downtown, but wouldnt go out of my way to eat here.
author: Jeremy N.

description: Probably one of SF's (the city proper) ramen joints. I came during an off-peak time and it was still pretty busy - no complaints for a place open til 2am. I'm sure on a cold Saturday night, this place might be packed, so plan accordingly. I didnt' have as many problems as others complained about bad service, luckily! Ordered the spicy tofu ramen in miso broth (be warned, no meat in this sucker) and the husband ordered the kimchee ramen in shoyu broth. Personally I liked the miso broth better, as it had a better kick than the shoyu broth. Ordered the shaved ice, slightly disappointed with this 1) they ran out of the green tea ice cream that I wanted to have on top of my shaved ice, 2) didnt' give me enough condensed milk, 3) the ice was a bit more chunky and less shaven than I'd like. Overall, a good experience - I'll be back during those late night hours when I'm craving some hot soup & noodles!
author: Jeannette L.

description: i highly recommend this spot for tasty late night eating.  i work late and before this place opened i was stuck eating jack in the box and greasy diner food.  the sushi is always fresh and the udon/ramen noodles are handmade.  if you like spicy food, try the spicy tofu ramen.  my co-workers and i are hooked on it.  they dont always get the to-go orders right so just be sure to check it before you leave.
author: ninja m.

description: this place is waaaaaaaaaaaay to small. i only get the udon now, cuz its the only consistant thing. they are always busy so be prepared to wait for a long time for a table if you decide to eat there. if you want order togo, it takes along time too. staff is hit or miss, sometimes they are nice and other times they aren't so much. but whatever. i used to get sushi, but since i've been going there for about 2 years now, the spicy tuna roll recipe has changed about 3 different times, so for now, i just stick to the udon which is pretty tasty.
author: puff e.

description: tried this place for the first time couple weeks ago.  so far just having the karage miso ramen, i was pretty impressed.  not much selection of ramen, but i like the choice of soup base you get for each type.  also, you can ask the chef if you want it a particular way, he'll most likely accomadate you.  the wait staff was friendly and responsive enough.  the only bad experience i had was when my girlfriend and i were the only customers there along with a gentleman sitting at the bar that was from out of town.  disregarding our presence, the staff and that one gentlemen were really disturbingly loud.  i can sort of understand because we were the only customers there but still, we are still customers.  however, there were once where my girlfriend wanted the full hamachi instead of their regular pieces that they give as appetizers.  though we paid much more for it, the hamachi was pretty good.  and the fact that they made it just for her, meant a lot to me.
author: Mac Y.
